title: KHMER ROUGE GET MORE CHINA ARMS
description: Despite public assurances by China that it has stopped sending military aid to the Khmer Rouge guerrillas since September, Chinese arms continue to flow across the Thai border to all the opposition factions fighting the Phnom Penh Government, including the Khmer Rouge, senior Western diplomats say.

title: Q&A Glowing Roots
description: Q. I found what looks like a root that glows in the dark. What is it?

title: Building Fire Disrupts Service on Metro-North
description: A fire that tore through a warehouse in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx last night briefly closed two Metro-North rail lines, delaying commuters trying to get home, officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Charter Medical Corp., Macon, Ga., an operator of hospitals, said it would report a $210 million loss for 1990 and take a $100 million nonrecurring charge for a writedown of assets and reserves related to its divestiture program and revised operating plans. * Environmental Power Corp., Boston, an operator of power plants, completed the sale of its cogeneration project in Venango County, Pa., to Falcon Power Corp., a subsidiary of Pacific Gas and Electric Co.'s PG&E Enterprise Inc. Environmental Power received $9.4 million plus a contingent 14 percent interest. * Hannaford Brothers Co., Scarborough, Me., an owner of supermarkets, has completed the acquisition of Alexander's Supermarkets, Lowell, Mass., for about $27 million. * IHD Holdings Ltd., Hong Kong, an investment and property holding group, said it had completed plans with Sheraton Corp., a unit of ITT Corp., to invest $110 million in a 48-story hotel, office and shopping complex in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. * Jordan Industries, Deerfield, Ill., a publishing, advertising and industrial company, has acquired Ebsco Ltd., a supplier of religious recordings. Terms were not disclosed. * Neorx Corp., Seattle, said that under a restructuring, it would cut its 115-person work force by about 40 percent. * Numed Inc., a health-care company, said it would sell Sherman Oaks Community Hospital, NuMed Regional Medical Center-West Valley and related assets to Triad Healthcare. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Random Drug Tests Ordered After Boston Trolley Crash
description: As investigators faulted an intoxicated operator as the likely cause of a trolley crash that injured 33 passengers here, local transit officials said today that they would begin random drug testing on workers despite union opposition.

title: As Violent Year Ends, India Pleads for Peace
description: In the closing days of a year that will be remembered as the most violent in four decades of Indian history, artists and intellectuals are coming out into the streets and meeting halls of this capital city to plead for peace and an end to the politicization of religion.

title: Key Rates
Review/Ballet; New 'Nutcracker' Prince For a Bolshoi Troupe
description: The Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company completed its season of "The Nutcracker" on Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The matinee featured the New York debut of Aleksandr Petukhov as the Nutcracker Prince and permitted balletgoers to assess the ensemble as a whole.

title: Seattle Journal; Flooded And Frigid: Could This Be Seattle?
description: Nearly 150 win ters ago, when the first white settlers landed on the shores of Puget Sound, they wrote letters home to the Midwest describing the benign weather in this part of the world. Here was a place, farther north than Maine, where vegetables could be grown in December.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1991
description: Markets The toughest year since 1981 for investors in stocks ended with a slight gain for the day. The Dow industrials rose 4.45 points, to 2,633.66. The Dow's decline for the year was 4.3 percent. [ Page 41. ]

title: Rose Bowl Overshadowed by Battle for the No. 1 Spot
description: A few weeks ago, the game had all the allure of a grand spectacle. Today, except for its name and its aura, the Rose Bowl, which will match Washington and Iowa, is just another game in an ocean of post-season bowls.

title: Review/Ballet; Lost Among the Sugarplum Fairies
description: "What is marzipan?" a youngster asked during "The Nutcracker" at the New York State Theater over the weekend. In 1954, when George Balanchine choreographed this production for the New York Ballet, everyone under four feet knew what marzipan was.

title: Second Suspect Is Charged In 'Godfather III' Shootout
description: An 18-year-old Queens man with a fondness for weapons and the nickname Homicide has been charged in the shootout at a showing of "The Godfather Part III" that left one moviegoer dead and three wounded.

title:
WITH RESPECT TO THE NEW;
Wheel of Fire, the Mojave
description: What is this white intensityswallowing me as the night swallows and now disgorgesonly Jonah was rocked and the nightis sorrowful musicbut this is something else? What is this absence,immersion as faith is a kind of immersion,a thirst for light in the true air?Look at the sun's jailbreak over the violentwalls. I've driven all nightto find myself here. Look at the gypsum desert,elements scattered like 7-11's all the way to Death Valley,the way L.A. reaches into it, one hundred miles or more.I'm talking about America, the thing itself,white line unreeling, pure distance, pure speed.I've driven all nightfrom fear of the darkness that would seize me if I stopped,even coffee at a truckstop, even water. Lookat the wraiths of stars,Buick Electras rusting in the freight meadow.It is the ghost of the light that moves me.I'm talking about the half-seen,dawn and evening, desert orchids,coyotes coming down to the river to drink.I'm talking about the thing itself,what rises in the night like anger or grief,language-less, blistering and over-brimmingas a river coming down from the mountainsto die, absolute purity of light or intention,memory of grace, seagulls canting windwardabove the Great Salt Lake --the sun, the desert,the weight of the light is staggering --until even the flesh of our days falls away,ash from a cone, fruit from a stone. Even nowwhen the whirling miraculouswheel in the sky has risen and vanished at first-light,gears of a huge engine, starlingsdrunk on oxygen --when the wheelis gone and I am alone with the willowsat the edge of the utterly desolateMojave River.I've driven all night toward the basinof angels. I've driven all night without understandinganything, need or desire, this desert, neonsigns remorseless as beacons.I'm talking about America.I'm talking about loneliness, the thing itself.I've driven all night to find myselfhere. Look around you,even now look around you.Dawn breaking open the days like jeweled eggs,Joshua trees crippled by this freakish rain of light.

title: Jets Gladly Celebrate Different Sort of Ending
description: The Jets have uttered so many "I can't wait until next year's" when their seasons have ended that it has become a hollow refrain. For "next year" has never come the way they have planned, at least not in the 1970's or 1980's or the first year of the 1990's. After all these years, the Jets still are defined by Joe Namath and Super Bowl III.

title: To Restore New York City: First, Reclaim the Streets; Billions for the Homeless: Snatched
description: As city and state revenues slide, outrage about the homeless mentally ill turns to resignation. It seems inevitable that the shortage of funds for more services will force New York to continue tolerating the intolerable: mental patients deteriorating -- and dying -- on the street.

title: Updating a Flawed Marvel
description: This column is being written on a Poqet PC, the best evidence yet to refute the saying "You can't take it with you." The Poqet is a one-pound, MS-DOS-compatible PC that has been miniaturized to fit into a jacket pocket, hence the name. It is about 9 inches wide and 4 inches deep and less than 1 inch thick. Poquet has also just miniaturized the price by $500, making it $1,495 instead of at $1,995.

title: What's a Staple? The List Expands
description: Conventional agricultural wisdom holds that only a handful of crop species -- as few as 7 and no more than 30, depending on different assessments -- account for most of the plant food consumed by humanity. But a new study says more than 100 species and possibly as many as 200 are important food sources.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about Vice President Quayle's cancellation of a round of golf in California over a country club's all-white membership misidentified a golfing partner in some copies. The partner, Ebersole Gaines, is the United States Consul General in Bermuda, not the Ambassador to the Bahamas.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KIRI TE KANAWA will star in the world premiere of "Liverpool Oratorio," PAUL McCARTNEY'S first classical work. In June, Miss Te Kanawa will join 200 musicians and singers in the performance at the Liverpool Cathedral in England.

title: Cuomo Is Sworn In for 3d Term Without Festivities
description: In a brief ceremony without the festivities or speeches that characterized his prior inaugurations, Mario Matthew Cuomo was sworn in today to a third term as New York State's Governor.

title: Iraqis' Script for Pullout: 'Grass Roots' Appeals?
description: European diplomats here say they have gathered evidence that Government party organizations are preparing for demonstrations calling on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull out of Kuwait as a means of saving his Government.

title: Data General Quits Venture With N.T.T.
description: The Data General Corporation has dropped a product development agreement with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation of Japan, company officials said today.

title: Detroit Priest Preaches Hope Through Job Training
description: Oakman Boulevard meanders across Detroit's tumbledown northwest side like a dry riverbed, past boarded-up storefronts and empty lots. But east of Linwood Avenue, the bleak roadscape suddenly comes to life: lights burn inside a row of deserted factories, and the street is filled with cars and delivery trucks.

title: Prosecutor Investigating Melee at Teen-Agers' Party in New Jersey
description: The Essex County Prosecutor's office today began investigating a melee that erupted as police officers tried to break up a teen-agers' holiday party at a home here early Sunday.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ABOUT THE SAFETY OF NAVY REACTORS
description: People who have worked for the Navy's nuclear reactor program, which has been quietly based here for four decades, have accused the program of serious safety lapses and say they were disciplined for raising safety concerns.

title: Washington Talk; Presidency on the Brink Of a Make or Break Year
description: George Bush begins the new year with his Presidency poised between success and failure. The country begins it with bated breath.

title: Lynn Brody Wed To R. J. Adelman
description: Dr. Lynn Alison Brody, a daughter of Sonia B. Brody of Short Hills, N.J., and Robert M. Brody of Roseland, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Robert James Adelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myles H. Adelman of Short Hills. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Sharey-Tefilo Israel in South Orange, N.J.

title: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; Thomas G. Labrecque/Rebuilding Chase After an Upheaval
description: When Thomas G. Labrecque was named chairman at the Chase Manhattan Corporation last year, he inherited more than just a new office. With the new title came a flood of problems that would make 1990 a dismal year for Chase and many other banking companies.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Notebook; A.F.C. Central Doesn't Disappoint
description: In a regular season where the last of 224 games was required to find the 12th playoff team, it was once again the American Football Conference Central division tussle that mirrored the league's penchant for parity. Cincinnati, Houston and Pittsburgh each finished with a 9-7 record for the first three-way divisional tie in A.F.C. history, but Cincinnati's 5-1 divisional record was its crowning edge as it took its second divisional title in the last three years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After taking a final curtain call as the Phantom of the Opera eight months ago, MICHAEL CRAWFORD returned to the show last night in Los Angeles. He created the role in London and played it on Broadway, where he won a Tony Award.

title: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; Lech Walesa/Daunting Challenge For Polish Leader
description: The election of Lech Walesa as president of Poland crowns his success at leading a decade-long political revolution that has brought his nation from dictatorship to democracy. Now the 47-year-old former electrician faces a daunting new challenge: shepherding Poland's half-finished economic revolution to success as his country seeks to leap from Communism to capitalism.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Mighty Chips Reinventing Silicon Circuits
description: Microelectronic circuits embedded on pieces of silicon are the building blocks of modern electrical devices, from computers and communication equipment to consumer electronics goods. They are also critical components of weaponry, automobile-engine control systems to improve fuel efficiency and factory automation systems.

title: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; James D. Robinson 3d/Ambitious Leader's Costly Reversal
description: For James D. Robinson 3d, 1990 was the year to bite the bullet and admit that some of his strategic plans of the last decade had failed.

title: Review/ Television; A TV Movie With a Familiar Ring
description: Few artifacts of popular culture invite more condescension than the made-for-television movie. There are some notable exceptions, usually those more ambitious productions inevitably nominated for Emmy Awards, but most television movies seem perfectly content to be, at best, mediocre. A case in point: "Her Wicked Ways," at 9 tonight on CBS .

title: Brazilian Indians Try To Save Forest Gently
description: To the Editor:

title: Czechs Begin Shift to a Free Market
description: Today, Czechoslovakia is taking a daring leap toward private enterprise, aimed at making it the second East European nation after Poland to scrap its rickety Communist economic structure.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Perfect Conductors New Grids, Rails And Sensors
description: Superconductors could have a vast payoff in energy, transportation and medicine. But most American research efforts seem aimed at less ambitious goals, chiefly in military electronics, than in electric power applications.

title: New Yorkers as Slowpokes
description: New Yorkers who thrive on the heady pace of their city life will be disappointed -- perhaps even incredulous -- to hear it's even faster in staid old Boston. Robert V. Levine, professor of psychology at California State University at Fresno, calculates that Bostonians live fastest of the 36 U.S. cities he timed. New York placed second, Salt Lake City third and, no surprise, Los Angeles dead last.

title: PATTERNS
description: A Little Nervous Music

title: Make Way for Bicycles, a Cleaner Way to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Union Sales
description: The Western Union Corporation, hoping to avoid involuntary bankruptcy, completed a deal today to sell its telex and electronic mail businesses to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for $180 million.

title: Ranking Questions Center on Colorado
description: If the Buffaloes can accomplish those objectives and preserve their top ranking in the news-agency polls, the annual controversy of an unofficial national championship could be reduced to an unprecedented Rocky Mountain coronation.

title: Church Cannot Be Regulated As Landmark, Court Rules
description: A landmark commission's effort to regulate changes inside a church in the city's historic South End violated the state constitution's guarantee of the free exercise of religion, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: 365 Clean Pages
description: One night last week winter's first snow fell on New York, and the city woke to a new world. An icy Eden it was, the roads not yet ribboned by car treads, the sidewalks unscarred by footsteps, the trees glazed. Later in the day there'd be holes in the blanket, and urine stains and streaks of soot; and the trees would have shaken off their shining coat. But not at dawn. At dawn on that chill morning New York, hushed and unsullied, promised perfection.

title: Our Towns; Some Things Change in a Year; Some Never Do
description: A pause this New Year's Day to update a few of the 1990 Our Towns columns:

title: Miss Lewis Weds Sheldon Kivell
description: Jacqueline Lewis and Sheldon Kivell were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the home of Robin Cutler and Robert Levine in Pittsburgh. The bride is a daughter of Joan Lewis of Wallingford, Conn., and Michael Lewis of Kingston, Pa. Her husband is a son of Edith M. Kivell of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Leo Kivell.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies
description: Trains that float above their tracks for a smooth, fast ride. Enormously powerful computers that will understand speech and help design new drugs. Motors the size of a dust speck, battery-powered cars, genetically engineered supercrops.

title: Critic's Notebook; Welcome Signs of Life At the Philharmonic, And a Fateful Choice
description: The New York Philharmonic, which had seemed for several years to be in a state of genteel limbo, touchy and defensive, is showing welcome signs of life. Chief among them is the vigorous presence of Kurt Masur, the orchestra's music director-designate. But there is a behind-the-scenes drama that is worth paying attention to, because its denouement is likely to affect the Philharmonic's future health fully as much as Mr. Masur's success or failure.

title: Chase Selling Student Loans
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell all of its Government-guaranteed student loans, totaling $1.2 billion, to the Student Loan Marketing Association, a privately owned company created by the Federal Government to handle such loans.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. Science Times begins on page 35, Business Day on page 41.

title: Barge Collision Spills Sewage Sludge Off Brooklyn
description: New York City environmental officials yesterday tested the waters of New York Harbor for pollution damage after a leak of 654,00 gallons of treated sewage on Sunday morning from a city-owned barge.

title: George Allen, Coach, Dead at 72; Led Redskins to Super Bowl VII
description: George Allen, a hard-driving, slightly eccentric football coach who had a knack for making winners out of losing teams, died today at age 72.

title: Italian Network Bars Hussein Interview, Setting Off Dispute
description: The state television network has refused to broadcast an interview with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, touching off a heated dispute among Italian journalists and politicians over whether press freedoms have been unjustly curtailed to help promote Government policies.

title: Law Now Protects Sculpture Buyers in New York
description: Nine years after it was first proposed, a bill providing protection in New York State for buyers of cast sculptures became law today. It is believed to be the first such state law enacted in this country.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday titled "How Stock Markets Fared Around the World" omitted the indexfor Japan. A corrected version of the Japan section appears today on page 44.

title: New York State Faces the Impact Of New Laws
description: When New Yorkers consider the accomplishments of their state government in 1990, most will probably begin and end by thinking about taxes.

title: Frieder Finds a New Home
description: A local bank here recently came up with an advertising campaign featuring the basketball coaches of the state's two biggest colleges.

title: Careers; Interns Study International Management
description: Too few senior business managers attempt to find and train international managers, according to Robert J. Cunningham. He is director of international programs at Babson College. "They want marketers or financial analysts first, and internationalists only second or third," he said.

title: Books of The Times; Art as a Bulwark Against Death
description: Patrimony By Philip Roth 238 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: N. H. Moss Dies at 64; Surgeon and Scientist
description: N. Henry Moss, a surgeon, scientist and past president of the New York Academy of Sciences, died Wednesday at Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia. He was 64 years old and lived in Merion, Pa.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; New Materials Instead of Metal, Novel Ceramics
description: To push beyond the present frontiers of technology, it will be necessary in many instances to develop materials with strengths and properties now unattainable.

title: ISRAEL EXPECTING IRAQ MISSILE STRIKE IF WAR BREAKS OUT
description: Israeli military experts are virtually unanimous that in the event of war, Iraq would launch at least 20 missiles against Israel armed with conventional or chemical warheads, and that some of those missiles would be certain to penetrate Israeli defenses.

title: Moscow Journal; With Medicine Itself Sick, Russians Turn to Herbs
description: A man complaining of a bad liver poked his head through the small kiosk window of a new private shop and begged for a cure. The entrepreneur, alas, was flush out of Immortal.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Fall by 0.7%
description: The prices farmers receive for raw products ended 1990 with a seven-tenths of 1 percent decline from November to December, the Agriculture Department said yesterday.

title: Suspect Is Arrested 2d Time in 2 Weeks In Evers Murder Case
description: Byron de la Beckwith was arrested for a second time in less than two weeks today on a warrant stemming from the 1963 slaying of the civil rights leader Medgar Evers.

title: Leaving Public Office, Dukakis Reflects, and Emerges Upbeat
description: It is a classic Dukakis moment.

title: Kersey Status Improves
description: Jerome Kersey's injured calf has improved considerably and he may be able to return to National Basketball Association action in the near-future.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Software Writing From an Art To a Science
description: As medical equipment, airplanes and weapons become increasingly computerized, errors in programming will increasingly have potentially fatal results unless ways can be found to produce software more quickly and reliably.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARY LOU RETTON, who somersaulted and back-flipped her way to an Olympic gold medal, married her longtime beau, SHANNON KELLEY, a former college football player, in Houston on Saturday.

title: Texas Drowns Out Miami Going Into Game
description: An interesting thing happened during lunch this afternoon: the University of Miami football team showed up and actually made some noise.

title: Parking Rules for Holidays in 1991
U.S.-Soviet Polar Team To Drift On Ice Floe
description: THE United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to establish a research station on the drifting ice of the Weddell Sea in their first joint scientific effort in Antarctica.

title: Andersen Kicks Saints Into Playoffs
description: Morten Andersen kicked a 24-yard field goal with two seconds left tonight to put New Orleans into the National Football League playoffs for only the second time in franchise history as the Saints beat the Los Angeles Rams, 20-17.

title: Superlative for the Old Year: It Was New York's Warmest
description: The old year is barely out the door, and already the record-keepers are saying it was one for the books: 1990 was New York City's warmest year.

title: Rangers Await Knock From a Soviet Center
description: The door to Neil Smith's office at Madison Square Garden was open. A couple of dozen strides from it, Sergei Nemchinov dressed quietly and then left, the implicit invitation ignored.

title: Poor Man's 'Shuttle' Gathers Riches
description: A gigantic balloon carrying some 3,000 pounds of delicate scientific equipment 25 miles above the earth completed a 10-day circuit of Antarctica Sunday, returning a trove of astronomical information to waiting physicists.

title: Julius A. Rippel, 89; Headed Foundation And Banking House
description: Julius A. Rippel, an investment banker and chairman of the Fannie E. Rippel Foundation of Annandale, N.J., died on Sunday at his home in Madison, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; L. William Seidman/Banking Regulator Gains New Respect
description: L. William Seidman says one of his New Year's resolutions will be to figure out when he leaves his post.

title: Secret Service Agent Seized On Shoplifting Charge in Vail
description: A Secret Service agent assigned to Vice President Dan Quayle's protective detail has been arrested on a shoplifting charge here.

title: Robert S. Hutchins, An Architect, 83, Of Public Buildings
description: Robert S. Hutchins, the architect of many buildings for educational, civic and religious institutions around the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: German Bank Displays A Get-Tough Approach
description: When Commerzbank A.G. decided last spring to create its own network of branch offices in eastern Germany, Frankfurt's bankers told each other that the nation's third-largest commercial bank was making a strategic error.

title: Scaffold Drops At S.I. Boiler; 9 Workers Hurt
description: Nine Consolidated Edison workers were injured yesterday on Staten Island when the scaffolding they were standing on inside a boiler collapsed, sending them and pieces of steel tubing and wooden planks to the bottom of the 140-foot-high structure.

title: As U.S. Car Makers Cut Back, Toyota Is Expanding Briskly
description: At a time when the American automobile industry is laying off thousands of workers, shuttering factories and bracing for a recession, Kunihiko Minami, the chief of operations at the Toyota Motor Corporation's sprawling Takaoka plant here, says he has his own problems: he cannot find enough auto workers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-7

title: King's Hat Trick Sparks Islanders
description: He called the first of his four goals a gift from his linemate Patrick Flatley. His final goal, the one that confirmed a 6-3 victory for the Islanders this afternoon against the visiting Quebec Nordiques with six seconds left on the time clock, came almost by default after both his linemates, Flatley and Brent Sutter, had already taken aim at and missed the empty Quebec net.

title: Bank Failures Dip, for Now
description: The number of bank and savings institution failures declined in 1990 for the first time in seven years, but the floundering economy may prevent any sustained improvement.

title: Disabled Soviet Craft Plunging Back to Earth
description: With rescue plans in tatters and all control apparently lost, an abandoned 40-ton Soviet space station will plunge to earth in a rain of fiery debris in the next few weeks, experts on the Soviet space program said yesterday.

title: Cuomo Gives Clemency to Inmate With AIDS
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has pushed unsuccessfully for a law that would sanction the early parole of terminally ill inmates, today granted clemency for the first time to a person with AIDS.

title: MCA Takeover Is Completed
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company has closed its $6.6 billion purchase of the entertainment company MCA Inc., completing the largest Japanese acquisition of an American company.

title: Make Way for Bicycles, a Cleaner Way to Go; Toxics in Gasoline
description: To the Editor:

title: Vasectomies and Prostate Cancer: A Link?
description: Two studies suggest that a vasectomy might slightly increase the risk of developing prostate cancer, but the researchers caution that the findings are highly tentative and that other factors may be at work.

title: McDaniel Proves A Perfect Steal
description: Jerry Colangelo, president and owner of the Phoenix Suns, tells the story of how Kevin Johnson, the team's playmaker, stopped him in the dressing room, shook his hand and said: "I can't believe we got the X-Man, and giving up so little for him. I don't know how you did it."

title: An Opportunity Born Of Adversity
description: The Fiesta Bowl, which pits Alabama against Louisville on Tuesday, won't have any impact on the national championship, but it has surely brought focus on the state of Arizona's bruised national image.

title: Treasury Issues Up on Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose solidly in light trading yesterday, as some traders and investors bought in anticipation of stronger demand in coming days.

title: A Writer Puts the Political Above the Personal
description: For the novelist Nadine Gordimer, direct involvement in the political battles of South Africa is absolutely necessary; "Writing is not enough," she says. Miss Gordimer, who says she remains a "fairly active" member of the African National Congress, as she has been for many years, has had some public disagreements with other writers over this issue. And while she does not discount the value of literary exposures of the reality of apartheid in her country -- she has written some of the best -- she remains firm in her political stand.

title: Highland Chain In Accord on Debt
description: Highland Superstores Inc. reached an agreement with its banks to defer half of its $22 million in short-term debt payments. But the company will continue to seek a buyer or a merger partner, officials of the consumer electronics retail chain said. Under the agreement, Highland, based in Plymouth, Mich., has until March 15 to pay the $11 million.

title: Stealth Bomber Production May Be Suspended in 1991
description: The Pentagon will probably decide not to begin construction in 1991 of any new B-2 Stealth bombers beyond the 15 already in production or flight testing, Government officials and industry analysts said today. The Air Force said it had not made a final decision.

title: Hard Times Spur Many to Help the Neediest
description: Ten months after losing his job as a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., Nicholas P. Heymann sent $3,500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and wrote that he considered himself fortunate.

title: Rushdie Says He May Go To Egypt if He Is Invited
description: Salman Rushdie said today that he would seriously consider any invitation to visit Egypt, but he denied newspaper reports that he had been formally asked to do so.

title: INSIDE
description: The Market's Bruising Year Shareholders had their toughest year since 1981. The Dow Jones industrial average closed 1990 at 2,633.66, down 4.3 percent for the year. Page 41. A No-Frills Swearing-In Forgoing festivities, Mario M. Cuomo was sworn in to a third term as New York's Governor to confront his biggest fiscal challenge. Page 31. Intense Fighting in Somalia Fighting between Government and rebel forces intensified in the Somali capital amid reports the President had gone to the airport. Page 3. Cycles of Abstinence Social scientists say a new American temperance movement seems to be under way. Science Times, page 35. Victory for Kasparov With a draw in the final game, Gary Kasparov won an outright victory in the World Chess Championship and the larger share of the purse. Page 32.

title: Costs of Acupuncture Are Overstated
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Ager Who Saved 5 From Fire Dies of Injuries
description: A 14-year-old girl who saved five family members from their burning home has died of injuries suffered when she went back into the house.

title: Congress Gets a Message
description: Members of Congress almost invariably miss more roll-call votes in even-numbered years than in odd-numbered, because in the even years they're out campaigning. But in 1990, for the first time since 1964, there was no slippage in election-year voting in the House and only a slight dip in the Senate.

title: Scrolls' Editor Is Formally Dismissed
description: The Israel Antiquities Authority announced yesterday that it had formally dismissed the American scholar who was the chief editor of the Dead Sea Scrolls containing the oldest known copies of the Old Testament and other ancient writings.

title: Rap, on Its Best Behavior, Returns to Hall in Oakland
description: Amid police barricades and metal detectors, rap music returned to one of this city's largest auditoriums after a yearlong ban imposed to curb violence at concerts.

title: Bridge
description: The Greater New York Bridge Association ended 1990 on Sunday with a very successful tournament. The Winter Regional Championships in Manhattan recorded 1,100 tables in play in four days, making it the biggest in 16 years.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Micro Motors Rotors and Gears For Tiny Robots
description: The saga of the incredible shrinking machine is expected to get a bold new chapter in the 1990's as scientists around the world perfect a new class of motors, sensors and mechanical devices so small that some would fit into the period at the end of this sentence.

title: Judith Leibowitz, 70, A Teacher at Juilliard
description: Judith Leibowitz, a teacher at the Juilliard School of Music, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 70 years old.

title: Yankees Get a Prize Starter in Sanderson of A's
description: Successful but spurned in Oakland, Scott Sanderson decided to become one of the Yankees' starting pitchers. He made the decision reluctantly, yesterday, but once he did, he immediately set out to help recruit another starting pitcher the Yankees are trying to sign. The Yankees hoped to learn today whether or not they will be as successful with re-signing Mike Witt, a new-look free agent, as they were with signing Sanderson.

title: City Report on Subway Fire Urges Better Rescue Efforts
description: New York City officials, drawing lessons from last week's fatal subway fire, recommended a series of steps yesterday to avert similar disasters.

title: Baltimore's Bridges Becoming More Colorful
description: For Stan Edmister, bridges are a canvas. Where an engineer sees a mass of concrete and steel, he sees a potential masterpiece.

title: First Executive Stake Is Sold for 14 a Share
description: Rosewood Financial Partners said yesterday that it had sold its entire stake in the First Executive Corporation, a Los Angeles insurance holding company with problems stemming from its sizable "junk bond" portfolio.

title: Temperance: An Old Cycle Repeats Itself
description: Today is the day after the biggest drinking holiday of the year. Although many Americans presumably overindulged, more and more are looking with disdain on the rite of getting drunk.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Genetic Redesign A New Ark Of Beasts and Crops
description: In the 17 years since scientists first managed to splice genes from one species of living organism into another, billions of dollars have been poured into biotechnology research and development. Only a trickle of products emerged during the 1980's; a steady stream is expected in the next decade.

title: That Aroma Must Be Classic Socks
description: From all over the land the people came, clamorous for food and drink, a soft touch for souvenir hawkers and women of a certain kind, their exuberance sweeping them like a tide into the stadium to cheer lustily as the young athletes ran from the vaulted tunnel out onto the field of competition.

title: Robin Rutherfurd Is Wed in Florida
description: Robin Weaver Rutherfurd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Rutherfurd of Palm Beach, Fla., was married at the Royal Poinciana Chapel there yesterday to Morgan Hatton Grace 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan H. Grace of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Thomas W. Kirkman, a Presbyterian minister, performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: Business and Health; Guarding Medical Confidentiality
description: Growing concern about the cost and quality of health care is prompting changes that are eroding confidentiality rules that have long protected both hospital patients and doctors. Hospital records are increasingly available to outside reviewers. Employers and insurers, who ultimately pay many medical bills, insist that their representatives often need to see information that used to be closely guarded.

title: Replacing a Telescope
description: A $55 million contract has been awarded to build and test a replacement for the huge radio telescope at Greenbank, W.Va., that collapsed two years ago. Astronomers predict that when the telescope begins operation in 1995, it will be the most productive astronomical instrument of its type ever built.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The new chairman of Pace University is CARL H. PFORZHEIMER 3D, an investment banker and civic leader. A member of the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Planning Board, he is the managing partner of Carl H. Pforzheimer & Company in New York. Mr. Pforzheimer, 54 years old, is a graduate of Harvard University and its business school; he has been on Pace's board since 1981. He is also president of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, the nation's largest nonprofit home health-care agency. Pace, with 23,000 students, has campuses in Manhattan and in Westchester County.

title: Agreement On Sabena Is Canceled
description: Faced with a year-end deadline and a variety of unresolved issues, the three companies involved in an agreement that would have given British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines each a 20 percent stake in Sabena Belgian World Airlines, canceled the deal today.

title: After First Year a More Relaxed Dinkins
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said "hell." More precisely, he said "what the hell" during a live radio interview on Dec. 27. Mr. Dinkins was addressing the supposed controversy over his excruciatingly formal manner of speech. "But what the hell," he said, "they criticize me for the way I dress, too." And tennis, of course. "If you really think about it," the Mayor said, "It ain't no pantywaist game."

title: Air Strike by Israelis Kills 12 Guerrillas In Lebanon's South
description: Israel unleashed its deadliest air attack of the year on Lebanon today, killing 12 Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas in a predawn raid near Sidon.

title: Army Activates 2,667 More From the Guard and Reserve
description: The Army said today that it was ordering to active duty 2,667 National Guard and Army Reserve members from 15 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico.

title: Gaudi's Church Still Divides Barcelona
description: The wooden scaffolding rattled 40 feet up on the Passion Facade of Antoni Gaudi's famous Sagrada Familia Church. But Josep Maria Subirachs, his bootlaces undone and his corduroys heavy with rock dust, was impervious as he admired his own stone creation on the facade: a faceless statue of Jesus on a horizontal steel cross.

title: Morning
description: I would open my eyes -- there was the cube of my room around me again, square bubble with me in my crib at its center. I'd pull myself up by the bars, and then the great work of the day would begin, I'd hear my elder sister, down the hall, I could hear the funnel of her throat, the milky mucus on her soft palate, I'd hear her body's soft ah and mm , the voice of the mouth. Mmah, mmah, she would go first, as she'd gone face-first, soft grater-cups of her eyelids and lips along the channel so when I had arrived I had poured through the worked hole and there she was, my sister! I had fit myself to her, waxing gibbous into the crescent's heat-shield, I rode behind her, and when she woke and cried, in her sweet descending scale, MMAA, mmaa, I'd sing right after, MA ma, it was the morning of the world, the dawn peak, she'd summon our god, our tongues still dewed deep with the cream from her rosy fissures, and I'd follow, flowing in her slip-stream I'd echo my sister, I was her living rhyme. Maa, maa, in her sturdy voice, then the silvery twin, Ma ma, almost not human, almost an element, air or water, and then the shrieks of pleasure, my mother would find me standing on the points of my toes staring at the doorway she would enter, my eyes calm with uncontrolled bliss.

title: How Bush Can Be Education President
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev Admits Errors but Predicts Gains; Bush Tidings Circumspect
description: In a friendly but circumspect New Year's Day message to the Soviet Union, President Bush applauded Moscow's cooperation in the Persian Gulf and encouraged a country troubled by ethnictensions and economic hardship to continue its "arduous journey" toward reform.

title: Europeans Expect Session on Friday to Lead to Talks With Iraqis
description: Foreign ministers of the European Community expect their special session in Luxembourg on Friday to lead to direct discussions with Iraq, European officials said today.

title: By Design/Adventure!
description: Experiment. Make that your fashion motto for 1991. When times are tough, it's not the time to retreat into old safe and sure styles. Instead, perk yourself up by bringing a little change into your wardrobe, as long as you don't spend too much, of course. Here are some suggestions.

title: 2 Cellular Phone Units To Be Sold
description: Two cellular telephone companies announced definitive agreements for their sale yesterday after they were unable to raise the cash to meet year-end bank loan payments.

title: Dime for Your Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Window View
description: Imagine being able to call up several programs in separate windows on your computer's screen. Imagine, furthermore, being able to move the windows around and make them bigger or smaller. Finally, imagine having one program continue to work -- say, a spreadsheet recalculating the profit and loss statement -- while you are using another -- say, the word processor to write a memo about what went wrong last quarter.

title: USG to Try Revamping Out of Court
description: With two leading makers of wallboard already in bankruptcy, the USG Corporation said today that it would attempt an out-of-court financial restructuring to avert a bankruptcy in the face of a deep downturn in its core Sheetrock business.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, page 22 of the Television section on Sunday carried erroneous highlights listings for today's news/documentaries, children's programming and sports events. The entries were a repetition of Monday's. Correct schedules appear in today's paper, on page 60.

title: Heavy Fighting Erupts in Somali Capital
description: Fighting between Government and opposition forces intensified today in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, amid reports that the President, Mohammed Siad Barre, had taken refuge at the international airport.

title: Experts Suggest Cures for an Ailing Bank System
description: As losses from bad loans mount at banks across the country, consultants outside the industry are proposing ways to prevent the painful 1990 experience from becoming a full-fledged disaster.

title: Raise Bolsters the Judiciary, Rehnquist Says
description: Chief Justice William Rehnquist said today that the 25 percent raise for Federal judges that becomes effective on Tuesday would help them cope with a sharply rising caseload of drug crimes and bankruptcies.

title: Credo
description: I believe in magic. I believe in the rights of animals to leap out of our skins as it is said in the Tlingit legend: That instant a bear appeared where a boy had been as I believe in the resurrected wake-robin, first wet knob of trillium to knock in April at the underside of earth's door in central New Hampshire where bears are, though still denned up at that early greening. I believe in living on grateful terms with the earth, with the black crumbles of ancient manure that sift through my fingers when I topdress the garden for winter. I believe in the red strings of earthworms aroused out of season and in the bear, asleep now in the rock cave where my outermost pasture abuts the forest. I cede him a swale of chokecherries in August. I give the sow and her cub as much yardage as they desire when our paths intersect, as does my horse shifting under me respectful but not cowed by our encounter. I believe in the gift of the horse, which is magic, their deep fear-snorts in play when the wind comes up, the ballet of nip and jostle, plunge and crow hop. I trust them to run from me, necks arched in a full swan's S, tails cocked up over their backs like plumes on a Cavalier's hat. I trust them to gallop back, skid to a stop, their nostrils level with my mouth, asking for my human breath that they may test its intent, taste the lure of it. I believe in myself as their sanctuary and in the earth with its summer plumes of carrots, its clamber of peas, beans, masses of tendrils as mine. I believe in the acrobatics of boy into bear, the grace of animals in my keeping, the thrust to go on.

title: Dow Ends Worst Year Since 1981
description: Wall Street gave investors the toughest time last year since 1981, final stock market figures showed yesterday.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; In Parallel Crunching Numbers By the Teraflop
description: By the end of this century, computer designers expect to see a "teraflop" supercomputer, one that can calculate more than a trillion mathematical operations each second. Based on a technique known as massively parallel processing, it will team hundreds or thousands of independent processors -- silicon chips that perform calculations -- to solve problems far too imposing for even the most powerful computers today. The teraflop computer will help scientists and engineers in areas like simulating the body's reaction to a new drug without the need for human subjects; mapping the human genetic structure to better understand inherited diseases; generating models of the world's climates to study changes induced by air pollutants and recognizing spoken languages and images in order to improve the versatility of factory robots.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If we do finally fall behind Germany or Japan because we just don't have the skilled work force to keep up, it may have less to do with our productivity than our racism." -- The Rev. William Cunningham, a priest in Detroit's inner city. [ 8:5. ]

title: Frank Maier, 57, Dies; Ex-Newsweek Reporter
description: Frank Maier, the former Midwest bureau chief of Newsweek whose personal account of his liver transplant was the magazine's cover story on Sept. 12, 1988, died at his home yesterday in Arlington Heights, Ill. He was 57 years old.

title: Quayle Draws Ovation on Visit to the Troops
description: Vice President Dan Quayle told American troops in Saudi Arabia today that if American military force was used against Iraq, it would be "quick, massive and decisive."

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Digital Imaging A Merger of TV And Computing
description: The line between the computer and the television is blurring: increasingly, the computer can display video images and high-quality sound, while the television has grown from offering a one-way broadcast to a machine that can be used to compose, store and retrieve personally tailored programs.

title: Contract Deadlock Imperils Busing of Disabled Children
description: Negotiations between New York City and bus companies that transport more than 7,000 young children with disabilities and AIDS broke off yesterday afternoon, hours before the companies' contracts expired.

title: Memorable, Forgettable And Others
description: On New Year's Day, we look back once more at the last year, which may or may not provide guidance for the future:

title: I.B.M. Plans Australian Hub
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has announced plans to establish a major telecommunications networking hub in Australia for the Asia-Pacific region. The move would double I.B.M.'s Sydney-based networking capacity over the next two years.

title: Michigan St. Tops U.S.C.
description: Michigan State abandoned its potent ground attack and relied on big plays by the receiver Courtney Hawkins today as the Spartans beat Southern Cal, 17-16, in the John Hancock Bowl.

title: New Year's Day
description: NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Only the emergency services window of the ain office, at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, open. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday parking rules. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleaning. Schools: Closed Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses and trains on holiday schedule. L.I.R.R. on weekend schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Buses and trains on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on weekend schedule.

title: George R. Vierno, 50, Ex-Correction Official
description: George R. Vierno, retired chief of department of the New York City Correction Department, died yesterday at his home in Huguenot, S.I. He was 50 years old.

title: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; Richard G. Darman/Getting the Blame For the Budget Pain
description: When Richard G. Darman became budget director, his goal was to engineer what he called "the Grand Compromise," a sweeping deal in which Republicans and Democrats agreed to politically painful measures to reduce the budget deficit.

title: Norman Rockwell, Less Memorably
description: He's famous for his homespun eloquence and for the puckish charm of his portraits of young Americans making their way in the 20th century. But even Norman Rockwell occasionally goofed.

title: Democrats Gain Advantage in Reapportionment
description: Democrats increased the number of seats they hold in state legislatures by 45 in the November elections, but their gains were smaller than in past years when there was no Presidential election, an organization of the country's state legislatures has reported.

title: The Price at the Pump: Quick Rise, Slow Fall
description: After a long rough spell at the beginning of the Persian Gulf crisis, the last two months have been a very good time to be in the business of selling gasoline. Pump prices have remained relatively high as crude oil prices have fallen steadily, giving rise to renewed allegations by consumer groups of price-gouging.

title: Baker Likely to Visit Gulf Allies As Kuwait Deadline Approaches
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is likely to visit Saudi Arabia and other nations in the Persian Gulf before the Jan. 15 deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to make sure that military plans are complete and that the international alliance is firmly in place, officials said today.

title: Courier Survives First Round
description: TENNIS

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Powering Up Will Solar Energy Dawn at Last?
description: Experts say the arrival of abundant, pollution-free energy awaits two developments: better battery storage and more efficient manufacturing of solar photovoltaic cells or wind turbines.

title: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies; Fiber Optics New Networks For the Nation
description: The "gigabit network" would make it possible to transmit computer data and video images among the nation's supercomputer centers, research laboratories and universities, as well as to businesses and homes. This network of fiber-optic cables, which would completely replace existing copper lines, is viewed by many scientists and executives as both a vital research tool and an essential part of the country's "information infrastructure" for the next century.

title: Hearns and Leonard Ready for Bout No. 3
description: Thomas Hearns and Sugar Ray Leonard say they will fight a third time.

title: A Few Words About Paying Bills of the 80's
description: "It is clear to me that both the size of the deficit problem and the need for a package that can be enacted require . . . tax revenue increases."

title: Pro Football; Giants Not Shaken Despite Close Call
description: Bill Parcells, the coach of the Giants, talked by telephone this morning with Buddy Ryan, the coach of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Research on Birth Defects Shifts to Flaws in Sperm
description: AFTER three decades of efforts to discover how a pregnant woman's environment can affect the health of her fetus, researchers are turning their attention to fathers.

title:
WITH RESPECT TO THE NEW;
A Chorus
description: Human beings suffer,They torture one another,They get hurt and get hard.No poem or play or songCan fully right a wrongInflicted and endured.The innocent in jailsBeat on their bars together.A hunger-striker's fatherStands in the graveyard dumb.A police widow in veilsFaints at the funeral home.History says,

title: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; Alan Greenspan/Fed Chairman Feels Chill of Recession
description: In his nearly three and a half years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan has gone through the repertory of experiences that can befall a central bank chief -- inflation, a stock market crash and now recession. Trying to shake it off is likely to occupy most of Mr. Greenspan's time in the final months of his term, which ends in August.

title: Kasparov Wins Match By Drawing Last Game
description: Gary Kasparov won the World Championship Chess Match last night against Anatoly Karpov by drawing the 24th and final game in Lyons, France.

title: Five U.S. Troops Are Killed In Separate Incidents in Gulf
description: The Pentagon said today that five members of the United States military had died in five incidents in the Persian Gulf in recent days, including two men who were killed by M-16 gunshots.

title: Shoulders Will Show Up All Over
description: Fashion may be fickle, but one thing is certain: there will be a lot of bare shoulders this year. Not only on the beaches and at grand parties, but at lunches at nice restaurants, in theaters, at private dinners: where women gather, smooth shoulders will be prominent.

title: Calling All Whistle-Blowers
description: Whistle-blowers, the A.C.L.U. wants you.

title: Saudis Say Costs of Crisis Outrun Oil Gains
description: The Saudi Government said today that military costs related to the Persian Gulf crisis have exceeded the extra revenue earned by the kingdom from higher petroleum prices and an increase in production.

title: A Very Serious Omission
description: No matter what you may have heard, I am not sulky about being omitted from New York magazine's list of the treasures of New York City. This rumor was probably started by a busybody who eavesdropped on my conversation with David Halberstam during the opera intermission the other night at Lincoln Center.

title: Degree Doesn't Include VCR Programming
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Dies After Shooting
description: A 20-year-old woman who was shot early Sunday as she sat in a car in the Bronx died last night. The woman, Marilyn Colon, died at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center 17 hours after she gave birth to a six-pound girl by Caesarean section. The baby was listed in good condition. Ms. Colon's companion, Carlos Ventura, 26, of 232 Sherman Avenue in Manhattan, was killed by the gunman, who approached their car in front of 2103 Vyse Avenue in the West Farms section near the Bronx Zoo. The police said they believed that Mr. Ventura was the target of the shooting, but they had no suspects.

title: Lujan Moves to Kill Japanese Contract for Concessions at Yosemite
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. today escalated his fight to keep Japanese commerce out of American landmarks by threatening to cancel a contract, newly acquired by a Japanese company, to provide food, lodging and other services in Yosemite National Park.

title: Credit Analysts Expect A Drop in Interest Rates
description: With the economy in recession and the Federal Reserve Board moving to prevent the downturn from being deep and prolonged, most credit market analysts anticipate that interest rates will fall, perhaps by a percentage point or more, in the first half of the new year.

title: Star-Ledger Raises Price
description: The Newark Star-Ledger increased the price of its daily paper Monday to 25 cents, from 15 cents. The increase is the first for the state's largest newspaper since 1980, when the price was raised to 15 cents, from 10 cents. The newspaper attributed the increase to sharply rising costs, compounded by reduced advertising revenues. The price of The Sunday Star-Ledger rose to 50 cents, from 35 cents, on Oct. 28.

title: A Masterstroke By the Champion
description: Although there were many smashing attacks, treacherous traps and delicate maneuvers during the World Championship Chess Match, the most spectacular moment of the match came early on.

title: School Renovation Plan Divides Carolina Village
description: The renovation of a historic school building in this tiny fishing village has snared this region in a tangle of race, education and environmental issues.

title: Biondi's Criticism Is Making Waves
description: Two days before the start of the world championships in Perth, Australia, Matt Biondi was already making waves. Biondi, winner of five gold medals at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, was quoted in Australian newspapers yesterday as having said USA Swimming officials were holding the sport back because of financial restrictions on top athletes.

title: Hard-Won Acceptance Spawns New Conflicts Around Ethnic Studies
description: At the outset, Robert C. Smith's course at San Francisco State University, "Black Politics," presented a tidy lesson in the dynamics of power and justice on which political science is based.

title: Elegant (and Loathing) Memories of Childhood and Junket
description: REMEMBER Junket? Then you may have thought you had lived long enough to see its demise or perhaps you may be happy to know it's still around.

title: Branding Doctors with HIV
description: AIDS remains a dreadful, and to date, universally fatal infection. People are very afraid of AIDS -- and they should be.

title: The Good Old Days
description: To The Living Section:

title: Capitals Outshoot Devils
description: The Devils again proved to be the right remedy for the struggling Capitals. Last season on Jan. 16, Washington ended a streak without a victory at eight games with a triumph over the Devils. The Capitals followed the same prescription this afternoon.

title: Do We Want to Be the Butchers of Baghdad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Needed: Middle East Peace Talks
description: "Linked" or not, there is no way to separate the crisis in the Gulf from the Israeli-Palestinian question. Following a settlement with Iraq, either through peace or war, even greater pressure will emerge within the international community to convene a peace conference. United Nations rsolutions on the Middle East, from four decades ago to the present, have been given a new vitality and will not go away again.

title: Review/Television; A Maestro in Exile Is Welcomed Home
description: "Soldiers of Music: Rostropovich Returns to Russia" seems curiously confused about which direction it should take. No sooner does it open with a close-up of Mstislav Rostropovich's cello and hands than it treats us to the sight of Mike Wallace being made up for "60 Minutes." While the camera focuses on Mr. Rostropovich, much of the talk is about the novelist Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn and the possibility of his returning to the Soviet Union. (Later in the year, he refused an invitation.) As a result, Mr. Rostropovich too often ends up a minor character in his own story.

title: Thousands of Albanians Flee to Greece
description: Tired Albanians wearing tattered clothes fled by the thousands into Greece today, crossing snow-covered Mount Tsamanta.

title: Review/Film; A Soviet Documentary Offers a Portrait of a Gulag
description: Marina Goldovskaya's 1988 "Solovki Power," opening today at the Film Forum, is first-rate film journalism, of historical importance for what it shows to have been and for the way it demonstrates the degree of self-examination going on within the Soviet Union now.

title: Somali Forces Clash With Rebels for 3d Day as Both Report Gains
description: Fierce fighting between rebel forces and the Government continued for a third day in the Somali capital today but there were conflicting reports about how much of the city and what strategic elements the two sides controlled.

title: Some Sectors Advance Despite a Deep Slump
description: Companies whose stocks were unaffected by the Middle East and by the recession ended 1990 as the big winners on the American Stock Exchange. Health-care and drug companies, for instance claimed 4 of the top 10 spots.

title: Seven Killed In Five Hours Of New Year
description: In the five hours after the end of a year that set a record for homicides, seven people were killed in New York City yesterday. Six of them were shot in separate incidents and one was stabbed to death in an elevator, apparently during an argument.

title: Blazes in Illinois and Indiana Kill Woman and 8 Children
description: A fire swept through a two-story house here today, killing a woman and four children, the authorities said. Elsewhere, a fire at a house near Michigantown, Ind., killed four children.

title: TOP BUSH ADVISERS CALLED IN TO MEET ON IRAQ STRATEGY
description: President Bush met with senior advisers tonight to discuss the military and political strategies for the final push leading to the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, Administration officials said.

title: Hussein Visited Troops at Front for New Year, Iraqi TV Says
description: Iraqi television tonight broadcast a videotape of what was described as President Saddam Hussein's visit on Monday night to his front-line forces in Kuwait, where he gave them a pep talk, stirred their campfire meals and pronounced them "ready to fight."

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ameriana Bancorp, New Castle, Ind., appointed Harry J. Bailey chief executive, succeeding Paul W. Prior, who will remain chairman. * Bank of New York named Edward J. Collins vice president in its personal trust sales and marketing division. * Barbers Hairstyling for Men and Women Inc., Minneapolis, appointed Kenneth Lessall vice president. * ESPN, Bristol, Conn., a cable network that is 80 percent-owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc., New York, promoted Edwin M. Durso to executive vice president of network marketing and general counsel. * FMC Corp., Chicago, producers of agricultural chemicals, named Frank A. Riddick 3d treasurer, replacing William H. Schumann 3d, who was appointed executive director of corporate development. * FMS Financial Corp., Burlington, N.J., named Craig Yates president and chief executive of the company and its Farmers' and Mechanics' Savings Bank units. He succeeds Michael Bisceglie, who continues as a board member. * Federal Housing Finance Board, Washington, appointed Lawrence U. Costiglio a director. * IE Industries, Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a holding company for gas and electric utilities, appointed Blake O. Fisher Jr. executive vice president and chief financial officer. * LSI Logic, Milpitas, Calif., supplier of semiconductors, named Frederick Brown 4th vice president of sales, Asia and Pacific. * Newsday and New York Newsday, New York, units of the Times Mirror Co., Los Angeles, named Alberto Ibarguen senior vice president. * Prestige International Ltd., North Reading, Mass., marketers of apparel and bags, appointed Clifford M. Davis executive vice president.

title: Grieving Families Reach Out to Aid Neediest
description: When Bruce and Denise Tredwell contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in 1989, their 8-year-old son Joshua was in the pediatric intensive-care unit at New York University Medical Center.

title: INSIDE
description: Top Resorts to Be Sold The Palm Beach Polo and Country Club, Kiawah Island in South Carolina and La Quinta in California will be sold to a management group and several Japanese investors. Page D1. Big Bank Cuts Prime Rate The Bank of America reduced its prime lending rate to 9.5 percent, from 10 percent, the first of the 10 largest banks to do so. Page D1. Paradox on Black Studies Can black politics be taught outside a black studies department? A San Francisco State University course raises a paradox. Education, page B8. Refilling the Hourglass After a 20-year reign of an anorexic esthetic, a consensus is forming that the perfect woman is full-figured, but fit. The Living Section, page C1. Troubled Times on Wall St. After a difficult year in the markets, attention is focused on interest rates and the prospect of economic revival. A review of 1990 in charts and tables, and a look ahead, pages D1 and D7-14.

title: Restoring Old Videotapes of Casals Festival
description: "Here, smell this," said Bob Kramer, handing a visitor in his office a reel of 25-year-old videotape. "It's mildewed, isn't it? And if you close your eyes, you can smell the ocean. It looks fairly clean now, but when we first opened the box, we found plaster, sand, pieces of wood: everything the wind blew in over the years."

title: Four Palestinian Protesters Are Slain
description: Four Palestinians were killed in clashes with Israeli authorities today, the 26th anniversary of the first military operation by Al Fatah, the main guerrilla group of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: The 90's Woman: How Fat Is Fat?
description: BITE by bite, American women dutifully serve the reigning image of body beautiful. Men have been almost blissfully immune from the vicissitudes of body style, but in the United States women have borne the burden with gusto.

title: Mingo Doing Well Despite a Tough Year
description: WHEN Frank Mingo died a little more than a year ago, many people in the advertising industry wondered whether the agency he founded, the Mingo Group, would survive.

title: Bus Talks Collapse; Transport in Doubt For Disabled Youths
description: Contract talks between New York City officials and school bus company executives collapsed late last night, leaving hundreds of disabled pre-schoolers with no transportation today, the first school day of the new year.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: THESE days many intelligent and pleasure-seeking eaters other than vegetarians enjoy meatless main courses. There is no better way of preparing them than in a microwave oven, where the flavors blend and the vegetables cook perfectly but retain individuality and texture.

title: Kiel Martin, an Actor, Dies at 46; Played a Detective on 'Hill Street'
description: Kiel Martin, who played the wheeler-dealer detective J. D. LaRue on the television series "Hill Street Blues," died here on Friday. He was 46 years old.

title: Dr. Karel Steinbach, Gynecologist, 96
description: Dr. Karel Steinbach, a gynecologist and general practitioner in Queens, died on Monday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 96 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Yanks Seem Set to Announce Agreement on Pact With Witt
description: Working overtime when most other people were taking time off, Gene Michael, the Yankees' general manager, appeared to solidify another fifth of the team's starting rotation yesterday. He didn't say so, but Michael's words indicated that the Yankees had reached agreement on a new contract with Mike Witt, their new-look free agent.

title: New Life For 'Willows' In London
description: On the stage where one expects to see the great plays of Shakespeare, Chekhov and Arthur Miller, audiences are instead finding a mole, a rat, a badger and a toad.

title: Saudis Step Up Civil-Defense Effort
description: For residents of the vast Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia, the news came in a six-paragraph box on the front page of the newspaper Monday: the Saudi Government will begin selling gas masks.

title: Economic Watch; Why Only a Few Big Airlines Prosper in a Deregulated Sky
description: Continental, Pan Am, T.W.A., Midway: The list of distressed airlines reduced to selling precious assets, courting merger partners or throwing themselves on the mercy of bankruptcy courts grows ever longer.

title: 13 Held in Kidnapping of Illegal Alien
description: The New York City police arrested 13 illegal immigrants from China yesterday and accused them of kidnapping another illegal alien because he had not made payments to a Hong Kong organization that had helped him slip into the country with false documents.

title: The Knicks Play It By Tin Ear
description: The current Knicks basketball team is often reminiscent of one of the fabled old Knick teams. Not the championship teams that are remembered by the disembodied shirts that now hang from the rafters of Madison Square Garden -- the Fraziers, the Barnetts, the Bradleys and the DeBusscheres -- but the teams that are best forgotten are those of the Micheal Ray Richardsons, the Ray Williamses, the Bob McAdoos, the Spencer Haywoods.

title: Students Trying to Draw Line Between Sex and an Assault
description: Among college students around the country, a very public soul-searching unthinkable a generation ago is occurring. Men and women are asking themselves and each other: When is sex considered sex, and when is sex considered rape?

title:
Real Estate;
Marketing 555 Broadway Amid SoHo Office Slump
description: BUILT in 1889 as a department store, then used for light manufacturing, the 12-story building at 555 Broadway has been almost vacant for two years. Now a Japanese company is marketing it as office space, despite a commercial real estate slump.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was an emotional performance by and for JOAN SUTHERLAND in London Monday night, with showers of bouquets from orchestra stalls and carnations tossed from boxes above the stage.

title: A Child's Q & A With Mr. Bush
description: Question: Who's in charge of the 1991 new world order?

title: COOKS ON THE MAP - This Month: Kalman Kalla, Washington; A Star Chef In Hungary Is a Hit in Washington
description: KALMAN KALLA has been in this country for just over two months and, except for a few words like "fried" and "chicken," his English is nonexistent. But Washingtonians lucky enough to receive an invitation have found that the Hungarian chef has quickly made his country's embassy near Rock Creek Park one of the more unusual and interesting places to dine in this city.

title: Irish Primate Calls for Inquiry Into Shooting
description: The Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland called today for an independent investigation of the killing of an unarmed man by British troops in Northern Ireland.

title: Ruth McAneny Loud, Civic Leader, 89, Dies
description: Ruth McAneny Loud, a former president of the Municipal Arts Society, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: At Peak of Career, Congressman Is Leaving Job, Citing Weariness
description: Representative Bill Frenzel is retiring after 20 years in Congress, a move that mystifies many other lawmakers.

title: Hero Meets Hero
description: The honor was mutual when the current star running back of the University of Illinois met the legendary one whose records he had broken.

title: Ferocious Miami Cuts Texas Down to Size
description: The Miami Hurricanes, taunted and challenged all week by a Texas team with national championship aspirations, put on one of the most explosive demonstrations in the 55-year history of the Cotton Bowl today.

title: Vice Chairman Named Midlantic Bank Chief
description: The Midlantic Corporation has named Desmond P. McDonald president and chief executive of its lead bank, the Midlantic National Bank.

title: California Rush to Comply With Firearms Law
description: Strict new firearm regulations took effect in California today after a last-minute rush to meet a registration deadline for military-style semiautomatic weapons.

title: Aid for Child Care Opens Worlds of Some Adults
description: Four years ago, Ruby Hinman, a high school dropout and mother of three, rarely ventured beyond her front porch and the smoky blue pines that surround it. She was a hermit, she said, shy and insecure, and nervous at having to meet people.

title: Oliver Daniel, 79, A Radio Producer And a Musicologist
description: Oliver Daniel, a musicologist who was a producer and director of documentaries and dramatic programs for CBS Radio and later a vice president of Broadcast Music Inc., died on Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Judge Approves Plan to Burn Dioxin-Tainted Soil
description: A Federal district judge has approved a multimillion-dollar plan to burn dioxin-contaminated soil from 28 communities in eastern Missouri at a temporary incinerator to be built in the former town of Times Beach.

title: Despite All the Trouble, Some Issues Won Big
description: Despite the troubled financial world of 1990, there were some big winners on the New York Stock Exchange last year, led by innovative corporations whose basic businesses prospered and companies that were reorganized to increase profitability.

title: U.S. Markets Guide
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising has produced "The Guide to Test Marketing, Media Planning and Market Selection," a 500-page manual, based on evaluations of various media and how they are used in more than 50 cities. The guide is intended to help agencies and clients in the unchartered market areas of America.

title: Shopping-a-Phobia
description: To The Living Section:

title: Fat and Fine Food
description: To The Living Section:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of California Bank Adds Chairman's Title
description: Roy G. Green, a former savings and loan regulator, has been named chairman of County Bank, a publicly held savings institution in Santa Barbara, Calif. He will retain the posts of president and chief executive.

title: Vincent Out of Hospital
description: Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, was discharged from Greenwich Hospital near his Connecticut home on Monday, two weeks after surgery to remove his infected spleen. (AP)

title: David O'Connell, 53, Reputed Chief of I.R.A.
description: David O'Connell, reputed chief of staff of the Irish Republican Army during the 1970's, died today at his Dublin home, the Sinn Fein party said. Mr. O'Connell, who used the Gaelic variant Daithi O Conaill, was 53 years old.

title: A $739 Million Asset Sale Is Seen for Landmark Land
description: The Landmark Land Company has agreed to sell the bulk of its golf courses, resorts and real estate assets for about $739 million to a joint venture led by its management and several Japanese investors, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: About New York; Taking Aim At Bureaucracy, In Two Acts
description: Beating up on the bureaucracy is a time-honored New York sport. But the blows are seldom self-inflicted, which is what makes Eric Zaccar's thrusts against a city housing agency so odd and unexpected.

title: After 5 Years, Case Against Former Mayor of San Diego Is Resolved
description: The political corruption case that forced Roger Hedgecock to resign as Mayor of San Diego has formally been closed after five years of appeals.

title: New Delhi Journal; In News-Hungary India, Videotapes Fill the Void
description: Information-hungry Indians, annoyed by the failures of state-run broadcasting networks, are turning in droves to private-enterprise "alternative television" news on videotape.

title: Broadening the Choice
description: New Year's Day is a time for optimism, however illusory; so as 1991 begins it may be no more than wishful thinking to see the faint possibility of averting war in the Middle East.

title: Food Notes
description: A California Freeze

title: Volunteers Catch Cavaliers At Finish
description: The Virginia quarterback, Shawn Moore, was anything but sharp tonight, and in the end, that might have cost the Cavaliers a victory in the Sugar Bowl.

title: For a Gloomy Outlook, Hungarians Top All
description: Last year, as democracy was making its comeback in this country of 10.5 million, polls showed a deep gloom descending over Hungary. Now, a year later, the mood has sunk even lower, making Hungarians the most pessimistic country of those surveyed in an international poll conducted by the Gallup Organization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The soldier told us we were traitors, pointed his machine gun at us, spat at us and let us through." -- Clearhos Bolomos, an Albanian who crossed the border into Greece. [ A3:5. ]

title: Do We Want to Be the Butchers of Baghdad?; Saudi Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: J. J. Gross and Kufeld Complete Their Merger
description: J. J. Gross & Company, New York, an advertising agency, has merged with the Kufeld Organization, an ad agency that specializes in real estate and hotel clients. The agencies have been sharing offices and have had an affiliate relationship for five years. The agency will be called Gross/Kufeld & Company, with Rony Herz, a Lintas alumnus, as its creative supervisor.

title: Exploring the Great Explorer
description: The Admiral was a well-built man of more than average stature, the face long, the cheeks somewhat high, his body neither fat nor lean. He had an aquiline nose and light-colored eyes; his complexion, too, was light and tending to bright red. In youth his hair was blond, but when he reached the age of thirty, it all turned white.

title: Restive Soviet Republic Yields to the Kremlin
description: Acting to defuse one of the Soviet Union's most explosive ethnic conflicts, Soviet Moldavia has agreed to comply with a Kremlin order to reconsider its law making Romanian the republic's official language.

title: Speedometers Can't Do a Thing to Make the Subways Go Faster
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street Paring Down To the Basics
description: Wall Street's painful shift from the takeover era to the hangover era is not over, but the securities industry last year finally started making the tough choices to transform itself into a smaller and healthier industry.

title: Economic Scene; Perestroika For Renters
description: WITH New York real estate in the dumps and unoccupied condos flooding the rental market, could the city's 43-year-old "emergency" rent controls be vulnerable?

title: Offerings Set a Record, but Fees Slip
