description: American corporations sought a record amount of cash from the public markets in 1990, but the volume of business did little to improve the financial condition of Wall Street. The collapse of the high-yield "junk bond" market and problems throughout the capital markets steepened a decline in fees paid to investment banks to their lowest levels since 1984.

title: Georgia Tech Coasts to Finish Without a Loss
description: The poll voters were waiting for the Orange Bowl before deciding which team would be unofficially declared No. 1 in college football, but Coach Bobby Ross was ready to make his opinion known. His Georgia Tech team soundly trounced Nebraska, 45-21, before a Florida Citrus Bowl record crowd of 72,328 fans this afternoon, and Ross said he believed the Yellow Jackets should be ranked the nation's best.

title: Big East Starting the Real Season
description: The basketball dates with St. Leo, New Hampshire and Winthrop are over for the boys in the Big East. They were not real dates, more like quick conversations to thank their inferior friends for easy victories.

title: A Question of Spelling Turns the French Testy
description: The French Academy, the secretive group of intellectual luminaries responsible for protecting the French language, has been riven by its worst dispute in decades -- a national backlash against its efforts to simplify the rules of French spelling.

title: Even Without a Title, Tyson Has Limelight
description: Despite a defeat that would turn out to be boxing's biggest story in 1990, Mike Tyson did not fade from the public consciousness as has many a vanquished champion.

title: Masters of Suspense, Saints Reach Playoffs
description: The thud brought a thump to Steve Walsh's heart.

title: Ring Out The Old Words
description: It's not a pretty list:

title: Top-Ranked Colorado Holds Off Notre Dame
description: At the end of New Year's Night, with an unofficial but desperately sought national college football championship waiting to be claimed, the University of Colorado Buffaloes did not stop Raghib Ismail. They merely survived him.

title: Computers, Having Learned to Talk, Are Becoming More Eloquent
description: After more than five decades of research, a growing number of commercial devices can replicate the human voice in words and even sentences.

title: Allen's Final Team Sad but Still Inspired
description: To his players at Long Beach State, George Allen was an idol who transformed their ragtag football team into a winner. His sudden death left them stunned but confident that his legacy of excellence would survive.

title: Bucks Want Robertson
description: The Milwaukee Bucks said yesterday they had reached agreement with Alvin Robertson on a contract revision that included extending his three-year contract through the 1997-98 season. The Bucks declined to divulge details. Robertson, acquired from the San Antonio Spurs in a trade May 28, 1989, had asked several times this season for improved terms.(AP)

title: Bridge
description: The concluding event of 1990 for New York bridge enthusiasts resulted in an upset victory. At the Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which ended on Sunday at the Vista International Hotel in the World Trade Center, an unheralded foursome from Long Island and New York City topped a strong field in the Flight A Swiss Team Championship. The winning team consisted of Jerome Ettlinger of Great Neck, Gary Paston of Syosset, Louis Lessinger of Plainview and Stephen Lucas of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Supercomputer Means Not Just Cray Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Kasparov Shows He's Better, but Just Barely
description: Gary Kasparov went into the World Championship Chess Match, which began Oct. 8 in New York and ended on Monday in Lyons, France, with three objectives: to defend his crown, to win the top prize of $1.7 million plus a trophy and to defeat Anatoly Karpov by a greater margin of victory than in their first four contests.

title: Strange Sandwiches
description: To The Living Section:

title: Eleanor S. Todd, 79, A Longtime Leader In New Jersey G.O.P.
description: Eleanor Schley Todd, a former Republican National Committeewoman, died on Monday at her home in Oldwick, N.J. She was 79 years old.

title: In Search of New York Steak? Ask Anywhere but New York
description: SOME aspects of New York mythology are easier to read at a distance. Take the famous New York steak. The term, according to Pat Cetta, who owns the Sparks Steak House in Manhattan, means one thing to people from out of town, but it means so many different things locally that it ends up meaning nothing.

title: Another Right-to-Die Case Poses New Questions
description: Christine Busalacchi was a junior in a suburban St. Louis high school when an automobile accident on May 29, 1987, left her in what her doctors described as a persistent vegetative state.

title: Church, a Survivor Of Famed 1871 Fire, Eludes Wrecker Ball
description: Holy Family Roman Catholic Church, which survived the great Chicago fire a century ago, has been saved from destruction once again, parishioners said today. They said a nationwide drive had raised $1 million needed for repairs.

title: Embassies Turning to Cultural Concerns
description: In the world of diplomacy, culture mostly ranks a distant third behind political and economic concerns. But some countries have begun to give new emphasis to promoting their cultural wares through their embassies in Washington.

title: Book Notes
description: More Bookstores

title: Wine Talk
description: IT'S the time of year when even normally prudent people lose all sense of caution and succumb to the urge to predict things. For futurologists, amateur and professional, who have had some measure of success in the past, it's a particularly dangerous time; they are expected to repeat their accomplishments yet again.

title: The Bully Pulpit, Half Empty
description: It turns out that George Bush wasn't kidding when he said back in 1988 that he had no appetite for "the vision thing." Just a few weeks shy of its second birthday, the Bush Presidency continues to confound anyone seeking tidy definitions, let alone a convincing agenda.

title: Reviews/Television; President and Mrs. Bush and an Amiable David Frost
description: "No price is too high to pay to stop Iraqi aggression," George Bush declares in "President and Mrs. Bush Talking With David Frost." The first half of tonight's hourlong program, at 8 on Channels 13 and 49 and at 10 on Channel 21, gives the President, who concedes that eloquence is not his strong point, an opportunity to make as coherent a case for his policy in the Persian Gulf as he has yet offered on television.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Arthur Lidov, 73, Artist and Inventor
description: Arthur Lidov, a painter, illustrator and inventor, died Sunday at his home in Poughquag, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As 1991 approached, the Rev. JESSE JACKSON was in no mood for predictions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On June 3, a plan for saving the world will be announced in Atlanta. Only one of more than 1,000 submissions will be announced as the winner of TED TURNER 's Turner Tomorrow Award. A manuscript that offers a method for saving the planet in the near future will be selected.

title: Do We Want to Be the Butchers of Baghdad?; Occupied or Annexed?
description: To the Editor:

description: Following is a list of estates and trusts whose gifts were received before the beginning of the current campaign: ESTATES Tillye B. Aaronson Anonymous (6) Sadie S. title: Eating Well
description: THE science of nutrition seems to change almost weekly as new research is published, written about and discussed. Despite the glut of new information about the role food plays in good health, there is plenty of misinformation that never seems to die. This is a good time to set the record straight on a few perennial errors. Taking huge doses of vitamin C prevents colds.

title: In Foreign Exchange, Stay Tuned to the Mark
description: The foreign exchange story to watch in 1991 is the strength of the German mark and how its European colleagues cope with it.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SALT cod, a staple of many Mediterranean countries and a popular ingredient in the cuisine of Languedoc and Provence in France, lends itself to all kinds of quick, inexpensive meals. It is sometimes added to bouillabaisse, boiled and served with potatoes and hollandaise sauce, poached and served with brown butter sauce and capers, or flaked and combined with a creole sauce.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Larsson Stuns Top-Seeded Becker Magnus Larsson earned the biggest victory of his career yesterday, toppling top-seeded Boris Becker in the first round of the Australian Hardcourt in Adelaide. The 20-year-old from Vaxjo, Sweden, ran past the three-time Wimbledon champion, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6. It was Becker's first loss in the opening round of a tournament since he was beaten by Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia in last year's French Open.

title: Future Buzzwords Rise From Ashes of the 80's
description: Forget "L.B.O.'s" and "M.&A.," those code words of the 80's takeover boom. These days, center stage belongs to those who talk of "inflection points," of "enhanced indexing," of "prepackaged bankruptcies" -- the investment buzzwords likely to dominate the intellectual landscape of Wall Street in the year ahead.

title: Newsstands On 5th Ave.? Battle Opens
description: Nine feet tall. Twelve feet wide. Six feet deep. Could it mean the end of Fifth Avenue as we know it?

title: Iraqis' Food Rations Are Reduced As Trade Embargo Cuts Supplies
description: After four months of total trade embargo, the shortages in the Government food rationing program that has helped Iraq sustain its defiance of the United Nations demand that it end its occupation of Kuwait.

title: More Phones On Airplanes
description: The Federal Communications Commission has awarded permanent licenses to four more companies to provide nationwide telephone service from airplanes.

title: Metro-North Restores Service After a Blaze
description: Train service resumed on two Metro-North lines early yesterday after a New Year's Eve fire at a warehouse in the Bronx had interrupted the service for seven hours.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: RICHARD KWARTLER is a passenger in a Port Washington (L.I.) radio taxi when he hears the driver of another cab talking to the dispatcher.

title: The Pop Life
description: Here's to the losers: Follow-ups to blockbusters didn't bust blocks, teen sensations weren't quite, and no rock album made it to No. 1 in 1990.

title: Impact of Easing of Credit May Be Most Vital '91 Issue
description: As bear markets go, this one so far has been much more alarming to the brokers than to the investors. But if the current recession ends up lasting longer, and going deeper, than is currently expected, that relatively happy outcome could change.

title: Economists Say New Jersey Can Weather the Recession
description: As the metropolitan region slips into recession, New Jersey appears better positioned to weather an economic slowdown than other states in the Northeast, economists say.

title: Washington Outlasts Fast-Finishing Iowa
description: If the game had the look of a rout by the time dusk arrived today, it resembled something distinctly different -- and clearly unpredictable -- by the time night finally settled. The University of Washington may have won today's 77th Rose Bowl from the University of Iowa, but by the end of the game, the victory was far less convincing than it appeared to have been after the start, or even after three quarters.

title: Foe of Drunken Driving Stricken but Undaunted
description: Joe Cyran, a 33-year-old New York State trooper, set out alone last summer on a cross-country bicycle trip from Los Angeles to Atlantic City to raise money for victims of drunken drivers. After 21 grueling days, his ride ended on June 16, just 38 miles from his goal, when he was nearly killed -- by a man the police accused of drunken driving. Mr. Cyran was hit so hard he was flung through the windshield and out a side door.

title: Harry Drackert, Dude Ranch Operator, 86
description: Harry Drackert, a former dude ranch operator whose ranches housed celebrities and others in search of quick divorces in Nevada in the 1940's to the 1960's, died Dec. 26 at St. Mary's Hospital in Reno. He was 86 years old and lived in Reno.

title: Correction
description: An article on Saturday about the deaths of Marshall S. Mundheim and Marie Mundheim in a fire in their home in New York City misstated Mrs. Mundheim's birthplace. She was born in Paris and raised in Venezuela.

title: Charles Johnson's Tale Of Slaving, Seafaring And Philosophizing
description: A freed slave, a roguish fellow, stows away on a ship in New Orleans to avoid creditors and a forced marriage, not realizing the clipper is bound for Africa to capture slaves. Put to work as a cook, he encounters a crew of misfits, a cruel and brilliant captain, legendary tribesmen, storms and rebellions, and is transformed by the journey.

title: Tributes and a Louisville Victory
description: The Fiesta Bowl, tainted by the controversy over Arizona voters' rejection of a state holiday in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was played without incident today after a local civil rights group staged a protest against the game.

title: To Fight in the Gulf?
description: In April 1954, President Eisenhower told the French he would launch air strikes against Vietnamese Communist troops surrounding French forces at Dien Bien Phu only if two key conditions were met: that U.S. intervention had to be part of a strong international coalition, and that Congress had to support the action.

title: Nairobi Street Children Play Games of Despair
description: As night fell, a group of girl prostitutes emerged from the squalid plastic and paper hutches they call home and ambled toward the luxury tourist hotel a few steps away.

title: Indians to Keep Jones
description: Doug Jones, who set a Cleveland Indians record with 43 saves last season, has agreed in principle to a one-year contract worth approximately $2 million. Willie Sanchez, Jones's agent, said yesterday that he expects the deal to be announced by the Indians later this week.

title: How Students Survive An Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; The First Amendment And Rebels It Protects
description: The First Amendment, Democracy and Romance By Steven H. Shiffrin 285 pages. Harvard University Press. One of the first surprises law students encounter in their course on constitutional law is that the First Amendment, as interpreted over the years by even the most liberal judges, doesn't give someone an absolute right to speak or write freely. Long before entering law school, most students have heard that free expression doesn't allow a person to shout "Fire!" in a crowded theater falsely. In addition to reasons of public safety, other limitations have been imposed by statutes and the courts, including laws against libel, invasion of privacy, blackmail and fraud.

title: Experts Were Wrong: Small Stocks Lagged
description: It was supposed to be the year of the small stock, with spectacular predictions by analysts and market watchers that 1990 would provide a bull market in stocks with small market capitalizations.

title: New York City's First Rest Stop For Children Taken From Abuse
description: Their names were Joseph, Anna and John S., two small brothers and their sister removed by caseworkers from an abusive home one recent night and taken to New York City's emergency care and placement office.

title: Medicaid and the Pregnant Cocaine User
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERTA GOLDMAN has been appointed executive director of the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity in New York. Ms. Goldman, most recently the director of development of the Big Apple Circus, will head the foundation established by Mr. Wiesel after the writer received the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize. The purpose of the foundation is to create forums for the discussion of moral and ethical issues.

title: It's Not Funny and I'm Sorry: Tacky Jokes of the Past, R.I.P.
description: IT was a big year for apologies.

title: Worthy Chocolate
description: To The Living Section:

title: People
description: * Josh Baran has been named general manager of Edleman Public Relations Worldwide, Los Angeles. * Michele Bruno was appointed public relations director at Walsh & Associates in Malverne, L.I.

title: Accounts
description: * Memorex Telex, to Long, Haymes & Carr Advertising, Winston-Salem, N.C., for its Network Systems Business group, with an undisclosed budget.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: 45 CREDIT UNIONS AND BANKS SHUT BY RHODE ISLAND
description: The new Governor of Rhode Island yesterday ordered the immediate closing of 45 state-chartered banks and credit unions until they have arranged Federal insurance for their deposits.

title: Gamble Sparkles as Rebuilt Celtics Sprint to Top
description: The Knicks will be back in Boston Garden tonight for the first time since that infamous Sunday afternoon last May when the aging Larry Bird, Kevin McHale and Robert Parish looked as beaten as they ever had since they donned the Celtic green more than a decade ago.

title: Speaker Foley's Broken Promise
description: After all the scandals and pious pledges of reform, members of the House and Senate return to work tomorrow more beholden than ever to the special interests that flood money into their campaigns. Consider last year's record-breaking contributions from political action committees, or PAC's, representing private industry and other interest groups. As of mid-October, House incumbents had received an astonishing $76 million from PAC's, compared to just $5 million for House challengers.

title: Providing Safety Measures for Skiers
description: Unlike other sports, skiing has its own body of law. Legislatures in 25 states have passed statutes outlining the risks of skiing, proper and safe conduct for skiers and, in some cases, the duties of ski-area operators to provide a safe environment for skiing.

title: A New Mayor Takes Oath, Ending Barry Era
description: Sharon Pratt Dixon, a former utility company executive who campaigned on a pledge to "clean house with a shovel," was sworn in today as Mayor of the nation's capital, bringing to an official end the tempestuous 12-year political reign of Marion S. Barry Jr.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday with an article about the New Jersey economy misstated the state's annual unemployment rate for 1990 in some editions. The rate, calculated for the first 11 months of the year, was 4.9 percent.

title: Penn Central Buys Insurance Group
description: The Penn Central Corporation completed the purchase of the American Financial Corporation's non-standard auto insurance group for about $335 million. The price is subject to change after a review of the group's pretax earnings for 1991-94, Penn Central said. The price could fall by up to $20 million or rise by up to $40 million.

title: About 10% of Credit Unions Are Privately Insured
description: The collapse of a private Rhode Island deposit insurance concern on Tuesday is a reminder that although Federal deposit insurance is taken as a given in banking in most parts of the country, it is not a given for credit unions. One out of every four Americans is a member of a credit union.

title: Why Can't a Toy Box Be Almost as Much Fun as the Toys?
description: TOYS, toys, toys. All through the house. These new Ninjas, Barts, dolls that do this and that, superheroes and dump trucks need a home of their own. A toy chest, in fact.

title: Canceled Condo Plan Had Flaws From Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Montana Approves a Plan to Kill Stray Bison
description: The state decided today that Montana game wardens and Federal park rangers would join hunters in killing any bison that strayed from their home in Yellowstone National Park this winter.

title: 'Godfather' Running A Brisk Business, But a Child Prevails
description: Francis Ford Coppola's long-awaited "The Godfather Part III" is off to an impressive start at the box office, thanks in part to a record-breaking opening day performance on Christmas, but the sleeper comedy "Home Alone" elbowed aside all competitors to emerge as the box-office champion for the holiday season.

title: The Keating Five and the Senate Six
description: The Senate Ethics Committee will call the Keating Five to the witness stand this week and start to wrap up hearings about the behavior of five Senators who jumped through hoops for one big political giver. Soon the spotlight will be not on Senators named Cranston, DeConcini, Riegle, McCain and Glenn but on the bipartisan Ethics Committee and the Senate itself.

title: Converted A-Plant Is Tested
description: The Zimmer power plant in Moscow, Ohio, originally planned as a nuclear reactor but abandoned in 1984 because of questions about the quality of construction, began life on Tuesday as a coal-fired electric plant.

title: Dehere Gets 37 Points As Seton Hall Wins
description: Terry Dehere scored a career-high 37 points tonight to lead Seton Hall to a 97-92 victory over Providence at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: In the U.S. Last Year, the Heat Was On
description: Mild winter weather made 1990 the seventh warmest year on record in the United States. It might have been the warmest ever, meteorologists said, had not a December chill in the Midwest and the West offset record high temperatures in the East.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday headed "Nasdaq's Performance in 1990" misidentified the second-mostactive issue. It was Telefonos de Mexico, not Telematics International.

title: Want a Marble Cadillac? You'll Really Save on Gas
description: TELEPHONES, vacuum cleaners, clocks and other everyday objects that proliferated in the United States in the boom years after World War II have long since achieved status. But only a small number have been memorialized in marble.

title: Detailing the Bolshevik Enormity
description: The Russian Revolution By Richard Pipes 944 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: Slight Rent Dip No Reason to End Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: After winning the World Championship Chess Match on Monday, GARY KASPAROV announced yesterday that he would donate the trophy, worth about $1 million, to a charity for Armenians left homeless after the 1988 earthquake.

title: Lightening Up Salvation Army
description: The Salvation Army is doing its first image campaign in several years. The ads, running in three New York daily newspapers, portray the charity's volunteers as latter-day Guys and Dolls

title: Yanks and Witt Agree To $8 Million Contract
description: On the day the owners transferred $120 million in collusion damages to money-market accounts in two banks in Texas, Mike Witt, one of the players colluded against in 1987, gained his personal benefits yesterday.

title: In College Football Ratings, No. 1 Is Split 3 Ways
description: Nobody threw a pass, ran back a punt or scored a touchdown in college football yesterday. But in the absence of a playoff tournament to choose a national champion on the field, Colorado, Georgia Tech and Miami were awarded what amounts to perpetual debating rights to the unofficial 1990 national championship.

title: Control Data Sells A Chip Factory
description: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said it had purchased an advanced semiconductor manufacturing plant from the Control Data Corporation for $14.7 million.

title: Some Say Using Pension Change Is Gamble Now
description: To pay for half the settlement reached yesterday with unions representing 150,000 city workers, the Dinkins administration proposed raising its forecast of earnings from city pension funds to one of the highest levels used by any municipal government.

title: Cost Is $233 Million
description: The Dinkins administration and two large municipal unions announced a tentative labor agreement yesterday that would provide 150,000 city workers with a wage and benefit increase of 5 percent over 15 months, less than city teachers are to receive but more than some fiscal experts say the city should pay.

title: Bridge
description: For every thousand players who compete in local clubs and tournaments there is a handful willing to cross the Atlantic and venture into competitive play in the Old World. The political opening up of Eastern Europe has focused attention on new bridge destinations that will have particular appeal in the coming months.

title: Navy Urges Aid to Aircraft's Makers
description: The Navy will urge Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to proceed with the troubled A-12 attack aircraft program by absorbing some of the contractors' cost overruns and buying fewer planes over a longer period, Pentagon officials said today.

title: How Bad Are Knicks? MacLeod Finds Out
description: The Knicks have endured many embarrassing moments at Boston Garden. Tonight's effort ranks among their most pathetic.

title: For Muscovites And Gothamites, Shared Insights
description: It's a one-party town. Party bosses dictated the choice of the City Council leader. Just once in his five-year tenure was legislation passed that he had strongly opposed personally -- a human-rights bill -- and only after he deigned to allow a vote. The Council's elected president is largely a figurehead.

title: Hills Is Closing 28 of 214 Stores
description: The struggling discount retailer Hills Department Stores Inc. said today that it would close 28 of its 214 stores.

title: Joseph Sharkey, 97, Former Head Of New York City Council, Is Dead
description: Joseph T. Sharkey, who was prominent in Brooklyn Democratic politics for more than three decades and president of the New York City Council from 1949 to 1951, died on Tuesday at the St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 97 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Stocks Retreat Broadly As Dow Falls by 23.02
description: Stocks sagged broadly yesterday on the first trading session of the new year, despite a jump in bond prices, a big decline in crude oil prices and widespread feeling that the Fed will continue to cut interest rates.

title: Packaging Becomes Critical In Luring Wary Consumers
description: IN a recent marketing campaign for Ralston Purina's new Breakfast on the Run, a single-serving box of cereal that includes a bowl, a spoon and a container of shelf-stable milk, the packages were designed to look like frames from an illustrated commercial. One features a woman coming out of the elevator of the building where she works, pouring milk into a bowl of Corn Chex.

title: Some of Those Closed May Not Get Insurance
description: Federal regulators said today that many of the 35 credit unions and 10 banks and investment companies that were closed on Tuesday in Rhode Island were too weak to be eligible for Federal deposit insurance.

title: Device That Opens Clogged Arteries Gets a Failing Grade in a New Study
description: A device that was hailed as a revolutionary way to open clogged coronary arteries can actually make matters worse, a new study has found.

title: Aluminum Furniture Is Lighter Than It Looks
description: THE aluminum furniture that Craig Hodgetts and Ming Fung designed for the Architects' Art Show at the Gallery of Functional Art in Santa Monica, Calif., just looks heavy. "It is actually very light," Mr. Hodgetts said of their assemblage of "Airframe" tables, chairs, shelves and screens.

title: The Home of 1991: What's New Is Old
description: "WE made no pretense of being innovative," the architect Deborah Berke said of "The New American Home for 1991." "There are no talking vacuum cleaners."

title: Ex-Regulator Denies Pressure by Senators in Lincoln Savings Case
description: After a two-week recess the Senate Ethics Committee resumed hearings today into five Senators' ties to Charles H. Keating Jr., with a former Federal banking regulator denying that the lawmakers had pressured her to go easy on Mr. Keating's savings and loan institution.

title: Ex-Congressman Halts Appeal and Enters Jail
description: Donald E. Lukens gave up his appeal today and began serving a 30-day jail term for having sexual relations with a teen-age girl in 1988, when he was a Congressman.

title: Astronomers' New Data Jolt Vital Part of Big Bang Theory
description: A critical element of the widely accepted Big Bang theory about the origin and evolution of the universe is being discarded by some of its staunchest advocates, throwing the field of cosmology into turmoil.

title: In Hot Spots Like Gulf, He's Baker's Cool Hand
description: "Perhaps you should leave through the back door," Robert M. Kimmitt suggested after he scanned the note his secretary had slipped him. The State Department's third-ranking official had inadvertently left a European ambassador waiting outside his office for nearly half an hour and, a stickler for protocol, he did not want to appear to be favoring a journalist over an ambassador.

title: What of Discrimination in Women's Colleges?
description: To the Editor:

title: Access Is Sought To Secret Files In New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission asked the State Supreme Court today for access to secret state grand jury testimony about purported abuses in the 1985 gubernatorial election.

title: Eduard in the Wilderness
description: The stunning resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze just prior to Christmas clearly marked the end of the reformist period of Mikahil Gorbachev's five-year reign. Yet until yesterday little light has been shed on the reasons underlying the Foreign Minister's renunciation of his partnership with Mr. Gorbachev.

title: A.T.& T. Rate Cuts
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had reduced its interstate and international long-distance rates by $83.4 million a year as of Tuesday. The reduction is $49.5 million more than A.T.& T. predicted in a filing on Dec. 18 with the Federal Communications Commission. The difference reflects an F.C.C. order deferring proposed increases in the fees A.T.& T. would be assessed this year for federally managed programs that subsidize local phone companies in areas that are expensive to serve or that have many low-income subscribers.

title: Declare War, Conditionally
description: When President Bush consults with Congressional leaders today on the Persian Gulf crisis, he reportedly will seek to devise a way to involve Congress without restricting his options or authority as Commander in Chief. Fortunately, just such a mechanism exists: a conditional declaration of war authorizing the President to take military steps if certain specified conditions are met.

title: Small Westchester Hospital Looks to Big Center to Save It
description: When John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, came to St. Agnes Hospital here in November, it was not a typical visit to comfort the sick. It was the hospital itself that was ailing, and he prescribed harsh medicine.

title: Iraqis in Kuwait Reported to Step Up Defenses
description: Less than two weeks before a United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, American military commanders in Saudi Arabia said today that Iraq showed no sign of leaving the emirate. They said Iraqi forces stationed in Kuwait were stepping up their defenses in preparation for a possible fight against American-led troops.

title: Where Is Congress on the Gulf?
description: Will Congress debate and vote on President Bush's war policy in the Persian Gulf? Will Mr. Bush ask it to? These questions belong at the top of the agenda when Congressional leaders meet with the President today.

title: Dineen Hospitalized
description: Kevin Dineen, the right wing and third-leading scorer on the Hartford Whalers, was hospitalized yesterday with an inflammation of the lower intestine that was diagnosed as a condition related to Crohn's disease, a digestive disorder.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misidentified the wife of Claus von Bulow, whom he was acquitted of having tried to kill, and misidentified her son. She is Martha (Sunny) C. Auersperg von Bulow; the son is Alexander von Auersperg.

title: Pardoning Mass Murder in Argentina
description: For no good reason, President Carlos Menem of Argentina has trashed his country's finest achievement of the last 60 years. Previous civilian authorities from President Raul Alfonsin on back courageously re-established the vital constitutional principle that all citizens, military officers included, are accountable to the rule of law. Now, in a country still prone to coup attempts, the tradition of military impunity has been restored.

title: O.K., Flabby Press Corps, 32 Pushups for Uncle Sam
description: Worried that too many reporters are too far out of shape to cover a war, Pentagon officials have imposed a physical fitness test on journalists who wish to be sent out with American troops if there is battle with Iraq.

title: Dr. Walter Modell, 83; Taught Pharmacology
description: Dr. Walter Modell, a retired professor of pharmacology at Cornell University Medical School and an editor of professional journals in the field, died on Dec. 23 at Heritage-Shadyside Nursing Home in Pittsburgh. He was 83 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: No Zapata Bankruptcy
description: The Zapata Corporation, an energy and fishing company founded nearly three decades ago by President Bush, avoided a bankruptcy filing today by successfully buying back a series of debt securities at a steep discount. Under an agreement Zapata reached with banks in August, the company had to retire 66.7 percent of these securities as part of a broader debt restructuring that would help insure its long-term survival. The deadline for the sale had been Friday, but Zapata board members voted to extend it to 4 P.M. Saturday, central standard time.

title: Kenneth Youel, 89, Public Relations Aide
description: Kenneth Youel, a public relations consultant who was a former president of the Public Relations Society of America, died Sunday at his home in Earlysville, Va. He was 89 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1982, MERCEDES ELLINGTON founded Dancellington for tap dancers. Now the company will have its first Manhattan series, a four-day run beginning Jan. 10 at Symphony Space.

title: Henrietta Isaacson Bicks; Lawyer, 89
description: Henrietta Isaacson Bicks, a retired lawyer, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89 years old.

title: Rangers Foil Gretzky, Sweep Past the Kings
description: The game was more full of grinding than grace, the emphasis for the Rangers more on disruption than execution. As such, it was a game for the checkers and consequently not one for the ages.

title: Bechtel Is Offering 3-Day Weekends
description: The Bechtel Group engineering concern is promising workers 26 three-day weekends a year to attract engineering talent to its San Francisco offices. The deal means workers will come to work nine days every two weeks instead of 10. All 4,000 Bechtel employees in the San Francisco area are eligible for the new schedule.

title: Eastern Job Recall
description: Eastern Airlines says it will recall 60 pilots who went on strike in 1989, but union officials are criticizing the move because it will bring top-ranking pilots back to lower positions.

title: Notorious Rapist Gets 2-Year Term for Theft
description: Lawrence Singleton, an infamous California rapist, was sentenced today to two years in prison for shoplifting a $3 hat and then lying to the police about his identity.

title: NATO Sending Jets to the Turks In Gulf Face-Off
description: NATO announced today that it would send three squadrons of German, Italian and Belgian jet fighters to Turkey to strengthen its border with Iraq in case a war breaks out. The move was strenuously endorsed by the United States.

title: Boat Luxury Tax Drives an Industry Aground
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds Unfair Procedure in Sales of S.& L.'s in 1988
description: The 1988 sales by Federal regulators of failed savings and loan institutions were flawed by an unfair competitive process, according to a new study ordered by Congress.

title: The White House Agrees: It's a Recession
description: The White House today acknowledged for the first time that the country is in a recession, a judgment reached weeks, if not months, ago by most private economists.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: KEEPING up with household maintenance can be daunting. By scheduling maintenance tasks according to the season, homeowners can perform repairs when weather conditions are most suitable and when results will be of greatest benefit. Here is a month-by-month guide for routine tasks.

title: Bush Picks 3 New Directors of Legal Services
description: President Bush today chose three new members and reappointed eight others to the board of the troubled Legal Services Corporation, the federally financed legal service for the poor.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Small Quakes Jar Nevada
description: At least two dozen earthquakes shook Nevada's capital today, causing minor damage and temporarily disrupting telephone service in some areas. No injuries were reported in the series of quakes that began just after 4 A.M. and continued for hours. The largest tremor registered 4.5 on the Richter scale, said Russ Needham, a geophysicist at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo.

title: Mackintosh's Small-Scale Big Hit
description: Cameron Mackintosh, Britain's leading producer of the mega-musical, has an unexpected hit in a small-scale production that leaves its audience shouting for "Moe."

title: News Workers Sit In at Office and Are Arrested
description: Concerned that the public could be forgetting them, 10 striking Daily News reporters and artists descended on the paper's empty Brooklyn news bureau yesterday morning, pushed a desk against the door as a makeshift barricade and with a box of doughnuts as provisions announced a campaign of civil disobedience.

title: Jordan's Muslim Militants Concern the Israelis
description: Jordan has mobilized its armed forces and reorganized its Government to include Muslim fundamentalists, bringing expressions of concern today from Israeli Government officials and military strategists.

title: Germany Slow to Embrace Its Eastern Artists
description: The velvety golden light of a late autumn afternoon slants through the window wall of Bernhard Heisig's spacious studio. Dust motes float lazily through sun and shadow among easels, canvases and a coal-scuttle helmet on a hat stand, forming occasional shapes and patterns like some torpid, pointillistic kaleidoscope.

title: Small Business Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrants From China Pay Dearly To Be Slaves
description: Hundreds of illegal Chinese immigrants pay tens of thousands of dollars to become modern-day indentured servants in the New York City area in return for counterfeit identification papers and passage to the United States, law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: John T. O'Hagan, 65, Fire Chief And Fire Commissioner in the 70's
description: John T. O'Hagan, who served simultaneously as chief of the New York City Fire Department and as Fire Commissioner in the mid-70's, died yesterday at his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 65 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Covenant Mutual, Hartford, an insurance and financial services company, has acquired a majority interest in Conning & Co., Hartford, an insurance company. Terms were not disclosed. * Family Weight Loss Centers Inc., Milwaukee, and Medical Nutrition Inc., Englewood, N.J., a weight loss company, have merged in a deal worth about $9 million. * Fund American Cos., Purchase, N.Y., a financial services company, completed the sale of its principal subsidiary, Fireman's Fund Insurance Co., to Allianz of America Inc., a subsidiary of Allianz A.G. Holding, Munich, for $3.1 billion. * B. F. Goodrich Co., Akron, Ohio, a plastics, specialty chemicals and aerospace company, has completed the acquisition of various business units of the Hercules Aircraft and Electronics Group, for $169 million. * Monarch Capital Corp., Springfield, Mass., an insurance holding company, said its Monarch Life Insurance Co. unit had closed a reinsurance agreement with the life insurance companies of Merrill Lynch & Co. Monarch said it had received an initial commission of $76.3 million and expects additional payments of an undisclosed amount. * National Convenience Stores Inc., Houston, said BP Oil Co. would purchase 28 of its convenience stores in the West Palm Beach, Fla., area, for undisclosed terms. * Phillips 66 Propane Company, Bartlesville, Okla., said it had acquired two St. Louis-area businesses for undisclosed terms. The company, a unit of the Phillips Petroleum Company, said its acquisition of Fallon Gas Service Inc. and the Home Service Propane Company would allow it to use the existing distribution networks of those companies to begin marketing propane as a fleet motor fuel. * Telus Corp. said it had sold its entire holdings in Novatel Communications Ltd. to the Alberta provincal government. Telus said it would realize net proceeds of $159.4 million (Canadian) for an estimated net gain of $20.4 million (Canadian). * Weeks Petroleum Ltd. said it had rejected the offer by Nycal Corp. to buy Weeks's share of the Bass Straits Royalty for about $163 million. Goodrich, B. F.British Petroleum+ (BP Oil)Alberta Government Telephones+ (Novatel Communiations)

title: Giants Take It Easy But Toughen Mentally
description: After two days at leisure, the Giants returned to work today, and for a pro football team preparing for the playoffs they did relatively little work with a football.

title: Arafat Eases Stand on Kuwait-Palestine Link
description: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, indicated tonight that neither he nor President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is insisting that the Palestinian problem be solved before Iraqi troops get out of Kuwait.

title: Events: Ceramics, Tapestry and Weaving
description: Wheel Thrown and Hand Built Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street (West Fourth Street); (212) 242-4106.

title: Money-Fund Yields Rise
description: For the week ended yesterday, yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were up for the first time in six weeks, as a result of year-end pressures on short-term interest rates.

title: Bankruptcy Court a Threat To Buyout Profits of the 80's
description: The excesses of the takeover years may be coming back to haunt Wall Street and investors in a new way: Firms and stockholders that profited from buyouts that subsequently failed could be forced to give their money back.

title: Board Ouster Disputed At Hollywood Park
description: A dissident shareholder in the Hollywood Park Operating Company said today that he had won a proxy fight to oust the company's board, but the race track concern said his claim was premature.

title: Happy Ending for Ga. Tech
description: There were no bed checks and no curfews Tuesday night, so the Georgia Tech football players got a chance to stay up past midnight after their 45-21 Florida Citrus Bowl rout of Nebraska to see if their dream of winning a national championship might come true.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "All I've got is the money in the cash registers. I can't pay my employees. I can't pay my vendors. I can't run a business." -- Joseph Dube, a Rhode Island businessman whose bank account was frozen in the state's bank emergency. [ A1:3. ]

title: It Wasn't a Good Year for Dividends
description: Big banks caught the most attention for slashing dividends last year, but they were not alone.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE coming of the New Year hits many children with an emotional thud as the excitement and fantasy of the holidays are replaced by the mundane reality of arithmetic tests and tuna casserole. For some, it is a time of great stress as they try to make sense of all they have done and felt over the past few months.

title: New Senator From California Is Named
description: In a characteristically pragmatic move, Pete Wilson today chose a state Senator noted for his fund-raising abilities to succeed him in the United States Senate when he is sworn in as Governor of California next Monday.

title: 3 Big Labor Contracts Down, 130 to Go for New York City
description: Just as the 5.5 percent raise for New York City teachers a few months ago set a hard precedent for the Civil Service and teamster negotiations resolved yesterday, so the new settlements set a standard for the remaining bargaining.

title: C.D. Yields Post Another Weekly Fall
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts declined for the week ended yesterday for the 11th consecutive weekly drop.

title: Arkansas Romps Past Rice to Go 12-1
description: Todd Day scored 21 points to lead four Arkansas players in double figures as the No. 2-ranked Razorbacks took advantage of error-prone Rice for an 86-62 victory tonight.

title: Oracle Returns To Profitability
description: The Oracle Corporation returned to profitability in its second fiscal quarter after reporting its first quarterly loss ever in the previous period. Based in Redwood City, Calif., Oracle is a leading producer of data base management software.

title: A Burglar's Worst Nightmare Wakes Up a Pair of Officers
description: A would-be thief picked the wrong place to break into -- an apartment shared by two police officers, who woke up and arrested the man when he broke down their door, the authorities said.

title: New Principal Takes the Reins At Bronx School
description: After months of politicking and protest, a new principal arrived yesterday at Public School 161 in the South Bronx. Less than a fifth of the students showed up to greet her.

title: Retarded Woman at Center of Furor Has Baby
description: A profoundly retarded woman whose pregnancy has prompted several investigations of the state school where she lives gave birth to a baby boy on Tuesday.

title: Islanders' 3-Goal Lead Isn't Enough
description: The Islanders began with a boom, then went bust.

title: Treasury Securities Rise Sharply
description: A big drop in commodity prices and a flurry of negative economic reports were well received in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose sharply and interest rates fell.

title: A 'Prime Time' Journey On the Trail of Carlos
description: Been losing sleep over what Carlos, the international terrorist also known as the Jackal, is up to these days? On "Prime Time Live," tonight at 10, the ABC correspondent Pierre Salinger declares that since December 1975, when Carlos and a band of Palestinians shot their way into a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna and took the oil ministers hostage, his whereabouts has been one of the world's biggest mysteries. Well, if Mr. Salinger says so.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rodman Enjoys a Career Game

title: Time to Change U.S. Policy in Somalia
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Banks Cut Prime By 1/2 Point
description: The nation's largest banks, almost in lockstep, lowered their prime lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent. It was their first drop in nearly a year and reflects efforts by the Federal Reserve Board to push interest rates lower.

title: Is Home Where the TV Set Is?
description: MINIATURE television sets are most plentiful at ball games, I am told, their antennas sprouting from the stands. After a particularly dramatic touchdown or double play, heads bend toward them as if in benediction. The screens are tuned not to favorite soap operas and sitcoms but to the very same game being played on the field. Such a peculiar combination of public gathering and private viewing, of an experience mixed with the televised image of it, is one consequence of the successful new crop of television sets the size of shirt pockets.

title: Bank Freeze in Rhode Island Puts Pressure on Depositors
description: It was payday today at the Wickford Gourmet. But Joseph Dube could not write checks to his 25 employees because the Davisville Credit Union, where he has his account, has been closed indefinitely by Rhode Island's new Governor as part of a "bank emergency."

title: Not a New Tub: A New-Looking Tub
description: WITH age and use, bathtubs and sinks can chip and become stained. One solution is to have everything removed and install new fixtures and tiles. An alternative is porcelain reglazing, a cleaning and spraying process.

title: German Drug Makers Refuse To Lower Prices in the East
description: Major drug companies in western Germany are refusing to ship their products to the eastern part of the country because of a clause in the German reunification treaty that says that as of the new year, their products must be sold there for 45 percent of the prices in the western part of the country.

title: Oil and Gas Exploration Will Increase
description: The energy industry expects to increase worldwide spending to find and produce oil and natural gas by nearly 14 percent this year, but a majority of the money will go to projects outside the United States and its coastal waters, according to an annual survey by Salomon Brothers.

title: INSIDE
description: Large Settlement In Pension Case The United Steelworkers of America has won a $415 million settlement from the Continental Can Company, which it accused of laying off workers just before they qualified for pension benefits. A Federal judge in Newark ruled in favor of the union and ordered the two sides to settle. Page D1. New Senator for California As his successor in the United States Senate, Governor-elect Pete Wilson chose State Senator John F. Seymour, a moderate Republican. Page A12. Warm, but Not Warmest Last year was the nation's seventh warmest, with an average temperature of 53.94 degrees. The record still belongs to 1934, at 54.67. Page A18.

title: Agreement in Boston Ends 13-Year Case Over Housing Bias
description: Blacks and other minority members in this city of ethnic enclaves would have increased access to white neighborhoods and $500 million in new Federal housing assistance under a tentative agreement ending a long legal fight against the City of Boston and the Federal Government.

title: A Treasure of Kitchen Hand-Me-Downs
description: SHOPS devoted to vintage clothing, 50's furniture, used books or costume jewelry are easy to find. But a shrine to second-hand pots and pans? Meet Judy Kaminsky, the proprietor of Cookin' in San Francisco; it may be the only shop dedicated to used cookware.

title: Vehicle Sales Decline by 19.1% in Midmonth
description: Sales of cars and trucks made in the United States fell by 19.1 percent in mid-December, as demand for vehicles sank to the lowest level since 1982.

title: MCA Rebuts Lujan on Japanese Contract
description: Two MCA board members accused Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. today of trying to coerce the company into giving the Government a subsidiary company that handles the food and hotel concessions at Yosemite National Park.

title: Soul Searching
description: Here are three wise men:

title: U.S. Chips' Gain Is Japan's Loss
description: For the first time in more than a decade, American semiconductor companies gained market share in 1990 at the expense of their Japanese competitors, a market research company reported today.

title: Living for Folk Art, and in It, Too
description: BEFORE he created his splendiferous garden of painted deer antlers, Carl Norton's life was as rocky as a river rapid. His son Med had been killed by lightning at the age of 15. The vigor not sapped by the coal miner's black-lung disease and failing eyesight were nearly done in by a heart attack.

title: Seeking Child Care in Middle of Night
description: FOR 12 years, Diane Allen, who is co-anchor of the 11 P.M. news at WCAU-TV in Philadelphia, has returned home from work around 1 A.M. and awakened each of her children, Sara and Leeds, to say hello. They often go downstairs to chat about their day over cups of hot chocolate.

title: China's Premier Talks Of Economic Distress
description: Prime Minister Li Peng acknowleged in a speech made public today that the Chinese economy faced severe difficulties, and he called for greater restructuring of prices and enterprises and the elimination of export subsidies.

title: People
description: * Leland L. Walton Jr. has been appointed senior vice president of client and strategic services at Lewis & Gace, New York, a health-care agency. Steve Barrett was named vice president, Julie Nies was promoted to senior vice president and director of client services and Fran Dyller was appointed senior vice president and creative director. * Transportation Displays Inc., New York, promoted Eric Solomon to senior vice president and national sales manager. * Patricia E. Vance has been promoted to vice president of Ancillary Marketing and Sales, a unit of ABC Distribution Co. * Jeff Weiner has been appointed director of corporate development at

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Dec. 24 about The Listener, a weekly television, radio and literary journal in London, referred incorrectly to the status of broadcast legislation in Parliament. It is not pending; it was passed in November, and its main provisions will go into effect between this year and 1993.

title: Entrepreneur Building Car Engine Franchises
description: With sales of new cars lagging, Joseph A. Robinson, a Philadelphia entrepreneur, hopes that drivers will turn increasingly to repair shops to keep their existing vehicles rolling.

title: Redskins Shuffle Roster
description: The Washington Redskins placed Eric Williams, the leading tackler on their defensive line, on the injured reserve list yesterday and re-signed a backup cornerback and special teams player, Sidney Johnson, who had been waived last week.

title: Bus Companies For the Disabled Agree to a Pact
description: After a day of havoc at many preschool programs, the New York City Board of Education reached a contract agreement late yesterday afternoon with bus companies that transport thousands of disabled preschool children to private schools.

title: Joseph Spengler, 88, Economics Professor At Duke University
description: Joseph J. Spengler, the James B. Duke Professor Emeritus of Economics at Duke University, died yesterday at a nursing home in Durham. He was 88 years old and lived in Durham, N.C.

title: Key Rates
Tartikoff Is Injured In Car Crash
description: Brandon Tartikoff, who has headed NBC 's entertainment division for 11 years, and his daughter were seriously injured on Tuesday in an automobile accident near Lake Tahoe in Nevada.

title: Dinkins Favors Proposal to Ban Assault Rifles
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins today will propose a ban on the sale of assault weapons in New York City and endorse an array of Federal, state and city legislation that would make it harder to buy, own and use weapons, his aides said yesterday.

title: The Look Is Lavish, But Not The Price
description: FOR fancy curtains, forget about silk or velvet. The trick is to buy lots of inexpensive sheer fabric and drape it with great abandon around the windows. The glamour lies in the soft translucence and abundance of fabric.

title: Bourque and Neely Win Starting All-Star Spots
description: Ray Bourque and Cam Neely, Boston Bruin teammates who led the fan balloting throughout the voting period, won starting spots yesterday on the Wales Conference team for the 42d National Hockey League All-Star Game, to be played Jan. 19 in Chicago.

title: St. Martin's to Miss Big Convention
description: In a break with publishing tradition, St. Martin's Press said yesterday that it and its subsidiary Tor Books would not exhibit at the American Booksellers Association convention in New York in June because of the high cost of doing so.

title: Bears' Carrier An Instant Success
description: Mark Carrier displayed an off-field grace that matched his striking on-field pose during his rookie season as a safety for the Chicago Bears. Everywhere Carrier traveled throughout the National Football League this season, he left a memorable mark on opposing receivers and coaches who marveled at his intelligence, quickness and hard hits.

title: Irving M. Johnson, Who Wrote of Trips At Sea, Is Dead at 85
description: Irving McClure Johnson, a yachtsman whose many years of adventures aboard sailing ships were chronicled in books and televison films, died yesterday at the Meadowood Nursing Home in Hadley, Mass. He was 85 years old and lived in Hadley.

title: Merrick Says 'Oh, Kay!' Is Closing for a Tour
description: David Merrick announced yesterday that he would close the musical "Oh, Kay!" at the Richard Rodgers Theater on Sunday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: P. D. JAMES is now a baroness, the only life peer to be named in the Queen's New Year's honors list made public by Buckingham Palace on New Year's Eve. The title means that Mrs. James, the mystery writer whose initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy, may sit in the House of Lords.

title: Nature Begins Winter's Sleep And All's Well
description: I MAY not actually take a vacation this month, but the thought that my garden would get along perfectly well without me if I did is comforting.

title: New Drug Approved to Treat AIDS Anemia
description: To the acclaim of AIDS researchers and advocates for people with AIDS, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a new drug to treat anemia in people with AIDS.

title: This House Sounds Just Right
description: WHEN George Izenour built his waterfront home in this village a few miles east of New Haven, he ended each day by shooting off a gun in the music room. By measuring the reverberation time, he was able to determine how much absorption he was adding to the room as he went along. "It was a lot of trouble," he said wryly.

title: Enter My Parlor! Do Buy Something
description: THE five blocks between 69th Street and 74th Street on Lexington Avenue have become so encrusted with antique shops over the last few years that they look as if they resulted from special zoning.

title: Grateful Immigrants Donate to the Neediest
description: Eric W. Zielenziger, a Holocaust survivor who lives in Great Neck, L.I., recently sent $44 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund -- one dollar for every year he has been in America.

title: Athens Is Alarmed Over Refugees From Albania
description: Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis said today that an exodus of Albanians to Greece had taken on the dimensions of a "national disaster" and declared a state of emergency in the frontier region.

title: Compromise Is Seen
description: The White House today effectively dropped its insistence that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d before Jan. 3. And it signaled Baghdad that if Iraq offered a compromise date before Jan. 12, Washington would most likely accept it.

title: Wright House Plan Is Being Reweighed
description: The defeat of New York State's environmental bond act has forced the owners of a house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright to rethink a preservation plan for the historic landmark.

title: India's Top Censor Says Films Must Be Cleaner
description: From an apartment building that overlooks the rain-swept Arabian Sea, a former police official who has battled brigands in real life has taken on what he regards as the villains of reel life -- India's movie moguls who flood their films with sex and violence.

title: Long Island Expressway to Get a Fourth Lane, for Ride Sharers
description: After years of debate, the congested Long Island Expressway is going to have new lanes added to it, but at a price for motorists devoted to their solitary commutes. Cars with just one person in them will be barred from the new lanes.

title: State of the State of the Union
description: It all started with Edmund Burke's 1769 essay on the "present state of the nation"; our Constitution-writers then required that the President report to the Congress information of the "state of the Union" along with "such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient."

title: Aikman Has Surgery
description: Troy Aikman, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, underwent double surgery yesterday to remove bone chips in his right elbow and repair his separated right shoulder.

title: Pilot Evacuates 14 U.N. Aides From Somalia
description: About noon on Tuesday as the bazooka fire and the wham of bullets hitting cars intensified, James W. F. Wallace 4th, a United Nations pilot, decided he had to make a break for the airport to evacuate 14 United Nations officials out of the Somali capital, Mogadishu.

title: Debate Over 'Alice' Set: Too Nouveau Riche?
description: WOODY ALLEN'S new film, "Alice," has prompted a small but intense debate among some architects and designers: Would a Park Avenue matron married to an old-money family really have an apartment with glass block walls, white furniture and ebony and stainless steel trim everywhere? Isn't this a bit too "new," even if it has been ripened by Art Deco touches, antiques and the pamper-me pale peach walls?

title: The Great Debate: Colorado Makes Its Case
description: Colorado's imperfect 13-game season, saved by a fifth-down touchdown in Columbia, Mo., and climaxed by a penalty marker in the final 43 seconds of the 10-9 Orange Bowl victory over Notre Dame on Tuesday night, was finally over.

title: Dancing 2 Roles and Making Mother Happy
description: Leonid Kozlov will be making history at the New York City Ballet when he dances two lead roles in "The Nutcracker" tonight at the New York State Theater. In the first act, he will play Herr Drosselmeyer, the mysterious old man whose gift of a nutcracker sets the holiday ballet in motion. In the second act, Mr. Kozlov will dance the handsome cavalier who squires the Sugar Plum Fairy through some difficult classical ballet partnering. And perhaps no one will be watching this feat with keener interest than Valentina Ivanovna Kozlova, Mr. Kozlov's 76-year-old mother, who lives in Moscow and has not seen her son dance ballet since he defected in 1979.

title: In Child Psychiatrist Shortage, Young Must Wait
description: When Dr. Rose Tharakan, a pediatrician, encounters a child with serious psychological problems in her practice in Sturbridge, Mass., she calls in Dr. Zamir Nestelbaum, a psychiatrist from the nearby town of Southbridge.

title: Personal Health
description: By the age of 60 one woman in three in this country has had a hysterectomy. This year some 650,000 women, most of them between the ages of 35 and 45, will have their uteruses surgically removed, making hysterectomy the second-most common operation after Caesarean sections in American women. Nearly a third of the women will also have their ovaries removed in a "while-you're-at-it" procedure done, in theory at least, to reduce their risk of cancer.

title: After Rout, Rough Play Has Miami Defensive
description: The University of Miami turned in the most awesome performance in Cotton Bowl history on New Year's Day, but this morning the Hurricanes woke up to criticism over the intimidating tactics they used to rout Texas, 46-3.

title: Purchasers' Index Dropped To 8-Year Low in December
description: With new orders dropping and production falling, the nation's manufacturing economy declined again in December, to its lowest point since the recession of 1982, a survey of purchasing managers has found.

title: Man Said to Kill Wife as 3 Children Watch
description: A Queens man shot and killed his estranged wife last night as she sat in the front seat of a car while her three children watched in horror from the back seat, the police said.

title: Burson-Marsteller Gets Lobbying Concern
description: Burson-Marsteller has acquired Black, Manafort, Stone & Kelly, a top Washington lobbying and public consulting firm, as had been expected. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Aquino's Successor? For Now, 'Just Call Me Mr.'
description: Here in Southern Leyte, in a town hit hard by a recent typhoon, is a good place to watch Fidel V. Ramos go about his unorthodox campaign to succeed President Corazon C. Aquino, who says she will not run again in 1992. Mr. Ramos, the Defense Secretary, is running for President by trying to do his job.

title: School Board Offers to Add Student Voice
description: The New York City Board of Education plans to add a high school student as a nonvoting member to give the board's adults a youngster's perspective on school life.

title: Lotus Development Names a Top Officer
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, the big computer software company, has brought in a new executive, Robert K. Weiler, to take charge of sales and marketing.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp. is offering $105 million in 7.42 percent consolidated systemwide bonds due 1994 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Co. * First Security Corp., Salt Lake City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $150 million in senior subordinated debt securities through First Boston Corp. * Kaufman & Broad Home Corp., Los Angles, said it had increased its line of credit to $265 million from $200 million. * Loews Corp., New York, says that on Feb. 1 it plans to redeem all outstanding 9 3/4 percent subordinated notes due 1993 at a price of 100. Of the $200 million of notes issued December 1985, about $193 million are currently outstanding. * Southern California Gas Co., Los Angeles-based subsidiary of Pacific Enterprises, has filed for $175 million in first mortgage bonds. * Union Pacific Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., has filed for up to $500 million in debt securities. Ratings * Beverly Enterprise Inc.'s subordinated debt rating has been increased to B-, from CCC+, by Standard & Poor's. The nursing home chain is based in Fort Smith, Ark.

title: Construction Spending Down 0.6%
description: Construction spending fell by six-tenths of a percent in November to its lowest level in two years, the Commerce Department said today. The decline wiped out October's rise, the first in building activity in six months.

title: Jordan Wasn't Site Of Scrolls Discovery
description: To the Editor:

title: After Mining, a Furor Over a Shrine
description: Like others born and raised in this tiny, century-old Mormon town, Norman Turley has spent a lifetime admiring the 1,200-foot-high volcanic cinder cone that rises from the desert and gives this place its distinction. His family has owned the formation, Woodruff Butte, since 1935.

title: Shevardnadze Says He Quit In Advance of a Crackdown
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said in an interview published today that he had resigned because he could not defend the use of force to restore discipline in the country.

title: Facing the Recycling Facts
description: Stephen Polan, New York's Sanitation Commissioner, shocked city officials when he said at a recent City Council hearing that collecting waste separated for recycling would cost twice what collecting unsegregated waste has been costing. The cost of collecting solid waste when recycling is fully in effect across the city will reach $250 million a year, compared with $125 million today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Continental Corp., New York, an insurance holding company, promoted Wayne H. Fisher to executive vice president and Kenneth B. Zeigler to senior vice president. Samuel T. Byron Jr. was named chairman and president of its Marine Office of America Corp. subsidiary and Thomas J. Prendergast president of Continental International Group. * Financial Institutions Retirement Fund, White Plains, promoted Robert D. Alin to senior vice president of legal affairs and Peter T. Baxter to vice president of thrift plan services. * HQ Office Supplies Warehouse Inc., Long Beach, Calif., appointed Chet E. Howard president and chief executive, replacing George J. Handgis, who returns to the position of president and chief executive of HQ International Inc. * Prairietek Corp., Longmont, Colo., manufacturers of hard-disk drives, named Michael Cannon vice president of Southeast Asia operations. * Scor U.S. Corp., New York, a subsidiary of Societe Commerciale de Reassurance, Paris, appointed Craig Johnson vice president and manager of its alternative risk unit and Daniel Brooks president of its Unity Fire and General Insurance Co. and General Security Assurance Corp. of New York subsidiaries. * Southern Phenix Textiles Inc., Phenix City, Ala., manufacturers of polyester industrial fabrics and a subsidiary of Johnston Industries, New York, appointed Richard J. Gibney vice president of its stitchbond and automotive fabrics divisions. * Sunrise Bancorp, Fort Mitchell, Ky., named Robert Patrella president and chief executive, succeeding James Davis, who resigned.

title: St. John's Loses to Syracuse in Overtime
description: If the Big East ever needed a video to promote its entertaining basketball conference further, it might insert a tape of tonight's game between Syracuse and St. John's into the recorder.

title: Colorado, Tech No. 1; Miami Better
description: What does a computer do on New Year's Day? It does what the rest of the nation does. It watches the tube.

title: SOVIET COMMANDOS GUARD RIGA PRESS
description: Armed Soviet police commandos surrounded Latvia's main newspaper publishing plant today to block the republic's independent government from taking it away from the Communist Party, according to the official Soviet press agency Tass.

title: Gunman Killed in a Shootout
description: An off-duty housing police officer shot and killed one of four masked gunmen last night as they tried to rob his family's grocery story in Astoria, Queens, the police said. The officer, who was not identified, was wounded in the left leg during a brief shootout with the gunmen at 8:40 P.M. He was in stable condition at Elmhurst General Hospital. One unidentified gunman died at the scene, the Del Sardo grocery store at 34-56 42d Street in Astoria, the police said. The others fled in a silver Camaro with New Jersey plates.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: U.S. Embassy Security Big Worry in Baghdad
description: The United States Embassy here is showing keen sensitivity to the physicial security of American diplomats as the deadline approaches for what could be a military showdown between Iraq and the United States in the Persian Gulf.

title: White House Advisers Agree on Fed Nominee
description: President Bush's top economic advisers, resolving a months-long disagreement, have recommended that the President nominate Lawrence B. Lindsey, a conservative economist on the White House staff, to the vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said today.

title: Article 366091 -- No Title
description: In what appeared to be the largest payment ever involving a violation of Federal pension law, the United Steelworkers of America has won a $415 million settlement from the Continental Can Company.

title: Corrections
description: Weather listings from Oct. 28 through last Sunday for United States and foreign cities misstated the times at which the readings were taken. The introductory paragraphs should have said Eastern standard time, not Eastern daylight.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Union Oil Company of California, a unit of Unocal Corp., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $1.5 billion in guaranteed senior and subordinated debt securities and warrants. COMMON STOCK * Marcam Corp., Newton, Mass., has filed for 1.5 million common shares through Hambrecht & Quist Inc. RATINGS * Idaho Power Co.'s preferred stock rating has been lowered to A, from A+, by S. &P.

title: Pentagon Seeks Tight Limits On Reporters in a Gulf War
description: The Pentagon has proposed rules for press coverage of a war in the Persian Gulf that are far more restrictive than the guidelines used in Vietnam.

title: In Focus Systems Sets Compaq Deal
description: In Focus Systems Inc. said it had licensed its technology for color liquid crystal computer displays to the Compaq Computer Corporation. In Focus, a company based in Tualatin, Ore., that went public last month, will receive royalties if Compaq uses the flat panel technology in its machines.

title: Montana Approves Plan to Kill Stray Bison
description: The state decided on Wednesday that Montana game wardens and Federal park rangers would join hunters in killing any bison that strayed from their home in Yellowstone National Park this winter.

title: Jane Pauley Returns, on Sundays
description: "Real Life With Jane Pauley" joins the NBC Sunday evening lineup this weekend, going smack against such favorites as "Murder, She Wrote" on CBS , "America's Funniest Home Videos" on ABC and "In Living Color" on the Fox network. NBC is not known either for its Sunday night hits or for its successful magazine shows, but the thinking around 30 Rockefeller Plaza seems to have been that if anyone can carry it off for the network at 8 P.M., the popular Ms. Pauley is that one.

title: Festival With Music
description: The Seventh Annual Boar's Head and Yule Log Festival, with music by Paul Halley, is to be held at 7:30 tonight at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, in Manhattan. The festival, based on an English tradition dating to 1350, celebrates Twelfth Night, the evening that the Three Wise Men reached Bethlehem. The performers include the Omega Liturgical Dance Company, the Combined Choirs of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Pipes and Drums of the New York State Courts, the Bouwerie Boys Morris Dancers, members of the Cathedral Players and Ralph Lee's Mettawee River Theater Company. The festival performances are to be repeated tomorrow at 1:30, 4:30 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $12. Information: (212) 307-7171.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Pianist Plus

title: Iraqi Government to Leave Baghdad
description: Iraqi authorities informed the foreign diplomatic corps here this week that the Government of President Saddam Hussein was planning to move "all functions of government" out of the capital in advance of the United Nations Security Council deadline demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, several senior diplomats said today.

title: Robinson a Big Challenge for Nets
description: David Robinson backs his man down low, spins and bulls his way to the basket for a dunk.

title: Rev. Jerome Pechillo, A Newark Bishop, 71
description: The Rev. Jerome A. Pechillo, an Auxiliary Bishop for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, died on Tuesday at his brother's home in San Francisco. He was 71 years old and lived at St. Aloysius Parish in Jersey City.

title: Lujan Softens Criticism of a Japanese Takeover at Yosemite
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. sought today to cool his criticism of the Japanese takeover of a company that has operated profitable concessions in Yosemite National Park for 65 years.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a plan by the New York City Board of Education to add a nonvoting student member misstated the role of another board's student member, a trustee of the City University of New York. The student on the CUNY board is a voting member.

title: Stocks Fall Again; Dow Drops 37.13
description: With the economy slumping and the deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait keeping investors on edge, the stock market headed sharply lower yesterday for the second consecutive day.

title: Woman Agrees to Sentence That Requires Birth Control
description: A mother who pleaded guilty to child abuse has agreed to have a birth control device implanted under her arm as part of a sentence of probation.

title: Defector Says K.G.B. Keeps Over 500 Agents in Germany
description: Up to 700 K.G.B. agents are still active in Germany, a former agent for the Soviet security service who defected to the West was quoted as saying today.

title: Review/Be-Bop; A Jazzman Mixing Jokes And Music
description: Well-played be-bop is often about deception: the more complicated it gets, the easier it seems. And in its offhanded quality and logic, it implies a type of naturalism, as if it were a common musical language accessible to anybody.

title: Thomas F. Zimmerman
description: The Rev. Thomas F. Zimmerman, General Superintendent of the Assemblies of God for 26 years, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at Cox Medical Center North in Springfield. He was 78 years old and lived in Springfield.

title: Is Playoff Needed? There's No More Agreement on This Than on No. 1 Team
description: The inability of writers, coaches and computers to agree on a national champion for the first time since 1978 has intensified calls for a national playoff system and solidified arguments against one.

title: Sears Says It Will Cut 21,000 Jobs
description: Struggling to reverse what has become a very serious decline, Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would eliminate 21,000 jobs at its stores nationwide.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Review/Art; Henry Fuseli's Drawings of Life's Lusts and Compulsions
description: "The Drawings of Henry Fuseli" is a small, knockout show. All of the 37 drawings are from the Auckland City Art Gallery in New Zealand, which acquired them from a New Zealand collector in 1965. Because of the works' high quality and their thematic and chronological span (almost 60 years, from 1764 to 1823) the curators of the show believe that Fuseli selected them himself as a gift to another artist, perhaps his supporter William Blake.

title: Browns Alter Shofner's Role
description: Jim Shofner will not return as the Cleveland Browns' head coach next season, but will be the team's director of player personnel.

title: Outcry Over Jews' Move to Germany
description: The recent migration of thousands of Soviet Jews to Germany has set off an impassioned response among many Jews, especially those who survived the horrors of the Nazi era.

title: Congress Takes First Step To Buoy Deposit Insurance
description: Lawmakers used the first day of the 102d Congress to introduce a flurry of legislation today to overhaul the Federal program that protects bank deposits and to change the framework of financial regulation. The moves are the first step in what promises to be months of debate over how to reorganize the banking industry.

title: Drug Appeal by Germany
description: The Government and a pharmaceutical trade group today urged Western drug concerns to resume deliveries of medicines to eastern Germany, where they can sell them only at a 55 percent discount.

title: Brooks Bros. Is Revising Commissions
