description: Brooks Brothers is putting many of its sales clerks on a new commission system that the men's wear retailer hopes will give them an incentive to increase sales and service.

title: Many Donate to the Neediest In Honor of Schoolteachers
description: Last month, after donating to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for decades, Irwin P. Boehm sent his first contribution in memory of his seventh- and eighth-grade teacher, Elizabeth Collins, who died 64 years ago.

title: Publishing Appointment
description: Mark McCormack, chairman and chief executive of International Management Group, based in New York, announced yesterday that Arthur Klebanoff would become vice president of IMG Publishing, in charge of the group's newly founded literary agency division.

title: William Davis, 68, of Times Co.; Founded and Edited Golf Digest
description: William H. Davis, a founder of Golf Digest magazine and a retired senior vice president of The New York Times Company, died on Wednesday at the Carolton Convalescent Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. He was 68 years old and had moved recently to Jupiter, Fla., from Greenwich, Conn.

title: Chancellor Takes Off the Lesson-Plan Shackles
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Flying Horses
description: The Flying Horse Honan Opera Troupe of Taiwan is to perform "The Romance of the Embroidered Sachet" at 7:30 tonight at Alice Tully Hall. Admission is free, but tickets are required. Information: (212) 431-9740.

title: PAN AM IS CURBING SERVICE IN MIDEAST
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it was suspending flights to Tel Aviv and to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, because of surging insurance rates, a result of the crisis in the Middle East.

title: Keep in Mind
description: "THE GIFT OF WINTER," a musical, performed by children, based on the book by John Leach and Jean Rankin, in which two boys go on a journey to see Winter, a friendly ogre. At Tada, 120 West 28th Street, Manhattan. Tonight at 7:30, tomorrow and Sunday at 1 and 3:30 P.M. Tickets, $7 for adults, $5 for children. Information: (212) 627-1732. "SPIRIT OF DEFIANCE: THE MANGBETU PEOPLE OF ZAIRE," a documentary about the oracles and rituals of Africans struggling against missionary influences. At the American Museum of Natural History, Linder Theater, Central Park West at 79th Street, Manhattan. Sunday at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. Tickets are free with suggested museum admission of $4 for adults and $2 for children. Information: (212) 769-5305. "RUMPLESTILTSKIN," a live musical comedy of the classic, performed by the Jan Hus Theater Company. At the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street, Manhattan, on Sunday at 1 and 2:30 P.M. Tickets, $4.95. Reservations: (212) 772-9180. "STARMITES," a musical about a girl who finds herself in her favorite comic-book world. At the Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street, Manhattan. Tonight at 7. Tickets, $10 for adults, $8 for students. Reservations: (212) 666-1716. "PLAY TO WIN," a Theatreworks/USA musical depicting Jackie Robinson's struggle to break the color barrier in major-league baseball. At the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow at 12:30 P.M., Sunday at 10:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. Tickets, $13 to $16. Information: (212) 677-5959. "A GARMENT FOR THE MOON," a performance of traditional Jewish folk tales created by the International Performance and Production Company. At Louis Abrons Art Center of the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, Manhattan. Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $3 for adults, $2 for children. Reservations: (212) 598-0400. BIRDING TOUR, a morning adventure with the naturalist Sarah Elliott, through the Ramble in Central Park. Meet at the Loeb Boathouse, 75th Street and East Drive, 10 A.M. Sunday, rain or shine. Information: (212) 360-2766, through today only.

title: P.R. Firms Head for Capitol Hill
description: America's largest public relations firms grew up believing that their job was to influence mass audiences by placing stories about their clients in newspapers and magazines and on television. Now, they know they need relations with different kinds of publics, chief among them Government regulators, the legislators to whom they answer and the voters who put the legislators in office.

title: Sidney Sokol
description: Sidney Sokol, a former United States Treasury Department official, died on Sunday at New York University Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhatan.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
A Neighborhood Assists Central Park West Project
description: A 19-story condominium is being constructed on land formerly occupied by three late 19th-century row houses at the northwest corner of Central Park West and 95th Street.

title: 'Don Giovanni' and 2 Virginia Woolf Lectures
description: Two public-television presentations this weekend powerfully reflect a couple of the more provocative movements of this century. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, the director Peter Sellars, an apostle of the new multi-culturalism, takes Mozart's "Don Giovanni" and places it in the contemporary rubble of the South Bronx. Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, "Masterpiece Theater" delves into two lectures given in 1928 by Virginia Woolf at Cambridge University. Published in 1929 as "A Room of One's Own," they have become a classic tract in the history of feminism.

title: Trace Illegal Firearms
description: Yesterday, in a special legislative hearing on illegal firearms held by the New York State Assembly Codes Committee, Mayor David Dinkins called on the New York City Council to ban the sale and possession of assault weapons in the city. Nine other witnesses who appeared before the committee in the daylong hearing sought to focus attention on lethal weapons and the trade in illegal firearms in the city. The Op-Ed page has asked six specialists for their suggestions for coping with the flood of guns on the streets.

title: Cerone and Yankees Likely To Part Ways for Third Time
description: Rick Cerone's career with the Yankees appears to be over -- for the third time.

title: On Trial: A Videotape of a Disabled Girl's Day
description: A closely watched case before the Illinois Supreme Court revolves around a severely disabled girl and a videotape her lawyers want to make: a tape that would show a day in her life.

title: Gerald L. Wallace, 90, Lawyer and Professor
description: Gerald L. Wallace, a tax lawyer and professor of law at New York University, died on Saturday, his 90th birthday, at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Restaurants
description: Spa food is the trickiest in the world to prepare. It requires the skills of a con artist to pull off the required culinary scam.

title: Dinkins Aides Say Budget Needs Millions More in Spending Cuts
description: Top Dinkins administration officials said yesterday that New York City's fiscal problems had worsened sharply in recent weeks and would require several hundred million dollars of additional budget cuts by June 30.

title: How the Supermarket Tabloids Stay Out of Court
description: Every few months a Hollywood celebrity walks into Vincent Chieffo's law office in Los Angeles, angrily waving a copy of one of the supermarket tabloids, those weekly newspapers that offer readers a feast of gossip, scandal and believe-it-or-not phenomena.

title: Hull Sets Vote Record
description: Brett Hull, a high-scoring, fan-pleasing right wing for the St. Louis Blues, set a record in leading the voting for this year's All-Star Game.

title: Fewer 'Brownies' May Mean Clogged Streets
description: At a time when New York City is experiencing some of its worst traffic jams ever, transportation officials are cutting the number of city workers directing traffic at bridges and construction sites.

title: A Boeing Official On Status of B-2
description: The Air Force has opted to freeze the Boeing Company's production of the B-2 stealth bomber at 15 planes this year, a Boeing official said. The Air Force said no decision had been made. "My understanding is that at this time, the Air Force does not intend to go forward," said the Boeing official, Jim Evatt. Congressional officials cited by The Seattle Post-Intelligencer today made similar assertions. The newspaper did not identify the officials.

title: Critic's Notebook; Opening One's Eyes To Godard
description: A RUMPLED, half-mad, once-famous director named Godard sits in a hospital room typing gibberish. When his niece comes to visit, he demonstrates his new invention, a camera that plays music, by sitting on the floor and holding a large boom box to his ear. "Don't you want to go back to making movies, Uncle Jean?" asks the young woman, and the director gives a typically inscrutable Godardian answer: "We should close our eyes, not open them."

title: Longing to Be Normal, but Never Acting Normally
description: A Dangerous Woman By Mary McGarry Morris 358 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Sharp Rise In Claims By Jobless
description: The number of Americans applying for unemployment benefits soared 16.8 percent, to 515,000, the week before Christmas, the highest level in nearly eight years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Review/Art; An Ambitious Effort to Praise de Chirico's Later Works
description: Against what seems the unmistakable evidence of the paintings, efforts to praise the later career of Giorgio de Chirico continue unabated. "Giorgio de Chirico: 1920-1950" at Borghi & Company is one of the most ambitious attempts yet.

title: For Children
description: Bowling Bowlmor Lanes 110 University Place (near East 12th Street) Manhattan (212) 255-8188 Recommended ages: 8 and up only

title: Missing Pin Cited In a Bus Accident That Injured Nine
description: A midtown bus accident last week in which nine people were injured was caused by a missing cotter pin "the size of a paper clip" in the bus's brake assembly, the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: The Rich Legacy Of an Economist
description: JOSEPH J. SPENGLER, the eminent economist at Duke University who died this week in Durham, N.C., saw modern economic science as stemming from two roots -- one administrative, the other ethical.

title: David Piper, 72, Dies; British Art Historian
description: Sir David Piper, an internationally known art historian and museum director, died on Saturday at his home in Wytham, near Oxford. He was 72 years old and had emphysema.

title: Fiat Truck Deal
description: The truck unit of Fiat S.p.A. took control of 60 percent of Spain's state-held Enasa truck maker, sealing an agreement reached last September. The unit, Iveco S.p.A., Europe's second-largest truck maker, paid 1.2 billion pesetas, or about $10.2 million, for the stake in Empresa Nacional de Autocamiones S.A., as Enasa is formally known. The venture's eight-member board will have five Iveco members, with the rest going to Instituto Nacional de Industria, Enasa's parent. The Spanish truck maker has 5,500 employees.

title: Leon R. McKinney; Psychiatrist, 66
description: Dr. Leon Russell McKinney, a psychiatrist, died Dec. 21 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 535 money market mutual funds plunged $5.9 billion, to $422 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 164 institutional funds decreased by $3.09 billion, to $108.38 billion. The assets of the 267 general-purpose funds were up by $30 million, to $150.44 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds decreased by $2.84 billion, to $163.18 billion, the institute said.

title: Deputy Chief of Federal Lab Removed Amid Investigation of Ties to Two Companies
description: The deputy chief of a major laboratory of the National Cancer Institute has been removed from his job pending the investigation of what an official at the National Institutes of Health called possible violations of criminal conflict-of-interest statutes.

title: U.S. Issues Rise on Jobless Data
description: After a big rise in initial unemployment claims was reported, prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday and interest rates fell further.

title: Purchase Index Up for Homes
description: Falling home prices and rising incomes combined to raise the typical American family's ability to buy a home to its highest level in 13 years, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Discount Stores Lead in December Sales Gains
description: In the face of the slowing economy, many consumers did their Christmas shopping at discount stores last month. While a number of the nation's largest department stores reported poor December sales yesterday, discount store chains like Wal-Mart Target and Venture posted respectable sales gains in light of the poor economy.

title: Group of Seven Plans Meeting
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and finance ministers from six other leading countries are planning their first meeting of 1991 for later this month to talk about bringing the Soviet Union closer to the economy of the West, diplomats said today.

title: Effort to Evacuate Foreigners From Somalia Stalls
description: Efforts to evaculate the remaining foreigners from the Somali capital, Mogadishu, were stalled today after Western governments failed in their efforts to get a lull in the fighting, now in its fifth day.

title: 'Bonfire of Vanities' Is No Satire
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: How Lawyers Can Make Divorces Less Painful
description: To the Editor:

title:
GUNS, GUNS EVERYWHERE -- STRATEGIES FOR ARMS CONTROL;
Use a Gun, Do Federal Time
description: Yesterday, in a special legislative hearing held by the New York State Assembly Codes Committee, Mayor David Dinkins called on the New York City Council to ban the sale and possession of assault weapons in the city. Nine other witnesses who appeared before the committee in the daylong hearing sought to focus attention on lethal weapons and the trade in illegal firearms in the city. Earlier, the Op-Ed page asked six specialists for their suggestions for coping with the flood of guns on the streets.

title: Godard Film Schedule
description: A festival devoted to the films of Jean-Luc Godard will run through Feb. 7 at Film Forum 2 and 3, 209 West Houston Street in Manhattan. Admission to each screening is $7. Information: (212) 727-8110. Most of the movies will be shown at Film Forum 2; those at Film Forum 3 are noted. Here is a schedule. TODAY TO THURSDAY "BREATHLESS" (1959), with Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg, and "PARIS VU PAR" (1965), with Joanna Shimkus, 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 P.M. JAN. 11 TO 15 "MASCULINE-FEMININE" (1966), with Jean-Pierre Leaud, Chantal Goya and Brigitte Bardot, 2:40, 6:20 and 10 P.M. on Jan. 11, 14 and 15; 2:45, 6:35 and 10:15 P.M. on Jan. 12 and 13, and "LA CHINOISE" (1967), with Jean-Pierre Leaud, 4:35 and 8:15 P.M. on Jan. 11, 14 and 15 and 1, 4:40 and 8:30 P.M. on Jan. 12 and 13. JAN. 16 AND 17 "EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF" (1980), with Jacques Dutronc, Nathalie Baye and Isabelle Huppert, 3:05, 5:50 and 8:35 P.M., and "LETTER TO JANE" (1972), 2, 4:45, 7:30 and 10:15 P.M. JAN. 18 TO 21 "WEEKEND" (1967), with Jean-Pierre Leaud, Mireille Darc and Jean Yanne, 2:40, 6:25 and 10:05 P.M., and "TOUT VA BIEN" (1972), with Yves Montand and Jane Fonda, 4:40 and 8:20 P.M. on Jan. 18; 1, 4:40 and 8:20 P.M. Jan 19 to 21. JAN. 22 TO 25 "PIERROT LE FOU" (1965), with Jean-Paul Belmondo and Anna Karina, 2:30, 6:05 and 9:40 P.M., and "A WOMAN IS A WOMAN" (1961), with Anna Karina, Jean-Claude Brialy and Jean-Paul Belmondo, 4:40 and 8:05 P.M. (Film Forum 3). JAN. 26 TO 29 "MY LIFE TO LIVE" (1962), with Anna Karina, 1:05, 4:15, 7:25 and 10:35 P.M. Jan. 26 and 27; 3:35, 6:45 and 10 P.M. on Jan. 28 and 29, and "TWO OR THREE THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER" (1966), with Marina Vlady, 2:40, 5:50 and 9 P.M. on Jan. 26 and 27; 2, 5:10 and 8:20 P.M. on Jan. 28 and 29. (Film Forum 3). JAN. 30 AND 31 "LES CARABINIERS" (1963), 3:40, 6:50 and 10 P.M., and "LE PETIT SOLDAT" (1960), with Anna Karina, 2, 5:10 and 8:20 P.M. FEB. 1 TO 5 "ALPHAVILLE" (1965), with Eddie Constantine and Anna Karina, and "ALL BOYS ARE CALLED PATRICK" (1957), with Jean-Claude Brialy, 2, 4:10, 6:20, 8:30 and 10:40 P.M. FEB. 6 AND 7 "HAIL MARY" (1985), with Myriem Roussel, 2:35, 6:10 and 9:45 P.M., and "FIRST NAME: CARMEN" (1983), with Maruschka Detmers, 4:35 and 8:10 P.M.

title: Critic's Choice
description: When Jimmy DeSana died of AIDS in July, on the threshold of his 40's, he left behind a diverse and seemingly inconsistent body of work. There were garish color photographs that bordered on the pornographic, as well as nearly abstract images of chairs, candlesticks and other domestic objects. Even in his treatment of the human body, his most enduring subject, he ranged from savagely explicit to purely symbolic.

title: Movie Tickets Off 10%, but Not Gross
description: Ten percent fewer Americans went to the movies in 1990 but higher ticket prices pushed the industry's box-office take to a near-record $5 billion.

title: Western Economists Urge Soviets to Take Radical Steps
description: In a report submitted to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, a panel of prominent Western economists has said the Soviet Government must free prices, slash its budget deficit and take several other radical steps in the next few months if it hopes to avert economic collapse.

title: Devils Try to Rally But Again Fall Short
description: The Devils are tied for the league lead in ties, with nine, which can mean one thing to optimists, another to pessimists.

title: King to Leave Auburn
description: Ed King, the all-America offensive lineman, said yesterday he would give up his final year of eligibility at Auburn and enter the National Football League draft.

title: 192-Year-Old Weekly To Cease Publication
description: The Washington County Post, a newspaper born when John Adams was President, and circulated nearly every week since, has printed its final issue.

title: Real Estate Downturn Can Help New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Light Mood as Golf Season Opens
description: As it has for the last several years, the golf season opened today with the Tournament of Champions at one of the country's most sumptuous decompression chambers, the La Costa Resort Hotel and Spa.

title: Another Misguided Labor Pact
description: New York City's latest labor settlement is another disturbing sign that the Dinkins administration does not fully grasp the severity of the city's fiscal predicament. Agreeing to give two major unions a 5 percent increase over 15 months -- 4.5 percent in wages, the rest in benefits -- means that City Hall has chosen to give higher salaries to union members at the expense of reducing services for all New Yorkers.

title: The Footnote Fetish in Judicial Opinions: A Weather Vane of High Court Philosophy?
description: When William J. Brennan Jr. stepped down last year from the United States Supreme Court, he was showered with superlatives. But one claim to fame was somehow overlooked: with a batting average of 11.690 for the 1989 term, he set the standard among the Justices for most footnotes per opinion.

title: To King Hussein of Jordan: Abdicate
description: Your Majesty,

title: Fernandez To Propose A Furlough
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said yesterday that he would ask the school worker unions and the city next week to agree to close schools for three days in the spring to avoid as many as 4,000 layoffs of teachers and other employees by Jan. 15.

title: Daniel M.C. Hopping
description: Daniel M. C. Hopping, an architect who specialized in restorations and who supervised the installation of 14 historic American rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Dec. 26 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Lemieux Practices
description: Mario Lemieux, the All-Star center whose rehabilitation from back problems has gone better than expected, plans to resume practicing with the Pittsburgh Penguins on Monday.

title: New Approach in Massachusetts
description: William F. Weld was sworn in today as the state's first Republican Governor in 16 years and gave an inaugural address advocating a conservative approach to healing Massachusetts's ailing financial condition.

title: Pinelands Chairman Is Finding 'Adventure'
description: Lawrence P. Fraiberg, with a long broadcasting career behind him, is now the head of a new company called Pinelands Inc., owner of WWOR-TV, a independent television station broadcasting in the New York area.

title: Big Note Offerings By Ford and G.M.
description: Auto makers accounted for a sizable amount of the total debt issued yesterday as Ford Capital B.V., an overseas unit of the Ford Motor Company, and the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of General Motors, priced $800 million in securities for offering to the public.

title: Small Software Maker Is Taking Giant Steps
description: The next Microsoft? Many software industry experts think it will be the Santa Cruz Operation Inc.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
K Mart Names President At Pay Less Drug Chain
description: Timothy McAlear, who climbed the corporate ladder at K Mart Corporation and was named president and chief executive of its Pay Less Drug Stores subsidiary on Thursday, says the most interesting and rewarding job he held was more than 20 years ago, when he became manager of a K Mart store in Richmond, Ind.

title: U.N. Rebukes Israel on Palestinian Deaths in Gaza
description: The United Nations Security Council formally rebuked Israel today over the recent killing of Palestinians by its security forces in the territories it has occupied since the 1967 war and reaffirmed that these territories include Israel's capital, Jerusalem.

title: Vanished: A Man, $13 Million And Faith in a State's Banks
description: Month after month last year, the money poured out of a small neighborhood bank here in what its president depicted as a legitimate series of $13 million in loans.

title: OFFICE IN MOSCOW OPENED BY ISRAELIS
description: Israel raised its blue and white flag over a consulate in Moscow today in a major step toward the restoration of full diplomatic relations between the two nations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a cut in the prime rate by the nation's largest banks misstated the last time the rate was raised to 11 1/2 percent. It was February 1989, not 1988.

title: Truck Ban Is Announced For a Bridge
description: The Manhattan Bridge is so deteriorated that its lower roadway will be closed to all trucks and vans and probably to all vehicles at nights and on weekends, city transportation officials said yesterday.

title: When the Stars Shine
description: The Hayden Planetarium is closed only two days a year: Thanksgiving and Christmas. Admission is $4 for adults and $2 for children ages 2 to 12. The planetarium is open to the public Mondays through Fridays from 12:30 to 4:45 P.M., and there are Sky Shows at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M.; on weekends there are shows every hour (Saturdays at 11 A.M., 1, 2:15, 3:30 and 4:45 P.M.; Sundays at 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 P.M.). There are shows for preschoolers on the first Saturday of every month ("Wonderful Sky, Featuring the Sesame Street Muppets") and for 7-to-11-year-olds ("Robots in Space, Featuring R2-D2 and C-3PO," created at Lucasfilm's Industrial Light and Magic studios). There are also three laser-light shows at the planetarium on Friday and Saturday nights: at 7 and 8:30, "Pink Floyd's Dark Side of the Moon," and at 10, "Laser Bowie." Admission for these shows is $6.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Washington Upends Arizona Dion Brown scored 13 of his 21 points in the second half last night to lead Washington over No. 4 Arizona, 70-56, in a Pac-10 Conference opener in Seattle. The victory snapped the Huskies' losing streak against the Wildcats at 10 games. The Huskies (9-1) trailed only once, 2-0, and led by 13 points at halftime. Arizona (10-2) closed the gap to 7 points several times in the second half but Washington held on, converting 12 of 14 free throws in the last three minutes. (AP) Ohio State 63, Iowa 59: Jamaal Brown and Jim Jackson each hit two free throws in the final 30 seconds for the No. 6 Buckeyes in a Big Ten Conference opener in Columbus, Ohio. Jackson led Ohio State (11-0) with 20 points, and Treg Lee had 12 and Brown added 11. Iowa (11-2), which had won 10 games in a row, was led by Acie Earl and James Moses with 16 points each. (AP) Michigan State 85, Michigan 70: Steve Smith scored 24 points and Matt Steigenga added 20 as the No. 25 Spartans opened defense of their Big Ten championship. It was the third consecutive game in which Smith and Steigenga have both scored 20 or more for Michigan State (8-3 over all, 1-0 in the Big Ten). The victory was No. 250 at Michigan State for Jud Heathcote who is 250-173 in his 15 years as coach of the Spartans. (AP) North Carolina 108, Cornell 64: Rick Fox scored 19 points as the No. 7 Tar Heels (10-1) jumped to a quick lead on Cornell with its 3-point shooting, then used its quickness and size advantage to score a lopsided victory. The Tar Heels (10-1), who won their 10th game in a row, played at Cornell (6-3) because it is Coach Dean Smith's custom to set up homecoming-type games for his seniors. This game was played for the benefit of the senior point guard King Rice, who played high school basketball in Binghamton, 30 miles southeast of Ithaca. (AP) TENNIS Courier Advances in Australia Jim Courier of the United States kept cool in sweltering conditions yesterday to beat Paul Haarhuis of the Netherlands in the second round of the Australian hardcourt championship in Adelaide. The second-seeded Courier moved to the quarterfinals with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Haarhuis in temperatures that reached 104 degrees. (AP) Savchenko Gains Quarterfinals: Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union overpowered top-seeded Jana Novotna, 6-2, 6-4, today to advance to the quarterfinals of the Danone Open in Brisbane, Australia. The unseeded Savchenko earned a quarterfinal meeting with fifth-seeded Sabine Appelmans of Belgium, who beat Shaun Stafford of the United States, 6-4, 6-3. (AP) Yugoslavia Defeats United States: Yugoslavia swept both singles matches against the United States yesterday to win the Hopman Cup team competition in Perth, Australia. Monica Seles started with a 6-1, 6-1 romp over Zina Garrison, and Goran Prpic beat David Wheaton, 4-6, 6-3, 7-5, making the score 2-0 with only the mixed doubles remaining. (AP) N.H.L. Hull Lifts Blues Brett Hull scored his league-leading 39th goal in 40 games on a deflection with six minutes left as St. Louis defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 8-7, at home to end a losing streak at three games. (AP) North Stars 3, Maple Leafs 3: Doug Shedden, whose tripping penalty led to Minnesota's go-ahead goal early in the third period, tipped in Dave Reid's shot with 4:20 left to force a tie. (AP) Bruins 8, Canucks 3: Ken Hodge stole the puck at the Boston blue line and skated in alone for a short-handed goal that broke a 3-3 tie. The Canucks have a 3-34-3 record at Boston Garden. (AP)

title: Zorich's Mother Dies
description: Chris Zorich, the Notre Dame nose tackle, returned home from the Orange Bowl to find the body of his mother, who had apparently died after watching the game on television.

title: 102d Congress Opens, Troubled On Gulf but Without a Consensus
description: The 102d Congress convened today, unenthusiastic about war in the Persian Gulf but institutionally uncertain about how and when to express those doubts.

title: Cuomo Fosters New Opposition To Utility Rises
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed an executive order yesterday that helps create a statewide consumer group to fight residential rate increases by utility companies.

title: HDM Officer Joins McCabe
description: Ed McCabe is at it again. Two weeks ago, the well-known creative director abruptly quit Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners to set up his own agency.

title: Pepsico Offering Of 4-Year Notes
description: Pepsico Inc. priced a $200 million public offering of noncallable four-year notes yesterday through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: What Really Drives A Writer to Write?
description: To the Editor:

title:
GUNS, GUNS EVERYWHERE -- STRATEGIES FOR ARMS CONTROL;
Teach Kids to 'Talk It Out'
description: Yesterday, in a special legislative hearing on illegal firearms held by the New York State Assembly Codes Committee, Mayor David Dinkins called on the New York City Council to ban the sale and possession of assault weapons in the city. Nine other witnesses who appeared before the committee in the daylong hearing sought to focus attention on lethal weapons and the trade in illegal firearms in the city. The Op-Ed page has asked six specialists for their suggestions for coping with the flood of guns on the streets.

title: Luke Appling, Ex-White Sox Star In the Hall of Fame, Is Dead at 83
description: Luke Appling, the sure-hitting Hall of Fame shortstop who bedeviled rival pitchers during 20 sparkling years with the Chicago White Sox and then astounded the baseball world by hitting a home run in an old-timers' game at the age of 75, died during emergency surgery yesterday. He was 83 years old and had retired two days earlier as a minor league hitting instructor for the Atlanta Braves.

title: Revoking Licenses To Kill
description: Yesterday, in a special legislative hearing held by the New York State Assembly Codes Committee, Mayor David Dinkins called on the New York City Council to ban the sale and possession of assault weapons in the city. Nine other witnesses who appeared before the committee in the daylong hearing sought to focus attention on lethal weapons and the trade in illegal firearms in the city. Earlier, the Op-Ed page asked six specialists for their suggestions for coping with the flood of guns on the streets.

title: Development's President Quits
description: Thomas Hutchinson, who took over as president of the General Development Corporation six months ago, has quit, the embattled construction company said today.

title: William H. J. Kennedy Jr.; Professor, 70
description: William Henry Joseph Kennedy Jr., a retired English professor and expert on the literature of the Renaissance in England and Italy, died Dec. 27 at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Du Pont Is Sued Again by Cetus
description: The Cetus Corporation has filed another patent infringement lawsuit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. The suit, filed in Federal District Court here, seeks to stop Du Pont from selling products that use a technology known as polymerase chain reaction, which amplifies minute amounts of genetic material. The approach is proving very useful in many areas of science and medicine.

title: Wyche Has Surprises In Store for the Oilers
description: The last time the Cincinnati Bengals made the playoffs, they drove opposing coaches, and the National Football League's front office, batty with a no-huddle hurry-up offense that made fun of the rule book. It helped get them to the Super Bowl two years ago.

title: As Apartheid Fades, Uprooted Try to Go Home
description: The graves, neatly piled with red stones pulled from the stony veld, offer proof that the Barolong tribesmen lived at this place they called Matloang until 1971, when the Government evicted them in the name of apartheid.

title: Key Rates
Republic Under Law
description: In 1991 Americans will celebrate the 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the Constitution. Those amendments, guaranteeing free speech and other rights, furthered the basic purpose of the Constitution: to create a national Government yet make sure that it would not become an autocracy.

title: London Is to Expel 75 Iraqis, Including 8 of Embassy Staff
description: Citing "public threats" and national security, Britain said today that it was expelling 8 staff members of the Iraqi Embassy, including 7 diplomats, and 67 other Iraqis.

title: Dr. Parcells Scores Some Points With a Psychology Game Plan
description: The Giants held a closed-door, players-only meeting today that may have been prompted by heavy criticism by Coach Bill Parcells and his assistants over the team's effort in the last two games. But many veteran players dismissed the whole thing as an exercise in coaching psychology.

title: John T. O'Hagan Is Dead at 65; Fire Commissioner in the 1970's
description: John T. O'Hagan, who served simultaneously as chief of the New York City Fire Department and as Fire Commissioner in the mid-70's, died on Wednesday at his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 65 years old.

title: Halls of History, Fame, Oddity and Wonder
description: TIRED of standing in line to see Mexican at the Met? Weary of looking high and low at the Museum of Modern Art? Wondering what's hanging on other walls while the Guggenheim reworks its bobsled ramp-run? Never mind, you ain't seen nothing yet, to coin a cliche (for other coins, try the American Numismatic Society in Harlem). The city that rarely owns up to a past as it ages gracelessly is home to more than a hundred museums and the multi-chambered megamuseum is but the tip of the burg.

title: Mr. Lujan's Embarrassing Rant
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan has been flirting with racism in his effort to win control of the company that owns grocery stores, hotels and other concessions in Yosemite National Park. Yesterday Mr. Lujan wisely sought to cool his anti-Japanese rhetoric. His earlier behavior had done little to help Japanese-American commercial relations, or the park.

title: In India, Muslims Fear Reign of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Pledges to Fight Corsican Crime
description: Alarmed that Corsica might be sliding into ungovernability, the French Government pledged today to restore order to the Mediterranean island after the recent slayings of three local politicians and a resurgence of separatist violence.

title: INSIDE
description: Test for Rail Safety Law Testing a new law, the Government is moving to bar an engineer with a poor safety record from operating a train anywhere in the country. Page A16. Officer Charged in Shooting A police officer is charged with manslaughter for shooting a Bronx woman he said threatened him with his nightstick. Page B1. Israeli Flag in Moscow Israel's flag was raised over its consulate, opened after 24 years in a step toward restoring full ties. Page A6.

title:
GUNS, GUNS EVERYWHERE -- STRATEGIES FOR ARMS CONTROL;
Let's Debate Drug Policy
description: Yesterday, in a special legislative hearing held by the New York State Assembly Codes Committee, Mayor David Dinkins called on the New York City Council to ban the sale and possession of assault weapons in the city. Nine other witnesses who appeared before the committee in the daylong hearing sought to focus attention on lethal weapons and the trade in illegal firearms in the city. Earlier, the Op-Ed page asked six specialists for their suggestions for coping with the flood of guns on the streets.

title: Lakers Beat Blazers, 108-104
description: Byron Scott scored 7 points in the final 1 minute 43 seconds, including three of four free throws in the last 18.1 seconds, as the Los Angeles Lakers beat Portland, 108-104, tonight, giving the Trail Blazers two losses in a row for the first time this season.

title: 22 Rhode Island Credit Unions to Be Insured
description: Federal regulators said today that they would provide insurance to depositors at 22 of the smaller Rhode Island credit unions closed earlier this week after the state insurance program declared that it might not be solvent. At least seven are expected to open Monday, and the others that have received insurance will open sometime next week.

title: Lower Prices Are Likely to Be on Exhibit
description: A nationwide slump in the sale of boats has turned the tide on prices, a softening effect that is likely to be seen at the upcoming New York National Boat Show.

title: Leslie Aronow
description: Leslie Aronow, a public relations executive and president of the Alliance of New York State Arts Councils, died on Monday at his home in Suffern, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

title: At the Movies
description: All the World's a Screen

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Marsalis Septet

title: CHRONICLE
description: MERLE HAGGARD will receive the Award of Merit at the America Music Awards ceremony on Jan. 28 in Los Angeles. He was chosen by a panel of music industry executives for his 30-career in country music, which he has used as a vehicle for social commentary.

title: Review/Art; A Never Land Version of the Palace at Versailles
description: Jean Lowe's faux Rococo installation, at the Gracie Mansion Gallery in SoHo, avoids many pitfalls of art focusing on political subjects. It has an unwieldy, perhaps deliberately pretentious title: "A Dilettante's Conversation on the Topics of Anthropocentrism and Western Consumerism."

title: George Allen: Won Games, Lost Jobs
description: As the 1966 season approached, George Allen was the Los Angeles Rams' new coach, but George Halas was still steaming. Halas had won a bitter court judgment that ordered Allen to remain as the Chicago Bears' defensive coordinator. With the validity of the Bears' contract upheld, Halas set Allen free to take the Rams' job, which Allen had pursued without the Bears' permission. But now, at a National Football League owners meeting, the Papa Bear was growling.

title: November New-Home Sales Up
description: Sales of new homes rose in November for the first time in five months, the Government said today. Analysts said the report indicated that the slumping housing market might be stabilizing.

title: Byner Leads Redskins' Charge
description: In late November, as the Washington Redskins geared for their playoff drive, their running game was going nowhere. The team obtained Gerald Riggs from Atlanta and Earnest Byner from Cleveland in April 1989 in hopes of recapturing its bruising, bullying ground game. But a foot injury would keep Riggs idle for six of the team's final seven games this season. Byner? Well, he was the special-situation guy, not the every-down every-game back.

title: Voyaging A Universe On Beams Of Light
description: THE great green dome. The cathedral of magic and wonder. It is so familiar -- yes, let's actually say it, so beloved -- that it is almost invisible. No matter that 550,000 people troop through it each year. No matter that the native New Yorker is predestined to visit it three times as a rite of passage: as a child, as a parent and as a grandparent. Though it is one of the best-known shrines in the city, for many residents who are casting about for a few hours of diversion, the Hayden Planetarium might as well not be there.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDRE AGASSI is planning to play at Wimbledon this summer, for the first time since HENRI LECONTE beat him easily in his first match there in 1987. Mr. Agassi, 20 years old, is currently ranked No. 4 in the world.

title: Irving M. Riffin Dies; Anesthesiologist, 77
description: Dr. Irving M. Riffin, a family doctor and anesthesiologist for almost 50 years, died on Friday at a vacation home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Production Co., Chicago, the petroleum exploration and production unit of Amoco Corp., said it had made a significant natural gas discovery in the Oklahoma portion of the Arkoma Basin within the last 24 months. * Bombay Co., Fort Worth, has completed the spinoff of its Tandy Brands Accessories Inc. division to Bombay common stockholders. They will receive one Tandy common share for every five Bombay common held. * Chrysler Corp., Detroit, said it was increasing the prices on its 1991 vehicles by an average of $37 each and was raising the destination charge for each car and truck by $20. * Consumers Union, Los Angeles, which publishes Consumer Reports, said it had sued Aetna Finance Co., a unit of ITT Corp., seeking $47.2 million in refunds for consumers it said were overcharged on loan fees. * Dean Foods Co., Franklin Park, Ill., a food processor and distributor, has completed the sale of its McCadam Cheese Co. unit to Valio Finnish Cooperative Dairies' Association of Finland. Terms were not disclosed. * GE Capital Corp., New York, a finance company, has entered into a $171.5 million sale-leaseback financing of manufacturing plants for Viskase Corp., Chicago, a unit of Envirodyne Industries, a maker of plastic casings. * Itel Corp., Chicago, a transportation company, has completed the sale of some assets of its Intermodal Container Leasing unit to Genstar Container Corp., a unit of GE Capital Corp. The price was $825 million. * Intergraph Corp., Huntsville, Ala., which makes computer graphics systems, has completed a $14 million buyout of Dazix Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., an electronic software company. * PNC Financial Corp., Pittsburgh, said its Pittsburgh National Bank unit would complete the acquisition of First Federal of Pittsburgh for undisclosed terms. * Qintex Entertainment Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., an entertainment company, said the $37 million sale of two television stations owned by H R Broadcasting to a group led by Abry Communications, Boston, had been completed. * Source Perrier S.A., Paris, said Perrier's share of the U.S. market for imported mineral water fell to 20.7 percent, from 44.8 percent, since last February. The drop was attributed to a recall after traces of benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, were found in some bottles.

title: Shoulder Injury Sidelines McEnroe
description: John McEnroe has withdrawn from a tournament in Sydney next week and might be forced to miss the Australian Open later this month because of a shoulder injury, his agent said yesterday.

title: Our Towns; 4 People Walking In the Darkness Toward Roselle
description: Deborah Daniels is a homeless working person. When she woke at the Spinning Wheel Motel on Thursday morning, she did not know where she and her three children would sleep Thursday night.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Clark-Schwebel Fiber Glass Corp., White Plains, a subsidiary of Springs Industries, Fort Mill, S.C., appointed William D. Bennison executive vice president and general manager of United States fabric operations. * Federal Home Loan Bank of New York named as vice presidents Donald H. Lee, for cost control and budget; Rae D. Rosen, for economics, and Albert R. Turbiak, for human resources. * North Fork Bancorporation, Mattituck, L.I., named Donald J. Kavanagh senior vice president. * Pico Products, Liverpool, N.Y., providers of security for pay television, appointed Peter Moerbeek chief financial officer and vice president of finance. * Primerica Corp., New York, a diversified financial services company, named Marc Weill vice president of investments. * Rykoff-Sexton Inc., Los Angeles, manufactuers and distributors to food services, appointed Mark Van Stekelenburg executive vice president. * Valid Logic Systems, San Jose, Calif., producers of turnkey computer-aided energy systems, named Ken Lally vice president of North American sales. * Walt Disney Television, a unit of Walt Disney Co., Burbank, Calif., appointed Kenneth D. Werner senior vice president of business affairs. * Zions Bancorporation, Salt Lake City, appointed Harris Simmons chief executive, succeeding his father, Roy Simmons, who remains chairman.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The Diner, Updated

title: Officer Is Indicted in Killing Of Woman in Confrontation
description: An indictment unsealed yesterday charged a police officer with manslaughter in the shooting death of a Bronx woman who the police had said threatened the officer with his nightstick as he tried to calm a domestic dispute.

title: Auctions
description: Old Master paintings and English silver acquired under Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former President of the Philippines, and his wife, Imelda, for their palaces and guest residences and for the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, are to be auctioned on Thursday and Friday at Christie's in New York. Christie's estimates that the 97 Old Masters and 78 lots of 18th- and 19th-century English silver will bring $9 million to $14 million.

title: Thompson Picks Up More Kodak Business
description: J. Walter Thompson, New York, has been awarded the Eastman Kodak Company's thermal printing systems account, its fourth large piece of business from Kodak. Billings for the account, which was previously handled by Rumrill-Hoyt, Rochester, were not disclosed.

title: Dispute Prompts Rudin to Quit Budget Panel
description: Lewis Rudin, the developer active in civic affairs, resigned yesterday from the board of the Citizens Budget Commission in a disagreement over the watchdog group's criticism of New York City's tentative labor agreement.

title: G. G. Campbell
description: G. G. Campbell, an F.B.I. agent who took part in the ambush of the outlaw John Dillinger in 1934, died Tuesday after a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: CalFed Is Expecting Loss of $140 Million
description: CalFed Inc., the parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan institution, said today that it expected to report a loss of $140 million in the fourth quarter because of a weakening commercial real estate market.

title: Gretzky Scores Goal No. 700 as Kings Top Islanders
description: Starved for goals and scrambling to mount a defense capable of containing Wayne Gretzky and his smooth-skating cohorts, the Islanders followed an uncharacteristically flashy second period with a full-fledged retreat in the third, a posture that produced a 6-3 loss to the Los Angeles Kings.

title:
GUNS, GUNS EVERYWHERE -- STRATEGIES FOR ARMS CONTROL;
Put the Heat On Washington
description: Yesterday, in a special legislative hearing on illegal firearms held by the New York State Assembly Codes Committee, Mayor David Dinkins called on the New York City Council to ban the sale and possession of assault weapons in the city. Nine other witnesses who appeared before the committee in the daylong hearing sought to focus attention on lethal weapons and the trade in illegal firearms in the city. The Op-Ed page has asked six specialists for their suggestions for coping with the flood of guns on the streets.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Silver's 'Bete' Noire

title: A Senator Arrives, Ruffling Feathers
description: On his first day in office, Paul Wellstone made it clear that he will not be a conventional go-along, get-along United States Senator.

title: Recession: Blaming Everyone But Bush
description: The Bush Administration has now grudg ingly conceded that the economy is in recession. So who is responsible for the economic bad times? Herewith the Bush team's top 10 offenders:

title: Elle Magazine Gets Publisher
description: Lawrence C. Burstein, associate publisher of New York magazine, was named publisher of Elle magazine yesterday. He replaces Anne Sutherland Fuchs, who became publisher of Vogue last month.

title: Arco Agrees to Record Fine For Violations in Texas Blast
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced here today that the Arco Chemical Company had agreed to pay a $3.48 million fine, the largest the agency has ever collected, for safety violations related to an explosion that killed 17 workers last July at the company's plant in a Houston suburb.

title: Edmond Jabes, 78, Writer of Meditations
description: Edmond Jabes, a writer known for his meditations on exile and Judaism, died on Wednesday at his home. He was 78 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It is not a mischaracterization to say that this is a fiscal crisis." -- Philip R. Michael, New York City's Budget Director. [ A1:1. ]

title: F.D.A. Allows Experiments With Pump That Aids Heart
description: The Food and Drug Administration has given a Houston hospital approval to begin experimental use of a portable, battery-powered mechanical device to help a failing heart pump blood until a heart donor can be found.

title: U.S. Hints Salvador Rebels Killed Airmen After Crash
description: Bush Administration officials suggested today that rebels may have executed the three United States airmen whose helicopter was downed on Wednesday while flying over a rural area in eastern El Salvador.

title: Knicks, in Misery, Find Good Company
description: The Knicks have problems, but not nearly as many as the Denver Nuggets.

title: Construction Industry Urged to Police Itself
description: Five years after it was ordered to investigate and analyze widespread corruption and Mafia influence in New York City's building trades, a state agency asserted yesterday that all the major components of the industry -- private developers and contractors, labor unions and the city's bureaucracy -- had to share the blame.

title: New York City Scraps Plans For South Ferry Office Plaza
description: New York City officials and the developers of South Ferry Plaza have agreed to kill the unrealized six-year-old project, which was meant to embellish the harbor-front skyline with a new pinnacle, rejuvenate lower Manhattan's ferry terminals and add a substantial cultural dimension to downtown life.

title: No Headline
description: Television and radio news, listings and advertising, normally found in Weekend, ap- pear today on pages B12-13.

title: Charlotte L. Peskin
description: Charlotte L. Peskin, chairwoman and president of Polyplastex United, a producer of interiors for aircraft cabins, died on Tuesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 76 years old and lived in Tamarac, Fla.

title: Lintas Hires Creative Head; Levine, Huntley Loses Chief
description: IN an unexpected move, Lintas New York said yesterday that it had reorganized its creative department and hired Tony DeGregorio, who produced numerous award-winning campaigns at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, with the work for Subaru automobiles perhaps the best known.

title: Cost of Labor Peace; With New Wage Pact, Dinkins Risks More Criticism of Fiscal Management
description: In two weeks, Mayor David N. Dinkins is to unveil a financial plan that seems certain to summon painful memories of the bad old days of the 1970's. So what was he doing this week giving municipal workers a raise?

title: CHRONICLE
description: The former Paris Opera Ballet star SYLVIE GUILLEM is about to sign a guest contract with the American Ballet Theater. She is expected to join the company during its California tour in March and will then appear during its New York season in June.

title: Review/Jazz; Don Cherry Mixes Modes With Several Ensembles
description: Don Cherry kept the band Happy House on its toes on Wednesday night at the Spiral. Playing keyboards, singing and occasionally picking up the instrument he is known for, the trumpet, Mr. Cherry moved from tune to tune on whims, turning most selections into medleys; a meditative ballad segued to a light-hearted song, a quasi-Moroccan vamp, a bluesy shuffle and then a zigzagging, stop-start melody in the style of Ornette Coleman. Happy House (named after a Coleman composition) kept up with Mr. Cherry, latching on to each new melody within a few notes.

title: U.S. OFFERS TO FLY BAKER TO GENEVA TO TALK TO IRAQI
description: In the latest move on an increasingly muddled diplomatic exchange with Iraq, President Bush offered today to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Switzerland next week to meet with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz.

title: Chairman's Stake In CBS Buyback
description: WHEN the planned buyback of 44 percent of CBS stock at $190 a share is completed in late January, the company's chairman, Laurence A. Tisch, will have succeeded in keeping control of about 24.9 percent of the broadcaster's stock, while recovering about two-thirds of his investment in CBS.

title: Nonprofit Hospitals To Justify Exemptions
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Iraqi Minuet on Talks Drags On In a Struggle to Project the Best Image
description: In proposing a meeting in Switzerland next week between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, President Bush has effectively acknowledged that his original formula for diplomatic contacts with Baghdad was flawed and had to be changed.

title: Boy, 15, Is Accused Of Shooting Cabby
description: A 15-year-old boy was charged yesterday with the shooting of a Brooklyn gypsy-cab driver last month.

title: In Test of Federal Rail Law, U.S. Moves to Bar Engineer
description: For the first time, Federal regulators are moving to bar a locomotive engineer from operating a train anywhere in the country, saying he is unfit because of his safety record and alcohol abuse, both on and off the job.

title: Czech Conversion to a Free Market Brings the Expected Pain, and More
description: Vera Tejcakova is a 68-year-old pensioner with a taste for beer and a plucky attitude about the hardships certain to accompany Czechoslovakia's efforts to create a free-market economy.

title: Redesigned Lineup Works for Rangers
description: For the Rangers, the roster shake-up was radical and total. No ego was spared, no track record considered, and so, no line went unchanged.

title: Margaret Whiting Stylizes Songs From Several Eras
description: When Johnny Mercer, at the time the president of Capitol Records, presented Margaret Whiting with her signature song, "Moonlight in Vermont," in 1945, there were two words in the lyrics that she didn't understand.

title: What Democrats Owe Hong Kong
description: The 1990's have already distinguished them selves as the decade of democracy. Yet the British Government is preparing to deliver Hong Kong's 5.8 million people, without their consent, into the hands of one of the world's last totalitarian Communist regimes, the People's Republic of China.

title: Accounts
description: * Keyes Fibre Co., Norwalk, Conn., a subsidiary of Van Leer Packaging Worldwide of the Netherlands, to Gregory & Clyburne, Stamford, Conn., for its Chinet disposable tableware account. Billings are estimated at $3 million to $4 million. * Dairyland Greyhound Park, a racing track in Kenosha, Wis., to Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee, with a budget of $2 million to $3 million. * Jenny Craig Inc., San Diego, a weight-loss center franchise, to Devon Direct Marketing and Advertising, Philadelphia, for a direct-response account. Billings were not disclosed.

title: In Shift, Health Chief Lifts Ban on Visitors With the AIDS Virus
description: After two years of debate, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, has removed AIDS-virus infection from the list of sicknesses that can keep someone from entering the United States, Federal officials said today.

title: Bonn, Rejecting Protests, Will Send Jets to Turkey
description: Despite opposition protests, the first German military unit to be sent to a distant war zone since World War II will begin leaving for Turkey on Sunday, Government spokesmen said today.

title: American General's Travelers Stake
description: The American General Corporation, a Houston-based insurer, said it had acquired interests in the last three months in certain financial services companies, including the Travelers Corporation.

title: Robert L. Edgell, 68, Longtime Publisher Of Trade Magazines
description: Robert L. Edgell, retired chairman of Edgell Communications Inc., a publisher of business magazines and a producer of trade shows, died Tuesday in a fall from the balcony of his seventh-floor condominium in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 68 years old.

title: A Family Comes to an End at 'Fort Pitt'
description: Capt. Kevin O'Donoghue of the New York City Fire Department, whose father was a fireman before him, studied the wake for Engine Company 17 being held in Smitty's Seafood last night.

title: Gorbachev Predicts an Accord on Budget
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with leaders of the 15 Soviet republics today and said afterward that agreement on a federal budget was now within reach.

title: Albanians Still Stream Into Greece Though Athens Asks Them to Stop
description: Hundreds of Albanian political refugees continued to pour into Greece today, despite appeals from the Greek Government that they stop coming.

title: TROOPS MAY GET UNLICENSED DRUG
description: The Defense Department is planning to administer experimental drugs, which experts say include a botulism vaccine, to troops in the Persian Gulf.

title: Alcohol May Be Tied To Death of Girl, 15
description: The death of a 15-year-old Fair Lawn girl during a New Year's Day party at a neighbor's home may have been from alcohol poisoning, the police said.

title: Gators Reward Spurrier
description: Steve Spurrier, who led Florida to a 9-2 finish in his first season as coach at the Southeastern Conference school, was given a two-year contract extension yesterday that will expire after the 1997 season.

title: New Battle Looming as Democrats Reintroduce Civil Rights Measure
description: Portending a revival of one of the most divisive debates in the last Congressional session, House Democrats today reintroduced a civil rights bill significantly tougher than the one vetoed by President Bush on the ground that it would force employers to adopt quotas.

title: Arab Bus Kills Israeli and Driver is Slain
description: A bus driven by an Arab collided with a car and killed an Israeli woman today, and the bus driver was then shot dead by an Israeli near the Gaza Strip.

title: Job Figures Lift Yields on U.S. Issues
description: An unexpectedly small rise in the unemployment rate in December caused prices of all Treasury securities to plunge and yields to soar yesterday.

title: Mortgage Rates Down
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.56 percent this week, down from 9.68 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The rate matched the 9.56 percent level reached on Dec. 14, which had been the lowest since a 9.43 percent rate on April 10, 1987. Rates had peaked in 1990 at 10.67 percent in the week ended May 4. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.78 percent, down from 7.92 percent last week.

title: Nakasone Plays the Mediator And Causes Tension at Home
description: An unusual attempt by former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone to personally mediate a compromise in the Persian Gulf crisis has irritated and embarrassed the Japanese Government, which said today that it had "nothing whatsoever" to do with the initiative.

title: Indonesia Helped East Timor to Decolonize
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Thursday about an acquisition by Covenant Mutual misidentified Conning & Company. It is an investment company specializing in insurance.

title: Indian Museum Fund Appeal
description: A full-page advertisement will appear in four daily newspapers across the country on Monday beginning the fund- raising campaign to build the National Museum of the American Indian at the Smithsonian.

title: Up, Down; Up . . .
description: Reporters who want to cover the (possible) war in Arabia will have to do pushups galore for Pentagon physical-fitness testers or stay back at headquarters with the brass.

title: 5 Banks Denied Insurance
description: Federal regulators said today that they would not provide insurance to five Rhode Island banks whose operations were suspended this week by the state's Governor.

title: Rhoda Bacmeister, 97, An Expert on Children
description: Rhoda Bacmeister, an authority on early childhood education who directed nursery schools and wrote eight books about children, died on Wednesday at All Saints Catholic Nursing Home in Jacksonville, Fla. She was 97 years old and lived in Clemson, S.C.

title: Count of People Abroad Gives Massachusetts House Seat to Washington
description: A Census Bureau decision to include Federal workers living overseas in the final population count has cost Massachusetts a Congressional seat, according to an analysis of the state-by-state data.

title: Trump Gives Taj Mahal Data
description: The Taj Mahal Casino Resort, owned by Donald J. Trump, will lose money in the next four years but will generate enough cash to meet interest payments on its huge debt, according to documents submitted to state gambling regulators on Wednesday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At 85, EDMUND G. (PAT) BROWN might be the oldest new prosecutor ever. But the former Governor of California wasn't taking a new job when he was sworn in Thursday as a Deputy District Attorney in Los Angeles County. Rather, he took the oath so he could swear in KATHLEEN BROWN , his daughter, as the state Treasurer.

title: Jobs Being Lost Fastest Among Some Top Paid
description: Until two years ago Dan Clark, a computer systems analyst, could walk into virtually any of the booming high technology companies along Route 128 here and be offered a job.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chicago Title and Trust Co., Chicago, a trust services and insurance company, has filed with the California Department of Insurance to acquire two title insurers, Ticor Title Insurance Co. of California and Ticor Title Insurance Co., as well as other assets, from Westwood Equity Corp. The agreement between Chicago Title and Westwood Equity calls for a cash deal of $70 million subject to certain potential reductions and a promissory note due in 1995 for an initial principal amount of $15 million plus interest. * Compucom Systems Inc., Dallas, a microcomputer dealer that is acquiring Computer Factory Inc., Elmsford, N.Y., a microcomputer dealer, for $39 million, said it had received commitments from a group led by Gateway Associates L.P. for the subordinated debt portion of its acquisition financing. * Hanson P.L.C., London, a consumer products company, has bought the Canadian assets of Garant Inc., a maker of lawn and garden tools, for $13.7 million.

title: Allen's Closest Fans Bid Farewell to Coach
description: Friends, family and former players paid tribute to George Allen today in a two-hour memorial service that celebrated the football coach's life.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Luke Appling, the former major league shortstop, referred incorrectly in some copies to the Kansas City team he managed during part of the 1967 season. It was the Athletics, not the Royals.

title: Olajuwon Sidelined A Minimum of 3 Weeks
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the Rockets' high-scoring and high-rebounding center, was lost to Houston for at least three weeks after suffering a black eye, a bruised cheek, a bloody nose and a fracture of the bony structure supporting the right eyeball Thursday night.

title: Miami's McKyer Makes Sore Points With Chiefs
description: More than 13 months ago, when the Dolphins' weaknesses were becoming more glaring and Miami was beginning to fall out of the group of teams that would likely reach the National Football League playoffs, Don Shula stood on the field in Kansas City and heard something he has not forgotten.

title: Once a Brothel, Soon a Refuge For Prostitutes
description: Dr. Joyce I. Wallace first appeared in this column almost three years ago, seeking prostitutes to test them for AIDS in her van. She seemed a cool, dedicated scientist. She went on to do research impressive enough to present to AIDS conferences around the world.

title: Auf Wiedersehen, Trusty Little Road Companion
description: Erich Lehmann sees himself as a kind of keeper of the graveyard. He goes about it with required dignity and reverence and adherence to the principle that nothing but good should be uttered about the deceased.

title: Bernard Amsterdam, Heart Researcher, 86
description: Dr. Bernard Amsterdam, a Manhattan internist who conducted research into the relationship between diet and heart disease, died on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patriots' Coach Pays After a 1-15 Season
description: Rod Rust was dismissed today as coach of the New England Patriots after one season and one victory.

title: Woman, 21, Is Charged With Killing Her Baby
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn woman was arrested last night and charged with murdering her badly bruised 19-month-old son, the police said.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
description: Seeking to avoid a divisive battle with Israel's supporters in Congress at a critical juncture in the Persian Gulf crisis, the Bush Administration said today that it was postponing the second part of a large arms sale to Saudi Arabia, valued at about $13 billion, until the crisis ends.

title: Plan but Rehabilitate
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the daily stock trading misstated the year in which the Commodity Research Bureau index reached its previous low. It was 1987, not 1977.

title: Giovanni Michelucci, Architect, 99
description: Giovanni Michelucci, considered the father of modern Italian architecture, died on Monday, two days before his 100th birthday.

title: Britain Says Computer Theft Wasn't Work of Iraqi Agents
description: The Defense Ministry said today that a laptop computer containing military secrets was stolen from a Royal Air Force staff officer's car by ordinary thieves and not by Iraqi agents.

title: Dorothy White, Nursing Professor, 67
description: Dorothy Wite, a professor at the Hunter-Bellevue Nursing School of the City University of New York, died last Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Adm. George Burkley Dies at 88; Was Doctor for Three Presidents
description: Vice Adm. George G. Burkley, retired, a doctor to three Presidents, died Wednesday at Nazareth House, a nursing home in Los Angeles. He was 88 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Donald D. Ashley, Advertising Executive, 53
description: Donald Desmond Ashley, an advertising executive, died Wednesday at John Muir Hospital in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 53 years old and lived in Moraga, Calif.

title: Woman Who Touched Off Boycott Describes Attack
description: Telling her story in court for the first time, the woman who touched off the black boycott of two Korean-owned grocery stores in Brooklyn testified yesterday that she was slapped, punched and kicked when she tried to leave one of the stores last Jan. 18.

title: Ferment in the Think Tanks: Learning to Live With No Global Threat
description: I first noticed the change last spring. Foreign policy arguments abruptly shifted ground. Familiar people took unfamiliar positions. Mellifluous talkers fell silent. The issue of Communist power, the centerpiece of U.S. foreign policy debate for 45 years, was no longer of immediate concern. A change so momentous required more than a mere pause for breath.

title: Israel's 2 Main Museums Cut Back
description: With most tourists staying away from Israel because of the Persian Gulf crisis, the country's two major museums have had to lay off employees and cut back operations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTIAN BRANDO pleaded guilty yesterday to a single charge of voluntary manslaughter in the shooting death of Dag Drollet, the boyfriend of his half sister, CHEYENNE BRANDO . The son of MARLON BRANDO , Mr. Brando was arrested in May and charged with murder in Mr. Drollet's death.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: BUSH CALLS TALKS WITH IRAQ 'USEFUL'
description: President Bush said today that Iraq's acceptance of his offer for direct talks in Geneva next week was a "useful step," but he insisted that the meeting would be solely to inform the Iraqis that they have to get out of Kuwait or face war.

title: Detmer Has Surgery
description: The Heisman Trophy winner, Ty Detmer of Brigham Young, underwent surgery yesterday to repair one of the shoulders he separated in his school's Holiday Bowl loss to Texas A&M, the Cougar coach, LaVell Edwards, said in Provo, Utah.

title: BAGHDAD ACCEPTS U.S. OFFER TO MEET BAKER IN GENEVA
description: Iraq accepted the Bush Administration's offer tonight for a high-level meeting on Wednesday in Geneva, at which Iraq's Foreign Minister said he would press for "justice and fairness" for the Palestinian cause.

title: AMERICAN MAY CUT 4% OF ITS FLIGHTS
description: American Airlines announced yesterday that it might cancel about 4 percent of its flights by February to deal with cancellations caused by a higher than usual number of pilots calling in sick.

title: Syracuse Tells Its Lawyers To Look Into Accusations
description: Lawyers for Syracuse University will conduct an internal inquiry into allegations that the school's basketball program violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: Europe's Statement Urging a Total Pullout
description: Following is the text of a statement on the Persian Gulf crisis issued today at the end of a meeting of Foreign Ministers of the 12-nation European Community. It was put out in the name of Jacques Poos, Foreign Minister of Luxembourg, which currently holds the rotating presidency of the community.

title: JOBLESSNESS IN U.S. INCREASES TO 6.1%, HIGHEST SINCE 1987
description: The nation's labor market deteriorated further in December, the Government reported today, but the figures were markedly less gloomy than many people had expected.

title: Despite Tough Times, Gifts For the Neediest Are Rising
description: In the midst of layoffs and concern over a recession, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $3 million mark this week and continued to maintain a precarious lead over the amount raised in the same period in last year's appeal.

title: Key Rates
Brash Eagles Are Ready to Do Some Bruising
description: Brian Mitchell, the Washington Redskins' rookie reserve running back, was a quarterback at Southwest Louisiana, where he ran a run-and-shoot offense that was spiced with an option attack. He finished his career as the first player in collegiate history to pass for more than 5,000 yards and to rush for more than 3,000.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 27 about Karl H. Hinke, a Buffalo banking executive, referred incompletely to his association with the Mastercard credit card. As an executive vice president of Marine Midland Bank in Buffalo he joined with other bankers in New York, California and elsewhere to form the Interbank Card Association, which issued a credit card known as Master Charge. The card's name was later changed to Mastercard. Mr. Hinke, who later became chairman of Interbank, was not the sole creator of the credit card.

title: Revlon Settles Logisticon Suit
description: Revlon Inc. said today that it had settled a lawsuit against a software supplier that had disabled some of the cosmetics company's computers, in a case that called attention to the vulnerability of computerized corporate operations.

title: Testing a Race Horse On Muscle Efficiency
description: A doctor in Philadelphia received a patent this week on a system for testing the muscle efficiency of race horses. His method employs nuclear magnetic resonance technology.

title: How to Avoid Phone Tie-Ups
description: The next time your long-distance carrier fails, what should you do?

title: Bernard King Rises to a Special Spot
description: "Are there still heroes in sports?" asked the caller, who said he was taking a survey for some business organization. "Are there still people we can look up to, and admire, the way we once did Joe DiMaggio and Ted Williams?"

title: Battered on Taxes, Florio Warily Considers Higher Tolls
description: As Gov. Jim Florio considers requests for toll increases by the two largest public authorities in New Jersey, increasing attention is being focused on the state's dozens of public authorities, how they raise their money and how they spend it.

title: Fernandez Proposes Placing Warranties On Graduates in '92
description: Cars, hair dryers and a profusion of other American products carry warranties that promise they are free of defects. Now, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, wants to place warranties on the students his high schools turn out.

title: History Doesn't Aid Greek Land Claim
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Alleges Fixing of Prices On Infant Food
description: The nation's three top producers of infant formula have been accused of price fixing in a lawsuit filed by Florida state officials, and several other states may soon file similar lawsuits.

title: Lansford Injured
description: Severe ligament damage is not the sort of knee injury baseball players normally suffer playing the game, but Carney Lansford, the 33-year-old Oakland A's third baseman, was not playing baseball when he may have suffered just such damage to ligaments in his left knee on New Year's Eve.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sukova Reaches Semifinals

title: Fear Returns to Argentina
description: In April 1977, Gen. Carlos Guillermo Suarez Mason ordered my kidnapping in Buenos Aires. A few days ago, this man, the cruelest leader of the dirty war, was released from prison, pardoned by President Carlos Saul Menem. Argentina had obtained his extradition from the U.S., where he had lived as a fugitive. He had been accused of 43 murders and 24 kidnappings in which the kidnapped individuals had disappeared.

title: Yankees Sign Hughes
description: Last season, Keith Hughes became the 41st player to play for both the Yankees and the Mets. Now he is in position to become the first player to play for the Yankees a second time after having played for the Mets once.

title: Polish Assembly Accepts Premier
description: Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, a business executive backed by President Lech Walesa, won Parliament's approval as Prime Minister today and pledged to risk unpopular decisions to achieve a market economy.

title: Stronger Warnings for Medical-Device Wearers
description: Under a new Federal law, companies that make lifesaving medical devices like heart valves and pacemakers will soon have to keep track of patients and warn them directly, should a device develop a serious malfunction.

title: Papandreou Trial Date Is Set
description: The Greek Supreme Court announced today that March 11 would be the date for the trial of Andreas Papandreou, the Socialist former Prime Minister, and three of his former senior Cabinet ministers, on charges of involvement in a $200 million bank embezzlement scandal.

title: Salvador Rebels Now Assert U.S. Helicopter Fired at Them
description: Leftist rebels gave a new version today of the deaths of three American soldiers whose helicopter they shot down this week, saying they fired on the aircraft after its crew fired at them.

title: 12-Year-Old From China Captures The World Platform-Diving Title
description: Fu Mingxia, a 12-year-old diver from China, became the youngest world champion in the history of an aquatic event today when she rallied to take the women's platform-diving event at the world swimming championships.

title: BELIEFS
description: Three weeks ago, Bishop Edmond L. Browning met at the White House with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. The Bishop, who heads the Episcopal Church in the United States, was conveying to the President, an Episcopalian, the views of 18 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox leaders newly returned from talks with religious and government officials in the Middle East.

title: And in Western Sahara
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of Report by Iraq Accepting U.S. Plan
description: Following is the text of a report on Baghdad's acceptance of President Bush's proposal for talks in Switzerland, as broadcast on Iraqi Television today and provided and translated by the Iraqi Ministry of Information:

title: Record Drop in Orders to Factories
description: Factory orders for manufactured goods in November took their steepest one-month plunge on record, the Commerce Department said today in yet another report reflecting a weakening industrial sector.

title: Few Riches in Rags These Days
description: The rag trade is looking a bit frayed. Already battered by competition from low-cost imports, hundreds more American clothing makers were driven out of business last year by the weak economy and poor retail sales.

title: Allison Schaefer Weds John R. Strack on L.I.
description: Allison Mary Schaefer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Schaefer of Oceanside, L.I., was married at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church there yesterday to John Raymond Strack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Strack of Oceanside. The ceremony was performed by Bishop John R. McGann of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, a cousin of the bridegroom.

title: New York Newsday Is Sued For $1 Million by The News
description: The Daily News filed a $1 million lawsuit yesterday against the owners of New York Newsday and two independent home-delivery companies in Queens, asserting that its tabloid rival had "willfully induced" the distributors to begin delivering New York Newsday to subscribers of the struck newspaper.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would take an after-tax charge of $275 million in the fourth quarter, primarily as a result of the declining value of certain of its non-aluminum operations.

title: Cipe Pineles Burtin Is Dead at 82; First Woman in Art Directors Club
description: Cipe Pineles Burtin, who broke the sex barrier at the Art Directors Club of New York by becoming a member in 1943 and went on to become the first woman inducted into its Hall of Fame, died on Thursday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. She was 82 years old and lived in Stony Point, N.Y.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROSEANNE BARR plans to change her professional surname to Arnold, beginning next fall. "My wife has offered," said her husband, TOM ARNOLD . "I didn't ask her to do this. But as a tribute to her loving husband, she will call herself on the show next year Roseanne Arnold instead of Roseanne Barr."

title: Forbes Will End Publication of Egg Magazine in March
description: Egg, the magazine started by Malcolm Forbes just before his death last year, announced yesterday that it would cease publication with its March issue.

title: Matthew R. Perkins, Restaurant Founder, 79
description: Matthew R. Perkins, a co-founder of the Perkins Family Restaurants chain, died of heart disease Monday at Bethesda North Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Subway Agency Blames Old Error for Fatal Fire
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that the electrical explosion and fatal fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel last week had been caused by a mistake that a construction crew made laying track about 20 years ago.

title: The Labor Pacts: Go Back to the Table
description: If these were normal times, New York City's first three labor settlements would be acceptable. But the times are not normal. The city is struggling through an economic and fiscal emergency unlike anything it has experienced in over a decade. In the last year 50,000 jobs disappeared. Property values have declined by a third in some neighborhoods.
