The city's own budget deficit continues to grow and because the economy is so weak, the needs of New Yorkers, especially the poor, are growing too.

title: Legal Shifts in Mail Bombings
description: The man charged with the slaying of a Federal appeals judge and a civil rights lawyer in a series of mail bombings last winter will drop his motion asking that all Federal judges be disqualified from presiding at his trial.

title: A Tube Is Developed To Treat Glaucoma
description: A New York ophthalmologist and one of his patients have teamed up to invent what they describe as a more effective way to treat glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness.

title: 76ers Trade Gminski to Hornets
description: The Philadelphia 76ers traded Mike Gminski, a 31-year-old center who has been struggling with his shooting touch this season, to the Charlotte Hornets today for Armon Gilliam and Dave Hoppen.

title: On 2d Try, Bush Is Likely to Pick Agriculture Chief to Head G.O.P.
description: After a search fraught with political embarrassment, Administration officials and party strategists said today that President Bush was expected to choose Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter for the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee.

title: Tribune Suspends Publication
description: The New York City Tribune, a Monday-through-Friday newspaper founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in 1976, suspended publication yesterday. The paper's paid circulation, which reached a peak of 400,000 during the newspaper strike of 1978, had dwindled to 12,000, said Thomas D. Zumbo, the associate editor. News World Communications, which owns The Tribune, described the suspension as a temporary "rest" forced by a poor economy.

title: How to Protect Family Business
description: People who own a business and hope their sons or daughters will carry it on should visit their lawyers soon unless they have done so recently. The reason: the tax law and Deficit Reduction Act passed just before Halloween last year makes it necessary to draw up new plans for the eventual transfer of the business to the next generation with as small a tax bite as possible.

title: Holiday Symbols
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany's Budget Timing Is Way Off
description: In 1987, the New York State budget was adopted 10 days late. One month later, we enjoyed a $900 million surplus. The 1988 budget was late again, but a month later the state faced a $900 million shortfall that grew to a $1.9 billion deficit. In 1989, the budget was 18 days late. By fall, another deficit was developing that ultimately reached $2 billion.

title: Estrogen's Health Benefits Exceed Risk of Cancer, Researchers Find
description: Older women who take estrogen tend to live longer than other postmenopausal women, suggesting that the hormone's ability to prevent heart disease outweighs its risk of causing cancer, scientists say.

title: Bank of New England Sees Loss, Pushing It to the Brink of Failure
description: The Bank of New England Corporation, the most troubled of the nation's large banking companies, moved to the brink of collapse yesterday when it announced that it expected a large fourth-quarter loss, leaving it with no funds to absorb future loan losses.

title: Dumars Leads Pistons to 5th Victory in Row
description: Joe Dumars scored 7 of his 25 points in the final 27.4 seconds, including a tiebreaking 2-point play, as the Detroit Pistons beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 98-94, tonight for their fifth consecutive victory.

title: Susan Lachapelle, A Model, Is Wed
description: Susan Hudson Lachapelle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cleo E. Lachapelle of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday in New York to Dr. Giovanni Marie Ropolo, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Umberto Ropolo of Turin and San Remo, Italy. Msgr. George Bardes and the Rev. Howard C. Olsen performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More.

title: Germans Cut Drug Prices
description: Pharmaceutical companies in western Germany agreed today to pay hefty subsidies so that drugs may be sold at discount prices in the former East Germany, a Cabinet minister said today.

title: Surgery for Seikaly
description: The Miami Heat suffered a similar, but expected, loss yesterday when the team's center, Rony Seikaly, underwent surgery to repair damage to his right knee caused when he was injured in a game on Dec. 27. He will be out for three to four weeks. (AP)

title: News Box Gives Change
description: A battery-operated news rack developed by USA Today will accept dollar bills and give change, the newspaper said this week.

title: Europe Offers Plan to Encourage Iraq's Withdrawal From Kuwait
description: In a move to encourage Iraq to pull its troops out of Kuwait, the 12-nation European Community promised Baghdad today that it would work to resolve all problems of the Middle East if the gulf crisis could be settled peacefully.

title: 2 Senators Deny Impropriety In Dealings With Keating
description: In the first public questioning by the Senate Ethics Committee, Senators John McCain and John Glenn described their links to Charles H. Keating Jr. today, but they insisted that they did no special favors for the savings and loan executive.

title: John C. Oxtoby, 80, Mathematics Professor
description: John C. Oxtoby, professor emeritus of mathematics at Bryn Mawr College in Pennsylvania, died Wednesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: Senate Prepares for a Gulf Debate Soon After Baker Meets With Aziz
description: The Senate today put itself in position to debate legislation concerning war in the Persian Gulf as early as Thursday, the day after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is scheduled to meet with Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister.

title: Health Funds Led the Way Last Year
description: The winning mutual funds in 1990 either put their money in health stocks or sent it abroad, to be invested in foreign bonds. The losers held a wide variety of investments, including "junk bonds" and shares in small gold-mining companies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We're willing to guarantee our product." -- Joseph A. Fernandez, the New York City Schools Chancellor. [ 1:1. ]

title: Arthur F. Rense, Public Relations Executive, 74
description: Arthur F. Rense, a retired public relations executive, died on Dec. 28 at his home in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 74 years old.

title: Best Products Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
description: The Best Products Company, a retailer whose shoppers buy from catalogues at stores famed for their bold architecture, sought refuge yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Carlos Duran, Boxer, 54
description: Carlos Duran, a former European boxing champion and the father of a reigning world champion, died on Wednesday of injuries suffered in a car crash. He was 54 years old.

title: A.T.&T. Cable Severed, Snarling New York Long-Distance Calling
description: A main telephone link connecting New York City and Newark to the rest of the world was severed yesterday morning when an American Telephone and Telegraph Company crew in Newark accidentally broke a fiber-optic telephone cable the thickness of a thumb.

title: Parts of the Ohio River Recede After Flooding
description: Trees and telephone poles poked out from receding water along some stretches of the Ohio River today, and residents began assessing the damage wrought by weeklong flooding.

title: Stocks Drop for 3d Consecutive Day
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday for the third day in a row as growing concern over the economy outweighed sentiment that war was beginning to look less likely.

title: Toll Is Rising In Shootings By the Police In New York
description: After almost 20 years of decline, the number of people shot by New York City police officers has climbed in the last three years, propelled in large part by a rising number of killings, shootings and other violent crimes in the city, law-enforcement experts say.

title: Cole Porter Sung Softly For His Centennial
description: This year being the centennial of Cole Porter's birth, a deluge of tributes to the most elegant of American pop songwriters has already begun.

title: Hungary Sets a 15% Devaluation of Forint
description: The Hungarian Government announced today a 15 percent devaluation of its currency, the forint, against convertible currencies effective Monday. The forint, now officially fixed at 60.7 to the dollar, will drop to 69.8.

title: Bridge
description: In duplicate play, scores of 670 and 730, for making a doubled part-score when vulnerable, are slightly more frequent than 470 and 530, the non-vulnerable equivalents. The reason is that there is a strong temptation to double a vulnerable opponent, in the hope of a one-trick defeat and a 200-penalty which will be better than any part-score results. And such close doubles often backfire.

title: LTV Names New Chief
description: The LTV Corporation, the Dallas-based steel and aerospace company that began 1991 in its fifth year of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, yesterday named David H. Hoag its president and chief executive.

title: Arts Endowment Reverses a Stand
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has approved grants to two performance artists, Karen Finley and Holly Hughes, whose work includes strong sexual content and who were denied Federal funds last year.

title: With Placing Stereo Speakers
description: The sound you hear from your stereo does not just depend on your components. It also depends on your room and how your speakers are set up in it.

title: How to Bargain With a Blackmailer
description: President Bush's willingness to be flexible about dates for a meeting with Iraq has now been rewarded by a positive Iraqi response. But the talks set for Wednesday in Geneva between Secretary of State Baker and Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, will not be worth much if both men treat them only as a public relations prelude to war. With more than a million soldiers mobilized at the front, it is none too soon for both sides truly to walk the last mile for peace.

title: Rosalind W. Alcott, Investment Banker, 105
description: Rosalind W. Alcott, a retired investment banker, died Dec. 28 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 105 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Dec. 28 misstated the position being assumed by Jack M. Cooper at the Seagram Company. He will be vice president and chief information officer.

title: 2 More Indictments Charge Corruption In South Carolina
description: The second-ranking lawmaker in the South Carolina House and a highway commissioner were indicted today, bringing to 13 the number of state officials charged by a Federal grand jury that since last summer has been investigating corruption exposed by an F.B.I. undercover operation.

title: Vehicle Sales Fell 5.1% in 1990
description: United States vehicle sales closed the year on a downbeat amid widespread expectations that the automotive industry's slump will probably continue well into 1991. Total sales in 1990 were the lowest since 1983.

title: Albanians in Greece Vow No Return
description: The Albanians who have fled to Greece over the last few days are living in harsh conditions in a camp here near the Greek-Albanian border, but they describe the squalor in their first Greek refuge as a newfound paradise.

title: The Safety Net for Securities Holders
description: How safe is your money?

title: Music Before 1800
description: Music by Renaissance and Baroque composers is to be included in a Festival of Lessons and Carols in the Music Before 1800 series at 4 P.M. tomorrow at Corpus Christi Church, 525 West 121st Street in Manhattan. The composers included on the program are Henry du Mont, Etienne Moulinie, Guillaume Bouzignac, Marc-Antoine Charpentier, Josquin Desprez and Jacques Arcadelt. The performers are the Choir of Corpus Christi Church, a seven-voice ensemble directed by Louise Basbas and accompanied by Louis Bagger, an organist, and Margaret Panofsky, on the viola da gamba. Admission is free. Information: (212) 666-0675.

title: Arun Rao, Executive, 39
description: Arun Rao, chief financial officer of Coach Leatherware, died on Thursday at his home in Hillsdale, N.J. He was 39 years old.

title: 2 in Congress Plan New Bill To Govern Cable TV Costs
description: In the latest attempt to re-regulate the cable televison industry, two members of Congress from Connecticut said today that they would introduce legislation to give state and local governments wide latitude to control prices charged by local cable systems.

title: What New York Needs Is a Great Green Way Along the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Weather Could Force Giants to Hit the Road
description: The Giants may be going on the road sooner than expected.

title: Avoiding a Blackout
description: Anyone who plugs a VCR, stereo set, food processor and coffeemaker into the same electrical receptacle could end up in the dark. Apart from major kitchen appliances, which usually have their own circuits (and fuses or circuit breakers), the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers recommends this rule of thumb: Each 15-ampere circuit should be able to run appliances with a total wattage of 1,500 to 1,600 watts. Generally, appliances that produce heat -- irons and hair dryers, for example -- use a lot of energy and should be plugged into separate circuits. Here is a list of household appliances and their typical wattages. Appliance Watts Blow dryer 1,400 Steam iron 1,200 Coffeemaker, 8 cups 975 Microwave oven, 0.9 cubic feet 700 Dishwasher 500 Food processor 300 Stereo receiver, 60 watts 245 Personal computer 150 20-inch color television set 70 VCR 19 Clock radio 0.5

title: E. A. Voyer Wed To Miss Laurent
description: Dominique Anne Laurent, the daughter of Arlette Laurent of New York and Andre Laurent of Brussels, was married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York to Edmund Allen Voyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Voyer 3d of South Orange, N.J. The Rev. Thomas B. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: Robinson Wins the Duel And Spurs Win the Game
description: There was a bit too much David Robinson and not quite enough of Derrick Coleman for the Nets tonight.

title: Woman in Abuse Case Agrees to Birth Control
description: A mother who pleaded guilty to child abuse has agreed to have a birth control device implanted under her arm as part of probation sentence.

title: C. Donald Kuntze, 68, A Retired Obstetrician
description: Dr. C. Donald Kuntze, an obstetrician and a former dean of admissions for New York Medical College, died on Tuesday at his home in Cohoes, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: Painful Memory
description: The Eagles joked about the Redskins' needing stretchers after Philadelphia punished Washington in a 28-14 victory on Nov. 12 at Veterans Stadium. Nine Redskins left the game with an assortment of injuries, most of them dispensed by the Eagles' dominating defense: Jeff Rutledge, qb (thumb). Stan Humphries, qb (knee). Darrell Green, cb (calf). Joe Howard, wr (concussion). Greg Manusky, lb (knee). Ralf Mojsiejenko, p (ankle). Walter Stanley, wr (knee). Gerald Riggs, rb (foot). Ed Simmons, ot (knee).

title: T. M. McDonnell, Wall St. Broker, 68; Led Family Concern
description: T. Murray McDonnell, chairman of McDonnell & Company from 1951 until the Wall Street brokerage house went out of business in 1970, died on Tuesday at his home in Peapack, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: Going Easy on Energy
description: The likelihood of war and the fact of recession, both heavily tainted with Mideast oil, demonstrate the need for President Bush to lead the country toward energy independence.

title: Madonna Refutes Rabbi's Accusation Of Anti-Semitism in a Song Lyric
description: A charge that Madonna insulted Jews by using a Bible reference to a "synagogue of Satan" in a re-mix of her single "Justify My Love" seemed resolved today with her quick denial of anti-Semitic intentions.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Figures in Arts Dispute Receive Endowment Grants

title: N.C.A.A. Reforms: Barely Eligible
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, prodded by growing public awareness of corruption in college sports, is billing its annual meeting as the "reform convention." But the meeting, which starts tomorrow in Nashville, Tenn., will probably be mean more business as usual.

title: Back Spasms Force Trevino To Pull Out of Tournament
description: Just as he was embarking on a new year of domination on the Senior PGA Tour, a pulled back muscle forced Lee Trevino to withdraw from the Tournament of Champions at the La Costa Resort Hotel and Spa today before the second round.

title: The Whiting Business
description: Among New York City's veteran cabaret divas, Margaret Whiting has one of the most resilient voices and heartiest senses of humor. Her new act at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza), a club she has not played before, is filled with amusing bits of business that complement her strong, heartfelt singing.

title: Money Managers Fell Behind the Indexes in 1990
description: Private money managers performed even worse than the broad market indexes last year. The year ended with Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks falling 6.6 percent (before dividends) and the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 4.3 percent, the worst performance since 1981. Most money managers would have done better last year if they had bought Treasury bills.

title: Unions' Pay Raises Won't Worsen Budget Gaps, Dinkins Says
description: Defending a 5 percent raise in wages and benefits for city workers in the face of a daily drumbeat of bad news about budget cuts, Mayor David N. Dinkins insisted yesterday that the raise would not worsen growing budget gaps and complained that news reports had distorted its impact.

title: A Concerto That Liszt Allowed to Languish
description: The blockbuster on Thursday evening's New York Philharmonic program at Avery Fisher Hall, which is to be played for the third and last time tonight at 8, is a Zubin Mehta speciality, Bruckner's massive Seventh Symphony. But the news item was the New York premiere of Liszt's recently discovered Piano Concerto in E flat.

title: Brace Took Up Bad Science in Good Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: The Soul Is the Subject in 'Eros'
description: The stark world of Butoh met lush new-age spiritualism on Thursday night at the La Mama Annex in a performance of "Eros," conceived by Maureen Fleming, and choreographed and performed by Ms. Fleming and Yoshito Ohno. Mr. Ohno was an early student of Tatsumi Hijikata, a founder of the experimentalist theater-dance form known as Butoh. He is also the son of Kazuo Ohno, who is known for his improvisational Butoh performing and whose students include Ms. Fleming, a New York-based performance artist. But there was little of the vivid madness of Kazuo Ohno's art here, or the stripped, dark look of much of the Butoh that has been presented in New York City.

title: Alberta Masiello, An Opera Coach And Panelist, 75
description: Alberta Masiello, a longtime singers' coach at the Metropolitan Opera and a regular panelist in the Saturday afternoon Metropolitan Opera Quiz, died on Christmas Day at her Manhattan apartment. She was 75 years old.

title: Two Insurers In Settlement
description: Two leading insurance companies agreed on Thursday to pay $750,000 each and testify in an antitrust lawsuit against some of the nation's largest insurers.

title: Tangled Phones and Flights As Cable and Tempers Snap
description: An Illinois woman had breakfast for lunch en route to New York yesterday because a telephone cable broke in New Jersey.

title: Brooklyn Officer Shot As Drug Bust Goes Bad
description: A police officer from the Brooklyn South Tactical Narcotics Team taking part in an undercover drug buy was shot once in the leg last night while stuggling with a suspect on a stairway, the police said.

title: Device Said To Provide Nausea Relief
description: For people who need relief from nausea but do not want to use drugs, a physical therapist in California has patented a device that combines the ancient Chinese practice of acupuncture with modern electronics.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Prosecutors Seek to Ban Doctor's Suicide Device
description: The matter of Dr. Jack Kevorkian and the device he built to help terminally ill people kill themselves returned to the courtroom today as the county prosecutors who failed to make a criminal case against him now try to have his device declared illegal.

title: Panel Recommends a 4-Cent Rise in Postage Rate
description: The Postal Rate Commission today unanimously recommended a 4-cent increase, to 29 cents, in the cost of mailing a first-class letter. The increase would be a penny less than that proposed last March by the Postal Service.

title: A Skeptic's Challenge To 'American Ideology'
description: Declarations of Independence Cross-Examining American Ideology By Howard Zinn 341 pages. HarperCollins . $25.

title: Preparing for a Grim Job of War: Bringing Home the Fallen
description: The military units trained to handle the bodies of soldiers killed in combat are a low-key group of men and women. Identifying and handling dead soldiers is an inevitability of war, they say. And though it is their job, they prefer not to dwell on it.

title: U.S. Switches Radiation Studies to Health Agency
description: After years of criticism from scientists and members of Congress, the Department of Energy said today that it was transferring to the Department of Health and Human Services its nationwide program for studying the effects of radiation on 600,000 Americans who have worked in the nuclear weapons industry.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Pitt Loses Center
description: Returning to action too soon after an operation to stitch up a finger cut during a game last month may keep the University of Pittsburgh center Bobby Martin out as long as a month.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: NIGHT STUDIO: A Memoir of Philip Guston, by Musa Mayer. (Penguin, $11.95.) The daughter of the artist Philip Guston, a contemporary of Pollock, de Kooning and Rothko, describes the difficulties of living with a famous and sometimes neglectful man. "As much an autobiography as a memoir of her father, 'Night Studio' is a rich study in father-daughter relations," Jill Johnston said here in 1988.

title: School Finance: It's a Jungle
description: In the world of school finance, these are unsettling times. From Texas to Mississippi to Illinois to Nebraska, states are struggling mightily to repair or reconfigure finance plans that are being challenged by parents and school districts or have already been struck down by courts as unconstitutional.

title: Wall Street; Shards of Gold Emerge Amid the Junk
description: "Cinderella Meets Godzilla" would just about sum up the "junk bond" market over the past few months. The fairy tale endings were reserved for investors whose bonds were on the short list of issues upgraded by one of the major credit-rating agencies. Happiest ever after were the investors in Knoll International, the office furniture supplier whose bonds were transformed into blue chips after Westinghouse Electric bought the company last fall.

title: 'Golden Arches' Not Yet Approved
description: As a member of the law firm representing the McDonald's Corporation, I wish to correct any confusion that may have occurred as a result of the article "Southold Approves McDonald's." While the article accurately reflected the approval process, the headline did not, since various departments and agencies of the Town of Southold have not yet completed their review of the application, and no public hearing has been conducted.

title: All About/Silver; With the Price Right, the White Metal Heads for a Rebound
description: When the price of silver reached a momentary peak of $48.70 an ounce during the Hunt brothers' buying spree a decade ago, and averaged out in 1980 at a stratospheric $20-plus, manufacturers abandoned the precious metal in droves.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: United Parcel Service and its pilots union resume talks on a contract that expired July 31. * USX and the United Steelworkers resume contract talks. TUESDAY: Consumer credit for November. * Resolution Funding Corporation bond auction. * S.E.C. chairman Breeden reports to the Senate on the condition of the securities industry. WEDNESDAY: Microsoft announces an enhanced version of its Excel spreadsheet to work with its Windows operating system. THURSDAY: Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas through Sunday. * Weekly jobless claims. * Wholesale trade for November. * Treasury auction of 52-week bills. FRIDAY: Producer prices for December. * Housing completions for November.

title: Movie Memories for Sale
description: WHEN my mother visited Hollywood in the early 40's, Errol Flynn gave her a look in a nightclub -- not just any look, the once-over. Big stuff! By the time I went out there, 30 years later, it was a less compact village of stars. Nobody famous gave me the once-over, though I did see Mel Brooks eating a cantaloupe at a diner. For real thrills, indulgent relatives took me to the memorabilia shops on Hollywood Boulevard, there to search out my idols. Small stuff, but not much else was left of the old days.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: As new catalogues come in, discard the old ones, but save those that have plant growing instructions. Check windowsills for drafts and remove house plants if the window seal is not tight.

title: An Eve When They Danced All Night
description: It was New Year's Eve in New York, and Tommy Tune and a dozen Rockettes from Radio City Music Hall performed at the Rainbow Room in a glittery Busby Berkeley extravaganza that included a midnight conga line. In Central Park, nearly 5,000 costumed runners turned out, and at Lincoln Center, Zubin Mehta led the New York Philharmonic in a special concert, followed by a supper sponsored by the evening's underwriter, Martell Cognac. Francis Dolard, Martell's general manager in the United States, presented awards to Betty Allen, Henry Z. Steinway and Mr. Mehta in recognition of their commitment to classical music.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Secretary Baker will restate, in person, a message for Saddam Hussein: Withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally and immediately, or face the terrible consequences." -- President Bush. [ 1:6. ]

title: Gardening; A Few Predictions For The New Year
description: The beginning of another garden year usually starts with an emphasis on what is new. Offerings provided by the colorful mail-order catalogues abound. And the response is a quick read of these catalogues to make early decisions and mail orders promptly to be sure of getting first choices before supplies run out.

title: Travel Advisory; Bhutan Plans To Double Tourist Visas
description: The Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan plans to gradually double the number of tourists granted entry -- to 4,000 a year -- and this year the country will reduce the rates it charges tour operators by an average of about 13 percent.

title: Data Bank/January 6, 1991
Redskins Move On by Stifling the Eagles
description: Joe Gibbs had made a pact with his players, and the Washington Redskins wanted to fulfill their side of the bargain in their playoff showdown here today with the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Reviving 'the Little Nothing Dress'
description: If designers and retailers have their way, 1991 will go down in fashion history as the year of the dress. At every level from haute couture to sportswear, dresses have added freshness to collections for resort and spring.

title: McGwire to Play
description: With a significant number of college presidents on hand and a number of significant issues on tap, the National Collegiate Athletic Association will open its annual meeting in Nashville tomorrow. Yesterday, though, the association's legislative services committee was in a quick huddle over an issue involving a 6-foot-8-inch quarterback, and that issue for the moment was dwarfing the more important matters.

title: Super Bowl 25: The Football Hoopla Yields to Hype
description: When the Super Bowl breaks for half time three weeks from today, Walt Disney World and Coca-Cola will take the field with a 12-minute show featuring New Kids on the Block, the teen-age pop group, and thousands of singing and dancing children. Throughout the game, television viewers will be bombarded with 28 minutes of network commercials, bringing ABC about $45 million in revenues. And when the game ends, the most valuable player will be given a Buick, part of a frenzy of product tie-ins involving everything from computers to beer.

title: America's Duty to New York; Fighting for Fairness: I
description: New York City is staggering because of tax dollars lost to the recession, which no one can control, but also because of massive Federal unfairness, which Congress can control. America calls on New York and its other largest cities to serve as the nation's poorhouse, but so far the rest of the country refuses to pay its fair share.

title: Shortwave Radios
description: To the Editor: The temptation to try shortwave reception (Practical Traveler, Dec. 2) while airborne should be resisted. All receivers (shortwave, AM and FM) have oscillators in their circuitry that emit low-level radio signals. These signals could interfere with the on-board navigation and communication equipment. Many airlines will ask you not to use your set. Some others may even ask you to remove the batteries to preclude an accidental turning on in your carry-on luggage. It is always wise to ask about your carrier's policy.

title: Style Makers; John Maizels, Art Magazine Editor
description: The French call it art offshore or art brut, and in English it is known as outsider art: works by unschooled visionaries, some of them patients in mental institutions, who know nothing of mainstream art.

title: Scores of Patients in State Await Organ Donations
description: WHEN 16-year-old Tony Fenton was diagnosed with advanced liver disease in 1988, his family was told that he needed a transplant to survive. Tony waited four and a half months at Yale-New Haven Hospital before he died. "We just never got a donor," said his mother, Jan Fenton, of New Canaan.

title: Learning By T-Shirt Design
description: T-SHIRTS, one of America's youthful fashion staples, will become a learning tool for toddlers and preschoolers if two adjunct instructors at the College of New Rochelle's Brooklyn campus have their way. They have designed an "Educational Garment" line of shirts printed with words like the days of the week, numbers or names of parts of the body, like the eyes and ears -- complete with illustrations and descriptions.

title:
ART;
Unusual Images in a Group Exhibition
description: "THE CONSTRUCTED IMAGE," currently on view in the Anthony Giordano Gallery at Dowling College in Oakdale, is a lively, busy exhibition that has considerable breadth.

title: Defeating Iraq Would Create Worse Problems; Oil Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: HELEN K. LIEBOWITZ;
Her Children Have Left but P.T.A. Goes On
description: LIKE many people, Helen K. Liebowitz joined her local Parent-Teacher Association when her oldest child began kindergarten. But instead of dropping out of the organization when her youngest graduated from high school, as most people do, Mrs. Liebowitz, a White Plains resident, decided to make even more of a commitment. In November she began a three-year term as president of the New York State P.T.A., a voluntary job that she said takes up to 60 hours a week.

title: Capturing The Roiling Russians
description: Discord, distress, the threat of dissolution. Such is the prevailing spirit in the Soviet Union today as vividly captured by "Soviets," the remarkably timely five-part series that begins on most PBS stations tonight. (WNET will carry it tomorrow through Thursday at 10 P.M.) Through striking photographs and probing interviews, Juris Podnieks, a Latvian director, conveys the misery, resistance and flickering hopes of people who are demanding much more than the Gorbachev reforms.

title: ...And of the Principles of Free Trade
description: To the Editor: It is curious that Bill Totten's book on Japanese-American relations is published only in Japanese. If he has some light to shed, why doesn't he publish it in English?

title: Subtitles That Aid Reading
description: CLOSED-CAPTION television, created a decade ago for hearing-impaired viewer, is increasingly being used to fight illiteracy. In elementary and high schools, adult reading programs and even prisons, educators have found that the captions, which appear on a TV screen much like subtitles in a foreign film, enhance reading skills of people struggling with reading or with English as a second language.

title: Audrey Unger Marries Keith Reich
description: Audrey Michelle Unger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Unger of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married last evening at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue to Keith Elliot Reich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour D. Reich of Great Neck. Rabbis Ephraim Wolf and Reeve Brenner and Cantor Eleazer Schulman officiated.

title: Military Contractors Struggle as Rules of the Game Change
description: A recent effort by the Navy and two of its largest contractors to save the troubled A-12 warplane is the clearest illustration yet of how policies intended for the arms buildup of the 1980's are haunting the military and its suppliers in an era of declining budgets.

title: The Lost Book Generation
description: ILLITERACY is primarily a problem of the third world. But it is the United States that appears to be leading the way in aliteracy -- the rejection of books by children and young adults who know how to read but choose not to.

title: Residential Resales

title:
FILM;
Hollywood's Hot Love: Politics
description: Almost from the moment Hollywood was invented as America's movie capital back in the 1920's, it has been infatuated with Washington. And the affection has been returned. In this article, Ronald Brownstein, a national political correspondent of The Los Angeles Times, explores the mutual fascination between the two power centers and explains how it has evolved over the years. The article is adapted from Mr. Brownstein's book "The Power and the Glitter: The Hollywood-Washington Connection," being published this month by Pantheon.

title: The Nation; A Hemmed-in Congress, Cranky From Gavel to Gavel
description: WHEN the 102d Congress convened last week, the usual heady talk of prospects for vital new initiatives was drowned out by grousing over what will never be accomplished thanks to the threat of war in the Persian Gulf and the budget constraints at home.

title: CRIME OVERWHELMS PRETORIA'S POLICE
description: Before dawn on Christmas Day, a gang of youths raided a Salvation Army home sheltering teen-age girls in the black township of Soweto.

title: Kean at Drew: Economics and Bikes
description: As the old saying goes, "A picture is worth a thousand words." While it was nice to read the article about former Governor Kean's commitment to Drew University, it was disappointing to see his lack of concern for education in another area, namely bicycle safety.

title: Striped Bass and the Big City
description: Having traveled the whole world in search of game fish, it still amazes me that the shortest fishing commute I have ever had is from my home in Cobble Hill in Brooklyn to the waters of New York Harbor. It's about a five-minute walk to the nearest pier and 10 minutes down to the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge, where, on an early winter's evening, I waited for my friends to take me on a fly-fishing excursion to the tidal flats between Ellis Island and the New Jersey shore.

title: Programs Starting '91 Offer Fare for All Ages
description: ALL kinds of musical events bring in this first full week of 1991.

title: THE BRADYS AND THE GUN LOBBY
description: Over the years, we have anguished over hundreds of our citizens taken hostage by various foreign powers, while, here at home, our entire populace has been held hostage by the National Rifle Association, as the article on the Bradys shows all too well. It astonishes me that an organization whose ostensible function is to defend the gun for "benign" sporting purposes (recreation and amusement) would block legislation to control its distribution to those whose intentions are a danger to us all. The N.R.A. (and those in its political pocket) thus must be held as responsible for crime in this country as the criminal element itself. JANICE L. GIUDICELLI Maplewood, N.J.

title: Replacing Shevardnadze: With Whom and With What?
description: ONE lesson of Marxism was meant to be that history is determined not so much by leaders as by the larger social and economic forces they seek to control. From Lenin and Stalin on, Soviet leaders have wrestled with this dilemma, none of them with more poignancy than President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Karen Gericke to Wed John Newhouse in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Karl Gericke of Chatham, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Karen Lisa Gericke and John Mark New house, a son of Mrs. Ross Newhouse of New York and the late Mr. New house.

title: After Release From Foster Care, Many Turn to Lives on the Streets
description: A large and disproportionate number of the nation's homeless are young people who have come out of foster care programs without the money, skills or family support to make it on their own.

title: Unacceptable And Disrespectful
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Oilers and Bears Take Their Second-Best Shot; Confident Carlson Fills in For Moon
description: After their 20-point victory over Pittsburgh last week, the Houston Oilers thought they were a team of destiny. If that is so, then Cody Carlson is the key in an amazing master plan.

title: The Cuning Ways of Trout
description: A FLY FISHERMAN'S BLUE RIDGE By Christopher Camuto. 238 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: HOPE IN HELL'S CLASSROOM
description: I don't know of any principals in New York City who do children's laundry (as Cartwright does), though some may do that, too. It is not uncommon, however, for principals and other supervisors to remain at school, sometimes until 5 P.M. or later, with a youngster whose parent has failed to pick up the child at the end of the school day; to escort a sick child to the hospital and remain until the child is in the care of a doctor; to provide clothing, food, counseling, weekend and summer vacations and myriad other services that would seem to belong to a surrogate parent rather than a school administrator. DONALD SINGER President, Council of Supervisors & Administrators New York, N.Y.

title: Commercial Property: City Leases; Financial District Slump Sets Up Some Good Deals
description: SIX-DIGIT deals have grown fewer and farther between in Manhattan's battered market, but the City of New York is still negotiating leases for 100,000 or 200,000 or 300,000 square feet and expects to do more while rents keep falling.

title: Lusty Dining Beyond Pizza and Pasta
description: SELDEN'S Cafe Stefano may look like yet another Italian cafe serving pizza and pasta, but this year-old sparkler soars to the top of its class.

title: Dr. Silvia Stambler to Wed
description: Drs. Salvador and Beatriz Stambler of Buenos Aires and Hollywood, Fla., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Silvia Stambler, and Andrew Stern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Stern of Chicago. Dr. Stambler, 32 years old, graduated from Brown University and received a D.D.S. degree from New York University. She is a dentist in private practice in Miami. Mr. Stern, 29, graduated from the University of Illinois. He is a certified public accountant and a vice president of J.C.C., a commodities brokerage in North Miami.

title: R.O.T.C. Doesn't Want You
description: THE Reserve Officers Training Corps, one of the best-financed Federal education programs in the 1980's and a rare source of scholarships for middle-class students ineligible for aid programs based on need, is shrinking in the 1990's.

title: Corrections
description: A map of Lebanon on Dec. 16 carried an erroneous scale. The scale line represented 20 miles, not 500.

title:
Your Own Account;
Teaching the Kids About Money
description: If you're a parent, put this resolution on your 1991 list: I will raise financially responsible kids.

title: The Upheavals in the Media
description: Though the media are confronted with a host of near-term problems, in general, they will continue to constitute a formidable institution in our lives. Over the course of the 20th century, the media have become the main integrators of our national culture. Older institutions like churches, social organizations, political parties and -- to a certain extent even the family -- have been replaced, at least in part, by the media. No other institution is poised to assume this role.

title: Hands-On Public Relations
description: STUDENTS at the School for Visual Arts in Manhattan faced a problem only the real world could provide: how to design a piece of junk mail people would actually read. Their solution: a brochure that presents composite case studies of people from different ethnic groups -- and below each, instant-lottery-type scratch-off boxes that explains which of the profiled cases is and is not affected by the new immigration laws.

title: Karen Faith Jacoby to Wed Richard Furst in May
description: Karen Faith Jacoby and Richard Philip Furst plan to marry in May. Ms. Jacoby is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. James Jacoby of Short Hills, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Furst of Huntington Station, L.I.

title: A March Bridal For Jane Russin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Russin of Dunmore, Pa., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Jane Ann Russin and Dr. Richard Jay Gersh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Gersh of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Cartography: The Limits of Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Vaiti to Wed Dr. David Moss
description: The engagement of Vanessa Louise Vaiti and Dr. David Barry Moss has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Stephen J. Zielinski of Shrewsbury, N.J., and Victor F. Vaiti of Allenhurst, N.J. Dr. Moss is a son of Dr. and Mrs. David I. Moss of Allenhurst and Edison, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Troubled Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: Joan Melvin Is a Bride
description: Joan Mary Melvin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Melvin of Southbury, Conn., was married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I., to Brian Peter Davey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Davey of Yonkers. The Rev. James P. Swiader officiated. The bride, 25 years old, is a broker at Euro Brokers Capital Markets in New York. She graduated from Fairfield University. The bridegroom, 25, is an accountant with Leipziger & Breskin in New York. A graduate of Villanova University, he is studying for a master's degree in taxation at Fordham University.

title: Corporations Pitch In to Aid Communities
description: FROM the glass-framed boardrooms of Newark to the flower-bedecked bridges of New Brunswick, corporate leaders are playing larger roles in improving the communities they serve. They call this responsibility and say they are learning to care.

title: Spanish Cities Where Sherry Rules
description: THE Spanish cities of Jerez, Puerto de Santa Maria and Sanlucar de Barrameda make most of the world's sherry, but there is plenty to do in these small cities besides drink wine, and plenty to see as well. Tropical and Baroque in ambiance, they are filled with grand avenues, palm trees and remnants of the successive cultures that passed through this part of Andalusia. To get into the proper spirit of the place, however, a bodega is a good place to start.

title: Fire Forces Evacuation of 400 From Penn Station
description: A smoky fire on the underground tracks of Pennsylvania Station last evening forced the evacuation of up to 400 people from the huge terminal and halted all train departures and arrivals for several hours.

title: Coslet Speaks His Mind
description: A week after his rookie season as a head coach ended with celebrating Jets acting as if they were headed for the playoffs, Bruce Coslet has no illusions about what took place in a 6-10 campaign. And he has definite ideas about where the Jets are headed.

title: Nets Fall After Fitch's Ejection
description: It was probably only a coincidence, the timing of the beginning of the inevitable end. But the Nets unraveled tonight after their coach made an early exit in a game against the Detroit Pistons at the Palace of Auburn Hills.

title: Jessica Sinnott To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Sinnott of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Michelle Sinnott, to William Joseph Cotreau, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Cotreau of Newburyport, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: About Men; Senior-Circuited
description: A FEW YEARS AGO when a friend turned 50, I took out a full-page ad in a newspaper in the city where he was working. It was merciless, reminding him he was now half a century old, that two-thirds of his lifetime had passed. At the time, I was in my late 40's and yet 50 seemed a distant number, so the fun was entirely at his expense. Ho, ho. Although he seemed to be impressed by my enterprise, he did not share the hilarity.

title: Candace Farrell Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Farrell of New York have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Candace Lee Farrell and Kevin John Daly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Daly of Los Angeles.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BRADOVICH. By William Herrick. (New Directions, $18.95.) In many ways, William Herrick's 10th novel conforms to the Pop Fiction Code. Stephen Bradovich, a craggy, widowed football player turned sculptor, lives in a city that purports to be New York but feels, with its cozy neighborliness and broad boulevards, like a dream. Here the hero is pursued by a supernaturally effective enemy called "The Authority." But instead of being the homage to Franz Kafka that the author clearly intended, the novel equally suggests Judith Krantz, featuring the sort of writing in which meals are described to the last crumb, yet logic evaporates at will. (Thwarted when he tries to book his escape at a travel agency or by phone, our hero never thinks simply to get in a bus, train or taxi, to rent a car or take himself directly to an airport.) Although it's a suspense novel, "Bradovich" is not intended to be commercial fiction; its dropped names are not those of brands beloved by Best-Selling Authors but those adored in our universities. And Mr. Herrick's pages are peppered with philosophizing about Life's Meaning and paeans to Great Art. So the really scary thing about this book is not the depredations capriciously wreaked by "The Authority," not the whipping, incest, bestiality, rape, mutilation and kinky sex that keep popping up, not death and its injustice, but rather the fact that New Directions, a house renowned for publishing writers like Jorge Luis Borges, Delmore Schwartz, Kay Boyle, Tennessee Williams and Jean Cocteau, is now offering thinking readers novels as meretricious as this one.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Winchester, Mass.;
Luxury Condos Selling Well
description: DESPITE the depressed housing market throughout the Northeast, a luxury condominium development in this commuter suburb eight miles north of Boston is selling well.

title: An Author I'd Walk the Plank For
description: During the late 1960's and early 70's I spent much of my time reading about wars, and the rest trying to keep out of one. I was in college then, and the war I wanted to avoid was, of course, Vietnam; I liked reading about any conflict remote enough to be harmless. I found particularly absorbing novels about the British Navy during the Napoleonic Wars when -- much as during the early days of World War II -- all Europe had fallen to a seemingly invincible conqueror against whom England fought on alone. In 1940 the Royal Air Force stood in the breach; in 1800, it was the "wooden walls," the fleet of Lord Nelson.

title: Baring Top Fashion Designers' Secrets
description: IT was Princess Yasmin Aga Khan's fifth and final fitting of the skin-tight silk taffeta gown she would wear to an Alzheimer's Foundation benefit.

title: Tax Change Altered Graduate Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Air Passes for Foreigners

title: Iraq Still Pressing for Talks Between Baker and Hussein
description: A senior Iraqi official said today that despite "negative" statements from the Bush Administration, the Iraqi leadership still believed that a meeting here between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and President Saddam Hussein should "not be excluded" from the final rounds of diplomacy in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: The Nation; Your Tired, Your Poor, Your Masses Yearning To Be With Relatives
description: THE term "push-pull" is a simple bit of shorthand used to explain why millions of people have undertaken the vast journeys of immigrants. Poverty pushes them. Economic opportunity pulls them.

title: Managing; Doing Business in Hard Times
description: Lawrence Caplan knew it was time to diversify when he noticed a decline in orders for poached salmon and a new appreciation for turkey sandwiches.

title: What Bush Might Learn From Hamlet
description: To the Editor:

title: Comparing Notes
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: Opening Next Week; Harlem Low-Rent Rehabs
description: Jason D. Carter, the developer of the high-priced Ritz Plaza apartment tower at 235 West 48th Street, has announced that the lower-priced apartments he has renovated in Harlem are to open next week. The rehabilitation will yield $20 million in tax exemptions for the Ritz Plaza. Altogether, there will be 129 units -- 87 studio apartments at 211 West 146th Street, 31 one- and two-bedroom apartments at 290-94 West 147th Street and 11 one- and two-bedroom apartments at 307 West 143d Street.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Some modern contraptions and the problems of etiquette that they pose.

title: Pressure Is Building to Relax Zoning
description: CONTROL is something that the Village of Munsey Park has almost always been able to maintain. Residents of the 800-home community are made to cross every "t" and dot every "i" in conformance with a Zoning Code that is considered the village bible.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE anger in the western sky diminished until heaven and earth were knit by a thin red scar. The neutral fog crept out of its hiding place, filling woodland hollows with murk and the air with the sour tang of oak leaves.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Week in Review last Sunday headed "It Isn't Just a Downturn, It's the Bill for the 1980's" discussed fears that structural weaknesses in the United States economy could contribute to a serious recession. The article ended with a description of what the country had learned about preventing such factors from leading to a depression.

title: Brains At Work
description: THE QUESTION itself seems audacious: Can the human brain understand what goes on inside itself? Can people, by thinking about thinking, discover what happens when they think? Although all -- or even most -- of the answers are not in, some researchers believe they are on their way to understanding thought.

title: Cynthia L. Ziegler Planning to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Ziegler of Alexandria, Va., have announced February wedding plans for their daughter Cynthia Lee Ziegler and Ethan Benjamin Charas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Ailloni-Charas of Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Families That Play Together, Stage Together
description: Is it an upscale marketing gimmick or could it be a useful shortcut to the kind of ensemble acting all performers aspire to achieve? After no less than three family reunions in the London theater recently, the evidence is still irritatingly inconclusive. No, casting sisters as sisters, or parent and child as parent and child, does not mean that the instinctive rapport of the playpen is magically re-established. Yes, it can amount to more than a high-cultural counterpart of those ads that bring together John Doe and his shiny brood in order to sell domestic togetherness and breakfast cereal.

title: They're Not as Grabby as We Think
description: JAPANESE TAKEOVERS The Global Contest for Corporate Control. By W. Carl Kester. 298 pp. Boston: Harvard Business School Press. $29.95.

title: Playoff Pressure For Instant Replay
description: Instant replay, a delight to some and a damnation to others, played a significant role at Veterans Stadium today. The process reversed an apparent touchdown play, a spectacular 88-yard run by the Eagles' Ben Smith, and cost the host team a needed 6 points and a likely lead of 13-7 over the Redskins in their playoff game.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on Dec. 23 about the resignation of Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Soviet Foreign Minister rendered a quotation from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev incorrectly. According to Izvestia, Mr. Gorbachev said, "And even after everything I said, I don't want us to decide now that Shevardnadze is 'written off' and, so to speak, goes off into history." The use of a partial quotation, "Shevardnadze is written off," distorted its meaning.

title: Text of the Radio Address by the President
description: Following is the text of the radio address by President Bush today, as issued by the White House:

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Fragile, Resonant Pieces of the Past Museums strive for perfection in their displays of art or artifacts, but Stephen J. Greenblatt says it's the ragged reality of the past that is most instructive. This is from "Learning to Curse: Essays in Early Modern Culture" (Routledge).

title: Madonna Placates Rabbi Over a Recording
description: A charge that the pop-music star Madonna insulted Jews by using a biblical reference to a "synagogue of Satan" in a version of her recording "Justify My Love" has apparently been resolved with her quick denial of anti-Semitic intentions.

title: Camera
description: It is time to clear up some hoary misconceptions. For example, a reader's letter came in the Christmas mail:

title: There's No Substitute for Parents
description: CHILDHOOD'S FUTURE By Richard Louv. 420 pp. Boston: A Marc Jaffe Book/Houghton Mifflin. $21.95.

title:
Style Makers;
Yelena Korenevskaya, Travel Editor
description: In a land where private initiative has been all but frozen since 1917, Yelena Korenevskaya is an enterprising powerhouse. As publisher of "Soviet Culture" she has puttogether an English-language magazine of travel information and political-social commentary that is distributed free by airlines, restaurants and travel agencies. Some diplomats and journalists in Moscow subscribe.

title: Lauren Berg Is Engaged
description: May wedding plans for Lauren Amy Berg and Richard Seth Meisner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Meisner of Dix Hills, L.I., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Roger A. Berg of Short Hills, N.J. Miss Berg, 25 years old, graduated from Carnegie Mellon University. She is an industrial designer for RPR Creative Marketing in Englewood, N.J. Mr. Meisner, 26, graduated from Cornell University. He is studying law at Rutgers University and is an M.B.A. candidate at New York University.

title: On the Street; Not Fur, Maybe, but Not Far From It
description: The lavish fur cuffs and collars that cuddled the fragile wrists and throats of the film queens of the 30's and 40's are turning up again, with a difference. Where once the furs were made from the rich pelts of exotic animals, the 90's look has been tailored to new sensibilities: the furs are now artfully made synthetics that mimic the deep pile of mink, beaver and nutria, or depict with photographic accuracy the distinctive markings of the leopard and its cousins. Tuxedo fronts and shawl collars provide a lot of fashion mileage for the money, with a bonus of practicality: they're lightweight, warm and weatherproof.

title: Too Oft, Fault Lies In the Stars
description: When Franco Zeffirelli's movie version of "Romeo and Juliet" opened in 1968, it burnished Shakespeare's good name and attracted viewers by the busload. This was documented by a New York Times reporter who interviewed a busload that had been shipped to a Manhattan theater from Peekskill Junior High. As one boy put it, "Shakespeare ain't dead when he can make pictures like that."

title: Businesses Profit by Job Illiteracy
description: By now, anyone unfamiliar with the budding literacy crisis in the American workplace is probably part of the problem. Time, money, equipment, personnel, all have been thrown at ailing schools and lagging students. And still, the bright spots of success remain isolated -- here, a high school with more graduates who attend college; there, a few more workers who can read instruction manuals.

title: A Yanomamo Romance
description: INTO THE HEART One Man's Pursuit of Love and Knowledge Among the Yanomama. By Kenneth Good with David Chanoff. Illustrated. 349 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Understanding For LaFontaine
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Reach Too Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy's Bullet-Scarred 70's Return
description: The news this November morning was not good:

title: Campus Life: Swarthmore; Topic Is Health: The Professor Is the President
description: For about a dozen Swarthmore College students this spring, the professor will also be the president.

title: Special Today: Education Life/Section 4A
description: A special report looks at new thoughts on thinking. There are also articles on shopping for a public school and how businesses profit by job illiteracy.

title: HOPE IN HELL'S CLASSROOM
description: Richard Louv's article "Hope in Hell's Classroom" (Nov. 25) gave me the same gift that Madeline Cart wright's work gives her school families -- a context for hopeful action. I am a parent of two young children who are growing up in rural New York, where they have the privilege of a safe and caring environment.

title: Little Movement, Except for Gold
Weighing Effect of the New Tax Laws
description: JOHN C. KELLY has developed an intimate understanding of a subject that most people would just as soon ignore: income taxes.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: WASSAIL PARTIES

title: Miss Grossman to Wed R. L. Reinhold
description: May wedding plans for Beth Stacey Grossman and Richard Lawrence Reinhold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Reinhold of Grand Island, N.Y., have been announced by her mother, Stephanie Grossman of Palo Alto, Calif.

title: A Summer Bridal For Ms. Mehlman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Mehlman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Mehlman, to Brian Scott Cousin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Cousin of Marblehead, Mass. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Devils Undone by Lapse in Second Period
description: The Devils, playing perhaps their most listless period of the season, suffered their third consecutive loss when the Pittsburgh Penguins scored four goals in the second period today and won, 5-2.

title: Headliners; Off the Shelf
description: Just when it was beginning to look as though the Republicans were running out of places to seek a new party leader, President Bush rummaged around his Cabinet once again and apparently came up with one. Administration officials and party strategists said last week that Mr. Bush would soon nominate Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter as Republican national chairman. Mr. Yeutter, who served as United States Trade Representative in the Reagan Administration, is not known as a particularly skilled political operator nor as a notable communicator of Republican views. But party leaders said he was looked upon as a safe choice for a post about which much controversy has swirled in recent months. William J. Bennett, Mr. Bush's first choice to replace Lee Atwater, who is suffering from a brain tumor, accepted and then declined the job for financial reasons. Before Mr. Yeutter's name came up, two other Bush Cabinet members were said to have asked that their names be taken out of the running.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Peace Corps Not for Novices
description: LIBERAL arts college students who count the Peace Corps among their postgraduate plansare discovering that it is not a sure bet: they must prepare for the program as carefully as they plan their careers.

title: Laparoscope-Tube Surgery Is Expanded
description: WHEN President Lyndon B. Johnson revealed a large scar from gallbladder surgery, he may have disclosed what to future generations may appear an artifact of the past, open abdominal surgery for routine problems.

title: Headliners; Keeping the Big Bang From Blowing Up
description: IN "Origins," a book of conversations with cosmologists recently published by Harvard University Press, Alan Lightman and Roberta Brawer end most of their interviews with a very hypothetical question: How would you have designed the universe? While many of the scientists were reluctant to play God, Dr. Maarten Schmidt of the California Institute of Technology, replied: "I would have constructed a bigger universe. I think the universe is small ."

title: CHILD OF THE MOVIES
description: JODIE FOSTER HAS ONLY ONE REGRET. IT CAME up one brutally hot day in August as she slouched in a chair in a warehouse in Cincinnati wearing a pair of blue gym shorts and a tank top. "The only thing I've ever regretted in my whole life," she said, stamping out a cigarette on the cement floor, "is that I started smoking." Seems remarkable. But there it is. She said it without a trace of exaggeration.

title: Alyzza Cohen Weds Ira Ozer in Miami
description: Alyzza Paulette Cohen, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert Sobel of Coral Gables, Fla., and the late Dr. Seymour Cohen, was married last evening at the Vizcaya estate in Miami to Ira Mathew Ozer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Ozer of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Mitchell Chevitz officiated.

title: Laili Radpour Is Wed To James Markert Jr.
description: Laili June Radpour, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Iraj Radpour of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married there yesterday to Dr. James McDowell Markert Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Markert of Wellesley Hills, Mass. The ceremony was performed under the auspices of the Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Hamilton County, Tenn.

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Chamber Recitals, Candlelight Concerts
description: CHAMBER music is today's prime focus. At 11:30 A.M., a restaurant in Storrs opens its doors to a new music series, "Chamber Music Brunch at Zenny's."

title: Travel Advisory; Puerto Rico On $14 a Night
description: An oceanview room at the Caribe Hilton and Casino in San Juan, P.R., cost $14 when the hotel was opened in 1950.

title: Remedying Indoor Condensation
description: SWEATING window panes, stained or mildewed walls and ceilings, peeling paint that exposes bare material underneath, not just earlier layers of finish. These are classic signs of indoor condensation, moisture in household air changing from vapor to liquid.

title: Heirloom-Worthy Jewelry for Children Is Revived
description: A growing sentimentality about heirlooms is lending support to fine jewelry for children, presumably those from families with money to spend but nothing in the vault.

title: Headliners; Easy Terms
description: The Heritage Loan and Investment Company in Providence, R.I., made $13 million in fraudulent loans last year and investigators are inclined to believe that the institution's president, Joseph Mollicone Jr., took the money and ran. The losses not only rocked little Heritage, which had just $22 million in deposits, but tested a private deposit insurance fund much the way a rock tests a spider web. The fund, which insures a third of Rhode Island depositors, was in danger of insolvency after a run on Heritage, and state officials last week froze deposits in other institutions covered by the fund. Despite a worldwide search, there has been no sign of Mr. Mollicone since his son dropped him off at Logan Airport in Boston on Nov. 8. Officials said that organized crime might have been involved in the scheme by which $13 million in loans were approved for 128 "borrowers" who later said they neither applied for nor received any of the money.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FLY-FISHING SCHOOL

title: Relax, It's Only Television
description: SIGN OFF By Jon Katz. 374 pp. New York: Bantam Books.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bronxville, N.Y. 730,000 26 Sunny Brae Place 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 64-year-old English stucco/stone; sunken living room, fireplace, new kitchen, breakfast room, sun room, marble bath, Jacuzzi; taxes $12,674. Mount Kisco, N.Y. 410,000 65 Cliffside Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; 2 fireplaces, sun room, deck, wet bar, eat-in kitchen, 2.1 acres; taxes $7,785. Rye, N.Y. 1.65 million 105 Evergreen Avenue 10-bedroom, 5 full- and 2 half-bath, 92-year-old Victorian; library, terrace, family room, new kitchen, 1.4 acres; taxes $10,649. Chester, Conn. 143,700 Brooks Lanecq 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new Cape Cod; dining room w/bay window, w/w carpeting, 1 acre; taxes to be determined. Deep River, Conn. 169,000 11 High Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 150-year-old, restored Federal colonial; wideboard floors, other antique touches, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,839. Westbrook, Conn. 130,000 1060 Essex Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 49-year-old Cape Cod; oversized 1-car detached garage w/ workshop, pool, 1.6 acres; taxes $1,200. OTHER AREAS Levittown, L.I. 150,000 119 Stonecutter Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 51-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, dining room, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Massapequa, L.I. 165,000 59 Arlyn Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,300. Glen Rock, N.J. 180,000 1 Oxford Place 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; deck, full basement; taxes $2,650.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CIRCE'S MOUNTAIN. By Marie Luise Kaschnitz. Translated by Lisel Mueller. (Milkweed Editions, Paper, $9.95.) Sixteen years after Marie Luise Kaschnitz's death at the age of 73, the fiction of this prolific German poet, novelist and essayist is beginning to be more widely available in English. "Circe's Mountain" contains a dozen short stories chosen by their competent translator, Lisel Mueller, to reflect the writer's versatility. Several are set in Italy, where Kaschnitz lived for many years, while the others are rooted in the Germany of World War II and the succeeding decades. Some are brief mood pieces, as piercing and insubstantial as a stranger's gaze, while others deal in the fantastic or tell conventional stories, albeit always allusively. Two stories, including the title one, are explicitly autobiographical widow's tales. In "The Landslide," a German couple, for no particular reason, postpone signing a long-term rental contract for an Italian villa that is fated to be demolished by a landslide. In "X Day," a German mother describes her vision of the day -- an ordinary day like any other -- when the world will finally be annihilated. In "Lupines," a timid young Jewish woman escapes from a Nazi deportation train, leaving behind her suddenly passive older sister. Although she finds a safe hiding place with the Aryan brother-in-law she loves, his resentment and her guilt ultimately drive her to suicide. In these stories, life is inevitably banal, unavoidably terrifying. One placid day succeeds another, but this placidity is misleading. Either the worst has already happened but is unacknowledged, chillingly engulfed by the daily rounds, or the worst is yet to come. Kaschnitz' voice is bleak, insistent and filled with integrity.

title: Headliners; Through the Ranks
description: In a break with tradition, the new Senate sergeant-at-arms, Martha Pope, plans to keep her hand in politics. With her election last week, Ms. Pope became the first woman to hold the Senate post, whose duties -- overseeing security, telephone and computer operations, among other things -- are considered nonpartisan and nonlegislative. (They can occasionally be physical, as when Ms. Pope's predecessor, a former police officer named Henry K. Giugni, bodily carried Republican Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon to the floor for quorum call.) But Ms. Pope comes to the Senate job after years as Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell's chief of staff and one of the most influential legislative aides in the Capitol -- she was known as an advocate of environmental legislation, in particular -- and she wants to continue to focus on such matters. "I don't want to feel that becoming sergeant-at-arms, I'm still not involved," she said. "I want to continue to work on specific, important issues that arise."

title: BUSH LEAVES OPEN TIMING OF ASSAULT ON IRAQ'S FORCES
description: President Bush said today that American military action against Iraq would not necessarily begin immediately after Jan. 15. But he warned President Saddam Hussein in a letter that he would "face destruction" if he did not withdraw his forces from Kuwait by that date, an Administration official said.

title: Social Events
description: Art Auction for Women

title: Miss Lucier Weds Christopher Cahill
description: Renee Susan Lucier, a daughter of Barbara Lucier and Ernest Lucier, both of Burke, Va., was married yesterday in New York to Christopher Cahill, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kevin Cahill of New York. The Rev. Joseph Fitzpatrick performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: Carol L. Charlton to Wed
description: May wedding plans for Carol Lawton Charlton and Dr. Jeffrey Thomas Ehreth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Ehreth of Warrenton, Va., have been announced by her parents, Carol Buckley of Sharon, Conn., and Thomas Charlton of Saxe, Va. Miss Charlton, 25, graduated from the University of Virginia, where her fiance received his undergraduate and medical degrees. She is a manager of the Good Earth restaurant in Tucson, Ariz. Dr. Ehreth, 28, is completing a residency in urology at the University of Arizona Hospital.

title: A Classic Inn in Puerto Rico
description: FOR years, most hotels in Puerto Rico have fallen into one of two categories. There are the large seaside hotels, usually glitzy but often impersonal, where food is prone to the international-hotel-cuisine blahs. Then there are the small Government-run paradors, where service can be haphazard and the food hearty but unimaginative. What Puerto Rico hasn't had is a top-notch inn along the lines of such Caribbean hideaways as the Bitter End in Virgin Gorda or the Cotton House in Mustique. All that changed in 1988 when a 24-room inn opened on Puerto Rico's largely undeveloped west coast.

title: Man, 42, Dies Trying to Save Dog in Icy Central Park Lake
description: A 42-year-old man who ran onto an ice-covered Central Park lake to save a drowning dog died yesterday morning after police officers had broken a path through 20 feet of ice in a futile effort to save him, the police said.

title: Art of a City Hall Labor Deal: 11 Months of Agony
description: Compared with the momentous fiscal and political issues at stake for New York City, the final point settled in the labor contracts for many municipal workers last week was tiny and arcane.

title: FLASHCARD
description: A MAJORITY of high school students have seen or heard about racial confrontations with overtones of violence, and 1 in 4 students say they have been the target of an incident of racial or religious bias, according to interviews with 1,895 students in the 10th, 11th and 12th grades. The Reebok/Northeastern Study of Youth Attitudes on Racism was conducted by Louis Harris and Associates between Aug. 31 and Sept. 18, 1990, in randomly selected public, private and parochial classrooms nationwide. The study found that black students (46 percent), those in big cities (33 percent) and Hispanic students (32 percent) were most likely to report being victims of racial or religious incidents. White students (22 percent) were less likely to say they had been a target of a bias incident.

title: Culinary Gala for Silver Hill Hospital
description: THE Silver Hill Foundation, a psychiatric hospital in New Canaan, will be the beneficiary of a black-tie gala held on Jan. 18 at the John G. Martin Center of the hospital. Proceeds are earmarked for programs of day care and follow-up care for its patients.

title: New Jewish Seminary in Mt. Vernon
description: EARLY each Monday morning, Seth Gordon drives from his home in Maryland to Mount Vernon for a class that in two years time will lead to his ordination as an Orthodox rabbi.

title: Building a Music Museum: The Long and Winding Road
description: In 1989, Mick Jagger dryly referred to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland as "the Phantom Temple of Rock." In its January issue, Spin magazine complains about the lack of progress in constructing the building, calling it "the Rock and Roll Hall of Shame." It seems people are losing patience.

title: Growing Up In 2 Languages
description: CHILDREN raised in bilingual households often confront an array of emotional and intellectual problems that their monolingual playmates are spared. Drifting between two languages and cultures, they can feel like outsiders in both.

title: Technology; The Tough Business of Recycling Newsprint
description: As newspapers rethink their futures and search for ways to cut costs, increase readership and prevent further erosion of their advertising revenues, new government regulations confront them with one more dilemma: recycling their newsprint.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: CALL it an embarrassment of riches, but how many authors with manuscripts in hand are as well endowed in name and experience as Joseph S. Frelinghuysen?

title: All the Best Houses Have Ghosts
description: THE CAVALIER CASE By Antonia Fraser.228 pp. New York:Bantam Books. $17.95

title: French Maneuvering: Taking the Lead for Europe
description: By taking the lead in promoting a European formula to end the Persian Gulf crisis, France appears to be responding to mounting fears in this country and elsewhere in Europe that the United States is intent on using military force to push Iraq out of Kuwait.

title: Janice L. Rosen To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barnett Rosen of Owings Mills, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janice Lynn Rosen to Paul Robert Schain, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Schain of North Bellmore, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title:
MUSIC;
Despite Soprano's Rise, She Keeps It 'Sensible'
description: THE soprano Dawn Upshaw, whose meteoric rise in her relatively recent career has brought her international attention, views that career with a sensible, down-to-earth approach. "I try to keep my head on straight and to make sure everything in my life -- all the parts -- work well together," she said. "Music keeps me very busy, but I don't like to think it's all I'm made of."

title: Travel Advisory; Amtrak Fare For the Disabled
description: Disabled passengers on Amtrak trains are now entitled to a 25 percent reduction year round on regular one-way coach fares. To obtain the discount, passengers must present identification from an organization like the Foundation for the Blind, a Government agency or a letter from a physician stating the nature of the disability. Disabled children aged 2 to 11 pay 50 percent of the disabled adult fare. Tickets must be bought before boarding. The discount is not available on the Auto Train (Virginia-Florida) or the Metroliner. Companions of disabled passengers do not qualify for the reduced fare, but guide dogs are permitted on trains.

title: Carol A. Melone Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Melone of Short Hills, N.J., have announced February wedding plans for their daughter Carol Ann Melone and Timothy Joseph Zuckert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Zuckert of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Hope E. Worley Weds Curtis William Hillegas
description: Hope Elizabeth Worley and Curtis William Hillegas were married yesterday at the chapel of Princeton University by the Rev. Willard Wetzel, a minister of the United Church of Christ. The bride, 23 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Worley Jr. of Riverside, Conn. A graduate of the Westminster School and Lehigh University, she is an advertising assistant at the Alan Harry Pollack advertising agency in Metuchen, N.J. The bridegroom, 25, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hillegas of Limerick, Pa. A graduate of Spring-Ford High School in Royersford, Pa. and Lehigh, he is studying for a Ph.D. in chemistry at Princeton.

title: A Cab That Stands Out in a Crowd
description: They are finally popping up, one here, another there. To car buffs, they are like the first robins of spring. And they are unusual enough to produce double-takes even among the uninitiated.

title: Jan Eliasberg, Film Director, to Marry
description: Jan Pringle Eliasberg, a television and movie director in Los Angeles, and Neil Friedman, an executive at Columbia Pictures, plan to marry in March.

title: A Dragging Pace for New-Condo Sales
description: NEW YORK CITY developers, hurt by tight mortgage-lending requirements and shrinking demand from foreign buyers, are struggling to sell hundreds of new condominiums in a market already reeling from a long real estate slump.

title: The Couple Next Door? Just Folks Whose Phone Is Tapped
description: A few minutes into the first episode of "Under Cover," ABC's new weekly series on life as a spy in the post-cold war era, an American intelligence agent operating under deepest cover from Iraqi-occupied Kuwait goes to a safe house and calls her boss back in Washington. Over a top-secret line and with agency brass hovering in the background, he informs her that her husband, also a veteran operative, has just been sent from headquarters to Baghdad on the most delicate of missions. "Who's with the kids?" she asks, worry furrowing her brow. "Your mother," her superior replies.

title: Defeating Iraq Would Create Worse Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title: Louis Cohen, 87, Rarities Expert And Founder of Argosy Book Shop
description: Louis Cohen, who stocked the libraries of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Michael Jackson and innumerable less-celebrated bibliophiles with everything from dogeared paperbacks to rare first editions, died on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Style Makers; Stephen Santinelli, Travel-Case Designer
