description: Three out of every four weeks, Stephen Santinelli, an optical engineer, would be on the road. Inevitably, the leather case that held his toiletries would rot after a year or so, ruined by exposure to water and steam in hotel bathrooms.

title: 7 Sentenced in First Tiananmen Square Protest Trials
description: Ending its first political trials arising from the Tiananmen Square democracy movement, a Chinese court announced today that seven democracy campaigners had been sentenced to two to four years in jail.

title: Hospital Links Its Policy on Abortion to Land Deal
description: As part of a real estate transaction with the Roman Catholic Church, a hospital here has agreed not to perform elective abortions, and that has drawn angry responses from both sides of the abortion debate.

title: The Quiz
description: The very phrase "The 60's" evokes a welter of firsthand memories and secondhand impressions: campus demonstrations, space exploration, fashion statements, assassination, assassination, assassination. Just how accurate are these recollections and pass-along tales? Only a quiz can tell.

title: Sunday Outing; Architectural History Still at Your Service
description: In 1686, five Dutchmen bought 2,200 acres on the east bank of the Hudson River from the Sepasco and Esopus Indians in exchange for 1 frying pan, 2 knives, 4 blankets, 4 guns, 5 kettles, 5 adzes, 8 shirts, 10 cans of powder, 240 feet of beads of polished shells and half a cask of rum.

title: Bengals vs. Oilers: Wild Ones Meet
description: Its early days brought together a down-in-the-dirt, old-fashioned collection of football teams. But the American Conference's Central Division is now an innovative operation symbolized by today's Oilers-Bengals playoff game (Channel 4, 12:30 P.M.).

title: Drug Companies in Germany End a Boycott
description: Drug companies in western Germany have agreed to end a boycott of pharmacies in the former East Germany and to pay large subsidies so that drugs can be sold at a discount there.

title: Andrea Weiner Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Weiner of Stamford, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Andrea Frances Mariam Weiner and Andrew Fairchild Schirmer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Emerson Schirmer of Sunriver, Ore.

title: Design; MATERIAL MATTERS
description: IN DESCRIBING THEIR design for this Manhattan penthouse, Gisue and Mojgan Hariri do not talk about style or use words like post-modern or deconstructivist. "We were trying to move beyond the vocabulary of everyday architecture," says Gisue, who with her sister owns the architectural firm of Hariri & Hariri. Instead, their goal was to create a design that melded interesting materials and shapes.

title: Mopeds
description: To the Editor: "Visitors Beware: Mopeds Can Be Hazardous" (Practical Traveler, Dec. 9) was right on target. My wife and I just returned from Bermuda, and I can say that we never have and never will ride on a moped, because we don't want to put ourselves at risk competing with people who don't know the first thing about them.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia; Rehabilitation By the River
description: DEVELOPERS and others who are working to give a lift to aging historic properties in this city's old riverfront community of Manayunk are finding some success.

title: Baseball Notebook; Arbitration Time Has Arrived, Courting the $2 Million Salary
description: Players earning millions of dollars should remember Peter Seitz with gratitude and appreciation. Seitz, after all, was the arbitrator whose decision led to the creation of free agency and the escalation of player salaries. Gene Michael, though, remembers him differently.

title: 15-Year-Old Charged In Shooting of Officer
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth has been charged in the shooting Friday night of an undercover police narcotics officer during a drug buy that went bad, the police said.

title:
DINING OUT;
Interesting Japanese Food and Decor
description: THERE are two Jo-Shos. The original in Rahway, which is nine years old, is little more than a store selling Japanese food and housewares, with a sushi bar and a few tables for diners (primarily Japanese). Small though it is, it has a liquor license.

title: As Ireland Battles AIDS, the Church Is Called a Roadblock
description: This nation is playing out the tragic drama of AIDS, and tradition, Roman Catholic orthodoxy and ignorance are among the grim protagonists, advocates in the fight against the disease say.

title: Strapped, Big Cities Take Painful Steps
description: With chronic deficits, ruined credit and little sympathy from state officials, Philadelphia is in the worst fiscal shape of any big American city. But many other cities are in trouble, too, and around the nation the steps mayors are taking to keep their budgets afloat are burdening residents and in some cases making government more efficient, officials in 40 of the nation's largest cities said in interviews.

title: Compass Points
description: To the Editor: Contrary to what Donald Thumim says (Letters, Nov. 4), the Turkish words for black, white, red and blue are not identical, respectively, with the words for north, west, south and east. The four color words in question are kara, beyaz (or ak), kirmizi (or kizil) and mavi, while the directional terms are simal, garb, cenub and sark.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Eager to Pay Taxes

title: Giving New Meaning to the Phrase Team Player
description: The lights dim, the ABC Sports theme fills the air and the referee bounds into the arena in a black-and-white-striped jersey, a whistle hanging from her neck. The judges prepare their score cards, the two four-member teams take their places, the referee flips a coin, and the match is on.

title: A Dizzying Essay in Higher Education
description: One of the more welcome changes that have come over the London art world since the end of World War II is the emergence of the National Portrait Gallery as one of the liveliest museums in town. Initiated with both vigor and panache by Roy Strong during his directorship (1967-1973), this emergence has been further fostered by Sir Roy's successor, Dr. John Hayes.

title: THE BRADYS AND THE GUN LOBBY
description: I propose that anyone who wishes to possess a firearm should become an automatic candidate for conscription, should such a need arise. This policy would be consistent with the intent of the Second Amendment, which was to have civilians carry arms so that a larger army could be raised at relatively short notice. Carrying arms might best be regarded as a privilege that comes with a cost. MAHESH CHITRAO Brooklyn

title: Sara Ann Jaffe to Wed Peter J. Hill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Jaffe of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced February wedding plans for their daughter, Sara Ann, and Peter Jameson Hill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Hill of London.

title: Must-See Ceramics
description: THE Newark Museum, like other museums around the world, possesses hundreds of treasures that are rarely seen by the public. Of course, one may suspect that fine paintings, sculpture and craft items are hidden away in the vast storage vaults. But the creme de la creme is right out in the open, under the spotlights.

title: PRO HOCKEY: Midseason Report; Islanders Aware Youth Is No Longer an Excuse
description: Ask those very tenured Islander officials, General Manager Bill Torrey and Coach Al Arbour, how they feel about their team's viselike grasp on last place in the Patrick Division and an identical answer springs to mind: "Unhappy."

title: Miss Samperton Plans Marriage
description: February wedding plans for Schuyler Drew Samperton and William Todd Coffin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralston H. Coffin Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John S. Samperton of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Georgia Birmingham, Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Birmingham of Carefree, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Georgia Atchison Birmingham, to Jeffrey Ahrens Hepinstall, the son of David Hepinstall of New York and Andrea Ahrens of Amherst, Mass. No wedding date has been set.

title:
RECORD BRIEF;
Kern: 'Sitting Pretty'
description: Judy Blazer, Paige O'Hara, Roberta Peters, Davis Gaines, Jason Graae and Merwin Goldsmith; Princess Theater Ensemble conducted by John McGlinn. New World 80387; two CD's and cassettes. One might sooner have expected new recordings of Jerome Kern's later experimental musicals like "Music in the Air" and "The Cat and the Fiddle" (and such recordings are still urgently needed), but this highly successful presentation of a 1924 show is welcome nonetheless. While the plot is standard stuff (mismatched couples, a lost inheritance), the musical style is somewhat unexpected: Kern repeatedly stresses a wistful strain of yearning in his remarkably delicate score -- so subdued that its orchestra's rhythmic propulsion comes not from piano or drums, but from harp. John McGlinn and his expert orchestra and chorus bring its distinctive atmosphere persuasively to life. The talented and stylish cast (with especially outstanding work from Ms. O'Hara, Mr. Gaines and Mr. Graae) and ideal sound make this the most satisfying of New World's documentations of the American musical.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THREE-FOURTHS of the public believe there would be large advances in science, medicine and technology if more Americans were able to get a college education, according to a survey recently released by the Council for the Support and Advancement of Education.

title: Owens Finalists
description: Five Americans are among the nine finalists for the 1990 Jesse Owens International Trophy, which is awarded to the outstanding athlete deemed to best personify the famous Olympian.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WATER BABY: The Story of Alvin. By Victoria A. Kaharl. (Oxford University, $21.95.) This is a fascinating history of Alvin, the world's first deep-diving submarine. The three-person craft, which opened the ocean depths to exploration in the mid-1960's, has shown scientists strange and previously unknown worlds and in the process helped alter our understanding of planet Earth. "Water Baby," by the science writer Victoria A. Kaharl, is, however, much more than a story about a titanium sphere with a curious name. It is also about the men and women who, during dives so deep it takes hours to surface, must trust that Alvin will protect them from thousands of pounds of pressure on each square inch of the hull. There is heroism as well as humor: stories of pilots jockeying the craft free from fissures more than 8,000 feet down, for example, and a running account of the motley crew of Alvin's mother ship, including a man nicknamed Bare Bear who slept in his bunk with a teddy bear. The best parts of "Water Baby" are the vivid descriptions of trips to the sea floor. Early in its career, Alvin had shown scientists that the deep ocean was not barren, as had been believed, but was teeming with life. However, even veterans of deep diving were surprised at the lushness of marine oases at the bottom of the Pacific, which they viewed in the mid-70's, courtesy of Alvin. "Water Baby" does bog down in places, but the information overkill is clearly the result of the author's extensive research and love for the subject. In the end, Ms. Kaharl's enthusiasm proves to be irresistible.

title: The Region; All the City's Crumbling Roadways Aren't Over Rivers
description: NEW YORK CITY'S intricate, interlocking grid of bridges, tunnels, roadways and subways, the underpinnings that make the city work, has recently been showing increasing signs of disintegration:

title: Diversifying to Counter A Slump on the Slopes
description: When the Resort at Squaw Creek opened near Lake Tahoe in California two weeks ago, its ski slopes were packed tighter than a cable car at Aspen, Colorado's legendary ski resort famed for its crowds and opulence.

title: Suzy Shore and T. R. Sandberg Marry
description: Susan Shore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sig Shore of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Trygve Ren Sandberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Trygve J. Sandberg of Wauseon, Ohio. The Rev. John Kauta performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Newark's Downtown Revival Moves East
description: THE most ambitious of all the commercial developments in downtown Newark in the last decade -- the four-building Gateway office and hotel complex -- rises on land that lies west of Pennsylvania Station, the city's transportation hub. Gateway turned the area from a moribund business district to one on the rise.

title: Patriot Prospect?
description: The Syracuse football coach, Dick MacPherson, is reportedly being considered for the head coaching job of the New England Patriots. WTVH-TV in Syracuse reported last night that MacPherson was in Boston for an interview with the Patriots' chief executive officer, Sam Jankovich. Syracuse officials declined to comment. Rod Rust was dismissed Friday as coach of the Patriots, who were 1-15 this season. (AP)

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE National Center for Education Statistics projects that there will be 10 percent fewer high school graduates in 1994 than there were six years earlier, a decrease from 2.8 million in 1988 to a forecasted 2.5 million. But over this same time period, the center calculates, the total number of students in elementary school will increase 8 percent, rising from 32.5 million in 1988 to a projected 35.3 million in 1994.

title: Worker Mistakenly Cut Phone Cable
description: New York City's most important telephone link broke on Friday because an A.T.&.T. employee mistakenly snipped it with a large pair of wire-cutters while removing old cables, the company said yesterday.

title: Head of Monitoring Panel Reports Progress by States on Education
description: The governor who is responsible for issuing a national report card on education next September says the states have made modest gains in revamping education, but still have a long way to go before real change is evident.

title: France's Favorite Country
description: MY most recent experience of the Frenchman's eternal love affair with his country and all things French began with cheese -- a five-pound slab of Cheddar, which I had brought back from London for a friend in Provence. It happened to be one of those days at the Marignane-Marseilles airport when the customs officers were feeling either bored or particularly efficient, and they were inspecting the contents of every suitcase.

title: Reuben P. Hughes, 79, President Of the Maker of Hawaiian Punch
description: Reuben Paul Hughes, who was president of the company that manufactured Hawaiian Punch and who later became a leading stockholder in the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, died Dec. 30 at St. Jude Medical Center in Fullerton, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: Twelfth Night -- and All's Well
description: For most Americans they're over: the days of the upraised glass and the hearty hug and the creative cooking. Oh, such creative cooking. Apple butter and marmalade and pickled green tomatoes and caponata and a veritable rainbow of curious vinegars because this was the year of the money-saving homemade gift. Platters of cute little cookies too, because their bakers know there's scarcely a person alive who can pass up a sweet something dressed in silver dragees and a sprinkle of pink sugar.

title: Ellen C. Procter To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Ellen Carleton Procter to Peter Daniel Wilson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Wilson of East Amherst, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Procter Jr. of Darien, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Mutual Funds; Why Stocks Make Sense Now
description: Should you sink money into stocks this year? No way, most mutual fund investors would probably say. And with good reason: Many were badly burned in 1990, when the average stock fund lost more than 7 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds.

title: Rewarding the Better Mousetrap
description: THE LEVER OF RICHES Technological Creativity and Economic Progress.By Joel Mokyr.Illustrated. 349 pp. New York:Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Miss Sonnenblick To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edmund H. Sonnen blick of Darien, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Jean Charlotte Sonnenblick and Adam Van Doren, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Van Doren of Evanston, Ill.

title: Talking: Repair Loans; Handyman Special Financing
description: PEOPLE of low or moderate income are often in a double bind when they try to buy a house. The sort of property within their grasp is frequently riddled with drawbacks such as bad plumbing or wiring or a dilapidated, leaky roof -- a handyman special that needs an immediate strong infusion of cash.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Mary Elizabeth Wildenthal and Jeffrey David Cohen misidentified the church in Houston where the ceremony was performed. It was St. Luke's United Methodist Church.

title: Travel Advisory; Squaw Valley's Newest Resort
description: Since the 1960 Olympics, Squaw Valley, Calif., has been known as a major ski resort. Its dimensions -- 2,850 vertical feet, 4,000 acres of skiing, 26 chairlifts, a tram and a gondola -- support the label, but Squaw Valley has never had sufficient overnight accommodations within walking distance of lifts.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIFE AFTER DEATH: And Other Stories. By Susan Compo. (Faber & Faber, $18.95.) Set in postpunk Los Angeles in 1985, "Life After Death" introduces us to a dozen or two young "scenesters," disaffected types with names like Cruella, Vex, Honor, Zelda and Nestor, who hang out in seedy clubs, fall easily into bed with one another and fall just as easily in love -- for whatever that's worth. ("You know I love you more than life," says one of the characters to his girlfriend. "Big deal!" she replies. "A whole lot that means!") The multitudinous characters in this collection of interconnected stories are differentiated only by the color they dye their hair (black, magenta or platinum), their drug of choice (heroin, alcohol, caffeine) and the movie or rock star with whom they're obsessed (Marilyn Monroe, David Bowie or, as no fewer than 10 of them are, Sid Vicious). None of the scenesters are wealthy, few have jobs, and yet somehow most of them manage to pick up and fly to London on the spur of the moment for "All Sids Day, the anniversary of the punk-rocker's everything but deliberate suicide." Even if their lives have no meaning, their attempts at self-examination only go about as far as that of Sharlott, who "often feels things as a result of something else, something indirect, like a shadow." Unlike other chroniclers of seamy underbellies -- William S. Burroughs and Charles Bukowski, for instance -- Susan Compo hasn't succeeded in using language to pull her fiction up out of mere banality. Instead of evoking Los Angeles in a way that might resonate thematically, she often resorts to standard shorthand descriptions. Ms. Compo, a Los Angeles writer, can be witty and colorful at times. Unfortunately, she relies so heavily on cryptic allusions that the whole book reads like a series of private jokes.

title: World Markets; Why a U.S. Recession Still Matters
description: Desynchronization is fast becoming one of the economic buzzwords of the 1990's. It is shorthand for the divergence of economic growth patterns around the world. Rather than everyone following the leader -- which had been the United States -- economies have become more independent. Right now, the United States and Britain are in recessions while Germany and Japan are growing.

title: Remember the Dreadnought
description: ARMORED SHIPS The Ships, Their Settings, and the Ascendancy That They Sustained for 80 Years. By Ian Marshall. Illustrated. 180 pp. Charlottesville, Va.: Howell Press. $39.95.

title: In the Hospital
description: On Friday, P. J. Boatwright, the executive director of rules and competitions for the United States Golf Association, was admitted to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Boatwright went to see doctors late last year for what was suspected to be a herniated disk, but a malignant tumor was found on his spine. After the tumor was removed, another malignancy was found several days later.

title: Scheduling War -- It's Hell
description: Used to be, you felt like having a war and, boom, you had one. Now you have to schedule it.

title: Civil War Games for Modern-Day Lees
description: THE climactic battle for the Shenandoah Valley, General Pickett's headlong charge at Gettysburg and the first and second battles of Manassas are the stuff Richard Berg has fashioned a business from. Mr. Berg, 47 years old, a former New York City criminal defense lawyer, is the inventor of more than a dozen Civil War games designed to give Civil War buffs an opportunity to change history.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Vacancy Rates Narrow in Westchester
description: WESTCHESTER'S market for office space at the end of last year reflected the slumping national economy and most industry observers say relief is probably 12 to 18 months away.

title: Buddy System Insults Cunningham
description: When discussing Randall Cunningham, Buddy Ryan has often said, "We wouldn't trade him for any other quarterback."

title:
THE GUARD CHANGES; THE PROBLEMS REMAIN;
O'Neill Image Belied His Skill
description: WILLIAM A. O'NEILL lacked the elements that often help shape a successful political career: charismatic personality, strong command of the language, personal wealth, even a college degree. Yet when he steps down as Governor on Wednesday, after 10 years in office, Mr. O'Neill will have served longer than any Connecticut Governor since 1809. During his decade in office, Mr. O'Neill never had a veto overridden by the legislature.

title: Hypocrisy In N.F.L. Stands
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RUSSIA AND SOVIETS DIVIDED ON BUDGET
description: The Soviet Union and its largest republic, Russia, are still 27 billion rubles apart on Russia's contribution to the 1991 Soviet budget of 261 billion rubles, the republic's leader, Boris N. Yeltsin, said today.

title: Headliners; Learning by Doing
description: When Robert C. Smith began teaching his "Black Politics" course at San Francisco State University last fall, he probably had no idea it would evolve into a lab course. But the course quickly became an issue of academic politics among black students and faculty members. The chairman of the black studies department, Oba T'Shaka, accused the university of trying to undermine his department by putting Dr. Smith's course under the aegis of the political science department. Professor T'Shaka argued that Professor Smith's course substantially duplicated a course that had been taught in the black studies department for 19 years, and some student protesters urged a boycott of the Smith class. But Dr. Smith argued that black politics courses should be part of every political science program. As the semester ended last month, each side could claim a victory of sorts. The course was still there but its enrollment had dwindled from 45 students, 35 of them black, to 5 students, all of them white.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Collegians Get a Line On Crime
description: STUDENTS at Purdue University, in West Lafayette, Ind., wanted to know about campus crime. Now Purdue police are obliging them to a degree unknown on other campuses with a monthly booklet, Crime Line, detailing crimes on campus.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Merit Pay for Good Grades
description: EVERY Saturday at 9 A.M., Florence Eddings and six tutors, among them a former soap opera actor and a grain corporation executive, arrive at Janis E. Dismus Middle School in Englewood, N.J., to teach the 10 fifth-graders who await them.

title: Sarah E. E. Jones and Peter Beshar, Lawyers, Are Married in Australia
description: Sarah Elizabeth Eggleston Jones, an associate at the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, and Peter Justus Beshar, an associate at the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. John Shephard performed the ceremony at the St. George's College Chapel in Perth, Australia.

title: At Yale, a Show of Royal Patronage
description: TUDORS, Stuarts, Hanoverians and a Saxe-Coburg, followed by Saxe-Coburgs-turned-Windsors: In a rare show of solidarity, the kings and queens of England are giving audience together at the Yale Center for British Art. It is an incomplete lineup, with the Houses of Normandy, Plantagenet, Lancaster and York missing, and only a passing mention of the first Tudor, Henry VII. But then this is an exhibition about royal patronage of art and there was not much of that until after England had joined the rush for colonies and virtually none at all during the Puritan hiatus -- hence the show's title "Crown Pictorial."

title: David Michaels Weds Sally Jutabha
description: Sally Jutabha and David Lawrence Michaels were married last evening at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I., by Rabbi Albert Sturmer.

title: Chilly Scenes of Nuclear Winter
description: A PATH WHERE NO MAN THOUGHT Nuclear Winter and the End of the Arms Race. By Carl Sagan and Richard Turco. Illustrated. 499 pp. New York: Random House. $27.95.

title: Enid Schoettle, Foundation Executive, Weds H. S. Okun, Ex-U.N. Delegate
description: Dr. Enid Curtis Bok Schoettle, the director of the international affairs program at the Ford Foundation, and Herbert Stuart Okun, a former deputy United States representative at the United Nations, were married at the Erminia restaurant in New York on Dec. 27. Judge Sheryl L. Parker of New York City Criminal Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Uncertain Course for Track and Field
description: For the last decade, track and field has been a sport in transition: from amateur to professional, from drug-plagued toward drug-free, from clinging to a proud past to grappling with an uncertain present and future. In many ways, Ben Johnson of Canada was the perfect athlete for that decade. He was a talented, hard-working and professionally trained and managed record-breaker. But imbued with the ethos that the ends justify the means, he took a shortcut to sprinting success via performance-enhancing drugs, and it resulted in crushing failure.

title: Tungsram's Track Record in Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Education Lobby Getting Crowded
description: NEXT MONTH the higher education lobby in Washington, D.C., will swing into action when Congress takes up the reauthorization of the Higher Education Act of 1986. Once, the most effective charge would have been led by the 27 education groups housed in the National Center for Higher Education -- more frequently referred to by its address, One Dupont Circle -- groups such as the American Council on Education, the National Council of University Research Administrators and the Council on Postsecondary Accreditation.

title: Her Guerilla Lover
description: THE VISION OF ELENA SILVES By Nicholas Shakespeare.250 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Stacey Baumann To Wed in 1992
description: An April 1992 wedding is being planned by Stacey Rockefeller Baumann and John Gleeson Aicher Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aicher of Rockville Centre, L.I. The engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Baumann Jr. of Rockville Centre.

title: Sunday Menu; Linguine With an Off-the-Cuff Sauce
description: My daughter, my husband and I came home at 10:30 one night after seeing the movie "Goodfellas." I didn't feel like cooking, but we felt like eating something, so I made do with what was easy and handy: minced garlic in oil, olive oil, canned tomato puree, some leftover red wine and parmesan.

title: Mopeds
description: To the editor: The hotel where I stayed in Bermuda rented mopeds, but no instructions were given; three people at the hotel had accidents. I had a bicycle accident when my brakes failed on a traffic circle. I met several moped accident victims at the hospital. Many accidents could be prevented if motorized and pedal bikes were better maintained; the rear hand brake of my bicycle fell off when we were 12 miles from the hotel and my bike shifted into 10th gear at every uphill. And this was the best of the bicycles for rent. JUDY ANTELL Brooklyn

title: Wall Street; What Rights for Warrant Holders?
description: Gaul is not the only thing divided in three parts. Nature offers animal, vegetable and mineral. School life features reading, writing and 'rithmetic. And on Wall Street, you've got stocks, bonds and warrants.

title: Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia; Rehabilitation By the River
description: DEVELOPERS and others who are working to give a lift to aging historic properties in this city's old riverfront community of Manayunk are finding some success.

title: Sorting Out The Caruso Alternatives
description: Old recordings may never die, but they do go out of print. Even election to the Grammy Hall of Fame doesn't assure currency: recent honorees still absent from the catalogue include Bidu Sayao's classic recording of Villa-Lobos's "Bachiana Brasileira No. 5," Lehman Engel's "Porgy and Bess" and Dimitri Mitropoulos's "Wozzeck." And while the CD medium is reviving a remarkable range of material, the end products often suggest that sound recordings are not yet treated in accordance with their role in music and society.

title: Rampant Among Birds
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne Greenberg To Wed in March
description: The engagement of Anne Sarah Greenberg to Greg Todd Michaelson has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joshua F. Greenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y. Mr. Michaelson is the son of Rita Michaelson of Pittsburgh. A March wedding is planned.

title: Dissection Hot Line Cuts It
description: ATTORNEYS were prepared last fall to help Chastity Boydston, 16 years old, through her sophomore biology class at Galesburg (Ill.) High School. Not that the coursework is unmanageable, but she faced a lowered grade for refusing -- on moral grounds -- to dissect an earthworm.

title: A June Wedding For Amy Geller
description: Dr. and Mrs. A. Neal Geller of Ithaca, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Amy Risa Geller and Robert Martin Geller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Geller of Paramus, N.J. The families are not related.

title: A Learned Response
description: Think again if you think the ability to reason comes easily, if at all. Think again if you believe that scientists are about to solve the mystery of human thought and its underlying biochemistry. Still, Americans are increasingly recognizing the importance of reasoning skills and are trying to develop, hone and teach them to adults and children alike. The endeavor is commanding national attention and demanding individual thought.

title: Choreography in the Pursuit of Happiness
description: Brian Jucha turned on a radio during "Life's Hell!!! Savettka Sings the Blues." What he heard was the speech of 1962 during which President John F. Kennedy announced the Cuban missile crisis. That news made the young man Mr. Jucha portrayed look uneasy. He had yet another reason to seem unsettled. Although Mr. Jucha ended his solo wearing a man's T-shirt and jeans, he began it in a long gown and a woman's silver-blond wig. As he danced, he recited a monologue about a man's fascination with women's clothes and his determination to go his own way.

title: Ms. Clark Weds R. D. Rosenbloom
description: Susan Rosemary Clark and Richard David Rosenbloom were married yesterday at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport, Conn., by Nancy Parker Cook, a Connecticut Justice of the Peace.

title: Harlem's Foreign Relations
description: THE CLASSROOM walls at a Harlem community center were decorated with a flag of Thailand and pictures of smiling children in a Thai refugee camp. Sitting at tables, a dozen inner-city 8-year-olds made collages and drawings to send to the camp, along with food, clothing and toys.

title: Rethinking Newspapers
description: Times are tough for the newspaper industry. Advertising is in a slump some analysts are calling the worst in 20 years. Profits are down substantially at many papers. Vacancies are being left unfilled and budgets are being squeezed if not slashed. Almost everywhere -- especially in the Northeast, where papers have been hit hardest -- the mood is black.

title: Ellen Berdy and S. B. Greenberg to Wed in Spring
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Berdy of River Edge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Louise Berdy, to Stephen Brody Greenberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Mortimer S. Greenberg of Belmont, Mass. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Chairman of Troubled New York State Republican Party Resigns
description: J. Patrick Barrett, the state Republican Party chairman who presided over a mounting debt and a disastrous gubernatorial campaign, has announced his resignation nine months before the end of his term.

title: Sports of The Times; Appling, Rose and an Inner Circle
description: Luke Appling was Peter Pan with a drawl, a gruff old boy who never wanted to grow up. His paunch bulging inside a modern form-fitting polyester uniform, he taught youngsters the fading art of swatting the ball behind the base runner. Maybe he couldn't get a job in any other field. Maybe he never tried.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Musikas of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Holly Jean to Michael Robert Cliggott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Cliggott of Greenwich, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Fame! Fortune! Matching Luggage!
description: WHEN those of us who live east of the San Fernando Valley think of Hollywood, the primary image we usually conjure up is of smoggy, sticky, interminably clogged freeways. Or of overcosmeticized actress-waitresses, and smarmy entertainment-industry types with gold chains dangling in their exposed chest hairs. A city filled with people who do lunch rather than eat it. While these grossly unfair generalizations may be more or less untrue, Hollywood, nonetheless, may not immediately strike the average New Yorker as a wonderful travel destination.

title: Sacred Tales of the Americans
description: THE MYTHOLOGY OF MEXICO AND CENTRAL AMERICA By John Bierhorst. Illustrated. 239 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $14.95.

title:
PROSPECT PARK JOURNAL;
Emergency Repair of Van on Sunday Runs Afoul of Blue Law
description: A LONGSTANDING blue law here that prohibits doing work on Sunday like lawn mowing, house painting and car maintenance got Robert Crawford in trouble with local officials recently.

title: Julia Ann Shapiro To Wed in March
description: Dr. and Mrs. Melvyn Shapiro of Rockville, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julia Ann Shapiro to Daniel Gary Cort, the son of Harvey Cort of New York and Diana Cort Van Arsdale of Rego Park, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: THE GIFT OF THE MAGGIE
description: It comes as no surprise that Peggy Noonan should prefer style to substance. After all, as a speechwriter for Ronald Reagan she did much to erect an aura around a man whose ideas and vision for his country were, at best, limited. Margaret Thatcher, then, is right up Noonan's stylistic alley, and, as we see in "The Gift of the Maggie" (Hers, Dec. 16), Noonan is still bewitched by appearance and not overly concerned with accomplishments. In this case, it is Thatcher's "champagne colored hair, combed, lifted and sprayed into place." Or perhaps her "good posture." These attributes were evident in Reagan as well.

title: Asian Gangs in New York -- A Special Report; Immigrant Waves From Asia Bring an Underworld Ashore
description: As waves of Chinese and Southeast Asian immigrants flood New York City in search of better lives, their expanding neighborhoods are being plagued by increasingly violent street gangs and new criminal enterprises that law-enforcement officials say may come to rival the Mafia in its heyday.

title: Vermont's Broad New Plan on Energy
description: In a sweeping attack on global warming, acid rain and dependence on foreign fuels, the Governor of Vermont has proposed a blueprint for reducing all three through energy taxes and subsidies that would also save large sums of money in the future.

title: Albania Says It Will Release Over 200 Political Captives
description: Albania's Communist Government said today it would free 202 political prisoners and citizens who had sought to defect from jails around the nation, the official news agency A.T.A. reported.

title: Sarah M. Salant To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Salant of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Meigs Salant to James Taylor Gleason, a son of Mary Taylor Gleason of Westerly, R.I., and Frederick C. Gleason of Groton, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Jean Camper Cahn Is Dead at 55; Early Backer of Legal Aid to Poor
description: Jean Camper Cahn, a lawyer who helped establish Federal financing of legal services to the poor and was a co-founder of the now-defunct Antioch School of Law in Washington, died on Wednesday at her home in Miami Beach. She was 55 years old.

title: Tar Heels Run Away From Irish
description: In years past, a college basketball game between North Carolina and Notre Dame might have had fans falling out of their seats because of the relentless and exciting play.

title: A Face for Mount Rushmore
description: THE PRIVATE WORLD OF KATHARINE HEPBURN By John Bryson. Photographs by the author. Foreword by Katharine Hepburn. 175 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $39.95.

title: Hard Edges Aside, Manhattan Still Lures the Ambitious
description: After months of persuasion, Sylvia Laniado, a recruiter for an advertising agency, convinced Bonnie Brainin, a talented copywriter from Connecticut, to set aside her fears about crime in Manhattan and take the train into the city for a job interview.

title: Casinos Press for More Slot Machines
description: ON most weekends and holidays, impatient gamblers wait in line to try their luck at Atlantic City's 21,000 slot machines, while gaming tables are often underused or deserted. Bills to correct what casino operators regard as an unfair state-imposed limit on the number of slot machines are in the works in the State Legislature.

title: Tech Notes; The Disappearing Bar Code
description: Bar codes have become ubiquitous on consumer products because they allow quick pricing information and product identification by machine scanning. But they can be unsightly on packages that emphasize glamor, such as cosmetics, and can add clutter to advertising messages. So the Battelle Memorial Institute, a contract research firm in Columbus, Ohio, has developed a line of bar code inks that are transparent to visible light, but visible to the infrared radiation used by the scanning devices.

title: Ruth Moors Plans to Wed
description: May wedding plans for Ruth Janet Moors and Anthony Mauro D'Eredita, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mauro D'Eredita of Liverpool, N.Y., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William J. Moors Jr. of Haddon Heights, N.J. Miss Moors, 28 years old, graduated from Mount Holyoke College. Mr. D'Eredita, 26, graduated from LeMoyne College. They received law degrees and master's degrees in environmental law, both magna cum laude, from Vermont Law School. She is an assistant corporation counsel for the City of Syracuse, he an associate in the Syracuse law firm of Hancock & Estabrook.

title: Costly Chiefs Error Spurs Dolphins
description: In an instant that can help create a shocking extension of a team's season and a cruel end of another's, Albert Lewis's calculated but costly risk allowed Miami's Mark Clayton to catch a 12-yard touchdown pass with 3 minutes 28 seconds to play today to defeat Kansas City, 17-16, in an American Football Conference playoff game.

title: Ms. Fried Weds Corey Brennan
description: Antonia Catherine Fried, the daughter of Charles and Anne Fried of Cambridge, Mass., was married there yesterday to Corey Brennan, a son of Col. and Mrs. David N. Brennan of Scranton, Pa. The Rev. John P. Boles performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Harvard Memorial Church.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title: Starting Early in Foreign-Language Class
description: A BILINGUAL teacher, Maridolores Donaghy, held up a tiger puppet to a kindergarten class at Edison School in Port Chester. She said, "Levantense," lifting her hands and the children stood up. "Escuchen," she said, pointing to her ear. She fingered the puppet, and she and the class recited a counting poem, beginning, "Uno, dos, toquen los ojos" or "one, two, touch the eyes."

title: On Language; Send In Sovereign For Socialist
description: IT'S NAME-CHANGING day in the socialist Eden.

title: Plight of Homeless Prompts Gifts to Neediest
description: "It's so sad!"

title: Playwrights Rate Life a Love Game
description: I don't know if you remember the ending of the second act of "The Last of the Red Hot Lovers," Neil Simon's 1971 triptych about the futile attempts of the proprietor of a seafood restaurant -- married, middle-aged and thickening at the waist -- to catch up with the sexual revolution. I found myself thinking of it the other night, while leaving a play that had nothing to do with seafood restaurants, the sexual revolution (whatever that is, these days) or middle-aged discontent. There it was, nonetheless, as clear in my mind as what I had just seen, and I believe I know why.

title: Sara Fanning Engaged
description: Mrs. John A. Van Voorhis and James E. Fanning, both of Madison, N.J., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter, Sara Barrett Fanning, and Thomas Victor Laprade, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Laprade of Barrington, Ill. Miss Fanning, 24 years old, graduated from St. Lawrence University, as did her fiance. She is a manager for Chicago Dining Authority, a restaurant management company. Mr. Laprade, 24, is in his final year at the Loyola University Law School.

title:
FORUM;
Free Speech in an Electronic Age
description: Three weeks ago, Geoffrey E. Moore, director of marketing and communications at Prodigy Services Company, wrote in the Forum that Prodigy has no First Amendment obligation to carry every message its subscribers post on the company's electronic bulletin boards. Jerry Berman, of the American Civil Liberties Union and Marc Rotenberg of Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility argue there is more to the controversy.

title: The Region; Layoffs and Cutbacks And 5 Percent Raises
description: NEW YORKERS got a small, bitter taste of the future last week. The city closed three fire companies, the first of 41 that may eventually be shut. It shifted traffic agents to replace more than 150 it has already lost. It began the process of laying off 280 workers in a purge that might trim more than 7,000 employees from the municipal payroll in the coming weeks. And it prepared a financial plan that seemed likely to make the city even less livable in dozens of different ways for years.

title: Lessing and Mailer To Give Readings at Y
description: Doris Lessing and Norman Mailer are among the writers who will take part in a series of readings next month at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, Monday nights at 8 o'clock. Miss Lessing will read on Feb. 4, and will also deliver the annual Rosenthal Lecture in Literature and Society on Jan. 31 at 8 P.M. Tickets are $15.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
Artist in Progress
description: LANDSCAPE: MEMORY. By Matthew Stadler. (Scribner's, $19.95.) The year is 1915. Nine years after the great earthquake, San Francisco is hosting a world's fair, Model T's and trench warfare have captured the popular imagination and the hero of Matthew Stadler's first novel is coming of age. "Landscape: Memory" is a portrait of the artist as a painfully sensitive young man, a richly impressionistic tale told in the form of a private journal and illustrated with Mr. Stadler's renditions of the narrator's painting-in-progress. Young Maxwell Kosegarten is a survivor of the great 1906 earthquake. He and his best friend, Duncan, brought together by the disaster, now spend their days exploring a changed San Francisco. They trace the quake's path along the coast, wander through the glittering fair at night and puzzle over their own shared recollections of the past. The process of memory is Max's true fascination: he struggles to fix dynamic events and impressions in his journal just as he yearns to capture a changing landscape in paint. The book remains a bit sketchy and disorienting until Max succeeds in bringing the reader closer to his private world. But the outside world is always interesting, as Mr. Stadler subtly weaves accurate historical details into Max's accounts of his daily experiences. This vivid narrative scene-painting brings a lost era to life, encompassing the thrill of a first automobile ride, the increasing horror of news from the European front and a child's terror as the earth rips apart. Max's memory of the earthquake unfolds late in the book, but it finally allows us to enter his emotional landscape, even as human figures begin to appear in his painting. When Duncan comes closer too, becoming lover as well as friend, the stage is set for passion and tragedy. "Landscape: Memory" is an unusual and impressive debut, a book that takes both a young man and his city through pain toward maturity.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Oilers and Bears Take Their Second-Best Shot; A Shaky Tomczak Will Start Again
description: Ron Tomczak played football as a young man and has coached it through his middle age, at the high school and small-college levels.

title: Reaction Is Split on a New Hudson Rail Crossing
description: THE new railroad link across the Hudson River proposed by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad would significantly expand its transportation network, and perhaps alter the way Westchester residents live and work and perceive suburban life.

title: Kurds Routinely, and Easily, Smuggle Food From Iran to Iraq
description: Mahmoud Ali, a burly Kurd, sat in a battered chair in Teheran's Atlas Hotel and happily admitted that his business smuggling goods into Iraq was booming.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Spurs 107, Magic 90: Willie Anderson scored 27 points and San Antonio held Orlando without a field goal in the final eight minutes to win for the 12th time in 14 games. David Robinson, who did not start for the first time this season, scored 18 points and 13 rebounds. The rookie Dwayne Schintzius, who grew up 80 miles from Orlando, started at center, and scored 6 points and blocked 2 shots in the first quarter. (AP) Hawks 117, Timberwolves 112: John Battle scored 5 of his 27 points in overtime as Atlanta extended its winning streak to six games. (AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 3, Nordiques 0: Patrick Roy, who missed the last nine games with a knee injury, made 18 saves for his first shutout of the season and Stephan Lebeau and Stephane Richer scored power-play goals as Montreal posted its second consecutive shutout. (AP) Capitals 5, Bruins 3: Dino Ciccarelli scored two goals as Washington ended the Boston goalie Andy Moog's 10-game home unbeaten streak. (AP) Swimming Dutch Diver Wins: Edwin Jongejans surprised the favored Chinese and held off a late charge by Mark Lenzi of the United States to win the men's 1-meter springboard yesterday at the world championships in Perth, Australia. Jongejans moved past the favorites, Wang Yijie and Tan Liangde of China, in the third round and stayed in the lead to the end, edging Lenzi by 10 points. His victory was the first by a non-American in world championship men's diving since 1975, when Greg Louganis accounted for five of the six events. (AP) Tennis Courier Upset: Michael Stich of Germany came back twice in the second set to upset second-seeded Jim Courier of the United States, 6-4, 7-6, yesterday and reach the final of the Australian hardcourt championships in Adelaide, Australia. In today's final, Stich will face Niclas Kulti of Sweden. Kulti, 19 years old, defeated his countryman and doubles partner, Magnus Larsson, 7-5, 6-4, in the other semifinal. (AP) Fromberg in Final: Richard Fromberg of Australia beat Christian Bergstrom of Sweden, 6-3, 5-7, 7-6, yesterday to reach the final of the BP Nationals tournament in Wellington, New Zealand. Fromberg will meet unseeded Lars Jonsson, also of Sweden, in the final today. Jonsson upset sixth-seeded Omar Camporese of Italy, 5-7, 6-3, 7-6. (AP) Track and Field Florida Youth Sets a Mark: Curtis Johnson, a senior at Palmetto High School in Florida, set a Dartmouth University field house record yesterday in winning the 55-meter dash in 6.25 seconds at the High School Track and Field Invitation in Hanover, N.H. Johnson is the 100-meter junior champion in The Athletics Congress. H. Andrew Downin of Duxbury, Mass., who posted this season's fastest mile time of 4:18 last week at Brown University, won the event again yesterday but in the slow time of 4:22.83. Jo-Dee Schufelt of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., took the girls' one-mile run in 5:00.41.

title: Hussein's Handy Home Survival Guide
description: SADDAM HUSSEIN doesn't talk much about the goals of Baath Party socialism these days. The party principles that ostensibly provide the ideological glue for the regime are largely forgotten, at least for the moment -- overtaken by a fierce pragmatism based on survival.

title: Rangers Prevail in Overtime as Nicholls Scores
description: The red light went on and then in an instant the riot of a celebration was under way, the Rangers pouring over the bench in exhaustion and shock, a 3-2 overtime victory over the Blues officially recorded in the National Hockey League books even if it had not yet fully registered in their consciousness.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT: N.C.A.A. Reforms Need More Work;
Too Expensive, an Punitive to Small Schools
description: When representatives of more than 900 colleges and universities gather this week in Nashville for the annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, much of the legislation being considered will deal appropriately with the scandals of illegal recruiting, exorbitant expenditures on athletics, and, worst of all, the exploitation of student athletes who achieve superbly on the field but get little from their academic experience.

title: In Paris, a Room Of Man Ray's Own
description: When Man Ray returned to Paris for good in 1951 with his American wife, Juliet, the artist was anxious to reacquaint himself with his adopted city, reconnect with friends and colleagues of the extinguished Dada and Surrealist movements, and resume a pace involuntarily tempered by the war years spent at home in the United States. All this would be possible in a suitable workplace.

title: Phys Ed: Not What It Used to Be
description: TAMMIE Williams, a junior at Hackensack High School in New Jersey, wanted to strengthen her stomach muscles and thighs, so she began using a routine thatincludes a stairclimber, leg press and toe raises.

title: A Gift Certificate to Pampering
description: As women in white coats peered at his pores, Kenneth Levine, a 34-year-old clothing company executive, lay under a sheet in a small, dim, clinic-like room last Thursday. Cotton pads covered his eyes and his feet, in black tasseled loafers, stuck out of the sheet. His chin was being painted with a mask of mud and sufhur that felt, he said, initially like good old shaving cream.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; Mapping the Terrain For Celestial Explorers
description: "Growing up in New York City, I couldn't see the stars" because of the glare from the city's bright lights, Jeremiah Ostriker explained from his Princeton University office.

title: Villanova Delivers Syracuse's First Loss
description: Villanova bumped Syracuse from the unbeaten ranks tonight, using a near-impenetrable zone defense to frustrate the Orangemen until Lance Miller and Chris Walker started a 17-4 run that carried the Wildcats to a 76-66 victory.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Travelers to Europe who don't want to be trapped for hours in smoke-filled buses should be warned to avoid tours offered by the Spanish company Pullmantur.

title: Staying Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Industrial Colossus Typifies the Miseries of the Soviet Economy
description: In November, workers battling management over the fate of the colossal Uralmash machine tool works here raised the stakes by changing one word in the name of their unofficial bargaining group.

title:
END PAPER;
Kindergarten Cop Lays Down Law on Exercise
description: One OF MY most succcessful action films was based on a look into the far-distant future. That's O.K. for the movies, because we know ahead of time from the script how the film ends. But when I think about the future in real life, I wonder about the children of today. How healthy are they going to be? How are they going to be able to cope?

title: A Conspicuous Priest
description: GOD, COUNTRY, NOTRE DAME By Theodore M. Hesburgh with Jerry Reedy.Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: Doubleday. $21.95.

title: Chess
description: The trouble with being a world champion chess computer is not that you cannot get revenge for a loss, but that you don't know what it is you have done. The machine cannot gloat, and what's winning without that delicious pleasure.

title: Photographer Slain in Argument in Village
description: A 45-year-old fashion photographer was shot and killed in his West Village apartment yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Hollywood by Hearse: A Zany Undertaking
description: I CIRCLED around the Beverly Hills Hotel, a sprawling Spanish-style stucco structure with acres of unblemished lawn, a star-studded swimming pool and tennis courts, Los Angeles at its flamingo-pink brightest, to show my Israeli cousin Ronit the $3,100-a-night bungalow. Ronit, who had dismissed the city's top tourist attractions -- the Farmer's Market, Rodeo Drive and the Venice canals -- as clones of things elsewhere, was yawning.

title: Coaching Is More Than X's and O's in Teen-Age Lives
description: WHEN the school bell rings, the thousand teen-agers flooding the halls of Ossining High School form a momentary river of faces and fashion punctuated by the maroon and white team jackets that the school's athletes wear.

title: Overflow Of Warmth Lifts Hopes Of the Poor
description: Two months ago, a homeless mother found a paycheck, tracked down the nurse who had lost it and gave it back. That act and the ensuing publicity won her a legion of new friends, who have not only helped her rebuild a rundown house but have also formed an informal network of supporters for other homeless families.

title: 'Patrimony'
description: Philip Roth's subtitle, "A True Story," is un ironically accurate; the homely phrase captures in spirit the ordinary dignity of Mr. Roth's material -- his father Herman Roth's struggle with a so-called benign tumor that presses against his facial nerve and his brain, and eventually kills him.

title: Taking a Home on the Road With an RV Rental
description: TRAVEL by recreational vehicle, despite the increased cost of gasoline, has become an important way of vacationing. But you don't have to buy one. In addition to the estimated 8.5 million RV's registered to private owners in the United States, there is a sizable pool of RV's -- campers, trailers and motor homes -- for rent in the United States and Canada, as well as in Europe, New Zealand and Australia. Germans and Britons are big customers for rental RV's in the United States.

title: Review/Music; Troupe From Taiwan Presents a Comic Opera
description: The Chinese-American Arts Council continued its valuable work of displaying the varieties of Chinese opera to New York audiences on Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall. For its 11th Viva Chinatown program, part of Lincoln Center's Community Holiday Festival, the council presented the Flying Horse Hunan Opera Troupe of Taiwan in "The Romance of the Embroidered Sachet."

title: Parental Leave: Part of 'Doing Business'
description: WHEN Claudia Shuster conducted a study of new parents who returned to work soon after their babies were born, she found many who considered their parental leaves too short, missed their babies and worried about the quality of available child care.

title: In Chester, A French Village Restaurant
description: YEARS ago, in the center of Chester, the main floor of a small frame house was transformed into an outpost of France. Spotless, stylish and simple, that was Restaurant du Village. The same adjectives describe the new Restaurant du Village, which was, as of 1990, owned by Alsatian chef Michel Keller and his American chef-wife, Cynthia. Much remains the same.

title: Rumbustious Glory
description: THE BUILDING OF CASTLE HOWARD By Charles Saumarez Smith. Illustrated. 221 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press.

title: Mr. Klug Goes to Washington: Winning Was Easy
description: Two months ago, Scott Klug of Wisconsin won an election to Congress and thereby entered an alien world. Now he grapples with what his chief aide calls "the monster" -- the letters, telephone calls, resumes and bureaucratic decisions that can engulf new lawmakers.

title: France's Maverick Gulf Role
description: France, which once had close ties to Iraq, now appears to be trying to rebuild its credibility in the Arab world by taking the lead in European peace efforts. News analysis, page 4.

title: Hypnotist, Heal Thyself
description: DOCTOR SLEEP By Madison Smartt Bell.290 pp. New York:Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Women Confront Blue-Collar Barriers
description: WHEN Susan Falcone and Carol Weinberger arrive on the job, heads turn. They have been mistaken for cleaning women and window washers. And when they say they are the plumbers, there often are dumbfounded looks, laughter and whistles from male co-workers at construction sites. But the two women take it in stride.

title: Postings: Speyer School Building; For Homeless AIDS Victims
description: For most of its 89 years, the Speyer School building at 514 West 126th Street has been a beacon of social concern -- as a progressive private school, as an experimental public school, as a headquarters for civil-rights programs and, finally, as a community center.

title: Islamic Bloc Gains in Jordan, Provoking Unease
description: A shake-up of Jordan's Cabinet this week has increased concern in this capital about the growing strength of Islamic fundamentalists and touched off an intense debate about how best to contain them.

title: Utah Crash Leads to Charges
description: The driver of a truck that slammed into the side of a Greyhound bus near here last month, killing 7 people and injuring 41, will be cited for driving with a suspended license, the Utah Highway Patrol said Friday. Sgt. Gary Whitney of the Highway Patrol said the Summit County Attorney's office was preparing the misdemeanor complaint against the 46-year-old driver, Robert Williams of Salt Lake City.

title: Court Gives a Town the Deed To a Daughter's Private Park
description: When Antonia Draper Dixon died in 1923, she bequeathed a small parkland overlooking the Hudson River as a memorial to her father, Prof. John William Draper, an illustrious historian, philosopher and scientist. Professor Draper, a physician, chemist and pioneer photographer took early photographs of the moon using a telescope on the family's estate here.

title: Why
description: It is time for some straight talk about why 400,000 young Americans spent Christmas in the deserts of Saudi Arabia and why in less than two weeks the U.S. may be once again at war.

title: U.S. and Italy Evacuating Foreigners in Somalia
description: Hundreds of foreigners were evacuated today from the battle-worn Somali capital, Mogadishu, in an air and sea rescue operation mounted by the United States and Italy.

title: Streetscapes: 515 Park Avenue; An Old Holdout Is Imperiled
description: WHEN it is viewed in a lineup with the other apartment houses of Park Avenue, nothing remarkable distinguishes 515 Park, built in 1912 at the southeast corner of 60th Street.

title: N.C.A.A. Tackles Reform
description: For most fans of big-time college sports, the annual N.C.A.A. convention is little more than bureaucratic mumbo jumbo that is only remotely related to slam-dunks, field goals and national championships.

title:
SPECIAL REPORT;
In the Market For a Public School?
description: SHOPPING for an elementary or secondary school is becoming as commonplace and complicated as searching for a college. Yet "as parents we know more about the daily operations of the grocery store where we buy our food than where we send our kids for most of the day," said Barbara Zohn, enrollment-options specialist with the Minnesota Department of Education.

title: In Defense Of Miami
description: After a couple of decades of watching football players spike balls in opponents' end zones and engage in an assortment of victory wiggles, it might be supposed that American sports fans had become resigned to such departures from traditional notions of sportsmanship requiring modesty in victory and grace in defeat.

title: Margaret A. Nagy To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Nagy of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ann Nagy, to Thomas R. Bosworth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood R. Bosworth of Vienna, Va. A March wedding is planned.

title: Defeating Iraq Would Create Worse Problems; Winners and Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: It's More Than Marches for a Bugle Corps
description: WHEN his local drum and bugle corps disbanded in the early 1970's, John Curran and a group of friends began commuting from Boston to to be part of the Connecticut Hurricanes. During the gasoline crunch in 1974, Mr. Curran said, the players squeezed six in a car, stuffing their instruments in the trunk, and showed up at practice sessions as often as three times a week.

title: When Water Is Drawn, Anything Can Flow In
description: In the summer of 1986, when Long Islanders looked out on sun-parched lawns, the need for water conservation was obvious. But in recent seasons, when heavy rains and flooding have been more of an issue, the question of where the water comes from has been less pressing.

title: Latest High-Tech Battleground: Robot Sumo
description: The two sumo wrestlers moved warily around the center of the ring, peering for any sign of vulnerability, feinting forward to mask their intentions. Finally, the squat wrestler known to the cheering throngs as Mozu raced in, threw the opponent off balance and out of the ring -- sending his wheels flying and motor whining uselessly.

title: Woolfs Under Glass
description: Vanessa Bell once said that the subject matter of photography should be a little absurd. By this, Bell may have been thinking of her great-aunt, the Victorian photographer Julia Margaret Cameron, "who posed her sitters in a 'high-art' mode, and whose aim was not merely to 'take' photographs but to immortalize those dragooned into posing for her," writes Frances Spalding in her brief, discerning foreword to BLOOMSBURY REFLECTIONS (Norton, $39.95), a collection of photographs of the friends and descendants of the Bloomsbury group. Likewise, Bell would have appreciated the photographer Alen MacWeeney's slightly absurd -- though exceptionally beautiful -- photographic portraits. Each, despite its appearance of spontaneity, has been composed with great artifice. Each of his pictures is a collage of allusions, a reference to the past, while at the same time a frozen moment revealing something essential about the sitter's character. To this end he makes use not just of color and light, but of the furniture, decorative objects and paintings of Bloomsbury. Among the book's most memorable photos, in fact, are his eerily evocative shots of such Bloomsbury haunts as Monk's House, where Virginia Woolf did much of her writing, and Charleston, the country home of Clive and Vanessa Bell. Unfortunately, while the photographs draw us in, the text, which largely consists of a brief reminiscence of Bloomsbury by each sitter, is far less absorbing. Even readers who normally subscribe to the cult of Bloomsbury will question the value of such banal revelations as that of Cecil Woolf, who recalls seeing his Uncle Leonard pick up a piece of chocolate from the floor of a theater and "pop it in his mouth," or Henrietta Garnett, who remembers that her grandmother Vanessa Bell was so frugal that she served "dessert at lunch, but none at dinner." The problem with most of these pieces, written by Sue Allison, a reporter at Life magazine, is that the speakers are of a different generation from the principals of Bloomsbury. With the exception of Quentin Bell, who speaks engagingly of life at Charleston, their memories are at best fragmentary, at worst too subjective to be revealing. Fortunately, Mr. MacWeeney's strangely canny photographs work independently of the text. While "Bloomsbury Reflections" reveals little of the actual stories behind these often guarded faces, it is a stunning visual record of what was once the spirit of Bloomsbury.

title: Dr. Jean Tostanoski Will Marry in Spring
description: May wedding plans for Dr. Jean Tostanoski and Edward John Higham Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Higham of Akron, Ohio, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Tostanoski of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Where Mortals Fear to Tread
description: ANGELS: An Endangered Species. By Malcolm Godwin. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Angels are all around us -- in movies ("Angels With Dirty Faces"), sports (California Angels), even law enforcement (Guardian Angels). Angels figure in our most rarefied worship and in everyday figures of speech. They appear in many guises, from ancient bringers of glad tidings to modern comic-book heroes who appear in the nick of time to rescue good and defeat evil. Artists have been known to spend lifetimes creating substantial representations of these insubstantial beings. But are angels merely figments of our collective imaginations, inspired by legend and fostered by religion? That is a question not easily answered without serious study of the delightful "Angels: An Endangered Species." Malcolm Godwin begins by discussing such cloud-shaking matters as just how seraphim are distinct from cherubim, who are in turn quite separate from archangels. Understanding this heavenly hierarchy creates an important foundation for our knowledge of the more advanced material concerning these winged messengers. But winged messengers from whom, what or where? The author, a British artist and lecturer, presents cases in which encounter and speculation in some way transform those who have been witness to angelic presences. If angels are real, could they appear in other forms -- as unidentified flying objects, for instance? And if real, how do they fly? Are those dainty, feathered shoulder appendages aerodynamically adequate? Just what did Ezekiel see in that fiery chariot, up in the air? Could the legends of the lost continent of Mu be based on fact? Obviously, the questions surrounding these issues require further study by angelic scholars. Tongue parked firmly in cheek, Mr. Godwin takes us through the intricacies of modern angelology and a good deal of our own history, using text, charts, drawings and glorious illustrations. As to whether angels are real or not, endangered or not, Mr. Godwin leaves that up to his readers to discover in this heavenly book.

title: Jennifer Keefe Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Keefe of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Douglas Keefe, to Joseph Frederick Anderson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Anderson of Clinton, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: A Year When Players, Not Plays, Were the Thing
description: THE stage directions could read something like this: An aura of suspense is essential. Participants are in a state of perpetual anxiety -- panic, even. Moods range from funk to despair. Some cover up with grand resignation; others rant. The pace is volcanic. Themes must encompass betrayal and hoped-for renewal. Significant exits and unanswered questions are to be highlighted.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PETE SEEGER

title: Blending Elements and Reconciling Opposites
description: MIRIAM SCHAPIRO'S career began in the late 1950's, but her fame dates from the 70's, when she became a major contributor to the "pattern" movement and also a voice for feminism. Since then, the artist's skillful blend of collage and paint has become more figural, but she retains her eye for pattern and luxuriant color.

title: Ties That Don't Bind
description: MARRIAGES By Amy Witting. 139 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: Seattle, Too Much of a Good Thing?
description: A FERRYBOAT WHISTLE SINGS OFF NEARBY ELLIOTT Bay and a warm rain dances off the awning that covers the sidewalk espresso stand -- one of a multitude that line the wide, spotless avenues of downtown Seattle. The streets are packed with people on the way to work in the gleaming skyscrapers that tower above Puget Sound or shop in the fashionable indoor malls that are the heart of the new downtown. The affluent crowd shuffling past is young, sharply dressed, upwardly mobile: for every briefcase, there's a backpack; for every pin stripe, a pair of blue jeans. Everyone looks fit and prosperous. The whole scene is an advertisement for the good life. I feel like I've stumbled onto the set of a credit-card commercial.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-11

title: U.S. Rebukes Israelis for Raising Firepower
description: The Bush Administration has rebuked Israel for increasing its firepower in clashes with Palestinian demonstrators in the occupied territories.

title: Ms. Arlin Engaged to S. M. Braverman
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Charles N. Arlin of Hillsdale, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Jennifer Brewster Arlin and Samuel Michael Braverman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Braverman of New York.

title: Winning Game Plans
description: AFTER YEARS of skepticism or timid acceptance, the notion that people can be taught to think better is now widely embraced by educators at all levels.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/December 30-January 4
description: THE ECONOMY The Trouble With Private Bank Insurance Questionable loans, nervous depositors, pliant public officials, a depleted insurance fund -- the collapse of Heritage Loan and Investment Company in Providence, R.I., at first glance seems familiar. The likely involvement of organized crime provides a dash of local color. But instead of sticking around to blame his troubles on regulators, Joseph Mollicone Jr., the bank's president, vanished. He had made $13 million in what investigators describe as fraudulent loans to himself. An investigation caused a run on deposits, draining the private fund that insures 45 banks and credit unions. The state's Governor, Bruce G. Sundlun, declared a bank emergency on Tuesday, shutting the affected institutions. Many will reopen with Federal insurance, but depositors at the weakest might lose their money. Will the story end in Rhode Island? Probably not, said Bert Ely, a financial institutions consultant. With private insurance programs for banks and credit unions elsewhere, he said, "One serious hit that isn't quickly and convincingly dealt with can bring the whole plan down." Some other states are likely to require privately insured institutions to switch to Federal coverage, resulting in depositor losses or state bailouts for those too shaky to qualify. Putting a Good Spin on Bad News Higher unemployment is good news of sorts when it is still lower than economists had expected. The rate rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December to the highest level since mid-1987. Non-agricultural payrolls fell by 76,000, but the decline was less than a third the drop in November. William C. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs said that even these figures overstate the economy's weakness, since hours worked in December rose six-tenths of 1 percent. "The report makes you more comfortable that the production cutbacks happened quickly enough in October and November so that further big cutbacks may not prove necessary," he said. A record 5.9 percent plunge in November factory orders was worse than economists expected, but no great surprise after news of low orders for durable goods. Dinkins, the Optimist First Donald J. Trump came up with his forecast for Atlantic City casinos. Then Robert Campeau and his New York deal-makers issued their outlook for retailing. Last week the Dinkins administration raised its 1991 earnings estimate for the York City's pension fund to 9 percent, more optimistic than about 9 in 10 of the nation's other cities. New York City's hopefulness certainly doesn't spring from its 1990 record, when forecasted earnings of 8.25 percent actually came in at just eight-tenths of 1 percent. More likely, the city's optimism comes from its need to reduce pension contributions and come up with millions, quickly, to finance 5 percent raises for workers under contracts reached last week. At this rate, Yankee management, come April, is bound to predict a pennant. A Skeptical Eye at Christie's For conservative valuation and fiscal prudence in New York, look instead to Christie's. The auction house prepared for the sale this week of the Ferdinand E. and Isabella Marcos collection of Old Master paintings by scrutinizing several pieces. Seven of the Marcos Canalettos were busted down to the Circle of Canaletto. What was a Giovanni Bellini in Manila, valued at perhaps $1 million, is School of Bellini in New York, worth a tenth as much. Several million dollars worth of English silver is for sale, too; no doubts, apparently, about whether copper lurks underneath. In Brief For the first time since 1979, American semiconductor makers gained in 1990 against the Japanese. Their share of the worldwide market rose to 36.5 percent from 34.9 percent. The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether the makers of infant formula colluded to raise prices. The prospect of Middle East peace talks pushed oil prices down to $24.90 a barrel, the lowest since the day after Iraq invaded Kuwait. There Goes the Prime The nation's major banks lowered their loan rates last week for the customers they still consider unquestionably credit worthy. The prime rate, a benchmark for many other loans, fell half a percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent, the first decline in a year. COMPANIES

title: Postings: South Bronx Factory; Doubling Space
description: Estee, Calvin and Elizabeth are doing well these days and so, therefore, is Plaza Packaging Corporation of 1350 Inwood Avenue, the Bronx. Using $4 million in tax-exempt industrial development bonds from the city, the 75-year old company is adding 50,000 square feet of manufacturing space, more than doubling the area in which it makes display packs for famous cosmetic firms with last names like Lauder, Klein and Arden.

title: Northeast Notebook: Wilmington, Del.; Hotel du Pont Refurbishment
description: THE Hotel du Pont, one of the country's classic Old World hostelries, is about to undergo a $40 million, two-year renovation.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Ottawa
description: Ottawa is a city that falls into two categories: it is the capital city of Canada, piled high with government offices, and it is also the beautiful town that Joni Mitchell referred to wistfully in her song about Los Angeles: "Oh I wish I had a river/I could skate away on." The Rideau Canal that cuts through Ottawa freezes over around now and becomes the world's largest skating rink -- four miles of ice right in the center of town.

title: Children's Books
description: MARY CASSATT By Susan E. Meyer.Illustrated. 91 pp. New York:Harry N. Abrams. $17.95. (Ages 8 and up) HATTIE AND THE WILD WAVES A Story From Brooklyn.Written and illustrated by Barbara Cooney.Unpaged. New York: Viking. $14.95. (All ages)

title:
DINING OUT;
French Fare in a Banksville Farmhouse
description: WORD of a new chef at La Cremaillere inspired our recent revisits to this rustic farmhouse restaurant run with some success since 1962 by "Robert Meyzen, pere et fils," as the father and son owners style themselves. In addition to the work at the stove, we noted several other changes deserving of mention. Lending an oddly modern feel to the old, unpretentious clapboard farmhouse, the entrance addition now provides space for a dramatic indoor staircase massed with plants and seasonal flowers.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Fort Washington
description: AT 268 feet above sea level, the highest rock in Manhattan was the foundation for a fort during the American Revolution. Named for George Washington, the fort did not last much beyond the war. Soon after the battles subsided, land-seekers bought up property around it, farming it in the 18th century and building great estates in the 19th.

title: For Casinos, Players of Every Stripe
description: LIKE a shopping mall, the Atlantic City casinos attract a cross section of people: the serious spenders, those simply lured by bright lights and lively ambience, and everyone in between.

title: Not Just By Number
description: Math software has come a long way in recent years. At least initially, programs for young students often were little more than automated flash cards, and some programs today still suffer from that lack of imagination.

title: Wine; Italian for Beginners
description: ITALIAN WINE IS A LOT LIKE Italian opera: There's a lot of good stuff there, if you can figure out what's going on.

title: Brian Radin Wed to Miss Bernstein
description: Stacey Bernstein and Brian Jeremy Radin were married last evening at Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I. by Rabbis Neil Turk and Herschel Jaffe.

title:
ART;
Prints Tell the Story of the Mexican Revolution
description: MEXICO has been on the minds of New York museum- and gallery-goers for several months. Its rich and vivid art certainly represents a contrast to the spare and heady work that has come to exemplify New York art. At the Bronx Museum is another contrast: In place of splendors from Mexico we have crisp documentary history.

title:
DANCE;
Newest Member of the Troupe: Video Camera
description: THE camera becomes an invisible dancer in "Video/ Vantage," a work created by Carolyn Dorfman and Dennis Diamond for members of the Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company.

title: Classroom Innovations Encourage Students and Teachers to Excel
description: IN some schools, a visiting parent usually means that a student is in trouble. But J. Brian Lally, a teacher at the Tashua School in Trumbull, has parents in the classroom so often that the pupils take their presence for granted. Parents help Mr. Lally teach everything from computers to cooking.

title: Sunday Dinner; Oven Side, Waterside, All Around Downtown
