description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. These restaurants in downtown Manhattan serve Sunday dinner, and in some cases brunch. La Boheme

title: Norplant Developed for All Women, Not Just the Well-to-Do; Not Safer Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: A la Carte: Back on Track
description: MAIN STREET PASTA in Smithtown, one of the Island's first pasta restaurants, got off to a fast start after opening in July 1987. The reception from diners and reviewers was positive.

title: Return of the Small-Stock Conundrum
description: It's January, the month when stock market lore says that small stocks outperform. And sure enough, last week they did just that. While big stocks started the year off declining rapidly, small stocks went down more slowly.

title: Scarsdale Rejects Early Lessons
description: ALTHOUGH its study of other school districts with foreign language study in kindergarten through sixth grade found them all pleased with the results, the Scarsdale School District decided not to go along with the trend to start teaching foreign languages earlier. District officials said that their elementary school curriculum was too crowded and that its high school foreign language program was turning out students who did well abroad and in college language classes.

title: Church and a Huguenot Cemetery Move Toward Landmark Status
description: A 131-year-old church and a cemetery dating to this city's 17th century Huguenots are the two latest properties to be recommended for landmark status by the Historical and Landmarks Review Board here. The City Council is expected to vote on the designations Jan. 22, after a public hearing on Jan. 15.

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; Students Receive Free Condoms And AIDS Advice
description: Preferring to nudge rather than nag students into participating in AIDS-awareness programs, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is giving out thousands of condoms, along with some friendly advice

title: Ms. Goldszmidt Engaged To Charles Stewart Cohen
description: Ofelia Goldszmidt, an architect in Caracas, Venezuela, and Charles Stewart Cohen, a doctoral candidate in bioengineering at the University of Pennsylvania, plan to marry in March.

title:
RECORDINGS VIEW;
How the Soviets Got It Together
description: Since the mid-1970's a new kind of music, partly rooted in the free jazz tradition and partly an amalgam of folk and classical music, has been spreading through the Soviet Union. Independent of the state and frequently clandestine, this music was one of the most adventurous forms of creative expression to emerge during the Brezhnev era.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 6, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran, stationed in Sioux country, adopts the ways of the Indians. 2 20 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) An author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 3 15 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 4 34 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 5 7 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: 'Lovingly, Georgia'
description: To the Editor:

title: Harris Reflects
description: The former star West Virginia quarterback Major Harris says he was treated for stress in a two-day stay last week at a Pittsburgh psychiatric hospital. Harris, 22, a Pittsburgh native who plays for the British Columbia Lions of the Canadian Football League, told The Pittsburgh Press: "I had a lot of things on my mind and I really couldn't think about them when I was in Vancouver because all my time was consumed by football. I think I'm over my problems now." (AP)

title: Miss Garretson To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans for Margaret Elizabeth Garretson and Edward Hill Carter, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burr N. Carter 2d of Richmond, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Garretson of Severna Park, Md.

title: State Water-Pumping Caps Under Fire
description: FOUR years after the State Environmental Conservation Department limited pumping by the 41 water suppliers of Nassau County, the Village of Garden City is awaiting a decision on its challenge to the rules.

title: Growing Old Fast in Guatemala
description: THE MOST POIGNANT evidence of Central America's lost decade of poverty and brutal oppression can be found not only in the economic statistics but in the streets of Guatemala.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE perception that undergraduates suffer when colleges employ foreign teaching assistants has been called into question by a recently released study by the University of Wisconsin. Analysis of 806 undergraduate courses offered in the fall semesters from 1983 to 1987 found that the grades earned by students in sections taught by assistants whose native language was other than English were a tenth of a grade point higher (on a 4.0 scale) than those earned by students in sections taught by native English speakers. English is a second language for about 20 percent of the university's teaching assistants.

title: Mother Held in Baby's Death
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn mother has been arrested and charged with killing her 19-month-old son, who was found badly bruised in his crib last week, the police said yesterday. The mother, Frances Velez, of 1381 DeKalb Avenue in the Bushwick section, was charged late Friday with second-degree murder. Her son, Anthony, died on Thursday morning at Wyckoff Heights Hospital. Earlier that morning, a crowd of neighbors and relatives flagged down a police car outside the Velez home.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: GREENWICH;
Waltzing Cats Not Too Elegant For a World That's Miniature
description: MINIATURISTS are showing off in a big way. At the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, the Greenwich Miniaturists, a group of 20 creators of microcosms, are celebrating the town's 350th anniversary. The Stamford Historical Society recently concluded a separate exhibition, "A Miniature Christmas in Connecticut."

title:
The Executive Life;
Trimming Wall Street: Jimmy the Barber
description: On a recent weekday afternoon in a barbershop deep in the canyons of New York's financial district, a crisis was taking place. Jimmy Ruotolo, the spry 74-year-old barber, who has been cutting the hair of Wall Street's best-known bigwigs since 1943, had three executives scheduled for 5 P.M. appointments, but at 5:15, no one had arrived.

title: Parents Face Timeless Reality
description: IN THE NEW EQUATION for children's success in school, it is parents who are a key factor. And they know it. Parents are more aware than ever that actively involving themselves in their children's education affects the kind of education their children receive. Schools and teachers, in turn, are open to the attention and participation of concerned parents.

title: G. H. Brown Wed To Ms. Waterbury
description: Suzanne Elaine Waterbury, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Waterbury of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Hewlett Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thatcher M. Brown 3d of New York and Dorset, Vt. The Rev. Vivian Jones performed the ceremony at Plymouth Congregational Church in Minneapolis.

title: Deborah Driscoll To Wed in August
description: The engagement of Deborah Bijur Driscoll to John Preston Turner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Turner of Hunt Valley, Md., has been announced by her mother, Barbara B. Driscoll of Bethesda, Md. An August wedding is planned.

title: Norplant Developed for All Women, Not Just the Well-to-Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion; STREET SMART
description: Drenched in beads and showered with pearls, this year's glamorous new bathing suits are more at home on the boulevard than the beach. So skip the laps. Instead, slip into a soft, feathery wrap, toss on a billowing chiffon skirt and add a pair of high heels, then float onto the dance floor. In these dazzling maillots, you're sure to make waves.

title: Troubled Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of Lotus in Japan . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: FLASHCARD
description: ABOUT a fifth of all adult Americans take part in formal Bible study and more than half read the Bible at least monthly, according to a recent Gallup Poll. The poll, conducted nationwide by telephone, in which 1,000 adults participated, indicates that 17 percent read the Bible daily and an additional 23 percent read it weekly. Protestants are more than twice as likely as Catholics to be frequent Bible readers or belong to Bible study groups.

title: THE BRADYS AND THE GUN LOBBY
description: Our Government has attempted to outlaw harmful drugs. In spite of an extensive and costly "war on drugs," drugs continue to be available readily to anyone who wants them and has the money to pay for them. If the Government enacts and attempts to enforce stricter gun control laws, it seems reasonable to assume that guns will continue to be available, either imported illegally or manufactured in clandestine machine shops out of reach of taxes and the controls we now have in place.

title: Food; Trinidad on the Hudson Caption:
description: THERE'S NO SIGN TO TELL YOU WHEN YOU'VE arrived in Tunapuna, the curry powder manufacturing capital of Trinidad, but if you've got a nose, you'll know. I grew up in New Jersey, and so am naturally wary of all emissions of an industrial nature. But the first time I visited Tunapuna, I found myself thinking that I might consider moving to a factory town some day, as long as it smelled like this. Clouds of roasted cumin and turmeric, garlic, coriander and those acidy-hot Caribbean peppers called Scotch bonnets -- simply by breathing, one was exposed to hazardous levels of piquant longing. To die in Tunapuna, I imagine, would be to die wondering what was for lunch.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Gettysburg Address For Blacks
description: TRACING the past of black families has become key to the future of black students at Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania, which has opened an Intercultural Resource Center -- complete with genealogy facility -- to help recruit and retain black students. At a college with one of the nation's worst records for minority recruitment -- the 2,000-member student body is mostly white and middle-class -- the center seems to be working.

title: New Musical's Opening Is Off Off Off Broadway
description: Stephen Schwartz and John Caird have been involved in some of Broadway's biggest hits, but they insisted that their new show, "Children of Eden," open first in London.

title: Shortwave Radios
description: To the Editor: Overseas travelers who carry portable shortwave receivers would be well advised to keep them in hand luggage only. This summer I was startled to discover, on arrival in Paris, that the lock on my checked bag had been jimmied by Heathrow security personnel in order to examine my Sony 7600D shortwave, which must have been visualized on X-ray. When I unpacked, I found the radio's batteries removed and the set neatly reassembled. (A small electronic pedometer had similarly been dismantled.) I applaud such thorough security precautions, but my suitcase will never be quite the same. JUDY LIBMAN Toronto

title: INSIDE
description: Fire Halts Rail Traffic

title: Medical Teams in Gulf Disagree Over Readiness
description: Senior medical officers in the Persian Gulf say they are prepared to treat heavy casualties in case of combat, but many of the doctors and nurses who will handle patients say they lack important medical supplies and modern equipment.

title: By Royal Command, It Was a Night at the Movies
description: "The first thing you have to remember is that whatever you do, you let the Queen do it first." Lizzie, my English friend who personally knows the royal equerry -- someone whose job, Lizzie told me, is to "walk six paces behind the Queen at all times" -- was briefing me on what she knows about close encounters of the royal kind.

title: Merengue's Dance-Till-You-Drop Beat
description: The power -- and air-conditioning -- goes out for at least four hours every day in sunbaked Santo Domingo, filling one's head with visions of the beach. But the beach is a 20-minute drive away, and in the Dominican Republic, the wait for a full tank of gas can take hours. Even a shower is impossible; without electricity, there's no water pressure. On these sweaty, miserable afternoons, it seems there's only one thing that hasn't quit in this capital city: merengue. It jumps from battery-powered blasters downtown on Calle El Conde, palpitates from the speakers of customized vans along the Malecon boulevard. The national rhythm of the Dominican Republic never stops.

title: THE PROBLEMS REMAIN; Weicker Faces A Bumpy Road
description: ON Wednesday, as the last echoes from Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s 19-gun inaugural salute die away over the State Capitol, Connecticut will begin its great experiment in non-party government -- or multi-party government, or whatever it is that the Weicker administration finally decides to call itself.

title: Brained by the Fastball
description: THE ASCENT OF MIND Ice Age Climates and the Evolution of Intelligence. By William H. Calvin. Illustrated. 302 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

title: Choosing New Seeds for the New Year
description: THE New Year is off to a great start for gardeners. They will be able to pick and choose from among 10 new seeds from All-America Selections, the non-profit association of the American seed trade that evaluates novelties in test gardens across the country. If the novelties prove to be better than a similar cultivar on the market, then the award is given.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEFORE THE STORM: Memories of My Youth in Old Prussia. By Marion, Countess Donhoff. Translated by Jean Steinberg. (Knopf, $22.95.) The way Marion Donhoff grew up is probably as foreign to most Americans as life in a novel by Goethe; it was certainly as romantic. The Countess, who is now the publisher of the Hamburg weekly Die Zeit, was the youngest daughter of an East Prussian family whose genealogical tree branched back to the Knights of the Teutonic Order, and she had the run of a castle and grounds visitors called "more beautiful than Versailles." Indeed, with the disappearance of East Prussia -- at the end of World War II, its castles were leveled and its land ceded to Poland -- the kind of childhood Countess Donhoff had has become something foreign to everyone. Whence the interest of "Before the Storm": it documents in knowing detail a semifeudal world most of us have glimpsed only in movies and caricatures, a world of kindly, paternalistic aristocrats and their class-conscious servants. "The cook would never have sat down to eat with the kitchen maids, nor the housekeeper with the housemaids," she writes; "the cook and the housekeeper ate in a separate room at a table to which only my mother's maid . . . [ was ] admitted." The tone of these memoirs, ably translated by Jean Steinberg, is unabashedly nostalgic, even, at times, defensive; the Countess's parents entertained lavishly, she tells us, but they lived austerely, and the children always rode third class. Countess Donhoff, however, is not sentimental. She frankly acknowledges the anti-Semitism of her parents' class, although, she explains, they also hated the Nazis. But the most powerful part of this book narrates her 1945 flight westward before the Red Army and the utter collapse of all she knew. "The end of East Prussia," she writes, "had come down to this: three dying soldiers trying to drag themselves across the Nogat bridge . . . and a woman on horseback, whose ancestors had come from the west into the wilderness east of this river six hundred years ago, riding back to the west -- six hundred years of history wiped out."

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PORTABLE PEOPLE. By Paul West. (Paris Review, Paper, $10.95.) All of us create for ourselves private pantheons inhabited by people we have never met but who nevertheless have left indelible impressions. Many of them live as vividly for us as people we encounter in daily life. The novelist Paul West shares with us his personal register of celebrities in "Portable People," a sly and witty updating of Aubrey's "Brief Lives." His 82 subjects range from Keats to Marlene Dietrich, Rodin to Chris Evert, Count Basie to Nabokov. His selections include artists, scientists, writers, musicians, athletes, statesmen, actors and a generous sprinkling of aviators. The archest of the lot present the subject speaking to us in the first person (Colette reflecting orgiastically on food, for one, or Richard Nixon on his Chinese hosts). The strongest contain memorable epigrams. Here, for example, is West on Evonne Goolagong: "Listen to her name: a puddle with a chime in it." And on Chris Evert: "Taut and tight-lipped mistress of the baseline, she is the all-American golden girl become the champion of monotony." Mr. West is most incisive about subjects that he takes most seriously: Simone Weil or Maurice Maeterlinck, Edith Sitwell or Samuel Beckett -- who, says Mr. West, "became a Frenchman so as to have no home to go to." Joe Servello's illustrations are sometimes inspired.

title: Letting Go
description: PATRIMONY A True Story. By Philip Roth. 238 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Travel Advisory; Phone Cards Gain in France
description: When in France, to telephone as the French do, use a telecarte. Telecartes are disposable phone cards that look like credit cards and are sold, in plastic wrappers, in cafes, at tobacconists and at post offices. Although using one costs slightly more than calling from a residential phone, the cards are cheaper than calling from a hotel or using an American telephone credit card. Public phones that accept coins or tokens are being replaced with telecarte machines. France-Telecom, the French telephone company, says that the system is available at about 25 percent of public telephones in France. Similar system are in place in Japan, Britain and Germany.

title: Glimpse of Where Homeless Go
description: UNIVERSITY students are drawing attention to the plight of the homeless with a window display in White Plains showing photographs of a shelter for the homeless and of mass graves for indigent children in New York City's Potter's Field. The display is at the Free Book Store, a shop on Main Street that benefits the homeless and is part of the Grace Episcopal Church community center.

title: Quarterbacks Need Protection
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Data Update
Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title: Postings: Homes Averaging $1 Million; 141 for the North Shore
description: For families "that have the wherewithal and staying power," say the press agents for Long Island's newest development of million-dollar houses, Gracewood at North Hills offers a location where the schools are superior, the shopping centers are sophisticated and the restaurants are fine.

title: Ruffles and Furbelows Make a Show of the Late 19th Century
description: ELABORATE dresses, embroidered hosiery and a ruffled wrap are among the women's clothes and accessories displayed in "The Gilded Age Emporium (1875-1900)" at the Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London. The exhibit also features dolls in furbelows and fur and a selection of men's apparel, including a suit in a style popularized by Queen Victoria's consort, Prince Albert. Accompanying the exhibit are three Sunday-afternoon lectures, starting today, on Victorian ideas of manhood, fashion, and dining.

title: The Lowly Bandanna: Styles in Tying One On
description: Bandannas -- emblazoned with boldly graphic images of folk heroes, political figures, comic characters, movie stars and World's Fairs -- are among the new collectibles, with a long past and a promising future.

title: Bridge
description: The world's most active bridge club, subject to any counter-claimants from China where the game is growing fast, is the Beverly at 130 East 57th Street in New York City. Day in, day out, afternoon and evening, the club averages more than 50 tables in play.

title: He Was Serenely Independent and Yet ...
description: A DAMNED SERIOUS BUSINESS By Rex Harrison. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE BRONX-WESTCHESTER CHRISTMAS COUNT CIRCLE;
65 Local Birdwatchers Take a Census and Log 117 Species
description: THEY start before daybreak and work until dusk. In chill early morning, dressed in warm clothes and, above all, hardy boots, they venture into woods, fields, marshes, even out onto jetties sticking far into the water. Equipped with binoculars, note pads and pencils and tape recorders, they are seeking just one thing: to glimpse, or merely to hear, as many birds as they can.

title: Miss Ernst to Wed Frederick Jenney
description: The engagement of Margaret Mary Ernst and Frederick Emerson Jenney has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. John T. Barton of Buffalo. Mr. Jenney is a son of Adele Gillespie Jenney of Arlington, Va., and Larry Lee Jenney of Alexandria, Va. Miss Ernst is also a daughter of the late John J. Ernst. A February wedding is planned.

title: Rena Epstein and Paul Filson Marry
description: Rena Joy Epstein and Paul Eliot Filson were married last evening at the Plaza Athenee in New York. Rabbi Lawrence Siegel performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. David Dyson, a Presbyterian minister who is the executive minister of Riverside Church.

title: Knocking At Door: The Wild Turkey
description: ONE morning in early autumn, Charles and Lillie DeBevoise glanced at their back porch in semisuburban Harding Township and saw two large, strange-looking creatures sharing birdseed with the sparrows and chickadees.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INVENTING CHAMPAGNE: The Worlds of Lerner and Loewe. By Gene Lees. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) A common criticism of today's musical theater is that emphasis is placed on spectacle above all else. One acid crack hurled now is that the audience leaves the theater humming the scenery. But in post-World War II America, when theatergoers left a Lerner and Loewe musical there was no question what was on their minds and lips: the fairy-tale stories and witty lyrics of Alan Jay Lerner and the beautiful music of Fritz Loewe. In "Inventing Champagne," Gene Lees reminds us of the phenomenal impact of the creators of the musicals "Brigadoon," "My Fair Lady" and "Camelot." Mr. Lees, the author of "Oscar Peterson" and "Singers and the Song," is in his element writing of the horrific rehearsals and openings of "My Fair Lady" and "Camelot." Prior to its New York opening, "Camelot" played in Toronto. Not only did the show run four and a half hours there, but Lerner entered the hospital with a bleeding ulcer, soon to be followed by the show's director, Moss Hart, who suffered his second coronary thrombosis. Despite Lerner and Loewe's professional and personal problems (Lerner was married eight times and was addicted to drugs), their musicals were what America saw, listened to and talked about. They, along with a handful of other librettists, lyricists and composers, helped define American popular culture.

title: Q and A
description: RTC Properties Question: I am interested in buying one of the homes being sold through the Resolution Trust Corporation. Is there a way to find out what is available in New York or California? . . . Gertrude Berger, Manhattan Answer: Yes. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency responsible for disposing of the properties that have gone into default as a result of the savings-and-loan crisis, will provide information on properties for sale through a toll-free number, 1 (800) 431-0600. You may also get lists of certain types of properties -- such as one-family homes -- in certain states or regions for $5 for the first 50 listings and 10 cents for each additional listing. A new list is now being prepared. Illegal Terrace Planters Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a building coverted to a co-op about two years ago. The apartment has a wrap terrace. When I moved in 17 years ago there were brick planters on each corner of the terrace. The building's management tells me that these planters are in violation of the city's Building Code and is holding me responsible for removing them. I have a floor plan showing that the planters were installed when the terrace was built. Am I now responsible for removing them? . . . Edward Vecchione, Manhhattan Answer: No. As a tenant of the apartment, you are not responsible for maintenance of the terrace or its structural features. "The tenant would have no right, responsibility or duty concerning the planters," said David L. Smith, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters. "The violation is the responsiblity of the landlord. Transferring Co-op Shares Question: My son died suddenly without a will. He was not married and had no children or siblings. I was appointed administrator of his estate. I believe he would have wanted to leave his co-op apartment to his roommate and would want me to transfer shares to her from the estate. But a board member says that this may cloud the title and has suggested that the shares be transferred first to me and then to her. I am concerned about being liable for charges, like gift taxes. Is this two-step process necessary? . . . Samuel Lee, Fair Lawn, N.J. Answer: Not according to Mark A. Goldsmith, a lawyer with the firm of Herrick, Feinstein who specializes in real estate tax matters. Mr. Goldsmith said that as the beneficiary, you would be considered the owner of the apartment and would be making a gift to the roommate no matter if the shares were transferred to you first or directly from the estate.

title: Columbia Astronaut Shares His Awe
description: ONCE it got off the ground, the Columbia space shuttle mission was a fabulous ride, said Dr. Jeffrey A. Hoffman, one of the seven astronauts aboard. Dr. Hoffman, a 1962 graduate of Scarsdale High School, called the trip a scientific success.

title: Travel Advisory; Soviets Open Four Cities
description: Tourists may now visit four cities in the Soviet Union that had been closed: Cherski (within the Arctic Circle), Yakutsk (on the Lena River), Vladivostok (the Soviet Union's main Pacific port) and Magadan (the point from which prisoners were sent to the gulags of the Soviet Far East).

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Highland Park, Ill.;
Shutting Out Train Sounds
description: UPSCALE condominiums are being built on a site close to the Chicago Northwestern commuter rail line in this affluent North Shore community outside Chicago. Trains running on the half hour from early morning to early evening pass, whistle blowing, within 30 feet of the five-story building.

title: I.B.M. Plan Stirs Critics
description: Mississippi welcomed 45,000 new first-graders this school year. If past statistics hold true, fewer than 30,000 of them will graduate from high school and many of those dropouts will join the one-third of all Mississippi adults who are illiterate.

title: Oh, What a Lovely Cold War
description: THE SECRET PILGRIM By John le Carre. 335 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Coins
description: Hawaii's first money was the Spanish milled dollar, that ubiquitous coin of Pacific trade. It brought a new concept to the people of the islands.

title: Another Compliment
description: To the Editor:

title: Kids In Cars
description: It is easy to predict what most parents will say when asked what the worst that could happen to them might be. It is the death of a child. But perhaps sometimes there is something worse than that. It is having a child die, and being somehow responsible for that death.

title: The Elderly Help the Elderly in Nassau
description: ANNA SAUNDERS of Baldwin was concerned about health-insurance coverage. At a consultation with Barbara Dank, project coordinator for Senior Financial Counseling, Mrs. Saunders, who is older than 60 and whose husband is a disabled veteran, wanted to find out if she was adequately covered.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT: N.C.A.A. Reforms Need More Work; Too Restrictive To Minor Sports
description: Recruiting scandals. Big-money payoffs. Gambling and point-shaving allegations. Altered transcripts and phony test scores. Substance abuse and unlawful behavior. The American public is painfully aware of the true picture of intercollegiate athletics.

title: Nobel Physicist Raises Alarm on U.S. Science
description: Despite the nation's growing budget problems, the next president of the country's largest general science organization plans to recommend that the Federal Government double the amount of money it spends on science.

title: . . . And the Lord Taketh Away
description: To the Editor:

title: John Rote to Wed Nadine E. Noyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Noyer of Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nadine Elizabeth Noyer, to John Matthew Rote, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Rote of Akron, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

title: U.S. and Philippines Set For New Talks on Bases
description: A deal on a new military basing agreement between the United States and the Philippines will probably not be reached before a Jan. 31 deadline imposed by President Corazon C. Aquino, negotiators for both sides say. But they are convinced that a deal will be struck before the old agreement expires on Sept. 16.

title: Army Reported Ready For Iraqi Germ Warfare
description: American military personnel in front-line positions in Saudi Arabia will be adequately protected against all but the heaviest doses of Iraqi biological warfare agents in the event of war, an Army expert says.

title: And So We Bid Farewell To Atonality
description: If we look back over 20th-century music, which we are now in a position to do, one fact stands out: severely atonal composition, once regarded as the wave of the future, is leaving remarkably few ripples. The seemingly irrevocable break with tonal music, with its hierarchy of pitches, its modulations and gravitations from key to key, was a long time coming, though it can be dated conveniently from Schoenberg's invention of the 12-tone system in the early 20's. The codification of atonality, however, was not simply one more step in an evolutionary process. In effect, it threw composers into unknown waters and held their heads under. A few survived to build academic careers, teaching the new orthodoxy. Many others, as they sank from view, could at least find solace in the belief that by abandoning tonality they were taking part in a necessary historical development.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title: The Answers
description: 1. Maj. Yuri Gagarin, a Soviet astronaut who orbited Earth in a vehicle named Vostok on April 12, 1961.

title: Campus Life: Trinity; A New Steward For Mark Twain's Personal Library
description: The spirit of Mark Twain will take on a new life in Hartford, where he once lived.

title: 'Golden Arches' Not Yet Approved
description: As was clear to careful readers of the Dec. 16 article on McDonald's, Southold is far from having "approved" the golden arches in Mattituck. At the moment, neither Southold's citizens nor its town government have given their approval to this newest attempt to siphon badly needed local dollars into distant coffers.

title: T.S. Matthews, 89, Ex-Editor of Time and Author
description: T. S. Matthews, a former editor of Time magazine, died on Friday at his home in Cavendish, England. He was 89 years old.

title: The Mass Media Is the Message
description: With an emotional depth and a comic flair worthy of the cinema's best short subjects, "The Bird and the Mouse" tells of a friendly rodent who teaches a baby robin to fly, later to be saved by the young avian from a ravenous hawk. Although done in simple black and white, the animated cartoon evidences creativity and pathos.

title: Karen L. Mizrahi, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Karen Lynn Mizrahi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Mizrahi of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Paul Martin Hertz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Hertz of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Jeffey Segelman and Cantor Martin Goldstein officiated at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: I.R.S. Sees Evidence of Wide Tax Cheating on Child Care
description: The Internal Revenue Service has striking new evidence that large numbers of Americans have been cheating on their taxes, claiming deductions for children who do not exist and child-care credits for baby sitters who are paid cash under the table.

title: Hello, Baghdad; Agreeing to Meet Puts New Pressure On U.S. and Iraq
description: WHO would have thought it? After five months of staring one another in the eye, George Bush blinked and Saddam Hussein blinked right back.

title: Among Shattered Young Souls
description: UNDER RUNNING LAUGHTER Notes From a Renegade Classroom. By Quincy Howe Jr. 156 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: Travel Advisory; Birthday Events for Henry VIII
description: This year, England celebrates the 500th anniversary of the birth of Henry VIII. Hampton Court Palace, west of London, is first to celebrate with its exhibit "Henry VIII -- Images of a Tudor King" in the Renaissance Picture Gallery. Tracing the evolution in images of Henry from accession in 1509 to his death 38 years later, the exhibit includes the only surviving portrait of him, a copy of one painted by Hans Holbein the Younger. Admission to the exhibit is included in the entrance fee to Hampton Court Palace: $8, $5 for children. Hours: 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. daily; information, dialed locally, 977 8441.

title: THE BRADYS AND THE GUN LOBBY
description: Those of us on the front lines of trauma care know all too well the tragedy of the Brady family. Perhaps if members of the gun lobby were to spend some time with us in the emergency rooms and operating rooms of trauma centers and see the thousands of victims brutalized by firearms, they would come to appreciate the profound tragedy that guns can produce. MICHAEL J. WEISS , M.D. Philadelphia

title: Ms. Wilson Weds Anthony Fleming
description: Edith Wilson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Wilson of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday at the Dwight Chapel at Yale University to Anthony David John Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Fleming of Leeds, England. The Rev. Richard G. Jordan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Piano; Recitalist's Bach, Prokofiev and Schumann
description: Eleonor Bindman, a pianist from Latvia who has been living in New York since 1979, played music by Bach, Prokofiev and Schumann in her debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening.

title:
FOCUS;
Federal Grants Help Nonprofits Serve Homeless
description: Three years of experience with a Federal program intended to keep homeless people off the streets appear to have demonstrated that more than housing is needed.

title: 'Hong Kong Boy': A College Student, and a Ghost Shadow
description: The shop owners along Mott Street in Chinatown call him Hong Kong Boy. He is a 20-year-old science major at a college in Queens. But his very existence, he says, is centered on Mott Street's choked sidewalks -- as a Ghost Shadow. The name of the gang is spoken softly, almost with veneration.

title: The Nation; Bomb Tests Not Gone or Forgotten
description: JUST when it appeared that the Congress, the Soviets and much of the American public had largely forgotten about nuclear testing, an unlikely coalition of third world countries and arms- control activists is rekindling the debate.

title: Where the Stars Dine Out
description: EVERY year, hundreds of thousands of people visit Los Angeles, hoping to see movie stars at work and at play. (After all, they can find beaches, freeways, smog, even Disneyland -- nowadays -- elsewhere. But when they say that Los Angeles is a company town, the town they mean is Hollywood.) To this end, hopeful tourists take the Universal Studios tour, buy maps to movie stars' homes, and ride around all day in sightseeing buses. But the only stars one sees at Universal are Jaws and King Kong (and only the top half of Kong, at that), the maps are long out-of-date, house windows shuttered, limousine windows smoked, and, once you've ascertained that your hand-and-footprints are bigger than Marilyn Monroe's and John Wayne's, literally if not figuratively speaking, you may find yourself standing in the forecourt of Mann's Chinese Theater wondering if that's all there is.

title: Kean at Drew: Economics and Bikes
description: In "For Kean, Drew Has Become a Laboratory for His Ideas" (Nov. 18), former Gov. Thomas Kean is quoted as saying: "One thing Keynesian and supply-side economists agree upon is that raising taxes in a falling economy is a mistake. I hope that if the economy continues to drop, the current administration will find some way to readjust the taxes."

title: BEST SELLERS: January 6, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 12 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age. 2 2 17 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 3 4 9 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 4 3 29 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride. 5 6 20 MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 6 5 6 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and romantic life of an eighth-generation California woman who becomes a celebrity photographer. 7 8 6 JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician's use of genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park threatens to become a global emergency. 8 9 30 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death. 9 15 3 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets, with surprising results for those past and present. 10 10 11 LONGSHOT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $19.95.) An author of survival guides attempts to write about the world of horse racing. 11 11 32 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 12 * 12 14 LADY BOSS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) Lucky Santangelo schemes and maneuvers to get control of a major movie studio. 13 7 4 CARL'S CHRISTMAS, by Alexandra Day. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A picture story about a dog who takes care of a baby while its parents perform Christmastime chores. 14 13 46 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 15 11 THE GENERAL IN HIS LABYRINTH, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $19.95.) The last, sad retrospective days of Simon Bolivar. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 8 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The memoirs of the itinerant television newscaster. 2 2 13 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 3 3 8 BO KNOWS BO, by Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The autobiography of the athlete who plays baseball for the Kansas City Royals and football for the Los Angeles Raiders. 4 4 15 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House. 5 5 8 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $8.95.) An illustrated gift edition of the inspirational essay, with new commentary. 6 6 7 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 7 7 12 THE CAT AND THE CURMUDGEON, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) The continuing contentions of two curmudgeons. 8 9 7 AN AMERICAN LIFE, by Ronald Reagan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The autobiography of the 40th President. 9 8 16 GET TO THE HEART, by Barbara Mandrell with George Vecsey. (Bantam, $19.95.) The autobiography of the country-music singer. 10 10 14 FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS, by H. G. Bissinger. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) A high school football season in Odessa, Tex. 11 12 4 SUDDENLY, by George F. Will. (Free Press, $19.95.) Essays about America's success in the cold war and the strains now developing in its society and Government. 12 15 52 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) A collection of inspirational essays. 13 11 3 IF I EVER GET BACK TO GEORGIA, I'M GONNA NAIL MY FEET TO THE GROUND, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $17.95.) The humorist recalls his Georgia boyhood and newspaper career. 14 22 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak and how the sexes can understand each other better. 15 14 95 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 5 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Ways to manage your money. 2 3 7 THE FRUGAL GOURMET ON OUR IMMIGRANT ANCESTORS, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $19.95.) Menus and recipes from 35 ethnic groups that immigrated to America. 3 5 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. 4 * 94 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's financial advice. 5 2 14 WHERE'S WALDO? by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a hitchhiker named Waldo. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: Campus Life: Tennessee; Campus Police Reject Assistance On Major Crimes
description: Amid charges of inadequate campus police protection, the University of Tennessee has refused an offer from the local police to investigate major crimes on campus.

title: Kite's Short Game Earns 2-Shot Lead
description: Tom Kite, giddy with anticipation entering his 20th year on the PGA Tour, shot past Lanny Wadkins today to take a two-shot lead into the final round of the Infiniti Tournament of Champions.

title: Priest in '05 Rising Served Czarist Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Is It Mahler? Or Is It Happy Talk?
description: "My time will come," Gustav Mahler prophesied, and history has proved him right. For me, in a less cosmic sense, Mahler's time came at about 3:30 of an insomniac morning in the late 60's. Having discovered classical music belatedly by way of rock and jazz, I had yet to warm to the Bohemian maximalist, whose Fourth Symphony was grinding away on the radio, occupying a sleepless hour without really filling it.

title: Miss Keating to Marry John Alter 3d
description: June wedding plans for Barbara Anne Keating and Ens. John William Alter 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alter Jr. of Potomac, Md., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kevin S. Keating of Darien, Conn.

title: FLASHCARD
description: PUBLIC television programs are used by 1.5 million teachers nationwide in classrooms from kindergarten through the 12th grade, according to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. There are more than 1,800 instructional series available each year on public television. More than 70 percent of public television stations broadcast programming specifically for use in the classroom, averaging about five hours a day. Instructional television programs include courses in foreign languages, mathematics, physical sciences and social sciences.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Good Word for Calcutta
description: If New York has a twin city in the language of urban despair, it is Calcutta. Any American deploring beggars and filth, crime and homelessness, almost reflexively invokes the warning name of India's huge and hopeless city. Yet in some ways the comparison is uninformed and, in Calcuttan eyes, cruelly unfair.

title: Ms. Reynolds to Wed M. L. Robertson
description: Sally Owen Reynolds and Richard Samuel Reynolds 3d of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Brice Reynolds to Matthew Leigh Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Leigh Robertson of Hinsdale, Ill. An April wedding is planned.

title: Islanders Go On Late Scoring Binge to Win
description: The Islanders, no strangers to grappling with deficits but rarely able to surmount them, upstaged the Flyers with a three-goal comeback in the final period tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title:
Focus: Housing the Homeless;
Federal Grants Bolstering Aid Programs
description: THREE years of experience with a Federal program intended to keep homeless people off the streets appear to have demonstrated that more than housing is needed.

title: Using an Oil Reserve to Control Prices
description: Oil prices are like a river that fluctuates wildly between flood stage and a trickle. To stabilize the river flow, you build a dam upstream, holding water back during flood season and releasing it during dry spells. The oil analogy is a reserve built up when prices are low, and gradually released when prices are high.

title: The Executive Computer; Are Computer Safety Laws Taking the Right Tack?
description: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors last month passed an ordinance that will require larger businesses in the city to pay more attention to the health and safety consequences of using computers in the workplace. The legislation, which Mayor Art Agnos signed after some last-minute compromises, is being heralded by labor unions as a model for other cities and counties.

title: Avianca Survivors Confront Their Fears
description: THE sun not yet risen, 10 survivors of the Avianca plane crash slowly made their way up the futuristic jetway of the Trans-World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport.

title: The World; Somalia, Abandoned To Its Own Civil War With Others' Weapons
description: IT has taken longer than many people thought, but the unraveling of Somalia, a small country that wraps like a boomerang around the eastern border of Ethiopia, is under way. Western nations started to weary of propping up one of Africa's most corrupt and brutal regimes two years ago. They regard last week's warfare in the capital, Mogadishu, as the final bloody coda: a struggle fought with rocket-propelled grenades, assault rifles and machine guns mounted on four-wheel-drive Toyotas stolen from aid agencies.

title: Unraveling Gulf Codes
description: Any activity that elicits fervent acclaim from political leaders, far and near, merits the microscopic scrutiny of humankind. I am thinking here of the swelling enthusiasm for direct talks between Washington and Baghdad.

title: Wendy Davidson Is Married on L.I.
description: Wendy L. Davidson and Jeffrey A. Krieger were married last Sunday at Temple Adas Israel in Sag Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Beth D. Davidson, the bride's sister, officiated. The bride is a daughter of Barbara A. Davidson of East Hampton, L.I., and the late Dr. David H. Davidson. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Krieger of Claremont, Calif.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Greenville, S.C.; Housing, Yes, Shopping, No
description: THE country's largest housing builder, Trammell Crow Residential Group, plans to go ahead with a 234-unit apartment complex here, but an adjoining retail development will not be built.

title: Winter Greens Add a Touch of Color During the Winter
description: WINTER greens aren't just for boiling with salt pork. Kale, collard, turnip and mustard greens are now showing up on the menus of sophisticated restaurants in fanciful ways. They are steamed and buttered and served alongside tiny lamb chops, or sauteed in olive oil with garlic and sprinkled with Parmesan cheese to go with an Italian dish.

title: Review/Television; When America Gave A Poor Account of Itself
description: If anyone can find comfort in the economic pains of the present from the recollection of miseries past, "After the Crash" should provide it. Tonight's chapter of "The American Experience," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49 and at 10:30 on Channel 21, tells of the bitter years 1930 to 1932, when hunger, homelessness and hopelessness spread through the land, and the United States seemed close to revolution.

title: Bridge
description: One of the hardest workers for the game in New York City is Saul Bronstein, who was for many years executive secretary of the Greater New York Bridge Association and has trained a small army of promising novices at his Academy Club. He works equally hard at the bridge table, as the diagramed deal from a club duplicate game illustrates. As South he landed in three spades after his partner, stretching his values or perhaps miscounting his points, opened one diamond. The two-spade bid was chancy, but North obliged by having a fit.

title: Miss Edersheim Weds B. A. Tuckman
description: Katherine Ann Edersheim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans S. Edersheim of New York, was married yesterday to Bruce Aaron Tuckman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Tuckman of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Neil Gilman performed the ceremony at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: USX Reopening Talks With Steelworkers
description: The USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America will reopen negotiations today that could determine whether the nation's largest steelmaker can retain the edge in cheaper labor costs it has enjoyed over its rivals for two years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Rhode Island Announces Bank Withdrawal Plan
description: Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun of Rhode Island has announced emergency withdrawal plans for residents left without money after he ordered 45 banks and credit unions to close last week.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Pagano Schenck & Kay, Providence, R.I., will handle the Rhode Island Zoological Society.

title: Midlife Executive Crisis Shakes Ad Agency
description: It is a 1991 story with the elements of the melodramas that played repeatedly on Madison Avenue in the 1980's, including a top advertising executive frustrated by his loss of autonomy after selling his shop and a creative department grown disgruntled as the agency chased larger and more conservative accounts.

title: Search for Piece of Past Offers Lesson for Future
description: Ruth McCarty and her colleagues on the Lyndon Bicentennial Commission have looked everywhere. They have looked in attics and basements, bank vaults and file cabinets. And still no time capsule.

title: IRAQI WARNS ARMY TO PREPARE ITSELF FOR MAJOR BATTLE
description: Three days before his Foreign Minister is to meet Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Geneva to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, President Saddam Hussein told his armed forces today that they were prepared to go to war to keep Kuwait a part of Iraq.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A novel by PAUL AUSTER has been named the best book of 1990 by the French literary journal Lire. "Moon Palace," which has been a bestseller abroad and was published in the United States last year by Viking, was named No. 1 of 20 top books selected by Lire's editors.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Offer to Help Investigation of Helicopter Deaths
description: Rebels offered today to cooperate with "any type of investigation" into the killing of two United States soldiers whose helicopter was shot down on Wednesday in a guerrilla stronghold in the eastern part of the country.

title: Oakland Paper Seeks Pay Cuts
description: Executives of The Tribune in Oakland have asked 600 employees to take 11 percent pay cuts so it can meet this month's payroll, union officials said Friday. The Tribune's managing editor, Eric Newton, said the company and union officials had agreed not to discuss the proposal publicly.

title: Europeans Press Baghdad on Talks
description: The European Community urged Baghdad today to reconsider its refusal to allow Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to meet three European foreign ministers this week.

title: BUSH MAY CALL OFF FEBRUARY MEETING WITH SOVIET CHIEF
description: In the clearest sign of newly emerging problems in Soviet-American relations, President Bush is on the verge of postponing a summit meeting scheduled for Moscow in February because of differences over arms control and uncertainty in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 7, 1990: MONDAY Central Vt Pub Svc Oxford Inds TUESDAY Weyerhaeuser Co WEDNESDAY Bard CR Inc USLife Income FD CBI Inds Walgreen Co Southwestern Pub Svc Woolworth Corp THURSDAY Adams Express Petroleum & Res Corp GTE Corp Rubbermaid Inc Idaho Power FRIDAY Flowers Inds Travelers Corp Mercury Fin Unum Corp

title: Claim You're Gay, Avoid the Military
description: The large-scale build-up of American troops in the Persian Gulf has led many to call for reinstatement of the military draft. Some experts believe that if a shooting war lasted longer than a few months, the military may need more troops than are now available among both active duty and reserve personnel. Shortfalls might have to be made up from conscription.

title: The Nuclear Priority
description: The Persian Gulf crisis has focused our minds again on the danger of proliferating atomic weapons. The idea of Iraq with nuclear missiles is worrying enough. But that development would surely also encourage other third world countries to try to join the club.

title: One Last Deadly Crossing for Illegal Aliens
description: Hundreds of illegal immigrants coming north from Mexico have been killed or injured in the past four years as they try to run across highways in an effort to avoid capture by immigration agents.

title: Congress's Calhoun Strategy
description: Under pressure from some senators, George Mitchell, the majority leader, is finally getting around to scheduling a debate on the gulf war before Jan. 15. That's the date President Bush considers himself authorized by the United Nations to use force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.

title: EPISCOPAL MEETING TO STAY IN ARIZONA
description: The executive council of the Episcopal Church has decided to hold the church's convention in Phoenix this summer despite requests that it be moved because Arizona voters rejected a paid state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Patriots Said To Hire Coach
description: The New England Patriots will hire Dick MacPherson, the Syracuse coach, as their new head coach, according to a television report yesterday.

title: FATHER'S INQUIRY LEADS TO ARRESTS
description: Frustrated with police progress in solving the killing of his only son four years ago, Joseph Viscido spent $50,000 investigating the case on his own. His efforts have led to the jailing of three men on first-degree murder charges.

title: Bank News Provides No Cause for Calm
description: To the Editor:

title: Baker Spurns European Plan on Gulf
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States could not support a French plan for resolving the Persian Gulf crisis because it linked an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to a settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Cuomo's Ties With Dinkins Are Splintered
description: A year after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo helped Mayor David N. Dinkins get elected, the once-warm relationship between their administrations has become a casualty of New York's growing fiscal problems.

title: Obsolete Tracking System Delayed Rescue of 1,000 Riders in Subway Fire
description: Behind the confusion and delay that have been cited in the response to a subway fire that killed two riders in New York City last month stands an antiquated system for tracking trains and an inadequate radio system, say some transit officials and investigators who are looking into the incident.

title: Confessions of an Ex-Cyberpunk
description: I'm 39 years old. In my early 30's, I wrote "Frontera," which has appeared on a few lists of formative cyberpunk novels.

title: America's Duty to New York; Fighting for Fairness: II
description: The poorhouse costs long borne by major cities stand out even more grimly and unfairly in the rising fiscal storms. New York City now spends almost a fifth of its municipal revenues on welfare, foster care, Medicaid and shelters. That leaves billions less to fight crime, clean streets and fix bridges.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Celtics 127, Mavericks 110: Larry Bird and Kevin McHale keyed a 42-point second quarter as Boston rallied from a 16-point deficit to gain its 16th consecutive home victory. While improving their season record to 26-5, their best since a similar start in the 1984-85 season, the Celtics recorded their 400th regular-season home victory since Bird joined the club in 1979. (AP) College Basketball Arkansas 95, Houston 79 : At halftime yesterday, Houston's 7-foot-1-inch Alvaro Teheran had five offensive rebounds and 16 points and the Cougars were within 4 points of second-ranked Arkansas. Teheran managed only 2 points and no offensive rebounds in the second half, and Houston couldn't stay with the Razorbacks, who pulled away for the victory at Fayetteville, Ark. The Razorbacks improved to 13-1 over all and 2-0 in the Southwest Conference. Houston is 9-3 and 1-1. (AP) Georgia Tech 101, Wake Forest 91: Kenny Anderson scored 32 points, including 10 in 43 seconds midway through the second half, as Georgia Tech (6-3 and 1-0), playing at home, gained its sixth consecutive victory. Wake Forest (6-3 and 1-1) pulled within 8 points twice in the last seven minutes, but the Georgia Tech guard Brian Domalik made three 3-pointers, his only points of the game. (AP) Hockey Devils 2, Dynamo Moscow 2: The Devils, returning home after three losses and a tie on the road that dropped them to fourth place in the Patrick Division, rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 2-2 tie with Dynamo Moscow last night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Ravil Yakurov and Aleksandr Semak, who was drafted by the Devils in the 12th round in 1988, scored the goals for Dynamo against Chris Terreri, who replaced Sean Burke after 30 minutes. The Devils got their goals in the third period, from Doug Brown and Zdeno Ciger. Ciger tied the score with 11 seconds left after the Devils had pulled Terreri for an extra skater. Tennis Kulti Wins in Australia: Niclas Kulti of Sweden overcame a midmatch slump yesterday to defeat Michael Stich of Germany, 6-3, 1-6, 6-2, to win the Australian hardcourt championship in Adelaide, Australia. Kulti's victory was the first of his professional career. Kulti, an unseeded 19-year-old, won three straight service games without dropping a point and broke Stich's serve in the sixth and eighth games. (AP) Fromberg Takes BP Nationals: Richard Fromberg of Australia beat Lars Jonsson of Sweden in straight sets to win the BP Nationals in Wellington, New Zealand. Fromberg won the opening event of the 1991 Association of Tennis Professionals tour with a 6-1, 6-4, 6-4 victory. (AP) Sukova Triumphs: Helena Sukova overpowered Akiko Kijimuta of Japan, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in straight sets to win the Danone Open in Brisbane, Australia. (AP) Skiing 2d Victory for Gutensohn: Katrin Gutensohn of Germany, the defending World Cup downhill champion, won her second downhill race of the season yesterday, edging Sabine Ginther of Austria and leaving her main rival, Petra Kronberger, far behind. Gutensohn skied the fast Strohsack course in Bad Kleinkircheim, Austria, in 1 minute 36.03 seconds, finishing 0.30 seconds ahead of Ginther. Kronberger was racing with her hand in a light plaster cast. (AP) Heinzer Moves Up: Gunther Mader of Austria won a men's Super-G race, while Franz Heinzer of Switzerland became the skiing World Cup overall leader by finishing second. (AP) Horse Racing True and Blue Wins: Benefiting from patient handling by Julie Krone, Robert Bauer's True and Blue made a strong late run for a 1 1/4-length victory in the $87,000 Paumonok Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The winner, carrying 112 pounds, covered six furlongs on a fast track in 1:10 2/5. Dargai finished second in the eight-horse field, a nose ahead of Man It's Cold. The victory was the 24th in 70 career starts for True and Blue, who returned $10.60, $5.20 and $4.20 for $2 across the board. (AP) Swimming Break-Stroke Mark Equaled: Norbert Rozsa of Hungary equaled the men's 100-meter breast-stroke world record at the world swimming championships in Perth, Australia, yesterday. Rozsa clocked 1 minute 1.49 seconds in the heats to equal the mark set three times by Adrian Moorhouse of Britain. Moorhouse swam 1:01.88 in the same heat as Rozsa. (Reuters) Boxing Hill Keeps Title: Virgil Hill won a unanimous decision from Mike Peak in Bismarck, N.D., last night to retain the World Boxing Association light heavyweight title. (Reuters)

title: Israeli Jets Attack P.L.O. Base in Lebanon
description: Israeli Air Force jets attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base in southern Lebanon today, killing one guerrilla and wounding six others, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines; Threats to Mass Circulation On Demographic Landscape
description: PETER FRANCESE, the publisher of American Demographics magazine, compares himself to the inspector who knocks on the door in the middle of a hurricane and wants to talk about termites.

title: Bears Smother Saints
description: For those who did not care who won today, the game was methodical and unexciting. For those who loved the Bears, it was a work of art. Their relentless defense shut down the New Orleans Saints, and their offense, also known as Neal Anderson, did enough to win, 16-6.

title: Bernard Hellring Is Dead at 74; Battled to Improve Varied Laws
description: Bernard Hellring, a leader in efforts to simplify and standardize state and national laws, particularly in business affairs, legislative apportionment and divorce, died on Friday in Orange, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: Rift Over Latvian Paper Taxes Moscow
description: A continuing dispute over control of the main newspaper printing plant in Latvia has dramatically intensified the conflict between the central authorities in Moscow and Baltic independence movements since the New Year.

title: The Czech Literati: Too Old to Be New, But New Nevertheless
description: After decades of censorship and imprisonment, Czechoslovakia's writers are mounting a literary revolution after the political revolution that ended Communist rule. Nearly every author, editor and samizdat publisher in the country has a story to tell.

title: Let's Talk About Reparations for Slavery; Not Devastation
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Pare Financial Supervision
description: The Bush Administration is preparing to recommend the creation of a "super regulator" of banks, savings associations and other financial services, in a sweeping overhaul of the complex regulatory system.

title: Despite Economic Woes, 2 States Seek More School Spending
description: When legislatures in Texas and Mississippi reconvene this week, they will renew their drives to raise more money for public education, in laborious efforts that have attracted widespread attention elsewhere.

title: Revived Dolphins Make Shula Beam
description: Too often in the last four football seasons, the ear-splitting devotion of south Florida for its Miami Dolphins has seemed to vanish into the suburban sprawl, forfeited when the team headed north from the Orange Bowl in search of the comfortable seat and the convenient parking spot.

title: U.S. IS TAKING OVER A GROUP OF BANKS TO HEAD OFF A RUN
description: Acting to avert a run on one of the nation's largest banking companies, the Federal Government today seized the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks and said it would protect all depositors until the banks could be sold.

title: Boy, 7, and Teen-Ager Shot
description: A 7-year-old boy and a teen-age girl were shot and wounded yesterday in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn when an argument between a woman and the teen-ager over clothing ended in gunfire, the police said. The boy, who was not identified, was shot in the ankle, and the 16-year-old girl, identified as Florence Thompson, was shot in the calf, a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, said. The police arrested Roberta Bedney, 24, of 486 Marcy Avenue, and charged her with first-degree assault and criminal possession of a weapon, Sergeant Mohrmann said. The shooting took place in front of 347 Greene Avenue, she said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Turmoil in Banking

title: U.S. Hardens Trade Stance With Japan
description: The Bush Administration has turned more truculent in its economic relations with Tokyo, reflecting both frustration over Japanese trading policies and unease over a wave of Japanese investments in the United States.

title: Rome Journal; Retiring a Token Makes Big Issue of Small Change
description: Obscured by oddments like the Persian Gulf crisis and Western Europe's latest gyrations toward unity was a recent notice that a small piece of Italian tradition is about to fade away.

title: Fire at Penn Station Prompting a Review Of Safety Procedure
description: Officials from Amtrak and the New York City Fire Department met yesterday and insisted that their workers had followed prescribed procedures during a fire on Saturday at Pennsylvania Station. But since it took more than two hours to put out the small fire, the officials agreed that both agencies should reconsider those procedures.

title: Syracuse Streak Ends at 13
description: Rollie Massimino, the basketball coach at Villanova, called his team's 76-66 victory at Syracuse on Saturday night "gigantic." His inexperienced Wildcats had lost four of five games before they challenged the undefeated Orangemen in the Carrier Dome.

title: With a New Hybrid Government, Weicker Is Facing a Budget Crisis
description: An unfamiliar hybrid form of state government is shaping up here, charged with the job, beginning this week, of addressing a budget crisis that is equally unfamiliar in its severity. At the center ring in both cases is Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: Market Place; A Profitable Year For Global Bonds
description: INVESTORS in government bonds around the world generally fared much better than their counterparts in stocks last year. The government bond markets in Britain, Spain, Italy and Australia all posted big gains. In the two worst-performing markets, Japan and Germany, a strong fourth quarter enabled investors to break even. That was better than the stock market did in 1990 and much bettter than the bond markets did in 1989.

title: I.B.M. Contract At Tax Agency
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has won a contract worth as much as $339.6 million to computerize the Internal Revenue Service's tax collection system.

title: Remarks by Hussein to Troops on Kuwait
description: Following are excerpts from a televised speech by President Saddam Hussein today as translated by The Associated Press from a transcript distributed by the Iraqi News Agency:

title: Penalties Against Upsala Upheld
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today upheld the stiffest sanctions ever applied to a Division III school when it let stand penalties imposed on Upsala College last year.

title: Corporate Issuers in Rush to Sell
description: Early January has usually been a sleepy time in the corporate bond market. But Saddam Hussein and the looming Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to pull out of Kuwait have made the beginning of 1991 an exception.

title: Votes Backing Use of Force Are Predicted in Congress
description: The likelihood of formal Congressional support for an attack on Iraq increased sharply yesterday when the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, said the House would vote on the issue this week and would probably "narrowly" support a decision by President Bush to use force.

title: Blackhawks Follow Their Leader to Top of League
description: The National Hockey League season is much like an N.H.L. game in that it can be divided into three distinct periods. The first period is the first half of the regular season, played mostly in autumn; the second period is the second half of the regular season, played mostly in winter, and the third period is the Stanley Cup playoffs, played in the spring.

title: F.D.I.C. Statement on Bank of New England
description: Following is the text of a statement issued this evening by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation regarding its takeover of the Bank of New England Corporation's three main subsidiary banks:

title: Carlson Was No Star, and No Moon
description: CODY CARLSON seemed to be lending a very close, if helmeted, ear to Warren Moon. It was on the moist sideline early in the second quarter of the Cincinnati-Houston first-round American Football Conference playoff game here yesterday and Carlson, the Oilers' active quarterback by virtue of a busted thumb to Moon, was apparently consuming copious wisdom from his injured predecessor.

title: The Letter
description: The most historic document of George Bush's Presidency is now in the pocket of his Secretary of State, who is en route to Geneva to deliver it personally to his Iraqi counterpart. It is the letter of final warning to Saddam Hussein.

title: Founder Sells Agency
description: Charles McKinney, founder of McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C., has sold the agency to a group of its executives headed by Bob Doherty, president and chief executive. Terms were not disclosed. "It came about because Mr. McKinney wants to retire," Mr. Doherty said. The agency has billings of about $100 million.

title: The Gulf and Capitol Hill
description: The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, indicated a sharp increase in the likelihood of formal Congressional support for an attack on Iraq, saying the House would vote this week on the issue. Page A11.

title: Stations Seek More Profits on News
description: A week from today, the NBC television station in Washington, Channel 4, will start a weeknight newscast at 7:30 -- but on a rival station, Channel 50.

title: Question Box
description: Home Runs by McGwire

title: Former Chief of Duvalier's Militia Claims Power After Coup in Haiti
description: Haiti's provisional leader resigned early today and Roger Lafontant, a supporter of the former Duvalier dictatorship, claimed power in an apparently bloodless coup late Sunday.

title: Morris County Sees Taxes Rise As Values Fall
description: After a 10-year boom in construction and property values, the taxable worth of real estate is dropping in Morris County, all but guaranteeing higher property taxes for homeowners.

title: Miss Amler Weds T. M. Goldstein
description: Jennifer Lynne Amler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Amler of New York, and Thomas Matthew Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Goldstein of Rockville Centre, L.I., were married yesterday at the Tower Suite in New York. Rabbi Jeffrey K. Salkin officiated.

title: Soviets Raise Hopes on Answers to Korean Crash
description: Recent Soviet statements about their shooting down of a South Korean airliner in 1983 have raised hopes that Moscow might provide missing official data on where the jumbo jet crashed and whether the bodies of any of the 269 victims were recovered.

title: U.S.-Soviet Space Deal
description: The United States is completing a deal to buy an advanced type of nuclear reactor built by the Soviet Union to generate power in space, Federal officials say. Unthinkable a year or two ago, the deal would be the first major sale between the former antagonists of a sensitive space technology with military potential. Article, page B8.

title: 5 Airlines, Citing War Fears, Suspending Flights to Israel
description: Airport officials said this weekend that the number of airlines announcing a temporary suspension of service to Israel in the gulf crisis had risen to five. The airlines are blaming skyrocketing insurance rates based on fears of a war.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AMENDMENT CONFERENCE TO PARTIAL TEST BAN TREATY -- 3 P.M.

title: A Success Story Turn Sour in New England
description: In only a year, the Bank of New England was transformed from a regional banking powerhouse into a ward of the state, waiting for Federal regulators to choose how and when they will sell it.

title: New, Light Model
description: Spectra, a new synthetic fiber that is being used in bullet proof vests, helicopter shields and sails for yachts, has now found its way into tennis racquets. Ellipse Sport, a company based in Redmond, Wash., was founded last year with development of its line of Spectra racquets. Tom Barrows, president of Ellipse, said recently that his company has an informal agreement with Allied-Signal, the firm that manufactures Spectra, to be the sole tennis racquet producer using the material.

title: Hong Kong Symbol Looks Away
description: From the days of opium and cannons to those of Valium and satellites, there has been one pre-eminent address in Hong Kong: 1 Queens Road, headquarters of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. It is the nexus of power and money, and these days an emblem of the difficulties of big Hong Kong businesses and of international banking as well.

title: Seething at 'Second Echelon'
description: THIS toddlin' town has seethed ever since A. J. Leibling dubbed it the "second city," meaning New York was first. And now, quietly and smugly, the Chicago Bears are seething about being considered in the "second echelon" of Super Bowl XXV contenders, meaning somewhere below that of the San Francisco 49ers, the Giants and the Buffalo Bills.

title: How About a G.I. Bill for Everyone?
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Killed as Airplane Crashes Into an Icy Field in Oklahoma
description: An eight-seat, twin-engine Cessna crashed shortly after taking off Saturday night in freezing drizzle here, and six people were killed.

title: Let's Talk About Reparations for Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Faso; Reporter, 54
description: Frank Faso, a Daily News reporter for 33 years who investigated organized crime, died yesterday at John F. Kennedy Hospital in Lake Worth, Fla.. He was 54 years old and lived in Lake Worth.

title: U.S. May Alter Student Lending To Skirt Banks
description: The Bush Administration is considering major changes in the student loan program that would increase direct lending by the Federal Government and sharply curtail the role of commercial banks, which now lend more than $12 billion a year to college students.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Consumer Credit . . . Nov. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Producer Price Index . . . Dec.

title: Plan for a "Super Regulator"
description: The Bush Administration is preparing to recommend a sweeping overhaul of the regulatory system, combining many functions of the eight Federal agencies that oversee financial institutions. Page D1.

title: New Federal Report Lends Urgency To Dispute Over O'Hare Expansion
description: A dispute over expanding O'Hare Airport, the clogged pivot of the nation's air traffic system, has taken on new urgency in the wake of a report by the Secretary of Transportation, Samuel K. Skinner.

title: Challenges and Rewards of Filming in New York
description: Deep in the winter of New York's discontent, when film making in the Big Apple has nearly come to a standstill because of cold weather and the lingering effects of a labor dispute, a hardy band of film makers is fighting gridlock, inflationary costs, chill winds and the wail of sirens to shoot an entire movie in New York City, about a quintessential New York theme: a slumlord who gets his comeuppance.

title: Louis Pergament; Executive, 86
description: Louis Pergament, who opened a home-improvement store in 1935 in Franklin Square, L.I., which grew into the Pergament Home Centers chain, died early Saturday in the emergency room of Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. A resident of Palm Beach, he was 86 years old.

title: Jackson Sparkles In Knick Victory
description: An optimist would say the Knicks are building momentum. A skeptic would say the Knicks are simply abusing weaker teams.

title: Prague Will Stop Representing Cuba in U.S.
description: Czechoslovakia has decided it will no longer represent Cuba in Washington, forcing the Cuban Interests Section to scurry in search for a new sponsor in another sign of Havana's growing isolation.

title: A Champion of the Sweet Tooth Is Closed
description: Another New York landmark closed up shop yesterday. As the last prune Danishes, coffee cakes and Rigo Jancsi chocolate cakes went over the counter, customers shook their heads sadly, as if they were losing a member of the family with the death of Grossinger's Home Bakery.

title: 72-Point Performance Erases Maravich's Record
description: It has been a final season to remember for Kevin Bradshaw and United States International University, and they can thank Loyola Marymount for the memories.

title: Lisa R. Zimmer, Student, Marries
description: Lisa Rachel Zimmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Zimmer of Livingston, N.J., was married there last evening at Temple Beth Shalom to Joshua Bruce Lisser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Lisser of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner and Cantor Henry Butensky performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Television; Espionage As the Base Of a Good Marriage
