description: Espionage and television's action-adventure genre were clearly made for each other. It all began in the McCarthyite 1950's when Federal Bureau of Investigation characters were forever finding Commies under beds. Subsequent treatments, involving an international array of intelligence organizations, covered everything from the derring-do exploits of "Mission: Impossible" to the dark duplicities of John le Carre adaptations.

title: Yellowstone's Rising Tourism Sets Off Debate
description: Two years of record tourism have shown that Yellowstone National Park did not lose its luster as a result of wildfires that swept across vast areas of the park in 1988. But the crowds have also touched off a debate over how many visitors the park can tolerate.

title: Transit Budget Cuts Hit Brooklyn Disproportionately Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHOSHANA SHOUBIN CARDIN has been elected chairwoman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, which represents 46 national groups. Mrs. Cardin, the first woman to hold the job in the conference's 31-year history, will begin her yearlong term later this month.

title: Saints Rue Crucial Penalty
description: It was one of those memorable plays that electrify a tepid football game, dramatically changing the momentum and propelling the underdog to an upset on enemy turf -- almost.

title: Kite, With a Final 69, Outlasts Wadkins
description: As he has during his entire career, Tom Kite combined steadiness with resiliency this afternoon, outlasting Lanny Wadkins and winning the Infiniti Tournament of Champions here at the La Costa Resort and Spa.

title: Turning Disease Into Political Cause: First AIDS, and Now Breast Cancer
description: Women with breast cancer are taking a lesson from AIDS advocacy groups and using political action to urge the Federal and state governments to pay more attention to their disease.

title: Saudi King Says He Expects Iraq to Yield
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia said today that he shared President Bush's impression that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would withdraw his forces from Kuwait in compliance with the United Nations Security Council deadline of Jan. 15.

title: Thatcher Will Lead a Group Opposed to a Federal Europe
description: Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has agreed to become the first president of a bipartisan group of British lawmakers opposed to a federal Europe, British newspapers reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "They showed us how to get through to the Government. They took on an archaic system and turned it around while we have been quietly dying." -- Shiela Swanson, a breast cancer patient, on learning from AIDS groups. [ A12:1. ]

title: Let's Talk About Reparations for Slavery; Sliced Too Fine
description: To the Editor:

title: Feel Fit and Trim With Flo Motion
description: IN the mid 1960's, Victor Blome was a teen-ager growing up in Barrington, N.J. He worked at a summer job collecting worms for a fish food dealer. The job required that Blome sift through the muck of river bottoms by screening silt through an elongated, tube-shaped bag. He would fling the bag over his head, and move it side to side, in patterns that he says became quite fancy.

title: Books of The Times; After the Thaw, le Carre Sums Up
description: The Secret Pilgrim By John le Carre 335 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.95.

title: Czarist Bond Claims Haven't Been Settled
description: To the Editor:

title: Bengals Trounce Oilers
description: Coach Sam Wyche had an unusual feeling this morning before his Cincinnati Bengals faced the Houston Oilers: His team was going to play a perfect game.

title: Koncak Is Earning That Big Salary
description: Jon Koncak began college life at Southern Methodist University as a pre-med student. But standing 7 feet tall and weighing 250 pounds, he eventually became a professional basketball player, and he now earns $2.1 million a year with the Atlanta Hawks.

title: More Recess Appointments
description: President Bush's appointment of 11 directors for the Legal Services Corporation brings to 53 the number of recess appointments he and President Reagan have made to the agency. That must be some kind of record for cynical mismanagement.

title: Giants' Walls May Lose Job
description: In 1981, as a rookie, Everson Walls showed he was a smothering pass defender and became a starting cornerback for the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Lori C. Berman Weds Gary D. Wolf on Long Island
description: Lori C. Berman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Berman of Brooklyn, and Gary D. Wolf a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wolf of Ridegfield, N.J., was married yesterday at Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Kenneth Hain performed the ceremony.

title: Arnold Rosenblum; Physicist, 45
description: Dr. Arnold Rosenblum, the director of the International Institute of Theoretical Physics at Utah State University, died on Tuesday at his home in Logan, Utah. He was 45 years old.

title: Oil Leaks Near Puget Sound
description: An underground pipeline used to transfer oil off a ship docked near Puget Sound apparently ruptured today, leaking an estimated 400,000 gallons of Alaskan crude into a drainage ditch. There were no immediate reports of damage to wildlife, said oil company and state officials. A small amount of oil seeped into Blair Waterway, where the ship was docked, said Bill Daberock, administrative services manager for the U.S. Oil and Refining Company.

title: For Some, Neediest Cases Is a Link to Home
description: After nine years away from New York, spent living in southern California, Lee Englander recently sent $35 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and wrote, "From a very homesick New Yorker."

title: A Tennis Twist to Day Care
description: WHEN Papa Agassi constructed a tennis ball mobile above Andre's crib and encouraged him to swipe at it with a Ping-Pong paddle, maybe he was on to something. These days no age seems too early to introduce a child to the game.

title: Noise Is Fine, but the Mud Is the Key
description: John Pascal has been to the opera, the ballet and the theater. He has seen the Ice Capades and the Rockettes. But never before had he seen fire-belching drag racers spinning through 30 inches of mud or balloon-tired trucks crushing parked cars.

title: Lord Einstein, HDM Merge
description: As Patrick Hillman took his last walk through the offices of HDM New York after resigning as its president last week, he may have bumped into executives from Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WENDY WASSERSTEIN paid a call on an old friend when she visited the National Museum of Women in Washington. In her Tony- and Pulitzer Prize-winning play, "The Heidi Chronicles," the leading character is an art historian who lectures on Lilla Cabot Perry, an American Impressionist in the late 19th and early 20th century. A retrospective of the artist is on view at the museum, and Ms. Wasserstein went to see it on Friday.

title: Charges May Be Filed After Fire Kills Four
description: The police were investigating today whether to file criminal child-neglect charges against the babysitter of four children who were killed today in a fatal fire.

title: U.S. Has Highest Rate of Imprisonment in World
description: With more than one million people behind bars, the United States imprisons a larger share of its population than any other nation, a private research organization has reported.

title: Critic's Notebook; Luring Actors Back to the Stage They Left Behind
description: Before he charmed movie audiences, Macaulay Culkin, the 9-year-old star of the high-grossing comedy "Home Alone," had a brief though notable career on the New York stage. In 1987, at the age of 6, he acted in "Afterschool Special," a surrealistic one act by Keith Reddin, in the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual marathon of short plays.

title: For a Soviet Military Editor, Battling Changes, Even Hitler Serves The Cause
description: Since taking over as editor of an obscure Defense Ministry magazine two and a half years ago, Maj. Gen. Viktor I. Filatov has lived up to his own standard for what a monthly should do: pack enough scandal into each issue to keep tongues wagging all month long.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Playing 9 Holes When Weather Outside Is Frightful
description: WINTER can be a trying time for golfers in northern climes. Local courses are closed, buried beneath snow and ice, and dream courses in Miami, Honolulu and Phoenix too often remain just dreams. Other than putting across carpets or driving buckets of balls at indoor practice ranges, there is little to be done about winter except wait for it to pass.

title: Outdoors: Sea Duck Shooting Has Rough Rewards
description: Late-season sea duck shooting, which is taking place right now in some Northeast coastal states, is not for those who wish to hunt in comfort. The sea ducks, scoters, eiders and old squaws will not, with rare exceptions, be taken from sheltered, conventional shore-based blinds.

title: For Rangers, 2 Goalies Are No. 1
description: CONFUSION had crept quickly into Roger Neilson's eyes as he gazed across a Madison Square Garden conference room crowded with reporters earlier this season. To that point, the news conference, following a triumph over the Washington Capitals, had unfolded typically enough, the coach of the Rangers answering questions with his mix of intentional understatement and dry humor.

title: U.S. Is Ready to Buy an Advanced Soviet Reactor
description: The United States is completing a deal to buy an advanced type of nuclear reactor built by the Soviet Union to generate power in space, Federal officials say. The transaction would be the first major sale between the former antagonists of a sensitive space technology with military potential.

title: Rules for Journalists: Necessity or Prior Restraint?
description: The Pentagon is establishing a system for covering a war in the Persian Gulf that would impose much stricter restrictions on journalists than they were subjected to during the Vietnam War.

title: 4 Apparent Victims of Fumes
description: Three men and a pregnant woman were found dead in their one-bedroom apartment on Saturday, apparent victims of poisonous fumes from a faulty heater vent, the authorities said. "At this time, it appears they are victims of asphyxiation due to a ventilation problem of a gas wall heater," a police dispatcher, Connie Troutt, said. The victims, all Vietnamese refugees, were in their 20's and 30's, friends and neighbors said.

title: Accounts
description: * Estee Corp., Parsippany, N.J., to Pedone & Partners, New York, for its dietetic foods and China Bowl foods accounts, with a budget of $3 million to $5 million. The account was previously handled by Lohmeyer Simpson Communications. * Spa Lady, a women's fitness chain, to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, with a budget of $1.5 million.

title: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sale
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes the regular weekly auction today of three- and six-month bills and the auction on Wednesday of seven-year notes. The Government has also scheduled an auction of a one-year bill on Thursday.

title: Union Accuses 98 Members Of Strikebreaking at News
description: As a bitterly divisive strike at The Daily News entered its 11th week, the newspaper's largest union announced yesterday that it had filed charges of illegal strikebreaking against 98 of its own members.

title: Vietnam's Brave Voices
description: Bui Tin was at Dien Bien Phu in 1954, when Ho Chi Minh's Viet Minh Army defeated French colonial forces to secure an independent Communist North Vietnam. Bui Tin was in Saigon, in April 1975 accepting the surrender of the South Vietnamese Government that paved the way for reunification under Communist rule. Now, Bui Tin is in Paris, calling for an end to Marxist-Leninist economic planning and political repression in statements broadcast back to his homeland over the BBC.

title: Amid Panic, Motorman Struggled to Save His Train
description: For the motorman in the subway train where two riders died on Dec. 28, it was a routine morning run, and a mild warning of trouble ahead was not too alarming. Then came the flames and the explosions. And then the smoke, suddenly filling the car.

title: Review/Dance; Where Pride Is in the Clumsiness
description: Five choreographers very artfully made dancers look ungainly in "Five Again," the program of 15 works presented on Friday night under the auspices of the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Beard Oil Company, Oklahoma City, has privately placed $25 million in 10 percent shared appreciation debentures due in 1994 with New York Life Insurance Co. and John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co. * Long Island Lighting Co., Hicksville, L.I., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $250 million in general and refunding bonds. * Student Loan Marketing Association, Washington, is offering $200 million in 7 3/8 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. * Southmark Corp., Dallas, does not plan to make the January interest payment on its 12 percent secured, redeemable notes due in 1997. The company, which recently emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy, said that subject to the bankruptcy court's approval $8 million in professional fees would be payable before any interest. * United Telecommunications Inc., Kansas City, Mo., has filed for $150 million in zero-coupon, exchangeable subordinated debentures due in 2006 through Kidder, Peabody & Co. * Washington Gas Light Co., Washington, has filed for $150 million in debt securities.

title: A New Bank Hopes to Grow In Brooklyn
description: Not many financial institutions in the nation can boast of making fewer bad loans than the tiny Community Capital Bank of Brooklyn.

title: Dealers Fighting A Slump
description: Persuading consumers to buy boats these days tends to be a hard sell. But manufacturers, hundreds of whom have gathered this week for the New York National Boat Show, are offering innovations as enticements. Numerous companies have redesigned products to be more practical or efficient. Others have come up with new ideas altogether.

title: Review/Pop; 2 Guitarists, 2 Bands And 2 Divergent Styles
description: Thursday's impressive double bill at the Knitting Factory, featuring bands led by the guitarists Chris Cochrane and Dave Tronzo, brought two utterly different ways of thinking about music to the stage. Mr. Cochrane and his band played a long piece, "Trying to Assess," which used quick textural cuts, loads of samples and turntables to make a piece that took its structural sensibility from the cut-and-paste possibilities of a modern recording studio. Mr. Tronzo's band played a handful of pieces that instead relied on loose improvisations that had their roots in live performance.

title: 1950's Jingle Is Revived By Chock Full o'Nuts
description: Chock Full o'Nuts has repackaged its 1950's jingle in a $5 million format.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Tensions Grow The Interior, Justice and Treasury Departments have taken steps that strike at Japan in a fresh show of Washington's unhappiness. Page D1. A Volatile Soviet Journal A journal edited by a Soviet major general has published part of Mein Kampf and printed K.G.B. material critical of Andrei D. Sakharov; now it plans to revive a notorious anti-Semitic tract. Page A3. Breast Cancer and Politics Adopting political tactics like those used for AIDS, women with breast cancer are pushing for more attention for their disease. Page A12.

title: Retailer Seeks Bankruptcy
description: Enstar Specialty Retail, which operates more than 700 clothing stores in the South, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday.

title: People
description: * Ozzie Spenningsby has been promoted to executive vice president at Ammirati & Puris, New York. Jan Boyle, Cheryl Bailey, Steve Stone and Andrea Sessler were promoted to senior vice presidents. Matthew Seiler and Lee Ann Daly were promoted to vice presidents. * Edward Haymes, chief financial officer of J. Walter Thompson, New York, will retire on Jan. 31. * Judy Pines has been appointed executive vice president and director of creative services at Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York. * John H. Grant Jr. has been named associate publisher and advertising director of Good Housekeeping. Sandra Lee Spaeth has been promoted to associate publisher and marketing director.

title: Coke and Pepsi Square Off In the Super Bowl of Colas
description: Viewers of the Super Bowl game on Jan. 27 will find another battle off the field.

title: Publisher Takes On a Declining Paperback Market
description: At a time when fewer mass-market paperbacks are being sold, Little, Brown & Company is preparing to start publishing them.

title: Pop-Music Fashion Becomes a Sales Hit
description: In a converted warehouse at the foot of the Bay Bridge here, hissing color presses stamp the likenesses of Madonna, New Kids on the Block, M. C. Hammer and other pop stars on thousands of T-shirts.

title: For Contemporary Music, Times Are Hard
description: For the contemporary music world, which has for decades been a vital part of New York City's musical life, the 1990's are shaping up as a bleak time.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Shell Canada Ltd. yesterday priced $300 million in 10-year notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company. The notes, due Jan. 14, 2001, have an 8 7/8 percent coupon and are priced at 99.921 to yield 8.886 percent, or about 79 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Dead but Hospitalized For Seven Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloom Office Chairman Is Asked to Step Down
description: Jeff Fine, the chairman and chief operating officer of the Bloom Agency's New York office, was asked to leave yesterday by Robert H. Bloom, the agency's chairman and chief executive.

title: Time to Open Envelope on Hall of Fame Results
description: Jim Bunning, who has found it easier to get into Congress than into baseball's Hall of Fame, will learn tonight if his 14-year losing streak has ended. Rod Carew and Rollie Fingers, on the other hand, will find out if they make it as rookies on the ballot.

title: Fossils Show Split in Primate Family Tree
description: FOSSIL skulls of a goggle-eyed animal the size of a mouse have been identified by paleontologists as surprising evidence that ancestors of apes and humans diverged from other primates millions of years earlier than previously thought.

title: Democrats Open Battle On Blame for Recession
description: Congressional Democrats began their campaign today to blame the Bush Administration for the recession.

title: Technology Transcends the Borders of Nations; Flat-Panel TV Displays
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Collect Tolls on the East River Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL UNIONS TRY TO AVOID FURLOUGH
description: Two major unions offered yesterday to defer part of their pay this year to rescue the New York City school system from a budget gap that otherwise could force severe layoffs or a payless furlough.

title: Jurisdiction in Right-to-Die Case Is Shifted
description: Ruling that another court had jurisdiction, a Missouri state judge today dismissed an order temporarily preventing the father of a brain-damaged patient from moving her to a state where less strict rules could allow removal of her feeding tube.

title: Saturn Shifts Management
description: Less than five months after it began producing a challenger to Japanese small cars, the General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary today named a new head of manufacturing.

title: Tigers' Lajoie Resigns
description: Bill Lajoie, the general manager of the Detroit Tigers since 1983, resigned yesterday to pursue "a more relaxed life style."

title: Power Station Finally on Line
description: After five years of environmental studies and construction, the Ocean State Power Company generating station was finally dedicated today. The first 250-megawatt unit of the plant, the first power plant in the region to rely solely on Canadian natural gas for fuel, has been operating for a week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: BANKING IN TROUBLE

title: Westchester Prevails On New Air Terminal
description: The Supreme Court today refused to block construction of a new passenger terminal at the Westchester County Airport.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sanchez Breezes Past Furlan Top-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain stopped Renzo Furlan of Italy, 6-4, 6-1, yesterday in the opening round of the New Zealand Open in Auckland. Sanchez was joined in the second round by second-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, fourth-seeded Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia and seventh-seeded Alex Antonitsch of Austria.(AP) Shriver Comeback Is Complete: Seven months to the day after Pam Shriver underwent shoulder surgery, she was back in the winner's circle after beating the 14th-seeded Isabel Cueto of Germany, 7-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the New South Wales Open in Sydney.(AP) N.B.A. Suns Beat Timberwolves Kevin Johnson had 29 points and 14 assists, and Tom Chambers returned to the lineup with 25 points and 11 rebounds as the Phoenix Suns beat the Timberwolves, 119-106, in Minneapolis last night. Coming off their worst quarter of the season -- a 12-point fourth period during which they blew a 10-point lead Saturday -- the Suns shot 59 percent to take a 38-23 first-quarter advantage. (AP) Spurs 111, 76ers 102: David Robinson scored 31 points, including 6 in overtime, and grabbed 16 rebounds to lead San Antonio won in Philadelphia. The Spurs have won 9 of their last 10 road games, including 3 in a row. Philadelphia has lost 5 of its last 6. A 3-point shot by Willie Anderson with 2:04 left in overtime gave the Spurs a 103-100 lead. After Robinson hit two free throws, Charles Barkley scored. But Robinson then hit four free throws as the Spurs pulled away. (AP)

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Review/Theater; Making History Repeat, Even Against Its Will
description: Perhaps if the world were not actually on the brink of war, "A Bright Room Called Day," a fatuous new drama about a world on the brink of war, would not be an early front-runner for the most infuriating play of 1991. But then again, is the time ever right for a political work in which the National Socialism of the Third Reich is trivialized by being equated with the "national senility" of the Reagan era? Or in which George Bush's ultimatum to Iraq, the Iran-contra scandal and Mr. Reagan's AIDS policy are all frivolously lumped together as historical progeny of the Reichstag fire and Dachau? "History repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce," goes one of the evening's many aphorisms. "A Bright Room Called Day" would be a sitcom if only it were any fun.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After 10 years spent trying to make it happen, TONY RANDALL expects to establish the National Players on Broadway this fall. Mr. Randall and JOHN NEVILLE will be the artistic directors of the players, a national classical repertory company to be based at the Belasco Theater. Mr. Neville, an actor, is a former director of the Stratford Festival in Ontario.

title: Jet Workers' Last Hopes Dashed by Announcement
description: It was cold and icy outside when Cassell Williams got the telephone call bearing the news that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had canceled plans to build a new Navy attack plane. He knew the announcement meant that about 1,500 members of his union would get layoff notices in the next few days.

title: PENTAGON SCRAPS $57 BILLION ORDER FOR ATTACK PLANE
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today canceled plans to build a new Navy attack plane, the largest weapons program ever terminated by the Pentagon.

title: Old Ways Are Dead
description: In canceling the Navy's A-12 attack plane program yesterday, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney sent an unmistakable signal to the military and its contractors that the old ways of doing business with the Pentagon are dead.

title: CRACKDOWN TALK EASED BY BEIJING
description: In the clearest sign so far of the Government's changing position on the army crackdown in June 1989, China's chief spokesman has said he hopes people will forget the matter.

title: Bears Must Use Run To Defeat the Giants
description: Some Bears feel Coach Mike Ditka gets impatient with the game plan if his running plays don't gain a lot of yardage right away. He then calls for more passes, the theory goes, and the Bears get away from what they do best, and then lose.

title: Raiders Impressed by the Transformed Bengals
description: A week ago, the Los Angeles Raiders were busily preparing for an unknown, unseen opponent. Today, they knew who the opponent would be and the problems it would create.

title: Teobly Journal; The Once-Mighty Cast Out: Liberia's Fallen Tribe
description: Normally, the harvest would be under way in Grand Gedeh County, where workers in some of the most fertile land in Liberia bring in rice, the country's leading cash crop. But now the fields are fallow as virtually everyone who once lived there has fled across the border to the Ivory Coast.

title: The Nativity Is Now Legal For Russians
description: Today was the first officially celebrated Christmas since 1917 in this rough beast of a city slouching toward an uncertain future.

title: Edward J. Geng, 59; Led Securities Concern
description: Edward J. Geng, a former Federal Reserve official and later president of Fundamental Brokers Inc., died on Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 59 years old and lived in North Merrick, L.I.

title: MacPherson Is Hired By the Patriots
description: In a rush to put a happy face on a sad team, the New England Patriots today hired Dick MacPherson, Syracuse's successful and spirited coach, as their third coach in three years.

title: BankAmerica Shows Interest in Failed Units
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it was interested in acquiring the three failed banks of the Bank of New England Corporation and "is in discussion" with the F.D.I.C., which took control of the banks on Sunday.

title: Review/Music; A Marathon of Bach's 6 Suites for Cello
description: Bach's six Suites for Unaccompanied Cello are formidable works that, even individually, demand much of a cellist's technique and resourcefulness while affording few moments of rest. Traversals of all six are common enough on recordings, but in concert, cellists usually consider one on a program to be ample exertion. Still, the draw to play the full cycle at one sitting must be fairly powerful, and most cellists get around to it eventually.

title: Game With Celtics Is Pivotal for Knicks
description: When asked if the game tonight against the Boston Celtics was crucial for the Knicks, Al Bianchi did not hesitate.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Love warmed the wintry climate of Gstaad, Switzerland, where JOHN TRAVOLTA and KELLY PRESTON became engaged on New Year's Eve. He gave her a six-carat diamond ring. She said yes.

title: Corrections
description: A Radio Highlights listing on Sunday for next Saturday's Metropolitan Opera broadcast of "Rigoletto" misstated the starting time. The broadcast, live on WQXR-AM and FM, begins at 1 P.M. and will run for three hours.

title: Ozzie Canseco to Japan
description: Ozzie Canseco, the twin brother of the Oakland Athletics' slugging star Jose Canseco, has signed a one-year contract with the Kintetsu Buffaloes of the Japanese Pacific League. The team said a fee will be paid to the Athletics for releasing the 26-year-old outfielder, who hit 21 home runs for Huntsville of the Southern League last season and also played in nine games for the Athletics.

title: Pan Am Sale Of Routes Called Near
description: The Transporation Department is expected to issue an order this week giving preliminary approval of the sale of Pan Am's London routes to United Airlines, an official familiar with the department's policy said yesterday.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States jumped by 22 last week, to 1,108, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count a year ago was 1,029, the company said. Baker Hughes has kept the rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, since 1940. It represents the number of rigs exploring for oil.

title: Sales Tax Receipts Have Been Proposed
description: To the Editor:

title: To Restore New York City - First, Reclaim the Streets; No Time to Give Up on Crime
description: New Yorkers rang in the New Year last week by committing seven homicides in five hours, and the Police Department expects the city's official count for 1990 to exceed 2,200. Are authorities helpless against the mounting violence?

title: People
description: * James F. Borcherdt has been promoted to creative director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis. * Julie S. Newhall has been promoted to vice president of communications for the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, New York. Martin J. Cody was named vice president and general manager of its Chicago office. * Lori Zelikow Florio was named publisher of New Woman magazine.

title: Profits, and Problems, for Recycler
description: Long before the recent spate of announcements of recycling plans by producers and users of plastic, Wellman Inc. was quietly demonstrating that a large, profitable business could be built using waste plastic as a raw material.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a French literary journal's choice of a Paul Auster novel as best book of 1990 misidentified it and two of his other works. Theaward went to "Moon Palace," not "Moon Prize." Mr. Auster's other novel is "The Music of Chance," not "The Music of Change." The reference book he edited is "The Random House Book of 20th-Century French Poetry," not "The Random House Dictionary of 20th-Century French Poetry."

title: Envoys in Baghdad Favor U.S. Meeting With Hussein
description: A final decision by the Bush Administration to reject a high-level, face-to-face meeting with President Saddam Hussein could be a miscalculation that would eliminate an opportunity to avert war in the region, diplomats here say.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering 3-year and 10-year debentures totaling $1.4 billion through various securities dealers.

title: If You Must Play by the Numbers
description: THERE are many ways to pick a lottery number. Some people choose a spouse's birth date, a phone number or any number encountered in what seem to be lucky circumstances. An acquaintance once played the license number of a truck towed away from in front of his business.

title: Compensation Weighed In A.T.& T. Cable Break
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company lost face but not much money Friday when a severed cable interrupted most of its long-distance and international service for the New York City area, Wall Street analysts and communications experts said yesterday.

title: Genentech Pact With Glycomed
description: Jumping into one of the most active areas in biotechnology, Genentech Inc., said today that it was forming an alliance with a smaller company to develop drugs for inflammatory diseases.

title: New York Reopened Bridge Subway Line In Spite of Warnings
description: New York City's Transportation Commissioner reopened the south side of the Manhattan Bridge to subway trains in September despite warnings from city engineers that the deteriorating bridge would suffer serious structural damage.

title: Q&A
description: Floating Ice

title: Congress Has to Limit Spoils of Seniority
description: To the Editor:

title: Selling Out the Baltics
description: George Bush has drawn a line in the sand in the Middle East but is putting his head in the sand in Europe. While America rushes to war in the Middle East, allegedly to defend the sovereignty of a small nation against aggression by a larger neighbor, the Administration has expressed only its "concern" about the Soviet Union sending troops into the Baltic states.

title: U.S. Seeks Ways to Delay Summit Parley in Moscow
description: The White House instructed the State Department today to explore a suitable way of postponing the February summit talks in Moscow, primarily because President Bush does not want to be in the Soviet Union if there is a war in the Persian Gulf, officials said.

title: Public Spaces or Peep Shows?
description: Near the corner of West Houston Street and Sixth Avenue, a large sign bearing the words "Kikit" and "Maurice Sassoon" showed a picture of a man standing behind a woman, pulling her by the hair. The woman's head was arched back, her body pushed forward against a wall, her arms behind her. She was wearing eye shadow so dark her eyes seemed bruised.

title: Jury Selection Is Scheduled For Last Trial in Jogger Case
description: The two sides in the trial of Steven Lopez, the sixth and final defendant in the Central Park jogger case, were ordered yesterday to begin selecting a jury on Feb. 4 in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Lament for Hacks
description: I have several guesses why young people don't read newspapers as much as young people used to. One, because newspapers no longer print the kind of news most people want to read.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about King Fahd's visit to troops in Saudi Arabia misstated the rank of the American commander, H. Norman Schwarzkopf. He is a general, not a lieutenant general.

title: Review/Fashion; Sick of Loud and Mini? Opt for Adolfo
description: The caftan is back. Gently or boldly printed, in diaphanous fabrics, it has been revived by Adolfo to float through summer evenings. Among the 500 or so Adolfo fans who sat through his spring and summer showing Friday at the Plaza were Kay Meehan and C. Z. Guest, who had worn his caftans the first time around and told the designer they were happy to see them back.

title: Bell Atlantic Sells Unit
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, Philadelphia, one of the seven regional Bell telephone companies, announced yesterday that it had sold its computer products division to Gemini Equities Inc. The price was not disclosed. The sale was the latest in a series of moves by the Bell companies to abandon some businesses they entered in the mid-1980's and to focus on local telephone operations. Bell Atlantic's stock fell $2, to $48.75 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Filipino Actress Allowed in 'Saigon'
description: A union-management arbitrator ruled yesterday that the Filipino actress Lea Salonga can come to Broadway to re-create her leading role as a Vietnamese bar girl in the hit London musical "Miss Saigon." The decision resolves a dispute over the casting of the $10 million show, which has a record advance ticket sale of $34 million.

title: 2 Men Die in Fire 9 Blocks From Closed Fire Company
description: Two brothers were killed early yesterday when a fire swept through their Queens home, and neighbors angrily contended later that the city's disbanding of a fire company nine blocks away had delayed rescue efforts.

title: U.N. Advises Its Non-Essential Staff to Leave Israel
description: The United Nations advised all its non-essential employees today to leave Israel right away, adding to the throngs of foreigners crowding Ben-Gurion International Airport, fleeing before the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraqi withdraw from Kuwait.

title: Our Guinea Pigs in the Gulf
description: The Defense Department, in obtaining permission to give experimental drugs to American troops in the Persian Gulf, is about to violate the Nuremberg Code, one of the primary moral documents to emerge from World War II.

title: Beene Gives His Regards to 7th Avenue
description: Geoffrey Beene said farewell to Seventh Avenue last week after laboring in the turbulent center of the garment district for more than 30 years. About 8 A.M. the day after New Year's, after a vacation in Hawaii, he stopped in to say goodbye to the people who will continue working in his old showroom at 550 Seventh Avenue. Then he headed uptown to his new salon at 37 West 57th Street.

title: Bridge
description: The Rule of Eleven dates back to the days of whist, and is exactly a century old. Like calculus, it was developed independently by two men: R. F. Foster and E. M. F. Beinecke. The idea is simple when you think of it. Take a fourth-best lead, subtract the spot card value from 11, and the answer is the number of cards in the other three hands higher than the card led.

title: War Fears Send Dow Falling 43.32
description: Fear on Wall Street toppled stock prices yesterday and brought the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average in just the first four trading days of this year to an ominous 111 points, or 4.2 percent.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Saturday about a proposed increase in first-class postage misstated the price of a 20- stamp book of 29-cent stamps. It would be $5.80.

title: Abducted Chinese Illegal Aliens Rescued
description: For the second time in less than a week, the police said they have rescued illegal Chinese aliens kidnapped and tortured by smugglers to force immediate payment for their passage. The rescues have interrupted what appears to be a widespread, highly-organized ring smuggling hundreds of immigrants here from the mainland's impoverished Fujian Province.

title: Christian Militia Threatens to Block Lebanon Pact
description: The largest Christian militia threatened today to block Lebanon's peace process if its conditions for joining a new Government are not met.

title: Accounts
description: * Suprema Specialties, Paterson, N.J.,to Follis & Verdi, New York, for its cheese products account. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Clue Seen to Depression In Premenstrual Women
description: CALIFORNIA researchers have found that women who suffer depression as a symptom of premenstrual syndrome secrete lower amounts of a brain chemical when they sleep. They described the findings as more evidence that abnormalities in the "biological clock" may contribute to the condition.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "This program cannot be sustained unless I ask Congress for more money and bail the contractors out. But I have made the decision that I will not do that." -- Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, cancelling the Navy's new attack airplane. [ A1:6. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: A copyright infringement case against JULIO IGLESIAS is scheduled to begin today in Federal District Court in Manhattan. DR. HENRY CHIA , an engineer and songwriter, contends that the music for "Hey," a hit for Mr. Iglesias, was copied from "Es," which Dr. Chia wrote.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, an investment management company, has sold three of its Florida home parks in separate transactions for a combined total of more than $20 million. * Canada Packers Inc., Toronto, reached an agreement to sell its Dairy division to Ault Foods Ltd., a wholly owned unit of John Labatt Ltd. The price was not disclosed. The division had sales of $158 million in the fiscal year that ended March 31, 1990. * Hirsh Co., Skokie, Ill., a maker of storage products and home workshop items, is acquiring the steel shelving division of Quaker Industries Ltd., Antioch, Ill., a maker of tray tables and decorative shelving. Terms were not disclosed. * Kerr Addison Mines Ltd., Toronto, a metals mining company and a unit of Noranda Inc., said it would sell its 30.5 percent equity interest in Anderson Exploration Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, an oil and gas company. * MEI Diversified Inc., Minneapolis, a candy, snack and health foods company, said it would sell almost all of the assets of its nut and related snack business to John B. Sanfilippo and Sons Inc., Elk Grove Village, Ill., a processor and distributor of snack foods. Terms were not disclosed. * Mitsubishi Corp., Tokyo, has received approval from the European Community Executive Commission to take a 50 percent stake in the Union Carbide Corporation's worldwide carbon business. The commission declared the accord compatible with the European Community's competition rules. Mitsubishi will buy half of the UCAR Carbon Company and its 19 subsidiaries that are involved in carbon, graphite and related products. * Murphy Oil, El Dorado, Ark., said it would acquire the remaining 39 percent of the stock of the Ocean Drilling and Exploration Co. in a swap of one half of a Murphy share for each Ocean Drilling share. * SKF A.B., Goteborg, Sweden, a maker of rolling bearings and industrial machinery, said MRC Bearings, a unit of its U.S. subsidiary, SKF USA Inc., would close down its plant in Philadelphia late this year. The plant, which employs about 360 people, manufactures precision bearings for the aerospace industry. * TRW Command Support Division, Fairfax, Va., a unit of TRW Inc.'s space and military sectors, has received a $90 million contract from Computing Devices Co., Nepean, Ontario, to support the modernization of the tactical command, control and communications systems for Canadian military forces.

title: 4 Gaza Arabs Give Up Deportation Appeals
description: Four Palestinians who last month were ordered deported retracted their appeals to the Israeli Supreme Court today, meaning they could be expelled within 24 hours.

title: Six Iraqi Pilots Defect and U.S. Claims a Psychological-War Gain
description: Six Iraqi helicopter pilots flew to Saudi Arabia today in one of the most significant defections of Iraqi military forces since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, American officials said.

title: By Design; How to Shop the Sales
description: January is the big month for sales: designer clothes reduced to half the regular price, and great chances to stock up on essentials like underwear and pantyhose. Sensible women pick up their basic suits and separates now, and some men have been known to wait until January to buy a winter overcoat.

title: Pentagon Issues Press Rules Authorizing Military Censors
description: The Defense Department issued rules today for journalists who would cover a Persian Gulf war, including a requirement that military censors review all reports before they are disseminated.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Capital Associates, Lakewood, Colo, a producer of computer equipment, appointed its chief financial officer, Ronald A. Larson, to the additional posts of president and chief operating officer, succeeding Richard Kazan. * Henegan Construction Co., New York, named Maureen Henegan president, succeeding Paul Henegan, who remains chairman. * Hexcel Corp., Dublin, Calif., a producer of structural materials and specialty chemicals, appointed Richard D. Anderson vice president. * Insituform of North America Inc., Memphis, a pipeline reconstruction company, named it chief executive, William C. Willis Jr., to the additional post of president, succeeding Jack Massar, who retired. * Kelly Services, Troy, Mich., a provider of temporary office help, named James T. Reilly vice president of administrative services. Charlotte M. Schwartz was made vice president of its Encore program. * LTV Corp., Dallas, named J. Peter Kelly president of its LTV Steel Co. subsidiary, based in Cleveland. * Occidental Petroleum Corp., Los Angeles, promoted J. Roger Hirl to chief executive of Oxychem, its chemical subsidiary. * Rose's Stores Inc., Henderson, N.C. a retail chain, appointed Dany Lee Overby senior vice president of store operations.

title: Oil Jumps By $2.75, To $27.65
description: Tough talk about the Persian Gulf, and the approach of a deadline that oil traders are calling "D-Day," helped to push oil prices sharply higher yesterday.

title: MOSCOW IS SENDING TROOPS TO BALTICS TO ENFORCE DRAFT
description: The Soviet Defense Ministry said today that it would send elite paratroop units to the Baltic republics and other separatist regions to arrest draft resisters and military deserters, a move that could dramatically raise ethnic tensions and complicate American-Soviet relations at a crucial time.

title: Gaser Tabakoglu, Interior Designer, 36
description: Gaser Tabakoglu, an interior designer who transformed the Gallery at the Carlyle Hotel into a sultan's dining room from a 17th-century harem, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 36 years old and lived in London and Manhattan.

title: The J.F.K. Baggage Blues
description: It is a typical Saturday night at Kennedy International Airport. After a 24-hour flight from Pakistan, hundreds of passengers, most of them Pakistanis, are groggily making their way through immigration and customs. No porters are available to help with the bulky suitcases that all too slowly wind around a balking carousel.

title: Philip Johnson, 75, Pastor Who Pressed For Social Harmony
description: The Rev. Dr. Philip A. Johnson, an internationally known Lutheran minister who worked to enlist businesses in social action, died on Sunday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chevron Sees Higher Profit
description: Sounding almost apologetic, the chairman of the Chevron Corporation said yesterday that because of the Persian Gulf crisis, his company's fourth-quarter profits would be sharply higher.

title: Baker Works to Firm Up the Alliance
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d worked today to cement the alliance against Iraq in advance of his talks on Wednesday with Iraq's Foreign Minister, but in doing so he underscored the subtle fissure in the coalition.

title: Alcoa Plans to Take $275 Million Charge
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, said it would take a one-time accounting charge of $275 million in reporting its 1990 fourth-quarter results. Alcoa said it would take a $142 million write-off on mostly non-aluminum businesses, a $90 million charge to clean up environmental problems at its United States plants and a $43 million charge for an anticipated loss on the previously disclosed sale of a unit in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: Red Cross Workers Pull Out Of Embattled Somalia Capital
description: As fighting in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, between Government forces and clan-based rebels has intensified, Red Cross workers were forced to flee the country early this morning, the Geneva headquarters of the International Committee of the Red Cross said.

title: Japanese Cite Studio Offer
description: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation, a leading Japanese maker of audio products, said today that Paramount Communications Inc. had approached it with an offer to sell its motion pictures division.

title: Blackman's 3-Pointer Beats Nets in Overtime
description: All the Nets had to do was hold the ball in the final seconds of overtime to preserve a close victory over Dallas. They could not do it. All they had to do was make an easy layup to achieve the same result. They could not do it.

title: High Court Refuses to Hear Free-Agency Case
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear a legal challenge to the National Football League's limits on free agency.

title: Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. introduced a series of products that are intended to make it easier for its Macintosh computers to connect to other computers in networks using the popular Ethernet standard. Providing easier connections to other computers is considered essential for Apple, because Macintosh computers are not compatible with the vast majority of personal computers in an office. The new products include Ethernet connectivity circuit boards for the Macintosh II family of computers and for the Mac LC.

title: Sixers to Finally Retire Chamberlain's Number
description: It took a long time, but Wilt Chamberlain says he's "very happy" that his No. 13 jersey will be hoisted to the rafters at the Spectrum in Philadelphia.

title: Review/Opera; Early Wagner From Liederkranz Troupe
description: Wagner's second opera, "Das Liebesverbot," a comedy based on Shakespeare's "Measure for Measure," is still little known in this country except on records. In 1983, Gerard Schwarz presented a concert version at the Waterloo Festival in Stanhope, N.J., which was billed as the work's American premiere. On Saturday evening, the Liederkranz Opera Theater gave another concert performance, at the Liederkranz Foundation, 6 East 87th Street in Manhattan, which, it was suggested with wise caution, may have been the work's New York premiere.

title: '90 Diamond Sales Up 2%
description: Sales of rough uncut diamonds rose 2 percent last year, to $4.17 billion, from $4.09 billion in 1989, the De Beers diamond cartel reported today.

title: The Oldest Universities
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * Fleishman-Hillard Inc., St. Louis, has formed a company with Jandt & Westermann, Frankfurt. It will be called F-H Westermann.

title: Market Place; Semiconductor Outlook Is Mixed
description: WITH the nation probably in a recession and the semiconductor industry's closely watched barometer at one of its lowest levels in years, now might not seem the time to buy semiconductor stocks. But a few analysts say there are bargains to be had.

title: A Fragrance for Elvis, And $5 Million for Ads
description: Just when you thought Elvis could not be exploited another inch, along comes a fragrance named after him. And where there's a fragrance, there's promotion.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Government's seizure of the Bank of New England misstated the source of the $2.3 billion that is the expected cost of bailing out the institution and two affiliated banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's bank insurance fund, which is financed by banks themselves, will be responsible for the cost; it will not be covered by taxpayer funds.

title: Bell Labs Has Smaller Laser
description: Bell Laboratories, the research and development arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that it had developed a laser smaller than a dime that is capable of generating 350 billion light pulses a second.

title: Executive Is Promoted At Shanken Magazines
description: M. Shanken Communications Inc. announced yesterday that Michael D. Moaba had been named president and chief operating officer. Based in New York, Shanken is the leading publisher of consumer and trade magazines on wine, beer and spirits, including The Wine Spectator, Impact and Market Watch.

title: Notes Offered By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $650 million in short-term floating-rate notes, due July 11, through various securities dealers.

title: Bankruptcy by Eagle-Picher Halts Asbestos Settlement
description: Eagle-Picher Industries, which faces up to 70,000 asbestos-related claims, filed a petition for bankruptcy protection yesterday. The move comes three weeks after the company fended off an effort by lawyers representing asbestos victims to force it into bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Careers; Vast Growth In Imaging Is Forecast
description: "THE Genesee River flows north through Rochester, N.Y., and into Lake Ontario, and we can determine the pollutants it carries into the lake through the use of imaging science," Dr. Rodney Shaw said last week.

title: Gold and Silver Prices Jump As Commodity Funds Buy
description: The futures prices of gold and silver soared yesterday amid heightened fear of a war in the Persian Gulf. But dealers stressed that the price rises were more reflective of buying by commodity futures funds than of significant demand for the actual metal.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-13

title: Groups Set Up Panel On Use of Fetal Tissue
description: Declaring that the Federal Government has failed in its responsibility, two medical societies said today that they would establish a board to set ethical guidelines for research involving fetal tissue and new reproductive technologies.

title: Kelly to Play, Doctor Says
description: Jim Kelly, the Bills' quarterback, will begin practicing with the team Tuesday and, according to the team's physician, will be ready for Buffalo's playoff game Saturday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: Shorter Helps Pitt Defeat Syracuse
description: Brian Shorter, bothered all season by a viral infection, scored 32 points tonight and No. 17 Pittsburgh beat No. 8 Syracuse, 93-79. It was the Orange's second consecutive loss after a 13-0 start.

title: France to Continue Efforts
description: The chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the National Assembly said tonight that France reserved the right to pursue a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis if Wednesday's talks between Secretary of State Baker and Foreign Minister Aziz failed.

title: Saatchi Reports Progress In Refinancing Bond Issue
description: Executives of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company said today that the ailing advertising company was making headway in its efforts to refinance a bond issue that could be converted in 1993.

title: Parade for Georgia Tech
description: A crowd estimated by the police at about 50,000 turned out for a parade in downtown Atlanta yesterday to honor Georgia Tech's first undefeated football team in 38 years.

title: Japan's Vehicle Sales Up
description: Japan's motor vehicle sales totaled 5.98 million in 1990, up 7.4 percent from the previous year, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association reported today. An association official said the sales consisted of 4,306,711 passenger cars, up 7.4 percent; 1,643,453 trucks, up 7.6 percent, and 24,925 buses, up 5.9 percent. Toyota topped the list with sales of 2,504,217 vehicles, up 8.5 percent, followed by Nissan, with sales of 1,403,894 units, up 6.4 percent; Mazda, 504,085, up 11.1 percent; Honda, 443,826, up 1.5 percent, and Mitsubishi, 426,115, up 11.7 percent.

title: Prices of Treasuries Drop Sharply
description: A big jump in the price of oil and other commodities -- a byproduct of a weekend of growing tensions over the Middle East -- hurt the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and interest rates rose.

title: Isadore Schlamowitz, Cardiologist, 75, Dies
description: Dr. Isadore Schlamowitz, a specialist in cardiology and gastroenterology for more than 40 years, died on Saturday at Cabrini Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: O. Wesley Davidson, Orchid Researcher, 87
description: Dr. O. Wesley Davidson, a research scientist in plant nutrition and orchid culture and a faculty member at Rutgers University for 40 years, died on Saturday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 87 years old and lived in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: Critics Group Votes 'Goodfellas' Best Film
description: "Goodfellas," Martin Scorsese's look at life in the world of organized crime, was voted the best film of 1990 on Sunday by the 33-member National Society of Film Critics. Jeremy Irons was voted best actor for his performance as Claus von Bulow in "Reversal of Fortune." Anjelica Huston was voted best actress for "The Grifters" and "The Witches."

title: Schembechler Absolved
description: For nearly three weeks, Bo Schembechler had endured, without complaint or response, vilification for the decision to dismiss Ernie Harwell, the Tigers' popular broadcaster, after the 1991 season.

title: East Side Man Charged With Killing His Wife
description: A 56-year-old woman fell 12 floors to her death on East 72d Street in Manhattan yesterday, and her 65-year-old husband was charged with killing her, the police said.

title: Fred Fortess, 77, Dies; Authority on Fabrics
description: Fred Fortess, an authority on the use of fabrics in clothing who was a retired professor at the Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science, died on Saturday at Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 77 years old and lived in Philadelphia and in Ventnor, N.J.

title: No Lines Before 9 A.M. Outside Hartford Bank
description: Passing through the lobby of the main branch of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company here this morning, few would have guessed that the bank had been declared insolvent Sunday and seized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation because it is a subsidiary of the Bank of New England Corporation.

title: Life's Machinery, Seen in a Translucent Worm
description: THROUGH a microscope, they look like tiny crystal serpents, curving and slithering across the dish with an almost opiated languor, doubling back on themselves as though discovering their tails for the first time, or bumping up against a neighbor clumsily and then slowly recoiling.

title: Warren E. Hyde, Executive, 82
description: Warren E. Hyde, retired president of Warren Hyde Associates in Manhattan, a consulting firm in health and social services, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Soviet Woes Tarnish Once-Shining Space Efforts
description: THE Soviet Union's space program, the largest and most active in the world, is starting to crack under the crushing weight of political and economic troubles.

title: Some Scientists Say Concern Over Radon Is Overblown by E.P.A.
description: RADON, described as the nation's most damaging cancer-causing pollutant and second leading cause of lung cancer, may be less of a hazard to the average American than is generally believed, a number of critics contend.

title: Mac Classic's Hot Price
description: THE biggest drawback of the new Apple Macintosh Classic is that it is sometimes difficult to find. Introduced nearly three months ago, it is only now starting to appear in stores in significant numbers, and Apple Computer Inc. says that orders could be backlogged until April.

title: A Year in the Life of a Troubled Bank
description: Dec. 15, 1989: Bank of New England announced that its bad loans would rise to $1.6 billion for 1989, that it might rescind a 34-cents-a-share dividend and that it was considering a merger and sale of assets.

title: PATTERNS
description: It's Hard to Be Young

title: 'Recyclable' Claims Are Debated
description: Alarmed by the spread of state laws regulating the use of environmental claims like "recyclable," many large consumer products companies are seeking national standards.

title: Faded but Vibrant, Indian Languages Struggle to Keep Their Voices Alive
description: When Lucille Watahomigie began to work as an elementary school teacher in Peach Springs in northwestern Arizona, the principal forbade the use of her native Hualapai language in the schoolroom. But moved by the struggles of children who spoke Hualapai and were having a hard time learning English, she defied the ban, translating words and ideas between the two languages.

title: Eddie Barefield, 81; Played Saxophone In Major Big Bands
description: Eddie Barefield, a saxophonist and clarinetist who played with virtually every major big band, died on Jan. 4 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Chess
description: A successful attack in chess, even the type that is often called "savage" or "wild," has to be controlled. As the world champion Wilhelm Steinitz pointed out a century ago, first you must get the superior position because equality does not justify an attack.

title: Feeling Unreal? Many Others Feel the Same
description: "I EXPERIENCED it as if I were standing on another balcony watching a pink cloud float down to the ground," said a woman of a fall from a third-story balcony in which she broke her pelvis. "I felt no pain at all and tried to walk back upstairs."

title: Reuben Tam, Landscape Painter, 74
description: Reuben Tam, a landscape painter, died on Thursday at his home in Kapaa, Hawaii. He was 74 years old.

title: Court Broadens Inquiry on Ex-Housing Secretary
description: A Federal court today authorized an expanded investigation of the former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. to determine whether he illegally steered Government-related business to his former law firm.

title: Courts Begin to Respect Memory of Child Abuse
description: When she was 10 years old, Lorretta Woodbury was raped. Her attacker was her father. He told her it was "something special" between fathers and daughters, and he commanded her not to talk about it.

title: Dimmer Outlook on Mideast Spurs Increase in Dollar
description: The dollar advanced sharply, then eased to more moderate gains yesterday as volatility in the Middle East and Soviet Union reinvigorated the currency's appeal as a safe-harbor investment.

title: Liggett Goes Outside To Hire a New Chief
description: Spencer J. Volk, who has led baking soda and fruit juice companies, will try his hand at tobacco as president and chief executive of the Liggett Group.

title: In Shift, Taxpayers Who Overpay Will Be Told
description: New York City officials said yesterday that they would reverse a longstanding policy and begin informing people who have overpaid their property taxes.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Rule on Outside Comments by Lawyers
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide what restrictions states may place on lawyers' out-of-court comments about cases involving their clients.

title: John Bystrom, Pioneer In Satellites, Dies at 69
description: John Bystrom, who established a satellite communications project designed to lessen the isolation of remote Pacific islands, died Friday. He was 69 years old.

title: South African Black Pupils' Failure Rate Surges
description: Nearly two out of every three black students completing high school in South Africa failed their final examinations in 1990, according to the results released today.

title: Right-Wing Protestant Elected President of Guatemala
description: A right-wing businessman who ran on a law-and-order platform with support from evangelical Christians emerged today as the overwhelming victor in voting for President in Guatemala.

title: Baghdad Schoolchildren Are Made Ready for War
description: At the Dijla School in the heart of Baghdad, the children are getting ready to go to war.

title: Who Cares About Somalia?
description: A dictatorial regime is under siege in Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, and the fighting threatens to touch off bloody clan-based vendettas. Western interest has so far been mainly limited to evacuating foreign nationals.

title: Sacramento Journal; At Capitol, Raining Out a Swearing In
description: In the fifth year of drought here, Cali fornia's new Governor, Pete Wilson, thanked God for the chill rain that forced his inauguration indoors today and turned one swearing-in ceremony into two.

title: Key Rates
Frank Mayfield, 82, Neurosurgeon, Is Dead
description: Dr. Frank Henderson Mayfield, a Cincinnati neurosurgeon who was a past president of the American Academy of Neurological Surgery, died Wednesday at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati. He was 82 years old and lived in Cincinnati.

title: Early On a Cold, Gray Day
description: One of the most famous players in baseball history, and the best-known inmate in the Marion Federal Prison Camp recently, earned his release from the minimum-security facility yesterday after serving five months for Federal income tax evasion, and was transferred to a Cincinnati halfway house. Pete Rose went home, after a fashion.

title: Troops, Storming Palace, Capture Plotters and Free President
description: Haitian troops stormed the Presidential Palace early this morning, smothering a coup attempt in its infancy and seizing a Duvalier-era official just after he tried to declare martial law.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Crest Industries, Miami, has increased its line of credit with Banque Nationale de Paris to $13 million from $9 million. * General Electric Capital Corp., a unit of the General Electric Co., is offering 75 million European Currency Units in 9.50 percent notes due 1993 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. A European Currency Unit represents a weighted index of 10 European Community currencies. The notes are rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.& P. * Hadson Corp., Oklahoma City, says its energy products and services group had established a $29.5 million line of credit with the Bank of Montreal, partly replacing a line of credit with the Bank of America.

title: Find at Ancient Harbor
description: In excavations at the site of the ancient harbor of Caesaria in Israel, two marble columns bearing inscriptions in Latin and Greek from the time of Roman rule in the Holy Land have been discovered by archeologists from Hebrew University in Jerusalem and the University of Pennsylvania.

title: When Fire Companies Close, Anger Follows
description: In the grim overview of firefighting in New York City, where bravery seems routine and the deaths of 250 people are a haunting prospect in 100,000 fires every year, the elimination of two engine companies and a fireboat in budget cuts last week was viewed by City Hall as a limited risk that might never prove catastrophic.

title: Advocacy Group Faults Cuomo On Lack of Funds for AIDS Fight
description: A leading advocacy group in the fight against AIDS accused Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today of failing to provide either the leadership or the financial support needed to arrest the spread of the epidemic.

title: Parcells Taking Precautions In Preparation for Bears
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants spent Sunday in front of a television set watching the Chicago Bears win their first-round playoff game. He spent today helping prepare the game plans for Sunday's game here between the Giants and the Bears.

title: In TV Ratings Battle, NBC Finds Constraints
description: After briefly analyzing the growing problems facing network programmers, Warren Littlefield, president of NBC Entertainment for just six months, added today with a smile, "I've got great timing, don't I?"

title: Neediest Cases Aids Elderly Man on His Own
description: Four years ago Nathan G. hit rock bottom. He was living in a tiny room in a boardinghouse on the Upper West Side, a considerable change from a few decades earlier when he lived in an elegant apartment on Beekman Place and was the president of a film distribution company.

title: Military's Role Raises U.S. Hopes for Better Ties
description: United States officials praised the Haitian Army yesterday for blocking a coup attempt by a supporter of the former Duvalier dictatorship, saying its defense of the civilian Government would bolster American efforts to improve ties with Haiti's military.

title: McDonald's Wider Lean-Burger Test
description: The McDonald's Corporation said it was expanding its new low-fat hamburger to four more markets. McDonald's introduced the Lean Deluxe in November in Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Technology Transcends the Borders of Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: RIEGLE PLAYS DOWN TIES WITH KEATING
description: In testimony more notable for lack of memory than for new detail, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. sought today to play down his ties to Charles H. Keating Jr., the head of a failed savings and loan association.

title: Looted Treasures Returning to Germany
description: The Quedlinburg treasures, a trove of gold, silver and bejeweled medieval artworks that were taken from Germany by an American Army officer at the close of World War II, will be returned to a German church in exchange for approximately $1 million under the terms of a settlement announced today in London.

title: Rangers Rally With Help of Unlikely Bounces
description: A goal off a skate. Another off a rear end. They will make more bloopers tapes than highlight films. Forgive the Rangers, though, for neither blushing over nor apologizing for the goals, because when they replayed them in their minds, they looked as official and satisfying as any others in this season of success.

title: Bowls Face Fine for Early Selections
description: In the wake of widespread criticism of the college bowl-game selection process, the Football Bowl Association today set Nov. 17 as the date for bids this year and ordered a $250,000 fine for premature invitations..

title: Books of The Times; Living a Life of Talent In a Land of Prejudice
description: Voices in the Mirror An Autobiography By Gordon Parks 351 pages. Illustrated. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $22.95.

title: Robert Jan Verbelen Dies at 79; Belgian Served Nazis, Then U.S.
description: Robert Jan Verbelen, a convicted Belgian Nazi war criminal who spent 10 years working for United States intelligence after World War II, died on Aug. 28 in Austria, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith, which investigated his case, has announced. Mr. Verbelen was 79 years old and lived in Vienna, working as a speaker for neo-Nazi groups.

title: Another Ominous Alarm in Moscow
description: Is Mikhail Gorbachev turning dictatorial? People shaken by Eduard Shevardnadze's sudden resignation last month were jolted anew by Mr. Gorbachev's decision yesterday to dispatch paratroops to the Baltics, the Ukraine and other republics.

title: Democrats Urge Big Shift In Florio Plan
description: The State Senate's Democratic leaders disclosed a plan today to sharply alter Gov. Jim Florio's income-tax and school-aid program, shifting $450 million intended for aid for poorer school districts to a new program aimed at bringing down property taxes.

title: Gilbert Price, 48, Broadway Baritone
description: Gilbert Price, a baritone who won acclaim for his Broadway debut in "The Roar of the Greasepaint -- the Smell of the Crowd" in 1965, was found dead on Wednesday in an apartment in Vienna. He was 48 years old and had gone there recently to conduct a workshop in singing and acting, friends said.

title: Talking Business with Kramer, Author of Insurance Study; Comparing Risks: Banks vs. Insurers
description: The rising trend of insurance failures in the 1980's, coupled with the nationwide slump in commercial real estate, has led to increased concerns that insurers might be vulnerable to some of the same problems confronting the banking industry.

title: Farm Income Drop Seen
description: Net income for United States farmers is expected to slip this year from the record levels of 1990, with rising costs and lower Government payments eating away at higher crop earnings, the Agriculture Department has reported. The department's forecast of trends, released last week, projected that farmers' net cash income in 1991 would be 2 to 3 percent below 1990's record $59 billion. Net farm income is expected to be $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with 1990's record of $49 billion.

title: Review/Television; NBC and ABC Series Take On Difficult Issues
description: Prime-time entertainment doesn't shy away from tackling the big issues, from drugs and abortion to battered women and AIDS. But what kind of messages are being delivered? And are they getting through?

title: India Reports I.M.F. Loan
description: A top Indian official said today that the International Monetary Fund had agreed to lend India $2.5 billion.

title: INSIDE
description: 6 Iraqi Pilots Defect; Baker and Allies Meet Six Iraqi helicopter pilots flew to Saudi Arabia in a significant defection from Baghdad's military forces, American officials said. Page A11.

title: Our Towns; Go On, Dump It Anywhere at All. Who's to Know?
description: Ron Terlizzese feels like an idiot. He listened to the Department of Environmental Conservation! For three years, he followed their rules, doing all the work required to get a permit for his company, Rapid Recycling, to accept construction and demolition waste.

title: Shutting Down the X Chromosome
description: A WOMAN has two hefty matching X chromosomes, while a man has one X and a much smaller Y chromosome. But the female's bigger X does not give her a bigger supply of genes. Very early in development, a master molecule shuts down thousands of genes on one of the female's X chromosomes, to prevent her from receiving a potentially lethal double dose of genes.

title: F.B.I. Taped Gotti Talks About Fixing Jury
description: From secret tape recordings, Federal agents overheard John Gotti talk of trying to fix the jury in his state trial last January, but they withheld the information from Manhattan prosecutors, law-enforcement officials disclosed yesterday.

title: U.S. Effort Off Mark in World Meet
description: Maybe they are too good for their own good. Maybe they are putting pressure on themselves, or having trouble adjusting to swimming summertime races in the middle of their winter. Or maybe the United States swimming team isn't as good as it is cracked up to be.

title: Panhandler Is Fatally Shot By Irate Subway Passenger
description: A panhandler who was aggressively soliciting money on a subway train was shot in the head over the weekend by an irate passenger, transit officials said.

title: Bullets in 2 'Lovers' Lane' Shootings Are Tied to Same Gun
description: Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown urged New Yorkers yesterday not to park in isolated areas of the city after the police linked a bullet that killed a young man in Bayside, Queens, on Sunday to a similar shooting in a nearby "lovers' lane" in March.

title: Rating Lowered For Nynex Unit
description: The rating on about $2.3 billion in New England Telephone and Telegraph Company long-term debt has been lowered to Aa-2, from Aa-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. New England Telephone is a unit of the Nynex Corporation.

title: Sugar Group's Effort Draws Health Organization's Fire
description: ABOUT to spoon some sugar on your breakfast cornflakes? Go right ahead, whatever your New Year's resolution. Or at least that's what the Sugar Association, the trade group that represents makers and marketers of sugar, is urging consumers to do in a new print campaign that begins later this month.

title: Scrutiny of Iraqis and Other Arabs in the U.S. Is Stepped Up
description: Federal law enforcement agencies have quietly heightened their scrutiny of Iraqis arriving in the United States in recent weeks and vastly stepped up intelligence-gathering activities directed at Iraqis and other allied Arab groups in this country, Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. Honda to Ship Wagons to Japan
description: The Honda Motor Company plans to import into Japan Accord station wagons produced at its United States plant, the company said. Honda spokesmen would not comment on the number of station wagons to be imported, or when such imports would begin. A published report today put the number at 6,000 station wagons in 1991, starting in April. Spokesmen said the company would announce its plans on Wednesday.

title: Unfestive Albany: Deficit and Layoffs to Dominate New Session
description: A new legislative season begins here on Wednesday, but despite the promise of swearing-in ceremonies for 19 newly elected lawmakers and the ritual gathering for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State address, the atmosphere is far from festive.

title: Czechoslovakia Gets $1.8 Billion I.M.F. Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund announced a $1.8 billion loan to Czechoslovakia today, its biggest loan yet to one of the new democracies in Eastern Europe, to support its radical overhaul from Communism into a market economy.

title: All the Fashion Rage in the Desert: The Coveted Olive Green Parka
description: The most chic article of war garb is definitely the parka. The nylon-lined, waterproof cross between a safari jacket and a poncho is the hottest item being distributed to soldiers here in the northeastern Saudi desert, and for those in the first "combat pools" of reporters who will follow them in case of war.

title: Mosbacher On Recession
description: The recession in the United States will be short and mild, with rising exports to Latin America helping to blunt its effects, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today.

title: 3Com Quits Software In Big Strategy Shift
description: The 3Com Corporation said today that it was getting out of the software business and looking for a buyer for its computer work station and server business. The company plans to refocus its strategy on network adapters and inter-networking systems.

title: The Transition to F.D.I.C. Control Is Said to Go Smoothly
description: When officials at the Bank of New England sent out for pizza late Sunday night, they ordered some for officials of the bank's new owners, too -- the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Insurance Limit On Bank Funds Seems In Doubt
description: The decision on Sunday to protect all depositors in a bailout of one of the nation's largest bank companies will make a move to limit deposit insurance less likely, Government officials and lawmakers said today.

title: N.C.A.A.'s Director Calls For Some Major Reforms
description: The executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association called tonight for a simplification of the organization's rules as well as a less combative process by which they are enforced, as he officially opened the association's 85th convention.

title: Nuggets' Opponents Get the Breaks
description: With the season nearing the halfway mark, the Denver Nuggets, with a record of 6-26, are reviving memories of the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers, the worst team in National Basketball Association history.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week that ended yesterday, continuing a three-month slide.

title: Why War Is Irrelevant
description: As Secretary of State James Baker meets the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, hopes rise that the talks will amount to more than a repetition of the public postures of the two sides. In an era suspicious of secrecy, millions wish devoutly for a hidden agenda today in Geneva.

title: Jordan Hits 41 as Bulls Are in Control Early
description: Had the game been just a little closer, Michael Jordan might have spent more time on the floor in an attempt to achieve another milestone. It would have been a bright footnote to an otherwise lackluster evening.

title: Mandela Asks Talks With All Parties
description: The African National Congress called today for a conference of all political parties in South Africa to ease the writing of a new constitution that would transfer political power to the nation's black majority.

title: NBC Puts New Blood In Old Vampire Series
description: It started as a desperate idea to fill some television time during the 1987 writers' strike in Hollywood; now the comeback of "Dark Shadows" is the great prime-time hope of NBC.

title: Ailing Cranston Is Excused From Public Questions
description: The Senate Ethics Committee voted unanimously today to excuse Senator Alan Cranston from public questioning in the panel's investigation of five Senators' ties to Charles H. Keating Jr. after Mr. Cranston's lawyer said he was too ill.

title: Issues Still Disputed in Fire
description: Several issues remain in dispute about the Fire Department's response to a fire on Monday that killed two men at 85-38 109th Street in Richmond Hill, Queens. Response Time

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
The Limited Names 2 Division Presidents
