description: The Limited Inc., the specialty retailing company, said yesterday that it had appointed new presidents at its Limited Stores and Victoria's Secret Stores divisions.

title: INSIDE
description: Republicans Pick Houston Republicans chose Houston for their 1992 national convention, favoring the city where the President has his legal residence over San Diego and New Orleans. Page A15. Yosemite Park Agreement A foundation will buy the concessions in Yosemite National Park that a Japanese company gained control of in a corporate purchase. Page A18. Hispanic Health Problems Hispanic Americans are much more likely than members of other groups to have some diseases and much less likely to have health insurance, several new reports show. Page A16. The Self-Esteem of Girls The self-esteem of American girls plunges by the time they reach high school, much more than it does among boys, a study found. Page B6. Vaccination System Faulted Flaws in the vaccination system caused a serious measles epidemic, a Federal panel said, and a key official promised to seek changes. Page A17.

title: 1 Dead, 248 Hurt in London As Commuter Train Crashes
description: One person died and 248 were injured today when a commuter train crashed into the buffers at a London station.

title: Savoring the Tastes of China in Streets and Kitchens
description: CHINA did not tempt Ken Hom. The cookbook author had crossed the Pacific from his home in Berkeley, Calif., to Hong Kong as many as 20 times a year to teach cooking classes and had been offered a contract for a book about China, but he had never traveled in the land of his ancestors.

title: Injuries and Another Loss for the Devils
description: As if Brett Hull's sniping from the right circle wasn't enough to handle tonight, the Devils also lost two of their most consistent players to injuries in the first minute of the game against St. Louis and suffered their fourth consecutive setback.

title: About New York; Some Are Made In Heaven, Some Elsewhere
description: The inspiration for this column came in the mail. Actually, two pieces of mail.

title: A Company Is Finding The Good in Pollution
description: A radically different approach to air pollution -- converting harmful combustion waste products into something useful -- is being tested here at New England's only cement plant. A geochemist has found a way to combine the acid and ash emissions from the plant to produce fertilizer, distilled water and limestone for the cement plant, and hardly anything else.

title: Ralph E. Pearson, 86; Recovered Artworks
description: Ralph E. Pearson, a retired Army colonel who during the closing days of World War II helped to recover a cache of European art treasures stolen by the Nazis, on Monday at Brackenridge Hospital here died of injuries from a car accident. He was 86 years old.

title: Many Hispanic Americans Reported In Ill Health and Lacking Insurance
description: Hispanic Americans lack health insurance more often than any other ethnic group in the United States, according to several reports in today's Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Richard Maibaum, Screenwriter For James Bond Films, Dies at 81
description: Richard Maibaum, who wrote or co-wrote the screenplays for a dozen James Bond films, died on Friday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 81 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Fingers's 341 Saves Are Waxed
description: After the Baseball Hall of Fame votes were counted last night, Rollie Fingers discovered that he wouldn't be going to Cooperstown this year, neither as the caretaker of the first handlebar mustache to be bronzed nor as the first who fulfilled today's definition of a late-inning firefighter.

title: Memorial for Major Holley
description: A memorial service for the jazz bassist Major Holley is to be held at 7 P.M. today at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. Mr. Holley died of a heart attack on Oct. 25 at the age of 66. The trumpeter Clark Terry and his group, the pianists Barry Harris and Jay McShann and others are to perform.

title: Sales Are Strong For Macintosh
description: Apple Computer Inc.'s chairman, John Sculley, said the new Macintosh Classic should sell more machines in its first year than any other computer introduced by Apple.

title: Supreme Court Ruling Supports Tax Protester
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that taxpayers who sincerely believe the Federal income tax laws do not apply to them cannot be convicted of criminal tax violations, even if there is no rational basis for their belief.

title: Ford's Pockets Are No Longer Full
description: Just a couple of annual reports ago, the Ford Motor Company was selling cars and trucks so briskly and profitably that union officials moaned about the crush of overtime and some investors fretted that the nation's No. 2 auto maker was not investing its multibillion-dollar hoard of cash quickly enough.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a consultant specializing in health and social services rendered his first name and that of his firm incorrectly. He was Laurin E. Hyde, not Warren, and his firm was Laurin Hyde Associates.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: A 'New' Soviet Policy
description: Marlin Fitzwater reached near-highs of understatement and wishful thinking in responding to threats of a Soviet crackdown against deserters and draft-dodgers in seven rebellious republics. Although Administration officials are hoping for a Gorbachevian miracle, everything is much worse than the White House spokesman let on yesterday.

title: Purse Snatcher's Push Kills Woman With $1 in Subway
description: A 31-year-old Manhattan woman died following surgery last night after a purse snatcher grabbed her handbag containing $1 and pushed her between two cars of a subway train pulling out of an Upper West Side station, the transit police said.

title: New Ballet School Opens, but Kirstein Worries
description: There is marble and soft carpeting everywhere at the new School of American Ballet headquarters at Lincoln Center. Small foot baths dot the halls at the school, which opens officially today, for use by young ballerinas who moistened their toe shoes before class at the old school by hoisting their feet into the drinking fountain. There are sleek meeting rooms and five large, light-filled studios, one of them equipped as an informal studio theater. On upper floors, there are rooms for boarders, simply but comfortably furnished, with nearby kitchenettes and dazzling views of the city.

title: Dow Falls 13.36 in Slow Trading; Slide Moves to 5th Day
description: Stocks lost further ground yesterday for the fifth straight session, extending the erosion in the Dow Jones industrial average so far this year by nearly 125 points, or 4.7 percent.

title: N.C.A.A. Agrees to Reduce Coaching Staffs
description: In a sweeping move to reduce costs in college athletics, delegates to the 85th National Collegiate Athletic Association convention overwhelmingly approved measures today to cut coaching staffs in 33 intercollegiate sports.

title: 4 Belgians Reported Freed By Arabs and Sent to Libya
description: Four Belgians held captive for three years and two months by a radical Palestinian guerrilla faction were released today and sent to Libya, where they are to be handed over to their Government, security officials said.

title: Giants Won't Underestimate Tomczak
description: At Ohio State, Mike Tomczak and Pepper Johnson were football teammates and good friends, even though Johnson broke Tomczak's foot in a preseason scrimmage. Now they are rivals, important players in Sunday's playoff game here between the Chicago Bears and the Giants.

title: Eagles End Their Relationship With Ryan
description: What got Buddy Ryan hired got him fired.

title: Books of The Times; Setting the Outer Limits for Critics
description: The Limits of Interpretation By Umberto Eco 295 pages. Indiana University Press. $27.50.

title: Vasko Popa, 68, Poet Examining Life With Humor
description: Vasko Popa, a leading Yugoslav poet whose works were translated from Serbian into 19 languages, died on Friday at the Military Academy Hospital in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, where he lived. He was 68 years old.

title: Padres Sign Barrett
description: The free-agent second baseman Marty Barrett, released by the Boston Red Sox after a season in which he played just 62 games because of a knee injury, agreed yesterday to a minor league contract with the San Diego Padres, and will go to spring training as a nonroster player.

title: Cuomo to Urge a Trust Fund For Environmental Projects
description: Under heavy pressure to find alternatives to the environmental bond act rejected by voters last fall, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will propose the creation of a state trust fund for environmental projects, state officials said today.

title: Consumer Debt Grows Only Slightly
description: Consumer debt grew by a slim $1.72 billion in November, the Government said today, in another reflection of consumer caution in a weakening economy.

title: Parker Sues On Monopoly
description: Parker Brothers filed suit today against the manufacturer of a board game that uses elements of Monopoly.

title: WigWag Will Suspend Publication Next Month
description: WigWag is waving goodbye, at least for now. The magazine with a folksy take on American life, which is slightly over a year old, will stop publishing after its February issue to "find investors and a capital investment," said Sam Schulman, the publisher.

title: MCA Agrees to Sell Interest In Yosemite to End Dispute
description: In an effort to end the emotional dispute over Japanese ownership of tourist concessions in Yosemite National Park, MCA Inc. agreed today to sell its interest in the park operations to a private nonprofit foundation and to give up its preferential right to renew its park contract.

title: U.S. DEPLORES PLAN BY SOVIETS TO SEND TROOPS TO BALTICS
description: The United States today condemned as "provocative" Moscow's plan to send troops to seven restive Soviet regions and suggested that such action could endanger Soviet-American relations if it led to violence or signaled a crackdown on political activity.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA
description: * Angus Maitland has been named vice chairman and board director of Burson-Marsteller Inc., London. Allan Gotlieb has been named chairman of its Toronto office. * Raymond A. Mayo has been promoted to media supervisor at Earle Palmer Brown & Spiro, Philadelphia. * Raju Puthukarai has joined Time Warner Direct, New York, as vice president.

title: CRISIS ATMOSPHERE IN IRAQ'S CAPITAL
description: As international diplomacy on the Persian Gulf crisis entered what appeared to be the end-game stage, Iraqis formed long lines at gasoline stations today, topping off their gas tanks and filling plastic containers with extra fuel supplies.

title: Key Rates
World Farmers Would Gain by Cut in Subsidies; Blame Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Influx Has the Israelis Building, Fighting and in Awe
description: Israel has become a nation consumed, not with the prospect of war in the gulf, but with the extraordinary wave of Soviet Jewish immigration that is altering the face of Israeli society.

title: Providence Tops Georgetown, 72-69
description: Eric Murdock scored 9 of his 29 points in the final five minutes tonight and Providence held on for a 72-69 victory over Georgetown in a Big East Conference game.

title: Scientist to Give Up Teaching and Pursue Cold Fusion Studies
description: Dr. B. Stanley Pons, one of two scientists who maintained that they had discovered cold fusion, has resigned his teaching position at the University of Utah so he can devote all his time to continuing the research, the university announced today.

title: A General Chooses Democracy in Haiti
description: Haiti's army commander, Gen. Herard Abraham, is a new kind of military hero. He has distinguished himself not in battle but by defending a fragile democratic order. Last month his troops insured the smooth conduct of Haiti's first-ever democratic election, won by the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Then on Monday he rolled back a brief seizure of power by Dr. Roger Lafontant, the feared former leader of the Duvalier-era secret police, the Tontons Macoute.

title: NATO Satellite Is Lofted
description: An unmanned rocket streaked into space Monday with a NATO communications satellite that will replace an older military spacecraft thousands of miles above the Atlantic Ocean. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's $110 million satellite was placed into an orbit that will link political and military leaders over an area stretching from the United States to Turkey.

title: Review/Music; New 'Andrea Chenier' Cast
description: Monday evening's dully competent performance of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" marked the opera's final performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera, and included a number of singers who had not participated in the Dec. 8 season premiere. Indeed, of the principals, only Sherrill Milnes's Gerard, bluff but sternly effective, remained.

title: Food Notes
description: Mushroom Farms

title: Kodak Plans Drug Venture With Sanofi
description: In the latest trans-Atlantic alliance in the steadily consolidating worldwide drug industry, the Eastman Kodak Company and Sanofi S.A. of Paris are pooling resources to create a new company. People familiar with the deal said the company would have $3 billion in combined pharmaceutical sales.

title: Across the South, a Clash of Doubt and Fervor
description: The electronic sign in front of the Royal d'Iberville Hotel here carries a message that can be found on billboards all over the South.

title: Unsung Bussey Leads Bengals' Revitalized Secondary
description: In the ninth week of the National Football League season, it appeared that the soggy bottom had finally fallen out of the Cincinnati Bengals' paper-sack secondary.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IN my travels around the country I find that offal is increasingly popular in restaurants.

title: Wall Street Is Preparing Contingency Plans for a Gulf War
description: Wall Street is preparing for war. From the largest securities and futures exchanges to brokerage firms and mutual funds, new rules are being put in place and old systems are being checked as some of the nation's most important institutions ready themselves for an outbreak of hostilities in the Middle East.

title: New Trials for Agents
description: Barry Elden, a Federal prosecutor in Chicago, said yesterday that the Government had decided to retry two sports agents, Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, who have been accused of using cash and threats of violence to recruit college athletes as clients. In 1989, they were found guilty after a five-week jury trial, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed their convictions last September.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., appointed Kazuo Yoshikawa vice president for its unit in Japan. * ALTA Health Strategies Inc., Salt Lake City, an independent health-care management company, promoted James A. Kenworthy Jr. to executive vice president and chief administrative officer. * American Superconductor Corp., Watertown, Mass., which developes ceramic superconducting wires, named Dr. Alexis P. Malozemoff vice president of research and development. * Atlantic Mutual Cos., New York, a property and casualty insurance concern, appointed Randolph J. Smith senior vice president of personal lines. * Comprehensive Health Services Inc., Rockville, Md., a provider of preventive and occupational medicine, named James S. Mitchell executive vice president. * GMI Engineering and Management Institute, Flint, Mich., appointed Dr. James E. A. John president. * North American Philips Corp., New York, a subsidiary of Philips Industries, Eindhoven, the Netherlands, named Donald L. Hamilton vice president of employee relations. Patrick J. Greaney was named senior vice president. * Volvo North America Corp., New York, a unit of Volvo A.B., Goteborg, Sweden, promoted Albert R. Dowden, to president and chief executive; David C. Korpics, to senior vice president and chief financial officer; Robert B. Mercer, to senior vice president; Keld Alstrup, to vice president of human resources, and Rob Wyder, to vice president of corporate development.

title: Mideast Crisis Threatens Unlikely Victim: Junk Mail
description: The prospect of war in the Persian Gulf may have one unlikely beneficiary: the nation's overstuffed mailboxes. Many direct marketing consultants say they are advising their clients to postpone plans to send out junk mail until after Jan. 15, the date when the United Nations has authorized the use of force to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.

title: The Pop Life
description: Roger McGuinn Is Back

title: CHRONICLE
description: After a year of trying to select a new chief editor for Le Monde, France's prestigious daily newspaper, its editors and reporters yesterday chose JACQUES LESOURNE, an economist, author and former business consultant. He is the first nonjournalist to be selected in the history of the paper, established in 1944.

title: Closing of Fire Company Hindered Queens Rescue, Firefighters Say
description: Firefighters who fought the blaze that killed two men in Queens on Monday said yesterday that they were forced to plunge into the burning house in a rescue attempt without any water because there was no pumper ready to hose the flames.

title: Carew, Perry And Jenkins Are Voted Into Hall of Fame
description: Rod Carew, on the ballot for the first time, and a pair of pitchers in their third attempts, Gaylord Perry and Ferguson Jenkins, won election to baseball's Hall of Fame last night.

title: Iraqi, in Geneva, Says Pressure Won't Work
description: On his arrival here, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq said today that he had come for his meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d with an open mind and prepared to conduct "constructive talks," but would not yield to American pressure.

title: Let Every Depositor Sleep Securely
description: Mobs of depositors descended on the Bank of New England Friday after it announced it was virtually insolvent. Fearing a run that could spread to other banks, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation swiftly took over the big bank and two affiliates and assured their depositors -- including those with accounts exceeding $100,000 -- that all their money would be safe. The banks reopened Monday; not one depositor was hurt.

title: Next in California: Wine, Italian Style?
description: CABERNET and chardonnay; chardonnay and cabernet. Do you get the impression that they are the only wine grapes that matter in this country?

title: Judge Acts on Welfare Hotels
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday found New York City in contempt for placing homeless families in welfare hotels without private cooking areas or bathrooms. She ordered the city to devise a schedule to begin removing families from the hotels. The order by Justice Helen E. Freedman in Manhattan dealt with 59 families in a suit filed by the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project. But the findings may also apply to nearly 600 other homeless families living in 10 welfare hotels. City officials last year agreed to stop placing families in welfare hotels by June 1, 1990. But by the middle of last summer, the demand for shelter vastly outstripped the supply of temporary housing and families were again placed in hotels.

title: Israel Ousts 4 Arabs Who Dropped Appeals
description: Israel deported four Palestinians to Lebanon today, less than 24 hours after they had dropped their final legal appeals.

title: Bridge
description: The first major tournament of the year for players in the New York metropolitan area is the Tri-State Regional Championships, beginning today at the Rye Town Hilton, Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Surgery for Olajuwon
description: Akeem Olajuwon of the Rockets will undergo surgery next Monday to repair damage from being elbowed on the right side of his face by Bill Cartwright of the Chicago Bulls in a game last Thursday, Steve Patterson, Houston's general manager, announced last night. The All-Star center will be out at least eight weeks, missing about 30 games.

title: Junket to the Rescue
description: To The Living Section:

title: Urban League Urges Action
description: The National Urban League today urged action by the Bush Administration and Congress to stimulate the economy, saying black Americans were in a "permanent recession" and would bear the brunt of hard economic times.

title: CLEAN WATER CITED IN SEAFOOD SAFETY
description: The safety of seafood could be better assured by reducing pollution in the waters where fish and shellfish are harvested rather than by putting more inspectors in processing plants, a National Academy of Sciences committee said today.

title: Philip K. Hills Jr.; Lawyer, 58
description: Philip K. Hills Jr., a senior partner in the New York law firm of Satterlee Stephens Burke & Burke, died on Monday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 58 years old.

title: New England Withdrawals
description: Officials at the Bank of New England estimated today that $800 million to $1 billion had been withdrawn from it and two affiliated banks on Friday and Saturday after the news that it expected losses of up to $450 million for the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Dolphins' Smith Quiets Doubters
description: Even before he joined the Miami Dolphins, there was a sense of promise and vulnerability in Sammie Smith, a combination of factors that are considered attributes in some lines of work, but not in the National Football League.

title: Economic Scene; Good Advice Nobody Wants
description: LOOKING for a painless primer on the Soviet economic crisis and how it might be solved? Look no further than the 17-page memo written by a group of brand-name Western economists at the behest of Stanislav Shatalin, sometime senior adviser to Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: Refunding Bonds Offered by Tampa
description: The City of Tampa, Fla., is offering $48.8 million in tax-exempt refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.15 percent for an issue due 2018 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Ralph Fairchild, 55, Medical Researcher At Brookhaven Lab
description: Dr. Ralph G. Fairchild, a physicist and medical researcher at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, died on Dec. 17 while vacationing in Mount Cook National Park, New Zealand. He was 55 years old and lived in Setauket, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline yesterday about a convicted Belgian Nazi war criminal who spent 10 years working for United States intelligence after World War II misidentified him in some editions. He was Robert Jan Verbelen.

title: Microsoft's New Spreadsheet Challenges Lotus
description: Microsoft will turn up the heat on Lotus on Wednesday when it introduces a new version of its Excel personal computer spreadsheet program that works with its popular Windows 3.0 graphics-based control program.

title: Bush's Letter to Congressional Leaders
description: Following is the text of President Bush's letter today to Bob Dole, Senate minority leader; Speaker Thomas S. Foley; George J. Mitchell, Senate majority leader, and Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader in the House:

title: U.S. Backs Sale of Overseas Routes
description: The Transportation Department today tentatively approved the sales by Pan Am and T.W.A. of lucrative international routes, including rights to fly between the United States and London.

title: Once a Desegregation Tool, Magnet Schools Become Schools of Choice
description: Originally developed as an alternative to forced busing, magnet schools have expanded beyond their desegregation purpose, and are now used to advance the cause of parental choice in education.

title: Soviet Ship Halted Near Red Sea May Violate Iraq Arms Embargo
description: United States and Spanish naval vessels are detaining a Soviet freighter near the Red Sea after searchers found tank parts, detonators and other military hardware that may be bound for Iraq in violation of the international embargo on trade with Baghdad, officials said today.

title: R.J. Reynolds Officer Resigns
description: The chief financial officer of an important unit of RJR Nabisco resigned unexpectedly, it was announced yesterday. He will be replaced by a top financial officer from the Quaker Oats Company.

title: Haiti Rounds Up Rebel Leader's Supporters
description: Many stores and businesses remained closed today and scattered gunfire could be heard as the police and soldiers rounded up associates of a former Interior Minister whose coup attempt was thwarted early Monday.

title: Some Dealership Fees Are Waived by Saturn
description: Because of a slow production start at its Tennessee assembly plant, the General Motors Corporation's Saturn division will absorb up to $5.8 million in fees it originally charged to dealers, company officials said today.

title: Fed Signals A Decline In Key Rate
description: In a surprise move, the Federal Reserve Board sent a signal yesterday that suggested it had again lowered a key short-term interest rate.

title: Eating Well
description: ALTHOUGH tofu has been around for more than 2,000 years, it is relatively new to American kitchens. While nutritionists and vegetarians rave over its versatility and nutritional attributes, many cooks are at a loss over what to do with white chunks of bean curd.

title: Aid for Teachers' Raise May Already Be Spent
description: Seventy million dollars in state aid earmarked as a major part of the wage and benefit increase for New York City teachers may have already been spent or allotted for other purposes, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: Florio's Gamble; No New Taxes but Talk of Benefits: The Governor Tries Damage Control
description: One year ago, Gov. Jim Florio said his goal was to save the State of New Jersey from what he saw as the failures of his predecessors. This year, both Democrats and Republicans say his goal is to save his party and himself.

title: U.S. Logistical Effort Nears Peak in the Gulf
description: Every few minutes during long stretches of the day, another American cargo plane laden with weapons or equipment rumbles to a halt on the runway of a giant military base here in the Saudi desert.

title: Astronaut, Quitting NASA, Urges Overhaul of Space Station
description: An astronaut who is resigning from NASA warned yesterday that its planned $37 billion space station could be canceled outright if its redesign, now under way, was superficial.

title: Fireman's Fund Makes Top-Level Appointments
description: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, just acquired by a German company, named a new chairman and chief executive yesterday. Herbert Hansmeyer, the new chairman, is director of Allianz of America, the United States unit of Allianz A.G. Holding of Munich, which completed the acquisition of Fireman's last week for $3.3 billion in cash.

title:
Real Estate;
Unfinished, But Leased, In Cincinnati
description: A BURST of corporate expansion, coupled with a periodic reshuffling of tenants, has enabled a Houston developer to find tenants for almost all the space in a large office building months before its completion.

title: Archbishop of Milwaukee Would Ordain Married Man
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Milwaukee, Rembert G. Weakland, has said if the growing shortage of priests forced him to choose between letting his parishes decline or ordaining married men, he would select a qualified married layman to head a parish and ask the Pope's permission to ordain him.

title: Ford Retirement Mystery: One Explanation
description: Senior executives of the Ford Motor Company say that two years ago the company's board, anticipating the hard times that have since arrived, set in motion an executive succession plan that led to the early retirement of Donald E. Petersen, Ford's chairman and chief executive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I am determined to do whatever is necessary to protect America's security. I ask Congress to join with me in this task." -- President Bush. [ A6:6. ]

title: Iraqis Get Ready for War
description: Iraqis formed long lines for gasoline, and health officials told hospitals to accept only urgent cases to make room for war casualties. Page A7.

title: NEW YORK EASING CITY WATER RULES
description: Reversing their position, New York State health officials have determined that New York City will be able to guarantee the safety of its drinking water for many years without having to spend billions of dollars to filter it.

title: Soviets Want Summit Talks Held as Planned Next Month
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, said today that the Soviet Union hoped that the Moscow summit meeting with President Bush would take place as scheduled, from Feb. 11 to Feb. 13.

title: Walter J. Campbell; Executive, 70
description: Walter J. Campbell, retired suburban advertising director of The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 70 years old.

title: Republicans Select Houston for 1992 Convention
description: Republican officials today selected Houston, President Bush's official residence, as the site of the party's 1992 national convention, over the initial objections of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.

title: Bridgeport Considering Filing Under Chapter 9 Bankruptcy
description: Mayor Mary C. Moran says the city is considering filing for Federal bankruptcy protection to solve its financial problems.

title: Appeals for Hope By Dinkins, Florio
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York and Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey looked past economic recession to deliver generally hopeful messages yesterday that seemed at times to clash with harsh realities.

title: The Hammer Collection
description: The Hammer collection includes some 100 Old Master, 19th- and 20th-century paintings, a number of works on paper, some 10,000 prints by the French satirist Honore Daumier, and a scientific manuscript by Leonardo da Vinci. An excellent assortment of Old Master drawings, the strength of the collection, was donated by Dr. Armand Hammer to the National Gallery in Washington in 1987.

title: Market Place; String of Dow Losses: Sign of an Off Year?
description: With worries growing that no peaceful resolution is possible in the Mideast, the stock market has gotten off to its second-worst start in history.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Wilkins Leads Hawks Past Spurs Dominique Wilkins scored 40 points last night, 10 after a fourth-quarter challenge by San Antonio, as the Hawks downed the Spurs, 109-98, in Atlanta for their seventh straight victory. David Robinson had 35 points and 16 rebounds for the Spurs, who had won three in a row over all and nine of their previous 10 road games. Atlanta has won 10 in a row at home. The Spurs had a chance to cut Atlanta's lead to 5 points with 6 minutes 35 seconds to play, with Sean Elliott driving for a fast-break layup. But Wilkins blocked the shot, which Sidney Moncrief retrieved in the corner, and the Hawks went on an 8-0 run to put the game away.(AP) Bucks 99, Bullets 96: Frank Brickowski hit two free throws with 15.8 seconds left as Milwaukee broke an 18-year-old single-season club record with their 18th straight home victory. Harvey Grant missed a jumper at the free-throw line with seven seconds to go and Jack Sikma made two more free throws for the Bucks. Ricky Pierce led the Bucks with 22 points. (AP) SuperSonics 96, Lakers 88: Derrick McKey scored 29 points and Seattle, playing at home, took advantage of the absence of Magic Johnson to pull away in the fourth quarter for the victory. Dale Ellis, who was scoreless and who missed his first seven shots from the field, scored 12 points in the final 8:23 for the Sonics. The Lakers were without Johnson for the second straight game. He has a jammed finger on his right hand. James Worthy led the Lakers with 21 points. (AP) Jazz 110, Cavaliers 88: Jeff Malone scored 28 points and Utah had a 25-5 surge in the third quarter en route to their sixth straight victory. Cleveland lost its eighth straight. Karl Malone added 24 points for the Jazz, winners in nine of their last 11 games. Henry James, a rookie, led the Cavaliers with 21 points. (AP) Heat 95, Kings 83: Sherman Douglas, back in the lineup after missing three games with a finger injury, had 20 points and eight assists as Miami handed Sacramento its 12th consecutive road loss. Sacramento, which shot just 38 percent, has lost nine of its last 10 games and has not won on the road since Nov. 20. The Kings are 1-15 on the road this season. Glen Rice scored 21 points for Miami. (AP) Clippers 122, Pacers 107: Danny Manning and Benoit Benjamin scored 25 points each as the visiting Clippers ended a seven-game losing streak. Ken Norman had 24 points for Los Angeles, 3-15 on the road this season. Reggie Miller led Indiana with 25 points.(AP) Trail Blazers 123, Rockets 97: Clyde Drexler, Kevin Duckworth and Danny Ainge had 20 points each as Portland, playing in Houston, improved to 10-0 against Midwest Division teams. Otis Thorpe led Houston with 17 points and 9 rebounds, followed by Buck Johnson and Sleepy Floyd with 15 points each. Terry Porter added 15 points and Cliff Robinson had 12 for Portland, 13-3 on the road this season. (AP) Pistons 101, Hornets 98: Isiah Thomas scored 27 points and blocked a shot with four seconds left as the visiting Pistons beat Charlotte for their seventh straight victory. The Pistons have beaten the Hornets, losers in 13 of their last 15 games, in all eight of their meetings. Mike Gminski scored 20 points in his first start for Charlotte, and Kendall Gill added 18. Joe Dumars, Detroit's leading scorer, sat out the second half after spraining his left big toe in the second quarter. He finished with 9 points. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins Move Into Second Place Jiri Hrdina and John Cullen each scored twice last and Pittsburgh used a four-goal first period to beat the visiting Oilers. Tom Barrasso, the Pittsburgh goaltender, won for the ninth time in his last 10 games for the Penguins, who moved into second place in the Patrick Division ahead of the idle Philadelphia Flyers. The Penguins are 11-4 in their last 15 games. His first goal completed a streak of four in 11 minutes against Bill Ranford, the Edmonton goaltender.(AP) Nordiques 4, Bruins 2: Joe Sakic scored the winner as Quebec, playing at home, erased a two-goal deficit with three goals in five minutes in the second period. Claude Loiselle, Claude Lapointe and Everett Sanipass also scored for the Nordiques, who snapped a losing streak at three games. Stephane Quintal and Dave Christian scored for the Bruins, who outshot the Nordiques, 34-28. (AP) Flames 5, Maple Leafs 3: Joe Nieuwendyk and Brian MacLellan each scored twice as Calgary extended its unbeaten streak to five games with the victory at home. Joel Otto scored the other goal for the Flames, 4-0-1 in their last five games. Kevin Maguire, Al Iafrate and Lucien DeBlois scored for the Leafs in the third period after Calgary had taken a 5-0 lead.(AP) SWIMMING U.S. Fails to Win a Gold Medal The United States, picked to dominate the world championships in Perth, Australia, failed to win a gold medal yesterday. Hungary got its second world-record performance in two days as Tamas Darnyi, holder of the world record in the men's 400 individual medley since August 1987, knocked an amazing 2.39 seconds off the mark, to 4:12.36. Eric Namesnik of Pittsburgh followed Darnyi to set an American record time of 4:15.21, .36 seconds better than the mark he had lowered twice this season. Matt Biondi, the star of the 1988 United States Olympic team in Seoul, South Korea, had a rematch with Anthony Nesty, the 1988 Olympic gold-medal winner, in the 100-meter butterfly. But Biondi finished sixth in 53.97 as Nesty defeated Michael Gross, the 1984 Olympic champion, by the length of a wrist, 53.29-53.31. (AP) TENNIS Lendl Defaults After Two Sets Ivan Lendl, complaining of an unspecified stomach injury, defaulted his first-round match yesterday at the New South Wales Open in Sydney. Lendl, who had split the first two sets of his match with Wally Masur of Australia before retiring, said he expected to compete in the Australian Open beginning Monday in Melbourne.(AP) Adams Upsets Fromberg: Chuck Adams, a qualifier from the United States, upset Richard Fromberg of Australia, seeded third, 6-3, 6-4, in the first round of the New Zealand Open in Auckland. Adams, a 19-year-old from Pacific Palisades, Calif., will face Christian Bergstrom of Sweden in the second round. Bergstrom beat Javier Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 6-1. (AP) SQUASH RACQUETS Talbott Wins 103d Tournament Mark Talbott, the world's top-ranked player in the North American hardball version of the game for eight years, won his 103d pro tournament last night when he defeated Ned Edwards of Philadelphia to capture the $20,000 Prudential-Bache/Mutual Benefit Life New Jersey Open at the Chatham Club in Chatham, N.J. The 30-year-old Talbott won, 7-15, 15-7, 15-9, 15-6.

title: With Tight Budgets, Dinkins and Florio Speak of Hope; Dinkins Sees Rebound But Offers Few Details To Curb Fiscal Woes
description: As his administration grappled with New York City's most serious fiscal problems since the mid-1970's, Mayor David N. Dinkins offered a message of hope in his first State of the City address, but provided few indications of how the administration would master its budget woes.

title: The Pentagon's Price for News
description: The Defense Department's revised rules for covering a war in the Persian Gulf are much less onerous than those originally proposed. Yet the Pentagon still says all dispatches will be reviewed by officers in the field. Censorship in wartime can be essential to safety and security. But when it becomes excessive, citizens lose their chance to judge public policy.

title: Pentagon Retracts Report of Iraqi Defections
description: Retracting earlier statements, the Pentagon said today that there was no evidence that six Iraqi helicopter pilots had defected to Saudi Arabia.

title: Student Loan Proposal Leaves Colleges Unsure
description: A proposal by the Bush Administration to streamline student loan programs by eliminating banks from the process has piqued the interest of colleges and universities. But they stopped short of endorsing the plan, because it does not address the problems of loan servicing and collections.

title: A City Dinner for Greenmarket Farmers
description: THERE was an air of city slicker about the 50 farmers and members of their families done up in suits and ties, silk dresses and high heels who came to town on Sunday. For once, they had not awakened at 4 A.M. to load the truck with broccoli and apple cider and drive to the Greenmarkets. Winter is the time when most farmers, except for a hardy few with potatoes and baked goods to sell, take a break to examine seed catalogues.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Walther Prokosch, 79, A Designer of Airports
description: Walther Prokosch, an architect and former partner in Tippets, Abbott, McCarthy, Strattony, New York architects and engineers, now Tams Consultants, Inc., died Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 79 years old.

title: How Fat Is Fat?
description: To The Living Section:

title: Holders Sue NCR Over A.T.&T. Bid
description: A group shareholders of the NCR Corporation, filed a lawsuit against the computer company in an attempt to clear the way for a takeover by A.T.&T.

title: Creditor Delay For Leventhol
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge enjoined the creditors of Laventhol & Horwath yesterday from taking any legal action against anyone who has ever been a partner or senior principal of the firm.

title: Junket for Christmas
description: To The Living Section:

title: J.A.L. Buying Stake In Lockheed Unit
description: Japan Air Lines will purchase 14 percent of a new Lockheed Corporation maintenance subsidiary, Lockheed said. The subsidiary, Lockheed Commercial Aircraft Center Inc., will eventually occupy four aircraft bays at Norton Air Force Base, which is scheduled to close in 1994, said John Dailey, a spokesman for Lockheed, based in Calabasas, Calif.

title: The Iron Medal
description: All right, superpatriots, let's hear it for the latest American victory:

title: Saudi Ruler Is Said to Expect a War
description: On the eve of the critical meeting between the American Secretary of State and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia has evidently concluded that Iraq is not likely to withdraw from Kuwait and that therefore the international coalition against Baghdad must be prepared to strike at military targets deep inside Iraq without destroying the country itself.

title: Islanders Shut Out Amid Boos
description: The Islanders, who hadn't played since Saturday's improbable comeback victory against the Philadelphia Flyers, looked tonight as if they had forgotten how to play at all. Their gamelong bout of amnesia was readily exploited by the visiting Minnesota North Stars, themselves winthout a victory in their previous five games, as they stunned the Islanders, 3-0, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Agassi Receives Record $25,000 Fine
description: The flap over his flip-flop over playing in the inaugural Grand Slam Cup last month cost Andre Agassi a record $25,000 fine yesterday, but he escaped suspension from this year's major tournaments.

title: Robert C. Cook, 92, A Longtime Scholar Of Human Genetics
description: Robert Carter Cook, a geneticist, demographer and author, died Monday at Collington Retirement Community in Mitchellville, Md. He was 92 years old.

title: Disharmony at Armand Hammer Museum
description: "Collecting art for the benefit of the public has been one of my goals for most of my life," said Dr. Armand Hammer at a press conference in January 1988, as he announced plans for the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center.

title: High Court Upholds Witness Fees for Inmates
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that convicted prisoners who are called to testify as witnesses in Federal court are entitled to be paid the same $30-a-day fee that other Federal court witnesses receive.

title: U.S. Must Join Signers Of Test Ban Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: For Secretary Cheney, a Hero's Medal
description: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney stunned the Navy and its contractors by canceling the A-12 Avenger, a new carrier-based attack plane that was way behind schedule and way over cost. By calling a halt to business as usual at the Pentagon, he performed a distinguished public service.

title: Jailed S.& L. Owner Stricken
description: Don R. Dixon, the former savings and loan association owner who was convicted last month of fraud, has been hospitalized after a heart attack.

title: Pan Am Reassures Ticket Holders and Frequent Fliers
description: Pan Am ticket holders will not be affected by the airline's bankruptcy filing yesterday, according to the Pan Am Corporation's executives and travel agents. Pan Am sales representatives spent yesterday morning assuring travel agents around the world that flight service would continue without interruption.

title: Ever Elusive, O'Neill Left His Mark
description: William A. O'Neill will leave office on Wednesday having served longer than any Connecticut governor in 180 years. Yet even after a full decade on the state's highest public stage, he remains an elusive figure, and even some of the people he is closest to say they do not know him very well.

title: Hope and Realities; Dinkins Address Expresses Optimism At Odds With Troubles Faced by City
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's assessment of the state of his city had at its essence an optimism for the future at odds with the harsh realities of the present.

title: Little Girls Lose Their Self-Esteem Way to Adolescence, Study Finds
description: Girls emerge from adolescence with a poor self-image, relatively low expectations from life and much less confidence in themselves and their abilities than boys, a study to be made public today has concluded.

title: Banking Regulators Seek Barring of President's Son
description: Enforcement officials at the Office of Thrift Supervision recommended today that Neil M. Bush, the President's son, be barred from working at any bank or other institution that received Federal insurance until he showed that he understood conflicts of interest.

title: Alan Wiggins; Baseball Player, 32
description: Alan Wiggins, a once promising major league baseball player who undermined his career with drugs, died at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles Sunday night. He was 32 years old.

title: Military Has Been Latin America's Curse
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Speech By New Jersey Governor
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. Jim Florio's State of the State Message:

title: Knicks Are Again No Match For Celtics
description: Until the Knicks can defeat quality teams, they cannot become a quality team. And their performance last night against the Boston Celtics was further confirmation that the Knicks are not even close to becoming a contender.

title: A-12 Loss Is Latest Jolt to Builders
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's decision on Monday to cancel the A-12 attack aircraft comes when the airplane's builders, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation, are facing steady declines in most of their other large Pentagon projects.

title: Panel Ties Measles Epidemic to Breakdown in Health System
description: A breakdown in the vaccination system caused the nation's worst measles epidemic in decades, and more epidemics may occur unless the system is changed, a Federal advisory panel said today.

title: Alfred Hinds; British Jailbreaker, 73
description: Alfred Hinds, a burglar and safecracker from London's East End who gained folk-hero status as a prison escapee, died on Friday. He was 73 years old.

title: World Farmers Would Gain by Cut in Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles C. Kujawa, 70, Executive of Y.M.C.A.
description: Charles C. Kujawa, who was associated with the Young Men's Christian Association for 44 years, died on Thursday at Cabrini Medical Center in New York City. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Talk of a Search for Relief and Suicide
description: For months, lawyers and ethics experts have debated the morality of a makeshift device built by Dr. Jack Kevorkian to help terminally ill people kill themselves.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10

title: Bankruptcy Petition Is Filed by Pan Am To Get New Loans
description: Pan American World Airways, nearly out of cash, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday. Pan Am, the nation's pioneer in commercial aviation, is the third of the nine largest United States carriers to seek such protection from creditors in the last 22 months.

title: Marko Nikezic, Yugoslav Liberal Forced to Quit by Tito, Dies at 69
description: Marko Nikezic, a former Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia who was considered the leading liberal politician of Serbia in the postwar era, died of intestinal cancer Sunday night in Belgrade. He was 69 years old.

title: Bush to Free Salvador Aid
description: President Bush has determined that the continued flow of weapons to Salvadoran rebels and their poor human rights record are grounds for freeing $42.5 million in withheld military aid to the San Salvador Government, officials in the Administration and in Congress said today. Under last year's foreign aid law, half the $85 million in military aid for El Salvador was frozen in an effort to encourage the Government to reach a negotiated peace settlement with the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.

title: William (Bill) Byrd; Pitcher, 83
description: William (Bill) Byrd, whose 115 victories gained from 1932 to 1949 for the Columbus Blue Birds and the Elite Giants of Nashville, Washington and Baltimore were the fourth highest total by a pitcher in Negro leagues baseball history, died of cancer on Friday at the Medical College of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He was 83 years old.

title: Japan Limit on Car Exports
description: Japan will limit its car exports to the United States to 2.3 million again in the fiscal year beginning on April 1, the Kyodo News Service reported today.

title: Iran and Iraq Agree on a Half-Mile Border Zone
description: The highest-level delegation from Iraq to visit Iran since before the two countries fought their brutal eight-year war in the 1980's arrived today in Teheran. The two countries announced that they would pull back the remaining forces on their mutual border to create a buffer zone about half a mile wide.

title: Joseph Spagna, 86, Head of Purchasing In New York in 50's
description: Joseph Vincenzo Spagna, a lawyer who was New York City's commissioner of purchasing in the 1950's, died on Dec. 26 at Peninsula Hospital Center in Queens. He was 86 years old and lived in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: BUSH ASKS CONGRESS TO BACK USE OF FORCE IF IRAQ DEFIES DEADLINE ON KUWAIT PULLOUT
description: President Bush called on Congress today to adopt a resolution supporting the use of force against Iraq if it did not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. He said such a vote would send a message to President Saddam Hussein that the United States was united in its determination to make him withdraw from Kuwait.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., said production of its first mini-vans with driver-side air bags began yesterday at its Windsor, Ontario, assembly plant. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, announced rebates of up to $1,250 and discounted interest rates for buyers of certain 1990 and 1991 Oldsmobiles. The models include the Cutlass Calais, Ciera and Supreme; Eighty Eight; Custom Cruiser; Ninety Eight; Toronado; Silhouette and Bravada. * Golden Nugget Inc., Las Vegas, Nev., decided to delay construction of a $200 million resort in Laughlin, Nev., because of worries about market saturation. * Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co., Akron, Ohio, announced it would close its factory in Eau Claire, Wis., before the end of next year. The company is owned by the Michelin Group of France. The plant, which has made tires since 1916, has a work force of 1,350.

title: Game Maker Sues Nintendo
description: American Video Entertainment Inc. said today that it had filed a $105 million lawsuit against Nintendo of America Inc. and its parent company, Nintendo of Japan, accusing the companies of violating antitrust laws.

title: Medellin Journal; In Colombia's Tortured City, Elite Lives in Fear
description: Classroom attendance has thinned at the private English-language high school here. Society reporters from newspapers encounter closed doors across town. And tables stand empty at the Cuatro Estaciones, this striving city's imitation of the Four Seasons restaurant in New York.

title: Wider Access to U.S. Securities Price Data Urged
description: A top Federal regulator said today that price data in the market for United States Government securities, the world's biggest market by far, should be made widely available rather than held within a select group of officially sanctioned bond dealers.

title: Birthrate Dropped at Schools With Contraception Information
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pan Am Bankruptcy

title: Memories of Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Winery's Answer to Critics: Print Good and Bad Reviews
description: LIKE restaurateurs and theatrical producers, wine makers are never slow to advertise a favorable review. Nothing moves cases quite like 90 points plus in The Wine Advocate, Robert Parker's influential newsletter, or The Wine Spectator, a twice-monthly magazine for wine buffs published by M. Shanken Communications.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At the annual awards dinner of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, MARTHA GRAHAM will be given a lifetime achievement award. The choreographer has used costumes designed by CALVIN KLEIN and Halston for her dance company.

title: NatWest Looking For Acquisitions
description: National Westminster Bank is considering buying deposits in New Jersey and New York from savings institutions offered for sale by the Resolution Trust Corporation, a senior official of the British banking comapny said.

title: Yale Weighs Challenge To Newspaper's Owner
description: Yale University is weighing whether to challenge the ownership of The St. Petersburg Times, in a move that could make The Times the property of Yale.

title: Lithuanian Premier Resigns Over Policy
description: The Prime Minister of Lithuania and her Cabinet resigned tonight in a dispute with the republic's Parliament over economic and political policy.

title: Richart Paget, 78; Helped Reorganize Federal Government
description: Richard M. Paget, a management consultant whose studies led to reorganization of the Navy and of other areas of the Federal Government, died on Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J., before moving to Naples in 1989.

title: Warming the Spirits: Pumpkin Soup and Sauteed Squid
description: AT any time of the year, but never more than on a cold winter day, soup is the first and foremost comforting food for me. It can be made ahead, enables you to use the leftover vegetables and meat in the refrigerator and is an ideal vehicle for seasonal vegetables like pumpkin.

title: Windfalls Bring Gifts to the Neediest Cases
description: A number of contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have come this year from people celebrating a sudden windfall or some turn of good luck. A wallet returned, a Christmas bonus, money for a retirement present -- all have been cause for donations to the Neediest Cases.

title: Reviews/Music; Barber, Copland and Other Moderns
description: Who could have imagined a concert of contemporary orchestral music in which Samuel Barber's youthful First Symphony (1936) -- a conservative work, even in its own day -- would sound like an essay in complexity and progressiveness?

title: Vincent Motion Denied
description: United States District Judge Leonard B. Sand yesterday denied a motion by Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, that a lawsuit by the Yankees executive vice president, Leonard L. Kleinman, be dismissed.

title: Aspin Sees Air Strikes Leading to a Quick Victory
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said today that if war breaks out in the gulf, the United States and its allies will attack in phases, beginning with an air campaign against Iraq and Iraqi troops in Kuwait.

title: Thoughts After Layoffs: Making Do and Moving
description: Scott Korgel glanced back at the hulking brick building where, minutes earlier this morning, he and more than 2,500 other engineers, technicians and office workers were ordered to clear out their desks and leave for the last time the top-secret development site for the Navy's A-12 attack aircraft.

title: Deal on Stolen German Art Meets With Mixed Reaction
description: The decision on Monday by the German Government to buy back religious artworks stolen by an American soldier at the end of World War II drew both sharply negative and cautiously approving reactions yesterday from arts administrators, dealers and lawyers.

title: Book Notes
description: Shevardnadze's Book

title: Excerpts From Dinkin's Speech: 'Forge Ahead'
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor David N. Dinkins's State of the City Message:

title: In London, It's the 40's. The Good 40's.
description: For many young Londoners, Saturday night is a time to "rave," to wear the latest fashions, to dance to the latest hit songs. But just off Leicester Square, young women in smart square-shouldered crepe dresses and open-toed, wedge-soled shoes and men in dapper double-breasted suits and two-toned shoes gather at Fortissimo, a basement club.

title: May Stores Prices $100 Million Issue
description: The May Department Stores Company, St. Louis, priced $100 million in debentures yesterday that are due in 2021 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: John G. Brookhuis, 69, A Chemical Executive
description: John G. Brookhuis, a chemical industry executive, died Jan. 2 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 69 years old and lived in Boston.

title: A-12 Decision Starts Scramble For Alternatives
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's decision on Monday to cancel the Navy's new attack plane has set off a scramble in the Pentagon to find a replacement aircraft and among military contractors to offer a solution.

title: The Creature of the Wild in Each Cat
description: When our ancient cat, Pectin, took his place on my lap while I was watching the premiere of a new National Geographic series, I felt like one of those movie reviewers who drag a kid along to Ninja Turtle shows to get the perspective from down there. Pectin's perspective, tail toward the tube, was not, I am sure, meant as a comment on the program, "Cats: Caressing the Tiger," which turned out to be a flattering appreciation of his species. Whatever his opinion, he seemed to me the right company in which to learn all manner of facts about a long-time companion. Similar arrangements are recommended for everyone who tunes into Channel 13 at 8 or Channel 21 at 10.

title: With Tight Budgets, Dinkins and Florio Speak of Hope; Florio Promises Jobs, Not Higher Taxes, To Help Economy
description: Faced with both recession and voters' hostility, Gov. Jim Florio tonight outlined a 1991 agenda centered on a jobs program to be fueled by new state construction projects and mortgage help for first-time homebuyers.

title: Birthrate Dropped at Schools With Contraception Information; Frank Discussions
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Receives Help From MTV On Saturday Night Programming
description: ABC has tried to solve the riddle of Saturday night by itself; now it's getting help from MTV.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Miscellany
description: * Gallagher-Widmeyer Group, Washington, a public relations firm, has changed its name to the Widmeyer Group, with Scott Widmeyer as its president and chief executive.* Cahners Publishing Co., a unit of Reed Publishing Inc., Newton, Mass., has acquired three electronic trade magazines -- Twice, Cars and Twice Today -- for undisclosed terms.* Business Week magazine will discontinue its personal finance magazine for executives, Assets.

title: U.S. Hopeful On Subsidies
description: A United States official said today that he was hopeful the European Community was making changes in its farm subsidy proposal that could revive the world trade talks that collapsed last month.

title: Raymond Stitzer, 85, An Investment Banker
description: Raymond D. Stitzer, a retired investment banker, died on Sunday at his winter home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Soviets Say a Budget Accord With Republics Is Set to Sign
description: A budget agreement for the Soviet Union for 1991, held up because of insufficient contributions from the country's largest republic, will be signed on Saturday, Soviet officials said today.

title: Soviets Buy U.S. Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought a large quantity of United States corn, a day after receiving a $900 million export credit, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Schools Can Help in Divorce
description: To The Home Section:

title: Grace Moving 400 Employees
description: W. R. Grace & Company, whose ties to New York City go back a century, said yesterday that it would move most of its staff, about 400 employees, from Manhattan to Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Review/Television
description: Practice may not always make perfect, but it can help enormously. On public television's "Mystery" series, for instance, some of the most durable detectives have simply gotten better with age. Prime examples have been Roy Marsden's Adam Dalgliesh and John Thaw's Inspector Morse. Now add to the list David Suchet's Hercule Poirot, returning tonight -- on Channel 13 at 8 -- in eight new stories involving the Belgian sleuth.

title: Why New York State Faces Crisis and Must Resort to Layoffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Sophomore Year; Mr. Dinkins Turns Wishful
description: To think back to Mayor David Dinkins's inaugural last January is to reflect, sadly, on what has happened to him and his city in just one year. The inauguration was a moment of excitement and promise; even the broadening signs of fiscal trouble could not still the enthusiasm. Then reality hit. The economy got worse, and the Mayor's life became one problem after another.

title: Beirut to Disband Groups
description: Lebanon's new Government promised today to disband all armed groups, including Palestinian guerrillas. Prime Minister Omar Karami told Parliament that his 16-day-old Cabinet "shall dissolve all Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias." He did not mention Palestinians directly, but the phrase "non-Lebanese militias" was taken as a reference to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Pentagon's cancellation of the A-12 attack plane misstated the starting date of the aircraft's development. The Navy began developing it in the mid-1980's, not in the 1950's.

title: Executive Shift At Landmark
description: Richard F. Barry 3d, president of Landmark Communications Inc. for almost 13 years, has relinquished that post to become vice chairman and will develop the company's growth and acquisition strategy.

title: We Can't Afford Big Science's Price Anymore; For Collaboration
description: To the Editor:

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ALL young children want to please their parents. Doing so brings them the affection and attention on which they thrive. Yet by the time they reach adulthood some are convinced that nothing they do is good enough to warrant praise from their parents. No matter how hard they try or how much they accomplish, they think their efforts will fall short.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It was a very discouraging day." -- Representative Lee Hamilton of Indiana. [ A1:5. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: He was living that year in Boston. That was where the Raymond Chandler estate found ROBERT B. PARKER , a best-selling mystery author with a weakness for heroes.

title: Jordan Closes Border to New Refugee Wave
description: Jordan closed its land border with Iraq today, saying it could not cope with another flood of refugees from the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Protests in Lithuania Continue, Turning Peaceful
description: Soviet Interior Ministry troops and Army personnel carriers appeared briefly today in the streets of the capital of Lithuania as large pro-independence demonstrations continued for the second day, but withdrew after crowds dispersed peacefully, witnesses said.

title: Lincoln Center Is Adding Jazz to Its Repertory
description: Duke Ellington, Charlie Parker and Thelonious Monk are to have a place alongside Bach, Beethoven and Mozart at Lincoln Center. Nathan Leventhal, the president of the center, announced yesterday that the bastion of classical music had added a jazz department to produce concerts and other programs year round, and that Rob Gibson, the director of the Atlanta Jazz Festival, would be its executive director.

title: Layoffs Set for 3,450 At Digital Equipment
description: Resorting to dismissals for the first in its history, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off about 3,450 employees by June 30.

title: Hussein's Vision for G.I.'s: 'Swim in Their Own Blood'
description: With diplomatic efforts deadlocked in Geneva, President Saddam Hussein told the top leaders of his ruling party that he would make United States military forces "swim in their own blood" if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, state-run television reported tonight.

title: 2-Part Offering by Greece Is Worth Over $700 Million
description: The Greek Government has priced more than $700 million of securities in a two-part offering.

title: In 2 1/2 Rooms on S.I., An English Castle
description: GEORGE WAY has about 40 old-master portraits, 2 banquet tables, 38 Charles II and William and Mary chairs, a dozen Jacobean chests and cupboards, 8 Bible boxes and a nine-foot-high Elizabethan canopy bed. All in all, an English castle's worth of furnishings.

title: F.D.I.C. Fails in Plan to Sell Giant Texas Development
description: The Government's plan to sell a prized 6,200-acre real estate development north of Dallas to a Japanese businessman collapsed late Tuesday after he said he could not obtain financing.

title: Unbelted Girl Dies; Father Charged in Crash
description: A man has been charged in the death of his 4-year-old daughter, who was not wearing a seat belt when she was thrown from his car and struck by another vehicle.

title: Debt Warning On Car Makers
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said today that it had put the Big Three auto makers on notice that their corporate debt ratings could be lowered because of a worsening economic picture and specific problems at each company.

title: Review/Music; Richard Rodgers Series at Y, With Songs and Narration
description: For the fourth time in four seasons, the 92d Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series is devoting all five programs to a single composer or team. This year, the subject is Richard Rodgers, who follows Cole Porter, the Gershwins and Irving Berlin in the songwriters examined.

title: BAKER-AZIZ TALKS ON GULF FAIL; FEARS OF WAR RISE; BUSH IS FIRM; DIPLOMATIC EFFORT TO CONTINUE
description: With six days remaining before the United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face possible military attack, the United States and Iraq failed today to reach agreement on a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: TV Set Manufacture Hasn't Gone Overseas
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: South Africa Moves To Integrate Schools Black South African children were admitted for the first time to previously all-white classes in 33 public schools where parents had approved plans for limited integration.

title: Deadly Impasse Said to Go On in Somali City
description: The Italian Ambassador, who is manning the only operating embassy in the embattled Somali capital, Mogadishu, said today that Government forces and rebels continued to fight with neither side holding an edge.

title: Review/City Ballet; It's On With Tchaikovsky After 'Nutcracker' Run
description: The New York City Ballet, after its usual monthlong run of "The Nutcracker," went back to its regular repertory on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with some splendid performances.

title: Parcells Undecided on Running-Back Starter
description: The Giants' starting running back in Sunday's playoff game here against the Chicago Bears will be Ottis Anderson. Or Rodney Hampton. Or even Lewis Tillman, but probably not.

title: Hearst Picks New Editors Of Magazines
description: Thomas Hoving, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a former Parks Commissioner of New York City, is being replaced as editor in chief of Connoisseur magazine.

title: France Will Pursue Peace Till 16th, Mitterrand Says
description: France will pursue its independent diplomatic efforts to find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis until the morning of Jan. 16, when a United Nations mandate clears the way to use force to push Iraqi troops out of Kuwait, President Francois Mitterrand said tonight. But he warned that unless Iraqi troops withdrew by then, war "is practically certain" and that France would join it.

title: Excerpts From Weicker's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s State of the State address to the General Assembly. You in this chamber and those who sent me here expect nothing short of total candor in dealing with the problems and opportunities of our state.

title: Cuomo Prescribes Austerity, Not Activism
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has often defined his activist vision of government with grand and expensive initiatives, said today that New York's deteriorating financial condition demands a new austerity that must be evenly spread.

title: Herta Prager, 81, Dies; Former Court Librarian
description: Herta Prager, former chief librarian of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, died on Tuesday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 81 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the expanded investigation of Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, referred incorrectly to a $1.3 million contract from the agency. H.U.D. awarded the contract to the investment banking firm of Paine Webber Inc. to act as the agency's financial adviser; it was not awarded to Mr. Pierce's former law firm, Battle, Fowler, Jaffin & Kheel of New York. Battle, Fowler acted as legal counsel on that and related contracts.

title: Justice Department's Civil Rights Chief Is Sitting on Sidelines of Main Battle
description: After eight months as the Justice Department's top civil rights enforcer, John R. Dunne remains politely in the shadows, relegated to a sideline role.

title: Mubarak Warns Israel to Stay Out of Gulf Conflict
description: As the fear of a Persian Gulf war sent thousands of Egyptians fleeing Iraq, President Hosni Mubarak warned Israel this week to stay out of the conflict, saying he would revise his policies on the crisis if Israel became embroiled.

title: U.S. Is Said To Pursue Pension Case
description: The Labor Department is investigating whether top executives of the Continental Can Corporation committed fraud, obstruction of justice and perjury in connection with a secret plan by the company to deprive laid-off workers of their pensions, people with detailed knowledge of the investigation said.

title: Education Chairman To Quit City Council
description: Arthur J. Katzman, who at 86 years old, is the senior member of the New York City Council, announced his resignation yesterday.

title: Scientist Is Given Deadline to Prove His Cold Fusion Research
description: The University of Utah scientist who asserts that he has achieved cold fusion has been given a deadline for sharing some results of his work or risk losing state money for research.

title: We Can't Afford Big Science's Price Anymore
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Australia Gives Its Tourism an Extra Push
description: AUSTRALIA has traded in its crocodile for a shark.

title: Racism and Plastic Surgery
description: To The Home Section:

title: Neediest Cases Helps Mother Who Fears Effects of AIDS
description: In the last year, Lillian O., who will be 31 years old next month, has started talking to her 6-year-old daughter about death.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Times and U.S. News Offer a Package Deal
description: The New York Times Magazine and U.S. News & World Report said yesterday that they would offer a special rate to advertisers who buy full-page ads in four issues of Business World magazine, which is published four times a year as a part 2 of The New York Times Magazine, and Quarterly Business Reports, which will appear four times a year in U.S. News & World Report.

title: New Venture May Resolve Kodak Issue
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced a joint venture with a large French drug maker yesterday, as expected, and in so doing may have found a virtually cost-free solution to a nagging problem. Ever since buying Sterling Drug in 1988 for $5.1 billion, Kodak has had difficulty convincing investors that the money was well spent.

title: Inquiry Finds Handles Are Faulty On Some Airliner Emergency Exits
description: Emergency exits on hundreds of McDonnell Douglas airliners have faulty handles that can snap in two if they are pulled hard the wrong direction by somebody trying to open the exits, Federal safety investigators said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Big V Supermarkets Inc., Florida, N.Y., which operates 27 Shoprite supermarkets, was sold for $200 million to Thomas H. Lee Co. by an investor group led by CS First Boston Inc. and Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., New York. * Enron Corp., Houston, an oil and gas concern, was authorized to buy back up to one million shares of its common stock on the open market. * Fluor Daniel Inc., Irvine, Calif., the engineering and construction concern, was awarded a $250 million contract by Logan Aluminum Inc. to expand its sheet producing facilities. * General Signal Corp., Stamford, Conn., the semiconductor and telecommunications concern, completed the previously announced sale of its New York Air Brake unit, Watertown, N.Y., to Knorr-Bremse A.G. of Munich, Germany, for undisclosed terms. * Hercules Inc., a chemicals and aerospace company in Wilmington, Del., established a voluntary retirement program for the corporate staff and the resins group that is expected to eliminate 475 jobs. * Itel Corp., Chicago, a transportation company, said its shareholders had approved the buyback of an additional one million shares beyond the 9.35 million shares remaining in Itel's previously announced agreement to buy back Henley Group's stake of 18.7 million shares of Itel stock. * KLA Instruments Corp., San Jose, Calif., is trying to sell its printed circuit-board inspection division and will take a pretax charge of about $15 million for the quarter that ended Dec. 31 to cover costs of divesting the unit. * KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Amsterdam, will order General Electric CF6-802C engines valued at $2.3 billion for its 10 McDonnell Douglas MD11 jets ordered in 1989 and for 10 other MD11's if options on the planes are exercised. * Quaker Oats Co., Chicago, will reduce pretax earnings for the current quarter by about $50 million, or 40 cents a share, for discontinued operations in its Fisher-Price toy unit, which it expects to finish spinning off in the first quarter of 1991. * Sundstrand Corp., Rockford, Ill., a maker of transmissions and hydraulic equipment, and Milton Roy Co., St. Petersburg, Fla., an instruments and pumps concern, said the merger of Milton Roy with a subsidiary of Sundstrand had been completed.

title: Charles W. Carleton, Executive, 71
description: Charles Webster Carleton, retired president of South American operations for Nabisco Brands, now R.J.R. Nabisco, died on Friday at a family home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: 10 Traders Found Guilty In Chicago Futures Case
description: A Federal jury today convicted eight soybean traders at the Chicago Board of Trade of racketeering, giving the Government its first major victory in the investigation of trading fraud in Chicago.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Seagram Tests Beverage With a Softer Campaign
description: The Seagram Beverage Company has created a sparkling water with a touch of alcohol and introduced it in three test markets.

title: POLL FINDS WHITES USE STEREOTYPES
description: Whites still cling to stereotypes of black and Hispanic people, a survey has found.

title: Decorating by Mail With Help From Eddie Bauer
description: MAIL-ORDER catalogues for the home are multiplying rapidly. And many have familiar names.

title: Danny Thomas Puts His Life and Work on Paper
description: Danny Thomas, 77 years and 1 day old, is sitting on a sofa at his midtown hotel comparing the comedians of today with the ones of his generation. "Most of the new comics have about six or seven great minutes," Mr. Thomas says. "After that, they have to garbage it up to be out there for maybe 20 minutes. In our day, you did an hour."

title: For Those Who Would Eat No Fat
description: When Dr. Donald Small devised his recipe for turning out red meat low in fat and cholesterol, he was thinking not of high science, but of his palate.

title: New Setback in Jesuit Case in Salvador
description: In the face of new accusations in the United States Congress that the Salvadoran Defense Minister and high command are obstructing the investigation into the slaying of six Jesuit priests, the two principal prosecutors in the case have resigned and have accused the Attorney General's Office of interference.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Slide
description: Failure to achieve a breakthrough leading to a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis threw the credit markets into turmoil yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities tumbled and long-term interest rates rose sharply.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: Key Rates
Israel Vows to Respond to Attack
description: Israeli officials leave little doubt about what they will do if Iraq carries out its repeated threat to draw this country into a Persian Gulf war. The Government says the Israeli Air Force will respond, and with great force.

title: Implanted Birth Control Device Renews Debate Over Forced Contraception
description: Less than a month after the Federal Government approved a new birth control device that is implanted under a woman's skin, the long-lasting device is the focus of a renewed debate over forced contraception.

title: Weicker, an Independent, Is Sworn In, Asking Bipartisan Help
description: Lowell Palmer Weicker Jr., who broke the rules of Connecticut politics last year with his successful third-party run for governor, took the oath of office today as the state's first independent chief executive in more than a century.

title: Steve Clark, Guitarist, 30
description: Steve Clark, the 30-year-old guitarist for the heavy-metal rock group Def Leppard, was found dead on Tuesday at his home here, the police said.

title: Oil Prices Fluctuate Wildly, Then Settle Just 9 Higher
description: Oil prices took a wild ride yesterday but came to rest just about where they started. When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced his disappointing news in Geneva just before 2 P.M., the price jumped nearly 30 percent in five minutes, rushing from $24 a barrel to $31.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MAXIMILIAN SCHELL and YEVGENY YEVTUSHENKO are on a double bill tonight at the Anti-Defamation League's Jewish Foundation for Christian Rescuers dinner at the New York Hilton.

title: FINANCIAL SCANDAL ROCKS YUGOSLAVIA
description: A financial scandal in Yugoslavia threatens to topple its federal monetary system, undercutting what was widely regarded in the West as Eastern Europe's most promising economic reform program and eroding what little remains of the country's crumbling unity.

title: OPEC Output Shows Rise
description: OPEC's oil production rose 300,000 barrels a day to a total of 23.5 million barrels a day in December, a seven-month high, the International Energy Agency reported today.

title: Pasqualoni Is Named Head Coach at Syracuse
