description: Paul Pasqualoni, the linebacker coach for the last four years at Syracuse University, was named head football coach yesterday to replace Dick MacPherson, who left on Monday to become the coach of the New England Patriots of the National Football League.

title: Weicker and Cuomo Say the Pinch Hurts
description: Fiscal worries overshadowed State of the State speeches in Albany and Hartford yesterday.

title: Arts Grants' Anti-Obscenity Clause Ruled Unconstitutional by U.S. Judge
description: A Federal judge in Los Angeles ruled today that the anti-obscenity clause in grants by the National Endowment for the Arts is unconstitutional.

title: Welbilt Chief Executive Quits to Form a Venture
description: Richard L. Hirsch joined the Welbilt Corporation, his family's stove manufacturing business, in 1963 and left at the first of the year after many years as its head. Yesterday, he announced plans for a new venture, Concurrent Industries Group, which will invest in and provide management for companies with potential that need help.

title: Informed Opinion
description: In Anthony Trollope's 1869 novel "Phineas Finn," the story of a neophyte politician, a parliamentary veteran tells young Finn how things work:

title: Sony's Columbia Unit Planning Theme Park
description: Columbia Pictures Entertainment, the Hollywood studio owned by the Sony Corporation, plans to enter the theme park business and may build one or more attractions in the United States or abroad.

title: New York Council Votes to Force City to Buy Clean-Fuel Vehicles
description: In an effort to reduce air pollution, the New York City Council voted unanimously yesterday to require the city to buy vehicles powered by fuels that burn more cleanly than gasoline and diesel fuel.

title: New Hall Of Famers Keep Rose On Minds
description: For Rod Carew, Gaylord Perry and Ferguson Jenkins, election to the Hall of Fame by the Baseball Writers Association of America has ended all doubts that adversities during their careers might have prevented such an achievement.

title: When Do You Stop The Fight?
description: The distance between the Opryland Hotel and Tennessee State University may be only 10 miles, but for Ed Temple, the legendary women's track coach at Tennessee State, the hotel might as well be 40 years away.

title: Neon's Not Just to Drink Beer By
description: JEFF FRIEDMAN, a partner in Let There Be Neon City Inc., stood beside a wall covered with clocks from the 1930's and 40's. Each was illuminated by bold neon bands.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Joe Palmo has been promoted to senior vice president and creative director at Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh.* Sara Coulter, Susan Johnson and Meredith Pillon have been promoted to executive vice presidents at the Rowland Co., New York. Promoted to senior vice president were Andrea Berken and Linda Stanier.* David J. Barrett has been named deputy general manager of broadcasting at the Hearst Corp., New York.* Victoria Lasdon has been appointed advertising director of Self magazine, a Conde Nast publication.

title: Walter Zirpolo, 75, Ex-New Jersey Mayor
description: Walter Zirpolo, a former mayor of Woodbridge, N.J., who served 15 months in prison for bribery and conspiracy in an oil-pipeline scandal, died on Tuesday at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 75 years old and lived in Woodbridge.

title: Ada Moore Is Dead; Singer and Actress, 64
description: Ada Moore, a singer and actress who performed on Broadway and in jazz clubs across the nation, died on Sunday at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 64 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: New York Board Backs School for Minority Men
description: The New York City Board of Education is preparing to establish an experimental high school that, while open to both sexes and all races, would have a special emphasis on the problems of young black and Hispanic men.

title: Company Devised AIDS Drug Test Partly as Sales Tool
description: The maker of an AIDS drug has acknowledged that it devised what it called a research study at least in part as a marketing device for the drug.

title: China Puts 4 Democracy Advocates on Trial
description: China began political trials for four more democracy advocates today, including at least one student, court officials said.

title: Stock Inquiry Said to Clear Dinkins
description: An independent city investigation into Mayor David N. Dinkins's transfer of stock in a communication company to his son has ended without any finding of criminal wrongdoing, officials familiar with the investigation said yesterday.

title: Aligarh Journal; Campus Under Fire: Not Just a Crisis of Identity
description: At Aligarh Muslim University, an island of uneasy calm in a storm of Hindu-Muslim violence that killed scores of people in this city in December, a concerned faculty is challenging religious bigotry and political opportunism where they believe it must be fought: in Government offices and the courts.

title: Police and U.S. Agents Seize 41 To Break Up Bronx Heroin Ring
description: The police and Federal agents arrested 41 people in the Bronx yesterday to shatter what they said was a major local heroin ring and seized one of the largest caches of weapons in recent memory.

title: Critic's Notebook; Gulf Tensions: TV's Cause and Effect
description: With the approach of the deadline for possible war in the Persian Gulf, television news has been contributing to the atmosphere of belligerent tension. CBS has instituted a "Countdown to Confrontation" on its nightly news, inspired perhaps by the sandwich boards that once announced the number of days to the world's end. (If apocalypse is delayed, the figure can easily be altered.) And there is Dan Rather, once again out in the field, speaking of "war drums beating along the Potomac and the Tigris." Tom Brokaw made it to Geneva for NBC , and yesterday afternoon all the networks carried the press conferences of President Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz.

title: Avoiding Ski Injuries In One Easy Lesson
description: It was reported in the news the other week that there are some 400,000 skiing injuries every year. This translates to the entire population of Pittsburgh walking around in neck braces, arm slings and casts on their legs. And those not walking would be hanging in traction.

title: Help for Canada's Nuclear Industry
description: THE last time Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd. had a foreign order for a nuclear reactor was in 1981, when Romania promised payment in everything from strawberries to underwear. Although Romania eventually paid what it promised, it ran out of money and left the plant half-finished.

title: Fabricland Gets Bid
description: House of Fabrics Inc. began a $43 million hostile tender offer yesterday for another fabric retailer, Fabricland Inc. of Portland, Ore.

title: Rangers' Unbeaten Streak Ends at 7
description: The breakdowns -- most glaring, a couple counteracted by great goaltending -- followed one after another in the defensive zone for the Rangers. Territory was conceded, assignments were missed, pucks were given away.

title: Inflatable and Hysterical
description: THE inflatable 40-foot bow and 300-foot ribbon designed for the opening of the Trump Taj Mahal Casino in Atlantic City made headlines for Goldman Arts last spring. Now the Boston-based company is making its larger-than-life inflatables for the home.

title: Review/Opera; A Piece for Young Singers
description: Youth and freshness were in the air on Sunday afternoon at the Mannes College of Music, when the Mannes Opera Ensemble presented Roger Trefousse's "Found Objects" to inaugurate a new commissioning project. Every two years, by present plans, the school will produce a chamber opera written specifically to suit the talents and stimulate the sensibilities of young performers.

title: Network Debate Coverage
description: Spokesmen for the three major television networks said yesterday that they plan periodic reports but not continuous coverage today on debates in both houses of Congress on a resolution supporting the use of force against Iraq.

title: Review/Theater; A History Of the World From Eden To Zaloom
description: To create his theater, all that Paul Zaloom needs is a stage, himself as actor -- and enough trash to fill a month's quota at a recycling center. In Mr. Zaloom's dextrous hands, the detritus of consumerism is converted into artful subjects for satire. One can imagine him wheeling a cart through a supermarket, shopping for visual puns and metaphors. The result, as demonstrated in his new show, "My Civilization" (at Dance Theater Workshop), is puppetry of a high political priority.

title: The Letter Rejected
description: Saddam Hussein's Foreign Minister took in hand the letter from the President of the United States, read it carefully, and answered it in the most contemptuous way available to nations: he passed it back across the table, refusing to "receive" it.

title: Johnny Depp Contemplates Life As, and After, 'Scissorhands'
description: There were times when Johnny Depp, teen-age heart throb and god of the check-out tabloids, doubted he could play an innocent, soulful, bashful boy who happens to have scissors where his hands should be.

title: We Can't Afford Big Science's Price Anymore; Home-Growing Centers
description: To the Editor:

title: McKellen Backed on Honor
description: A group of 18 film and theater professionals who identified themselves as homosexuals signed a letter published today in The Guardian supporting a decision by Ian McKellen, the English actor and director, to accept the knighthood conferred on him in the annual honors list.

title: Alvin W. Singleton, Foundry Executive, 64
description: Alvin W. Singleton, president and chief operating officer of the Intermet Corporation, a manufacturer of iron castings based in Atlanta, and president of the Lynchburg Foundry Company, a subsidiary of Intermet, died Tuesday at Lynchburg General Hospital in Lynchburg, Va. He was 64 years old.

title: Watson Sees Progress
description: Tom Watson said yesterday that his resignation late last year from the private club where he learned to play golf to protest its discriminatory membership policies has resulted in a positive reaction nationwide. His act was in reaction to the Kansas City Country Club's refusal to accept an application for membership of Watson's friend, Henry Bloch, who is the co-founder of the nation's largest tax preparation firm, H&R Block, and is Jewish, as are Watson's wife and children.

title: Arab Cultural Center in Paris Buffeted by Persian Gulf Crisis
description: In these chilly days, as the gray light merges with the glass of a modern palace in the heart of Paris, Edgard Pisani can be found on its top floor, juggling shards of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: PENTAGON ADOPTS GULF NEWS RULES
description: The Defense Department gave its final approval today to a set of rules for reporters covering a possible war in the Persian Gulf, despite widespread objections from print and broadcast executives that the rules are needlessly restrictive and amounted to an objectionable attempt at censorship.

title: Managua Defends Army Chief in Missile Uproar
description: Defying pressure from its political allies and the United States, the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has defended Nicaragua's military commander against criticism in the recent transfer of Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles from Nicaraguan Army stockpiles to Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Gloom in Washington; Bleak Geneva Outcome Seems to Convince Many Skeptics That War Is Now Likelier
description: A mood of foreboding settled over official Washington tonight with the failure of talks between the United States and Iraq in Geneva and highly public signs that the Administration was moving the United States toward a war footing.

title: Sequent Shares Drop by 33.3%
description: Shares in Sequent Computer Systems Inc. plummeted today after the company said its earnings for the fourth quarter, which ended on Dec. 29, would be lower than in the corresponding period last year.

title: Pro Hockey; Islanders Are Beaten In Overtime
description: Brian Skrudland's second goal of the game, at 2 minutes 30 seconds into overtime, rallied the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-3 victory over the Islanders tonight.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on Baker's Mission and Diplomacy's Fate
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's White House news conference today, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Books of The Times; Oil and Terrorism in a Puzo Thriller
description: The Fourth K By Mario Puzo 479 pages. Random House. $22.

title: A Weak Outlook For Phone Giants
description: THE stocks of the nation's three main long-distance telephone companies all fell sharply last year after three years of strong gains, and some analysts say they are unlikely to recover soon because of concerns about the weakening economy.

title: Calendar: Old Resorts of the East Side
description: An Urban Retreat Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street; (212) 838-6878.

title: Trade U.S. Food and Goods for Soviet Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Bank Seizure Stirs Hope
description: State business leaders and bank analysts believe this week's takeover by Federal regulators of Connecticut Bank and Trust, a subsidiary of the insolvent Bank of New England Corporation, could help Connecticut's economy if the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, manages to sell the bank to a strong institution within a few weeks.

title: Pro Football; Bears Are Receiving Some Special Respect
description: When Bill Parcells recalls the 1985 Chicago Bears, the Giants' coach says that he thinks of "the best defensive team I've ever seen."

title: Governor Again Proposes to Limit Campaign Funds and Ease Voting
description: Deriding New York's election system as "among the most Byzantine schemes in the nation," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo used his State of the State address today to propose major changes in state election laws, including stricter limits on campaign contributions and measures to improve access to the voting booth.

title: Connecticut Inaugural: A Celebration of Firsts
description: Ninety minutes before Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was sworn in as governor today, a solitary figure with a video camera stood shivering on the sleet-slickened front lawn of the State Capitol awaiting the arrival of the inaugural procession.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18

title: Fund Yields Are Down
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report reversed course and declined in the week ended yesterday, in large part because of a seasonal inflow of savings.

title: Kinder-Care Plans To Skip Payment
description: Hard pressed by its heavy debt load, Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc., an operator of day-care centers, said it would not make a $63 million payment to bondholders due on Friday. It said bondholders had indicated they might extend the repayment period for 18 months. But Sharon Rives, a Kinder-Care spokeswoman, said the company needed a longer time to deal with its financial problems.

title: Review/Music; The Spirited Elza Soares, a Legend of Brazil
description: Elza Soares is a legend in her homeland of Brazil not only for her ebullient, percussive singing but for her dramatic personal life as well. The country's "queen of samba," who opened a five-night engagement at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) on Tuesday evening, came from extreme poverty and has weathered scandal and much personal tragedy. Now in her 60's, with 300 albums to her credit, the singer looks 20 years younger. Like Tina Turner, the American singer with whom she has frequently been compared, she projects an indomitable vitality along with a metallic sexiness that is friendly and playful in its exaggeration.

title: Themes for '91: A Sense of Limits And Wistfulness
description: Becoming Mayor during a recession was David N. Dinkins's first mistake. So it was no surprise that he referred almost wistfully this week to "a new beginning" as he and the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, each facing daunting deficits, delivered their ritual prognoses for the new year.

title: Semiconductor Chief Quitting
description: Semiconductor industry officials said today that Charles E. Sporck would step down as president and chief executive of the National Semiconductor Corporation, possibly as soon as the end of this month.

title: It Is the Clothes That Make the Chair
description: As one might expect, Bill Blass designed a red, black and white houndstooth suit. Pat Kerr whipped up an ivory lace and tulle wedding dress, replete with a fake white dove.

title: Sophomore Year; Mr. Florio Tiptoes Into 1991
description: A chastened Gov. Jim Florio proposes nothing bold for New Jersey this year. Scorched by the uproar over last year's hefty tax bill and increased aid to poor school districts at the expense of those better off, he carefully avoided new controversy in his State of the State address. Mr. Florio is presumably more interested in retaining Democratic control of the Legislature in the November elections than in making new waves.

title: Markets in U.S. Shift Abruptly On Gulf Report
description: Financial markets gyrated wildly yesterday as traders reacted first with hope, then with alarm, to the American-Iraqi talks on the Middle East. But some markets, notably gold and oil, turned again and ended little changed.

title: 2 May Join MacPherson
description: The Boston Globe reported yesterday that two Syracuse assistant coaches -- Randy Edsall, the secondary coach, and George DeLeone, the offensive coordinator -- were likely to join MacPherson with the Patriots, as were Norm Gerber and Ivan Fears, the defensive coordinators.

title: What Congress Should Tell Bush
description: Following is a draft resolution for Congress to consider in response to President Bush's request for support for the use of force against Iraq.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) -- Signed Jeff Reed, catcher, to a two-year contract and Luis Quinones, infielder, to a one-year contract. Agreed to terms with Freddie Benevides and Brian Lane, infielders; Milt Hill, pitcher; Glenn Sutko, catcher, and Chris Jones, outfielder, on one-year contracts. SAN DIEGO (NL) -- Agreed to terms with Dennis Rasmussen, pitcher, on a one-year contract. COLLEGES JACKSONVILLE -- Named Ed Hanozaryk men's golf coach and Floyd (Smitty) Smith women's golf coach. SYRACUSE -- Named Paul Pasqualoni football coach.

title: Wallpapers From Long Ago
description: SINCE the 1930's, the Manchester City Art Galleries in England have been collecting wallpaper samples -- everything from 20th-century designs to 19th-century scenic wallpapers to a stenciled fragment, circa 1740, dusted with powdered mussel shells that give it a glimmer.

title: Challenge for Cuomo Is Keeping Alive His Programs in Fiscally Bleak Period
description: Presenting his State of the State address today, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo banged up against the toughest challenge of his administration: maintaining the liberal agenda he has advocated in good times through a period that promises to be bleak.

title: How 3 Embattled Builders Survive
description: With real estate prices falling and buyers treating the new-home market as if it had a wet basement and no rooms with a view, many builders are struggling to stay alive until the next upturn in sales.

title: That Person in the White Smock Is Not a Doctor
description: In the operating room at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, Debra Shrebnick wields her scalpel with aplomb and weaves the gleaming suture needle smoothly through the patient's flesh as she and Dr. Craig Smith prepare to place a patient on a heart bypass machine. By all appearances she is a "blade," the medical slang for a surgeon.

title: Basketball; Knicks Still Can't Beat the Quality Teams
description: The Knicks practiced today and tried to put their 101-87 loss to the Boston Celtics on Tuesday night out of their minds. Who could blame them?

title: Pro Football; Green Inspires Redskin Defense
description: On the third play of last week's playoff game, the Philadelphia Eagles flew on a 66-yard pass play to the Washington Redskins' 11-yard line, and Darrell Green, the Redskins' outstanding defensive back, implored his teammates to stop the Eagles without a touchdown.

title: Kevin Thompson, Designer, 32
description: Kevin Thompson, a designer of men's clothes, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 32 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK , the teeny-bopper all-male quintet, was taken to Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday by Kids on the Block Inc. The second group, a Maryland corporation that makes puppets used in plays to teach children about disabilities, is seeking a preliminary injunction against New Kids.

title: Pan Am Expected to Meet Resistance on a Debt Plan
description: Now under the protection of the bankruptcy court, Pan American World Airways is looking for ways to reduce the cost of its crushing debt. But some analysts of the airline industry say that will not be easy.

title: Mitchell H. Cohen, 86, Federal Judge, Is Dead
description: Mitchell H. Cohen, a senior Federal District Judge and a former prosecutor in Camden County, N.J., died on Monday at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 86 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Dow Off 39.11, To 2,470.30; Volume Rises
description: After trading sharply higher much of the day, stocks fell steeply yesterday only minutes after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d grimly went before television cameras in Geneva to report on his talks with Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister.

title: Regulators Are Glum On Outlook
description: The nation's senior banking regulators said today that more large failures like the Bank of New England would occur if the economy did not turn around by the middle of the year.

title: Congress Weighs a Fee Rise For Business on U.S. Land
description: Congressional leaders said today that they thought businesses were paying the Government too little for the privilege of earning billions from services and products in Federal forests, parks and other Government-owned areas. They said they were investigating whether to raise the fees.

title: How to Make Furniture: Got 30 Minutes and a TV?
description: WOODWORKERS, gather your tools. The third season of the television show "The New Yankee Workshop" begins in the metropolitan area on Jan. 26 at 5:30 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Trade U.S. Food and Goods for Soviet Oil; Decentralize Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the Senate Ethics Committee hearing misidentified James Hamilton in some copies. He is a lawyer for Senator Dennis DeConcini, not for Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr.

title: 2 Youths Get at Least 5 Years in Attack on Jogger
description: Accusing them of "cowardly, mindless, mob-induced madness," a Manhattan judge yesterday sentenced two more defendants in the rape and beating of a woman who was jogging in Central Park.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SWIMMING Gold Medals for Biondi and Evans Matt Biondi and Janet Evans, both Olympic champions, got the United States squad back on the victory stand in a big way at the world championships yesterday in Perth, Australia. Biondi retained his gold medal in the men's 100-meter freestyle in 49.18 seconds, well off his world record but a big victory for him. Evans, a triple gold medalist in the 1988 Olympics, finally added a world-championship gold to her victory list, beating the Australian teen-ager Hayley Lewis with a 4:09.40 in the women's 400 freestyle. The victory gave Evans revenge for Lewis's victory Tuesday in the 200 freestyle. It also helped take the sting out of a disappointing fourth in the 400 individual medley and a disqualification in the Evans-anchored 800 freestyle relay Monday. The United States got a surprise gold medal in diving when Kent Ferguson, a six-time national champion but never winner of an important international meet, beat top-ranked Tan Liangde of China in the men's 3-meter springboard. TENNIS Becker Loses Another Opener Boris Becker's preparation for the Australian Open continued to sag yesterday when he was beaten, 5-7, 7-5, 6-4, by Goran Ivanisevic in his opening match of the six-man Rio Challenge exhibition tournament at Adelaide, Australia. The defeat followed Becker's first-round loss to Magnus Larsson last week in the Australian hardcourt championships. (AP) Chesnokov Upset: Second-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union was upset by Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia yesterday, 6-1, 5-7, 7-5, in the second round of the New Zealand Open at Auckland. (AP)

title: Francis B. Bushey, 71, Ex-Shipyard Executive
description: Francis B. Bushey, a former executive in the tugboat and shipyard industries in New York Harbor, died Tuesday at Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida. He was 71 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Bush, Noting a Hussein 'Stiff-Arm,' Finds Hopes for Peace Waning
description: Accusing President Saddam Hussein of giving him a "total stiff-arm," President Bush said today that he was losing hope for a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Whitney Museum Appoints Director
description: In a move that has been awaited for several weeks, the trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art voted yesterday to confirm the appointment of David A. Ross as the Whitney's new director.

title: They Bring a Smile, Then They Brighten It
description: THE toothbrush has evolved into a design statement.

title: Ramussen Re-signs
description: Dennis Rasmussen re-signed with San Diego at the last minute, while Dave Schmidt and Denny Walling decided to leave their teams.

title: Cheney Says He Will Seek Longer Term for Reservists
description: The Defense Department plans to ask the White House for emergency authority to keep reservists in the military for as long as two years, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Please Stay, Morgan Stanley
description: Please, Morgan Stanley, stay in New York City. As a major investment house, it's in your long-term interests to continue operations in the city rather than move to Stamford, as rumor has it that you will. Besides, I don't want you here.

title: Death for a Dollar
description: Headlines proclaim that Grace Cheng died for the sake of the dollar a mugger found in her purse: has life become that cheap in New York City? How does one make sense of so senseless a death?

title: Fire Set by Victim, Official Says
description: The New York City Fire Commissioner, Carlos M. Rivera, said yesterday that one of the two brothers killed in a Queens fire on Monday had set the blaze.

title: Separate Studies Rank '90 As World's Warmest Year
description: The earth was warmer in 1990 than in any other year since people began measuring the planet's surface temperature, separate groups of climatologists in the United States and Britain said yesterday.

title: Purse-Snatching Suspect Is Charged With Murder
description: A suspect with a long conviction record -- including several robberies on subways -- was charged with murder yesterday in the death of a purse-snatching victim who was dragged by a train along a subway platform Tuesday morning while chasing her attacker.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: "Don't go out without a hat." "Wear your boots if you're going to play in the snow." "I didn't buy you gloves to keep your pockets warm."

title: Paley Estate Sells Shares
description: The estate of William S. Paley, the founder of CBS, said announced today that it had sold 250,000 shares of CBS common stock for $180 a share.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * W. R. Berkley Corp., Greenwich, Conn., an insurance holding company, appointed E. LeRoy Heer senior vice president and chief corporate actuary. * Equimark, Pittsburgh, a banking company, named Richard L. Stover executive vice president and chief credit officer, replacing Thomas Middleton. John C. Williams Jr. was named executive vice president in charge of commercial lending, replacing William F. Jones. * Graphics Information Inc., Denver, producers of map-based information systems, appointed Albert B. Cerand senior vice president of development and Stephen J. Mulvihill vice president of sales and marketing. * LADD Furniture Inc., High Point, N.C., appointed Jerry L. Baker president of its Daystrom Furniture unit, succeeding Gerald L. Grubbs, who has been promoted to executive vice president of the company. * The Limited Inc., Columbus, Ohio, operators of women's fashion stores, promoted Cynthia Fedus to president of its Victoria's Secret Catalogue. * Lori Corp., Providence, R.I., a subsidiary of Artra Group Ltd., Northfield, Ill., that makes fashion jewelry, named W. Jeffries Lewis president, succeeding Harris Kruger, who becomes vice president of corporate development at the parent company. * MGM Grand Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., an airline company, appointed Robert R. Maxey president and chief executive. * Southern Phenix Textiles Inc., Phenix City, Ala., a unit of Johnston Industries, New York, appointed Richard J. Gibney vice president of its stitchbond and automotive fabrics division.

title: Basketball; Smith Notches 700th as Tar Heels Rout Maryland
description: Dean Smith gained the 700th victory of his coaching career tonight as North Carolina routed Maryland, 105-73. Hubert Davis scored a career-high 25 points for the Tar Heels, who improved their record to 12-1 over all as they won their Atlantic Coast Conference opener.

title: South Africa Integrates Some Schools
description: As a new school year began here today, black South African children were for the first time admitted to previously all-white classes in 33 public schools where parents had approved plans for limited integration.

title: John Flanagan, 84, Orthopedic Surgeon
description: Dr. John J. Flanagan, an orthopedic surgeon, died on Tuesday at his home in Spring Lake, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: DeConcini Is Adamant On His Help for Keating
description: Senator Dennis DeConcini told the Senate Ethics Committee today that his intervention with Federal regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. was "not only a right but an obligation."

title: New Impetus in Honda Car-Building Effort
description: The Honda Motor Company, responding to "a number of socio-economic changes" that have complicated business, including the new Clean Air Act in the United States, announced today that it was intensifying efforts to develop vehicles that will set new environmental, energy and safety standards.

title: Recycled Refrigerators in New England
description: OLD refigerators are a problem. Sanitation departments don't want them. Junkyards won't take them. Charities won't go near them.

title: Nassau Landfill Ordered to Close as Health Hazard
description: The Nassau County Board of Health today declared the North Hempstead landfill a health hazard and ordered the town to shut it down within 10 days.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in Business Day yesterday about a resignation at the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company misidentified the company that had annual sales of $3.7 billion in the year that ended June 30, 1990. It was the United States grocery products division of the Quaker Oats Company; it was not R. J. Reynolds Tobacco.

title: Surgeon General Calls Potent Wine a Threat
description: Surgeon General Antonia Novello said today that consumers, particularly teen-agers, were being endangered by a high-alcohol drink that looks like a mild wine cooler but is as potent as five shots of vodka.

title: N.C.A.A. Cuts Practice, Scholarships And Seasons
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association voted today to reduce scholarships in all sports by roughly 10 percent and to limit the time demands on student athletes.

title: Metro-North Chief Is Called Choice to Head M.T.A.
description: Peter E. Stangl, president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, has been chosen by the Governor's selection committee as the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, high-ranking officials of the state authority said yesterday.

title: Waterville Valley Journal; Snow Isn't Just a Four-Letter Word
description: Every night since early November, the residents of this resort community nestled in the White Mountains have waited, eyes upturned, for a hint of the winter storms that are their livelihood.

title: U.S. Battle Plan: Massive Air Strikes
description: An American-led air campaign against Iraq and Iraqi forces in Kuwait would involve around-the-clock bombing strikes against military and industrial targets that could last several weeks, according to military experts.

title: David Hockney Is Back in Opera, With a Few Ifs, Ands and Buts
description: A decade ago, the flamboyant painter David Hockney was the toast of operatic New York, having designed not one but two triple bills for the Metropolitan Opera in the single year of 1981.

title: Associates Corp.
description: The Associates Corporation of North America offered $300 million worth of four-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. The 8.80 percent notes, which mature on Jan. 14, 1995, were priced at $99.837 to yield 8.85 percent, 1.32 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 5/8 percent four-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are rated AA-3 by Moody's and AA-minus by S.& P.

title: Old Reliables Shine At Wares Show
description: Marketing experts say rule No. 1 in a recession is not to be overly daring. Stick to familiar, time-honored designs. Use natural materials when possible. And make sure to meet genuine needs rather than engage in gimmickry.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Eric Mower Acquires Blair
description: Eric Mower & Associates of Syracuse has acquired Blair Advertising, a Rochester-based agency, from the Omnicom Group, for undisclosed terms.

title: U.S. EMBASSY AIDE IS HELD IN BERLIN
description: An official of the American diplomatic mission in Berlin was taken into custody on Tuesday by German police on suspicion of spying for the Soviet Union, prosecutors said today.

title: Basketball; Seton Hall Dismantles Sealy and St. John's
description: Malik Sealy was frustrated. His ankle was twisted and his pride was bruised. Four times his shots were swatted away, numerous other times he never managed a shot and 10 of his 13 attempts took unfriendly bounces off the rim.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Carrier Corp., Farmington, Conn., a division of United Technology, Hartford, to DDB Needham, Chicago, for its residential heating and air-conditioning business, with billings of $10 million. The previous agency was Ogilvy &Mather;, New York.* National Organization for the Blind, Madrid, to BSB Madrid Backer Spielvogel Bates, with a budget of $10 million.* Landmark Savings Bank, Pittsburgh, to Dudreck, DePaul, Ficco & Morgan, Pittsburgh, with a budget of $1 million. The account was previously handled by Werner Chepelsky & Partners, Pittsburgh.* Coast Federal, a financial institution in Sarasota, Fla., to Earle Palmer Brown, Tampa, with a budget of $1 million.

title: Home Improvement
description: EXTENDED cold weather strains home heating equipment, increasing the likelihood of an unexpected breakdown. Such breakdowns are rarely dangerous, even in furnaces that burn explosive natural gas, but they may mean a cold and frustrating wait for a technician from the utility or heating company. Here are a few simple steps that may help you restart the furnace yourself, quickly and safely.

title: Route to Japan Is Transferred
description: The Transportation Department approved the transfer today to American Airlines of the route between Seattle and Portland, Ore., and Japan now held by financially ailing Continental Airlines.

title: Chairman Takes On 2 Added Jobs at Mitel
description: The Mitel Corporation, an Ontario- based telecommunications company striving to improve profitability, has returned the jobs of president and chief executive to its chairman, Anthony F. Griffiths.

title: HITLER QUOTE TIED TO PAPER'S STAFF
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said today that it was a Dartmouth Review staff member who placed a quotation from Hitler in the conservative weekly last fall.

title: The Larger Patriotism
description: The world's hopes for a diplomatic breakthrough at Geneva have been cruelly disappointed. Today Congress begins to debate peace or war; Iraq's intransigence invites an angry vote. What Members of Congress owe America, however, is neither anger nor truculence but their best judgment on what best serves the vital interests of the United States.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * American General Finance Inc., Evansville, Ind., a unit of American General Corp., is offering $100 million in 8 3/4 percent notes through Merrill Lynch & Co. The three-year noncallable notes were priced at 99.90 to yield 8.789 percent, or 140 basis points over comparable Treasuries. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The notes were rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Castle & Cooke Inc., Los Angeles, has signed a four-year, $800 million revolving credit agreement with a group of banks led by Security Pacific National Bank. * Coastal Corp., Houston, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $250 million in senior notes due in 2001 through Lehman Brothers. * Delta Air Lines, Atlanta, is offering $225 million in 9 7/8 percent notes through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The seven-year noncallable notes were priced at par to yield 188 basis points over comparable Treasuries. They were rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.& P. * Ford Motor Credit Co., Dearborn, Mich., is offering $300 million in 8 5/8 percent notes through Goldman, Sachs. The three-year noncallable notes were priced at 99.97 to yield 8.636 percent or 128 basis points over comparable Treasuries. They were rated Aa-3 by Moody's and Aa- by S.& P. * Idaho Power Co., Boise, Idaho, is offering $75 million in first mortgage bonds through Goldman, Sachs. The 30-year, 9 1/2 percent bonds, noncallable for the first 10 years, were priced at 99.50 to yield 9.55 percent, or 125 basis points over comparable Treasuries. They were rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. RATINGS * Old National Bancorp's subordinated debt has been lowered to BBB+, from A-, by S.& P. The bank holding company is based in Evansville, Ind.

title: Congress Nears War Debate, as Bush Side Gains
description: Congress stepped to the brink today of debating war in the Persian Gulf, with the House's agenda clearer than the Senate's. The outcome in both chambers is dependent on how many Democrats join nearly solid Republican ranks in support of resolutions backing President Bush's use of force in accordance with United Nations resolutions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about mutual fund performance misstated the financial condition of the Benguet Corporation, a gold and copper mining company with operations in the Philippines. Although its third- quarter profits fell 64 percent, the company remains profitable.

title: As Family Protests, Hospital Seeks An End to Woman's Life Support
description: In a case that medical ethicists and legal experts say is apparently a first, a Minneapolis hospital plans to go to court for permission to turn off a patient's life support system against her family's wishes.

title: Modernist Classic Is Gleaming Again
description: IN 1931, a 26-year-old Vanderbilt heir named Frederick Vanderbilt Field rebelled against the dark ornament-encrusted mansions in which he had spent his childhood. On a wooded hillside here, about 20 miles northwest of Hartford, he built a sunny stucco box with a steel frame, the first International Style country house in America.

title: Court Considers Suspending Durenberger
description: A lawyers' monitoring group asked the Minnesota Supreme Court today to indefinitely suspend Senator Dave Durenberger's license to practice law, and the Republican Senator agreed to the suspension.

title: Hull's Torrid Pace: A Goal a Game
description: It was late morning, the night's game more than eight hours away as Brett Hull stood alone on the ice, the net empty in front of him, Madison Square Garden empty all around him. A snap of the wrists made a blur of the puck as Hull fired one after another through the half-light and into the cage.

title: KUWAIT INVESTS IN HUNGARY CHAIN
description: Stripped of its land and its oil, but not of its wealth, Kuwait has embarked on a strategy of investment in Eastern Europe's new and struggling democracies, starting with a modest joint venture agreement signed with Hungary's state-owned gasoline station chain this week.

title: Whither Design? Thithers Aplenty
description: LOOK backward, angel. To many architects and designers, this seemed to be the credo of the 1980's. Revivals of revivals, neo-Gothic or other, seemed to be the designer's mission.

title: Celtics End Bucks' Eight-Game Winning Streak
description: The Boston Celtics lost all but 2 points of a 28-point lead tonight before Reggie Lewis and Brian Shaw led them to a 110-102 victory over Milwaukee. The loss ended the Bucks' eight-game winning streak.

title: Toyota Set to Expand in U.S. Market
description: In a bid to expand in the United States market, the Toyota Motor Corporation today announced a two-seat sports coupe made in Japan but aimed at young Americans buying their first cars.

title: Stanley Expecting Drop in 1990 Net
description: The Stanley Works, the hardware and tools supplier, predicted its earnings for 1990 would be down 5 percent to 8 percent. "Stanley fourth-quarter sales and earnings have been affected by the spreading economic weakness in the United States," said Richard H. Ayers, chairman and chief executive. The company has not yet released earnings for the fourth quarter or the year.

title: Bridge
description: It is not easy for modern players to appreciate that the early days of the game were a time of enthusiasm and confusion. Perhaps the only living journalist who recorded the transition from auction to contract is 97-year-old George Copeland of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Fighting Said to Intensify in Somalia's Capital
description: Intensified fighting was reported today in Somalia's capital, and Western doctors who have established a hospital in the city appealed for additional medical supplies to treat the wounded.

title: A Legacy of Law
description: Providing lawyers to poor defendants is a noble, venerable -- and narrow -- idea. Providing true legal services to the poor is a much more challenging and recent undertaking.

title: Rich Got Richer in 80's; Others Held Even
description: The wealth of affluent people grew substantially in the 1980's while the assets of other Americans barely kept pace with inflation, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "We have not cleared him. We have simply concluded that the evidence is legally insufficient to warrant a criminal prosecution." -- Elkan Abramowitz, the chief investigator of a stock transaction involving Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Speculators Help to Raise Prices
description: Speculators, apparently gambling that peace in the Persian Gulf still has a chance, buoyed the Treasury securities market yesterday by stepping up and buying notes and bonds.

title: Reprieve Obtained By Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways last night was saved from running out of cash and having to shut down when a bankruptcy judge approved a $150 million loan to the ailing carrier.

title: Dennis J. Whimpey, Actuary, 52
description: Dennis J. Whimpey, an actuary and insurance executive, died Wednesday at his home in Avon, Conn. He was 52 years old.

title: RIVALS IN MIDEAST WARN OF DANGERS
description: From opposing perspectives across the Arab political spectrum, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that the deadlock in diplomacy between the United States and Iraq had heightened grave dangers in a region increasingly nervous about the possibility of a Persian Gulf war.

title: New England Bank Review
description: L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that he will try to assess how well the F.D.I.C. is running three failed New England banks when he visits Boston on Friday.

title: An Old Jet May Revive Grumman's Fortunes
description: After some bleak times, things are looking up for the Grumman Corporation.

title: Some Fault School Plan As Political
description: Critics and supporters began staking out positions yesterday on a proposal for a New York City high school that focuses on the needs of black and Hispanic young men, while a number of current and former school officials said politics and money, as much as educational philosophy, lay behind the idea.

title: Toward a Three-State Truck-Freight Network
description: To the Editor:

title: Posing Animals To Pose a Question
description: THE strength of photography as a medium of information is its faithful inclusivity. Nothing is left out of a scene. Wildlife, in particular, can be viewed in natural surroundings, the shore or savannah, the jungle or tundra, where they belong and are in danger of being lost without.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DELTA BURKE has sued the producers of "Designing Women," the CBS television series of which she is a star, contending that she was written out of an episode as a punishment by the producers. She is seeking $55,000, unspecified punitive damages and a court declaration that the defendants' actions have voided her contract.

title: Granatelli Makes Deal
description: Vince Granatelli, the second-generation Indy-car owner whose team has struggled recently for lack of the dominating Chevrolet V8 engine, has become co-owner of the team that won last year's Indianapolis 500.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Year of the Noodle

title: Legislation and Crises, Illusions and Realities
description: Some laws are more needed than others. It is also the case that some crises are less real than portrayed.

title: Stars & Stripes Price Rise
description: The newspaper Stars & Stripes, a main source of news for American soldiers, said on Wednesday that it was raising its prices after losses of more than $570,000 last year.

title: Scott Paper Effort To Sell Off Assets
description: The Scott Paper Company said it would sell off some assets to improve its earnings potential and reduce debt as the economy headed into recession. The company also said it would reduce capital spending, lower working capital and intensify cost-reduction efforts.

title: Review/Art; Paintings Filled With Oak, And Hints of Religion
description: Cheryl Laemmle first gained widespread attention with the emergence of the East Village art scene in the early to mid-1980's. Her highly realistic -- almost Surrealistic -- approach to an intensely personal, always to some degree imaginary world was an East Village feature. Her interest in childhood was another aspect of a scene that believed -- sometimes to the point of insistence -- that art could be fun. Her art helped define something of a neighborhood esthetic tone, which was at once optimistic and pessimistic, buoyant and bleak.

title: A $200 Million Project for Cherry Hill
description: A developer who expects to appeal to "every market niche" on his 224-acre site has started out by offering to build single-family houses that sell for $320,000 to $405,000.

title: Nintendo Sales Fall Short of Goals
description: The video game maker, Nintendo of America Inc., said it had record sales last year, but the results fell short of expectations because of a slowdown in the economy here. The subsidiary of the Nintendo Company of Japan, said it would release a 16-bit game machine in the second half of 1991.

title: Johnson Returns Tonight And the World Is Watching
description: While it might be some time, if ever, before Ben Johnson runs as fast as he once did, his return to competition Friday night after a two-year suspension for drug use has aroused a level of curiosity for a race perhaps unmatched since the race that got him in trouble.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some copies yesterday about Ada Moore, a singer and actress, misstated her relationship to Paul J. Ash. He is her former husband, not her husband. A corrected obituary appears today on page B7.

title: Restaurants
description: A new place on the Upper East Side restores the feeding frenzy of the 1980's with hearty food.

title: August Ihlefeld, 82; Led Savings Bank Trust
description: August Ihlefeld, an official of the Savings Bank Trust Company of New York from its founding in 1933 until he retired as chairman in 1965, died on Tuesday at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington. He was 82 years old and lived in Essex Center, Vt.

title: Senator Tries to Balance Party and Constituency
description: James Jeffords' views of the Middle East were shaped in 1957, when he served on the first ship that steamed through the reopened Suez Canal.

title: Rohatyn Agrees To Retain Post On Fiscal Panel
description: While Felix G. Rohatyn won't be staying in his post as head of New York City's fiscal watchdog agency for very long, he won't be leaving right away either.

title: U.S. Abandons Plan for AIDS Survey
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control has abandoned hopes of carrying out a national survey of households to determine the prevalence of AIDS infection, the agency said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ATC Inc. said it would acquire a majority position in Reserve-a-Phone Systems Inc., which sells and leases portable cellular telephones in Canada. Terms were not disclosed. * Aerospatiale, the French aerospace company, said it would conclude its acquisition of Boeing of Canada's de Havilland division within weeks. * Aztar Corp., Phoenix, a casino gaming company, said it would seek to buy back its common stock from holders of 99 or fewer shares. Aztar will pay a price equal to the average closing price on trading days from Jan. 28 to Feb. 22 plus a premium of 12.5 cents a share. * British Aerospace P.L.C., London, said its four-wheel-drive vehicle unit, Land-Rover Group, would build a Brazil manufacturing plant. * British Airways, London, said it had coverted two further options on Boeing 767's into firm orders, making a total of 22 firm orders plus 15 options remaining. No terms were disclosed. * Cambrex Corp., East Rutherford, N.J., a chemicals company, will buy the chemicals business of Solvay Animal Health Inc., including its chemical manufacturing plants in Charles City, Iowa. Terms were not disclosed. * Commodore International Ltd., West Chester, Pa., a maker of computer systems, introduced a CDTV player, a compact disc-based multimedia player that connects television and stereo equipment. * Eastern Enterprises, Weston, Mass., a barge operator, has completed the acquisition of certain assets and operations of A & P Water and Sewer Supplies Inc., Fairfax, Va. No terms were disclosed. * P A Consulting Group, Highstown, N.J., a technology consulting firm, will acquire Pugh-Roberts Associates, Cambridge, Mass., a business and technology consulting firm. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Salomon Brothers May Move 700 Jobs Out of New York City
description: Joining the corporate concern about the cost of doing business in New York City, Salomon Brothers Inc., the large Wall Street investment house, is considering moving hundreds of jobs out of the city, executives with the firm and city officials said yesterday.

title: Judge Is Firm on Forced Contraception, but Welcomes an Appeal
description: The judge who ordered a convicted child abuser to have an innovative birth control device implanted in her arm declined to reverse himself at a hearing today.

title: How to Trade Lawyer Futures as a Commodity; Develop Business
description: To the Editor:

title: ARABS SAY IRAQ PLANS OFFER LINKING PULLOUT TO ISRAEL; CONGRESS OPENS WAR DEBATE
description: Arab diplomats here said today that they had been told that President Saddam Hussein plans an initiative soon after the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for giving up Kuwait that will express his support "in principle" for pulling out of Kuwait and simultaneously call for an international conference to address Palestinian grievances against Israel.

title: Grammy Nominees Announced
description: The British singer and songwriter Phil Collins, the producer Quincy Jones and a pop newcomer, the singer Mariah Carey, garnered the most nominations for the 33d annual Grammy Awards. The nominations were announced yesterday by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences.

title: Review/Film; Violence, Blood: You Know
description: New dimensions in decadence: in "Lionheart," Jean-Claude Van Damme engages in gory clandestine street fights that are staged for the amusement of bejeweled Eurotrash. The mighty Mr. Van Damme, whose specialty is a vicious flying kick to the kidneys, can perform well under these circumstances (though perhaps not any others). But the film still exaggerates his feats with fancy editing and overloads its soundtrack with gasps, slaps and other pumped-up sounds of battle. Using tactics like these, Woody Allen could become an action hero, too.

title: D.M.B.&B. Buying Agency To Expand in Health Care
description: MEDICUS INTERCOM INTERNATIONAL, the health-care agency subsidiary of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, plans to announce today that it has acquired the Sutton Healthcare Group.

title: Review/Film; Sally Field, Fervently
description: "Not Without My Daughter," a title that sounds like a line from a traveling salesman joke, is the first major clinker of the year. It's a seriously intended movie that goes grossly comic when it means to be most solemn. It's a tale of mother love and freedom that is both mean and narrow.

title: Pennyweight
description: Many people do not like pennies. They wouldn't dream of bending down to pick one up; and if the bill is, say, $6.96 they hand over $7 and say "Forget it." Come Feb. 3, these people will have to change their tune.

title: Avarice and Audacity in Texas
description: In April 1945, American troops occupying a German town called Quedlinburg were ordered to guard a mine shaft containing an extraordinary trove of medieval artworks and manuscripts. They were the treasury of a local church, and had been placed there for safekeeping.

title: Rev. Gerard Mahoney, 57, Dies; Leader at St. John's and Niagara
description: The Rev. Gerard M. Mahoney, former chairman of St. John's University and former president of Niagara University, died on Wednesday at the Vincentian Seminary in Princeton, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: Patriotism Has Price: 99.9 Cents A Gallon
description: The pumps at the B & C Quick Stop boast what its owner says is the lowest gasoline price in the nation: 99.9 cents for a gallon of unleaded regular.

title: Part of Boeing Pact Canceled
description: The Air Force said today that it had canceled parts of a $1 billion contract with the Boeing Company for development of a new air defense network for Saudi Arabia.

title: The Castoff Children: Who's to Give Them Love?
description: At Tuesday morning breakfast, Bogdan Stoian, a 16-year-old resident of the home for severely disabled children in this hamlet near Bucharest, grinned broadly as he peered up from his new wheelchair.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday described the Defense Department's final approval of rules for reporters who would accompany troops if combat occurred in the Persian Gulf. It noted that major newspapers and television networks had complained that the rules were too restrictive, amounting to an attempt at censorship.

title: Support the President
description: The message was clear all along. It did not take a meeting between the Secretary of State and the Foreign Minister of Iraq to deliver it.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF:  Saudi Contributions in Crisis Are Called Generous; Dhahran Prepares for War
description: With war possible in the near future, residents of this drab coastal town seem more resigned than frightened.

title: 6 Los Angeles Officers Charged in Drug Cases
description: A grand jury today indicted six members of a police narcotics unit in connection with a series of incidents of brutality, theft and cover-ups in the latest of several cases of police misconduct in Los Angeles.

title: Palmer Eyes Comeback
description: Jim Palmer, who won 268 games for the Baltimore Orioles and was inducted into the Hall of Fame last summer, is mounting a comeback at age 45, and yesterday he threw to hitters for the first time since he retired in 1984.

title: For Children
description: 'Charles Dickens: His Life and Work' New York Public Library Berg Exhibition Room Fifth Avenue and 42d Street (212) 869-8089 Recommended ages: 9 and up Through April 13

title: JAPAN EASES RULE ON KOREAN ALIENS
description: Japan and South Korea signed an agreement here today to end the routine fingerprinting of Japan's ethnic Korean minority, a practice that has been one of the main obstacles to better relations between the two countries.

title: Judge's Overruling of Crack Law Brings Turmoil
description: A Minnesota judge's ruling that an anti-crack law discriminates against blacks has set off alarms among prosecutors and politicians.

title: Elsie Frum, Johnstown Flood Survivor, 108
description: Elsie Frum, a survivor of the Johnstown flood of 1889, died in her sleep early Wednesday. She was 108 years old.

title: Fiat Plans 65,000 Weeklong Layoffs
description: Fiat S.p.A. said it planned to lay off 65,000 workers for a week next month because of the sluggish demand for automobiles. Paolo Gasca, the head of industrial relations for the company, said the temporary reduction that will begin on Feb. 11 will cut back production by 40,000 cars.

title: Merrill Lynch Sells Notes Due in 1993
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday priced $125 million in senior notes through its own securities firm.

title: Rubbermaid Names Next Chief Executive
description: Rubbermaid Inc. made its succession plans official yesterday, announcing that Walter W. Williams, 56 years old, would be named chairman and chief executive on May 1. He will succeed Stanley C. Gault, who is retiring at age 65, amid praise for his decade-long tenure.

title: Rochester Telephone In Deal With Centel
description: Two large independent telephone companies signed an agreement yesterday to exchange operations in a deal involving cash and stock.

title: Prosecutors of Noriega Set to Defend U.S. Action
description: Federal prosecutors in the case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega have been subpoenaed to testify Friday at a hearing to determine if drug trafficking charges against the general should be dropped because the Government taped his telephone calls.

title: Fitting 'Baby' For New Braces, And Quite a Bite
description: If circumstances were a bit different, it would have been routine orthodontia: braces to correct an underbite. Overbites, cross bites, underbites, Dr. Myron Belkin has straightened them all out in 29 years as an orthodontist. But this? "This I'm not very optimistic about."

title: Russell Markert Memorial
description: A memorial service for Russell E. Markert, the founder, director and choreographer of the Rockettes of Radio City Music Hall, is to be held at 4 P.M. Sunday at the Michael Paul Recital Hall of the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street. The Rockette Alumnae Association will sponsor the service for Mr. Markert, who died Dec. 1 at the age of 91.

title: McKids Is Closing
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said that sales at its McKids children's clothing stores had not produced an adequate return and that it would close the 47 stores. The first McKids stores opened in Illinois in August 1988, and the chain was expanded to 14 other states. While the free-standing stores will be shut, Sears said it would continue selling the McKids brand of clothing and footwear in its 863 retail stores and through its catalogues. Some of the 600 McKids employees will lose their jobs, while others may be offered positions elsewhere in Sears.

title: Daniel B. Dodson, 72, Retired Professor, Dies
description: Daniel B. Dodson, professor emeritus at Columbia University, died on Sunday at his home in Sollies-Ville, France. He was 72 years old.

title: Saatchi Proposes Recapitalization
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the ailing advertising giant, proposed a recapitalization plan today that would eliminate a threat to its survival and would provide the company with new funds and equity.

title: Review/Dance; Peter Pucci Opens Festival At the Joyce
description: Altogether Different, this year's modern-dance sampler at the Joyce Theater, is not a particularly revealing title. But like Peter Pucci, who opened the three-week festival on Tuesday, each of the participating choreographers does have a distinctive -- "different" -- voice.

title: S.E.C. Makes Rule Shift on Executives' Stock Reporting
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to change the requirements for top corporate officers to report their transactions in their own company's stock. The changes make clear which executives must report, and it is hoped they will get more corporations to comply with the rules.

title: New Chairman at CSX
description: John W. Snow, president and chief executive of the CSX Corporation, was elected to the additional position of chairman of the railroad company, the board announced on Wednesday. Mr. Snow will assume the position on Feb. 1, replacing Hays T. Watkins. Mr. Watkins, who is about to reach the company's mandatory retirement age of 65, was elected chairman emeritus.

title: President Nominates Cardiologist to Lead Institutes of Health
description: President Bush says he will nominate Dr. Bernadine P. Healy, a cardiologist, as director of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Brooklyn Youth Slain Over Leather Jacket
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was fatally shot by another youth who tried to rob him of his leather jacket last night on a street in the Bushwick section, the police said.

title: Legislators Take Sides for Combat Or for Reliance on the Sanctions
description: Congress today began debating the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf, arguing whether an early attack on Iraq or continued reliance on economic sanctions was more likely to force Iraq out of Kuwait.

title: Teri Garr Promoting New Line of Underwear
description: Teri Garr is starring in yet another Fruit of the Loom ad, this time for the introduction of the Feminie Style line of underwear.

title: Foreign Envoys Leave Baghdad As Fear Grows
description: American, European and several other foreign governments began evacuating their remaining diplomatic personnel here today as many Iraqis openly expressed their fear that war is coming.

title: Inquiry on Dinkins Stock Raises Possibility He Lied Under Oath
description: An independent city investigation into a stock transaction by Mayor David N. Dinkins concluded that there was troubling circumstantial evidence that the Mayor might have lied under oath, but it found insufficient proof to warrant prosecution.

title: Bronx Didn't Hamper 'Bonfire' (Just Hates It)
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Scrimping and Saving To Raise Money for Neediest
description: From fourth-grade classrooms to executive offices in midtown Manhattan, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has inspired people to scrimp, save and scavenge to raise money for the sick and the poor.

title: Where Cuban Crisis Differs From Today's
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of a New York City Ballet performance misidentified the dancer in the foreground. He was Damian Woetzel.

title: U.S. Presses Europeans To Ease Curbs on Meat
description: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, today escalated a trade conflict with the European Community over its ban on practically all imports of American meat -- and at the same time suggested a resolution may be in the offing.

title: Baker and Saudi King Talk About Timing of an Assault
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia today to discuss the timing of an attack on Iraqi forces in Kuwait if they have not withdrawn from that country by the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline, senior Administration officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Fred Fortess, a retired professor who was an authority on fabrics, misidentified a surviving daughter. She is June Gerber of Manhattan.

title: In de Klerk's Family, Reports of Interracial Romance
description: Rumors that the younger son of President F. W. de Klerk has fallen in love with the daughter of a mixed-race Cape politician took on credence today when a respected Afrikaans-language newspaper reported that they were engaged to be married.

title: Anthony M. Rey, 74, Executive Who Led Atlantic City Hotel
description: Anthony M. Rey, a retired hotel executive who was president of the Resorts International Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City when legalized gambling began in New Jersey in 1978, died on Wednesday at the Linwood Convalescent Center in Linwood, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Ventnor, N.J.

title: Once Balloon Lovers, Children Spurn Them
description: It is a familiar but exhilarating sight: Thousands of brightly colored helium balloons billowing into the air, and becoming tiny points against the sky before they disappear.

title: Antiwar Effort Buds Quickly, Nurtured by Activism of 60's
description: Before a shot has been fired between allied forces and Iraq, an antiwar movement has been building quietly in the United States since late October, drawing on the legacy of Vietnam War peace activists.

title: The Countdown in One Kitchen
description: MARCO TOMASSI checked his watch. Not many minutes left. The madness was near.

title: Chemical Concern In Spain Sells Unit
description: Spain's largest chemical company, Ercros S.A., sold its petrochemical unit to Luxembourg investors. Ercros did not disclose the price in the sale of its Ertoil S.A. unit to General Mediterranean Holding, but people familiar with the sale estimated the transaction brought Ercros about $500 million.

title: At the Movies
description: 'Home Alone'

title: New York Dismisses Official Who Attacked Bridge Cuts
description: New York City's Deputy Commissioner for Bridges, who spoke out publicly against cutbacks in bridge maintenance, warning that they would endanger public safety, was dismissed last night.

title: Federal Reserve Acts Warily In Combating This Recession
description: Facing a recession and a banking crisis, the Federal Reserve's top policy makers are cutting interest rates almost every week as they seek to reawaken the economy. But they are taking each step reluctantly -- not convinced that the recession will turn out to be severe or that many banks will fail.

title: Review/Opera; A Substitute As Elisabetta In 'Roberto Devereux'
description: Here is the "glass is half full" report of Wednesday evening's performance of "Roberto Devereux" at Carnegie Hall: the event took place and no one fell off the stage. Furthermore, the soprano who bravely substituted at a late hour in the leading female role did nothing to seriously disrupt the progress of her career. A "half empty" view of the Opera Orchestra of New York's concert version of Donizetti's drama would have to point out, however, that this remarkable work received a coarse reading in which his bel canto style was mostly notable for its absence.

title: Chrysler Offers Certificates Backed by Loans on Vehicles
description: The Chrysler Corporation is offering $1.48 billion in certificates backed by automobile and light-truck loans through its U.S. Auto Receivables Trust 1991-A.

title: In Rare Move, Big Donors Push Energy Efficiency
description: In a rare collaborative undertaking, three of the country's leading philanthropies are establishing an Energy Foundation to promote energy efficiency and greater reliance on renewable sources like wind and solar power.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: New York Sues to Get Escrow Money
description: Nearly $1 billion is sitting in escrow accounts held by title insurance companies in New York City, municipal officials say, and some of it -- perhaps tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars -- is owed to the city.

title: Hall of Fame Panel Moves to Keep Pete Rose Out
description: A special committee of baseball's Hall of Fame effectively barred Pete Rose from election yesterday by recommending a change in the admission rules to exclude any person banned from baseball.

title: Subway Platform, 2 Days Later: Cries for a Sister's Spirit
description: Paul Cheng, his eyes red with exhaustion and grief, stood over the tracks of the West 96th Street subway stop in Manhattan and spoke to the darkness.

title: Paderewski's Body Must Go to Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Cuban Crisis Differs From Today's; Kennedy Version
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AMENDMENT CONFERENCE ON PARTIAL TEST BAN TREATY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Steve Clark Guitarist, 30
description: Steve Clark, the 30-year-old guitarist for the heavy-metal rock group Def Leppard, was found dead on Tuesday at his home here, the police said.

title: F.C.C. Plan To Set Up 2-Way TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed making a special broadcast frequency available for ordering goods and services through television sets.

title: At End of Term, Ohio's Governor Commutes Death Sentences for 8
description: Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, a staunch opponent of capital punishment who leaves office Monday, today commuted to life imprisonment the death sentences of eight prisoners, including all four women awaiting execution.

title: Dow Rises 28.46 Points in Thin Trading
description: After six declines in a row, buyers moved into the market yesterday, driving stock prices higher for the first time this year.

title: Chinese Leaders Warn of Electronic Spying
description: China's leadership has begun a new effort to tighten secrecy after uncovering attempts by foreign countries to use electronic equipment to eavesdrop on high-level conversations, Chinese officials say.

title: Yale Names A Dean For Drama
description: The artistic director of the Center Stage in Baltimore, Stan Wojewodski Jr., has been named dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: Saudi Contributions in Crisis Are Called Generous
description: Saudi Arabia has spent every penny it earned from windfall profits from oil sales last year and has committed double that amount to defend itself from Iraq and support those who have come to its aid, diplomats and Saudi officials say.

title: GORBACHEV WARNS THE LITHUANIANS TO HALT DEFIANCE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called on Lithuania today to halt its defiance of Soviet authority immediately, and warned that "people are demanding" the introduction of direct Kremlin rule of the breakaway republic.

title: Gibbs Thrives On Big Games
description: The Redskins vs. the 49ers. Another big game for Joe Gibbs.

title: Mercer Put on Gloves To Get Out of the Cold
description: Ray Mercer, who began fighting professionally in 1989, is 29 years old. By boxing standards, that marks him as a late starter.

title: SERB CHIEF WARNS OF LAND DEMANDS
description: At a meeting of leaders of Yugoslavia's republics, the president of Serbia officially warned today that if Yugoslavia became a confederation of independent states, Serbia would demand territory from neighboring republics to bring all of the country's 8.5 million Serbs into a single state, a federal official said.

title: Hall of Fame List
description: There are six members of the Pittsburgh Steelers' four-time Super Bowl champions of the 1970's enshrined already, and yesterday two more teammates, L. C. Greenwood and Lynn Swann, were on the list of 15 finalists announced as eligible to be voted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Jan. 26.

title: Market Place; Investors Loyal To Buyout Firm
description: SOME institutional investors, it seems, are still willing to take the risks of leveraged buyouts. Forstmann Little & Company, a pioneer in the field, said yesterday that it had raised another $1.4 billion, primarily from large private pension funds.

title: Key Rates
U S Sprint Pares Telemarketing Jobs
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company laid off 280 telemarketing employees, the nation's No. 3 long-distance telephone company said. The employees, who were laid off on Wednesday, were part of Sprint's consumer services group, which had 4,000 workers when it was formed in August to increase sales to residential and small-business customers.

title: Ada Moore Is Dead; Singer and Actress, 64
description: Ada Moore, a singer and actress who performed on Broadway and in jazz clubs across the nation, died at Long Island College Hospital on Sunday. She was 64 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: How to Trade Lawyer Futures as a Commodity; The Other Unemployed
description: To the Editor:

title: New Chairman Hired At Jordan Marsh Chain
description: Jordan Marsh, battered by the New England recession, announced yesterday that it had hired a new chairman and chief executive with a turnaround background.

title: Weicker and the Assembly: New Lines of Power
description: When Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. stepped into the House chamber on Wednesday to deliver his State of the State speech, not a single member of his own party was there to gaze up at the rostrum and applaud on cue. Mr. Weicker, representing the independent Connecticut Party, stood alone at last against the sea of Democrats and Republicans and the two-party system that he railed against in last year's election.

title: Numerical Palindrome
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: A new place on the Upper East Side restores the feeding frenzy of the 1980's with hearty food.

title: Review/Film; Living in a Violent World
description: The story behind "Rodrigo D: No Future" is dramatic, disturbing and true. In 1988, Victor Manuel Gaviria, a Colombian poet and short-film maker, directed this fictional feature based on the violent lives of young people in the drug- and crime-filled city of Medellin. Of the nine nonprofessional actors he cast in major roles, six are now dead, obscure victims of the small-time crime that ruled their lives.

title: Critical Talk Banned; Trade Talk Prevails
description: Any Knick who in the future publicly criticizes a teammate will be fined.

title: Kickers Beware: Winds in Giants Stadium Could Be Tricky
description: For the kickers, Giants Stadium will be no paradise on Sunday when the Giants play the Chicago Bears in a second-round playoff game. The Giants' kickers, Sean Landeta and Matt Bahr, are resigned to winter winds blowing around this big beacon in the wetlands of north Jersey.

title: How to Trade Lawyer Futures as a Commodity
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Reported Likely to Send Official to Visit Israel Soon
description: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger will travel to Israel soon to discuss with its leaders the Persian Gulf crisis, officials said today.

title: Bills' Coach Enjoys Winter Wonderland
description: The weather turned nice today. It snowed.

title: Review/Art; Barbara Kruger's Large-Scale Self-Expression
description: For several years now, Barbara Kruger has been marking time; riding on her reputation as one of the best artists of the 1980's without actually doing much that is new. Her staunchly feminist art has set an example for many younger artists, while the Kruger graphic look has enjoyed a spreading influence. Echoes of the artist's distinctive splicings of black-and-white photographs and red or red-on-white typeface can be found in magazine layouts, subway posters and exhibition catalogues (the New Museum of Contemporary Art's current "Rhetorical Image" catalogue, for example), as well as in other art.

title: It's Not Over
description: "Saddam says that he will win," President Hosni Mubarak said. "The man is living in another world."

title: Trammell Crow Plans Revamping
description: The partners of the Trammell Crow Company, the nation's largest commercial real estate developer, voted yesterday to abandon the company's partnership structure and reduce its size sharply.

title: Welfare Theft Uncovered In Newark
description: The Essex County Prosecutor said today that furniture store owners and Welfare Department workers in the Newark area cheated welfare recipients of $10 million to $20 million over the last four years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 15 about the possibility of extended tours of duty for reservists and National Guard members in the Persian Gulf crisis described their civilian re-employment rights incompletely. Under Federal law, those called to active duty are guaranteed re-employment at their previous pay level and stature; their civilian jobs would not be in jeopardy. But no such protection exists for self- employed people or temporary workers called to active duty.

title: Revenue Bonds By Pennsylvania
description: The Pennsylvania Higher Educational Facilities Authority is offering $60 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.40 percent for an issue due in 2017, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Pop/Jazz; Paquito D'Rivera Heads Up 3 Village Gate Weekends
description: On May 6, 1980, Paquito D'Rivera defected from Cuba to the United States, taking with him his saxophones and clarinets. Ten years later, Mr. D'Rivera, no longer a media curiosity, has settled into his role as a cross-cultural ambassador, playing -- and selling -- a hybrid music that moves from be-bop to salsa to Mozart. When Mr. D'Rivera plays, he exudes a generosity that manages to combine the details of a fine art and the crowd-pleasing abilities of entertainment without compromising either. And in the response of the Hispanic members of his audience, Mr. D'Rivera -- who will be performing a varied program Friday and Saturday nights this month at the Village Gate -- is clearly a symbol of an immigrant made good.

title: Iraq's Untenable Argument
description: If the facts are against you, pound the law; if the law is against you, pound the table. In his extraordinary plea before the bar of world opinion, Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, adroitly embraced this old chestnut of lawyers' advice.
