He ignored Saddam Hussein's rape of Kuwait in his news conference after his empty Geneva meeting with Secretary of State Baker. The proposition he pounded instead was that "what happened on the 2d of August" arose from Iraq's compassionate concern for the Palestinian cause.

title: Steel Output Is Off by 1.8%
description: World crude steel production fell by 1.8 percent, to 769.4 million tons, in 1990, mainly because of reduced output in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today.

title: Haiti's Victors Working to Soothe Fears
description: Three days after a failed coup attempt set off a spree of looting and vengeful attacks that left at least 70 dead, supporters of Haiti's President-elect, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, have begun working to calm the fears of those who warned that the leftist priest's election last month would unleash a wave of revenge.

title: Chief Executive Resigns At Saatchi's AC&R Unit
description: Stephen Rose is retiring as chief executive of AC&R Advertising, New York. He will be succeeded by Alvin Chereskin, the vice chairman.

title: People
description: * Simon Bowden has joined McCabe & Co., New York, as executive vice president and director of creative services. * Ann Kalman was promoted to senior vice president, director of media and marketing services at Della Femina McNamee, Los Angeles. * Alan Pilkington has been named managing director at DDB Needham, Chicago. * Margaret Noon was appointed vice president at Sudler & Hennessey, New York.

title: Restaurants
description: A new place on the Upper East Side restores the feeding frenzy of the 1980's with hearty food.

title: TV Weekend; The N.A.A.C.P. Awards, With Some Hard Edges
description: One thing prime-time hardly needs is another awards show, but then the "N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards" is not just another awards show. The annual event has been around for 23 years and, in delayed tape broadcasts, has been televised for a good many of those years in out-of-the-way time slots. Tonight the awards can be seen on NBC at the choice hour of 9:30. The ceremonies were recorded on Dec. 1 in Los Angeles.

title: Bush Writes to College Papers In Appeal for Support on Gulf
description: In a letter distributed to college newspapers across the nation, President Bush has appealed for support for a possible war in the Persian Gulf, saying he might have to use force "to stand up for human life."

title: Europeans Are Struggling to Keep Their Diplomatic Initiative Alive
description: In an atmosphere of deepening gloom, European Community governments led by France struggled today to keep alive their efforts to avoid a war in the Persian Gulf despite virtually no evidence that Iraq is interested in dealing with them.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Margaret Whiting, Rainbow and Stars, 30 Rockefeller Plaza on the 65th floor, (212) 632-5000. Margaret Whiting, the veteran singer who popularized the 1940's standards "Moonlight in Vermont" and "It Might as Well Be Spring," still has a sensual trumpet of a voice and a big-hearted sense of humor. In her new act, she scans the history of Capitol Records, sings powerful renditions of "Little Girl Blue" and "Last Night When We Were Young" and pokes fun at herself in a mock television advertisement for her own golden oldies. Shows are to be at 9 and 11:15 P.M. today and tomorrow. There is a $35 cover charge and no minimum. Music of Gambia

title: Rose Continues to Arouse Passions
description: Is baseball the national pastime or the national passion or both?

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALEC BALDWIN, the actor, recently got a zoning clearance to put a second story on his house in Amagansett, L.I. Mr. Baldwin bought the 135-year-old house, a former whaling-captain's cottage, two years ago for $390,000.

title: Ford Maintains Dividend, But May Cut Future Payouts
description: The Ford Motor Company did not cut its dividend this time, but a top company official said it might do so in the future. Amid predictions that it might trim its quarterly payout, the company today declared the regular dividend of 75 cents a share for the first quarter of 1991.

title: Eight Vehicles Strike Man, But Only One Driver Stops
description: Eight vehicles ran over and fatally injured a pedestrian on a busy street Tuesday night, and the police say only one driver stopped.

title: BOLIVIAN IS GUILTY ON DRUG CHARGES
description: A former colonel once known as Bolivia's "Minister of Cocaine" has been convicted by a Federal jury here of conspiring to smuggle the drug into the United States.

title: Witnesses For The Positive, Promising Young Black Men Adorn A Harvard Calendar.
description: Troy Chapman read all about them: Some were convicted of beating up a jogger in Central Park. Another was accused, falsely as it turns out, of murdering a pregnant woman in Boston. It was high time, Mr. Chapman concluded, to present a different portrait of young black men like himself. For that he turned to his colleagues at Harvard Law School.

title: Paine Webber Expects A Loss of $95 Million
description: Yet another Wall Street firm gave out some grim numbers yesterday. The Paine Webber Group Inc. announced that it would have a quarterly after-tax loss of about $95 million because of the cost of hundreds of dismissals as well as for new reserves against risky investments.

title: INSIDE
description: 2-Way TV Is Aim Of F.C.C. Plan Television viewers will be able to use their sets to order goods and services under a proposal by the Federal Communications Commission. A special broadcast frequency would enable viewers to gain access to a diverse menu of home-shopping and information services, as well as see regular television programs. Page D1. AIDS Survey Abandoned A lack of cooperation by people at high risk of developig AIDS has scuttled plans for a nationwide household survey to assess the prevalence of HIV virus infection. Page A14. Rohatyn Decides to Stay Felix G. Rohatyn said he would not resign his post as head of New York City's fiscal watchdog agency, at least not for now. Page B3. Echoes of a Sister On the subway platform where his sister Grace died in a mugging, Paul Cheng cried out her name, calling on her spirit to return. Page B1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13

title: Fire Officials Investigating Delay on Fatal Queens Fire
description: The New York City Fire Department said last night that it was investigating why the pumper truck that was supposed to be the first at the scene of a fatal Queens fire on Monday arrived late, forcing another truck to switch hydrants in the crucial opening minutes of fire-fighting.

title: A Tragic Convergence
description: Many Americans and Arabs, as well as Americans of Arab origin, have watched in silence and with almost inexpressible feelings of apprehension the slide into an appalling and horrendously costly war. The main reason for our silence is that the current discussion extends no further than the choosing of sides. The tragic nature of what is unfolding -- a collision between the anachronistic but still powerful ideologies of western imperialism and Arab nationalism -- has gotten little attention.

title: Eligibility for Division III Is Redefined
description: On the final day of their annual meeting, delegates to the 85th National Collegiate Athletic Association convention approved a measure today that would prevent members of the association's two most powerful divisions from participating in the Division III football playoffs.

title: Going for Broke: Bradshaw Pouring It On in U.S. International's Last Season
description: One day earlier this week, only days after he had scored 72 points to break Pete Maravich's 21-year-old Division I single-game scoring record, Kevin Bradshaw sat quietly in a hotel lobby listening to his coach trying to find ways to pay for the rest of the season.

title: Chiat/Day Quits CNBC
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo, New York, said it had resigned the $3 million account of CNBC, a financial news cable television channel based in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Chip Industry Pioneer to Retire
description: Charles E. Sporck, a founding father of Silicon Valley, will retire in May as president and chief executive of the National Semiconductor Corporation, ending a career that reflected both the great triumphs and the recent problems of the American semiconductor industry.

title: Accounts
description: * Sea Ray Boats Inc., Knoxville, Tenn., a subsidiary of Brunswick Corp., Skokie, Ill., to the Richards Group, Dallas, with a budget of about $2.5 million. * The North Face, Berkeley, Calif., an outdoor equipment subsidiary of Odyssey International Pointe Ltd., Hong Kong, to Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley Advertising, San Francisco, with a budget of $2 million. * Restaurant Associates, New York, a unit of Kyotaru Co. Ltd., Tokyo, to Baron & Zaretsky, New York with billings of $2 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Budget Rent a Car, a unit of Beech Holding Corp., Chicago, promoted William N. Plamondon to executive vice president and general manager of its North American operations. Gannett News Service, a division of Gannett Co., Arlington, Va., named Calvin Stovall senior managing editor. National Council on Compensation Insurance, Boca Raton, Fla., appointed Chapin Clark senior vice president of rates and external affairs. New York State Electric and Gas, Binghamton, N.Y., named James A. Carrigg president, succeeding Allen E. Kintigh, who is retiring. Ontologic Inc., Burlington, Mass., a supplier of data base products, appointed Frank Ingari president and chief executive. PLM International Inc., San Francisco, appointed Dennis C. Kreuser vice president and controller of its subsidiary PLM Investment Management Inc. Procter & Gamble Co., Cincinnati, appointed Gary T. Martin senior vice president, succeeding David S. Swanson, who is retiring. Twin Disc Inc., Racine, Wis., a manufacturer of industrial clutches, named Michael Joyce to the newly created position of president of North American operations.

title: Economic Scene; Mideast Standoff's Effect on Business
description: THE markets reacted with alarm to what President Bush called a "total stiff-arm" by Iraq at the Geneva talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. And it looks as though the markets and business decision-makers will have to live with extreme uncertainty on war or peace, not just for a few days but possibly for weeks or months.

title: Sand? Birds? Rock? Clubs for All Tastes
description: THE crisis in the Persian Gulf has brought an unexpected bonanza to one group in the New York area: the International Sand Collectors Society. As the television cameras pan over the Saudi horizon, its members feast on images of the stuff that most people would regard as a paler, more organized form of dirt.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: So Thoughtful

title: After Apology, Ads Resume on Hispanic Station
description: Goya Foods has resumed advertising on a station of the nation's largest Spanish-language television network after a Cuban-American commentator apologized on the air for his remarks about Puerto Rican women. The network has also agreed to produce a program to discuss issues affecting Puerto Ricans.

title: Pre-Theater Frenzy of Dining
description: YOU see them most evenings about 6 P.M., roving packs of theatergoers checking out restaurant awnings, mulling over menus, pressing their noses to frosty windows. Time is critical in this pursuit, yet they are determined to find that perfect little spot with the magical ambiance, congenial servers and stellar food. All, of course, at bargain prices.

title: Israel Close to War Footing
description: Israeli officials told citizens that a conflict appeared likely and that they should begin preparing for a possible Iraqi attack. Page A11.

title: Overseers Silence Bridgeport's Talk of Bankruptcy
description: When Mayor Mary C. Moran said this week that she was considering declaring Bridgeport bankrupt, something that has never been done by a city its size, state officials were stunned, credit markets were shaken and residents were talking about it everywhere.

title: A.T.&T. Plan For Rates Is Rejected
description: The Federal Communications Commission today rejected A.T.& T.'s proposal to include promotional discounts in its overall rate structure. The plan would have allowed the company to raise other charges.

title: Canseco Pays Fees
description: Jose Canseco, threatened with foreclosure on his two luxury homes in a Florida development, won't lose them after all.

title: Surgeon General Calls Potent Wine a Threat
description: Surgeon General Antonia Novello said Wednesday that consumers, particularly teen-agers, were being endangered by a high-alcohol drink that looks like a mild wine cooler but is far more potent.

title: Israel Advises Citizens to Prepare for Iraqi Attack
description: Israel moved palpably closer to a war footing today as the Defense Ministry and other officials alerted citizens that conflict in the Persian Gulf now appeared likely, and that they should begin preparing for a possible Iraqi attack.

title: Auctions
description: Baseball memorabilia -- one of the hottest categories of collecting today -- are to be auctioned at 7 P.M. next Friday by Guernsey's at the Puck Building in Manhattan. Other offbeat collectibles in the weekend sale include meerschaum pipes, pre-Castro Cuban cigars, Salvador Dali plates, Greta Garbo letters, fish decoys, weapons, model trains, ships and circus wagons, and a punctured 1787 wine bottle that may have belonged to Thomas Jefferson. The auction continues from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. next Saturday and Sunday.

title: H. W. Geiger, 84, Dies; Made Expedition Gear
description: Howard W. Geiger, a manufacturer of survival and expedition gear, died on Wednesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Arkansas Overruns League-Rival Texas
description: Arlyn Bowers, the shortest player on the court, and the reserve Ron Huery scored in double figures in the second half and Oliver Miller made his first nine shots as second-ranked Arkansas defeated Texas, 101-89, tonight.

title: The Cuomo Eloquence, Without Money
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo said the right things in his State of the State address Wednesday and, being Mario Cuomo, said them so entertainingly and eloquently that it was tempting just to enjoy the performance. New York's battered economy won't permit that, though. The fact is that little of what Governor Cuomo had to say was comforting, for the very reason he cited: "We don't have any money."

title: Marcoses' Silver Sets Record At Auction
description: A hoard of English silver acquired by Imelda and Ferdinand E. Marcos when he was President of the Philippines was auctioned yesterday at Christie's for a total of $4.9 million, a record for a sale of silver.

title: Ex-Aide Says Her Memo to Keating Used 'Bit of Hyperbole' on Regulators
description: A former lobbyist for Charles H. Keating Jr. testified today that she had used "a bit of hyperbole" to get his attention when she wrote in a memorandum that his efforts to pressure Federal regulators were working.

title: Books of The Times; Against Those 'Old Male Celibates'
description: Eunuchs for the Kingdom of Heaven Women, Sexuality and the Catholic Church By Uta Ranke-Heinemann 360 pages. Doubleday. $21.95.

title: Official Who Fought Bridge Cuts Loses Job
description: New York City's Deputy Commissioner for Bridges, who spoke out publicly against cuts in bridge maintenance, was dismissed last night by Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio.

title: Nycor Plans Zenith Fight
description: Nycor Inc., which owns 8.2 percent of the loss-plagued Zenith Electronics Corporation, said today that it would mount a proxy challenge to oust the company's management.

title: War and Peace: A Sampling From the Debate on Capitol Hill
description: Senator George J. Mitchell Democrat of Maine

title: A Shrine Is Saved From Rose
description: Baseball socked it to Pete Rose again yesterday, and this is all to the good, naturally. A special panel was convened by the Hall of Fame to decide whether Rose should be on the ballot next year, when he becomes eligible for the first time. But the committee decided to recommend a change of rules to its rubber-stamp board of directors, and determined that anyone who is on the "permanently ineligible list" from baseball, as Rose is, cannot be on the ballot.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Federal Farm Credit Bank Funding Corp announced that because of the limited need of the farm credit system banks and its borrowers for medium- and long-term financing, it will not be offering a term issue for Jan. 22 delivery. Terms for the next offering will be made on Jan. 17. * Iowa is offering $75 million in 5 percent tax and revenue anticipation notes due June 28 at a price of about 100.43, to yield 4.45 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The tax-exempt issue is supported by a letter of credit from the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and rated MIG-1 by Moody's and SP-1+ by S.&P.

title: Reservist Headed for the Gulf Challenges Homosexual Ban
description: Just days before her scheduled deployment to the Persian Gulf, an Army reservist declared in a letter to her post commander on Wednesday: "I am an open lesbian and I wish to be deployed as such with my unit."

title: McVicker Hunt Is Deat at 84; Expert on Young
description: Dr. J. McVicker Hunt, a psychologist whose research in the early development of children was a major influence in inaugurating Project Head Start in the 1960's, died Wednesday at the Clark-Lindsey retirement community in Urbana, Ill. He was 84 years old and had lived in Urbana since 1951.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Kings Held to 59 Points Sacramento scored 59 points last night, the second-lowest total since the 24-second clock was instituted for the 1954-55 season as Charlotte defeated the Kings, 101-59. The Milwaukee Hawks set the league record in a 62-57 loss to Boston on Feb. 27, 1955 at Providence. The Kings' previous franchise low of 69 points was set by the Cincinnati Royals against Detroit on Jan. 10, 1959. Sacramento also set a franchise low for the first half with 27 points. It was the fourth straight loss for the Kings and their 12th consecutive defeat on the road where they are 1-16. (AP) Bullets 122, Clippers 110: Bernard King scored 45 points and Harvey Grant a career-high 34 for Washington. King took over the league scoring lead with his seventh 40-plus game of the season. Benoit Benjamin had 24 points and 19 rebounds for Los Angeles, which has lost 13 of 15 games and 10 of 11 on the road. The Clippers have lost 10 of their last 11 games against the Bullets and have won only once at the Capital Centre since the 1979-80 season. King, who improved his average to 31 points, made 18 of 30 shots and was 7 of 9 free throws. (AP) TENNIS Krickstein Defeated in Sydney Fabrice Santoro, an 18-year-old Frenchman with a two-handed forehand, overpowered sixth-seeded Aaron Krickstein of the United States, 7-5, 1-6, 6-3, yesterday in the third round of the New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia. Third-seeded Guy Forget of France also advanced to the quarterfinals by beating an Australian, Todd Woodbridge, 6-1, 6-0. Forget is the only seeded male player to have made the quarterfinals. In women's play, second-seeded Aranxta Sanchez Vicario of Spain, fourth-seeded Zina Garrison of Houston and seventh-seeded Barbara Paulus of Austria advanced to the quarterfinals. Sanchez Vicario beat Carrie Cunningham of Livonia, Mich., 6-1, 6-1. Garrison defeated Rosalyn Fairbank-Nideffer of Escondido, Calif., 6-3, 6-3. Paulus downed Kristin Godridge of Australia, 6-1, 6-1. Sixth-seeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia advanced when ninth-seeded Judith Wiesner of Austria sprained her right ankle during their match. (AP) Sanchez Struggles to Advance: Top-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain struggled past a qualifier, Malivai Washington of Swartz Creek, Mich., yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the New Zealand Open in Auckland. Sanchez beat Washington, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6, to earn a meeting with a Frenchman, Jean-Philippe Fleurian, who beat Eric Jelen of Germany, 6-3, 6-1. In other second-round matches, fifth-seeded Luiz Mattar of Brazil defeated Jaime Ygaza of Peru, 6-2, 6-2, and Christian Bergstrom of Sweden beat Chuck Adams of Pacific Palisades, Calif., 6-3, 4-6, 7-6. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins Top Flames Kevin Stevens assisted on three of Pittsburgh's four first-period goals and the goaltender, Tom Barrasso, won for the 10th time in 11 games as Pittsburgh defeated Calgary, 5-1, last night. Brian MacLellan scored a power-play goal with 5 minutes 21 seconds remaining. The Penguins scored on three of their first five shots against Rick Wamsley and won for the 12th time in 16 games. (AP) Bruins 5, Nordiques 3: Dave Christian and Craig Janney each scored twice to power Boston over Quebec, extending the Nordiques' drought at Boston Garden to 0-12-2. (AP) GOLF Sutton Shares Tucson Lead Hal Sutton hit a 166-yard, 6-iron shot and saw the ball disappear into the hole at Tucson National. He thought he had an eagle and the first-round lead in the Tucson Open. But he didn't get all of the ball all the way into the hole and had to settle for a closing birdie and a share of the top spot with Bob Tway at eight-under-par 64, one stroke ahead of the field. (AP)

title: Critic's Choice
description: Fresh from its annual marathon whirl with "The Nutcracker," the New York City Ballet has returned to the rest of its repertory. The programming this weekend offers a nicely varied sampling of ballets by George Balanchine, Jerome Robbins and the company's director, Peter Martins. And a fine selection of City Ballet's members are to be performing them. But no one quite matches Maria Calegari for sheer piquancy of presence and style.

title: Bears' Anderson Is Doing It All
description: Everyone knows Neal Anderson can run with the football. Everyone also knows Anderson can catch passes. But now Anderson seems to be a triple threat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the administration being formed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut referred incorrectly to the position designated for Henry S. Scherer Jr. It is commissioner of housing, not banking.

title: Fire Is Set at Jewish Center
description: A building that was a meeting place for a Jewish youth congregation was destroyed early today by a fire that the police said had been ignited by Molotov cocktails. The arson is being investigated as a hate crime, said Sgt. George McCormick. The synagogue next to the building was not damaged.

title: Florio Needs $800 Million To Balance Budget for '92
description: Gov. Jim Florio's administration acknowledged more bad news today: the state needs to find about $800 million in cuts to balance its budget for the fiscal year beginning in July. Administration officials are asking labor unions to bear half the burden of finding the money.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Wasserstein, a Name That Sells

title: As U.S. Officials See It, Hands of Aziz Were Tied
description: As American officials replayed and analyzed the 6 hours and 27 minutes that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met on Wednesday with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, they concluded that the Iraqi Minister had not come from Baghdad with the authority to make even the smallest concession.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A bolt of Italian brio hit London this week in the person of GIANNI VERSACE. The flamboyant Italian designer, more at home clothing celebrities like CHER and TINA TURNER, stirred the normally sedate audience at the Royal Opera with his costumes for Richard Strauss's "Capriccio" when it opened on Monday night. The sellout crowd gasped and applauded as the sumptuously clothed cast appeared.

title: Frederick Van Vechten Jr., Lawyer, 74
description: Frederick Rust Van Vechten Jr., a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Webster & Sheffield who specialized in trusts and estates, died at St. Luke's Hospital on Monday. He was 74 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: U.S. Evidence on Dinkins 'Substantial,' Officials Say
description: The United States Attorney in Brooklyn concluded six months ago that there was "substantial" evidence that Mayor David N. Dinkins and his son, David, had provided authorities with a fabricated letter documenting a disputed stock transaction, several officials familiar with the inquiry said.

title: Minimal Sentences Are Given To Bensonhurst Defendants
description: Despite the prosecution's plea for strong sentences, two defendants convicted of lesser charges in the Bensonhurst murder case were sentenced to minimal punishment yesterday.

title: Greek Clashes Over Schools Leave 4 Dead and 100 Hurt
description: The Greek Government said today that four people had been killed in a fire and more than 100 hurt overnight as high school students and leftists clashed with riot policemen during protests over educational changes.

title: I.B.M. to Complete Unit Sale in March
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it expected to complete the sale of its operations that make printers and related products to Clayton & Dubilier Inc. by the end of March. The new company, to be named Lexmark International Inc., will manufacture personal printers, typewriters and keyboards and have annual revenues of about $2 billion. The chief executive of Lexmark will be Marvin L. Mann, an executive with 32 years of experience with I.B.M.

title: End of the Southern Strategy
description: Three seemingly unconnected events may push the Bush Administration into significant policy changes on civil rights and signal an end to the Republican "Southern strategy" that began three decades ago.

title: U.S. Sued on Drugs Given in Gulf
description: A soldier stationed in Saudi Arabia sued the Government today over its plan to give unapproved drugs to soldiers without their consent.

title: Review/Television; NBC's 'Expose' Challenges '60 Minutes'
description: "Expose" is the latest attempt by NBC news to catch up to "60 Minutes," the most popular program ever to have emanated from CBS News. The new NBC offering is only half as long and, so far, about three-quarters as good. "Expose," presided over by Tom Brokaw, is the second, grittier portion of the new NBC hour, from 8 to 9 on Sundays, which begins with "Real Life With Jane Pauley." The idea seems to be that Ms. Pauley, like the opening act in burlesque, will warm up the audience with a peek at this and that, and then, at 8:30, Mr. Brokaw will bare everything.

title: Bridge
description: The Tristate Regional Championships that began on Wednesday in Rye, N.Y., were attended by a substantial contingent of players who have won major national and international titles, but all but one of them were shut out of the winners' circle during the first two days.

title: How Harsh Will the Recession Be? Most Experts Forecast a Mild One
description: There is no dearth of intrepid economists who forecast that the recession will be brief and mild, as these things go. In fact, that is the predominant view of leading analysts. But economic predictions, which are inherently risky, are particularly hazardous now, with new cracks showing in the nation's financial structure and increasing fear of war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Recovering From Alcoholism Is Tough Work; Other Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Discovery of 5 Ballots Puts Election in Doubt
description: Washington's closest legislative race on record is in doubt again because, more than two months after the voting, uncounted ballots have been found.

title: Africa Suffers From Leadership Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Links 2 More AIDS Infections to a Dentist
description: Florida health officials are awaiting confirmation from the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta that two additional patients were infected with the same strain of the AIDS virus that killed their dentist and infected a third patient.

title: Fighting Robot Tellers
description: The metal door of the bank's machine clicked open and the customer waited for the $100 she wanted. No money came out; the receipt said the amount had already been deducted from her account.

title: Inquiry Says Indian Agency Lost Track of $95 Million
description: A Federal investigation has found that the Bureau of Indian Affairs, which manages health, education and cultural programs on the nation's Indian reservations, cannot account for $95 million appropriated to the bureau in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

title: Mother Describes Wild Ambulance Ride
description: Two Emergency Medical Service attendants were suspended yesterday after a Queens woman complained that her son's trip to the hospital was first delayed by a fistfight between the two, then turned into a terrifying ordeal as the ambulance driver swerved, sped and screeched to a series of stops in an apparent attempt to injure his partner in the back.

title: Ewing Dismayed With Knicks' Brass
description: Losing is making it difficult for the Knicks to contain their frustration.

title: Robert L. Cecchi, 49, AIDS-Care Advocate
description: Robert Lee Cecchi, founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis ombudsman's program in 1984, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bicknell Lands a Job
description: Jack Bicknell, dismissed as football coach at Boston College, was hired as coach of the Barcelona Dragons of the new World League of American Football yesterday.

title: Los Angeles Orchestra Names Music Director
description: The Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra has appointed Christof Perick, a German conductor, as the group's new music director.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aegon N.V., a Dutch insurance company, said it would take over a British life insurance company, Regency Life Group P.L.C., from a subsidiary of Transamerica Life Companies, Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed. * DeSoto Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., said it had again rejected a proposal by the Sutton Holding Corp. to buy the company's stock for $5.25 a share. * Fuqua Industries, Atlanta, a maker of lawn mowers, gardening products and sporting goods, will take a pretax charge of $13 million to $16 million against 1990 earnings to set up a reserve to cover the costs of closing two plants by its Snapper Power Equipment division. * Hyundai Motor Co., the Korean auto maker, said it would add 120 new vehicle dealers to its United States distribution network in 1991. * Paradigm Technology, San Jose, Calif., a semiconductor company, said NKK Corp., Tokyo, a steel and diversified industries company, would make a major investment in Paradigm, including a 10 percent equity interest.

title: Berkeley Journal; Is the Home Of the Left Turning Moderate?
description: The last two months have been a harsh test for iconoclastic Berkeley, where the City Council often weighs in well to the left on world and national matters.

title: 12 Keating Charges Are Dismissed
description: A judge today dismissed 12 of the 46 fraud counts pending against Charles H. Keating Jr. and three of his former associates at the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, citing technical problems with amended charges filed by the prosecution.

title: Wilson D. Hall, Radio and TV Correspondent, 68
description: Wilson D. Hall, a former NBC News radio and television correspondent, who was acting chairman of the department of journalism at the University of Tennessee at Martin, died Thursday at Jackson-Madison County Hospital in Jackson, Tenn. He was 68 years old and lived in Martin, in northwestern Tennessee.

title: Soviet Press Curbs Hint at a Retreat
description: The Government appeared today to be scaling back its free-press policy by closing the offices of an independent news agency and maintaining a blackout of the nation's main television outlet for satirical criticism of the Kremlin.

title: Bernard Schlanger, 75, Ex-Professor at CUNY
description: Bernard B. Schlanger, professor emeritus of speech and audiology at the City University of New York, died on Wednesday at Palm Beach Gardens Hospital in Florida. He was 75 years old and lived in Palm Beach Gardens.

title: Religion Notes
description: In Religion We Trust

title: 3 Are Held in Slaying of Girl on School Bus
description: The police have arrested three suspects in the sniper attack that killed a 14-year-old girl riding in a school bus near this Cape Cod town last Saturday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: U.S. Oil Use Fell in '90, But So Did Production
description: Driven by war fears, recession and the weather, the nation's petroleum consumption fell in 1990, the first year-to-year drop in seven years, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday. Although the Government has called for conservation, the institute said other factors were responsible this year.

title: Health Workers Need Hepatitis B Shots
description: To the Editor:

title: New Clouds Over Mayor Dinkins
description: Two investigations of a stock deal Mayor David Dinkins of New York says he transacted with his son have raised serious questions. Both the U.S. Attorney in Brooklyn and an independent city investigator have found circumstantial evidence that the Mayor and his son may have lied. The evidence wasn't strong enough to recommend prosecution, but the incident leaves a cloud over Mr. Dinkins, who resolutely insists he's been cleared.

title: Philips Offers Its Challenge To Sony Digital Tape Player
description: The talk of the Consumer Electronics Show here this week has been the increasingly likely war between two versions of the new generation of cassette recorder.

title: Judge Backs Right to Challenge Bison Killings
description: A Federal district judge has given an animal rights group permission to sue the state and Federal governments to stop the killing of bison that wander from Yellowstone National Park.

title: Riders May Have Breathed Toxic Fumes in Brooklyn Subway Fire
description: The head of the Transit Authority said yesterday that passengers who suffered smoke inhalation during a fatal fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel last month may have been exposed to dangerous levels of toxic substances. He promised that the Transit Authority would contact the riders after the completion of a toxicological analysis to determine the extent of the danger posed by the smoke.

title: Donors Maintain Record Pace To Help the Neediest Cases
description: In the next seven weeks, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund must raise $644,190.84 if it is to surpass the previous campaign's total and become the sixth consecutive campaign to record an increase.

title: Norway Plans Bank Aid
description: The Norwegian Government said on Thursday that it would propose an $833 million state guarantee fund to assure stability and confidence in the nation's troubled banks. The proposal, to be presented to Parliament this month, would establish a fund to offer capital to the private commercial bank reserve fund and the savings bank reserve fund. The banks have been hurt by an economic slump.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the opening paragraphs of an article yesterday about the antiwar movement misstated the extent of religious opposition to a war in the Persian Gulf. Leading Christian denominations in the United States have announced opposition to such a war; national Jewish organizations have not been a part of the antiwar effort.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a plan by the New York City Board of Education to establish an experimental school with special emphasis on the problems of young black and Hispanic men described a similar program in Milwaukee incorrectly. Like the New York program, the one in Milwaukee would be open to students of various backgrounds; it would not be exclusively for young black men.

title: Good Morning, Mr. Snow; How Did the Plows Do?
description: The first snowflake to fall in New York City yesterday touched down about 9:30 A.M. on Staten Island. But by then snow had already been foremost in the mind of one Sanitation Department official for over 24 hours.

title: Hussein Tells Muslims Of Holy War in the Gulf
description: President Saddam Hussein told a conference of Islamic leaders today that he was preparing for a holy war against the United States-led military alliance in the Persian Gulf that could only be averted if greater priority is given to solving the Palestinian problem.

title: Sampras Withdraws
description: Pete Sampras, who limped through a five-set loss to Stefan Edberg in an exhibition in Adelaide yesterday, withdrew today from the Australian Open, which begins next week. Sampras, suffering from shin splints, told Tennis Australia officials by telephone that he would be returning to the United States for treatment.

title: Cabbies Can Be Lured Better by Restrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook; The Gulf: Postcards From the Edge
description: How does the looming showdown in the Persian Gulf look to worried neighbors in South Asia? In a month's travels through India, Pakistan and Nepal, a visiting American learns there is no consensus.

title: At End of Term, Ohio's Governor Commutes Death Sentences for 8
description: Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, a staunch opponent of capital punishment who leaves office Monday, on Thursday commuted to life imprisonment the death sentences of eight prisoners, including all four women awaiting execution in Ohio.

title: Ronald Sanders, 58, Who Wrote On Jewish History and Dispersal
description: Ronald Sanders, a writer who specialized in Jewish history and the immigrant experience in New York and elsewhere, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.

title: Gulf Cost: $10 Billion in '90
description: The Persian Gulf military operation cost $10 billion in 1990, the White House said today. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said in a written statement that the United States had received $6 billion "in cash and in-kind support from our allies to defray this cost." A further $2 billion has been pledged and payment is expected soon, he said. The statement represented the first formal accounting by the White House of the cost of the gulf operation.

title: INSIDE
description: New York Panel Urges Small School Districts

title: The Search for a Safer Humidifier
description: Health concerns about humidifiers have led several manufacturers to refine older technologies to try to reduce the bacteria and mineral dust they discharge.

title: Aides Urge U.N. Chief to Offer Iraq Mideast Talks if It Quits Kuwait
description: Senior United Nations officials have urged Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, now on his way to Baghdad, to offer President Saddam Hussein a possible way out of the Persian Gulf crisis by asking him for a firm pledge to leave Kuwait immediately in return for an international conference to address the Palestinian question.

title: Panel Proposes More School Districts and a Shifting of Power
description: Twenty years after New York City's schools were decentralized, a commission created by the State Legislature will recommend that the corruption-plagued system be retained but that it be divided into smaller districts and that more power be shifted to the school level.

title: Jose Lampreia Is Dead; Parisian Chef Was 36
description: Jose Lampreia, chef and co-owner of La Maison Blanche, a favored meeting spot for French celebrities and epicures, died on Wednesday at his home in Paris. He was 36 years old.

title: Questions Arise on Methods Of Filtering Ultraviolet Light
description: After the patient had picked out new frames, he thought that was the last step in shopping for new glasses, but then the optometrist asked, "Do you want the ultraviolet coating?"

title: First Fidelity Buys Branches in Jersey
description: The First Fidelity Bankcorporation, the largest banking company in New Jersey, announced yesterday that it had acquired 48 branches and $2.5 billion of deposits from the City Federal Savings Bank, a failed bank that has been operating under Government control. The branches, in Union, Middlesex, Ocean, Morris, Essex and Somerset counties, have about 430,000 accounts and will open for business on Monday. First Fidelity, which paid $21 million for the deposits, bought nine City Federal branches with $468 million of deposits in September.

title: Have a Nice Age
description: What an eerie time. Natalie Wood alive, stray bullets, insolent foreign rulers' "asses" threatened with American kicking. And by a President, no less, of the United States.

title: Upshaw and Levine
description: The soprano Dawn Upshaw will sing songs by Wolf, Richard Strauss, Shostkovich and Rachimaninoff at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall. James Levine, the artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera, is to be her accompanist. Tickets are $22. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Bills and Dolphins Will (Try to) Run
description: There are times in sports when a contest looms with built-in drama, contrast and energy, and this is such a time here. Welcome to the Snow Belt, with Rich Stadium's 80,290 seats looking down on the field where the Bills and the Miami Dolphins will play Saturday afternoon in an American Football Conference playoff game.

title: Dow Up 2.73 Points After a Slow Session
description: Stocks edged ahead yesterday for their second consecutive gain, but activity continued to be extremely light.

title: Drop Prosecution of Father in Auto Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Recovering From Alcoholism Is Tough Work; A Fellowship First
description: To the Editor:

title: Long City Hall Debate: Poor Bridges vs. Budget
description: For the last several years the plight of New York City's bridges has at times inspired a contentious internal debate between passionate advocates for the structures in the Transportation Department and increasingly cost-conscious city officials.

title: Review/Theater; A New Incarnation for 'Country Girl'
description: Although "The Country Girl" proved to be one of Clifford Odets's most popular works, he considered it a superficial play. In this instance, it is the author who should have the last word, or so it would seem from Kenneth Frankel's production at the Roundabout Theater Company.

title: Yale M. Fendell, Executive, 67
description: Yale M. Fendell, a Manhattan sporting goods executive, died on Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived in Watchung, N.J.

title: In His Return, Johnson Is Fast but Finishes 2d
description: In his first race after a two-year suspension for drug use, Ben Johnson proved tonight he can run fast even without the anabolic steroid that caused his expulsion from the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.

title: More on the Gulf
description: Iraqi Leader Warns Of Plan for Holy War

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a letter from President Bush to college newspapers about his policy on the Persian Gulf misidentified the editor of The Colorado Daily. He is Clint Talbott.

title: The Tank War Continues, on Paper
description: When Washington and Moscow signed a treaty last November to cut conventional forces in Europe, it was widely thought that the Soviets would destroy tens of thousands of tanks. The fact that they are not doing so gives new ammunition to opponents of the treaty, who hope to kill it when it comes before the Senate.

title: Japan's Car Export Limit
description: Japan said today that it would limit car exports to the United States to 2.3 million annually, prompting an outcry from some quarters of the United States auto industry, which has been losing ground steadily to Japanese auto makers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: He's not exactly a standard on the classical music circuit, but JULIUS ERVING will cut a familiar figure when he appears Monday with the Philadelphia Orchestra. The retired star of the Philadelphia 76ers will perform under the baton of RICCARDO MUTI in remembrance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the eve of Dr. King's birthday.

title: Patents; A New Artificial Hip Is Said to Last Longer
description: Stephen M. Horowitz, an orthopedic surgeon at the University of Pennsylvania, won patent approval this week for an artificial hip that he said would outlast those now being used.

title: Richard H. Hansen, Lawyer, 61
description: Richard H. Hansen, a lawyer whose 1962 book played a role in the drafting of the constitutional amendment on Presidential succession, died at a Lincoln hospital on Jan 4. He was 61 years old and lived in Lincoln.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD BRANSON, the founder and chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways, Virgin Records and the Virgin Group of Companies, and PER LINDSTRAN, the founder of Thunder and Colt Balloons Ltd., will attempt to become the first men to cross the Pacific in a hot-air balloon. A Pacific crossing was made in a helium balloon in 1981 by Ben L. Abruzzo.

title: Producer Prices Fell Last Month
description: Reflecting a sharp decline in energy prices and the inflation-dampening effects of recession, prices paid to American producers fell six-tenths of 1 percent in December, the first decline since April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 2d Official In Bridge Unit Is Discharged
description: The New York City Transportation Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio, dismissed another city bridge official yesterday and said he would personally oversee the city's Bureau of Bridges until a new deputy commissioner for bridges was named.

title: Gorbachev Seeking a Way Out in Gulf
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set off a round of Soviet-American consultations today by offering President Bush new proposals about ending the Persian Gulf crisis. But the White House said Mr. Gorbachev presented "nothing that looks like a breakthrough."

title: Payment Made For Hotel Site
description: The Trump Organization said yesterday that it and its partners in Trump Wilshire Associates had received $48 million from the Los Angeles Unified School District for most of the site of the Ambassador Hotel. The school district is condemning most of the site.

title: Fears Grow of Terror Attacks if War Erupts, and Nations Tighten Security
description: The Bush Administration said today that terrorists supported by Iraq were planning worldwide attacks against the United States and its allies in the event of war in the Persian Gulf. Several Government agencies are taking countermeasures both in this country and abroad, including increasing security at airports, tightening screening procedures at entry points and briefing corporations on how to thwart attacks.

title: Queen Isabella Doesn't Merit Sainthood
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
Excerpts From Gulf Resolutions Before Congress
description: Following are excerpts from resolutions on the Persian Gulf before Congress: Mitchell-Nunn

title: Seymour Lakritz, Judge, 69
description: Seymour Lakritz, a New York State Supreme Court Justice in Queens, died on Dec. 27 at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Laurelton, Queens.

title: Your Money; Company Loyalty: A Potential Risk
description: The humbling of once-proud companies like Pan American World Airways and the Bank of New England has cracked the nest eggs of many of their loyal executives and employees who hold company stock, and it suggests a warning for others across America.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons Top Blazers in Overtime Bill Laimbeer's basket with 0.3 seconds remaining in overtime last night lifted Detroit to a 100-98 victory over Portland. Danny Ainge, who scored 4 of his 19 points in the overtime, tied the score, 98-98, with a jumper with 11.8 seconds remaining, and Detroit called timeout. When play resumed, Dennis Rodman inbounded the ball to Isiah Thomas, who passed to Laimbeer near the baseline. His basket from about eight feet gave the Pistons their eighth consecutive victory and seventh straight at home. (AP) Celtics 109, Clippers 107: Reggie Lewis, who didn't go to the foul line until the final minute, scored the game's last 4 points on free throws, including the game-winners with 2.5 seconds left. The Celtics (29-5) extended their winning streaks to 18 games at home and 6 games over all. (AP) Bulls 99, Hawks 96: Michael Jordan scored 31 points and Bill Cartwright added 20 as Chicago snapped Atlanta's seven-game winning streak. Chicago has won four straight games and 11 in a row at home. (AP) 76ers 120, Bucks 105: Charles Barkley scored 37 points and Philadelphia used a 19-0 first-quarter run to end Milwaukee's 18-game unbeaten streak at home. (AP) Suns 114, Rockets 110: Xavier McDaniel scored 33 points and Jeff Hornacek made four free throws in the final five seconds as Phoenix won its fifth straight game. (AP) Lakers 105, Cavaliers 93: Magic Johnson had 27 points, 14 assists and 10 rebounds as Los Angeles won at home and extended Cleveland's losing streak to 10 games. Last Dec. 19, in an 84-74 road loss to the Cavaliers, the Lakers were held to their lowest point total in their 31 seasons in Los Angeles. That game is Cleveland's only triumph in its last 17 games. (AP) N.H.L. Blackhawks Get 30th Victory Steve Thomas scored midway through the third period to break a tie, leading Chicago over the Winnipeg Jets, 3-1, last night. Thomas's goal gave the Blackhawks (30-14-3) their league-leading 30th victory. (AP) Capitals 4, Flames 2: Michal Pivonka scored two power-play goals, including the game-winner with 3 minutes 56 seconds left as Washington stretched its unbeaten streak to four games. (AP) TENNIS Fernandez Loses to Novotna Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia eliminated top-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez, 7-5, 6-3, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia. Novotna will face seventh-seeded Barbara Paulus of Austria today in the semifinals. Paulus advanced with a 7-6, 6-4 victory over third-seeded Manuela Maleeva-Fragniere of Switzerland. (AP) Fleurian Upsets Sanchez: Jean-Philippe Fleurian of France upset top-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 7-6, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the New Zealand Open in Auckland. Fourth-seeded Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia and fifth-seeded Luiz Mattar of Brazil were given walkovers when Lars Jonsson and Christian Bergstrom of Sweden were forced to withdraw because of food poisoning. (AP) SKIING Schneider Gets First Victory Vreni Schneider skied to her first World Cup victory this season yesterday, winning the women's giant slalom in Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia. Schneider, the 1989 overall World Cup winner from Switzerland, flashed down the icy Vitranc track with a winning aggregate of 2 minutes 11.66 seconds. (AP) SWIMMING World Record for Barrowman Mike Barrowman of Potomac, Md., lowered his world record in the men's 200-meter breast-stroke to 2 minutes 11.23 seconds last night at the world championships in Perth, Australia. The men's 400-meter freestyle relay team of Tom Jager, Brent Lang, Doug Gjertsen and Matt Biondi won in 3:17.15. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Columbia Edges Dartmouth Buck Jenkins's layup with 19 seconds left in overtime capped Columbia's comeback in a 77-75 Ivy League victory over visiting Dartmouth last night. Columbia (3-9 over all, 1-0 in the Ivy League), trailed by 56-43 midway through the second half before Jenkins started a 6-0 run and the Lions steadily cut the margin. Dartmouth (4-8, 0-3) led by 66-61 with 20 seconds left in regulation, but after Columbia's Eric Speaker hit a 3-pointer and Dartmouth's James Blackwell missed two free throws, Jenkins drove the length of the court and put up a 15-foot jumper that bounced off the rim and dropped through as the buzzer sounded. (AP) Princeton 55, Yale 27: Princeton (9-2) ran off a 26-2 spurt in a 15:33 span during which it held visiting Yale (5-6) without a field goal in the Ivy League opener for both schools. The 27 points were the fewest by Yale since it dropped a 56-38 decision to Princeton in the 1956-57 season. (AP)

title: Day 2: Lawmakers Debate War and More Time for Sanctions
description: Following are excerpts from the debate in Congress today on President Bush's request for support for military action in the Persian Gulf, as transcribed by The New York Times: Senator Bob Graham Democrat of Florida

title: The Punitive Society
description: With the Federal Government and most of the states caught in a budget squeeze -- New York may have a $4 billion deficit in the next fiscal year, New Jersey faces an $800 million shortfall and Virginia's Governor, Doug Wilder, is proposing $1.9 billion in spending cuts -- a question being asked by the National Council on Crime and Delinquency is right to the point:

title: 3 Dangers To Avoid In the Gulf
description: As the Jan. 15 deadline approaches, several military issues with potentially grave repercussions remain incompletely resolved. Foremost among these are difficulties of command and control, up to and including the inadvertent shooting of friend by friend; the military involvement of Israel, especially where Jordan is concerned, and the potentially adverse consequences of the successful liberation of Kuwait.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They have harvested an abundance of prizes and awards: Pulitzer, Grammy, Tony. Now they are teaming up for a production of "The Secret Garden" to open on Broadway April 25 at the St. James Theater. And they are all women.

title: Elinor Cocheran Ayers, Dog Breeder, 62
description: Elinor Cocheran Ayers, a former high school teacher who became a leading dog breeder, died on Wednesday at the Southwestern Vermont Medical Center in Bennington. She was 62 years old and lived in Manchester, Vt. No cause of death was given.

title: Buy American. American What?
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan proclaims that he wouldn't buy a Japanese car. In fact, he wouldn't buy any foreign car. "I don't think it does any good to siphon our money overseas," he said recently. To Mr. Lujan, it would seem, to buy American is to be all-American.

title: About New York; Store to Store, A Vertebral Line Of Evolution
description: New York City has become a pretty grim place. But imagine its charms if you had real money in your pocket and time to shop.

title: A Time For Cheers And Fears
description: A field-goal attempt had fallen short of the crossbar with 49 seconds to play. The men in the striped shirts beneath the upright at the east end of Joe Robbie Stadium waved their hands, palms down, which started an uncharacteristically boisterous celebration of Miami Dolphin fans and signaled the beginning of the end of Marty Schottenheimer's season.

title: U.S. Team Seeks to Reassure Israel
description: President Bush dispatched a high-level mission today to inform Israel that the United States would try to protect it from Iraqi attack should a war erupt in the Persian Gulf and to urge Israel to stay out of the conflict.

title: Marcoses' Raphael Sold To Italy for $1.65 Million
description: An early Raphael painting, "Saint Catherine of Alexandria," was bought for $1.65 million by the Italian Government yesterday in a sale of art from the collection formed by Imelda and Ferdinand Marcos when Mr. Marcos was President of the Philippines.

title: Mercer Knocks Out Damiani
description: With one punch, Ray Mercer turned a bad night into a dream victory. Mercer caught Francesco Damiani, the World Boxing Organization heavyweight champion, with a left uppercut to the face and knocked him out at 2 minutes 47 seconds of the ninth round of a scheduled 12-round bout at the Trump Taj Mahal tonight.

title: SOVIET ARMY RAIDS LITHUANIA OFFICES
description: Soviet Army troops using tanks and live ammunition today stormed the Lithuanian press center and a building occupied by the Lithuanian civilian militia, sharply escalating Moscow's campaign against this rebellious republic.

title: Red Wings Roll Over Rangers
description: With the second-best record in the National Hockey League and with ties to Michigan's hockey culture, it seemed that the Rangers had the talent and the incentive to challenge the Red Wings tonight on a visit to Joe Louis Arena.

title: A Retraction By Pioneer
description: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation, a leading Japanese audio products maker, has retracted its report that Paramount Communications Inc. approached it with an offer to sell the Paramount motion picture division.

title: Rev. Marilyn Moore, A Church Official, 57
description: The Rev. Marilyn Adams Moore, an executive with the United Church of Christ, died Jan. 3 at her home in Dayton, N.J. She was 57 years old.

title: Kraft Fat-Free Mayonnaise
description: Kraft General Foods Inc., the nation's largest food company, said on Thursday that it planned to introduce nationally a fat-free mayonnaise in April known as Kraft Free.

title: Crisis Raises TV News Audience
description: Tension in the Persian Gulf drew more television viewers to network news programs this week, setting advertisers to debating whether they, too, should pay more attention to the news.

title: Faculty Group Fights College Post for Barry
description: Former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., convicted earlier this year of a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession, has been recommended for a one-semester faculty post teaching criminal justice at the University of the District of Columbia.

title: Officer Who Shot Car-Theft Suspect Faces Murder Charge
description: A rookie police officer was charged with murder yesterday afternoon in the fatal shooting of a man trying to steal his car Thursday morning as the officer was getting ready to go to work, the police said.

title: Patents; Protein in AIDS Virus Studied as a Vaccine
description: Researchers at a small biotechnology company won patent protection this week for a protein in the AIDS virus that is being explored as a potential vaccine against AIDS.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-9

title: Devils Call Up 3 Players
description: With Brendan Shanahan out for four weeks and Bruce Driver out for 10 days because of injuries, the Devils yesterday decided to promote three players in time for their game this afternoon against the Edmonton Oilers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Citing Sex Classes, Bishop Bars School Leases
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn has refused to lease two unused parochial school buildings to the New York City Board of Education because of his objections to a sex-education curriculum that would be taught in the schools.

title: Review/Dance; Discovering Inspiration in a Painting
description: The Wendy Perron Dance Company is the second entry in a new season that the Joyce Theater is presenting under the optimistic title "Altogether Different."

title: Kodak's Payment To Polaroid Reduced
description: A Federal district judge yesterday reduced by $36 million a patent infringement award that had required the Eastman Kodak Company to pay the Polaroid Corporation $909.4 million for infringing Polaroid's patents for instant photography.

title: Southern Democrats Are Torn as Vote Nears
description: Until Thursday, Senator J. Bennett Johnston said, "I thought sanctions were the way to go." But the Louisiana Democrat emerged from a meeting at the White House supporting President Bush. "The die was cast," he said, and it is important for senators to "present a united front."

title: New U.S. Weapons: Facing Their First Combat Test
description: Whether a war with Iraq can be won swiftly and with relatively little bloodshed will depend partly on the performance of a host of new American weapons that have yet to stand the test of combat.

title: Coping/With Elder-Care Benefits
description: With child care already a solid part of the employee benefits package at many companies, more businesses are focusing on a newer family benefit, services for older dependents, known as elder care.

title: Mark Morris Returning to New York
description: The American choroegrapher Mark Morris and his 25 dancers are returning to New York in July as an independent company after three tumultuous years here as employees of the Belgian state.

title:
Guidepost;
No Squeeze on Vitamin C
description: A freeze destroyed about half of the California citrus crop three weeks ago. Eighty-five percent of this country's fresh oranges come from California, so it's no surprise that navel oranges have more than doubled in price since then. But the price of orange juice may actually drop, because many California oranges once destined to be packed fresh will now be used for juice. Normally, almost 75 percent of the country's orange juice comes from Florida, which has had no freeze so far. Fresh oranges are rich in vitamin C, but there are less expensive sources. Here are some, with the percentage of the United States Recommended Daily Allowance from each:

title: Seidman Is Hopeful on Boston Bank
description: L. William Seidman said today that he hoped the Bank of New England would be sold in three to four months and added that several more potential buyers had emerged.

title: Plan to Revise Aid to Schools Deepens New Jersey Tumult
description: A plan by Democratic leaders in the New Jersey Senate to take $450 million in new aid marked for public schools and use it to cut property taxes has deepened the uncertainty surrounding the state's school-financing law.

title: Review/Opera; Hockney Adds Magic To Mozart
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Die Zauberflote" seemed out of tune from its inception, many months ago. The originally scheduled director, Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, died. His replacement, the movie maker Werner Herzog, withdrew when it became apparent there would not be time to mount his ambitious version of Mozart's seriocomic tribute to the Enlightenment. What finally appeared on the stage on Thursday evening was basically the John Cox staging that originated at the Glyndebourne Festival 13 years ago and subsequently traveled to the San Francisco Opera. Was it reasonable to expect much magic from such a secondhand "Flute"?

title: Carl Anderson, Physicist, Is Dead; Co-Discoverer of Positron Was 85
description: Carl D. Anderson, a co-winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1936, died yesterday morning at his home in San Marino, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: A Crystal Ball for Banking's Ills
description: No single statistic can foretell which banks will fail, but from the welter of financial reports banks issue, government and private analysts can glean strong hints which are the shakiest.

title: Patents; Electric Jolt Removes Itch From a Bite
description: An inventor in Minneapolis received patent approval this week for a battery-powered device that uses a minute electrical jolt to take the itch out of bug bites.

title: Invitation for Gossage
description: Rich Gossage, the 39-year-old retired relief pitcher, has won an invitation to attend the Texas Rangers' spring camp.

title: New Director At Whitney Looks Ahead
description: As he sees it, David Anthony Ross, the new director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, has a lot in common with New York City -- above all, energy.

title: FIVE-MONTH DELAY IN NORIEGA TRIAL
description: A weary and angry Federal district judge today delayed the start of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's drug-trafficking trial until June in an effort to resolve the many tangled issues in the deposed Panamanian dictator's case.

title: Barium Cloud Release Postponed by Scientists
description: Storm clouds hugging Earth's surface prompted space scientists on Thursday night to postpone release of a barium cloud that would have created a brilliant blue-green and purple aurora in the night sky.

title: Drunken-Driving Charge for Lewis
description: On the day his rival, Ben Johnson, prepared to return to competition at a meet in Canada, Carl Lewis dashed from a police substation to an awaiting car today and was driven away hiding his face after being charged with drunken driving.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the indictment of six members of a police narcotics unit in Los Angeles misidentified an organization that filed charges of police brutality in another case. It was the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., not the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Budapest Journal; On a Clear Day, You Can Glimpse the Tow Trucks
description: When the first tow trucks swooped through Budapest's car- and exhaust-choked streets more than a month ago, the public actually cheered, one more sign of just how fed up city residents are over traffic and air pollution.

title: Pan Am Obtains Access To $50 Million of Loan
description: Pan Am got access yesterday to $50 million of the $150 million loan that was authorized by a bankruptcy judge on Thursday night.

title: Whirling Up a Collage of Joy and Delays
description: The first snowfall of the year obliterated the New York metropolitan area yesterday, forcing schools, businesses and government offices to close early and transforming the region into an icy obstacle course for homebound commuters and other travelers.

title: Football; Giants' Hostetler Confident He'll Pass First Playoff Test
description: Jeff Hostetler wants to know what the big deal is.

title: MGM-Pathe Payment
description: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company, formerly the MGM/UA Communications Company, said today that it had paid a total of $26 million in interest on MGM/UA's 12 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 and 13 percent debentures due in 1996. The company paid the interest today after delaying payment on Dec. 15 to pay other bills.

title: Recovering From Alcoholism Is Tough Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicholas Marsicano, An Art Teacher, 82
description: Nicholas Marsicano, who taught painting and drawing at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art for 42 years, died at his home in Woodstock, N.Y., last Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: Slim Senate Majority Is Expected But House Backing Appears Solid
description: After a second day of sober debate, Congress appears ready to vote over the weekend to give President Bush the authority to go to war against Iraq.

title: For Many Arab-Americans, F.B.I. Scrutiny Renews Fears
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrived at Nazih Deyda's office in Los Angeles last week, unannounced, unexpected and accompanied by a member of the Los Angeles Police Department's anti-terrorist squad.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle answer yesterday, for Thursday's puzzle, included two erroneous entries. A corrected version appears today on page 16.

title: Emergency Oil Release Plan Is Set
description: The International Energy Agency, a 21-nation group of oil-importing nations, adopted an emergency plan today to bolster oil supplies by releasing two million barrels a day from government reserves if war begins in the Persian Gulf.

title: DRUSE CHIEF QUITS LEBANESE CABINET
description: Walid Jumblat, the leader of the Druse militia in Lebanon, resigned today from the Cabinet of national unity set up three weeks ago, and his surprise departure has deepened a political crisis facing President Elias Hrawi.

title: Ismail Must Decide By Feb. 1 Deadline
description: Notre Dame's acclaimed breakaway runner, Raghib (the Rocket) Ismail, is wrestling with which way to run three weeks before the Feb. 1 deadline for deciding whether to enter the National Football League draft.

title: John C. Wrightson, Textile Executive, 67
description: John Chaffe Wrightson, a retired textile industry executive, died Thursday at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. He was 67 years old and had moved to Walpole, N.H., from Darien, Conn.

title: Late Rally Trims Losses in Bonds
description: A strong rally late in the day helped long-term Treasury securities erase a good part of their earlier losses yesterday but prices still ended down and yields rose. The bill market, however, strengthened.

title: Japanese Leader Cancels Trip
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan has canceled a trip to Southeast Asia next week, citing the need to stay in Tokyo and watch developments in the Persian Gulf crisis. Mr. Kaifu expressed disappointment today at the apparent failure of talks between the United States and Iraq to avert war.

title: Daniel B. Dodson, 72, Retired Professor, Dies
description: Daniel B. Dodson, professor emeritus at Columbia University, died on Sunday at his home in Sollies-Ville, France. He was 72 years old.

title: As War Seems Nearer, Washington Students Look Within
description: At the elite, private St. Albans School for Boys, young men sang "America" during a chapel service and wrestled with the question of what constituted a just war and whether they would be called to fight in the Persian Gulf.

title: SUPPORT IN CONGRESS IS SEEN; ADDRESS TO TROOPS
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told American forces in Saudi Arabia today that if Iraq did not withdraw from Kuwait by the United Nations deadline of midnight on Tuesday, the United States was not likely to wait very long to go to war to force the Iraqis out.

title: Magadan Signs for $1.25 Million
description: Dave Magadan has joined the legion of Mets players earning $1 million or more, agreeing yesterday to a 1991 salary of $1.25 million rather than debate the Mets in salary arbitration.

title: Familiar Names Receive Book Critics' Nominations
description: John Updike, Robert Caro, Irving Howe and Wallace Stegner were among the familiar authors whose books were nominated on Thursday for the National Book Critics Circle awards as the most distinguished books published in 1990. Also nominated was "Middle Passage" by Charles Johnson, which last month won the National Book Award for fiction.

title: Books of The Times; 9 Heroes and What Made Them Act
description: Rescues The Lives of Heroes By Michael Lesy 213 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $18.95.

title: Berry Kroeger, 78, An Actor in Radio, Theater and Films
description: Berry Kroeger, an actor who performed on Broadway with Ingrid Bergman and in many major radio shows and network serials, died on Jan. 4 at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 78 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Citing Role in a Nazi Project, Canada Bars Ex-U.S. Scientist
description: An immigration court today barred entry to Canada to Arthur L. Rudolph, the 84-year-old German-born engineer who managed the development of the Saturn 5 rocket used in the American moon landings.

title: Chamorro's Kin Moving Against Her
description: In a sign of widening public unhappiness with the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, her relatives have moved to reclaim editorial control of the family newspaper that brought her international fame in the early 1980's as a symbol of opposition to Sandinista rule.

title: Lennon's Son Expands a Song of Peace
description: An all-star recording and music-video of John Lennon's antiwar anthem, "Give Peace a Chance," with new lyrics by the slain Beatle's 15-year-old son, Sean, will be released Tuesday by Virgin Records. Among the more than 20 stars participating on the record, which was conceived and produced by Lenny Kravitz, are M. C. Hammer, Bonnie Raitt, Tom Petty, Peter Gabriel and L. L. Cool J.

title: Flunking World Order 101
description: Iraq's intransigence notwithstanding, George Bush is heading toward a C minus or worse in World Order 101, the newest elective course in the foreign policy curriculum.

title: 49ers Are Still Expecting to Deliver Their Best Shot of the Season
description: As the San Francisco 49ers concluded their preparations today for their National Football Conference playoff game Saturday with the Washington Redskins and for a luminous run toward a third consecutive Super Bowl title, two things were evident for pro football's most glamorous team:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I hope that the next time I meet you is in Kuwait City." -- Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, speaking to the exiled Emir of Kuwait. [ 8:2. ]

title: Adventures At Lincoln Center
description: To the Editor: I am actually most flattered by Donal Henahan's connection between Lincoln Center and the bold experimentalism of Peter Sellars [ "When Auteur Meets Opera, Opera Loses," Dec. 9 ] . Such an association may have been unlikely in the past, but today Mr. Sellars's daring and unusual settings of Mozart's trio of operas presented on PBS may be just the kind of adventurous programming we have been presenting in such Lincoln Center series as Great Performers, Serious Fun! and Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors.

title: Ramie Targoff and Edgar Pew to Wed
description: Ramie Targoff, a doctoral student in English literature at the University of California at Berkeley, and James Edgar Pew, a law student at Columbia University, plan to marry in August.

title: Questionable Lineage
description: To the Editor: Witold Rybczynski's article "It Seems That God Isn't in the Details, After All" [ Dec. 16 ] takes as its starting point the aphorism "God is in the details," which is sometimes attributed to Mies van der Rohe.

title: Shot Dead Stealing an Officer's Car, and Luckless From the Start
description: The life of the young Brooklyn man who was killed by an off-duty police officer last week while trying to steal the officer's car had been soured from an early age, when his parents separated and his father became addicted to drugs, friends and relatives said yesterday.

title: Pioneer of Stock Market Regulation Needs to Be Heeded More
description: To the Editor:

title: Fence at Well Upsets Southampton
description: OVER the last few years, the Suffolk County Water Authority has found itself at odds with officials in towns on eastern Long Island. Another dispute is developing over a fence that was built around a well in November in a rural part of Bridgehampton.

title: Dr. Peter Sands and Lisa Rae Calgaard
description: Lisa Rae Calgaard to Wed in March

title: C. W. Gifford Wed To Miss Korones
description: Susan Beth Korones, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Korones of Memphis, was married yesterday at the English Speaking Union in New York to Christopher William Gifford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hazen Gifford of New York. The Rev. Dr. Douglas E. Brown of the Church of Christ in Memphis officiated.

title: Wall Street; Pick the Market, Weigh the Assets, Watch the Premium
description: Results from 1990 teach a sober lesson about the risk of investing in closed-end country funds. Picking the right stock market is not enough. You have to pick the right fund.

title: Top Bowler
description: After becoming the first bowler to earn $200,000 in two successive years, Amleto Monacelli of Venezuela has been named the Professional Bowling Association's bowler of the year for the second successive year. The 29-year-old Monacelli, who led the tour with a 218.16 pinfall average, 9 championship round appearances and 16 match-play appearances, got 908 of the 1,209 votes cast by his fellow professionals. . . . Karina Habsudova of Czechoslovakia and Andrea Gaudenzi of Italy were the top junior players in the world for 1990, according to the year-end computer ranking of the International Tennis Federation. (AP)

title: Postings: Real Estate Board; It's Time to Dine
description: The city's real-estate players have not yet traded in their black ties for black armbands. Some 2,000 members and guests of the Real Estate Board of New York are expected to don dinner jackets and evening gowns for the 95th annual banquet, at $450 a plate, being given Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 13, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 13 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age. 2 2 18 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 3 6 7 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and romantic life of an eighth-generation California woman who becomes a celebrity photographer. 4 3 10 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 5 4 30 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride. 6 5 21 MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 7 7 7 JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician uses genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park. 8 8 31 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) The autobiography of the athlete who plays both baseball and football. 4 6 8 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 5 5 9 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $8.95.) Essays about America's success in the cold war and the strains now developing in its society. 12 15 96 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays. 13 9 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. 14 14 23 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 15 10 16 FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS, by H. G. Bissinger. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) A high school football season in Odessa, Tex. 16 * 2 THE DISCOVERY OF THE BISMARCK, by Robert D. Ballard with Rick Archbold. (Warner, $35.) A profusely illustrated account of the finding of the wreck of the German battleship. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 6 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. How to find the child you once were. 3 * 2 8 THE FRUGAL GOURMET ON OUR IMMIGRANT ANCESTORS, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $19.95.) Menus and recipes from 35 ethnic groups that immigrated to America. 4 56 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: Pacts for Tettleton and Sasser
description: Two catchers reached agreement on 1991 contracts yesterday. For one, Mickey Tettleton, the agreement meant he was changing teams. For the other, Mackey Sasser, it meant a serene winter, unlike a year ago.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title: 3 Are Held in Slaying Of Girl on School Bus
