description: The police have arrested three suspects in the sniper attack that killed a 14-year-old girl riding in a school bus near this Cape Cod town last Saturday.

title: The World; In the Baltics, the Red Army Is a Red-Flag Issue
description: IN the intensifying battle between the Kremlin and the Baltic states, most of the key players these days seem to be 17- and 18-year-old boys.

title: The Lonliness of an Orge
description: A DANGEROUS WOMAN By Mary McGarry Morris. 358 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: U.S. Health Officials Said to Link 2 More AIDS Infections to Dentist
description: The strain of the AIDS virus that has infected two patients of a Florida dentist has been identified by Federal health officials as the same one that killed the dentist last year and infected a third patient of his, according to a published report.

title: TV Companies Finding Interest in Gulf Debates
description: Dudley Sauve said he thought the speeches he heard this weekend favoring continued sanctions instead of military force against Iraq were "tremendous." Unfortunately for opponents of intervention, the speakers were not Congressmen but the college students he was judging at a debating competition at New York University.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Dec. 23 about plans for uses of new state aid at a grammar school in Trenton misidentified an adult working with a pupil in a classroom. She was Cruz Feliciano, a parent volunteer at the school.

title: Trade Talks With Japan Face Stormy Reopening
description: Trade negotiations between Japan and the United States, which resume here Thursday, are headed for rough weather.

title: A Revue of Reassuring Sentiment
description: TO placate subscribers, who were put off by this season's two previous hard-to-take productions, the Boston Post Road Stage Company in Westport canceled the play "Wenceslas Square" and substituted "Closer Than Ever," which is easier to pronounce.

title: Sharpton Is Stabbed at Bensonhurst Protest
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton was stabbed in the chest yesterday as he prepared to lead a protest demonstration through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn with the parents of Yusuf K. Hawkins, the black youth slain there by a white mob 17 months ago.

title: Ideas & Trends; Catholic Scholars, Citing New Data, Widen Debate on When Life Begins
description: WHETHER one is for or against abortion, one of the fixed points in the debate has been the Roman Catholic Church's teaching that human life deserves full protection from the moment of conception. Now in two important scholarly articles, several Roman Catholic ethicists are questioning whether the very earliest stage of fetal development can legitimately be thought of as an individual human life.

title: Home Rule Is Really a 'Myth'
description: Re: "Regional Approach to Services Reconsidered," Nov. 25:

title: Homeless Women's 'Survival School'
description: THE shouts and laughter of children reverberate through the sunny rooms of the big white house, which sits on a corner in a neighborhood of small single-family homes near Route 35 in the Cliffwood Beach section of the township. The walls are festooned with artwork fashioned by young fingers that make up in enthusiasm what they lack in skill. Stuffed animals and toys abound.

title: Basketball; Ex-Knick Trying To Stay Drug-Free
description: The chant belonged to another era, to a place far removed from the drug-infested corners of 130th street and Madison Avenue. Even in the early hours of an icy December morning, with the sounds of police sirens wailing in the distance and strong, frigid winds blowing the lids off aluminum garbage cans, the chant still conjured up positive images.

title: Campus Life: Penn State; Where Makers Of Ice Cream Go Back to School
description: Eleven students in white gowns, plastic hairnets and gloves crowded around a legless ice cream Santa Claus last week at Pennsylvania State University, preparing to eat the botched creation as part of a special course on ice cream making.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures of two couples last Sunday with the reports of their engagements were reversed. Candace Farrell and Kevin Daly were at the right; Barbara Keating and Ens. John W. Alter 3d were at the left.

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Certain things are constants, and Ted Allbeury is one. In book after book the prolific British writer of espionage tales has maintained a superior level. Generally he concerns himself with issues as well as a story, and A TIME WITHOUT SHADOWS (Mysterious Press/Warner, $19.95) is no exception.

title: Which Book Review Do You Get?
description: To the Editor:

title: Agoura Hills Journal; Bob Hope Stirs Debate In Going for the Green
description: It is the disappear ing Amazon rain forest, Los Angeles style: a swath of undeveloped oak and scrub land just above the smog line, owned by the comedian Bob Hope, contested by developers and environmentalists, with a golf course as the prize.

title: Boston Shootings Kill 5 at Chinatown Club
description: Five men were slain and a sixth was critically wounded by gunfire today as they played cards in a social club in the city's Chinatown neighborhood.

title: Football Snapshots in the Land of the Rising Sun
description: We came to Tokyo to play a football game, 38 Ivy League All-Stars for the Epson Ivy Bowl, unique among the many bowl games in that it matches American athletes against those of another country in a sport that has been all ours.

title: Ski Industry Wary of Move On Helmets For Children
description: A BILL to require all skiers under the age of 14 to wear helmets has caused alarm in the state's growing ski industry.

title: Carrie Kempner Weds Matthew Getz
description: Carrie Susan Kempner and Matthew Steven Getz were married last evening at the Yale Club in New York by Rabbi Eugene Lipsey.

title: Maria Leandra Imperial Wed
description: Maria Leandra Imperial, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Imperial of Yonkers, was married yesterday at St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx to Roland Richard Acevedo, a son of Mr. and Mr. Robert Acevedo of Kissimmee, Fla. The Rev. George Delaney officiated. The bride, 31 years old, is keeping her name. A cum laude graduate of Harvard University, she has a master's degree in public administration from New York University and a law degree from Harvard. She is the general counsel of the Metropolitan Assistance Corporation in New York. Mr. Acevedo, 36, is the senior coordinator for advocacy programs for the Legal Aid Society in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If the temperature remains above 40 degrees for the day, re-apply anti-desiccant sprays to broadleaved evergreens, especially hollies, young rhododendrons and azaleas to protect them from winter sun. If it remains cold and the steps, walks and driveways are icy use sand or cat-box filler for safety, but never salt because it melts and seeps down to root systems and damages them.

title: Kristen Mayer to Wed Peter Otridge
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Mayer of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kristen Elizabeth Mayer to Peter Andrew Otridge, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Brian W. Otridge of Dublin. An October wedding is planned.

title: In Vast Desert, Massed Forces Look Small
description: As a chill wind swept dust clouds across the barren Arabian Peninsula, the vast army being readied for war against Iraq seemed today to have been swallowed by the immensity of the largest desert in the world.

title: Technology; Pursuing Zero Defects Under the Six Sygma Banner
description: When Motorola Inc.'s fiscal year ended in December, the payoff from improving the quality of the company's manufacturing operations suddenly became evident: $500 million saved during the year from reducing defects.

title: Travel Advisory; Hong Kong '97 Hotel Offerings
description: On June 30, 1997, the Union Jack will be lowered in Hong Kong and the flag of China will be raised. In the freewheeling capitalistic spirit of the British colony, some hotels are already accepting bookings for the momentous occasion.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Winston-Salem;
Reusing The Old
description: A FINE Queen Anne-style house built in 1906 that was threatened by demolition because it was in Old Salem, a restored Colonial village in this North Carolina city, has been saved by a construction company that moved it 150 yards beyond the historic district for use as its offices.

title: Diane Geller Wed To Ashley R. Joffe
description: Diane Elaine Geller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Geller of Miami Beach and New York, was married last evening to Ashley Roy Joffe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solly Joffe of Toronto. Rabbi David B. Saltzman performed the ceremony at the Hamptons in North Miami Beach.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Dec. 16 about Columbus quincentenary celebrations misstated the origin of the reproductions of the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria that will tour the United States in 1992. They were built in Spain; plans have been dropped to build another set of copies in Port Canaveral, Fla.

title: The Region; Sounding Notes of Fiscal Stability, Austerity and Pain
description: THEY are as much a January ritual as the department-store white sales: the State of the State speeches in Albany and Hartford and the State of the City address in New York. But last week the customarily upbeat rhetoric was overshadowed by the reality of recession and its consequences: declining revenues, skyrocketing deficits and -- perhaps most frustrating to elected officials not accustomed to having expensive initiatives scuttled for lack of cash -- scaled-down dreams.

title: Faded Movie Palaces Recall Gilded Past
description: EVEN in these days of sterile suburban multiplexes, some moviegeors still prefer the old downtown theaters that were built with details like plaster gargoyles on the balconies and painted dragons on the ceilings.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article last Sunday described the increasing power of Chinese and Southeast Asian gangs in New York City. It reported that they were growing in number and expanding into new types of crime.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title: Tennis Teens on Money Train to Nowhere
description: Let's dream for a minute. You bought a lottery ticket three weeks ago and this morning you received final confirmation that you have the winning number and will receive an after-tax sum of $5 million, all in the first year. Now let's move ahead six months. You really like your work but with millions of dollars sitting in the bank, how much grief in the form of company politics, irritating new policies and incompetent leadership are you willing to put up with before you are up and out of there for good?

title: Ms. Rachlin Wed To W. G. Portnoy
description: Ellen Joan Rachlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lauren Rachlin of Buffalo, was married at Temple Emanu-El in New York last evening to William G. Portnoy, a son of Sara Portnoy of New York and the late Alexander Portnoy. Rabbis Richard Chapin and Martin Goldberg officiated.

title:
Northeast Notebook: York, Me.;
Resales Suffer As Base Closes
description: THE closing of Pease Air Force Base in New Hampshire is causing hardship for civilian employees and military personnel who bought homes at the height of New England's economic boom and must now sell them in a declining real estate market.

title: Preacher Who Inspires, Protester Who Polarizes
description: Yesterday's stabbing thrust the Rev. Al Sharpton once again into a spotlight focused on both civil rights and anti-establishment protest -- a role that Mr. Sharpton has developed into a power base that both borrows from and challenges more traditional protest in New York City.

title: Sunday Brunch; Tapas to Tapestries and Beyond
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. These are some Manhattan restaurants that serve brunch or lunch. The Ballroom

title:
THE VIEW FROM FRIENDS OF KAREN;
A Year After Its Founder's Death, a Charity Keeps Growing
description: WHEN Barbara and Angus MacInness decided to take their terminally ill daughter out of the hospital 12 years ago, they were not about to be stopped by lack of money for home-nursing care. Eighteen-year-old Karen, who was in the final stages of a rare metabolic condition known as la Flora's disease, wanted to die at home and that wish took precedence over every other consideration, her parents said.

title: BIRTH-CONTROL BACKLASH
description: I certainly appreciated Philip J. Hilts's cautionary note on modern America's ongoing retreat into the dark ages of contraception ("Birth-Control Backlash," Dec. 16). I couldn't help wondering, though, why he chose to stretch the contraceptive label to encompass even RU-486, the so-called "abortion pill." After all, this drug is intended not to prevent conception, but to reverse its outcome. Could it be that such semantic obfuscation is intended to make an otherwise unpalatable concept easier to sell? GEORGE W. HARPER Ipswich, Mass.

title: Errors Stall Weather Service Upgrading
description: The National Weather Service's $3 billion upgrading is so far behind schedule that the agency is forced to rely on deteriorating equipment, a dependence that meteorologists in and out of Government say could jeopardize the service's ability to warn of dangerous storms.

title:
Gardening;
Proven Performance for a Worthy House Plant
description: House plants that are easy to grow and flower year-round are rare. One such plant that should be more popular is not. Its acceptance has been painstakingly slow.

title: No Malaise, Please; Reports by Dinkins and 3 Governors Focus on Silver Linings, Not Money
description: In major speeches in recent days, the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and the Mayor of New York City assessed the generally grim state of their respective domains, looked into a future tempered by a souring economy and gaping holes in their budgets and tried to sound at least a little optimistic.

title: Cornelia Powers Wed to P. G. Markle
description: Cornelia R. Powers, the daughter of Professor Harold S. Powers and Elizabeth C. Powers, both of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Patrick Gerard Markle, a son of Patricia Thompson Markle of Niagara Falls, N.Y., and the late J. Glynn Markle. The Rev. Sue Ann Morrow, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 9 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Off Broadway musical "Nunsense" misstates the record held by the run of "Little Shop of Horrors." It was the third-longest-running Off Broadway musical, not the second. The second was "The Threepenny Opera."

title: Daniel Routman Plans To Wed Miss Horchow
description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Roger Horchow of Dallas have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Horchow and Daniel Glenn Routman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Routman of Birmingham, Ala.

title: Wendy L. White Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. John J. White Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Louise White to Peter Michael Brockelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Stoddard Brockelman of Brookfield, Conn. A wedding in early 1992 is planned.

title: Jasmin Bey Weds Kenneth Cowin
description: Jasmin Bey, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Khalil Bey of Bretten, Germany, was married yesterday in the Rainbow Room in New York to Kenneth A. Cowin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Cowin of New York. Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the civil ceremony.

title: Review/Theater; A Killer, a Private Eye And Urban Unhappiness
description: In the plays of Squat Theater, the urban center cannot hold. Everything flies askew: the police as well as codes of criminal behavior. And there is a literalness about the expression "man in the street." The streets are filled with nightmarish events.

title: Postings: 90 Low-Income Rehabs; In the Valley
description: In a continuing effort to upgrade abandoned housing owned by New York City, Manhattan Valley Restoration Corporation, a neighborhood group that has rehabilitated more than 800 apartments since the late 60's, has received city approval to buy and rebuild eight five-story buildings on Columbus Avenue between 108th and 109th Streets.

title: Iraq's Empty Threat Against Israel
description: In the last few days, the Iraqi regime has indulged in much bombast that the world has taken much too seriously. Saddam Hussein's threat to U.S. troops, Israel and to Western cities (through terrorism) has been hugely exaggerated.

title: POP MUSIC: RECORD BRIEF
description: French Frith Kaiser Thompson: 'Invisible Means' Windham Hill WD-1094; CD and cassette.

title: World Markets; Discounting a Short Mideast War
description: Stock markets regularly surprise or confound. They did so again last week and produced interesting signals about the impact of a war -- or the avoidance of one -- in the Persian Gulf.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Evening Hours page on Dec. 30 about the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball misidentified Olivia Slocum's dance partner. He was her stepfather, Nicholas Firth.

title: THE RUSH HOURS
description: Lewis Grossberger's tireless, even desperate efforts to explain Limbaugh's success as the result of show-biz manipulation and the gullibility of his listeners missed the obvious: Limbaugh is popular because he makes sense and is resoundingly articulate. MICHAEL ROZEK Seattle

title: Campus Life: Middlebury; Bread Loaf School Adding a Branch In Santa Fe
description: Middlebury College's Bread Loaf School of English, in the wooded mountains of Vermont, will expand its graduate program this summer to the dry plains of Santa Fe, N.M.

title: The Executive Computer; Excel Raises the Spreadsheet Stakes
description: The Microsoft Corporation last week showed off a substantially improved and innovative version of its PC Excel spreadsheet program, the first number-crunching program to run with the enormously popular Windows 3.0 operating software that Microsoft produces.

title: Appling Obituary Evokes Memories
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On the Street; New or Old In Style, Hats Warm Winter
description: A hat with character can give basic winter coats a lift and chase the winter blues. Hats are a novelty for many young women who have now taken to wearing them with barrel-shaped short coats and stretch stirrup pants or tights. This freshens the "hat look," and gives it quite a different proportion. Not that the traditional look has been discarded. Dressy hats still look fine with leg-baring skirts and coats.

title: Knicks Sparked By Vandeweghe
description: While the Knicks' search for an outside shooter goes on, Kiki Vandeweghe, who was brought to New York in 1989 for his long-range prowess, did the job last night.

title: Campus Life: Bryn Mawr; Fears for Future Of Honor Code Lead to Action
description: Amid concern that Bryn Mawr College's honor code, and the privileges it confers, is in jeopardy, the Honor Board that oversees it plans to make several recommendations to strengthen it at a meeting of the student body next month.

title: Carolyn Gusoff Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Gusoff of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Sue Gusoff to Dr. Jon Branden Turk, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen N. Turk of New York. A September wedding is planned. Miss Gusoff, 27 years old, is a reporter for News 12 Long Island, a television station in Woodbury owned by Cablevision. She graduated from Cornell University and received a master's in journalism from Columbia University. Dr. Turk, 27, graduated from Amherst College and the Downstate Medical School. He is a resident in plastic surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York.

title:
ART;
Real Art Ways in Hartford Celebrates 15 Years of Innovation
description: THE current exhibition at Real Art Ways in Hartford may look sparse for a show that celebrates the 15-year history of this dogged alternative space; only 11 artists or collaborative teams are represented. But on inspection, one sees how each of the pieces is a link in a strong chain of innovative work coming out of Real Art Ways. At the very least, we are reminded that alternative spaces have nurtured several eminent careers.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY, TROUT

title: Now That the Recession Is Official ... Three Experts Predict the Recovery
description: Amid a great deal of publicity -- and several false calls -- the recession has finally arrived. But by all accounts it is not a typical recession, nor was it pronounced in the typical way. The seven-member Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research normally makes its dour recession confirmation only after two quarters of a downturn in the gross national product have been observed.

title: Bradley Jack Is Wed To Karin Sue Addison
description: Karin Sue Addison was married yesterday at Norfield Congregational Church in Weston, Conn., to Bradley Harris Jack. The Rev. James Gertmenian officiated, assisted by the bride's brother, the Rev. Carl V. Addison Jr. of the Church of God.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Project Provides Access to Records On Indian History
description: Recordings of religious songs, copies of turn-of-the-century photographs and reprints of detailed studies of American Indian life, which are in collections at the University of California at Berkeley, are being made available to Indian tribes through a partnership among the Indians, the university and county libraries.

title: Commercial Property: The Bernstein Brothers; A Tangled Tale of Americas Towers and the Crown
description: ONE of the most complex real-estate webs in Manhattan is slowly being untangled, freeing up two prominent office towers whose future had long been clouded by legal battles that left one unbuildable and the other unrentable.

title: Adding Irish Sensibility On Stage and in Films
description: DURING the summer of 1973, everything, it seemed, changed for Nye Heron. Between semesters of law school at the University of London, the Dublin-born Mr. Heron, then 21, was supposed to take a job in the student program of a camp for Jewish children in upstate New York. Salary: $40 a week; no smoking on Saturdays.

title: ROLLING BOYLE
description: Hallelujah! Finally, baby boomers no longer have to hang their heads in shame at the thought of McInerney, Janowitz and Ellis as the only products of our literary legacy. ("Rolling Boyle," by Tad Friend, Dec. 9).

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Builders Take a Cue From Home Sellers
description: RONALD AND NILZA SCHNEIDER had their heart set on a two-bedroom, 2,300-square-foot condominium in a 348-unit development called the Lakes at Setauket, but $239,000 was more than they felt they could afford.

title: Date Investigation: Personality Change
description: The article on investigating [ About Long Island, Dec. 23 ] is worth answering. Before investigators and back in the 1930's a close friend of mine was investigated by his future father-in-law. What the father particularly wanted to know was if the young man going with his daughter had a record of promiscuous drinking. Since he questioned a relative by letter, the answer was naturally complimentary to the person. As the relationship developed the husband became a drinker and the marriage wound up in divorce.

title: Group Homes Cause Little Trouble
description: The opposition to building homes for mentally retarded people in residential neighborhoods on Long Island [ "Group Home Foes Trot Out New Tactic," Dec. 9 ] is largely based on the assumption that such homes will have negative effects on the neighborhoods. This is actually quite unlikely, as the mentally retarded residents placed in such homes are nonviolent types, in fact, often very timid individuals, who leave their homes only with trained protectors for infrequent outings.

title: Polly Glenn Engaged to Paul O'Brien
description: The engagement of Pauline Eastwood Glenn to Paul Edward O'Brien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. O'Brien of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Glenn of Roanoke, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: Banking's Real Estate Miseries
description: Imagine every office building in Manhattan empty, a commercial ghost town. Now double it. That's how much vacant office space -- 500 million square feet -- there is in the United States today. Behind much of that empty office space stands the nation's banking system.

title: Sarah A. Johnson to Marry
description: Barbara J. Perkins of Greenvale, L.I., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter, Sarah Anne Johnson, and John Peter Viscardi 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Viscardi Jr. of Plandome, L.I. Miss Johnson, 24 years old, is also a daughter of Warren L. Johnson of Geneva, Ill. A cum laude graduate of the State University of New York at Plattsburgh, she is a sales representative for Ned Dougherty Real Estate in Westhampton Beach, L.I. Mr. Viscardi, 32, owns J. P. Viscardi Realty in Long Island City, Queens. He is a graduate of St. Michael's College in Winooski, Vt.

title: The Weather and the Deficit
description: I can remember when people actually talked about reducing the debt. There were two things wrong with that concept: It was too easy to understand and we couldn't do it.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Dec. 16 with an article about driving a camper through Europe reversed the labels of two German cities. Magdeburg is east of Hanover.

title: Eileen Connaughton and Thomas Marsich to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Terry Connaughton of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter Eileen Connaughton to Thomas Marsich, a son of Mario Marsich of Riverdale and the late Nancy Marsich. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Canvas of the Land
description: AMBER WAVES OF GRAIN America's Farmlands From Above. Photographs by Georg Gerster. Text and captions by Joyce Diamanti. Foreword by Garrison Keillor. 256 pp. New York: Harper Weldon Owen. $50.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: SOL C. CHAIKEN;
From Union Head to Business Promoter
description: SOL C. CHAIKIN, who was long associated with the labor movement, is now chairman and acting chief executive of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. He is also associated with the Council on Foreign Relations, Freedom House, the Trilateral Commission and the International Rescue Committee.

title: That Classic Female Trait
description: PRISONERS OF MEN'S DREAMSStriking Out for a New Feminine Future.By Suzanne Gordon.324 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: Jacquelyn Casella, Engineer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Pershing L. Casella of Endwell, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jacquelyn Anne Casella to Peter Gerard Newman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter G. Newman of Pleasantville, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: Review/Music; 3 Concerts Conclude Series of Mexican Work
description: The Mexican Council for Culture and the Arts has been presenting an ambitious series devoted to Mexico's large but often overlooked musical heritage. All told, there have been 23 concerts in museums, libraries, concert halls and churches in New York City, covering everything from 18th- century choral music to contemporary chamber works.

title: June Wedding Plans For Sandra Rudolph
description: Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Rudolph of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Sandra Rudolph and Raymond Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willie Levin of Cape Town.

title: Ms. Paul to Wed John Schaefer Jr.
description: June wedding plans for Elaine Ninon Paul and John Ellis Schaefer Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Schaefer of Berwyn, Pa., have been announced by her parents, Janet Eddy Rosenthal of Clearwater, Fla., and Robert E. Paul of Concord, Mass.

title: Heidi Arnold Wed To Thomas Prins
description: Heidi Maxwell Arnold, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Arnold of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Quinnell Prins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Kimberly Prins of North Stamford, Conn. The Rev. John Bell, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Christ Church.

title: The Virtues Of Not Building
description: It was with a great deal of perverse satisfaction that I read in "Office Vacancies Climbing to a Record" [ Dec. 23 ] that some of the newest and biggest office buildings on Long Island are largely vacant. Maybe it will put a damper on the pell-mell rush to fill every vacant space on Long Island with some sort of building.

title: From Provence, Winter Brighteners
description: AS appropriate as the sunny flavors of Provence may be in summer, they can also brighten winter menus. Garlic, olive oil, olives and herbs combined with canned plum tomatoes standing in for fresh enhance a simple dish of baked chicken breasts. Alongside, a gratin of squash and rice, the typical tian of the south of France, is a perfect accompaniment. In Provence, the term tian refers both to the preparation and to the oval dish in which it is baked.

title: Turkey Is Toughening Ground and Air Defense
description: Turkey, the only NATO member that shares a border with Iraq, has been steadily toughening its ground and air defenses as the United Nations deadline approaches for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.

title: Made for Each Other
description: THE POWER AND THE GLITTER The Hollywood-Washington Connection. By Ronald Brownstein. Illustrated. 437 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95.

title: How to Do the Right Thing, Musically
description: "What is musicology?" asked Jesting Producer, and would not stay for an answer.

title: Northeast Notebook: Burlington, Vt.; Developing The Waterfront
description: AFTER years of haggling, voters here approved the first phase of a plan to develop extensive holdings of public and private land on the city's long-neglected waterfront. City planners say development of a 70-acre area could total $100 million to $140 million in 5 to 10 years.

title: Maradona Fined
description: The superstar Diego Maradona was fined $70,000 by Italy's soccer tribunal yesterday for missing practices and games with Napoli, the club he plays for in the Italian League. Napoli also is suing Maradona, contending that he has engaged in misbehavior damaging the club's image.

title: Headliners; All Right, Who Turned Up the Heat?
description: ONE difference between global warming and a warmer-than-usual globe is that one is our fault and the other may not be. Another is that the former carries the cachet of epochal change -- melting polar ice packs, new coastlines here and there and radically new weather for everybody -- and the latter is just a bigger version of, "Hot, today, isn't it?"

title: Ruth Lax and Eric Kober Are to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Lax of Summit, N.J., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Ruth Laurie Lax and Eric Allen Kober, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kober of Yonkers.

title: Parliament in Poland Approves Cabinet for New Prime Minister
description: The Parliament today approved the Cabinet of Prime Minister Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, who has pledged to speed the pace of economic change and placate those segments of the population hit hardest by the program.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SPORTSMEN'S SHOW

title: Victoria Bostock To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Victoria Christine Bostock to Daniel Eugene Waters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Waters of Cumberland Center, Me., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roy J. Bostock of Rye, N.Y. a June wedding is planned.

title: Marinovich Out
description: IF Todd Marinovich, Southern Cal's quarterback, hadn't already made up his mind to pass up his final two college seasons in favor of the National Football League draft this spring, his coach gave him a little push on Friday. He suspended him from the team indefinitely.

title: Don't Mess With the Archetypes
description: OPERA AND ITS SYMBOLSThe Unity of Words, Music, and Staging.By Robert Donington.Illustrated. 248 pp. New Haven:Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: Resource Center A Success at University
description: In her recent letter to the New Jersey editor commenting on the article "Rutgers Confronts a Crossroads," Ruth H. Gottdiener characterizes my enthusiasm for the creation of an academic resource center for students at Rutgers as a calculated but empty public relations effort: "He wants to do something for students and if he cannot, the budget crisis is set up to be blamed."

title: Headliners; Amusing the King
description: Except for handing out the Nobel Prizes every year, Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden must find the late 20th century a fairly boring time to be king. As in other erstwhile monarchies, the duties of his office have been largely reduced to pomp and circumstance. To make matters worse Drottningholm Castle, where he lives with his family, only gets two television channels -- and, this being Sweden, both are noncommercial public stations. A Swedish newspaper reported last week that the King would like to broaden his video horizons by installing a satellite dish antenna to pick up foreign broadcasts. But it seems not even that modest wish is within his circumscribed powers. Swedish cultural authorities decided an antenna would look tacky and detract from the appearance of the 18th-century castle, an important tourist attraction. Installing an underground cable would cost $175,000, too much a strain for the royal treasury to withstand. The King's spokeswoman, Elisabeth Tarras-Wahlberg, said the price was "not realistic."

title: Manhattan Blues Clubs Draw New Fans
description: At a time when New York City is serving up pink slips and its bridges are verging on collapse, New Yorkers are turning to the emotional pitch and grit of blues music.

title: For Glasnost in the Arts, Blues in the Night
description: While Mikhail Gorbachev battles a sagging economy in the Soviet Union, glasnost has become one of the hottest trends of the American arts scene. Since the restoration of cultural relations between the two superpowers six years ago, the flow of artists from East to West has achieved near flood-tide proportions. In concert halls, regional theaters and museums around the country, the number of Soviet artists is at an all-time high: glasnost can also mean boffo box office.

title: Why a Cashless Society Wouldn't Work; 'Looking Backward'
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Lusty Flavors From Italy in White Plains
description: TUCKED away from the proximate hustle-bustle of the Galleria, Il Faro di Vieste is a welcome new contributor to the county's culinary scene. The staff is young and attentive, the pasta magnificent, the portions daunting.

title: Which Book Review Do You Get?
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; The Tuscan Table
description: I THINK OF THE PLAIN-SPOKEN TUSCANS AS the Yankees of Italy. This may be one reason that Tuscany appeals so much to rock-ribbed Yankees like me. A Tuscan's highest praise for any comestible, be it food or drink, is to call it genuino . The word means genuine, not so much in the sense of real as in the sense of pure and unadulterated. Tuscans, like Yankees, are thrifty in their approach to food (truth is, one of their favorite foods is leftovers), and they share a similar passion for beans: other Italians call them mangiafagioli , or bean eaters.

title: Lisa Lazarus, Personnel Aide, to Marry in May
description: May wedding plans for Lisa Beth Lazarus and Marc David Vitale, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory F. Vitale of Haverford, Pa., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arlie G. Lazarus of Short Hills, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A group of fashion pictures last Sunday with the On the Street feature carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Bill Cunningham.

title: Bridge
description: If one wanted to select the bridge writer with the greatest creativity in terms of card-play theory, two Hungarians would be among the strongest candidates. One is Robert Darvas, who died in 1957 and is remembered for the classic "Right Through the Pack" written with Norman De V. Hart and read and reread with great delight all over the world since it first appeared in 1947. Each card in the deck tells a story in which it plays a key role. The themes, both technical and human, are astonishingly varied.

title: Women's Own Way With Survival
description: Claude Chabrol's film STORY OF WOMEN (1988, New Yorker, $79.95) was not easy to sell to American audiences. In a marketplace where commercial blockbusters eat up the movie screens, there wasn't much room for a thoughtful foreign film on the potentially depressing subjects of illegal abortion and collaboration with the Nazis. Fortunately, this beautifully made and acted film will be released on video Thursday, Jan 24.

title: When City Hall Fails, Do It Yourself
description: From Grand Street in Brooklyn to Grand Central Station -- and soon to the Times Square area and a strip of Greenwich Village -- New York City businesses are banding together, and taxing themselves, to relieve their neighborhoods of grime and crime. It's a sad fact that City Hall hasn't kept up with the degradation, but it is reassuring when private interests do it themselves. Reclaiming the city's streets is everyone's job.

title: High-Powered Swiss Refuge
description: LIKE a tiny high-definition camera, the small capital of one of the smallest of Switzerland's 23 cantons captures a characteristic national trait: on the one hand it is, like the entire country, enamored of its own medieval past and lovingly cultivates its historical roots; on the other, it has a cozy relationship with international big business and big money.

title: Excerpts of Resolutions Debated by Congress
description: Following are key provisions of the resolution approved by the House and Senate today authorizing President Bush to use force in the Persian Gulf, as well as excerpts from Democratic alternatives that were rejected: Authorization for Use Of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution

title: From Indiana, a Banzai Buckaroo
description: Patsy Cline was wailing sad wails when it occurred to me that there was something incongruous about country music coming from the compact-disk player of my Isuzu.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBIN H. BRADLEY;
Overcoming a Resistance to Midwifery
description: TO some, the word midwife conjures up a time gone by when pregnant women did not get sophisticated medical care and delivered their babies at home, with the help of an older woman who was usually not formally trained but was very supportive of the mother. When obstetricians and hospitals became accessible to more women, midwives disappeared.

title:
The Executive Life;
An Ethos for the 90's: Work's Out, Play's In
description: Executive stress is in vogue for 1991, but only because the country has slipped into a recession. It actually should be out of fashion, for this year people are taking a more cynical view toward corporate ladder-climbing, vowing to work less and play more.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Mo' Better Blues 1990. MCA/Universal. $91.95. Laser disk, $39.98. 2 hours, 9 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Denzel Washington plays Bleek Gilliam, a straight-arrow, middle-class jazz musician. Though rich photography presents a sleek, handsome surface, Spike Lee's film has no inner life and, worse, little of the director's originality. Playing the trumpet or making love, Bleek performs with mechanical, macho self-absorption. Ultimately, the film is "more Hollywood than Spike Lee and much the worse for it." (Caryn James) Young Guns II 1990. CBS/Fox. $92.98. 1:45. CC. PG-13. Billy the Kid (Emilio Estevez) is more gun-toting cutup than true desperado in Geoff Murphy's sequel about the Kid's split with the sheriff Pat Garrett. Billy's gang of post-adolescent heartthrobs (Kiefer Sutherland and Christian Slater, among others) are "geared far more carefully to today's teen-age audiences than to the folklore of the Old West." (Janet Maslin) The Adventures of Ford Fairlane 1990. CBS/Fox. $92.98. 1:40. CC. R. Andrew Dice Clay is a leering, leather-clad rock-and-roll detective in a film designed to showcase his one-liners, primarily sex-ed jokes at the third-grade level. "The person most likely to be entertained by 'The Adventures of Ford Fairlane' need not be made aware of the film's existence. He's already on the screen." (Maslin) Delta Force 2 1990. Media. $89.98. 1:40. CC. R. Chuck Norris takes on a South American drug lord in a swiftly paced film with good pyrotechnics and a moderately exciting final chase. While there's nothing too original about any of that, the star's behavior is something of a departure. "Out of all the invincible heroes who fight their way through American action movies, Mr. Norris sweats and growls the least." (Stephen Holden) Speaking Parts 1987. Fox Lorber. $79.95. 1:26. No rating. Video monitors preside eerily over practically every move as three strangers gradually begin to interact with one another in undramatic yet mesmerizing ways. Sleek, somber and technology-mad, Atom Egoyan's film has a chilly high-tech cachet, creating a "perfectly controlled environment in which even the tiniest gestures harness their own shallowness by appearing to take on great import." (Maslin) The Lemon Sisters 1990. HBO. $92.99. 1:33. CC. PG-13. Bound by old loyalty and shared vapidity, three lifelong friends (Diane Keaton, Kathryn Grody and Carol Kane) face life in Atlantic City. In addition to inspiring bad puns, the Lemons inspire "disbelief that professional film makers could have made such an amateurish movie." (James)

title: Another European Hits the Canvas
description: For eight rounds, Ray Mercer, the 29-year-old former Army sergeant, was taking a whupping from Francesco Damiani of Italy.

title: Kim Wachenheim Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Wachenheim 3d of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim Wachenheim, to David Adlai Wagman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Wagman of Rye. A June wedding is planned.

title: In a Corner of Yonkers, Lamps Signal Restoration's Progress
description: RICHARD KERN, a former special-education teacher who gave up his career to pursue a dream, said this city is the best thing that ever happened to him.

title: Dead Pockets
description: To the Editor: Over the past 30 years, I have spent many a magical evening in Carnegie Hall. But its present-day acoustics are a disaster above the ground-floor level. I am not saying that our finest singers and solo instrumentalists sound less than their best in the various balconies. I am saying, from bitter experience in many locations, that, astoundingly, they often can't be heard at all.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an essay about biography in The New York Times Book Review today, under the headline "Choosing a Life," refers incorrectly in some copies to Robert A. Caro, the biographer of Robert Moses and Lyndon B. Johnson. Mr. Caro was born in Manhattan; his father emigrated from Poland.

title: Tracey E. McGan To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Belser McGan of Shrewsbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Tracey Elizabeth McGan to Robert Brewster Hamill, the son of Mrs. Philip Axel Litchfield of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and the late James Lyon Hamill 3d. A May wedding is planned.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: West Palm Beach, Fla.;
Trump Cuts Condo Prices
description: IN the aftermath of a well-publicized auction last month, the Trump Organization is marketing apartments in an upscale condominium here at about a third off earlier asking prices, reflecting what 35 went for at the auction.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
Downturn's Impact Uneven
description: NEW residential building permits in the Baltimore-Washington area have been only mildly affected so far by the recession. The two exceptions are affluent Montgomery County, Md., just north of Washington, and tiny Howard County, Md., where a cap on development has severely reduced new construction.

title: THE RUSH HOURS
description: Just as Morton Downey Jr. was forced to become increasingly bizarre in order to maintain his ratings, so will Limbaugh have to become increasingly insulting, increasingly insensitive and increasingly ridiculous.

title: Review/Dance; Balanchine Program by City Ballet
description: Eight couples in "Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbundlertanze' " leap across a ballroom floor. Nevertheless, although their feet are light, their hearts are heavy in this eloquent work by George Balanchine, which received a compelling performance by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF Occupied Lands: Economy in Ruins -- A special report.; Palestinians Find Life More Bitter Than Ever
description: The Persian Gulf crisis and the anti-Israel uprising have seriously damaged the economy and dampened the hopes of the 1.7 million Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Sir Alec Rose, World-Circling Sailor, 82
description: Sir Alec Rose, who sailed alone around the world in the 1960's, has died, his family said today. He was 82 years old.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Down and Out in Darien: The Shopping
description: DARIEN'S reputation as a town teeming with beautiful and expensive homes matches that of Greenwich, Westport and New Canaan. But when it comes to shopping, Darien runs a poor third.

title: Hong Kong
description: Wintertime in Hong Kong is cool and clear and generally sunny. And while this is not a peak season for tourists, it is nevertheless a wonderful time to visit, because the colony is at its most festive, decked out in lights and flowers for Chinese New Year next month, welcoming performers from around the world for its annual arts festival, and adding special exotic winter dishes to its restaurant menus.

title: Data Bank/January 13, 1991
In the Shadow of War
description: On the imitation wood-grain surface of the table lay a pile of fliers, small print dominated by letters two inches high: STOP THE WAR NOW! Like Proust's madeleine on low-grade bond, it flung me back, to hundreds of undergraduate bulletin boards, dozens of speeches, but especially to one march in 1972. I held my notebook like a shield between my face and the angry man, on his way home from the night shift, who was watching people move down the avenue beneath banners of peace. "Put down that they're a disgrace to this country," he shouted over the noise of the chanting. "Put down that I'm a veteran of World War II."

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Let's not pull the rug out from under the President when the pressure is building on Saddam Hussein by the minute. Let's don't give him any relief." -- Bob Dole, Senate minority leader. [ 1:6. ]

title: Roll-Call in Senate On a Gulf Assault
description: Following is the 52-to-47 roll-call vote by which the Senate approved a resolution authorizing President Bush to "use United States armed forces" to expel Iraq from Kuwait. A yes vote was a vote to authorize force; a no vote was a vote against the resolution. Voting yes were 9 Democrats and 43 Republicans. Voting no were 45 Democrats and 2 Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by x.

title: Aquino's New Chief of Staff Is Raising Hopes in Manila
description: The young and energetic Oscar Orbos, newly appointed executive secretary to President Corazon C. Aquino, is expected to work varying miracles on behalf of a faltering administration facing severe economic difficulties.

title:
ART;
Unusual Images in a Group Exhibition
description: "THE CONSTRUCTED IMAGE," currently on view in the Anthony Giordano Gallery at Dowling College in Oakdale, is a lively, busy exhibition that has considerable breadth.

title: Managing; A 'Gunslinger's' Growing Pains
description: IN the spring of 1989, Sun Microsystems Inc. seemed to be battered from all sides. Its executive vice president, Bernard J. Lacroute, resigned, telling his friends he felt burned out. Its chief financial officer, Joseph Graziano, went to Apple, and lower-level defections followed. Glitches in a companywide computer system shut down manufacturing operations. Then the really bad news came, the company's first loss -- a $20.3 million deficit for its fourth fiscal quarter.

title: Peru's New President Unable to Halt Rising Rebel Violence
description: Dashing hopes for a drop in South America's highest rate of political violence, Peru's internal war has claimed 1,500 lives in the six months since Alberto Fujimori was inaugurated President.

title: The Sum Of His Oddities
description: DICKENS By Peter Ackroyd. Illustrated. 1,195 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $35.

title: Wall Street; Keeping Tabs on the Rascals
description: Once again, it is time to look at Wall Street's dirty linen, the brokerage industry's disciplinary experience in 1990. It is a sobering pile, ranging from cheating on the broker's exam to outright theft. Even the major sins came in all sizes: One brokerage firm employee stole $312; several others pocketed a thousand times that amount. The humdrum miscreants who made unauthorized trades mingled with the creative souls who used forged paperwork to borrow money against customers' life insurance policies.

title: The World; Cambodia's Uneasy Truce With the Future
description: DESPITE considerable uncertainty over their own future in a draft peace settlement, Cambodian leaders last week organized lavish celebrations of their Government and its accomplishments, celebrations that included a relaxation of Phnom Penh's curfew and even produced a sort of traffic jam.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Islanders Waste 2-0 Lead
description: Just before the start of tonight's game between the Islanders and Detroit Red Wings, the 11,807 fans in Nassau Coliseum received this message over the public-address system: "For tonight's game, scratch number 16, Pat LaFontaine."

title: Residents Are Taking Action To Cut Crime in Their Towns
description: AFTER some children had their bicycles stolen from them last summer in Fairfield, about 100 residents showed up at a Police Commission meeting in September. They demanded, and soon received, more police patrols for their Stratfield neighborhood.

title: County Is Asked for Drop-In Shelter
description: WITH the onset of bitter winter weather, advocates for the homeless are pressing the county to reopen an emergency shelter for homeless men and women who are not officially eligible for assistance.

title: Chevy's Cab Picks Up Comment
description: Last week's column on the new Chevrolet taxi seems to have touched a chord. Here are excerpts from three of the letters: Dear Sir,

title: 'If I Stood Up Earlier...'
description: The dark terror of the television lacklisting days (1950-1955) now seems far off, and most of us who were caught in the middle of the storm have developed fuzzy memories -- perhaps deliberately. And we dig into our consciences to examine the part we played in that shameful era. Like the French after the liberation, we all claim to have been part of the Resistance. None of us were collaborators. Or were we? Was I?

title: Sunday Menu; Scandinavian Salmon Cakes With a Taste of the Fjords
description: Salmon cakes seasoned with the flavors of Scandinavia offer a savory departure from the garden variety. Use fresh salmon in the cakes rather than canned, because the difference is the same as that between homemade bread and store-bought.

title: Corrections
description: The Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today omits an airline under the headings "Discount Fare" and "Unrestricted Fare." The airline, Pan American World Airways, matches the lowest fares, $1,133 and $1,752, available on the New York-Rio de Janeiro route.

title: A Small Revue Sings Of the Things That Last
description: TO placate subscribers who were put off by this season's two previous hard-to-take productions, the Boston Post Road Stage Company in Westport canceled the play "Wenceslas Square" and substituted "Closer Than Ever," which is easier to pronounce.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Baltimore;
Downturn's Impact Uneven
description: NEW residential building permits in the Baltimore-Washington area have been only mildly affected so far by the recession. The two exceptions are affluent Montgomery County, Md., just north of Washington, and tiny Howard County, Md., where a cap on development has severely reduced new construction.

title: Post-Modern Kisses and Other Ideas
description: Since we ended 1990 with a look back, it seems appropriate to start 1991 with a look ahead. The outlook, to be sure, is gloomy: The new year begins with a depressed economy, not a single trendy new style to distract us, and not even a new architectural celebrity on the horizon. What can follow a year in which Peter Eisenman, the master of obtuse architectural theorizing, reached such heights of media fame that he was profiled in Vanity Fair? Herewith a few events that may happen in the world of architecture in 1991 -- or may not.

title: On the Eve of Drifting Into War, Once Again
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Haiti Puts Its Hopes To a Test, And Passes
description: WITH the free election of a President in December and the thwarting last week of a coup by the sort of thugs who ran the country for three decades, many Haitians believe they have finally ended the long nightmare of Duvalierism.

title: Quick! What's a Quark
description: At the 1987 commencement celebration of Harvard University, while champagne corks popped among the black robes, a film maker carried his camera into the crowd. Approaching new graduates at random, he posed a simple question: "Why is it hotter in summer than in winter?" The results, starkly displayed in the film "A Private Universe," were that only 2 of the 23 students queried could answer the question correctly. Even allowing for the festive atmosphere of a graduation ceremony, this doesn't give us much faith in the ability of America's most prestigious universities to turn out graduates who are in command of rudimentary facts about the physical world.

title: The Region; Florio's Battle For Survival And Florio's War Within
description: OVER the last year Gov. Jim Florio often appeared to be battling just about every group in New Jersey, from suburban school districts to the pro-gun lobby to organized labor. But now, after his original vision for the state stirred the rage of the public, Mr. Florio's ability to survive may increasingly depend on the outcome of a battle inside himself.

title: CORRECTION
description: The subheading of the Executive Life column last Sunday misidentified the charity to which Jimmy Ruotolo, a Wall Street barber, contributes. It is the Boys Club of America, not Boys Town.

title: THE RUSH HOURS
description: Granted, there's no business like show business, but the apparent success of The Rush Limbaugh Show is a graphic illustration as to why the United States has been in decline for more than a decade ("The Rush Hours," by Lewis Grossberger, Dec. 16).

title: Barbara H. Earle, TV Producer, Wed To Robert D. Ballard, Oceanographer
description: Barbara Hanford Earle, a television documentary producer, and Dr. Robert Duane Ballard, the director of the Center for Marine Exploration at the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institution, were married yesterday at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn. The Revs. T. Guthrie Speers and Lawrence M. Horton officiated.

title: Bush's Limited Victory
description: They were no clarion calls to battle, but today's Congressional votes were probably enough for President Bush to take the country to war, provided it is the short, sharp conflict he has envisaged.

title: Headliners; Life in the Balance
description: In recent years the "right to die" has been sought by growing numbers of people on behalf of irreversibly comatose relatives. Now, for the first time, it appears, a hospital is preparing to ask the courts for permission to let a patient die against the wishes of the next of kin. The patient, 87-year-old Helga Wanglie, has lain with severe brain damage, unresponsive and tied to life support systems in Minnesota's Hennepin County Medical Center for eight months. Her husband, Oliver, does not dispute that she will never get better, but he insists on all efforts to keep her from getting worse. The doctors say that since they can do nothing to improve Mrs. Wanglie's life, they should cease to do anything. The doctors got the county commission's approval last week to take the matter to court. "This hospital has the technology to keep 50 Helga Wanglies alive for an indefinite period," said Dr. Michael B. Belzer, the medical director. "Just because we can do it, do we have to?"

title: The Late News From Afghanistan
description: THE HIDDEN WAR A Russian Journalist's Account of the Soviet War in Afghanistan. By Artyom Borovik. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/The Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95.

title: Welfare System Is 'Muddled,' Says New Commissioner
description: WHEN County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke introduced Mary E. Glass as the new Commissioner of Social Services earlier this month, he spoke of her as "an innovator, a leader, a compassionate administrator and disarming." In fact, he added, "She disarmed a person who brought a shotgun into a district office and has taken a few knives from clients."

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WEIR FARM;
Federal Protection Assures Inspiration For Future Artists
description: IN 1882, a promising artist swapped a painting, and possibly a few dollars, for an underused farm that he wanted to capture on canvas. Today, the farm remains much as it was when the artist, J. Alden Weir (1852-1919), painted there, eventually becoming a leader among American Impressionists. The gently rolling hills, woods and wetlands on the 62 acres in Wilton and Ridgefield seem to define a classic New England setting.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 13, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran, stationed in Sioux country, adopts the ways of the Indians. 2 21 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 3 * 35 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 4 6 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Ancient documents and arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 5 8 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes of his behavior. 6 16 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 7 3 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) Two Navajo tribal policemen pursue a mystery involving ceremonial masks. 8 13 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 9 1 MYSTERY, by Peter Straub. (Signet, $5.95.) A bright young man and an elderly eccentric join hands to solve a murder that haunts them both. 10 12 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former prosecutor defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 11 13 THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $5.95.) Espionage changes its ways as glasnost begins to rust the Iron Curtain. 12 * 11 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 13 4 SLEEPWALK, by John Saul. (Bantam, $5.95.) A madman with terrifying powers haunts the teen-agers of a quiet New Mexican desert town. 14 * 30 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 15 * 1 SPY LINE, by Len Deighton. (Ballantine, $5.95.) To salvage his reputation, the British agent Bernard Samson undertakes a hazardous mission in Vienna. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 60 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 27 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $7.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat that adopted and soon owned him. 3 7 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Cliff Stoll. (Pocket, $5.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker. 4 22 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict as observed by a New York Times correspondent over the past decade. 5 377 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 6 7 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Lynn Goldsmith. (Kodak/Rizzoli, $24.95.) Three months in the lives of the singing quintet, in photographs and words. 7 31 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 8 16 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. 9 6 EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.95.) The author recalls the places he visited and the books he read in his youth. 10 18 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian remembers her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 7 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 2 16 THE AUTHORITATIVE CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons from "Yukon Ho!" and "Weirdos From Another Planet!" 3 4 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1991. (World Almanac/Pharos, $6.95.) The latest edition of a standard reference work. 4 10 WIENER DOG ART, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) "Far Side" cartoons. 5 12 THE "LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN" BOOK OF TOP TEN LISTS, by David Letterman, Steve O'Donnell, et al. (Pocket, $8.95.) Humor. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Garbage Company Faces Charges Of Illegal Medical-Waste Storage
description: The owners of a garbage-carting company in Port Jervis, N.Y., have been indicted on charges of illegally storing more than 160,000 pounds of blood vials, fluid samples, used hypodermic needles and other medical waste.

title: Regina Rehkamp Weds J. J. Ketting
description: Regina Alma Rehkamp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George John Rehkamp of Mill Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Jaap Jan Ketting, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaap Ketting of Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald E. Murray performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Dominic Chapel in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Praising Good Deeds Over Dinner
description: A series of sitdown dinners celebrated the deeds of men in the week after the holidays. On Thursday Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Rupert Murdoch received the United Cerebral Palsy Humanitarian Awards at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Text of Letter from Bush to Hussein
description: At their meeting in Geneva on Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, a letter to be passed on to President Saddam Hussein. Mr. Aziz read the letter and then refused to accept it, saying its tone was inappropriate.

title: Which Book Review Do You Get?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parks That Preserve the Old Hawaii
description: MILES -- and sometimes centuries, it seems -- from the posh resorts with swimming pools measured in fractions of an acre, which have been rising near almost every sandy beach in the state recently, another Hawaii is surviving, preserved by state and Federal park agencies.

title: Currency; The Dollar Gains On Pound, Mark
Devils' Slump Hits 5 Losses in a Row
description: Frankness is one of John Cunniff's characteristics. When being interviewed, the coach of the Devils always speaks his mind and looks reporters in the eye while answering the type of unpleasant questions that arise during a losing streak.

title: Preparing for 911: Is There a House Number?
description: MUNICIPAL officials, with help from the county, have begun the massive chore of identifying every home and business in Westchester to bring a long-awaited E-911 emergency response system to the county by late 1992 or early 1993.

title: In Defense of Peat Marwick and Reputation
description: To The Editor:

title: A Wrong Turn in Connecticut
description: A CHANGE OF LUCKBy Julia Markus.305 pp. New York:Viking. $18.95.

title: 35 Die in South Africa Township Attack
description: Gunmen stepping from the shadows fired automatic weapons at mourners during a vigil for a slain African National Congress youth organizer early today, killing at least 35 people and wounding 40.

title: Trenary Ailing
description: An ankle infection has cost the women's world figure skating champion, Jill Trenary, the chance to defend her United States title next month and may keep her out of the world championships in March.

title: Stamford Gets Another Indian Restaurant
description: A GROWING interest in spicy food has led to the emergence of three Indian restaurants in Stamford alone. The latest to arrive is Gandhi, in Ridgeway Shopping Center space that was formerly occupied by Bonani (which has moved farther downtown, on Summer Street). Gandhi, a storefront restaurant has kept Bonani's Indian motifs and has created the illusion of spaciousness by using smaller tables.

title: New Admirers Attracted to a Historic Building in Canterbury
description: THE Prudence Crandall House in Canterbury is rarely overwhelmed by tourist crowds. But since the publication last spring of a book entitled "A Whole-Souled Woman: Prudence Crandall and the Education of Black Women" (W. W. Norton), the number of visitors has steadily increased.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; Playing Congress: Much Tougher Than It Looks
description: Seated in ascending rows of horseshoe tables and surrounded by soft-drink cans, coffee mugs and mounds of paper, 47 first-year graduate students at Princeton University played Congress and hammered out a budget package days before classes ended for winter break last month.

title: Style Makers; Norma May, Accessories Specialist
description: Women are traveling with fewer dresses and more accessories, Norma May has found. So she is phasing out the dresses and other apparel she used to carry in the New York shop she calls Norma May's Gallery of Collectibles.

title: Ellen Lipp Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Lipp of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Ellen Wells Lipp and Edward Henry Sherk Jr., a son of Mrs. Edward H. Sherk of Wyndmoor, Pa., and the late Mr. Sherk. Miss Lipp graduated from Colorado State University and the Art Institute of Philadelphia. She is a graphic designer at Adams Graphics in Philadelphia. Mr. Sherk, a graduate of Pennsylvania State University, is a sales manager for R. Kaller & Sons Energy Miser Windows in Conshohocken, Pa.

title: Harm to Saudi Oilfields Seen as Limited in War
description: Saudi Arabia's oilfields, refineries and pipelines are well protected and would probably suffer little damage in a Persian Gulf war, military and oil industry analysts say.

title: Works In Progress
description: To the Editor: I was fascinated by Mark Dery's article regarding "culture jammers" [ "The Merry Pranksters and the Art of the Hoax," Dec. 23 ] . But conspicuous by its absence was any reference to my own group of Merry Pranksters, who regularly infiltrate the media with satirical headline stories that are patently false.

title: Travel Advisory; Airport Hotels Open in London
description: The Heathrow Sterling, the only hotel at Heathrow Airport in London adjacent to a terminal, was opened last month. A covered walkway links the hotel to Terminal 4, used principally for British Airways flights. . The 400-room hotel has four ground-floor rooms designed specifically for people with mobility difficulties. Rates: $230, double; reservations: (81) 759 7755.

title: Kremlin Talked Peace While Preparing Raid
description: Preparations for the early-morning Soviet Army tank attack that left scores of casualties in Lithuania apparently were being made Saturday in Vilnius even as Kremlin officials here were promising a fresh attempt at a "political settlement" through the Federation Council.

title: Race No Excuse For Miami
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Incredible Shrinking Career of a Pop Star
description: No one ever became a musician for the job security -- at least, no one with a glimmer of sanity. But in recent years, it seems the length of the average pop career has dwindled fast. The 1980's and 1990 brought record sales to new peaks while the performers themselves tended to flash and burn out.

title: Brave New Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Brakman To Wed in May
description: May wedding plans for Sarah Vaughan Brakman and Dr. James Maurice Youakim have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Brakman Jr. of Brookville, L.I. Dr. Youakim is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice I. Youakim of Tampa, Fla.

title: A Final Pause
description: With Congress now backing force to oust Iraq from Kuwait, President Bush has a decent chance to win without fighting.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Old Lines, Old Phones

title: F.A.A., as Expected, Orders Inspection of DC-9 Rear Exits
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, responding to concerns that two lives may have been lost because of a jammed emergency rear exit on a burning jetliner at Detroit last month, has ordered the immediate inspection of tailcone exits on hundreds of DC-9 aircraft.

title: Aching In Australia
description: On the eve of the Australian Open, the first of the year's four Grand Slam tennis events, medical reports are taking precedence over analysis of the game.

title: Wurzburg's Grand Palace
description: GERMANY in the 18th century was divided into more than 300 states, and their rulers -- Margraves and Palgraves, Electoral Highnesses and Prince-Bishops -- depended on splendor for recognition. A grand palace, of course, made the point most visibly. Building one required wealth and ambition. As it happily developed, both these conditions were amply met in Wurzburg.

title: The World; For the Europeans, Worry That War Could Hit Home
description: IF the United States decides to force Iraq out of Kuwait, Western European governments will have no choice but to support the action. They have all endorsed the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for an Iraqi pullout, Britain and France have significant troop contingents in Saudi Arabia, and most others have sent warships or aircraft into the gulf region.

title: Creating a Theater of Different American Voices
description: "I hate the word sexism," says Emily Mann, stubbing out a cigarette in a Manhattan cafe. "But as a director you produce what you need to produce, and in this country there is a feeling that people don't want to hear stories about women. But I'm an optimist. Things can change. And with more and more women running arts institutions -- yes, they are -- I think you can stage all kinds of stories."

title: Wrong Message For a Generation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nets Drop 9th In Row
description: The Philadelphia 76ers played without Charles Barkley tonight. They played without Hersey Hawkins, too. But they were playing the Nets, so it didn't matter.

title: Kathryn Wikman Wed to Bart Wu
description: Kathryn Wikman and Peter Bartlett Wu were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York by the Rev. Kenneth O. Jones. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Wikman of Freeport, L.I. The bridegroom, who is known as Bart, is the son of Arlouine Goodjohn Wu of New York and the late King-Mau Wu. The couple are vice presidents, and Mr. Wu is also a senior associate counsel, of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. Mrs. Wu graduated from Molloy College and received a master's degree in English from Hofstra University and a law degree from Fordham University, where she was the editor in chief of The Urban Law Journal. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Her father is a carpenter. Her mother, Ann Wikman, is a secretary at Delta Airlines in New York.

title: CONGRESS ACTS TO AUTHORIZE WAR IN GULF; MARGINS ARE 5 VOTES IN SENATE, 67 IN HOUSE
description: After three days of solemn, often eloquent debate, Congress today voted to give President Bush the authority to go to war against Iraq.

title: U.N. Chief in Baghdad With Proposals
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, arrived here tonight carrying what an aide described as "substantive" proposals to prevent the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf as the last major evacuation of foreign diplomats flew out of the country at midday on an American-chartered Iraqi Airways flight.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Winter Is a Foreign Land Winter doesn't simply alter a landscape: it transforms it into an unknown country. This is from Patricia Hampl's essay "Italian Two-Part Invention," included in "The House on Via Gombito: Writing by North American Women Abroad," edited by Madelon Sprengnether and C. W. Truesdale (New Rivers Press, 420 North Fifth Street, Minneapolis, Minn. 55401, paper).

title: Acting Troupe Makes Words Visible
description: THE National Theater of the Deaf gives its audience a chance to appreciate language in a new dimension. The troupe, based in Chester, is composed of both deaf and hearing actors, who synchronize sign language and spoken narration, so every word is both seen and heard.

title: Track and Field; Johnson Is Shaky In Return to Racing
description: Just about everything that could have gone wrong did. Ben Johnson was slow getting out of the starting blocks. He tightened a bit when he needed maximum acceleration, and he misjudged the finish, leaning at a line on the track 50 yards from the start, rather than one marking the true end of the race, a stride away at 50 meters.

title: Whose Life Is This, Anyway?
description: I was a student of Richard Ellmann's at Oxford in the early 1970's, and spent many afternoons in his gloomy, cavernous study at New College, working my slow way through "Finnegans Wake." Lost in the maze of Joyce's hermetic "night language," I would stare at the row of pale-green Dublin phone books on the shelf behind Ellmann's desk and speculate about what made him so . . . Joycean. Outwardly the eminent biographer of Joyce could hardly have been more different from his subject. Joyce was, in his own words, "a small man, prone to alcoholism"; Ellmann was a moderate drinker and a rather bulky man, with a balding brow and a flat Midwestern accent that years of dining at High Table with murmurous Oxford dons had failed to mitigate. Maybe it was his effortless fidelity to his own nature that made him such a shrewd interpreter of others. Ellmann treated his subjects -- William Butler Yeats, James Joyce, Oscar Wilde -- with a benign, avuncular tolerance. He noted, and forgave, their failings. Even the title of his biographical essays on the major modernists, "Golden Codgers" -- the phrase is from Yeats -- reflected his affection for the writers to whom he devoted his life. Ellmann was drawn to genius, yet was himself an ordinary man -- the Leopold Bloom of biography.

title: Retirees Find They Need to Return To Work, but the Outlook Is Dim
description: BOB REINHARDT, 64 years old, of Stony Brook, worked for a telephone company for nearly 40 years. For 17 of those years, he was a district manager.

title: Chess
description: If someone were to advise, "Beware of forcing moves," most players would think that only the opponent's forcing moves were meant. But your own forcing moves can sometimes create psychological havoc in your thinking.

title: Style Makers; Roger Sadowsky, Guitar Maker
description: From the Broadway orchestra pits to Los Angeles music studios to the tours of Paul Simon, Prince and the Rolling Stones, one name stands out: Sadowsky.

title: Design Your Own Games, Monopoly Rivals Told
description: In what could be characterized as an anti-antitrust action, the makers of Monopoly, the board game, have filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeking to maintain their monopoly on their famous game board.

title: Hers; Our Toys Are Us
description: At 9 o'clock this morning, my son, age 4, was still sound asleep in his Ghostbusters sleeping bag. He was wearing Superman pj's. In one fist he was clutching a food fighter -- Major Munch, I think. His Dino-Riders, with motorized walking action and full battle accessories, were waiting nearby. So the first thing he would see when he woke up would be the scaly faces of accurate models of the extinct giant lizards of prehistory, framed colorfully with plastic brain-packs and laser cannons.

title: Beneath a Calmer Exterior, Ditka's Still Iron Mike
description: Mike Ditka holds his press conferences in a basement classroom, directly below a Halas Hall weight room, where his Chicago Bears train their muscles with heavy metal.

title: A Bad Week for the President
description: THE FOURTH K By Mario Puzo. 479 pp. New York: Random House. $22.

title: 49ers and Bills Roar Into Conference Finals
description: When a team tackles the two-time defending Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers, it must be prepared to fight fire with fire. The 49ers shoot bullets. Their opponents, especially in post-season play, usually fire blanks.

title: Sunday Menu; Seasoning and Peppers With Grilled Lamb
description: The seasoning mix suggested for these grilled loin lamb chops is equally good on any cut of lamb. And the spices that season the lamb contrast nicely with the sweetness of sauteed peppers.

title: U.S. Soccer Team To Play in Tampa
