description: The United States national soccer team will face the South American club champion, Olimpia of Paraguay, in an exhibition match on March 9 in Tampa Stadium.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Jazz, in the Pantheon
description: Jazz is American. It is the only musical art form to which this country can lay exclusive claim. Built on improvisation, jazz has profoundly influenced dance, painting and other arts, and has exerted wide international appeal for most of this century.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Renovating a Mall to Stay Competitive
description: BUILT as an open-air shopping center in the 1960's and enclosed in the 70's, the 73-acre Menlo Park Mall on Route 1 in Edison has lost much of its luster and customer appeal over the years. Now, to remain competitive, it is undergoing a more than $100 million redevelopment and expansion.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: A Very Model of a Modern Major Mini-Series
description: Turning 20 this month, public television's "Masterpiece Theater" will be feted from coast to coast, more or less, with elaborate tributes planned in Los Angeles and Washington. Hearty congratulations are certainly in order.

title: When Shakespeare Joins the Science Class
description: BARBARA NADOLNY sets the stage for her general science and biology classes at Morristown High School with abundant examples of plant, animal and mineral life. Silhouettes of hawks and other birds, a set of antlers, a shell collection, a profusion of lush tropical plants and brightly colored posters and charts, along with the usual assortment of glass beakers in cabinets, identify Room 354 as the home of the "hawk lady."

title: Roll Call in the House on Resolution Authorizing Use of Force
description: Following is the 250-to-183 roll call today by which the House gave President Bush the authority to wage war in the Persian Gulf. A yes vote is a vote to authorize the use of U.S. armed forces pursuant to U.N. Security Council Resolution 678. Voting yes were 86 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting no were 179 Democrats and 3 Republicans. Also voting no was 1 Independent. X denotes those not voting.Present denotes those who voted they were "present" at the time of the vote but did not vote "yes" or "no" on the issue.

title: Pamela Schargel to Marry
description: May wedding plans for Pamela Beth Schargel and John Beaton Montgomery 2d have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sol Schargel of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Mr. Montgomery is the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Montgomery of Providence, R.I. Miss Schargel, 28 years old, and Mr. Montgomery, 27, are graduates of the University of Rhode Island. She is a freelance visual-display artist and he is a financial consultant at Shearson Lehman Brothers, both in New York.

title: THE RUSH HOURS
description: Limbaugh is not some latter-day Will Rogers. He is, instead, a brilliant but vicious and dangerous individual who abuses his own intelligence and the freedoms afforded him under our democratic system for his personal aggrandizement. His humor is not satire, but very cruel ridicule.

title: Ex-Newark Aide Faces Prison
description: A former Newark housing official faces up to 15 years in prison and $750,000 in fines after he pleaded no contest on Friday to three charges of mail fraud. He is to be sentenced on March 18. Four of the seven charges against the official, Oscar James, were dismissed, including an accusation that he embezzled $5,000 in Newark funds while he was executive assistant to the city Director of General Services. Mr. James, 33 years old, of Newark, was accused of having city carpenters and an electrician use city supplies to repair an apartment of a city secretary with whom he had a daughter.

title: Tunes From Arlen to Kern, Mermaids in Clamshells
description: MARY is a Midwestern farm girl. Mitzi is a telephone operator from Brooklyn. Madeline is a Main Line debutante from Philadelphia. What they have in common is a dull life (Mary sings that her's is "an udder bore,"), a dream (to get into the Ziegfeld Follies) and a destination (Broadway).

title: Keeping Pipes Unfrozen
description: FROZEN plumbing can be one of winter's worst household disasters. Water freezing inside pipes expands, creating pressure powerful enough to rupture joints where sections of pipes meet and sometimes even bursting the pipes.

title: Business Education and Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Mamaroneck Selects a Motel Plan
description: A MAMARONECK TOWN project to replace a former motel for the homeless with 58 to 60 affordable apartments is nearly set now, with the selection of a plan proposed in a joint venture by the Per Bar Realty Corporation and Caramar Construction Corporation, longtime Elmsford-based companies.

title: Why a Cashless Society Wouldn't Work; Shades of Technocracy
description: To the Editor:

title: For Men, Underwear Is Turning Inside Out
description: Men's underwear is not what it used to be.

title: Carolyn Cornell To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Cornell of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Curley Cornell, to Paul - Stephen Donohue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Donohue of East Williston and Sag Harbor, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Headliners; Jazz at the Center
description: Lincoln Center, a bastion of classical music, has been been permanently stormed by the likes of Duke Ellington, John Coltrane and Louis Armstrong. Announcing the addition of a jazz department that is expected within a few years to become a full-fledged constituent on a level with the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, center officials named a 32-year-old Atlantan, Rob Gibson, as the new division's executive director. Mr. Gibson, the director of the Atlanta Jazz Festival, intends to include in his programming weekend tributes showcasing the careers of notable musicians. Within 5 to 10 years, Mr. Gibson said, he hopes to be presenting three nights of jazz every weekend, like the Philharmonic. "I think people will be very pleased by the fact that we're giving recognition to jazz, and that jazz has a place at Lincoln Center," said Nathan Leventhal, the president of the center. "If I'm wrong, if it turns out that we fall on our faces and there's no funding, then obviously we have to rethink the issue."

title: Primary Credit Goes To 49ers' Secondary
description: When he was done explaining the intricacies of the play that may have saved the day for the San Francisco 49ers, Johnny Jackson stopped, looked up slowly at a questioner and finally smiled.

title: Ex-Builder Trades Bulldozer for a Brush
description: THE Marine Raider Museum in Richmond, Va., will honor some of its own next month. Oil paintings of four prominent Marine Raider commanders -- Evans F. Carlson, Merritt A. Edson, Harry B. Liversedge and Alan Shapley -- will be unveiled at the museum before becoming part of its permanent collection.

title: Day 3: Remarks in Congress During the Last Hours of Debate
description: Following are excerpts from the debate in Congress Friday night and today on President Bush's request for support for military action in the Persian Gulf, as transcribed by The New York Times: Senator Robert C. Byrd Democrat of West Virginia

title: Casinos Working On Their 'Mission'
description: The optimistic tone of the recent article "Hopes for Casinos Buoyed by 'Savior' " is appreciated by those of us who are deeply interested in Atlantic City's future.

title: Four Generations in the Projects
description: In Chicago the fates have avenged themselves on the fighting liberals of the first half of the 20th century. Their names live on in the titles of the city's most infamous public housing projects. Ida B. Wells, Henry Horner, Harold L. Ickes, Jane Addams, John Peter Altgeld -- all instantly call to mind stories of children falling out of windows, broken heating that never gets fixed and gun battles between teen-age gangs. The most memorialized liberal of all was Robert R. Taylor, the first black chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority; the Robert Taylor Homes are Chicago's (and America's) biggest project, 28 16-story brick buildings laid out in a narrow two-mile strip, housing more than 25,000 people.

title: Prophets of War; Men Plan; Battle Has a Mind of Its Own
description: IT was a week of high drama and, for many, a passage of painful uncertainty. But as the deadline decreed by the United Nations for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait drew ever closer -- so close that the time remaining could be counted in hours -- there were some, convinced that war was imminent, who thought they could foresee the shape of the conflict.

title: Jenny A. Kletzin, An Editor, Weds
description: Jenny Augusta Kletzin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen B. Kletzin of Jamestown, N.C., was married yesterday in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y., to Thomas Aquinas DiBiase, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. DiBiase of Bedford. Msgr. Thomas A. Gartland performed the ceremony.

title: The Incessant Lure of Kuwait's Oil
description: Kuwaiti oil is, after all, the immediate prize of the Persian Gulf crisis. But the oil was never supposed to be there. The world's great experts insisted that Kuwait would be dry of it, and the timing of its discovery was the peculiar result of the obsessions of a mining engineer from New Zealand and a noodle vendor in Japan. Thereafter, the development and shifting ownership of Kuwaiti oil embody much of the story of world oil -- from the end of World War I to the ticking clock of the current conflict with Iraq.

title: First Openly Gay Legislator Brings a Full Agenda to Albany
description: As she was sworn in last week as the first openly gay member of the New York State Legislature, Deborah J. Glick raised her right hand and placed her left hand on a dogeared copy of her bible -- the 1970 feminist anthology "Sisterhood Is Powerful."

title: Ann-Marie Blake Weds Charles Hall
description: Ann-Marie Blake and Charles Edward Hall were married yesterday at Stouffer's Wailea Beach Resort in Maui, Hawaii, by the Rev. Piula Alailima, a Methodist minister.

title: School Bell Rings for Soviet Nurses
description: WHEN Galina Katz studied English in Odessa, it was for "one, maybe two hours a week," she recalled.

title:
FOCUS;
Philadelphia's Housing Program Picks Up Steam
description: After years of problems with its housing program, Philadelphia is enjoying greater success with a Federal tax-credit program to increase the rehabilitation of rental apartments for the poor. Created in 1986, the program has lured corporate and other private investors into the low-income housing market.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: 49ers and Bills Roar Into Conference Finals; Kelly Effective In His Return For Buffalo
description: Jim Kelly parted the snowflakes today in a sparkling return from a knee injury, and his three touchdown passes and timely running for the Bills won the battle of two hard-nosed quarterbacks from western Pennsylvania.

title: Q and A
description: Paying Off Liens Question: I am considering buying foreclosed property through public auction. I have noticed that some properties have mechanic's liens attached to them. If, for example, there is a mechanic's lien of $15,000 against a property and I have a winning bid of $10,000, would I have to come up with $25,000 to make the purchase? . . . Timothy Keane, Staten Island Answer: It would depend on the rules of the particular public auction.

title: About Those Computer Bulletin Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice for Characters, Real or Imagined
description: WRITERS, like actors, use their wits and emotions to give life to characters, who, if well drawn, will be commiserated with, worried about, loved -- or despised so much that their comeuppance is relished.

title: Flaubert Does Hollywood -- Again
description: With a hearty laugh that shook his rounded shoulders and interrupted his assault on a plateful of smoked salmon, Claude Chabrol readily admitted that he has directed one or two of the worst films ever made. His only defense, he insisted, is that he never passes off bad films as good. "I have made films fully aware of their mediocrity," the 60-year-old French director boasted good-naturedly.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PORTRAITS IN PRINT A Collection of Profiles and the Stories Behind Them. By Helen Benedict. Columbia University, $32.50.

title: Going Too Far
description: PRIZED POSSESSIONS By Avery Corman. 320 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster.

title: Carolyn Stanton To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Stanton of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Roy Stanton to Douglas J. Calnan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Calnan of Duxbury, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Style Makers; Gene London, Clothing Collector
description: Since Gene London first began collecting antique clothing 14 years ago, he has amassed a collection of over 60,000 items of museum-quality clothing and accessories, including furs, jewels, hats, fans and parasols. His collection ranges from gowns and capes of the 1870's to to the glamorous Diors, Givenchys, Schiaparellis and Balenciagas of the 1950's.

title: Touring Oahu by Bicycle
description: MY bike has just gotten a flat tire. I don't welcome the inconvenience of fixing it, but I can't complain about the job site: Sunset Beach, one of the crown jewels of Oahu's North Shore. It's a sparkling December day, and the atmosphere here is one of mellow anticipation: a couple of dozen surfers bobbing in the blue water, a couple of hundred onlookers waiting to see if they get any good waves.

title: The Exotic Gardens of Oahu
description: ASIDE from its splendid beaches, the most memorable feature of Hawaii for visitors from less benign climates is perhaps the extraordinary variety of its tropical plant life. What many may fail to realize is that every single element of this botanical luxuriance came from somewhere else and that most of the more celebrated ornamentals arrived within the past 200 years.

title: For 'Nunsense,' Irreverence Pays Long-Term Dividends
description: It might be argued that a sex change is among the reasons for the success of the Off Broadway musical "Nunsense," which played its 2,096th performance at the Douglas Fairbanks on Theater Row last Sunday.

title: Social Events
description: Human Rights Anniversary

title: Andrea Sernatinger Is Wed
description: Andrea Julianna Sernatinger, a daughter of Robert A. Sernatinger and a stepdaughter of Diane Sernatinger of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Bennington, Vt., to Gilbert Kipp Good 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Good 2d of Palm Harbor, Fla. The Rev. Charles Fox officiated. The couple, both 25 years old, are graduates of Gettysburg College. She is a research assistant at S. G. Warburg & Company, stockbrokers and investment bankers, and he is a marketing analyst for Prudential Mutual Fund Management, both in New York.

title: THE RUSH HOURS
description: Limbaugh is the best argument yet for the restoration of the "fairness doctrine." His long-winded, right-wing preachments are for the already converted.

title: Man Shot to Death Outside A Nightclub He Worked At
description: A maintenance man for a comedy club on the Upper East Side was shot to death on Friday afternoon during a robbery on the street in front of the club, the police said.

title: Against Trend, Health-Care Jobs Rise
description: While hundreds of thousands of workers are being laid off around the country, employment in the health-care industry is booming.

title: Epidemic
description: To the Editor: While perusing my Sunday Times on Dec. 23, I twice encountered the term "politically correct." An Arts and Leisure letter writer told of attending a "politically correct dinner party" at which she was ostracized because she found Mapplethorpe's photographs artistically flawed. The other reference, in the Style section, concerned a professor of anthropology at Berkeley [ "Campus Is Split Over Statements by a Professor" ] .

title: 'An American Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Irritable Friend
description: THE JAPAN THAT CAN SAY NO By Shintaro Ishihara. Translated by Frank Baldwin. 158 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Shaping Ergonomics to the Computer Age
description: ROBERT F. BETTENDORF has no quarrel with the United States Department of Labor when it says that cases of repetitive motion disorders in the workplace have greatly increased. But he contends that the problem is not an ominous byproduct of the computer age.

title: Frugging With Wolves
description: In his epic, entertaining and wildly successful "Dances With Wolves," Kevin Costner plays the most blissed-out Civil War soldier ever to face the frontier. As Lieut. John Dunbar, he is a Union officer who at first finds himself alone in Indian territory in the 1860's, and eventually "finds himself," in the 1960's sense of the term, when he adopts a Sioux identity and name, Dances With Wolves. "As I heard my Sioux name being called," he says, "I knew for the first time who I really was."

title: Why a Cashless Society Wouldn't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Gravy Train May Have Left the Station
description: An American League general manager recently considered the cascade of multimillion-dollar contracts showered on free agents this off season and said, "I'm just curious to see what the last 40 will do when there's no money left."

title: Raul Ricardo Ardito Barletta, Banker, Is Married to Jacqueline Anne Blau
description: Jacqueline Anne Blau and Raul Ricardo Ardito Barletta were married yesterday in Washington at St. Alban's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Bruce Jenneker. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Jose Blau of Buenos Aires. Mr. Ardito Barletta is a son of Martii Preston Barletta of Southport, N.C., and Nicholas Ardito Barletta of Panama.

title: Pro Football; Bears and Giants: Nothing Fancy
description: A half-century ago, when the Chicago Bears were the Monsters of the Midway, their games against the Giants were physical and brutal. On Sunday, when the Bears meet the Giants at 12:30 P.M. in Giants Stadium, it should be more of the same.

title: Backward Glances at the Russian Avant-Garde
description: It has been barely 20 years since the public and critics in the West have rediscovered (discovered is the more apt term) the avant-garde in the arts that produced so much ferment and experimentation in Russia from World War I through the 1920's.

title: A Poet's Pure Music Enhanced
description: Heinrich Heine was the most important of Robert Schumann's song-poets, and the Schumann-Heine songs have a bittersweet flavor unique in the banquet of the German lied. They are permanently important and, at the moment, newly prominent in record releases. Of course it is primarily the composer's work that makes a song significant and engages its interpreters -- but after listening to several new recordings and missing, much of the time, that special tang, I want to say a little about Heine.

Hicksville, L.I. 179,000 107 Cortland Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, patio; taxes $2,700.

title: Trendy Storefront Dining in Massapequa
description: OUTSIDE, the neon sign proclaims Twenty Three Broadway. Inside, the menu says, "Where Manhattan Comes to Massapequa." The decor at this trendy storefront is city slick. A wall of smoky mirrors reflects the Art Deco-inspired Giancarlo Impiglia posters, glass-topped tables, fresh flowers and flickering oil lamps.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JAMES A. RATIGAN;
Giving Course Credit for Life Experience
description: WHEN James A. Ratigan came to Thomas A. Edison State College in 1974 as an academic counselor, he didn't plan to stay long. Mr. Ratigan, who had previously taught philosophy at several colleges and universities, including Georgetown University, said, "It was hardly the place where I thought I'd be interested in making a career." But working at Edison, a nationally recognized pioneer in higher education for adults, proved more stimulating than he had anticipated.

description: Bellmore 136,000 100 Herkimer Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 50- year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, detached 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Hicksville 179,000 107 Cortland Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, patio; taxes $2,700. South Orange, L.I. 169,900 32 University Court 4-bedroom, 1 1/4-bath, 47-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, den, fireplace; taxes $4,052.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CONCISE COLUMBIA BOOK OF POETRY Edited by William Harmon. Columbia University, $39.95.

title: Listening for A Scary Word: Depression
description: War and peace caught traders' attention last week, but the growing evidence of a deteriorating economy may yet have a bigger impact on securities prices.

title: You Are What You Retrieve
description: TELL ME A STORY A New Look at Real and Artificial Memory. By Roger C. Schank. 253 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: The Dining Out column on Dec. 30, listing the critic's favorite Westchester restaurants of 1990, misstated the telephone number of Auberge Maxime in North Salem. Its number is 669-5450.

title: Travel Advisory; Tour for Deaf
description: Contiki Holidays, which specializes in tours for travelers aged 18 to 35, is offering a departure of its 19-day European Encounter tour particularly for deaf people and their hearing friends. The trip, departing July 26, will be accompanied by two signing interpreters. Beginning in London, the tour goes to Amsterdam, then by bus to Germany, Switzerland, Austria, Italy and France. Price per person, in double occupancy, is $1,470, including hotels and some meals, but not air fare. Contiki Holidays, 1432 East Katella Avenue, Anaheim, Calif. 92805; (800) 626-0611.

title: Travel Advisory; Folk Arts In Bangladesh
description: Travelers in South Asia, a region rich in handicrafts, can easily overlook the intriguing folk arts of Bangladesh, a small country not on the tourist map.

title: Wanted: Art Scholar, M.B.A. Required
description: When Jack Lane took over as director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art three years ago, one of the first things he did was shut his office door. "The previous director's door was open to everyone who wanted to talk to him," Mr. Lane explains. "That just seemed unworkable. I wanted to clarify the chain of command, so we divided the museum into four major areas, and the heads of those areas report directly to me."

title: Crowds in European Cities Protest a War in Gulf Area
description: Mobilized by leftist, environmental, pacifist and trade union groups, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets of major West European cities today to demand that force not be used against Iraq in Kuwait.

title: THE RUSH HOURS
description: Limbaugh claims he is doing "legitimate political satire." I've always believed the true political satirist tilts his satirical lance not at society's underdogs, but at its most powerful and influential figures and institutions. Limbaugh's targets are the homeless and their advocates, minorities and the "NOW crowd." This is hardly a satirical hit list with which a modern-day Swift or Twain could identify.

title: INSIDE
description: 35 Slain in South Africa Gunmen fired automatic weapons at mourners during a vigil for a slain African National Congress youth organizer, killing at least 35. It was the worst incident of violence in the black townships in recent months. Page 3. Atwater: Regrets and Fears In a candid magazine interview, the Republican chairman apologized again for some negative campaigning and told of his desperation over his inoperable brain tumor. Page 16. Clouds at Weather Service A $3 billion program to upgrade the National Weather Service is far behind schedule, a development thatcould jeoparidze the agency's ability to predict dangerous storms. Page 16. Help Wanted While hundreds of thousands of workers are being laid off around the nation, employment is booming in the health-care industry. Page 19. title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: INTERIM IN THE DESERTBy Roland Sodowsky.Texas Christian University, $19.95.

title: Data Update
GARDENING Tips for Taking Care of Greenery in Pots
description: ALMOST everyone has a plant or two in a pot. Even those who garden in apartments have a bit of greenery around them. And those who have big gardens have at least a few pots on their windowsills. Now that the season has changed, more time can be spent on taking care of these indoor plants.

title: Headliners; Criminal's Justice
description: Richard Demarest was sentenced to a Colorado state prison for murder, but nobody said he was stupid. Having become a passable jailhouse lawyer while doing his time, Mr. Demarest took immediate note of the Government's failure to compensate him in 1989, when he spent 10 days traveling to and from and testifying in a Denver Federal court, where he was called as a defense witness in a criminal trial. Federal law requires the payment of a fee, currently $30 a day, to any witness appearing in any Federal court. The law does not exclude Federal prisoners, but Federal policy did. So Mr. Demarest, working without legal assistance, took the matter to court. Last week, the United States Supreme Court found in his favor. The letter of the law was unambiguous, said Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, and it could not be assumed that "the payment of witness fees is so bizarre that Congress could not have intended it." Mr. Demarest, who has 12 years to serve before he is eligible for parole, will get $300 in fees.

title: Endangered Species In Halls of Hartford: Legislative Veterans
description: STATE Representative John J. Tiffany 2d, a Republican from Lyme, recalls that when he was first elected to the legislature in 1962, several politicians at the Capitol had 20 or 30 years' experience in Hartford. But after last week's departure of Gov. William A. O'Neill and Lt. Gov. Joseph Fauliso, with a half-century in state government between them, Mr. Tiffany is one of only two elected officials left from the 1960's. The other is State Senator George R. Gunther, Republican of Stratford.

title: Virginia Is Winner In Record Shootout
description: The largest crowd ever to watch an Atlantic Coast Conference women's basketball game turned out at North Carolina State's Reynolds Coliseum today. And by the time the 11,520 fans had filed from the building, two National Collegiate Athletic Association women's records had fallen and second-ranked Virginia had survived three overtimes to down the third-ranked Wolfpack, 123-120.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today, headed "First Hearing," gives incorrect dates in some copies for an appearance by the New York Chamber Symphony. It is at the 92d Street Y at 3 P.M. today, not next Saturday and Sunday.

title: Jacqueline Jacobs, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Jacqueline Anne Jacobs and Michael Grundei, lawyers in New York, were married last evening at the Westbury in New York by Rabbi Mark N. Goldman.

title: When Artists Turn Their Hands to Creating Greeting Cards
description: FOR the cover of its December issue, The New Republic appropriated Munch's "The Cry," a painting in which a figure stands on a bridge, screaming. The composition remains the same but the figure (said to be of the artist himself) has acquired a Santa Claus suit and the title has been changed to "The Horror of Christmas."

title: Official China Mostly Hears A Party Line
description: A Chinese official was expounding the other day on the glories of the present hard-line Government as his two lieutenants sat beside him, nodding solemnly as if they agreed with everything he said.

title: Miss Metz to Wed John F. Simons 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Thornton Metz of Sharon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lauren Harding Metz to John Farr Simons 3d, the son of Lois Ann Glasgow of Fort Washington, Pa., and the late Mr. Simons Jr. A June wedding is planned.

title: State's Cavalry Upholds a Proud Tradition
description: ALLERGIES clogged Pvt. Dawn Hafner's lungs and made grooming a horse intolerable. So she did what any upstanding cavalry soldier would do. She bought a gas mask.

title: Raiders Prepare For Worst
description: The Los Angeles Raiders still aren't sure whether Sam Wyche had his fingers crossed this week, but they figure to find out soon enough. From experience, the Raiders know well that Wyche, the Cincinnati Bengals' coach, sometimes fibs about things like injuries, so they went ahead and prepared for the worst.

title: Streetscapes: 121 Madison Avenue; Designed as a Co-op And Dating to 1883
description: IT has distinction of the footnote variety: 121 Madison Avenue, at the northeast corner of 30th Street, is the oldest structure in New York designed as a cooperative.

title: Janet Johnson and Allan Chapin Marry
description: Janet Margaret Johnson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth P. Johnson of Delaware Township, N.J., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York to Allan Melville Chapin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville Chapin of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: State Limits On Bass Size Are Fought By Baymen
description: ARE new state regulations intended to protect various species of fish actually contributing to their demise -- and to the problems of commercial fishermen who depend on them?

title: The Winter Antiques Show
description: The winter antiques Show -- long the nation's most prestigious and profitable antiques fair -- will be dramatically different when it opens later this month at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan.

title: The World; Saudi and Proud of It: A New Nationalism Hedged by Uneasiness
description: THE countdown to the United Nations deadline authorizing force to evict Iraq from Kuwait has become ritualized here. Each day this month, The Arab News, the kingdom's largest English-language newspaper, has featured a calendar with Jan. 15 circled and the number of days remaining until "K-Day" duly noted.

title: Laura Miller to Wed Michael Bland in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ludlow Miller of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Swan Miller to Michael Garrett Bland, the son of Evelyn B. Bland of Midlothian, Va., and Waddy G. Bland of Richmond. A June wedding is planned.

title: Stamps
description: The Stamps column on Dec. 16 reported a plaint of several non-Christian readers that finding a stamp to use on seasonal greetings other than Christmas cards was nigh impossible. One reader suggested a Hanukkah stamp, which would presumably depict a menorah; another suggested a generic Happy New Year stamp, similar to the Greetings stamps of 1987 and 1988.

title: Bush Suggests Iraqis Might Prevent Attack by Starting to Withdraw
description: President Bush said today that he was inclined to order military action against Iraq "sooner rather than later," but suggested that he might hold back if President Saddam Hussein began a large-scale withdrawal from occupied Kuwait before Tuesday.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Harry J. Hartley; Cheers and Problems for UConn President
description: HARRY J. HARTLEY was chosen last month from 117 candidates to be the 12th president of the University of Connecticut. A 52-year-old native of Pennsylvania who has spent his entire career in public higher education, Dr. Hartley came to UConn in 1972 as a professor of educational finance, served the school three years as dean of the School of Education and seven years as vice president for finance and administration.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: MNC Financial Inc. faces deadlines today and Tuesday for repaying loans from other banks. TUESDAY: Deadline for NCR shareholders to tender their shares to A.T.& T. * Retail sales for December. * National Labor Relations Board hearing in Milwaukee on union complaints about Greyhound Bus Lines's negotiating tactics during the 10-month drivers strike. * Ten-day auto sales for early January. WEDNESDAY: Consumer prices, industrial production and capacity utilization for December. * Business inventories for November. THURSDAY: Housing starts for December. * U.S. District Court hearing in Dallas on an injunction against sickouts and other job actions by American Airlines pilots. FRIDAY: Merchandise trade deficit for November.

title: Dead Reckoning: From Obituary to Art
description: A visitor to the Marian Goodman Gallery in Manhattan until the end of this week will encounter the mundane but affecting props in the theater of the French artist Christian Boltanski. Across one long wall of the West 57th Street gallery and from floor to ceiling hang 174 black-and-white photographs, arranged neatly in rows. The photographs depict faces, young and old, mostly smiling, which Boltanski has clipped from the obituary pages of a Swiss newspaper. He has enlarged and rephotographed the images, and in the process they have become blurred so that the faces take on a grainy, cadaverous cast.

title: Unclear Message?
description: To the Editor: As Jon Pareles's article " 'Radical' Rap: Of Pride and Prejudice" [ Dec. 16 ] makes clear, 'radical' rappers are successfully drumming repetitive "educational" messages into the minds of young black listeners.

title: Campus Life: U.S.C.; 2 Entrepreneurs Send Monopoly Off to College

Now Tommy is staring up at students from the cover of a Monopoly-style game board that is more than faintly reminiscent of the U.S.C. campus.

title: St. James's Street: Catering to Royalty
description: THE shops are like museums. Standing in the same location in London since the 18th and 19th centuries and still owned by some of the same families, they continue to sell shoes and hats, umbrellas and gloves, fragrances and wine and all manner of worldly and not so worldly goods in a setting that makes it hard to believe there is traffic outside once you have closed the door.

title: Gravely Ill, Atwater Offers Apology
description: In a detailed and candid article about his career and his fight against an inoperable brain tumor, Lee Atwater has apologized to Michael S. Dukakis for the "naked cruelty" of a remark he made about the Democratic Presidential nominee in the 1988 campaign.

title: The Wrong Nobel
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: The Mahwah Incentive; Sweetening the Deal With 'Cash Advances' to Buyers
description: Would-be home buyers who are having trouble raising cash for a move before selling their current home are being helped by East Crescent Developers of Cherry Hill, N.J. The company is expanding its Apple Ridge project in Mahwah and is offering what it calls "cash advances" to people who buy one of the new homes.

description: To the Editor:

title: A 'National Treasure' That Bops and Swings
description: THE Smithsonian Institution called it "a national treasure," and the jazz band leader and composer Benny Carter says "it's just a great orchestra." That's the American Jazz Orchestra, an ensemble of 18 virtuoso musicians led by John Lewis (of Modern Jazz Quartet fame) that is appearing at the Rye Performing Arts Center tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: The Winter's Tale, Part II
description: I was supposed to be a traveler's dream -- a December weekend in the English countryside visiting friends whose cottage nestled among the rolling hills of the Midlands. He is an old friend of my husband, Adrian, she the "serious other" he was anxious for us to meet. Even their names -- Nigel and Felicity -- stirred up thoughts of Noel Coward and drawing rooms with potted palms.

title: Nancy Ernst to Marry Robert Bowen Jr. in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Ernst of Neversink, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Nancy Ernst and Lieut. (j.g.) Robert Malcolm Bowen Jr., the son of Mr. Bowen of Princeton, N.J., and Mrs. James H. Jones of Fort Washington, Pa. Miss Ernst, 25 years old and a graduate of Sullivan County Community College, is a financial service associate at Great Western Bank in San Diego. Her father is an executive vice president of Norstar Bank in Newburgh, N.Y.

title: The Message, Stronger
description: Until yesterday, Saddam Hussein may have been unsure about the meaning of the debate in Washington over how to respond to Iraq's rape of Kuwait. Now that Congress has authorized President Bush to wage war in the Persian Gulf, Saddam Hussein cannot possibly misread America's message: Get out of Kuwait.

title: C. P. Foster Wed To Miss Pomeroy
description: Nancy Holt Pomeroy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burdette Pomeroy of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday in Chestnut Hill, Mass., to Christopher Pierpont Foster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Torrey N. Foster of Pepper Pike, Ohio. The Rev. Stephen J. White performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

description: In a storefront on Chambers Street near City Hall, the Municipal Building and Police Headquarters, a city-owned store sells bits of New York City history and symbolism to eager buyers who have discovered it.

title: THE GUIDE
description: EDUCATION'S FUTURE

title: With the Motley Look, Clashing Is the Intent
description: In Shakespeare's time, all the fools wore motley. Their patchwork clothes usually indicated destitution and disconnection from reality. But sometimes they signified philosophical insight, like the fool's garb in "As You Like It," which inspires a lord to say, "O that I were a fool! I am ambitious for a motley coat."

title: Called Up
description: War clouds in the Middle East have cast a shadow over the Yeshiva University basketball team's most promising season in more than 30 years. That's because Miko Danan, the team's star forward, who was once a member of the Israeli national team, has been called home for active duty with the Israeli Defense Forces.

title: No One Wants to Appear in Germany's Must-Read Magazine
description: The more things change in Germany these days, the more at least one institution stays the same. Der Spiegel, Germany's most influential publication, continues to prosper from a formula of aggressive investigative reporting and an entertaining, if often strident, writing style.

title: Tech Notes; Ferreting Out the Cars That Pollute
description: Today's new cars are relatively mild polluters. They are designed to emit no more than 5 to 15 grams of carbon monoxide a mile. But as these cars age, especially if they are poorly maintained, they become dirtier. In areas where monitoring is lax, these dirty cars can emit between 100 and 500 grams of carbon monoxide a mile. To spot them -- and get them fixed or off the road -- the Clean Air Act requires what is called "on-road emissions monitoring." To do this, Donald H. Stedman, a professor of chemistry at the University of Denver, has designed and built a prototype remote-emissions monitoring system. The system takes a second or less to measure the level of emissions from the tail pipe of a passing car. The system works like an infrared spectrascope. A parallel beam of infrared light is focused at a mirror across a road. The beam travels through the plume of exhaust gases, bounces off the mirror and returns to the device. The car's exhaust gases alter the wavelength of the light in a measurable way. When the infrared light re-enters the device, it hits a spinning mirror that focuses it on a series of detectors that can tell which gases are present and in what quantities. The device can be connected to a video camera to record the license number of each car tested.

title: Sports of The Times; The Weather Didn't Matter at All
description: Despite the snow, despite the wind, despite the slippery, white-coated field, the result hinged on what it would have if the Bills-Dolphins game yesterday at Rich Stadium had been played not here but in the gentle latitude of the Florida visitors. That is, it was dependent on the arms of the opposing standout quarterbacks, Jim Kelly for the cold-weather hosts, and Dan Marino for the tanned visitors. Also, surprisingly, the relatively gimpy leg of Kelly played a significant role.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-15

title: Arizona Edges U.C.L.A. And Extends Streak to 56
description: Sean Rooks's hook shot with 4.3 seconds remaining tonight helped Arizona extend the nation's longest home winning streak to 56 games as the Wildcats defeated U.C.L.A., 82-77.

title: Colombian Rebels Unleash Wide Counteroffensive
description: Far from failing to subdue the country's largest leftist guerrilla group, the Colombian military's seizure of the group's headquarters last month has touched off one of the bloodiest guerrilla offensives in recent years.

title: Postings: Sunday Outings; 2 Historic Tours
description: For two midwinter retreats into New York City history, Adventure on a Shoestring, a nonprofit group that has been organizing walking tours of the city's neighborhoods for 28 years, is offering Sunday afternoon outings at Beekman Place and Sutton Place next Sunday and along the most historic blocks of Chelsea on Jan. 27.

title: Long Island City
description: To the Editor:

title: A la Carte: Beef From Sake-Massaged Cattle
description: JAPAN'S legendary Kobe beef is now available on Long Island. The Bryant & Cooper Steak House in Roslyn is the only Island restaurant offering this exclusive grade of beef.

title: Amy L. de Joia To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alex de Joia of London, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Louisa de Joia, to David Charles Brewitt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Denis Brewitt of Thorne, South Yorkshire, England. A May wedding is planned.

title: Small Works, High Standard
description: A CONCRETE and glass tower complete with escalators, lobby plants and, opposite, Pennsylvania Station, the Gateway Center is the kind of building that only its architect and developer could love. At street level, though, it has one esthetically redeeming feature -- the City Without Walls Gallery. The art that hangs in this corner storefront may not please all the public all the time, but it can't fail to attract attention for looking handmade, not "generated" to suit corporate taste.

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; Testing the Physics of M & M's Sweet Smell Of an Experiment in Chocolate
description: When the first of the boxes carrying what would come to more than a ton of uncoated plain and peanut M & M's arrived in Prof. Jeffrey L. Feerer's chemical engineering laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology last fall, he and his undergraduate students had big grins on their faces. What more could a college group want than to spend days on end with a virtually limitless supply of chocolate, the smell wafting into every corner of the lab?

title: Jazz Orchestra Offers Salute to Porter
description: THE New World Jazz Orchestra, founded last summer by Roy Wiseman, is dedicated to the authentic re-creation of historic American popular music and jazz. Today at 3 P.M., the ensemble opens the Essex Winter Series at the John Winthrop School in Deep River. For this centennial salute to Cole Porter, the baritone Richard Lalli will sing some of the composer's best-loved songs and a few rarities, too, all with their original orchestrations. And speaking of rarities, the orchestra is winding up the concert with Porter's only ballet score, "Within the Quota."

description: Deep River, Conn. 133,500 16 Southworth Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old Cape Cod; new roof, new rear deck, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,306. Fairfield, Conn. 223,000 33 Bel Air 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old split level; hot tub, exceptional landscaping, 0.33 acre; taxes $2,429. title: For Philip Bosco, Acting Isn't Everything
description: "IT'S not that I don't enjoy the limelight. It's just that it doesn't really matter to me." That's how the actor Philip Bosco feels about his status in the theater (he had the lead in "The Miser," which was recently on Broadway), films (roles in, most notably, "Three Men and a Baby" and "Working Girl") and television (soap operas and guest appearances on series).

title: Surprised By a Prize
description: To the Editor: It is sad to think that Paul Goldberger finds the Town Hall in Borgoricco, Italy, in any sense noteworthy [ "The Important Things Were What Didn't Happen," Dec. 30 ] . We have an incinerator building in Jersey City that would make that utterly idiotic prize winner by Aldo Rossi look sick. Post-modern architecture is often as prosaic, boring and depressing as modern was, except that it is also trite and in poor taste. Mr. Rossi's town hall looks like a power station (an ugly one). JOSEPH R. LICCARDO Jersey City

title: It Can Be Live, Real -- And Fake
description: Here is the law that technology requires us to live by: if it is possible to do something, it must be done to death. The science of road paving having been perfected, it was necessary that by the end of the 20th century two-thirds of the world's surface would look like the parking lot of a shopping mall. The science of data storage having been taken to its apparent limits with the invention of the sheepskin manuscript, researchers nonetheless went ahead and developed the personal computer and placed one in every home, where it proved to be of little use.

title: Rising Personal and Public Toll In New England Economic Plunge
description: For decades, Gardner has called itself "Chair City," for the furniture factories that dominated its economy.

title: Industry Hopes the Bad Memories Fade Quickly
description: Three months after the sad events of the Breeders' Cup, the marquee stars of the horse-racing world are starting to stir in stables from coast to coast, as a new year of pursuits and prizes dawns.

title: Sunday Outing; Where the Fish Bite (And So Does the Cold)
description: For the really avid fishing fan, winter is no time to nap. Cold-weather fishing has been gaining in popularity over the last few years. "One of the main reasons is less boats in the water, less people fishing and more fish to catch," says Steven Forsberg, captain of the Viking Starship at Montauk Point, L.I.

title: On Language; The Crackdown Watch
description: Will Mikhail Gorbachev crack down on separatist movements in the disintegrating Soviet Union? Can we expect a crackdown to begin in the three Baltic nations, illegally occupied by Soviet forces since the von Ribbentrop-Molotov deal of 1939?

title: Talking: Co-op Shares; Lenders Tighten The Rules
description: A SERIOUS consequence of the uncertain financial situation of many cooperatives in New York City that have a high percentage of sponsor-owned apartments is the growing reluctance of lenders to finance the purchase of shares in the buildings.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants-Bears: Snow, Ice and Wind
description: If it's the Giants and the Bears in the playoffs, it must be the Arctic. Snow on the sidelines. Ice on the yard lines. Wind howling across the tundra.

title: The Nation; Are the Pentagon's Cuts Leaving Defense Thin?
description: THE Navy promised a technological marvel when it persuaded Congress to begin paying for the A-12 Avenger attack plane in 1988. The carrier-based aircraft would be able to fly deep into enemy territory without being detected by radar and drop bombs with pinpoint precision. But even before a single plane was built, the program's costs soared at least $1.6 billion over budget.

title: Jennifer Dodge Kimball to Wed in May
description: Geoffrey D. Kimball of New York and Carol H. Kimball of Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Dodge Kimball, to Daniel Parker Beard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Beard of Wayland, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Cargo Ship Sinks Off Newfoundland
description: A 43,000-ton cargo ship with a crew of 33 sank before dawn today in stormy seas southeast of Newfoundland, and eight hours later, an air-and-sea rescue effort had failed to turn up any sign of survivors, Canadian rescue officials said..

title: 'An American Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Confrontation in the Gulf
description: Syrian Appeals to 'Brother' To Withdraw From Kuwait

title: Unlikely Hero For Syracuse
description: In five previous games against Seton Hall, David Johnson of Syracuse had never scored a single point. But he made up for that lack of production tonight when he sank a free throw with 4.9 seconds to go and then followed up his missed second foul shot with a 15-foot jumper with 2.6 seconds left that gave the Orangemen a 69-67 triumph over the Pirates before a crowd of 17,162 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: On Reforms, N.C.A.A. Will Get a Grade Later
description: Have things changed as a result of last week's National Collegiate Athletic Association convention? In theory, the answer is that things have changed significantly.

title: Travel Advisory; New Unleaded Gasoline Sold In Mexico
description: Officials in Mexico say that a new unleaded gasoline, Magna Sin, now being sold there is suited for use in cars brought in from the United States and Canada and will reduce pollution from car emissions. Developed by Pemex, Mexico's state-owned oil company, the brand has an octane level of 87, the highest in the country. (In the United States, regular unleaded has an octane level of 87; midgrade, 89, and premium, 93.) Magna Sin sells for about $1.28 a gallon, compared with $1 usually charged for other unleaded gasolines, including one called Extra, which has been taken off the market. The leaded brand, Nova, sells for about 91 cents a gallon.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures of two couples last Sunday with the reports of their engagements were reversed. Candace Farrell and Kevin Daly were at the right; Barbara Keating and Ens. John W. Alter 3d were at the left.

title: Dedicated Breed: Rescuers of Wildlife
description: Not too long ago, a silver fox was hit by a passing car on the Palisades Parkway in Rockland County. A policeman spotted the animal, saw it had a broken leg and radioed a call for help to Westchester Wildlife in Peekskill, N.Y. The fox was picked up by Wildlife workers, treated by a veterinarian, and spent three months healing at a Wildlife facility before its release into the Catskills wilderness.

title: Ms. Boericke Plans to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Rensselaer Boericke of Glenville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Youngman Boericke to Michael Barden Prisant, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Millard B. Prisant of Roslyn Harbor, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Want a Hit? Send In the Songwriter
description: Desmond Child, a Los Angeles-based songwriter and producer, has a way with catchy song titles. He had one in mind, "You Give Love a Bad Name," when he walked into his first songwriting session with Bon Jovi. The band, it turned out, had a spare tune called "Shot Through the Heart." Mr. Child and Bon Jovi spliced his title onto their song, revamped the lyrics with a furious eight-second opening salvo -- "Shot through the heart/ And you're to blame/ You give love a bad name" -- and, as is the custom with Mr. Child, had a hit.

title: Cleaning House
description: The Minnesota Vikings, who finished 6-10 this season with an offense that faltered as much as the defense, said yesterday that they had released their offensive coordinator, Bob Schnelker, and their defensive coordinator, Floyd Peters.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title: The Nation; The Road to Bank Reform May Be Bumpy
description: AMERICA'S banking system is in serious trouble, and a consensus has developed in the White House, in the Capitol, on Wall Street and on Main Streets across the land that something must be done in Washington to change the laws that govern the banks. The laws, written during the Great Depression, are obsolete.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Mindful of History, Congress Agonizes Over Going to War
description: These have not been glory years for Congress. Ethical storms, budget squabbling and the chronic appearance of political deadlock have all left their mark on the image of this proud institution.

title: Trenton Becomes Gomorrah
description: "I LOVE MY WIFE," the musical romance by Michael Stewart and Cy Coleman now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is a Christmas Eve fantasy shared by two married couples.

title: Hopeful E.P.A. Report Fans a Debate as Talks on Warming Near
description: The Environmental Protection Agency says that at a time when most other countries have only pledged to take action, the United States has already taken steps that will keep emissions of heat-trapping atmospheric gases at current levels for the next two decades.

title: Providing Help When the Fear Is Fear Itself
description: SOME are afraid to ride in an elevator. For others, a traffic jam, the supermarket checkout line, a ringing telephone or a visit to the dentist can cause crippling fear and any excuse to avoid the situation. For still others, these irrational fears so severely impair the quality of their lives that they remain prisoners in their homes.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TEACHERS FOR OURNATION'S SCHOOLSBy John I. Goodlad.Jossey-Bass, $21.95.

title:
ART;
In a Large Township Exhibition, a Non-juried Show of Small-Scale Pieces
description: THIS year's annual exhibition by the members of the Huntington Township Art League is significantly larger than the previous show. Without a jury to reduce the number of works -- 166, up from 125 last year -- it is no wonder that the league restricts entries to small-scale pieces.

title: Why a Cashless Society Wouldn't Work; Income Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubt and Betrayal on the West Bank
description: THE SMILE OF THE LAMB By David Grossman. Translated by Betsy Rosenberg. 325 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: Bridgit O'Hara Weds Carl Riley
description: Bridgit Nola O'Hara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. O'Hara of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Carl Joseph Riley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl C. Riley of Colts Neck, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the Tower Hill Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J., by the Rev. Robert Bell and Ralph Imholte, a deacon at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Colts Neck.

title: Distinguished Antecedents
description: To the Editor: As a former editor of the Harvard Lampoon and National Lampoon, I'm writing to thank you for recognizing the intimate link between art and parody in Mark Dery's article. The article was both droll and overdue.

title: On the Eve of Drifting Into War, Once Again; Eisenhower Doctrine
description: To the Editor:

title: Building New Life Around Rail Depots
description: NEW efforts by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to encourage development near its railroad stations has underscored once more the interest in the New York City region in bringing housing, offices and shopping close to mass transportation.

title:
Pompton Lakes Journal;
Du Pont and Residents Try to Resolve Contamination Issue
description: ACID BROOK, which runs from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's explosives plant on Cannonball Road through residential areas down to the lake, carried a bitter message to this community last year when high levels of lead and mercury were found along its banks.

title:
Focus: Philadelphia;
Housing for the Poor Picks Up Steam
description: AFTER years of problems with its housing program, Philadelphia is enjoying greater success with a Federal tax-credit program to increase the rehabilitation of rental apartments for the poor. Created in 1986, the program has lured corporate and other private investors into the low-income housing market.

title:
Your Own Account;
'Tis the Season to Get Divorced
description: Many couples with troubled marriages, who managed to get through the holidays for the sake of the family, are probably deciding at about this point to throw in the towel and get a divorce.

title: Scott Finessed Nascar Barriers
description: Wendell Scott, whose struggles and exploits as the first -- and thus far the only -- black driver to reach the top level of stock-car racing were portrayed in the movie "Greased Lightning," died of spinal cancer on Dec. 23 at the age of 69.

title: Assad Urges 'Brother' to Quit Kuwait
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that Syrian troops in the anti-Iraq coalition in Saudi Arabia would not participate in an attack to drive Iraqi forces out of Kuwait, a senior American official said.

title: JERSEYANA
description: THE hostages have returned from Iraq, and righteous anger has been voiced about the barbarous practice of holding innocent people captive for political purposes. But hostage-taking was not invented in the Middle East. A couple of centuries ago, this country took a hostage and threatened to kill him.

title: Review/Music; Dutoit Conducts Kodaly, Schumann and Dutilleux
description: With one orchestra and another, Charles Dutoit conducts a lot of concerts in New York, and most are good ones. It came as something of a surprise, then, when he led a slack and disappointing program last November with the New York Philharmonic. So it was heartening -- a restoration of the natural order of things, if you will -- to find him back in form on the Avery Fisher Hall podium Wednesday night for the first of five Philharmonic subscription concerts extending through Tuesday night.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AMERICAN WOMEN Their Lives in Their Words: A Documentary History. Edited by Doreen Rappaport. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. (Ages 12 and up)

title: All About/Hats; The Baseball Cap Is Breathing Life Into Headwear Sales
description: Roy Langenberg says that people burst out laughing when he tells them he produces hats. "How do you make a living?" they ask. But Mr. Langenberg, the fourth generation in his family to head the Langenberg Hat Company of Washington, Mo., says that the headwear business is actually enjoying a comeback. No one in the industry expects formal felt hats to recapture the universal popularity they enjoyed before World War II. But most Americans own many more caps and leisure hats than they realize and seem eager to accumulate more.

title: 'Dark Shadows' Returns to Haunt Prime Time
description: "Of everything I've done, this will end up on my gravestone," says Dan Curtis in a voice that melds resignation and amusement. The figure of speech is apt: Mr. Curtis, whose extensive television pedigree includes directing and producing the epic mini-series "The Winds of War" and "War and Remembrance," was talking about "Dark Shadows," the supernatural soap opera about a 200-year-old lovelorn vampire and the family he haunts.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PUBLIC AFFAIRS PRIVATE RELATIONS By Letitia Baldrige. Doubleday, $18.95.

title: Ms. Meyer to Wed Donald Lowman
description: May wedding plans for Diane Lori Meyer and Donald Lee Lowman have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Meyer of New York and Highland Lakes, N.J. Mr. Lowman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence P. Lowman of Virginia Beach, Va., and St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Review/Dance; Illusions of Time and Space in 'Dances at a Gathering'
description: One of the pleasures of Jerome Robbins's "Dances at a Gathering" is its way of creating a sense of particular if fluid time and place out of almost nothing but movement in space. True, Mr. Robbins does give the hint of a suggestion in his title for this flowing suite of dances: this is a gathering. The men and women know each other. But they also seem tinged with a fresh American innocence and a European knowingness and calm, gathered in a wide open space that might be a prairie for Old World pastoral encounters.

title: Travel Advisory; Sharing Skiers Get Price Cuts
description: The ski-in, ski-out Hyatt Regency Beaver Creek, eight miles from Vail, Colo., has started a "single share" program of the kind that cruise ships have long offered. Solo travelers may ask to be paired with a roommate of the same sex, with each paying half the double occupancy rate or half the cost of a ski package for two that includes lift tickets. A room at the Hyatt Regency normally costs $325 or $350 a night in winter. Under the roommate program, a three-night package with lift tickets and round-trip ride to Vail is $429 a person, and a five-night stay, $739 a person.

title: Camera
description: It was New Year's Eve, minutes before midnight, and suddenly I was appointed to take a group portrait of a small assemblage of my friends. Fine, I thought, as I loaded up my camera and threaded it onto a tripod. Then I remembered: that trusty flash unit so small and lightweight was sitting on a shelf at home, roughly a thousand miles from where I was.

title: Wedding in June For Jessica Ross
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur L. Ross Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jessica Colby Ross to Kenneth Richard Rupert Scofield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Scofield of Harare, Zimbabwe. A June wedding is planned.

title:
MUSIC;
Giving a 'Lift' With Gospel Songs
description: FOR Marion Williams, who has often been called the Queen of Gospel, gospel is "a very religious experience." It is also all she has ever sung since she began singing in church at the age of 3.

title: Wedding in May For Gail Darche
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Marcel Darche of Spring Lake, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Gail Christine Darche and Michael Thomas Short, a son of Florence Lincoln Short and Thomas Lloyd Short, both of Gambier, Ohio.

title: Fashion; If it works, Wear It!
description: What a testimony to the variety of looks that are valid today! On these pages are 11 women (and one dog) who are well turned out in what they wear to work on an average day. It proves that personal style is everything -- as long as it also suits the job.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Comfortable Place on a Country Road
description: IN a more competitive location, Luzzi's middle-of-the-road Continental food and casual, folksy service might not stand up so well. But the attractively decorated roadhouse is not in a large town dotted with better restaurants; it's on a country road in northern Morris County not far from Sussex County's lakes and the Craigmeur ski area -- and there it fills a comfortable niche.

title: At Last, Schroeder Feels He's Trusted
description: Here and there, a persistent rain broke its fall. But as morning stretched into afternoon one day recently, it became clear that the dark clouds would not budge. Players and practice field would get soaked, but the workout at the Los Angeles Raiders' complex would not stop. No one seemed to notice.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: VLADIMIR NABOKOV: Selected Letters, 1940-1977. Edited by Dmitri Nabokov and Matthew J. Bruccoli. (Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) "Vladimir Nabokov, the universally acknowledged virtuoso of the word, is a treasure house," our reviewer, Victor Erofeyev, said when this collection of letters was published in 1989. "He had an arsenal of stylistic weapons, and he used them in his letters like a fencer whose attacks are a pleasure to watch."

title: It's Not Just Steak or Poi Anymore
description: ASKED four or five years ago to define the ingredients of Hawaiian cuisine, many of that state's chefs would have listed local fish, pineapple, mangoes, coconut and poi, the starchy paste pressed from the root of the taro plant that has long been a fixture at island luau dinners.

title: Disagreement Arises on Bill On Smoking And Hiring
description: DONALD W. TORTORELLA, an artist, was looking for a job. So when he applied for part-time work at a company that prohibited smoking, the 57-year-old, two-pack-a-day smoker decided that the job was more important and that he would refrain from smoking during work.

title: Ridership Is Growing on County Buses
description: WHEN the first snowfall of the season dumped eight inches on her new home in Yonkers, Michele James decided to allow an extra 15 minutes for the bus ride to her job in White Plains. With her auto-driving colleagues still stuck in the slush, Ms. James walked in 15 minutes early.

title: Bush's Remark's After Congress Authorized War
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference today after the vote in Congress authorizing him to use military force in the Persian Gulf, as recorded by The Associated Press: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Landmarking's Doubled-Edged Sword
description: EVIDENCE is mounting that in many parts of New York City, landmark and historic-district designation is acting as a force for neglect rather than for the encouragement of improvement and preservation.

title: Business Education and Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Eve of Drifting Into War, Once Again; It's Not Mandatory
description: To the Editor:

title: Heads It's Sell; Tails They Rent
description: Around video the current hot topic is "sell through," the industry's term for that portion of the business -- roughly 30 percent of it by some estimates and growing -- involving sales of cassettes rather than rentals. Many sales are of older titles, but nothing stirs video's blood like a new smash hit that sells in the millions -- a "Pretty Woman," say, or a "Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles."

title: Mideast Buildup Stirs Old Political Divisions
description: WILLIAM P. THRALL of Port Jefferson was a warrior. But until the 766th Supply Company in Bellmore was called to active duty in the fall, the only attack he ever launched was on a chess board, where his bold play was defined by slashing assaults on opposing pieces.

title: Emperors of the Stage
description: Who were Sam, Jacob and Lee Shubert, and how did they come to play such a major role in creating the Broadway we know today? In THE SHUBERTS OF BROADWAY: A History Drawn From the Collections of the Shubert Archive (Oxford University, $35), Brooks McNamara, a professor of performance studies at New York University and director of the Shubert Archive, provides a detailed if somewhat bland history of the brothers and their phenomenal impact on the theater. Discarding their Yiddish, inventing middle initials, streamlining their personal histories (matters of age, birth order and place of origin were altered to suit), these sons of a peddler were brilliant entrepreneurs who saw opportunities for profit in the American passion for stage entertainment. Generously illustrated with photographs from the Shubert Archive, the book brims with lore about these colorful, ruthless and enigmatic brothers, as well as with details of the spectacular rise and subsequent ignominious decline of their immense theater empire. But Mr. McNamara's respectful, gee-whiz, only-in-America approach does not do justice to his subjects. Still, "The Shuberts of Broadway," an insider's authorized history, offers much in the way of information and memorabilia, and readers eager to know something of the three men whose name has become synonymous with Broadway today might find it right up their alley.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Instead of facing 'After the tone . . . BEEEEP!,' some people still lovingly write notes.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Twenty years ago, we paneled our den with mahogany panels and added cabinets covered with mahogany Formica. Now we would like to have a lighter color on the walls and cabinets. What is the best way to do this?

title:
FILM;
A Director Weighs a Society in Turmoil
description: More than any other foreign city, Paris has had a powerful hold on the Russian imagination. The 1989 Grand Palais exhibition entitled "La France et la Russie" documented that conclusively in visual-arts terms. On the printed page, the 19th-century Russian novel fairly drips with aristocrats and artists who, having shed the scales from their eyes during a visit to the City of Light, return home to subject Mother Russia and her customs to pitiless dissection.

title: Soviet Tanks Roll in Lithuania; 11 Dead
description: A column of Soviet Army tanks, plowing through a street crowd of civilians and a cordon of parked cars, seized the television broadcast center of Lithuania in the early-morning darkness today in a fusillade of cannon and gunfire. At least 11 civilians were killed and 100 or more were wounded.

title: Business Diary/December 6-11
description: THE ECONOMY Baker and Aziz Send the Markets Spinning Minutes before 2 P.M. on Wednesday, Brian Tagler of Shearson Lehman Brothers was trading oil for $23.85 a barrel. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had been meeting with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. The moment Mr. Tagler heard Mr. Baker say on television, "Regrettably . . . ," the trader was on the phone to the commodity pit. Buy orders had pushed the price to $31 -- the quickest rise he had ever seen. Economists are somewhat more stable in their sentiments, occasionally holding them for a whole week. Their consensus by the weekend was that if the United States fights and wins quickly and tidily, oil prices would fall and the economy would benefit. "I understand the mood swings, but people are exaggerating," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns. "There is a worldwide glut of oil against a backdrop of weak demand." But if there is a protracted war, many economists say, the budget deficit would widen, and oil prices and interest rates would rise. "The uncertainty will have a debilitating effect," said Richard B. Berner, a Salomon Brothers economist. "People will hold back from making long-term commitments." Even a last-minute settlement will not be enough to overcome recession, economists say, since growth was slowing before Iraqi troops set foot in Kuwait. Again, Sweat Doesn't Pay Will the returns on labor rebound and surpass the returns on wealth in the 1990's? From 1984 to 1988, the wealthiest gained in net worth, while everyone else stagnated, the Census Bureau reported last week. The less affluent depend mostly on their wages, which in the 1980's barely kept pace with inflation. Stocks and bonds, meanwhile, enjoyed strong returns. Lacy H. Hunt, chief United States economist for the Hongkong Bank Group, doubts that investments will continue soaring. But wages will rise as labor supplies tighten, he says. "The headlines of one decade go into the trash bin of the new decade," he said. For investors, "The decade hasn't started off very well, has it?" Wholesale Comfort The wholesale inflation news for December was comforting at every stop in the production chain. For finished goods, prices fell six-tenths of 1 percent overall; they only rose three-tenths of a point excluding food and energy. Prices for intermediate and crude goods, earlier in the production process, also fell. Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley said the report leaves the Federal Reserve plenty of room to stoke the economy. "The fundamentals are as constructive for inflation as they have been at any point in the onset of the last few recessions," he said. The annual gain, 5.6 percent, was the highest since 1981, but a mild 3.5 percent core rate. An Uptown Jazz Market Where sopranos now screech, saxaphones will squeal and coo. Lincoln Center has launched a jazz department with a $1 million annual budget. The marketing problem for Rob Gibson, the department's chief: How to create an uptown audience, week after week, for music usually heard in downtown clubs. His answers include children's concerts, master classes and small, informal theaters in the center. One possibility is a tribute to Sun Ra, the band leader whose fans can verify his claimed birth in outer space. But judging by what works best at Lincoln Center, Mr. Gibson might better raise his top ticket prices to $115, require black tie on opening nights and drag dozens of shield-bearing supernumeraries on stage. Banking Forecast: Rain At times last week, L. William Seidman's spirits improved to merely gloomy. Otherwise, he was downright dismal. On Wednesday, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned the Senate Banking Committee that more major bank failures were likely if the recession persists past mid-year. On Friday, he landed in Boston, like a governor visiting a hurricane disaster zone, to say that the region needs more widely available bank credit to free itself from a recession. "I don't think there's probably a bad loan being made in New England at this time," he said. "Unfortunately, there aren't many others either." INTERNATIONAL

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Patients' Groups And Cancer-Drug Tests
description: I was very pleased to see the very complete article on prostate-cancer drugs [ Dec. 16 ] . As was appropriately mentioned in that article, there is indeed a serious flaw in the study design using Casodex.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CALLING THE SHOTSMy Five Decades in the NBA.By Earl Strom with Blaine Johnson.Simon & Schuster, $18.95.

title: Travel Advisory; Vermont Road Avoids Snags
description: The latest segment of the improved U.S. 7 between Manchester and East Dorset, Vt., opened this winter, reducing driving time between the towns by up to 20 minutes -- because it bypasses the busy shopping district in Manchester.

title: Coping With Electrical Outlets Abroad
description: IN a Jerusalem hotel some years ago I was feeling particularly smug that I'd had the foresight to buy an adapter so I could plug in the heat disinfecting unit for my contact lenses. My pride, how ever, turned to horror the next morning when I discovered my lenses had been charred.

title: Pamela Brenner and Joseph Muratore Are Married
description: Pamela Robin Brenner and Joseph Salvatore Muratore were married last evening at the Pierre in New York by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel.

title: F.D.I.C. Offers to Aid Plan For Minority-Owned Bank
description: Federal bank regulators have offered to reopen an effort by investors interested in starting a new minority-owned bank in Harlem by selling them the remaining assets and deposits of the Freedom National Bank, which failed last November.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MIXED BILL

title: Donors Maintain Record Pace To Help the Neediest Cases
description: In the next seven weeks, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund must raise $644,190.84 if it is to surpass the previous campaign's total and become the sixth consecutive campaign to record an increase.

title: First Shoreham 'Idyll,' Then Stardom
description: IN case those who missed D. B. Sweeney's volatile portrayal of Constantine Treplev, the suicidal performance artist in "The Seagull: The Hamptons: 1990," a much-talked-about piece of revisionist Chekhov that closed two weeks ago at the Rapp Arts Center Off Broadway can catch him as Dish Boggett, a character he calls "a young lovesick hopelessly ineffectual cowhand" in "Lonesome Dove."

title: Tale of One City Set in Two Times -- Both Fearful
description: Tony Kushner's "Bright Room Called Day" (at the Public Theater's LuEsther Hall) is an ambitious, disturbing mess of a play, and while I can't deny that it exercises a certain dank fascination in places, I suspect my discontent would have been less if the pieces had fit together better.

title: Civil Liberties Union Likens Minority-School Plan to Segregation
description: Officials of the New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that they would consider filing a lawsuit to prevent the establishment of a proposed school that would focus on black and Hispanic young men on the grounds that it would violate laws banning both school segregation and discrimination on the basis of race and sex.

title: Architectural Showdown in the House of Lords
description: Tomorrow the house of Lords will become the next battleground in a long-drawn-out territorial war punctuated by vicious infighting. Like Dickens's famous case in Chancery Court that dragged on for generations, this one seems to have gone on forever, pitting supporters of contemporary architecture against preservationists over the development of a site in London's historic square-mile financial center. The case will be settled not on the merits of the proposed structure but on the question of whether the Environment Secretary, in approving the construction of a six-story office building, adequately explained why he thought it appropriate to demolish eight Victorian buildings on the site.

title: Late Flurry Gives Islanders the Edge
description: The Islanders saved the best for last as goals by Brent Sutter, Randy Wood and Derek King on their final three shots of the game turned a two-goal deficit into a 4-3 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight.

title: E.P.A. Said to Fight Effort to Sway Report on Electromagnetic Risks
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has rebuffed what researchers say was a White House attempt to weaken an E.P.A. report that finds health risks in household electromagnetic fields.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: State of the States, 1991: Rocky, Almost Everywhere
description: It is normally a time for upbeat comments about bright futures and expansive political visions. But governors from coast to coast, Republicans as well as Democrats, conservatives and liberals, have stood before their state legislatures in recent days to open the new year with refrains that were as depressing as they were similar.

title: Moscow Protesters Denounce Attack in Lithuania as Kremlin Keeps Silent
description: The Kremlin was a study in stony silence today as thousands of protest marchers braved the new mood of authoritarian crackdown and angrily denounced President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a fascist for the deadly use of military force in Lithuania against unarmed civilians.

title: Chief of Bridges To Seek Advice On Repair Plan
description: New York City's Transportation Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio, said yesterday that he planned to enlist consulting engineers from outside the department to re-evaluate completely the Bridge Bureau's budget and maintenance priorities. He acted in the face of a city move to scale down a 10-year plan for the repair of all bridges.

title: EUROPEANS WARN SOVIET ABOUT AID
description: Reacting with a mixture of shock and disappointment, governments in the European Economic Community today condemned Moscow's violent overnight crackdown in Lithuania and warned that $1 billion in economic aid promised to the Soviet Union might be suspended.

title: Sanctions Will Bite -- and Soon
description: Proponents of a military solution to the Kuwaiti crisis have asserted repeatedly that there is no proof that sanctions will work. Only war, they say, guarantees that Iraq will get out of Kuwait, and soon. But there is abundant proof that sanctions can work -- a recent report by the Central Intelligence Agency notwithstanding -- and there is considerable evidence they can do so within the next 12 months.
