title: Bills Riding High Toward Title Game
description: The Buffalo Bills have never been to a Super Bowl. Now, as they seem to be barreling toward the big game, they are approaching stardom as well.

title: A.T.& T. Is Paid In Phone Suit
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has settled a lawsuit involving allegations that International Telecharge Inc. had surreptitiously switched long-distance service at pay phones.

title: Outdoors: Cooking the Catch Completes the Hunt
description: TO this hunter at least, the chase and the kill is a farce unless linked with the feast.

title: Treasury Auction
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: A Skiing Focus On Cross-Country
description: TUCKED into the northern White Mountains is the village of Jackson, N.H., a resort town complete with covered bridge and quaint, comfortable lodges. But the biggest winter attraction is cross-country skiing on the community's 150 kilometers of trails.

title: Blazers Crush Nets
description: Attempting to stop a losing streak at two games tonight, the Portland Trail Blazers used an obvious game plan: they turned Buck Williams loose against the Nets, the team he led for eight seasons.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sabatini Takes Opener: A year after Gabriela Sabatini left the Australian Open in a wheelchair, she returned cautiously but triumphantly today to lead a charge on Steffi Graf's three-year championship reign. Sabatini, the United States Open champion, defeated 19-year-old Linda Harvey-Wild of the United States, 6-3, 6-1 in a windblown match on center court as play got under way at Melbourne. Sabatini, seeded No. 4, returned to the tournament where she sustained a severely sprained ankle in the third round a year ago. Katerina Maleeva, seeded No. 5, beat Brenda Schultz, 6-1, 6-3, and Amy Frazier, No. 13, beat Kate McDonald, 6-3, 6-4. In men's matches, 12th-seeded Jay Berger beat Magnus Larsson, 6-3, 6-4, 6-0, and Lars Wahlgren beat 15th-seeded Marc Rosset, 4-6, 2-6, 7-6, 6-3, 9-7. (AP)

title: Susan F. Klinger Marries
description: Susan F. Klinger, a vice president and director of staff relations for the Northeast division of Citibank, in Long Island City, Queens, was married yesterday to Sheldon Gartenstein, a vice president and regional manager of the National Cooperative Bank in New York. Rabbi Sandy Bogin performed the ceremony at the Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y. The bride, who is keeping her name, is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Klinger of Brooklyn. She graduated from Brooklyn College. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Gartenstein of Brooklyn. He is a City College graduate. He was a widower; a previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: American Diplomat Returns From Baghdad Disappointed
description: The diplomat who has been the top American representative in Baghdad since Iraq invaded Kuwait returned to the United States today vowing to continue to work to peace.

title: Era Ends as Times Square Drops Slashers for Shakespeare
description: To certain devotees, it became painfully clear in the last week that their Times Square is dead. At West 42d Street's oldest theater, the Victory, stagehands replaced the front three rows of seats -- the very seats where filmgoers had watched "Hot Saddle Tramp" and "One-Armed Sholin Temple Master" -- with a piazza where Romeo will stand below Juliet's balcony.

title: The New Old Face of Tyranny
description: A Soviet colonel in Vilnius, enraged at being sprayed by a fire hose, Friday showed his young Lithuanian tormentors just who is who. He shot one young man in the face.

title: For Salvadoran Refugees, an Empty Promise?; No Gift, Only Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Telling a Detective Story On Cold Fusion in a Jar
description: The 1989 announcement by two electrochemists at the University of Utah that they had produced a fusion reaction by a simple experiment set off quite an explosion around the world. If confirmed, it held the promise of cheap, pollution-free, limitless energy. But confirmation proved elusive, and within a year the claim was widely written off as a dud. The tale, which combines a lesson in scientific technique with elements of a detective story, is better told than titled on "Confusion in a Jar," tomorrow's episode of "Nova," at 8 on Channels 13 and 49.

title: War or Peace: Wall Street Waits
description: Credit market analysts and participants are awaiting Tuesday's midnight deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait with a rising sense of urgency.

title: Allen Foils Bengals
description: The fans in Los Angeles Coliseum quieted themselves this afternoon when the running back Bo Jackson went down on the second play of the third quarter, after carrying the ball for a 34-yard gain.

title: Knicks Get a Lift From Vandeweghe
description: It had been a while since the Knicks' dressing room was filled with positive talk after a game rather than excuses and sniping.

title: Oliver Gleichenhaus; Burger Maker, 79
description: Oliver Gleichenhaus, whose spicy "Ollieburgers" were sold nationwide, died Thursday after open-heart surgery. He was 79 years old.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Asian-Americans' Tastes Are Surveyed by Marketer
description: WHAT kind of liquor do Asian- Americans prefer? Do they chew gum? Eat cookies? Drive only Toyotas?

title: After Freeze, Counting Losses to Orange Crop
description: Jim Powell is grim as he looks over the acres of destroyed oranges around him, the leaves of the trees curled and burned by frost.

title: In S.& L. Case, 2 Dramatically Contrasting Views
description: With seven weeks of Senate hearings about to end, two dramatically different pictures have emerged of why five Senators joined Charles H. Keating Jr. in his war with Federal savings and loan regulators.

title: Baker Says Anti-Iraq Allies, Except Syria, Agree on Force
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that except for Syria, the nations of the anti-Iraq coalition were in agreement on the timing and necessity of force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait after midnight Tuesday.

title: Top Japanese Executive To Step Down
description: Seiji Tsutsumi, founder and chairman of the Saison Group, said Saturday that he planned to step down from active management of the large Japanese conglomerate and hand over authority to a collective leadership.

title: Management of T.V.A. Is Cut Into Three Parts
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority, the nation's largest power agency, has reorganized its management in an effort to improve service.

title: S.& L. Fraud Indictments
description: In what a Federal prosecutor called the largest savings and loan fraud in the history of Kansas, three former executives of a failed savings institution were indicted last week on charges that they defrauded the instituion of more than $105 million.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Berkeley; Coffee Is Strong, Opinion Is Split
description: Strong coffee, thick newspapers and good conversation are the hallmarks of Sunday mornings at Vine and Walnut Streets in this iconoclastic city where everyone has an opinion on just about everything.

title: Publisher Buys A Lotus Unit
description: The International Data Group, which publishes periodicals dealing with information technology, has acquired the Lotus Publishing Corporation from the Lotus Development Corporation in Cambridge, Mass.

title: David A. Morse Memorial
description: A memorial service for David A. Morse, former director general of the International Labor Organization, is to be held at 11 A.M. Wednesday at Temple Emanu-El, East 65th Street, at Fifth Avenue. Mr. Morse died on Dec. 1 at the age of 83.

title: Israel, Rebuffing U.S. Plea, Says It Will Answer Attack
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens made clear today that Israel would not meet an American request to stay out of a Persian Gulf war if it is attacked.

title: Peru, Its U.S. Aid Imperiled, Plots a New Drug Strategy
description: With Peru facing a March 1 deadline for the possible cutoff of $100 million in American anti-drug aid, officials here are working to fashion a new strategy to cut exports of the raw material of cocaine.

title: Runners Can Avoid Winter of Discontent
description: RUNNERS who cut back on training in the winter neglect an important phase of conditioning that can be used as a foundation for peak performance later in the year.

title: Capital Gains Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Takes Over Airport for Atlantic City
description: After more than a decade of squabbling and intergovernmental rivalry, the State of New Jersey has acquired Atlantic City's tiny airport, promising to turn it into a "world class" place that will open this area to expanded tourism and a larger gambling market.

title: Backman-Dykstra Reunion
description: As if the presence of Vince Coleman and Tom Herr in the same lineup were not enough of a blast from the past for National League East teams, here comes another: Len Dykstra and Wally Backman are hoping once again to bat one-two and batter psyches of the likes of the Cardinals, Cubs and Expos.

title: Fire in Old Building Kills 3
description: A fire in a rundown building killed at least three people and forced dozens to flee on Saturday, the authorities said. Three bodies were found in the rubble, and at least one person was believed to be missing after the blaze caused the five-story building to collapse.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Chicago; Who Will Pay Raises Concern
description: There were 24 parishioners and a minister missing this morning from the wooden pews at Chicago's First Baptist Congregational Church. They have been absent since August, preparing to fight for a cause that many church members say they neither understand nor believe in.

title: Topics of The Times; Baghdad Betty, Animated
description: "Ridiculous," President Bush called the program when he was in Saudi Arabia in November. He was referring to "Voice of Peace," Iraq's version of the Axis Sally or Tokyo Rose propaganda broadcasts during World War II, and he couldn't know how right he was.

title: Gorby's Black Berets
description: The winner of last year's Nobel Peace Prize, the politician who entranced a gullible world with talk of reform and glasnost, the supplicant we have just given a billion dollars in food aid to help keep in office, the Soviet leader supposedly working behind the scenes to cut a deal in the Persian Gulf -- has just ordered his tanks into Lithuania to roll over the bodies of patriots resisting his dictatorship.

title: Sheena Singh, Doctoral Student, Weds D. M. Danziger, New York City Official
description: A wedding ceremony for Sheena Singh and David Michael Danziger was performed yesterday at the Four Seasons in New York by Cantor Raymond Smolover. A Sikh ceremony was performed Jan. 5 in New Delhi at the home of the bride's parents. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jogindar Singh of New Delhi. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Michael Danziger of New York.

title: Parents Give to the Neediest
description: Although Richard and Barbara Marsh have given to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for several years, their latest contribution has special meaning to them because it comes from their newborn son, David.

title: SOVIET LOYALISTS IN CHARGE AFTER ATTACK IN LITHUANIA; 13 DEAD; CURFEW IS IMPOSED
description: The National Salvation Committee, a faceless group of Communist Party loyalists, imposed a series of repressive measures on Lithuania today after the Soviet Army, with tanks and machine guns, had seized power for the committee overnight.

title: Back to San Francisco: Giants Bury the Bears, 31-3
description: Coach Bill Parcells, who does not praise easily, called it one of the Giants' better games this year. Ron Erhardt, his offensive coordinator, called it the Giants' best game of the season. Maurice Carthon, his fullback, called it the best game the Giants had played in two or three years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was one of those glorious pristine snow days Saturday at Ski Windham resort in Windham, N.Y. The newly groomed moguls on the slopes were exceeded only by the culinary moguls in the kitchen. More than 20 leading chefs from New York City and beyond went to the ski resort to prepare a spectacular four-hour feast to honor PIERRE FRANEY, a food columnist for The New York Times, cookbook author and television host, on his 70th birthday. The party was given by MICHEL ROUX, president of Carillon Importers Ltd., which sponsored yesterday's Grand Marnier Chefs Ski Race.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Ad Agency Principals In Praise of Each Other
description: When ad agencies speak of one another, they sometimes can be mean-spirited. But in a new trade campaign, they will do nothing but pat each other on the back.

title: Stocks Fall in Tokyo
description: Fears of war in the Middle East and the onset of a military crackdown in the Soviet Union pushed stocks slightly lower today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 27.79 points, or less than 1 percent, to 23,213.23. The Nikkei finished the morning session down 329.87 points, or 1.4 percent, to 22,911.15. The index lost 268.03 points in the first 30 minutes of trading. Morning trading was thin on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, at 90 million shares, because many traders stayed out before a national holiday on Tuesday. "Many players just didn't come into work today," a trader at a Japanese brokerage said.

title: Arts Organizations In New York City Fear Planned Cuts
description: Leaders of major arts organizations in New York City have said they will be badly hampered by the budget cuts Mayor David N. Dinkins is expected to announce on Wednesday, and many arts officials are asking him to consider reducing these cuts.

title: Insilco Declares Bankruptcy
description: The Insilco Corporation, a diversified company whose products include military equipment, Rolodex files and textbooks, filed today for bankruptcy protection from its creditors.

title: Graham Heir and Cunningham Look
description: It is a rare pleasure to settle down with a dance as one does with a good book. But that was the case with a program of new and recent work presented by the Shelley Lee Dance Company on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Ms. Lee trained at the London School of Contemporary Dance, an English outpost for the technique of Martha Graham, and appeared in New York in works by Jane Dudley, one of the great Graham performers. Oddly enough, however, much of the choreography presented by Ms. Lee, who is now based in New York, had the pulled-up, tilting-through-space look of Cunningham dance.

title: Miscellany
description: * Edelman Public Relations Worldwide has acquired a majority interest in Gruppo D' Relazioni Pubbliche, a public relations firm in Milan, Italy.* Coca-Cola signed the heavyweight boxing champion Evander Holyfield to a six-year commitment as spokesman.

title: Letter from Kuwait
description: The following letter is from the American wife of a Kuwaiti businessman in Kuwait. The woman, who lives on the East Coast with their children, requested anonymity for herself and her husband. This letter, and her husband's letter, which follows, were adapted by The New York Times.

title: Tyson Undercard To Include Chavez
description: The complicated business life of Julio Cesar Chavez continues.

title: Miss Scheid Wed To Russell Fuhrer
description: Nancy J. Scheid, a daughter of Gayle Scheid and Nicholas J. Scheid Jr., both of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Dr. Russell Fuhrer, a son of Mrs. Morris Black and Neil Fuhrer, both of New York. Rabbi Alvin Berkun performed the ceremony at the Tree of Life Synagogue.

title: Topics of The Times; Congress's Budget Surplus
description: Serious competition for House seats, rare enough in the fall elections, could become rarer still unless Congress finally cleans up campaign financing.

title: Political Memo; D'Amato Aide Is in Line To Be State G.O.P. Chief
description: The leaders of the New York State Republican Party, scheduled to meet in Albany today, are expected to elect Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's upstate coordinator, William Powers, as the party's latest chairman and would-be savior.

title: Weary Residents Fear More Turmoil to Come
description: Jeffrey Foote stood on 20th Avenue in Bensonhurst yesterday, midway between the spots where the Rev. Al Sharpton was stabbed on Saturday and where Yusuf K. Hawkins died in 1989, to watch protesters marching in support of Mr. Sharpton.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Friday about the movement against a Persian Gulf war misidentified the university at which a teach-in was held to oppose a possible draft. It was Michigan State University, not the University of Michigan.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Atlanta; Vague Possibility Now a Step Away
description: For Liz Doyle, as for so many others, what even a week ago seemed a vague, unlikely possibility now seems only a horrifying step away.

title: Bensonhurst Protest March Is Peaceful
description: Several hundred demonstrators marched peacefully through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday, a few hours after the Rev. Al Sharpton and the Rev. Jesse Jackson appealed for calm in the wake of Mr. Sharpton's stabbing in the predominantly white neighborhood on Saturday.

title: NO SHORTAGE SEEN IN SUPPLIES OF OIL DURING A GULF WAR
description: A war in the Persian Gulf may not create shortages of oil in the United States, oil company executives, Government officials and other experts say. But they caution that prices may surge if panic buying drains supplies from gas stations and distribution centers.

title: Better Yet, Reduce the Size of the House
description: To the Editor:

title: Bach's Handwriting Identified in Pittsburgh
description: One of the earliest known examples of Johann Sebastian Bach's handwriting in a musical score has been identified in Pittsburgh by Hans-Joachim Schulze, the director of the Bach-Archive in Leipzig, Germany.

title: Europeans Issue a Warning
description: Governments in the European Economic Community condemned the crackdown in Lithuania and warned that $1 billion in economic aid to Moscow might be suspended. Page A8.

title: With Bach-Busoni Preludes
description: Young Concert Artists has had a laudable 30-year record of presenting promising talents to the New York public. But Tuesday evening's piano recital by Eduardus Halim at the 92d Street Y proved disappointing.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.63 percent last week, up from 9.56 percent the previous week, according to a national survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.76 percent last week, down from 7.78 percent the previous week and the lowest since 7.66 percent in the week that ended on May 13, 1988.

title: Palestinians in Occupied Territories Face War Unprepared
description: After months of hoping that President Saddam Hussein would use military force against Israel, the growing possibility of attack has jolted Palestinians into frantic preparations for war and criticism of Israel for failing to protect them from Iraqi chemical weapons.

title: TESTING BY NASA LIGHTS UP THE SKY
description: The night sky glowed green, purple and red Saturday night and early today as a satellite released clouds of barium and lithium vapor in space to study geomagnetic storms.

title: The Art of Bartending Is Used to Define an Era
description: The Last Fine Time By Verlyn Klinkenborg 209 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Gasoline Prices Drop 7 Cents
description: Gasoline prices across the nation fell an average of nearly 7 cents in recent weeks because of lower winter demand, according to a survey released today.

title: First Lady Breaks a Leg in a Sledding Mishap
description: President Bush's wife, Barbara, broke her left leg this morning when she hit a tree while sledding on an icy hill at the Presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., the White House said.

title: Rushdie Affair Gives Islam a Bad Name
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Dove To a Hawk: 25-Year Trip
description: Twenty-five years ago, Stephen J. Solarz was managing one of the first anti-war Congressional campaigns in the country.

title: Fourth Downs Were Decisive
description: When Dan Hampton could finally look back at the last game of his 12th and final season as a defensive tackle for the Chicago Bears, he pointed to the opening drive of the third quarter.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Congress in Step; After the Vote, Margins Are Ignored, But Potential Divisions Are Serious
description: A Congress that had seemed loath to deal with the Persian Gulf finally went ahead when its leaders despaired of getting President Bush to promise to ask formally for their support before attacking Iraq, some members of Congress and highly placed aides said today.

title: Newspapers Raising Prices as Advertising Falls
description: Across the country, newspaper prices have been increasing in a trend that has not been seen since the early 1980's, when prices jumped to their current levels.

title: Raiders Oust Bengals, 20-10
description: As the sun made its way across the afternoon sky today, the Raiders made their way across the Los Angeles Coliseum field one final time. The day was slipping by, their halftime lead had dissolved into a tie and overtime beckoned.

title: Condom Plan Hearing Delayed
description: The New York City Board of Education said yesterday that it would postpone its public hearing on a plan for expanded AIDS education that includes the availabilty of condoms to high-school students. Gwendolyn C. Baker, board president, said the hearing, scheduled for Wednesday, had been delayed until soon after the spring term begins on Feb. 1. Dr. Baker said that "given the universal concern about the developments in the Persian Gulf and the passing of the United Nations deadline, the board felt it was inappropriate to proceed on that day." Dr. Baker said board members also felt it was necessary to focus attention on Mayor David N. Dinkins's new budget.

title: Dokes, Ex-Champion, Is Arrested
description: Michael Dokes, a former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, was arrested on several charges Saturday night, the police said today.

title: More Books Revealing Lusts, Especially for Sales
description: The joke in the publishing industry these days is that if you cannot say anything good about someone, say it in a book. As never before, bookshelves are crowded with biographies and autobiographies filled with charges and countercharges, accusation and invective.

title: Run, Rabbit, Run
description: HE has always sounded the same. Jeff Hostetler has been around the Giants for seven seasons, but in conversations the tone of his voice has seldom changed. Cool, calm and collected. Even in his frustration at not getting a chance to be anything but a backup quarterback.

title: After Layoffs, St. Louis Rethinks Future, Again
description: Outside the gargantuan 400-acre complex of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation it rained ice this week; inside the dozens of buildings there was a blizzard of pink slips. In the wake of the Defense Department decision to scrap the unbuilt, multibillion-dollar A-12 attack aircraft, the aerospace company began laying off one out of every seven workers.

title: Quintet Is From Las Vegas, But It's Far From Glittery
description: The Sierra Wind Quintet, which played a fascinating collection of recent music at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night, discourages the usual image of Las Vegas as purveyor of sin, bad taste and tough college basketball. Its five members teach at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas and play in that city's symphony orchestra. Lynn Arnold Huntzinger, the hornist, is also busy as a musician for popular casino acts.

title: Man Faces Charges For Keeping Secret His AIDS Infection
description: A Santa Barbara man has been charged with assault in an indictment that accuses him of having sex with a woman without telling her he is infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Government Is Battered In 2 of ABC's Movies
description: Perhaps it's just coincidence, or maybe it's the beginning of an odd trend, but governmental authority is taking a beating in prime-time television movies these days.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARLENE DIETRICH emerged from seclusion to join a host of celebrities trying to save the movie studio near Berlin where she, BILLY WILDER and FRED ZINNEMAN first earned their stars in the 1920's and 1930's. The old Universal Film Company, better known as the U.F.A., in the town of Babelsberg just south of Berlin, dismissed several hundred workers on Dec. 31 in an attempt to stave off economic collapse.

title: Lieder From Award Winner Of Lotos Foundation
description: The Lotos Foundation presented the winner of its first $10,000 career-enhancement award, LeRoy Villa nueva, in his New York recital debut on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. (Future awards may go to artists and writers as well as musicians.) With forgivable enthusiasm, a foundation representative introduced Mr. Villanueva as one of America's great baritones.

title: Going to School In the Boxing Ring
description: FOR more than a decade, Westchester Community College has offered a boxing course, the only one of its kind in the country that can be taken for credit. "Introduction to Boxing," taught by Stephen Acunto, starts with the origins of the sport in ancient times, but soon enough the lectern is abandoned for the ring.

title: Galeries Names Head in U.S.
description: Eugenia M. Ulasewicz, a regional vice president for Bloomingdale's, has been appointed president of Galeries Lafayette/USA, the American branch of the Paris-based department store chain, said Georges Meyer, Galeries Lafayette's chairman and chief executive.

title: Mine Work Held Responsible For Damage to Bottle House
description: Local residents say a mining operation is responsible for damage to a historic house built of bottles.

title: Questions About New Glaxo Drugs
description: IN the last decade, Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. has been one of the strongest British stocks, largely as a result of Zantac, its anti-ulcer medicine that is the world's top-selling drug. In the year that ended June 30, Zantac accounted for 49 percent of Glaxo's sales of $:2.85 billion ($4.98 billion).

title: In Germany, a Feeling Of Shock at Crackdown
description: Germany, where Mikhail S. Gorbachev enjoyed perhaps higher esteem than elsewhere in Europe for his role in bringing about unification, has reacted with extraordinary shock and anger to the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania.

title: Jane Brown Weds Dr. Jay Stallman
description: Jane Bayless Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daren D. Brown of Mobile, Ala., was married yesterday to Dr. Jay Bennett Stallman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Stallman of Forest Hills, Queens, by Rabbi Steven Silberman at Congregation Ahavas Chesed in Mobile.

title: Lithuania; AT A GLANCE
description: Government

title: 40 Are Killed and 50 Injured as Fans Riot at a South African Soccer Match
description: At least 40 spectators were killed and 50 others were injured in fighting today during a soccer game at Orkney, a gold-mining town 80 miles southwest of here in the western Transvaal.

title: Wheat Planting Down
description: Farmers have planted slightly more than 51 million acres of winter wheat for harvest this year, down 10 percent from 1990, the Agriculture Department said Friday. A major reason for the reduction is the department's requirement that farmers take more land from wheat production this year in an effort to stem rising stockpiles and depressed market prices. Winter wheat accounts for about three-fourths of the total United States wheat output.

title: Norwegian Violist Plays Bach
description: Lars Anders Tomter, a Norwegian violist with an exceptionally rich tone, made his New York debut on Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. His partner was Leif Ove Andsnes, a pianist who made an impressive debut in the same hall nearly two years ago. They collaborated as equals, and mirrored each other closely in matters of dynamics, phrasing and style.

title: Presidential Power
description: The Congressional debate on war in the Persian Gulf paid belated respect to the constitutional system for deciding when America goes to war. It was an impressive debate. But it showed, in reality, how dominant is the power of the modern President.

title: Blind Rage in Bensonhurst
description: The stabbing of the Rev. Al Sharpton on Saturday as he prepared to lead a protest demonstration in Brooklyn deserves condemnation from every New Yorker. No citizen should have to put his life at risk to exercise the right of protest. And as provocative and difficult as Mr. Sharpton can be, that is all he was doing on Saturday.

title: Carter's Touchdown Caps Trek Back From Misery
description: Michael Carter said on Saturday that he had lost 12 pounds in the last 12 days. That meant that Carter, the 49ers' robust nose tackle, was down from 338 pounds to 326 pounds when he galloped 61 yards with an interception for a touchdown in the waning seconds of San Francisco's 28-10 playoff victory here over the Washington Redskins.

title: 3 Killed, 2 Injured When Cars Crash on L.I.
description: Three teen-age girls were killed and 2 other youths were injured in a Nassau County auto accident involving two drunken drivers early today, the police said.

title: Some New Ski Pants
description: Style is as much a part of ski wear as warmth and comfort. Sidewinders, a skier's answer to cowboys' chaps, fall somewhere in between. Maverick Mountain of St. Louis has made the chaps out of Supplex, a Du Pont water-repellent material. They are designed to slip over street wear.

title: The Bridge Time Bomb Remains
description: The problem was undeniably serious. The tracks that carry subway trains across the Manhattan Bridge rely on a series of steel support beams. Late last month, inspectors discovered that a plate needed to hold one of those beams in place was missing. As a result, the beam had slipped to within half an inch of falling -- creating a real risk of a derailment and injury to passengers.

title: A Legend Turns to Selling Social Change to Companies
description: TONY SCHWARTZ, the one-time record maker, former advertising executive, occasional political consultant and constant media theorist, wants to give something back to his country. So, at the age of 67, he is joining the peace corps to help the underprivileged.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 13, 1990: MONDAY Dial Reit Inc Helene Curtis Inds Inc Indiana Energy Inc Phillips Pet Co TUESDAY AAR Corp Citicorp Federal Natl Mtg Assn Scott Paper Co Southern Ind Gas & Elec Co Teco Energy Inc WEDNESDAY ARCO Chem Co Barnett Bks Inc Cincinnati Gas & Elec Co Columbia Gas Sys Inc Dun & Bradstreet Corp Republic NY Corp St Joseph Lt & Pwr Co Wallace Computer Svcs Inc WPL Hldgs Inc THURSDAY Bear Stearns Cos Bearings Inc Clorox Co Comdisco Inc Firstar Corp Hartmarx Corp Ogden Corp Outboard Marine Corp PPG Inds Inc Ralston Purina Co Standard Fed Bk Troy Mich FRIDAY Aluminum Co Amer Communications Satellite Equitable Res Inc Nationwide Health Pptys Twin Disc Inc SATURDAY RMI Titanium Co SUNDAY Williams Cos

title: Rangers Snap Out Of Slump
description: The switch was a total hunch. What clicked as a result was pure magic.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The 1991 American Jazz Masters were named by the National Endowment for the Arts yesterday. The jazz masters, who will each receive a $20,000 N.E.A. grant, are DANNY BARKER, the New Orleans guitarist and banjo player; BUCK CLAYTON, the trumpeter and arranger; ANDY KIRK, the saxophonist and bandleader, and CLARK TERRY, the trumpeter and teacher.

title: FOREIGN RESIDENTS FLEE SAUDI TOWN
description: Fearing that Iraqi missiles could begin hitting this town and its important airport two days from now, Dhahran's large Asian population has begun to flee.

title: Iraqi-Americans Fearful Of Their Relatives' Fate
description: Behind the clamor of backgammon, dominoes and billiards at the Iraqi-American social club here, it is difficult not to strain to hear the latest news from the Middle East on the television set, which is never turned off.

title: Quayle's Family Connections Didn't Get Him Into the Guard
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Giants and Raiders Closer to Super Bowl The Giants beat the Chicago Bears, 31-3, and will meet San Francisco for the National Conference title.

title: Raiders' Townsend Leader of the Sacks
description: Greg Townsend was fooled once. Shame on Boomer Esiason. Greg Townsend would not be fooled twice.

title: In the Art World, As in Baseball, Free Agents Abound
description: Will Eric leave Mary? Will Brice go with Larry? Will Don find happiness with Arne, and David with Larry? Soap opera questions like these swirl around artists and dealers in a continuing cliff-hanger serial that might be called "As the Art World Turns."

title: Redmen Stop UConn's Streak
description: Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, wasn't doing too badly with his old lucky sweater, but he decided to break out a new one today as his Redmen went into Harry A. Gampel Pavilion, the year-old home of the University of Connecticut Huskies.

title: With Debuts and 'Vienna Waltzes'
description: The New York City Ballet's dancers hit an astonishing high over the weekend at the New York State Theater where the company introduced several debuts and George Balanchine's "Vienna Waltzes" into the season.

title: Knowing The Way Around
description: Most jazz singers take pop song forms as their universe; a few, since the 1960's, have jettisoned them completely. Cassandra Wilson, who performed at Fat Tuesday's on Tuesday evening, has other plans.

title: Mickelson Earns Improbable Victory
description: Phil Mickelson escaped the chill embrace of a snowman in the desert and, with birdies on two of the last three holes, gained a little piece of golfing history this afternoon.

title: Salzburg and the Cleveland in Pact
description: The Salzburg Festival said yesterday that it would enter an "ongoing relationship" with the Cleveland Orchestra beginning in the summer of 1992. The agreement was announced in Cleveland yesterday by Gerard Mortier, the festival's new artistic director, and Thomas Morris, executive director of the Cleveland Orchestra.

title: Metro Matters; If It's Tuesday, It Must Be Time To Fight Crime
description: When Mayor David N. Dinkins declared last year that New Yorkers must "take back our streets, by night as well as by day" nobody said it would be easy. Yet this may be one war in which some couch potatoes willingly enlist.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Hilde Oord has joined OMON New York Ltd., as director of account planning.* David Dinger has been named senior account executive at the Rowland Co., Los Angeles.* Clark Rector has been promoted to vice president of state government relations at the American Advertising Federation in Washington.* Thomas J. Hickey Jr. has been appointed associate publisher at Sports Illustrated.* Jay C. MacDonald has been named publisher of Inc. magazine in New York.* Floyd Sembler was promoted to publisher of the Hertz Travel Guide Network, San Francisco.

title: Text of Congressional Resolution on Use of Force in the Persian Gulf
description: Following is the text of the joint resolution approved by the Senate and the House of Representatives on Saturday, regarding the use of force in the Persian Gulf:

title: Miami Losing The Concorde
description: British Airways will suspend its Concorde service to Miami to save money, a company spokesman said.

title: For Salvadoran Refugees, an Empty Promise?
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Bush's Fateful Days; Lithuania Crisis Complicates Matters For President as Gulf Deadline Nears
description: On this momentous weekend when ominous news from Vilnius and Moscow vied with that from Jerusalem and Baghdad for the world's attention, comparisons between January 1991 and October 1956 were unavoidable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: Romania Eases Currency Rules
description: The Romanian Government said last week that it would allow companies and banks to trade freely in some hard currencies in an effort to hasten convertibility.

title: As Deadline Nears, America Speaks of Fear and Resolve
description: On what many Americans see as the eve of war in the Persian Gulf, the mood of the nation yesterday was somber, divided, apprehensive: a people caught between a desire for peace and the burden of what Woodrow Wilson called the right more precious than peace.

title: Georgians View Lithuania And Fear They Are Next
description: All day long, the anxious knots of men and women gather in front of the Government headquarters on Rustaveli Boulevard and talk about the one thing that unites them all -- the fear that Soviet Army tanks will soon rumble in and sweep them away, too.

title: E. C. Moore Is Dead; Embattled Advocate For Disabled Was 41
description: Eddie C. Moore, an administrator and advocate for people with mental and physical disabilities, died on Saturday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 41 years old.

title: Roll-Call in House on Measure Authorizing the Use of Force
description: Following is the 250-to-183 roll call today by which the House gave President Bush the authority to wage war in the Persian Gulf. A yes vote is a vote to authorize the use of U.S. armed forces pursuant to U.N. Security Council Resolution 678. Voting yes were 86 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting no were 179 Democrats and 3 Republicans. Also voting no was 1 Independent. X denotes those not voting.Present denotes those who voted they were "present" at the time of the vote but did not vote "yes" or "no" on the issue.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Just days after her half brother pleaded guilty to manslaughter and the Los Angeles District Attorney stopped trying to force her to return to testify at his trial, CHEYENNE BRANDO traveled to Paris from Tahiti and checked into a psychiatric clinic.

title: Shoal Creek Decision Puts Golf on a New Course
description: IT'S still debatable whether what has come to be known simply as "Shoal Creek" sounded the death knell for the nation's exclusionary private golf clubs or was merely an annoying wake-up alarm that has left most of America's privileged reaching for the snooze button.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column in some editions on Friday about Delta Berke's lawsuit against the producers of "Designing Women" misidentified the program on which Barbara Walters interviewed Ms. Burke.It was "The Barbara Walters Special," not "20/20."

title: Bush Deplores Soviet Crackdown But Takes No Steps in Response
description: President Bush today condemned the Soviet Union's military action in Lithuania, saying there was "no justification for the use of force" in the breakaway Soviet republic. But the President refrained from taking immediate steps to punish Moscow for its actions.

title: First Sale of State Holdings A Disappointment in Poland
description: Poland's campaign to sell five big state-owned companies seems to have been a disappointment.

title: Dinkins Plans $500 Million in New Taxes in Next Fiscal Year
description: The Dinkins administration will propose to balance New York City's budget for the coming fiscal year with nearly $1 billion in service cuts and more than $500 million in new taxes, city officials said last night.

title: Swedish Tobacco Move
description: Drawings of skulls and stories of smokers who have died will be printed on cigarette cartons next year, an official of the National Board of Health and Welfare said last week. Swedish cigarette packs now carry a brief health warning in small type. Cigarette cartons have no such warning. The board is the Government's policy-making body for a variety of social issues. The tobacco industry can appeal the board's plan.

title: With a Sense of Foreboding, Jordan Puts Troops on Alert
description: Wedged between Israel and Iraq, Jordan has ordered a military alert and stationed thousands of troops in defensive positions overlooking the Jordan Valley, in part as a signal to Israel to avoid involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis, diplomats here said.

title: Baltic Lands: 50 Years of Turmoil and Strife
description: 1939 A non-aggression pact is reached by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, and Hitler's Foreign Minister, Joachim von Ribbentrop. Secret protocols give Moscow predominance in Lithuania and the other Baltic states, Estonia and Latvia.

title: Bridge
description: Players at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Rye, N.Y. during the weekend had a difficult opportunity to move toward World Championship honors. Ron Gerard of White Plains and Mike Kamil of Teaneck, N.J., won the Pan-American Imp Pairs and qualified for a playoff in Memphis to choose one American team for the 1991 Bermuda Bowl in Yokohama, Japan. But as they are already qualified for the team trial, which will be held in parallel, the runners-up, Russ and Sheila Ekeblad of Providence, R.I., will go to Memphis in May. If they finish in the top three there in a pairs event they will go to Yokohama.

title: Life May Become a Weekly
description: Life magazine, which ceased publication as a weekly in 1972 and came back to life as a monthly in 1978, is now looking into the possibility of becoming a weekly again.

title: Giant Defense Makes Just the Right Move
description: Football players often set goals to push themselves ever farther. It matters not that the goals might be unrealistic, like allowing the Chicago Bears just one field goal.

title: Peat Says It Will Cut 300 Partners
description: Bowing to the economic downturn, KPMG Peat Marwick, the large accounting firm, has told its 1,875 partners that it will dismiss about 300 of them, or roughly one out of six.

title: Cuts Threaten School's Scant Supply of Hope
description: Louise Warren, who teaches students with learning disabilities to read at Public School 94 in the north Bronx, sat down one night last week to write letters to city and state officials protesting proposed budget cuts. To reach her students, Mrs. Warren uses poetry, pop-up picture books, goldfish crackers, hugs -- whatever it takes. Now, she found herself agonizing over how to get the people in charge to pay attention.

title: Greek-Albanian Talks Stalled Over Ethnic Issues
description: Talks between Greek and Albanian leaders failed today to resolve the crisis that has led to an exodus to Greece of more than 6,000 Albanians.

title: Roll-Call in Senate On a Gulf Assault
description: Following is the 52-to-47 roll-call vote by which the Senate approved a resolution authorizing President Bush to "use United States armed forces" to expel Iraq from Kuwait. A yes vote was a vote to authorize force; a no vote was a vote against the resolution. Voting yes were 9 Democrats and 43 Republicans. Voting no were 45 Democrats and 2 Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by x.

title: Ford Extends Shutdowns
description: The Ford Motor Company will continue temporary shutdowns among its 16 United States assembly plants through the first quarter of this year as dealer orders trickle in at a feeble pace, the auto maker's chairman said last week.

title: NBC Faces a Struggle To Keep Its Hit Shows
description: At a time when NBC needs its established hit shows more than ever, the network is about to enter negotiations with the producers of its four highest-rated comedies. At stake: whether the shows will remain on NBC next season -- and at what cost.

title: Accenting Craft in Potpourri of Settings
description: Examples of tap, ballet and modern dance were presented on Friday night in the third annual Choreographer's Showcase at the Soundance Studio in TriBeCa. All were competently put together. Yet, although no there were no totally clumsy sequences, there were few really imaginative ones. This was an evening of craft, rather than inspiration.

title: Evening of Piano Works By Mozart's Last Child
description: As it happens, 1791 saw not only the death of Mozart but also the birth of his sixth child, Franz Xaver Wolfgang, who became a pianist and composer himself. So along with the promised overload of Wolfgang Amadeus's music in this bicentennial year may come an occasional reminder of Franz Xaver's modest achievements.

title: Art Center for Newark Receives $3 Million
description: An ambitious proposal to build a performing-arts center in Newark got a lift yesterday with the announcement of a $3 million donation from the Samuel I. Newhouse Foundation, the philanthropic arm of Advance Publications , which publishes The Star-Ledger of Newark.

title: Marine Dies After Exercising
description: A marine died, apparently of a heart attack, after physical training, and six soldiers were hurt when their helicopter made a forced landing, the United States Military Command said today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday Retail Sales...Dec. Wednesday Consumer Price Index...Dec. Industrial Production...Dec. Capacity Utilization...Dec. Business Inventory...Nov. Thursday Housing Starts...Dec. Friday U.S. Balance of Trade...Nov.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Disney Adventures, a unit of Disney Publications in Burbank, Calif., to Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, New York, with an undisclosed budget.* Burns & Ricker Bagel Crisps to Heidelberg & Associates, New York, with a budget of about $3 million.* The Christian Science Monitor, to Orsatti & Parrish, Boston, for direct response broadcast business, with undisclosed billings.

title: 13 Arrested at Klan March
description: Thirteen people were arrested here Saturday when scuffles started during a Ku Klux Klan march. The charges included inciting a riot and assault. About 1,500 to 2,000 people lined the streets as 47 Klansmen walked along a six-block route. All the fights started in the crowd and involved no Klansmen, the police said. The Klansmen were demonstrating against the national holiday in honor of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I could not be the Secretary General and not be hopeful. Otherwise I would have to commit suicide in front of you." -- Javier Perez de Cuellar. [ A9:3. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Government's inability to sell a real estate development near Dallas misstated the involvement of Robert S. Strauss, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in the Gibraltar Savings Association, a Texas institution that was declared insolvent in 1988. Mr. Strauss owned stock in Gibraltar Savings but did not serve as a director.

title: How A.T.&T. Accident Snowballed
description: A series of errors allowed an A.T.& T. employee to cut a vital cable by mistake on Jan. 4. The errors then seriously delayed the restoration of long-distance service to New York City and surrounding areas.

title: Question Box
description: Perfect Football Seasons Q. Among Division I-A colleges this past season, Georgia Tech, at 11-0-1, was the only football team to finish undefeated. When did a college last complete a season not only undefeated, but also untied and unscored upon?

title: Dinkins Strongly Criticizes Report on Stock Sale Inquiry
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins angrily criticized yesterday the report of an independent city investigator that found troubling circumstantial evidence that the Mayor may have lied about a stock transaction with his son that was a major issue in his mayoral campaign.

title: Westchester 'Fatal Attraction' Trial to Open
description: Almost two years to the day after a 40-year-old woman was shot nine times in her Westchester County home, the woman who was romantically involved with the victim's husband will go on trial today in the slaying.

title: TURKEY GIVES U.S. LIMITED BASE USE
description: Turkey agreed this weekend to let the United States use air bases here in a war against neighboring Iraq, but said operations would be confined to "humanitarian and limited logistical support."

title: Maturing Group Visits the Fans, Lets Them Help
description: On Friday night at Madison Square Garden, Bell Biv DeVoe set its audience chanting the band's marketing slogan, and the full house shouted, "Hip-hop smoothed out on the R&B tip with a pop feel appeal." Ronnie DeVoe explained that the hip-hop came from the disk jockey, Spinbad, who was scratching records; the R&B came from the band, and the pop appeal meant that white people could also enjoy the music.

title: BRIEFS
description: RATINGS * Koger Properties Inc.'s subordinated debt rating has been lowered to B, from BBB, by Standard & Poor's. The company is based in Jacksonville, Fla. * Pacific Enterprises' preferred stock rating has been lowered to Baa-1, from A-3, and its commercial paper to Prime-2, from Prime-1, by Moody's Investor's Service. The holding company, which has interests in natural gas distribution and retailing, is based in Los Angeles. * Thermo Electron Corp.'s subordinated debt rating has been increased to BBB, from BB, by S.& P. The company is based in Waltham, Mass.

title: For Lithuanian-Americans, the News About Home Seems Terrible Indeed
description: Alina and Edward Staknys of Jamaica, Queens, are preoccupied by the news these days. They pore over newspapers, listen to reports by two radio stations at once and wait anxiously for television news broadcasts.

title: Retailers Are Facing Hard Choices
description: After the worst and most perplexing Christmas season in more than a decade, American retailers face an agonizing quandary: Should they be cautious and conservative, or aggressive, hoping to force their luck?

title: Johannesburg Journal; A White Liberal Finds Old Foes Are Now Allies
description: When President F. W. de Klerk asked Harry SchwarzHarry Schwarz to become South Africa's next ambassador to the United States, it was as if President Bush, in looking for a diplomatic troubleshooter to sell his policies abroad, had settled upon Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Bridge Battle: Clashes and Flurry of Memos
description: The inner workings of city government rarely offer glimpses of high drama, but the recent dismissal of the deputy commissioner in charge of New York City's bridges came close: beneath a policy dispute within the Department of Transportation -- whether to return subway traffic to the badly deteriorated Manhattan Bridge -- lay a complicated saga of bureaucratic infighting, vivid personalitiy clashes, a flurry of memos and heated debate that caused one city employee to compare it to the Caine Mutiny.

title: U.N. CHIEF'S TALKS WITH IRAQIS BRING NO SIGN OF CHANGE
description: Emerging from two and a half hours of talks with President Saddam Hussein, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations said tonight that he could report no progress on persuading Iraq to pull out of Kuwait by Tuesday's deadline.

title: Financing Is Offered on S.& L. Assets
description: In an auction next month, Federal officials plan to offer purchasers financing for up to 85 percent of the price of dozens of apartment buildings in Texas that the Government acquired in the savings industry bailout.

title: Turning Against the Military Life They Once Chose
description: Growing up in the rural community of Hollister, about 125 miles south of here, Jeffrey A. Paterson decided that joining the Marines after graduation would be a way to "break away from being a high school kid."

title: Sir Robert Jackson Is Dead at 79; A Former Major Official at U.N.
description: Sir Robert Jackson, a former Under Secretary General of the United Nations, died of a stroke on Saturday morning in the apartment of his son in London, the United Nations Secretariat said yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons Win 10th Game in a Row Vinnie Johnson scored 10 of his 19 points in the fourth quarter last night as the Detroit Pistons won their 10th consecutive game, 89-81, over the Dallas Mavericks. Joe Dumars added 17 points for the visiting Pistons, who won for the 12th time in their last 14 games. (AP) Bulls 110, Bucks 97: Michael Jordan scored 34 points -- his 10th consecutive game with 30 or more -- and Scottie Pippen scored 20 of his 23 points in the second half as the Bulls retained first place in the Central Division in the game at Chicago. The victory was Chicago's sixth in a row, 14th in the last 16 games and 12th in a row at home, where the Bulls are 17-3. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins Start Fast in Beating Wings Dave Christian and Ray Bourque scored power play goals last night on the game's first two shots to lead the Boston Bruins at home over the Detroit Red Wings, 6-1. Glen Wesley scored Boston's fifth and sixth goals before Steve Yzerman of Detroit spoiled Andy Moog's shutout bid with a short-handed goal early in the third period. Wesley, Bourque, Craig Janney, Ken Hodge and Bob Sweeney each had two assists as Boston regained a 3-point lead over Montreal in the Adams Division race. (AP) Sabres 9, Maple Leafs 3: Pierre Turgeon and Aleksandr Mogilny had two goals and three assists each to lead the visiting Sabres. Turgeon's line amassed 11 points, with Dave Snuggerud also getting a goal. Mike Hartman, Rick Vaive, Lou Franceschetti and Rob Ray also scored for Buffalo, 8-3-2 in its last 13 games. Daren Puppa, the Buffalo goaltender, added two assists for the Sabres. Mike Foligno, Gary Leeman and Dave Ellett scored for Toronto. Peter Ing, the Toronto goaltender, was honored before the game as the league's top rookie for December. (AP)

title: Drugs, Then Bureaucracy, Divide Mother and Children
description: One morning last month Michelle Rogers returned to Family Court in Manhattan to try to get her children back. It was her 10th appearance before Judge Judith B. Sheindlin since July. The judge was eager to return Mrs. Rogers's three children who are in foster care, but one obstacle remained. The 31-year-old mother did not have an apartment.

title: Suffolk County Leadership Is in Turmoil Over Budget
description: Government is in turmoil here, where the Suffolk County Executive, Patrick G. Halpin, has sued the County Legislature over whose budget for the county will take effect.

title: Security Pacific Changing Role
description: The Security Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that it intended to give up its primary dealership in Government securities and restructure its activities into a regional, non-primary dealer operation.

title: Americans Don't Expect Short War
description: A majority of Americans say they are satisfied that President Bush has done everything he should to prevent war in the Persian Gulf. But the country remains deeply divided over whether fighting Iraq is the right policy, and most people do not expect the short war with relatively low casualties that Mr. Bush and his officials have talked about, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

title: Your Move, Mr. Hussein
description: Dear President Hussein:

title: Airlines Must Do More for Business Travelers; Too Much Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Christian Democratic Figure Resigns in German Scandal
description: Leaders of the governing Christian Democratic Union in Baden-Wurttemberg moved today to choose a new premier after the resignation of the longtime incumbent, Lothar Spath.

title: Some Wimp Stuff
description: Here are some columns I'd write if the deadline weren't already here:

title: Airlines Enrich Lures, But Will They Work?
description: The new frequent-flier lures being dangled by the nation's major airlines this winter seem to be reshuffling passengers among different carriers and have not attracted many new travelers, travel agents and airline industry officials say.

title: France and 3 Arab States Issue an Appeal to Hussein
description: France and three Arab countries issued 11th-hour appeals tonight urging President Saddam Hussein to announce Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait before midnight Tuesday to avoid a war with the United States and its allies.

title: Owens Finalists Named
description: Greg LeMond, the American cyclist; Rosa Mota, the Portuguese marathoner, and Merlene Ottey, the Jamaican sprinter, are finalists for the 1991 Jesse Owens International Trophy, given to the world's top amateur athlete. The winner will be announced Feb. 5.

title: New Surveys Of the Universe Confound Theorists
description: ASTRONOMERS' increasing power of observation is exposing awkward weaknesses in cosmology's cherished theories and imposing ever-narrowing limits on the imaginations of scientists engaged in the audacious vocation of figuring out the origin, evolution and ultimate fate of the universe.

title: Gorbachev Puts Blame for Clash On Lithuanians
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev blamed leaders of the separatist Lithuanian Parliament and their supporters today for bringing on the Soviet military attack that killed 14 people in Vilnius on Sunday morning.

title: Elevated Freight Line Being Razed Amid Protests
description: Demolition has begun on the southern end of what was once known as the Life Line of New York, an elevated freight railroad that threads around and burrows through the vast industrial mesas of the lower West Side of Manhattan.

title: Knicks Are Routed By Hawks
description: Considering what John MacLeod watched tonight, it was hard to blame him for being ejected.

title: Retail Sales Group Told Recession May Be Short
description: Two economists told the annual convention of the National Retail Federation in New York yesterday that the recession would be of relatively short duration and would be followed by a gradual improvement as the year progressed. But both speakers took pains to hedge their forecasts.

title: Hilton Hotels' Net Is Up 1.5%
description: Facing intense competition and a weak travel environment, the Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter earnings had increased only 1.5 percent, to $27.3 million, or 57 cents a share, from $26.9 million, or 55 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on Saturday with excerpts from the Congressional debate about the Persian Gulf referred incorrectly in some copies to Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan. He is a Senator, not a Representative.

title: AT THE FRONTIER, NO SIGN OF EXODUS
description: The Lithuanians who walked across the Soviet-Polish border today at the crossing in this remote village were talking of jobs, not political flight.

title: Man Faces Charges For Keeping Secret His AIDS Infection
description: A Santa Barbara man has been charged with assault in an indictment that accuses him of having sex with a woman without telling her he is infected with the AIDS virus.

title: UAL's Unions Prepared To Renew Buyout Effort
description: United Airlines' union workers are ready to renew their efforts to buy the company once the economy improves, the head of the pilots union said. "The union employees at United are fully prepared and economically capable of maintaining their role as major players in any acquisition efforts at our company," Frederick C. Dubinsky, chairman of the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, said.

title: No Aid for a Repressive Moscow
description: Washington can deal with, but no longer support, a Government in Moscow that forcibly suppresses a democratically elected government in Lithuania.

title: Gift to Barnard Honors Iphigene Sulzberger
description: The late Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, central figure in the family that has published The New York Times since 1896, was honored yesterday with a $5 million contribution from her family to her alma mater, Barnard College.

title: Airlines Must Do More for Business Travelers; British Restrictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; Dawn Upshaw, Romantic
description: The American soprano Dawn Upshaw is a hot item just now in the world of classical music, the thinking person's soubrette. With her voice both crystalline and warm, at ease in light lyric and coloratura roles, her demonstrable intelligence in repertory selection and her musicality in interpretation, she has won a fervent group of admirers, the New York chapter of which turned out in droves on Sunday afternoon for her recital at Alice Tully Hall.

title: The Vote That Congress Can't Forget
description: For more than two decades, the Congressional vote that lawmakers most often cite as the one they would like to take back is their 1964 vote for the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, the resolution that was used as authority for the war in Vietnam. Only two Senators and no Representatives voted no.

title: Foreigners Are Scrambling To Exit Israel on Few Flights
description: Some were anxious, others apologetic. But every one of the 412 passengers who climbed aboard Pan Am flight 6119 to New York at dawn today was clearly relieved. It was the airline's last flight out of Israel before Jan. 15, the deadline for possible war.

title: Atwater Has Brain Surgery
description: Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican Party, had four hours of brain surgery today and came through the operation well, Leslie Goodman, a party spokeswoman, said. She said Mr. Atwater's doctor, Edward Laws, removed tissue to relieve pressure on Mr. Atwater's brain. The surgery, while not a cure for Mr. Atwater's brain tumor, was expected to eliminate occasional episodes of confusion and disorientation that Mr. Atwater was having.

title: Rose Starts Service
description: Pete Rose yesterday began serving a court-ordered community service sentence as a gym teacher's aide in Cincinnati schools. He showed up at Heberle Elementary School wearing blue jeans and running shoes shortly after students reported for school. Rose must do 1,000 hours of community service as part of a sentence for evading Federal income taxes.

title: United Church of Christ Urges Fight Against Rising Racism
description: The United Church of Christ has issued a pastoral letter warning that racism is a deepening problem in America.

title: Ralph Paine Jr., 84, Fortune's Publisher From 1953 to 1967
description: Ralph Delahaye Paine Jr., a former publisher of Fortune magazine and other Time Inc. periodicals, died on Saturday at Tisch Hospital in Manhattan. He was 84 years old and lived in Barton, Vt.

title: Schemes Are Debated For Dumping Sewage Deep Beneath the Sea
description: OCEANOGRAPHERS are debating whether sewage sludge and other wastes can be safely deposited on the deep sea floor.

title: People
description: Robert Chimbel has joined Zwiren Ayer, Chicago as executive vice president. Sharon K. Tettenhorst, Bryce C. McTavish, James R. Fortune and Thomas K. Townsend have been named vice presidents of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis. Michael Stocker was named vice president and senior copywriter at Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Southfield, Mich. Ira Garey was named vice president of group sales for Murdoch Magazines. Michelle Berman was named publisher of Seventeen magazine.

title: Decision on Bahr Expected Today
description: Matt Bahr, the Giants' kicker, underwent tests today to determine the extent of a neck injury he suffered Sunday. Coach Bill Parcells said he hoped to know Tuesday if Bahr would be able to play next Sunday in the National Football Conference championship game against the 49ers in San Francisco.

title: Edberg Is a First-Round Survivor
description: Stefan Edberg, a first-round loser as the top seeded player in the French and United States Opens, slipped away from an attack by a scrappy Soviet qualifier to avoid the same fate at the Australian Open.

title: Chief Executive Named For A. L. Laboratories
description: A. L. Laboratories Inc. has an ambitious growth plan, and it named a new president and chief executive yesterday to try to carry it out.

title: Oil From Rice Aids Monkey
description: In preliminary animal studies using monkeys, rice bran oil showed an ability to lower harmful cholesterol levels by up to 30 percent without reducing the so-called good cholesterol believed to protect against heart attacks, a researcher said today.

title: The Stakes in the Gulf
description: As the clock ticks off the minutes till midnight, the imminence of war in the Persian Gulf presses Americans into several camps. Some are pacifists who oppose ever using force. Many are impatiently eager to punish, and incapacitate, Saddam Hussein. Still others accept last weekend's decision by Congress to support the President's Jan. 15 deadline but urge that the vote be understood as authorizing war, not ordering it.

title: Spatula's Purpose
description: Archeologists call it the mystery of the bone spatula.

title: Charles J. Muss; Developer, 89
description: Charles J. Muss, a real-estate developer, died on Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: 375 at Green Giant Face Layoff Friday
description: About 375 workers at Green Giant's Western United States processing plant will be laid off on Friday, but the parent company, Pillsbury, said it hoped to offer most of them other jobs. The layoffs are part of a reorganization by Pillsbury's owner, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate. Workers were told of the laoffs in May.

title: Horton Finds a Home as a Raider
description: For the true athlete, for the diligent and determined football player whose athletic gifts are sometimes hidden or simply have not surfaced, somehow, some way, when he loses the game as his career, the game always seems to find him. The football does, too.

title: Prosecutors' Feuds Hinder Inquiries
description: For the Federal Bureau of Investigation it was a coup. In late 1988, agents slipped into the Manhattan headquarters of John Gotti and planted a concealed listening device.

title: Dow Declines 17.58 in Day of Wide Swings
description: In a roller-coaster ride propelled by war rumblings, stocks plunged yesterday for most of the session but bounced back sharply in late trading after the Cable News Network reported that Iraq might be willing to withdraw its troops from Kuwait.

title: A 'Guarantee' for Graduates
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez proposes a warranty on products of the New York City school system: high school graduates. The warranty, a certificate of "employability," would guarantee that students have mastered basic reading, writing and math skills. That's what a high school diploma used to guarantee. But diplomas have been devalued by a growing number of graduates with poor skills.

title: Books of The Times; An Old Pinocchio Reverting to Wood
description: Pinocchio in Venice By Robert Coover 330 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: 6 More Are Arraigned In California Drug Case
description: Five sheriff's deputies and a police officer pleaded not guilty in Federal court today to charges that they beat suspected drug dealers and then robbed them of at least $100,000.

title: Mitchell and Dole Set Senate Legislative Agendas
description: Emerging briefly from the shadow of the Persian Gulf crisis, the Senate Democratic and Republican leaders introduced bills today setting out their legislative priorities for the 102d Congress.

title: Moscow's Poisoned Tomato
description: For me, the Hitler-Stalin pact of 1939, as a result of which Lithuania, a peaceful, neutral country, was incorporated in 1940 into the Soviet Union, is not an abstraction. I was in Vilnius and saw the Soviet tanks roll in. Immeasurable suffering followed: mass terror and deportations of hundreds of thousands to gulags.

title: Review/Music; With Russian Folk Melodies
description: The Andreyev Balalaika Orchestra was established at the Russian Imperial Court in St. Petersburg in 1888, and made its American debut at Carnegie Hall in 1911. The orchestra has not performed in the United States since then, but it appears to have flourished over the last 80 years and on Saturday evening it returned to Carnegie Hall for a program devoted largely to Russian folk melodies and transcriptions of short orchestral works.

title: Barbara Bush in Wheelchair
description: Barbara Bush, using a wheelchair to get around the White House today, was "uncomfortable, but in good spirits," a day after breaking her left leg in a sledding accident at Camp David, said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. Doctors ordered Mrs. Bush to put no weight on the leg for three days and then to use crutches, said her press secretary, Anna Perez. Mrs. Bush, 65 years old, broke the fibula bone in her left calf when her sled hit a tree.

title: Yonkers Pact Is Signed For Integrated Housing
description: The court-ordered desegregation of Yonkers' mainly white neighborhoods reached a milestone yesterday when a developer signed a contract to build 142 units of public housing on five sites.

title: Q&A
description: Cats on TV

title: Minimum Wage Rise Hurt Restaurants
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc., Enfield, Conn., has established a $50 million line of credit with a group of banks led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Ratings * New Haven's general obligation rating has been lowered to Baa, from Baa-1, by Moody's Investors Service. * Occidental Petroleum Corp.'s senior debt rating has been increased to BBB, from BBB-, by Standard & Poor's. The company is based in Los Angeles.

title: The New World Order Dies
description: The New World Order was born in Washington on Sept. ll, 1990, and was shot dead in the streets of Vilnius on Jan. 13, 1991.

title: IRAQI PARLIAMENT VOTES TO DEFY U.S.
description: In an extraordinary war rally two days before the United Nations deadline, Iraq's Parliament voted unanimously today to follow President Saddam Hussein into combat with the United States and its allies in a "showdown" over this country's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

title: Mexican Inflation at 30%
description: Mexican consumer prices rose by 30 percent in 1990, the central bank reported last week. The figure is higher than the previous year but still somewhat heartening in a country that once suffered triple-digit inflation. Officials have pledged to cut the 1990 figure in half this year as they press for a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada.

title: El Cajon Journal; Iraqi Emigres Torn Between 2 Homes
description: Behind the clamor of backgammon, dominoes and billiards at the Iraqi-American social club here, it is difficult not to strain to hear the latest news from the Middle East on the television set, which is never turned off.

title: Bridge
description: Of the players who follow the tournament trail assiduously and win significant titles, the oldest is perhaps David Treadwell, 78 years old, of Wilmington, Del. At the Tri-State Regional Championships, which ended on Sunday in Rye, N.Y., he added to his large collection of titles by winning the Knockout Teams along with Brian Trent, Arnie Fisher, both of Cherry Hill, N.J., Jeanne Elkner of Clementon, N.J., Juanita Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., and Lynne Deas of Newport News, Va.

title: On the Verge of War, G.I.'s Are Anxious
description: Only hours before a deadline that could thrust them into war with Iraq, American troops say they are at least thankful that the long, often nerve-racking wait in the lonely northern deserts of Saudi Arabia may be over.

title: Troop Moves Show Hussein Wants To Fight, Many U.S. Officials Say
description: Iraqi forces have tightened their defensive positions in Kuwait and stepped up aircraft training in recent days as Baghdad and Washington gear up for war, American intelligence reports say.

title: D'Amato Aide Elected State G.O.P. Chairman
description: William Powers, a top aide to United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for a decade, was elected today as state chairman of New York's Republican Party.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a New York City Ballet review was published through a mechanical error. The dancer shown was indeed Judith Fugate, but without Peter Boal.

title: Disarray in Moscow Vilnius Crackdown Raises Questions On Who Leads Nation and to Where
description: The violent attack in Lithuania has only intensified the question of whether the crisis in the Soviet nation is beyond the control of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: U.S. AND IRAQ PREPARE FOR WAR AS TONIGHT'S DEADLINE NEARS; DIPLOMACY REMAINS FRUITLESS
description: The United States girded for war, perhaps as early as this week, as hopes for a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis faded rapidly today.

title: Murder Trial Focusing On Battered-Wife Issue
description: The facts are not in dispute: On the night of May 23, 1989, Sarah Smith, a 43-year-old social worker, shot her sleeping husband once in the head with a .25-caliber pistol that she had taken from his pocket.

title: Killing of 5 in Boston's Chinatown Raises Fears of Asian Gang Wars
description: The killing of five men in a Chinatown social club on Saturday has raised fears that new and more violent Asian gangs are struggling for control in Boston and underscores how a recent wave of immigrants from Asia has transformed this city's small Chinatown, the police and community leaders say.

title: Airlines Must Do More for Business Travelers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corps of Engineers Struggles to Alter Mississippi's Fate
description: IN the quiet of the Louisiana countryside, five miles from the nearest tiny town, the Army Corps of Engineers carries on a titanic struggle with the Mississippi River. Many believe it is a battle that in the long run the engineers are bound to lose.

title: CHRONICLE
description: QUINCY JONES received an award on Sunday night in Los Angeles from the American Friends of Hebrew University. Mr. Jones, the composer and conductor, produced the recording "We Are the World," which benefited African famine victims.

title: BRIEFS
description: Air Products G.m.b.H., a unit of Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., an industrial gases and chemicals company, has acquired PURA International Hapke G.m.b.H., Hamburg, Germany, a supplier of polyurethane release agents. Terms were not disclosed. * Boeing Aerospace Operations Inc., Seattle, said it had been given a three-year, $103 million extension to the five-year flight equipment processing contract first awarded by NASA in 1985. * Brittania Airways, London, has ordered six twin-engine Boeing Co. 757 aircraft powered by Rolls-Royce RB211-535 engines. The order is worth about $:36 million for Rolls-Royce. * Conversion Industries, Pasadena, Calif., an alternative energy sources company, said its 52 percent owned unit, International Colin Energy Corp., would purchase Amoco Canada Petroleum Co. Ltd.'s assets in the Panny area of northern Alberta for $8 million. * Courtaulds P.L.C., London, a maker of chemical and industrial products, said its Courtaulds Coatings unit had bought the marine coatings business of Veneziani S.p.A., a unit of the Italian paint company Maxfin S.p.A. Terms were not disclosed. * Reynolds Metals Co., Richmond, said it would buy Mawson Pacific Ltd., the Australian gold-producing subsidiary of NZ Forest Products Ltd. of New Zealand. Terms were not disclosed. * Saab Automobile A.B., the Swedish auto maker, which is 50 percent owned by the General Motors Corporation, said it expected its capital base to be severely reduced by heavy losses. David Herman, president of Saab Automobile, indicated that Saab might lose less than half of its $1.2 billion in capital. He said the losses were partially attributable to weakness in the automobile markets. * Schield Management Co., Denver, an investment company, said it would acquire Affiliated Investment Advisers Corp., Chicago, for undisclosed terms. * Siemens A.G., the German electronics group, said it would take over the machinery manufacturers Starkstrom-Anlagenbau Leipzig G.m.b.H. and Starkstrom-Anlangenbau Rostock G.m.b.H. in eastern Germany. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bush Aide Is Named to Fed
description: President Bush today nominated the White House economist Lawrence B. Lindsey to fill a longstanding vacancy on the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Touring the Human Body With a Computer
description: PEN and ink remain the traditional tools of medical illustrators, but some are using powerful computers to create detailed three-dimensional pictures of the body on computer screens.

title: An Arbitrary Diplomatic Deal Becomes an Imminent Threat
description: The Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait was adopted by the United Nations Security Council as a result of diplomatic compromises and policy considerations.

title: Suspect in '63 Evers Slaying Vows Appeal of Extradition
description: A judge here ordered today that Byron de la Beckwith be returned to Mississippi to face a charge of first-degree murder in the 1963 slaying of Medgar Evers, the civil rights leader.

title: Accounts
description: * Parker Pen dropped Lowe International in favor of Eurocom for its $11.5 million account. Della Femina McNamee will handle the $3 million U.S. portion of the account. * Sport Graphics Inc., which makes leisure products in Cranston, R.I., to Griffin Bacal Inc., New York, with a budget of $2 million to $3 million. * Thomas Nelson Publishers Inc., Nashville, to CDHM Advertising, Stamford, Conn., with a budget of more than $1 million. * New York Mets, to TBWA Advertising, New York, with a undisclosed budget. The previous agency was Della Femina McNamee, New York. * Perrier Group of America, Greenwich, Conn., a division of Source Perrier S.A. of France, to Chapman Direct Advertising, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam, for undisclosed billings. The previous agency was Hal Riney & Partners.

title: McCabe's New Agency Is Luring Top Talent
description: Most new agencies set up shop with at least one well-known client lined up and then use this to lure top talent.

title: Children's Book Award Winners Named
description: The John Newbery Medal for the outstanding children's book of 1990 was awarded yesterday to Jerry Spinelli, the author of "Maniac Magee," published by Little, Brown.

title: By Design - Green: The New Neutral
description: Green, in all its subtle gradations, is fast becoming the new neutral. Are you among those who find black banal and beige boring? Or perhaps you think gray is a bit too grim, navy nothing new and white too bright (not to mention a chore to keep clean). If so, then the new off-tone greens are for you.

title: Leland L. Tolman, 82, Ex-Court Administrator
description: Leland Locke Tolman, a lawyer and former New York State court administrator, died on Friday at his home in Castine, Me. He was 82 years old.

title: Warner to Make 20 Films With European Companies
