description: The Warner Brothers film studio said today that it had formed a partnership with a group of European entertainment companies to produce and distribute at least 20 films.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Several hundred friends will celebrate RONALD REAGAN'S 80th birthday at a party on Feb. 6 at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif. Among those who have said yes to the invitation are MARGARET THATCHER, MERV GRIFFIN, the hotel's owner, and LIZA MINNELLI and LEE GREENWOOD, who will provide the entertainment.

title: Sharp Gyrations Mark Trading
description: Talk of war and peace in the Middle East led to sharp gyrations in the credit markets yesterday, but by late in the session prices of Treasury securities were little changed.

title: Key Rates
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13

title: Sharp's Futuristic Approach To Selling Office Products
description: RESPONDING to rising competition in office equipment, Sharp Electronics will begin a series of futuristic ads on Thursday intended to sell products ranging from facsimile machines to copiers.

title: Review/Cello; Yo-Yo Ma Personalizes Six Bach Suites
description: Presenting Bach's Six Solo Suites for Cello in one long gulp is an adventure in concentration for both listener and performer. Bach wrote them for an instrument altogether quieter and more modest than the one Yo-Yo Ma brought to Carnegie Hall on Sunday. And certainly solitary study or at most the presence of a few colleagues was the intended milieu, not the vastness of Carnegie Hall, the presence of 2,800 listeners and the marathon format of two complete recitals with an hour's break between them.

title: Whittle Forms Unit for Book Series
description: Whittle Communications yesterday announced the formation of Whittle Books, a division intended to expand the publication of books containing advertising. William S. Rukeyser was named chairman and chief executive of the division, which will be based at corporate headquarters in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: Jenkins's Wife Dies
description: Last week was one of triumph and sadness for Ferguson Jenkins. Four days after he was elected to the Hall of Fame, his 31-year-old wife, Maryanne, died Saturday at Oklahoma Memorial Hospital in Oklahoma City from injuries sustained in a Dec. 9 automobile accident.

title: And the Winner Is. . . .
description: Officials at the world championships have apologized to Hayley Lewis of Australia and Tamas Darnyi of Hungary over a mix-up at the meet's closing ceremonies Sunday.

title: Tracing Arctic Haze
description: SCIENTISTS in Canada have traced pollutants that contribute to the Arctic equivalent of smog to industrial sources in Western Europe.

title: European Nations Plan No Further Peace Efforts
description: Frustrated at seeing their diplomatic efforts rebuffed by Baghdad, European Community governments said today that they planned no new last-minute initiative aimed at persuading Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.

title: The Vietnam Generation Surrenders Its Certainty
description: Where once they were certain about so many things, people of the Vietnam generation, approaching middle age, have discovered that life is more ambiguous, a palette of many shades of gray.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Said to Seek Bank
description: American Banker, a newspaper for the banking industry, reported yesterday that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the pioneer of leveraged buyouts, had emerged as one of the suitors for the Bank of New England and its affiliates. Kohlberg, Kravis joins two banking companies that have confirmed their interest -- the BankAmerica Corporation and the Banc One Corporation -- and at least three other potential bidders.

title: More on the Gulf Crisis
description: VIETNAM AND KUWAIT Many Americans who lived through the Vietnam era are finding as they face a new war that answers are no longer so simple. Page A14.

title: Net Up at Chase and Morgan; First Chicago Posts Decline
description: Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan yesterday announced higher profits for the fourth quarter of last year, as Chase benefited from the sale of office buildings and Morgan reaped rewards from its strong financial condition.

title: Season at Saratoga Extended to Five Weeks
description: In an attempt to attract a broader public, New York horse racing made a major marketing pitch yesterday when it expanded the season at its popular upstate track in Saratoga from four weeks to five.

title: CO2 Rises May Favor Trees Over Grasslands
description: ECOLOGISTS studying the prairie suggest that higher levels of carbon dioxide could change the vegetative face of America, benefiting woody plants at the expense of grasslands.

title: The Kremlin Revives an Old Refrain
description: The official Soviet explanation for the military intervention in Lithuania, belying President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recent policies of glasnost, strongly resembles official explanations by his predecessors of the invasions of Hungary in 1956, Czechoslovakia in 1968, and Afghanistan in 1979.

title: Market Place; An Object Lesson From a High Flier
description: SEVEN months after the Securities and Exchange Commission began an investigation, a home remodeling company whose shares were once high fliers on Wall Street has conceded that many of its old financial statements were "materially incorrect."

title: Careers; Colleges Help Alumni Who Lose Jobs
description: UNIVERSITIES are facing a troubling question: How much help can and should they give their alumni who lose middle-management jobs?

title: N.F.L. Games To Be Played As Scheduled
description: Although the National Football League is planning to hold the climactic moments of the professional football season as scheduled, an official acknowledged yesterday that events in the Persian Gulf could eventually cause the league to consider a change in its plans.

title: Don't Obscure the Real Crime of Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Jazz; Balancing the Stoic and the Assertive
description: During its second tune at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night, the pianist Geoff Keezer's group broke down regular time for just a moment, trading the steady authority of the beat for ambiguity and chance. For a second the group showed a real vulnerability, as if music were not only about assertion.

title: Poets for Lithuania
description: We are three poets, friends, representing three languages: Lithuanian, Russian and Polish. We call upon the world community -- our fellow writers and all people of conscience -- to raise its voice in protest against the inhuman Soviet assault on the people of Lithuania. The events of the last days remind us bitterly of the worst excesses of the Soviet state. THOMAS VENCLOVA JOSEPH BRODSKY CZESLAW MILOSZ

title: Credibility, Too, Is a Victim Of the Repression in Vilnius
description: Yelena Trifanova turned on her television Sunday evening to hear the latest news about events in Lithuania and, she said, she felt as if she had stepped back in time, to the years before Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader and began encouraging honest and truthful reporting.

title: Turner Shifts 4 Executives
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. announced today that it had promoted four senior executives in a further realignment of top management.

title: Law and Order in China Means More Executions
description: In normal times, Zhou Hongqing might have gotten off with half a dozen years in prison, but instead the court apparently decided to make an example of the 26-year-old man. At the end of last month, he was sentenced to death.

title: Business Scene; The New Surge In Self-Employed
description: THE late 20th century has left quite a mark on the American labor force. The very image of the worker has switched from blue-collar factory hand to white-collar sales clerk. Women have become almost as visible as men at work. And now, it turns out, the self-employed are making a comeback -- mainly because so many women are choosing to work for themselves.

title: Villanova Tops Georgetown, 65-56
description: Lance Miller scored 18 points and Villanova made 10 consecutive free throws in the final 2 minutes 4 seconds tonight as the Wildcats defeated 19th-ranked Georgetown, 65-56, in a Big East Conference game.

title: Restraint, Mr. Bush
description: As we wait to see what will happen now in the Persian Gulf, it may be useful to record what was supposed to happen but did not. We were supposed to see the emergence of a "new world order" in the course of the first crisis of the post-cold-war era. For a period, it looked as if we might just; then, in an instant, we relapsed into the cold war mode.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Public School 94's response to budget cuts referred incorrectly in some copies to the women shown. The upper picture showed Irene Dunbar, a school aide, not Gail Rubin, a first- grade teacher. The lower picture showed Louise Warren, a teacher, not Judith Markowitz, a guidance counselor.

title: Loved Ones Inspire Gifts To Neediest
description: For the last 20 years, Rhea Blackwood of Forest Hills, Queens, has sent $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund "in loving memory of my dear husband, Henry."

title: NCR's Net Down 24.5%
description: The NCR Corporation, the computer maker fighting a hostile takeover bid by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 24.5 percent despite record revenue.

title: Preventive Medicine
description: USERS of personal computers take their disk drives mostly for granted. There is not much you can do about a hard-disk drive anyway. Don't even think of opening it for repair; it was manufactured in conditions too clean to duplicate in a home or office.

title: Wilkinson Loses Ruling
description: A Federal judge in New York ordered a permanent injunction yesterday barring Wilkinson Sword Inc. in Atlanta from making claims that its Ultra Glide shaving system provided a shave "six times smoother" than the Gillette Company's products. Gillette sued the company in 1989.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Friday misstated the location of Allegheny General Hospital. It is in Pittsburgh.

title: Wiggins Touched The Hot Iron
description: Jack McKeon could hardly believe his eyes, or his luck. It was the first time he saw Alan Wiggins, in 1980, when McKeon, the new general manager for the San Diego Padres, was scouting his Class A Reno club.

title: OPEC Output Rose in '90
description: Oil production by OPEC kept rising in December, and the group's output for 1990 was the highest in 10 years, despite the global boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, according to a survey released today.

title: Jordanians Feeling Vulnerable as Deadline Nears
description: Palestinian and Islamic fundamentalist demonstrators burned American flags and lofted portraits of Saddam Hussein here today as the deadline for possible war in the Persian Gulf drew closer.

title: Review/Television; PBS's 'Frontline' Traces the Path To the Brink of War
description: Tonight, three hours before the midnight deadline for the possible use of force in the Persian Gulf, "Frontline" offers a cogent review of the planning or misplanning in Washington that has sent 400,000 American troops to Saudi Arabia. Relying mainly on interviews with White House and State Department reporters from The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times and Newsweek, the hourlong report covers the Administration's treatment of Saddam Hussein in the weeks leading up to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August; the announced reliance on sanctions in September and October; the doubling of American forces that began after Election Day, and the threat of attack. "To the Brink of War" is being carried at 9 P.M. by Channels 13 and 49.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; Close Scoring Race a Reminder of '78 Duel
description: Today is the 75th day of the 171-day National Basketball Association season and nine different players have led the league in scoring for at least a day. The leaders often change weekly, sometimes even daily.

title: Parcells's Gambles Pay Off For Giants
description: According to Bill Parcells, philosophies change once the playoffs begin. Conservative football is out. Gambling football is in.

title: Blair Among the 10 Nominated for Sullivan
description: Three repeat finalists -- the speed skater Bonnie Blair, the pentathlete Lori Norwood and the wrestler John Smith -- were among the 10 candidates for the 1990 Sullivan Award announced yesterday in New York. The award, given to the nation's outstanding amateur athlete, is sponsored by the Amateur Athletic Union. The winner will be named March 11.

title: The Man Behind Munich
description: Saleh Khalef founded the Black September terrorist movement, which engineered the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich and the assassination of the United States Ambassador to the Sudan in 1973.

title: Foreign Ownership of Farms Found to Be Steady in 1980's
description: Foreign ownership of farm land in this country held fairly steady in the 1980's, an Agriculture Department study says.

title: Patterns
description: The Return of Courreges

title: Schools for Minority Men Violate '54 Segregation Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, excerpts on Sunday from a speech about the Persian Gulf by Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, rendered the name of a resolution incorrectly. The passage should have read, "I found myself feeling that if I voted for the Mitchell-Nunn resolution, I would do so hoping that it would not prevail." The Senator did not say "Mitchell nonresolution."

title: Janet Woodbury Adams; Art Expert, 60
description: Janet Woodbury Adams, an authority on decorative screens, died Sunday at Hazelfield, the family farm in Jefferson County, W. Va. She was 60 years old.

title: Dr. Stuart Forster, 44, Physician at Theaters
description: Dr. Stuart (Stubsy) Forster, the house physician at the New York Shakespeare Festival and the Second Stage Theater and a member of the staff at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, died Friday in his office on West End Avenue. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: American TV News Networks Prepare for War
description: As American troops get ready for a possible Mideast war, their endgame preparations are being paralleled by the nation's television networks, who say they think getting the story on air might prove as daunting as reporting it.

title: India About to Embark on Its Census
description: In a few weeks, an army of 1.8 million people will fan out from the frozen Himalayas to the sultry shores of Great Nicobar Island to complete one of the world's most challenging jobs: a national census for India.

title: As War Looms: Marches and Vigils, Talk and Fear
description: For some Americans, those few who know exactly what they think about it, the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf was a call for action.

title: Broad Shift Planned by Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation took its first big steps yesterday to reshape itself now that Armand Hammer is gone. Shifting direction after the death last month of its longtime chairman, the company announced that it planned to sell roughly $3 billion in assets to focus the company more closely on its oil and chemicals businesses.

title: Hostetler Is Forcing 49ers to Change Plans
description: The National Football Conference championship game will call for a shift in style for the San Francisco 49ers' defense because of the Hostetler factor.

title: Cable TV Regulation Bill Is Reintroduced
description: Legislation that would regulate cable television prices was reintroduced today by three Senators. But the bill does not include a proposal to let telephone companies provide cable service, a move championed by some, including the Bush Administration, as a way to increase competition.

title: With Lives at Stake, Issue Is Secrecy of Data
description: HUNDREDS of scientists will gather today at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., to grapple with a fundamental issue in medicine: when and how to release findings from studies of new therapies and procedures.

title: AIDS Vaccine Found Safe in Human Trial
description: RESEARCHERS conducting one of the first tests of an AIDS vaccine in uninfected volunteers have reported that early results suggest that the vaccine is safe and well tolerated.

title: Bank's Plan In Maryland
description: Maryland's largest banking company said today that it would announce before the opening of the stock market Tuesday how it intended to repay millions of dollars in debt.

title: A Sugar-Free 'Nutcracker' With Men in Tutus
description: Mark Morris made his departure from Belgium a triumphal march this weekend with a widely praised version of the "Nutcracker" story called "The Hard Nut."

title: A Reverse of Fortunes For Harvard and Yale
description: Harvard is down and Yale is up, a reversal in the ECAC Hockey league. The Bulldogs, chosen for 10th place in the pre-season coaches' poll, have now won 5 straight, 8 of their last 10 games and are tied with St. Lawrence for second place in the league standings, a point behind Cornell.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Media Business page yesterday about the growing market for provocative biographies and autobiographies referred incorrectly to thebest-seller standing of the book "In All His Glory: The Life of William S. Paley: The Legendary Tycoon and His Brilliant Circle," by Sally Bedell Smith. It has appeared on several best-seller lists, including those for Publishers Weekly, Newsday, Doubleday Book Shops and The Los Angeles Times Best-Seller List for Southern California.

title: American Pilots Anticipate Tough but Brief Battle
description: Despite their powerful advantage in numbers and equipment, American fighter pilots expect a difficult fight in the now seemingly inevitable war with Iraq.

title: Roger W. Tubby, 80, Publisher; Promoted the Adirondack Region
description: Roger W. Tubby, a newspaperman and Government official who briefly served as press secretary to President Harry S. Truman in 1952, died yesterday at his home in Saranac Lake, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: British No Longer Fly Cargo From Athens, Citing Security
description: British Airways said today that it has stopped taking cargo from the Athens airport, saying it had poor security against possible terrorism.

title: 3 Protesters Arrested Near the White House
description: The police arrested three protesters near the White House tonight while Indians with a "peace drum" pounded out a protest against the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf. The national park police estimated that 5,000 people in an evening prayer service marched past the White House.

title: The Brain May 'See' What Eyes Cannot
description: A WOMAN suffers brain damage from carbon monoxide poisoning and can no longer recognize objects. Yet she can grasp and use them, without knowing how she does it.

title: White House Sticks to Its Subdued Reaction to Baltic Crackdown
description: Moving cautiously in response to the Soviet military action in Lithuania, Bush Administration officials said today that the White House was reluctant to take stringent economic or political measures against Moscow.

title: Antoinette Rampinelli Sole; Interior Designer, 87
description: Antoinette Rampinelli Sole, an interior designer, died on Saturday at a convalescent center in Holmdel, N.J. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Japanese Premier Urges Iraq To Avoid a War at All Costs
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan recently sent President Saddam Hussein of Iraq some advice based on his own nation's experience: avoid war at all costs, because it can reduce a country to ashes.

title: First Executive In Policy Talks
description: The First Executive Corporation, an insurance company suffering heavy losses because of its investment in troubled "junk bonds," is negotiating the transfer of up to $2.3 billion of liabilities to the Hartford Life Insurance Company.

title: Chess
description: The ninth Katholieke Radio Omroep exhibition match, which took place in Hilversum, the Netherlands, Dec. 14 to 21, resulted in an impressive 4-2 victory for Yasser Seirawan, a Seattle grandmaster, over Jan Timman, the leading Dutch grandmaster.

title: Two Ranking Aides To Arafat Are Slain By Gunman in Tunis
description: A gunman in Tunis shot and killed two of the highest-ranking leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization late Monday night. The victims were among the closest and most influential aides to the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "People just want this thing finished." -- Sgt. Nelson Molinarey, who is with the Army in Saudi Arabia. [ A1:3. ]

title: Tax Value Off For Property In New York
description: In a report that provides the first government confirmation that New York City's real-estate market has tumbled sharply, the City Finance Department estimated yesterday that the taxable value of all property in the city fell by 7 percent in the last year.

title: Strawberry Rises to a New Dawn
description: On the first real day of his new job, Darryl Strawberry buttoned his jersey, looked at the blue letters stitched across the front and smiled to himself.

title: DINKINS ABANDONS PROPOSAL TO CLOSE 41 FIRE COMPANIES
description: After intense pressure from the public and the city's firefighter unions, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had abandoned the idea of closing 41 more fire companies across New York City.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Clarke American, San Antonio, a unit of MB America Inc., Westport, Conn., which prints checks, named Dale P. Schaufel vice president in charge of sales and marketing. * Environmental Tectonics Corp., Southhampton, Pa., a producer of environmental chambers, appointed John F. Schoenfelder vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding William F. Mitchell, who continues as president. * Forstmann & Co., a unit of Forstmann Textiles Inc., Dublin, Ga., promoted Peter Roaman to senior vice president of marketing. Brian Moorstein was promoted to vice president of its women's wear division. * MBIA Corp., Armonk, N.Y., municipal bond insurer, named James E. Malling senior vice president of corporate marketing and new products. * New York Life Insurance Co., New York, appointed Ralph Casale executive vice president and chief marketing officer and James Kelly vice president of its New York Life Worldwide Holding Inc. subsidiary.

title: Our Towns; War Edges Near, And the Young Talk and Worry
description: Even the third graders were talking war yesterday. "Well, I don't think Saddam Hussein's troops are going to leave," said Alexis Faraci, age 8. "I mean, we only have one more day. No, I'm not too happy about it."

title: Airlines Must Do More for Business Travelers; Serving Consumer Only
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Group in Hong Kong Taken To Task on Advice to Boat People
description: Responding to complaints from the United Nations refugee agency, the Hong Kong Government has curtailed the activities of a legal assistance group that has been advising Vietnamese boat people held in detention camps here.

title: Trial Date Is Set In Go-Video Case
description: Federal Judge Robert Broomfield has scheduled a trial for April 2 in Go-Video's antitrust suit against five Japanese electronics companies.Lawyers expect the trial to last about three months.

title: Yield Independence Claim or Face Worse Strife, Lithuanians Warned
description: After an overnight truce that raised fleeting hopes of compromise, the suppression of Lithuania's independence government continued today with the capture of the Parliament's last radio outlet and a threat of more bloodshed if the government did not quickly capitulate.

title: Kuwaiti Threatens Attack on Iraqi Civilian Targets
description: The Crown Prince of Kuwait says the multinational coalition against Iraq would strike deep inside the country at civilian as well as military targets if Iraq bombed Kuwait City after allied forces retake it.

title: Grand Jury Investigates Sharpton Stabbing
description: A Brooklyn grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday against a white Bensonhurst man accused of stabbing the Rev. Al Sharpton in an attack listed by the police as a bias crime. No indictment was handed up, but the panel was expected to continue its work today.

title: Church's Bane: Madonna and Other Temptations
description: Only a few sounds are audible at the main office of the seminary here: the swishing of cassocks as priests glide across the marble floor, and the chirping of swallows that inhabit the lush inner courtyards, thick with ferns and poinsettias.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Spoleto U.S.A. Festival Announces 1991 Season
description: Some 120 music, dance, theater and art productions and an 80th-birthday tribute to Gian Carlo Menotti are planned for this year's Spoleto Festival U.S.A., which runs from May 23 to June 9 in Charleston, S.C. Mr. Menotti founded the festival in 1977, 19 years after starting the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy.

title: Former White House Aide Is New Chairman of Xsirius
description: William R. Graham, who served in the Reagan and Bush Administrations as the Presidential science adviser and director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, has been named chairman and chief executive of Xsirius Scientific Inc., the company said yesterday.

title: Athens Chief Is Cheered by Greeks in Albania
description: Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis of Greece, flanked by his Albanian counterpart, assured hundreds of cheering Greek-Albanians today that they would be free to come and go across the Greek border.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Stanley, a lion cub, flew from New York yesterday to the Shambala Preserve, founded by TIPPI HEDREN primarily for retired animal actors. The six-month-old lion was found in a Yonkers transmission shop on Dec. 11 by the police, who were investigating neighbors' complaints about roaring. He was picked up by the A.S.P.C.A. and taken to the Animalport at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Savings Bailout Gets Overseer
description: An experienced Pentagon investigator started work today as the top overseer of contractors for the Government's savings and loan industry bailout.

title: Teacher's Trial: Passion Killing Or Frame-Up?
description: A Westchester teacher accused of killing her lover's wife was driven by a "consuming desire to possess" the man, the prosecution said today in its opening statement.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Decide on Role of Parties in Nonpartisan Contests
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether political parties have a First Amendment right to endorse or oppose candidates for offices that a state has designated as nonpartisan.

title: Mary Francis Shura Craig; Mystery Writer, 67
description: Mary Francis Shura Craig, a writer of mystery novels and children's books, died on Saturday at the Loyola University Medical Burn Center in Maywood, Ill. She was 67 years old and lived in Hinsdale, Ill.

title: Dataquest Losing Chief To Gartner, Its Rival
description: Manny A. FernandezManny A. Fernandez, chief executive of Dataquest Inc., is leaving to become president and chief operating officer of the rival Gartner Group Inc., Gartner said yesterday. Both companies provide research on companies in the computer and other technological industries.

title: Of Mice and Men, Revisited
description: LOGITECH Inc., which says it is the world's largest manufacturer of computer-pointing devices, has created a new family of ergonomically designed mice, including big ones and little ones, left-handed ones and right-handed ones, even one that has had its tail cut off. All of them are lopsided and have three ears.

title: Channel in Bankruptcy
description: Channel Home Centers Inc. filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code today and announced it would sell or close 34 of its 86 home improvement stores. Joseph Nusim, president and chief executive officer, said the company would concentrate on New Jersey and Pennsylvania by closing stores in Baltimore, Washington, and New England. The company reached agreement with the General Electric Capital Corporation for up to $145 million in financing that effectively puts G.E. first in line for repayment.

title: Sixth Loss In a Row For Devils
description: The Devils failed to contain Wayne Gretzky and his linemates, Tomas Sandstrom and Tony Granato, and paid the price with a 6-1 loss to the Los Angeles Kings tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Chrysler's Heirs Are More Apparent
description: Chrysler named Robert A. Lutz as president of the corporation today, apparently solidifying his status as a leading candidate to succeed Lee A. Iacocca as chief executive. The nation's No. 3 auto maker also realigned the top management of its vehicle development groups.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Film Collaboration That Redefines the Term
description: When Sally, the cigarette girl and aspiring actress in "Radio Days," gets her big chance to play Chekhov, the broadcast is canceled minutes before air time because of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: Companies Focusing On Security
description: With the deadline for Iraqi withdrawal at hand, companies are poised to put into effect security and business plans they have been preparing quietly since the invasion of Kuwait in August.

title: As Libel Case Opens, a Debate on What Is Truth
description: The Supreme Court grappled today with one of its most celebrated libel cases in years in a lively hour of argument that at times verged on a metaphysical inquiry into the nature of truth itself.

title: Nicaragua Sinks Further as Chamorro's Magic Fails
description: Despite expectations of a quick economic turnaround after the inauguration of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro last April, the Nicaraguan economy has not recovered and is now deteriorating amid large deficits and continued high military spending, economists and diplomats say.

title: Kidney Drug Setback For Genetics Institute
description: In a setback for Genetics Institute Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., the Food and Drug Administration has denied several of the company's petitions to market an anti-anemia drug to patients with chronic kidney failure.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Guide column of the Long Island Weekly on Sunday, about musical programs, misstated the date for a talk by Herbert Kupferberg about his book "Amadeus: A Mozart Mosaic" at the Rockville Centre Public Library. It is on Thursday at 1 P.M., not today.

title: INSIDE
description: Trouble in Family Court As poverty, drugs and homelessness overwhelm more New York City families, the overburdened child-care system often seems to do more to thwart them than to help. Page B1. Court Considers Libel The Supreme Court heard arguments on a prominent psychologist's claim that he was deliberately misquoted by a New Yorker writer. Page A16. Mastering the Mississippi Engineers are struggling hard to prevent the Mississippi from taking a short cut. Science Times, page C1.

title: Oil Leaps By $3.49 on War Fears
description: The price of oil leaped yesterday to its highest level since early December as traders, oil companies and investors perceived that war was imminent in the Middle East and that crude production might be disrupted there.

title: For Summer, Cheery Colors Seem Statement Enough
description: The cleanly tailored shift dress is decorated with cutouts on the chest, the sleeves or near the hemline. Suits have scalloped edges, gold borders or boldly printed jackets. Coats are roomy in shiny white plastic or bright primary colors. Of course, they shed the showers.

title: Henry W. Kumm, 89, Foundation Official
description: Dr. Henry W. Kumm, a Rockefeller Foundation specialist in tropical diseases and later the foundation's fellowships director, died Thursday at his home in Pennswood Village in Newtown, Pa. He was 89 years old.

title: Sunny Weather in the Gulf
description: Rare torrential rains in eastern Saudi Arabia ended today after flooding streets in several cities and driving American troops in remote desert camps to seek temporary shelter in their tents.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about the Hilton Hotels Corporation misstated the company's reason for setting aside $6.5 million after taxes. It was for potential real estate losses in general, not related to the sale of the company's interest in the Hotel Conrad-Hong Kong.

title: Agencies and Clients Plan Strategies if War Occurs
description: MANY advertisers have called for emergency meetings with their agencies to formulate strategies in case there is a protracted war in the Middle East.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The Mood; Personal Steps in March of History
description: When the day of reckoning finally arrived, it brought uncertainty. Many sought a kind of do-it-yourself catharsis. Church bells rang, protesters marched, and people donated blood for soldiers. Yesterday, millions of Americans who had uneasily awaited the Jan. 15 deadline overwhelmed by a sense of helplessness felt compelled to do something.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Israel; No Plan for Israeli-U.S. Coordination
description: The commander of the Israeli Air Force said this evening that the United States and Israel still have no mechanisms in place to coordinate the two nation's military activities.

title: A Busy Time For Airline Security Firm
description: Arik Arad has not slept in 48 hours. He runs United States operations for the company that has spread the security system of El Al, the Israeli airline, to airlines throughout the world. With war threatening in the Middle East, the company, International Consultants on Targeted Security, is getting more business than he can handle.

title: News Strikers Ease Stance On a Big Issue
description: The nine striking unions at The Daily News agreed yesterday to take a new tack on a crucial bargaining issue, and union officials said it might eventually lead to a settlement of the 12-week strike.

title: Japan and the Mercury-Poisoned Sea: A Reckoning That Won't Go Away
description: It is more than 35 years now since the cats in this fishing village along Japan's rugged southern coast began to foam at the mouth, tear at themselves and, in fits of crazed blindness, throw themselves into the sea. Next came the townspeople. Older residents of Minamata still tell vivid stories of watching their parents and children die excruciating deaths from mercury poisoning.

title: Loss of a Job Doesn't Keep Some From Aiding the Neediest
description: Linda Winston, an unemployed New York City teacher, has been contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since her childhood, and her lack of a job this year was not going to change that.

title: Review/Television; Rock's Top Women of the Present and the Past
description: Sinead O'Connor, Janis Joplin, Aretha Franklin and Tina Turner: the lineup of pop-music women on basic cable this week doesn't stint on superstars.

title: Barkley Wearing a Cast
description: Charles Barkley will wear a cast on his injured left foot for a week and will miss at least three more games, the Philadelphia 76ers said.

title: INSIDE
description: Abu Nidal Group Suspected In Slaying of P.L.O. Officials The Palestinian faction led by Abu Nidal is suspected in the killing of two leading Palestine Liberation Organization officials in Tunis. P.L.O. officials backed away from charges that Israel was responsible. Page A14. Soviet Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Ambassador to the United States, succeeded Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Foreign Minister and pledged good relations with the West. Page A9. Daily News Strikers Budge The nine striking unions at The Daily News agreed to drop their demand for the dismissal of replacement workers but insisted that all 2,300 strikers be reinstated. Page B1. Ethics Hearings Near Close In closing arguments, the Senate ethics panel's counsel made an impassioned case for punishment of three of the Keating Five. Page A18.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In a debate tomorrow, ALAN M. DERSHOWITZ and MICHAEL F. ARMSTRONG are to collide at the Fordham University School of Law in Manhattan. While the two have never faced off in a courtroom, Professor Dershowitz won the acquittal in 1985 of CLAUS VON BULOW , who was appealing his conviction of attempting to murder his wife, Sunny. Mr. Armstrong represented Mr. von Bulow's stepchildren in a civil case brought the following year.

title: Caustic Water Supply Leads to Alert on L.I.
description: Health officials warned residents today not to use tap water provided by the New York Water Service Corporation after high levels of sodium hydroxide, a caustic substance used to control pipe corrosion, was discovered in the supply.

title: Bertha A. Normano, Russian Teacher, 104
description: Bertha A. Normano, a teacher of Russian at Middlebury College before her retirement in 1968, died Sunday at the Porter Medical Center in Middlebury, Vt. She was 104 years old and lived in Middlebury.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a music review on Monday about a performance at Weill Recital Hall by Lars Anders Tomter, a Norwegian violist, appeared with an incomplete final sentence. It should have read, "Mr. Tomter's solo piece was Johan Kvandal's Elegy and Capriccio (Op. 47), a plaintive contemporary score that gave him ample opportunity to display his singing tone, his impressive timbral palette and his speed and accuracy in double-stopped passages."

title: Willie Brown Gets Long Beach State Job
description: Willie Brown, a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame who played a dozen years as defensive back with the Oakland Raiders, was named head coach at Long Beach State University yesterday, succeeding George Allen, who died on Dec. 31 after suffering a heart attack.

title: Books of The Times; Why Happiness for All Is a Fool's Goal
description: The True and Only Heaven Progress and Its Critics By Christopher Lasch 591 pages. W. W. Norton . $25.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Lithuania; The Crushing of Lithuania's Independence Drive: A Precise Script Is Detected
description: From a review of recent events in Lithuania and interviews with people on both sides of the conflict, it has become clear that the crushing of the republic's drive for independence was planned with precision.

title: In China, a Political Cartoonist Thrives
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "There is a fatal moment when one must act. This moment has, alas, arrived." -- Prime Minister Michel Rocard of France. [ A1:6. ]

title: The Script in Lithuania
description: A review of recent events in Lithuania and interviews on both sides of the conflict make clear that the crushing of the republic's drive for independence was precisely planned. Page A8.

title: European Publishers Oppose New Rules
description: A group of some of Europe's biggest newspaper and magazine publishers hope to stymie restrictions on certain types of advertising that the European Community is trying to put into effect.

title: U.S. Grant Saves a Program To Prevent AIDS in Soweto
description: Filling a vacuum all but ignored by the South African Government, the United States has donated $242,000 to try to stop AIDS from sweeping Soweto, the country's largest black township.

title: His Highness And His Herd Take a Hike
description: The Sport of Kings has one less king in 1991. At least, there's one less in England, where the Aga Khan has gathered his 90 thoroughbred racing horses and shipped 30 to Ireland and 60 to France in one of the more spectacular hikes in history. And he did it to prove a point: If you're going to test horses for drugs, you'd better make sure they get as fair a shake as Olympic racers like Ben Johnson.

title: Opening Nation's Phone Networks
description: Drivers can freely use the interstate highway system and homeowners can obtain electricity simply by putting a plug in an outlet, but equal access to all does not yet exist in the nation's telephone system. Historically, the regional phone companies have served as gatekeepers for telephone networks, dictating the terms under which outsiders can plug into the system.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Jordan; Seeing War Near, King Hussein Vows to Protect Jordan's Land and Sky
description: King Hussein of Jordan, evidently abandoning all hope for Western or Arab diplomacy in the Persian Gulf crisis, sought tonight to ready his people for embroilment in war and said the Middle East stood on the verge of imminent catastrophe.

title:
Real Estate;
Developers And a Town Compromise
description: DEVELOPERS are pressing ahead with a 164,000-square- foot office and retail project in this suburban town that was planned when the market for commercial space was strong but not approved until the market started to sour.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The Saudis; Boom Town in Desert: Expansion Amid the Crisis
description: The first sign that something was not quite right here in Saudi Arabia's petrochemical heartland was the birds.

title: Rangers Rally For a Tie
description: Patience, as often as not a virtue for the Rangers this season, had become a form of torture last night against the Edmonton Oilers at Madison Square Garden. Chances weren't taken, more rushes were abandoned than finished, shots were held and then misfired.

title: Guilty Pleas In Pentagon Fraud Case
description: A Southern California military contractor and its former top executive pleaded guilty today to conspiracy and other charges stemming from the Justice Department's investigation of purported fraud in the Pentagon's purchasing of arms and equipment.

title: Henry K. Silver, 72, Pediatrician, Is Dead
description: Dr. Henry K. Silver, a pediatrician who developed pioneering programs in the 1960's to ease the shortage of doctors and nurses and who later studied abuses of medical students by their teachers, died Sunday at University Hospital in Denver. He was 72 years old and lived in Denver.

title: 'Shogun' Closing Sunday
description: "Shogun: The Musical," a play based on James Clavell's novel, with book and lyrics by John Driver and music by Paul Chihara, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 46th Street. Directed by Michael Smuin, the show will have run for 12 previews and 72 performances.

title: Fats That Hide In Margarine
description: SWITCHING from butter to margarine is considered a positive move toward a more healthful diet. But it's not just a question of butter versus margarine. Consumers who have made the decision face no fewer than 10 varieties of margarine or combinations of margarine and butter that vary widely in content.

title: Article 169491 -- No Title
description: One of New York's lost amenities will be making a limited comeback with the announcement yesterday that the J. M. Kaplan Fund has contributed $50,000 for the restoration of toilets in Bryant Park. The 45-year-old fund "has long been concerned about the need for public facilities in New York," Joan K. Davidson, president of the fund, said.

title: Home Loan Bank Sets Bond Prices
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, a federally chartered agency that supervises and is owned by member savings and loan associations, yesterday priced one-year and three-year bonds totaling $1.12 billion.

title: Channel Chapter 11
description: Channel Home Centers Inc. filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Monday and announced it would sell or close 34 of its 86 home improvement stores. The company reached agreement with the GE Capital Corporation for up to $145 million in financing that effectively puts it first in line for repayment.

title: News from the Mideast via the P.C.
description: The nation's technology-minded citizens -- from antiwar groups to arms makers to veterans and relatives of members of the military -- are turning in large numbers to their personal computers for news bulletins from the Persian Gulf.

title: A Dangerous Message From City Hall
description: Even as New York City struggles to cope with a worsening fiscal crisis, Mayor David Dinkins persists in sending a dangerous message to special interests worried about budget cuts: Yell loud enough, get enough attention, and you will get what you want, invariably at the expense of others.

title: Liquidation Fears Rise For Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines, which last November fought off an attempt by its creditors to shut down the carrier, may stop flying within days and be liquidated because it is short of cash and cannot find more, a person familiar with the airline's finances said yesterday.

title: California Housing Dip
description: Consumer fears about the recession and a scarcity of financing for developers helped to push new housing construction in California in November to its lowest level in eight years, an industry group reported today.

title: More on the Gulf
description: OIL DOWN Oil fell 71 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $30.07 a barrel, as traders awaited last-minute developments in the Persian Gulf. Business Day, page D1.

title: Initial Days of a War May Not Hurt Stocks
description: The initiation of wars has caused some of the most dramatic plunges in stock market history. Unexpected events often shock markets, and wars have been among the most surprising.

title: Bad Loans Take Toll At Banks
description: Three large New York banking companies -- Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical -- announced poor quarterly results yesterday, reflecting losses on loans for real estate projects and some corporate takeovers. The losses overshadowed the benefits of falling interest rates and cuts in their work forces. Manufacturers Hanover also said it was cutting its dividend.

title: Topics of The Times; Skating Swell
description: When the only skaters one ever sees are on television -- Olympic winners, Olympic hopefuls and the incomparable Torvill and Dean -- it's easy to forget that skating is hard work. But to watch the crowd at Rockefeller Center's rink one noon last week was to be forcibly reminded.

title: Dinkins Is Expected To Lay Off 16,000 To Close Budget Gap
description: Struggling to close a growing budget gap, Mayor David N. Dinkins will announce today that he will lay off about 16,000 city workers in the next year and a half, including half of the city's school crossing guards and more than 200 school nurses, city officials said.

title: David M. McCann, Lawyer, 51
description: David M. McCann, a senior partner in the Newark law firm of Carpenter, Bennett & Morrissey, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 51 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Phelps H. Adams, 88, Writer and Executive
description: Phelps H. Adams, chief Washington correspondent for The New York Sun and later an adminstrative vice president for United States Steel, died Sunday in Maryvale Samaritan Hospital in Phoenix. He was 88 years old and lived in Litchfield Park, Ariz.

title: No Merchants of Death
description: Amid all the terrifying prospects over war in the Persian Gulf, one fear can be safely dismissed: The U.S. economy can withstand such a war, even a prolonged one.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The P.L.O.; Suspicion in Palestinian Slayings Now Focuses on Abu Nidal Group
description: Suspicion in the killing of Salah Khalaf, the No. 2 official in the Palestine Liberation Organization, on Monday night has turned toward the renegade Palestinian terrorist group headed by Abu Nidal.

title: Mars So Far
description: As I write this, Flight Commander Ed Hill, his ex-wife Dr. Judy Hill and Mission Specialists Jay Garr and Bob Stein are presumably getting the first good night of sleep they've had since Quayle I cartwheeled down a sloping wall of Valles Marineris and slammed into a pink boulder the size of Belgium. It'll be at least three days before the flapper valves in their leg veins start closing between heart beats, so while the crew readapts to gravity, let's review the first 38 months of the mission to Mars.

title: Keye Luke, Actor, Is Dead at 86; 'No. 1 Son' and 'Kung Fu' Master
description: Keye Luke, an actor who first gained notice as the brash but earnest No. 1 Son in the Charlie Chan detective films of the 1930's and 40's, died on Saturday at Presbyterian Intercommunity Hospital in Whittier, Calif. He was 86 years old and lived in Whittier.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Troops; Soldiers Wonder How Bad It Will Be
description: As the United Nations deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait expired, taking with it virtually all hope for peace in the Persian Gulf, the people of this desert kingdom and the fighting men and women who have journeyed so far to defend them seem to share a single thought, a single fear: how terrible will war be?

title: Advanced Micro Loss
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported a fourth-quarter loss today, reflecting reserves it set aside for litigation and coming layoffs.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Science Times yesterday with a diagram of a huge chain of galaxies known as the Great Wall misstated the structure's length. It is 500 million light-years, not 500 billion. (A light-year is the distance traveled by light in a year, or about six trillion miles.)

title: Modest Prime-Time Hopes
description: Executives at the three broadcast networks and at Fox Broadcasting are all describing midseason prime- time programming strategies that are built around not-at-all-great expectations. Page C9.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Baltics; Wider Soviet Crackdown Is Foreseen in the Baltics
description: There were more signs today that the Kremlin was preparing to follow up the military crackdown in Lithuania with similar actions in the other Baltic states of Latvia and Estonia.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $150 million in debt securities. * J.C. Penney Co., Dallas, has established a $750 million, three-year international revolving line of credit with a group of banks and arranged by Credit Suisse First Boston. The line of credit is extendible to five-years. RATINGS * Maine's general obligation bond rating of triple-A is under review for possible downgrading by S.&P.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ZUBIN MEHTA , the music director of the New York Philharmonic, was to fly back to New York from Munich yesterday, but changed his mind and headed for Tel Aviv.

title: 3 Pirate Stars Top List Of 159 in Arbitration
description: While the Mets continued paring their salary arbitration list, three Pittsburgh Pirates players, among the best in the major leagues last year, led 153 players in filing for arbitration yesterday. The number fell four short of matching the record one-day filing that was set on the last day of the filing period a year ago.

title: Increased Activity In Collagen Stock
description: The Collagen Corporation said there was no business reason for the recent share-price volatility and increased trading in its common stock. The company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., speculated that the activity might be related to a coming television program that focuses on the use of injectable collagen, one of its products, in surgical and cosmetic facial treatments.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S. WEIGHS TIMING OF ATTACK AGAINST IRAQ AS DEADLINE PASSES AND DIPLOMACY FAILS
description: The deadline for Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait passed at midnight Tuesday with the Iraqi Army still in place and the Bush Administration poised at the "point of decision" to unleash an American attack.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a news analysis article on Monday about the effect that Lithuanian developments could have on Bush Administration policies omitted a passage in some copies. The sentence should have read, "Washington has advocated a conference but opposes linking it to the gulf crisis."

title: Carbajal Is on Way To Money Milestone
description: Michael Carbajal is the International Boxing Federation light flyweight champion, and has been featured regularly on network television. His promoter, Bob Arum, has predicted that Carbajal will be the first boxer in his weight class to earn a million-dollar purse.

title: London Route Talks Break Off
description: Talks between British and United States aviation officials broke off today, leaving unsettled whether American Airlines and United Airlines would be able to fly into London on routes purchased from T.W.A. and Pan Am.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A FRIEND writes:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-15

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Bluntly Put, Graft Is Rife: U.S. Envoy Speaks Out
description: The official corruption that is routine dinner-table talk in Argentina, but generally cannot be proved, has been thrust into banner headlines by a blunt accusation from the normally polite and circumspect American Ambassador.

title: New Member for Fiscal Panel
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would appoint Robert R. Kiley, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, to the New York State Financial Control Board. Mr. Kiley will replace Donald B. Kummerfeld, who retired last month. The board consists of the Governor, the Mayor of New York City, the State Comptroller, the City Comptroller and three members named by the Governor. The board was created in 1975 during New York City's fiscal crisis to monitor the city's finances. It could take control of the city's finances if the city runs up a deficit of $100 million or more.

title: Quick Recovery Predicted
description: President Bush reviewed the state of the economy today with his top economic advisers and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Afterward, the Administration again voiced a belief that the recession would be short.

title: Colombia Drug Baron Surrenders Under Offer of Lenient Treatment
description: The No. 2 man in the Medellin cocaine cartel surrendered today in exchange for the Government's promise not to extradite him to the United States, where he is wanted on drug charges.

title: TV's Mid-Season: Modest Ambitions
description: Network programmers used to talk about shooting for the stars; now they talk about trying not to shoot themselves in the foot.

title: Studies Don't Show That Condoms Lower Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Turn to Anderson to Carry Bigger Load
description: When the Giants began practice today for Sunday's conference championship game against the 49ers in San Francisco, Rodney Hampton, who broke his leg last Sunday, was missing. Coaches and players said that as good as Hampton was in his rookie season, other running backs would take up the slack.

title: Review/Dance; Where Physical Fitness Counts
description: Mark Taylor and Friends is the third group in Altogether Different, the modern-dance series continuing through Jan. 27 at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street). Mr. Taylor's five pieces on Sunday afternoon showed him well within the popular trend of physical theater, in which athletic partnering explores highly emotional relationships. Mr. Taylor also has a certain distinctiveness. For better or for worse, his starting point seems to be a nondance idea, literary in inspiration, rather than an exploration of movement.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: News Analysis; Stake for Bush: Presidency and Politics
description: The decision President Bush is confronting could change the face of domestic politics, the map of the Middle East, the realities of big-power relationships and the world economy for years or decades to come.

title: Where Women Are Chief Cooks And Bottle Washers and More
description: MORE than in any other city, women in restaurants in the San Francisco Bay Area are doing the cooking and are often owners or partners as well.

title: Vermont Journal; Billboard Ban? Try a 19-Foot Genie!
description: James McGrath believes there is a much larger issue at stake than the 19-foot-high, 10-ton genie that sits outside his carpet store. To Mr. McGrath, owner of the Upper Room Design Center in this western Vermont town, the battle with local officials over the future of the genie is about his civil rights.

title: Ambulance Driver Dismissed Over Fight During a Sick Call
description: New York City's Emergency Medical Service has dismissed an attendant who stopped an ambulance carrying a woman and her sick child to Queens Hospital Center on Thursday to fight with his partner, a spokeswoman for the service said.

title: Despite Stiff Winds, Graf Wins In a Breeze
description: Steffi Graf's last big moment in tennis was winning the 1990 Australian Open here.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The Secretary General; Text of Statement by U.N. Chief in Appeal to Iraq
description: Following is the text of the statement made today by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar:

title: People
description: * John Quincy Adams 4th, Robert Edward Rath and Neal Jay Spector have been named vice presidents at Leo Burnett Co., Chicago.

title: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Down
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, but further declines might halt temporarily should an outbreak of hostilities in the Persian Gulf occur.

title: New Boom Hits Suburbs: Evictions and Foreclosures
description: Evictions for nonpayment of rent and mortgage foreclosures are increasing rapidly in New Jersey, Connecticut and New York. More middle-class tenants and homeowners, pressed by rising unemployment and large mortgages, are joining low- and moderate-income families for whom finding affordable shelter has long been a struggle.

title: EX-OFFICIAL GUILTY IN DETROIT FRAUD
description: A former deputy police chief who was a business partner of Mayor Coleman A. Young has been convicted of engaging in a pyramid scheme that duped investors of millions of dollars.

title: Hollywood Park Dispute
description: The battle for control of the company that operates the Hollywood Park race track here took a new twist today when Marjorie L. Everett, the chairman and chief executive, said she wanted to bring in Stephen A. Wynn, the casino executive, to replace her.

title: Public Hospitals Can't Handle the Mentally Ill; Tomorrow's Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Father of Black Conservatism Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Studies Regulating Art Sales Like Commodities
description: Should the art market be regulated like the stock market? A hearing to explore that possibility will be held in Manhattan on Jan. 30 by the New York State Assembly's committees on investigations and on tourism, sports and the arts. The hearing is based on a wide-ranging memorandum and draft legislation prepared by Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Westchester.

title: Sharpton Urges Followers to Forgo Violence
description: Speaking from a wheelchair at Coney Island Hospital, the Rev. Al Sharpton urged his followers yesterday to refrain from violence in the aftermath of the attack against him last weekend, when he was stabbed by a young man before a march through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALISTAIR COOKE , DIANA RIGG and JOHN HURT were among those who celebrated the 20th anniversary of "Masterpiece Theater" in Washington on Monday night. The Mobil Corporation, which underwrites the PBS series, was the host for a dinner that drew the capital's culture crowd, along with many of the actors responsible for the series' 25 Emmy Awards.

title: Ross McLeod, Lawyer, 91
description: Ross McLeod, former vice president and general counsel for the New York Life Insurance Company in Manhattan, died on Saturday in a nursing home in Stamford, Conn. He was 91 years old and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: GATT Chief Sees Break In Farm Trade Impasse
description: As negotiators met for the first time since world trade talks collapsed in December, the chief of the four-year round of talks indicated today that he might soon reconvene the negotiations because he sees signs of flexibility to end the deadlock over farm trade.

title: Panel Is Asked to Punish 3 Senators
description: Declaring to the Senate Ethics Committee that the "political heart and soul of this country" was at stake, the panel's special counsel made an impassioned case today that three Senators should be punished for their dealings with the savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr.

title: Rhode Island Suit Is Filed
description: A lawsuit was filed today contending that Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun violated state and Federal constitutional standards when he closed 45 Rhode Island banks and credit unions.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE devastation of Long Island bay scallops by a mysterious algae several years ago has only recently begun to turn around. The sweet little scallops are available in several seafood shops near my home on eastern Long Island, but the prices are staggering, up to $18 a pound.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Changes at Home; Amid the Grief and Worry, Life Will Go On as Before
description: Beyond casualty lists and the concern and disquietude that war inevitably brings, what would an outbreak of fighting in the Persian Gulf mean for the day-to-day routine of Americans on the home front?

title: Zenith Data Systems Picks Olivetti Official as President
description: Enrico Pesatori, a longtime Italian computer executive, was named president and chief executive of Zenith Data Systems yesterday. Zenith Data was acquired by Groupe Bull S.A., the French state-owned computer maker, from the Zenith Electronics Corporation in 1989.

title: Bridge
description: When pondering an opening lead, it is often possible to rule out one suit altogether. It can come as a rude shock in the post-mortem when it transpires that this ridiculous choice was the only one that would have succeeded.

title: Restaurateur's Paris Romance Is Bittersweet
description: Like some psychotropic drug, this city can have a powerful impact on the mind, impairing one's reason with no warning and clouding one's vision with an open-ended sense of possibility.

title: Nets Fall in Overtime For 11th Loss in a Row
description: Reggie Theus had a chance to make the winning shot in overtime and he hit nothing but air. Derrick Coleman had two chances after grabbing the rebound and he did not fare any better. One attempt was blocked by Alton Lister and the other five foot shot rolled around the rim and slipped off as the buzzer sounded.

title: Chief Executive Named At Southeast Banking
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation, one of Florida's largest banking companies, yesterday named Douglas E. Ebert, its president and chief operating officer, to be chief executive -- ahead of schedule, as the ailing bank seeks to put its strategy in place.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Iraq; Gamble for Hussein: Power or Oblivion
description: President Saddam Hussein goes to the brink of war with the United States and its allies today because, many analysts say they believe, the Iraqi leader is trying to get -- up until the last possible instant -- the thing he most desires: recognition from the West and a protected role as the region's pre-eminent power.

title: China Charges 8 Dissidents In 1989 Tiananmen Protests
description: China started court proceedings today against eight dissidents, including a prominent historian, for their roles in the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in 1989.

title: Savoring His Victory, Mickelson Goes Back to School
description: Even before his stunning victory Sunday at the Northern Telecom Open in Tucson, Ariz., Phil Mickelson and a lot of other people had a strong suspicion he could play like the best pros on the PGA Tour. The only remaining question now is when he will be ready to live like them.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 60 last week to a total of 1,048, Baker Hughes Inc. reported this week. The count a year ago was 1,019 rigs, the company said. Baker Hughes has kept the rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for petroleum.

title: Demand Soars For Gold Coins
description: The United States Mint said yesterday that sales of its American Eagle bullion gold coin had skyrocketed yesterday and Monday. Analysts say fears about the possibility of war in the Middle East had caused demand to soar.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Security; U.S. TAKES STEPS TO CURB TERRORISM
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been ordered to track down as many as 3,000 Iraqis in this country whose visas have expired, the Justice Department said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Television; Bill Moyers on Saving the Children
description: In reporting tonight on what he calls "small but crucial victories," Bill Moyers brings home the dimensions of the nation's failure to save tens of thousands of teen-agers from the streets, the jails, the shadows of despair. "All Our Children With Bill Moyers," at 8 on Channels 13, 31 and 49 and at 9 on Channel 21, is a 90-minute visit to three cities that are trying in similar ways to rescue adolescents who seemed beyond the help of regular schools.

title: Ryan Vs. Ryan
description: When the Texas Rangers face the University of Texas in an exhibition game on April 2, the scheduled starting pitchers are Nolan Ryan, the major league's career strikeout leader, and his son, Reid Ryan, an 18-year-old freshman for the Longhorns, who won all-district honors as a senior at Alvin High School in Texas.

title: New Harcourt Editor
description: Anne Freedgood, who has been an editor at Doubleday, Random House and Summit Books, has been named senior editor of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich . Ms. Freedgood, who has edited such writers as John Barth, Mary Gordon, Jonathan Miller and Carl Sagan, will join the company early next month.

title: Christopher J. O'Brien, Executive, 30
description: Christopher J. O'Brien, chief operating officer of Multitasking Systems of New York, died on Jan. 8 at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 30 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: In Provence, Tradition Has Its Reward
description: FIFTY years ago, when Lucie Tempier and Lucien Peyraud were given the Tempier country home here as a wedding gift from her father, there was little to suggest that the property could produce a great wine. A simple rose was made from the old vines.

title: Accounts
description: * Yugotours, a unit of Genex that operates tours to Europe, to McCaffery & Ratner, New York, with billings of $3 million. * Country Kitchen, a restaurant chain of Carlson Cos., Minneapolis, to Lindsay & Stone, Madison, Wis., with a budget of about $1 million. The previous agency was Lacey, LeMaster, Farmer, Minneapolis.

title: Insuring 'War Risks' at Lloyd's
description: It is 11:50 A.M., and as war clouds gather over the Persian Gulf, a line of insurance brokers forms at the second-floor desk of Christopher W. Rome in the Lloyd's of London building on Lime Street.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: War Supplies; Somber Workers Press to Fill A Rush Order for Body Bags
description: The crisis in the Persian Gulf has brought a flurry of business to the rows of women bent over sewing machines at the Lite Industries factory here, feeding through heavy, gray, rubberized fabric, rushing to meet a Pentagon order.

title: Mr. Bush's War Strategy
description: With the irrevocable default of diplomacy to the will of Saddam Hussein and George Bush, the brave and frightened now begin to settle accounts. There is a hush, a reverence, an emptiness as leaders bow to the inevitability of their decisions.

title: Book Notes
description: Popular Success at Last

title: Change of Leadership In the U.S. Federation
description: The sweeping changes of the United States Soccer Federation's new regime have reached the coaching hierarchy of the World Cup team.

title: Uninsured Hospital Patients Found Far More Likely to Die
description: A report has found that hospital patients who lack medical insurance die at up to three times the rate of similar patients with insurance.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Businessland Inc., San Jose, Calif., a retailer of microcomputer and networking systems, appointed D. Scott Mercer senior vice president and chief financial officer. He replaces Leo F. Korman, who resigned. * Kinney Shoe Corp., a unit of Woolworth Corp., New York, promoted Bill DeVries to senior vice president and general manager of the Kinney Shoes division. Randy Snyder became vice president and general manager of its Champs Sports division, and George Konogeris was named director of corporate development for its Foot Locker Europe division. * North American Philips Corp., a unit of Philips N.V., the Netherlands, promoted Donald L. Hamilton to senior vice president. * Philip Morris Cos., New York, named Rosemary Ripley vice president of corporate business development. * Thrifty Corp., a unit of Pacific Enterprises Los Angeles, a drugstore chain, appointed B. Chris Schwartz president and chief executive of its Michigan Sporting Goods Distributors Inc. subsidiary in Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: Court Rules Letters to the Editor Deserve Protection From Libel Suits
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that letters to the editor and other forms of commentary deserve substantial protection from libel suits because the context in which they appear makes it clear that they tend to represent opinions, not statements of fact.

title: Islander Files Suit
description: Mark Fitzpatrick, the Islander goaltender who is working out lightly while recovering from an illness that has sidelined him this season, filed a lawsuit in Manhattan State Supreme Court yesterday charging that a diet supplement poisoned him and left him unable to play hockey.

title: The Ethics of Troop Vaccination
description: Some leading medical ethicists are distressed because the armed forces will give promising but not fully tested drugs and vaccines to U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf without asking their permission. However well intentioned, the ethicists are splitting hairs and offering advice that, if followed, could undermine efforts to insure the health and effectiveness of fighting units.

title: Bergen's Budget Plan Calls for 317 Layoffs
description: Bergen County's newly elected Executive, William Schuber, today proposed a $338.3 million budget that calls for dismissal of 317 of the county's 5,175 workers and a half-cent increase in the county property-tax rate.

title: Top Editor Is Named for Trade Books
description: HarperCollins, the book publishing subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, yesterday appointed the editor in chief at Doubleday, Susan Moldow, as associate publisher and editor in chief of its adult trade division.

title: How Nissan Smooths Out the Bumps
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation has introduced on its Infiniti Q-45 luxury model the first computerized suspension system in the United States that adjusts each shock absorber independently for stiffness and extension.

title: Corrections
description: A roll-call listing on Monday and in late editions on Sunday misstated the vote by Representative Tom Lantos, Democrat of California, on the use of force in the Persian Gulf. He favored a resolution authorizing war.

title: Wine Talk
description: SCHEUREBE. Hardly a household word, is it? Probably never will be, either. But it happens to be a respectable German wine grape. And it turns up in California, too. It's another example of the astonishing diversity of the grapes grown in this country and turned into wine.

title: Panel Picks Cuomo Ally As Chief of Javits Center
description: Fabian G. Palomino, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's special counsel and closest friend, was elected today on the Governor's recommendation to be president of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a job that will increase both his salary and his state pension.

title: Dow Up 6.68 As Trading Slows Down
description: Stock trading slowed sharply yesterday as investors waited for any kind of news that would change the almost inescapable conclusion that American troops may soon be fighting in the desert.

title: Building of New Stores Expected to Slow
description: Construction of new stores and shopping malls will be considerably slowed over the next five years because of the difficulty in obtaining financing as banks become increasingly cautious, speakers told the annual convention of the National Retail Federation yesterday.

title: Home Is No Help Again As Bruins Top Islanders
description: It was another night of concurrent disappointments for the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: E.P.A. Urging Electricity Efficiency
description: In a rare Federal venture into electricity efficiency, the Environmental Protection Agency began a campaign yesterday to convince the nation's 1,000 largest businesses that they can reduce pollution, and increase profits, by buying better lights.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: France; Paris Says Its Last-Ditch Peace Effort Has Failed
description: Having risked dividing the anti-Iraq coalition with a last-minute initiative to avert a gulf war, France conceded today that its plan had been ignored by Baghdad and said that force would now have to be used to drive Iraq from Kuwait.

title: Gerald J. Multer, Executive, 61
description: Gerald J. Multer, a founder of Planned Communication Services, which produces television and radio public-service campaigns, died on Sunday in Miami. He was 61 years old and lived in North Miami.

title: Donald F. Barrow, Executive, 77
description: Donald F. Barrow, a former executive in the oil and travel industries, died on Sunday at Huntington Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The U.N.; Last-Minute Debating, Then Final Plea to Iraq
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, made a final personal appeal tonight to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to give up Kuwait and avoid armed conflict in the Persian Gulf.

title: Recession Forces Sharp School Cuts
description: Squeezed by the tough financial times, the Gloria Floyd Elementary School in Dade County, Fla., has enlisted parents' help in a way it had never before done. The school asked them to contribute toilet paper, tissues and paper towels.

title: Frederick Croxton, 91, Statistician and Author
description: Frederick E. Croxton, a statistician, educator and author, died on Thursday at the Lakeland Health Care Nursing Center in Florida. He was 91 years old and moved to Lakeland in 1987 from Leonia, N.J.

title: About New York; Creating Faces, Since the World Sees Only Faces
description: Joseph G. McCarthy remembers a spring day in his New England youth. He saw a boy wearing a Red Sox baseball cap. The boy's face was grossly deformed.

title: Biagio Battaglia, Physician, 81
description: Dr. Biagio Battaglia, a retired medical officer for the New York City Fire Department, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

title: Lack of Day Care Cited in Benefits Appeal
description: A woman who was dismissed from her job because she regularly missed work to care for her sick infant is appealing her denial of unemployment benefits to the Minnesota Court of Appeals.

title: Charter Medical To Revise Its Debt
description: The Charter Medical Corporation, which owns and operates 101 hospitals in the United States and Europe, retained a financial adviser to help it restructure more than $1.7 billion in debt. The company also said it had revised preliminary estimates to show a $206.3 million loss for the year that ended on Sept. 30.

title: Key Rates
Embracing Self-Rule, 7 Tribes Begin A 3-Year Experiment in Sovereignty
description: In trying to assert the right of American Indian tribes to exist as nations within a nation, Joseph DeLaCruz has chased non-Indian cars off tribal beaches, introduced separate license plates and killed a Federal road leading into the coastal rain forest here at land's end.

title: Notes and Bonds Decline in Price
description: The looming reality of war enveloped the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped after a report this afternoon that France had abandoned all hope that a peaceful resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis could be reached before midnight.

title: St. John's Slips Past Providence in Overtime
description: As St. John's prepared for its game against Providence this week, the Redmen's coaching staff concentrated on getting one idea across: Keep the ball away from Eric Murdock.

title: Justices Rule Mandatory Busing May Go, Even if Races Stay Apart
description: The Supreme Court ruled in a major school desegregation case today that formerly segregated school districts may be released from court-ordered busing once they have taken all "practicable" steps to eliminate the legacy of segregation.

title: A 'Gorbachev Doctrine' Takes Shape
description: The vicious crackdown by Soviet armed forces in Lithuania has been viewed by many as a sudden reversal of Mikhail Gorbachev's program of glasnost and reform. It was heralded by Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation, warning that the Soviet Union was moving toward dictatorship. Yet the Soviet Government's response to charges of brutality in Lithuania raises questions about whether Mr. Gorbachev masterminded the repression or whether he is allied with an army that is not completely under his control.

title: India's Violence Damaging Tourist Industry
description: Political uncertainity and thousands of deaths in sectarian and caste violence last year have led to widespread tourist cancellations and jeopardized plans by the Indian Government, which has billed 1991 as "Visit India Year," to generate funds from tourism.

title: Public Hospitals Can't Handle the Mentally Ill; Reclaimed From Chaos
description: To the Editor:

title: John Hancock Preview Of Changes at the Top
description: John Hancock Financial Services, the nation's ninth-largest insurer, announced changes at the top yesterday that will take place a year from now.

title: BRIEFS
description: * America West Airlines, Inc., Tempe, Ariz., said its ridership increased 8.4 percent in the fourth quarter, but not enough to prevent a fourth-quarter loss. The carrier's chairman, Edward R. Beauvais, estimated a loss of $50 million. * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., a maker of auto-exhaust and ride-control products, has completed the sale of its Arvinair division to a group of private investors, including Arvinair management and led by Oppenheimer & Co., New York, the investment firm.
