Terms were not disclosed. * Comerica Inc., Detroit, a bank holding company, and Plaza Commerce Bancorp, San Jose, Calif., a bank holding company, have completed their merger. Comerica acquired all outstanding shares of Plaza Commerce common stock by exchanging one share of Comerica common stock for each 3.5 shares of Plaza Commerce common stock. The total value of the transaction is $86.5 million. * Consolidated American Industries said it would pay a one-time dividend to holders of record on Feb. 1 of one common share of Gemstar Enterprises for each 12 common shares of Consolidated American held. * Sogeti S.A., Paris, a professional services holding company, said it would acquire a majority interest in MAC Group, Cambridge, Mass., a management consulting group, for undisclosed terms. * Toshiba Corp., Tokyo, the Japanese electronics company, said it has developed a robot so flexible it can arrange flowers into a bouquet. The robot is made of silicon gum and nylon and is moved by air or water pressure. * Ver-Val Enterprises, Fort Walton Beach, Fla., a maker of fabrication materials for the military industry, has offered to purchase the assets of the telephone line sharing switch technology operations of Rainier Technologies Corp., Kirkland, Wash. The proposed purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Richard B. Nolan, Surgeon, 69
description: Dr. Richard B. Nolan, a surgeon, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 69 years old and had moved from Manhattan to Paris about a year and a half ago.

title: Missouri Rallies to Trip Oklahoma, 80-72
description: Doug Smith scored 31 points tonight to lift Missouri over Oklahoma, 80-72, as Coach Norm Stewart won his 200th Big Eight game.

title: We'll Never Catch Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Maze of Troubles Posing Challenges To Power and Popularity of Dinkins
description: As he confronts the fiscal problems that may be the biggest challenge of his career, Mayor David N. Dinkins faces cracks in his political coalition, malaise among his staff, aspersions on his integrity and the acknowledged prospect that "things may worsen before they improve."

title: Oil Traders Are Calm At Deadline
description: The oil market stared war in the face yesterday, and barely moved.

title: A. Adnan Saygun, Turkish Composer, 84
description: Ahmet Adnan Saygun, one of Turkey's leading composers, died in Istanbul on Jan. 6. He was 84 years old.

title: Iran-Contra Prosecutor Is Seeking High Court Review in North Case
description: The prosecutor in the Iran-contra case said today that he planned to ask the Supreme Court to review an appellate court decision that set aside the convictions of Oliver L. North.

title: Pollard Looks to Foil Giants Again
description: The last time the Giants were in Candlestick Park was on a cool Monday night in December when the San Francisco 49ers would edge them by 7-3. Only one principal player in what was arguably the game's biggest play returns on Sunday when the teams clash for the National Football Conference championship.

title: Court Says Ill Child's Interests Outweigh Religion
description: Parents in Massachusetts may be forced to have their children treated for life-threatening illnesses, but adults have a right to refuse medical care, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: Murder Defendant Wanted To Keep Lover, Friend Says
description: A college friend of Carolyn Warmus, the teacher on trial in the killing of her lover's wife, told jurors today that in conversations in the weeks and months before the fatal shooting, Ms. Warmus said she "would take it upon herself to make sure that she would end up" with her lover.

title: Topics of The Times; Yankee Flier
description: On hearing that a celebrity has suffered a broken leg while engaged in a winter sport, it is only natural to assume that said celebrity was on the slopes. On skis. In Aspen. Or maybe Gstaad. Unless one is talking about the First Lady, Barbara Bush.

title: Food Notes
description: Knowing Your Oranges

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: China; Few Hearts in Beijing Go Out To Lithuanians in Crackdown
description: While some Beijing residents see parallels between the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania and the Chinese Army's destruction of the Tiananmen democracy movement, there seems to be little interest here in the events in Vilnius and most people express only mild sympathy for the Lithuanians.

title: Wall St. Already in Position for War
description: On the day of the deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait, traders, dealers and fund managers in markets from equities to foreign exchange said they hoped they were ready for war, which most of them now expected.

title: Public Hospitals Can't Handle the Mentally Ill; The Case of Creedmoor
description: To the Editor:

title: Asking What Schools Have Done, Or Can Do, To Help Desegregation
description: Can efforts to integrate public schools help integrate society at large? Should schools be forced to bear such a burden? And how long must they be required to try?

title: Paul R. Miller Jr., 65, Public-Affairs Official
description: Paul R. Miller Jr., a vice president of the Council for Aid to Education and a former academic and corporate public-relations official, died on Sunday at his home in Amagansett, L.I. He was 65 years old.

title: Excerpts From Court Decision on Desegregation
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 5-to-3 decision today on conditions for ending Federal court supervision of formerly segregated school districts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: BRACING FOR WAR

title: Mitterrand's Cynical Gaullist Posturing
description: France's last minute solo attempt at Persian Gulf diplomacy before the U.N. Security Council came as no surprise here. President Francois Mitterrand has been signaling something of the sort for weeks, saying he reserved the right to "independent" action.

title: New Questions on Origin of Universe
description: In another discovery troubling to current theory, a German X-ray telescope orbiting Earth has detected strong evidence indicating the extensive clustering of quasars, mysterious luminous objects thought to lie at the heart of some galaxies.

title: Parcells Expects Bahr to Face 49ers
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said today that Matt Bahr's neck injury was not as serious as first suspected and that he expected Bahr to kick in Sunday's conference championshp game against the 49ers in San Francisco unless the soreness became worse.

title: Sales of U.S.-Made Vehicles Down 31.4% in Early January
description: Paralyzed by consumers' uncertainties about a weak economy and the prospect of war, sales of cars and trucks made in the United States were mired at recessionary levels in early January.

title: Father of Black Conservatism Remembered; Second to Hartford
description: To the Editor:

title: In Reunited Berlin, a New Excitement Over Opera
description: A longstanding love affair between Berlin and opera has flared anew at the news that talks are going on to win Daniel Barenboim and Zubin Mehta as music directors for the city's two principal opera houses.

title: Vienna Takes Aim at Myths About Mozart
description: On Dec. 5, 1791, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart died of poisoning while working on a Requiem Mass commissioned by a gray-cloaked stranger. Too poor to buy even a proper coffin, Mozart's wife, Constanza, buried the composer in an unmarked pauper's grave with four other bodies. Right?

title: New Government in Bangladesh Frees 151
description: A group of 151 prisoners, some jailed for political offenses, was freed today after being granted amnesty by the country's caretaker Government, officials said.

title: Eyes Caught As Intended By a Flash In Times Sq.
description: "Yo! Look up!" commanded an advertisement on the television screen high above Times Square.

title: Financial Exchanges Plan To Stay Open if War Comes
description: The nation's financial exchanges plan to remain open if war comes, but if the New York Stock Exchange closes, the others have agreed to follow its lead.

title: Public Hospitals Can't Handle the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; No Accounting For Bad Banks
description: WHICH banks should be counted as the walking dead, doomed to follow the Bank of New England into Federal receivership? Regulators are not telling -- and could not, even if they were so inclined. For the accounting methods currently used by banks, argues Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's business school, offer only the haziest clues to their net worth.

title: Review/Music; Harlem Vocal Ensemble Traces Roots of Spirituals
description: When they are heard in the concert hall these days, spirituals straddle the line between folk music and art song, usually leaning in one direction or the other according to the aims and styles of the arrangers and performers. The Harlem Spiritual Ensemble, the vocal sextet that performed at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, focused on the music's folk roots and its ties to the more virtuosic side of gospel singing.

title: Stop That Blank Check!
description: Despite the defeat in Congress last week, those who oppose war should not give up. The other side's margin of victory was scarcely overwhelming. Only three votes need to be changed in the Senate to create a majority

title: 3 More Banks Given Authority to Trade Stocks
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that it would allow Bankers Trust, the Royal Bank of Canada and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce to trade corporate stocks, further rolling back the barriers of Depression-era regulation that had separated the banking and securities businesses.

title: G. I. Newcombe, 67, A Retired Headmaster
description: Gordon I. Newcombe, former headmaster of the Horace Mann School, a coeducational preparatory school in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, died on Monday at Lawrence Hospital in the Bronx. He was 67 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Poor Holiday Season Pushed Retail Sales Down by 0.4%
description: Retail sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent in December, largely because of declining automobile sales and a poor Christmas shopping season, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Vietnam generation's attitudes toward the Persian Gulf conflict miscalculated the number of Congressmen who served in the military in Southeast Asia in the Vietnam era and cast votes this month on the use of force in the gulf. That group numbered 19; 13 of them voted to authorize the use of force. Denny Smith of Oregon, defeated in the November election, should not have been included.

title: Don't Call It Shish Kebab: In Binghamton, It's Heaven
description: BUFFALO has its chicken wings. Philadelphia has cheese steaks. Baltimore has crab cakes. Binghamton has the spiedie.

title: H. J. DuLaurence, 85, A Real Estate Lawyer
description: Henry J. DuLaurence Jr., a Cleveland laywer active in real estate and investments, died Saturday at the Manor Care Nursing Home in Mayfield Heights, Ohio. He was 85 years old and lived in Shaker Heights.

title: 500 at Wang Face Layoffs
description: In the latest item of bad news for New England's high-technology industry, Wang Laboratories Inc., said yesterday that it would be laying off 500 workers in the next three weeks.

title: Car Insurers Ask Voiding Of New Jersey Assessment
description: Lawyers for the insurance industry challenged New Jersey's new auto insurance law today before the state's highest court, saying the $1.7 billion assessment that the law requires insurance companies to pay the state would prevent them from earning a fair profit.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Wilkins Leads Hawks Past Pacers Dominique Wilkins had 28 points and 12 rebounds last night and the Atlanta Hawks rallied from a 19-point deficit after the first period to beat the Indiana Pacers, 117-106. Chuck Person scored 27 points and Reggie Miller 26 for Indiana, while Glenn Rivers had 24, John Battle 21 and Moses Malone 19 for the visiting Hawks, who have won nine of 11 games. Trailing, 90-89, with 10 minutes remaining, Atlanta took the lead for good with a 16-2 run. Rivers scored 10 points and Wilkins hit a 3-pointer during the run, which gave the Hawks a 105-92 lead with five minutes left. The Pacers made the score 105-99 with 3:51 left on George McCloud's 3-pointer and Mike Sanders's two layups, but they got no closer.(AP) Trail Blazers 132, Timberwolves 117: Clyde Drexler scored 13 of his 32 points in Portland's 41-point first quarter and finished with 11 assists and 10 rebounds as the Trail Blazers set a record for the most points scored against Minnesota. Buck Williams, the league leader in field-goal percentage and Portland's top rebounder, injured his groin 2:31 into the game and didn't return for the Trail Blazers. The victory gave the Trail Blazers a 15-5 road record, the best in the league.(AP) N.H.L. Tocchet Reaches 30-Goal Plateau Rick Tocchet scored two of Philadelphia's four first-period goals last night as the Flyers defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 5-4. Tocchet, selected to start for the Wales Conference in Saturday's All-Star game, leads Philadelphia with 30 goals. This is the fourth season in a row that he has scored at least 30. Tocchet has 13 points in his last 10 games. The victory, Philadelphia's second in its last seven games, snapped a seven-game (0-4-3) streak without a victory for the Flyers. Pittsburgh was 12-4 in its previous 16 games with Tom Barrasso, the Pittsburgh goaltender, allowing only four goals in the previous three. Dale Kushner, Kjell Samuelsson and Mike Ricci had the other Philadelphia goals. Bob Errey, Phil Bourque, Paul Coffey and Gord Roberts scored for Pittsburgh. Philadelphia, 20-0-2 when scoring four or more goals, has beaten Pittsburgh in three of four meetings this season. Pittsburgh came into the game as the league's top-scoring team. But the Flyers, who hadn't scored more than three goals in any of their previous seven games, jumped out to the big lead. Tocchet scored on a power play at 10:37 and at even strength at 14:12. Coffey made it 4-3 when he beat Peeters on a power play at the 9:25, making him the highest-scoring defenseman in Pittsburgh history with 344 points. (AP) SKIING Girardelli Wins 2d Race in a Row Marc Girardelli overwhelmed the competition in a World Cup giant slalom yesterday to win his second consecutive race and widen his lead in the overall standing. Girardelli, a three-time cup champion racer who was born in Austria but lives in Luxembourg, finished in a two-heat combined time of 2 minutes 5.72 seconds over the course in Adelboden, Switzerland. He beat Alberto Tomba, the Olympic giant-slalom champion, by 1.56 seconds. Tomba's time was 2:07.28. Rudolf Nierlich of Austria was third at 2:07.41. Girardelli was fastest in both 44-gate runs of the season's fourth giant slalom.(AP)

title: Studies Don't Show That Condoms Lower Teen-Age Pregnancy; Less Dramatic Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcohol Ads Aimed At Blacks Criticized
description: The Center for Science in the Public Interest, a media monitoring group in Washington, has criticized beer and alcohol producers for aiming their advertising at black consumers.

title: Ben Johnson Charged
description: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter whose use of steroids nullified several world-record achievements and a gold medal in the 1988 Olympic Games, was charged with assault yesterday in Toronto. Cheryl Thibedeau, a former teammate at the Mazda Optimist Track Club, accused him of attacking her on Dec. 17 at the track and field center of York University.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Foreign Minister Man in the News: Aleksandr Aleksandrovich Bessmertnykh; Soviet Master of Washington's Ways
description: In 1988, after assuring members of the Soviet Parliament that the treaty limiting medium-range nuclear missiles was good for Moscow, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, then a Deputy Foreign Minister, paused in the Kremlin to chat in English about the agreement with an American journalist.

title: Design Is Chosen for One Detector In Superconducting Supercollider
description: A race between three consortiums seeking approval to install detection equipment in the superconducting supercollider planned for Texas has ended with one competitor selected, another eliminated and a third facing an exhaustive review. Each of two initial detectors would cost about $500 million.

title: Twisters Strike Miami Area
description: Two tornadoes destroyed airplanes at a small airport in Broward County and smashed windows and doors in the Sylvania Heights Elementary School in West Miami this afternoon, slightly injuring a teacher, the authorities said. The first tornado hit in the Pembroke Pines area, flipping about 15 planes at North Perry Airport. Jim Reynolds, spokesman for the Broward County Aviation Department, estimated the damage at up to $1 million.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Kremlin; MOSCOW APPOINTS FOREIGN MINISTER
description: Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, succeeded Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Foreign Minister today and pledged to maintain good relations and cooperate with the West despite the crackdown in Lithuania.

title: The Pop Life
description: Sting's 'Soul Cages'

title: Review/Dance; An Evocation of a Classic By a Young Classical Troupe
description: It takes a brave soul to form a ballet company these days, particularly one devoted to classical ballet created by fledgling choreographers. Carrie Diamond's New American Ballet Ensemble, which performed on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, has survived a year and a half. It clearly has a devoted audience. The five dances the ensemble presented were informed by good taste, intelligence and craft, and were performed by well-trained and personable young dancers. But soon into the program, one began to long for a little passion -- or even a vulgar touch of excess.

title: Stocks Tumble in Tokyo
description: Share prices tumbled in thin and nervous trading and the dollar bounced upwards here today as the United Nations deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait passed without signs of any Iraqi concessions.

title: An Old Friend of Marcos Tests Campaign Waters
description: Filipinos are known for their willingness to forgive the most outrageous conduct on the part of public figures. But even their tolerance is likely to be stretched by the prospective presidential candidacy of Eduardo Cojuangco Jr., the estranged cousin of President Corazon C. Aquino and one of the closest associates of the man she ousted, the late Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: In Districts That Bus, Issues Remain
description: Officials of public school systems reacted cautiously yesterday to the Supreme Court ruling on school desegregation, many of them saying the ruling left many issues unresolved.

title: California Art Museum Names a New Director
description: Michael Botwinick, the director of the Brooklyn Museum from 1974 to 1983, has been named director of the Newport Harbor Art Museum in Newport Beach, Calif. The museum, founded in 1961, is known for its permanent collection of Californian art created since World War II and for its innovative shows in the fields of modern and contemporary art.

title: MNC Financial Meets Deadline
description: Maryland's largest banking company met a critical debt payment deadline today with loans of $271 million from two of its own bank subsidiaries.

title: Perez Status Uncertain
description: Pitchers and catchers begin reporting to spring training Feb. 22, but whether the Yankees pitcher Pascual Perez will be among them remains to be seen.

title: N.F.L. PLAYOFFS: The Conference Championships; Kelly Says He Is in Fine Shape for Raiders
description: A week after the uncertainty of Jim Kelly's return as the quarterback of the Buffalo Bills became an important factor in the National Football League playoffs, there is no longer any question of his status.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A14-19

title: Hussein Urges Unity Against 'The Invaders'
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in a broadcast early this morning said "a fateful dual battle has begun -- a clash between believers and infidels."

title: Analyzing TV Helps Sharpen Young Minds; Words and Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health
description: School and professional athletes are not the only ones who push their bodies to continue performing when they are crying out from overuse or injury. Millions of ordinary exercise and sports enthusiasts fail to heed the warnings of discomfort or even outright pain in muscles and joints until they have so compounded the injury that they have no choice but to take time off.

title: Two Missing in Mine Fire
description: Fire broke out today at a coal mine three miles south of this town in southern West Virginia, and two of the seven miners working there were later reported missing. The authorities said they believed that the blaze had been set off by an electrical problem. The mine is owned by Firecreek Inc. of Princeton, W.Va.

title: New Leadership Is Seen For Carter Hawley Hale
description: H. Michael Hecht, chairman of the Broadway-Southern California department stores, is expected to be named president soon of its owner, Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., retail executives say.

title: Correction
description: An obituary yesterday about Paul R. Miller Jr., a former academic and public-relations official, misidentified a surviving sister. She is Polly Spalding of Ridgefield, Conn..

title: TOP DRUG SUSPECT WEIGHS SURRENDER
description: This country's most notorious drug smuggler is considering following the example of his No. 2 man, who surrendered to the authorities on Tuesday as part of a peace effort to end Colombia's war over drugs.

title: BOMB BAGHDAD AND KUWAITI TARGETS; 'NO CHOICE' BUT FORCE, BUSH DECLARES; A TENSE WAIT ENDS
description: In one long moment yesterday, word that the United States had attacked Baghdad swept the country.

title: Businesses Brace for Temporary Sales Slump
description: As the nation went to war against Iraq, many business executives braced themselves last night for a possible sales slump. Retailers and others who depend on confident consumers or low gasoline prices said they expect their businesses to suffer, at least in the short term.

title: Harry Shorten, Creator Of Cartoon, Dies at 76
description: Harry Shorten, a publisher who created the syndicated cartoon feature "There Oughta Be a Law," died on Monday at the Vencor Catastrophic Illness Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 76 years old and had moved from Rockville Centre, L.I., to Pompano Beach, Fla., in 1982.

title: Help for a Vintage Fountain Pen
description: BOXES of nibs, barrels, springs, caps and levers line the wall above Richard Weinstein's desk at Authorized Repair Service, which has repaired fountain pens and mechanical pencils for nearly 30 years. The spare parts are for Parkers, Schaeffers and others from the 1880's to the 1950's that pen enthusiasts collect.

title: Democracy Era Begins For Largest U.S. Tribe
description: After two years of political upheaval in the nation's largest Indian tribe, the leadership of the Navajo Nation has been turned over to its first elected tribal president under a shift to a more democratic form of government.

title: Profit Up at Primerica, but Down at Schwab
description: The Primerica Corporation, the diversified financial services company, reported yesterday that it had earned $98.8 million, or 89 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1990, compared with $95.9 million, or 87 cents a share, in the comparable period in 1989.

title: Paper Points to Iraqi in P.L.O. Killings
description: A daily Egyptian newspaper raised the prospect today that the killing in Tunis of two senior Palestine Liberation Organization officials on Monday had been ordered by President Saddam Hussein and carried out by the Abu Nidal renegade Palestinian organization based in Baghdad.

title: With Such Good Cheer, Tapping Through the Night
description: Dancellington tapped out messages of good cheer in "A Black and Tan Fantasy," the tap-dance revue it presented on Saturday night at Symphony Space. The troupe was good looking, well-trained and unmannered. And it was at its best when its choreography was most forthright.

title: Device Is Said to Help Predict Strokes in Sickle-Cell Children
description: A new ultrasound device could enable doctors to prevent crippling strokes in children with sickle cell anemia by identifying the children at greatest risk, a researcher said today.

title: Anti-Bias Law Sought for Overseas Workers
description: The Bush Administration urged the Supreme Court today to apply an anti-discrimination law to United States citizens working overseas for American businesses.

title: Brisk Trading Worldwide, but No Panic; Yen Soars And Tokyo Stocks Rise
description: Early reports of American success in attacking Iraqi military positions sent Japanese stock prices and the yen sharply higher, while oil prices in Asia tumbled. The financial markets appeared to express relief at the early signs that the world economy would not suffer major damage from a war in the Persian Gulf.

title: The Best Alternative to Abortion
description: "The prevalence of abortion on demand in America calls into question our respect for the fundamental right to life," President Bush said on declaring next Sunday "National Sanctity of Human Life Day." Perhaps. But it calls even more into question this country's commitment to making safe, effective birth control accessible to all Americans.

title: For Helpers of Retarded, A Way to Move Up
description: Annabell Kendrick has been working with mentally retarded adults for more than 30 years, helping them write their name and brush their hair, leading them in games and attending to their most basic needs. But despite her experience and dedication, without a college degree she had no chance to advance in her career -- to be a teacher or therapist rather than an assistant.

title: Gorbachev Urges Curb on Press Freedom
description: Faced with growing condemnation of his administration's weekend assault on unarmed demonstrators in Lithuania, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for suspension of a much-hailed law guaranteeing freedom of the press.

title: U.S. and Allies Open Air War on Iraq; Bomb Baghdad and Kuwaiti Targets; 'No Choice' But Force, Bush Declares
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Jan. 17 - The United States and allied forces Wednesday night opened the long-threatened war to drive President Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait, striking Baghdad and other targets in Iraq and Kuwait with waves of bombers and cruise missiles launched from naval vessels.

title: Cheney's Remarks on Attack on Iraq
description: Following are a transcript of the statement by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney at the Pentagon last night and excerpts from a subsequent news conference given by Mr. Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Capitals Obtain Iafrate
description: In search of a high-scoring defenseman, the Washington Capitals yesterday obtained Al Iafrate from the Toronto Maple Leafs for Peter Zezel, a center, and Bob Rouse, another defenseman. Iafrate, who has been selected twice for the N.H.L. All-Star Game, last season had 21 goals and 42 assists for 63 points to lead his team's defensemen in scoring for the third straight season.

title: President Quits Post At Browning-Ferris
description: John E. Drury, the president and chief operating officer of Browning-Ferris Industries, the nation's second-largest waste-management company, resigned yesterday. His duties are to be assumed by the company's chairman and chief executive, William D. Ruckelshaus, a former director of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Newsday Announces Advertising Rate Rise
description: Newsday announced yesterday that it was raising its advertising rates but guaranteeing that the circulation gains it has made since The Daily News strike began would hold through 1991.

title: BOMB BAGHDAD AND KUWAITI TARGETS; 'NO CHOICE' BUT FORCE, BUSH DECLARES; No Ground Fighting Yet; Call to Arms by Hussein
description: The United States and allied forces Wednesday night opened the long-threatened war to drive President Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait, striking Baghdad and other targets in Iraq and Kuwait with waves of bombers and cruise missiles launched from naval vessels.

title: Profits Off by 28% At Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported today that profits fell 28 percent last quarter, but analysts were pleased and said the report showed the computer company was on the way to recovery.

title: Well Done, My Son
description: To The Home Section: The column about children who cannot please their parents [ Parent & Child, Jan. 10 ] evoked memories of my father, whom I always found to be hypercritical.

title: Latvia's Leader Tries to Placate the Kremlin
description: Defended by a mere truck barricade and bonfire vigil, the Latvian government sought to protect its fledgling democracy today, presenting a conciliatory tone toward the Kremlin.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Casting black actors in roles traditionally played by white actors is nothing new. But choosing EARLE HYMAN , who plays Bill Cosby's father on "The Cosby Show," to play Colonel Pickering in "Pygmalion" suggests some daring.

title: If Only Alice Could See: Looking Glass Goes Video
description: I AGED 60 years at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas last weekend. My eyes gradually sank into my face behind increasing folds of skin; my jowls grew heavy, pulling down my chin in cascading wrinkles; the lines from my nose to my mouth seemed carved by more than a lifetime's cares. And all I was doing was looking at a computer screen.

title: Lithuanian Dead Buried as 'Martyrs'
description: Mourners by the hundreds of thousands streamed through the streets of the Lithuanian capital today to bury those killed by the Soviet Army.

title: Nets Get Anderson Of Bucks
description: The Nets, who have lost 11 consecutive games, acquired Greg (Cadillac) Anderson, a power forward, from the Milwaukee Bucks yesterday for a veteran guard, Lester Conner. The trade was announced by Willis Reed, the Nets' senior vice president of basketball operations.

title: A Short War Will Test Recession Assumptions
description: A brief Persian Gulf war would test one of the great assumptions about the national recession: that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait precipitated the recession and an American military victory will make the economy rebound. But evidence is accumulating that the recession has taken on a life of its own and will probably endure.

title: CNN Takes an Early Lead In Coverage of the Gulf War
description: The shooting in the Persian Gulf began tonight with the three broadcast networks committed to covering the war on a 24-hour basis, although their image as news leaders was damaged by the Cable News Network's early dominance of the coverage.

title: To Hang Your Coat (and More) In the Place You Hang Your Hat
description: CLOSETS overstuffed? Chairs piled high? How about a coat tree? From twig to high-tech, the assortment will suit any space or decor.

title: Romania Seeks to Reduce Abortions
description: The scarcity and high cost of contraceptives here as well as a lack of easily available information about birth control have left abortion as the primary means of family planning, slowing the country's recovery from the harsh population building policies of its former Communist dictator, health officials here said.

title: Filling the Gap Where a Living Will Won't Do
description: Several years ago Lily Stone signed a document called a "living will," rejecting in advance any heroic medical treatment in the event she became hopelessly ill and unable to speak for herself.

title: Old Forms in New Composition
description: In this age of historically informed performance, can historically informed composition be far behind? It is slightly eerie to hear a new Poe-inspired work by a young New York composer written in a style so unabashedly reactionary that apart from the 20th-century sound of the vibraphone, it could hardly have shocked old Poe.

title: Art Deco Lovers Gather in Miami
description: Admirers of the pastels and streamlined forms of the Art Deco hotels and apartment houses in Miami Beach came here from around the world last weekend to learn from preservationists who helped establish the nation's first historic Art Deco district. The event was the World Congress of Art Deco.

title: Brisk Trading Worldwide, but No Panic; Companies Set Gasoline Price Curbs
description: The news of military action drove oil prices wild last night, first up by 20 percent in a few minutes, and then down below their starting point, as it appeared that the American air strike met almost no resistance from the Iraqis.

title: Another Major '89 Protester Is Placed on Trial in Beijing
description: China opened court proceedings today against another prominent dissident, Liu Xiaobo, who was involved in the Beijing protests of 1989.

title: Consumers in Revolt? Light a Fountain of Joy
description: Next to a good book, a poem or a penetrating film, there is little a Bengali intellectual enjoys more than a political argument. There is no dearth of those this winter, and that could add up to trouble for the leftist coalition that has ruled the city and the state of West Bengal for almost 14 years.

title: Super Lotto Tickets To Go on Sale Today
description: Tickets for the biggest New York State lottery jackpot ever go on sale on Thursday. The drawing for the $50 million Super Lotto jackpot will be on Jan. 26, the day before Super Bowl Sunday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Some may ask, why act now? Why not wait? The answer is clear. The world could wait no longer." -- President Bush. [ A1:6. ]

title: Drug Maker Halts Orders
description: A drug manufacturer has suspended shipments of all its products after discovering employees had falsified some applications to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: 16,000 Will Be Laid Off, And Lives Are Shaken
description: It was not as if Azalee Williams, a single mother from Brooklyn, did not have enough worries. One son is in the Army in Saudi Arabia and another is trying to make ends meet to stay in college. Yesterday she learned that the city plans to lay off about 16,000 workers in the next 18 months and that she could be one of them.

title: For News, 3 Options
description: By declaring yesterday that the newspaper cannot continue to operate as it is, The Daily News narrowed its options to three: settling promptly with its striking unions, negotiating a sale or closing the paper.

title: An Organist Who Probes Bach's Mind
description: Ton Koopman, the Dutch early-music conductor and keyboard player, gives organ recitals in New York only rarely, so his appearance late Sunday afternoon on the new (as of 1987) Rieger organ at the Church of the Holy Trinity attracted a lively crowd of organists and organ lovers.

title: USF&G Planning To Trim 900 Jobs
description: The USF& G Corporation, the troubled insurance and financial services company, said it would eliminate 900 jobs. The layoffs will involve 360 employees in the Baltimore headquarters and 540 people in branches and subsidiaries, the company said.

title:
TWO CAUTIONARY THOUGHTS AS THE U.S. PLUNGES INTO THE PERSIAN GULF WAR;
Deflate, Don't Destroy, Hussein
description: Before the Persian Gulf war began, the White House was frequently urged to pursue war against Iraq all the way to Baghdad, eradicating Saddam Hussein's regime and taking out the country's nuclear, chemical and biological warfare capabilities. But this was short-sighted.

title: Excerpts From CNN Report
description: For many Americans and others around the globe, the reports by Bernard Shaw, Peter Arnett and John Holliman of the Cable News Network provided the first eyewitness reports of the bombing of Baghdad. Here is an excerpt from CNN's broadcast last night from the Al Rashid Hotel in Baghdad.

title: Talking Deals; Saving Pan Am From Liquidation
description: JUST hours before Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection early on the morning of Jan. 8, the airline's management was still not certain it would have enough money to avoid liquidation. The final agreement that provided the carrier with a $150 million loan from Bankers Trust and United Airlines was not worked out and signed until 6:45 that morning.

title: Rumble in the Sky Ends a 5-Month Wait
description: "It's absolutely awesome, I mean the ground shook and you felt it," said Col. Ray Davies, describing the takeoff of the first planes to attack Iraq from a big Saudi air base where he is chief maintenance officer.

title: USX Said to Seek To Extend Contract
description: The USX Corporation has asked for a 90-day extension on its labor contract with the United Steelworkers of America, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported on Tuesday. Company and union officials did not comment because negotiations are being conducted under a news blackout.

title: Armco in Agreement To Acquire Cyclops
description: Armco Inc., the nation's fifth-largest steel producer, yesterday took a step toward becoming a bigger force in the stainless-steel market by agreeing to buy Cyclops Industries, a specialty steel products company based in Pittsburgh, for $22 a share, or $156 million.

title: Excerpts From U.S. Report Of Its Attempts to Avoid War
description: Following are excerpts from a letter sent by President Bush today to notify Congressional leaders that he had exhausted all diplomatic means to persuade Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The letter was required under the resolutions approving the use of force that were passed on Saturday by both houses of Congress.

title: Treasury Prices Decline Slightly
description: Although war fears remained pervasive in the credit markets yesterday, comments about the economy by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, were the major cause of a slight drop in the prices of Treasury securities.

title: Mr. Dinkins Does His Painful Duty
description: The preliminary budget Mayor David Dinkins released yesterday offers a plausible start at getting ahead of the continuing plunge in New York City's revenues. His plan confronts an anticipated budget gap of nearly $2 billion mainly by cutting some spending and seeking an unusually large package of new taxes. It is not yet as rigorous as it may have to become, but it's a conscientious start.

title: Ciba-Geigy Sales Are Down by 4%
description: Sales at Ciba-Geigy A.G., Switzerland's biggest chemical and pharmaceutical company, fell 4 percent last year, to 19.7 billion Swiss francs, or $15.3 billion, the company reported. The company attributed the decline to a weakened dollar and yen against the Swiss franc.

title: Drop of 0.6% in U.S. Output Erodes Hopes on Recession
description: A new Government report today showed a surprisingly big decline in industrial output that analysts said eroded confidence in the widely held, though far from unanimous, view that the recession would be brief and mild.

title: Gorbachev Is Moving To Muzzle the Press
description: Faced with mounting condemnation of the assault by Soviet forces on demonstrators in Lithuania, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev moved to undermine a law guaranteeing freedom of the press -- a hallmark of the era of openness that he himself ushered in. Page A8.

title: Price Data Set On U.S. Issues
description: The Public Securities Association, a trade group, said yesterday that an industrywide joint venture to disseminate price information on Government securities had named its system Govpx Inc.

title: Falling Short of Dinkins's 'Smaller Government' Goal
description: "In the future, ours will be a smaller government," Mayor David N. Dinkins said last week in his State of the City message. "One able to cope with the rapid changes, but a stronger one, more creative, more productive and more responsive."

title: Money-Fund Yields Drop
description: Yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report declined for the week ended yesterday. It was the second consecutive week that yields had fallen.

title: Snowshoeing a Sport on the Move
description: Until recently, snowshoes had been regarded as little more than quaint wall decorations set over the fireplace in a hunting lodge or country home, respected for their traditional place in the North American experience. Used by Indians, adopted by explorers and trappers, snowshoes seem to epitomize the rugged outdoors and a way of life distant and forgotten by contemporary Americans.

title: Striking Images of Massive Stars Are Captured by Space Telescope
description: New observations by the Hubble Space Telescope have produced what astronomers say are exciting images and data on some of the most massive stars known in the universe.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Pope County, Ark., is offering $27 milllion in 8 percent tax-exempt waste-disposal revenue bonds due 2021 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bonds, for an Arkansas Power and Light Company project, are rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by Standard & Poor's. * Telephone and Data Systems Inc., Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million in senior unsecured debt securities through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The company expects to offer the securities from time to time with various terms ranging from 9 months to 30 years. Common Stock * Marcam Corp., Newton, Mass., a supplier of applications software and services for process manufacturing,is offering 1.5 million common shares at $21 a share through Hambrecht & Quist Inc. Ratings * Burlington Industries Capital Inc.'s senior discount debentures rating and floating-rate notes rating have been lowered to Caa, from B-3, by Moody's. The company is based in Greensboro, N.C. * PNC Financial Corp.'s subordinated debt and preferred stock rating has been lowered to A-, from A+, by S.&P. The company is based in Pittsburgh.

title: Dentist With AIDS Is Linked to 2 Other Cases
description: A lawyer for a woman who was apparently infected with the AIDS virus by her dentist confirmed yesterday that a Federal investigation showed that two other patients were almost certainly infected in the dentist's office.

title: Kidnapping Victim Back Home in Florida
description: A wealthy businessman and philanthropist was abducted from his driveway Monday morning but returned home safely by taxicab early today after he had been left at a shopping center, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Transcript of the Comments by Bush on the Air Strikes Against the Iraqis
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks in the Oval Office last night about the Persian Gulf action, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Free Transit Offers Few Savings and Little Inducement to Ride; Of Benefit to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Transit Offers Few Savings and Little Inducement to Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: Civilian Agencies Sending Blood to Augment Military's Gulf Supply
description: Anticipating a brief, intense war in the Persian Gulf, the American military is gathering blood supplies from civilian agencies for the first time since the Korean War.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CONVENTIONAL clothes closets, with one high shelf and a single rod for hangers, waste space and become cluttered too easily. Both problems can be solved by dividing the closet into compartments with freestanding storage units or a combination of built-in units and rods.

title: Murder Victim's Child Tells of Ties to Defendant
description: The teen-age daughter of the woman Carolyn Warmus is accused of killing testified today that Ms. Warmus had sought her friendship, taking her skiing and giving her diamond earrings from Tiffany's for her 16th birthday.

title: Legislators Are Eager to Curb New Jersey's Weapons Law
description: Both houses of the Legislature are moving to weaken New Jersey's assault weapon law, the most restrictive in the country, as national groups favoring and opposing gun control threaten to make the state a battleground for the issue in November's legislative elections.

title: 25% of Assaults Against Women Are by the Men in Their Lives
description: Women are less likely to be victims of violent crime than are men, while women who are victimized are far more likely to have been attacked by someone with whom they are intimate, according to a new study by the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics.

title: Banc One Deal For PNC Units
description: The Banc One Corporation agreed today to acquire four affiliates of the PNC Financial Corporation for $225 million in cash and securities.

title: L. F. E. Goldie Dies; Ex-Law Professor, 72
description: L. Frederick E. Goldie, a retired law professor at Syracuse University, died on Saturday at Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse. He was 72 years old and lived in Fayetteville, N.Y.

title: Raids, on a Huge Scale, Seek to Destroy Iraqi Missiles
description: The military campaign to evict Iraq from Kuwait began, as expected, with air strikes on a huge scale at targets deep in Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Cutbacks Bring Loss At GlenFed
description: GlenFed Inc., parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan association, said today that it would add to loan-loss reserves, sell some assets, freeze management salaries and suspend its dividend. The company also said it would eliminate 600 jobs in the next quarter through attrition, but layoffs were not ruled out.

title: Storm's Eye: Bush Decides To Go to War
description: The war began early in the Oval Office.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Warriors End Celtic Home Streak Tim Hardaway's career-high 37 points and an inbounds violation by Kevin Gamble of Boston gave the Golden State Warriors a 110-105 victory last night that ended the Celtics' 18-game home winning streak.

title: No. 1 Question for the Poles: When Do Soviet Troops Go?
description: Poland is hearing conflicting messages from Moscow these days, and the dissonance between military and civilian officials has stirred considerable unease here.

title: A.T.&T. Says Tender Offer For NCR Stock Yields 70%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has received a strong show of support for its takeover bid for the NCR Corporation, reporting yesterday that it had received tenders for about 70 percent of the computer maker's common stock.

title: Syracuse Sets Back UConn
description: Billy Owens made four consecutive free throws to give No. 8 Syracuse the lead in overtime and the Orangemen held on for an 81-79 victory last night over No. 13 Connecticut. It was the ninth victory in a row for Syracuse against a ranked opponent.

title: Fleet/Norstar Posts Deficit
description: Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc. today reported a fourth-quarter loss of $48.9 million after increasing its reserve fund for potentially bad loans to $700 million from $638.7 million.

title: Dorothy Rosenman, A Housing Specialist And an Author, 90
description: Dorothy Rosenman, an authority on housing and a lifelong advocate of low-cost housing, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: From TV Reporters in Iraq, News an Attack Has Begun
description: Three Cable News Network correspondents gave the world terse and vivid descriptions of the American air attack as they looked out the window of their Baghdad hotel, reporting the sky ablaze with antiaircraft fire and bomb blasts as explosions thundered in the background.

title: Sleep in It, but You Can't Take It With You
description: Foldaway beds are not customarily as chic as the one designed by Clements Rameckers and Arnold Van Geuns for their new Warrior collection.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Oilers Appeal Fuhr Ban
description: The Edmonton Oilers have asked John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, to put an end to the one-year suspension for using cocaine that he levied in September on Grant Fuhr, the Edmonton goalie. When he suspended Fuhr before the beginning of the season, Ziegler said the goalie could apply to him for reinstatement on Feb. 18.

title: Philharmonic Ensembles: Homey View
description: The New York Philharmonic Ensembles programs at Merkin Concert Hall give the orchestra's players -- and not only the principals -- opportunities to shine, or not, in a more intimate setting than usual. The orchestra's audience is clearly interested in hearing what the musicians sound like in such comparatively intimate circumstances: the concerts are generally sold out or nearly so. There were few empty seats on Sunday afternoon, when the players addressed music by Mozart, Reger and Brahms.

title: Israel Declares Emergency; Staying Indoors Urged
description: Israel declared a state of emergency early this morning, minutes after word reached here of the American attack on Iraq. The authorities advised all Israelis to stay in their homes, open their chemical warfare kits and make their gas masks ready for immediate use.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
2 Music Executives to Share Top Job at Mercury Records
description: Mercury Records, the largest American record label owned by Polygram N.V., has named two executives with familiar music-industry names as co-presidents: Ed Eckstine, son of the jazz singer Billy Eckstine, and Mike Bone, a former president of Island Records and Chrysalis Records.

title: Tight Ends Are Formidable 49er Weapons
description: Maybe a good place for the Giants' defense to begin its preparations for the San Francisco 49ers' multifacted offense is to listen intently to the words of Fritz Shurmur, who was recently let go as the Los Angeles Rams' defensive coordinator. Shurmur tried devising a scheme to shut down the 49ers in last season's National Football Conference championship game. Of course, he and the Rams failed miserably in the 30-3 shellacking dispensed by the 49ers.

title: The News Says It May Close Or Seek a Buyer
description: The Daily News, once the nation's largest metropolitan daily, threatened yesterday to close down soon or seek a buyer unless it stemmed heavy financial losses resulting in part from the strike by nine of its unions.

title: Broken Glasnost
description: Glasnost was Mikhail Gorbachev's way to criticize the past in order to reform the present. But glasnost opened newspapers and airwaves to many voices he could not control, and apparently cannot abide. Now glasnost is the first casualty of Soviet repression. Perestroika, or reform, could be next.

title: The White House Works to Evoke World War II Memory, Not Vietnam
description: In telling Americans that war with Iraq had started, President Bush harked back to one of the great days in American military history -- June 6, 1944.

title: National Tests Urged for Public Schools
description: A Presidential advisory group recommended to President Bush today the creation for the first time of national examinations for elementary and high school students.

title: Continental Pilots In Wage Freeze
description: About 3,900 Continental Airlines pilots have agreed to a temporary pay freeze and other cost-saving measures, the company said. The Pilot Operations Group also agreed to defer bonus payments that are based on fuel saved on flights and a 30 percent cut in the company's cost for meals.

title: Chet B. Opal, 48, Dies; Astronomy Researcher
description: Chet Brian Opal, an astronomer, research scientist and astrophysicist, died Saturday at St. David's Hospital in Austin, Tex. He was 48 years old and lived in Austin.

title: Knicks Humbled by Lowly Timberwolves, 93-89
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves, a struggling expansion team with an 11-23 record, 4-13 on the road, was the opposition for the Knicks last night.

title: Dr. Leona Baumgartner, 88, Dies; Led New York Health Department
description: Dr. Leona Baumgartner Langmuir, a public health official who was New York City's Commissioner of Health from 1954 to 1962 and later was an assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development, died on Tuesday in Chilmark, Mass. She was 88 years old and lived Chilmark.

title: Personally
description: Woman walks into a bakery, where there's a sign announcing that the price of bagels will go up a nickel on Jan. 15. "War and an increase in the price of bagels on the same day," she says.

title: Alfred Frauenknecht; Swiss Engineer, 64
description: Alfred Frauenknecht, a Swiss engineer found guilty in 1971 of selling Mirage jet-engine secrets to Israel, has died at the age of 64, his family said today.

title: Parent of American Air Reports a Record Loss
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, today reported a loss of $215.1 million in the fourth quarter, the worst quarterly loss in company history. The company cited soaring costs for jet fuel, a weakening economy and labor troubles.

title: Hostetler Starting To Feel Pressure
description: The last time the Giants played the 49ers, a dramatic 7-3 loss six and a half weeks ago, Jeff Hostetler was in the game for one play, holding for Matt Bahr's 20-yard field goal. When the Giants and the 49ers meet in San Francisco on Sunday for the National Conference championship and a trip to the Super Bowl, Hostetler will be the Giants' quarterback.

title: Black Leftist's Jail Ordeal In the South in the 1930's
description: In 1932 a black union leader, Angelo P. Herndon, was wrongfully imprisoned for his efforts at organizing workers in Georgia. The story of Herndon's incarceration and his eventual release is the inspiration for Oyamo's impassioned new play, "Let Me Live."

title: Metro Matters; Shaving Nickels From the Budget At City Hall
description: "Now more than ever," Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday as he sketched his latest budget strategy, "New York City's most precious natural resource is its collective imagination."

title: Mozart Before Concerts
description: The New York Philharmonic Ensembles, the orchestra's chamber-music branch, will offer 30-minute recitals before Philharmonic subscription concerts in Avery Fisher Hall starting Jan. 29 at 6:30 P.M. The all-Mozart programs, part of the Mozart Bicentennial at Lincoln Center, will continue through the 1991-92 season. The recitals will be free to holders of tickets for orchestra concerts the same evening.

title: Market Place; Finding a Haven In Nestle Stock
description: SOME analysts regard Nestle S.A., the world's largest food company, as a haven for investors during this period of geopolitical tension and economic slowdown, even though it has been hurt by the weak dollar and tough competition in the United States.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's a sweet moment for GUY PASCAL , the French patissier whose desserts have graced some of New York's best-known tables. In early March, he will open Le Salon de The in the new Henri Bendel store at 712 Fifth Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets.

title: In a War, Sports Here Continue
description: On Dec. 7, 1941, the New York Giants were playing the Brooklyn Dodgers, then a National Football League rival, at the Polo Grounds when the public-address announcer interrupted the game.

title: What the Bombs Said
description: Until the electrifying television reports of the sudden flashes in Baghdad's night sky, there was hope against hope.

title: Senators Seek Exoneration As Hearings on Ethics End
description: After hearing vigorous appeals for exoneration by lawyers for five Senators accused of improper links to Charles H. Keating Jr., the Senate Ethics Committee concluded eight weeks of public sessions today and prepared to deliberate their fate.

title: Sundance Film Festival Veers From Mainstream
description: For the next 10 days, the ski slopes and theaters in Park City, Utah, will be crowded with Hollywood agents and studio executives looking for new talent and marketable films at the annual Sundance Film Festival. This year, they may get something of a shock.

title: Economy Is Chief Concern In Survey of Cities' Officials
description: City officials surveyed around the country say they think the worst problems facing their communities are the national economy, drug abuse, disposal of solid waste, their cities' financial condition and crime.

title: A Resignation At Chiat/Day
description: As expected, Michael Smith has resigned as senior vice president and creative director of Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York.

title: THE N.F.L. PLAYOFFS: The Conference Championships; Giants Decide to Start Bahr as Kicker Against the 49ers
description: Matt Bahr, not Raul Allegre, will be the Giants' kicker on Sunday at San Francisco when the team takes on the 49ers for the National Football Conference championship.

title: Bush Backs but Delays Payment to El Salvador
description: President Bush is authorizing a $42.5 million military aid payment to El Salvador's Government but is setting the money aside for 60 days to give peace talks "every possible chance to succeed."

title: Volatile Trading Expected After Dollar's Drop in Asia
description: Traders said last night that they expect the currency markets in New York to be volatile today, responding, as one dealer said, to just "fragments of news." But they expect that the surprising fall of the dollar overnight should continue unless news from the Persian Gulf does not remain positive for the U.S.-led coalition.

title: Allies Tell U.N. Security Council of Attack
description: The United Nations Security Council met late tonight so that the United States, Britain and France could officially inform the other members that they had taken military action against Iraq.

title: Interpreting Cranbrook's Influence
description: LIKE emissaries from a technologically advanced planet, design graduates from the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., descended upon corporate America over the past decade. Their work, and the theories behind it, are the subject of "Cranbrook Design: The New Discourse" ( Rizzoli , $50 hardcover, $35 paperback). From Feb. 8 to March 22, Cranbrook will also be the subject of a related exhibition at the Steelcase Design Partnership, 305 East 63d Street in Manhattan.

title: Should the Store Be Sold Or Should It Be Saved?
description: Set in a fading sporting goods store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Richard Schotter's slender comedy, "Taking Stock," at the Jewish Repertory Theater, is so consumed with the problems of maintaining a small business that audiences should come prepared to do some mental calculating.

title: William B. Lewis Jr.; Banker, 81
description: William B. Lewis Jr., a retired banker, died on Dec. 27 at his home in Shushan, N.Y. He was 81 years old and had been a resident of Smithtown, L.I., before he retired.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AMENDMENT CONFERENCE TO PARTIAL TEST-BAN TREATY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A Code Word, a Lunch And a Series of Briefings
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave the news to Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States, early today in a private briefing. The Prince then called King Fahd and, using a prearranged code word, gave the hosts of the allied coalition final word of imminent war against Iraq.

title: It's Playful, Yet Has A Purpose
description: IT looks like something that might have been inspired by English Romantic poetry. But in fact, this turreted folly at the end of a 50-foot catwalk serves a highly unromantic purpose -- as housing for a pumping station.

title: Texas Insurer In Settlement
description: A former Texas insurance commissioner who was accused of conspiring to steal millions of dollars from an insurance company he ran has settled an $11 million civil lawsuit.

title: FRANCE'S TROOPS NOW AT U.S. CALL
description: A few hours before war began in the Persian Gulf this morning, the French Government won strong parliamentary backing for French participation in military action to evict Iraq from Kuwait.

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: Bush Evokes Glory Of Past, Not Vietnam To tell Americans that war with Iraq had started, President Bush harked back to one of the great days in American military history -- D-Day, June 6, 1944. News analysis, page A16. In Cairo, Jubilation Among Kuwaiti Exiles Hundreds of Kuwaitis drove their cars through the Egyptian capital, honking and waving flags after hearing news of the American-led attack. "Thank God! Thank God!" was a cry heard over and over again. Page A18. Israel on Alert Israel declared a state of emergency minutes after word of the attack. There was no immediate indication an Iraqi attack on Israel. Page A18.

title: Markets Remain Cautious, but No Big Selloff Is Expected
description: It is uncertain how the financial markets will react today to the events last night in the Persian Gulf, but market traders indicated that a heavy selloff of stocks looked less likely than was originally feared.

title: Transit Agency Plans Improvements
description: Electronic turnstiles that deter fare beaters. A subway tracking system that tells passengers waiting on the platform when the next train will arrive. Emergency call boxes in each subway car that allow passengers to talk to the conductor.

title: Devils Rally in 3d Period to Tie Blackhawks
description: Except for a moment of silence before the national anthem in honor of the United States and allied forces in the Persian Gulf, it was business as usual for the Devils tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Decoupage Adorns Tables and Walls
description: FOR Joanne Creveling, decoupage helped to make two five-foot-long Parsons tables look interesting yet remain unobtrusive in small rooms decorated with texture and fabric. The broad, flat Parsons table often appears to be the most important element in such rooms, said Ms. Creveling, a Manhattan publicity agent. "It would look less important and make the room look a lot more comfortable if it was covered in some way," she said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ask Corp., Waco, Tex., a maker of air-conditioning and heating units, said it had signed a consent agreement to settle a lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission that charged the company with violating securities laws in its financial reports of 1982 through 1985. * Bilspedition A.B. said its Scansped U.S.A. unit had acquired Universal Transcontinental Corp., New York, a freight forwarder and customs broker. Terms were not disclosed. * Battle Mountain Gold, Houston, said that based on initial estimates, its Crown Jewel project in Washington State contains proven and probable reserves of 707,000 ounces of gold at a grade of 0.127 ounces a ton. * Hotel Investors Trust, Woodland Hills, Calif., a real property investment company, and Hotel Investors Corp., San Diego, a hotel management company, have rejected Leonard M. Ross's offer to acquire the paired entity. * Interco, St. Louis, signed a letter of intent to sell certain assets of its Megastar Apparel Group unit to Hampton Industries. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. * Arthur B. Little Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a management and technology consulting concern, has formed an alliance with Aeronomics Inc., Atlanta, a revenue management consultant, to work together in the revenue-management consulting field. Terms were not disclosed. * Lockheed Missiles and Space Co., a unit of Lockheed Corp., is forming a joint venture with Telecom Australia, the Australian national telephone company, to provide software development for a $970 million radar network in Australia. * Maxwell Communication Corp. P.L.C., London, said negotiations to sell its Panini Group of Companies for $:60 million, or $114.5 million, to a group of investment funds had been terminated. Panini has printing businesses and publishes children's books. * National Tollroad Authority Corporation, a consortium led by Perot Group of Dallas, has completed negotiations with the California Transportation Department to build a $700 million express toll road as an 11.2-mile extension of the Orange Freeway in Orange County, Calif. * Pacificorp, Portland, Ore., a utility company, has submitted a plan to the reorganization trustee of Colorado-Ute Electric Association, Montrose, Colo., an electricity company, to acquire 400 megawatts of generating assets from Colorado-Ute for $385 million. * RMS International Inc., Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., a maker of electronic devices and power supplies, said it would acquire the assets of American Fiber Optics Inc., West Palm Beach, Fla., and D & G Communications, Boynton Beach, Fla., for undisclosed terms. Both companies are installers of cable systems. * Royal Ordnance P.L.C., a British arms group, said it would acquire Heckler & Koch G.m.b.H., a German rifle maker, for undisclosed terms. Hotel Investors CorporationLittle, Arthur B.

title: In a Lot, A Little Bit Of Home
description: WITHIN the Puerto Rican communities in East Harlem and the South Bronx, las casitas serve as havens in an often tumultuous world.

title: Honoring Anna Sokolow
description: The choreographer Anna Sokolow is to be honored tonight at 8 in an 80th birthday celebration at the 92d Street Y, at 1395 Lexington Avenue. Miss Sokolow's modern-dance company, Players' Project, is to perform three of her pieces. Tickets are $20; $75, which includes a reception after the performance, and $250, which includes the performance, the reception and a dinner before the performance. Reservations: (212) 415-5488. Charge: (212) 996-1100.

title: Lowell Hoskins; Executive, 63
description: Lowell Hoskins, the president of Arbor Acres Farm, a poultry genetics company that supplies breeding stock to the poultry industry, died on Dec. 30 at his home in Glastonbury, Conn. He was 63 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coltec Industries, New York, an aerospace and automotive supplier, named Michael J. Burdulis president of its Central Moloney Transformer division. Klemens B. Schoenfelder was named president of industrial sealing products, a unit of the company's Garlock Mechanical Packing division. * Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., New York, appointed Peter Schementi vice president of management information systems. * A. B. Dick Co., Chicago, a maker of copying equipment and a unit of General Electric Co. P.L.C., London, appointed James L. Bast president and director of the company. * Foster Wheeler Energy Corp., a unit of Foster Wheeler Corp., Clinton, N.J., named Mani Seshamani vice president of commercial operations. * GFT USA Corp., New York, a clothing distributor and subsidiary of GFT S.p.A., Turin, Italy, appointed Elayne M. Garofolo senior vice president of corporate communications and image development. * GTE Corp., Stamford, Conn., named Ernst A. Burri president of its Compania Dominicana de Telefonos unit in Irving, Tex. * Sheldahl Inc., Northfield, Minn., which produces electronic components, named James E. Donaghy president and chief executive, succeeding James S. Womack, who continues as chairman.

title: Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame Inducts Its 6th Crop of Legends
description: The sixth annual Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame rumbled into the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, bringing in its wake a disparate grouping of rock, blues and rhythm-and-blues stars as inductees, including LaVern Baker, the Byrds, John Lee Hooker, the Impressions, Wilson Pickett, Dave Bartholomew and Ralph Bass. There were also posthumous honors for Howlin' Wolf, Jimmy Reed and Nesuhi Ertegun.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Reacting to War

title: Notre Dame's Ellis Academically Ineligible
description: LaPhonso Ellis, the leading scorer on a beleaguered Notre Dame team that has had a seven-game losing streak this season and has lost 9 of 15 over all, is academically ineligible to play in any of the remaining games on the 1990-91 schedule. The 6-foot-9-inch junior forward from East St. Louis, Ill., who is averaging 15.3 points, passed all of his courses, but failed to maintain the 2.0 cumulative grade average that Notre Dame requires for athletes to compete.

title: George Foreman V
description: Joan Foreman, the wife of the heavyweight challenger, gave birth to their ninth child yesterday, an 8-pound-13-ounce son who was named George Edward Foreman V. All four of the Foreman's sons have been named George and his three older sons are distinguished from one another by the nicknames Monk, Big Wheel and Little George. Foreman has been in training for his heavyweight title fight April 19 against Evander Holyfield.

title: Dr. Robert A. Milch, 61, Surgeon Who Founded Chemical Business
description: Dr. Robert Austin Milch, an orthopedic surgeon who became an entrepreneur and founded Igene Biotechnology Inc., an industrial and agricultural chemical company in Columbus, Md., died Tuesday at his home in Baltimore. He was 61 years old.

title: Dow Climbs by 18.32 Despite War Fears
description: In trading that ended just hours before the attack on Iraq yesterday, stocks defied war fears and actually rose a little.

title: New Computer Technology
description: Seven computer makers and software publishers this week endorsed a new commercial data processing technology offered by the Transarc Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based software house, developed in conjunction with the Open Software Foundation, one of two industry groups trying to standardize the Unix operating system.

title: Exiles From Kuwait Rejoice in Cairo
description: Hundreds of Kuwaitis drove their cars around the corniche and over briges crossing the Nile River in downtown Cairo, honking and waving flags at around 2 A.M., after news of the American attack against Iraq and Kuwait began to spread here.

title: 4 Women Named to Kohl's New Cabinet of 20
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his coalition partners announced today that they had chosen a 20-member Cabinet to govern Germany for the next four years.

title: Supply and Demand Govern Ship Charter
description: To the Editor:

title:
TWO CAUTIONARY THOUGHTS AS THE U.S. PLUNGES INTO THE PERSIAN GULF WAR;
Bombing Reactors -- A Big Mistake?
description: Iraq's nuclear facilities were among the first targets for last night's air strikes. If the two nuclear research reactors at the Tuwaitha Research Center 15 miles southeast of Baghdad were bombed, U.S. interests may have been injured more seriously than if the reactors had been left intact.

title: Events: Mousetraps and Meadows
description: From Idea to Patent Arthur A. Houghton Jr. Gallery and the Herb Lubalin Study Center at Cooper Union, 41 Cooper Square (Astor Place); (212) 353-4155.

title: Monteverdi's Enlightening Evensong
description: Vespers is the service that marks the end of the Christian day and the lighting of lights for the night to come. In the Middle Ages, the second function invited ritual processions which in turn invited a heavy emphasis on music. Vespers in the monastery might have been unison singing in the simplest sense, but as with most everything else in the history of the Roman Catholic Church, it could also grow into opulent display and artistic sophistication.

title: Navy Ends Plan for Dolphins to Guard Submarines
description: Citing budget concerns, the Navy said today that it had canceled a program to use dolphins to guard nuclear-armed submarines based on Puget Sound.

title: Just Like Going to The Movies
description: AS every red-blooded American knows, some of the most memorable design imagery over the past decade has been lavished not on buildings, but on athletic shoes.

title: Stu Jackson Is Hired By N.B.A.
description: Stu Jackson, who was dismissed as the Knicks' coach on Dec. 3, has found new work.

title: Analyzing TV Helps Sharpen Young Minds; See It as an Ally
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Insurers Expecting Small Loss in Gulf War
description: Insurance company executives in the United States predict their losses will be small now that war has erupted in the Persian Gulf.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A CHILD'S whine is one of the most annoying sounds parents hear. It is a cross between crying and talking, with a tone that grates like nails on a chalkboard.

title: Southwestern In Acquisition
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said today that it had bought a cable television company in Britain. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Gorbachev's 'Bloody Sunday'
description: Aleksandr Bessmertnykh came over to me at a reception a couple of years ago, said he heard I'd written a book about Lincoln and our Civil War, and proceeded to cast Mikhail Gorbachev as the Soviet Lincoln -- dedicated to preserving his Union.

title: The Decline of a Class and a Country's Fortunes
description: The Way of the WASP How It Made America and How It Can Save It, So to Speak By Richard Brookhiser 171 pages. Free Press/Macmillan. $19.95.

title: Omnicom Seeks Stake in British Agency
description: THE OMNICOM GROUP, the giant agency network that includes BBDO and DDB Needham, is negotiating to buy a minority stake in Abbott Mead Vickers, a highly regarded London agency known for its innovative ads for clients like Volvo and J. Sainsbury, a leading British supermarket.

title: Bridge
description: It has the smallest field, the highest quality and the longest name. It is the Cap Genini Pandata World Top Tournament, beginning today in The Hague with 16 pairs. Half the players have won world titles and the rest have well-established international reputations, so it is sure to be the strongest event of the year in average quality -- stronger even than the world team championships to be played in Japan in October.

title: Condom Plan May Lose Pivotal Vote
description: A plan to make condoms available on request to all New York City high school students appeared to lose vital support yesterday, raising the likelihood that the plan may have to be scaled down before it can win approval of a majority of the Board of Education.

title: FATHER CAN MOVE DAUGHTER IN COMA
description: A judge ruled today that a man may move his daughter from a Missouri hospital where she has lain for more than three years with severe brain damage and take her to Minnesota where the law might allow the removal of her feeding tube.

title: Inventories Rose 0.3% In November
description: Total sales by businesses fell 1.2 percent in November, helping to push inventories up three-tenths of a percent, the Government said today. Analysts said the backlog was not dangerously high.

title: Sporting Events Go On, but Outlook Is Unclear
description: After the outbreak of war in the Middle East, virtually all sporting events went on as scheduled last night. It was unclear what effect the conflict would have on coming events.

title: Amid Distraction, Becker Gains
description: The Australian Open, without John McEnroe's antics, Andre Agassi's swagger and Pete Sampras's serves, had its loudest moment today when a fan removed her shirt to show Boris Becker her Mickey Mouse tattoo as security guards led her from the stadium.

title: What Recession? Auction Records of 1990
description: THE weak economy notwithstanding, last year antiques and collectibles buffs paid the highest prices ever for the rarest objects auctioned. While sales slowed at auctions, fairs and antiques shops, bidders flocked to those auctions where uncommon items were offered, some with choice pedigrees. Most of the records were toppled in sales held during the first half of the year, before the worldwide economy worsened and war threatened in the Middle East.

title: Dinkins Offers $29 Billion Budget With Cutbacks and Layoffs
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins presented a $29.3 billion preliminary budget for New York City yesterday whose mix of pain and uncertainty prompted the City Council and some fiscal watchdogs to suggest that he had not gone far enough in making cuts and led others to complain about how far he went.

title: U.N. Delays Food Relief Operation in the Sudan
description: With at least 15 million people threatened by famine in the Horn of Africa this year and despite American objections, the United Nations has delayed a major relief operation in the Sudan because of that country's decision to side with Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis, officials said today.

title: ARCO Investment Head
description: ARCO said on Tuesday that it had hired the Deputy Comptroller of New York City to become president of the ARCO Investment Management Company. As president of ARCO Investment, Beverly L. Hamilton, 44 years old, will invest the assets of ARCO's employee benefit plans. The plans have assets totaling about $3.6 billion.

title: On Television, the Theater of War
description: Television achieved the excitement of old-time radio reporting last night as war began in the Persian Gulf. The first tentative word that something was happening came a few minutes after the start of "World News Tonight" on ABC, when Gary Shepherd, on the telephone from Baghdad, told of seeing an "incredible panorama of flashes" from his room at the Rashid Hotel on what he called "a very black and clear night." A minute or two later, he reported, "Obviously an air raid is under way right now."

title: Some Pain Relievers Tied to Kidney Problems
description: Women who regularly used over-the-counter pain relievers containing the drug phenacetin had higher rates of certain illnesses and death than women who used aspirin or no pain reliever, a new study has found.

title: One of China's Old Men: A Potent Apparition
description: Chen Yun's influence over this nation is sometimes baffling: at 85 years old, he has become China's Wizard of Oz, a humble man, ensconced behind a curtain of secrecy but projecting his ideas everywhere.

title: Ameritech Net Falls Sharply
description: The Ameritech Corporation yesterday announced a sharp drop in fourth-quarter profits, and Wall Street analysts greeted the report as a poor omen for results soon to be released by the other six regional Bell companies.

title: Fighting Asian Stereotypes in 'Yellow Punk Dolls'
description: "Yellow Punk Dolls," Ruby Shang's new dance piece in the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater, is a moral disaster.

title: What U.S. Is Doing for Hong Kong
description: To the Editor:

title: Donors to the Neediest Cases Hope to Help Those With AIDS
description: Edward U. Gips used to give to a variety of causes. Now, almost all of his money, including his $10 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, is directed to help people with AIDS.

title: Museum of Modern Art Considers Building Gallery Under Garden
description: Eager for more exhibition space six years after its major expansion in 1984, the Museum of Modern Art is considering a plan to dig under its famous and much-loved garden to build a large gallery for contemporary art. The proposal has prompted hot debate among the Modern's trustees.

title: THE N.F.L. PLAYOFFS: The Conference Championship; One Raider Linebacker Refuses to be Stopped
description: A funny thing happened to Riki Ellison on the way to the Coliseum last Sunday.

title: An Emergency Call From the Philharmonic
