description: Samuel Wong, the New York Philharmonic's 28-year-old assistant conductor, was told on Tuesday morning that he would lead the orchestra's concerts tonight, tomorrow afternoon and next Tuesday evening. Zubin Mehta, the orchestra's music director, had decided to follow his heart to Israel, saying he wanted to be there if war began in the Persian Gulf. On Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Wong was at Avery Fisher Hall, rehearsing with the orchestra.

title: Analyzing TV Helps Sharpen Young Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: High Above the City, Minimalist Sparkle For Subway Queen
description: THE first encounter between the architect and his potential clients was made in design heaven.

title: Harold J. Mason; Bookseller, 64
description: Harold J. Mason, a seller of rare books and a publishing company executive, died on Jan. 8 in Ventura, Calif. He was 64 years old and lived in Phoenix.

title: Derek Jarman's 'Garden' Offers Visions of Decay
description: The spirit of "The Garden," Derek Jarman's virtually wordless 90-minute assemblage of turbulent images, is a peculiar blend of reflectiveness and fury. Mr. Jarman, whose 1987 film "The Last of England" had a comparable free-associative vehemence, this time turns his thoughts to AIDS, Christianity and intolerance, combining these themes into a feverish vision of far-reaching decay.

title: New Campaign on Buses Urges Help for Homeless
description: When the cold blows in, so do pro bono advertisements for the homeless. Transportation Displays Inc., New York, is starting a new national campaign that will appear on the sides of buses.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GORDON PARKS , the photographer, painter, film maker, poet, composer and fierce tennis player, is to be honored by his friends tonight in a tribute at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. GEORGE PLIMPTON will be the host.

title: Federal Judge Backs Killing of Bison in Montana
description: Turning down the arguments of an animal rights organization, a Federal judge has ruled that Montana may continue killing bison that wander from Yellowstone National Park in an effort to keep infectious disease from spreading to the state's cattle.

title: Accounts
description: * Pebble Beach Company, Pebble Beach, Calif., owners of resort chains, to GSD&M, Austin, Tex., with undisclosed billings.

title: Key Rates
What They Did For Love
description: SOME think of them as "memory pictures." To other elderly artists, their work -- be it embroidery or a telephone-wire sculpture -- is company in later years.

title: Times Mirror's Work For Agency Magazine
description: Sports Marketing Group Inc., the custom publishing division of Times Mirror magazines, will begin publishing Agency magazine, the trade publication of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: In Midst of Big Bailout, Banker Stays Positive
description: Slumped in a chair, after having just met with Federal regulators, Lawrence K. Fish, chairman of the failed Bank of New England, looked tired, but ebullient. A "Smile It's a SNAPP" button dangled from his shirt pocket, referring to a new checking account the bank was promoting. His bank is on its way to becoming the object of one of the costliest bailouts in history, but the 46-year-old Mr. Fish was irrepressible.

title: Yellow Jackets And Lions to Play
description: Georgia Tech, which earlier this month was voted the nation's top college football team by United Press International's coaches poll after an 11-0-1 season, will play Penn State on Aug. 28 in the Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium, organizers of the event said today.

title: Edberg and Lendl Advance Amid Subdued Atmosphere
description: The mood at the National Tennis Center was somber today as the Australian Open was overshadowed by the news of war in the Persian Gulf. But there was neither an interruption of play nor a suggestion that the matches come to a halt as top-seeded Stefan Edberg and third-seeded Ivan Lendl advanced to the third round.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: With the start of war, the American-led military command in Saudi Arabia put into effect a system worked out beforehand under which journalists from many newspapers, news agencies, television and radio stations are assembled in groups and given access to various military sources.

title: Chrysler Program For Sporty Jeep
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it planned to use a six-cylinder engine manufactured in Kenosha, Wis., as the standard power plant in the company's proposed ZJ sporty Jeep model. Robert A. Lutz, who was named Chrysler's president earlier this week, said employment at the Kenosha plant would not increase as a result of the new plan. But the Kenosha operation would have lost some of its 1,100 hourly and salaried workers without the plan, he said. The plant produces about 1,300 engines a day.

title: Review/Film; A Festival of Animation
description: Spurred by the successes of "Who Framed Roger Rabbit," "The Little Mermaid" and "The Simpsons," as well as by rapid advances in computer technology, animated film is in a boom phase. Just how many styles of animation are available to contemporary film makers, from traditional cartoons to clay animation to computer-generated drawings, is suggested by "The Third Animation Celebration," an anthology of 25 short animated films opening today at the Angelika Film Center.

title: CBS and G.M. In Sports Pact
description: The General Motors Corporation has signed a seven-year agreement with CBS Sports to be the exclusive United States automobile advertiser during coverage of N.C.A.A. basketball games. The terms are reported to be near $400 million, and the contract is believed to be the largest deal ever made involving advertising and sports.

title: Why Fifth Avenue Is in Every Way No Place for Newsstands; Do It in the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; A Second Chance For Greenspan
description: WAR in the Persian Gulf could give Alan Greenspan a chance to redeem his reputation. During his first three and a half years as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Mr. Greenspan was generally viewed by politicians here and by economists on Wall Street and in the universities as a masterful captain who was sailing the economy on a steady voyage, fighting the tailwinds of inflation while avoiding the shoals of recession.

title: AIDS-Infected Doctors and Dentists Are Urged to Warn Patients or Quit
description: America's leading medical and dental associations said yesterday that doctors and dentists infected with the AIDS virus should warn their patients about their condition or give up surgery.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Decision; Setting the Hour for the War to Start: Bush Gave Iraqis One Day of Grace
description: Senior Administration officials who took part in the decision to attack Iraq say President Bush decided to give Saddam Hussein one day of grace -- all day Jan. 16, Baghdad time -- before giving the order for war.

title: Grumman Promotes Official to No. 2 Post
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that Robert J. Myers had been promoted to the position of president and chief operating officer. He was also elected to the aerospace company's board.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Networks; GIANT TV AUDIENCE FOR BUSH'S SPEECH
description: President Bush's address to the nation on the air strike against Iraq Wednesday night apparently attracted the largest audience in the history of American television.

title: Sales of Mideast Books Surge on News of War
description: For several weeks, books about the Middle East have enjoyed unusually brisk sales, but yesterday -- one day after the start of the war in the Persian Gulf -- bookstores were besieged by customers wanting anything about the region they could get their hands on. Many stores also reported a run on maps.

title: Payment Halt By Hills Stores
description: Hills Department Stores Inc., a discount-store chain that has been trying to restructure its debt, said yesterday that it had temporarily stopped paying its creditors for merchandise and would not make the interest payment due on Tuesday on its 11 percent convertible debentures. The junior subordinated debentures have a 30-day grace period on interest payments.

title: Blockbuster Gets Executive From the Toys 'R' Us Chain
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, which has built a chain of 1,500 video-rental stores since 1987, is getting a new president from Toys "R" Us Inc., the world's largest toy company.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Masters of Suspense

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; ISRAELIS REPORT LIMITED DAMAGE
description: At least seven Iraqi missiles carrying conventional warheads fell on Israel early this morning in an area running from Tel Aviv to Haifa.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The U.S. and Israel; Barrage of Iraqi Missiles on Israel Complicates U.S. Strategy in Gulf
description: The Iraqi missile attack on Israel could seriously complicate Washington's strategy in the Persian Gulf war. Much depends on whether Israel retaliates and if it does whether any of Washington's Arab allies bolt the anti-Iraq coalition.

title:
So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Entertainment;
Higher Demand For Escapism
description: Paramount Pictures releases "Flight of the Intruder" today, two days after American planes began bombing Iraq. Will people flock to a Vietnam film about Navy jets, or stay home watching television news?

title: Our Towns; After Five Years, The Lawnmower Is Passed
description: With the outbreak of war, could anything seem more trivial than a suburban feature column? And yet this is how I've spent my last five years, often rising at dawn to get over the Throgs Neck Bridge to beat the traffic to reach another suburb.

title: Father Wins a Ruling on Right to Die
description: A judge has ruled that the father of a young woman who has been severely brain-damaged for three and a half years has the right to determine his daughter's medical care -- even if that means removal of the feeding tube that keeps her alive.

title: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks
description: American and Japanese negotiators met today in the opening round of talks intended to follow through on agreements reached last summer to remove "structural impediments" to trade. Among the American complaints are that Japan does not provide full access to foreign investors and does not impose strict enough penalties on antitrust activities. The Japanese complain that the United States has not acted decisively enough to reduce its budget deficit and to provide workers with a better education, which would make it more competitive in world markets. At a briefing after the opening session, delegates from each side said the talks had been frank but provided no details.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQIS FIRE MISSILES AT ISRAELI CITIES AFTER SECOND DAY OF ALLIED BOMBING; U.S. DISCOURAGES AN ISRAELI RESPONSE
description: After a day of allied successes in the war against Iraq, Baghdad struck back today with missile attacks on Israel and Saudi Arabia.

title: TV Weekend; Mingus's 'Epitaph' by a 30-Piece Band
description: A year and a half after its world premiere at Lincoln Center, Charles Mingus's "Epitaph" is getting its first presentation on American television. A tape of that landmark concert at Alice Tully Hall may be seen from 10 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. today on the cable channel Bravo.

title: Metro Datelines; 25 Years to Life For Killing of Girl, 14
description: A maximum sentence, 25 years to life in prison, was imposed yesterday on 21-year-old Christopher Loliscio for the rape and murder last year of a 14-year-old girl.

title: Islanders' Maloney Announces Retirement
description: The segue from the ice to the front office had been under way since the start of the season, and yesterday Don Maloney, who counts a coaching career among his post-playing ambitions, made it official.

title: Ronald Michels, 47, An Ophthalmologist And Retinal Expert
description: Dr. Ronald G. Michels, an internationally known ophthalmologist, died Tuesday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 47 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * May Department Stores Co., St. Louis, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $800 million in debt securities. RATINGS * Ameritrust Corp.'s debt is under review for possible downgrading. The bank-holding company is based in Cleveland. * Corestates Financial Corp.'s debt rating is under review for possible downgrading by Moody's. The bank-holding company is based in Philadelphia. * Sweden's debt rating has been lowered to Aa-1, from Aaa, by Moody's. * Tribune Co.'s senior debt rating is under review for possible downgrading by Standard & Poor's because of the costs of the strike at The Daily News in New York and the potential impact of the tentative decision to close or sell the newspaper. Tribune Co. is based in Chicago.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: TV Critic's Notebook; A Day of Good News; Then Urgency
description: The morning brought good news, as the networks carried on yesterday with what they had promised would be 24-hour coverage of the war against Iraq. After the excitement of Wednesday night, however, they were finding that 24 hours was a lot of time to cover a war that was far out of the camera's range.

title: U.S. Dropping Case That Led to Miami Riot
description: United States Attorney Dexter W. Lehtinen has decided to drop murder charges against six members of a police drug squad whose partial acquittals in the slaying of a drug dealer led to rioting in the city's Puerto Rican section last month.

title: School Staffs Show Anxiety As Talks Stall
description: New York City school employees and administrators spent an anxious day yesterday, worrying about the possibility of thousands of immediate layoffs and the not-so-distant prospect of hundreds of millions of dollars in budget cuts.

title: Panel Proposes Paying Towns To Take Waste
description: Acknowledging that New York State probably could not force a community to accept a low-level nuclear waste dump against its will, the state commission charged with finding a dump today proposed a different approach: offering money.

title: Elliott Must Lead the Way For the Giants to Run Well
description: About 90 athletes will perform in numerous matchups when the Giants play the 49ers for the National Conference title at San Francisco on Sunday, and no matchup will be more important than that of John (Jumbo) Elliott and Kevin Fagan.

title: Allied Backing, But Protests Too
description: Western European governments gave their full backing today to the American-led offensive against Iraq and urged President Saddam Hussein to "see reason" by leaving Kuwait to avert "pointless suffering" by his own people.

title: Review/Film; Car Bomb And Chianti In 'Macbeth' Variation
description: IN the 1920's it was presented disastrously, with actors (chief among them Lionel Barrymore) wearing red and silver masks, and sets that looked like abstract arches rather than the obligatory heaths and castles. In the 1930's, Orson Welles transposed it to Haiti and staged a so-called voodoo version. In the 1960's, it became a political joke on the Johnson Administration. And now "Macbeth" is a story of New York gangsters, in particular a mad-dog hoodlum (Mike Battaglia) and his ambitious, highly unscrupulous wife (Ruthie).

title: Segregation or a Solution? Students Ponder a School Plan
description: Lonique Burnett, a senior at Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, said he had only five childhood friends left in October to celebrate Halloween. The rest, about 30 others he had grown up with in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, were either in jail or dead, he said.

title: U.S. Panel Lists Steps to End Rail Contract Dispute
description: A Presidential emergency board has issued recommendations to end a two-year-old contract dispute between the nation's freight railroads and unions representing 200,000 workers, and a leading negotiator for the unions says they will probably accept.

title: Sales-Tax Bonds Yield Up to 7.05%
description: The County Transportation Commission of Riverside, Calif., is offering $112.7 million in tax-exempt sales-tax revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.05 percent for an issue due in 2009.

title: Dictionaries Recognize 'Gender' for 'Sex'
description: To the Editor:

title: R. Burdell Bixby, 76, G.O.P. Aide Who Directed Thruway Authority
description: R. Burdell Bixby, a lawyer, former chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority and a prominent figure in the state Republican Party, died on Wednesday at the Columbia-Greene Medical Center in Hudson, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Hudson.

title: A Man With A Lot on His Mind
description: On the overcast morning yesterday, the tall man in brown-rimmed glasses, dark business suit and short dark winter coat crossed Park Avenue at 55th Street in Manhattan. He passed others on their way to work. He appeared to be a typical businessman, although he carried not a briefcase but a small egg-yellow shopping bag.

title: What Army Ads Don't Say
description: When Baghdad was bombed, I thought of the kids I taught for 10 years in Seward Park High School on Manhattan's Lower East Side. They're the sons and daughters of the working poor and the welfare system. Given their stunted job expectations -- McDonalds, supermarkets, the drug trade -- no wonder the military is alluring.

title: A Magazine's Double Take
description: "Are you politically correct?" New York magazine asks on its current cover.

title: Market Place; Traders Defy Forecasts Again
description: MANY expected a war to bring panic. Instead, the reaction verged on euphoria.

title: Tribune Didn't Scuttle Talks With Union, Publisher Says
description: The publisher of The Daily News denied a report yesterday that the board of the Tribune Company, the newspaper's corporate parent, had scuttled an impending negotiating breakthrough between The News and its striking drivers' union.

title: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Advertising; Culling Ideas That May Offend
description: Advertising agencies are hunched over print advertisements, reviewing videotapes of television commercials and scrutinizing sweepstakes, discounts, free samples and other promotions to find any hint of a message that could offend potential viewers worried about war.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Schools; Coming to Grips With Pupils' Trauma
description: Not since the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger have American schools been forced to deal with such large numbers of frightened, depressed and upset children as they do now with the onset of war in the Persian Gulf.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; Ankara Authorizes Use of Mediterranean Base by U.S. for Attacks on Iraq
description: Turkey took a big step today toward opening a second front in the air war against Iraq when its Parliament authorized United States fighters and bombers to launch strikes from this Mediterranean base.

title: Unimpressive Islanders Smothered by Oilers
description: The Islanders, who have still not jelled as a team at this advanced stage of the season, were administered a 6-1 browbeating tonight by the Edmonton Oilers, a club that is their stylistic opposite.

title: Financial Aid Is Pledged
description: Japan responded today to the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf with a new pledge of financial aid to the United States and allied troops in the region and a reiteration of its determination to avoid direct combat itself.

title: Review/Film; Wolf Meets Civilization
description: The fluffy white bunny seen at the beginning of "White Fang" has been attacked and devoured by a wild wolf pack almost before the opening credits are over. "White Fang," adapted from Jack London's tale of a wolf-dog hybrid and his encounters with civilized man, is a scenic and enveloping nature film about a young man and his beloved pet. But it is by no means strictly a children's film, and it certainly isn't "Lassie."

title: Precious Metals Prices Fall; Gold Loss Biggest Since '83
description: Belief that the war with Iraq would be short and successful sent precious metals prices plunging yesterday, with gold registering its biggest one-day loss since early 1983.

title: Books of The Times; Out of the Woods and Into a New Life
description: A Change of Luck By Julia Markus 305 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Airlines Cancel Mideast Flights
description: Almost every major airline canceled most flights to the Middle East after the United States and its allies attacked Iraq on Wednesday evening.

title: Big and Small Schools Will Continue Playing
description: From high-profile conferences like the Big Ten to tiny Division III leagues like the Constitution Athletic, college presidents and chancellors decided yesterday not to postpone intercollegiate athletic contests because of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Philip Bond, a Singer And Radiologist, 81
description: Dr. Philip Bond, who combined careers as a radiologist and opera singer, died on Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 81 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: N.F.L. Says It Will Play, With Tight Security
description: After indirect communication with the White House, the National Football League announced yesterday afternoon that, barring later developments, its conference championship games would be played Sunday, as planned, and that Super Bowl XXV would take place in Tampa, Fla., on Jan. 27.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Families; With Children in Israel, Parents Agonize at Home
description: At 4:30 A.M. Sunday, Hana Gruenberg called her parents from Jerusalem, where she is studying at Hebrew University, and said she was frightened and wanted to come home. An hour later, she called back and said she had changed her mind. "This is where I belong," she said.

title: Fire Destroys 15 Paterson Stores; Firefighter Is Missing Amid Ruins
description: A fire raged out of control throughout the day yesterday in downtown Paterson, N.J., destroying at least 15 stores and casting a pall of black smoke over the old industrial city of 139,000 people.

title: Miscellany
description: * Nathan's Famous Restaurants has become a corporate sponsor of the United Cerebral Palsy Associations. * Don Dickison and Ric Hendee have formed Dickison & Hendee Advertising in Westport, Conn. Mr. Dickison will be chairman and creative director, and Mr. Hendee will be president and chief executive.

title: Strong Display Of Support
description: As Prime Minister John Major warned today that it was too early to predict how quickly the allies would vanquish Iraq, the British people donated blood, offered prayers and put aside political differences in an overwhelming display of support for their troops in the Middle East.

title: Public Relations Was Lobbying From the Start
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., appointed Andrew E. Cummins president of its Air Products Pacific Inc. unit in Tokyo. * Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., New York, a private banking firm, named Austin J. Belton a senior manager. Brian A. Berris was admitted as a general partner. * Harris Corp., Melbourne, Fla., a manufacturer of advanced electronic systems, named Phillip Mighdoll corporate vice president of quality and new produdcts. * Lands' End Inc., Chicago, a mail order clothing company, appointed William T. End executive vice president of marketing and corporate planning. * Pueblo Railroad Service Co., a subsidiary of CF&I Steel Corp, Pueblo, Colo., named Gerald M. Bloder vice president and general manager. * Reebok International Ltd., Stoughton, Mass., appointed Barry Culkin executive vice president and acting head of its Boston Whaler division, replacing William J. Ryan, who resigned. * Retirement System Investors Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Retirement System Group Inc., named James P. Coughlin president. * TBC Corp., Memphis, which distributes automotive replacement parts, named Louis DePasqua president and chief operating officer. * Televideo Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., designers of video display terminals, appointed David Kim vice president of business development. * Trust Co. of New Jersey, Jersey City, appointed Jamille Krupa assistant vice president. Robert V. Spinello was named vice president and business development officer. * VTN Corp., Orange, Calif., an engineering and planning concern, named Dennis Brown vice president. * Warner Brothers Inc., Burbank, Calif., a unit of Time Warner Inc., New York, named Patricia Morin Brown vice president of television merchandising.

title: Bush Wins Early Support
description: The initial reaction by the American public to President Bush's decision to go to war with Iraq is positive, according the Gallup Poll.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The President; Bush Sets Somber Tone, Seeing Hard Days Ahead
description: At an afternoon Cabinet meeting today, the men who had decided to go to war could not help but be in a good mood. Initial reports showed that America's forces had performed with a "Top Gun" expertise and panache, the international coalition was holding, and Congressional leaders and the public were giving the President firm backing.

title: Texas Woman's Kin Is Accused in Rape That Led to Inquiry
description: The brother-in-law of a profoundly retarded woman was arrested today and charged with rape, and the family said court-ordered DNA tests apparently showed that he was the father of the baby borne by the woman two weeks ago.

title: Reopening '88 Bailout Deals
description: The Bush Administration gave regulators permission today to renegotiate savings and loan bailouts concluded in 1988. The move is intended to save taxpayers up to $4 billion.

title: Auctions
description: Gothic Revival Table

title: Power and Obligation
description: What we have felt so far is surprise at the overwhelming demonstration of American military power. We expected air superiority. Few thought it would be so one-sided, so total.

title: Alfred Levitt; Jeweler, 74
description: Alfred Levitt, a wedding jewelry maker, died on Tuesday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Neil Bush Gets Extension
description: The nation's top savings and loan regulator today granted Neil Bush, the President's son, a 10-day extension to file documents arguing that he should not be penalized for his actions as a director of a failed savings and loan association.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Government's Strict Orders Limit Reports
description: A strict information policy has been imposed by the Bush Administration on the war against Iraq, with few specific details being made e available to reporters and the public about the first day of the bombing against targets in Baghdad and Kuwait.

title: Witness Says Teacher Wanted to Buy a Gun
description: The Westchester teacher accused of killing Betty Jeanne Solomon talked to a private investigator a few months before the slaying to seek protection from a woman named "Jeanne or Betty Jeanne" who was trying to hurt her family, the investigator testified today.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Kremlin; Gorbachev's Limits Censorship on Army in Baltics Means Glasnost Is Not Public Accountability
description: "Instead of asking why there are disturbances, why the situation is getting worse in this or that republic, in this or that region, everybody is asking who is the instigator, who gave what orders," President Mikhail S. Gorbachev complained on Tuesday to the standing Soviet legislature.

title: For Children
description: My family skated on a ripply pond -- made that way by the wind blowing in from Long Island Sound -- every winter. And though ice-skating rinks in New York City may not be bumpy or ringed with weeping willows, they do offer dramatic and picturesque venues for skaters of all skills. There are indoor rinks, cool enough to require rejuvenating sips of hot chocolate. And there are outdoor rinks, open to any weather, though heavy rain often keeps even stalwart skaters home. Here is a rundown on privately owned rinks, as well as those run by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, to try out now that it's the heart of winter. All offer skate rentals, starting with size 8, which, according to one rink manager, is a child's size 6 in shoes. Most rinks suggest that only children from age 3 and up attempt the ice. But, as Chopin Berry, a park supervisor, suggested, try to pad children's knees and hands; maybe they should even wear helmets. Keep in mind, too, that holiday hours are not included here, and that many rinks are open this Monday (Martin Luther King Jr. Day), with special schedules. Sky Rink 450 West 33d Street Manhattan (212) 695-6555 or (212) 695-6556

title: Accounts
description: * Ford and Mercury Dealers Association of Canada, to Young & Rubicam Toronto, with a budget of $25 million. * World Boxing Council, Mexico City, and its medical research foundation, SPAR at U.C.L.A., to Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Co., New York, with undetermined billings. The account was previously handled in-house. * Esquire magazine, New York, a Hearst publication, to the MacDougall Co., New York, with billings of about $1 million. The account was previously handled by Welch Advertising, Garden City, L.I.

title: Gulf War Thoughts Prompt Donations to Neediest Cases
description: Eugene O. Smith recently sent a $100 check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of giving his daughter, Jessica, money to pay her fine for being arrested at a peace demonstration in December.

title: Hofstra Seeking To Move Up
description: Hofstra is seeking to reclassify its football program from Division III to I-AA, Dr. James Shuart, the university president, announced yesterday. Shuart said he would petition the National Collegiate Athletic Association for reclassification.

title: Eager to Help Russians, Germans Cut Other Aid
description: The outpouring of German emergency aid for the Soviet Union has led some Germans to reduce their contributions to groups helping the third world, relief and charity workers say.

title: Boston Journal; For Homeless Veterans, a Barracks
description: Outside a 10-story building in the heart of down town Boston, a weary-looking man squints at a sign that says "New England Shelter for Homeless Veterans" and leans his way through a revolving door. "Law and order," he sighs, moving through a metal detector to the front desk.

title: STOCKS SOAR AND OIL DROPS ON WAR NEWS Dow Jumps 114.60 Points; Tokyo Gains; Rise Resumes in Tokyo
description: Reports of an Iraqi missile attack on Israel sent financial markets gyrating here early today but did not burst the generally optimistic view investors have taken of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Delta Blues and Girl Groups In 2 New Incarnations
description: It's common practice for the music industry to package bands in order to sell them, but some young rock groups are beating the game by pre-packaging themselves. The Chickasaw Mudd Puppies and the Pussywillows, both of whom perform this weekend at CBGB, come complete with their own image, sound and esthetic. They're not just bands; they're concepts.

title: I.B.M. Surprises Wall Street With Strong Quarterly Net
description: I.B.M. surprised Wall Street analysts yesterday by reporting an usually strong fourth quarter. The hefty increase in earnings and sales for the world's largest computer maker was taken as evidence that the industry was set for a significant shakeout.

title: Metro Datelines; Witness Describes Bucket With Skull
description: A topless dancer's skull and a knife apparently used to dismember her were found in a bucket of cat litter in a Port Authority bus terminal baggage room, a detective testified yesterday.

title: When Soldiers Go to War, They Assume the Risks
description: The war in the Persian Gulf is unlikely to result in a flurry of negligence suits against the military or its contractors, because of a number of United States Supreme Court decisions over the last 40 years.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Riyadh Prepares for New Dangers After Iraqi Attack on Israel
description: The kingdom braced today for growing internal and external threats in the wake of Iraq's missile attacks on Israel and the Saudi city of Dhahran.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Air Force Base; Pilots' Wives' Comfort: Pride and One Another
description: For five long months after Lieut. Col. Howard Pope roared off to Saudia Arabia in his F-15 warplane, Phyllis Pope fought back the tears. Then, when word came Wednesday night that the 71st Tactical Fighter Squadron that Colonel Pope commands was in the air over Iraq, a crack rent the brave facade that Mrs. Pope had built up in 20 years as an Air Force wife.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Americans' Reaction; Anxious Nation, Drawn Together For Support, Exhibits a Quiet Pride
description: Sobered by the hail of missiles on Israel but proud in a subdued way about America's early military success in the Persian Gulf, men and women around the nation drew close yesterday on the first full day of war.

title: Mandela and Buthelezi Set Date to Meet
description: After months of delay and argument, South Africa's two largest black movements announced today that their leaders will meet on Jan. 29 in an effort to defuse their bitter rivalry, which has caused thousands of deaths and damaged black unity in the struggle against apartheid.

title: Contract Freeze Clouds Private Agencies' Plans
description: A group home for the recovering mentally ill is set to open in a Colonial-style house here in this Nassau County village.

title: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual
description: Some executives canceled flights, fearful of terrorism. American flags sold briskly at Woolworth's. And advertising agencies scanned commercials for messages that might seem offensive to a nation at war.

title: Big Changes for 2 Papers
description: Two national newspapers have decided to depart from their traditional publishing practices in efforts to attract readers with news about the Persian Gulf war.

title: Big Wave Of Trading At the Merc
description: By the time the trading ended on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday afternoon, officials at the world's most important energy market were glowing with pride, and sighing with relief.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Health page yesterday about health care proxies, in which people designate surrogates tomake medical decisions for them if they become incapacitated, misstated the Ohio law. Although the surrogate's powers do not take effect until death is imminent, the law does allow the surrogate to withdraw medical treatment.

title: Gjirokaster Journal; Behind Albanian Curtain: The Sad and the Seedy
description: Images pile up: ox- and donkey-drawn carts, grimy steam-powered factories, tractors and threshers dating from the 50's, towns and villages with few shops, endless lines of people waiting for exit visas, streams of laborers trudging to work or piling into rickety buses, and hardly a car on the streets but for the gleaming limousines of the ruling Communist elite.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington; BALTIC CRACKDOWN ANGERS CONGRESS
description: Voicing anger at repressive measures taken by the Soviet authorities against pro-independence forces in the Baltic republics, members of Congress called on the Bush Administration today to impose sanctions on Moscow and take other retaliatory steps.

title: Review/Art; The Reach and Grasp of Jacques Lipchitz's Sculpture
description: Jacques Lipchitz is one of the best known, though not one of the most respected, modern sculptors. The prevailing wisdom is that he had an extended shining moment during and after World War I, when he created some of the finest Cubist sculpture; but then his work became increasingly grandiose and anecdotal, particularly after he immigrated to the United States during World War II. Lipchitz may have a secure place in the history of modern sculpture, and he has been influential, but not many contemporary sculptors feel obliged to think about him.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARVIN S. TRAUB, the chairman of Bloomingdale's, received the Gold Medal award from the National Retail Federation on Wednesday in New York, in recognition of his contributions to retailing. He joined Bloomingdale's in 1950.

title: Vaughn to Enter N.F.L.
description: Jon Vaughn, the third-year redshirt sophomore who last season rushed for 1,364 yards on 216 carries, second best in the Big Ten and 11th nationally, has decided leave the Wolverines and enter the National Football League draft.

title: Parcells Denies Claim By Former Giant End
description: One day before the Giants leave for San Francisco and Sunday's championship showdown with the 49ers, Coach Bill Parcells addressed several issues at a news conference today, including the heated words from Jamie Williams that emerged on Wednesday at the 49er camp.

title: High Court Wields a Powerful Footnote
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Ed Blackwell's Drums

title: War Coverage and Commercial Limits
description: EVEN though war coverage will limit advertising on television, especially in the early days, many agency executives say the situation for advertisers will probably return to normal rapidly.

title: Let's Not Get Carried Away
description: Flush with early success in the battle with Iraq, the Bush Administration and U.S. military planners must guard against drawing conclusions or forming new objectives that, in more sober moments, would be rejected out of hand.

title: Bank Robber in Wheelchair Has an Alibi: Costly Medicine
description: A 75-year-old man in a wheelchair apologetically robbed a bank of $70 here on Tuesday so that he could buy heart medicine.

title: Gulf Oil Flows as Usual Despite Damage to Storage Tank
description: The Government said today that Persian Gulf oil flowed as usual after war broke out with Iraq, the only damage coming when Iraq destroyed a Japanese-owned storage tank in northern Saudi Arabia that held 200,000 barrels.

title: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Retailing; A Run on Flags, But No Trends
description: There was no obvious slowdown in retailing yesterday and few industry executives were willing to quantify what the effect of the war could be.

title: U.S. Clears Japanese Stake In Atomic-Arms Toolmaker
description: The White House has approved a Japanese company's purchase of 40 percent of the only American company that makes precision machine tools that satisfy the requirements of the Defense and Energy Departments for making atomic weaponry.

title: Dow Jumps 114.60 Points; Tokyo Gains
description: After a moment of silent prayer for the troops in the Persian Gulf and a short clang of the opening bell on the New York and the American Stock Exchanges, trading got off to a flying start yesterday.

title: Drug Eases Infection in Children With AIDS
description: A new study has shown that children with AIDS get fewer bacterial infections if they are treated with concentrated antibodies against bacteria, Government researchers announced today. They said the treatment could not cure the disease but could improve the quality of the children's lives.

title: Round One -- and Beyond; The Cradle, Ironically, of Civilization
description: WHATEVER the crimes of Saddam Hussein, Americans and their allies have no quarrel with his people nor any wish to devastate Iraq's cities, whether ancient or modern. Gen. Colin Powell correctly stressed his concern yesterday for sparing lives of innocent civilians and avoiding damage to irreplaceable cultural and religious sites. But this calls for determined repetition, since experience confirms that zeal can overwhelm scruple in conducting aerial attacks.

title: Jail Term in Savings Case
description: A former Texas savings and loan executive, Paul S. Cheng, was sentenced today by a Federal judge to a 30-year prison term for directing a single transaction that defrauded the institution he controlled of $7.8 million in 1986.

title: Rangers Acquire Cirella
description: The Rangers yesterday obtained the veteran defenseman Joe Cirella from the Quebec Nordiques for the defenseman Aaron Miller and a 1991 fifth-round draft choice.

title: 2 Top Movie Producers Sign Disney Accord
description: The high-profile Hollywood producing team that achieved great success with "Top Gun" but recently stumbled with "Days of Thunder" has signed to make films for the Walt Disney Company.

title: Keep in Mind
description: SING-ALONG, a family program offering folk songs, singing games and contemporary selections, led by Christine Campbell, a Caribbean-American singer. At the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, Manhattan. At 2 P.M. on Sunday. Admission: $2 for children and $3 for adults. Reservations: (212) 598-0400.

title: NEW U.S. CARDINAL MAY BE APPOINTED
description: Pope John Paul II will name at least one new American cardinal this year along with several in East European countries chosen to show support for local churches as they emerge from Communist domination, a leading Jesuit expert on Roman Catholic Church governance says.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; HUSSEIN IS DEFIANT AS RAIDS CONTINUE
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, defiant on the second day of devastating air strikes aimed at forcing his troops from Kuwait, played one of the most powerful cards in his hand by launching missile attacks against Israel.

title: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Steel; Looking for Help In Durable Goods
description: Steel industry executives said the war in the Middle East would not affect their business prospects in the near term.

title: Jabbo Smith, 82, Trumpeter, Dies; Called Rival to Louis Armstrong
description: The trumpeter Cladys (Jabbo) Smith died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: Ever a Hotel Whose Heart Is in Its Lobby
description: ARCHITECTURE is not a science. An architect simply cannot know that some chunks of oak and a few 18th-century English knockoffs will create an illusion like the one on West 44th Street: a perpetual cocktail hour, with an entire city invited.

title: BankAmerica Earnings Climbed 6.3% in Fourth Quarter
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company, reported a 6.3 percent earnings increase for the fourth quarter. In a statement, it also reiterated its interest in using its increasingly strong financial position to acquire the failed Bank of New England Corporation.

title: The First Battle
description: The first battle was won brilliantly, but hold the victory parties; the war goes on.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Salute for a Man and a Uniform
description: Last night, as I watched Gen. Colin Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, tell the press and the nation how well the forces under his control were performing, I was flooded with memories of my own military service half a century ago. General Powell is the highest-ranking black military officer in the nation's history. But back then he would have had difficulty getting a respectful salute from his white comrades-in-arms.

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: Oil Falls, Stocks Climb On Hope for Quick War The price of oil tumbled more than $10 a barrel, the biggest single-day drop in history. Oil closed at $21.44 in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, lower than its price on the day before the invasion of Kuwait.

title: Genentech Up in Quarter
description: Genentech Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 10.3 percent, but the biotechnology company reported a loss for all of 1990 primarily because of costs related to its merger with Roche.

title: Toll-Free Lines For Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special, 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf.

title: News Summary
description: War in the Gulf A8-15

title: Nets Now in Quest of a Big Scorer
description: The Nets got frontcourt help in a trade on Wednesday night and Willis Reed, the senior vice president of basketball operations, was busy on the trading market again yesterday, this time in quest of a scorer.

title: State Bond Issuer Challenges I.R.S.
description: The Louisiana Public Facilities Authority said yesterday that it was defending its assertion that about $41 million in bonds it issued in 1984 and retired in 1987 should remain tax-exempt.

title: U.S. Security Prices Stage Rally
description: The stunning successes scored by the United States and allied aircraft on the first day of the attack on Iraqt generated a powerful rally in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of some Treasury securities rose by as much as 2 3/8 points and interest rates fell sharply.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Pentagon; Excerpts From Remarks by Cheney and Powell on War Effort
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference at the Pentagon today by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Review/Film; In Old Japan, a Soldier and a Master Clash on the Way of Tea
description: Hiroshi Teshigahara's beautiful, very fine "Rikyu" reveals itself with a cherished Japanese kind of reluctance to impose on the stranger.

title: Texas Instruments Cuts 725 Workers
description: Citing the persistent weakness in the military supply business, Texas Instruments Inc. said it had laid off 725 employees. The cuts, which took place on Wednesday, ranged from production workers to managers, said Terri West, a company spokeswoman.

title: Jazz Sign O'Sullivan
description: Dan O'Sullivan, a 6-foot 10-inch center-forward from Fordham, has signed a contract for the rest of the National Basketball Association season with the Utah Jazz. After the Jazz waived Pat Cummings, the former Knick reserve frontcourt man, O'Sullivan signed a 10-day contract on Dec. 27 with the Jazz. Utah had scouted his play with the Omaha Racers of the Continental Basketball Association. He signed a second 10-day contract on Jan. 7

title: Child World Debts
description: Child World Inc., which told its vendors on Dec. 4 that it would not pay its bills for six weeks, has been holding talks with the unsecured creditors and bank lenders to propose a revised payment schedule. The company, based in Avon, Mass., operates 182 stores under the names Child World and Children's Palace. It is the second-largest toy chain in the country after Toys "R" Us.

title: Killer of 2 Draws 20 Years
description: A man who killed two people and seriously wounded a third during a shooting spree on a busy street last year was sentenced today to 20 years to life in prison. The defendant, Michael Giles, 34 years old, of Syracuse, apologized for his crime, saying he had tried to get help for psychiatric problems but never had received the help he needed. He pleaded guilty Jan. 3 to two counts of second-degree murder.

title: Corrections
description: A TV Critic's Notebook in some editions yesterday, about coverage of the war in the Persian Gulf, misidentified the White House correspondent for NBC News. He is Jim Miklaszewski.

title: Rauschenberg Recalls Warhol as the Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Pilots; Allied Fliers Jubilantly Tell of Early Control of the Skies as Iraq Planes Fled
description: Hours after their bombing runs reduced Iraqi targets to rubble and flame, American fighter pilots returned to bases here today and jubilantly described how Iraqi fliers had offered little resistance, with some Iraqi combat jets even scrambling far to the north to avoid combat.

title: Mullins Back at School
description: Chucky Mullins, the former University of Mississippi football player who was paralyzed by a neck injury in a game against Vanderbilt on Oct. 28, 1989, is rebuilding his life. He has re-entered the university at Oxford, Miss., and begun classwork with the goal of attaining a college degree.

title: ANOTHER QUESTION IN A COSMIC RIDDLE
description: In the first announced results of an astronomy mission flown by a space shuttle in December, scientists have found strong evidence disputing one more idea advanced to help solve the riddle of the missing mass of the universe.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Around the World; Soviets Wanted U.S. Delay But Plea to Iraq Was Late; Coalition's Allies Are Firm
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today blamed Iraqi intransigence for the war in the Persian Gulf, but only after trying to get President Bush to put off the attack long enough to give him a chance to talk President Saddam Hussein into withdrawing peacefully from Kuwait.

title: Cheap Oil May Not Be Enough to Cure Recession
description: A free fall in the price of crude oil for February delivery, which plunged more than $10, to $21.44 a barrel yesterday, may have raised hopes for a rapid recovery in the nation's slumping economy. But even if a quick, successful end to the military campaign against Iraq pushes oil prices well below $15 a barrel by midsummer, as some oil analysts predict, daunting obstacles to economic growth will remain.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an excerpt in some copies yesterday from reports by Cable News Network correspondents in Baghdad misattributed some remarks. Paragraphs 1, 3 and 6 should have been attributed to Peter Arnett; paragraphs 2, 5 and 7 should have been attributed to John Holliman; paragraph 4 should have been attributed to Bernard Shaw.

title: School Bus Crash Kills Girl
description: A school bus collided with a tractor-trailer rig near this southern Oklahoma town today, killing a child and injuring 16 other people, the authorities said. A 7-year-old girl, Lacey Hull, died of head injuries, the authorities said. Another girl was in critical condition, and two people were in good condition.

title: Of the Palate, From the Palette
description: "ART WHAT THOU EAT," a display of 19th- and 20th-century American paintings and sculpture at the New-York Historical Society through March 22, makes a good case for developing an eating disorder. Eating too much -- or not eating at all -- is one of the few ways that individuals can still exert some control over the corporate takeover of American food supplies that is depicted here.

title: Oil Prices Fall Over $10 To $21.44
description: The price of crude oil dropped by a third on Wednesday night and yesterday as traders reacted to the air strike against Iraq. The price dropped by more than $10 a barrel, to $21.44, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, by far the biggest single-day drop in history. The price at the close yesterday was 40 cents lower than on Aug. 1, the day before the invasion of Kuwait.

title: Miami of Ohio Banned
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday put Miami of Ohio University on two years' probation because of violations by the former men's basketball coach, Jerry Peirson, but said Miami's cooperation in the investigation spared it from more severe penalties.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Military; U.S. Says Early Air Attack Caught Iraq Off Guard
description: Iraq's air defense command was caught off guard at the outset of the Persian Gulf war by a combination of tactical surprise and nighttime stealth air attacks in which unmanned cruise missiles were used to protect allied pilots, military officials and analysts said today.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Pistons Win 11th in a Row Joe Dumars made six foul shots in the last 1 minute 27 seconds of overtime last night, leading Detroit past the Houston Rockets, 97-91, and extending the Pistons' streak to a season-high 11 consecutive victories. Vinnie Johnson led Detroit with 18 points and Dennis Rodman had 16 points and 18 rebounds. The Pistons tied the score at 82 and again at 84 after two free throws by James Edwards with 32 seconds left. Johnson missed a 23-foot jumper at the buzzer that would have given the Pistons a victory in regulation. (AP) N.H.L. Neely Leads Bruins Over Kings Cam Neely scored his seventh career hat trick last night to power Boston over Los Angeles, 5-3, in the Boston Garden. Neely, who sat out a game Tuesday night because of a knee injury, tied the score, 2-2, with his 26th goal early in the second period and broke a 3-3 tie late in the period with a power-play goal. The Kings pulled their goaltender, Daniel Berthiaume, for a sixth skater in the third, and Neely clinched Boston's third consecutive victory by scoring his 28th goal into an empty net at 18 minutes 58 seconds. It was the Kings' second loss in a row after a seven-game winning streak. (AP) Canadiens 4, Blues 2: Mike McPhee and Russ Courtnall each had two goals and an assist as Montreal ended St. Louis's unbeaten streak at five games. The Canadiens also averted a first-ever season sweep by the Blues, who held the Canadiens to one goal in winning the first two games of the series. (AP) Flyers 5, Nordiques 1: Ron Hextall made 25 saves and Rick Tocchet scored his 31st goal, tying him for the second-best total in the league. The victory was Philadelphia's second in succession at the Spectrum after a seven-game slump at home and left the Flyers unbeaten in their last eight home games against Quebec. (AP) North Stars 5, Capitals 2: Brian Hayward made 34 saves as Minnesota snapped a losing streak at three games. The North Stars, 2-7-2 in their last 11 games, were outshot by 36-20. The loss was Washington's third in a row. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Arizona Edges Arizona St. Chris Mills scored 19 points last night as the Wildcats defeated its archrival for the ninth consecutive time, 74-71, in a Pac-10 game. Brian Williams added 17 points and Matt Othick and Ed Stokes had 11 each for the Wildcats (14-2 over all, 4-1 in the Pac-10). Arizona State (11-4, 2-3) was led by the freshman Jamal Faulkner with 18 points. (AP) Wisconsin 91, Iowa 79: Tim Locum scored 25 points and John Ellenson added a career-high 21 for the Badgers in a Big Ten game. The Badgers (8-6 over all, 2-2 in the Big Ten), made 11 3-point shots, have beaten the Hawkeyes four successive times. Iowa (13-4, 2-3) has lost 14 consecutive road conference games. (AP) AUTO RALLY Finn Wins Paris-Dakar Rally Ari Vatanen of Finland, driving a Citroen, wrapped up his fourth Paris-Dakar Rally championship yesterday, completing a dominating performance in the 5,709-mile event. The rally started Dec. 29 from Vincennes, near Paris, with more than 400 drivers. Only about 180 competitors were able to complete the trek to Dakar, Senegal, across the desert of five African countries. Vatanen kept his Citroen ZX in a comfortable lead most of the way. He led by as much as four hours and wound up beating the Mitsubishi of Pierre Lartigue of France by 2 hours 42 minutes 27 seconds. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a tribute to the photographer Gordon Parks misstated the date of the event in some copies. It is tonight at 7:30 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine; it was not last night.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Domino's Pizza Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., has received an exclusive contract from the Marine Corps to open pizzerias on five bases. Terms were not disclosed. * Eastchester Financial Corp., White Plains, said its shareholders had approved the merger of its wholly owned unit, Eastchester Savings Bank, with Southold Savings Bank, a subsidiary of North Fork Bancorporation Inc., Mattituck, L.I. Eastchester shareholders will receive $15.50 a share. * First Florida Banks Inc., Tampa, Fla., and Mid-State Federal Savings Bank, Ocala, Fla., said the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta had urged First Florida to withdraw its application to acquire Mid-State. * GE Capital Retailer Financial Services, a unit of General Electric Co., has acquired the retail credit-card portfolio of American TV and Appliance of Madison Inc., Madison, Wis., a consumer appliance retailer. GE Capital will provide a $150 million credit line for buying and financing the portfolio. * Ogden Corp., New York, a waste recovery company, and ERC Environmental and Energy Services Co., Fairfax, Va., an environmental services company, said their boards had approved a merger agreement. Ogden will acquire ERC shares for $15.13 each. * One Liberty Properties Inc., New York, a real estate investment trust, completed the sale of its 40 Firestone retail locations for $26.3 million. * Tuscarora Plastics Inc., New Brighton, Pa., a plastics maker, said it would buy the business and related machinery and equipment of Precision Post Inc., Marion, Ohio, a maker of interior protective packaging products. Terms were not disclosed. * Xerox Corp., Stamford, Conn., will buy 30 percent of Image Sciences Inc., Dallas, a maker of electronic publishing software. No terms were disclosed. * Zytron, Menlo Park, Calif., a microfilm publishing service, and Endata Inc., Nashville, a microfilm company, have merged. The new name is First Image Management Co., a unit of First Financial Management Corp.

title: At the Movies
description: Alaska's Tricks

title: Key Rates
SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Latvia; A GORBACHEV CALL LIFTS LATVIA HOPE
description: As violent harassment apparently inspired by Moscow continued, a phone call from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev raised hopes today that a brutal crackdown by Moscow here might be avoided.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD BRANSON and PER LINDSTRAND became the first men to cross the Pacific in a hot-air balloon when they landed yesterday 150 miles west of Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories of Canada. They had lifted off from Miyakonojo, Japan, less than two days earlier.

title: A Sharp Drop in Dollar Counters Expectations
description: The dollar fell sharply yesterday, confounding the expectations of many analysts who thought the United States currency would be a safe harbor in a time of war.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Advice; Medicine for a Child's Fears
description: Child and school psychologists say the best way to deal with a child's fears about war is to face the worries head on.

title: Bill to Cut Florio's Aid To Schools Is Gaining
description: A Senate bill to alter Gov. Jim Florio's tax and school-aid program by taking $450 million in school aid, much of it for poorer districts, and using it for property-tax relief is gaining momentum here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: REACTING TO WAR

title: I.B.M. Laboratory Opens in Florida
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has opened a $38 million research and development laboratory here intended to introduce products more quickly into the fast-growing personal computer market. "We are blurring the lines between software and hardware and trying to build teamwork," the lab's director, Paul Mugge, said.

title: Round One -- and Beyond; The Suspense, at Least, Is Over
description: RELIEF. The word recurred everywhere Wednesday night and all yesterday. Relief that only one American pilot had been killed in the first day of hostilities. Relief that Iraq put up so little initial resistance. Relief, finally, that the long-frozen moment had ended. The nation had lived with it, after all, for months. Despite the best efforts of peacemakers, the prospect of war has hung in view clear as a desert moon.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Thanks to RICHARD FEIGEN and YVES SAINT LAURENT , Manhattan has two newly beautified structures, one an historic landmark and the other a brand-new storefront. Last week, Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts gave Mr. Feigen, the art dealer, and Mr. Saint Laurent, the couturier, awards for their efforts.

title: People
description: * Felicia Ferber, Catherine Basile, Linda Greene, Paul Mavis and Nick Provenzana have been promoted to vice president at Geer, DuBois Advertising, New York. * Larry Dobrow has resigned as manager of corporate communications at Bozell, New York.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Optional. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular garbage pickups and recycling. No street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Open. Transportation: Buses, subways, L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on regular schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. Some modified bus schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed Post offices: Express mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on regular schedule.

title: Reviews/Art; Chuck Close Browses and Assembles an Exhibition
description: Chuck Close proves that the simplest ideas can sometimes be the cleverest. Mr. Close is the third artist (after Scott Burton and Ellsworth Kelly) to participate in "Artist's Choice," the Museum of Modern Art's version of the "Artist's Eye" series begun some years ago at the National Gallery in London, for which artists organize small shows based on works belonging to the museum.

title: Why Fifth Avenue Is in Every Way No Place for Newsstands
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspension by Coach Leaves Southern Cal's Marinovich Confused
description: Todd Marinovich never dreamed that Larry Smith, the coach of the University of Southern California football team, would suspend him, according to a source close to the Trojan quarterback.

title: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Real Estate; A Way to Cure Buyer Paralysis
description: Real estate executives, analysts and builders were relieved but cautious yesterday about what theinitial phase of the Persian Gulf conflict meant for their troubled industry.

title: N.F.L. PLAYOFFS: The Conference Championships; Lofton Brings Healing Touch
description: As the events in the Persian Gulf developed Wednesday night, and Carlton Bailey, a linebacker for the Buffalo Bills, became concerned about his father, a chief warrant officer in the naval reserve stationed there, one of the two telephone calls Bailey received from a teammate came from James Lofton.

title: Review/Film; Technology Is the Star Of 'Intruder'
description: John Milius's "Flight of the Intruder," about United States Navy pilots during the Vietnam War, works less well as an adventure movie than as a slick piece of bogus hardware.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: War's Opening Night

title: Olav V, Norway's King 33 Years And Resistance Hero, Dies at 87
description: King Olav V of Norway, who as Crown Prince was a national symbol of resistance to Nazi Germany's occupation of his country in World War II, died yesterday after a heart attack, the Palace announced. He was 87 years old.

title: Review/Art; Revisiting the 70's in Brice Marden's 'Grove Group'
description: The exhibition of Brice Marden's five "Grove Group" paintings and eight related drawings at the Gagosian Gallery on Madison Avenue is a trip down memory lane. The time is the mid-1970's, Minimalism is king and painting is considered pretty much finished. If it isn't finished, it is supposed to be resolutely abstract and literal, devoid of references to things beyond itself. Frank Stella's famous dictum for 60's painting -- "What you see is what you see" -- was still very much in force.

title: More Cells for More Prisoners, but to What End?
description: At a time when the hard-pressed Federal and state governments are desperately trying to reduce most of the services they provide, they continue to build prisons as fast as possible. America's taxpayers are financing several billion dollars in new prisons every year -- and still there are not enough cells for the flood of prisoners, many of them with special mental, medical and educational problems.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Dr. Richard B. Nolan, a surgeon, omitted a survivor. She is his wife, Olga.

title: Jackson Out, So Raiders Will Rely on Allen, Bell
description: Art Shell made his pronouncement just before noon today, as the Los Angeles Raiders were taking a lunch break at their training complex here.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Dhahran; HOTEL GUESTS HELD IN BOMB SHELTER
description: Hundreds of guests at a luxury hotel in eastern Saudi Arabia were moved to a bomb shelter before dawn today and, during several anxious minutes, were told to put on the bulky charcoal-lined uniforms intended to protect against chemical and biological weapons.

title: Review/Film; Harshness of Soviet Life In Lungin's 'Taxi Blues'
description: From its first nighttime shot of a boisterous, glittering Moscow, Pavel Lungin's superb tragicomedy "Taxi Blues" presents a Soviet Union that is new to the screen. Even without the rollicking byplay that temporarily unites the film's two central characters, a debauched Jewish musician and a bitter, tormented, vaguely anti-Semitic cabby, "Taxi Blues" would be a haunting travelogue filled with raw, pitiless glimpses of a troubled society.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Travel; Disruptions For Subways And Airports
description: More than 60,000 rush-hour subway riders were delayed for more than an hour last night because of suspicious packages that forced officials to turn off the power on the East Side IRT local and four heavily traveled IND lines in Queens.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We went in there and did exactly what we wanted to do." -- Col. John McBroom, describing a bombing run over Iraq. [ A10:1. ]

title: Intel Earnings Climb by 34%
description: The Intel Corporation today reported record revenues and earnings, as personal computer buyers stepped up their purchases of machines using Intel's most powerful chips.

title: Taylor Rises in Class, but Still Wants Chavez
description: Last March, Meldrick Taylor was on the verge of beating the fighter considered by many to be pound for pound the best in boxing, Julio Cesar Chavez, the undefeated World Boxing Council junior-welterweight champion.

title: Strife Empties South African Village
description: This village in the rolling Marico hills near Botswana seems a picture postcard of bucolic tranquillity, with shade trees to ward off the sun, green pastures for livestock and comfortable concrete houses built with the remittances of migrant workers employed elsewhere in South Africa.

title: Round One -- and Beyond; In the Wake of Iraq's Missiles
description: ANOTHER evening, another shock -- but this time full of anxiety for innocent Israelis and full of fear for the world that Saddam Hussein's missiles against Tel Aviv might torpedo the alliance opposing him in Kuwait. Despite the remarkable success of the air war against Iraq, it didn't take long for reality to ratify Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's caution yesterday that the larger war is unlikely to proceed with such ease, and could last for "a significant period."

title: Review/Film; Rebuilding A Life
description: Dyan Cannon's "End of Innocence" is the latest entry in what threatens to become a full-blown movie subgenre: the rehab film. The first full-length feature to have been written and directed by Ms. Cannon, who also stars, it tells the story of Stephanie Lewis, an emotionally besieged woman who staves off her anger by popping pills and smoking pot. One evening, after her faithless boyfriend fails to show up as planned, she snaps, runs off hysterically into the rainy night and eventually ends up at a rehabilitation center.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Lithuania; Soviets Insist They Won't Use Force to Unseat Lithuanians
description: Representatives of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet military told Lithuanian leaders at the heavily fortified Parliament today that they would not attempt to overthrow the elected, independence-minded government of President Vytautas Landsbergis by force.

title: Surge in World Markets Takes Many by Surprise
description: After days of worry about how far the world's stock markets might drop at the start of a war, markets rose strongly yesterday around the world, beginning in Tokyo and continuing through Asia to Europe and the United States.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Some Arabs Greet Fighting, But Deeper Divide Is Feared
description: On the first day of the war in the Persian Gulf, but before Iraqi missiles landed in Israel early this morning, the Arab world responded with mixed exuberance, relief and sorrow.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Rogers & Barbero

title: Big Board Chief Urges Caution
description: William H. Donaldson, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that despite a rally for the Dow Jones industrial average of more than 114 points, he would advise investors not to make any quick investment decisions.

title: Prime Gives President Additional Job as Chief
description: In a move that appeared to show that the recovery efforts of Prime Computer Inc. were on track, the company carried out a planned change in top management yesterday.

title: At the Bar; Bashing the bar, a treasured and still thriving tradition that dates from the Bard.
description: "The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers."

title: The Anti-War Movement, This Time
description: As the country plunges into its riskiest military adventure since Vietnam, many observers are seeing flashbacks to the 1960's as newsrooms across America search out the signs of renewed popular protest.

title: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Aerospace; No Rush Soon To Reorder Arms
description: A short war with Iraq would not have any direct mpact on aerospace companies and other military contractors, analysts and industry executives said. The war is being fought with existing inventories of weapons systems and other hardware, and contractors generally do not expect immediate new orders to replace arms expended or lost in the conflict.

title: A $150 Million Loan Buys Philadelphia Some Time
description: City officials have finally obtained a $150 million loan, or enough currency to relieve a sort of Russian winter that has settled over city government, complete with lines of creditors, a weekly specter of payless paydays for municipal employees and erratic shortages of everything from fax paper to pants for new police recruits.

title: Trump Casino Hires a Rival
description: In a move to bolster the performance of his weakest casino here, Donald J. Trump hired the top executive of a rival casino, executives in the Trump Organization said today.

title: Review/Film; She Just Wanted to Be Married
description: "Once Around" asks this question: Should the father of a naive, sheltered, not very self-sufficient young woman be disturbed if she takes up with a noisy, ostentatious older man who has made far too much money hustling time-share condominiums in the tropics and whose idea of enlivening a family gathering is hiring a belly dancer? It would be a much better film than it is if it had an answer.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Amnesty International, London, to Ahern & Heussner Advertising, New York.

title: Caution Signs Lure Aliens to Road Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Kelly Signs With the Yankees And Avoids Arbitration Hearing
description: The Yankees shaved one name from their salary arbitration list yesterday, reaching agreement with Roberto Kelly, their center fielder, on a $900,000 salary.

title: Restaurants
description: If you listen to some restaurant-industry pundits, La Grenouille is just the type of expensive, opulent institution that is slated for extinction as ineluctably as the dinosaurs. In this era of austerity and a return to more ingenuous foods, they say, the dining public is turning away from haute cuisine and embracing little pizzas, pasta, coq au vin and grilled chicken.

title: Search for Miners Halted
description: High levels of explosive methane gas forced rescue workers today to suspend a search for two coal miners believed killed in an explosion deep inside a mine Wednesday. The search, at the Firecreek No. 1 mine near this town in southern West Virginia, was halted at 3 A.M., about 18 hours after the mine had been evacuated. The miners were reported missing after five other miners smelled smoke and left the mine Wednesday morning.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Blackhawks Outmuscle Rangers
description: The night began with the Rangers half a dozen points behind the Chicago Blackhawks in the race for the distinction as the top team in the National Hockey League. It ended with the gap at 8 points and the sobering sense at Madison Square Garden that the statistics were an inadequate measure of what separates the two contenders.

title: Montana Is Center Of Attention For 49ers
description: The San Francisco 49ers are making their ninth playoff appearance. They have already won eight divisional championships, five of them consecutively. They have won four National Conference championships and against the Giants on Sunday in Candlestick Park they will be seeking their third straight one. They are on course for three straight Super Bowl titles, something no team has accomplished.

title: Review/Circus; Frisky People and Bears
description: At the Moscow Circus, the Cranes soar high above the stage. With split-second synchronization, these aerialists twist, turn, do multiple somersaults and fall headlong in space before being caught by the outstretched arms of their partners. Repeatedly, the Cranes defy gravity. At one point, a Crane leaps upward as if jet propelled, moving from a trapeze to the utmost heights of Radio City Music Hall, where a catcher is waiting.

title: Metro Datelines; Holtzman Rebuked Over 1987 Incident
description: New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman has been privately reprimanded by a court agency that monitors lawyers' ethics over an incident in which she criticized a judge while she was Brooklyn District Attorney.

title: In Rehearsal: Broadway At Cut Prices
description: A $24 top ticket price for a Broadway play? It's finally happening.

title: I.B.M. Surprises Wall Street With Strong Quarterly Net; Apple Posts 20.6% Rise
description: Buoyed by strong sales of three new Macintosh models, Apple Computer Inc. reported increased sales and earnings for its first quarter, which ended Dec. 28. With demand exceeding supply of the Macintosh Classic, a new low-priced computer, Apple's results could have been stronger yet.

title: Critic's Choice
description: To his great credit, James Levine acts like a music director of olden times. He stays based in New York for months every year, resisting the many temptations placed before him to gad about the globe. And he doesn't just work at the Metropolitan Opera, where he remains artistic director in every sense of the term.

title:
Chinatown Housing;
Condo Project to Pay for a New Church
description: A lot in Manhattan's Chinatown formerly occupied by three tenements housing the Episcopal Church of Our Savior is being redeveloped with a $7.25 million church complex and a 12-story, 32-unit residential condominium.

title: Woman Is Arrested in a Series of Killings in Florida
description: The police said today that they had arrested a woman believed to be the killer who in the last year has slain as many as seven middle-age male motorists whose bodies were found alongside highways in north and central Florida.

title: With a Premiere
description: JoAnn Rice is to lead the Florilegium Chamber Choir in the world premiere of Kim Rich's "Daniel and the Lion" at 3 P.M. tomorrow at the German Church, 315 West 22d Street. The program also includes choruses from Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus." Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 691-4568.

title: High Court to Decide Issue On Election of State Judges
description: Acting in cases that could affect the makeup of state courts throughout the South, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether an important section of the Voting Rights Act applies to judicial elections.

title: Hull Out as All-Star
description: When the National Hockey League holds its All-Star Game in Chicago this afternoon, it will be without Brett Hull, the league's top goal-scorer and top vote-getter in the fan balloting. The St. Louis Blues wing withdrew because of a sprained left ankle, incurred in a game last Tuesday.

title: Pro Basketball; Nets Hold Off Celtics' Rally And End 11-Game Slump
description: It looked like an instant replay of numerous other games the Celtics have played at Boston Garden. Whether in grainy black and white or vivid color, the result was usually the same, with Boston coming back to slay an opponent late in the contest.

title: Toll-Free Lines For Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special, 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf.

title: 3 East Europe Leaders Delay Talks on Soviets
description: The leaders of Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have postponed their meeting scheduled for Monday, when they were to discuss possible sanctions against the Soviet Union over the crackdown in Lithuania. Polish officials said they were reluctant to irritate Moscow when the attention of the world was focused on the Persian Gulf.

title: Gorbachev Draws Ex-Backers' Rage
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's crackdown on separatism in the Baltic states has kindled long-smouldering discontent into a blaze of censure by Soviet journalists, intellectuals, and reform-minded bureaucrats who once were his main supporters.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday about the Tomahawk cruise missile misstated its diameter. It is 20.9 inches.

title: Fire-Vulnerable Spots Are Found in Subways
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that its engineers had discovered four more spots in a Brooklyn subway tunnel vulnerable to the kind of short circuit that started a fire that killed two riders last month.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DERRICK A. BELL JR. has been named Feminist of the Year by the Feminist Majority Foundation, a nonprofit women's rights organization in Arlington, Va. Plaques are in the mail for the award winners: 11 individuals and 2 groups.

title: Chad Walsh, Teacher and Writer of Poetry and Prose
description: Chad Walsh, a longtime English professor, poet and writer, died on Jan. 17 at The Arbors, a nursing home in Shelburne, Vt. He was 76 years old and lived in South Burlington, Vt.

title: Article 775891 -- No Title
description: The Bush Administration will ask Congress for an additional $80 billion to bail out 225 more savings and loans associations this year, or 10 percent of the industry, officials said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Weapons; Incoming Iraqi Missile Destroyed Over Saudi Base
description: In its maiden flight of destruction, the American-made Patriot missile won the gratitude of thousands of soldiers and civilians this morning as it blew an Iraqi Scud missile out of the sky over one of Saudi Arabia's largest air bases.

title: Selma Tamber, 84, Broadway Producer
