description: Selma Tamber Eisenman, a Broadway producer and manager, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In her current film, "Not Without My Daughter," SALLY FIELD plays the wife of a doctor of Iranian descent who is held as a hostage on a trip with him to Iran. Now she has hired a bodyguard after receiving threats that apparently were inspired by her role in the film.

title: Latin Redux in Our Schools? A Risible Notion
description: To the Editor:

title: Parents Sue Alabama Over School Financing
description: Alabama education officials were sued yesterday by parents who charge that the school finance system is unconstitutional because it distributes an inadequate amount of state money to public schools and does so inequitably.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holdiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Optional. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular garbage pickups and recycling. No street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses, subways, L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on regular schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. Some modified bus schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on regular schedule.

title: 2 Years Late, Joint Venture In Music Goes to Moscow
description: Sarah Caldwell is often late, but she is persistent. Two years behind schedule, the second leg of Making Music Together is arriving in the Soviet Union next week. This American-Soviet performing-arts venture, of which she is artistic director, threatens to be as rich and chaotic as were its beginnings in Boston during the spring of 1988.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Suns End Pistons' Streak Phoenix held Detroit scoreless for the final 3 minutes 5 seconds last night as the Suns scored a 103-102 victory, ending the Pistons' streak of 11 consecutive victories. Tom Chambers and Kevin Johnson scored 27 points each for the Suns, who won their sixth consecutive game and beat Detroit for the first time since Jan. 26, 1987. Joe Dumars, playing despite a hyperextended toe, led the Pistons with 23 points while Mark Aguirre had 19 and Vinnie Johnson 18 points and 11 assists. Detroit played without Isiah Thomas, who sat out the game with a pulled left groin and strained right shoulder. (AP) Warriors 141, Sixers 138: Tim Hardaway scored a career-high 40 points and Mitch Richmond added 35 as Golden State defeated Philadelphia in overtime at the Spectrum. Chris Mullin scored 29 points, 8 in overtime, for the Warriors, who won their fourth successive road game in gaining their fifth victory in six games. Hardaway, who had a career-high 37 points in the Warriors' victory over Boston on Wednesday night, has scored 112 points in his last three games. He also had 14 assists last night. Hersey Hawkins had 30 points for Philadelphia. Golden State, trailing by 92-86 in the third period, used a 19-2 run, with Rod Higgins scoring 8, to take a 105-94 lead with 11 minutes 52 seconds to play. Philadelphia rallied to cut the deficit to 117-115 on a 3-point play by Hawkins with four minutes remaining. The 76ers trailed by 127-123 with 1:01 to go, but Kenny Payne hit two successive jumpers, the last with 11 seconds remaining, to send the game into overtime. The 76ers were playing their second game without their leading scorer, Charles Barkley, who is suffering from an injury to his right ankle. (AP) Hawks 114, Bulls 105: Atlanta, playing at home, ended the Bulls' streak of seven consecutive victories. Dominique Wilkins scored 17 of his 34 points in the third period for the Hawks. Sidney Moncrief added a season-high 16 points, 11 in the final period, for the Hawks, who won their 12th consecutive game at home. Michael Jordan had 30 points for the Bulls, who lost for only the third time in 18 games. The Hawks overcame an early 11-point deficit for their 18th victory in 23 games, trailing, 43-32, with 7:42 left before halftime. (AP) Hornets 117, Spurs 110: Rex Chapman had 35 points and Johnny Newman scored 11 of his 30 in the final 3 minutes 36 seconds as Charlotte won for just the fourth time in 17 games on the road. Mike Gminski added 25 points for the Hornets, who shot a franchise record 60 percent from the field. San Antonio, which lost twice in 15 previous home games, was led by David Robinson with 26 points. (AP) Clippers 119, Mavericks 112: Danny Manning scored 8 of his 25 points in overtime to power Los Angeles. Manning gave the Clippers the lead for good at 105-103 with a turnaround jumper 53 seconds into overtime. (AP) Bucks 125, Magic 106: Ricky Pierce scored 25 points for Milwaukee, which is 20-1 at home. Terry Catledge led the Magic with 21 points, but missed 7 of 12 free throws. (AP) Jazz 106, Cavaliers 99: John Stockton atoned for a turnover late in regulation by scoring 5 points in overtime as Utah won in Richfield, Ohio. The victory was the ninth in 11 games for the Jazz. The Cavaliers lost for the 12th time in 13 games. Stockton, who had 27 points and 19 assists, traveled with 46 seconds left in the fourth quarter, giving Cleveland the ball while Utah was leading, 95-93. Cleveland's Gerald Paddio missed badly on a jump shot, but Brad Daugherty put the ball back in to tie the score with 25.2 seconds left. Utah was unable to score on its final possession of the quarter. (AP) GOLF McGuire Takes Lead by One Shot Sarah McGuire shot a four-under-par 67 for a one-stroke lead as the season-opening Ladies Professional Golf Association Jamaica Classic tournament began yesterday at the Tryall Golf and Country Club in Montego Bay. But Kathy Postlewait stole the show, shooting a hole-in-one on the par-3 sixth. The eagle was the first hole-in-one in the three-year-old tournament and only the second ever struck on the course. The first time was in 1983, by Nancy Lopez in the Mazda Champions tournament. McGuire started quietly by parring the first four holes. She birdied the fifth, sixth and seventh holes to finish the front nine at three-under 31. She bogeyed the 13th before coming up with birdies on the 14th and 15th for a one-under 36 on the back nine. At second after the first 18 holes of the 54-hole tournament was the defending champion, Patty Sheehan, who shot a 68. Jill Briles-Hinton was with Postlewait at 70. (AP) SKIING Kronberger Notches 7th Victory Skiing down the tough 1992 Olympic course, Petra Kronberger of Austria won the women's World Cup downhill race yesterday in Meribel, France, and increased her lead in the overall standing. The victory was Kronberger's second in the downhill this season and her seventh of the current tour. She also won the last World Cup race, a slalom last weekend in Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia. Kronberger covered the 9,042-foot course in 1 minute 57.59 seconds. Carole Merle of France was second in 1:58.37. Veronika Wallinger of Austria was third in 1:59.02. Kronberger has 251 points for the season, 170 more than Katrin Gutensohn of Germany, who finished fourth in the downhill race. (AP)

title: Iraqi Wanted in U.S. For 18 Years Is Seized
description: An Iraqi man wanted for the attempted bombing in March 1973 of two Israeli banks in New York City has been arrested in Rome, and the Federal authorities are seeking to have him extradited to the United States to stand trial, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Newark Faces Tax Increase; Mayor Tries to Avert Layoffs
description: This city faces higher property taxes to make up for a $50 million budget shortfall, Mayor Sharpe James said on Thursday, but he promised to try to avoid layoffs of city employees and to try to increase the police force.

title: Stuart Sebastian, Choreographer, 40
description: Stuart Sebastian, former resident choreographer and artistic director of the Dayton Ballet in Ohio, died on Wednesday at the Hospice of Dayton. He was 40 years old.

title: Youth Pleads Guilty in Friends' Drownings
description: A Niagara Falls youth pleaded guilty today to two counts of criminally negligent homicide for causing the death of two friends who drowned after he pushed them off a rock in the Niagara River.

title: Coping; With Snow and Ice Removal
description: Removing snow and ice from walks and driveways is a matter of safety and common sense, and in many communities, it's required by law.

title: Review/Jazz; Scat Singing, Ballads And Jazz
description: Judy Niemack's career as a singer has drawn on two relatively disparate jazz sources during the past dozen years. She knows the jazz singing styles of the 1920's as exemplified by the Boswell Sisters, styles that she sings as a member of a trio called the Jazz Babies. And she also knows, performs and teaches the scat singing styles that developed out of be-bop.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Iraq Fires New Missle Attack at Israel; Allies Continue Bombing; Seek Launchers
description: Iraq launched a second missile attack against Tel Aviv this morning, military officials said. The Israeli authorities said the missiles carried conventional explosives, like the missiles that hit Tel Aviv and Haifa early Friday.

title: Mozart Opener Without Mehta
description: Zubin Mehta, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, has canceled his performances with the orchestra for the opening concert of the Lincoln Center Mozart Bicentennial and for the orchestra's subscription concerts. Mr. Mehta flew to Israel on Tuesday and it is not known when he will return to New York.

title: Nissan Plans New Factory For Engines in Tennessee
description: The Nissan Motor Company said today that it planned to build a second plant in the United States that would make automobile engines, enabling the company to increase the domestic content of its American-assembled cars.

title: U.S. Admits Payments to Noriega
description: The Federal Government said today that the Central Intelligence Agency and the Army had paid Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega $322,000 in cash and gifts during his relationship of more than 31 years with the United States.

title: Milken and S.&L. Executives Sued
description: Federal banking regulators yesterday filed a $6 billion suit yesterday against Michael R. Milken and a number of well-known former executives with savings and loans contending that they had participated in a fraudulent scheme that led to huge losses at the institutions from their "junk bond" investments.

title: End of Ocean Dumping of Sludge Offers Long-Range Benefits
description: To the Editor

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: Dow Rises; Week's Gain Sets Record
description: As the Persian Gulf war grew more complex, one of the most hectic weeks in Wall Street history ended yesterday with a last-minute flurry that carried the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 23.27 points.

title: Panel Turns Down Plan For Korean War Shrine
description: The Commission of Fine Arts sent the design team for the Korean War Veterans Memorial back to the drawing board on Thursday.

title: Superstar At Home in 'Super' City
description: Like any country kid who gets giddy when the circus comes to town, Dwight Gooden has it all mapped out next Sunday when the big show comes to his town.

title: Guidepost; Pick a Card. Any Card?
description: Most interest rates are declining, but three-quarters of all credit-card holders will not reap the benefit. The reason: their interest rates are fixed and rarely change. To find lower rates, they must shop around. The remaining quarter of all credit cards offer variable interest rates, usually tied to the prime rate. Last year the average cost of financing purchases on a standard fixed-rate Visa card or Mastercard was 18.86 percent. The Bank Rate Monitor, an industry weekly, says these three banks offer the best deals on credit cards in the country, taking into account interest rates, annual fees and grace periods before interest charges are added. Bank Annual rate Annual fee Grace period on purchase People's Bank, 13.9% $25 25 days Bridgeport, Conn. (800) 423-3273 Amalgamated Trust and Savings, Chicago (800) 365-6464 16.0% (variable 0 25 days rate) Penn Security Bank, 14.8% 10 None Scranton, Pa. (800) 327-0394

title: N.F.L. Playoffs: The Conference Championships; Simms on Giants' Sideline For Remainder of Playoffs
description: Phil Simms's football season is over. Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants confirmed tonight that Simms, normally his starting quarterback, must wear a cast on his right foot for two more weeks. That ruled out any chance for Simms to play in Super Bowl XXV on Jan. 27 in Tampa, Fla.

title: Alcoa Posts $140.4 Million Quarterly Loss
description: The Aluminum Company of America, stung by lower aluminum prices and $275 million in reductions to after-tax income, yesterday reported a $140.4 million loss for the fourth quarter. The company had net income of $164.7 million, or $1.88 a share, in the quarter in 1989.

title: David Carpenter, 41, Figure in 80's Fraud
description: David J. Carpenter, a defendant in a securities-fraud case in the mid-1980's that resulted in the jailing of a Wall Street Journal reporter for insider trading, died on Thursday at Bess Kaiser Hospital in Portland, Ore. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giacomo Manzu Is Dead at 82; Prolific Sculptor of Varied Images
description: Giacomo Manzu, one of Italy's leading sculptors, died on Thursday at his hilltop home at Ardea, just south of Rome. He was 82 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; U.S. IS SAID TO USE TURKISH AIR BASES
description: Using Turkish bases to open a second front in the air war against Iraq, United States planes began bombing runs on Iraqi military targets today, foreign diplomats here said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Impact of an Israeli Act Weighed by the Arabs
description: Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations opposing Iraq would face increased domestic political pressure if Israel were to retaliate for the Iraqi missiles launched against its cities, but they would probably not desert the American-led coalition in the Persian Gulf, Saudi officials and Western diplomats say.

title: Alternative Realities Generated by Computer
description: Visitors can sample different realities from noon to midnight tomorrow at the Wetlands Preserve nightclub, 161 Hudson Street, Manhattan, where there will be demonstrations of "virtual reality," a new technology that allows a person to experience in sight, sound, touch and movement a computer-generated alternative world.

title: War Summary
description: THE ALLIED AIR ASSAULT

title: Lithuanians, Improvising, Resume TV Broadcasts
description: The Lithuanian republic's embattled independence government raised some cheer from behind its bunker walls today by resuming television broadcasting to rebut Kremlin propaganda salvos.

title: News Summary
description: War in the Gulf 6-13

title: Review/Music; 3 Changes in One Concert
description: Repercussions from the war in the Persian Gulf were felt by the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday evening. Zubin Mehta was to have conducted the subscription concert, but in an insert in the program the orchestra's music director explained that in this time of crisis, "I know my place is in Israel." He left for Israel earlier in the week to show solidarity with its people and especially its musicians. Mr. Mehta, who is in his last season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, also holds the title of music director for life of the Israel Philharmonic.

title: Among New York's Neediest, The Mentally Ill Homeless
description: John P. Greenbaum saw the homeless man curled in a ball in a corner of the Grand Army Plaza subway station, his jacket pulled over his head and two almost-empty pint bottles of whiskey at his feet.

title: City Cites Firefighters' Errors In Delay at Fatal Queens Blaze
description: The New York City Fire Department said yesterday that firefighters had made mistakes that delayed the response to a fire in Queens this month in which two brothers died. The department announced that it would begin disciplinary proceedings against two firefighters and four of their officers.

title: Mellon Bank Posts a Loss
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation today posted a fourth-quarter loss of $99 million and attributed it to an increase in the company's reserves against losses from bad real estate loans.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., has sued Du Pont Co., Wilmington, Del., in Federal court. The suit accuses Du Pont of monopolizing the $70 million market for polyimide plastic film. * Bath Iron Works Corp., Bath, Me., has received a $513.5 million contract from the Navy to build two Arleigh Burke-class destroyers. * Dorset Exploration Ltd. said it would buy some properties and associated facilities from Esso Resources Canada, a unit of Imperial Oil Ltd., Toronto. Terms were not disclosed. * Ford Motor Credit Co., Dearborn, Mich., a financial services company, has completed the transfer of Ford Consumer Finance Company to Associates Corp. of North America, New York, a financial services company. Both are units of Ford Motor Co. * Heldor Industries, Morristown, N.J., a swimming pool equipment distributor, said it would sell its assets and business to Aqua Fab Industries, a swimming pool and spa company. Terms were not disclosed. * Myers Industries, Akron, Ohio, a tire recapping equipment and supplies company, has reauthorized the repurchase of up to one million common shares from time to time on the open market. * Ryder System Inc., Miami, a transportation and storage company, has completed the sale of Ryder Temperature Control Carriage, a refrigerated common carrier, to a management group led by Roger Blume. Terms were not disclosed. * Tracor Holdings Inc., Austin, Tex., a military electronics concern, said it had reached an agreement in principle with its creditors for a plan to restructure its indebtedness and would file a plan of reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.

title: 18-Wheeler Returns to Earth
description: All 18 wheels of Vincent Gramuglia's truck in the sky are firmly on the ground again, but he's still bitter that New York State ordered him to haul it down. Mr. Gramuglia had put a full-size tractor-trailer atop an oil tank along the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to advertise his truck stop in this community about 40 miles west of Albany. The State Thruway Authority called it an eyesore and ordered him to take it down last year. He brought the truck to earth on Tuesday, he said.

title: U.S. Acts to Kill Rumors on Oil
description: Difficult as it is to imagine, the gyrations in oil prices that began even before the assault on Iraq would probably have been even wider without a new rumor-squelching communications link between the Government and the markets.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: For American Jews and Arabs, the Tug of Divided Emotions; A Recurring Dread that Iraqi Victims May be Relatives
description: Al-Tae Dawod fled his native Iraq as a teen-ager, but considered himself an American before he ever arrived in this country, became a citizen or developed a taste for steak and mashed potatoes.

title: A Quick Victory? It Better Be
description: President Bush has vowed that the war with Iraq "will not be another Vietnam." In its essential shape, however, the war will be quite similar, except that everything will be compressed in time. And, as in Vietnam, the key to the outcome is not the unquestionable American ability to impose damage but the enemy's ability to maintain a fighting force that can inflict casualties on Americans.

title: Bridge
description: Preparations for the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, to be played in Atlantic City in mid-March, are well advanced. Heading the organizing committee is Joan Gerard of White Plains, with Steve Surasky, also of White Plains, as treasurer.

title: What Prompted Investigations Into Pricing of Baby Formula
description: The infant-formula industry, which likes to project a warm and comforting image, now finds itself at the center of Federal and state price-fixing investigations.

title: Documents Case Plea
description: A consultant was sentenced on Wednesday to six months of house detention after pleading guilty to interstate transportation of technical documents stolen from the General Electric Company.

title: Becker Wins Australian Marathon
description: What spectators at the Australian Open needed was a great match, and today they got one.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs: The Conference Championships; N.F.L. Will Make Final Decision Tomorrow
description: Although the National Football League does not plan to change its playoff schedule, it could decide as late as tomorrow morning, game day, to postpone the two conference championship games, which are the preludes to Super Bowl XXV.

title: NCR Sees Violations In Bid by A.T.&T.
description: The NCR Corporation is contending in court documents that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's hostile takeover offer for the computer maker violates Federal law.

title: Pro Basketball; From Bad to Worst: Knicks Fall Apart in Miami
description: This may be remembered as the night the Knicks' season fell completely apart.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: View in Poll: a Recession
description: An overwhelming majority of Americans say the country is in a recession, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: About New York; In a Dark World, A Diverse Few Pray for Peace
description: At 3:30 A.M. yesterday, a cool breeze caressed a nearly empty Amsterdam Avenue in front of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. A newspaper truck rumbled past. A man carrying a mountain of plastic bags stumbled toward tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: Headlines in some copies yesterday with the continuations of two articles about an Iraqi missile attack on Israel referred incorrectly to the aftermath. The United States discouraged an Israeli response; there was no counterstrike.

title: Attorney General Backs Philadelphia Loan
description: The Pennsylvania Attorney General announced today that he had overcome his reservations about allowing a state pension fund to make a loan to financially troubled Philadelphia. His decision cleared the way for completion of the deal.

title: Maradona Announces That He Will Retire
description: He has a contract that would pay him $2 million a year until 1993, but at the age of 30, Diego Maradona, the Argentine star of the Naples soccer team, has decided it's time to find less demanding work.

title: Players and Clubs Show Figures for Arbitration
description: Additional evidence of baseball's new world of economics erupted yesterday when 138 players and their clubs exchanged figures for salary arbitration. The salaries sought and offered reflected the contracts other players have signed this winter:

title: GTE and Contel Merger Advances
description: A merger of the GTE Corporation and the Contel Corporation has been approved by the United States Department of Justice and 11 of 18 state regulatory agencies, the companies said. The companies said they were confident they would receive the remaining state approvals as well as a needed approval from the Federal Communications Commission. The merger was announced last July and was approved overwhelmingly by shareholders of both companies in December.

title: Price of Oil Dips Below $20 a Barrel
description: Oil prices fell 10 percent more yesterday, the day after the biggest one-day drop in the market's history. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude for February delivery lost $2.19 a barrel, to $19.25, its first close under $20 since July. The drop for the week was $8.04 a barrel.

title: Inland Steel Posts a Loss
description: Inland Steel Industries, the operator of the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, yesterday reported a net loss of $57.1 million for the fourth quarter. The loss was a result of start-up expenses on a new joint venture with the Nippon Steel Corporation that were higher than expected, the company said.

title: Savvy Woman Magazine Sets Last Issue
description: Savvy Woman, a magazine for executive women, announced yesterday that it would cease publication after its February issue, becoming the latest victim of the deteriorating advertising market.

title: Martha Graham in Hospital
description: Martha Graham has been hospitalized with the flu, a spokesman for the Martha Graham Dance Company said yesterday. The 96-year-old modern-dance pioneer returned in mid-December from a 55-day tour of Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong with her company. Ron Protas, the troupe's executive director, said Miss Graham appeared to be suffering from bronchitis after the trip and entered a hospital Tuesday for tests and treatment. He said her condition was improving.

title: Economics by the Cup
description: To the Editor:

title: School Desegregation and Practicality
description: The Supreme Court, 1991, has just amended the historic views of the Supreme Court, 1954, on school segregation, but not as much as feared and not enough to be discouraging.

title: The Grande Bande
description: Frederick Renz is to direct the Grande Bande in a program of Italian string orchestra music at 8 o'clock tonight at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. The program includes concertos by Corelli, Geminiani and Vivaldi, along with Salieri's Scherzi Instrumentali di Stile Fugato, Rossini's Sonata No. 6 and Mauro Giuliani's "Siciliana" for guitar and strings. Richard Stone is to be the soloist in the Giuliani. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 749-6600.

title: Sure, But Also . . .
description: Great men tend to have had it nowadays. George Bush, for instance, had had it with Saddam Hussein. He told the world about it several weeks ago. Said he'd "had it" with that guy. Look what happened.

title: Review/Dance; Ferocious, As Becomes The Tyger
description: "Fearful Symmetries" is exciting but, fortunately, not dangerous. One of Peter Martins's best pieces of choreography, the work unites total control with the illusion of reckless abandon. Its performance by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater was a fine example of disciplined energy.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Ghost of Reform in Nashville
description: The ghost of Robert Maynard Hutchins drifted through the N.C.A.A. convention last week, searching in vain for fundamental reform of intercollegiate athletics. The spectral Hutchins, once president of the University of Chicago, heard nothing even close to the words he spoke 50 years ago. Warning of sport gone wild, he banned football at his school and later withdrew Chicago from the Big Ten athletic conference.

title: Japan's Homeless: Seen Yet Ignored
description: In a silent, dark alley near piers that bustle during the day, a few small piles of cardboard and blankets are all that keep the late-night chill from 10 sleeping men, a handful of the scores of homeless vagrants of this otherwise prosperous port.

title: Marie Provaznic, 100, Ex-Leader Of Czech Nationalist Sport Group
description: Marie Provaznik, a leader of the nationalist Sokol gymnastics movement in Czechoslovakia who defected to the United States after directing the Czechoslovak women's contingent at the 1948 Olympic Games in London, died on Jan. 11 at St. Clair's Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y. She was 100 years old, and her family said she suffered a stroke two weeks earlier.

title: Condoms in Schools: The Right Lesson
description: Does the distribution of condoms, as has been proposed for New York City's schools, encourage and condone sexual promiscuity? A growing body of research and the experience of AIDS educators suggests just the opposite: Condom availability, combined with AIDS education, can delay and discourage casual sexual activity.

title: Many May Avoid Paris Couture Shows Because of War
description: The Persian Gulf war has cast a shadow over the spring European couture collections, scheduled to be shown starting next week, as some fashion magazines and retailers have canceled or re-evaluated travel plans. Executives mentioned fears of terrorism and concern about the appropriateness of viewing fashion now.

title: Review/Dance; Petronio Company Explores Esthetics of a Post-Punk Era
description: More than one great hope emerged in experimental dance in the 1980's. There is still hope for Stephen Petronio, who, unlike so many of his colleagues, has not sputtered into the ordinary.

title: At Hub in Atlanta, Bewildered Eastern Travelers
description: The dismantling of Eastern Air Lines began today at Hartsfield International Airport just before 6 P.M. when Eastern officials here were notified that all international flights from Atlanta had been canceled.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Western Europe; Western Europe Assails Iraqis' Attacks on Israel
description: Western European governments have strongly condemned Iraq for attacking Israel with missiles. But fearful that retaliation by Israel could weaken the anti-Iraqi alliance, they also urged its Government to show restraint in its response.

title: New York Won't Tell Doctors With AIDS to Inform Patients
description: Taking issue with the nation's two leading medical and dental associations, the New York State Health Department yesterday issued guidelines saying that health-care workers infected with the AIDS virus need not tell patients their status and may continue to operate or do other invasive procedures.

title: Feuding Lawyers Get a Hearing; Their Peers, an Earful
description: There were the Montagues against the Capulets. The Hatfields and the McCoys. Donald and Ivana.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Sea War; Computerized Accuracy: 'A Relief to See the Tomahawks Fly'
description: As darkness hung over the Persian Gulf early Thursday morning, the first volleys of war hurtled from American warships in fiery balls of light and bone-jarring booms.

title: Israel's Agonizing Choice
description: The sirens yesterday turned out to be a false alarm, but that didn't efface the horrible fears of the night before. As good as his threat, a desperate Saddam Hussein struck blindly at Israel with potentially deadly Scud missiles. Once again Jews are being targeted because they are Jews, by a tyrant vowing to spill rivers of blood in order to extirpate a "criminal Zionist entity."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Air Commander; General Who Planned Air Assault, With Lessons of Vietnam: Charles Albert Horner
description: The lush green jungles of Vietnam were far from the Saudi desert and from the tactical demands weighing on Lieut. Gen. Charles A. Horner, commander of the American Air Force in the Persian Gulf, as his jets streaked over Iraq yesterday, pounding missile sites, command centers, radar stations and other targets.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Missing in Action; Friends Recall Downed Pilot's Can-Do Outlook and Love of Flying
description: Friends and neighbors of the Navy flier who became the first American shot down by Iraq struggled hard today not to talk about him in the past tense.

title: Corrections
description: A TV Critic's Notebook article yesterday about coverage of the war in the Persian Gulf misidentified a CBS correspondent reporting from the Pentagon. He was Morley Safer, not Harry Reasoner.

title: Leo Hurwitz, 81, Blacklisted Maker Of Documentaries
description: Leo Hurwitz, an award-winning documentary film maker who dealt with social justice and similar themes and who was on an industry blacklist in the 1950's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Tapes, Lost and Found
description: As rental companies offer more cars equipped with tape players, a growing number of forgetful travelers may find themselves losing their favorite cassettes.

title: INSIDE
description: Former Supporters Rush To Censure Gorbachev

title: Modest Late Rally Lifts Treasuries
description: A modest late rally lifted prices of long-term Treasury securities yesterday. The market had marked time earlier waiting for bond traders to convert some of their huge gains of the previous session into cash. But dealers said no significant profit taking materialized.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Air War; Fighters Target of Flak Triggered by Other Jets
description: Having been almost unchallenged during the first day of war, pilots of the United States Air Force's F-117A Stealth fighters say they are now encountering heavy antiaircraft artillery and ground-to-air missile attacks.

title: Review/Film; Secret Robot Runs Amok In a Miniskirt
description: "Eve of Destruction," which opened here yesterday, is an undistinguished, barely functional action-melodrama with a body count higher than some wars.

title: Review/Dance; Ensemble's Debut in 'Orfeo'
description: Bart Folse, the music director of the Pro Arte Chorale and the founder of I Cantori di New York, has started an opera ensemble, Opera Quotannis. On Sunday evening, he led the group in its first production, Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice," at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle. He plans to offer a production of Benjamin Britten's "Rape of Lucretia" in May.

title: Patents; Preserving Wine After Bottle Is Opened
description: A Boston restaurateur and two other inventors obtained a patent this week on an aerosol canister for wine bottles that makes it possible to drink part of the bottle and preserve the rest for as long as wanted.

title: Review/Opera; A Menacing Sort of Devil
description: To write that Samuel Ramey and the role of Mephistopheles were born for each other sounds dangerously like billboard advertising, but Gounod's character and Mr. Ramey's particular set of assets do match with unusual precision.

title: U.S. Judge Says Jail Must Relax Limits on Gotti
description: John Gotti has been confined in jail under excessive and punitive conditions, a Federal judge said yesterday in ordering the restrictions eased.

title: Rock Stars Flock to Rio For 9 Days Of Concerts
description: The world's biggest soccer stadium now has a dance floor. For nine days, Maracana Stadium will hold what is being billed as the world's biggest rock festival: Rock in Rio II. When the festival was planned, its promoters hoped to draw attention to a new, modern Brazil. After the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, the festival remains determinedly apolitical, presenting pop music as escapist entertainment.

title: More on the Gulf
description: PRIDE OF WORKERS -- The 24,000 employees building F-16's at a General Dynamics plant in Fort Worth are rooting for the jet fighters with pride, confidence and worry. Business Day, page 37. GAMES STILL ON -- There are no plans to cancel, postpone or reschedule any sports events. But the National Football League said television rescheduling could determine if Sunday's Giants-49ers and the Bills- Raiders games are played. The league can postpone the games up to Sunday morning. Sports, page 49. PRAYERS FOR PEACE -- In the middle of a vast cathedral in the middle of the night, a diverse few gather to pray for peace. About New York, page 33. WAR AND GOD -- Amid war's anguish, millions turn to God, stirring questions on the nature of prayer. Beliefs, page 17.

title: Review/Music; Inevitably, War Intrudes
description: Like so much in American life, the concert presented Wednesday evening at the Symphony Space by the Manhattan Chamber Orchestra was affected by larger world events. Richard Auldon Clark, the ensemble's artistic director and conductor, asked for a moment of silence before the music began, and chose to eliminate the intermission so that everyone could get home earlier.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Desert Weather; Advantage for the Iraqis: Clouds Hinder Air Raids
description: Military experts said yesterday that the clouds over the battle zone in the Persian Gulf yesterday were making it more difficult to pinpoint targets and to assess the success of air strikes, and that this would reduce the ability of pilots to evade enemy fire.

title: Books of The Times; A Quest to Kill Time in the Yucatan
description: Gringos By Charles Portis. 269 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: We Don't Need Another Dr. King
description: "If King were alive, things would be different." "I wish we had a civil rights movement, then we could do something." "We need another King."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; RAIDS SAID TO CUT POWER IN BAGHDAD
description: Sketchy reports from Western news agencies and television correspondents suggest that the Iraqi capital has lost its electricity and telephone service and is suffering a severe shortage of water.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; Air Assault Fails to Wipe Out All Mobile Missiles
description: Allied warplanes mounted a huge effort to destroy Iraq's mobile missile launchers on Friday and again this morning, but apparently failed to wipe them all out.

title: Gotti Arrest Followed Proper Procedure
description: To the Editor:

title: Jonathan Etra, Writer, 38
description: Jonathan Etra, a writer, died on Thursday while vacationing in Key West, Fla. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 'Mud and Blood Are Sisters'
description: I am not too worried about the final form of our Tower Babel but, as it collapses, I do not want its pieces to fall and kill our children.

title: Review/Theater; Lyndon Johnson's Duet With Power
description: Laurence Luckinbill's impersonation of Lyndon B. Johnson in James Prideaux's monodrama, "Lyndon," is a life-size portrait of a larger-than-life character. The Johnson visage -- from the jug ears to the jowls -- fits Mr. Luckinbill, and so does the role, surprisingly so, considering the actor's previous accomplishments. With his even features and usually urbane manner, Mr. Luckinbill would not seem a natural to play Johnson.

title: Steering Inmates to Jobs By Innovative Training
description: Even as the nation's overloaded prison systems struggle to house, feed and control three-quarters of a million inmates, a modest but hopeful array of experimental counseling and education programs have begun to emerge.

title: Rhode Island Bank Inquiry
description: Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun urged on Thursday that an independent prosecutor be appointed to investigate Rhode Island's banking crisis.

title: Pride of a Texas Plant: The Fast and Agile F-16
description: Until Thursday morning's air raids into Iraq and occupied Kuwait, American pilots had never flown the F-16 Falcon jet fighter in combat. Now the American-led force has 175 of the single-engine planes engaged in the war in the Persian Gulf. And, like workers at military-equipment plants across the country, the 24,000 employees building F-16's at the General Dynamics plant here find themselves rooting for their products and the Americans operating them with a blend of pride, confidence and worry that they never felt before.

title: Ryan Talks to Vikings
description: It's hard to keep 'em down on the farm once they've seen Paree, but the way Buddy Ryan was telling it last week, he'd rather retire to his Kentucky horse farm than accept an assistant coaching position after his five years as head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: U.S. Airlines Ordered To Lend More Planes
description: The Pentagon has called on commercial air cargo companies to supply additional long-range aircraft to the military operation in the Persian Gulf, increasing the military's ability to deliver ammunition, spare parts and weapons to the forces there.

title: Some Progress Is Seen in Talks With Teachers
description: Negotiators reported some progress yesterday on proposals to halt the imminent layoff of thousands of New York City teachers, paraprofessionals and school aides in the middle of the current school year.

title: Chief of Claris Is Selected For a High Post at Go Corp.
description: The Go Corporation, which will display its pen-based computer operating system software next week, yesterday named William V. Campbell president and chief executive. Since 1987, Mr. Campbell has been president and chief executive of the Claris Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Apple Computer Inc. devoted to software.

title: Trade Gap Narrowed in November
description: The nation's trade deficit fell 12 percent in November, to $9.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported today, as the weakening economy dampened demand for oil and other imports.

title: A Picture of the War
description: The camera doesn't lie. Yesterday it brought home the marvels of high-tech warfare in the Persian Gulf. But the camera doesn't necessarily tell the whole truth, any more than the home team's highlight film adequately depicts a football game.

title: South African Judge Throws Out Police Suit Against 2 Papers
description: A judge ruled today against a senior police general who sued two leading anti-apartheid newspapers after they reported that he had supplied poison to police operatives to kill members of the African National Congress.

title: Track and Field; Johnson Starts Off Slowly Again and Finishes 2d
description: Ben Johnson, who two years ago appeared to be track's super-human sprinter, is apparently a mere mortal in his comeback from a two-year ban for steriod use.

title: Beliefs
description: "Incredible," said the Rev. F. Forrester Church. "In 13 years here I have never seen anything like it."

title: Eastern Airlines Is Shutting Down And Plans to Liquidate Its Assets
description: Eastern Airlines, a fixture in United States aviation since 1928 and the nation's eighth-largest airline, announced that it had stopped flying last night and would begin to sell off its planes and other assets.

title: Jury Has Case of Lujan's Son
description: The rape trial of Robert Jeffrey Lujan, son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., went to the jury in Alexandria Circuit Court today. The prosecution asserts that on Nov. 11, the younger Mr. Lujan carried a shotgun into a woman's apartment in the same building where he lived with his parents, then raped her. The defendant's lawyers acknowledge that he had sexual relations with the woman but contend that she freely consented to it.

title: No. 7 IRT Line Will Shut Down For 7 Weekends
description: Tens of thousands of Queens subway riders will contend with major service disruptions on the No. 7 Flushing line for the next seven weekends as Transit Authority engineers replace an outdated series of track switches.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Public Opinion; Approval of Bush Soars
description: President Bush's job approval rating has sharply increased in the past week, reaching the highest level measured for an American President in the last 30 years, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Father in Right-to-Die Case Loses an Appeal
description: The father of a brain-damaged young woman was prevented by a state appeals court today from moving her to Minnesota, where laws governing the removal of life-support systems are less restrictive.

title: Bungamati Journal; A Town So Old, Communism Is Hope of Future
description: Over the hills and far away in Eastern Europe, democratic elections have ended a Communist era. Here, in a 16th-century red-brick town where corn hangs out to dry under the eaves in the golden winter sun and men wrapped in shawls warm themselves on the steps of the village temple, a lot of people say they believe that Communism is the hope of the future.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Psychological War; C.I.A. Joins Military Move to Sap Iraqi Confidence
description: Through public actions and covert military and intelligence missions, the United States is waging a psychological campaign to shake Iraq's confidence, undermine its military and deceive its leaders about American military intentions.

title: Teacher Corps May Feel Weight Of New York City Budget Crisis
description: The first teacher-recruits in a new national program to help troubled schools have come to New York City and met the enemy, but it's not truancy, or poverty, or drugs or violence. It's a budget crisis.

title: Frances A. Kolb, 53, Education Consultant
description: Frances Arick Kolb, an education consultant who worked to shape public school curriculums that would encourage achievement by girls and minorities, died last Saturday at Marlborough Hospital in Massachusetts. She was 53 years old and lived in Marlborough.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Kuwaitis; Kuwait Says Iraq Flew 10 Stolen Jets to Africa
description: Iraq flew 10 stolen Kuwaiti jet airliners, repainted to look like Iraqi Airways planes, to Mauritania and perhaps other North African countries just before the war erupted in the Persian Gulf, Kuwait's Government in exile told a committee of the United Nations Security Council today.

title: Your Money; One Simple Way To Help on Taxes
description: This may be the simplest advice an accountant ever gave. Yet for some people it could save no end of aggravation and even money. It concerns all those envelopes that arrive from mid-January through early February marked important tax document: Open them straightaway.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs: The Conference Championships; Montana Misses 49ers' Practice With the Flu
description: Stay focused. That was George Seifert's primary command for the San Franciscio 49ers in their training camp in Rocklin, Calif., not just last summer, but a year before that, in his first season as the team's head coach.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Moscow Urges Middle East Nations to Avoid an Arab-Israeli War
description: The Soviet Union appealed to the leaders of Israel and Arab countries today to join in an alliance against Iraq to rebuff Saddam Hussein's attempt to provoke a new Arab-Israeli war.

title: New Chairman at Heileman Replaces Ousted Executive
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company, the nation's fifth-largest brewer, has ousted its president and chief operating officer, Murray S. Cutbush, and named Thomas J. Rattigan, a former president of Pepsico Bottling International, to replace him. Mr. Rattigan takes the titles of chairman and chief executive.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: For American Jews and Arabs, the Tug of Divided Emotions; Words of Support for U.S. Goals and Prayer for Israel
description: In homes, on the streets and in their places of business, many American Jewish men and women wept openly late Thursday when news of the attacks on Israel was first reported. Even as word came that the missile attacks were not as deadly as first believed, hundreds rushed to synagogues for special prayer vigils that continued through the day yesterday and into last night.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "So far, so good." -- President Bush. [ 7:5. ]

title: A Correction
description: A sentence in a letter Tuesday by Donald C. Comlish on British and United States airlines appeared incorrectly. The affected paragraph should have read: "The United States Government could agree with the British to increase the number of British carriers allowed to serve the United States. However, I find it extremely hard to believe that such a British carrier, or carriers, would or even could offer service at the lower fares you seem to envision."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan; In Jordan, the Iraqis Regain Respect by Striking at Israel
description: In his photo store in central Amman, Naser Jafr had not known about the Iraqi missiles that crashed into Israel early Friday, until a friend called with the news at 4 A.M. And then, he said, he was filled with delight.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Hit Civilian Targets
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Plans to Reduce Beds for Homeless
description: New York City will provide fewer beds on average for homeless men and women this year than in 1990 because the numbers of adults seeking emergency shelter have begun to level off during the peak winter period, city officials said yesterday.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; 2d Iraqi Attack on Israel Raises Concern in U.S.
description: Reports of a second Iraqi missile attack on downtown Tel Aviv early today renewed concerns in Washington that Israel may strike back at Iraq and thus be drawn into the Persian Gulf conflict.

title: Key Rates
WAR IN THE GULF: Television; Feast of Viewing, but Little Nourishment
description: After Wednesday night, news coverage of war will never be quite the same.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs: The Conference Championships; Defense Could Define Giants-49ers Game
description: All week, the talk has been about Joe Montana and Jerry Rice on one hand, Jeff Hostetler on the other.

title: Review/Music; Argentine Chamber Players
description: Argentina's Camerata Bariloche played an old-fashioned but satisfying concert on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. The chamber ensemble, founded in Buenos Aires in 1967, consisted on this occasion of 14 string players, most of whom performed standing, along with two wind soloists and a harpsichordist as needed.

title: Patents; Customized Candy Bars
description: A California candy entrepreneur has patented a way to make customized chocolate bars that can be engraved with whatever logo, picture or message a customer wants. The system was invented by Jeffrey Robinson, founder of Totally Chocolate Inc. of Valencia, Calif., for companies that want to send gifts with messages. Mr. Robinson's company is using the system and selling close to $1 million worth of chocolate.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WALTER H. ANNENBERG has sent a check for $5 million to the United Negro College Fund, part of the $50 million he promised if the fund raises $200 million in three years. His challenge grant is the largest given to a black cause, the fund said yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs: The Conference Championships; Bills' Fans Attend Service as Rally Is Canceled
description: The plan had been for about 7,000 fans of the Buffalo Bills to appear in the County Office Building Plaza, spilling down the steps and on to Franklin Street, two days before the most highly anticipated football game to be played here in nearly a quarter-century.

title: Miles Copeland, 74, Expert on Mideast, Writer and Ex-Spy
description: Miles Copeland Sr., a political consultant on the Middle East, writer and one-time spy, died Monday at Padocks Hospital in Oxfordshire, England. He was 74 years old and had homes in Oxfordshire and Washington.

title: U.S. Says Air Crashes Dipped
description: Aviation accidents declined in all categories last year, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: How to Obtain Ticket Refunds
description: Eastern Airlines said last night that customers who had purchased tickets could get refunds through the company's Miami headquarters.

title: Coal Company Admits Safety Test Fraud
description: The nation's largest coal company has pleaded guilty to criminal charges of tampering with mine safety tests and agreed to cooperate in a broad Federal inquiry into safety fraud in the nation's coal mines.

title: Patents; Bouncing Messages Off Meteor Trails
description: Hoping to offer a lower-cost alternative to satellites for long- distance communication, a start-up company in New Jersey patented a system this week that bounces messages off tiny meteor trails that each last only a few seconds before disappearing.

title: Latin Redux in Our Schools? A Risible Notion; From Out of Town?
description: To the Editor:

title: Alan I. Chalfin, Ophthalmologist, 50
description: Alan I. Chalfin, an ophthalmologist and teacher, died on Tuesday at his home in Lawrence, L.I. He was 50 years old.

title: Latin Redux in Our Schools? A Risible Notion; Secret of Vocabulary
description: To the Editor:

title: Accountants as Financial Planners
description: The nation's certified public accountants are beginning a major effort to convince the public that they are the best sources of advice on financial planning. Other financial planners who are not accountants say that is not necessarily so.

title: 41 Students Sprayed by Mace
description: Forty-one elementary school students were injured today when a canister of Mace found on the back of their bus apparently went off and sprayed them, authorities said. Fire Chief Gary Kish of Hillside said a group of 8-year-olds from Hyde Park Elementary School found the canister on their bus on the way home from a half-day of school at 11:30 A.M. Someone was apparently holding the canister when it went off.

title: WAR IN THE GULF': Tel Aviv; A Day of False Alarms and Fear, Flanked by Real Explosions
description: One of the missiles that landed here early Friday morning, a day before the latest attack, plunged into a poor and densely populated neighborhood, but landed and exploded at the edge of the only empty lot for blocks.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LAYING OUT OF GUSSIE HOOT By Margot Fraser. Southern Methodist University Press, $14.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Friends of Karen, a charity that helps seriously ill children and their families, included an erroneous report of a death. Charlotte O'Connor was operated on for kidney cancer and is now 4 years old.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: UKRAINIAN HERITAGE CENTER;
Connections to the Old Country Nurtured by Volunteer Curators
description: MARY HEZZEY pointed to a well-worn saddle. "This is several hundred years old," she said. "We have perhaps the only Cossack saddle around."

title: Giving Help to Nurses With an Addiction
description: I want to express the deep appreciation of the Committee on Substance Abuse in Nursing, of the Nurses Association of Westchester County, for the article "When the Healer Is a Drug Abuser" that appeared Dec. 23.

title: Secrets About Beets: Bake Them, Eat the Leaves
description: THERE are two things many people don't know about beets. One is that they taste best when baked whole in their skins instead of being boiled. Baking concentrates their flavor and makes them sweeter. The other is that their leaves, which are often routinely discarded, make a delicious green vegetable. They can be steamed, sauteed or stir-fried like spinach, served on their own or mixed with other vegetables. They are good hot or cold.

title: War on All-Stars' Minds
description: Uwe Krupp, a Buffalo Sabre and a National Hockey League All-Star, grew up in Germany but has developed a fondness for the United States in the four years he has lived here.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ACTS OF MEANING By Jerome Bruner. Harvard University, $19.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Missing; Despite Downed Jets, Those at Home Retain Hope
description: The Pentagon had listed Lieut. Robert Wetzel and Lieut. Jeffrey N. Zaun of the Navy and Maj. Thomas F. Koritz of the Air Force as missing in action, their planes lost somewhere over Iraq. But the families and friends of the fliers, two of whom grew up in New Jersey, had not given up hope as they gathered yesterday to pray and remember.

title: Secession of the Successful
description: The idea of "community" has always held a special attraction for Americans. In a 1984 speech, President Ronald Reagan celebrated America's "bedrock" -- "its communities where neighbors help one another, where families bring up kids together, where American values are born." Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, with a very different political leaning, has been almost as lyrical. "Community . . . is the reality on which our national life has been founded," he said in 1987.

title: Rams' Coach Says Meggett Is the Man
description: If the Giants are to defeat the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday they must look to their offense and hope for big plays from their all-purpose back, Dave Meggett.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Santa Monica, Calif.; The Last Of the Giants
description: GLASS and granite are beginning to sheath two of four office buidldings going up in the 17-acre Water Garden here, a project likely to be the last of its scope for some time because of new density restrictions and a commercial construction moratorium in this cramped seaside community.

title: Ex-Priest Now Booking Casino Acts
description: HOW does a Franciscan priest, who once took vows of chastity, obedience and poverty, end up booking acts for a Boardwalk casino? Answer: through a tumultuous midlife crisis.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Dec. 23 about rail travel in Canada gave an outdated telephone number for calling the Great Canadian Railtour Company from the United States. The number given for Canada, (800) 665-7245, can also be used from the United States.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Home, Sweet Damp Home
description: By providing a wealth of details in its photographs and text, VANISHING PARADISE: The Tropical Rainforest (Overlook, $35) provides the perspective needed to grasp the full meaning of the destruction of Amazon rain forests. A single tree may house "over fifty species of ants and ten thousand other species of insects, spiders and mites," writes the zoologist Andrew Mitchell. The photographs, by Stephen Dalton and George Bernard, vividly illustrate the connections of everything in these ecosystems. A basilisk or Jesus lizard runs across a river on its hind legs; a jaguar stares out of its hiding place; an algae-covered sloth lolls on the forest floor -- these and dozens of other shots make this faraway world real. "Vanishing Paradise" is an important book -- as well as a delight to look at and to read.

title: Talkin' 'Bout My G-G-Generation
description: Over three consecutive nights, beginning tomorrow, PBS will broadcast a six-part series chronicling the events and impact of the 60's. Where Ken Burns, in creating his masterful Civil War series, had to draw on the written word, the still photograph and the contemporary historian to summon up the sense of an era, the makers of this documentary series faced a different challenge: to sift through a staggering abundance of television-ready material in a way that would live up to its title, "Making Sense of the 60's."

title: In the Wee, Small Hours
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Airlines Brought Down by a Strike So Bitter It Became a Crusade
description: As word filtered out Friday night that Eastern Airlines would shut, some members of its machinists union, which has been on strike since March 1989, rejoiced.

title: Toll-Free Lines For Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special, 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf.

title: 'Home Alone': Are Its Kicks Painful for Kids?
description: It's sad when a 4-year-old thinks you're crazy. "Let's go see a really funny movie," I said. "It's about a boy whose parents go on a long trip and forget to take him with them and leave him home alone."

title: With Walking Stick on Solid Ground
description: ON my first trip to England in 1960 as a college student, I desperately wanted to look like a native -- though the proper London look, whether Burberry mac or wool Jaeger suit, was not one I could easily afford. What I eventually acquired to transform myself was a long beige nylon umbrella with a plastic fake-bone handle. I loved that umbrella. Although it was undeniably useful during London's drips and drizzles, I really treasured it because I could tap it so smartly on the pavement as I walked. When I swung up Regent Street or along the Embankment, its brisk rat-a-tat was an assurance that I knew where I was going -- and that I could take care of myself.

title:
Focus: South Florida;
Developers Turning to Deep Discounts
description: PRICE discounting by developers of one-family homes is brewing unusual opportunities for southern Florida buyers.

title: Food Shortages, Now Violence Make Soviet Investing Dicier
description: At the same time as war engulfs the Middle East, the Soviet Union continues to unravel both politically and economically. After five years, the democratic reforms and economic liberalization initiated by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seem to be backfiring, threatening, among other things, the future of thousands of joint-venture plans between Western and Soviet enterprises, only a small fraction of which are in place.

title: Jeanne Jennings Has a Wedding
description: Jeanne Elizabeth Jennings was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York to Manville Edmund Hendrickson 3d by the Rev. Mark Connelly.

title: Postings: A Vast Pied a Terre; Mansion To Share
description: What may be Manhattan's most exceptional pied-a-terre -- a Beaux-Arts mansion at Fifth Avenue and 82d Street that has belonged to the same family since the century began -- is on the market. But Mary Duke Biddle Semans, whose grandfather moved into the newly finished house in 1901, hopes to keep part of the dwelling for her visits from Durham, N.C.

title: Roemer's New Tack for Old Problems
description: As visitors to the Louisiana governor's mansion pass the guard's desk they are likely to see a photograph of the current occupant showing him in profile with his eyes squinting and his mouth tight. It is very much the angry young man that Buddy Roemer used to be.

title: A Poetic Touch in Folk Songs
description: LISTENING to John Gorka sing his brand of folk music, one can get goose bumps all over. There are many reasons -- fresh lyrics, a stunning, emotional baritone voice, his twisted humor -- but to focus on one limits the experience.

title: Q and A
description: Alligator and Crocodile Skins

title: Tanya Linzalone to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Linzalone of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tanya Grace Linzalone, to George F. Mills, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Mills of Woodhaven, Queens. A wedding next year is planned. Ms. Linzalone, 24 years old, graduated from St. John's University, where she received a master's degree in audiology. She is a clinical audiologist with the Lexington Hearing and Speech Center in Jackson Heights. Mr. Mills, 25, is a trade administrator at Barclay's Bank in New York.

title: Jessica Sunshine Weds J. D. Selengut
description: Jessica Miriam Sunshine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Sunshine of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeremy David Selengut, a son of Barbara Norris Sorce of Mahwah, N.J., and Arnold Selengut of Temple Terrace, Fla. Rabbi Isaac Swift officiated at the Pearl River (N.Y.) Hilton.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A New Proposal for 64 Acres in Mahwah
description: AFTER winning a court battle over their plans for a large tract in Mahwah, four Bergen County developers are now trying to get a new plan approved that they think will be more salable in today's more difficult market. The developers, Darlington Associates, are seeking the change for 64 acres of their 435-acre property along Ramapo Valley Road.

title: The Executive Computer; The Latest Excel Leapfrogs Its Spreadsheet Rivals
description: PersonaL computer spreadsheets have become much more than mere number-crunching engines. Although they are primarily used to collect, organize and analyze numbers, spreadsheets are also used by many executives as data bases, as report generators and as chart and graphics designers. Some hard-core spreadsheet users even use them as word processors.

title: Poetic Fashion
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Abortion Referendum Loses in Texas
description: A proposal to change the city's charter to declare that life begins at conception was soundly defeated in a referendum today.

title: Patricia Epworth Greene Is Married To Richard Ruopp in Massachusetts
description: Patricia Epworth Greene, who retired last year as the vice president for finance and administration at the Bank Street College of Education in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Randolph Ruopp, a president emeritus of the college. The Rev. Dr. Sam Keen, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Dr. Nancy Rockwell, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Memorial Chapel at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Dinner; On Upper West Side, Bistro Fare and Tapas
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some places to dine on Sunday on the Upper West Side. Andiamo!

title: Don't Worry, Be Happy
description: LEARNED OPTIMISMBy Martin E. P. Seligman.319 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: The Back Fence
description: If annyone had looked inside the meeting room, they would have seen a peculiar sight. More than a hundred people had paid to hear a lecture, but the speaker had stepped aside because of circumstances and instead the audience was staring at a kind of Frankenstein monster, a figure with a brown podium for a body and a small television for a head. Suddenly the head had a face, the face of George Bush, telling the nation it had gone to war.

title: Sunny Days Along the Indian River
description: IN the compass of idle horizons off Dick Jones's small pier on the Indian River a roseate spoonbill has just appeared, scooping for shrimp among the spidery legs of mangroves and flashing its pink feathers as unexpected as underwear.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Katonah, N.Y. 1.9 million East Lake Drive 9-bedroom, 8 1/2-bath, 3-year-old English stone; 3 fireplaces, library, wet bar, butler's pantry, pool, 3-stall barn, greenhouse, 8.9 acres; taxes $25,000. Larchmont, N.Y. 350,000 37 Lookout Circle 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 65-year-old colonial; stone fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $7,633. Scarsdale, N.Y. 555,000 111 Brewster Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 44-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, new family room, 2-car garage; taxes $9,650. Essex, Conn. 95,000 33 Gates Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 130-year-old colonial; new well, 1-car garage, 0.20-acre; taxes $824. Old Saybrook, Conn. 126,800 2 Sherman Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; living room w/bay window, and updated bathroom, new furnace; taxes not available. Vernon, Conn. 139,900 71 Range Hill Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; walk-out basement, eat-in kitchen, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,838. OTHER AREAS East Islip, L.I. 130,000 94 Meroke Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; new eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $3,200. Glen Cove, L.I. 325,000 3 Sherman Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 34-year-old ranch; new eat-in kitchen, family room, fireplace, finished basement, pool; taxes $5,100. Livingston 203,000 1 Locust Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old split level; family room, 1-car garage, den; taxes $3,681.

title: Cross-Country Skiers Are Taking Off With a Swoosh
description: FORGET the long lift lines. Forget the long hours traveling north to the mountain resorts. If cross-country skiing is on your agenda this winter, your playground may not be far from your front door.

title: Background Mush
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago
description: To the Editor: I was surprised that William E. Schmidt ("What's Doing in Chicago," Travel Nov. 4) left out the University of Chicago from an otherwise well-rounded article.

title: New York's Gordian Knot of Labor Talks, Layoffs and Pay Freezes
description: New York City's effort to get its fiscal house in order is particularly complicated because of the Dinkins administration's labor strategy of simultaneously trying to settle past, present and future contracts and ordering the first major layoffs in more than a decade.

title: Style Makers; Janet Brown, Clothier
description: Janet Brown's boutique in Port Washington, L.I., carries clothes by Jean Muir and Jil Sander, shoes by Prada and accessories by Loro Piana. But what she is really selling is the taste of Janet Brown.

title: Journalism vs. Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking: Co-ops; Assuming Control of Operations
description: INTEREST in self-management has been growing among co-operatives in the New York City area, where traditionally boards have hired professional management firms to run their buildings.

title: Is It Ibsen? Or Is It Stephen King?
description: "They shoulda rolled the head on stage," said the burly high school student in the letter jacket, who had just seen the Hartford Stage Company's production of "The Master Builder" and was making his way up the aisle and out into the street, where a yellow bus waited to collect him and his companions.

title: Postings: At the Orsini's Site; Japan Tea Club Moving In
description: During the 60's and 70's, Orsini's restaurant drew a glittering crowd to the town house at 41 West 56th Street with a dining room that served up classic Italian cuisine to patrons like Jacqueline Onassis and Gloria Vanderbilt.

title: Mallory J. Knickerbocker Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Candee Knickerbocker Jr. of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mallory Jane Knickerbocker, to Michael Anhouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart M. Anhouse of New Hyde Park, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Ms. Spiro to Wed Mark K. Feldman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Spiro of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Ann Spiro to Mark Koeppel Feldman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Feldman of Sands Point, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Leroy Anderson Tribute Includes Piano Concerto
description: HARDLY a pops concert goes by without something by Leroy Anderson: "Blue Tango," perhaps, or "Fiddle Faddle" or "Belle of the Ball" or any of the dozens of his other delectable miniatures. Anderson lived in Woodbury, and along with his composition work, he served as manager of the Waterbury Symphony for seven years, until his death in 1975. How appropriate that Frank Brieff, who became music director of the Waterbury Symphony that year, has chosen to remember Anderson with a concert tribute on Friday and Saturday evenings at 8:15 in Kennedy Auditorium in Waterbury.

title: Rescue Crews Stars of TV Series
description: THE red lights are flashing, the sirens are screaming, the 911 emergency telephone number is in danger of being overloaded, and the alarming chatter over the squawk box seems endless.

title: New Approach Is Offered for a White Plains Mall
description: STUNG by the effects of the recession, a White Plains developer has scaled down his proposal for a 75-store high-fashion shopping mall on the former Alexander's department store site. He has offered instead a 25-store complex that would attract bargain-conscious shoppers.

title: 2 Slain and 3 Wounded in Harlem Shooting
description: Two men were shot and killed late Friday in a Harlem grocery store where they had gathered with friends to play dominoes, the police said. Three other men were wounded but survived.

title: Austrian Skier Dies After Race Fall
description: An Austrian ski racer in his first year on the World Cup circuit today died of injuries suffered during a qualifying run for the Lauberhorn World Cup races.

title: Popular Music Creeps In
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Catholic University; Program Reflects Cultural Heritage Of Young Orators
description: It was Jill Washington's first time speaking before an audience, but she took the stage at Catholic University of America's Hartke Theater without a trace of nervousness. As she began to recite the Langston Hughes poem "The Weary Blues," the fourth-grader's voice became deep and sorrowful like that of an old man singing the blues.

title: A Chance to Learn About Intaglio and to Enjoy It
description: PRINTMAKING, like bronze casting, is a process that must be seen to be understood. Failing this, there is the current show at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Museum, on the Rutgers campus here.

title: Wall Street; Trouble as Defaults Rise
description: When demand for credit-enhanced securities took off in the 80's, many banks gladly offered to act as a lender of last resort. And why not? In exchange for promising to cash out bondholders in a pinch, the banks collected fees ranging from one-half of 1 percent to 2 percent of the issues. And unlike interest income, which is earned slowly over the life of a loan, fee income lifts profits immediately.

title:
RUTGERS-NEW BRUNSWICK JOURNAL;
Helping Female Science Students Form Bonds
description: HELP, advise and encourage are the watchwords of a program for 100 undergraduate women living in Douglass College's Bunting-Cobb Math, Science and Engineering Hall. For some, the program may provide just the help needed to reinforce their decisions to seek careers in mathematics and science.

title: Is Old Landfill Near School a Risk?
description: A DECISION by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to cap the 35-acre Syosset landfill to prevent ground-water contamination is raising questions over whether the procedure poses health risks for the 300 children at an adjacent elementary school.

title: Pax Americana; What the United States Has Taken On In the Gulf, Besides a War
description: IT takes a long time to plan a war, but it takes an even longer time to design a peace. Many people are already beginning to ask: If the anti-Iraq coalition emerges victorious from this conflict, what will the peace look like and how long will the United States have to remain heavily involved in the Persian Gulf?

title: In the Age of the 'Black Box' War
description: For the past several decades, the Pentagon and the military contracting industry have spent billions of dollars developing sophisticated electronics capabilities, betting that advanced technology would give the United States a decisive advantage in any war. In the skies over Iraq and Kuwait last week, their strategy was put to its first real test, and the preliminary results seem to be good news for the military and its weapons suppliers.

title: Montana to Rice: Scoring in Sync
description: Pass by pass, yard by yard, touchdown by touchdown, Joe Montana and Jerry Rice have ascended together. As the 49ers awaited the National Conference championship game with the Giants today, their quarterback and wide receiver form arguably the classic combination of passer and pass catcher. Montana's arm, Rice's hands. Montana's accuracy, Rice's speed. Montana's sense of when Rice is open, Rice's sense of when Montana knows he's open. But other reasons exist.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: THINK GREEN

title: Canvas Flapping Loudly in the Dark
description: In the dark on Friday night, a white Lincoln Town Car with three people inside turned off Route 219, drove with scanning headlights through the snow-covered parking lot and then along the road that circles Rich Stadium. The large arena, which will be the site of the American Football Conference championship game between the Buffalo Bills and the Los Angeles Raiders this afternoon, was dark, except for a blinking red aerial light on a few of its light towers. It is in a desolate area and the structure at this moment appeared like something from a science-fiction movie. Overhead a helicopter with red and green lights hung in the black sky.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MEMORY OF KIN Stories About Family by Black Writers. Edited by Mary Helen Washington. Doubleday, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $12.95.

title: Urban Disarmament and Uncle Sam
description: Guns accounted for 7 out of 10 of the appalling 2,200 homicides in New York City last year. The police are moving more aggressively against illegal gun dealers, but there is only so much they can do, in New York and other big cities, without new Federal laws against interstate gun-running.

title: Surprising Woven Works
description: THE gray winter light filtering in through the large windows of an 1848 Italianate villa here reveals top-notch work by 15 of the nation's most innovative fiber artists. Despite the time warp, the setting seems appropriate.

title: All Unions Have Stake In Teamsters' Elections
description: Perhaps no union has been blamed more for the blemishes of organized labor than the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, with its history of autocracy, intimidation and corruption. Yet the teamsters are preparing to hold elections that could rank among the fairest and most democratic in the history of organized labor.

title: Jumping In With Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Janina Valdez Marries Walter Terry
description: Janina Valdez, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Valdez of San Antonio, was married there yesterday to Walter Bliss Terry Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Terry of Peapack, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. William Martin and the Rev. Edward A. Schroder, an Episcopal priest, at St. Peter's Prince of the Apostles Roman Catholic Church.

title: What Business Can Teach the Schools
description: With their ability to compete undermined by poorly trained graduates from failing public schools, many companies have been forced to pick up the pieces. In fact, business has become America's second-largest educator. It now spends a record $40 billion a year on education, about three-quarters of this to teach workers basic skills they should have learned in school.

title:
Your Own Account;
Eliminating Chaos From Investing
description: In times of great political and economic uncertainty like these, investors worry that they simply can't digest all the conflicting reports and make the right decisions about their investments. Should they move to stocks? To cash?

title: Nonprofit Groups Need A Sense of Mission
description: The article "Hard Times Strain the Spirit of Giving" [ Dec. 16 ] , considered the situations of several nonprofits in Westchester and offered the conclusion that the current economic climate has weakened their financial positions. Because there are more nonprofits than profit-making organizations in the county, the issue is important.

title: The World; Experts Say Oil Shocks Are Unlikely To Go Away
description: THE oil price fever that has burned since August -- the industrial world's third bout with the malady since 1973 -- was broken last week when traders concluded that the intense air raids on Iraq had eliminated the threat to Saudi installations. The price of crude fell by more than $10 overnight and ended the week at a level lower than before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait.

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. War Plan: Still the Ground to Conquer
description: Though there is hope in the Pentagon that Iraqi forces might collapse before the allied bombing campaign ends, the more likely scenario for the next stage of the Persian Gulf war involves the far more dangerous task of pushing President Saddam Hussein's army out of Kuwait with a ground campaign.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Jackson Hole
description: Jackson Hole is often billed as "the last and best of the Old West," and it does a good job living up to that standard.
