Visitors to the town of Jackson, one of several communities in the valley of Jackson Hole, hear the tromp of boots on boardwalks around the Town Square; wooden signs outnumber neon, and the townspeople hold onto an Old West sense of hospitality.

title: Marinovich Positive
description: One week after he was suspended from the Southern Cal football team for missing a mandatory team meeting and failing to register for the spring semester, Todd Marinovich, the Trojans' star quarterback, has apparently sought to patch things up with Coach Larry Smith.

title: Garrison Seethes as Its Town Grows Independent of Soviets
description: At the home base of Soviet Army Paratroop Division No. 93613 here in Lithuania's second city, the garrison museum features proud displays of the division's role in suppressing democracy movements in Hungary in 1956 and Czechoslovakia in 1968.

title: An Irredeemable Clan
description: THE PALACE OF THE WHITE SKUNKS By Reinaldo Arenas. Translated by Andrew Hurley. 356 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.

title: Beauty; THE ROOTS OF ROCK
description: "ALMOST CUT MY HAIR," David Crosby sang 20 years ago. What a tease: Crosby, albeit a little bigger, a little older, is hanging on to what's left of his hair as if it still meant something. It certainly used to. In the late 1960's, the rocker with hair below the ears was a remarkably effective symbol of dissent against everything from the Tet offensive to Mom. But these days, Crosby's straggly head is just that: a straggly head, completely devoid of its original social import. For while the hair of a 90's musician is still a kind of political statement, the politics may be a tad closer to Madison Avenue than Kent State. In other words, radical hair sells records.

title: Starched in Connecticut
description: THE WAY OF THE WASP How It Made America, and How It Can Save It, So to Speak. By Richard Brookhiser. 171 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Western Europe; Citing Missiles, French General Says Gulf War May Last 2 to 3 Months
description: Warning that Iraq may still have as many as 30 mobile missile launchers, France's armed forces chief of staff said today that it was "a reasonable hypothesis" to expect the war in the Persian Gulf to last for two to three months.

title: Headliners; In Crime, Too, Some Gender-Related Inequities
description: BY one measure, at least, violent crime seems to be declining. But as in so many other things, the trend appears to be benefitting men more than women.

title: A Drink of Shampoo? No Thanks
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Just How Sacrosanct Are the Words Inside Quotation Marks?
description: JOURNALISTS have an expression for making up quotations. It is called "piping a quote," as a shepherd might pipe a tune on a flute, making up the melody as he goes along.

title:
MUSIC;
State Opera Will Stage Rarely Seen Verdi Epic
description: THE New Jersey State Opera will open its 25th season next week with two performances of a rarely produced Verdi opera. The company, said its general director and conductor, Alfredo Silipigni, has established a tradition of producing, each season, "a revival, a standard work and a novelty."

title: Rival Liberia Rebels Agree to Cooperate
description: Two rival rebel leaders in Liberia have reached a settlement that could help pave the way for the formation of a government of national unity, news reports monitored here said today.

title: Abandonment By the Coach
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Karyn E. Kirkman Is Wed
description: Karyn Elizabeth Kirkman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Kirkman of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Gerard Lanzano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl N. Lanzano of the Bronx. The Rev. Robert Hundley officiated at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. The bride, a graduate of the University of Connecticut, is a lending officer at the Union Trust Company in Greenwich. Her husband, a computer consultant at General Electric Consulting Services in Fairfield, Conn, has a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A. from Manhattan College and a master's in computer science from Iona College.

title: Learning How to Interrogate Suspects
description: THE attention of everyone in the room was focused on the image of a dark-haired woman on a television screen. Two men were interrogating her; one spoke in gentle, soothing tones, while the other fired staccato bursts of terse, accusatory questions. The woman's eyes darted from man to man.

title: We Learned the Wrong Lessons in Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Stock of Creativity During the Thatcher Years
description: How will the performing arts under Margaret Thatcher be remembered? Politicians may not like it, but we remember an age for its artists rather than for its leaders. Who cares a fig about Mozart's Emperor, Joseph II? We care about Mozart. I don't think Thatcherism bred any Mozarts. The most successful composer of the time was Andrew Lloyd Webber.

title: A la Carte: Lively Noodles
description: THERE are now four Pastas Cafes on Long Island. Two of these cafes opened during 1990. The most recent of them is in Glen Cove. The third, in the Woodbury Commons, opened last February and is now well established.

title: Hamlet Admired the Invader of Poland; What Duncan Said
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE HUDSON OPERA THEATER;
In the Wings, a Fledgling Company With a Grand Dream
description: IT began, as many things do, with a casual conversation between friends: Wouldn't it be nice to start a professional opera company right here in Westchester?

title: Israel Says It Must Strike at Iraqis But Indicates Willingness to Wait
description: Israeli officials insisted today that the second Iraqi missile strike in two days had left them no choice but to retaliate, but they indicated that they were willing to wait in deference to American requests and because of new missile defenses provided and manned by the United States, which are already in place.

title: Corrections
description: A Streetscapes column on Jan. 6 about 515 Park Avenue referred incorrectly to 471 Park as the first luxury apartment house on Park Avenue. The first was at 449. Because of an editing error, both the headline and the index misstated the subject of the article. In addition, the article misstated the location of the now-demolished Mineola Garage. It was at the northeast corner of 59th Street and Park Avenue.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SHAKESPEARE'S LIFE

title: Why the Boom Went Bust
description: WITHIN OUR MEANS The Struggle for Economic Recovery After a Reckless Decade. By Alfred L. Malabre Jr. 167 pp. New York: Random House. $21.

title: Felicity Wilmerding to Wed G. A. Otis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pratt Wilmerding of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Felicity Wilmerding to Gregory Alan Otis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Otis 3d of Basking Ridge, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Koch Puts Sailors to the Test
description: Prospective crew members for William Koch's America's Cup defense syndicate are learning that to become one of yachting's elite sailors they must first approach the sport as if they were players at a National Football League training camp.

title: Why Hussein Hasn't Budged
description: Why did Saddam Hussein reject the face-saving formulas offered to him in order to escape war? The grim answer must be that Mr. Hussein reconciled himself to the inevitability of war, believing that it offered him the best chance for political survival. Indeed, a limited defeat would not only be acceptable but would enable him to emerge victorious.

title: Majoring in Boyfriends
description: EDUCATED IN ROMANCE Women, Achievement, and College Culture. By Dorothy C. Holland and Margaret A. Eisenhart. 273 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: Farcical Maneuverings In 'Lend Me a Tenor'
description: ON Broadway, "Lend Me a Tenor" was a victory of camouflage over content. A front-line cast, a spiffy production and, most of all, the legerdemain of a master director, Jerry Zaks, virtually disguised the inherent witlessness of Ken Ludwig's script.

title: Housing Brought to Life By Volunteer Effort
description: WHEN the legislature established the Connecticut Housing Partnership Program in 1987, the lawmakers neglected to appropriate money to administer it. The innovative program, intended to encourage the growth of low-cost housing, might have remained little more than a dream. But it was brought to life by staff members of the State Housing Department who volunteered their free time.

title: Divinely Disordered
description: NATURE'S CHAOS By James Gleick. Photographs by Eliot Porter. Edited by Janet Russek. 125 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.

title: The World; Is the 'Liberation' of Lithuania The Death Notice for Reform?
description: BACK in the heady first flush of glasnost, one of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's most ardent supporters penned an imaginary debate between a Communist official of the old school and a reformer of the new breed.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: I recenlty ran across Kathy Glass's account of "Climbing Mount Fuji by Night" (Travel, Aug. 26) and enjoyed it very much. However, the author has perpetuated a commonly held, but erroneous Western belief that the words "Fuji-san" may be translated as "the honorable Fuji." This is understandable. Until a short while ago, I had thought the same thing. Then one day, in conversation with some Japanese friends, I heard them refer to another mountain by its name plus "san." Confused, I asked if the use of "san" wasn't reserved for Mount Fuji.

title: Cuba Puts It All On 1991 Games
description: A substantial number of construction workers seemed busy as usual at the new aquatics center on a gray and unusually cool morning here last week. But for all their efforts, one of the walls had still not been erected, a major support beam for the roof sat unattended on the ground, and not a shovelful of dirt had been removed from where the pool will be.

title: Sarah G. Miller, Executive, Wed
description: Sarah Gaines Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Thomas Miller of Dillsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Edward McMichael Shaw, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar M. Shaw of Boston. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill officiated at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights, N.Y.

title: In Hollywood, Class Doesn't Put Up Much of a Struggle
description: Increasingly in recent years movies have been dealing with power issues and class relationships -- inter actions between masters and servants, executives and underlings, yuppies and waitresses, millionaires and hookers, rich aristocrats and social-nobody lawyers. Think of "Reversal of Fortune" and "The Bonfire of the Vanities." Think of "White Palace" and "Pretty Woman." Think of Michael Corleone's struggle for social acceptance in "The Godfather Part III." Think of "Working Girl," or "Driving Miss Daisy" or "Dirty Dancing." Script after script links up clout and cloutlessness, often to stunning box-office effect.

title: Ideas & Trends; As Recycling Becomes A Growth Industry, Its Paradoxes Also Multiply
description: NOT very long ago, recycling had a certain innocent glamour. Collecting old bottles and cans was seen as an easily achieved means for husbanding dwindling resources. Turning in old newspapers not only saved space in the local dump, it preserved forests. Making plastic bottles into new products like park benches and cottony filling for winter jackets made everybody involved feel pleased with themselves.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Howell 149,700 16 Hedgewood Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, fenced yard, eat-in-kitchen, c/a; taxes $2,968. Livingston 203,000 1 Locust Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old split level; family room, 1-car garage, den; taxes $3,681. Ringwood 175,000 82 Catherine Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; skylights, oak kitchen, cathedral ceilings; taxes $3,800. Rumson 165,000 8 Haggers Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; screened porch, fireplace, full basement; taxes $3,100. Short Hills 421,000 290 Long Hill Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; c/a, fireplace, 2-car garage, patio; taxes $5,675. Springfield 157,000 139 Hawthorn Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old split level; 1-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, family room; taxes $3,150. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. 350,000 37 Lookout Circle 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 65-year-old colonial; stone fireplace, playroom, 1-car garage; taxes $7,633. Essex, Conn. 95,000 33 Gates Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 130-year-old colonial; new well, 1-car garage, 0.20-acre; taxes $824. East Islip, L.I. 130,000 94 Meroke Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; new eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $3,200.

title: Newly Militant Indians in Ecuador Unnerve Propertied Class
description: Looking forward to the 500th anniversary of Spain's discovery of the Americas, Ecuador's increasingly militant Indians say they wish that Christopher Columbus never left home.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DR. KING BREAKFAST

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; Turkey's Role in Air Assault Sets Off Fear of Retaliation
description: Turkey's decision to let its territory be used as a second front in the air war against Iraq has deeply divided the Muslim country, with many people worried that they now face retaliatory strikes.

title: Tar Heels Upended By the Blue Devils
description: Thomas Hill scored 20 points and Christian Laettner added 18 as Duke ended some home-court frustration tonight with a 74-60 triumph over North Carolina in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Political Memo; Capitol Is Transformed By the Governor's Pace And Even His Family
description: ELEVEN-YEAR-OLD Lowell P. Weicker 3d plopped down in his father's chair at the State Capitol one recent morning and announced to a roomful of reporters that his first act as governor would be to insure that "nobody has to go to school."

title: True Grit: Quarterbacks From Steel Belt Football
description: Quarterbacks, like most kinds of steel, are not an export commodity in the Rust Belt these days. Time is running out on a golden age. Meanwhile, has the rest of the world noticed that Joe Montana, Jim Kelly and Jeff Hostetler, the quarterbacks, respectively, of the San Francisco 49ers, Buffalo Bills and the New York Giants, three of the four teams in the National Football League's conference championship games, are from western Pennsylvania?

title: Liberating the Slaves and Himself
description: ABRAHAM LINCOLN AND THE SECOND AMERICAN REVOLUTION By James M. McPherson. 173 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: BASIC SERVICES CUT TO IRAQI CAPITAL
description: With its power and water supplies cut and allied bombing raids forcing residents to sleep in bomb shelters and basements, Baghdad seemed increasingly embattled tonight, according to reports reaching here.

title: On the Street; Call It Fashion, American Style
description: Fashion and patriotism often merge and this is one of those times. The American flag is now appearing frequently in the form of the newest leather jacket. White stars are embroidered on a navy leather background and white and red stripes are set into the back of a navy-blue leather jacket. This winter's design is from North Beach Leather. It's by Michael Hoban, who created leather jackets last year emblazoned with highway signs on the backs and elbows. Some bore numbers.

title: No Sign of Terrorism, But F.B.I. Is Preparing
description: Although officials say they have no hard evidence indicating that the war in the Persian Gulf will lead to terroist activity, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an agressive operation to heighten vigilance within the United States against terrorist attacks.

title: Mandatory Vaccinations: What the State Law Requires
description: IN the last 50 years, mandatory vaccination in the United States has virtually wiped out the incidence of crippling and potentially lethal diseases like measles, rubella, polio and whooping cough, also known as pertussis.

title: Deborah Arbit to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Arbit of Highland Park, N.J., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Deborah Arbit, and Dr. Yariv Ephraim, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Shaul Ephraim of Ashdod, Israel. Dr. Arbit, 33 years old, is the chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the State University of New York Health Center in Brooklyn. She graduated from Brandeis University and received her M.D. from the Sackler School of Medicine at Tel Aviv University.

title: Review/Ballet; An Evening Highlighted By Debuts
description: The New York City Ballet made a good case for the persistence of art in the darkest of days with its performance on Thursday evening at the New York State Theater. Some in the audience listened to radios during intermissions for the latest war news. In between, there were intervals of dance whose sublimity seemed more than ever to be cherished.

title: Robin A. Stafford To Marry in June
description: Jane T. Kendrick of Woodbury, Conn., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Robin Anne Stafford and Mark Harril Saunders, the son of Harold H. Saunders of Falls Church, Va., and the late Barbara M. Saunders.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Brookville 880,000 Regina Lane 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; pool w/cabana, tennis court, 2-bedroom guest cottage, 3-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $13,000. East Islip 130,000 94 Meroke Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old ranch; new eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $3,200. Glen Cove 325,000 3 Sherman Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 34-year-old ranch; new eat-in kitchen, family room, fireplace, finished basement, pool; taxes $5,100. Kings Park 155,000 2 Stattel Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; new windows and roof, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. Lattingtown 229,000 26 Egypt Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 70-year-old colonia; 2 fireplaces, den, 1-car garage, 0.50-acre; taxes $1,700. Northport 137,000 33 Royal Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, den w/fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. 350,000 37 Lookout Circle 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 65-year-old colonial; stone fireplace, playroom, 1-car garage; taxes $7,633. Essex, Conn. 95,000 33 Gates Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 130-year-old colonial; new well, 1-car garage, 0.20-acre; taxes $824. Howell, N.J. 149,700 16 Hedgewood Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, fenced yard, eat-in-kitchen, c/a; taxes $2,968.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in a Streetscapes column on Dec. 23 about the Andrew Carnegie Garage, the name of the director of the Horace Mann School's nursery program was misspelled. She is Frances Fein.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep up with new seed and nursery catalogues as they arrive. If seed has been planted indoors, keep the pots or trays out of direct sunlight until germination; then move them into good light. Use sand or cat-box filler on icy walks. Allow ice to melt off plants naturally; careless hacking may damage woody plants.

title:
ART;
Linking Czech Historical Eras
description: THE current exhibition of 20th-century Czechoslovakian art, on view through April 10 at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, is as frustrating as it is enlightening.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Weapons; Scud Missiles: An Arsenal of Terror
description: Iraq's surface-to-surface Scud missiles have always been more a weapon of terror than of destruction.

title: Australian Open
description: At the Australian Open, the three top seeded players in both the men's and women's singles draws advanced to the round of 16 in Melbourne. Stefan Edberg, seeded first, needed nearly three hours to beat a rejuvenated Pat Cash in four sets, to join Boris Becker (No. 2) and Ivan Lendl (No. 3). In the surprise of the day, Mats Wilander upset Brad Gilbert and will play Jaime Yzaga of Peru in the fourth round.

title: James A. Clendinen, A Newspaper Editor In Tampa, Dies at 80
description: James Augustus Clendinen, who in 27 years as the editor of The Tampa Tribune in Florida helped bring about many government reforms in his city and state, died Friday at Tampa General Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Real Pain in Wall Street Layoffs
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
A Touch of the Great Outdoors in Rye
description: DINING at the the Black Bass Grille is like dining at Abercrombie & Fitch or L. L. Bean. Adirondack lodge-style walls are studded with such equipment as creels, snowshoes, canoe paddles and photographs of serious fishing. It all suggests that explorer-adventurer types will feel at home here, lace curtains notwithstanding. Others, too, appeared to enjoy the room's comfortable rusticity; the place attracts a steady clientele that fills the restaurant throughout the week.

title: Quinnett, Starks Spur Knicks' Upset
description: When John MacLeod announced tonight's starting lineup, the Knicks were surprised. And when the lineup change worked to perfection, the Philadelphia 76ers were surprised, too.

title: Travel Advisory; Australia Cuts Some Air Fares
description: Deregulation of Australia's airlines has meant lower fares on selected routes, but the major carriers, Australian and Ansett, say visitors from the United States save almost as much by reserving flights in Australia when purchasing their international ticket before leaving home.

title: The Catskills Story, in Oral History
description: AS a resort and entertainment Mecca, the Catskills have suffered some lean years, especially since the emergence of, first, Las Vegas, and, secondly, Atlantic City.

title: We Learned the Wrong Lessons in Vietnam; Administering Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books
description: RISK N' ROSES By Jan Slepian. 175 pp. New York: Philomel Books. $14.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Thousands in Bulgaria Without Heat in Crisis
description: Dozens of enterprises and tens of thousands of apartments in Plovdiv, this fuel-starved country's second biggest city, were without heat today, an official said.

title: The New World Order So Far
description: Troops from more than 15 countries, backed by stern authority of the United Nations, last week began to fight Iraq in the first post-cold-war war. They share goals that are both limited and lasting: to drive Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, and in the process to establish a "new world order" assuring that collective security, not the law of the jungle, replaces the recent pattern of proxy conflicts and thermonuclear deterrence.

title: Another Tennis Program for Tots
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cynthia Anne Thomas To Wed D. E. MacLean
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leo J. Thomas of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Anne Thomas to David Edward MacLean, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Albert MacLean of Long Boat Key, Fla. A July wedding is planned.

title: Metro Dateline; An Off-Duty Officer Is Shot in Argument
description: An off-duty police officer was shot in the leg during a dispute with another man in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said.

title: Postings: For the Poor and Homeless; A Phoenix in the Bronx
description: When a fire in 1989 gutted the 66-year-old Louise Chazin Apartments, a once grand, five-story apartment house in the Bronx, it was something like putting a building out of its misery. For years, it had been vacant, decayed and owned by the city.

title: RULING THREATENS MANY DRUG CASES
description: A judge's ruling has raised the prospect that hundreds of drug cases in Louisiana may have to be thrown out because of a mistake by the State Legislature.

title: The World; War Offers Turkey a Chance to Take a Larger Role
description: THE Turks may record the Persian Gulf crisis as the occasion when they proved they still count -- assuming, that is, that the war goes well, which here means above all that not a drop of Turkish blood is shed.

title: Varied Productions Visit Stamford
description: AN affectionate down-home folk tale recounts the coming of age of a black farmer from North Carolina in the late 1950's and 60's. Highlights: his five-year prison term for refusing to fight in Vietnam, his detour to "a very, very large American city" to sample the seamy side of life, his return to his boyhood sweetheart -- and his roots. Critical consensus: "sweet, simple, funny and endearing."

title: BEST SELLERS: January 20, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 9 2 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) On the eve of his retirement, a member of British intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy. 2 1 14 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age. 3 4 11 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 4 2 19 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 5 3 8 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and romantic life of an eighth-generation California woman who becomes a celebrity photographer. 6 7 8 JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician uses genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park. 7 6 22 MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 8 8 32 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death. 9 13 5 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets, with surprising results for those past and present. 10 15 2 THE FOURTH K, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $22.) The tumultuous career of President Francis Xavier Kennedy, cousin of John and Robert Kennedy and inheritor of their charisma. 11 10 34 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 12 1 VITAL SIGNS, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $21.95.) A physician's quest for fertility brings her horrifying experiences in America, Australia and China. 13 11 16 LADY BOSS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) Lucky Santangelo schemes and maneuvers to get control of a major movie studio. 14 47 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 15 4 CROW AND WEASEL, by Barry Lopez. Illustrated by Tom Pohrt. (North Point, $16.95.) A fable about a journey through the wilderness. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 10 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The memoirs of the itinerant television newscaster. 2 4 9 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 3 2 15 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 4 1 THE NEW RUSSIANS, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A former Moscow correspondent surveys the profound changes in the Soviet Union during the past 15 years. 5 3 10 BO KNOWS BO, by Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The autobiography of the athlete who plays baseball for the Kansas City Royals and football for the Los Angeles Raiders. 6 6 17 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House. 7 14 24 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 8 7 14 THE CAT AND THE CURMUDGEON, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) The continuing contentions of two curmudgeons. 9 8 18 GET TO THE HEART, by Barbara Mandrell with George Vecsey. (Bantam, $19.95.) The autobiography of the country-music singer. 10 * 13 10 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. 11 2 GOD, COUNTRY, NOTRE DAME, by Theodore M. Hesburgh with Jerry Reedy. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The autobiography of the theologian and former president of the University of Notre Dame. 12 1 THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The nature of God and salvation as perceived by Christian, Jewish and Muslim children. 13 13 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. 14 11 6 SUDDENLY, by George F. Will. (Free Press, $19.95.) Essays about America's success in the cold war and the strains now developing in its society. 15 5 10 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $8.95.) An illustrated gift edition of the inspirational essay, with new commentary. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 7 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) Ways to manage your money. 2 2 23 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you and use it to deal with today's problems. 3 95 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's financial advice. 4 6 7 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. 5 4 57 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrated games. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: Sharyn West Engaged to R. S. Sheldon
description: Dr. and Mrs. Theodore L. West of Closter, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharyn Rebecca West, to Richard Stephen Sheldon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack C. Sheldon of London. A June wedding is planned.

title: Demure, Bulletproof and Ready to Bristle
description: At Femme Fatale Security Ltd., an agency that employs women as bodyguards, when the women need something to wear on the job they head for the Seventh Avenue showroom of Jiuliana Originals, which carries a line of bulletproof clothing, from parkas and windbreakers to trench coats and furs.

title: Gorbachev Aide Who Quit Doubts Pledge for a Free Market
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's personal economic adviser said today that he resigned this week because of doubts that the Soviet leader would fulfill his promise to introduce a market economy.

title: G. A. Kerr to Wed Dorothy Escher
description: July wedding plans for Dorothy Schuyler Escher and Gilbert Alan Kerr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kerr of Larchmont, N.Y., have been announced by her mother, Mrs. David A. Escher of Englewood, N.J.

title: Chess
description: Ninety-nine times out of a hundred, it is folly to let your king be compelled to move in the opening, but there is no "always" in chess.

title: All About/Fish Farming; Sparing the Rod, Seeding the Pond, Americans Grow More Fish to Eat
description: Chances are one in four that the seafood you eat in a restaurant or at home was farmed, not caught. For a diner at one of the 247 Bob Evans Restaurants, mostly in the South and Midwest, the odds are 100 percent, because the menu's two fish dishes -- fried catfish and Cajun-style catfish -- are raised, not hooked or netted.

title: A Mexican Village Preserves the Rebozo's Flair
description: AS a young man, Cecilio Duarte left his native Santa Maria del Rio, in the state of San Luis Potosi, to find work wherever he could. Over the years he worked as a carpenter, a baker and a heavy laborer in Mexico City and Monterrey. But he always managed to return for Santa Maria's yearly festival. During one of those trips home he found out about a new school operated by the state government. He had no idea what he was getting into but decided he was tiring of traveling and was willing to take a chance on something new. Today, at 51, Mr. Duarte is a master weaver and teacher at Santa Maria's Escuela del Rebozo, the same school he took a chance on more than 30 years ago.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Tradition as Change Roxana Waterson argues that "tradition" within a society is actually an active, essential process that never ceases accumulating and discarding ideas -- rather than the unthinking worship of the past with which we often confuse the term. This is from "The Living House: An Anthropology of Architecture in South-East Asia" (Oxford University).

title:
Gardening;
A Showy Meadow Has Many Facets
description: The concept, indeed the image, of a meadowland is as varied as the number of individuals entertaining the thought. There is no clear and concise definition, but I believe there is an ideal of what a meadow should be: a natural, peaceful bit of grassland, remote from cares and worries, yet accessible for retreat and rest.

title: Signs of Growth in the Hispanic Market
description: "THERE are already 85,000 to 90,000 Hispanic residents of Westchester and more are coming in every day," said Manuel Duran, explaining why he decided to publish El Heraldo de Nueva York, the county's second Spanish-language newspaper.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Nearby Deer Hunters

title: At Home on Morning Radio
description: ON a sleety, slushy made-for-radio-listening morning in New York City, Howard Stern is discussing sex. A turn of the dial and another talk-show host, Don Imus, is talking about sex. But tune in WOR-AM, and John R. Gambling is talking about a lost dog he took into his home on Long Island.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: In his article about Milan (Travel, Dec. 2), Paul Hofmann referred to the restaurant Gualtiero Marchesi as the only restaurant in Italy to have three Michelin stars. There is another, Antica Osteria del Ponte, just south of Milan in the little town of Cassinetta di Lugagnano.

title: On Language; MAIL CALL (ALL CAPS)
description: IF YOU WERE SITTING there addressing mail all day, and you wanted a new sense of bureaucratic self-importance, what would you call what you were doing? You would call it "outputting addresses to mailpieces."

title: Chana Goldsmith To Wed in March
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Sheldon D. Goldsmith of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Chana Goldsmith to David Aaron Felsenthal, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Felsenthal of Baltimore. A March wedding is planned.

title: Tech Notes; Diatek's Aural Thermometer
description: Using infrared sensors developed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to measure remotely the temperatures of planets and stars, a company based in San Diego has developed a thermometer that measures human body temperature in less than two seconds. The new thermometer works by sensing the infrared radiation emitted by the ear's tympanic membrane, commonly known as the eardrum. Developed by the Diatek Corporation with the the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, the Model 7000 Infrared Temperature-Taking System does not come into contact with mucous membranes, and is thus intended to minimize concerns about spreading infections among patients. "The challenge was to design Diatek's sensor so the instrument could make accurate measurements of a patient's temperature by using a hand-held portable device," said Philip Faris, Diatek's president. The company estimates that the worldwide market for electronic and infrared thermometers could total $126 million.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Jan. 6 about Turkish place names misrendered the Greek phrase for Black Sea attributed to Euripides. It is Pontos Melas.

title: THEY KNOW BO
description: Well, we know one thing. Based on her letter (Dec. 16) in response to Warren Berger's article, "They Know Bo" (Nov. 11), Amanda Merwin of Swarthmore, Pa. doesn't know "Diddly."

title: Campus Life: U.C., Santa Barbara; Easing Tensions Between Town And Gown
description: Surrounded on three sides by the Pacific Ocean, the University of California at Santa Barbara assumed what critics considered a haughty position when it announced to the surrounding community that it intended to expand physically by 60 percent within the next l5 years.

title: Dwindling Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Charges Denied
description: The former Loyola Marymont basketball coach, Paul Westhead, has denied charges that he asked a cardiologist to reduce medication being given to the Marymount star, Hank Gathers, a week before Gathers died of a heart ailment last March 4.

title: Commercial Property: The West Side Viaduct; Conrail Looking to a Revival of Its Freight Traffic
description: WITH demolition under way on the southern end of New York Central's unused elevated freight railroad through the industrial West Side of Manhattan, the Federal Government last week rebuffed an effort by local property owners to force an abandonment of the entire line.

title: Ross Is Truly No. 1
description: His team claimed the No. 1 position in the final Associated Press poll of football writers and broadcasters, so it should come as no surprise that the Football Writers Association of America has named Bobby Ross of Georgia Tech the winner of the Bear Bryant Award as the college football coach of the year. (AP)

title: Michele S. Koenig Is Wed To Robert Barry Shapiro
description: Michele Susan Koenig, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Koenig of Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday evening to Robert Barry Shapiro, a son of Joel Shapiro of New York and Ann Shapiro of Hewlett, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster and Cantor Avraham Albrecht officiated.

title: Jennifer K. Petite, Designer, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Michael James Petite of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Kristin Petite, to Anthony A. Sirianni 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sirianni 2d of Todt Hill, S.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Social Events
description: Helping the Lighthouse

title: A Museum Looks at a Gift Horse, Not in the Mouth
description: "He brought out the hero in the common man. The timeless in the everyday," proclaim the advertisements in The New Yorker, Art in America and other magazines. The man in question is the photographer Paul Strand (1890-1976), whose first retrospective exhibition in 20 years is now appearing at the National Gallery of Art. The ads are paid for by Southwestern Bell Corporation, the exhibition's sponsor and major lender -- and thereby hangs a tale, of a show profoundly compromised by its origins.

title: HARLEM'S ARDENT VOICE
description: THE REV. CALVIN O. BUTTS 3D HAS JUST been badly disappointed by a telephone call. His effort to arrange a meeting with a major religious leader has been rejected. Sitting in his modest office, the 20th pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem pauses for a moment to regain his composure. Finally, he leans forward in the way he has of making every conversation seem intimate. An uncommon weariness creeps into his voice. "I came from the left," says Butts, joining his palms over the left edge of his cluttered desk. "I moved to the center because I have this institution." The hands shift to the middle of the desk. "I'm trying to work in the center." He shrugs inside his double-breasted suit. "I don't want people to be surprised when I finally flip out. I want people to know we did try and we were rejected. "

title: A Hypersensitive Nose for the Next New Thing
description: With apologies to Hollywood, "quest for art" may be the phrase that best describes the varied career of the American artist Robert Morris, currently the subject of a large exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. It fits the restless, searching way that this erstwhile Minimalist sculptor has moved from style to style over the last 30 years, teetering from one cutting edge to the next without ever quite losing his balance.

title: Tips for Staying Healthier on the Road
description: WITH the weather turning colder, a lot of people are making plans for travel to warmer places. Dr. Kenneth R. Dardick of Mansfield, the author of the recently published "Foreign Travel and Immunization Guide" (Medical Economics Books, Oradell, N.J.), is a principal in the Center for International Health and developer of Immunization Alert, a computer compilation of international health data. Dr. Dardick, 44 years old, is a family practicioner. A graduate of Dartmouth College and Harvard Medical School, he was born in New York City and grew up in the Danbury area.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The towel rack in our bathroom has pulled out of the wall, leaving a hole in the dry wall. The rack was apparently secured with plaster inside the wall. How can we remount this towel rack without tearing up the wall?

title: 'Mr. Mozart' Comes to Lincoln Center
description: Musicology, like many other forms of scholarship, is largely a private pursuit. And Neal Zaslaw, a Mozart specialist based at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., who also teaches at the Juilliard School, is a master of the solitary side of his profession. By all accounts, his scholarship is impeccable. Even the few colleagues who miss a certain imaginative vision in his work agree that the seriousness and thoroughness of his research are beyond reproach. "He's a bulldog in the library," said John Spitzer, who is collaborating with Mr. Zaslaw on a history of the pre-Classical orchestra.

title: Providence Upsets Connecticut, 108-102
description: Eric Murdock scored 22 of his 30 points in the second half tonight as Providence overcame a 17-point deficit for a 108-102 Big East Conference victory over No. 13 Connecticut.

title: Coming to Grips With Demography
description: To the Editor:

title: FURTHER PRESSURE IS PUT ON LATVIA
description: The Tass news agency today published a statement by an anonymous All-Latvian Committee of National Salvation declaring that it was assuming all powers of state over the Latvian republic and dissolving the elected government, which seeks independence.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MICHAEL G. MRUZ;
Fighting the Fear on the Home Front
description: SINCE Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, the newscasts and newspapers have been filled with projections about American casualties in the event of fighting and fears about what the Middle East would be like after a war.

title: Mutual Funds; Going Undercover to Find Service
description: The woman seemed like any other investor. She mailed an application and a $5,000 check to open a mutual fund account. A few weeks later, she switched money from a stock fund to a money market fund. She called the fund, asking to take dividends in cash. She filled out the paperwork needed to change her address. After three months, she closed the account.

title: A Parisian Trip to the 1700's
description: COUNT MOISE DE CAMONDO was in love with the 18th century. In the decades before his death in 1935, the Count, a wealthy French businessman and vice president of the Union of Decorative Arts, amassed a magnificent collection of Louis XV and XVI furniture and paintings, Aubusson, Savonnerie and Beauvais tapestries and Sevres, Meissen and Chinese porcelain.

title: Rachel B. Redd, Banker, Marries
description: Rachel Barton Redd, a daughter of Marianna Redd of Portland, Ore., and Richard Redd of Bethlehem, Pa., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Roney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Roney of Syracuse. The Rev. Hubert L. Flesher, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Packer Chapel at Lehigh University in Bethlehem.

title: Rudolph Rella, Pressman, 62
description: Rudolph Rella, the general foreman of the pressroom of The New York Times, died on Friday at his home in Sayreville, N.J. He was 62 years old.

title: N.B.A. Fight Brings a Lesson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Roseanne McHugh Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. McHugh of Seaford, L.I., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Roseanne Mary McHugh and Bard Mayhew Stephens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McLeod Stephens of St. Louis and Jacksonville, Fla. Miss McHugh, a graduate of Siena College, is an assistant vice president at Kidder Peabody in New York and is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Fordham University. Mr. Stephens, a graduate of the University of Florida, is a financial consultant in St. Louis with Paine Webber.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The President; Bush Urges Israeli Restraint In Phone Appeals to Shamir
description: President Bush called Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel twice this morning from Camp David and later dispatched two senior officials to Israel to express concern about the second Iraqi missile attack on Tel Aviv and his continuing hope that Israel would let the United States retaliate on its behalf.

title: A.F.C. Matchup 30 Years in Making
description: With a community's intense anticipation muted by events in the Middle East, the Buffalo Bills and the Los Angeles Raiders are expected to conduct the kind of business Sunday that somehow never took place in their American Football League days.

title: Giants Take a New Shot at the Top
description: The 49ers are an elite team that often struggles, but still finds ways to win. The Giants are a good but not elite team that often teeters on the brink of defeat, but usually wins.

title:
ART;
Gallery's Newest Members Display Variety and Innovation
description: FOR 10 years, Art/Place, an artist-run gallery, has occupied the railroad station on the southbound side of the tracks in Southport. In a comfortable arrangement, the gallery maintains the waiting room. When a train roars past, the vibrations misalign some of the smaller works. Watching them being straightened, one appreciates that this is a true hands-on gallery.

title: Belichick Is Anointed As the Latest Genius
description: To a large degree, the Giants' chances against the 49ers in Sunday's conference championship game rest on the genius of their defensive coordinator, Bill Belichick. He is living proof that genius can appear early in life.

title: We Learned the Wrong Lessons in Vietnam; Arab-American Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Campbell, Lawyer, to Wed
description: The engagement of Catherine Suzanne Campbell to Arthur Lott Scinta, a son of Marilyn D. Keating of Massapequa, L.I., and Arthur H. Scinta of Jensen Beach, Fla., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Shepherd S. Campbell of Murrells Inlet, S.C. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Scoop Before Dying
description: RUMOR HAS IT By Charles Dickinson. 232 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Boston;
Trade Center About to Grow
description: PLANS for a $400 million, 1.7 million-square-foot addition to the World Trade Center in the Fort Point Channel district of Boston Harbor are moving forward following its approval by the city. The co-developer expects the final element of the environmental impact statement to be approved by the state shortly.

title: A Grant Ends, but Not the Advice
description: THE funds have run out, but the free advice will continue. So says Helaine Lesnick, manager of the Energy Conservation Program that for three years has provided nonprofit agencies with money, expertise and, in some cases, energy-conserving equipment.

title: Campus Life: Cincinnati; Hoping Children Learn Happily Ever After
description: There are variations of the Cinderella story in countless cultures, and Anndrena Belcher was spinning an Appalachian version. The heroine was a luckless young woman named Ashpet, and her Prince Charming was a wealthy man who wanted her to join him in New York. Ashpet refuses, but they eventually marry and live happily ever after in Appalachia.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Jan. W. Doeff (Letters, Nov. 18) paints a misleading picture of today's Soviet Union. Dr. Doeff bought some Russian articles on the street and paid with dollars. His letter said that "everybody else seemed to be doing" it. Dr. Doeff was approached by the police, detained for two hours, made to sign a confession and was then led to a taxi. The conclusion drawn in the letter is that "the instruments of repression are untouched and can be turned on at a moment's notice."

title: Pentagon's List
description: Following is a partial list, released by the Pentagon, of Americans missing in action in the Persian Gulf.

title: Redefining 'Affordability' for the 90's
description: MORE than a decade after soaring real estate values made "affordable housing" a rallying cry across much of the nation, economists, builders and community activists are challenging deeply ingrained assumptions about how much Americans can -- or should -- pay for housing.

title: Karen Aboud to Wed Jason P. Hauben
description: Sylvia Aboud of Riverdale, the Bronx, has announced the engagement of her daughter Karen Elizabeth Aboud to Jason Paul Hauben, a son of Carolyn Hauben of Providence, R.I., and Bruce Hauben of Stow, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Outdoors; Honors for a Leading Protector of International Salmon
description: Admirers of the Atlantic salmon, regarded by many as the world's supreme game and food fish, will be able to meet Richard Buck, one of the species' most vocal and indefatigable champions, when the Connecticut River Salmon Association holds its 16th annual dinner on Saturday.

title: War's Success Hurts the Dollar
Wall Street; When the Bank Can't Back the Bond
description: When Tierney Properties Inc. of Pittsfield, Mass., raised $7.5 million from the public debt market in 1987, investors who ordinarily shy away from obscure bonds snapped up the issue. After all, a prominent bank had promised to make good on the bonds in the event of a default.

title: Making It
description: BREAKING BARRIERS A Memoir. By Carl T. Rowan. Illustrated. 395 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: Lujan's Son Is Found Guilty In Rape and Burglary Case
description: The son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. was convicted today of rape, sodomy and burglary by an Alexandria Circuit Court jury.

title: A Bicycle Journey in Search of America
description: LAST spring, Kent Sabin mounted an 18-speed bicycle in the driveway of his home here and pedaled off to see the world or, more precisely, the United States. By the time his odyssey ended five and a half months later, he had covered 9,200 miles, visiting 25 states and the province of Ontario in Canada.

title: Technology; How Practical Is the 'Sky Plane'?
description: Back in the late 1950's, Paul Moller had a vision of a lightweight, four-passenger aircraft that could take off from a driveway or city street and then cruise at high speeds and altitudes. It would be a kind of "sky car," that would rise above commuting woes. It was a common vision for forward-looking individuals in those days.

title: Allies Hunt Missiles
description: Allied pilots continued today to search for and attack surface-to-surface missile sites, particularly those in western Iraq that have been used twice in two days to fire missiles into Israel. The operations advanced the air campaign to destroy the forces of President Saddam Hussein in preparation for a ground offensive or to persuade him that further resistance is futile.

title: A Buick Show Car Takes to the Road
description: Think luxury cars today and you'll probably think imports. Mercedes-Benz. BMW. Lexus. Infiniti. You might even think Lincoln or Cadillac, but you probably wouldn't think Buick.

title: Sunday Outing; A Winter Playland, And Views To Prove It
description: Only 40 miles from Manhattan, the Bear Mountain winter sports complex offers ice skating, cross-country skiing, ice fishing, hiking, bird-watching, walking in the woods, picnicking in the snow and a comfortable inn for relaxation.

title: Beverly Grindstaff Weds Peter Tauber
description: Beverly Grindstaff and Peter Tauber were married yesterday at the Pearl Street Inn in Boulder, Colo. Judge David R. Torke of the 20th District of the State Court of Appeals in Colorado officiated.

title: At Airports, Passengers Pay A Price for Eastern's Demise
description: Elizabeth Rosa arrived at Newark International Airport early yesterday morning with her luggage and a confirmed reservation for an Eastern Airlines flight to San Juan. "At the counter, they told me they no longer exist," she said, still looking a little stunned.

title: String Rarities: 'A Little Bit of Pluck'
description: IT is another busy musical Sunday, with more than a half-dozen concerts in the area. Today at 2 P.M., the Philharmonia Virtuosi presents another of the delightful "Coffee Concerts" at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, with coffee and pastry served at 1 P.M.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Press and U.S. Officials at Odds on News Curbs
description: Three days into the fighting, the United States Government continues to exercise tight control over news of the war, withholding information about the extent of the bombing and the destruction in Iraq and restricting interviews with troops and returning pilots.

title: Corrections
description: The Art column of the Connecticut Weekly on Dec. 2 about exhibits at the William Benton Museum at Storrs misidentified an artist. She is Li-Lan, not Lin-Yan. The museum has pointed out the error in a letter received at The Times this Thursday.

title:
POP MUSIC;
The Auteur Theory of Music Video Means No More Pretty Cliches
description: When MTV appeared in August 1981, the art world watched with a hopeful but skeptical eye -- hopeful that the four-minute audio-visual format could become a vanguard genre born of the marriage of music and moving images, skeptical of its innate commercialism and teen-age target audience.

title: Mr. Hussein, Please Surrender
description: From the way the world's markets reacted last week, one would have thought that victory in Iraq had already been won. The Dow Jones industrial average gained more points than it ever had in a week, amid general rejoicing over early success in the air war.

title: Jupiter, a Quiet Corner of Florida
description: NOT all of Florida is a stage set for "Miami Vice."

title: ABC Makes an Effort To Reassure Children
description: Prompted by concerns that live scenes from the war front might frighten children more accustomed to seeing the skirmishes of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, ABC News took time yesterday morning to explain the war to youngsters during a special report on the Persian Gulf conflict.

title: Style Makers; Michael Roman, Print Artist
description: Michael Roman, a Manhattan print artist, combines the art of myth, ritual and ethnic culture with fashion.

title: Janis Cohen Engaged To Wed Rodd Schlerf
description: The engagement of Janis Ellen Cohen to Rodd Warren Schlerf, a son of Gilbert Schlerf of East Islip, L.I., and Joanna Glenn of Wilmington, Del., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Cohen of Wheatley Heights, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Krone On Road Back Again
description: Julie Krone slipped into a chair in front of two TV sets in the jockeys' lounge at Aqueduct and stared at the war pictures from the Persian Gulf. She looked like a ballet dancer with mud on her face, a delicate figure at 4 feet 10 1/2 inches and 100 pounds, not counting the 4-inch steel plate and the seven screws holding her left arm together.

title: Scypion Is for Real
description: He and his managers are back in the good graces of Florida boxing authorities, but when Roy Jones Jr. returns to the ring in Pensacola on Jan. 31 for his first sanctioned bout since he knocked out a man who turned out to be an imposter last year, nobody is taking any chances that another ringer might slip into the ring against the 21-year-old middleweight. Jones's opponent in the bout will be Wilford Scypion, a former top contender whose face is familiar to boxing officials.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Security; With No Signs of Terrorism, F.B.I. Still Adds Precautions
description: Federal law-enforcement officials say they have no hard evidence that the Persian Gulf war will lead to terrorist acts in the United States, but they say extra security precautions are justified.

title: With a Great Clamor, Machine Age Enters Gallery
description: IT is a wonder that any work at all is being done in the offices of this town's Municipal Building. The racket coming from the gallery that shares the premises is excruciating: gears grind, metal clangs against metal and interspersed with a whirring sound is the tinkle of Scarlatti-type music played at high speed on an electronic harpsichord.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan; JORDANIAN PLEADS FOR A CEASE-FIRE
description: Caught between Israel and Iraq and facing increasing risks of embroilment in the Persian Gulf war, King Hussein urged a temporary cease-fire today to give "dialogue and diplomacy" a chance to avert a "tragic disaster."

title: INSIDE
description: Eastern's Fatal Struggle

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Needs of the Old And the Young
description: The "Tenafly Journal" on Dec. 2 describes the admirable achievements of Tenafly's elderly residents in raising $190,000 in public and private funds to enhance their senior center. Their efforts as well as the generosity and assistance of the entire community are to be commended.

title: Headliners; Tribal Democracy
description: The Navajo were among the most feared opponents of white settlers until they were starved into submission in the 1860's, when Kit Carson orchestrated the slaughter of their sheep herds. But after making their peace with Washington in 1868, they were among the most successful native Americans in their adaptation to the changing world, particularly since the discovery of oil and gas under their sprawling Arizona lands in the 1960's. But with relative wealth, they also discovered political corruption, which led in 1989 to the first suspension of a tribal leader by the tribal council. Since then, the Navajo, who with 219,000 members are America's largest Indian tribe, have worked to reshape their government along more democratic lines. Last week, they inaugurated their first elected tribal president, Peterson Zah, a 62-year-old education consultant who has been active in tribal politics. Addressing an audience of 8,000 Navajos, Mr. Zah said, "In unity, we will demonstrate that we have regained our stability."

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holdiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Optional. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular garbage pickups and recycling. No street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses, subways, L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on regular schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. Some modified bus schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on regular schedule.

title: CRIME
description: Don't be put off by the noisy jacket design for THE CITY WHEN IT RAINS (Putnam, $19.95). Thomas H. Cook's brooding study speaks quietly and soulfully about people who photograph better in black and white: "people who rescued children from cars, rivers, fires, or threw them out of windows." These are the subjects that stir David Corman, a freelance photographer who covers Manhattan after dark, when its guard is down.

title: Alison A. Smith Engaged to John P. Shoemaker
description: The engagement of Alison Avery Smith to John Prevost Shoemaker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin V. Shoemaker of Chatham, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Baldwin Smith of Glen Head, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Skeleton Keys
description: WITNESSES FROM THE GRAVE The Stories Bones Tell. By Christopher Joyce and Eric Stover. Illustrated. 333 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; LONG WAIT BEGINS FOR GROUND FORCES
description: The long, agonizing wait has begun for hundreds of thousands of American ground troops who know that when the air war against Iraq is over, it will be their turn to fight.

title: Looking Ahead
description: SUNDAY: Financial ministers from leading industrialized nations begin a two-day meeting in New York. MONDAY: Martin Luther King holiday. Markets open; many government offices closed. TUESDAY: Postal Service Board of Governors meets to consider postal rates. * Fed Chairman Greenspan testifies before House Budget Committee. WEDNESDAY: Treasury deficit statement for December. * Fed Open Market Committee's beige book regional economic report. THURSDAY: Mid-January auto sales. * Jobless claims for the week ended Jan. 12. FRIDAY: G.N.P. for the fourth quarter.

title: Auto Insurance: A New Option, A New Dispute
description: UNDER recently enacted state regulations, New Jersey drivers who renew or purchase automobile insurance this year will be given the option of designating either their auto insurers or their health insurers as responsible for medical expenses they incur if injured in automobile accidents.

title: R.I.P. Shoreham And Its Energy Rods
description: Every so often we read letters from Long Islanders who express indignation about the closing of the Shoreham plant. They chastise those of us who supported the move and suggest that it's still possible to open the Shoreham plant and provide more electricity for Long Island.

title: Grief and Gloom From a Sting Without a Cause
description: Books, plays and films tell us how great composers and authors transmute private pain into enduring art. What they don't say, however, is that misery doesn't guarantee excellence -- that pain is as likely to strangle inspiration as to stimulate it. When that happens, all that's left is, as Todd Rundgren once called it, "the ever popular tortured-artist effect."

title: Washed Up in Buffalo
description: THE LAST FINE TIME By Verlyn Klinkenborg. 209 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Bridge
description: Until recently, an expert asked to name the toughest test of card playing ability would have hesitated. But now the answer is clear. The Pamp Par Hands contest was the most difficult and challenging event in the history of bridge.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline in some editions yesterday about air strikes in the Persian Gulf misstated American losses. Of the eight allied planes reported lost as of Friday, four were American, not all eight.

title:
Managing;
Miming the Capitalists Is Not Easy
description: On a snowy morning in Merseburg, in eastern Germany, Henning Rost, chairman of the managing board at Mansfeld A.G., led a group of Western bankers and journalists to an overheated conference room near a busy railroad line to hear his company's restructuring plans.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The towel rack in our bathroom has pulled out of the wall, leaving a hole in the dry wall. The rack was apparently secured with plaster inside the wall. How can we remount this towel rack without tearing up the wall?

title: Deadline Looms for Victims of Required DPT Immunizations
description: QUIETLY stacking up in huge boxes at a court building a short distance from the White House are thousands of petitions representing a sad minority among an otherwise healthy majority of citizens.

title: Miss Fields, Teacher, and R. M. Hayes, Head of Coalition for Homeless, Wed
description: Betsy Lynn Fields, a teacher, and Robert Michael Hayes, the founder and chairman of the Coalition for the Homeless in New York, were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York by Rabbi Ronald Sobel.

title: Michele H. Jones, Lawyer, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Jones of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Michele Hewitt Jones to John Robert Delmhorst, a son of Margaret M. Delmhorst of Stonington, Conn., and the late Berton J. Delmhorst. A June wedding is planned.

title: Chicago Goes for the Burn
description: During the summer, they began setting fires across the West and South sides, igniting blazes in a dozen old warehouses and abandoned buildings. City crews would block off the streets, and fire trucks lent by the Chicago Fire Department would roar by, past the crowds of neighborhood youths drawn not only by the smoke and sirens but a small and glamorous army of cameramen and crew members and actors gathered there to make a movie.

title: Gifts to Neediest Put Problems in Perspective
description: For some donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the decision to contribute came only after they had complained and groaned about their own problems. Whether it was a sprained ankle or a strained budget, personal hardship gave many people a perspective on the plight of the poor and inspired them to give to the fund.

title: Data Update
ALLIES INTENSIFY BOMBING OF IRAQI TROOPS; ISRAEL HOLDS FIRE, GETS AMERICAN DEFENSES
description: After three days of concentrated aerial attacks on Iraq and parts of Kuwait, the United States said today that it had air control over many areas of Iraq and was now able to intensify bombardments of the Republican Guards, the elite Iraqi ground forces.

title:
Food;
Street Life
description: THEY HAPPEN FIRST ON THE streets: spandex bicycle shorts, neon clothing, hip-hop, graffiti. Next, they show up in couture showrooms and on gallery walls. Madonna haunted downtown clubs in bustiers and camisoles; a year or two later, Paris designers had the

title: Youth Dies in Concert Crowd
description: One teen-ager was killed and two were seriously injured when they were crushed by a surging crowd at a concert Friday night by the hard rock group AC-DC, the police reported. Police officers found Jimmy Boyd, 14 years old, of Salt Lake City in cardiac arrest on the floor near the stage. Two other teen-agers were also found on the floor and were hospitalized, the police said.

title: Miss von Estorff To Wed in May
description: Mrs. Schacco von Estorff of West Vancouver, British Columbia, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Daniela Donata von Estorff, to Thomas William Rowe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Rowe of Westfield, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Jennifer L. Pariser Weds Stuart Katz
description: Jennifer Lynn Pariser, a daughter of Judge Burton C. Pariser of Mendham, N.J., and the late Susan Miller Pariser, was married last evening at Temple B'nai Or in Morristown, N.J., to Stuart Brian Katz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Katz of Woodbury, L.I. Rabbi David Nesson officiated.

title: Haunting Symbols Mark the Bones Of New Guinea
description: Owl-eyed faces, parrot heads, interlocking human figures, suns within suns and sweeping spirals -- the haunting symbols Pacific peoples used to embellish their ceremonial houses, memorial poles and canoe prows -- are equally intense, if less awesome, when miniaturized. The same motifs retain their magic even when scaled down to less than one-tenth of their usual size. These images appear on the 125 objects on display in "New Guinea Bone Carvings" in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art through May 19.

title: War Summary
description: ALLIES CLAIM WIDE AIR CONTROL

title: Postings: Quaker Restoration; Farmhouse Museum
description: An 1879 Quaker farmhouse, a relic of Long Island's Quaker past, will reopen as a museum on the campus of the Friends Academy, the Locust Valley prep school, late this spring.

title: Retiring Hinson Sits Out Big Loss
description: After more than 500 games in eight productive seasons, the Nets' Roy Hinson is ready to retire from the National Basketball Association at the age of 29. Before New Jersey defeated the Celtics, 111-106, on Friday night at Boston Garden and ended a losing streak at 11 games, Hinson said he thought that he was playing in one of the last games of his career.

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: A Critical First-Test for Costly High-Tech Weapons For decades, the Pentagon and military contractors have bet billions on high-tech weapons without a chance to really test them. The war is providing the first test. If Pentagon claims of success eventually prove correct, manufactureres who are expert at "black box" electronics stand to benefit most.

title: Carol Ann Thieman Weds Valentine Hollingsworth 3d
description: Carol Ann Thieman and Valentine Hollingsworth 3d were married yesterday at St. Anne's-in-the-Fields Episcopal Church in Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. Mark Hollingsworth Jr., a cousin of the bridegroom, and the Rev. Mark Hoying, a Roman Catholic priest who is a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Coins
description: The $2 bill isn't printed any more and some think that's a good thing. The note was always considered an unlucky bill. Some people abhorred receiving one and if kept at all, the bill often lingered in wallets as emergency money, used when all other money, real money, was long gone. But that emergency bill may finally be bringing its owner some good fortune.

title: Ms. Biddle Wed To Yves Hentic
description: Pandora Duke Biddle and Yves F. M. Hentic were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. John G. Hartnett.

title: Sealy Gets 35 Points As Redmen Win
description: Malik Sealy has arrived. Once college basketball's best-kept secret, the 20-year-old St. John's University junior finds opposing coaches gearing their defenses more and more to him and the pro scouts showing up to watch him.

title:
FOCUS;
Troubled South Florida Developers Try Discounts
description: Price discounting by developers of one-family homes is brewing unusual opportunities for buyers in southern Florida.

title: Shades of the 60's, for Viewing the 90's
description: The latest sunglasses reflect a nostalgia for the fashions of the 1960's. Frames and lens tints recall those that were popular then, designers and retailers say.

title: The World; How Presidents Take The Nation Into War
description: IN the early days of the Republic, George Washington declared that "it is our own true policy to steer clear of permanent alliances with any portion of the foreign world." However, since the Presidency of Woodrow Wilson, the United States has frankly abandoned its professed proclivity for isolationism.

title: Air Travel
description: To the Editor: Regarding Norman P. Goldman's letter and the response from Continental Airlines (Travel, Nov. 25), I too obtained a "voluntary denied boarding compensation" ticket and was never informed of the restrictions on its use.

title: Ian Newberg Engaged To Wed Cynthia Axinn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Axinn of Lake Success, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Beth Axinn to Ian Scott Newberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Newberg of Ellicott City, Md. A June wedding is planned.

title: Iraq, the Movie
description: There's a lot of grumbling about television coverage of the Persian Gulf war. We've heard it all -- rumors, hype, endless talk running way ahead of information. I myself, however, think a good case can be made that "Iraq, the Movie" is better TV than the war itself.

title: Topics of the Times; Out and About on Tuesdays
description: New York City is cooking up an anti-crime plan that will also cut entertainment prices, boost business and perhaps even raise tax collections. Called "Tuesday Night Out," it is Consumer Affairs Commissioner Mark Green's response to Mayor David Dinkins's declaration that New Yorkers must "take back our streets, by night as well as by day."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Tel Aviv; In Two Nights, Missiles Turn Fear Into a Grim New Routine
description: After 30 hours, several national alerts and two missile attacks, Israelis are quickly becoming veterens of a routine of late nights, air-raid sirens and gas masks -- a demoralizing, frightening and infuriating drama that many believe could continue for days or weeks to come.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: Because the articles on Venice (Travel, Oct. 6) were so evocative, I changed my plans and went to Venice late last year.

title: Travel Advisory; Neighbors to Aid Mayan Ruins
description: In a cooperative effort said to be the first of its kind, Mexico and four neighboring Central American nations -- Belize, Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras -- have announced a joint program to promote tourism and preserve the artifacts of Mayan culture. The program, Mundo Maya, was announced in Mexico City by the ambassadors of all five countries, and will start in March.

title: Chinese Fare With a Moderate Hand
description: WHEN Chan's Choice opened in Norwalk some years ago, we sampled its cuisine and decided to give it more time before reviewing it. Since then, the tiny storefront restaurant has developed a loyal following.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Graduate Students Find Tribute to Ancient Battle
description: Without lifting a shovel, a team of graduate students at the University of California at Berkeley has discovered an ancient monument in Greece that settles long-simmering questions about a battle fought in 86 B.C.

title: Review/Theater; A Folkloric Antihero Changes His Stripes
description: "Philemon," a chamber musical by Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt, who created "The Fantasticks," is an ambitious oddity of a show. It was the most warmly received of four experimental musicals that evolved out of the Portfolio Studio, a music-theater workshop that the team established with profits from "The Fantasticks," and had a brief commercial run in 1975. Sixteen years later, it has been revived by the York Theater Company in a production supervised by Fran Soeder, who directed the York's memorable revival of "Pacific Overtures."

title:
DINING OUT;
A Cozy Place Serving Spanish Dishes
description: FIVE years ago, Manuel Mendez opened a Spanish restaurant in Elizabeth called Manolo's. Those unfamiliar with the area may well believe, as they leave the brightly lighted stretch of the very long Elizabeth Avenue, that they have been misdirected. But just one block from the Arthur Kill, on the corner where Elizabeth Avenue joins First Street, are the welcome lights of this Union County restaurant.

title: Dorothy Meek to Wed Nicholas Porter
description: August wedding plans for Dorothy Lyles Meek and Nicholas Tewkesbury Porter, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. H. Boone Porter Jr. of Southport, Conn., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Joanne Marston Lauder of Sun Valley, Idaho, and Samuel W. Meek Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Greenwich, Conn.

title: Miss Besse Wed To Lance Bakrow
description: Jannell Mary Besse, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Besse of Toledo, Ohio, was married yesterday to Lance Bakrow, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Bakrow of Rockport, Mass. The Rev. Aldo Tos performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: China Tries to Win Back Tourists
description: THE Forbidden City has had its difficulties with visitors -- 17th-century Manchu invaders, 19th-century foreign devils refusing to kowtow -- but these days the problem is a new one: visitors aren't coming. The 9,000-room complex, which once housed the emperor and his eunuchs and concubines, is largely bereft of Western tourists.

title: OUT OF HIDING
description: "Anti-Semitism is a crime against God and humanity" -- this is the text of a recent and often reiterated pronouncement by the Hungarian Government, echoing the words of Pope John Paul II ("Out of Hiding," by Judith Miller, Dec. 9). We in Hungary feel strongly about this problem and welcome articles on the subject, as long as they are entrusted to the pen of people who are ready to penetrate complex problems because they have acquired adequate knowledge of a country's history and national character. Judith Miller, undoubtedly, is an excellent writer; however, anyone who really knows Hungary and the history of Hungarian Jewry will agree that her article was biased, historically unsound and presented mostly extreme views not typical of mainstream Hungarian thinking.

title: For Car Phones, Antenna Magic
description: Buick's solar-control glass is one of those quietly innovative materials that come along, and it is a good idea. The glass is produced by Libby-Owens-Ford and the company has gone on line with another interesting product, this one anticipating increases in the demand for car cellular phones, which now number about 4 million.

title: Persuasion Pays Off for a Talent Scout
description: BRIAN KOPPELMAN slips into a smoke-filled nightclub in Greenwich Village. Nobody there knows that he is a vice president at Giant Records, a subsidiary of Warner Brothers, or that he discovered Tracy Chapman, the folksinger.

title: The Nation; Starting With Upbeat Economy, Richards Sets Out For 'New Texas'
description: THE symbolism was heavy in Austin at Ann Richards's inauguration on Tuesday as the 45th Governor of Texas. From the winter-white dress Ms. Richards wore, to the invitation she issued to the crowd to join her as she strolled to her new office in the Capitol, everything about the day was carefully designed by the team that organized the 1988 Democratic Convention. Their buzzwords were "fresh," "pure" and, above all, "new."

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Builders See Hope, but Cut Home Costs
description: THE 1990 residential real estate market, characterized by falling prices and faltering sales, was one of the most dismal in recent years for Long Island builders, but some of them now feelthe worst may be over.

title: Doing Business With Moscow Inc.
description: PATHS TO RUSSIA From War to Peace. By F. Wilhelm Christians. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. Foreword by Helmut Schmidt. 236 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $24.95.

title: Fish Fall From the Sky for a Reason
description: THE STORIES OF EVA LUNA By Isabel Allende. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. 331 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: Memorializing Sensational Crimes
description: "Murders: Some Perceptions Questioned" [ Dec. 30 ] illuminates inwriting the shocking and tragic crimes I have been dealing with in my sculpture "The Recall Series."
