These narrative works force viewers to confront and remember the victims and crimes sensationalized in the media of today. These awful events are too quickly replaced by even more terrible and violent crimes perpetrated by males on women.

title: The War Machine Drives U.S. Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Will the Gulf War Reignite a Battle Over Stock Futures?
description: After being in the hot seat for most of last year, Wendy Lee Gramm is not about to start gloating now. "Reports of my victory have been greatly exaggerated," she said recently, in a dry twist of Mark Twain's famous retort about his death.

title: Big Names Change Leagues
description: Glenn Davis, Jack Clark, Joe Carter, Roberto Alomar, Tim Raines and Kirk Gibson have moved from the National League to the American. George Bell, Fred McGriff, Tony Fernandez, Dave Righetti and Willie McGee have switched from the American to the National.

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. CLAUS CHRISTMAS COVER
description: I protest the grotesque photograph of Mrs. Claus on the Dec. 23 cover of the Magazine. It's apparent that few traditions are out of range of ridicule, but attempting to pass this abomination off as art is an insult.

title: Camilla Williams to Wed Christopher Behn in June
description: June wedding plans for Camilla Ashe Williams and Christopher Bradford Behn have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Sewall Williams of Warren, Vt. Mr. Behn is the son of Ulla Nielsen Behn of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Peter C. Behn of Warren.

title: New Albania Barely Conceals a Stalinist Bedrock
description: Bent, rusty iron reinforcement rods are all that remain of the colossal statue of Stalin, recently uprooted from its pedestal near Tirana's main square. But no such fate has disturbed the adjacent statue of Lenin, and giant slogans lauding the Communist Party are still seen across the Albanian capital.

title: Clemens Arrested
description: Less than three months after he was disciplined for cursing an umpire from the mound during the final game of the American League playoffs, Roger Clemens has had another run-in with authority, this time with a policeman working in a West Houston bar.

title: Searching Out Family Roots In Scotland
description: SHORTLY after I arrived in Edinburgh for a vacation, a chatty cabdriver, learning that I was an American of Scottish heritage, inquired if I had an appointment at the Register. When I admitted my ignorance of the Register, he explained that the General Register Office of Scotland was the repository of old parish registers, containing births, baptisms, proclamations of banns and marriages, and deaths and burials, from 1553 to 1854. He went on to say that in 1855 a compulsory civil registration was initiated and that the Register also contained this material. In addition, I found out that census records taken every 10 years from 1841 to 1891 were available, too.

title: Vivid Flashback to Italian Dining of Old
description: ITALIAN restaurants that have opened on the Island recently are neon meccas of trendy pastas and pizzas, with hip crowds to match. But the 18-month-old Ristorante Giulia in Great Neck is an Italian throwback molded in the old style of laid-back luxury and quiet efficiency.

title: Travel Advisory; Fire Delays World's Biggest Cruise Ship
description: Delivery of the world's largest cruise ship, the 2,766-passenger Monarch of the Seas, will be delayed until November because of damage by fire last month in the French shipyard where she is being built. The ship ordered by the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line was to have begun cruises in the Caribbean in May. The delay has forced Royal Caribbean to cancel its 1991 European cruise program to maintain its presence in the Caribbean and to Alaska and Mexico. It has also affected the traveling plans of thousands of people.

title: Grit or Glamour? Time to Investigate
description: Brian Ross, the reporter half of an award-winning NBC News team, believes that television has entered "the golden days of investigative reporting."

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: IT was cold, and the woodlands were locked in old snow -- the kind that crunches underfoot. This was my third trip to the park in a week, and although the first two visits could not honestly be called unproductive, they were, if measured against my narrowly defined standards, unsuccessful. I was searching for a special prize, you see -- one I knew could be found here.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Andries Retains Title: Dennis Andries of Britain outboxed Guy Waters last night in Adelaide, Australia, to retain his World Boxing Council light heavyweight title with a unanimous 12-round decision. It was the second successful title defense for Andries, whose record is now 39-8-2. Waters is 13-2-1. (AP) Skiing Kronberger Increases Her Lead: Petra Kronberger of Austria reached the midpoint of the women's World Cup season with a huge lead in the overall competition by completing a weekend sweep with a victory in the super-G yesterday at Meribel, France. It was Kronberger's third consecutive victory and eighth in 16 races. She has 276 points in 16 races as she bids to win the overall title for a second year in a row. Carol Merle of France is second with 92 points. Kronberger had almost a half-second on the field yesterday as she clocked a time of 1 minute 20.99 seconds. Michaela Gerg of Germany, at 1:21.48, edged Merle, at 1:21.49, for second. (AP) Golf Cook in Lead Alone: John Cook, who insists his comeback from career-threatening wrist surgery won't be complete until he wins again, took sole control of the lead after the third round of the Hawaiian Open in Honolulu. Cook, who was tied with Scott Simpson after the second round, shot a 69 in blustery winds yesterday. He completed three rounds at 17-under 199 on the Waialae Country Club course, which played much tougher with the return of the breezes. With one round to go in the chase for a $198,000 first prize, Cook held a two-stroke advantage over Gil Morgan, who remained close with a last-hole eagle-3. That eagle completed a 69 and got him through 54 holes at 201. (AP) Two-Stroke Lead for Sheehan: Patty Sheehan, the defending champion, shot a one-under-par 70 yesterday to take a two-stroke lead over Judy Dickinson after two rounds of the Jamaica Classic at Montego Bay. Sheehan, a stroke down when play began, was at four-under 138 after two tours of the 6,202-yard Tryall Golf and Beach Club course. While the first-round leader, Sarah McGuire, was sliding back in the field with a 76, Dickinson, with a 68, and Caroline Keggi, who shot 67, made moves to the top of the leader board. They were only two players able to break 70. Dickinson was at 140, one shot ahead of Keggi. (AP) College Football Hollingsworth Stars: Gary Hollingsworth, the Alabama quarterback, engineered three first-quarter scoring drives yesterday that gave his A.F.C. team a lead it never relinquished in a 38-28 victory over the N.F.C. in the Senior Bowl in Mobile, Ala. The game matched college seniors on teams coached by Jim Mora of the New Orleans Saints, a member of the National Footbal League's National Conference, and Marty Schottenheimer of the Kansas City Chiefs of the American Conference. Hollingsworth threw a 21-yard touchdown pass to L.S.U.'s Harvey Williams late in the opening period after his passing set up a 1-yard touchdown run by Penn State's Gary Brown. (AP) East Over West in Hula Bowl: The Michigan connection of John Langeloh and Jarrod Bunch provided the East with three field goals and a touchdown in a 23-10 victory over the West in the Hula Bowl in Honolulu yesterday. Langeloh, a kicker from Michigan State, tied a Hula Bowl record with field goals of 31, 42 and 22 yards. He was selected the game's most valuable offensive player. Bunch, a Michigan running back, twisted and broke tackles to score a second-quarter touchdown. (AP) Horse Racing Favorites Lose at Aqueduct: At Aqueduct yesterday, favorites settled for less in two stakes races. In the Busanda Stakes for fillies, I'm a Thriller scored by four lengths over Win Crafty Lady and clipped four-fifths of a second off the stakes record by going the mile and 70 yards in 1:41 4/5. The rider was Art Madrid Jr., and the payoff was $10 for $2 to win. The favorite, Flawlessly, began to bleed going to the far turn and was eased up by her jockey, Julie Krone. In the Affectionately Handicap for fillies and mares, Carlos Lopez rode My Treasure wire to wire to win at a mile and one-sixteenth, outrunning the favored Buy the Firm by a length and a quarter and returning $42.40 for $2 to win.

title: Defiant Yugoslav Republics Brace for Assault
description: Slovenia and Croatia today defied army warnings to disarm their militias by midnight and prepared for a possible military assault by federal forces.

title: Don't Forgive Ben Johnson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Lindh Weds David John Little
description: Beverly Yost Lindh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. P. Lindh of Dallas and Newport, R.I., was married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York to David John Little, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John R. Little of New York. The Rev. Brenda Husson officiated.

title: How a British Nerd Turned Into a Raconteur
description: ON the surface, Larry Shue's "The Foreigner," now playing at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, is as contrived a story as the most fantastical fairy tale ever told.

title: A Reluctance To Offend
description: To the Editor:

title: De Valois: In Motion Through Time
description: Dance, perhaps strangely, has carved a special place in its history for works that were never considered first rate. The names of such ballets are widely known in the field, and their entries in reference books are de rigueur. It is not that dance has insufficient works of genius compared to the other arts.

title: Karen Wisbaum To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wayne D. Wisbaum of Buffalo have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Karen Gail Wisbaum and David John Van Dyke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne E. Van Dyke of Waukegan, Ill.

title: Travel Advisory; Alert Cites Burmese Unrest
description: Americans considering visiting Myanmar (formerly Burma) are advised by the United States Department of State to exercise caution because of political unrest and are warned about air and train travel dangers there. A travel advisory from the department says while security conditions have improved slightly since last summer, political dissatisfaction continues and armed security forces are often on the streets of all major cities.

title: Catherine Oppen and James R. Haslem Are Wed
description: Catherine Faris Oppen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Oppen of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday in Carmel, Calif., to James Robert Haslem, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Haslem of Washington. The Rev. Carl R. Hansen performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: N.F.L. Decision Comes Down to Game Day
description: It was Jan. 15, the deadline the United Nations had given Iraq to pull out of Kuwait. But President Bush paused last Tuesday in the White House for a few minutes. He had to tape his halftime Super Bowl message.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Military Aircraft Made Available for Evacuations
description: The United States Embassy said today that United States military aircraft would be made available to evacuate Americans and their immediate relatives trapped in Eastern Saudi Arabia since the war began.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an essay last Sunday about biography ("Choosing a Life") referred incorrectly in some copies to Robert A. Caro, the biographer of Robert Moses and Lyndon B. Johnson. Mr. Caro was born in Manhattan; his father was an immigrant from Poland.

title: A Polish Pastoral Letter on the Jews
description: A pastoral letter on Christian-Jewish relations and anti-Semitism was read today during masses in all Roman Catholic churches in Poland. Signed by the nation's bishops, including its primate, Josef Cardinal Glemp of Warsaw, the letter reflects the appeal to combat anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe made by Catholic and Jewish representatives at a joint meeting in Prague last September. The letter also follows the emotional controversy about relocating a convent from the Auschwitz concentration camp site. Reminding Polish Catholics of the Jewishness of Jesus and his mother, the bishops recapitulate the Second Vatican Council's affirmation of Christianity's debt to the Jewish people and repudiation of the charge that Jews bear responsibility for the death of Christ. The excerpts here, on Polish-Jewish relations and the Holocaust, were translated by Thomas E. Bird of Queens College, City University of New York.

title: How to Obtain Ticket Refunds
description: Eastern Airlines said Friday that customers with unused tickets could get refunds through the company's Miami headquarters.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Trade Center About to Grow
description: PLANS for a $400 million, 1.7 million-square-foot addition to the World Trade Center in the Fort Point Channel district of Boston Harbor are moving forward following its approval by the city. The co-developer expects the final element of the environmental impact statement to be approved by the state shortly.

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: Dressing Up and Down When Flying to the Sun
description: Planning to get away from it all? If the answer is yes and the destination is a sunny resort, here's the ticket for a timely wardrobe. Pack five or six easy pieces of clothing into a carry-on bag, and make them color-coordinated and multifunctional.

title: U.S. Technology Won't Win the War
description: The sophisiticated war equipment fashioned by military contractors may not be enough to win a war in the Persian Gulf, according to Steven L. Canby, a retired lieutenant colonel in the Army Reserve. Mr. Canby, a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard University, contends that the American military has spent too much on technology and paid too little attention to strategy. Currently an adjunct professor of national security studies at Georgetown University, he spoke about the cost of a gulf war with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.

title: Don't Knock Corporate Philanthropy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Markets; A Direct Hit on the Pessimists
description: One thing the intensive air attacks on Iraq did last week was knock out the war pessimists. Money managers and analysts who had worried that a war would not go well, even at the beginning, were transformed by the success the United States and its allies had in the air. Even the Iraqi attack on Israel on the second day of fighting did not significantly undermine this confidence, as reflected in the rise in stock markets in Japan and the United States Friday and the relatively small declines in Europe.

title: Getting Medical Care in the Caribbean
description: THIS is the time of year when people repair to the Caribbean to escape the phone, the rain and the gloom. But people with medical concerns, either chronic diseases or past narrow escapes, and families with children, may have legitimate worries about getting help in an emergency.

title: The Good Thousand Days
description: PROMISES KEPT John F. Kennedy's New Frontier. By Irving Bernstein. Illustrated. 342 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Last Straw
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Take Crash Course in City Life
description: THE Fairfield University students were spending their Saturday evening in an unlikely place, the Prospect House shelter for the homeless in the South End neighborhood of Bridgeport.

title: Wilander Upsets Gilbert in Australia
description: Since he reached a zenith of sorts in 1988 by winning the Australian, the French and the United States Opens, Mats Wilander has been erratic. But when he lands on Australian soil, watch out.

title: Lisa Katz Plans To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans for Lisa Katz and Martin Fleischmann, a son of Muriel Fleischmann and Karl Fleischmann of West Hartford, Conn., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Katz of Dunwoody, Ga.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 13 about West Brighton misidentified its City Council member. He is Jerome X. O'Donovan, a Democrat-Conservative.

title: Small Florida Community Has a Death in the Family
description: This small community cheek by jowl with the sprawling Eastern Airlines headquarters has long enjoyed a symbiotic relationship with the airline. It was Eastern, said James Stadnik, a local pharmacist and former Chamber of Commerce official, "which made everything possible."

title: About Men; Notes From Underground
description: TWENTY-ODD YEARS ago, I had a friend with whom I worked until 3 o'clock every morning. We were rewrite men who were supposed to write late-breaking stories right until the last edition closed. It was a time when many things happened at night: riots, student seizures of campuses, the shootings of Robert F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr. Still, for my friend and me there was plenty of time for talk and confession. Often the two of us were too excited to head home when our shift ended, and we would walk the streets in argument and conversation, heading for breakfast in Chinatown.

title: Review/Music; Avant-Garde Group Flirts With an Uptown Ambiance
description: For two decades, through fashions thick and thin, Phill Niblock has been a fixture of the downtown Manhattan avant-garde music scene. On Thursday night, as the second event in a series presented by the World Music Institute and the baritone Thomas Buckner, Mr. Niblock moved his operation uptown to the Merkin Concert Hall, with a considerable change of atmosphere and format.

title: The Roots of Prostitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Goes The Music -- Classical, Too
description: David Lang sits at the window of his loft in lower Manhattan, staring admiringly at the jumble of people and traffic several floors below. Dressed in black, with close-cropped hair and an informal manner, Mr. Lang seems more like a member of a downtown rock band than a classical composer. That contradictory image also finds its way into his compositions, which combine the European classical heritage, Minimalism and American popular music into an irresistibly rhythmic, high-decibel urban brew.

title: Moscow Still Planning on February Summit
description: The Soviet Union is still planning on a Moscow summit meeting with the United States from Feb. 11 to 13, despite the war in the Persian Gulf and the crisis in the Baltic republics, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: On Campus; A War Again Stirs Anguish, but of a Quieter Kind
description: Unsettled by the grim images of war, college students born in the shadow of the defiant 1960's are struggling to reconcile their feelings about the conflict in the Persian Gulf with expectations of how they ought to act.

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: One Last Test of Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion; THE STAR SYSTEM
description: When Todd Oldham opened his collection of spring fashions last November, the house was formidably full. There in the front row were all the key figures -- the retailers, journalists, socialites and supercelebrities -- looking weary after a week of shows but resolutely poker-faced. Yet Oldham, a relative newcomer on Seventh Avenue, and something of a maverick, had made up his mind to woo them. To that end, he had instructed his models to beam incandescently as they sauntered down the runway in shirts that were sashed at the midriff and slashed at the rear. Bouffant-coifed like Barbie dolls, they emerged out of the painted backdrop, a kitschy tangle of flowers and trees meant to evoke the rustic charms of Dogpatch.

title: Miss Hunt Weds Sean McDowell
description: Susan Marie Hunt, a daughter of Mrs. William E. Hunt of Albany and the late Mr. Hunt, was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Clement in Albany to Sean Campbell McDowell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay H. McDowell of New York. Bishop Edwin B. Broderick, a former Bishop of Albany, performed the ceremony.

title: The Region; The Dinkins Budget Is a Long Way From the Bottom Line
description: THE worst-of-both-worlds preliminary budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed for New York City last week was, as usual, only the first step down a long road. But even more than usual, the path is strewn with rocks and roadblocks and bridges to cross.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Columbia, Md.;
A New Hotel, Built in Pieces
description: A $10 MILLION hotel with factory-built guest rooms has gone from foundation to four stories here in less than three weeks, about half the time required with conventional construction.

title: Toby E. Fischer To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jay D. Fischer of Clifton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Toby Elizabeth Fischer to Dr. Joel Morse, a son of Dr. Frederick H. Morse of Washington and Naomi S. Morse of Silver Spring, Md. A May wedding is planned.

title: An Athlete's Courage Conquers Disability
description: THE basketball player with the ungainly gait takes a pass and arches a three-point shot from the right side that swishes cleanly through the net. The game between Torrington and Naugatuck High Schools is in its final quarter. On a set play, the same unorthodox Torrington player, Chris Samele, connects on another three-point jump shot. Even though his team is routing the opponents, the crowd of about 200 in the Torrington gymnasium roars in delight at each of the baskets.

title: State Orders Bridgeport to Lay Off Workers
description: A state board created to oversee Bridgeport's troubled finances has ordered the city to lay off 100 workers unless it can find other ways to balance the budget.

title: Finally, a Lincoln Center for American Music
description: A year or so ago, while on a panel about the arts in this country, I fully meant to rouse the rabble in the audience when I shouted what would become my mantra for the rest of the discussion: "There are no Lincoln Centers for American music!" A bit obvious, but effective.

title: U.S. to Determine Danger From Barrels of Atomic Waste in Pacific
description: The Federal Government has begun an extensive study to determine whether barrels of radioactive waste dumped in the Pacific Ocean could break open and spill their contents into a national wildlife sanctuary that is the richest marine habitat in the West.

title: Illegal Debris Tied To Noxious Odors At Closed Dump
description: THE cause of the offensive odor from the North Hempstead Town landfill in Port Washington remains something of a mystery, even after the Nassau County Board of Health ordered the dump shut this month.

title: Metro Dateline; Man, 30, Found Slain In East Side Home
description: A 30-year-old Bloomingdale's clerk was found slain in his Upper East Side apartment late Friday night, the police said.

title: Finding a Solution For Too Much TV
description: I read the Dec. 2 article "In the Natural State" with interest, as I have also sought the solution to children's television addiction. In our house, a step more Draconian than the gentle persuasion of bird watching was needed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday about the real estate troubles of American banks misstated the involvement of J. P. Morgan & Company with a Boston office building, 73 Tremont Street. A subsidiary, J. P. Morgan Investment Management Inc., invested pension money from clients in the office development and the Morgan-managed fund is now the principal investor in the building. The bank itself made no loans to the Boston building.

title: Human Touches for the Computer Age
description: ROBERT F. BETTENDORF said he has no quarrel with the United States Department of Labor when it says that cases of repetitive-motion disorders in the workplace have greatly increased. But he said that the problem is not an ominous byproduct of the computer age.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on page 30 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Mozart celebration at Lincoln Center carries an outdated reference to the conductor for the opening concert at Avery Fisher Hall next Sunday. Raymond Leppard will conduct, replacing Zubin Mehta, who departed for Israel before the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf 14-18A

title: New York's Largest Savings Bank Investigated for Possible Tax Fraud
description: Executives of New York State's largest savings institution, the Crossland Savings Bank, are under investigation after state and city tax officials concluded that the bank set up six dummy companies in Delaware to evade taxes on $150 million in corporate profits, law-enforcement officials say.

title: 'American Psycho'
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The towel rack in our bathroom has pulled out of the wall, leaving a hole in the dry wall. The rack was apparently secured with plaster inside the wall. How can we remount this towel rack without tearing up the wall?

title: Obsessed in Cairo
description: PALACE OF DESIREThe Cairo Trilogy II.By Naguib Mahfouz.Translated by William Maynard Hutchins,Lorne M. Kenny and Olive E. Kenny.422 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Verona
description: WITH its tree-lined streets, 30- to 60-year-old housing stock and neighborhood schools, this small town has the feeling of a village. It is not uncommon here for three generations of families to live within blocks of one another. Volunteers still coach the town's Little League teams and maintain the ball fields.

title: We Learned the Wrong Lessons in Vietnam; A Feminist Issue Still
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Freedman To Wed in April
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome K. Freedman of New Haven have announced the engagement of their daughter Eleanor Jane Freedman to Craig Stephen Deardorff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Deardorff of Rockville, Md. An April wedding is planned.

title: Montana's Set; 49ers Are Ready
description: Joe Montana reported to the 49ers' training complex this morning, visited with team doctors and then returned home. His flu bug had improved, but he skipped the 49ers' walk-through practice. Montana is scheduled to start at quarterback against the Giants on Sunday in the National Football Conference championship game at Candlestick Park.

title: It's Sweepstakes Time, and It's a Frenzy
description: IN five days, a number will be removed from a vault in Port Washington, and members of the Publishers Clearing House Patrol will be told their destinations.

title: Headliners; Deals for Dealers
description: It would seem a victory for the drug warriors to get Jorge Luis Ochoa behind bars. But after Mr. Ochoa, the No. 2 man in the No. 1 Colombian cocaine cartel, turned himself in to the authorities in Bogota last week in a deal for leniency, some American drug experts were unsure who got the better part of the bargain. Hoping to end a wave of violence directed against anti-drug forces, the Government has offered traffickers who surrender and plead guilty to one crime a promise of light sentences and a guarantee that they will not be extradited to the United States. Officials said that Mr. Ochoa's surrender demonstrated the program's value. But one student of drug politics, Ambler Moss, the former American Ambassador to Panama, had his doubts. "It may mean that light sentences will be traded for peace, and Colombia will remain a big drug production country," said Mr. Moss. "This is far from what the U.S. Government wanted."

title: Headliners; Laughing Last
description: Following show business tradition, Mark Morris saved his best for the end. During the three years that Mr. Morris and his mostly American dance company have been under contract with the Monnaie Opera House in Brussels, reviewers have often judged them wanting, or worse. One pan in Le Soir, the city's largest newspaper, was headlined "Mark Morris Go Home." But Mr. Morris, whose contract is not being extended beyond its June expiration date, has left his detractors with something to think about. His final exclusive work for the Monnaie, an offbeat adaptation of "The Nutcracker" called "The Hard Nut," drew high praise from audience and reviewers alike at its premier last weekend. The Le Soir critic, whose reviews were said by some Morris dancers to be their principal frustration in Brussels, called the new ballet, in which many characters have reversed gender roles, "a total success, not to be missed for any reason." Said Mr. Morris, "It went great because my dancers are so fabulously good."

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THEIR PROMISED LANDArab Versus Jew in History's Cauldron -- One Valley in the Jerusalem Hills.By Marcia Kunstel and Joseph Albright.Crown, $19.95.

title: Even WASP's Are Allowed to Have Feelings
description: They're cold as ice, they're wound like springs, and they make everyone around them miserable. In the movies, Robert Redford's "Ordinary People" (1980) was the classic indictment of WASP's. The only way Mr. and Mrs. Jarret (Donald Sutherland and Mary Tyler Moore) could think of to cope with the drowning of their oldest son and the attempted suicide of their youngest was through stiff upper lips, good manners and denial.

title: Phone Messages on 136 Health Topics
description: WHILE counseling his parishoners on such sensitive issues as adoption and alcoholism, the Rev. Jack Silvey Miller, senior minister of the Mount Kisco Presbyterian Church here, became aware that he was repeating himself. "People asked the same questions and I said the same thing to each person," Mr. Miller recalled recently. "I thought, why not have a telephone system that will give out information in a non-threatening way?"

title: Weirdos in a Strange Land
description: GRINGOS By Charles Portis. 269 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Ms. Gershen to Wed Joshua Finkelstein
description: Mrs. Alvin E. Gershen of Princeton, N.J., has announced March wedding plans for her daughter Elana Lynn Gershen and Rabbi Joshua Steven Finkelstein, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Ezra M. Finkelstein of Syosset, L.I.

title: Winning Team: Partners Cast Sports Heroes in Profitable Light
description: JACK RUDOLF, a politician and businessman from East Norwalk, and Peter Rubino, a sculptor from Wilton, might seem like unlikely partners. But they have scored a striking early success with Rudolf-Rubino Creations, crafting and distributing figures and busts of sports heroes like Babe Ruth and Lawrence Taylor.

title: Lily M. Hampton Becomes Bride Of Alfred Brittain
description: Lily Middleton Hampton of Rochester was married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., to Alfred Brittain 3d. The Rev. Sydney Woodd-Cahusac of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich performed the ceremony at Mr. Brittain's home.

title: The Band Played, But Not the Guests
description: The announcement that the air strike in the Middle East had begun came as the National Center for Learning Disabilities was sponsoring a dinner-dance and auction at the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan. When the news spread through the dining room on Wednesday evening, the party's organizer's hastily arranged for President Bush's address to be seen on the ballroom movie screen.

title: Red Lentils With Vegetables and Rice
description: Dried peas, beans and lentils are the new trend-setters and you'll find them on the fanciest menus in the fanciest restaurants.

title: For Handmade Rugs, Beat Them! Beat Them!
description: ALTHOUGH precious, most hand-knotted rugs except antiques and silk rugs can withstand normal household use and be cared for by amateurs.

title: Haitians' Lament: Anemic Opposition
description: A month after Haitians voted in the country's first free presidential elections, voters will return to the polls on Sunday to choose legislative representatives and local government officials.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A HOLE IN THE LANGUAGE By Marly Swick.University of Iowa, $17.95.

title: Campus Life: Michigan; Selling Off Pieces Of Football Glory By the Yard
description: The University of Michigan football team lost its footing this year -- 88,000 square feet of it.

title: Corporate Employees Bolster Emergency Squads
description: AT a time when rising demand for emergency medical services is putting added pressure on volunteer rescue squads across the state, New Jersey businesses are stepping in to help municipalities cope with medical emergencies.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Colchester, Vt.;
Condos In a Fort
description: OFFICERS' quarters built nearly a century ago here at Fort Ethan Allen are being converted into condominiums under the auspices of the Vermont Housing Finance Agency.

title: A MOTEL SETTLES BEST WESTERN SUIT
description: A motel in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., has retracted its accusation that the Best Western hotel chain acted out of racial discrimination when it rescinded the motel's franchise after the motel began taking in homeless people, most of them black or Hispanic.

title: Taylor Pounds Davis to Take Title
description: Meldrick Taylor is the new World Boxing Association welterweight champion. He took the title tonight from Aaron Davis on a unananimous 12-round decision, using a nonstop assault that had the game Davis bewildered from start to finish at Convention Hall here.

title: Art Imitates Hype
description: NOTHING IF NOT CRITICALSelected Essays on Art and Artists.By Robert Hughes.429 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 9 about Dominica misidentified the island that can be seen in the distance from Coconut Beach. It is Guadeloupe, not Martinique. Because of a transmission error, the article also misstated the year of Dominica's independence from Britain. It was 1978, not 1977. In addition, a picture caption with the article misidentified the village shown. It is Scott's Head, not Soufriere.

title: The Palaces And Gardens Of Chengde
description: THE Qing emperor Kangxi came to the Mountain Manor for Escaping the Summer Heat (Bishu Shanzhuang) in Chengde, about 150 miles northeast of Beijing, as early as May each year because he so loved the imperial resort.

title: A Winter of Abnormal Happenings
description: THIS has been an unusual winter so far, too mild in many respects. Forsythia was in full bloom in many locations in November. English primroses flowered just as gloriously in December as they do in spring. Tulips and daffodils pushed the tips of their foliage above ground, and buds of many woody plants swelled.

title: SoHo Stares at Hard Times
description: LESS THAN A YEAR AGO, MARGO DOLAN AND her husband, Peter Maxwell, dealers in contemporary art, ambitiously absorbed the gallery next to their New York headquarters at 156 Wooster Street. It was an effortless expansion. The newly acquired, 3,500-square-foot space already boasted the typical gallery accouterments: track lighting and a small kitchen.

title: Dropping By Mao's Home
description: ONLY 15 years and 50 ideologies ago, it was the most popular excursion in China. Every Red Guard's idea of militant tourism was paying a visit to Shaoshan, the birthplace and boyhood home of Chairman Mao Zedong. This farmhouse deep in the countryside of Hunan Province served to confirm the plebian roots of the Chinese revolution and its No. 1 peasant. Train lines were extended specifically to accommodate the hordes who made this pilgrimage to the holiest of revolutionary shrines. "Paving the highway all the way to Mao's house was a great expense to the province," says the driver of the taxi for which I've opted. His tone suggests little nostalgia for reading the little red book instead of his meter -- though he has to admit that most of the local trade died off with the Chairman himself. When I look out across the rice paddies, I can almost see the robust, ruddy-cheeked zealots in their green caps and red armbands, marching arm in arm with Mao's quotations in one hand and a steamed bun in the other. I wish I was coming down this road as something other than a capitalist-roader.

title: Hamlet Admired the Invader of Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: Perspectives: The 'Cuomo Tax'; As the Gravy Train Slows, Questions Rise
description: IN real-estate circles it is universally known as the "Cuomo tax," and that surely does not displease Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Fashion; THE NEW DEALERS
description: The biggest surprise is that there are so many of them right now. In any season, a few new names or labels crop up on Seventh Avenue, and out of those, one or two may hang in and really make it. But in this uncertain spring with all its bleak economic aspects, the fashion underbrush is thick with young sprouts, all seemingly healthy and steadily growing. By hook or by crook, these talents are finding the financial backing, manufacturing wherewithal -- and perhaps most important, the store buyer support -- to take root and blossom. In most cases, the clothes will start arriving next month in a select but impressive number of the nation's stores. Then it will be up to the customers to determine who makes it and who becomes history. On these pages are examples of the diverse wares being produced by just a few of this current group. And there are many more promising young designers with equally strong views on style. With luck, all of them will pass muster. They deserve it.

title: Travel Advisory; Philadelphia's Flowery Week
description: Organizers of the Philadelphia Flower Show will take a leap into the jet age this year. The show will feature tens of thousands of freshly cut flowers flown from around the world and replaced at least twice during the show.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Muslims; Saudis Decree Holy War on Hussein
description: Saudi Arabia's highest religious authority has issued a decree sanctioning a holy war against Saddam Hussein by all Muslims and "those assisting them" to evict his forces from Kuwait.

title: Chinese Dissident Relives the 1989 Massacre
description: In the 18 months since the Chinese Government crushed the democracy movement that she helped lead, Chai Ling has tried to put the memory of the tanks rumbling through Tiananmen Square behind her.

title: Saving Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Operatic Legends Arise From the LP's Ashes
description: In the age of the long-playing record, there was considerable interest from the major recording companies in keeping a strong cross-section of recorded operatic history before the buying public. In addition, some small-scale endeavors focused on less-familiar recordings by established names or by singers no longer deemed sufficiently interesting by the big labels.

title: Scaling the Heights Of a Sacred Peak
description: "BURN money," the old woman said encouragingly.

title: A Power Death in the Hamptons
description: MAGIC HOURBy Susan Isaacs.412 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $21.95.

title: Camera
description: Usually the least glamorous aspects of photography can stand the most improvement. Take changing bags. These light-tight fabric compartments with elastic sleeves have been around for ages, helping photographers load and unload film while on the road. Has anyone ever noticed that they are a hassle to use?

title: Lesbian Is Discharged From Army Reserves
description: An Army reservist who declared herself a lesbian as her unit trained for deployment to the Persian Gulf has been discharged.

title: Streetscapes: The Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Hall; The Legacy in Granite Of a Failed Grand Scheme
description: IS it "the most inspiring memorial ever designed, excepting perhaps only the Taj Mahal," as Henry Fairfield Osborn said? Or was Lewis Mumford closer, describing it as a "sheer ghastly fantasy" of "pompous bad taste"?

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 20, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran, stationed in Sioux country, adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 2 36 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 3 22 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) An author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 4 4 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: A Conductor Reflects On Europe and the U.S.
description: EVERY few years Edwin Scholz returns to the United States, a place familiar and foreign at the same time.

title: Denise Binday Is Engaged
description: June wedding plans for Denise Lori Binday and Jeffrey Alan Koslowsky have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Binday of Scarsdale, N.Y. Mr. Koslowsky is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Koslowsky of North Caldwell, N.J. Miss Binday, 22 years old, graduated from Barnard College. She is an assistant in the photography department at Swann Galleries in New York. Mr. Koslowsky, 22, graduated from Lafayette College and is studying law at Fordham University.

title: Lite-Headed Marketing
description: The moralistic 1990's are turning out to be a real bummer for beer. Recently, the makers of our national brew have been blamed for everything from carnage on the highways to promiscuity among college kids. Normally, that would be a signal for the beer makers to play it safe and consign their brands to a kind of cheery oblivion until the national emergency has passed.

title: A Challenge In Court
description: The first major challenge to Gov. Jim Florio's Fair Automobile Insurance Reform Act reached the State Supreme Court last week, with lawyers for the insurance industry saying that the act prevents auto insurance companies from earning a fair profit in New Jersey.

title: Miss Sting to Wed Jonathan Frattaroli
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Sting of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lang Sting to Jonathan Andrew Frattaroli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Frattaroli of Morristown, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Hamilton Fish, in Congress 24 Years, Dies at 102
description: Hamilton Fish, who as a conservative Republican Congressman from New York opposed United States involvement in World War II until Pearl Harbor and clashed with President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died on Friday evening in his house in Cold Spring in Putnam County. He was 102 years old.

title: Sign Language: Bridging the Gap
description: As a teacher who retired some years ago after teaching deaf children for 18 years at the New York School for the Deaf on Knollwood Road in White Plains, I was fascinated with the article, "American Sign Language Joins the Curriculum as an Elective" [ Dec. 30 ] .

title: Mali
description: To the Editor: Having lived in Mali for six months and visited many times, I was happy to see "The Mali Express" (Travel, Nov. 25). This is a fascinating country with the sweetest people I have ever encountered, but there are caveats about travel there.

title: Q and A
description: Delinquent Condo Fees Question: I am the board president of a 28-unit condominium. One unit owner has not paid maintenance fees for three months. We have found that his mortgage is also delinquent. Should we wait for the bank to start proceedings? . . . Joel Behr, Brooklyn Answer: No. Richard Siegler, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said there is no reason to wait for the bank to proceed against the owner. You need to put the debt on the record as a notice to any purchaser that common charges are due and so the condominium has a place in the line of creditors in case of a foreclosure sale.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 30 about energy conservation misstated the usage of electricity at the Manhattan offices of the Natural Resources Defense Council and the estimated savings in energy costs over 10 years. It uses 30 percent of the power needed for a comparable space where there are no conservation measures, and it expects to save $750,000 in utility costs over 10 years.

title: We Learned the Wrong Lessons in Vietnam; Peacetime Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany's New Custodian of Stasi Secrets Insists on Justice
description: From a drab and unmarked office in what was once East Berlin, an earnest clergyman named Hans Joachim Gauck is working to unravel the secrets of one of the world's largest and best-organized spy networks.

title: Business Diary/January 13-18
description: WAR IN THE GULF Why Can't America Make a VCR to Match Its F-117? Radar-jamming F4-G Wild Weasels carrying antiradiation missiles disrupted Iraqi defenses Wednesday night. As F-117 stealth fighters led the attack, the skies were initially all theirs. The first reports indicated that America's technological superiority was manifest. So why can't the United States make the world's best VCR's? Or subcompact cars? Scholars say the nation's military sophistication at best leaves its economic competitiveness unharmed. "Defense needs are not the same as civilian needs in most industries," said Michael E. Porter of Harvard Business School in his recent book. Defense products can sometimes serve other ends; the first military jet transport evolved into the Boeing 707. But sometimes, he said, military contracts merely blunt healthy business competition. Paul Kennedy, a Yale historian, goes further, saying that the nation's military responsibilities are eroding its economic advantages. "Rome fell; Babylon fell; Scarsdale's turn will come," he said. Only the week before last, the Pentagon canceled a $57 billion program to build a new Navy attack plane when the ultimate cost appeared far greater than Scarsdale and the rest of the nation can afford. Traders in Battle American traders were as awesomely prepared as the military for war in the Middle East: all set for a furious aerial battle, the destruction of Saudi oil refineries and panic buying of oil. They had pored over tables showing that when war breaks out, investors dump stocks. And so, when American jets flew virtually unopposed Wednesday night and the Saudis initially escaped with damage to a single storage tank, traders were able to change course faster than F-15's. On Thursday, the Dow climbed 114.60 points on heavy volume, the second-best day ever. Oil futures dropped by more than $10 a barrel in a day, then, on Friday, fell by $2.19, to $19.25. And yet, the euphoria may prove fleeting; William H. Donaldson, the New York Stock Exchange Chairman, warned investors against acting in haste.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The towel rack in our bathroom has pulled out of the wall, leaving a hole in the dry wall. The rack was apparently secured with plaster inside the wall. How can we remount this towel rack without tearing up the wall?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Military Briefing; Excerpts From Briefings by American Generals In Washington and Riyadh
description: Following are excerpts from news conferences given by the American military yesterday at the Pentagon in Washington and in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, as transcribed by Reuters. Remarks in Washington were made by Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and in Riyadh by Maj. Gen. Robert Johnston of the United States Central Command.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: WILLIAM H. MILLER;
Recalling the Heyday of Ocean Liners
description: BON VOYAGE! Those two words once implied fruit baskets delivered by uniformed messengers, staterooms full of farewell orchids and roses, the command "All visitors ashore," last-minute hugs, handkerchiefs waved at rails and piers and, above all, the trip across the Atlantic on ships considered floating palaces.

title: A Legend in Life, Teacher Leaves Unexpected Legacy to School
description: IN his lifetime, Edwin D. Barlow was a legend at Horace Greeley High School here. A brilliant teacher who would read poetry or "Alice in Wonderland" to his math and physics classes, he combined an authoritarian teaching style with an intense dedication to his students. Mr. Barlow was known to exasperate administrators and parents, but would spend hours before and after school helping students.

title: Data Bank/January 20, 1991
New Home for a Quaker Meetinghouse
description: "THE building will be reborn," Doris Finch Watson announced recently, sounding very much like a proud parent. Mrs. Watson, a founder and executive committee member of the North Castle Historical Society, was talking about the society's latest major project, the dismantling, moving and reconstruction a 1798 Quaker meetinghouse.

title: New Signs for Ryan
description: Every strikeout Nolan Ryan chalks up in 1991 will add to his writing cramp once the season is over. Ryan has authorized a pictorial book about his career that will include previously unpublished photos from the Ryan family collection. He has also agreed to autograph a number of those books equal to his career strikeout total after the 1991 season. That's 5,308 signatures plus whatever whiffs the 44-year-old righthander adds this year. (AP)

title: The Time Is Ripe For Regionalization
description: Like many of those quoted in the recent article "Regional Approach To Services Reconsidered," I believe it's time for local governments to take a long, hard look at the concept of regionalization.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DRAWINGS OF WOMEN

title: Raiders Remember Bad Bills' Memory
description: As much as they disliked the questions and attempted to side step them this week, the Los Angeles Raiders -- to a man, it seemed -- could not avoid one inescapable fact: from a historical perspective, they did not have the best of memories about the Buffalo Bills.

title: In Murky Trials, China Buries Tiananmen Affair
description: They are only tiny trial notices, scribbled on pieces of paper that crackle in the wind on a board outside the Intermediate People's Court, but they suggest that China now hopes to write the last chapter in the chronicles of the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Does everyone lie about something? Well, perhaps lie is a bit strong -- let's say instead "stretch the truth," a description that somehow makes the whole thing sound less serious and more like a peccadillo. Even people who don't consider themselves liars in the absolute sense of the word have no hesitation in admitting to more than a bit of stretch from time to time.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CROSSTOWN TRAFFIC Jimi Hendrix and the Post-War Rock 'n' Roll Revolution. By Charles Shaar Murray. St. Martin's, $18.95.

title: Jovitita M. E. Pacia, Nurse, Weds Glenn Eiger, Doctor
description: Jovitita Maria Ebreo Pacia and Dr. Glenn Eiger were married last evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Bauer in Middletown, N.Y., by Rabbi Herschel Jaffe. Mrs. Eiger is a daughter of Rosario E. Azcona of Digos, Philippines, and Augusto Pacia of Manila. Dr. Eiger is the son of Arline Woronoff of Bloomingburg, N.Y.

title: Review/Jazz; Fearless Piano Improvisations From by Toshiko Akiyoshi
description: Toshiko Akiyoshi's Orchestra, which has begun an open-ended Monday-night engagement at the Village Gate, balances itself between fearlessness and quiet subversion. As a composer and arranger, Ms. Akiyoshi is fearless because she unhesitatingly goes after textures that are traditionally beautiful and luxuriant, using flutes and clarinets to invoke a pastoral serenity that might seem trite in some hands. But like many modernists who came to artistic maturity in the 1950's, Ms. Akiyoshi has a notion that music should be more than entertainment. Though the basic idiom she uses is deep in the big-band tradition, her vocabulary often includes odd dissonant clusters that act rhetorically, short bursts of sound seemingly meant to teach an audience that conventional lack of consonance can have value as well.

title: The Peaks And the Pits Of Criticism
description: Critics open their daily mail with the mingled feeling of hope and dread that children bring to opening presents. Some especially thoughtful letters agree with our views in every particular and could not be more welcome. Others are the equivalent of a piece of coal in the Christmas stocking. There is the inevitable response from the reader who happens to know more about the subject under discussion than any other living being. Often as not, the correspondent will have written a doctoral thesis on the swampy area into which the critic has stumbled. In any event, in the face of such formidable expertise the critic can only feign boredom and quickly move on.

title: Style Makers; Nancy Judson, Travel Planner
description: Looking at Winston Churchill's battle maps in the Cabinet War Rooms in London, Nancy Judson was struck with an idea for a way to make travel plans.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Japanese Investors Begin to Feel the Pinch
description: JAPANESE real estate investors who have entered the Westchester County market are beginning to feel the recession's impact. Several are going forward on residential and commercial projects but others are waiting for the economy to improve.

title: Romancing the Muse: Just Wait, and She'll Come Sidling Up
description: The decades have taught me patience with my muse: before she'll sit in my lap and sing, she visits me less like one of Zeus' daughters by Mnemosyne than like one of those vintage Hollywood monsters, almost human, whose inchoate grunts and rumbles move the heroine to declare, "I think it's trying to tell us something." Always, in the past, in her own good time, she has cleared her throat, refound her voice -- which is to say, mine. But she won't be hurried.

title: Headliners; Learning the Ropes
description: As Argentina becomes accustomed to its relatively new free-market economy and civilian government, officials' notions of how the two should relate are sometimes a bit fuzzy. With American companies clamoring to do business there, Ambassador Terence A. Todman has found himself complaining to the administration of President Carlos Saul Menem that certain kinds of behavior -- bare-faced solicitations of bribes, for example -- tend not to make for happy trade relationships. A letter from Mr. Todman complaining that the Swift-Armour Company had been asked for "substantial payments" in order to import machinery needed for a new plant, was made public recently, precipitating embarrassment for Mr. Menem when reporters began to question his dealings, including how some Italian businessmen planning to build hotels in Argentina gave the President a red Ferrari 348. When it was suggested that he give the car to charity, Mr. Menem replied, "It's mine, mine. Why should I give it away?"

title:
The Executive Life;
All This Tech Talk Gabble, And No One Is Listening
description: "Digital supports O.S.F.'s Motif as its G.U.I.," said an executive of the Digital Equipment Corporation at the opening of a recent sales presentation to an audience of potential customers.

title: Train Travel
description: To the Editor: In the item "Booking Easier for Talgo Train" (Travel Advisory, Nov. 18) a statement about FrenchRail said, "They could not make reservations (required before boarding) for seats and sleepers." This is incorrect. FrenchRail, which represents the Spanish railroads in North America and sells rail tickets and passes for Spain, is able to reserve seats and sleepers on Talgo trains, Rapidos, overnight trains and international trains within Spain as well as those originating or terminating in Spain. This includes the Catalan Talgo from Barcelona to Geneva and any city in between, the Paris-Madrid Talgo from Madrid to Paris, the Barcelona Talgo from Barcelona to Paris, the Talgo Costa del Sol from Madrid to Malaga and all Talgos from Barcelona to Madrid.

title: Ingrid Hill to Marry Richard J. Wolff
description: Ingrid Dee Hill, a model and actress, and Richard James Wolff, the head of a New York real-estate concern, plan to marry in March.

title: Metro Dateline; Inmate Loses Appeal On Right to Abortion
description: A divided Federal appeals court ruled on Friday that the constitutional rights of a pregnant inmate were not violated when administrative delays prevented her from getting an abortion.

title: Tampa Journal; Larger Conflict Looms In Plans for Big Game
description: Barbara Casey, the coordinator of this city's Super Bowl festivities, arrived at Tampa Stadium at 7 A.M. today. It was the last strategy session before the game and she heard reports from 15 committees dealing with things like budget and finance and banners and transportation -- right on down to vans, limousines and buses.

title: What to Expect From Physicians
description: I read with interest the article "Religion Is Playing a Major Role for the Aged Ill" [ Dec. 23 ] . I was extensively quoted in that article.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE ACOLYTE, by Thea Astley. (Penguin, $6.95.) Finally coming to in middle age, a man named Paul Vespers realizes he has ruined his life because of his excessive devotion to an eccentric blind pianist who has become one of Australia's leading composers. "The integrity and intelligence behind Thea Astley's work make hers a voice worth hearing," Bret Lott said in The Book Review in 1988.

title: Catholic Order Helps the Homeless
description: Pat Maurer has devoted her life to helping this city's homeless people, but there are days when the despair of the men and women in New Haven's soup kitchens and shelters seems to overwhelm her.

title: Topics of the Times; Voting Reform Rip-Off
description: It was proposed three years ago as a promising way to improve an election system marred by corruption, patronage and the disenfranchisement of voters. But as hearings a month ago made abundantly clear, New York City's Voter Assistance Commission is at least as incompetent and mired in politics as the Board of Elections it is supposed to oversee.

title: Review/Dance; Sokolow Takes a Bow for 50 Years
description: For more than 50 years, Anna Sokolow has reigned supreme as a choreographer of deep social commitment. Above all, she has been concerned with the crushing toll that society exacts on the individual in a world at war, or at war with itself.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We're not saying what we will do, when we will do it, where or how we will do it." -- Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. [ 17:5. ]

title: Moses the Bobsledder
description: For years as a world-class hurdler, Edwin Moses finished ahead of the pack. Yesterday as a bobsleder in Cervinia, Italy, Moses found himself and his teammates on the United States team back in the pack. Moses made his debut in the European bobsled championships with a 13th place finish in a qualifying trial, but he and the driver, Brian Shimer, said they hoped to improve in practices today and tomorrow. The two were nearly six seconds behind the fastest team, Canada-One of Greg Haydenluch and Peter Robertson Stovel. (AP)

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Seattle; Tower Rising In a Seedy Area
description: A $60 MILLION mixed-use development with 194 apartments and a large retail component now rising here is expected to help turn around one of the most neglected downtown areas.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate

title: Alexandra Cross Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Alexandra Haslam Cross to Frederick Behrens Mitchell, a son of Sheila Ryan Wells of Bedford, N.Y., and Donald L. Mitchell of Lakeville, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Cross of Bedford. An August wedding is planned.

title: Singing in 'Godfather III,' Without Fear
description: ANOTHER actor may have been nervous about making his film debut in "The Godfather Part III," one of the decade's most widely anticipated and highly acclaimed movies, but not Franc D'Ambrosio.

title: Topics of the Times; Telling the Kids
description: A New York woman, who recalls the anxiety she felt as a child during the Cuban missile crisis, confronted the task last week of having to tell her 6-year-old daughter about the frightening events unfolding in the Persian Gulf.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Jan. 6 about bar codes misstated the use of a new form of the code, which depends on infrared scanners. The new coding would be used in addition to present coding, which depends on visible-light scanners, but would not replace it.

title: Israel Outsmarts Iraq
description: There is the story of the masochist who says to the sadist, "Hurt me," and the sadist replies, with exquisite cruelty, "No."

title: Accounts
description: * Video Technology Industries Inc., Wheeling, Ill., to Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, New York, with a budget of $10 million. The account was previously handled by Ayer, New York and Zwiren Collins Karo Trusk, Chicago. * Blockbuster Video, Washington, to DDB Needham, Washington, with billings of $2 million to $3 million. * CVS, to Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, Boston, for its Peoples Drug Stores. The previous agency was Ehrlich-Manes Associates, Bethesda, Md. * Century 21 Real Estate, Irvine, Calif., to Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Detroit, for three of its Midwestern offices. Billings could not be learned.

title: St. John's Prepares For Connecticut
description: While millions of other sports fans were watching the Buffalo Bills crush the Los Angeles Raiders early yesterday afternoon, Coach Lou Carnesecca of St. John's was hard at work, studying a videotape of Providence's 108-102 victory over the University of Connecticut on Saturday night.

title: New Tax to Aid Canada in Trade
description: As Canadians grouse about a new tax that adds 7 percent to the price of newspapers, haircuts, clothing and just about everything else they buy, businesses on the American side of the border are fretting about the implications of the tax on their trade with Canada.

title: Conflicting Censorship Upsets Many Journalists
description: Many news corespondents covering the war with Iraq are bridling under a system of conflicting rules and confusing censorship.

title: Others Are Expected to Fill In for Arrested Colombian Drug Dealer
description: American drug experts say they doubt that the surrender of Jorge Luis Ochoa, one of the world's leading cocaine smugglers, will have a significant effect on the flow of the drug into the United States.

title: Taylor Bounces Back and Wins a Title
description: When last seen, Meldrick Taylor looked as though his controversial loss to Julio Cesar Chavez had damaged him.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; CNN Wins Much Acclaim, But Will It Win Sponsors?
description: To amplify Rolling Stone magazine's fabled advertising campaign, perception is often far more important than reality when it comes to selling ads. The latest beneficiary of this marketing wisdom could be the Cable News Network, whose dramatic coverage of the Persian Gulf war has been praised by everyone from Tom Brokaw to Tariq Aziz.

title: Arnett Stays Behind At Cannon's Mouth In One More Capital
description: After the Iraqi Government's expulsion of other foreign journalists, Peter Arnett of Cable News Network reported yesterday that he was the only correspondent from a major Western television network still working in Baghdad. He reported the Iraqis said they had selected CNN because of its "proven impartiality."

title: War News Captivates, And Commerce Slows
description: As the nation followed the war news from the Persian Gulf last week, the pace of business in America slowed.

title: Sports of The Times; For the Raiders, No Huddle Was No Fun
description: AFTER the game yesterday, as the Raider players silently cleaved the tape and the uniforms from their battered persons in the silent, sweaty and cramped locker room, Al Davis, the owner and the long-time spirit of the team, went over and spoke to some of his players. It is not easy to say something to one who has just absorbed one of the worst drubbings in the history of pro football championship games, which the Raiders did, losing to the Bills in the American Football Conference title game here in Rich Stadium, 51-3. But Davis, in black-and-silver Raider jacket, was valiant.

title: We Really Need a Calendar With 13 Months
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Can Make Better Use of the Police It Has Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter as It Was
description: In this amiable winter, an octogenarian New Yorker was recalling to himself how different the season was when he was young -- an endless time of stinging snows and near-zero days, anything but friendly. But he had grown up with grandfather tales of the Great Blizzard of 1888. And just as he had been skeptical of those recollections then, he suspected his own now.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 20, 1990: MONDAY Archer Danls Mdlnd Co Kennnametal Inc Centl & Sth West Corp Rollins Inc Crmptn & Knowles Corp Southern Co TUESDAY Amoco Corp Hillenbrand Inds Inc Ball Corp K Mart Corp Cash Amer Invts Inc Kansas Gas & Elec Co Eaton Corp Loral Corp Edo Corp Norwest Corp Fedders Corp Schwab Charles Corp Gleason Corp Smucker J M Co Glenfed Inc USLife Corp Hexcel Corp WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Co Mapco Inc Baker Hughes Inc Pope & Talbot Inc Downey Svgs & Ln Assn Shaw Inds Inc Energen Corp Tokheim Inc Inland Stl Inds Union Carbide Corp Johnson Ctls Inc Wisconsin Energy Corp THURSDAY CRSS Inc Morton Intl Inc Delta Air Lines Inc Pfizer Inc Empire Dist Elec Co Potlatch Corp Handy & Harman Potomac Elec Pwr Co Health Care Ppty Invs Inc PSI Res Inc Iowa Ill Gas & Elec Co Trinova Corp Jostens Inc Universal Foods Corp FRIDAY Acme Elec Corp Homestake Mng Co Armco Inc Kysor Indl Corp Del Central La Elec Inc McDonnell Douglas Corp CMS Energy Corp Mobil Corp Coachman Inds Inc Monsanto Co Ferro Corp Rollins Env Svcs Inc First Wachovia Corp Wicor Inc Harland John H Co

title: Mario Siletti; Acting Teacher, 65
description: Mario Siletti, an acting teacher who helped found the National Shakespeare Conservatory, died on Jan. 7 at New York University Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Group of 7 Opens Talks On Outlook
description: Against the backdrop of war, the top economic policy makers from the United States and its six main industrial allies gathered in New York yesterday for a two-day assessment of the world economy.

title: Phone Numbers for Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf. Army: (800) 626-1440 Air Force: (800) 253-9276 Marines: (800) 523-2694 Coast Guard: (800) 367-8724 Navy: (800) 255-3808* Navy: (800) 732-1206+ * Immediate family members. + Other relatives and friends Callers will be asked for the spelling of the service member's last name. They should also provide as much information as possible about rank, Social Security number and military unit. Pentagon officials said the phone numbers might often be busy.

title: John C. Morgan, 76; Won Medal of Honor
description: John C. Morgan, whose actions on a World War II bombing mission over Germany won him a Medal of Honor and helped inspire the book "Twelve O'Clock High," has died at the age of 76, his son said today.

title: Knicks Find the Right Mix
description: By putting John Starks and Brian Quinnett in the starting lineup Saturday night, John MacLeod finally woke up the Knicks.

title: Palestinians Are Buoyed By the Attacks on Israel
description: "There is an Arabic proverb which says there are days of honey and days of onion," a young Palestinian, shoulders hunched against wind and rain in the Old City, says philosophically. "For years Israel has known only honey -- now it is tasting the onion."

title: Moderate Quake Jars Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake struck south-central Alaska on Saturday, but no damage or injuries were reported. The earthquake, which occurred about 11 P.M., measured 4.6 on the Richter scale, according to the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer. It was centered about 30 miles northwest of Anchorage, officials said.

title: Haiti Turnout Is Sparse In Legislative Elections
description: Voter turnout was sparse across much of the countryside today in legislative and local government contests that concluded Haiti's first fully free national elections.

title: Paris Journal; Gluttons for Tranquilizers, the French Ask 'Why?'
description: Sparkling with impeccable, sleek fittings, the pharmacies of Paris are hybrids of a cheerful laboratory and a stylish boutique, places that exude promises of beauty and everlasting health. Their clientele often looks equally polished and self-assured.

title: Review/Music; Works by 3 Women
description: With its retrospectives organized around the works of either single composers or groups united by nationality or esthetic, Continuum has introduced New York audiences to a wealth of 20th-century music over the years, and has often brought to light composers, particularly those from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, who are eventually taken into the mainstream. This year, Continuum is celebrating its 25th anniversary, and on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall the organization continued its exploration of the contemporary literature with a program devoted to three female modernists.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about repairs on the No. 7 subway line in Queens misstated how long service disruptions will continue. The line will be closed for eight consecutive weekends, from Jan. 19 until March 11.

title: Bridge
description: The world's strongest tournament ended yesterday in the Netherlands, and the victory went to two stars who were once rivals and are now a partnership. Billy Eisenberg of Los Angeles, who has won world titles for the United States, played with Benito Garozzo of Palm Beach, Fla., who won even more world titles when he was playing for Italy, sometimes against Eisenberg.

title: Younger McEnroe Has a Big Day
description: Patrick McEnroe is not exactly waiting for the day when people refer to John McEnroe as "Patrick's older brother," but he certainly doesn't mind stealing some of the limelight.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Wadkins Rallies to Win: Lanny Wadkins beat a strong wind with one of the finest rounds of his life and rallied from six shots back yesterday to score his 20th career victory, winning the Hawaiian Open in Honolulu by four strokes. The winds, gusting to 35-40 m.p.h. and creating white-caps on the nearby Pacific surf, prohibited anyone else from making a major move. The 41-year-old Wadkins, however, unleashed a seven-under-par 65 -- by three shots the best round of day -- passed nine players and won going away. He scored the 20th victory of his career -- and second in this tournament -- with a 270 total, 18 under par on the Waialae Country Club course. John Cook, a two-stroke leader starting the final round, could do no better than a struggling 75 that left him a distant second. (AP) Geddes Wins by 3: Jane Geddes had two eagles and three birdies over the last nine holes yesterday and overtook Patty Sheehan to win the Ladies Professional Golf Association Jamaica Classic by three strokes. Geddes, whose earlier rounds of 71 and 72 had left her five strokes off Sheehan's lead, cut two strokes off par on the front nine yesterday. She charged into the lead with an eagle on the par-5 15th, regained the lead with an eagle on the par-5 17th and padded her margin with a birdie at No. 18. Geddes finished with a seven-under-par 64 to complete three rounds at 207, six under for the tournament on the 6,202-yard Tryall Golf and Beach Club course in Montego Bay. Sheehan, the defending tournament champion who spent much of her round in a fight for the lead with Dottie Mochrie, bogeyed the last two holes to finish with a 72 and was in second at 210. (AP) Horse Racing Proud 'n' Appeal Wins: Proud 'n' Appeal raced to a five-length victory yesterday in the Broadway Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. The winning time of 1:42 4/5 was a stakes record for the one-mile race, bettering the old mark of 1:43 by Leecoo in 1985. It was the sixth victory in 11 career starts for Proud 'n' Appeal, ridden by John Velazquez and carrying 117 pounds. The winner earned $51,930 and returned $7 for $2 to win. Dusty's Talc, coupled in the wagering with Happy Dapple, finished second. (AP) Pro Basketball Trail Blazers 116, Bucks 112: Terry Porter scored 9 points in the final 3:14, including two game-clinching free throws with 6 seconds to play, as Portland, playing at home, came from 9 points down in the final seven and a half minutes. Porter, who struggled offensively for most of the game, hit a 3-pointer with 3:14 to go, added a driving layup with 43 seconds remaining, then sank four straight free throws to preserve Portland's fourth straight victory. (AP) College Basketball U.C.L.A. 98, California 81: Tracy Murray scored 22 of his 26 points in the first half and Gerald Madkins had 15 of his 18 in the second half as U.C.L.A., playing at home, ended a two-game Pacific-10 Conference losing streak. Don MacLean had 24 points for the Bruins (14-3, 3-2). (AP) Tulane 70, Hofstra 68: Anthony Reed hit a go-ahead 10-foot jumper with 26 seconds remaining as visiting Tulane (8-7) snapped a three-game losing streak. Reed led Tulane with 18 points. Anthony Knight led Hofstra (8-9) with 18 points. (AP)

title: Conflicting Censorship Upsets Many Journalists
description: Many news corespondents covering the war with Iraq are bridling under a system of conflicting rules and confusing censorship.

title: We Really Need a Calendar With 13 Months; What of the Sabbath?
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie A. Kahn and Jeffrey Marcus Are Married
description: Leslie Ann Kahn, the daughter of Lois Kahn of Miami, was married yesterday at the Westbury in New York to Jeffrey Gordon Marcus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Marcus of Manhasset, L.I. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated.

title: 2 Store Owners Are Shot to Death
description: Two store owners -- a Ghanaian immigrant who saved his accountant's salary to buy a laundry business, and a Bronx man who opened a video store not far from his home -- were shot and killed in their stores in the Melrose section Saturday night, the police said.

title: End Gun Violence By Banning Bullets
description: To the Editor:

title: In Ads, Simple Is Replacing Slick
description: There can be little doubt about the subject of a new advertising campaign splashed across the pages of Gourmet magazine and other publications aimed at the affluent. Beneath seemingly candid photographs of fashionable diners is a large banner that declares, "Remy Martin est l'eau de vie."

title: Send a Bit Less Mail, Army Urges Families
description: The United States Central Command has asked the families and friends of those serving in the Persian Gulf war to limit personal mail to first-class letters and audio cassettes.

title: Sure Losers: the Palestinians
description: Saddam Hussein has presented himself as the Palestinians' Great Liberator; Saladin on a white Arabian charger. In fact, he's turned out to be their albatross, weighing down legitimate grievances with the insupportable burden of his bloody aggression.

title: Clothes That Shine In Dark
description: A garment manufacturer in Garfield, N.J., has developed a new line of sportswear that uses a reflective ink to create designs on clothing.

title: Abusive Nursing Home Aide Gets a 6-Month Prison Term
description: A former nursing home aide has been sentenced to six months in prison after she became the first person to be convicted under the state's new law protecting the elderly from abuse in nursing homes.

title: Lynn Weissberg, Lawyer, Is a Bride
description: Lynn G. Weissberg, the daughter of Marcia Weissberg of Elizabeth, N.J., and the late Dr. William W. Weissberg, was married yesterday to Robert M. Bensetler, a son of John Bensetler of Springfield, Pa., and the late Alice Scott. Judge Richard Newman of State Superior Court in Newark performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S. FOILS MISSILE ATTACKS ON 2 SAUDI CITIES; CLAIMS HITS ON IRAQI NUCLEAR AND GAS SITES
description: Iraq launched repeated barrages of missiles toward Saudi Arabia on Sunday night and early this morning, but American missiles fired from the big allied air base here and from Riyadh, the capital, knocked most or all of them from the sky before they could hit their targets.

title: War May Postpone Davis Cup Matches
description: The United States Davis Cup team, which won the cup last year, expects to learn today whether its opening-round match with Mexico will be postponed because of the war in the Persian Gulf. Andre Agassi, Aaron Krickstein, and the doubles tandem of Rick Leach and Jim Pugh is the team designated by the Davis Cup captain, Tom Gorman, to provide the first round of defense of the title the United States captured in December by defeating Australia at St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: We Really Need a Calendar With 13 Months; When Romans Began
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; A Confusing Decade, Its Roots and Its Legacy
description: "Making Sense of the 60's," the latest PBS opus, tells the story of that "most tumultuous, confusing and controversial decade" through the recollections of some of its participants. These middle-aged folk seem generally pleased with their youthful activities, and they cannot complain of unkindness from the producers of this six-hour series, which begins tonight at 9 on Channels 13 and 49 and runs two hours a night through Wednesday.

title: Juliet Man Ray, 79, The Artist's Model And Muse, Is Dead
description: Juliet Man Ray, the widow and major subject of later portraits by the avant-garde painter and photographer Man Ray, died on Thursday at the Huntington Hospital on Long Island. She was 79 years old and lived in Paris.

title: Varied Polish Reaction To a Rebuke Over Jews
description: To Przemyslaw Kociewski, the reading from the pulpit of an official Roman Catholic Church statement condemning anti-Semitism was long overdue. But Helena Michalczyk left the white brick church in this small parish church on the outskirts of Warsaw with her suspicions of Jews intact.

title: Fantastic Finish Puts Giants in Super Bowl vs. Bills
description: On the last play of an intense game today, the Giants got to the Super Bowl. In a spectacular finish to an already spectacular fourth quarter, Matt Bahr's 42-yard field goal with no time remaining gave them a 15-13 upset victory over the 49ers.
