title: Treasury to Sell 2-Year and 5-Year Notes
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes an auction of new three- and six-month bills tomorrow, followed by an auction of new two-year notes on Wednesday and new five-year notes on Thursday.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Both Uniting and Dividing, the War Reaches Into Small Towns of America; In Texas, a Memorial to the Living
description: At her clapboard farmhouse about a mile out of town, Stacey Hogg spent this afternoon carefully stenciling in the names of about 50 men and women on a sheet of plywood that had been painted black, with streaks of tan to give it marble-like effect.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A happy ending: FREDERICA VON STADE and MICHAEL G. GORMAN were married on Dec. 30 in San Francisco. Last year, Ms. von Stade, the mezzo-soprano, was involved in a much publicized divorce case, in which her former husband, PETER ELKUS, contended that as her voice teacher he was entitled to part of her earnings. The court rejected that claim in September.

title: Big Kick Sets Up Giants-Bills Super Bowl
description: The New York Giants won a trip to the Super Bowl yesterday when Matt Bahr kicked a 42-yard field goal on the last play of a tense National Football Conference championship game to defeat the San Francisco 49ers, 15-13.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Prisoners; Iraqi TV Broadcasts Interviews With 7 Identified as Allied Pilots
description: Iraqi television broadcast crackly, sometimes inaudible interviews yesterday with seven men it identified as allied pilots shot down in the Persian Gulf war and taken prisoner. At least four were heard criticizing the allied attack.

title: Darrell Barnett; Dancer, 41
description: Darrell Barnett, a dancer with the Harkness and Joffrey ballet companies in the 1970's, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Reacting to War

title: SOVIET COMMANDOS STAGE LATVIA RAID; AT LEAST 5 KILLED
description: Soldiers from a special unit of the Soviet Interior Ministry gunned their way into a Latvian government ministry building on Sunday night, then left early this morning, according to reports from Riga, the Latvian capital. At least five people were reported to have been killed.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Helps Troubled Man to Live Fully
description: Alex C. could be the only person in the world who works on an assembly line wearing a vintage 1920's pin-striped three-piece suit, a fedora, arm garters and white spats.

title: Market Place; Short-Term Lift For Arms Stocks
description: THESE are days of trial for American military contractors. Many of the weapons systems they have built over the last two decades have been deployed in the war with Iraq. And after years of being derided as a hotbed of fraud and waste, the industry has gotten a big psychological lift from seeing many of its advanced products work as advertised in the heat of combat.

title: Review/Dance; Memories Of a Life In Texas
description: Carol Clements did something ingenious in "Chicken Tawk," the dance-theater work she presented on Friday night at the Dia Art Foundation in SoHo. She started out by being obnoxious. Then she slowly revealed that she was portraying a complex and ultimately sympathetic young woman in this solo, which was directed by Constance McCord.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A6-12

title: CLAIMS HITS ON IRAQI NUCLEAR AND GAS SITES; The Nuclear Targets
description: Iraq has three nuclear-reactor sites and at least four major nuclear-research laboratories that would be prime targets for allied warplanes. All three reactors, used for research and not to generate power, are at Tuwaitha, a city about 15 miles southeast of Baghdad.

title: Subway Plan On Homeless Is Abandoned
description: The Transit Authority's ambitious plans for mass sweeps to clear the subway system of homeless people have largely been abandoned, undermined by winter weather and the reluctance of transit officers, officials say.

title: Europeans Optimistic on Short War
description: Europe's economy caught a cold in August when oil prices jumped after Iraq invaded Kuwait, but a quick allied victory in the Persian Gulf could help provide a cure.

title: Bills' Quick Offense Trounces Raiders, 51-3
description: In a place that requires optimism at this time of year, the snow-blown fans of the Buffalo Bills, who had become much too accustomed to January disappointments, saw their team exceed every wildest hope this afternoon.

title: Most of Iraqi Air Force Safe, U.S. Command Concludes
description: After four days of aerial bombardment, American officials have concluded that the vast majority of Iraq's air force has escaped destruction.

title: Rosana Madrigal Weds Richard Gelb
description: Rosana Abad Santos Madrigal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio P. Madrigal of Manila, was married there yesterday to Richard Eden Gelb, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Gelb of New York. The ceremony was performed by Bishop Frederic Escaler of Legaspi City and the Rev. Moises Cabrera at the San Sebastian Roman Catholic Church.

title: Ohio St. Coach Still Building
description: Randy Ayers chuckled when someone asked him recently whether tonight's showdown with Indiana in Bloomington would be the most significant game of the season for Ohio State. Ayers, the Buckeyes' second-year coach, was reminded of an observation made by Duane Thomas, the former Dallas Cowboys running back, when asked if the Super Bowl was the ultimate football game. Thomas said that if it was the ultimate game, why were they playing another one the following year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a feud between two lawyers, Alan M. Dershowitz and Michael F. Armstrong, misstated the day of a debate between the two at Fordham Law School. It was on Thursday.

title: Episcopal and Lutheran Churches Propose a Union Just Short of Merger
description: Leaders of the Episcopal Church and the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America have proposed a plan to bring their churches into a close union, just short of merger.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: News Analysis; Hard Times, Better Allies
description: Cooperation between the Bush Administration and Israel in dealing with Iraq's missile attacks has strikingly improved United States-Israeli relations after two years of mounting tension, Israeli and American officials said today.

title: Anti-Abortion Measure Rejected in Corpus Christi
description: Voters resoundingly rejected a city charter amendment on Saturday that would have declared human life to begin at conception.

title: After 303 Years, Sunday Is a Workday at Lloyd's
description: David Peachey, an aviation underwriter, did not seem to care much that he was helping to make history at the Lloyd's of London insurance market today, which was open for the first Sunday in its 303 years.

title: Washington Talk; Abortion Fight Goes On, State by State by State
description: In what has become an annual ritual, anti abortion demonstrators will march on the nation's capital on Tuesday to mark the 18th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision recognizing a constitutional right to abortion.

title:
ON YOUR OWN: The Eternal Race Between Man and Woman;
He: Secret Fears Acknowledged
description: THE dawn broke blue and cool over Central Park. I slowly ran around the first lap of the reservoir, letting each muscle ease into action. The second lap around the 1.6-mile loop, I pushed myself into oxygen debt. Then I headed home. A morning run is a beautiful way to start the day. But I wasn't out for peace and recreation. I was building up mileage and endurance to turn back a threat to my manhood.

title: Union Blocks Graham Tour
description: The American Guild of Musical Artists has informed the Martha Graham Dance Company that because of the Middle East crisis it will not allow the Graham dancers to travel to Paris for the weeklong engagement that was to start tomorrow at the Paris Opera/Garnier.

title: Stardom or Obscurity: A Dancer on the Brink
description: Whirling gracefully in the complex embrace of a pas de deux, Philip Neal does not look at all like a young ballet dancer at the turning point of his career. Relaxed, exuberantly at work in a practice room at the New York State Theater in Manhattan, he is soaring to the music with Helene Alexopoulos, his partner for the morning. He hardly has the look of a performer withstanding the intense pressures of competition.

title: 7 Hurt in Oil Refinery Blast
description: An explosion and fire ripped through an oil refinery on Saturday, shaking houses in nearby neighborhoods and sending black smoke about 1,500 feet into the sky. Seven workers were injured, one critically, in the explosion at the BP America refinery about seven miles north of Bellingham, fire officials said. A unit used to make crude oil into gasoline exploded while being put back into operation after repairs, said a company spokesman, Jerry Eklund.

title: Conflicting Censorship Upsets Many Journalists
description: Many news corespondents covering the war with Iraq are bridling under a system of conflicting rules and confusing censorship.

title: The Hostetler Cow Pasture
description: UP on a platform in the Giants' locker room, Jeff Hostetler was surrounded by notebooks and microphones. And not far away, four men and a 9-year-old youngster were wearing gray hooded sweatshirts with a blue "Giants" and a blue 15 across the chest: Hostetler's father, Norman; his brothers, Ron, Doug and Todd, and his nephew Jared were basking in the celebration of the 15-13 victory that dethroned the two-time defending champion San Francisco 49ers and put the Giants into Super Bowl XXV against the Buffalo Bills.

title: Bahr Has a Very Healthy Day
description: Only a week ago Matt Bahr, his neck sore from being jammed on a tackle during a kickoff in the playoff game against the Chicago Bears, was concerned about what he termed his "general health." And when a strange line showed up on an X-ray, he underwent a series of tests.

title: In Tense, Fearful Lithuania, a Bride and Groom Exchange Hopeful Vows
description: Against the tide of crisis, Yuratia Shaevienie went ahead with her wedding and managed to be radiant today amid the wintry frost that glazed this embattled republic. She was a study in white against white, hope against hope.

title: Clemens Agent Comments
description: An agent for the Boston Red Sox pitcher Roger Clemens said a fracas involving Clemens, Clemens's brother, Gary, and a police officer at a Houston nightclub was "an unfortunate misunderstanding."

title: What Only the War Dead Can Teach
description: From the steps of the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, 14-year-old Kristin Progule looked out over the rolling lawns of Arlington National Cemetery and the files of white marble headstones lined up in military formation to the horizon.

title: Figuring the Cost if War Is Long
description: Some financial analysts are beginning to calculate the consequences of a long Middle Eastern war for the Federal budget deficit and the bond markets.

title: Gulf War Is Creating Havoc for Networks
description: The war in the Persian Gulf has cost the broadcast networks millions of dollars, scuttled program schedules and thrown the seasonlong battle for ratings into turmoil.

title: 10,000 at Jewish Rally Urge Hussein Ouster
description: Amid fluttering American and Israeli flags, thousands of demonstrators at a midtown Manhattan rally in support of Israel and the allied troops lustily cheered repeated calls for the ouster of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein -- not only from Kuwait, but also from power in his own country.

title: REBELS ARE POSING THREAT IN PANAMA
description: The leaders of a military revolt last month have eluded capture with the aid of active-duty officers and constitute a terrorist threat to the United States-installed Government, American and Panamanian officials say.

title: An Unusual Day For Football Fans
description: It was an unusual day for America's professional football fans. At noon, 30 minutes before game-time at Orchard Park, N.Y., NBC opened its broadcast of the American Conference championship game not with Buffalo's Jim Kelly or Los Angeles' Jay Schroeder, the opposing quarterbacks, but with a video of the after-burners of a jet blazing.

title: In the National Gathering Place, a Truce
description: So far, it has not been a made-for-TV war. Viewers have heard much but seen little of the destruction being rained on Baghdad.

title: Rice Stared Down by Collins
description: As the afternoon edged forward, Mark Collins never changed his psychological game plan. He kept staring coldly into Jerry Rice's eyes, kept hoping it would act as a edge, kept believing it would finally unnerve the 49ers' receiver.

title: Croatian Police Forces Move To Counter Yugoslav Army
description: Special police units, making use of an extension of a federal deadline for disbanding of unauthorized militias, fanned out today across the Croatian capital to counter any move by the Yugoslav army against the independence-minded republic. Slovenia also readied its forces.

title: An Everyday Officer's War For Neighborhood Quality
description: Probably nobody in the 103d Precinct -- not the tough and towering commander, Deputy Inspector Philip W. Erickson, not the crisply efficient administrative lieutenant, Joseph McGrann, not even the crusty 34-year veteran desk officer, Marty Stancik -- has more to do with keeping things running day to day than Officer Ronald Guilford.

title: Southern Cal Star Arrested for Drugs
description: Southern Cal's Todd Marinovich, one of the nation's top college football quarterbacks, was arrested early today for investigation of cocaine possession.

title: Martin Luther King's Moral Authority
description: Feelings about the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. have run high between his last birthday and the one we celebrate today. Dr. King has returned to the news under circumstances that cause some Americans to wrangle over what he was at the time of his assassination and what he means today.

title: Amid Prayers for Peace, Preachers Split on War
description: After days of brutal war in the Persian Gulf, with round-the-clock bombing and reports of fearful missile strikes and lost pilots, many people across the New York metropolitan area and the nation paused over the weekend to pray for peace and to reflect on spiritual values at a time of crisis.

title: More on the Gulf
description: IRAQI PLEA TO ARABS Saddam Hussein sought to rally Arab supporters and Iraqis, saying Iraq had used only a fraction of its weaponry so far. Page A10.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dozens of contemporary artists, photographers and craftsmen of note have donated works to the fifth arts auction organized by the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York: DAVID HOCKNEY, ELLSWORTH KELLY, JASPER JOHNS and BRUCE WEBER, to name just a few.

title: Furor Erupts Over Hong Kong Plan
description: Plans for a new airport here have led to a furor over who now speaks for this British colony's 5.7 million people -- Britain or China, which is scheduled to take control in 1997.

title: Nederlander Defends Yanks' Policy on Free Agents
description: FOR the better part of the off season, the silence in the Bronx has been deafening. Free agents have come and gone in a lively market, but the Yankees, except for a dabble here and there, have for the most part sat it out, allowing most heavyweight players and heavy-spending teams to pass them by.

title: On the Kuwait Border, Iraqi Shells Empty a Town
description: Since allied warplanes began their sorties against Iraq on Thursday, this virtually abandoned Saudi city just a few hundred yards from the Kuwaiti border has taken the brunt of the damage done in Saudi Arabia by Iraqi forces.

title: Montana's Season Comes to End
description: When Joe Montana left the game with 9 minutes 41 seconds left after a crunching sack by Leonard Marshall, he was gone for good. Montana broke a bone in his right hand just below the little finger and also suffered a bruised sternum. He would have missed the Super Bowl even if the 49ers had won.

title: Demonstrators Foil Plans For a Ku Klux Klan Rally
description: Ku Klux Klan members who gathered today outside the state Capitol to protest the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday were pelted with snowballs and epithets by an angry mass of more than 1,000 counter-demonstrators.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas Offers Help in Crisis
description: With the start of the Persian Gulf war, one New York City advertiser has begun a campaign to offer help to military families, a move that also promotes its corporate image.

title: Busch Makes Foreign Moves
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the world's largest brewer, announced a number of management and organizational changes on Friday, apparently aimed at extending the company's reach overseas.

title: WAR SUMMARY
description: MISSILE ATTACKS ON SAUDI ARABIA The United States said Iraq launched 10 Scud missiles toward Saudi Arabia Sunday night and early today, but American Patriot missiles knocked most or all of them from the sky. As warplanes bombarded Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait for the fourth day, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces, said Iraqi nuclear installations and factories producing chemical and biological weapons had been dealt punishing blows. But 80 percent of the Iraqi Air Force may have withstood the onslaught in hardened shelters. PRISONERS REPORTEDLY TAKEN President Saddam Hussein went on the air to rally Iraqis and Arab supporters to win "the mother of all battles." He forecast a long war, saying that his country's land forces had not yet been engaged and that only a fraction of its air force had been lost. News reports from Baghdad said residents were scavenging for food and beginning to draw water from the Tigris River. ISRAELI-U.S. RAPPROCHEMENT American and Israel officials agreed that cooperation in dealing with Iraqi missile attacks on Israel had dramatically improved relations between their two Governments after two years of estrangement. THE PENTAGON'S TALLY OF LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Aricraft: At least 15 planes, 9 of them American, have been lost. Three were lost on Saturday - two F-16 Air Force fighters with a single pilot each, and one Air Force F-15E attack jet with two crewmen listed as missing. Of the six allied aircraft lost, three were British, one was Italian, one Saudi and one Kuwait. Personnel: One American dead and 12 missing in action, 3 of whom may have been captured. Nine members of allied-forces are also dead or missing, some of whom may have been taken prisoner. IRAQI FORCES Aircraft: The U.S. command said a total 15 planes had been downed in aerial combat, including 5 yesterday. Personnel: Twenty-three Iraqi soldiers were captured and 5 killed in Saturday's raid on Kuwaiti oil platforms. The complete death toll among Iraqis in air attacks is unknown.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Delaware State Housing Authority is offering $40.4 million in tax-exempt senior home mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.80 percent for a bond due in 2020 through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Yields on serial bonds range from 6.10 percent for those due in 1992 to 7 percent in 2000. A bond due in 2013, with sinking-fund payments that give it an average life of 3.22 years, yields 7.25 percent. Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service, the offering includes zero-coupon bonds that pay no interest but, if held to maturity, yield from 7.50 percent in 2001 to 7.75 percent in 2010; prices range from $467.28 per $1,000 of bonds to $221.34 per $1,000. * Indiana Gas Co. Inc., a unit of Indiana Energy Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $75 million in debt securities through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Common Stock * E'Town Corp., Westfield, N.J., has filed for 500,000 common shares through Kidder, Peabody & Co. * John Nuveen & Co., Chicago, has filed for the initial public offering in February of three tax-exempt funds, the Nuveen Florida Investment Quality Municipal Fund, the Nuveen New Jersey Investment Quality Municipal Fund and the Nuveen Pennsylvania Investment Quality Municipal Fund, through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. Each fund will be offering five million common shares. * Sports-Tech International Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., citing poor market conditions, has withdrawn its registration statement for an offering of a million units. Each unit would have consisted of one common share and one four-year warrant to buy a half common share. * Washington Energy Co., Seattle, has filed for 2.65 million common shares through Lehman Brothers Inc. The shares are expected to be offered in early February.

title: Debra Paris Wed To Seth J. Finkel
description: Debra Paris, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Paris of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., to Seth Joseph Finkel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Finkel of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Azriel Fellner performed the ceremony.

title: Budget Cuts Jar University of California
description: The University of California, regarded by many as the nation's leading state university system, faces its deepest crisis since Gov. Ronald Reagan fired its president and slashed its budget nearly a quarter of a century ago.

title: Mr. Bush Pours Oil on Troubled Traders
description: Mideast war is supposed to send oil prices skyward and oil-importing economies downward. But that's not what happened last week. Allied forces bombed Iraq and Kuwait -- and oil prices nosedived more than 30 percent, the biggest one-day drop in history. That caught oil companies flat-footed. Indeed, expecting prices to rise, they were promising to freeze prices as a gesture of good will against charges of profiteering.

title: Unions at Javits Center Are Accused of Abuses
description: When the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in 1986, the center's officials pledged to keep exhibition costs low and mobsters out.

title: Bills Overwhelming But Not Quite Perfect
description: The Buffalo Bills had only one failure today in their game against the Los Angeles Raiders. The point-after-touchdown kick by Scott Norwood was blocked by Scott Davis's left hand after the fourth Buffalo touchdown.

title: More Banks Turn to Wall St. to Sell C.D.'s.
description: American banks are turning to Wall Street brokerages with increased frequency to help them attract new depositors by selling the banks' Federally insured certificates of deposit.

title: Bills in a Hurry to Beat Raiders
description: After the Buffalo Bills' first five plays, which moved the ball with lightning speed from their 25 to the Los Angeles 20, the Raiders called a time out. This was a basketball-type time out, one to regroup, to suck a little air and try to grasp what was happening to the defense, second best in the American Conference this season.

title: U.S. Wants Technology Trade Curb
description: The United States is circulating to its allies and to American businesses proposed restrictions on exporting chemical and biological material and missile technologies to third world countries.

title: Excerpts From Sessions On Missiles and Goals
description: Following are excerpts from briefings by Lieut. Col. Mike Gallagher and Lieut. Col. Greg Pepin, American miliary spokesmen. The Gallagher briefing, transcribed by Reuters, took place early today and the Pepin briefing, from the Associated Press, was on Sunday: Gallagher Statement

title: Reviews/Music; A Meditation in Playfulness
description: At the beginning of "House Cleaning, Food, Sex, Money and Death," a solo performance piece the experimental composer Linda Montano presented at the Kitchen on Saturday evening, Ms. Montano impersonated a white-habited nun in oversize sunglasses named Sister Rose Augustine.

title: Outdoors: Paddling in the Northlands
description: IT was winter again in the Upper Peninsula in Michigan. When the snow came, an abundant, purifying snow that fell six or eight inches at a time, ski-resort owners danced in it, children rolled in it and the people who had been entertaining fantasies about a mild, snowless season turned inward, to their televisions and Scrabble boards. It was winter again. We collected our camping gear, dug the boats out of the snow and went canoeing down the Au Sable River.

title: Put Moscow in a Deep Freeze
description: Since U.S. economic aid and other manifestations of improving U.S.-Soviet relations have been based on continuing Soviet reform, President Bush needs to do more than reproach Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: Why Hurry Into a Costly Land War?
description: The allies have won the first phase of the war with air power, and are talking about how to win the land war against Iraq's half a million men in Kuwait. Fortunately, this time they haven't given themselves an ultimatum to start the second phase by a date certain, but officials talk about the desert battle as if it were inevitable.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two News Organizations To Promote War Coverage
description: WHILE most big advertisers are exceedingly reluctant to tie their advertising to the Persian Gulf war, some media companies are not being quite so shy.

title: Woeful Fumble For 49ers' Craig
description: When the doors to the San Francisco 49ers' locker room swung open, all that could be heard was the pitter-patter of water dripping against the shower floor and walls. Some of the 49ers were still in front of their lockers and some were hiding in the training room. All of them were silent, seemingly mesmerized.

title: TV Guide Growth Plan: Bigger Pages
description: Faced with increasing competition from television supplements in Sunday newspapers, TV Guide will begin testing a larger version of its digest-sized magazine in March.

title: Israeli Tension Eases a Bit, as New U.S. Help Arrives
description: After a welcome quiet night, the Israeli Government began trying today to move the nation out of its state of siege, while warning that more Iraqi missile attacks probably still lie ahead.

title: War Hero Status Possible for the Computer Chip
description: If the Pentagon's claims of success in the Persian Gulf war bear up, a hero of the conflict will be the ubiquitous computer chip, no larger than a fingernail and usually made of silicon, which processes reams of information in an instant for planes, bombs, sensors and cruise missiles.

title: More Mexicans Come to U.S. to Stay
description: In a marked shift in immigration trends, increasing numbers of Mexicans are coming to the United States to stay rather than to work for a few months as seasonal farm laborers, new studies show.

title: Bad Memory Erased With Three Big Plays
description: In one corner of the Giants' euphoric locker room, someone was recalling the sack that put Joe Montana out of the game. In another, there was talk about the fumble that gave the Giants one final chance to drive the field. Somewhere else, they were replaying the startling run by Gary Reasons that kept alive a fourth-quarter march.

title: Metro Matters; The Home Front: A People Divided Knows No Peace
description: "What are we fighting for?" the Rev. Charles L. Norris, pastor of Bethesda Missionary Baptist Church in Jamaica, Queens, and a member of New York City's Human Rights Commission, demanded last week.

title: Critic's Notebook; High Tech and Spirits at Rio Rock Festival
description: Rock festivals have entered the computer age with Rock in Rio II, the 10-day, nine-concert series that opened on Friday night here at Maracana Stadium.

title: U.S. Sees Some Progress in Japanese Trade Talks
description: Japanese and American trade negotiators resume their talks this week after an initial round that the American side characterized as showing "steady incremental progress" on some issues but little forward movement on many others.

title: Personal Bankruptcies Mounting With the Trepidation Lessening
description: Throughout most of the 1980's, Paul Bernier, like many people here, prospered. He owned a 20-year-old contracting business. He also owned a fairly modest $300,000 home in this wealthy Fairfield County town.

title: Gina Davidson Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Gina V. Davidson, the daughter of Cantor and Mrs. Louis E. Davidson of Livingston, N.J., and Roman R. Rossell, a son of Dr. Ana Rossell and Dr. Rafael Rossell, both of Brooklyn, took place yesterday at the Manor in West Orange, N.J. The bride's father officiated.

title: Vicki Panzier Is Married
description: Vicki Robin Panzier, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Panzier of Woodmere, L.I., and Michael S. Gross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Gross of East Lansing, Mich., were married last evening by Rabbi Philip Lazowski at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Mrs. Gross, 25 years old, is an associate in the corporate finance department at Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York. She is a cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. The bridegroom, 29, is a principal at Apollo Advisers, an investment management concern in New York. He is a graduate of the University of Michigan with an M.B.A. from Northwestern University.

title: Martin Luther King Jr.'s Birthday
description: NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Optional. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular garbage pickups and recycling. No street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Open. Transportation: Buses, subways, L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on regular schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedule. Some modified bus schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Metro North and New Haven lines on regular schedule.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Many people have said that we could win this with an air war alone. That's entirely conceivable. Many people have said that it's absolutely necessary to have a ground war. That's entirely conceivable also." -- Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf. [ A8:4. ]

title: Eastern's Rivals Stand to Benefit
description: The shutting of Eastern Airlines on Friday night is likely to benefit Delta Air Lines and Pan American World Airways in particular, because they have competed directly with Eastern's largest business, carrying passengers from the Northeast to Atlanta and Florida.

title: Review/Ballet; In 'Scotch Symphony,' a New Sylphide and Swain
description: Inspired by the grandeur and freshness of the Scottish landscape and massed regiments when he visited Edinburgh in 1952, George Balanchine paid homage to both in "Scotch Symphony," created soon after. Balanchine's inspiration is evident in the sweet-spirited formality of the ballet. But "Scotch Symphony" is also a loving, slightly teasing homage to 19th-century Romantic ballet and its conventions. And that was made clear in a stylish performance of the work by the New York City Ballet on Saturday evening at the New York State Theater.

title: Tide of Anti-Catholicism Is on the Rise; What Cardinal Wrote
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Today; Markets Open
description: In observance of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, Federal Government offices will be closed today. State and local government offices will also be closed in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and most other states, as will many banks. Financial markets in the United States will be open, although the Federal Reserve will be closed and the weekly Treasury bill auction will be postponed until Tuesday.

title: Paul A. Roberts; Consultant, 54
description: Paul A. Roberts, a personnel consultant in Manhattan and past president of the Association of Personnel Consultants of New York State, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan and Stanfordville, N.Y.

title: Dr. King's Widow Asks End to War in the Gulf
description: On the eve of a Federal holiday honoring her husband, Coretta Scott King called today for an immediate cease-fire in the Persian Gulf and an end to what she described as a system that puts militarism ahead of education.

title: Tide of Anti-Catholicism Is on the Rise; It Hurts to Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: Return of Welfare Hotel Is Angering West Siders
description: As New York City began temporarily lodging the first of 190 families in the Regent Hotel, residents in its Upper West Side neighborhood and advocates for the homeless had the same reaction: not again.

title: 100,000 in Moscow Protest Crackdown
description: More than 100,000 people marched to the Kremlin under cold gray skies today to denounce the bloodshed in Lithuania and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's increasingly hard line.

title: Review/Television; Tyne Daly in a Marriage Gone Wrong
description: Tyne Daly is on a versatility binge. On the television show "Cagney and Lacey," she was a tough big-hearted New York City cop. Then she emerged on Broadway as Rose, the brassy stage mother in "Gypsy." Now back on television, she's having a go at being an utterly respectable, ultimately miserable surburban matron. "The Last to Go," a made-for-television movie based on a novel by Rand Richards Cooper, is a collection of bittersweet scenes from an American marriage. Ms. Daly steals most of them.

title: Review/Theater; The Limits of Love and Little Glass Animals
description: Emily Mann opened her first season tonight as the artistic director of the McCarter Theater with a production of "The Glass Menagerie" that demonstrates the director's fidelity to Tennessee Williams and the play's eloquence, undiminished after 46 years. "The Glass Menagerie" remains Williams's most deeply personal work, a play that expresses both his rite of passage and a coming to terms with family ghosts.

title: Firefighter's Body Is Found
description: Paterson firefighters have found the body of a missing colleague, two days after a fire destroyed much of two city blocks. The body of the firefighter, John Anthony Nicosia, was found on Saturday afternoon in the corner of a women's apparel shop called the Underground II, where the fire is believed to have started. Mr. Nicosia, 28 years old, was lost inside the burning building in the first minutes of the blaze on Thursday. The firefighter was a member of the first company to arrive at the fire, which burned out of control for more than 12 hours and caused about $15 million in damage.

title: Jeanne A. Henabery; Executive, 61
description: Jeanne A. Henabery, a public relations specialist in the beauty and fashion field, died on Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reviews/Music; Flute and Piano at the Met
description: It is an unusual and pleasing experience to walk through an open and active museum of art on the way to an evening of music. It makes music no nearer to or further from the visual arts, but it makes one feel an imagined nearness nonetheless.

title: Captive Condors Lay Eggs At 2 Locations in California
description: Two pairs of California condors have laid eggs in captivity, raising hopes that the birds might be freed, wildlife officials said today.

title: Susan Masling and Eric Rubel Wed
description: Susan Lynn Masling, a lawyer for the Department of Justice in Washington, and Eric Alexander Rubel, an associate in the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, were married yesterday at the Arts Club of Washington by Rabbi Isaac Serotta.

title: Magazine Revenues Up, But Ad Pages Decrease
description: Total magazine advertising revenues in December 1990 were up nearly 6 percent from December 1989, the Publishers Information Bureau reports. But the number of advertising pages was down nearly 2 percent.

title: National Dairy Board Drops DDB Needham
description: The National Dairy Board has dropped DDB Needham, Chicago, as the agency for its cheese account. The board decided to consolidate the $20 million account, which had been handled by DDB Needham for more than three years, with other business handled by Grey Advertising, New York.

title: Tide of Anti-Catholicism Is on the Rise
description: To the Editor

title: Excerpts of Interviews With Men Identified as Pilots Downed Over Iraq
description: Iraq broadcast interviews yesterday with seven uniformed men that it identified as allied pilots downed in the first days of the Persian Gulf war. Audio portions of interviews with six of the men were broadcast by the Cable News Network, which obtained a recording through its correspondent in Baghdad, Peter Arnett. Following is a partial transcript of the CNN transmission. First Prisoner

title: NEWS FROM FRONT BLUNTS PROTESTS
description: Before the bombs began falling over Baghdad, David Pierce was a staunch opponent of military action in the Middle East. Now he feels that the United States has no choice but to keep fighting.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Both Uniting and Dividing, the War Reaches Into Small Towns of America; Flags and Protest Mix in Vermont
description: Allen Devereux took his American flag out of winter storage today and put it on the pole in front of his mountainside home in this tiny snow-covered hamlet.

title: A 'New' Sharpton: Maturing of a Maverick?
description: When the Rev. Al Sharpton leads a march across the Brooklyn Bridge today to celebrate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., he is scheduled to be greeted on the steps of City Hall by Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Desperation and Folly
description: "It is a great day," a Palestinian in Amman said on Friday. "It is the first time we have hit Israel with missiles."

title: ON YOUR OWN: The Eternal Race Between Man and Woman; She: Part Pride, Part Pettiness
description: IT was a crisp, clear Sunday afternoon in Princeton. I trotted down my driveway and turned right onto the road, picking up speed as I warmed up and relishing the quiet, the winter chill, the sight of towering fir trees and sloping lawns. I passed a few neighbors' houses, then turned right, pushing myself to charge up the short hill.

title: Fans Focus Beyond Game Too
description: Rafael Trinidad seemed to echo the thoughts of many of those in and around New York City who watched yesterday's Giants victory over San Francisco.

title: IRAQI SAYS ALLIES FACE HARDER WAR
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sought to rally Arab supporters and embattled Iraqis today, saying his forces had used only a fraction of their weaponry to fight and win what he again called "the mother of all battles."

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL SIMON, the pop singer, is making a donation to the effort to have Arizona declare a paid state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: To Freedom Triumphs
description: To Freedom, running for the first time in more than five months, held off a 32-to-1 shot, Dark Brew, by a neck this afternoon to win the $58,945 Spectacular Bid Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: Books of The Times; In Wartime, the Conflict Between Lies and Truth
description: The Voice of America Propaganda and Democracy, 1941-1945 By Holly Cowan Shulman 282 pages. University of Wisconsin Press. $37.50 hard cover; $12.95 paperback.

title: Steinbrenner Returns To U.S. Olympic Post
description: After six months of voluntary inactivity while the clamor over his problems with baseball abated, George Steinbrenner has returned to his post as vice president of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A8-A12

title: 159 Freed From Soviet Plane As Bulgarians Seize Hijacker
description: The police overpowered the hijacker of a Soviet aircraft carrying 159 passengers and crew today after the plane was forced to make an emergency landing in Bulgaria.

title: Orienting Yourself Worldwide In Time
description: GEOCLOCK puts the world at your fingertips or, rather, just beyond them, on your computer's screen.

title: Few Towns Ready for Connecticut Recycling Law
description: Three weeks past Connecticut's self-imposed deadline for its communities to begin mandatory recycling, most are still scrambling to start their programs.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Rescue; Navy Pilot Is Plucked From Iraqi Desert
description: A downed American Navy pilot was rescued in the Iraqi desert this afternoon by an Air Force team in what military officials said was the first successful such mission over hostile territory in the war with Iraq.

title: Events in Middle East Could Postpone Game
description: With an eye to Middle East developments, the National Football League continued its cautious stance today regarding the games it plays. But this time, it involved the Super Bowl.

title: Flights to the Middle East Are Limited and Uncertain
description: Airline travel to the Middle East, especially to and from cities like Tel Aviv; Amman, Jordan, and Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, has become limited and uncertain as most of the world's leading carriers have canceled flights to the region.

title: A Potent Peptide Prompts an Urge to Cuddle
description: IT is just the potion for a bellicose world. In some cases, it works as an aphrodisiac, inspiring males to seek females more ardently and females to invite their overtures more passionately.

title: White Agrees to Pact
description: The center fielder Devon White and the Toronto Blue Jays reached agreement yesterday on a one-year contract for $750,000.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.75 percent last week, up from 9.63 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey released on Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.74 percent, down from 7.76 percent last week and the lowest since 7.66 percent in the week that ended on May 13, 1988.

title: Special Order for Gulf
description: UNITED STATES military personnel in the Persian Gulf war are using surprisingly advanced personal computers to handle logistical and administrative tasks in Saudi Arabia, according to companies that supplied the computer systems.

title: Dinkins Word On Garbage Is Questioned
description: Environmental groups and several elected officials say recent actions of the Dinkins administration strongly suggest that the Mayor is moving toward greater use of garbage incinerators, despite his 1989 campaign promise to delay a decision until 1993.

title: Rift Grows on Protecting Patients From Surgeons With AIDS Virus
description: ASK patients if they would like to know whether their surgeon is infected with the AIDS virus, and most will say yes. Even the nation's leading medical and dental associations announced last week that infected doctors should warn their patients.

title: Nothing Must Halt Telecommunications Flow
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Plan for More Police Mired in Mistrust in Albany
description: It is a political axiom in the state Capitol, as in most seats of government, that it is unwise to oppose any plan aimed at putting police on the streets.

title: Soft on Crime in Trenton
description: These days, most state legislators consider toughness on crime as important a political posture as reluctance to tax. That's why New Jersey's lawmakers last year enacted a strict ban on semiautomatic assault weapons.

title: Our Towns; Nate the Clothier: Bidding Farewell In Way That Fits
description: "O.K.," said Nate, peering down his horn-rimmed bifocals, "you're a man. Do you just love to shop around for clothes? Of course not! Men aren't missionaries always seeking new places. Men want a good store. Good value. Good treatment. Good talk -- sports, politics, maybe markets. And then outta there. Am I right? So, that's me, Nate Friedman, clothing therapist."

title: Henry Piper Andrews Jr., Executive, 43
description: Henry Piper Andrews Jr., a vice president of Citicorp, died on Wednesday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan and Quogue, L.I.

title: Substance Confirmed
description: The police in Newport Beach, Calif., said yesterday that a substance found on Todd Marinovich, the Southern California quarterback, has been determined to be cocaine. Marinovich was also carrying a small amount of marijuana, according to authorities.

title: Cycles of the Sun
description: New analysis of solar observations may have produced a solution to the mystery of why the Sun experiences its 22-year cycles of magnetic storms and sunspot activity.

title: Davis Injured Thumb In Defeat to Taylor
description: Aaron Davis sustained a fracture and dislocation at the base of his left thumb Saturday night when he lost his World Boxing Association welterweight title to Meldrick Taylor.

title: Eliminate Saddam Hussein
description: Without anyone saying so, allied war aims seem to have changed. While the official purpose still is to liberate Kuwait, the actual goal is the destruction of enough of Saddam Hussein's war machine to assure he can't go home and start again.

title: Review/Ice-Skating; An Escape to a World of Grace and Glitter
description: It's been a week of sitting home and watching the world skate on thin ice and a pause may be in order, without for a moment forgetting the awesome imbalances of global politics, to go out and relax by seeing some great skaters demonstrate equilibrium on the real stuff.

title: As Ethnic Albanians Join Exodus, Greeks Are Appealing for a Halt
description: Greece issued a new appeal today to Albanian refugees to stop streaming into this country. The appeal came after a new exodus, this time consisting mostly of ethnic Albanians instead of ethnic Greeks.

title: Roadblocks to Equivalency Exam Deny Many a Chance for Success
description: For thousands of New York City residents with no high school degree, passing the equivalency test is the key to getting a job, getting off welfare or pursuing vocational or college studies. But educators who prepare people throughout the city for the test say the route is increasingly obstructed by delays and bureaucratic complications that put lives on hold for months or more.

title: PATTERNS
description: Travel Bans

title: Female Canaries as Listeners
description: A MALE canary sings such intricate songs to attract mates and deter competing males that a large region of its brain, called the higher vocal center, is devoted to composing songs.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQ'S MILITARY REPORTED HURT BUT NOT HALTED IN 5 DAYS' RAIDS; VOWS CAPTIVES WILL BE SHIELDS
description: Five days of air war against Iraq, one of the most intensive air campaigns in the history of warfare, has weakened Iraq but has not eliminated its capacity to wage war or Saddam Hussein's ability to command his forces, Administration officials and private military experts said today.

title: Two Hornets Out
description: The Charlotte Hornets placed the guard Rex Chapman and the forward Randolph Keys on the injured list yesterday.

title: Election Today in New Hispanic District
description: For the first time in more than a century, the focus was on the concerns of Hispanic residents in a campaign that ended today for the job of Los Angeles County supervisor.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, promoted Susan Collens Heide to vice president of credit research in the company's corporate investment division. * Chemical Bank, New York, promoted Patricia Meier and William E. Newell Jr. to managing directors. * Datapoint Corp. San Antonio, which develops, manufactures and markets computer and communications products, appointed Joe W. Tucker vice president of its United States operations. * Genus Inc., Mountain View, Calif., a manufacturer of tungsten chemical vapor deposition systems, named Dr. David Cheng vice president of its systems engineering unit. * Metropolitan Financial Corp., Minneapolis, a financial services holding company, appointed Steven B. Dewald senior vice president and corporate controller and chief accounting officer. * Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc., Oshkosh, Wis., a clothing manufacturer, promoted Oliver E. Wood Jr., to corporate vice president of international sales and marketing. * Polygram Holding Inc., New York, a unit of Polygram N.V., London, named Helen Murphy vice president and treasurer. * USG Corp., Chicago, which manufactures gypsum wallboard, named J. Bradford James vice president and chief financial officer. * Varian Associates Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a producer of electron tubes and devices, named Richard A. Aurelio president. * Vical Inc., San Diego, a biopharmaceutical company, appointed Dannie King president and chief operating officer, replacing Wick Goodspeed, who resigned.

title: The Wait Is Over for Lofton And Bills
description: They are children of Super Sundays, regardless of how old they were when they discovered that football was a way they could make a living. The Buffalo Bills had little time for feelings with their first Super Bowl just a week away, not with meetings and tickets and travel and family plans and all those long, lost, suddenly relocated friends on their minds.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Kremlin; Moscow's Iron Hand
description: When the old czarist order collapsed, "Only dictatorship could put an end to the process of final dissolution and the triumph of chaos and anarchy," the anti-Marxist historian Nikolai A. Berdyaev wrote 50 years ago.

title: G.E. Sets Thorn Deal; Lamp Chief Is Chosen
description: The General Electric Company completed its deal yesterday to buy Thorn EMI P.L.C.'s $360 million European light bulb business and named David E. Momot to be president and chief executive of the newly created company, G.E.-Thorn Lamps Ltd.

title: Inhuman Shields
description: Over centuries, the behavior of nations at war has come under certain limits of civility -- limits that are now being trampled by Saddam Hussein. His regime's mistreatment of captured allied airmen is cruelly consistent with Iraq's repeated, barbarous attacks on civilian targets in Israel.

title: Varian Net Climbs 63%
description: In the first sign that its turnaround efforts are paying off, Varian Associates Inc. today reported sharply higher first-quarter earnings. One of the pioneer Silicon Valley companies, Varian had been sluggish in recent years.

title: Statement of the Group of 7
description: Following is the statement issued yesterday by the finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of Seven after their meeting in New York:

title: Profits Rise 68.6% At Amoco
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that its net income surged 68.6 percent in the last three months of 1990. It was the first report in what analysts expect will be a series of large gains in fourth-quarter profits within the oil industry.

title: On Top of Clouds, Giants Dance to Tampa
description: The Giants arrived here early this morning for Sunday's Super Bowl game after a flight from San Francisco that was uneventful except for the following: a nightlong performance by Pepper Johnson, disk jockey; a conga line that snaked through the two aisles of the chartered DC-10, and the unending backslaps and high-fives of giddy winners.

title: Owens-Corning
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation has been fined $2.3 million by a Texas judge for resisting court orders to produce 11,000 documents related to asbestos litigation against it. The company said it was appealing the fines, which were ordered on Jan. 11 by Judge Neil Caldwell of the Texas Supreme Court. The company said that it had won similar battles in other states over its right to protect the documents, which relate to its defense strategy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics Lose Fourth in a Row Joe Dumars scored 26 points and Vinnie Johnson 18 as Detroit beat Boston 101-90, at Auburn Hills, Mich., last night. The Celtics' losing streak was stretched to four games. Counting playoff games, the Celtics loss in Detroit was their seventh in a row. The Celtics have never won in The Palace. Kevin McHale led Boston with 24 points. The Pistons, who never trailed, began an 11-0 run with 1:07 left in the first quarter that resulted in a 36-24 lead. The Pistons outscored Boston, 20-7, for a 56-40 lead with 44 seconds left. (AP) Bulls 117, Heat 106: Michael Jordan scored 37 points, including 13 in the third period, as Chicago broke away from Miami on the way to victory. Chicago was clinging to a 69-66 lead when Jordan hit a free throw to open an 11-3 run that made the score 80-69 with 4:14 left in the third quarter. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL East Tennessee Is Upset LaVert Threats sank two free throws with four seconds left to give Tennessee-Chattanooga a 76-74 victory over No. 12-ranked East Tennessee State last night, snapping the Buccaneers' winning streak at 13 games. The victory moved Tennessee-Chattanooga (12-6) into first place in the Southern Conference with a 5-0 record. East Tennessee dropped to 4-1 in the league and 14-2 over all. (AP) Arkansas 109, Florida State 92: Todd Day scored 30 points and five other players scored in double figures as second-ranked Arkansas extended its winning streak to 15 games by beating Florida State in Tallahassee, Fla. The Razorbacks are 18-1. (AP)

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Bombers; Giant B-52 Grows Old Virulently
description: More than 30 years after the lumbering aircraft first rolled off the production line and 18 years after they tramautized Hanoi in the Christmas raids of 1972, Air Force B-52 bombers are hammering targets throughout Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Review/Music; Honoring the Two M's (Mozart and Menotti)
description: The anniversaries of Gian Carlo Menotti and Mozart, both being celebrated at the Washington Opera, represent two very different triumphs of public acceptance. Wildly popular in his own lifetime, Mozart continues to hold the love of listeners and the awe of professionals. His great test awaits: whether he will survive the bicentennial onslaught about to be visited on him.

title: How a College Test Helps Select Youngest Scholars
description: In 1972, Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore started a program to identify mathematically gifted youngsters, typically 10 to 13 years old, and nurture them in three-week summer workshops on college campuses.

title: Q&A
description: Snakes in Ireland

title: Ira F. Aldridge, Accountant, 68
description: Ira Frederick Aldridge, an accountant with I.B.M. for almost 20 years and a deputy commissioner in the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay, died on Sunday at Dobbs Ferry Community Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Irvington, N.Y.

title: Salvador Rebels Admit Slaying of U.S. Airmen
description: The Salvadoran rebel front admitted today that two of its guerrillas had killed two injured United States airmen this month after shooting down their helicopter.

title: A Japanese Ballerina's Success Story
description: The Matsuyama Ballet of Tokyo, which is to open tonight at City Center, is both new and familiar. The one-week engagement will be the American debut of the 42-year-old company, a leading ballet troupe in Japan. Devoted to the presentation of the classics and modern ballets with Japanese themes, Matsuyama will present "Mandala," created by Tetsutaro Shimizu, the director and lead dancer of the company, who based the full-evening ballet spectacle on a 300-year-old folk legend and on his childhood memories. But Matsuyama will also present "Giselle," with the title role danced by Yoko Morishita, a ballerina known for her bravura glitter.

title: Judge Voids Retrial Order, Saying Prosecutor Wasn't Overemotional
description: A Superior Court judge has dismissed arguments that a sexual assault defendant be given a new trial because a prosecutor became too emotional.

title: Missing Lawyer: Robin Hood or $25 Million Thief?
description: A Manhattan lawyer has apparently absconded to Africa, leaving behind what authorities fear could become the largest theft of client funds ever perpetrated by an American attorney.

title: Arthur Harriman, 84, Lipton Research Chief
description: Dr. Arthur J. Harriman, who was director of research for Thomas J. Lipton Inc., the food company, for 25 years before he retired in 1971, died on Sunday in Freehold, N.J. He was 84 years old and lived in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Taking a Break From Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, which is based in Houston, said yesterday that Michael S. Swavely, its president for North America, was taking a six-month sabbatical.

title: Group of 7 Backs Action on Markets
description: The chief economic policy makers of the United States' six main industrial partners expressed support yesterday for the nation's war effort and promised to take steps to stabilize the international financial markets if the Persian Gulf war caused damaging fluctuations.

title: Thousands Recall Quest for Equality
description: Much of the nation observed the 62d birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today amid continued poverty and discrimination at home and war abroad that competed with his messages of racial equality and nonviolence.

title: Cerone Is Happy to Join Mets After Weak Year With Yanks
description: Saying he had found everything he wanted in a baseball team, Rick Cerone, the veteran catcher released by the Yankees last week, stepped across town and signed with the Mets yesterday.

title: Andre Kaminski Novelist, 67
description: Andre Kaminski, a Swiss writer whose novel "Next Year in Jerusalem" brought him wide acclaim late in life, died on Jan. 12, his family said on Sunday. He was 67 years old. His family said the announcement of his death was delayed so other relatives could be notified.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; U.S. HOPING TO CUT IRAQ DOWN TO SIZE
description: The Bush Administration is taking advantage of combat in the Persian Gulf to try to achieve military aims that go beyond an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, including the destruction of President Saddam Hussein's ability to project power beyond his borders.

title: Arab Judges for Iraqi War Criminals
description: Iraq's apparent brutalization of its first prisoners of war and its announcement that they will be placed at strategic targets as human shields buttress already compelling reasons for the allied coalition to call for war crimes trials.

title: Careers; Opportunities in Health Care Appear Good
description: RECESSION or not, health care is a growing industry offering good jobs.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Moscow; Senior Soviet Officer Says U.S. Rushed Into War
description: A military adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union said today that the United States had acted prematurely in attacking Iraq.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Servicewomen; War Puts U.S. Servicewomen Closer Than Ever to Combat
description: Within days, Staff Sgt. Hattie Brown and her air defense unit expect to be deployed close enough to the Kuwait border to fall under Iraqi mortar fire.

title: Novotna Ends Graf's Reign at Australian Open
description: The Steffi Graf era at the Australian Open is over.

title: Yugoslavia Warns Croatia to Disarm Its Forces
description: The central Yugoslav Government reportedly warned the republic of Croatia today that the official Croatian armed forces were not exempt from an ultimatum to disarm or face a military crackdown.

title: 'Cheap Shot' Accusations Anger 49ers' Burt
description: A part of him once seemed to be forever linked to the Giants. But today, Jim Burt said the ties had been broken.

title: Corrections
description: The chart at the top of the Business Digest yesterday summarizing market activity last week misstated the results in some editions. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 145.29 points last week; the dollar fell 1.55 yen against the Japanese currency; gold fell $17.40 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell from 8.35 percent to 8.17 percent.

title: Publisher Names President
description: Jonathan Newcomb, the executive vice president of operations at Simon & Schuster, has been named to the newly created position of president and chief operating officer.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Oval Office; BUSH CALLS IRAQIS 'BRUTAL' TO PILOTS
description: President Bush vowed today to hold President Saddam Hussein accountable for what he called "the brutal parading of allied pilots," an act that he denounced as a "direct violation of every convention that protects prisoners."

title: Trump Aided By a 'Loan'
description: Donald J. Trump received a helping hand from his father last month when he faced an $18.4 million interest payment, the developer said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Linking a Bond's Quality and Yield
description: IN the decline of long-term interest rates last week on the surge of optimism that followed initial successes in Iraq, lower-quality bonds did less well than higher-quality issues.

title: Buckeyes Look Perfect as They Go 16-0
description: Unbeaten Ohio State extended its winning streak to 16 games and in the process broke an Assembly Hall drought tonight in a 93-85 victory over Indiana before a partisan Hoosier crowd of 17,318.

title: Medic in Navy Is Awarded First Purple Heart of the War
description: The United States has awarded the first Purple Heart in the Persian Gulf war to a Navy medic from Southern California who was wounded by Iraqi artilleryfire, officials said Sunday.

title: Pinochet, Under Fire, Seems Willing to Yield Army Command
description: Buffeted by family and army scandals and apprehensive about a coming human rights report, Gen. Augusto Pinochet appears willing to give up the army command that many once feared he would use to hinder Chile's transition to democracy.

title: Shares of L.A. Gear Drop on News of Loss
description: Shares of L.A. Gear Inc. tumbled 21.5 percent today, the worst performance on the New York Stock Exchange, after the company said it expected to lose $4 million to $6 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Stan Szelest, Rock Pianist, 48
description: Stan Szelest, a rock pianist who toured with Neil Young, Jackson Browne and Graham Nash, died on Sunday. He was 48 years old.

title: Behavior Varies in Babies Exposed to Cocaine
description: COCAINE use by pregnant women can cause a variety of effects in their children, a new study has found. Some are sluggish and depressed, others are excitable and jittery, and still others may show both kinds of behavior.

title: Seeding With Iron
description: A proposal to fight global warming by seeding Antarctic waters with iron would not do much good, a new study suggests.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Saudis Try to Cope With Too Few Masks and Too Little Information
description: Handguns have become one of the hottest items on the black market.

title: Mongolian President in U.S. to Sign Trade Agreement
description: Mongolia, a fledgling democracy wedged between the Soviet Union and China and long isolated economically, will sign its first trade agreement with the United States on Wednesday as part of efforts to broaden exchanges, officials of both Governments said.

title: No More Mister Nice WASP
description: We have formed a new organization called Let's Get Touchy and are already at grips with many vexing language problems. Foremost among these is choosing a word to replace the offensive term "WASP." Once Let's Get Touchy becomes synonymous with righteous fury, no one will ever again be able to write or utter the word "WASP" with impunity.

title: Kentucky Farm Chief Begins a Term in Jail
description: The Kentucky Agriculture Commissioner began a one-year jail sentence on Saturday for a payroll violation.

title: Chess
description: When Roman Dzindzichashvili said, "I had to do a little magic to win," referring to his game with Alex Sherzer in the National Chess Congress in Philadelphia, he wasn't bragging but shuddering. After playing deftly to obtain a decisive advantage, the New York grandmaster lost the thread and had to work furiously to pull out the victory.

title: Maxtor's President Resigns As Do Two Vice Presidents
description: In an apparent management shakeup, the Maxtor Corporation said yesterday that George M. Scalise had resigned as president and chief executive. Maxtor, a disk drive company based in San Jose, Calif., said its co-founder and chairman, James M. McCoy, would serve as president and chief executive while a search for a permanent successor was conducted.

title: Business and Health; Can Canada Plan Cut Costs in U.S.?
description: IN the debate over paying for health care, all sides have been adding up the costs of adopting a Canadian-style system. But consumer groups, doctors and other interested parties, not surprisingly, each tend to view the numbers differently.

title: U.S. Securities Mixed in Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in thin trading yesterday in a session that would not have taken place but for the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: By Design; Scarfs to Throw Around
description: It seems hard to believe, but there is a new scarf trick or two.

title: Cuomo's Staff Stays Largely Intact and in Shadow
description: Perhaps the surest measure of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's concern about the state's fiscal condition is that he has allowed so little turnover in his staff at the beginning of his third term.

title: Trying Times for U.S. Honeybee
description: AFTER more than 350 years of peaceful existence, the American honeybee is under assault.

title: Bill of Reckoning
description: As long as his life lasts, Saddam Hussein can count on two inevitabilities. Each day the sun will rise and set -- that is one. The second is that on one of those days Israel will present him with its bill of reckoning.

title: Oil Prices Edge Upward As War Optimism Wanes
description: After collapsing last week, the price of oil rebounded slightly yesterday, with less optimism about the course of the war and a sense that the market had overshot its proper level.

title: New York City Shouldn't Set Up a center to Buy Recyclables; Union Resistance
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Soldiers Fault Lack of News Since War Began
description: Journalists covering the war against Iraq are not the only ones complaining about censorship by the Defense Department. So are some of the troops.

title: Big Game Revealing a City's Changes
description: Henry Carley lives on the west side of town, only a couple of miles from Tampa Stadium. The last time the Super Bowl was played there, in 1984, he felt as distant from all the hoopla as if he were 1,000 miles away, he recalls. Carley, who is president of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, had no interest in being inside the stadium. He says he only wished the black community could have shared in some of the considerable profits generated by one of America's greatest sports events.

title: The Spy Who Went Into Retailing
description: Marian Zacharski has a finely tuned sense of irony, and he ought to. A decade ago, he was sentenced by an American court to life in prison, a Polish agent who paid a high penalty for stealing military secrets. Today, six years after his release in a spy exchange, he is a leading businessman in Poland, director of this country's most profitable retailer.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington; Bush Appeals to Kremlin Leaders To Refrain From Force in Baltics
description: President Bush said today that he was increasingly concerned about violent repression of nationalist independence movements in the Baltic republics by the Soviet authorities.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Latvia; LATVIA TO CREATE SELF-DEFENSE UNIT
description: After a night of deadly harassment by troops backing Moscow, the Latvian government stiffened its independence campaign today by planning its own self-defense unit to be staffed by young Latvians who object to serving in the Soviet Army.

title: Officer Is Stabbed; Possible Suspect Shot
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was beaten and stabbed in an apparent robbery attempt in the East New York section of Brooklyn last night, and a possible suspect was shot in the neck, the police said.

title: Technical Knockout: Knicks Stop 76ers
description: Strange events occur at Madison Square Garden on Martin Luther King Day.

title: New York City Shouldn't Set Up a Center to Buy Recyclables
description: To the Editor:

title: War Is Having Effect On Athletes' Travel
description: The war in the Persian Gulf is having a mixed effect on American athletes competing in Europe, as some federations have brought their teams home while others have have left them to compete. The bobsled federation is sending over more athletes.

title: Good Government Scares a Good City in India
description: It's a chilly, drizzly evening in this industrial town, and seven 9th-grade girls are huddled in the small room of a community center recording a song of praise to the Tata Iron and Steel Company.

title: Reynolds Metals Says Earnings Plunged 89%
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second-largest aluminum producer, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings plunged 89 percent, the result of a $94 million after-tax charge and lower aluminum prices on world markets.

title: Trying to Sell Cars, by Jingo!
description: The House majority leader, Richard Gephardt, four fellow House Democrats and Chrysler's chairman, Lee Iacocca, have found a new reason to justify cutting imports of Japanese cars: jingoism. Japan, they contend, isn't helping enough in the Persian Gulf.

title: Raytheon Gets Lift From Profits and Patriot
description: The Raytheon Company, already basking in the success of its Patriot missiles, announced record sales and earnings today for the sixth straight year. Employees of the $9 billion military contractor will have little time to celebrate though, because the Government asked the company today to step up production of the anti-missile missile system to support the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: 3 Stars Leave Shows To Spend Time in Israel
description: The Israeli stars of two New York musicals have taken one-week leaves from their shows to be in Israel in the early days of the Persian Gulf war. And the comedian Jackie Mason has canceled three days of his one-man Broadway show to go on a good-will mission to Israel arranged by the Israeli Consulate.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Saturday about the downing of an Iraqi missile over Saudi Arabia misidentified an American serviceman who took part in the action. He is Capt. Jim Spangler.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; CAPTURED AIRMEN MOVED TO TARGETS
description: The Iraqi military announced today that it had dispersed captured allied airmen "among scientific and economic targets, as well as among other selected targets."

title: Islanders Get Tucker
description: The Buffalo Sabres traded the little-used center John Tucker to the Islanders yesterday for future considerations. Tucker, who appeared in 18 games for Buffalo this season and scored only one goal, was traded at his request, a Buffalo spokesman said.

title: Designers Working From the Legs Up
description: Fashion is firmly focused on legs for the months ahead.

title: Amid Glory, A Radar Glitch
description: While the Patriot ground-to- air missile system is scoring at a phenomenal clip, it showed on Saturday that mistakes can still happen. Two Patriot anti- missile missiles were fired for no apparent reason from inside Saudi Arabia and self-destructed in midair.

title: Shooting From Car Kills Boy on Street
description: A 14-year-old boy was shot to death on the street, the city's first homicide victim of the year, the police said.

title: New Luxury Tax May Cost More Than It Can Bring In
description: The luxury tax that Congress adopted in its closed-door budget sessions last year may cost retailers and the Internal Revenue Service more to collect than the revenues it brings in, some tax experts and business leaders contend.

title: Delta to Buy Atlanta Gates From Eastern
description: The dismantling of Eastern Airlines has begun in earnest. Delta Air Lines announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy airport gates in Atlanta and an international air route from Eastern for $42.9 million.

title: What's Watts
description: To the Editor:

title: Gratton A. Stevenson, Obstetrician, 73
description: Dr. Gratton A. Stevenson, an obstetrician and gynecologist who practiced in Garden City, L.I., for a quarter-century before he retired in 1973, died on Jan. 10 at Wentworth-Douglass Hospital in Dover, N.H. He was 73 years old and had lived since his retirement in Lee, N.H.

title: Texas Utility Concern Names New Chairman
description: The Central and South West Corporation, a big electric utility holding company based in Dallas, changed top managers yesterday and announced its 40th annual dividend increase.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER, 69, was in stable condition after suffering two broken arms in a car crash, a hospital spokeswoman said Saturday. She was transferred to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore on Friday from a Washington hospital. Administrative offices at the hospital were closed for the holiday yesterday, and it was not disclosed when she would be released.

title: Distant Flash Equals A Million Years of Sun
description: A DISTANT object in space has erupted in a violent three-minute outburst that released a blaze of energy equal to almost a million years of sunlight.

title: A New York Super Bowl, Sort Of
description: Ever since the beginning of Super Bowl time, the all-New York matchup has been awaited. Finally, with the Giants and the Buffalo Bills, it's here. Or at least the all-New York State Thruway Super Bowl is here, with a detour down Route 17 in New Jersey to Giants Stadium.

title: Hardaway Does It Without Style
description: Tim Hardaway looks like he can't shoot, even though the ball goes in more often than not. He just slings the ball up without any rotation, which may be why 13 teams in the style-conscious National Basketball Association overlooked his quickness, ball handling and toughness in the 1989 draft.

title: Saks Assets Back Euromarket Notes
description: A three-part, $500 million private placement of various floating-rate notes backed by 42 properties owned by the Saks Fifth Avenue retail chain was made in the Euromarket yesterday.

title: Kansas City Agency Acquires Rice & Rice
description: Rice & Rice, a small Minneapolis agency, has been acquired by Valentine-Radford, an agency in Kansas City, Mo., with billings of about $100 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A.&S. Plans Store In Nanuet Mall
description: Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn-based department-store chain, will open its first store in Rockland County, N.Y., in the Nanuet Mall in Nanuet. The mall will be expanded to accommodate the new 180,000-square-foot store.

title: Wang and MIPS In Marketing Pact
description: MIPS Computer Systems Inc., based in Sunnyvale, Calif., and Wang Laboratories of Lowell, Mass., said they had signed a worldwide agreement under which Wang will market computer systems from MIPS based on reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. Wang will sell, service and support MIPS Riscomputer systems under the Wang Dynamix label.

title: 'Africa-Centered' Proposal Outlined for a Trial School
description: In considering a plan for a high school for black and Hispanic boys, the Board of Education appears to be embarking on a far-reaching experiment to promote racial and cultural pride and transform what some see as the European slant of traditional instruction.

title: Accounts
description: * The Washington Times is taking its $8 million account for the newspaper and its Insight magazine in-house. The business had been split between Earle Palmer Brown, Bethesda, Md., and Grey Kirk & Evans, Baltimore. * Italian Tourist Board to BSB Italia, the Milan office of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, with a budget of $5.2 million. * Houston Metropolitan Transit Authority to the Hively Agency, Houston, with billings of $2 million. * Progress Software Corp., Bedford, Mass., to Pagano, Schenck & Kay, Providence, R.I., with a budget of $1.5 million. * M Inc. magazine, New York, a Fairchild publication, to Chalk & Partners Ltd. Billings could not be learned.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "He's real pleased. It was a rather indescribable feeling to know that he was now on the helicopter and we were coming out of enemy territory, that we were about to pull this off." -- Capt. Paul Johnson, who led a mission in which a downed American pilot was rescued from the Iraqi desert. [ A11:4. ]

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, said its Bell Atlantic Business Systems Services subsidiary had completed the integration of Control Data Corp.'s third-party maintenance business, acquired a year ago, with the former Sorbus company. The consolidation will result in about 240 layoffs. * Canadian Pacific Ltd., Montreal, a transportation, hotels, forest products and telecommunications concern, has completed the $25 million purchase of the core assets of the Delaware & Hudson railroad. The D.& H., a unit of Guilford Transportation Industries, filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in 1988. * Ennis Business Forms Inc., Ennis, Tex., a maker of business and office bookkeeping equipment, said it would buy the operating assets and operations of an unspecified printing company in the upper Midwest. * Foster Wheeler Energy Corp., Clinton, N.J., a contracting and engineering concern, said Bechtel Power Corp., San Francisco, an engineering and construction company, had ordered two 140-megawatt pulverized coal-fired steam generators for $85 million. * Merrill Lynch Canada Inc., a unit of Merrill Lynch & Co., said it would pull out of institutional trading and focus on corporate finance and the debt markets. The move will result in about 150 layoffs. * Midland Bank P.L.C., London, said it would trim 6 percent of its British branch network to reduce costs and focus operations around full-service offices. * Norsk Hydro A.S., Oslo, a fertilizers, energy and chemicals company, said its Norsk Hydro Produksjon A.S. unit had 90 days to find a buyer for its 10 percent block of shares in Ranger Oil Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, for $9 (Canadian) a share. * Pearson P.L.C., London, a publishing group, said News International P.L.C., a subsidiary of News Corp. Ltd., had sold about three million Pearson shares, reducing its holding in Pearson to 9.9 percent. * 3Com Corp., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of networking systems, said its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional five million shares, or about 18 percent, of its common stock. * Todd Shipyards Corp., Seattle, a shipbuilding company, said it emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection under a plan of reorganization approved by the bankruptcy court last month.

title: Montana to Undergo Hand Surgery
description: Joe Montana, who sustained a broken bone in his right hand Sunday in the San Francisco 49ers' 15-13 loss to the Giants, will undergo surgery this week, a team spokesman said.

title: Policies Vary on Pay for Reservists
