description: Since August, when the first troops were sent to the Middle East, only 35 employees of Borden Inc. have been called to duty. Not a hefty number, but one of the employees worked in a personnel department that had little excess staff.

title: S.&P. Affirms Airline Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that Eastern Airlines' current debt ratings were still in effect but that they would be reduced if the airline decided to liquidate under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Tel Aviv; Tel Aviv Feeling Tense and Besieged
description: As darkness fell tonight, the only pedestrian for blocks on normally bustling Dizengoff Street, a young woman in a long maroon coat, had the most fashionable item in Israel these days slung over her shoulder: a small brown cardboard box on a black plastic strap.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Europe; European Nations Prepare to Impose Sanctions on Moscow
description: Angered by continued Soviet military actions in the Baltic states, European Community and NATO governments are preparing to apply economic and other sanctions against Moscow after Sunday's violence in the Latvian capital of Riga, European officials said today.

title: Other Goose-Bump Classics
description: 1958: Baltimore 23, New York Giants 17 (OT) First sudden-death overtime championship game, launching the popularity of modern pro football. 1967: Green Bay 23, Dallas 17 Bart Starr ran a 1-yard quarterback sneak for a touchdown to end a championship game in sub-zero temperatures. 1969: New York Jets 16, Baltimore 7 Joe Namath's "guaranteed" victory in Super Bowl III earned respect for the American Football League. 1971: Miami 27, Kansas City 24 (2 OT) The longest game ever, 82 minutes 42 seconds, occurred in an American Conerence divisional playoff. 1972: Pittsburgh 13, Oakland 7 Franco Harris caught a deflected pass -- the "immaculate reception" -- and returned it for a winning touchdown in an American Conference playoff game. 1981: San Francisco 29, Dallas 27 Joe Montana hit Dwight Clark for "the Catch" with 41 seconds to play to win the National Conference title. 1982: San Diego 41, Miami 38 (OT) Rolf Benirschke's 29-yard field goal ended teh highest-scoring game in playoff history. 1986: Denver 23, Cleveland 20 (OT) John Elway took his team 98 yards in 15 plays for a game-tying touchdown, and Rich Karlis won the game 5:38 into overtime.

title: Why Make Public Employees Pay for Deficits?
description: To the Editor:

title: Networks Cutting Back On Live War Coverage
description: The television networks said yesterday that they were trying to scale back the amount of live coverage they were devoting to the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Warning on Gas in Cameroon Lake
description: SCIENTISTS are warning that another disaster is possible at a lake in Cameroon that suddenly released huge amounts of carbon dioxide in 1986, killing 1,700 people, as well as cattle, birds and other animals.

title: OPEC Oil's Value Soars
description: Rising oil prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis helped propel the value of OPEC's petroleum exports last year to the highest level in nearly a decade, analysts estimated today.

title: Key Rates
Allison Moore Coudert, Philanthropist, 74
description: Allison Moore Coudert, a philanthropist who was active in civic causes, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: One Man Is Rescued And One Dies in Fire
description: Firefighters rescued a Bronx man from a burning apartment yesterday but were unable to save another man, who burned to death in the blaze, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HERBERT TENZER is being honored at a dinner by the America-Israel Friendship League, which he founded 19 years ago. Mr. Tenzer, 85, stepped down as president last year. A Democratic Congressman from Nassau County from 1964 to 1967, he is a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Tenzer, Greenblatt, Fallon & Kaplan.

title: In Gulf War, Many Wounds Will Be Mental
description: DRAWING on lessons learned in World War II, the Vietnam War and other battles in the Middle East, military psychiatrists are refining the way they treat battle fatigue.

title: Kohl Loses State Election to Socialist-Green Coalition
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political alliance lost control of the central state of Hesse in a regional election on Sunday, and thereby lost its majority in the upper house of the German Parliament.

title: A Battle in Pen-Based Computers
description: A battle to control what is expected to become the next big form of personal computing begins in earnest this week with the introduction of software for operating small computers that are controlled by writing with a pen rather than typing on a keyboard.

title: Top Contender For Levine Post
description: Just two weeks after the unexpected departure of Robert Schmidt, the former chairman and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, the New York agency is close to picking his replacement.

title: Adoption Can Save Foster-Care Children
description: To the Editor:

title: More on the Gulf War
description: PLEDGE BY PARTNERS Economic policy makers of the United States' six main industrial partners expressed support for the war and pledged to keep financial markets stable. Business Day, page D9.

title: A Throwback to Segregation
description: New York City's Board of Education is examining a proposal to create a school that would pay particular attention to the problems of young black and Hispanic men. One proposal now circulating privately among board officials suggests that the school be Africa-centered, teach American history from "an African-American frame of reference," and rely primarily on black men as teachers.

title: Budapest Gets Cold Feet On Big Fair With Vienna
description: Back in 1987, when East was East and West was West, the Austrians and the Hungarians decided to hold a joint world's fair in Budapest and Vienna in 1995 and offer the event as a symbol that would arch over the Iron Curtain and restore one of central Europe's most historic links.

title: Bridge
description: It would be quite surprising if a White House Chief of Staff resigned and returned five years later as President, but he would have the advantage of knowing the ropes. Something comparable happened recently at the world's most celebrated bridge club, the Cavendish, at 105 East 73d Street near Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Washington Offers Mountain of Debt To Save Forests
description: COULD foreign debt be the lever that moves poor countries to save their rain forests? President Bush apparently thinks so. The White House is backing a bold program to channel billions of dollars that Latin American governments owe Washington into local conservation projects.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT YOUNG, the 83-year-old actor and star of the television series "Father Knows Best" and "Marcus Welby, M.D.," attempted suicide on Saturday at his home in Westlake Village, Calif., the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said yesterday. Mr. Young tried to asphyxiate himself by running a hose from the tailpipe of his car into the passenger compartment, the sheriff's office said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; 'We Have a Common Cause,' Says Senior U.S. Official Visiting Israel
description: Capping five days of rapidly warming relations between Washington and Jerusalem, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger spoke here today of the Bush Administration's admiration and "affection" for Israel.

title: Drugs Avert Bone Thinning
description: Blood-pressure drugs used by millions of Americans also protect against bone thinning, a condition leading to 200,000 hip fractures a year among older people, scientists have reported.

title: Richard B. Young, 68, A Professor of English
description: Richard Benjamin Young, a professor emeritus of English at Smith College who specialized in English Renaissance poetry and drama, died yesterday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 68 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Families; Joy Is Darkened by Fear For Kin of Captured Pilots
description: The families of the captured American fliers shown on Iraqi and American television were joyful yesterday that the men were still alive but fearful that the pilots, shown in what appeared to be battered conditions, would be used as human shields against allied bombing in the Persian Gulf war.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; As Leader Keeps Nation's War Role Secret, Many Turks Express Alarm
description: As in other countries, Turks have learned much of what they know about the Persian Gulf war by watching Cable News Network, carried live by the state television and translated simultaneously into Turkish.

title: Report Cites Bailout Waste
description: Poor management by savings and loan regulators resulted in nearly $1 million in excess costs to collect payments on loans inherited from failed savings and loans, said a Congressional report released today.

title: Giants Look for Offensive Punch
description: All season long, probably the most feared weapon in the National Football League was the San Francisco 49ers' passing attack. By shutting it down, the Giants upset the 49ers, 15-13, Sunday and won a berth in next Sunday's Super Bowl XXV here against the Buffalo Bills.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Off Sharply on Big Board
description: The latest figure is equivalent to six-tenths of 1 percent of the total shares listed on the Big Board. Amex Short Sales Also Decline

title: Indonesia Is Still Oppressing East Timor
description: To the Editor:

title: Orangemen Hold Off Hoya Rally
description: The play happened so quickly that Dikembe Mutombo was not sure if he had enough time to dunk. There were 0.2 seconds left and Georgetown had the ball beneath its own basket, trailing Syracuse by 2 points.

title: Bound for High School, They Test for College
description: Already under pressure from parents, peers and a society that often sees test scores as measures of success, increasing numbers of students as young as 12 years old are taking the difficult, three-hour college entrance examination before entering high school.

title: U.S. Proposes Rules to Bar Obstacles for the Disabled
description: The Federal Government proposed sweeping rules today under which stores, restaurants, banks, theaters, hotels and offices must take specific new steps to accommodate people who are disabled in any way.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Air War; Allied Aides Scaling Back Claims To Have Achieved Air Superiority
description: Allied officials are scaling back their earlier claims to have achieved air superiority over many areas of Iraq and to have disabled most of President Saddam Hussein's Scud missile-launching sites.

title: G.E. Halts Commercials That Feature Hungary
description: While many companies are deciding whether it is wise to advertise during the Persian Gulf war, General Electric has decided it is definitely improper to run ads highlighting changes in Eastern Europe while a crackdown is taking place in the Baltic republics.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: Harriet M. Griffin, Professor, 87
description: Dr. Harriet M. Griffin, who taught mathematics at the City College of New York for 36 years before retiring in 1966, died on Jan. 13 at Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J. She was 87 years old and had lived in Lakewood since her retirement.

title: A Popular View: Giants-49ers Was Memorable
description: Pete Rozelle, a former commissioner of the National Football League who saw many fine playoff games during his 28 years in the job, said yesterday that the Giants' 15-13 victory over the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday was "one of the top half-dozen championship games I've witnessed."

title: Rate Request By A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had requested $77 million in price increases for 800-number and WATS-line services for business customers.

title: 3 Fans Are Killed By Crush of Crowd At a Rock Concert
description: The surge of a crowd watching a rock concert has left three teen-agers dead, the authorities said.

title: A Proposed Ban on Most Abortions Gains in Utah
description: A joint committee of the Utah Legislature sent to the State Senate today a two-part bill that would prohibit most elective abortions in the state.

title: NCR Meeting Is Requested
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had delivered to the NCR Corporation written requests on behalf of shareholders controlling more than 33 million shares, or 51 percent of NCR stock, asking NCR management to call a special meeting of shareholders.

title: Military Suppliers Up, but Dow Falls 17.57
description: From Raytheon to Martin Marietta and McDonnell Douglas to General Dynamics, the stocks of military contractors, electronics producers and high-tech companies advanced sharply yesterday in an otherwise weak market.

title: Review/Art; A Restored Ringling Museum Reopens in Subtropical Glory
description: Ten years ago, the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art here was widely thought to be a subtropical sleeping beauty in a state of terminal coma. It still had its glorious and unspoiled site on the Sarasota Bay. A copy of the "Apollo Belvedere" still stood before the front door. Out back, a copy of Michelangelo's "David" stood guard before a backdrop of palm trees. On velvet evenings and new-moon nights, bayou and banyan wrought their magic, and rooftop statues by the score gleamed as white as ever. At such moments, the museum still looked like one of the more remarkable of 20th-century imaginings.

title: INSIDE
description: Latvia Hardens Its Stand Despite harassment by Soviet troops, the Latvian government stiffened its independence campaign by planning its own self-defense unit. Page A14. Aid for the Rain Forests The White House is backing a plan to convert billions of dollars of Latin American debt to regional conservation projects. Science Times, page C1. Tampa Revisited Seven years after Tampa's last Super Bowl, the black community is playing a bigger role. Sports Pages, B7.

title: Robert G. Levy, Benefactor of Blind, 91
description: Robert G. Levy, founder of the one of the nation's largest producers of tape-recorded books for blind people, died in Houston on Friday. He was 91 years old.

title: More on the Gulf
description: PUBLIC SUPPORT Backing for the war remains broad, and approval of the President high in the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll. Page A12.

title: China Ousts Foreign Human-Rights Group
description: A seven-member delegation that came to China from foreign countries to express concern about political prisoners had its own run-in with the law today, as the police detained the seven and ordered them to leave the country within 24 hours.

title: B.S.B.'s Crystal Ball Predicts Some High-Tech Wizardry
description: VCR'S with scanning sensors that eliminate commercials from videotaped programs, passive "people meters" that can identify television viewers, personalized magazines delivered by computer, and fascimile transmission of newspapers -- these are the advances that will have the greatest impact on media in the future, a new study predicts.

title: Sky Diver Dies in Jump
description: A sky diver apparently panicked after her parachute failed to open on the first try, and she fell 10,000 feet to her death despite her instructor's efforts to signal instructions during their free-fall together, the authorities said. Investigators will try to determine whether the 29-year-old sky diver, Susan Chase of Falls Church, had defective equipment or failed to pull her rip cord on Saturday, said Duncan Pardue, a public affairs officer with the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Ileana of Romania Is Dead at 82; Princess Founded Convent in U.S.
description: Princess Ileana of Romania, who was known as Mother Alexandra after becoming a nun, died at midday yesterday in St. Elizabeth Hospital Medical Center in Youngstown, Ohio, Mother Christophora, abbess of the Monastery of the Holy Transfiguration, said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Public Opinion; Poll Finds Deep Backing While Optimism Fades
description: The American public's initial soaring optimism about the war against Iraq has flattened a little, but support for the war remains broad and President Bush's approval rating continues to stand at a record level, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Mexican Films Abroad
description: By the accounting of any major Hollywood production, the movie set built in an old electrical generating station here was scarcely worth a budgetary footnote. A creative paint job substitutes for expensive stage props, and a lump of smoking coal took the place of elaborate special effects.

title: Holiday Festivities Provide A Chance to Aid the Neediest
description: Last month, in the midst of popping corks and unwrapping presents, a number of people decided to channel some of the energy behind their holiday celebrations into more than eating, drinking and dancing. They dedicated their holiday parties to the sick and the poor, and their annual get-togethers became occasions to raise funds for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 4 Held in Jewel Theft At Store in Chinatown
description: Four members of a Chinatown street gang were arrested last night after the police said they held up a jewelry store at gunpoint and tried to flee with $350,000 worth of jewelry.

title: Books of The Times; Modern Art in the Eyes of Commedia dell'Arte
description: Conversations With a Clown By Michael Welzenbach 210 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press . $19.95.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of a malfunction in the computers that receive and send market data at The Associated Press, several tables reflecting yesterday's trading in options on futures were not available for this edition.

title: Trash-to-Electricity Disposal Lags in Maine
description: The idea of converting trash into electricity, and making money in the process, has not worked out as planned in Maine.

title: War Summary
description: AT THE PENTAGON Five days of air war against Iraq, one of the most intensive air campaigns in the history of warfare, have weakened Iraq but not eliminated its capacity to wage war or President SaddamHussein's ability to command his forces, American officials and experts say. American-led air attacks on Iraqi Scud missile bases and other targets continued round-the-clock, officials said. A RESCUE IN THE DESERT A downed American Navy pilot was rescued in the Iraqi desert yesterday by an Air Force team in what military officials said was the first successful such mission over hostile territory in the war with Iraq. A THREAT FROM IRAQ Charging that civilians had been bombed beyond a "minimum of human standards," Iraq threatened to disperse "more than 20" human shields. President Bush and British officials expressed outrage, saying such a move would violate the Geneva Conventions. WAR LOSSES: THE PENTAGON'S REPORT ALLIED FORCES Troops: Twenty-five airmen were listed as missing after their planes went down, with 23 of them believed to have been taken prisoner. Iraq claimed to hold "more than 20." Aircraft: Seventeen aircraft were reported lost as of yesterday, 10 them American, four British, one Italian, one Saudi and one Kuwaiti. The Iraqis claimed they have shot down 160 allied planes. The allies say 14 of the lost aircraft were downed in aerial combat and the other three crashed in accidents. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Forty-five soldiers were killed in action, 40 of them in Kuwait and five earlier in raids on off-shore Kuwaiti oil platforms. Twenty-three othes were taken prisoner during the raids. There were no estimates of military or civilian casualties in aerial bombardments. Iraq listed 31 soldiers as killed in action. Aircraft: The Pentagon claims 17 Iraqi jets destroyed in the air.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Ba Liep Journal; Family Braves a Cruel Sea and Just 2 Come Back
description: Dang Chi Cuong came home today to his father's house in this little village in the Mekong Delta, eight months after he left by boat with his wife and two children.

title: Review/Dance; Offbeat Images From Australian Songlines
description: The Altogether Different series, which continues through Sunday at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), has tended to present altogether indifferent choreography.

title: Florio Is Fought On Health Plan For Uninsured
description: The Florio administration is pressing a 28-point health-care reform plan that would address the growing problem of uninsured patients at New Jersey's hospitals, but it is running into resistance from business and labor groups and from a key legislator who says Gov. Jim Florio once again is trying to do too much too fast.

title: Lithuania Feels Betrayed by 'Bad King' Gorbachev
description: The early optimism about democracy and about life itself spawned in the first years of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's rule haunts Lithuanians now as they wait in bitterness at their barricades.

title: War News Pushes U.S. Rates Up
description: The impact of the Scud missile attack on residential Tel Aviv reverberated through the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities fell and long-term interest rates rose after news of the blast flashed across trading screens.

title: High Court to Hear Case On Special Tax Judges
description: In a case that could affect the way appeals are handled in many complex tax disputes, the Supreme Court agreed today to hear a challenge to the Tax Court's growing use of specially appointed trial judges.

title: Oil Damage To Kuwait Is Assessed
description: In the wake of Iraq's attack on Kuwait's oil operations today, oil industry experts evaluated what the impact would be if Saddam Hussein makes good on his threat to destroy all Kuwaiti oil installations.

title: Economic Scene; Charity Begins In Washington
description: DECEMBER, the peak month for philanthropy, is history. And when the figures are totaled, 1990 will almost certainly prove to have been another record year for giving: By the reckoning of the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel, contributions in real terms have risen in 26 of the last 34 years.

title: Review/Jazz; For the Love of Be-Bop
description: Halfway through his impressive last set at Birdland on Saturday night, the alto saxophonist Donald Harrison launched into a fast version of Charlie Parker's "Now's the Time." Replacing the tune's low-slung blues elegance with a jittery intensity, Mr. Harrison proceeded to cloak the tune with rapid, precise be-bop lines that sounded like a speeded-up record. Familiarity, in jazz, has always bred speed, and Mr. Harrison knows his way around be-bop.

title: Cunningham Is Voted N.F.L. Player of Year
description: His team never made it past the first round of the playoffs, but based on his outstanding regular season, Randall Cunningham, for the second time in three years, has been voted winner of the Bert Bell Award as National Football League player of the year. The award will be presented on Feb. 19 by the Maxwell Football Club of Philadelphia, the city for which Cunningham does his running, passing and signal-calling.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Calling SOPHIA LOREN "one of the genuine treasures of world cinema," the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has given her an honorary Oscar. She will receive it on March 25, during the Academy Awards ceremony.

title: Ames Stores Has a Profit
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it had a profit in December, the first month the retailer has been in the black since before it filed for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors in April. Ames, which operates 455 discount stores in 17 states, said it earned $25.1 million for the five weeks that ended on Dec. 29 on sales of $528.3 million.

title: Citicorp Plans More Cost-Cutting
description: Calling real estate loans a growing problem, Citicorp said yesterday that it would slash annual expenses by $1.5 billion by 1993 and continue to look for ways to raise capital.

title: Cuts of $14 Million Ordered as Weicker Starts Budget Effort
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. took his first public steps on the state's troubled budget today, asking his agency heads to impose 35 specific cost-cutting or revenue-raising measures to combat a projected $670 million shortfall in revenues for the current fiscal year.

title: Rehabilitated Girardelli Finishes on Top in SlalomSAALBACH-HINTERGLEMM, Austria, Jan. 22
description: Marc Girardelli won the men's slalom today, the opening event in the world ski championships.

title: Diversity Deserves Laughs
description: To The Living Section:

title: Reports Vary on How Band Acted as 3 Fans Were Killed
description: At least three witnesses say the rock band AC-DC played on as three young fans were being fatally crushed by a surging crowd in front of the stage at the Salt Palace last Friday night.

title: Slaying Defendant Shot at Bronx Court
description: The father of a Bronx teen-ager who was shot to death at a party last year waited on the steps of the Bronx County Courthouse yesterday for the man accused of the killing and shot him as he left a hearing, the police said.

title: Opera Is on the March in Boston, But Financing Is Lagging
description: Looked at one way, these are heady times for opera in Boston. Over the weekend, the ambitious, rapidly expanding Boston Lyric Opera presented two well-received performances of Richard Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos" at the recently renovated Emerson Majestic Theater.

title: Hearing Set on Asbestos
description: A panel of Federal judges from around the nation has ordered a hearing to determine whether tens of thousands of personal injury asbestos cases in hundreds of courts should be consolidated before a small group of judges.

title: Postal Service Approves a 4 Rise In Cost of First-Class Letter to 29
description: The governors of the United States Postal Service today approved "under protest" a new 29-cent rate for mailing a first-class letter, effective Feb. 3.

title: Review/Music; Works More Talked About Than Heard
description: Instrumental ensembles that last in this city -- and the Little Orchestra Society has done so 44 years -- rely on faithful audiences built up over the years, but also on programs that light a little fire of curiosity under unattached listeners and get them moving toward the concert hall. Conducted by Dino Anagnost at Alice Tully Hall last Thursday evening, this venerable small orchestra attracted a crowd that seemed a mixture of both. It came to hear a concert of Haydn, Barber, Brahms and Menotti.

title: Kentucky Fried Offering New Line
description: The Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation said a line of skin-free fried chicken lower in fat and cholesterol than the company's regular products will be introduced next week in about 700 of its restaurants in the Northeast. The new produc should be available at the chain's 5,000 restaurants nationwide later this year.

title: 'A Few Good Men' to Close
description: "A Few Good Men," a drama by Aaron Sorkin, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street. The play, directed by Don Scardino, will have run for 497 regular performances and 15 previews.

title: Youths Playing Deadly Game in Subway
description: Thousands of New York City teen-agers are playing dangerous variations on the age-old game of "chicken" in the subways, and two weeks ago a Brooklyn teen-ager was killed by a train he was trying to outrun, transit and school officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A6-10

title: Japan Trade Surplus Off
description: Japan's trade surplus with the United States shrank by 15.4 percent last year as it shipped fewer cars and bought more American airplanes, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: U.S. Moving To Derail Gotti Lawyer
description: Three times in the last five years, prosecutors have tried to convict John Gotti, the man they describe as the boss of the Gambino crime family. But all three cases ended with Mr. Gotti winning acquittals. And the lawyer representing him each time was Bruce Cutler.

title: Soviets Withdrawing 33% of Currency
description: The Soviet Government announced today that it was withdrawing 50- and 100-ruble notes from circulation at midnight in a dramatic effort to bring the country's floundering economy and blossoming black market under control.

title: CUNY Plans Tougher Standards That All Must Meet to Graduate
description: The City University of New York is moving to impose new course requirements that will keep students from graduating unless they demonstrate that they have met standards like those New York State sets for its best high school graduates.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Steven J. Romer, a lawyer who has been accused of stealing up to $25 million from clients, rendered the name of another attorney incorrectly. That lawyer, who represents Mr. Romer's wife, is Michael Berardino.

title: Drysdale Arraignment
description: Don Drysdale, the Dodgers' broadcaster and Hall of Fame pitcher, is scheduled to be arraigned Feb. 11 on a felony charge of drunken driving stemming from a traffic accident that injured a 24-year-old woman, the Los Angeles police said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: More on the Gulf
description: OIL FIRE IMPACT: In a worst-case scenario, energy experts said, a full-scale destruction of Kuwaiti oil operations could eventually lead to shortages of refined products among Kuwait's former customers. Business Day, Page D5. TO STUDY WAR?: As high schools debate what to teach about the Persian Gulf war, some parents and students say they are teaching too much, others too little. Education, page B6. SUPER SECURITY: The Super Bowl on Sunday between the New York Giants and the Buffalo Bills will have extraordinary security,including metal-detector searches of all fans. Sports Pages, B9. NOT LIKE THE MOVIES: Films about World War II emphasized clear choices. In recent war movies, triumph comes to the swaggering hero. The real war now on television screens teaches painful lessons. The Arts, page C11. TELEVISION AND THE WAR: The networks and producers of children's programming are trying to help young viewers cope. Page C11. The networks differ on their use of videotaped statements from Americans captured in Iraq. Word and Image, page C18.

title: Hussein's Nuclear-Proof, Buried Fortress
description: Reports in the German press this week assert that with the help of German companies, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has built a luxurious underground bunker capable of withstanding atomic blasts.

title: Pilots' Relatives Are Captives of Fear
description: For the families of American combat fliers, it was one of the tensest days they have endured since the military buildup in the Persian Gulf and the onset of war.

title: Sale by Marriott
description: The Marriott Corporation agreed to sell 120 coffee shops it owns in California to a privately held restaurant company for $65 million. The restaurants, Bob's Big Boy and Allie's, are being sold to the Restaurant Enterprises Group of Irvine, Calif., which operates 514 restaurants in 26 states.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Mayonnaise With No Fat

title: Baltic Officials Meet With Baker And Congressional Panel on Crisis
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d received officials of the three Baltic republics today to hear their views of the latest actions by the Soviet authorities to repress independence movements in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

title: Critic's Notebook; Why Movies Are Only Movies And a Real War Is War
description: For years we have thrilled to the movie exploits of the one-man army, the bold and celebrated fighter pilot, the anti-terrorist vigilantes who accomplish miracles while armed to the teeth. Now the consequences of all that false bravado have come home to roost.

title: Baltic Assaults Lead Europeans To Hold Off Aid
description: In the strongest Western response to date, the European Parliament blocked a $1 billion European Community food-aid package for the Soviet Union today to protest the crackdown by Moscow against pro-independence groups in the Baltic republics.

title: Eastern to Sell Northwest Its Washington Operations
description: The carving up of Eastern Airlines continued yesterday, as Northwest Airlines agreed to buy the carrier's gates, landing and takeoff rights and other operations at Washington National Airport for $23.2 million.

title: Merrill and List of Ifs to Go South
description: Stump Merrill is the first to say he cannot wait to head south, to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to spring training and into his first full season as the manager of the Yankees. And if he had to do so today, this very moment, Merrill says he wouldn't have any regrets about what the team that finished in last place in the American League East did or did not accomplish this off season.

title: The New Thought Police
description: To The Living Section:

title: A Top British Panel Supports Shifts in Routes at Heathrow
description: In an important decision for United States airlines, Britain's Civil Aviation Authority recommended today that the British Government change rules that since 1977 have barred new airlines from flying to and from London's Heathrow Airport.

title: Dow Loses 25.99 in Sharp Late-Day Selloff
description: Stocks fell sharply late yesterday in heavy trading after reports of a missile attack against Tel Aviv erased what looked like the makings of a small gain.

title: Track Fire Stops IRT Service
description: A trash fire on the tracks in the Borough Hall station of the IRT in Brooklyn briefly disrupted service to and from Manhattan on the No. 2, 3, 4 and 5 lines last night, the Transit Authority and the Fire Department said. Power was turned off at 7:16 P.M. after trains had pulled into the nearest stations in the area to let passengers off, transit spokesmen said. Service resumed at 7:53. No injuries were reported. Trains were turned around at Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn and at the Bowling Green and Wall Street stations in Manhattan, the Transit Authority said.

title: A Mambo King Speaks Words of Comedy
description: He sounds Japanese. He looks Japanese. But he's really Hispanic. He stands onstage in a gray worsted suit from Savile Row and asks provocatively, "Why settle for being Latin trash when you can settle for so much more -- like being Japanese ?" He eyes the audience confidently. "I used to be loud and obnoxious and full of street mannerisms. Now I listen to Lite-FM!"

title: Lockheed Getting New Trial In Wrongful Dismissal Suit
description: A judge today threw out a $45 million verdict against the Lockheed Corporation in a wrongful termination case after it was discovered that one of the jurors had been convicted of a felony.

title: Hueys and Scuds: Vietnam And Gulf Are Wars Apart
description: High technology is one thing the biggest thing, perhaps -- that sets this war apart from Vietnam.

title: Martin Marietta Earnings Fall
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 22 percent because it had created a $78 million reserve to cover the costs of a delayed Army project.

title: A Wise Old Coach Surveys Pro Scene
description: People are pouring into this city for the 25th Stupendous Bowl. John McKay, the smartest coach never to coach in one, will be pouring out. McKay gave away his six tickets, passing up an offer of $1,000 apiece (which, he says, "tells you how smart I really am"), and he and his wife, Corky, will fly to a retreat they lease in Palm Springs, Calif., every year.

title: Donors to the Neediest Cases Focus Attention on the Elderly
description: Anthony Rossitto sent $25 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund along with this note: "Please spend this small donation on those whose golden years is a tragic misnomer."

title: Texas School Law Is Upset
description: The Texas Supreme Court ruled today that the latest version of the state's public school financing law was unconstitutional because it did not solve the problem of unequal financing of rich and poor schools.

title: Dinkins to Press Albany to Alter Election Laws
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would lobby in Albany for a revision of the state's election laws, which he said prevented 750,000 city residents from registering to vote.

title: Benjamin Mendelsund, Architect, 48
description: Benjamin Mendelsund, an architect and sculptor, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Peter B. B. Andrews, Marketing Executive, 85
description: Peter B. B. Andrews, a former marketing executive, died on Monday at his home in Fair Lawn, N.J. He was 85 years old and also lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Nursing Homes Are Criticized on How They Tie and Drug Some Patients
description: Large numbers of nursing home residents are tethered to their beds or wheelchairs or given powerful tranquilizing drugs without documentation that they are needed, two new studies show.

title: White House Strains to Wage War In Gulf as Congress Seeks Information
description: In Saudi Arabia, the military briefing officer was so careful about sensitive information that he would not say whether it had been good flying weather today.

title: Editorial Notebook; Buffalo, Finally Favored
description: Buffalo, erstwhile Queen City of the Great Lakes, a town often said to have a glorious past but a dismal present, is certifiably on the way back. Its football team, the Bills, is finally going to the Super Bowl. Suddenly the citizens of New York's second-largest city sense a long-deferred recognition, especially from the opposite end of the state where the Giants dwell.

title: Review/Dance; The Selective Variety of a Small Ohio Troupe
description: The Ohio Ballet from Akron was founded by its artistic director, Heinz Poll, in 1968 chiefly, it seemed, as a creative outlet for Mr. Poll's choreography.

title:
Real Estate;
Downturn in Boston Area Is Expanding to Route 495
description: THE economic downturn that has slowed commercial real estate development in downtown Boston has now spread into areas far beyond the city and is especially acute along Route 495, the beltway that sweeps in a 115-mile arc from Cape Cod to Newburyport, Mass., just below the New Hampshire border.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article last Thursday about the strike at The Daily News reported a threat by the paper to close or seek a buyer unless it could stem heavy losses. The article also reported an assertion by an official of the Tribune Company, The News's parent, "speaking on condition of anonymity," that the paper and one union had been close to an important agreement on staff size until the company's board, in Chicago, "shot it down" as an unacceptable compromise of management rights.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Tennessee Stuns L.S.U., 92-89 Allan Houston and Lang Wiseman each scored 32 points to lead the Tennessee Volunteers to a 92-89 upset of Louisiana State last night in a Southeastern Conference game at Knoxville. Tennessee (8-10 over all and 2-5 in the S.E.C.) rallied from a 9-point halftime deficit for a 58-57 lead on Houston's 3-point basket four minutes into the half. From there, the Vols and the Tigers (12-4, 5-2) staged a furious sprint to the wire, with four ties and 11 lead changes. Tennessee took a lead it would keep on consecutive baskets by Carlus Groves for an 89-86 edge with 1:22 to play. (AP)

title: Edberg Once Again Looks Like No. 1
description: Stefan Edberg wasted little time today in showing why he is the No. 1-ranked player in the world. He secured a semifinal berth in the Australian Open with little effort, claiming a 6-2, 6-3, 6-2 victory over Jaime Yzaga of Peru in 89 minutes.

title: Wine Talk
description: THIS is the time of year when it's difficult to work up much enthusiasm for anything other than a week in the tropics. And though a good bottle of wine should be an antidote for the winter blahs, some of the prices being asked are more likely to contribute to the problem than ease it.

title: Exiled Leaders Appeal For Calm by Kuwaitis
description: The Kuwaiti Government in exile and resistance groups are appealing to the 230,000 Kuwaitis still in the country for calm, urging them to stay home and avoid provoking Iraqi soldiers, Kuwaiti officials say.

title: Fearing Attacks, Americans In Germany Try to Blend In
description: Cowboy boots are out and barbed wire is in as Americans in Germany seek to protect themselves against possible outbreaks of terrorism.

title: AIDS Protesters Enter Sets of 2 Newscasts
description: Protesters from Act-Up, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, interrupted two national television newscasts last night, one on CBS and one on PBS.

title: Bush at War: Seeking to Be Not Too Detached, Yet Not Gripped by Detail
description: Unlike Lyndon Johnson during the Vietnam War, George Bush does not sit in the White House choosing enemy targets. Indeed, President Bush does not even know the specific targets American forces are bombing in the Persian Gulf war, his aides said, and he has not talked to the commander of the allied forces, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, since the war began.

title: Post at Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. announced yesterday in Los Angeles that H. Michael Hecht had been named its president. Mr. Hecht, whose appointment had been expected, will succeed Waldo H. Burnside, who is retiring on Feb. 15. Mr. Hecht has been chairman of Broadway-Southern California, the biggest store division of Carter Hawley Hale.

title: 3 DIE, 96 ARE HURT IN ISRAELI SUBURB
description: An Iraqi Scud missile evaded two American Patriot air-defense missiles and slammed into a Tel Aviv suburb on Tuesday night, leaving 3 people dead and 96 wounded, Israeli officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with a theater review of "The Glass Menagerie" misidentified the cast member at the left. He was Jeff Weatherford, not Dylan McDermott.

title: INSIDE
description: Pope Urges New Drive To Win Converts In a new encyclical, Pope John Paul II exhorted Catholics to go out and spread Christianity, emphasizing the need to evangelize in all parts of the world, including those where Islamic laws forbid proselytizing.

title: Michigan Faces Painful Choices in Cutting Budget
description: Michigan legislators today faced the kind of excruciating fiscal dilemma that is likely to lie ahead for many other states. They had to vote on whether to eliminate a state-financed welfare program that helps 125,000 poor residents, or accept smaller cuts in a wide array of social programs that help millions of people throughout Michigan.

title: They Keep the Abortion Protest Alive
description: Pausing from his preoccupation with the Persian Gulf war, President Bush spoke words of encouragement to an estimated 25,000 anti-abortion demonstrators here today, exhorting them "to keep this issue alive and predominate in the halls of Congress, the courts and the minds of the American people."

title: No News Is No News
description: After almost a week of continuous live-action coverage on television and vast attention in the press, the startling fact about Operation Desert Storm is that the American public knows surprisingly little about what is taking place in the Persian Gulf. Because of the restrictions placed on the news media by the Pentagon, rarely have so many labored so hard to convey so little.

title: St. John's Turns Back Connecticut
description: Plays were not completed, shots were not taken and possessions were more like missions for St. John's and Connecticut in their Big East game last night at Madison Square Garden. The mission involved clinging to the ball long enough to score. For the Redmen and the Huskies, the mission was very often impossible.

title: Parcells Keeps Future To Himself for Now
description: The Super Bowl XXV between the Giants and the Buffalo Bills on Sunday will mark the end of Bill Parcells's eighth season as the Giants' coach.

title: Further Security For Game Unveiled
description: Every one of the 72,500 fans attending Super Bowl XXV on Sunday will go through a metal detector on the way into Tampa Stadium; the trunk of every car parking outside will be examined, and even the equipment of the Giants and the Buffalo Bills will be screened.

title: Harold H. Hall, 64; Ex-Railroad President
description: Harold H. Hall, who rose from telegraph operator to president of a major railroad corporation, died Saturday at his home in Virginia Beach, Va. He was 64 years old.

title: Nude Pictures Are Ruled Sexual Harassment
description: A female shipyard welder who accused her employer of sexual harassment has won a groundbreaking ruling that posting pictures of nude and partly nude women is a form of sexual harassment.

title: Decision on Marinovich
description: A decision on whether charges will be filed against the Southern California quarterback Todd Marinovich will be made within the next couple of days, the Orange County Deputy District Attorney, Mike Koski, said yesterday. Marinovich was arrested Sunday for investigation of possession of cocaine, the police said. "We want to have the substance weighed and analyzed," Koski said. (AP)

title: Refugees From Baghdad Report Some Casualties Among Civilians
description: Refugees from the Persian Gulf war at this ramshackle town on the desert border between Jordan and Iraq said today that the allied bombing of Baghdad had caused some civilian casualties and had damaged civilian buildings.

title: Two Turning Pro
description: Herman Moore, Virginia's all-America wide receiver, will give up his final year of eligibility to enter the N.F.L. draft, he said yesterday, adding that money was not the important factor. ' Moore set two National Collegiate Athletic Association records in his career, becoming the first player to catch a touchdown pass in nine consecutive games and averaging 22.0 yards per reception for his career.

title: GREENSPAN DOUBTS NEED FOR TAX RISE TO MEET WAR COST
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged Congress today not to raise taxes to pay for the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Athletes Are a Credit to Higher Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Scheme Bilks Hundreds, Authorities Say
description: Hundreds of New York Telephone customers have been tricked into paying for long-distance calls to Latin America by a group of confidence men working in midtown Manhattan, the police and telephone company officials said yesterday.

title: Complacency Over Chemical Attack Setting In
description: Western military officials said today that Iraq is likely to attack allied ground forces with chemical weapons if a land battle breaks out.

title: War News Raises Oil To $24.18
description: Oil prices jumped yesterday after the first flames leaped from Kuwaiti oilfields. They rose more later when an Iraqi missile exploded in Israel.

title: Plan to Store Atom Waste Clears Big Hurdle
description: The Interior Department transferred control of 16 square miles of desert near Carlsbad, N.M., to the Energy Department today in what appears to be the last major hurdle before the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository is opened for experiments.

title: 'Black and Blue' Closes
description: "Black and Blue," a music and dance revue conceived and directed by Claudio Segovia and Hector Orezzoli, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the Minskoff Theater, 200 West 45th Street. The show ran for 829 regular performances and 32 previews.

title: 2 Baby Bells Report Dips In Profits
description: Two of the seven regional Bell companies yesterday announced write-offs and lower fourth-quarter profits from operations. The stocks of the two companies dropped sharply as a result.

title: Remember All of This As Iraq War Begins
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota, Fla., misidentified one of the museum's longtime supporters in the state Senate. He is Senator Bob Johnson.

title: SUPER BOWL: Big Talk, Small Talk: For Now, a Contest of Words; Bills, in Loud Form, Demand Respect
description: Other Bills may be thinking it. Bruce Smith is the Bill who will boldly say it.

title: Dr. C. V. Teodoru, 76, Specialist in Geriatrics
description: Dr. Constantin V. Teodoru, a doctor who specialized in geriatric medicine for 30 years, died on Friday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: BOXING: Notebook; Family Harmony Is Broken by a Discordant Note
description: Boxing quarrels happen all too often. But rarely do they breach family bonds, as they have at Ten Goose Boxing, a managerial and promotional outfit based in Van Nuys, Calif.

title: Patriots Add Aide
description: Needing to shake up a stagnant offense, the New England Patriots added another new face to the coaching staff yesterday by naming Dick Coury as offensive coordinator.

title: How the Bills Build Their Vocabulary
description: In team meetings, Buffalo Bills players sometimes turn to each other with a blank look on their faces when listening to their coach.

title: Bill Riordan, a Tennis Promoter Who Guided Connors, Dies at 71
description: Bill Riordan, a freewheeling promoter who managed the early career of Jimmy Connors and promoted a series of lucrative but falsely labeled "winner-take-all" televised tennis matches featuring Connors, died of heart failure at Community Hospital in Naples, Fla., on Sunday. He was 71 years old.

title: S.E.C. Expected to Appoint An Interim Chief Accountant
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Richard C. Breeden, is expected to name George H. Diacont as the S.E.C's interim chief accountant as early as today, accounting executives said yesterday. The move should buy Mr. Breeden time to find a permanent replacement.

title: German Unions Plan Postal Strike in East
description: German unions threatened today to mount a major postal strike in the former East Germany if the Government refused demands by tens of thousands of postal workers for more pay.

title: Hinson's Basket Sends Nets To Victory Over Hornets
description: Roy Hinson's follow shot with 3.3 seconds left capped a fourth-quarter comeback that gave the Nets a 92-90 victory over the Charlotte Hornets tonight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Last week, 700 invited guests to the Feb. 9 wedding of ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER and MADELEINE GURDON received a letter from the prospective bridegroom. After some thought about the war in the Persian Gulf, the couple came to this conclusion: "We feel we should not give in to the forces that have caused this situation and that we should continue with the party."

title: Market Place; Consumer Stocks In This Recession
description: IN the playbook of reflexive investment strategies, one of the most common is buying the stocks of companies that make food, household products and packaged goods during a recession. Such stocks, favorites of the sharpies at big institutional investors and of such legendary stock pickers as Warren Buffett, seem like safe harbors in a storm.

title: 1 Part Chicken, 10 Parts Comfort
description: AT this time of year warm, comforting chicken soup often lives up to its reputation as a folk remedy. It nourishes aching, flu-ridden bodies and reawakens appetites numbed by head colds.

title: In a Rare Public Forum, Bavaro Avoids 'Retiring'
description: Two football products of the University of Notre Dame -- one among the most public-relations conscious and the other among the most reticent in the 25 buildups to Super Bowls -- conducted business in the sunshine this morning at Tampa Stadium.

title: Fernandez Rebuffed in Bid For Veto of Superintendents
description: In a setback to Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, a commission created by the State Legislature to evaluate New York City's decentralized school system recommended yesterday that the Chancellor not be given a greater role in appointing local superintendents.

title: The War On the Tube
description: A week of televised war has demonstrated the technical wizardry of the networks and CNN, the dedication of their correspondents, the glamour of high-tech combat and the armed forces' skill at it -- as well as the Pentagon's controlling hand on information.

title: What Should Be Taught About War in the Gulf?
description: In high schools around the country, the Persian Gulf War has unleashed a conflict in the classroom: Should the war be discussed? If so, in what context and to what extent?

title: Tribal Network Is Nurturing Minds
description: Faced with crippling poverty, a string of fledging colleges with names like Stone Child, Dull Knife and Little Hoop are turning to the example of one minority group to improve the educational opportunities of another.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Research Corp., Baltimore, which develops and produces ammunition systems, named Dale Hardy president of its Barnes & Reinecke Inc. subsidiary in Elk Grove Village, Ill. * Citibank N.A., New York, named Leslie E. Bains a managing director in its investment division. * Harvey Group Inc., Roslyn Heights, L.I., a retail seller of consumer electronics, named Donald J. Shea president and chief operating officer. * Kulicke & Soffa Industries, Willow Grove, Pa., a producer of precision machines, appointed Barbara Leff vice president of administration. * Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., New York, appointed Richard M. Blackwell senior vice president and general counsel and secretary. * Oesterreichische Laenderbank, a bank in Vienna, named Heinrich P. Schmitz executive vice president and general manager of its New York branch. * Pinkerton's Inc., Van Nuys, Calif., the security and investigation company, named Earl A. Smith and Thomas L. Irvin executive vice presidents and co-managers of its U.S. and Mexican field operations. * Ridgewood Savings Bank, Ridgewood, Queens, promoted Kenneth C. Camelo to senior vice president and senior mortgage officer, and William C. McGarry to senior vice president and chief financial officer. * Symbol Technologies Inc., Bohemia, L.I., manufacturers of portable bar code data-capture systems, appointed Thomas G. Amato senior vice president and chief financial officer. * Times Mirror Magazines Inc., New York, named Mark Edmiston executive vice president. Citicorp

title: Hearing for Clemens
description: Another Cy Young Award winner, Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox, had a scheduled hearing in Houston yesterday concerning felony charges that he and his brother assaulted a Houston police officer put off until next month.

title: Curbs Lifted On Bulgaria
description: President Bush cleared the way today to lift trade restrictions on Bulgaria by affirming that the Eastern European nation now allows unrestricted emigration.

title: Another Sanger Leads Planned Parenthood
description: The grandson of Margaret Sanger, the fiery birth-control pioneer, has become president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood of New York City.

title: Postwar Mideast Dreams
description: Contrary to frequent charges, Bush Administration officials are thinking about the postwar peace process. The direction of their brainstorming will displease knee-jerk advocates of an international Mideast conference and give Yasir Arafat a well-deserved diplomatic body blow.

title: TV Tries to Help Children Deal With the War
description: Producers of children's shows and the networks have been rushing to consider ways to address youngsters' possible fears of war. Some experts, however, are skeptical about whether television is useful for this.

title: Brush Wellman Executive Will Fill the 3 Top Positions
description: After a year's search, Brush Wellman Inc., which produces the specialty metal beryllium, has named a new chairman, president and chief executive. Holding those titles will be Gordon D. Harnett, a senior vice president of the B. F. Goodrich Company.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Shuffle at Teledyne Reveals Heir Apparent
description: Henry E. Singleton, the founder and longtime head of Teledyne Inc., has relinquished the chairman's position as part of a succession plan that identifies William P. Rutledge as the company's next-generation leader.

title: Movie Maker Is Slain Filming Latvia Assault
description: Andris Slapins, a film maker who specialized in anthropological subjects, was fatally shot by pro-Soviet troops on Sunday evening while filming their attack on the Latvian Interior Ministry in Riga, friends said yesterday.

title: Excerpts From the Encyclical
description: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's encyclical "Redemptoris Missio," as issued in translation yesterday by the Vatican under the English title, "The Church's Missionary Mandate":

title: The Pop Life
description: Shirley Horn's Backup

title: Article 734891 -- No Title
description: A woman who was infected with the AIDS virus by a dentist has won a $1 million settlement from his insurance company.

title: Istanbul Explosions Raise Fears of Terrorist Attacks Linked to War
description: Bomb explosions at a United States military warehouse in Istanbul created fears today that Turkish terrorists may exploit the Persian Gulf war to mount new campaigns of violence.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about a proposed high school for black and Hispanic young men was published in error. It showed Dr. Edison O. Jackson, president of Medgar Evers College, not Basir Mchawi, who was hired to plan the school.

title: Dinkins Says Tax for Police Hides Surplus
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins admitted yesterday that his tax plan to pay for thousands more police officers would actually raise hundreds of millions more in taxes than the police hiring would require.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: John L. Swink, Educator, 76
description: John L. Swink, a retired senior vice president and treasurer of Rutgers University, died on Sunday at his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 76 years old.

title: Spira's Trial Will Start On Day the Yanks Open
description: In one of the more intriguing developments of the yearlong Howard Spira-George Steinbrenner affair, a Federal judge yesterday set the start of Spira's trial on extortion charges for April 8, opening day of the 1991 baseball season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We cannot accept that Soviet troops attack the legally elected authorities in the Baltic states. No one knows exactly who gave the orders, but one thing is clear: the responsibility rests with the top leadership." -- Prime Minister Poul Schluter of Denmark. [ A12:6. ]

title: Key Rates
All-Male Club at Princeton Must Stop Excluding Women
description: The Supreme Court today refused to let the only remaining all-male eating club at Princeton University continue excluding women as members.

title: The Air or the Ground: A Debate Over Strategy
description: With the American Air Force trying to destroy Iraq's military abilities, a debate is developing in Washington over whether the United States should resort to a ground war to drive the Iraqis from Kuwait, considering the large number of American casualties that could result.

title: Weighing The Present In Menus of Old
description: MENUS of restaurants past can cause a certain kind of vertigo. They're artifacts of people who could afford to dine out, elegant footprints in the march toward modernity. Old menus lead the culinary cartographer through Edens of plenty and down cul-de-sacs of extinct provisions, up Everests of exuberant cooking and across deserts of culinary humdrum. After a while, there is a certain circularity in the path from a 1776 Tavern Bill of Fare to Le Menu du Bistro today.

title: Marie Therese Gehin, Professor, 90
description: Marie Therese Gehin, a professor of French at Manhattanville College for 30 years, died on Saturday at the Holmdel Convalescent Center in New Jersey. She was 90 years old and lived in Marlboro Township, N.J.

title: Making a Faster Bicycle
description: Call it reinventing the wheel, but engineers at Specialized Bicycle Components of Morgan Hill, Calif., and the advanced composites division of Du Pont have created a vision in composite plastics that they say can shave 10 minutes off a cyclist's time in a 100-mile race.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq Shows 2 More It Calls U.S. Airmen; Sites for 20,000 Prisoners
description: Military police officers have begun building compounds to accommodate as many as 20,000 Iraqi prisoners of war.

title: Herbert A. Lewis, Hockey Player, 85
description: Herbert A. (Herbie) Lewis, the captain of Detroit Red Wings hockey teams that won the Stanley Cup in 1936 and 1937 and a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, died of heart failure on Sunday in Indianapolis. He was 85 years old.

title: Books of The Times; Shouts and Whispers for Mankind
description: The Collected Poems, 1952-1990 By Yevgeny Yevtushenko Edited by Albert C. Todd, with the author and James Ragan. 659 pages. A John Macrae Book/Henry Holt. $29.95. Wolfwatching By Ted Hughes 66 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $18.95.

title: Flatley Overcomes Vanbiesbrouck
description: They were possessive about the puck, heedful of the necessity for keeping it away from the Rangers, and adamant about battering into submission John Vanbiesbrouck, a goalie for whom they harbor a healthy respect.

title: Panama Canal a Worry to Shippers
description: International maritime officials are expressing concern that the condition of the Panama Canal is slowly deteriorating and that Panama will be unable to manage the waterway properly when it takes full control in 1999.

title: The Soviet Union Has Ceased to Exist
description: Although Mikhail Gorbachev insisted yesterday that "neither the internal nor the external policy has changed" in the Soviet Union, the truth is that everything has changed.

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: He's No L.B.J. Unlike Lyndon Johnson, George Bush does not sit in the White House choosing enemy targets. He is trying to be a cross between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, aides say. Page A8. Much Noise Over Silence The Administration's handling of news coverage of the war has become controversial even before the public has judged its progress. Page A8. Linkage Once Again Iraq showed what it said were two more captured Americans and sought to link its captives to Israel's Palestinian detainees. Page A10.

title: Data on Soviet Prisoners Lack Reliability
description: To the Editor:

title: Sterling Car a Test for Grace & Rothschild
description: FOR the last four years, Grace & Rothschild Advertising, a small New York agency, has managed to persuade people to buy the Range Rover, a British off-road vehicle that does what a Jeep can do -- but that costs as much as a Mercedes.

title: Name That Steak
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bridge
description: Cover the East-West hands shown in the diagram and plan the play in six no-trump after a club lead.

title: A Junketer Not Alone
description: To The Living Section:

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: A System to Speed Computer Data
description: From a computer-filled trailer next to the Tampa stadium where the Super Bowl will be played on Sunday, photographs taken on the field will be relayed over telephone lines to newspapers in two minutes. That is about 10 times faster than has been possible in the past.

title: Net at Merck Increases 20%
description: Spurred by strong sales of drugs that lower blood pressure and cholesterol, Merck & Company today reported a 20 percent increase in earnings for the fourth quarter of 1990.

title: Masked Gunmen Slay 15 Salvador Peasants
description: Armed men with black kerchiefs covering their faces roused members of six peasant families early today, robbed them and killed 15 men and women, survivors said.

title: Young People Belong on Community Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: John W. Gleeson, 57, Official in New Jersey
description: John W. Gleeson, a government official in New Jersey for 25 years, died on Monday at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh, where he was awaiting a liver transplant. He was 57 years old and lived in Pennington, N.J.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc. is selling $30 million in 9.53 percent debentures due 2003 at a price of 100 through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. Common Stock * Alta Health Strategies Inc. is making an initial public offering of 1.5 million common shares at $9.50 a share through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. * California Energy Co., San Francisco, has privately placed $21 million in common and preferred stock with United States, British and Norwegian investors. * Manpower Inc., Milwaukee, a newly formed corporation, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for about 72.5 million common shares. Ratings * Ameritrust Corp.'s senior long-term debt has been lowered to Baa-3, from Baa-2, by Moody's Investors Service. The bank holding company is based in Cleveland.

title: Streak Without Victory Goes to 11 for the Devils
description: Sean Burke, the towering goaltender for the Devils, found himself sprawling from side to side in his attempts to push aside the shots and rebounds that were coming from all sides during the first period tonight.

title: A Delight of Yore
description: To The Living Section:

title: Pope Urges a Convert Drive, Even Where Muslims Ban It
description: Pope John Paul II, in a new encyclical, issued a clarion call to Catholics today to go out and spread Christianity, emphasizing the need to evangelize in all parts of the world, including those where Islamic laws forbid proselytizing.

title: Public Health Doesn't Gain From AIDS Edict; For Mandatory Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Operating Officer For Montgomery Ward
description: In a promotion that Montgomery Ward & Company called a step toward corporate growth, the Chicago-based retailer has announced the appointment of Daniel H. Levy as vice chairman and chief operating officer. He will be the first company executive in more than a decade to hold both titles.

title: Asians Lead Virginia's Population Increase
description: Virginia's population rose by 15.7 percent to 6.2 million in the last decade, with an influx of Vietnamese, Cambodians and other Asians accounting for 11 percent of the state's total population increase, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Eating Well
description: IN recent years there has been a spate of research on how diet affects health and a dearth of practical information on what to do in the kitchen if one aspires to good health yet lusts for good food.

title: War Summary
description: KUWAITI OIL PLANTS AFLAME The Iraqis have torched Kuwaiti refineries and oil wells near the Saudi border, United States officials reported. It is believed the fires were set to obstruct aerial observation with thick black smoke or to prepare for a retreat from that part of Kuwait. The fires were spotted by American satellites. The bombardment of Iraqi targets accelerated after two days of bad flying weather. ANOTHER ATTACK ON ISRAEL One Iraqi missile evaded American counterfire and hit an apartment building in a densely populated neighborhood of Tel Aviv. At least 3 people died and more than 90 were wounded. THE ORDEAL OF BAGHDAD Refugees reaching Jordan described Baghdad as a city without lights or food, whose 4.5 million people either had either fled or were hiding underground. They said bombs had caused civilian casualties as they hit residential buildings around sites targeted for air strikes. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Four American fatalities have been listed by the Pentagon as noncombat deaths since the allied offensive began. The allies listed 24 airmen as missing in action: 13 Americans, 8 Britons, 2 Italians and a Kuwaiti. The Iraqis said Monday that they were holding "more than 20" airmen. Aircraft: No American planes were reported lost yesterday. But the allies said a fourth British Tornado fighter-bomber had been shot down, bringing the number of planes reported lost in combat to 15, with 4 other planes reported lost to causes other than hostile fire. American combat losses accounted for 9 of the planes. The Iraqis claimed to have downed 178 aircraft. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraq said 31 of its soldiers and 40 civilians had been killed in the allied offensive. The allies said 23 Iraqis had been taken prisoner. Aircraft: The Pentagon claimed 17 Iraqi jets destroyed in the air.

title: Networks Differ on Prisoner Tapes
description: For the second day yesterday, all the national television news organizations except ABC News carried most or all of the videotaped statements of two more American airmen captured in Iraq.

title: MNC Financial Spins Off Credit Card Unit
description: Unable to fetch an attractive price for its credit card business in a private transaction, the parent of Maryland National Bank spun off 85 percent of the subsidiary yesterday in an initial public offering valued at $861.6 million.

title: Souter Joins Liberals in Florida Case
description: A closely divided Supreme Court set aside a Florida death sentence today, finding that the State Supreme Court had ignored evidence that under Florida law could have weighed against execution.

title: Junket: The Real Thing
description: To The Living Section:

title: Parcells Says Giants Are Fit
description: The Giants, at least physically, will all be ready for Sunday's game against the Bills. "We're fine," Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach, said today. "I don't think we're going to have anything that's going to bother us."

title: MEXICO OVERHAULS ELECTORAL ROLLS
description: In a vast door-to-door campaign, Government workers here have begun a nationwide overhaul of Mexico's electoral rolls intended to combat charges of corruption in future national elections.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Applied Biotechnology Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a developer of genetically engineered products, purchased E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.'s half share in Oncogenetic Partners, a maker of clinical research products. Terms were not disclosed. * Fiberglas Canada Inc., Willowdale, Ontario, a unit of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., said it would close its plant in Sarnia, Ontario, in the spring. About 190 workers will be laid off. * Fifth Avenue Group, New York, acquired all of the outstanding stock of Intellisys Inc., Syracuse, an advanced computer systems company, for undisclosed terms. * FSM, a Polish auto maker, will manufacture a new small car, the X-1-79, designed by Fiat S.p.A. of Italy, in June. * Fuji Heavy Industries, Tokyo, said it expected to export 208,000 vehicles in 1991, up 15.6 percent from 1990. Fuji makes Subaru and Isuzu. * Hitachi Software Engineering Ltd., a unit of Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, bought 36 percent of the stock of Information and Graphics Systems Inc., Boulder, Colo., for undisclosed terms. * Hydrogen Energy Corp., Olathe, Kan., completed the acquisition of the operating assets of Rankin Oil Co., Midland, Tex., for undisclosed terms. * Manpower Inc., London, a unit of Blue Arrow P.L.C., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, seeking approval for an exchange of shares in order to move its legal residence to the United States. * Maxtor Corp., San Jose, Calif., a maker of disk drives, said it would lay off 140 employees as part of a reorganization of its Colorado and California operations. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, said its Space Systems unit, based in Huntington Beach, Calif., would lay off 300 workers nationwide. * Salomon Inc., New York, formed Salmaz PGM Inc., a joint venture with a Soviet state company, Almazjuvelirexport, to market platinum. * Varian Associates Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a high-technology company, completed the sale of its space communications operations to Hughes Aircraft Co.'s electron dynamics division. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Rural China Learns to Earn a Little Extra
description: The way for peasants to get rich, Wang Hongjun used to think, was to raise more livestock and plant more grain and potatoes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Israel Asks U.S. for Extra $13 Billion
description: Basking in warm praise from Washington for its sacrifice and restraint since the gulf war began, Israel today presented the United States with the bill: $13 billion.

title: Advertising 'Bad Boys' Grow Up in a Downturn
description: It was 2:20 P.M. at the headquarters of Kirshenbaum & Bond Advertising on the fringe of SoHo, and surprisingly enough, nobody was swinging from the chandeliers. Instead, 10 copywriters, art directors and executives were crowded into a tiny conference room, debating whether a market research study adequately tested consumer reactions to a new ad.

title: General Electric Reports 6% Rise in Profits and Revenues
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its net income and revenues both rose by 6 percent in the last three months of 1990.

title: Iraq Shows 2 More It Calls U.S. Airmen
description: Iraq showed what it said were two more captured American airmen on Baghdad television today and sought to link its handling of American captives to Israeli treatment of Palestinian detainees in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BILLIE JEAN KING is opening a chain of fitness centers for children. "I wanted to invest my money in something I believed in," she said Monday at the opening of the Discovery Zone in Fremont, Calif. That center is one of eight that she and two partners have opened, The Associated Press reported.

title: Gorbachev Denies Any Shift Away From Liberalization
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared today that the confrontations in the Baltic states did not mark any change in his policies, and he rejected accusations that he had abandoned his reformist course.

title: SUPER BOWL: Big Talk, Small Talk: For Now, a Contest of Words; Giants Take Understated Approach
description: The Giants remember their 17-13 loss to the Bills last month in a cold, gnawing rain. They know the Bills have been on a roll the last two weeks, with 44 points against the Miami Dolphins and 51 against the Los Angeles Raiders in the playoff victories that put Buffalo in the Super Bowl on Sunday.

title: IRAQ SETS OIL REFINERIES AFIRE AS ALLIES STEP UP AIR ATTACKS; MISSILE PIERCES TEL AVIV SHIELD
description: As the skies over Iraq cleared and allowed an intensification of the American-led air war, allied military officials said today that Iraq had set fire to two Kuwaiti oil refineries and to an oilfield near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia.

title: Technologies' Profit Off 8%
description: The United Technologies Corporation today reported an 8 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings, citing the nation's faltering building industry and continued losses at its military division.

title: Book Notes
description: Mailer's New Novel

title: Mexico City Journal; Down the Years, a Father Hunts His Stolen Son
description: Gil Abeyta's interest in Mexico was set in motion on July 15, 1986, while he and his wife were asleep at their home in Colorado Springs. Sometime that night, Mr. Abeyta says, a stranger entered the unlocked house and stole his 7-month-old son, Christopher, who has not been seen again.

title: Back Up the Bombing Boasts
description: Government accounts of how the war is going are beginning to encounter skepticism, and rightly so. Two of the most important claims about the war have proved wrong. Military officials have backed down from an earlier claim that they had achieved air superiority over much of Iraq. Now, they say, they have local superiority wherever they need it, but most of Iraq's air force may be intact.

title: SAUDIS IMPORTING FUEL TO FIGHT WAR
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's second largest oil producer, has become a major importer of petroleum products because of the Persian Gulf war, Western diplomats and Saudi oil analysts said today.

title: About New York; Front and Center With the Queen Of the Apollo
description: The curtain shimmers, chandeliers gleam, the women are seriously beautiful, dreams float in the blue darkness like a perfect song.

title: Mobil Profits Rise by 45.6%, In Quarter
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that rising crude oil prices and sharply improved profits on refined products overseas allowed the company to earn $651 million, or $1.58 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1990, up 45.6 percent from $447 million, or $1.08 a share, in the 1989 period.

title: Antitrust Lawsuit Is Filed by NCR
description: The NCR Corporation filed a Federal antitrust lawsuit against A.T.& T., charging that a takeover by A.T.& T. would reduce competition in computers and telecommunications. Last month, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company began a hostile $6.1 billion takeover bid for NCR.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the main front-page article yesterday about the war in the Persian Gulf referred incorrectly in some editions to the aircraft reported to have rescued an American pilot downed inside Iraq. It was a helicopter.

title: China's Cooking Thrives
description: To The Living Section:

title: Justice Department Reports 403 S.&L. Fraud Convictions
description: In a report to President Bush and Congress, the Justice Department said today that in the last two years Federal prosecutors had convicted 403 people of savings and loan fraud involving hundreds of savings institutions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ISAAC STERN, MIDORI and ITZHAK PERLMAN will share a stage in New York on Monday when they team up to honor ZUBIN MEHTA . Mr. Mehta, who is stepping down at the end of the current season as the music director of the New York Philharmonic, gave Midori her big break when she appeared as a surprise soloist with him and the orchestra in 1983, her American professional debut.

title: British Chief Assails Hussein, Saying He Is 'Without Pity'
description: Prime Minister John Major lashed out today against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, calling him "amoral" and "a man without pity" over Iraq's treatment of allied prisoners of war.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IT is interesting to note that two countries as similar in many ways as Spain and Portugal are so fundamentally different. Both suffered invasions over the centuries -- by Vandals, Celts, Visigoths, Romans, Muslims -- each of which left behind a spice in the simmering ethnic stews.
