Both Spain and Portugal launched great explorations in the 15th and 16th centuries, often in search of spices, and to a large extent, their respective discoveries defined their national cuisines.

title: Two-Year Colleges Flourished in 80's
description: At a time when nearly all colleges and universities are struggling to attract and retain students, two-year community colleges, once considered stopgap schools of last resort, continue to grow faster than traditional four-year colleges.

title: Decisions at OTB Add To New York Revenue
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; A Notable Boston Debut
description: The Boston Lyric Opera production of Richard Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos" on Friday night at the Emerson Majestic Theater, repeated Sunday afternoon, showed heartening growth for a company until recently mired in amiable provincialism. It was not perfect and betrayed some signs of budgetary modesty. But it served the opera well, and it introduced one truly remarkable singer in Deborah Voigt.

title: ...And in This Corner, All Kinds of 'Gladiators'
description: MAYBE it's the competition, or the hint of violence, or the skimpy costumes. Or maybe it's just the novelty for television audiences that have seen everything. Whatever the reason, "American Gladiators," a syndicated program shown by 156 stations nationwide, is drawing more viewers every week who find something special in its peculiar melding of sporting event and game show.

title: Knicks Hope Oakley Will Stay on Target
description: In the hours before the Knicks open their five-game Western swing tonight against the Utah Jazz, Eddie Lee Wilkins is likely to come off the injured list and Stuart Gray is likely to be placed on waivers. Once the game begins, Charles Oakley is likely to keep shooting, as he has done in the last two games, both Knick victories.

title: Delay in Shipping Of Compaq Laptop
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation told some retailers its newest laptop computer might not be available until March. Houston computer dealers said they had received back orders for the LTE 386s20, the seven-and-a-half-pound Compaq machine introduced in October.

title: Public Health Doesn't Gain From AIDS Edict
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Repression -- and Courage
description: First Lithuania, now Latvia -- but the world is transfixed by war in the gulf. Even so, as the Kremlin again unleashes deadly force, again it faces angry resistance from within. Across the Soviet Union, courageous citizens by the thousands stand up to protest the turn to repression. Their vigorous dissent is a hopeful sign that today's Soviet Union has come a long way from its totalitarian past, too far to retreat.

title: At the Sign Of the Plastic Cow
description: IT'S what you might call a cozy cottage on the Sunset Strip. A yellow brick road (painted), a black and white cow (plastic) and a picket fence set the tone outside. (Never mind the palm trees and the parking lot.)

title: See Bills Run. See Bills Pass. See Bills Score.
description: The Buffalo Bills' no-huddle offense is the catchiest topic prefacing Super Bowl XXV. It is an explosive, and so far unstoppable, weapon that is making the Bills feel awfully good about their chances against the Giants.

title: U.S. Budget Deficit Grows
description: The Federal deficit grew by $7.4 billion in December, swelling to $87 billion for the first three months of the 1991 fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Educational Fashions Have the Lives of Flies
description: To the Editor:

title: Jurors' Doubts Help Migrant Worker Win Freedom
description: The jury was unanimous: Santiago Ventura Morales was guilty of murder. He had stabbed a fellow migrant farmhand in the chest, leaving the man to die in a strawberry field.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Missiles; 'Just Bad Luck' in Tel Aviv: Patriot Bumped Scud Off Path
description: The Patriot missile fired at an Iraqi Scud missile over Tel Aviv on Tuesday night hit the Scud but failed to destroy it, an Israeli Air Force commander said today.

title: Farmer to Plead Guilty In Slaying of 5 Drifters
description: A 76-year-old farmer charged in the serial killing of five drifters has agreed to plead guilty in exchange for prosecutors' promise not to seek the death penalty for him and his wife, who has already been convicted in the case.

title: AIDS-Related Disease Kills Elderly
description: A fungus that is the leading cause of fatal infections among AIDS patients has afflicted a small number of elderly New Yorkers without AIDS and experts do not know why, according to a report published today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Cuts Planned By Shawmut
description: The Shawmut National Corporation, blaming problems with real estate loans, said today that it lost $133 million last year and would eliminate about 1,200 jobs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Our strategy to go after this army is very, very simple. First, we're going to cut it off, and then we're going to kill it." -- Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. [ A11:4. ]

title: Job Isn't A Snap For Bills' Center
description: When he was the center for the New Jersey Generals of the old United States Football League, Kent Hull one day in the locker room asked the owner of the team, Donald Trump, if he had any stock tips.

title: Calendar: Antiques And Youthful Art
description: Live and Silent Auction

title: Wang Posts Loss Again
description: The computer maker Wang Laboratories Inc., which has been slashing costs, said today that it lost money in the last quarter as its revenue slumped.

title: Hangers That Hold History, Not Clothes
description: NOW wait a minute.

title: Bell Atlantic Is Losing Chief Financial Officer
description: Philip A. Campbell, the vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, said yesterday that he would retire on March 1 and pursue unspecified "once-in-a-lifetime opportunities."

title: Nets Obtain Petrovic And Look Out for No. 1
description: By acquiring Drazen Petrovic from Portland for a first-round draft pick, it might look as if the Nets are giving up a piece of the future for a player who has not performed particularly well in the present.

title: Wife's Heir Pursues Suit Against Hammer Estate
description: The industrialist and art collector Dr. Armand Hammer was unfaithful to his wife and coerced her into signing away her rights to his assets, say papers filed last week in Los Angeles Superior Court.

title: Washington at Work; C.I.A. Sidelines Its Gulf Cassandra
description: As Iraqi forces massed along Kuwait's border on Aug. 1, a Central Intelligence Agency analyst named Charlie Allen walked into the offices of the National Security Council's Middle East staff.

title: Boy, 14, Is Slain By Men Barging Into Apartment
description: A 14-year-old boy was killed on Wednesday night in a run-down Coney Island apartment when two men burst in and shot him in the chest, the police said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Japan; Japan Pledges $9 Billion to War Amid Opposition
description: The Japanese Government said today it would contribute $9 billion to the allied force fighting Iraq and supply military aircraft for evacuating refugees from the war zone. But both proposals are encountering stiff opposition among the Japanese people.

title: INSIDE
description: New Jolt to Soviet Economy Moscow's abrupt withdrawal of large ruble bills from circulation caused havoc, anxiety and confusion over how to trade them in. Page A3. Stanford Refund to U.S. Already stung by controversy, the school said it would refund $500,000 in research money used for upkeep of university-owned homes. Page A16.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the closing of Savvy Woman magazine misstated the situation of another magazine, Wigwag. It has suspended publication, intending to seek new investors; it has not closed because of the declining advertising climate. Wigwag's advertising pages were up 22 percent in the final quarter of 1990.

title: Knicks On a Roll In Utah
description: Some unused and largely unheard-from Knicks stepped forward tonight.

title: Larkin Agrees to Terms
description: The Minnesota Twins outfielder Gene Larkin came to terms on a two-year, $1.675 million contract yesterday. Larkin was one of three players to sign and avoid salary arbitration. Also signing were the Cubs outfielder Dave Clark, for one year at $350,000; and the Reds second baseman Mariano Duncan, who signed a one-year, $925,000 deal.

title: Key Rates
Carbide Net Down 85%
description: Despite a slight rise in sales, the Union Carbide Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter earnings plummeted 85 percent after a one-time charge of $86 million. For the quarter that ended on Dec. 31, its net profit totaled $7 million, or 5 cents a share, on sales of $1.87 billion. That compared with fourth-quarter earnings of $47 million, on sales of $1.81 billion, a year earlier.

title: Treasuries Rise in Active Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in fairly active trading yesterday, largely on comments from the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, that suggested to credit market participants that the central bank would almost certainly ease monetary policy again soon.

title: CUNY's Rules: Pressure on High Schools
description: To produce graduates who can meet the new academic standards that the City University of New York is planning to impose on its students, the city's high schools must start teaching students far better than they do now, education experts said yesterday.

title: U.S. Inquires Into Report of Faulty Chryslers
description: The Federal Government is investigating reports of transmission problems in Chrysler front-wheel-drive vehicles a decade after halting a similar inquiry into Ford automobiles over the protests of consumer advocates.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Diners Club Effort Seeks World Symbol
description: Diners Club has begun a new campaign that juxtaposes the international symbol for "no" with its own logo, which the company is trying to make the new international symbol for "yes."

title: Austrian Triumphs in His First Race
description: It was a little later than usual, but Stefan Eberharter of Austria finally celebrated Christmas by winning the world title in the men's super-giant slalom.

title: Gargoyles to Gargle By
description: TIRED of the same old accessories? The slim glass obelisk, the shagreen box? Then what about a gargoyle to liven up your interior?

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES D. WOLFENSOHN , the chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, was a host at a preview reception Tuesday for a photography exhibition celebrating Carnegie Hall's centennial. As chairman of Carnegie Hall, he was, in a way, host to himself.

title: Editors' Note
description: A television-page article on Tuesday about cutbacks in the networks' live coverage of the Persian Gulf war quoted an executive, "speaking on the condition of anonymity," who accused CNN of "getting a lot of things wrong."

title: No New York Lotto Drawing
description: There was no New York State Lotto drawing last night. The New York State Lottery cancelled the drawing to allow a longer sales period for tickets for the Super Lotto drawing scheduled for Saturday night, said Anne Doyle, a spokeswoman for the Lottery. The jackpot for Saturday night's drawing had reached $80 million last night, she said, and could go higher.

title: Hofstra Quarterback Is Cleared by N.C.A.A.
description: Rhory Moss, the Hofstra quarterback who failed a drug test following a playoff game last November, was cleared yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in upholding an appeal by the university.

title: War Summary
description: CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM AT PENTAGON

title: Delta Loss Sets Record
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that it had lost $207.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1990. It was the worst quarterly performance in company history.

title: N.C. State Surprises Duke, 95-89
description: Rodney Monroe scored 35 points to lead five players in double figures, and Chris Corchiani led a second-half rally tonight as North Carolina State upset Duke, 95-89.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics Top Pistons to End Slide Brian Shaw and Dee Brown led a 16-4 surge in the final period as the Boston Celtics ended a four-game losing streak with a 111-94 victory at home last night over the Detroit Pistons. Kevin McHale had 26 points as Boston handed Detroit just its second loss in 14 games. The victory, coupled with Chicago's loss at New Jersey, clinched the Eastern Conference All-Star coaching berth for Boston's Chris Ford. Shaw had 6 points and Brown 4 in a surge that gave the Celtics a 103-89 lead with just over two minutes left. (AP) Pacers 110, 76ers 109: Chuck Person had 24 points and Reggie Miller led a 9-point Indiana run in the last three minutes as the Pacers broke a 10-game losing streak against the 76ers. (AP) Bullets 104, Hawks 99: Pervis Ellison scored 6 points during a 12-0 run late in the final period as the Washington Bullets ended the Atlanta Hawks' five-game winning streak. Bernard King scored 25 points and Darrell Walker had his second straight triple-double with 12 points, 10 rebounds and 13 assists. (AP) N.H.L. Whalers Set Back Flames Paul Cyr got two goals, including the winner, as Hartford overcame a third-period collapse to beat Calgary, 5-4, last night for its fourth straight home victory. The Whalers led by 3-0 going in the third period, then rallied after Calgary scored four goals. (AP) Canadiens 7, Maple Leafs 3: Shayne Corson and Stephan Lebeau each scored two goals as Montreal romped on home ice. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of a Bronx father in the shooting of a man accused of killing his son included an erroneous report from the police about his background. The father, Jose Dominguez, has no arrest record.

title: Curb on Questioning of Arabs Is Urged
description: Six House Democrats demanded today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation curb interviews with hundreds of Arab-American civic, political and business leaders who have been questioned in an information-gathering operation aimed at deterring terrorism.

title: Books of The Times; The Wit and Insights of a Nurturer of Authors
description: In the Company of Writers A Life in Publishing By Charles Scribner Jr. Illustrated. 193 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.50

title: Jackson G. Cook, Lawyer, 82
description: Jackson G. Cook, an immigration lawyer, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
BBDO, Abbott Merge Operations in London
description: Abbott Mead Vickers P.L.C., a British ad agency, and BBDO Worldwide have merged their London operations to form Abbott Mead Vickers/ BBDO Ltd. BBDO Worldwide recently purchased a 23 percent stake in Abbott, including equity held by Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Terms of he deal were not disclosed.

title: Chairman of Sematech
description: Robert W. Galvin, head of the executive committee of Motorola Inc., has been unanimously elected chairman of the Sematech semiconductor research consortium. He replaces Charles Sporck, president and chief executive of the National Semiconductor Corporation, who remains on the Sematech board. Sematech is a nonprofit industry-government research group that is developing advanced semiconductor manufacturing methods.

title: Business and the Law; The New Powers Of the S.E.C.
description: THE rules of enforcement are changing for the Securities and Exchange Commission. Fortified by its success in persuading Congress to give it broader powers, the commission is preparing procedures to handle many cases within the agency that previously had been taken to the Federal courts.

title: Fed's Advocate of Lower Rates to Resign
description: Martha R. Seger, the Federal Reserve Board's most outspoken advocate of lower interest rates, announced today that she would resign within the next two months.

title: Kohl Says Gulf War May Bring Tax Rise
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today raised the possibility of lifting German taxes, citing Bonn's increased contribution to the allied effort in the Persian Gulf war as the reason. But economists said part of any additional tax revenues would be used to finance the ever-higher costs of German unification.

title: Guarding the Children's Hour on TV
description: WITH a flick of a television dial, Peggy Charren accidentally tuned in to her calling in life. It happened one day when she was at home in Newton, Mass., outside Boston, with her younger daughter, who was then 4 years old. Mrs. Charren thought it would be fun to spend some time together watching television.

title: Gen. Joseph F. Carroll Dies at 80; Led Defense Intelligence Agency
description: Lieut. Gen. Joseph F. Carroll, retired, the first head of the Defense Intelligence Agency, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Alexandria, Va. He was 80 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: Drunken Driving Count Dropped in Fatal Crash
description: Nassau County authorities are dropping a drunken-driving charge filed against a teen-age driver who was in a two-car collision on Jan. 13 that killed three of her friends.

title: Paul Bikle, 75, Dies; Headed NASA Project
description: Paul F. Bikle, who oversaw NASA's X-15 program as director of the Dryden Flight Research Facility, died Saturday at a son's home in Salinas, Calif. He was 75 years old and lived in Lancaster, Calif.

title: Patient Whose AIDS Was Tied to Dentist Will Get $1 Million
description: A woman believed to be one of the first patients to be infected with AIDS by a health-care worker has reached a $1 million settlement with her dentist's malpractice insurer.

title: Credit Units Sold By Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the largest retail company on the West Coast, said it had agreed to sell its credit card and accounts-receivable operations to the GE Capital Corporation. Carter Hawley Hale said the transaction would result in a net gain of $50 million and the elimination of $600 million in debt.

title: Open Financing Sought In U.S. Savings Rescue
description: The Bush Administration today asked Congress for open-ended financing for the savings and loan rescue, saying that would be the cheapest way to complete the bailout of the industry that began two years ago.

title: Albany Breaks Faith On Scholarships
description: To the Editor

title: Senate Bill Seeks Rise in Voter Registration
description: A bill that would require states to allow people to register to vote when they apply for a driver's license was introduced in the Senate today by sponsors who said the Persian Gulf war underscored the need to invigorate the nation's electorate.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Terrorism; Threats, Real or Not, Stir Fears Across U.S.
description: It certainly looked suspicious, the taped shopping bag found outside the Louis Vuitton luggage boutique on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills the other morning.

title: What Is 'Outside'?
description: To The Home Section:

title: BRIEFS
description: * P.T. Amoco Indoprakarsa, a joint venture between Amoco Chemical (Indonesia) and P. T. Lumbung Usahakita, has been granted an investment license by the Indonesian Government to construct a 250,000-metric-ton-per-year purified terephthalic acid plant on Java. * Associated Natural Gas Corp., Denver, will purchase Mega Natural Gas Co., Tulsa, Okla., for about $75 million and certain contingent deferred payments. * Conoco, Houston, an oil and gas company and a subsidiary of Du Pont Co., will purchase nine convenience store gasoline retail outlets from Wal-Mart Stores Inc., Bentonville, Ark. Terms were not disclosed. * Home Savings of America, Irwindale, Calif., a financial services company and subsidiary of H. F. Ahmanson & Co., will acquire all of the San Diego County branches of Coast Federal Savings Bank for about $20 million. * Kaneb Services Inc., Richardson, Tex., an energy company, will acquire Furmanite P.L.C., Kendal, England, an industrial-services company, for $66 million. * La Quinta Motor Inns Inc., San Antonio, said its board had asked its financial adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Co., to evaluate opportunities for shareholder enhancement, including the possible sale of the company. * Herman Miller Inc., Zeeland, Mich., an office furniture company, will sell the Taftville, Conn., operations of its Helikon Furniture Inc. unit to a Pittsburgh investor, Michael P. Carlow, who recently acquired control of Kittinger Co., Buffalo, a wood casegoods manufacturer. Terms were not disclosed. * Northwest Airlines, a unit of NWA Inc., Eagan, Minn., will begin service to Beijing some time this year under a recently negotiated agreement between the United States and China. * Wasserstein, Perella & Co., an investment company, was given approval in Britain to increase its stake in Isosceles P.L.C., a British supermarket chain, to 40 percent from 20 percent.

title: Hartford Panel Urges Overhaul Of Government
description: An independent commission established two years ago to study what does and does not work in state government said in its final report today that Connecticut's fiscal crisis offers an "unmatched opportunity" to overhaul the scope and vision of government.

title: Former F.D.A. Official Sentenced for Lying
description: A former chief Government regulator of the generic drug industry was sentenced today to five months in a work program for lying when he denied that he had accepted free meals from drug company executives.

title: Nat Broudy, 76, Ex-Timekeeper For Basketball Games at Garden
description: Nat (Feets) Broudy, the longtime basketball timekeeper at Madison Square Garden, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The President; Excerpts From Bush's Remarks to Reservist Group on Resolve in the Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech in Washington last night to the Reserve Officers Association, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Military Analysis; Gulf Outlook: No Quick Victory in Sight
description: The most important underlying message of the high-level briefing today on the Persian Gulf war was that the air campaign against Iraq and its combat divisions in Kuwait had produced no evidence that President Saddam Hussein's forces will capitulate or collapse in the near future.

title: Twins for Mother of Septuplets
description: A woman who gave birth to America's first septuplets six years ago after taking a fertility drug and then sued a clinic over the babies' health problems has now delivered twins after using the same drug.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the New York advertising agency Kirshenbaum & Bond misidentified a new client. It is the Chase Manhattan Bank, not Chemical Bank.

title: War Hurt Theaters And Helped Films, But Effect Was Brief
description: War in the Persian Gulf glued people to their television sets and reduced attendance at some entertainment events last week, people in the cultural and entertainment industry in New York report. But they add that some escapist entertainment benefited from the war and that attendance and video rentals are returning to normal.

title: New York Total For Job Losses Tops Early 80's
description: The recession in New York State, when measured by the number of jobs lost, is already worse than the economic downturn of the early 1980's but is not nearly as severe as the recession of the mid-1970's, according to a report released today by the State Department of Labor.

title: Kampala Journal; In Uganda, a Light of Learning Dims
description: Tumusiime Dennis is one of his country's promising engineering students. But things have reached such a low point at Makerere University here, once one of the stellar institutions of higher learning in sub-Saharan Africa, that the talented 23-year-old mathematician cannot afford the space on a page for a margin.

title: Carpenter to Go Pro
description: Rob Carpenter, Syracuse's 6-foot-2-inch, 188-pound receiver from Amityville, L.I., will pass up his final year of college eligibility and make himself available for the N.F.L. draft in April, The Syracuse Post-Standard reported yesterday.

title: Sandiford Wins Second Term As Barbados Prime Minister
description: Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford, running on a platform of "economic justice," easily won a second consecutive five-year term in parliamentary elections, according to final results today.

title: What If the Oil Just Burned Away?
description: I had a little daydream as I watched the latest television reports from the war in the Persian Gulf. As plumes of black smoke rose from the blasted refineries in Kuwait and Iraq, and Saddam Hussein promised to blow up still more, I found myself briefly imagining what would happen if all the oil beneath the desert sands of that troubled region were set ablaze by this war.

title: Audi Spending Heavily to Rebuild Image
description: Few automotive brands have been besmirched in recent years as much as Audi.

title: Fall in Yields Is Slowing
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report declined for the week ended yesterday. It was the third consecutive week that they had dropped, but the rate of decline appeared to ease considerably.

title: Washington at Work; C.I.A. Sidelines Its Gulf Cassandra
description: As Iraqi forces massed along Kuwait's border on Aug. 1, a Central Intelligence Agency analyst named Charlie Allen walked into the offices of the National Security Council's Middle East staff.

title: More on the Gulf
description: TRAVEL BANS Many large corporations have halted travel to the Middle East and greatly curtailed other international travel. Business Day, page D1. HE TOLD THEM SO The C.I.A. analyst who warned of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has a problem: often the Government chooses not to believe him. Washington at Work, page D22. EFFECT ON ENTERTAINMENT Attendance at New York theaters declined briefly, but movies did better. The Arts, page C15.

title: Foreign Airlines Can Raise Stake In U.S. Carriers
description: With the nation's airlines losing billions of dollars, the Administration moved today to attract foreign investment to the industry. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner announced that foreign airlines would be allowed to invest more heavily in domestic carriers.

title: Mongolia Gets U.S. Trade Aid
description: President Bush accorded Mongolia most-favored-nation trade status today and saluted the democratic and economic changes unfolding in the former Communist state.

title: Monroe Greenbaum, Executive, 76
description: Monroe Greenbaum, the founder of the Encore Sales Corporation, which makes advertising promotion items, died on Tuesday at West Boca Medical center in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Vice President; Quayle Aims At Protests, A la Agnew
description: Until now, the White House has made a point of treating the antiwar demonstrations across Pennsylvania Avenue and across the country with benign neglect. But, in visits to three military bases today, Vice President Dan Quayle took a page from Spiro Agnew's approach during the Vietnam War and offered some tart criticism of the demonstrators and coverage of them.

title: BBC Urges Sensitivity In Wartime Programs
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation has urged its 37 local radio stations to guard against causing distress by playing certain songs at sensitive moments during the Persian Gulf war, a BBC spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

title: Restoring Brilliance to Architect's Home
description: The house of England's great classical architect Sir John Soane is starting to look as it did in 1837, the year he died at age 84. As its restoration, started last year, continues, the four-story town house at 13 Lincoln's Inn Fields in the Holborn section is looking almost new.

title: Eastern German Mail Strike Is Voted by Postal Workers
description: Postal workers in eastern Germany voted overwhelmingly today to strike for more pay, and union officials said work stoppages would hit mail and telephone service in the south and gradually spread through the region.

title: An Elegant Old Facility Will Gain a New Felicity
description: IT might just be the most elegant restroom in all of New York City. The Bryant Park Restoration Corporation has announced that the structure, one of two 1911 landmark buildings in Bryant Park, at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas behind the New York Public Library, will be restored with $50,000 from the J. M. Kaplan Fund and state environmental quality bond money.

title: A Rock Climber's Reach For the Top on Wall St.
description: Before going to Wall Street, Steve Wunsch became a legend in the world of free rock climbing -- scaling sheer rock faces using gear only to break a fall. He became so known for his death-defying climbs with names like Supercrack that he is immortalized in such places as Moose, Wyo., at the base of the Grand Tetons, where his portrait hangs at the local outfitting store.

title: Correction; Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a plan to pay for more New York police officers miscalculated the city's estimate of the money raised by taxes that would go toward hiring. The city expects $672 million to be dedicated to the police plan, leaving a surplus of $528 million for the general fund.

title: Offensive Play
description: Sunday the Super Bowl will be played in Tampa and so, inevitably, my thoughts turn to abortion.

title: Theus Overshadows Jordan As Nets Triumph Over Bulls
description: On an evening when Michael Jordan came to Byrne Meadowlands Arena and the Nets made more deals and shuffles with their roster than a poker player, it was fitting that the play of Reggie Theus decided the game.

title: Trial for Murder Delayed by Illness
description: Testimony in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus, the former teacher, was postponed today because the defendant was hospitalized with an undisclosed illness.

title: 3M Earnings Rise 1%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, its business affected by the weakened economy, said its earnings rose 1 percent in the fourth quarter and 5.6 percent for all of last year. For the three months that ended on Dec. 31, 3M's net income totaled $295 million, or $1.34 a share, up from $292 million, or $1.31 a share, in the 1989 period. Sales totaled $3.28 billion, up 11 percent from $2.95 billion in the 1989 quarter. For the year, 3M's net income was $1.31 billion, or $5.91 a share, compared with $1.24 billion, or $5.60 a share, in 1989. Revenues totaled $13.02 billion, an increase of 8.6 percent from $11.99 billion in 1989.

title: Alfa Romeo Aid Repayment Urged
description: The Attorney General of the European Court recommended that the former owner of Alfa Romeo repay $700 million in state aid. The Attorney General, Walter Van Gerven, recommended that the court uphold a 1989 European Commission order that Finmeccanica, an Italian holding company, repay aid received in 1985 and 1986.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The General; Briefing by Powell: A Data-Filled Showcase
description: In a nationally broadcast report on the Persian Gulf war today at the Pentagon, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, showcased himself in a new role, that of an articulate and persuasive spokesman for Bush Administration policy.

title: Venezuelan Flutist in Debut
description: Marco Granados, a Venezuelan flutist who recently joined the Quintet of the Americas, gave his New York debut recital last Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall and performed reasonably well. But the impression was marred by an insufficently varied program and by a remarkably unprofessional presentation.

title: Florio Rejects Plan to Raise the PATH Fare
description: Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey yesterday rejected a Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plan to raise the fare on PATH trains and withheld a decision on an increase in bridge and tunnel tolls that the authority is seeking.

title: Bavaro Out of Practice But Not Out of Game
description: Mark Bavaro, the Giants' starting tight end, was in uniform today, but did not take part in practice for Super Bowl XXV against the Buffalo Bills on Sunday. Although Bavaro also sat out Tuesday's light practice, Coach Bill Parcells said his absence was precautionary.

title: From Pre-Columbian to Post-Tourist
description: ROBERT F. NICHOLS, a gallery owner in Santa Fe, N.M., said the large storage or water jar at left was made about 1880 "before the railroads came to the Southwest, bringing tourists who bought pottery that resulted in a change of decorative styles."

title: Baxter's Net Climbs 28.1%
description: Hospital supplier Baxter International Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter net income rose 28.1 percent.

title: New Chief of USAir To Take Over in June
description: The board of USAir, which has been struggling with service problems, high fuel costs and heavy losses, said yesterday that Seth E. Schofield would succeed Edwin I. Colodny as chief executive of USAir and president of the airline's parent, the USAir Group Inc., in June.

title: At Last, Pax Americana
description: It will be weeks before the guns in the gulf fall silent, but we can see already the political contours of the world following an American victory. Important changes are in the offing on three levels of politics: domestic, Arab and global.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Waring Names Vice Presidents
description: Waring & LaRosa has named two new senior vice presidents who will be co-creative directors and principals of the agency.

title: Angola Accepts Plan to End Its 15-Year War
description: The Angolan Government announced today that it had accepted in principle a peace plan to end the 15-year-old civil war against Unita, the United States-backed guerrilla movement led by Jonas Savimbi.

title: Chicago and New Orleans Found With Losers in Latest U.S. Count
description: The population of Chicago, the city that has been the Midwest's muscleman, continued to thin out in the last decade, declining by 220,000 people, or 7 percent, to 2.8 million, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Big and Little Buzzes at the Sundance Festival
description: No television news bulletins from the outside world interrupt the orgy of movies here. The Sundance Film Festival, now nearing the end of its 10-day run at this ski resort, is not a matter of life and death -- except in terms of careers.

title: What Women Want: Their Own Recliners
description: IT was Super Sunday at the home of the Three Bears. Papa Bear got himself a beer and switched on the TV in the den. He was eager to sink into his big brown vinyl La-Z-Boy and watch Super Bowl XXV, even though the Chicago Bears were not playing.

title: Giants' Collins Awaiting a Tough Choice on Coverage
description: A season was going to end within four seconds or extend to another Sunday. The Giant field-goal unit was lining up. Matt Bahr was preparing for the 42-yard kick that would help define a season. The San Francisco 49ers' fans at Candlestick Park, their hopes for a third consecutive Super Bowl appearance threatened at the worst possible time, waited for an answer.

title: Queens Mother Pleads Guilty In Fatal Battering of a Boy, 3
description: Workers refurbishing an old cemetery in Queens in September 1989 found the hastily buried remains of a 3-year-old boy who had been reported missing by his mother the previous April. Shortly after the discovery, the mother and her male companion were accused of battering the child to death.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; No Immediate Retaliation, Israelis Say
description: Senior Israeli officials said today that despite Tuesday night's missile attack against Tel Aviv, the Government would not carry out an immediate retaliatory strike against Iraq.

title: Video Poker Games Criticized at Hearing
description: Mob-dominated video poker games have become a major law-enforcement problem in New Jersey, and legalizing the industry would not help, an assistant attorney general testified yesterday before the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Rodney Hardesty, 40, A Countertenor, Dies
description: Rodney Hardesty, a countertenor and a recitalist, died on Jan. 15 in Wichita, Kan. He was 40 years old and lived in East Orange, N.J.

title: Fourth-Quarter Profit Dropped 10% at Southwestern Bell
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings had fallen 10 percent because of one-time charges.

title: Bridge
description: More than half a century ago a battle began between the entrenched strong two-bidders, following the dogma of Ely Culbertson, and the upstart weak two-bidders, headed by Howard Schenken.

title: Of Light and Shadow
description: ABOUT 15 years ago, Jan Hashey, a New York artist, painted objects she called "unsentimental and unloaded in meaning." These included plain kitchen bowls.

title: HOPE FOR AVERTING NEW YORK LAYOFFS SEEN BY OFFICIALS
description: A week after Mayor David N. Dinkins called for the immediate layoff of thousands of teachers and other city workers to close a looming budget gap, city officials agreed yesterday that most of the layoffs might be averted, at least for now.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Fast Start for G.M. Redesign Strategy
description: The new Buick Park Avenue sedan holds the distinction of being one of the few car models that has been selling briskly in a time of weak demand, and without the costly stimulus of rebates or other discounts.

title: New Data Base Ended By Lotus and Equifax
description: The Lotus Development Corporation and Equifax Inc. said today that they had canceled plans to sell a data base of names, addresses and marketing information on 120 million United States consumers.

title: Review/Dance; From Japan, a Tapestry of Truths in an Epic Tale
description: Classical ballet has been exceedingly popular in Japan since the 1950's, and in recent years international ballet competitions have seen a huge increase in young Japanese entrants, many of whom jete off with the gold medals.

title: Drug Ban for Barnes Is Upheld
description: Randy Barnes, the world-record holder in the shot-put, has succeeded in convincing an appeal panel of American track and field officials that his positive drug test last August and two-year suspension from competition should be considered invalid.

title: Utah Senate Approves Strict Limits on Abortions
description: The Utah Senate passed a bill today with strict limits on abortion despite plans by opponents to fight the bill in court and to use the issue to try to block the state's effort to host the 1998 Winter Olympics.

title: Mary de Groat Reed, Politician, 77
description: Mary de Groat Reed, a leader in the reform wing of the Democratic Party in Manhattan in the 1950's, died on Tuesday at the Southampton Nursing Home on Long Island. She was 77 years old and lived in Sagaponack, L.I.

title: New Trials Ordered for 2 Facing Death
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today overturned the murder convictions of two men, leaving only 7 of the 33 original inmates on the state's death row still facing the death penalty.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: France; French Policy Upsets Friend and Foe, at Home and Abroad
description: France has yet to experience the pain of losing any planes, pilots or soldiers in combat in the Persian Gulf, but the week-old war has already made itself felt here through political in-fighting, rising social tensions and a crisis in French relations with longtime Arab allies.

title: Review/Theater; Comedy From Economic Devastation
description: Richard Dresser's "Better Days" could be regarded as a black comic postscript to Jerry Sterner's "Other People's Money." In the New England town that is the setting of Mr. Dresser's play, the mill is permanently closed and almost everyone is out of work and out of money -- and many are already out on the street. People are thrown back on what is left of their wits. Scrounging and stealing have become favorite occupations.

title: Early Ceramics
description: To The Home Section:

title: More Signs Of a Slump Nationwide
description: Business activity was falling in most parts of the country in the weeks leading up to the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, with little sign that the contraction was being blunted by lower interest rates, a Federal Reserve survey showed today.

title: HarperCollins Addition
description: Michael di Capua, who has published books under his own name at Farrar, Straus & Giroux since 1987, will join HarperCollins Publishers, the company announced this week. He will be publisher of Michael di Capua Books, reporting directly to George Craig, president and chief executive of HarperCollins.

title: Trump Fills Casino Post
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, today named his chief legal counsel for casinos, Nicholas L. Ribis, as the head of his struggling Atlantic City holdings.

title: Giants Say Players, Not Tactics, Win Games
description: Six and a half weeks ago, when the Buffalo Bills beat the Giants, 17-13, during the regular season, they scored their touchdowns with a no-huddle offense. Now that hurry-up attack is a major concern for the Giants as they prepare to play the Bills here Sunday in Super Bowl XXV.

title: To Restore New York City - First, Reclaim the Streets; A Union Lock on Litter
description: New York's fiscal crisis could turn badly littered streets into avenues of ankle-deep trash -- unless the city holds out for significant changes in a new sanitation workers' contract.

title: Edward E. Lewis, Industrialist, 98
description: Edward E. Lewis, an industrialist who headed the Mutual Security Agency's European production program under the Marshall Plan, died on Saturday at his daughter's home in Verona, N.J. He was 98 years old.

title: War's Hazards for Environment Are Assessed
description: The war in the Persian Gulf could have serious environmental consequences for the region, although most scientific opinion is that even an extensive burning of Kuwait's oilfields would not affect the global climate.

title: In Hyderabad, a Pall Darkens 400th Birthday
description: The past tense has a way of intruding into conversations about how this city in south-central India should celebrate its 400th birthday.

title: Levy Catching Up in Duel of Coaches
description: Marv Levy was happy today, as head coaches go. He had finished the Buffalo Bills' game plan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a luncheon to honor Zubin Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic, misstated the scheduled date. It is Tuesday, not Monday.

title: Personal Health
description: Injuries go with the territory for people who are active in sports or who regularly exercise.

title: U.S. Match With Mexico Postponed
description: The opening-round match between the United States, the 1990 Davis Cup defending champion, and Mexico that was scheduled to begin Feb. 1 in Mexico City, was officially postponed yesterday at the request of the United States Tennis Association. The association cited the war in the Persian Gulf as the cause of its decision not to participate.

title: Keeping Winter Out
description: THE wind is blowing, there's still a little snow on the ground and all you can think about is warming up indoors. Products to warm both body and soul include a pineapple-shaped hot-water bottle in yellow or green and a stuffed cotton draft dodger in the form of cats plump enough to block air creeping under the door, from Toy Works of Middle Falls, N.Y. For cold toes, there is a 19th-century American tin and soapstone foot warmer. But nothing works quite as well for the insides as warm beverages. John Stymeist has designed a teapot for Lindt-Stymeist of San Francisco in periwinkle blue with a mint green lid.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; Iraq: Hidden Cards?
description: Is Saddam Hussein playing possum? If so, what does that portend for the course of the war in the Persian Gulf? A week after allied bombers opened the campaign to oust Iraq from Kuwait, those are the most pressing questions facing American strategists.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
For Tobacco and Alcohol, Some More Ground Is Lost
description: SAN FRANCISCO joined a growing number of local governments that restrict alcohol and tobacco advertising in public places, when the city on Tuesday banned such ads from buses, cable cars and streetcars.

title: Political Giants Deflated in California
description: In the past, the January after an election was usually a happy time for powerful Democratic lawmakers as they came to receive choice committee assignments and other political plums from Willie L. Brown Jr., the Speaker of the California State Assembly.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Fire Fight; U.S. and Iraqi Soldiers Skirmish Near Border
description: In the first significant ground skirmish reported in the Persian Gulf war, Iraqi troops crossed the border into the Saudi desert on Tuesday night and exchanged fire with American troops, wounding two of them before six of the Iraqis were taken prisoner, United States military officials said today.

title: Robert J. Wert, Educator, 69
description: Robert J. Wert, former president of Mills College, died at Marin General Hospital Tuesday of complications from heart disease. He was 69 years old.

title: N.C.A.A. Curbs Player Taunting
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Football Rules Committee, concerned with mocking incidents like those by Miami players in the Cotton Bowl, adopted new regulations today to curb taunting and showboating.

title: Under Audit, Stanford Will Repay U.S.
description: Stanford University said today that it would refund about half a million dollars of Government research money used for the upkeep of university-owned homes for the university's president, Donald Kennedy, and two other administrators.

title: Fighting Fire With Rubles
description: President Mikhail Gorbachev can't be serious. He may think he can solve his political problem in the Baltics even to the extent of some 19 deaths in Latvia and Lithuania. Now he purports to get tough with the Soviet Union's economic problems by withdrawing 50- and 100-ruble notes from circulation. That is supposed to control an explosive growth of the money supply and stifle a booming black market.

title: Earnings Jump 35% At Texaco
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings jumped 35 percent as it profited from the rise in oil prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Monsanto-Exxon Deal
description: Monsanto Inc. said on Tuesday that it and the Exxon Corporation were merging their artificial rubber businesses to form a jointly owned business called Advanced Elastomer Systems. Monsanto said the partnership, which resulted from talks with Exxon that started in 1986, involved nearly 450 employees and units that had 1990 sales of more than $100 million.

title: Shift of Taiwan Funds Is Less Than Reported
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; PENTAGON IS CONFIDENT ON WAR BUT SAYS IRAQIS REMAIN POTENT; SEES NO IMMINENT LAND ATTACK
description: In a confident report on the Persian Gulf war, the nation's top military officials said today that allied forces were now intensifying a campaign to isolate and destroy Iraq's front-line force in and near Kuwait in hopes of forcing an Iraqi withdrawal.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Keep Pushing Staples, A Media Planner Urges
description: War is the best time to advertise staples, even if they are defined as videos and and steak sauce.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; P.O.W.'s Now Told to Resist Cooperation to 'Best of Their Ability'
description: In light of a major shift in what is expected of Americans who become prisoners of war, the appearance on Iraqi television of captured American pilots can be seen as part of a ploy to survive rather than a break in discipline, military psychiatrists say.

title: Dean of Architecture To Lecture at Columbia
description: Prof. Bernard Tschumi, the dean of the Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation at Columbia University, is to lecture on "Six Concepts in Contemporary Architecture" on Feb. 13 in the rotunda of the Low Memorial Library, Broadway at 116th Street.

title: Novotna and Seles Gain Australian Open Final
description: After Jana Novotna beat top-seeded Steffi Graf in the quarterfinals at the Australian Open, she was so excited by the achievement, she said "I feel like this is it, the end of the tournament."

title: Democracy Leader on Trial in China
description: Wang Dan, the scrawny Beijing University student who was the foremost leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement, went on trial today on harges of "counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement."

title: 2 in Runoff for New Hispanic District
description: A City Councilwoman and a state legislator she once worked for will face each other in a runoff to pick the county's first Hispanic supervisor in more than a century after neither got a majority of votes in a court-ordered election on Tuesday.

title: Szarkowski Of Modern Museum To Retire
description: John Szarkowski, director of the Museum of Modern Art's photography department for 29 years, will retire on July 1, ending an invigorating and occasionally controversial career as one of the medium's most eloquent exponents.

title: Reviews/Music; 2 Languages and Laughter In 'Fledermaus' at the Met
description: Otto Schenk's production of "Die Fledermaus," first seen at the Metropolitan Opera in December 1986, has been justly praised for Gunther Schneider-Siemssen's handsome period sets but reviled for its penchant for burlesque comic exaggeration. In its defense, whatever bittersweet sentiment and sophistication the score possesses would probably work better in a smaller theater with a practiced ensemble of comic actors. Given the Met's 4,000-seat opera barn and the constantly shifting parade of famous and semifamous singers that have traipsed through this production over the last four years, Mr. Schenk's approach maybe makes sense.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Marines; Finding Life's Meaning in Winds and Rains of War
description: Night comes early in the Saudi desert and these days it is accompanied by a bitter wind, sporadic rain and the loneliness that isolation and fear bring to the hearts of young soldiers about to go to war.

title: Finicky or Not, Children Find a Way to Eat Well
description: A new study of the eating habits of young children has found that they take in roughly the same amount of calories each day even though they may eat very little at one meal and a great deal at another.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Damage; Assessing Damage Can Be Fettered by the Weather and Pilot Hyperbole
description: Bomb-damage assessment, a difficult skill at the mercy of the weather and enemy guile, is proving a frustrating bottleneck in this high-technology war of instant communications and precision-guided arms.

title: Don't Scrap U.S.-Soviet Arms Accord Summit
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia Fights Intimidation of Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: MILA SCHON , the Milan-based fashion designer, yesterday canceled what was to be her first showing in Paris, "due to the serious current events," a spokesman said. Last month she announced her decision for a show in Paris rather than Rome, for the first time in 25 years. It was to be the season's first show, on Saturday.

title: Washington at Work; C.I.A. Sidelines Its Gulf Cassandra
description: As Iraqi forces massed along Kuwait's border on Aug. 1, a Central Intelligence Agency analyst named Charlie Allen walked into the offices of the National Security Council's Middle East staff.

title: Small Company in Effort To Clone an Apple Computer
description: Working in a small office here two miles from the headquarters of Apple Computer Inc., a start-up company is close to completing the technology for what it says will make possible the first legal clones of the Apple Macintosh computer.

title: High Dioxin Levels Linked to Cancer
description: A new Federal study suggests that the toxic chemical dioxin causes cancer in people exposed at high levels, but may not pose a substantial risk of cancer at lower levels.

title: Dow Gains 15.84 Points, To 2,619.06
description: In a tense market where investors make big decisions on the strength of little headlines, nervous stock traders touched off heavy selling late yesterday after reports of two explosions in Saudi Arabia and air raid sirens in Israel.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; Fear for Turks Near Base: Iraqi and 'His Chemicals'
description: "Peace at home, peace in the world," said Kemal Ataturk, and for 70 years the modern Turkish Republic has more or less taken the admonition of its founding father to heart.

title: Williams Activated
description: The Dallas Mavericks yesterday activated Herb Williams, the forward who was on the injured list for more than a month with bursitis in his right knee. He had averaged 8.3 points and 5.1 rebounds before he went on the injured list Dec. 18. He missed 22 games. To make room for Williams, Dallas released Howard Wright from his second 10-day contract.(AP)

title: Service Improves at Eastern Slopes
description: Like other businesses, ski areas have been feeling the pinch of slowing economic conditions. A few years ago there was a splurge of construction and expansion with high-tech lifts, computer-controlled snowmaking, powerful grooming vehicles and wide, steep trails at many Eastern ski areas. But this year, additions have been fewer and smaller.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: PARENTS usually give their children toys, especially expensive toys and games, to celebrate special occasions like a birthday or Christmas. They use them to comfort their children after painful or frightening experiences like a stay in the hospital. They use them as tokens of their love, which is why a child's heartfelt plea for a particular toy or game can be difficult to refuse.

title: Metro Matters; Striving to Keep Libraries Open In Budget Pinch
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy is the unsung hero of the Saratoga branch library, but his may have been a hollow victory.

title: Farm Bank Issues' Top Yield Is 6.70%
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced for sale a three-part bond offering totaling $2.32 billion, through various securities dealers and dealer banks.

title: F. Hodge O'Neal, 73, Ex-Law School Dean
description: F. Hodge O'Neal, a former dean of the Washington University School of Law in St. Louis, died on Sunday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 73 years old and lived in Sarasota and St. Louis.

title: Events: Seminars And Tours
description: A new semester of classes at cultural institutions is about to begin. Here is a selection of lectures, workshops, tours and seminars: Cooper-Hewitt Museum

title: Mary Martin Memorial
description: A memorial service for the actress Mary Martin is to be held on Monday at 2 P.M. at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street. Among those scheduled to participate are Theodore Bikel, Carol Channing, Helen Hayes, Jerry Herman, Florence Henderson, Van Johnson, Carol Lawrence, Kathleen Nolan, Bernadette Peters, John Raitt and Jerome Robbins. A videotape will feature remarks by former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy. The service is open to the public. Miss Martin died of cancer on Nov. 4 at the age of 76.

title: Cray Income Down 36.4%
description: Cray Research Inc. today reported a decline in revenues and earnings for the fourth quarter, but an increase for the year. The company said it expects to resume strong growth in 1991.

title: CHRONICLE
description: W. WILSON GOODE JR. , the son of the Mayor of Philadelphia, has announced that he is running for the City Council. The 25-year-old University of Pennsylvania graduate said that he would seek one of the five Democratic nominations for a four-year term as a Council member at large in the May 21 primary.

title: Ruble Recall Deepens Soviet Hardships
description: The Soviet Government's abrupt withdrawal of large ruble bills from circulation today deepened the chaos in the Soviet economy.

title: Review/Music; 'Highbrow/Lowbrow' And the Area Between
description: The interplay between popular art and the other kind -- call it classical, elitist or whatever shibboleth works best for you -- runs through the history of Western music. We know a confluence sometimes occurs, but exactly when, how and why are questions as obscure as the Eleusinian mysteries. There was no reason, then, to expect that the process would be plumbed in depth by the program presented Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall under the tongue-in-cheek title of "Highbrow/Lowbrow: An American Sampler."

title: Oil Prices Move Higher; Crude for March at $22.04
description: The price of oil edged up yesterday as traders continued to fret about the possibility of Israeli retaliation for a fatal Iraqi missile attack on Tuesday.

title: Garden Catalogues To Dream With Through Winter
description: THEY are tempting beyond most gardeners' space for planting. Mail-order catalogues -- also fondly called wish books -- rarely fail to turn an armchair gardener's thoughts to spring. Gardeners thrive on discovery, and suppliers large and small accommodate them by adding something special every spring. Winter skies may still be moody gray, but a rhapsody of flawless plants beckons.

title: Super Bowl Is All New York! (With Some Qualifications)
description: A battle between a state's two largest cities sounds like such a promising civic rivalry, a throwback to the famous Subway Series between New York's baseball teams. But something seems to be missing from the Super Bowl this Sunday.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Warsaw Pact; Eastern Europe Treads Softly on the Baltic Issue
description: Eastern Europe's new democracies are taking a cautious approach to the Kremlin's crackdown against the Baltic republics, joining the West in words of condemnation but stopping short of any move that might put a new strain on their frayed relations with Moscow.

title: Agency's View Of Recession
description: Congressional budget officials today joined the growing number of economic experts predicting that the recession will be a brief one.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington; White House's Quandary In Relations With Kremlin
description: The crisis in the Baltic republics placed the Bush Administration in something of a quandary today, as the White House sought to balance its desire for a modicum of good relations with the Gorbachev leadership against its interest in backing democratic movements in the Soviet Union.

title: UConn Starter Is Out
description: Murray Williams, a Connecticut forward, has been ruled academically ineligible and will not play the rest of the season, Coach Jim Calhoun said on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Grants $1 Million To Newark Arts Center
description: A multi-million-dollar arts complex proposed for Newark has received a Federal grant of more than $1 million for open-space improvements.

title: Review/Theater; Feiffer's Family Caldron, 10 Years Old but Fresh
description: One of the happy surprises of the American Jewish Theater's scorching revival of Jules Feiffer's "GrownUps" is how well this nasty Freudian comedy has aged since it opened on Broadway nearly 10 years ago.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SOME homeowners consider squeaky stairs an economical alarm that signals the presence of a family member, friend or intruder. And sometimes squeaky stairs indicate broken parts that can cause an accident or lead to major damage. While some stair problems are easy to fix, severe ones are usually best left to an experienced carpenter because of the complexity of stair construction.

title: Banks Try to Make Students Debt Junkies
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Is Acquitted In Attack on Sons
description: A woman who told psychiatrists her teddy bear had directed her to kill her three sons has been acquitted of attempted murder by reason of insanity.

title: Rangers Angered by Nicholls's Injury
description: The Rangers-Islanders rivalry, which alternately boils and simmers, grew hot again Tuesday night when Bernie Nicholls of the Rangers suffered a serious separation of his left shoulder in a 3-2 Islanders victory at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Editorial Notebook; They Tortured My Mother
description: The hospital was a torture chamber. Doctors were the torturers.

title: Ex-Banker Admits Embezzling
description: A former bank official from Rensselaer County surrendered today in Federal court and waived indictment on charges that he embezzled $255,000 from Marine Midland during an eight-year period. The former bank official, Gerald W. Whitman, 46 years old, of Troy, pleaded guilty to a felony charge of bank fraud. He said he would make restitution to Marine Midland for $256,200, Sentencing was set by Judge Con Cholakis for March 6 in Federal District Court in Albany.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A10-15

title: Review/Music; Levine and Chamber Group
description: James Levine, the artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera, and members of his vaunted orchestra emerged from the pit on Sunday afternoon for their annual concert of chamber music at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. Four varied ensembles played a program ranging backward through history from Bartok's "Contrasts" to Bach's "Brandenburg" Concerto No. 5, both with Mr. Levine at the piano. In between came Wagner's "Siegfried Idyll," with Mr. Levine conducting, and Mozart's Oboe Quartet (K. 370).

title: Help in the Past Inspires Gifts To the Neediest Cases Fund
description: "With thanks for the services rendered me by your agency 30 years ago -- when I was needy" is all that was jotted on the peach-colored stationery. It was enclosed with a $25 gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Ismail to Decide
description: Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, Notre Dame's flanker and return specialist, has called a news conference for today at which university officials expect he will announce his decision to enter the National Football League draft.

title: British Detain 32 More Iraqis
description: The British Government has announced that it has taken 32 more Iraqis into custody with the intention of deporting them. The 32 were detained on Tuesday and today. A Home Office spokesman said that since Iraq invaded Kuwait the Government had taken action against 160 Iraqis with no connection to the Iraqi Embassy here and 12 other nationals, either deporting them or preventing them from re-entering the country.

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Baltics; Stalemate In Baltics
description: Whether through grisly plot or lethal indifference, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has managed to settle nothing in the Baltic republics except to leave them resembling a broken stage set underfoot for a continuing production about liberty.

title: Disney Talks on MTM Reported
description: The Walt Disney Company is negotiating to acquire MTM Entertainment and a minority stake in its parent company, TVS Entertainment P.L.C., a British broadcaster, according to an executive familiar with the talks.

title: Teachings Of a Jersey Philosopher
description: Up behind the lectern in a white tent outside the Hyatt Regency West Shore hotel yesterday, Bill Parcells, wearing a blue-gray sweatshirt over a sportshirt, was conducting a Super Bowl ritual: the inquisition by several hundred sportswriters. In assessing the Bills' no-huddle offense, the Giants coach talked about how explosive it was.

title: War Cuts Companies' Trips Abroad
description: Most globe-trotting executives will be staying home for a while. With war raging in the Persian Gulf, many large corporations have banned travel to the Middle East and greatly curtailed other international travel, officials of several dozen top companies said.

title: Market Place; Indictment Offers A Rare Glimpse
description: IN an indictment that can only increase investor fears of trading low-priced over-the-counter stocks, New York prosecutors said yesterday that traders for six over-the-counter firms had been involved in a conspiracy to fix prices and defraud investors.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Egypt; In Egypt, Public Sentiment Is Shifting in Baghdad's Favor
description: A segment of public opinion in Egypt, the largest Arab country and a key Arab ally of the United States, is clearly shifting in favor of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.

title: When Nora Met Wendy
description: You don't have to read Henri Bergson to know that to a serious student of film, there is nothing funny about comedy. Dissecting humor, particularly in the company of film scholars, can be downright deadly.

title: Judge Backs F.B.I. in Dismissal of an Agent
description: A Federal district judge ruled Tuesday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation acted properly when it dismissed an agent who had become a pacifist and refused to investigate peace groups or carry a gun.

title: Cabdriver Is Shot to Death; Suspect in Drug Case Is Held
description: A 33-year-old cabdriver was slain early Tuesday in the East Village and a 20-year-old Manhattan man was charged yesterday in the death, the police said.

title: Israel Is Ruling Out Retaliation, for Now
description: Israel said it would not carry out an immediate retaliatory strike against Iraq despite the missile attack on Tel Aviv that killed three people.

title: The Other War
description: The second skirmish of the Soviet Civil War, following "Bloody Sunday" in Lithuania, took place this week in Russian-occupied Riga, Latvia.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Helping Your Old Rugs Lie Longer
description: SOME of Ronnee Barnett's work graces the walls of apartments, houses, art galleries and even the New York University Law School. But much of it winds up on the floor, and people walk all over it.

title: Don't Scrap U.S.-Soviet Arms Accord Summit; Reliable Detection
description: To the Editor:

title: Marv Albert's Home Base Is an All-Sports Shrine
description: CERTAIN sports fixtures are ubiquitous in the American home: a suburban driveway without a basketball hoop is as naked as a summer lawn without a sprinkler.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Toronto, appointed Michael R. Goldhawk vice president to be in charge of its U.S. corporate finance offices and its structured finance group. * General Public Utilities Corp., Parsippany, N.J., named Philip C. Mezey vice president and corporate executive officer. He was also named chairman of its energy initiatives unit. * Home Depot, Atlanta, a retail chain of home-improvement centers, promoted Jesse Behnke to vice president of merchandising for its mid-South region. * Maxtor Corp., San Jose, Calif., a provider of computer disk drives, promoted Gary Galusha to vice president of worldwide sales. * Maytag Corp., Newton, Iowa, named Terry A. Carlson corporate vice president of purchasing. * NCR Corp., Dayton, Ohio, appointed Gary J. Cotshott vice president of its Cimeg division in its U.S. group. * NUI Corp., Bedminster, N.J., a utility holding company, named Jack Langer chief executive of its City Gas Co. of Florida unit. * New York Life Insurance Co., New York, appointed Julia A. Romano vice president of its information systems and services department. * Technology Applications Inc., Alexandria, Va., which provides information systems, appointed Thomas R. Edgar vice president of human resources and communications. * United Airlines, Elk Grove Village, Ill., a unit of UAL Corp., named James E. Goodwin senior vice president of maintenance operations. Terry Hall was appointed vice president and treasurer. * Waxman Industries, Bedford Heights, Ohio, which sells plumbing and hardware products, named William R. Pray to the new position of president of its U.S. operations. * Whirlpool Corp., Benton Harbor, Mich., named Richard P. Palmieri president of its Whirlpool Financial Corporation unit. James Winschel was promoted to vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Brokerage Is Punished
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday fined Salomon Brothers $1.3 million and censured the firm for 1987 violations of Federal securities laws and exchange rules covering program trading activities that bilked customers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: President LECH WALESA of Poland is being sued by Penta Promotions, a Dutch company, for the last-minute cancellation of a speaking trip last fall to the Netherlands when he was the Solidarity union leader. Lawyers for the company sent a letter to Solidarity headquarters in Gdansk demanding that a lawyer for Mr. Walesa appear in court in Utrecht on April 21, Gazeta Wyborcza said.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany; Kohl Is Sending $165 Million In Humanitarian Aid to Israel
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that his Government would send $165 million to Israel as "immediate humanitarian aid" after Iraqi missile attacks, and that more money would be sent to support the anti-Iraq alliance in the Persian Gulf.

title: Recovery 'Hotel': It's Not the Ritz, but It's Restful
description: For most patients who undergo surgery, recovery can be a dismal business. Hospital nurses may wake them at odd hours, the food comes even if they are not hungry and the patient in the next bed may moan through the night.

title: U.S. Reports AIDS Deaths Now Exceed 100,000
description: The death toll from AIDS in the United States has climbed to more than 100,000, with nearly a third of the deaths occurring last year, Federal health officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about staff reductions for California legislators referred incorrectly to results of the November election. California voters chose the second Republican Governor in a row, not the third.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, page D23 was omitted from some copies yesterday and replaced by a duplicate of page D20. Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Radon in Homes Associated With Gravel Deposits and Soil Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Royal Navy to Train Women To Fly Helicopters, Then Jets
description: Women are to be trained for the first time to fly Royal Navy aircraft, Britain's Minister of State for the Armed Forces announced today.

title: War Summary
description: SAUDI PILOT DOWNS 2 IRAQIS As the weather improved, allied bombers stepped up the pace of their attacks deep inside Iraq, concentrating on positions of the Republican Guards. A 30-year old Saudi pilot in an American-made F-15 shot down a pair of French-built Iraqi Mirage fighters over the Persian Gulf. A force of Marines, described as the largest amphibious group since the Korean War, practiced landings. DANGEROUS BRITISH MISSIONS The most dangerous missions of the war are being carried out by British pilots, most in their 20's, who fly into Iraq a few hundred feet above the ground to drop cluster bombs on well-protected Iraqi airfields. So far, 10 of the Tornado bomber airmen have been killed or are missing. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Fourteen Americans and 12 allied airmen are listed as missing in action. Aircraft: A 15th American plane, an Air Force F-16, was lost, but its pilot was picked up by a Navy helicopter. The allied command has reported 21 warplanes lost, 17 of them in combat. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraq has reported 39 military deaths and nearly 100 civilian deaths. The allies say 29 more Iraqis were taken prisoner on the island of Qura off the Kuwaiti coast. Aircraft: The American command reported that the allies had shot down 19 enemy planes and destroyed 41 on the ground. A Pentagon spokesman said Wednesday's announcement of 19 planes shot down was an overcount by two. A Saudi pilot shot down two Iraqis yesterday so the count was placed at 19.

title: Lendl Survives 2 Match Points To Beat Edberg and Gain Final
description: Ivan Lendl gladly took the gift of 12 double faults by Stefan Edberg, including one at match point, and marched into his third consecutive Australian Open final.

title: Johnson Case Put Off
description: A case involving an assault charge against the sprinter Ben Johnson was put off yesterday until Feb. 18.

title: Canadian Fighters Help U.S. In First Gulf Combat Flights
description: Four CF-18 fighters of the Canadian Defense Forces flew air cover for United States Air Force bombers today, marking the first time that Canadian air units have flown combat missions since World War II.

title: Disney Profits Drop 2% for Quarter
description: The Walt Disney Company's profits dropped 2 percent in the final three months of 1990, the first quarterly decrease in six years, as the recession and Persian Gulf worries hurt theme park attendance, Disney said.

title: Market Place; I.B.M. Gets Lift From Mainframes
description: STRONG sales of I.B.M.'s newest mainframe computers gave the computer maker a solid fourth-quarter report, and analysts say the trend will continue in 1991.

title: Ismail Enters N.F.L. Draft; Patriots Consider Options
description: A short time after Raghib (Rocket) Ismail officially declared his intention to forsake his senior season at Notre Dame and enter this spring's National Football League draft, Dick MacPherson, the new head coach of the New England Patriots, was wishing aloud today that this time the Rocket would not get away from him.

title: Pepsi Cancels Big Giveaway
description: Pepsico Inc. decided last night that much as it wanted to promote Diet Pepsi it was not worth the risk of snarling the nation's telephone network in the process.

title: Microsystems' Results Soar
description: Buoyed by strong demand for its newest work stations, Sun Microsystems Inc. today reported record revenues and earnings for its second quarter. The company said internal cost controls helped increase its profitability.

title: Critic's Choice
description: They stole into town seven weeks ago, won glowing reviews, then slipped away. Now the three ingenious con artists of "The Grifters" have returned for a regular New York run. The earlier weeklong engagement qualified them for Academy Award nominations, which are certainly in this film's future. Bet on that.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Musical Returns To America
description: WHEN the 1980's departed, it was not only the Trump yacht and Drexel Burnham Lambert that sailed into the sunset. Somewhat less conspicuously, the theater's own symbol of a money-crazed decade -- the over-produced English musical -- began its inexorable retreat to the wings. Built on opulent stage effects, London's theatrical spectaculars were as symptomatic of the money-mad 80's as a Malcolm Forbes birthday bash, and in the 1990's, their party, too, seems to be over.

title: Accounting Group Is Facing New Deficits, Official Says
description: The executive vice president of the Financial Accounting Foundation told the group's trustees yesterday that the organization was facing the strong possibility of a third consecutive annual deficit and continued deficits through 1995 unless they acted to reverse the trends.

title: It's First-and-10 for Buffalo's Zooming Civic Pride
description: When Carletta Rock was a girl, Buffalo was bigger than Los Angeles, and everybody really did call the place the Queen City of the Lakes. She grew up on stories about the days when this terminus of the Erie Canal was one of the busiest ports in the world, the meeting place, residents boasted, of Western supply and Eastern demand.

title: Ford Cash Search To Exclude Mazda
description: The Ford Motor Company, sitting atop a dwindling pile of cash, is intensifying a search for new sources of money, but it does not intend to sell its share of the Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan, a spokesman, Dick Routh, said. Mr. Routh was responding to a report in The Wall Street Journal today that Ford might reduce its dividend or sell all or part of its 25 percent Mazda stake to raise money.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Reversing an earlier decision to halt all overseas travel, thus preventing editors from attending the Paris couture shows beginning this weekend, Conde Nast executives are allowing ANNA WINTOUR, the editor of Vogue, and ANNE SUTHERLAND FUCHS, the magazine's publisher, to make the trip.

title: Books of The Times; When Things Go Bad, They Sometimes Go All the Way Bad
description: An Honorable Profession By John L'Heureux 403 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: John Pauker, 70, Dies; Ex-U.S. Aide and Poet
description: John Pauker, a former official of the United States Information Agency who was also a poet, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 70 years old.

title: Now, Cities Hit Drug Suspects Where They Live
description: Even by the standards of Times Square, the Hotel Strand was a blight on the neighborhood, said those who lived and worked nearby. Drug dealers used its rooms to cook cocaine into crack. The police were repeatedly called in to arrest occupants, both in the Strand's rooms and on nearby streets, on charges of drug and gun possession and of stealing and fighting.

title: Five Days Of Theater By Blacks
description: A new work by Amiri Baraka, entitled "General Hag's Skeezag," and other plays by Richard Wesley, Bonnie Lee Rattner and Zakes Mda, among others, will be included in Festival '91, a free, five-day series of events devoted to African and black American theater that opens this weekend. The festival's first event will be a panel discussion on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at the John Houseman Theater, 450 West 42d Street.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: The 'Private Lives' of Joan Collins

title: H. Norman Runsdorf, Physician, 82
description: Dr. H. Norman Runsdorf, a doctor in Brooklyn for more than 50 years, died on Wednesday at his home in the Midwood section.

title: Bills Aren't Only Team That Has an Offense
description: If you listen to all the talk here during this Super Bowl week, you may think that Sunday's game will involve only the Buffalo Bills' offense and the Giants' defense. Except for curiosity about Jeff Hostetler, the Giants' new starting quarterback, the Giants' offense and the Bills' defense have been overlooked.

title: Elegant Outhouse
description: Joan Davidson predicts it will be "New York's flagship restroom." Daniel Biederman promises that "anyone who comes in there, including the homeless, will be treated like a king." The project, though grandiose, could set an example for other civic groups and City Hall.

title: Jury Selection Starts for 2 Men In Bensonhurst Murder Case
