description: Jury selection began this week for two of the last three defendants in the Bensonhurst murder case, a killing that produced several trials and aroused racial passions in New York City.

title: 2 Unsavory Choices on the Budget: Increase Borrowing or Raise Taxes
description: No one knows how much the war will cost. That is because no one knows how long it will last, how many lost planes and expended weapons will have to be replaced and how much money the allies will contribute to offset the price to the American taxpayer.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Wednesday about Grace & Rothschild Advertising misidentified the copywriters for two advertisements. Diane Rothschild oversees copywriting for the J & B Scotch and Range Rover accounts; Craig Demeter wrote the copy for J & B's " ingle ells, ingle ells" ad, and Gary Cohen wrote the Range Rover ad with the caption "The British have always driven on the wrong side of the road."

title: A Saudi Pilot Downs 2 Jets
description: Two Iraqi Mirage F-1's loaded with bombs and Exocet anti-ship missiles were streaking low this morning, heading south along the coast, when a Saudi pilot swung his F-15 fighter in from behind.

title: Chief Executive Quits At Ailing Child World
description: Child World Inc., the struggling No. 2 toy chain, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Peter J. Hayes, had resigned.

title: Air Midwest Gets Mesa Bid
description: Mesa Airlines Inc. offered today to buy Air Midwest Inc. in an arrangement that would total about $27 million, company officials said.

title: Parcells Plays Numbers Game at Practice
description: When the Giants and the Buffalo Bills practice this week for Super Bowl XXV on Sunday, all reporters, photographers and others are barred except for one pool reporter. Still, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants took measures to assure that his secrets remained secret.

title: 50 Westinghouse Years, 50 New York Triumphs
description: In certain high school circles, they are known simply as the "Westies" and spoken of as reverently as Hollywood talks about the Oscars. The Westinghouse Science Talent Search has a 50-year tradition as the most prestigious science and mathematics competition in the nation and yesterday, when the list of finalists was released, another 50-year tradition was continued: students who attend New York City public schools led the list.

title: Dime Savings Bank Raises Its President to Chairman
description: The Dime Savings Bank of New York yesterday elevated its president and chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, to be chairman and chief executive and hired a new president and chief operating officer, Lawrence J. Toal, a former Chase Manhattan banker.

title: McGovern: 'I Am Ready' to Run
description: The year is 1991 and America is at war in the Persian Gulf. But for a moment today it seemed as if it was the early 1970's and a different war, for here was George S. McGovern on a college stage talking about running for President.

title: Westchester Housing; Project in Dobbs Ferry for Firemen
description: With a plan that may become a model for other communities, the Westchester village of Dobbs Ferry will begin work this spring on an affordable housing project designed to attract badly needed volunteer firefighters to the area.

title: A.T.& T.'s Earnings Are Flat
description: A.T.& T. announced yesterday that its earnings were nearly flat in the fourth quarter. The loss of tax credits, higher interest expenses and reduced gains from cash investments and asset sales offset a strong increase in operating profits.

title: Peru Develops Plan to Work With U.S. to Combat Drugs
description: Peru has drawn up plans for a multi-faceted joint venture with the United States to fight coca leaf cultivation, a detailed outline received here indicated today.

title: Americana Prevails At Antiques Show
description: GERRY KORNBLAU, a folk-art dealer, had a difficult assignment: installing his 20-foot carved wood and gilded trade sign depicting the Winchester Model 73 -- the gun that won the West -- on the back wall of his booth at the Winter Antiques Show in the Seventh Regiment Armory. "It's 20 feet of solid lumber and there is a lot of bulk to it," Mr. Kornblau said. "It weighs 250 pounds."

title: More Soviet Workers at U.N. Are Really Working for U.N.
description: The 430 or so Soviet citizens who work for the United Nations Secretariat got a welcome New Year's gift this year: Starting Jan. 1, they are no longer expected to hand over a chunk of their salaries to the Soviet Mission.

title: United Deal to Buy Eastern Operations
description: United Airlines said it planned to pay $60 million for the airport space and takeoff rights of Eastern Airlines in Chicago and Los Angeles. United would get three gates each at Los Angeles International Airport and at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. The airline would also get takeoff and landing rights at O'Hare, probably about 20. United, based in Elk Grove Village, Ill., has 729 O'Hare slots.

title: Top Milers in Meet
description: Three top milers, Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, Peter Rono of Kenya and Steve Ave of the United States, will compete in the USAir Invitational indoor track and field meet at East Tennessee State University in Johnson City, Tenn.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; Iraqi Use of Captured Airmen: Old Tactics
description: Iraq's parading of captured pilots in front of television cameras, their faces bruised and their statements apparently made under coercion, and its threat to use them as human shields is reminiscent of the Iraqi treatment of Iranian prisoners during the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Northrop Frye, 78, Literary Critic, Theorist and Educator, Is Dead
description: Northrop Frye, the Canadian literary theorist, critic and educator who was noted for his systematic and erudite studies of myth and symbolism as the unifying models of Western literature, died on Wednesday at his home in Toronto. He was 78 years old.

title: 2 Top Bills Fight Off Personal Emotions
description: Today provided an extreme high for Darryl Talley and an awful low for Bruce Smith, two of the Buffalo Bills' key defensive players in Super Bowl XXV. And as Talley and Smith have done throughout their college and pro careers, they shared the moments, the laughter and the sorrow.

title: Where The Kick Fits In
description: Grown men and women turned from their television sets because the tension they felt was so great. Huge people in shoulder pads knelt on the sidelines, helmets bowed, as the game clock in Candlestick Park was stopped at ":04" in the final quarter last Sunday. The hometown San Francisco fans were on their feet in anticipation. The Giants, as the football world knows, were behind to the 49ers by 13-12, and were 24 yards from the goal line. Time for one last play, a play that would determine the outcome of the game, and which team would go to the Super Bowl to meet the Buffalo Bills.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Frenchwoman Captures Title Surya Bonaly, a 17-year-old from the island Reunion in the Indian Ocean who was adopted by a couple from Nice, became the first Frenchwoman to win a European figure-skating title yesterday in Sofia, Bulgaria. Bonaly came from behind to take the free-skating portion and move past the defender, Evelyn Grossman of Germany, who finished second. (AP) GOLF Jones Leads Phoenix Open by Shot Steve Jones carded a bogey-free eight-under-par 63 yesterday to take a one-shot lead over Curtis Strange before first-round play was suspended at the Phoenix Open. Play was stopped because of darkness with 21 players still on the course. None were in contention for the lead. (AP) N.B.A. Lakers Roll to 9th Victory in a Row James Worthy had 17 of his 24 points in the first quarter last night as the Los Angeles Lakers took a 14-point lead en route to their season-best ninth consecutive victory, 113-93, over the Hornets in Charlotte, N.C. The Lakers, who also got 19 points from Magic Johnson, made 58 percent of their shots to hand Charlotte its third successive loss and sixth in seven games. (AP) Rockets 118, Timberwolves 94: Larry Smith had 23 rebounds -- his third 20-plus performance in the last five games -- as Houston, playing at home, beat Minnesota to win for just the second time in eight games. Otis Thorpe scored 23 points and had 12 rebounds as the Rockets outrebounded Minnesota, 53-32. (AP) Spurs 111, Cavaliers 103: David Robinson scored 30 points and San Antonio hit 13 free throws in the final three minutes to beat Cleveland in San Antonio. The loss was the Cavaliers' 13th in 15 games. (AP) N.H.L. Moog Notches His 11th Shutout Andy Moog stopped 20 shots for his 11th career shutout and Ray Bourque, with two assists, became the highest-scoring defenseman in Boston history last night in the Bruins' 3-0 victory over the Hartford Whalers at Boston. Bourque has 240 goals and 650 assists for 890 points. Bobby Orr had 888 points for Boston. (AP) Flyers 6, Capitals 1: Rick Tocchet scored three goals for the Flyers' first hat trick of the season, leading Philadelphia at the Spectrum. The victory was the Flyers' fourth in a row and ended an eight-game streak without a victory (0-6-2) against the Capitals. Tocchet's three goals, his eighth career hat trick, lifted his season total to 34, second only to Brett Hull of St. Louis, who has 48. (AP) Sabres 5, Blackhawks 4: In Chicago, Mike Ramsey's goal with 7:39 remaining in regulation gave Buffalo its fifth consecutive victory. (AP)

title: 2 Officers Killed in Santiago
description: Suspected guerrillas shot and killed two police officers in northern Santiago today, the police said. An anonymous caller told a local news agency that the attack had been carried out by the Lautaro Front, a small leftist guerrilla gang, to protest the Government's handling of the investigation of human rights abuses under the former military Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: NASA Weighs Plan To Send Astronauts To Repair Telescope
description: Space agency officials are considering a plan to send astronauts to correct the blurred vision of the Hubble Space Telescope. It calls for them to insert mirrors the size of postage stamps on four instruments to sharpen their focus.

title: Bombings Lead Beirut To Tighten Gun Curbs
description: The Lebanese Government imposed strict new regulations on firearms today, in an effort to tighten security in the Beirut area and head off further attacks against Western interests.

title: Thomas Delays Surgery
description: The Pistons' Thomas says he won't have surgery to repair his injured right wrist until at least after the playoffs.

title: Bush Said to Lean Toward Summit Delay
description: Administration officials said today that it was increasingly likely that the next Soviet-American summit meeting would be postponed, as President Bush came under increasing pressure from Congress to put off the Moscow meeting because of the violence in the Baltic republics.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The margin for error is very small. Some of the American planes are a mile up. We are flying at 100 feet in the face of antiaircraft fire in darkness. There is no time to recover." -- Group Capt. Bill Hedges, commander of a detachment of British Tornado bombers. [ A1:5. ]

title: Defiant Croatian Republic Refuses to Disarm Paramilitary Police
description: In defiance of mounting threats by Yugoslavia's Communist-led army, the anti-Communist and independence-minded Government of Croatia refused today to disarm paramilitary police, accusing the army of seeking to undermine the republic's young democracy.

title: F.B.I. Is Monitoring Terrorist Supporters In U.S., Official Says
description: An Assistant Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation told the nation's mayors today that the agency was monitoring supporters in the United States of Abu Nidal, Hezbollah and other Middle East terrorist groups that "have the capability to take action."

title: American Express Net Drops 46%
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that its net income had dropped 46.4 percent in the fourth quarter and 84.6 percent for all of 1990, because of a loss of nearly $1 billion on the year at its troubled Wall Street brokerage house, Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Beijing Journal; Whatever the High Walls Hide, It Isn't Opulence
description: Behind 15-foot walls in the center of the capital is a vast and lovely park called Zhongnanhai, which was once a playground of the emperors and their concubines and which today doubles as the Communist version of a Forbidden City and the most exclusive retirement home in the world.

title: British Feel Pinch as Dollars Stay Home
description: With Americans and other business travelers staying home in large numbers because of the war with Iraq, some London hotels and shops say that they are having a terrible time.

title: CHRONICLE
description: More than 200 bidders bought items belonging to WILLIE NELSON, from a grand piano to a golf cart shaped like a Rolls-Royce, at an auction on Wednesday. It was the first of three being held by the Internal Revenue Service in Briarcliff, Tex., about 30 miles west of Austin, to pay some of the $16.7 million that the I.R.S. says Mr. Nelson owes in back taxes and penalties.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Halcyon in the Rihga Royal

title: War: The One-Week Jitters
description: Can you imagine? This war is a week old already and we don't even know yet when it will end!

title: Pilot Killed as 2 Jet Fighters Collide in Kansas Training
description: One pilot was killed today when a pair of F-16A jet fighters collided during a training exercise and crashed in farm pasture near this town 50 miles east of Wichita.

title: Review/Film; How Evil Can One Person Be?
description: At the start of the gripping Dutch psychological thriller "The Vanishing," a crisis of confidence interrupts an otherwise sunny vacation. Rex (Gene Bervoets) and Saskia (Johanna ter Steege), a happy and attractive couple from Amsterdam, are driving along a French highway when they decide to take a detour along a scenic route. The scenery is indeed beautiful, and so mountainous that the road passes through a very long tunnel. Midway through it, in the dark, Rex and Saskia run out of gas.

title: Blissfield Journal; A Palestinian Casualty, All Too Close to Home
description: Vandals attacked the local Dairy Queen with paint on Saturday and arsonists set it afire on Tuesday. In a farming village of 3,000 people whose Police Chief says he cannot remember the last major crime, many residents say they suspect the violence was meant to punish the restaurant's owner, a Palestinian-American, for opposing the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Sales of Cars and Light Trucks Down by 20.2%
description: Sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States fell 20.2 percent in mid-January, as demand for vehicles remained sluggish.

title: Astronomers Duck as a Tiny Asteroid Passes
description: Astronomers scanning the sky a week ago were astonished to see a small asteroid streaking by Earth, within less than half the distance to the Moon. It was the smallest, closest asteroid ever observed passing safely by Earth.

title: Interim Stamp Uses 17 Words Just to Say 4 Cents
description: It is the Postal Service's newest stamp, and even its creators acknowledge that it is less than beautiful.

title: I.B.M. Credit Sues Leasing Company
description: The I.B.M. Credit Corporation has sued a competitor, Comdisco Inc., accusing the computer-leasing company of misappropriating components that had been leased to customers. In a lawsuit filed in Delaware, I.B.M. Credit said Comdisco had persuaded its customers to allow them to remove parts from mainframes made by the International Business Machines Corporation and exchange them for parts from other vendors. Comdisco then would resell the parts, in several cases winning bids for contracts in competition with the big computer maker.

title: Jennings Turns to Children's Worries
description: Peter Jennings, the anchor of ABC News, was on the air in the middle of the evening newscast on Jan. 16, when the ABC correspondent in Baghdad, Gary Shepard, began describing the attack by allied warplanes.

title: Toronto Symphony
description: Cho-Liang Lin is to be the soloist with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra in Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1 in D (Op. 19) at Carnegie Hall, tonight at 8 o'clock. The program, which is to be conducted by Gunther Herbig, the orchestra's music director, also includes Webern's Six Pieces for Orchestra (Op. 6) and Schubert's Symphony No. 9 in C (D. 944). Tickets are $24 to $27. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Kentucky Freshman Makes His Mark
description: Jamal Mashburn may be about 750 miles from home but his adjustment from New York City to the University of Kentucky has been like a walk around a city block: somewhat routine, but potentially adventuresome.

title: Northwest Air in No Hurry to Spend
description: While strong airlines like American and United have been jumping to buy the precious international routes that weaker carriers have been forced to sell, Northwest has so far remained on the sidelines, picking up only small pieces.

title: Once a Hero, Simms Can Only Watch From Sidelines
description: Four years ago, when the Giants won Super Bowl XXI, Phil Simms was their hero.

title: Maine Governor's Son Dies
description: Peter McKernan, the 20-year-old son of Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, died Wednesday night, nine days after his heart stopped during varsity baseball practice at Dartmouth College. He had collapsed near the end of a two-mile jog and never regained consciousness. Dr. Bruce Friedman, a cardiologist at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, where Mr. McKernan died, said the disorder would not necessarily have been detected in routine medical screening and that it could have been hereditary or caused by a viral infection. Tests indicated that no drugs were involved.

title: Marines Take Goat Hill But Camels Don't Care
description: Blunt-nosed armored personnel carriers, surrounded by squat jeeps equipped with anti-tank missiles and .50-caliber machine guns, accelerated down a rise and headed across the desert valley.

title: Surge of Rock Fans; Then Death, Grief and Anger
description: Jimmie Boyd Sr. barely earns enough as an auto mechanic to feed and clothe his family, but when his 14-year-old son, Jimmie Jr., pleaded for $18 to go to a heavy-metal concert here last weekend, he acquiesced.

title: A Lone Practitioner in the Tradition of Lawyer as Counselor, Confidant and Friend.
description: A specter is haunting an Eastern European community -- that is, the community of scholars, artists and intellectuals who came to the United States from Poland after two world wars. One day, Ludwik Seidenman is going to retire, and they will have to find another lawyer.

title: More on the Gulf
description: NOW A CRITIC Gen. William C. Westmoreland, criticized in the Vietnam War, is the critic now. And George McGovern says he may run for President. Page A14.

title: Angels Sign Gaetti to 4-Year, $11.4 Million Deal
description: Gary Gaetti, who anchored the Minnesota Twins' infield as a third baseman for nine years, decided to try to turn his recent spate of poor seasons around in a new environment by signing a four-year, $11.4 million contract with the California Angels last night.

title: Article 287391 -- No Title
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced today that he expected New York State's budget gap to balloon to $6 billion, or one-fifth of the state budget, in the next fiscal year and that the state would have to borrow $900 million to close this year's budget deficit.

title: U.S. Revises New York Census: City Is Growing, Not Shrinking
description: The United States Census Bureau revised its 1990 count of New York City's population yesterday, adding 289,385 people to its August count and providing the city with a net gain since 1980.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Be-Bop With Tap

title: The Dinkins Quandary; Amid Maze of Problems, Mayor Is Perplexed By Trouble in Making Administration's Case
description: Amid his sea of troubles, Mayor David N. Dinkins has one that suffuses the rest: an inability to make his administration's case. That has undercut his credibility and allowed his critics to cast the most unfavorable light on a range of problems that were bound to hurt him anyway.

title: CNN Warns on Censorship
description: The Cable News Network has added an additional caveat to its televised news reports from Baghdad, informing viewers that its reporter Peter Arnett, the only Western correspondent for a major television network still working in the Iraqi capital, is unable to select or verify the news he is allowed to broadcast.

title: Salomon Picks Chief for Asia
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. announced yesterday that it had appointed William S. Thompson Jr. chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Gerald M. Miller has been named executive creative director at Leo Burnett, in its International Europe/ Middle East region, based in London.* Kevin McKeon has been promoted to senior vice president and associate creative director at Ammirati & Puris, New York.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PHILLIP A. GRIFFITHS was named director of the Institute for Advanced Study, the Princeton, N.J., a forum for scholars. Dr. Griffith, the provost of Duke University, where he is the James B. Duke Professor of Mathematics, will replace MARVIN L. GOLDBERGER, a physicist and the director since 1987, who is stepping down. Dr. Griffiths, 52, will take over July 1.

title: Legal Aid Lawyers Plan to Strike Courts
description: The union of 1,000 Legal Aid Society lawyers will try to disrupt New York City's courts with a one-day strike today or next week to draw attention to a contract dispute, its officers said yesterday.

title: War Against Iraq Promises Nasty Surprises
description: To the Editor:

title: GATHERING OPENS WITH G.O.P IN FLUX
description: The Republican National Committee began meeting here today with its next chairman, Clayton K. Yeutter, embroiled in the politics of the Persian Gulf while another top Republican campaign official, Edward J. Rollins, said that he planned to resign.

title: Eugene P. Gross, 64, Theoretical Physicist
description: Dr. Eugene P. Gross, a theoretical physicist who had been a professor at Brandeis University since 1956, died on Tuesday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived in Waltham, Mass.

title: THE OVERVIEW; ALLIES, AIDED BY WEATHER, INTENSIFY BOMBING OF IRAQ; HUSSEIN RESTATES DEFIANCE
description: As allied bombers, taking advantage of improving weather, stepped up the pace of their attacks deep inside Iraq, the largest marine amphibious force assembled since the Korean War practiced landings in the Persian Gulf today and a 30-year-old Saudi pilot shot down a pair of enemy Mirage fighters.

title: Review/Photography; Without Sentimentality, The Work of 6 Germans
description: The influence of Bernd and Hilla Becher on contemporary German photography is not exactly a secret. The dryly observant, seemingly neutral style of their detailed pictures of industrial structures has been adopted by Andreas Gursky, Thomas Ruff, Thomas Struth and other artist photographers who studied with Mr. Becher at the Art Academy of Dusseldorf. These younger artists' pictures have frequently been shown in Manhattan in the last two years, creating the impression that German photography is particularly vigorous these days and that the Bechers are largely responsible for it.

title: It's Very Clear That Jazz Is Here to Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies
description: Though nearly three weeks lie between now and Valentine's Day, Alan J. Pakula is already deeply immersed in the mysteries of love.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 531 money market mutual funds increased by $3.19 billion, to $449.62 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 161 institutional funds increased by $2.01 billion, to $122.55 billion. The 267 general-purpose funds were down by $169.1 million, to $155.46 billion. The 103 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.35 billion, to $171.61 billion, the institute said.

title: For the 2d Time in a Decade, Iraqi Port Faces Devastation
description: For more than a millennium travelers knew Basra as a shabbily cosmopolitan river town laced with canals and studded with millions of date palms -- the Venice of the East, residents boasted, and site of the original Garden of Eden.

title: Gulf Fighting Shatters Europeans' Fragile Unity
description: The war in the Persian Gulf has abruptly halted momentum toward political unity in Europe, breathed new life into the "special relationship" between the United States and Britain and raised widespread concern about pacifism in Germany, diplomats, Government officials and strategic experts here say.

title: Anderson Leaves Driving To Others
description: Long before Ottis Anderson finally experienced Super Bowl week as a runner in the National Football League, he was able to see things up close as a runner for the National Football League.

title: Chrysler Transmissions Draw Criticism
description: Consumers Union issued a warning today against buying certain Chrysler cars and mini-vans equipped with electronic transmissions, citing poor reliability and possible safety hazards.

title: Heileman in Chapter 11, but Upbeat
description: One of America's most venerable brewers, the G. Heileman Brewing Company, today became the latest victim of the widespread use of debt in the 1980's.

title: A Dark Trumpet
description: After one week of the war with Iraq, I am persuaded of three propositions.

title: Review/Film; Old Man And Nature
description: "A Tale of the Wind" was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 25, 1989. The film -- in French with English subtitles -- opens today at the Public, 425 Lafayette Street in Manhattan.

title: Export Funding In Secured Offer
description: The Private Export Funding Corporation, which makes loans to foreign companies to finance the purchase of United States goods and services, is offering $100 million in secured notes due Jan. 31, 2001, through the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, which managed the transaction.

title: Westmoreland: 'I'm Very Upbeat'
description: When the United States went to war in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon never bothered to consult one of its more famous old soldiers, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the commander of American forces in Vietnam from 1964 to 1968. But that does not mean he has nothing to say about the new war.

title: Communism's Last True Believer
description: How are we to reconcile the contradictory images of Mikhail Gorbachev? Should we think of him as the great liberator of Eastern Europe and recent winner of the Nobel Peace Prize or as the demagogue who has sent tanks into Latvia and Lithuania and demanded the restoration of press censorship? Were perestroika and glasnost one more mirage in a long tradition of Russian deceptions dating all the way back to Potemkin's villages?

title: Kenneth J. O'Keefe, Restaurateur, 53
description: Kenneth J. O'Keefe, a former restaurateur and promoter of men's fashions, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Key Biscayne, Fla. He was 53 years old.

title: When Bohemia Was in Bloom
description: THE Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, is a long way off from Greenwich Village. On a cold winter day in 1991, when anyone with any sense is politically depressed anyway, the museum's exhibition "Within Bohemia's Borders: Greenwich Village, 1830 to 1930" might also seem far from that springtime of liberal American hope, of modern American literature and art, that in the years before "Mr. Wilson's War" (as John Dos Passos bitterly called it) found a home and an everlasting name: Greenwich Village.

title: Dale L. Fishbein, Student, Is Wed to Jeffrey Bennett
description: Dale Lori Fishbein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Fishbein of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married in Newton, Mass., yesterday to Jeffrey Bennett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Bennett of Cumberland Foreside, Me. Rabbi Robert M. Miller performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Avodah.

title: A Real Nightmare Scenario
description: A number of commentators have sought parallels between the Persian Gulf crisis and Europe in the summer of 1914. But until last week, the parallels were few. While war with Iraq was always risky for the U.S., it never held the potential of creating a worldwide disaster. Now, with the violent Soviet interventions in Lithuania and Latvia, a parallel to 1914 has emerged, and with it a danger of general war.

title: Panel Allows Bias Suits Over Ads in Newspapers
description: In a case pitting the First Amendment against Federal civil rights laws, a Federal appeals court has ruled that newspapers may be sued under the Fair Housing Act for racial discrimination in advertisements.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Baxter International Inc., Deerfield, Ill., a health-care products company, said its I.V. Systems division had signed a five-year agreement to supply products to American Healthcare Systems Inc., San Diego. * Fortune Petroleum Corp., Agoura Hills, Calif., has completed the acquisition of assets from Fairbanks & Haas Inc. and its partners. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, the aerospace and military contractor, handed over the first of its new MD-11 jets to Korean Air Lines. The carrier had ordered up to eight aircraft. * Search Exploration Inc. said it would sell certain oil and gas assets to Marshall Exploration Inc. for $11 million. * Triquint Semiconductor, Beaverton, Ore., a unit of Tektronix Inc. that makes linear and microwave products, said it would merge with Gitabit Logic Inc. No terms were disclosed. * Thomson-CSF S.A., the French electronics and military contractor, and Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, a computer systems company, will combine resources on computer hardware and software contracts from the Army.

title: A Slight Gap in Louisiana's Anti-Drug Law: No Penalties
description: Hundreds of Louisiana drug cases are in limbo because of an omission in a newly expanded state law: the Legislature did not include penalties for violating the measure.

title: Blasts Rock Sites in Athens Linked to Allies in Gulf War
description: Three explosions rocked branches of American and British banks and the home of the French military attache early today, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S.-Soviet Conference May Be Postponed American officials said it was increasingly likely that the Soviet- American summit meeting planned Feb. 11 to 13 would be postponed. President Bush came under pressure from Congress to act because of violence in the Baltics. Page A3. Big Gain in the Drug War A survey found that high school seniors' acknowledged use of cocaine dipped in 1990, and experts said it might mean an end to the drug crisis among middle-class youth. Page A18.

title: Some Big Names Gather With Their Big Rings
description: There are times when people stare at his left hand, Willie Wood said with a smile today.

title: Marinovich Case Filed
description: A misdemeanor charge of possession of cocaine was filed against Southern California quarterback Todd Marinovich, the Orange County Deputy District Attorney, Mike Koski, said yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; A Necklace Of 3 Jewels In Motion
description: The New York City Ballet has been dancing on such a consistently high level that one wonders at each performance how the company can, so to speak, top itself.

title: For Children
description: The Paper Bag Players Symphony Space 2537 Broadway (at 95th Street) (212) 864-5400 or (212) 362-0431 Recommended ages: 4 to 9 Through March 10

title: Borrow a Few Billion, Not Trouble
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned Congress this week not to raise taxes to pay for the war against Iraq. It's very good advice.

title: Drop in Youths' Cocaine Use May Reflect a Societal Shift
description: Acknowledged use of cocaine and crack among high school seniors dropped dramatically last year, according to a national survey released yesterday in Washington. The results prompted independent drug experts to declare that the drug crisis among mainstream American youths appeared to have run its course.

title: Seat Is Filled At F.A.S.B.
description: Joseph V. Anania, a partner in the Pittsburgh office of Price Waterhouse, will occupy the seventh seat on the Financial Accounting Standards Board no later than May, the board announced yesterday.

title: 'Newport Suite'
description: Stephen Rogers Radcliffe is to conduct the New York Chamber Ensemble in the Brahms Serenade in D (Op. 11) and the New York premiere of John Bayless's "Newport Suite" for piano and chamber ensemble, at Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, tonight at 8. Mr. Bayless is to be the soloist in his own work. The Brahms Serenade is being presented in a reconstruction of Brahms's original 1858 nonet version. Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 307-7171.

title: Iraqis Using Clouds to Cover Scud Firings, Meteorologists Say
description: Iraq tends to fire missiles at Israel and Saudi Arabia under cloud cover, especially low-lying clouds, meteorologists said yesterday. The clouds presumably allow the missile launchers to hide better from retaliatory raids.

title: CONSTABLE'S DEATH SEEN ON VIDEOTAPE
description: With the help of a videotape shot by a camera mounted in the victim's patrol car, two men have been arrested and charged with the murder of a county constable.

title: View From Inside a Landmark Libel Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Bethlehem Steel Seeks A Venture
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it was discussing a joint venture with British Steel P.L.C. to produce rail and structural steel.

title: War Against Iraq Promises Nasty Surprises; The Cost in Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: 'All the Way' in the Gulf?
description: Inevitably, once adversaries are driven to war, pain and passion tempt them to expand their war aims. It's just so in the Persian Gulf. President Bush initially set out to expel Saddam Hussein from Kuwait and restore stability to the region. As late as Wednesday afternoon, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs, said, "Our military objective is the Iraqi army in Kuwait."

title: Kuwaiti Students to Help U.S. Uncover Iraqi Spies
description: About 300 young Kuwaitis have been trained to help American-led ground forces identify Iraqis in Kuwait in the event of a land war in the Persian Gulf.

title: British Pilots' Risky Mission: Low-Level Raids on Airfields
description: They fly the most dangerous mission of the air war against Iraq, these daring young British pilots, most in their 20's, who must skim over Iraqi territory just a few dozen feet above the desert sands and try to bomb well-defended airfields.

title: Alan L. Hale, Publicity Agent, 41
description: Alan L. Hale, a publicity agent for performing arts organizations and artists, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Palisades, N.Y.

title: Our Towns; Sad Pioneers On the Frontier Of Medical Ethics
description: They sit in their living room and look out the big windows back over the wintry valley and the long years and what it was like to be inadvertent pioneers for an inattentive nation.

title: Exxon Has Threefold Profit Rise
description: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest oil company, yesterday reported a threefold increase in fourth-quarter earnings.

title: Review/Art; Celebrating Japan in Its Infancy and as It Grew Up
description: A splendid exhibition at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art celebrates the origins of Japanese civilization, while also demonstrating that these roots are more ancient than many people realize. It sets before the visitor 84 vessels and figurines borrowed from 45 Japanese institutions, many of which are being shown in this country for the first time. They encapsulate a dazzling range of esthetic thought, technical development and sheer visual spiritedness as well as a good deal of new historical information.

title: Agreement Appears Near on School Layoffs
description: Negotiators appeared close to an agreement yesterday on a plan to avert the need for immediate layoffs of thousands of New York City school employees, even as administrators began distributing 3,000 layoff notices.

title: Unbeaten Ohio State Upends Minnesota
description: Jamaal Brown scored 7 of his 17 points in a 21-8 first-half run tonight as Ohio State defeated Minnesota, 80-70, in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: Key Rates
With Scant Hope, North Africans Call For a Truce at U.N.
description: The United Nations Security Council met tonight to consider a call by five North African Muslim nations for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. But a clear majority of the Council's 15 members opposed a cease-fire and none was expected to be approved.

title: Zeroing In on Geiberger's Record
description: Nearly everyone in the game agrees that equipment, golf swings and turf conditions are better than ever, and that the "all-exempt" structure of the PGA Tour makes it easier for players to shoot fearlessly at the flags. Yet the fact remains that Al Geiberger's 59 in the second round of the 1977 Danny Thomas Memphis Classic has never been equaled on the tour.

title: Savings Units' Earnings Hurs
description: Real estate problems hurt fourth-quarter earnings at two of the largest savings and loan companies.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A8-12

title: Nuggets Stop Knicks' Streak at Three Games
description: There were numerous players to blame tonight for the Knicks' 120-117 loss to the Denver Nuggets.

title: Restaurants
description: Pierre's

title: New York's Urban Problems Inspire Gifts to the Neediest
description: For some contribututors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, concern about New York City's sick and poor was only a secondary reason for giving. They were moved by their devotion to New York -- and the pain they feel at its current plight.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Miscellany
description: * Ketchum Public Relations, New York, has acquired an interest in London-based Group Public Relations P.L.C., a $3.5 million consulting firm. Terms were not available.* BDDP Worldwide has offered to buy outstanding stock of the British public relations firm Broad Street. BDDP currently holds a 38 percent share, which it acquired last year.

title: The News Faces a Deadline, but the 2 Sides Aren't Even Negotiating
description: The Daily News and leaders of its nine striking unions are locked in a new dispute that has stopped all negotiations, even though the clock is ticking on a management threat to close the paper unless the strike is settled or the paper is sold.

title: Auctions
description: Americana in the form of old furniture, pistols and silver is the focus of large sales this weekend and next, coinciding with the Winter Antiques Show.

title: Mubarak Cites Accords To Help Rescue Kuwait
description: Facing growing hesitation here about the extent of Cairo's military and political involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis, President Hosni Mubarak said today that Egypt was obligated by its commitments to the United Nations and the Arab League to go to the rescue of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.

title: Judge Spurns Plea Bargain in Missouri Killings
description: A county judge today refused to accept a plea agreement in which an elderly farmer was to have admitted killing five transient farm workers from 1986 to 1989.

title:
SUPER BOWL XXV;
First Downs Will Be Key
description: Buffalo will have to create a scoring game and the Giants will aim for a possession game, a clock game.

title: Sali Vongkhamsao, Laotian Politician, 66
description: Sali Vongkhamsao, a Deputy Prime Minister of Laos and a senior member of its governing Communist Party, died on Wednesday, the state radio has reported. He was 66 years old.

title: Dr. Winston Bostick, Atomic Physicist, 74
description: Dr. Winston H. Bostick, an atomic physicist who was a former head of the physics department at the Stevens Institute of Technology, died on Saturday in Tijuana, Mexico. He was 74 years old and lived in Dennis, Mass.

title: Plan for Property-Tax Relief To Cut Urban School Money
description: Many of New Jersey's urban school districts would lose tens of millions of dollars in anticipated school aid increases, while suburbs would gain money, under a property-tax relief bill that emerged today from two committees in the State Senate.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Campaign by Bozell Wins Esquire Contest
description: Bozell Advertising in New York has won Esquire magazine's competition for a public education campaign on behalf of the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of America, San Francisco, appointed Alan Koch senior vice president. * Bear, Stearns & Co., the New York securities firm, named Mark A. Kurland director of its equity research department and a senior managing director. * Crosspoint Solutions Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a semiconductor company, named Gene Hill executive vice president and chief operating officer. * Norwest Corp., Minneapolis, a bank holding company, appointed Peter E. Hosokawa vice president and manager of cash management for United Bank of Denver. * TRW Inc., Cleveland, an automotive and aerospace equipment maker, named Peter S. Hellman executive vice president and chief financial officer. * Tektronix Inc., Beaverton, Ore., which manufactures electronic laboratory equipment, appointed John W. Vold vice president of business developement. * Teleport Communications Group, Houston, named John R. Reese vice president and general manager. * Wasserstein, Perella & Co., New York, an investment banking firm, named Jon B. Kutler managing director.

title: Review/Theater; A Precarious Balance As Husband and Countess
description: "When Lightning Strikes Twice" inspires Everett Quinton into a double feat of acting acrobatics. In these two short plays by H. M. Koutoukas, he leaps with boundless abandon from hapless husband to unaccountable countess. The two Koutoukas plays are performed in repertory with Mr. Quinton's impersonation of "Camille" at the Charles Ludlam Theater.

title: 4 Soviet Republics Defy Gorbachev on Currency
description: Four Soviet republics, including Russia, challenged President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today by giving their residents more time to exchange high-denomination ruble notes before they become worthless.

title: Woman Overcomes Bureaucratic Odds to Regain Her Children
description: Michelle Rogers got her children back yesterday.

title: Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Jumps 24.01
description: With no unsettling news from the Middle East by closing time, stock prices advanced broadly yesterday in the heaviest trading in a week.

title: Fred Schmidt, Physicist, 75
description: Fred Schmidt, a physicist on the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb, and an expert on energy policy and nuclear power, died of cancer on Jan. 17 in Seattle. He was 75 years old.

title: New Jersey's High Court Upholds Death Sentence After Blocking 26
description: After blocking the executions of 26 other convicted murderers, the New Jersey Supreme Court upheld a death sentence today for the first time since capital punishment was reinstated in the state eight years ago.

title: War Against Iraq Promises Nasty Surprises; Replacing Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Release of Trafficker Shakes Hope in Colombian Drug Plan
description: A Colombian judge's recent release of a confessed drug trafficker wanted in the United States has deepened fears that the Government's anti-drug program will not succeed in keeping drug bosses out of circulation.

title: Blacks Wary of Their Big Role as Troops
description: Wesley Hatch, a black teen-ager from Chicago's impoverished West Side, graduated from high school with few choices two years ago. He dreamed of going to college to study architecture, but his mother did not have the money. That left dead-end jobs, the streets and the military. He chose the military.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GREGORY PECK, MICHAEL DOUGLAS and CHARLTON HESTON showed up, with a lot of other movie types, for the opening of the Center for Motion Picture Study in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Wednesday night. Run by the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, the group that gives out the Oscars, the center comprises a library and archives of movies and stills.

title: Zenith Board Rebuffs Challenge From Nycor
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said yesterday that its directors had unanimously opposed a proxy challenge by Nycor Inc. and expressed support for Zenith's embattled chief executive, Jerry K. Pearlman.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Utah House Passes Amended Abortion Bill
description: The Utah House of Representatives today approved an amended version of an anti-abortion bill that raced through both chambers this week, stripping it of its most restrictive elements.

title: Arafat Calls on Pope To Try to Halt Conflict
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organizaiton, asked Pope John Paul II today to intervene to stop the Persian Gulf war, the Palestinian press agency, WAFA, announced.

title: Covering the War Cost
description: Since the shooting began, the gulf war has cost the United States several hundred million dollars a day. The length of the war will determine the ultimate cost, but it is bound to be substantial. Since few in Washington are willing to cut domestic spending to pay for the war, a debate has begun: raise taxes or borrow?

title: War Against Iraq Promises Nasty Surprises; Congress Slinks Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Resignation At Midlantic
description: The Midlantic Corporation said today that Robert Van Buren would resign as the company's chief executive and chairman.

title: Ex-Mayor Rizzo to Run Again
description: Out of office for a decade, former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo announced Wednesday night that he would be a candidate in the Republican mayoral primary in May. Mr. Rizzo, 70 years old, held the office as a Democrat from 1972 to 1980. He left in 1980 only after losing a fight to change a City Charter provision that prohibits a mayor from serving three consecutive terms.

title: 3 Clowns With a Message On Ritual, Art and Comedy
description: One of the most joyous moments in "Tubes," the delightfully circusy performance piece at La Mama, comes when its three creators, known as the Blue Man Group, enact a percussion-and-paint ritual that tickles one's primal fantasies of making noise and splatter.

title: Iraqi Ambassador to Quit Britain
description: Iraq will soon withdraw its Ambassador to Britain but is seeking to send a replacement, Prime Minister John Major said today.

title: Hostetler's Tactics May Confuse Bills
description: The Giants are what I call a traditional National Football League team: strong defense, sound running game, solid special teams, few mistakes. Like most successful teams, the Giants are led by their defense.

title: CBS News Says Crew Vanished Near Front Lines
description: A four-man CBS News crew led by the veteran correspondent Bob Simon has been missing in a front-line region of the Persian Gulf war since early Monday, the network said yesterday after the crew's vehicle was found in the Saudi desert near the Kuwaiti border.

title: 2 Campeau Units Seeking Extension
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, two units of the Campeau Corporation that have been in voluntary bankruptcy for more than a year, said they expected to request an extension of a Feb. 28 deadline for submitting a reorganization plan to a Federal bankruptcy court judge in Cincinnati and then to creditors.

title: Made Homeless by Missiles, 1,000 Israelis Fight for Aid
description: Each time the smoke cleared after Iraqi missiles exploded in Haifa and Tel Aviv, Israelis rejoiced that most of the damage was limited to buildings and property. Now, with the distance of a few days, it has become clear that the rockets have brought long-term misery to well over 1,000 people.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing in some editions of Business Day on Wednesday misstated the action taken by a joint venture of the Hudson General Corporation and the Oxford First Corporation. The venture terminated a previously announced agreement to sell land at the Kohala Ranch in Hawaii.

title: Jordan Only All-Star To Top 1 Million Votes
description: The fans who vote for the starting teams in the National Basketball Association All-Star Game have decided to shake up the Western Conference lineup and stand pat with the Eastern one, which features Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, the only player to receive more than a million votes.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 8 about a Christmas celebration in Moscow misstated the religion of the clergymen shown. Although the service was Russian Orthodox, the celebrants pictured were Lutheran.

title: Norman Cousins Memorial
description: A memorial service for Norman Cousins, editor in chief of The Saturday Review for more than 30 years, will be held at on Tuesday at 4 P.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street at Central Park West. Mr. Cousins, who was also an author and lecturer, died of cardiac arrest in Los Angeles on Nov. 30 at the age of 75.

title: Abused Wife Found Guilty Of Murder
description: Sarah Smith, a 43-year-old Bronx social worker who said she shot her abusive husband to death to save her own life, was convicted of his murder yesterday.

title: War Against Iraq Promises Nasty Surprises; Anti-Israel Feeling
description: To the Editor:

title: Pupil Abducted And Sodomized; Choir Aide Held
description: A 14-year-old girl in the sixth grade was kidnapped from her school in Brooklyn by a teacher's aide and sexually abused and sodomized in his apartment, the police said yesterday.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Westin Hotels and Resorts, Seattle, to Cole & Weber, Seattle, with a budget of $4 million. The previous agency was HDM, Los Angeles.

title: Devils Gain a Victory For First Time in '91
description: While the Devils were going one month, covering 11 straight games, without a victory, it appeared to some of their regular watchers that the Devils did not have to worry about Quebec's finishing last in the league behind Toronto and depriving New Jersey of the first draft pick. It looked as if the Devils might finish there themselves.

title: Mary Goldburt Siegel, 94, Lawyer Who Fought Obstacles to Women
description: Mary Goldburt Siegel, a lawyer who in the 1920's helped break down barriers against women in the legal profession, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94 years old.

title: Harcourt Accepts Bid From General Cinema
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the publishing and insurance company that has been struggling under a heavy debt load, yesterday accepted a $1.4 billion takeover bid from General Cinema, the movie theater company that controls the Neiman Marcus retail chain.

title: Chrysler Senior Debt Rated Below Investment Grade
description: The rating of $12.5 billion in debt of the Chrysler Corporation and the Chrysler Financial Corporation was lowered by Fitch Investors Service Inc. yesterday.

title: Transamerica Gives President a New Title
description: The Transamerica Corporation said yesterday that its president, Frank C. Herringer, would assume the additional post of chief executive.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL USA BASKETBALL -- Announced Atlanta; Lincoln, Neb.; Long Beach, Calif., and Pittsburgh as sites for the U.S. Olympic Festival women's teams trials.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Low-Key Charm

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Decrease by 5% on Nasdaq
description: The association also said that 30.4 million shares were in a short position as of mid-January in 1,122 less-active over-the-counter securities that are traded in its automated quotation system, but not in the national market system. That report represented a decrease of 16.3 percent from the 36.3 million shares held short in the December period, when 1,181 securities were involved. Investors Who Expect Declines

title: So Far From Mideast: Mongolia's Oil Intrigues Bush
description: It has a vast desert and a large oil potential, President Bush was told, and this piqued his interest in Mongolia, a country about three times the size of Texas and thousands of miles from the Middle East.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
History Written Off at California S.& L.'s
description: JUDGING from the advertising, one might not know that the savings and loan crisis had ever hit California.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
3 New Posts At Ross Roy
description: In its effort to become the leader in integrated marketing, Ross Roy Group, Detroit, has created three position.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article on Wednesday about an Iraqi missile attack on Israel referred incorrectly in some editions to the missile's range. It is roughly 400 miles, not kilometers.

title: Soviet Influx Is Unabated
description: The fear here over the Scud-missile attacks by Iraq appears to have had little effect on the flow of Soviet immigrants, who are still arriving at the rate of several hundred a day.

title: Another Report On Hussein Kin
description: A London newspaper quoted diplomatic figures today as saying that President Saddam Hussein's family has flown to Zambia and is staying in a house owned by President Kenneth Kaunda, who has received large amounts of aid from Iraq.

title: Miami Beach to Report Drug Arrests to Employers
description: This city's governing body has passed an ordinance directing the police to report drug arrests to defendants' employers immediately, before the courts have decided whether the defendants are guilty.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Norfolk Southern Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $750 million in debt securities. * Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, plans to redeem three issues of fixed-rate notes totaling $500 million. The issues include 9.47 percent notes due Feb. 15, 1993; 9.45 percent notes due Feb. 21, 1993; and 9.71 percent notes due Feb. 23, 1993. All will be redeemed at 100 percent of the principal amount. Common Stock * Ionics Inc., Watertown, Mass., is offering 1.3 million common shares at $31 a share through Paine Webber Inc. Ratings * Michigan's general-obligation bond rating of AA is under review for possible downgrading by S.&P. * Southeast Banking Corp.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to BB-, BB (plus), by S.&P. The bank-holding company is based in Miami.

title: Economic Scene; Figuring a War Into the Budget
description: THE problem of managing the American economy now is complicated by the war in the Persian Gulf, coming on top of a recession that is cutting tax revenues, increasing unemployment and swelling the Federal debt and the budget deficit.

title: British Court Decision Could Hurt U.S. Banks
description: In a decision that exposes United States commercial and investment banks to tens of millions and possibly hundreds of millions of dollars in potential losses, the House of Lords today upheld a lower-court ruling that local governments in Britain had no authority to enter into complex financial transactions known as interest-rate swaps.

title: Metropolitan Life Settles Its Bond Dispute With RJR
description: Metropolitan Life and the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation announced a settlement yesterday that in effect restores much of the value of RJR bonds that was lost when RJR was taken private in 1989.

title: Iraq Closes Border With Jordan, Cutting Off Escape for Foreigners
description: Iraq was reported today to have barred war refugees from entering Jordan, blocking the major escape route for hundreds of thousands of foreigners trapped behind the lines and prey to deprivation and allied bombardment.

title: New Executive At McCall's
description: Barbara J. Litrell has been appointed vice president and associate publisher of McCall's magazine, William T. Kerr, president of The New York Times Company Magazine Group, announced yesterday. She will report to Michael Golden, the publisher of McCall's.

title: Treasury Issues Continue Upward
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose again yesterday and yields fell, as traders responded to a second day of seemingly positive developments in the Persian Gulf war by buying notes and bonds.

title: Mr. Skinner Aids the Traveler
description: Eastern Airlines stopped flying last week. Pan Am and Continental are bankrupt, though still operating for now. Gone too are a number of former regional carriers -- like Ozark, PSA, Air California and Republic. Deregulation of the airline industry has spurred numerous mergers and failures, leaving only a half dozen major U.S. carriers.

title: Review/Art; Spirituality, Magic and Identity of 3 Harlem Museum Artists
description: "From the Studio: Artists in Residence, 1989-90" is a good example of why the Studio Museum in Harlem is so consistently a pleasure to visit. The emerging artists in this handsome show -- Raul Acero, Paul Gardere and Jerome B. Meadows -- are exceptionally gifted. Their work is independent. It is also refined (even when, in Mr. Gardere's case, it is raw), intense, essentially figurative, hand-crafted and wide ranging in its artistic and cultural references.

title: Review/Film; When You're Gay But Must Beget an Heir
description: The place and the time are immediately identified: Los Angeles, 7 A.M. The camera pans down from a sky of pristine blue to discover a city in the grip of terminal smog.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; CNN Reports Allied Bombs Killed 24 Civilians in Iraqi Neighborhood
description: Peter Arnett, the last correspondent for an American news organization in Iraq, reported today that allied jets had bombed what appeared to be a residential neighborhood 100 miles north of Baghdad, killing 24 civilians. The Pentagon later said the area was home to several military installations.

title: Administration Foresees a Deficit In Bank Insurance Fund by 1992
description: Raising the specter of another huge taxpayer bailout, the White House has estimated that the program that insures bank deposits will show a deficit sometime next year, Government officials said today. And after that, they said, the hole will only grow deeper.

title: Strict Anti-Abortion Law Signed in Utah
description: The Governor of Utah signed into law yesterday the toughest anti-abortion measure in the 50 states, after it sped through both houses of the Legislature in three days.

title: U.S. Is Called Set to Urge Summit Delay
description: Administration officials said today that the United States intended to inform the Soviet Union on Saturday that because of the crackdown in the Baltics, Washington wants to "postpone" the next summit meeting indefinitly.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraqi Attacks 7 Iraqi Missiles Are Fired at Cities in Israel and 2 at Saudi Arabia's Capital; Patriots Stop Scuds but Israeli Man Is Killed by Debris
description: American Patriot missiles intercepted seven Iraqi Scuds that were fired at Haifa and Tel Aviv this evening. But at least one person was killed and 42 were wounded when the midair explosions spewed heavy, burning shrapnel onto residential areas below.

title: Consumers and Industry to Pay Clean Air Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: 50th for Hull in 49th Game
description: Brett Hull of the St. Louis Blues tonight became just the third player in National Hockey League history to score 50 goals in fewer than 50 games.

title: U.S. Contractor In Guilty Plea
description: A Defense Department subcontractor pleaded guilty to charges related to lying to the manufacturer of the F-16 fighter about the capabilities of a radar jamming system, prosecutors said on Thursday.

title: Soviets, Citing Rise in Crime, Send Troops to Patrol Cities with Police.
description: The Kremlin announced tonight that Soviet Army troops would patrol jointly with the police in major cities starting Feb. 1 to combat an escalation of "crimes of an audacious and cynical nature."

title: Sundance Festival Honors Gay Film
description: With less pain and more unanimity than is usual at the Sundance Film Festival, the dramatic film jury here awarded its grand prize to "Poison," a first feature by Todd Haynes, a gay film maker. "Poison," which Mr. Haynes said was inspired by the novels of Jean Genet, interweaves three stories in three different styles and time periods. In one of the stories, AIDS is handled metaphorically as the plague of a leper killer in a 1950's horror movie.

title: Shell Oil Earnings Increased By 68.9% in Fourth Quarter
description: The Shell Oil Company yesterday joined the ranks of large oil companies reporting strong profits because of oil prices pushed higher by the Persian Gulf crisis. Shell's fourth-quarter earnings soared 68.9 percent from the 1989 period.

title: Yugoslavia Tense Over TV Film on Croatian Arms
description: Tensions rose tonight after Yugoslav television stations aired film footage purporting to show Croatian Government officials as they allegedly purchased weapons abroad, planned attacks on national army officers and talked of waging a merciless civil war.

title: Keeping Your Dog Warm
description: Dogs, like humans, run the risk of frostbite in bitterly cold weather, so when the temperature drops, precautions are the order of the day.

title: McDaniel Fined $1,500
description: Xavier McDaniel of the Phoenix Suns was fined $1,500 by the N.B.A. yesterday for instigating a fight with Portland's Jerome Kersey on Tuesday night by throwing a forearm at the Trail Blazer player. Referee Dick Bavetta ejected both players.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Before the second preview of "Henry IV, Part I" at the New York Shakespeare Festival, LOUIS ZORICH , who plays Falstaff, was stricken with an infected vocal cord. So at the matinees today and tomorrow audiences will see LARRY BRYGGMAN in the role.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Diner's Journal column of Weekend on Jan. 11 misstated the location of Tang, Tang in Manhattan. The restaurant is on Third Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Jane Murchison Haber, Volunteer, 65
description: Jane Murchison Haber, a leader in volunteer activities in Dallas and later in Manhattan, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 65 years old.

title: Opera in Philadelphia Names New Director
description: The Opera Company of Philadelphia has named Robert B. Driver its general director. Mr. Driver, who is 48 years old, has been the general and artistic director of the Syracuse Opera and the artistic director of the Indianapolis Opera and Opera Memphis. Earlier in his career, he was assistant stage director of the Bayerische Staatsoper of Munich, Germany, assistant director of the Kentucky Opera and associate director of the Kansas City Lyric Opera.

title: K. Brent Woodruff, 86; Priest and School Head
description: The Rev. K. Brent Woodruff, an Episcopal priest and a former college official, died Wednesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in San Jose, Calif. He was 86 years old and lived in San Jose.

title: Review/Fashion; Bohan: A Gallic Revolution in London
description: Marc Bohan gave the stolid British couture a lively injection of Gallic style with his first collection for Norman Hartnell , dressmaker to the Queen and her mother. Mr. Bohan, 63 years old, was for almost 30 years the designer for Christian Dior in Paris. His new clothes were graceful, colorful and stunningly simple.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about Jews' reaction to the war in the Persian Gulf referred imprecisely to the timing of a statement issued by the World Council of Churches that condemned the air raids on Iraq and Kuwait without mentioning the ones on Israel. Although the statement was issued and dated Jan. 18 in New York, it was written and issued in Geneva on Jan. 17, before the first attack on Israel occurred.

title: Patriots Quizzed
description: Dick MacPherson, who has yet to sink his teeth into his new job as head coach of the New England Patriots, is already feeling pro-style pressure.

title: Why Library Funds Shouldn't Be Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Cordero Injured in Spill
description: The jockey Angel Cordero Jr. hurt his right shoulder in a spill yesterday during the fourth race at Aqueduct. Frank Sanabria, Cordero's agent, said the jockey had suffered a shoulder separation and would be out for about a week. The 48-year-old rider was injured when his mount, Modest Glow, fell over Originate, who broke down in midstretch. Originate's rider, J. C. Ferrer, escaped injury. (AP)

title: Ouster of Realty Leader Jolts Corporate Japan
description: The harmonious facade of corporate Japan cracked today in an extraordinary board room attack, as the directors of Itoman & Company, an ailing trading and real estate concern, rose up and voted to oust the company's president, Yoshihiko Kawamura.

title: Ratings Cut On Citicorp By Moody's
description: Ratings on Citicorp and its primary banking unit, Citibank, were reduced by Moody's Investors Service yesterday.

title: Treasuries Unsettled by G.N.P. Data
description: The Treasury securities market was unsettled yesterday by a smaller-than-expected decline in the nation's gross national product and the erratic behavior of the interbank lending rates in recent days, which suggested that banks have become reluctant to lend reserves to other banks, or even to dealers.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Environment; Oil Threatens Fishing and Water Supply
description: Millions of gallons of crude oil spilling from a Kuwaiti offshore terminal could wreak major, lasting environmental damage in the Persian Gulf and could cripple fishing and desalting plants that supply much of the region's fresh water, environmental experts said yesterday.

title: Islanders Routed by Jets, 8-1
description: Winnipeg's Bob Essensa set a team record for consecutive scoreless minutes in goal as the Jets routed the Islanders, 8-1, tonight.

title: Religion Notes
description: High-Tech Scriptures

title: One City's Merchants Sense an Eerie Quiet
description: To Hugh Cline, owner of a two-store appliance business in the suburbs of Richmond, big news is usually good news. Whatever happens, he figures on doing a brisk business in television sets.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Twins Sign Pagliarulo
description: Mike Pagliarulo, slipping neatly into the void created in the Minnesota infield by Gary Gaetti's departure, signed a one-year contract with the Twins as a free agent yesterday. The former Yankee third baseman came to terms on a $605,000 deal a day after Gaetti, a new-look free agent, signed a four-year, $11.4 million contract with the Angels.

title: U.S. Indicts 3 After Searches Find Explosives And Racist Literature
description: Three men who Federal investigators said were trying to start a white supremacist group were indicted Thursday on charges that they stole weapons and explosives from the military and had transported and stockpiled more than 90 pounds of explosives.

title: Girl, 13, Is Raped and Killed On Way Home From School
description: A 13-year-old girl who disappeared on her way home from school Thursday evening was found stabbed to death on the East River promenade under the Wards Island Bridge, the police said yesterday.

title: Parcells Says Team Must Keep Score Low
description: If the Super Bowl game on Sunday becomes a shootout, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants will be unhappy. Coach Marv Levy of the Buffalo Bills may not be.

title: Bouncer Killed in Argument At a Nightclub in Manhattan
description: A 28-year-old bouncer was shot and killed at a Manhattan nightclub early yesterday after he argued with three men who did not want to check their coats, the police said.

title: Mourning Moon Palace, a Place to Eat and Be at Home
description: In a city where almost everything seems to change every 15 minutes or so, the closing of a Chinese restaurant does not often arouse grief, or even attention.

title: Still Missing
description: Bob Simon, a CBS News correspondent who disappeared with his three-man crew on Monday, failed to turn up again yesterday, network officials said today. Saudi trackers followed footprints leading from the crew's empty vehicle to the Kuwaiti border, which the footprints crossed. Television gear and $6,000 in cash were reportedly found in the vehicle.

title: TEACHERS TO DEFER WAGES IN NEW YORK
description: Four months after they won a 5.5 percent wage increase that was attacked as too generous, New York City teachers agreed yesterday to save their younger colleagues from layoffs by deferring part of this year's salary for four years.

title: Student Self-Confidence Helps the Neediest
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund does not send out direct mail, but Tiziana M. Tabucchi, a student in her third year at Columbia Law School, said an envelope was part of the reason she decided to give.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRIAN HENSON , the eldest son of the late Jim Henson, is taking over as president of the film production company founded by his father in 1958 as the Muppets Inc. Mr. Henson and his four siblings own what is now Jim Henson Productions Inc. Their father died of a bacterial infection last May. Mr. Henson, 27 years old, replaces DAVID LAZER , who has been the acting president and who will remain on the board.

title: Carter Hawley Cuts Nearly 100
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said it had dismissed nearly 100 workers after failing to achieve enough job cuts through attrition. In October, the Los Angeles-based retailer cut 350 workers and said it would eliminate another 650 jobs by leaving openings unfilled. But the level of attrition was low because of the uncertainties of recession and the Persian Gulf crisis, forcing this week's action, a company spokesman, Bill Dombrowski, said.

title: Review/Television; 3 Films About Women Behind Bars
description: Stories about women in prison too often seem to be told for easy laughs or soft-porn leering. These inmates have served as the centerpieces of countless campy plays and dopey situation comedies. With "Prison Stories: Women on the Inside," HBO Showcase takes a far more serious view of the situation, noting that women are now, with a total of 40,000 incarcerations, the fastest-growing segment of the United States prison population. Significantly, this dramatic trilogy, which is to have its premiere at 10 o'clock tonight, represents the work of some of today's leading female directors.

title: Iran Says it Won't Join Iraq
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran yesterday strongly rejected any idea that Iran join forces with Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, saying such a move would be an act of suicide.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Weapons; Pentagon Said to Authorize U.S. Use of Nonlethal Gas
description: The Pentagon has authorized the United States commander in the Persian Gulf to use nonlethal riot-control gases in certain circumstances against Iraqi forces and prisoners of war, Administration officials said today.

title: Books of The Times; 2 Versions of the Long View of the Vietnam War
description: The Vietnam Wars 1945-1990 By Marilyn B. Young Illustrated. 386 pages. HarperCollins. $25. Where the Domino Fell America and Vietnam, 1945 to 1990 By James S. Olson and Randy Roberts Illustrated. 321 pages. St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: Polish Poet Given '91 Jerusalem Prize
description: Zbigniew Herbert, a Polish poet, is the winner of the 1991 Jerusalem Prize.

title: Entire Staff Is Laid Off From Operation PUSH
description: Operation PUSH, the grassroots firebrand of civil rights organizations and brainchild of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, has been searching for an identity since its charismatic founder left Chicago for Washington more than a year ago. Now the group is in such deep financial trouble that this week laid off its entire staff of 12.

title: Florio Budget Is Said to Cut 8,000 Jobs
description: The Florio administration is planning to eliminate up to 8,000 state jobs -- about 9 percent of the state work force -- in the next fiscal year as part of budget plans that include more than 4,000 layoffs and the reduction of the number of departments to 16, from 19, administration officials said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Religious Leaders; Cardinal Says Iraqi's Acts Prove Bush Right
description: Saying that prompt military action in the Persian Gulf now appears to have been necessary, Bernard Cardinal Law of Boston has become the highest-ranking Roman Catholic prelate in the nation to offer support for President Bush's position.

title: Turner to Offer Global Services
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. will offer two channels of international programming to 700,000 cable households in 16 countries, starting on Monday.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Names Congressman As Agriculture Chief

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: Pentagon Authorizes Use of Riot Gases

title: In Europe, It's the Year of Mozart
description: He was born in Salzburg in 1756 and he died in Vienna in 1791, but in between, during 27 voyages that lasted a total of 10 years, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart unknowingly sketched out the program for this year's European extravaganza marking the bicentennial of his death.

title: Rangers Down Oilers As Miller Scores 2 Goals
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 25 With Bernie Nicholls out for a month with a separated shoulder, the Rangers are seeking increased production from their other centers. They got a helping of it tonight when Kevin Miller scored twice and had an assist in a 4-3 victory over the Edmonton Oilers at Northlands Coliseum. It was the first victory for the Rangers in four games and only their second in seven. Miller had six shots on goal. He also his a goalpost and slid head first into the net on another attmpt. "I was due," Miller said. "Lately I've been getting all kinds of chances. It's not just me. With a scorer like Bernie out, everybody's got to pick it up." Tonight's three periods were dramatically different. The first featured open skating and even play and ended with a 1-1 tie. Joe Cirella, recently acquired from Quebec, scored for the Rangers; Steve Smith for Edmonton. The second period was dominated by the Rangers, who emerged with a 3-1 lead on goals by Miller and Kris King. In the third, the Oilers opened by severely testing Mike Richter. He held them off until Miller increased the lead to 4-1 with his second of the game, on a breakaway from center ice. Edmonton's Smith scored with a two-man advantage late in the game. Glenn Anderson's goal with 15 seconds left ended the scoring. The Rangers have four days before their next game, but Coach Roger Neilson has planned what he calls a "mini training camp" near a resort in Banff, Alberta, with double-sessions scheduled for Sunday and Monday. Richter said the successful effort may have improved the team's chances for other recreation at Banff. "Maybe we just saved a lung or two on this team," he said. Tie Domi of New York, back from the minor leagues, played sparingly but did what he was brought up to do: fight. In the first period, Domi challenged Dave Brown and lost in a rapid exchange of punches. In the second, Domi squared off with Jeff Beukeboom. He came into the game with 272 penalty minutes this season in both major and minor-league action. Adam Graves of Edmonton and Randy Moller of New York were ejected for fighting after officials had broken up the second Domi altercation. Before the game, the availability of Brian Leetch had been in doubt. The Rangers' defenseman and leading scorer sprained his right ankle during Tuesday night's 3-2 loss to the Islanders. Leetch took a regular shift tonight and played well, setting up the third Ranger goal with a pass across the goalmouth to King - PRO HOCKEY

title: 165 Layoffs Set At Armco Steel
description: The Armco Steel Company is laying off 165 workers at its Middletown Works because of sagging market conditions.

title: Saudi Aramco in Korea
description: Saudi Aramco, the Saudi Arabian oil company, has asked the Finance Ministry for authorization to invest in an oil refining business in South Korea, the ministry said this week.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Security; Pan Am Barring All Iraqis From Flights
description: Pan American World Airways, which lost a jet with 270 aboard from a terrorist bomb two years ago, has refused to carry any Iraqi passengers since the Persian Gulf war broke out last week.

title: Review/Dance; Amid a City of Bones, Decay And Lost Souls at Large
description: If only the scenery could have danced. If only the choreography had been as strong as the set.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Britain; BOMBING EXPECTED TO LAST FOR WEEKS
description: The allied air campaign against Iraq will continue for two to three more weeks before ground forces go into action, senior British officials said today.

title: News Summary
description: War in the Gulf 4-9

title: Newspaper in Paris Rocked by Bombing
description: A bomb exploded early today at the French newspaper Liberation in what the police said was the first Persian Gulf war-related act of terrorism in France.

title: Seles Is Youngest to Win Australian Open Women's Title
description: Monica Seles, cutting the angles of her two-fisted strokes sharper and sharper after a perfect start by Jana Novotna, became the youngest Australian Open women's champion in history today.

title: Iraq Won't Put Pilots on TV
description: Iraq said today that it had stopped screening television interviews with captured American and allied pilots "until further notice" but added that the practice, widely condemned in the West, would resume "at the appropriate time."

title: Truth and the Police Plan
description: Last fall New York's Mayor, David Dinkins, earned justified praise for a well-conceived plan designed to strengthen law enforcement. Now he deserves criticism: Though the plan still merits enactment, the Mayor has abused public belief in it, and in him.

title: 25 Years Ago, Mara, Wilson Fueled Merger
