description: Although they didn't know each other then, Wellington Mara and Ralph Wilson were involved in creating the Super Bowl a quarter of a century ago. Now, as the rival presidents of the Giants and the Bills, they are in Super Bowl XXV together as a rarity: owners of two teams controlled only by their respective families.

title: U.S. Seizes Columbia Savings
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, which bought more "junk bonds" than any other savings institution, was taken over by the Government today, paying the final price for its risky investment strategy.

title: More Dormant Bank Accounts Reclaimed
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeutter Steps In and Atwater Gets a New Post
description: The Republican National Committee bid a sad farewell to the hard-driving chairmanship of Lee Atwater today and unanimously elected a new chief, Clayton K. Yeutter, who seemed to be signaling a far different style of leadership.

title: Key Rates
Hamilton Wanted Strongest Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald P. Cottrell, 88, Education Dean, Dies
description: Donald P. Cottrell, dean of the College of Education at Ohio State University from 1946 to 1967, died Monday at his home in Worthington, Ohio. He was 88 years old.

title: USAir Pulling Back on West Coast
description: USAir, abandoning its hopes to become a force on the West Coast as it is in the East, said yesterday that it was pulling out of six markets in California and one each in Oregon and Washington state.

title: U.S. Makes Official a Plan on AIDS Policy
description: The Bush Administration today formally announced its proposal to lift a requirement that bars foreigners with AIDS or any of six other communicable diseases from entering the country.

title: Bridge
description: One of the most common errors of average players is a tendency to play too quickly to the first trick when the dummy appears. Even experts can fall from grace, and one did on the diagramed deal from the Philip Morris European Mixed Pair Championship in Bordeaux, France, last March. The East-West beneficiaries were the eventual winners of the title, Ginette Chevalley and Paul Chemla of France.

title: Profit Falls At Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. cited a steep drop in investment banking revenues as it reported sharply lower fourth-quarter earnings yesterday. But the drop was offset by healthy trading revenues and lower compensation to employees.

title: Patents; Shade Said to Cut Glare And Improve Lighting
description: To reduce glare and improve the illumination of table lamps, a California inventor obtained a patent this week on a lampshade that he said let out more "good" light and less "bad" light.

title: Columbia Planning Symposium on TV
description: Dan Rather, Hodding Carter and the Rev. Jesse Jackson are among those taking part in a free two-day symposium next week at Columbia University on the impact of television news on world events.

title: Modem Suit Is Decided
description: A Federal jury returned a verdict today favoring Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. in its patent infringement suit against three companies.

title: Review/Music; Orchestral Turbulence On an Unlikely Topic
description: The New York Philharmonic continues to improvise in the absence of Zubin Mehta. The orchestra's music director, who left for Israel before last week's concerts to join his adopted country in its time of trouble, was replaced at Thursday evening's subscription concert by Zdenek Macal, the Milwaukee Symphony's music director. The Czechoslovak conductor's first challenge was to make sense of David Lang's "Eating Living Monkeys." He could not rise to that challenge, but the fault probably lay elsewhere than at the podium.

title: U.S. Seeks Jobs in Japan
description: United States and Japanese negotiators failed to reach agreement this week on a request by Washington for greater American access to Japanese construction projects, a Japanese official said today.

title: New York Celebrates the Maestro, Too
description: Mozart may well have been the European composer, but Americans have taken him to heart, too, and seem intent on proving it. New York, in particular, will weigh in with perhaps the most mammoth celebration of the bicentennial of the composer's death anywhere: the Mozart Bicentennial at Lincoln Center proposes to traverse all 835 of Mozart's surviving works over the next 19 months.

title: Everett Freeman, 79, Prolific Screenwriter
description: Everett Freeman, a screenwriter and producer whose films include "Marjorie Morningstar," "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty" and "You Can't Cheat an Honest Man," died Thursday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived in Westwood, Calif.

title: Two Giants Were Heroes Far From Playing Field
description: If things don't go well for the Giants in the first half of their Super Bowl showdown with the Buffalo Bills in Tampa Stadium tomorrow, and if Coach Bill Parcells decides some halftime inspiration is in order, he could do worse than to ask the lads to go out there and win one for Big Al Blozis.

title: Dinkins to Lead Contingent in Trip to Israel
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has repeatedly criticized the American effort in the Persian Gulf, said yesterday that he would travel to Israel next week in a symbolic gesture of support for Israelis and for American troops.

title: For Buffalo, the Bills Pay Off
description: No city, once it has been great, ever forgets the feeling of greatness. It warms the blood. It makes strangers look each other in the eye. It feels remarkably like divine favor, for which it is often mistaken.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Japan; Tokyo Leader, Facing a New Debate, Appeals for Support for War Aid
description: Facing renewed opposition to deeper involvement in the battle against Iraq, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu opened a campaign for public understanding today by warning that Tokyo risked "international isolation" if it did not contribute more money and personnel to the war.

title: Prosecutor Tells of Suspect In Florida Students' Slayings
description: Investigators have a new suspect in the slayings of five Florida college students last August, a prosecutor confirmed today. The prosecutor, John Moore, said in an interview that Danny Harold Rolling, 36 years old, was "being targeted as a prime suspect."

title: Iceland Proposes Reopening Its Ties With Baltic Republics
description: Iceland has become the first country to propose reopening diplomatic relations with the three Baltic republics struggling toward independence amid a Soviet military crackdown.

title: Jack Schaefer, 83, Author of Westerns, Including 'Shane'
description: Jack Schaefer, a newspaperman turned author of westerns whose most well-known work was the novel "Shane" about a gunfighter who sacrifices himself for a young boy and his family, died Thursday at St. Vincent Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 83 years old.

title: Tagliabue Calls Game 'Winter 4th of July'
description: "A week's delay or a two weeks' delay is what we're looking at rather than a delay of a day or two," he said.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "The current economic downturn is likely to be relatively brief and mild. Inflation is subsiding, overall inventories are relatively lean in relation to sales, and the Federal Reserve continues to take steps to support economic growth." -- Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher.

title: U.S. Seeking Chip Accord
description: The United States today asked Japan to begin talks on a new semiconductor agreement to replace a controversial accord that expires in July, Japanese officials said.

title: Dow Up 16.34, to 2,659.41, in Volatile Day
description: Stock prices took wide swings in hectic trading yesterday on the heavy flow of war news but managed to end the day higher.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The President; Bush Calls Gulf Oil Spill A 'Sick' Act by Hussein
description: President Bush said today that the spilling of crude oil into the Persian Gulf was a "sick" act of desperation by Iraq and ordered the Pentagon to move to stop the spill. Officials said the effort could include a military action intended to stop the spill at its source in a Kuwaiti offshore terminal.

title: Isiah Thomas To Undergo Surgery
description: Isiah Thomas's wrist injury hurt too much for him to continue playing, so the Detroit Pistons said yesterday that their point guard, voted to the All-Star team a day before, would undergo surgery and be out for at least 12 weeks.

title: More on the Gulf
description: DINKINS VISIT -- In a move that could prove politically awkward, Mayor David N. Dinkins said he would visit Israel in a gesture of support for Israelis and American troops. Page 29. A CITY REACTS -- In Richmond, Va., the outbreak of war has meant damage to an economy already in recession. Business has slowed atCline Appliance and Hyman Brothers Pontiac. But some merchants -- selling shortwave radios, maps and pizza -- have had a sales spurt. Business Day, page 31. THE SUPER BOWL -- The N.F.L. Commissioner said that if events in the gulf forced the postponement of tomorrow's Super Bowl, it would be held the following Sunday. Page 45.

title: Economy Falls at 2.1% Rate; Decline Is Biggest in 8 Years
description: The economy contracted at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1990, the biggest quarterly drop in more than eight years and the most definitive proof yet that the nation's longest peacetime business expansion has ended.

title: 12 Held in Ring to Obtain Papers for Illegal Aliens
description: Four immigration workers and two Army recruiting sergeants were charged yesterday with taking bribes as part of a ring that obtained green cards and other documents for more than 1,000 illegal aliens, mostly West Indians living in Brooklyn and Queens, Federal authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about "debt for nature" swaps misidentified the donor organization in a swap benefiting the Dominican Republic. It is the Conservation Trust of Puerto Rico.

title: Colman M. Mockler Jr. Dies at 61, Gillette's Top Executive Since 70's
description: Colman M. Mockler Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of The Gillette Company since the mid-1970's, died yesterday at his office in the Prudential Tower in Boston. He was 61 years old and lived in Wayland, Mass.

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.61 percent this week, down from 9.75 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.69 percent, down from 7.74 percent last week and the lowest since 7.66 percent in the week that ended on May 13, 1988.

title: Nets Take the Lakers to Overtime and Lose
description: There are some nights on the court when the improbable becomes probable and things that are not supposed to happen unfold before thousands of surprised eyes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page on Jan. 18 about the future of American prisons misstated the population of Sacramento, Calif. According to the United States Census Bureau, it is 369,365.

title: Patents; Toothpaste Said to Remove Plaque and Tartar Safely
description: A California company obtained a patent this week on a toothpaste formula that it said could clear away plaque and tartar without endangering tooth enamel. The formula uses citric acid and an enzyme derived from papaya fruit.

title: E.P.A. Moves to Change Environment Priorities
description: The Environmental Protection Agency took to Congress today its campaign to reassess national environmental priorities that the agency's leader says are sometimes misplaced.

title: Florida Press Issue: Court-Ordered Guilt Ads
description: A weekly newspaper is accepting court-ordered advertisements of guilt from people convicted of drunken driving and other misdemeanors -- an idea rejected by another Florida newspaper.

title: IMAGES OF VENUS REVEAL VOLCANISM
description: As the Magellan spacecraft completed mapping nearly half the surface of Venus, scientists yesterday reported increasing evidence that molten rock rising from inside the planet and often erupting as volcanoes has a major role in the planet's rugged landscape and poisonous, thick atmosphere.

title: Petrensko Repeats as Champion    Viktor Petrenko of the Soviet Union, with a stunning jumping performance yesterday, repeated as men's champion yesterday at the European championships in Sofia, Bulgaria. Petrenko, second in the world championships to Kurt Browning of Canada last March, had six triple jumps that included a triple axel just 30 seconds from the end of his routine. In the final free program, Petrenko gained marks of 5.8 and 5.9 for technical merit and all 5.9's with a a single 6.0 for artistic impression. Petr Barna of Czechoslovakia was second with another Soviet skater, Vyacheslav Zagorodniuk, third.(AP)
description: N.B.A. Pistons Win Without Thomas Bill Laimbeer hit a jumper at the buzzer last night and the Detroit Pistons, now minus Isiah Thomas for three months, beat the Dallas Mavericks, 84-82, in Auburn Hills, Mich. The victory was the Pistons' 13th in 15 games. Brad Davis of Dallas made a 3-point shot with 4.5 seconds left to tie the score after Joe Dumars made two free throws with 8.8 seconds remaining to put Detroit ahead, 82-79. Thomas, the Pistons' captain, who was put on the injured list earlier in the day. He will undergo wrist surgery next week and will be out at least 12 weeks. Rolando Blackman had 23 points, 11 of them in the fourth quarter, to bring Dallas back. Davis stole the ball twice and Randy White grabbed three offensive rebounds in the quarter as Dallas clawed its way back from an early 14-point deficit. Vinnie Johnson led Detroit with 21 points and Dumars had 20. (AP) Sixers 116, Celtics 94: At the Spectrum, Hersey Hawkins had a career-high 38 points and added 9 steals and 8 rebounds for Philadelphia, which ended a four-game losing streak. Hawkins got help from Rickey Green, who scored a season-high 27 points on 13-for-17 shooting and contributed 9 assists. Kevin McHale scored 26 and Reggie Lewis 24 for the Celtics, who lost for the fifth time in their last six games. The 76ers played their sixth game without Charles Barkley, who is sidelined with a broken right foot, while the Celtics were without Larry Bird, who has been out with an injured back for nine games. The 76ers have gone 2-4 without their top scorer and Boston has gone 5-4 without Bird. (AP) Pacers 106, Bullets 100: Chuck Person scored 25 points, including 5 in Indiana's 13-3 closing run, as the Pacers rallied from a 14-point fourth-quarter deficit to win in Baltimore. The Bullets held a 97-93 lead with 3:21 left but did not score again until Harvey Grant made a 3-pointer at the buzzer. By that time, Indiana had long since wrapped up its third road victory in four games after starting out 1-17 away from home. Bernard King scored 34 points and Grant had 27 for the Bullets, who lost at home for the first time in seven games. (AP) SCHOOL BASKETBALL

title: Review/Music; Violinist in a Soviet Mode
description: The Soviet violinist Vladimir Spivakov began and ended his Sunday afternoon recital at Avery Fisher Hall with evocations of 19th-century Vienna, in the form of works by Schubert and Beethoven. But the heart of the program was a pair of contemporary Soviet works, and at the heart of both works was the spirit of Dmitri Shostakovich, glimpsed from a distance.

title: Cioffi Is Looking Beyond Shrine Game
description: Paul Cioffi, a 6-foot-2-inch defensive end from Montclair State, will be the only Division III player among the outstanding seniors who have been invited to play in the East-West Shrine Game today at Stanford Stadium in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: State Capitals Show Population Gains
description: Expanding employment in state government and higher education in the 1980's fueled population gains in college towns and state capitals, according to 1990 census figures released today.

title: Bankruptcy Petition Is Filed by Interco
description: Interco Inc., the footwear and furniture maker struggling with a heavy load of "junk bond" debt, filed today for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: SUPER BOWL XXV: Notebook; Simms, With Cast Off, Starts on Road Back
description: The cast came off Phil Simms's injured right foot today, and on Saturday Simms will start working on foot motion and lifting weights with the foot. He will remain on crutches for two weeks.

title: Frederick Dorian, 89, A Professor of Music
description: Dr. Frederick Dorian, a lecturer, author and professor of music, died on Thursday at Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 89 years old.

title: Medical Dean at Cornell Quits to Take Texas Job
description: The dean of Cornell University's medical college resigned yesterday to become head of surgery at Texas Tech University's medical school.

title: Rear Adm. Thomas D. Davies, 76, Aviator and Expert on Navigation
description: Rear Adm. Thomas D. Davies, retired, a navigation expert, aviator and disarmament official, died Monday at a hospital on the Caribbean island of St. Martin, where he was vacationing. He was 76 years old and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: Noriega Gains Access to $1.6 Million of His Money to Pay Drug Defense
description: The Government said today that Austria has agreed to release $1.6 million from a bank account of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in that country, a step that will apparently settle a dispute over how the deposed dictator will pay his legal expenses.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany; Kohl Draws Rising Charges Of an Insufficient War Role
description: Less than two months after Helmut Kohl's overwhelming election as Chancellor of the newly united Germany, his Government is being besieged by criticism for its response to the Persian Gulf war.

title: Lebanon Belongs In Any Mideast Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq's Army; The Formidable Republican Guard Blocks the Road to Victory
description: Iraq's best-trained and most heavily armed divisions, the Republican Guards, must be destroyed if the allies are to decisively win the war in the Persian Gulf, American military analysts say.

title: Sine Nomine Singers
description: Harry Saltzman is to conduct the Sine Nomine Singers in selections from Heinrich Schutz's "Cantiones Sacraes" and "Kleine Geistlichen Konzerte" at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, at 3 P.M. tomorrow. The program also includes Henry Purcell's "Funeral Sentences" and some of his incidental theater music. Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 362-8719.

title: Job Cuts Planned in New Jersey
description: Gov. Jim Florio is planning to cut up to 8,000 state jobs in the next fiscal year and reduce the number of departments to 16 from 19. Page 27.

title: Germany's Ostrich-Politik
description: The new world order begins with a huge hole in the center of Europe. Germany, now Europe's most important state, is trying to minimize its involvement in the gulf war, citing the country's militarist legacy. It would be more constructive to redeem past errors by making collective security more truly collective, providing a real alternative to superpower policing of global crises.

title: Publisher Slain in a Raid in Colombia to Free Her
description: Police officers in helicopters raided a drug cartel hideaway today and freed the kidnapped daughter of a former president who had been held captive since Aug. 30. But she was shot by her captors during the battle and died a few hours later, the police said.

title: Saddam Hussein Is No Saladin
description: In proclaiming a holy war against his foes, Saddam Hussein has likened himself to Saladin, the great Islamic adversary of Richard the Lion-Hearted in the Third Crusade. This suggests abysmal ignorance of Saladin's code in dealing with foes, infidels and prisoners of war.

title: Guidepost; Beyond Bananas
description: Tropical fruits have become staples on produce stands: think of the banana. But aside from the familiar bananas, mangoes and papayas, there are other varieties of less common tropical fruits. Many are bizarre looking, with leathery skins and names as odd as their appearance. Most have more than one name. Here's a guide to some of these fruits and their flavors. Common Name Other Name Season Flavor Custard apple Cherimoya Winter and spring Sweet, custardy Passion fruit Granadilla Spring and summer Tart-sweet Pineapple guava Feijoa Spring and summer Tart, floral Soursop Guanabana Winter and spring Tart Star fruit Carambola Fall and winter Tart or sweet

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Cuomo Expects SUNY Tuition To Rise Again
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who last month approved the first tuition increases at the State University and City University of New York since 1983, said today that tuitions would probably go up again in September.

title: Japan Vehicle Output Up
description: Japan's auto makers produced a record 13.5 million cars, buses and trucks in 1990, up 3.5 percent from the previous year, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Influential Illinois Congressman Is Named Secretary of Agriculture
description: President Bush today nominated Representative Edward Madigan of Illinois, one of the most influential farm policy experts in Congress, to be Secretary of Agriculture.

title: Review/Television; The Subtle Role of Religion In American Voting Habits
description: If you missed the premiere of the new season of "Bookmark" Monday evening on Channel 31, you can catch it this morning at 9 on Channel 13, a bit of scheduling that signals what New York's main public station thinks of the appeal of its only book series.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook; Saudis Would Like to Know Whose Holy War It Is Anyhow
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has called for a holy war against Saudi Arabia and its Western allies, but Saudi soldiers and airmen at the front lines of the battle say they are confident that theirs is the divinely backed side.

title: Players' Group Eyes Free Agency
description: The National Football League Players Association, no longer a labor union but now a trade association, said on Thursday that it would continue to fight for total free agency for all N.F.L. players and would not attempt to bargain for a contract with the owners.

title: Avery Charge Of $85 Million
description: The Avery Dennison Corporation, an office and industrial products company formed three months ago through the merger of Avery International and Dennison Manufacturing, said today that it would take an $85 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the cost of job cutbacks and other changes.

title: 2 Charged in Illegal Serving Of Alcohol to 7 Teen-Agers
description: The owners of a home where a 15-year-old girl was fatally stricken during a teen-agers' New Year's Eve party were charged today with illegally serving alcohol to seven minors.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: North Africa; Pro-Iraq Sentiment Is Increasing in North Africa
description: All along this city's main boulevard, clusters of young men, many of them unemployed, form in front of newsstands and grow angry as they read the latest news from the Persian Gulf war.

title: Sheriffs Seize 9 Items at Antiques Show Preview
description: Antiques collectors and socialites sipped champagne yesterday afternoon while two New York City sheriffs directed the partial stripping of the booth of Fleming & Meers, Washington dealers in English furniture, during the opening preview of the Winter Antiques Show.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Chronicle column on Wednesday about the opening of a chain of children's fitness centers by Billie Jean King misstated the name and the sponsor of the professional tennis league that she helped establish. It is Teamtennis, sponsored by FTM Sport, not Domino's Pizza Team Tennis.

title: WORST U.S. SPILL
description: The worst oil disaster in American history was the March 24, 1989, spill from the Exxon Valdez, off Alaska. Nearly 11 million gallons were released into the ocean, or 260,000 barrels. Each barrel contains 42 gallons. The oil spill in the Persian Gulf is so far a dozen times larger than the Exxon Valdez spill, or about 3 million barrels, the Pentagon said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AON Corp., Chicago, an insurance holding company, said its retail brokerage subsidiary, Rollins Burdick Hunter Co., would acquire Huntington T. Block Insurance, Washington. Terms were not disclosed. * Computer Sciences Corp., El Segundo, Calif., a computer services company, said an affiliate had acquired Analytics Inc., Willow Grove, Pa., an information security and communications systems company. Terms were not disclosed. * Energy Service Co., Inc., Houston, an oil and gas drilling company, has completed the acquisition of the operations of Argosy Offshore Ltd., for $24.2 million, along with certain merchandise credits from Energy Service's supply division, not to exceed $5 million. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, said its Hungarian subsidiary plans to sell 4,000 Opel cars in Hungary this year and about 17,000 to 18,000 next year. * Hawker de Havilland Ltd., which is 70 percent owned by Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C., London, a maker of electrical equipment, will cut 200 jobs at its airframe and aircraft engine parts plant at Port Melbourne, Australia. * Heilig-Meyers Co., Richmond, a home furnishings company, has acquired seven stores from Furniture Center Inc. for undisclosed terms. * Morrison Knudsen Corp., Boise, Idaho, a construction, engineering and environmental company, has received contracts to manage new construction projects for General Motors Corp. in Hungary, Glaxo Inc. in Triangle Park, N.C., and the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation in the Pacific Northwest. Terms of the contracts were not disclosed. * Nabisco Brands Ltd., a Canadian unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp., will close its cannery in Simcoe, Ontario, on Feb. 22. The plant has 98 employees. * Telesphere Communications Inc., Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., a telecommunications and data management company, said it had signed agreements for investors to buy $22 million of its common shares and signed agreements with its lenders and vendors for $35 million of additional credit in the next 12 months. * Tetra Technologies Inc. has acquired TSI, an oilfield equipment, supplies and services provider, in a stock purchase exchange.

title: The Sky Ought To Be the Limit
description: After a decade of deregulation, the U.S. airline industry is disintegrating. In the 1980's, it suffered more than 150 bankruptcies and 50 mergers. Of the handful of surviving airlines, five are liquidating major assets and three of those have fallen into bankruptcy, including Pan Am this month. Last week, Eastern Airlines died after its prolonged illness.

title: Macy's Sales Fall
description: R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that its same-store sales fell 11.8 percent in December from the corresponding month in 1989. The stores involved are those that are at least one year old. In a statement, Macy said the lower level of sales had been expected. The retail chain also said that it had formalized a previously announced sale of $25 million of its convertible participating preferred stock, series III, at $31.81, a share to Winmex Investments Ltd. Winmex is affiliated with Sir Run Run Shaw, a Hong Kong investor. Macy said it would also grant Winmex an option to purchase up to $25 million more of the stock at the same price by April 2.

title: Ghosts of Vietnam
description: Since the war in Indochina, the reluctance of some Americans to commit U.S. troops to foreign wars has been derided as the "Vietnam syndrome." But the most persistent hangover from that lost war appears to be the conservative and military myth that restraints imposed at home made victory in Vietnam impossible.

title: Coping; With Disposing of an Estate
description: Disposing of the contents of an entire house or apartment can be a daunting task. Often, emotions run high: a relative or friend may have died, an older couple may be leaving a large house for a smaller retirement apartment, or a young couple and their children may be facing a transfer continents away.

title: For Collection Agencies, These Are Busy Times
description: In the current recession, promptly paying bills -- or not paying bills -- is perhaps the best indicator of an individual's financial health. And the people who best know when and whether bills are being paid these days are the nation's 6,000 collection agencies, the companies that collect debts owed to others. As they tell it, there's been a slowdown in paying bills, which makes them busier than they've ever been before. What's more, today there are more collectors in the field.

title: War: Live. Fears: Magnified.
description: The televised scene in Saudi Arabia: A reporter shouts "Gas attack!" and drops his microphone to struggle into a gas mask. The untelevised scene some hours later in Stroudsburg, Pa.: The Army and Navy store on Main Street sells its last gas mask, ending a record gas-mask year in the Poconos.

title: Article 317491 -- No Title
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had lost $56 million in the fourth quarter, as demand for computer chips remained depressed and prices continued to fall. The company's chairman, Jerry R. Junkins, indicated the loss would widen in the current quarter.

title: Oil Prices and Profits: What Goes Up . . .
description: Next to blood and water, gasoline is the most important liquid for Americans. So they wonder why the combination of plunging crude oil prices and ballooning petroleum industry profits isn't leading to a rollback of gasoline prices, which could help jump-start the stalled economy.

title: President Bush Makes His Call: 'Play Ball'
description: At his news conference yesterday at the White House, President Bush said the Super Bowl should be played as scheduled tomorrow despite the war.

title: Hussein Ouster Urged by Imam
description: The Imam of Islam's holiest mosque called in a sermon today for the overthrow and punishment of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Dinkins Staff Withholds Papers on Bridge Safety
description: The Dinkins administration has refused to provide documents that a City Council committee considers crucial to its investigation of why the city returned subway service to the Manhattan Bridge despite the warnings of engineers that it was unsafe, city officials said last night.

title: Pepsi in a Super Bowl Rush After Scrapping Its Contest
description: In the aftermath of one of the strangest marketing mishaps in recent history, Pepsico executives scrambled yesterday to re-edit television commercials for tomorrow's Super Bowl to remove references to a phone-in contest that has been canceled.

title: Consumers and Industry to Pay Clean Air Cost; Gas Price Gouging
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Resales Rise by 2.2%
description: Sales of previously owned single-family homes rose 2.2 percent in December, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.22 million units, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: Paradise for Pentagon
description: Thursday I turned to soap opera. Yes, I felt slightly ashamed. The war was still running full time on CNN, and patriots, I suppose, should stay glued to the screen at such times.

title: Your Money; 2 Trusts Suitable For Middle Class
description: Trusts, long a favorite financial planning tool of the rich, can also be used advantageously by middle-income people. In recent interviews, two advisers offered trust plans that are particularly appropriate in a sluggish economy.

title: Patents; Structures Developed For Compact Use
description: Using a new approach to folding, a former art student who turned to mechanical engineering has invented a family of structures that can collapse into compact bundles in seconds.

title: Kelly Grows Into the Role of Leader
description: Jim Kelly cannot be pinpointed as the only Buffalo Bills player in recent seasons who lacked the maturity and the ability to brush his ego aside on a team that featured little of the first trait and plenty of the second. But on the eve of Super Bowl XXV, it is Kelly who shines most as the Bill who has turned silver into gold.

title: About New York; Bombing Iraq From Broadway For a Mere 50
description: The F-15 pilot stares into the electronic screen. The ground jerks from horizontal to vertical through every dizzying position in between. The speed almost exceeds a human's ability to respond. Lasers guide bombs to targets on the barren, sandy desertscape. Enemy missiles appear on the spinning horizon. Hit them!

title: Iraq to Allow CNN Satellite
description: The Cable News Network has received permission from the Iraqi Government for a producer and television crew to enter the country with a satellite transmitting device that will provide live pictures from Baghdad, a CNN executive said yesterday.

title: Moscow Journal; Literary Magazine's Struggle in a Time of Change
description: Novy Mir, the most distinctive of the Soviet literary magazines that defined the limits of officially publishable writing for most of 70 years, may not survive the economic chaos that recently led President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to threaten a return to censorship.

title: Picturing Columbus and His Sponsors
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Music fans heard something new on Wednesday night at a two-day Mozart symposium at the Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester: for the first time in 200 years, Mozart's Rondo for Horn was played in its original version by PETER KURAU , an Eastman professor.

title: So, What Is 'Environmentally Friendly'?
description: As the battle heats up to win over consumers who are concerned about the environment, packaging is becoming more of an issue. When one package is marked "environmentally friendly," and the one next to it is not, would you buy the former in hopes of doing a little to improve the health of the planet?

title: U.S. SAYS IRAQ PUMPS KUWAITI OIL INTO GULF; VAST DAMAGE FEARED FROM GROWING SLICK
description: The United States accused Iraq on Friday of releasing millions of gallons of Kuwaiti crude oil into the Persian Gulf, creating a huge slick that allied officials described as dwarfing that of the Exxon Valdez disaster.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the front page of Business Day yesterday titled "A Link Between Movies and Books," with an article about a takeover bid by the General Cinema Corporation for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, misstatedthe full-year revenue figures for Harcourt, as well as the stock prices and fiscal years of Harcourt and General Cinema. Harcourt's revenues were $1.11 billion in 1987; $1.27 billion in 1988, and $1.34 billion in 1989. Harcourt's stock closed Thursday at $1.25 a share, unchanged; its fiscal year ended Dec. 31. General Cinema stock closed Thursday at $20.50, up 12.5 cents; its fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

title: Business Diary/January 20-25
description: INTERNATIONAL Now, Almost Everyone Has Become Energy-Dependent Even our modern-day Newcastle has to bring in some fuel. Saudi Arabia, the world's second-largest oil producer, has imported 8 million barrels of diesel and jet fuel to power the attack against Iraq. American forces guzzle gasoline faster than the rush-hour crowd on the Ventura Freeway; some tanks get only about 3,000 feet to the gallon. The shortage comes not in crude oil, but in end products. "The quantities used are enormous and the refinery capacity is elsewhere," said Robert G. Neumann, director of the Middle East program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies and a former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. The situation is worse in Iraq, which has banned fuel sales to civilians. And in Kuwait, the Iraqis set wellheads and refineries on fire last week. Christopher Flavin, an energy specialist at the Worldwatch Institute, said it might take Kuwait five years to rebuild. In his view, the United States will be as vulnerable to energy shortages as ever in the coming decade. "Future crises are all but inevitable," he said.

title: Cartoon Art Museum Plans Move to Florida
description: The Museum of Cartoon Art is moving to Florida.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our screened porch has a slate floor. There are some paint spots on it, and the floor is rather dusty. We would like to apply a sealer, but we want to remove the paint spots first. How would you suggest we go about it?

title: Time Needed On Rose and Hall
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
Northeast Notebook: Saco, Me.;
Gambling on The Currents
description: A GROUP of about a dozen optimists are gambling that nature or man or both will restore tidal land now lying below the Atlantic Ocean.

title: In Britain, One Voice Rules Rock Radio. Tune In, America.
description: John Peel has been the ruling voice of British rock-and-roll radio for nearly 25 years. He may also be the most influential rock disk jockey anywhere. Since 1967, when Mr. Peel joined the BBC's all-pop Radio One, he has commanded a large and loyal audience with a programming style distinguished by his droll fireside manner, prescient musical taste and fannish enthusiasm for new sounds and underdog musicians.

title: Decreasing Our Word Power: The New Newspeak
description: The ailment of hypersensitivity, a symptom of the disease of political correctness, is breaking out in journalism. Fresh evidence comes from the University of Missouri School of Journalism in the form of the "Dictionary of Cautionary Words and Phrases: An Excerpt From the Newspaper Content Analysis Compiled by 1989 Multicultural Management Program Fellows."

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Bach: Orchestral Suites (BWV 1066-69) Moscow Virtuosi conducted by Vladimir Spivakov. RCA Victor 60360; two CD's.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Deadly Debris Shows Limits Of Patriot Missile Defenses
description: Flaws are becoming apparent in the Patriot air defense system deployed against Iraqi Scud missiles, with some warheads exploding and wreaking damage even though the missiles themselves are shot down.

title: OIL SPILL, GROWING RAPIDLY, HEADS FOR VITAL SAUDI SITES; AIR--WAR GOALS SAID TO SHIFT
description: Saudi officials readied barriers and dispersal chemicals today to try to contain an enormous oil slick flowing south from Kuwait, but they held out little hope of keeping the sludgy pollutant away from vital desalting plants.

title: Towns' New ZIP Codes Bring Pride (Mail, Too)
description: FOR Jerry B. Lucas, Killingworth's First Selectman, the best part about his town's getting its own ZIP code is that his subscriptions will now be addressed properly.

title: Tradition Rules a Sacred Text on Loneliness
description: "The Glass Menagerie," we are told at the outset, is a memory play. At the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., where the telling is currently unfolding, memory sure is one big place.

title: Elizabeth Heard, Executive, Weds Robert Gambee
description: Elizabeth Gregory Heard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Heard Jr. of New York, and Robert Gambee, a son of Mrs. A. Sumner Gambee of Englewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Gambee, were married yesterday. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Garo's Gaffe, McGee's Hangover And More: The First 24 Years
description: A little Texas girl's drawling description of her high-bouncing Super Ball gave her daddy the inspiration back in 1967: "We'll call it the Super Bowl," said Lamar Hunt, whose Kansas City Chiefs faced the Green Bay Packers in that first game.

title: Notes From a More Real World
description: LETTERS FROM THE LEELANAU Essays of People and Place. By Kathleen Stocking. Illustrated. 182 pp. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $13.95. ON BECOMING LOST A Naturalist's Search for Meaning. By Cathy Johnson. Illustrated. 176 pp. Salt Lake City: Peregrine Smith Books/Gibbs Smith. Paper, $14.95

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It's not just this Administration. In the Congress or in the private sector, the problems of the poor are just not on the agenda. They're becoming more visible and yet invisible." -- Representative John Lewis.

title: Amy Dixon Plans Wedding in June
description: June wedding plans for Amy Marie Dixon and John Richard Rhinelander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Rhinelander of McLean, Va., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Dixon of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Katherine Mitchell Engaged to Wed
description: Michael W. Mitchell of New York and Brooke Mitchell of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Brooke Mitchell to Andrew Davis Constan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Constan of Dayton, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Dr. James L. Nelson;
When the Doctor, Too, May Have AIDS
description: IN response to the case of an AIDS-infected Florida dentist who may have transmitted the virus to three patients, the American Medical Association and the American Dental Association recommended earlier this month that AIDS-infected doctors and dentists warn patients about their condition or give up surgery.

title: DIVIDED LOYALTIES
description: In his article "Divided Loyalties" (Dec. 16), Joel Brinkley argues that Jordanian society is split over the question of support for Saddam Hussein.

title: Eliza Adams Wed To T. W. Easton
description: Eliza Stokes Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Adams of Providence, R.I., was married there yesterday at the First Unitarian Church to Thomas William Easton, the son of Joan K. Easton and William L. Easton, both of New York. The Rev. Thomas E. Ahlburn officiated.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CLASSICS AND JAZZ

title: Marian Leerburger to Wed
description: April wedding plans for Marian Julie Leerburger and David Richard Mahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Mahl of Norwalk, Ohio, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benedict A. Leerburger of Scarsdale, N.Y. Miss Leerburger is an analyst for the Department of Defense at Fort Meade in Anne Arundel County, Md. A graduate of Colby College, she has a master's degree in international affairs from American University and a master's in national security studies from Georgetown University. The prospective bridegroom is a computer systems analyst with Cable and Wireless Communications in Vienna, Va. He is a graduate of the University of Toledo.

title: Jil Robbins to Marry John H. Pollock
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Robbins of New York have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Jil Patricia Robbins and John Henry Pollock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Pollock of Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Newark Arts Center: Other Opinions
description: As the president of the board of the New Jersey State Opera, which has called Newark home for 22 years, I feel I must protest the headline "Arts Center's Impact on Newark Debated."

title: Lithuania's President a Genuine Democrat
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Museum Is Given a Six-Month Reprieve
description: For now anyway, the one 1903 BMT Q car still on the tracks is safe. As are the gracious antique brass turnstiles and the bus cockpit that children can climb into and drive.

title: Ashley Merriam Weds J. L. Pyatt
description: Ashley Jean Merriam, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brower A. Merriam of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Second Lieutenant James Lloyd Pyatt of the Army, a son of Sheila Weissenburger of Kirkwood, Mo., and Donald L. Pyatt of Arnold, Mo. The Rev. David S. Hoag performed the ceremony at Christ the Redeemer Episcopal Church in Pelham, N.Y.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Muslims; Islamic Asians Solidly Back Hussein
description: Since the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, there has been a marked surge in sympathy for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and hostility toward the United States among Asian Muslims outside the Arab world.

title: Andrea Borden To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans have been announced by Andrea Hill Borden, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Borden Jr. of Fair Haven, N.J., and Douglas Paul Edler, a son of Paul J. Edler Jr. of Lighthouse Point, Fla., and Judith A. Dean of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Sondheim's 'Assassins': Insane Realities of History
description: Seated on the floor of a barn in Caroline County, Virginia, a tall, thin, mustachioed man is singing passionately about why he did what he did. He did it, he declares amid a crescendo, for the sake of his country. He has destroyed a tyrant, the scourge of his nation. All about him, smoke is rising. Soon, before he is consumed by the blaze, he will put a gun to his head and blow his 27-year-old life away.

title: Newark Arts Center: Other Opinions
description: Re: "Arts Center's Impact on Newark Debated," Dec. 16: The construction of a cultural center at the cost of $200 million (read $300 million before it is finished) in poor, dirty, old, tired and mismanaged Newark will not aid its 325,000 residents. We must learn from history. Ancient Rome died because the leaders sponsored circuses instead of providing for basic human needs.

title: Style Makers; Andrew Doucette, Music Video Director
description: Music videos are not usually considered fine art, but Andrew Doucette directs them with an exciting, renegade style that could change that perception.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; Ban on Smoking Expands to Cover Most of Campus
description: A smoking ban affecting almost all 900 buildings at the University of Wisconsin at Madison was announced last week by Chancellor Donna E. Shalala. Smoking is currently banned in 18 campus buildings.

title: Despite War, Parties Still Raise Money
description: Fund-raising benefits continue to draw their supporters but they are turning out in less formal, quieter dress. Since the outbreak of the war in the Persian Gulf they are wearing a lot of black dresses, both short and long, and fewer jewels. And the evenings end early, between 10 and 10:30 P.M.

title: Soon Will Begin Appeals for Iraq's War Victims; Winning Is Losing
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
A Pictorial Look at Street Life and Where People Interact
description: STREET life and the places where people interact are the common themes running through "Visual Narratives," a five-artist photography exhibition on view at the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove.

title: Postings: Office Complex; Pluck in Pluckemin
description: At a time when commercial builders throughout the Northeast are struggling with high vacancy rates and scrapping new projects, developers in Bedminster, N.J., are completing a new office complex that they hope will beat the odds. The project, Crossroads Business Center, is scheduled for completion by the end of April on a 10-acre site near the intersection of Routes 287 and 78 in the historic Pluckemin section of the community.

title: Bombing of Newspaper in Paris Tied to War
description: In the first terrorist action in France since the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, a bomb exploded early today in front of the entrance of a left-leaning Paris daily, Liberation, causing extensive damage but no injuries.

title: Czechoslovakia Auctions Stores to Private Buyers
description: The auction gavel came down today in Prague city hall, and Ladislav Krombholc became one of Czechoslovakia's first private owners of a fruit and vegetable store.

title: Chess
description: Frank Marshall, United States champion from 1909 to 1936, used to complain that he disliked match play because it lent itself to wearing the opponent down. He believed that it crimped his natural gambit style and put him at a disadvantage.

title: A Quintessential Romantic Painter Revisited
description: Few romantic artists may seem more familiar -- and are more elusive -- than Caspar David Friedrich. His austere landscapes are frequently reproduced in books on Romanticism, and neo-Romantic painters liberally borrow from them today.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Avon, Conn. 265,000 76 Paper Chase Trail 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, new kitchen, period details, 1.3 acres; taxes $3,646. New Fairfield, Conn. 178,000 13 Eastview Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old raised ranch; large deck, fenced-in yard, 1 acre; taxes $2,477. Westbrook, Conn 295,000 181 Old Kelsey Point Road 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 71-year-old beach cottage; screened porch, large pantry, 10,000-square-foot lot; taxes $1499. Pleasantville, N.Y. 293,000 34 Martling Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 71-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, flagstone terrace; taxes $4,267. Scarsdale, N.Y. 2.7 million 7 Sheldrake Road 6-bedroom, 6 1/2-bath, year-old colonial; 2-story entry hall, study, heated pool, brick terrace, 3-car garage; taxes not yet assessed. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 285,000 466 Fisher Pond Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, deck; taxes $7,638. OTHER AREAS Ridgewood, N.J. 400,000 245 Lott Road 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 36-year-old custom built split level; h/w floors, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $8,588. Springfield, N.J. 270,000 120 Laurel Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 43-year-old split level; c/a, 1-car garage, deck, den; taxes $4,540. East Hills, L.I. 385,000 15 Candy Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 39- year-old ranch; den, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,500.

title: Eastern Workers Line Up at Unemployment Office
description: For Robert Fanfauzzi, who had been a ramp worker at La Guardia Airport for Eastern Airlines for $6.75 an hour, the shutdown of the carrier over a week ago was not a big deal.

title: Soon Will Begin Appeals for Iraq's War Victims; Where the Buck Stops
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT/REFERENCE BOOKS
description: THE DINOSAURIA Edited by David B. Weishampel, Peter Dodson and Halszka Osmolska. University of California, $85.

title: Detecting High Cholesterol in Children
description: WHEN a 13-year-old Long Island boy died while undergoing dental work, the Suffolk County Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Sigmund Menchel said he had a "significant degree of coronary artery atherosclerosis in light of his age."

title: Yugoslav Players Create A Stir
description: Drazen Petrovic and Vlade Divac, once the elite of Yugoslav basketball, are now working stiffs in the National Basketball Association. In the transition, both have made waves this season with what they have said or, then again, might not have said.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MOZART COMMEMORATION

title: Fidelity's Secret Agent Man
description: Alfred Fenaughty is the president of Information International Inc. in Culver City, Calif., a publicly traded company that makes advanced computer equipment for the publishing industry. When a pleasant analyst showed up one day in 1987 saying he was from the Boston-based Kelso Management Company, which provided investment recommendations to "the Fidelity group," Mr. Fenaughty was pleased and proud.

title: Cortlandt Opens First Youth Center
description: THE Town of Cortlandt is opening its first youth center this weekend, in a renovated house at 129 Albany Post Road in Montrose.

title: Hickel Wants New Alaska Gold Rush
description: Flush with oil money gained since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis, Alaskans are once again dreaming aloud of grand schemes to extract riches from the nation's largest and least developed state.

title: Sports People; Fleeting Fame
description: It wasn't exactly his dream of glory, but Dave Gagnon, a rookie goalie for the Detroit Red Wings, had a hand in a milestone Friday night, but only because he didn't get his stick on the puck.

title: Stamps
description: The rise in postal rates on Feb. 3 offers an offbeat opportunity to put together a mini-collection of commercial envelopes with what are known as false frankings. Such frankings occur when the amount of postage shown is inappropriate or outdated. The United States Postal Service permits such false frankings to allow bulk mailers to use up their supplies of older stamps and to reduce somewhat the demand for new stamps for the higher rates.

title: Janice Gable and Howard Bashman Are to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Gable of Dresher, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Karen Gable, to Howard Jonathan Bashman, the son of Marcia Bashman of Margate, N.J., and the late Stanley Bashman. A September wedding is planned.

title: Real-Estate Agent Becomes an Advocate
description: A FEW years ago, Phyllis Matthey spotted a deal on a town house she couldn't resist. A real-estate agent, Ms. Matthey had sold about 70 units of an Edison town house complex, Victoria Park, when she decided to buy one for herself.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Decoys; A Firm's Fake Weapons Have Real Use: Deception
description: For seven years Mario Moselli has built fake military hardware -- life-size jet fighters, tanks and rocket launchers, skillfully crafted from metal and fiberglass. One eager buyer was the Government of Iraq.

title: India
description: To the Editor: On the Merce Cunningham Dance Company's recent tour of India, several of us took with us the article (Travel, Oct. 21) on the food of southern India, since Bangalore was one of the cities we visited. However, I thought that readers might like to know of another dining possibility. At a reception given for us by the United States Information Service, we met Ashrafa and Saeed Sattar, who had lived for several years in Milan, where Mr. Sattar was an executive with Air-India and learned to cook Italian food. Taking early retirement, he returned to India, bought a farm and turned it into a restaurant called the Farmhouse. It is usually open only on weekends, but Mr. and Mrs. Sattar agreed to serve dinner to members of the dance company following a Tuesday performance.

title: Nevada-Las Vegas Runs Its Winning Streak to 26
description: Top-ranked Nevada-Las Vegas extended its winning streak to 26 games this afternoon and pushed its record for the season to 15-0 by defeating Louisville, 97-85, here at Freedom Hall.

title: Naked Came the White Truffle
description: A GLUTTON FOR PUNISHMENT Confessions of a Mercenary Eater. By Jay Jacobs. 314 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.95.

title: Touring African Wilds With Panache - and an Ice Machine
description: To the tens of thousands of travelers inspired to visit Kenya by the movie "Out of Africa," Geoffrey J. W. Kent looks as though he just stepped off the set. The 46-year-old Kenyan is a polo player, a one-time British Army officer and a former big game hunter.

title: Old-Calcutta Walking Tours
description: STRANGERS in search of old Calcutta, a city that has just celebrated its 300th birthday, rarely get beyond the monumental British town, with its abundant Victoriana, or the temples and slums of ancient Hindu Kali Ghat to the south, where Mother Teresa ministers to the poor. This limitation is not the visitor's fault.

title: Miss White Weds Mark T. Rogers
description: Allison Joy White, the daughter of Dolores S. White of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there yesterday to Mark Theodore Rogers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brien Rogers of East Varick, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Clerkin performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: Rabbi David H. Panitz, Educator, Is Dead at 72
description: Rabbi David Hirsh Panitz, an educator who served as rabbi at Temple Emanuel in Paterson, N.J., for 30 years, died on Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson. He was 72 years old and lived in Shrub Oak, N.Y.

title: Safety and Freedom Vie After Deaths at Concert
description: Rock-and-roll has long been a fervent expression of a younger generation's rebellious freedom. But the deaths of three fans at a heavy-metal concert in Salt Lake City last weekend have forced promoters and arena managers to reconsider how much freedom to allow concert goers.

title: Stepping Into a Mystical Realm
description: As little Buttercup reminds us in "H. M. S. Pinafore," things are seldom as they seem. Indeed, as Robert Desrosiers might be quick to add, we are seldom as we seem.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Antiwar Rallies; DAY OF PROTESTS IS THE BIGGEST YET
description: Invoking a specter of spiraling human and environmental costs, tens of thousands of demonstrators here and on the West Coast today engaged in the largest protests yet against the Persian Gulf war.

title: Travel Advisory; Help Needed On Projects
description: Volunteers are needed to spend two or three weeks this year assisting on projects of the Research Expeditions Program of the University of California at Berkeley. The projects range from a survey of plants and wildlife in a tropical forest in Costa Rica to a study of how white pelicans are endangered by pesticide runoffs in California's Klamath Basin. Archeological expeditions will take research teams fromm Montana to Mongolia; projects involving animals include sea creatures around Point Reyes, Calif.

title: In Three Districts, Parents Learn To Read to Help Their Children
description: IN what looks more like an Army barrack than a classroom, 13 adults took turns the other day reading an article about Charles Drew, a medical researcher who devised a method for extracting plasma for blood transfusions. Some read well; others stumbled.

title: The World; The Tough New Leaders in Moscow Have Kremlinologists Up and Guessing
description: THE classic Kremlinologist, a veteran practitioner of the trade once noted, divides knowledge about Moscow roughly into two categories: secrets and mysteries.

title: Horse Racing; Foot Injury Mars Unbridled's Plans
description: Thoroughbred racing, which in 1990 saw star horses suffer injuries and death, is opening 1991 on the same painful note.

title: Susan L. Jacobs Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Jacobs of Montpelier, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lea Jacobs, to Werner Scott O'Connell, the son of Anita Pittner O'Connell of Harrington Park, N.J., and Lawrence J. O'Connell of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Domi Gives Rangers Punch
description: Talking about fighting in polite and official hockey circles is like discussing X-rated films at the Acadamy Awards.

title: Wall Street; War Plays Bring Their Own Dangers
description: As long as there are wars, there will always be a profit-minded few whose fortunes are made by ministering to the needs of war. The 12-day-old war in the Persian Gulf is no exception.

title: Stacey Schiff Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Schiff of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stacey Beth Schiff to Daniel Andrew Kohl, a son of Allen Kohl of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Barbara Kohl-Spiro of Milwaukee. A summer wedding is planned. Miss Schiff, 25 years old, graduated from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in journalism from Northwestern University. Mr. Kohl, 25, graduated from Brown University and is studying law at the University of Wisconsin at Madison. His mother is an artist.

title: The Wedding; Wedding Belles
description: Here comes the bride -- beautiful, yes, and every bit her own woman. She's determined to put a personal stamp on her wedding. If she owns an etiquette book at all, chances are it's stashed in a drawer. In her book, wedding rules are meant to be bent. Who says a bride has to wear white? Weddings are the stuff of dreams, and bridal fantasies come in all shapes and colors. A sleek pink minidress or bright blue ruffled pants may suit your style better than the usual fairy-princess confection. Why commit to the standard solitaire and gold band? A simpler, one-ring affair -- perhaps an antique or a modern, sculptural band -- may fit your finger better. And who needs to settle for the watercress-sandwich solution to reception fare? An ethnic buffet with Cuban or Jamaican food may say a lot more about a couple's culinary sophistication. All this originality doesn't mean that people have fallen out of love with the wedding tradition itself. Far from it. Weddings factor into our lives -- and bank accounts, alas -- as much as they ever have. Still, couples do seem to be taking a more relaxed walk down the aisle -- and at their own pace.

title: The War's 3d-World Reverberations
description: What will be the economic and political effect of the gulf war on other countries? Benjamin Weiner, president of Probe International, a political risk-analysis firm in Stamford, Conn., is telling his corporate clients that much of the Middle East and the third world will be affected. The Philippines, Egypt and perhaps even Saudi Arabia may grow unstable as the war continues. Mr. Weiner discussed his views with Joel Kurtzman of the New York Times.

title: Hearty Stews and Casseroles Warm the Hearth
description: WINTER'S menus, whether for family or for entertaining, call for stews and casseroles. Dishes that can be set on the stove or in the oven to simmer or bake do not seem to be the bother in cold weather that they are in warm.

title:
ART;
Vibrant Glimpses of American Life From Black Printmakers
description: EVERY January, Black History Month opens windows onto American life and culture. One of the major exhibitions this year is "Black Printmakers and the W.P.A." at the Thomas J. Walsh Art Gallery at Fairfield University in Fairfield.

title: The Best of Breakthroughs
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Meet Families In Shanghai
description: Foreigners in Shanghai are being welcomed through a daylong tour in which they visit private citizens in their homes.

title: Shy Maidens, Cossack Thugs
description: To the Editor: Hilary de Vries's article "For Glasnost in the Arts, Blues in the Night" [ Jan. 13 ] , while pointing out some schlock in Soviet imports, failed to mention the outright propaganda nature. Perhaps the most egregious of these imports has been the Moiseyev troupe, which for three decades has been promoting the picture of happy Soviet ethnics busy doing their native dances. By now it has become a formula for Central Committee acceptance.

title: New Jersey Drivers Set A Record for Speeding
description: NEW JERSEY drivers broke the speed limit in record numbers last year, raising worries among transportation officials that the state may lose part of its Federal highway funds.

title: Soon Will Begin Appeals for Iraq's War Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Anchor for the Arts Rising in Stamford
description: WHEN the Stamford Center for the Arts opens its new 46,000-square-foot multimedia complex next September, organizers and supporters say, Atlantic Street will take its place as the entertainment center of southwestern Connecticut.

title: Oil's Inconvenient Bonanza
description: In almost any industry, a batch of quarterly earnings reports heralding huge profit gains would bring on buoyant appraisals from gleeful executives. But not Big Oil. Despite vigorous profit gains in the fourth quarter announced last week by several oil giants, few industry executives were celebrating.

title: IN SHORT/REFERENCE BOOKS
description: MAYO CLINIC FAMILY HEALTH BOOK Edited by David E. Larson. Morrow, $34.95.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Waltham, Mass.;
Countering The Trend
description: THE Bay Colony Office Park on Route 128, the high-tech beltway around the Boston metropolitan area, has opened its third office building here, bolstering the image of this city as one that is weathering the commercial real-estate storm better than many others.

title: The Importance of Hanukkah
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD: The Wedding; Wedding Bites
description: If the symbolic wedding feast of the early 1970's happened out of doors with barefoot guests and whole grains, and the 1980's found the wedding cast in huge hotel ballrooms with mountains of catered food, then the emerging pattern for the 90's is in some ways a return to a simpler time altogether -- when the ceremony took place in a house of worship, community hall or at home, and the reception was held on the lawn.

title: Lest We Forget the Battles on the Home Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Mount Holyoke; Finding History In Day-to-Day Life With the Pilgrims
description: Ten Mount Holyoke students have immersed themselves in their studies of 17th-century New England by taking on the identities of Pilgrims at the recreated Plimoth Plantation village in Plymouth, Mass.

title: East Hampton at Odds Over Landmark Pond
description: WHAT to do when a local landmark is in danger of becoming an embarrassment?

title: Johnson Shows Track's Ills
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mary Pat Lester to Wed Douglas H. Greeff in June
description: Ronald H. Lester of Kittaning, Pa., and Mrs. Mary L. Lester of Bath, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Patricia Lester to Douglas Haven Greeff, a son of Ernest Twyford Greeff of New York and the late Eugenie Haven Lee. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHILD OF THE MOVIES
description: Your article on Jodie Foster proves that she is as self-centered and sexist as every other feminist in this country ("Child of the Movies" by Jonathan Van Meter, Jan. 6).

title: School Boards Scrambling To Make Up For Aid Cuts
description: A DRASTIC cut in state school aid, announced last month, has forced local districts to develop immediate strategies to make up the difference for the current school year.

title: Lida E. Sunderland to Marry in April
description: The engagement of Lida Elizabeth Sunderland to Thomas Maurice Fitzgerald 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitzgerald Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Sunderland of Baltimore. An April wedding is planned.

title: Review/Theater; Miami's Cubans and Family Conflict
description: Raul de Cardenas's play "In Miami as It Is in Heaven" examines the generational conflicts among Cuban refugees living in Miami, and finds a spiritual void amid prosperity and cultural assimilation. The opening production of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's 24th season, the drama is set in 1985 and follows one tempestuous day in the life of a family that fled Cuba 20 years earlier.

title: Your Own Account; Should You Switch Policies?
description: With the insurance industry in turmoil, brokers may approach you, toting news reports of troubles in your company and urging you to change policies. Be careful. Brokers may be following their own agendas, and reports can be misleading.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Environment; Saudis Seek U.S. Help With Oil Spill
description: As the oil spill in the Persian Gulf threatened to force the closing of Saudi Arabia's largest desalting plant, the Saudi Government today turned to American companies to provide every available technology to halt its spread.

title: Back to the Future, With a Detour Through Miami
description: At a moment of supreme silliness in too much of the profession, Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk are by far the most interesting young architects practicing today. Their work neither deconstructs nor self-destructs. It makes sense. Working together out of Miami, Duany and Plater-Zyberk are coming close to bringing to fruition the most important contemporary movement in architecture. That movement is, of course, the revival of the vernacular and classical traditions and their reintegration into the mainstream of modern architecture in its fundamental aspect: the structure of communities, the building of towns.

title: Strings Show Their Strength
description: THE strings have it at concerts this week, starting today at 2 P.M., when the Gabrieli String Trio plays Beethoven's Opus 9 No. 1 in a free recital at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. Maintaining the English franchise, the ensemble will also be joined by Judith Pierce for the Flute Quartet by Nicholas Maw, a native of Lincolnshire, who will be present to discuss his music with his fellow composer Martin Bresnick, a Yale professor. For information, call 432-2850.

title: Panel Begins Overhaul of Education
description: AGAINST the unsettled and politically charged backdrop of school financing in New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio's new Quality Education Commission has started work on a major overhaul of the state's educational system.

title: Play It Again, Sviatoslav
description: Musical performance, that most immediate and most ephemeral of the arts, isn't easily fixed into the solid stuff of reference books, and THE ART OF THE PIANO: Its Performers, Literature, and Recordings (Summit, $40) doesn't entirely overcome the strain between its form and its subject. In the first section, which lists the seemingly innumerable pianists who have dazzled or importuned audiences since the beginnings of the modern piano in the 18th century, David Dubal, the music director of WNCN, a radio station in New York, concentrates less on the performers' biographies than on the elusive matter of their interpretive methods and styles. All the giants, as well as scores of lesser meteors, are here. But although Mr. Dubal is an erudite and insightful critic, the entries, with their cascades of adjectival evaluation (Josef Lhevinne is "inherently musical, aristocratic, and possessed of poise and balance"; Sviatoslav Richter the "most mercurial, intellectual, exasperating, and profound of all Soviet pianists"), read like reviews rendered frustratingly vague by being detached from their enlivening occasion. The second section, with its brief descriptions of piano compositions, accompanied by listings of Mr. Dubal's favorite recordings, is much more useful for anyone who wants an inclusive overview of the pianistic repertory.

title: American Disciple
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read John Russell's enthusiastic review of the "Raj" exhibition at London's National Portrait Gallery [ "A Dizzying Essay in Higher Education," Jan. 6 ] . All too often exhibitions that combine history and the arts are overlooked, so it is splendid to see the latest remarkable offering from the innovative London Gallery so prominently covered.

title: Meryl Maneker, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Morton M. Maneker of New York and Deanna M. Maneker of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Meryl Colle Maneker to Peter Charles Herman, a son of Philip E. Herman of Montreal and the late Florence Herman. A June wedding is planned.

title: World Markets; A Warning Flag Over New Zealand
description: New Zealand is a story of what can go wrong when a Government tries to do right economically in the rush to free markets.

title: Cost-Cutting Plan Inspires Question: Is Cheaper Better?
description: FROM the very beginning, in 1989, when the General Assembly appropriated $4 million for an independent report on improving the efficiency of state government while reducing state spending, the question nagged: would the report tell lawmakers and agency heads how to do things better, or simply how to operate on the cheap?

title: V.A.T.
description: To the Editor: Jean Gerlach's complaint (Letters, Nov. 18) regarding the lack of a V.A.T. refund in Ireland reminded me of our visit in 1989 to a Naf Naf store near St. Eustache in Paris where we spent several hundred dollars and charged it to our MasterCard. The clerk completed the refund papers for us and imprinted my card on a credit voucher. At the airport our forms were completed by the Customs officials and we mailed them back to the store. Six months later, however, after a letter to the store and two faxes to the president of Naf Naf in Paris, we still had not received the refund. It was only thanks to our bank, First USA, that we finally got our money. (Forms mailed the same day to Galleries Lafayette were processed immediately.)

title: ECUADOR FIGHTING TO AVOID DRUG LINK
description: Sandwiched between Colombia, the world's largest cocaine refiner, and Peru, the world's largest coca leaf grower, tiny Ecuador is fighting to keep out of South America's drug trade.

title: Katharine Dyckman, a Buyer, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hamilton Dyckman Jr. of Skillman, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katharine Stuart Dyckman to Peter Gerard Benziger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph Benziger of Bronxville, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Nontalking Heads: A Gallery Of Portraits
description: Oscar Wilde looks characteristically outrageous. Virginia Woolf looks uncharacteristically demure. And Queen Victoria looks, well, Victorian.

title: Alan Salzberg to Wed Lisa Smith in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Smith of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Shari Smith to Alan Jay Salzberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Salzberg of Columbia, S.C. An August wedding is planned.

title: Andrea Weitman to Marry
description: Andrea Weitman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Weitman of Wantagh, L.I., is to be married in July to Elliot Simon, a son of Helen Simon of Youngstown, Ohio, and Norman Simon of New York. The bridegroom, a graduate of the University of Chicago, is the president of Vital Transportation, a limousine service in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Amy Frothingham, Executive, Weds George W. Ford 3d, Software Designer
description: Cornelia Amory Frothingham and George Whitmarsh Ford 3d were married yesterday at St. John's Church in Beverly Farms, Mass. The Rev. Cynthia Kittredge performed the Episcopal ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bainbridge Frothingham Jr. of Manchester, Mass. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ford 2d of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: The Specter of Capitalism
description: THE ANTI-COMMUNIST MANIFESTO Whom to Help in Russia. Edited by Lev Timofeyev. Translated by Vitaly Kisin and Oleg Glebov. Foreword by Richard Pipes. 96 pp. Bellevue, Wash.: Free Enterprise Press. Paper, $7.95.

title: Q and A
description: 'Last Minute' Cruise Space

title: The Painful, Essential Images of War
description: In October of 1862, just a few days after the bloodiest single day of fighting in the Civil War, when there had been more than 25,000 casualties, Mathew Brady opened an exhibition of photographs at his New York gallery, titled "The Dead of Antietam." Nothing like them had ever been seen in America before. There, next to familiar roads and fields and peach orchards, were Americans, stiff, with arms outstretched, bloated and contorted, heaped in sunken roads or lined to the horizon in cornfields and in front of pacifist churches, dead.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Cut branches from early-flowering shrubs and trees such as forsythia, crabapple and flowering cherry to force indoors for a hint of spring. Discard older catalogues as new ones arrive. Study garden books and continue making plans.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday showing major military units in the Persian Gulf area omitted in some copies a United States Navy battle group and an estimate of the number of forces from the Gulf Cooperation Council and local Arab states. The Navy formations included the Kennedy battle group. The estimated number of troops arrayed against Iraq from the Gulf Cooperation Council and other local Arab forces is 144,000. The chart referred incorrectly in some copies to a guided missile cruiser in the America battle group. It is the Normandy, not the Ticonderoga.

title: Troops in the Gulf Eager to View Game
description: Most United States soldiers with access to television sets will be able to watch the Super Bowl early Monday morning to get a little taste of Americana and get their minds briefly off the Persian Gulf war.

title: 2 Suspects Sought in 2 Series Of Bronx and Queens Rapes
description: The police are seeking a rapist they believe is responsible for attacking and robbing six women in the Bronx and another man who has sexually assaulted four women and girls in Queens.

title: Consumers And the Sound Of Silence
description: The American consumer, whose willingness to spend has repeatedly confounded bearish forecasters, may finally be refusing to pay out the cash -- or the plastic.

title: 9 Power Plays Frustrate Devils
description: Two nights after they ended a monthlong misery of 11 games without a victory, the Devils fell to their losing ways again tonight, suffering a 3-1 setback to the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Where Has Progress Got Us?
description: THE TRUE AND ONLY HEAVEN Progress and Its Critics. By Christopher Lasch. 591 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: Urban-Suburban Scenes and Unlikely Shapes
description: AT the Morris Museum here there are shows by Harry Devlin, Robert Birmelin and John van Alstine. The lineup is probably fortuitous but, in the case of the two painters, seems calculated,; Mr. Devlin's theme being the suburban idyll, Mr. Birmelin's the urban nightmare.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Iraqi Leaders; Very Tight Inner Circle Surrounds Iraq's President
description: When it comes to political maneuvering or military strategy, Saddam Hussein is his own best adviser.

title: A Children's Dictionary? Don't Leave It to the Experts
description: For an unpracticed child, looking up a word in the dictionary is like finding your feet stuck in a bad dream. You can't get anywhere, even with wolves snapping at your heels to hurry things up. The word is always somewhere else. After fumbling along the boggy paths of alphabetical order to find the word, children face yet another mire. The dictionary inevitably offers either more than they wanted to know -- at least more options than they wanted to read and write down on assignment -- or less than they wanted to know for information outside of assignments.

title: Sports People; Break for Nicklaus
description: It has been so long since a United States Open was held without Jack Nicklaus in the field, the tournament's organizers probably wouldn't know how to hold one without him. That helps explain why the four-time Open champion has been granted an exemption to play in the 1991 Open at the Hazeltine National Course in Chaska, Minn., in June without meeting the usual qualifications.

title: Poland's Jester in Chief
description: NEW WORLD AVENUE AND VICINITY. By Tadeusz Konwicki. Translated by Walter Arndt. Drawings by the author. 212 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.95.

title: Emily J. Ceisler, Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Ceisler of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Emily Joanne Ceisler to Mark Lawrence Blitzer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Blitzer of Scotch Plains, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: One That Got Away
description: To the Editor: Paul Goldberger's article "The Important Things Were What Didn't Happen" [ Dec. 30 ] at first glance led me to believe that at last I was going to see an expose of significant building projects thwarted in 1990 by economic paranoia, political pettiness or a combination of the two. But alas, only one of the "did not happens" was lamented.

title: Loopy in the Lake District
description: THE OLD CONTEMPTIBLES By Martha Grimes. 333 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.
