title: No Football? No Problem
description: In biblical literature and the writings of ancient Greeks, there is mention of a game involving kicking around a ball. Cultures as diverse as Polynesians and Eskimos have played forms of football. At least twice, Shakespeare used the word football.

title: Headliners; Family Tradition
description: The birth control movement in the United States could be said to have begun in 1912 when a young mother, who had tried to give herself an abortion, died in her nurse's arms. The nurse's name was Margaret Sanger and she went on to found the National Birth Control League, which became Planned Parenthood. Last month, her grandson, a former Wall Street lawyer named Alexander C. Sanger, was elected president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood of New York City. "With all her success, my grandmother left some unfinished business, and I intend to finish it," he said. This year the United States Supreme Court will rule on a challenge to regulations barring groups that receive Federal family-planning money from discussing abortion with their clients. "We will close down rather than stop counseling about abortion," Mr. Sanger said. "But I will vigorously go to the state, the city and private funders and get every penny I can to keep our clinics going."

title: THE LAST DAYS OF HERMAN ROTH
description: Philip Roth's memory of his father, Herman, was moving ("The Last Days of Herman Roth," Dec. 30). His words brought to mind my own recollection of Herman Roth. One day in 1982, when I was a rabbi in Miami, a secretary interrupted the weekly staff meeting to inform me that a Mr. Herman Roth was there to see me. Further questioning revealed that he was the father of the writer, Philip Roth. I went out to meet him, and he said, "I hear that you gave my son's latest book a wonderful review at a Sisterhood meeting last week and I want you to have this autographed copy of one of his books."

title: Few Bargains for Early Birds at Antiques Show
description: The 37th annual Winter Antiques Show -- the Super Bowl of high-ticket bazaars -- kicked off genteely on Friday with collectors and connoissers vying for furniture, armor, carpets, tapestries, quilts and such.

title: You Can Look It Up
description: Everything in the world exists in order that it may end up in a book, wrote the poet Mallarme (cleverly anticipating a subsequent and more famous mot, "You could look it up," by the eminent sage Casey Stengel). That, probably, is as good a reason as any to explain why American publishing can now boast "The Klingon Dictionary" (Pocket Books, $4.95), a handy grammar/lexicon enabling fans of "Star Trek" to chew the fat in syntactically accurate guttural-brute style. ("Finally!" says the jacket copy.) Trekkies can choose from a pretranslated list of Useful Klingon Expressions ("Four thousand throats may be cut in one night by a running man," "Where is the bathroom?") or, with a little practice, construct their own (e.g., "yISug yIn," "Get a life").

title: Yale Repertory's Winterfest: 'A Terrific Showcase'
description: WHATEVER its merits or demerits, Yale Repertory's Winterfest 11 is bound to be remembered for a surprise debut and a notable farewell.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Laurens, S.C.; Two Boons For Economy
description: TWO large distribution centers -- one under construction and another built two years ago -- have given the economy of this northwestern South Carolina city a jumpstart.

title: The World; Japan Counts the Costs Of Gulf Action -- or Inaction
description: AS surely as it is for the United States, Japan's response to the gulf war is seen increasingly as a defining moment for Tokyo in the post-cold-war world order. That response so far has been marked by anguished debates about what Japan's role should be, with its actions until now limited to some financial aid and the promise of more. But perhaps the most striking aspect of Japan's behavior is the growing perception that the Japanese see little at stake for themselves in the war's outcome, despite their dependence on Middle East oil.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Johnson Finally Wins: Ben Johnson tasted victory for the first time since his suspension in 1988 for taking steroids when he captured the 55-meter dash at the Ottawa Winternational Indoor Games last night. Johnson won a close race with a time of 6.20 seconds, breaking the Canadian record of 6.21. Johnson was competing for the third time since he was suspended after failing a drug test at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. Brian Morrison of Canada was second in 6.21. (Reuters) N.H.L. Canadiens' Streak at 4: Russ Courtnall and Stephan Lebeau scored their 17th goals of the season yesterday as the Canadiens beat the Buffalo Sabres, 4-1, in Montreal and extended their winning streak to four games. (AP) Bruins 5, Flames 2: Cam Neely, Ken Hodge and Glen Wesley scored first-period goals and the Bruins went on to beat the Calgary Flames in Boston for their fifth victory in the last six games. (AP) Skiing Kronberger Aims for 5 Medals: Petra Kronberger of Austria started her attempt for an unprecedented five medals at the world Alpine championships in Saalbach-Hinterglemm, Austria, yesterday by striking gold in the downhill. Kronberger, who was timed in 1 minute 29.12 seconds over the 2,361-meter course, defeated Nathalie Bouvier of France by nearly half a second. (AP) Figure Skating Soviet Team Takes 3d Title in Row: Marina Klimova and Sergei Ponomarenko of the Soviet Union won the ice dance title for the third consecutive time at the European championships yesterday in Sofia, Bulgaria. A first-place finish in free dance moved them past the French pair of Paul and Isabelle Duchesnay, who led after the original dance part of the competition. (AP) Horse Racing Killer Diller Wins: Killer Diller, with Julie Krone riding for the injured Angel Cordero Jr., rallied off the far turn yesterday to win the $89,400 Assault Handicap at Aqueduct. Killer Diller carried 114 pounds to a 1 3/4-length victory in the event for 3-year-olds and up. The 4-year-old covered 1 1/8 miles on the fast track in 1:50.2 to earn $53,640 for his owner, Barry K. Schwartz. He paid $9.80, $4.20 and $2.80 for $2 in winning for sixth time in 16 career starts. (AP) College Football West Defeats East, 24-21: Robbie Keen of California kicked a 24-yard field goal with 2 minutes 17 seconds remaining yesterday in Stanford, Calif., and the West defeated the East in the 66th annual East-West Shrine Game. Henry Jones of Illinois intercepted a pass by San Diego State's Dan McGwire and ran 39 yards for an East touchdown, tying the score at 21-21 with 2:32 left in the third quarter. Roman Phifer, a linebacker from U.C.L.A., intercepted a halfback pass by Louisiana State's Harvey Williams at the East 41 to set up the West's final drive. (AP) Golf Fast Finish for Henke: Nolan Henke birdied three of the final four holes for a 5-under-par 66 and a four-stroke lead over Robert Wrenn after the third round of the frost-plagued Phoenix Open in Scottsdale, Ariz., yesterday. The 26-year-old Henke has a 16-under 197 total heading into today's final. (AP) High School Basketball St. Anthony Wins Tourney: Roderick Rhodes, the tournament's most valuable player, had 25 points and 5 rebounds to lead St. Anthony of Jersey City (15-1) to a 65-40 victory over Lincoln of Brooklyn (12-4) yesterday in the championship of the second annual Metro Classic at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: MacLeod Makes Quinnett Ewing's Sub
description: The Knicks, who had already tried five different starting lineups this season, planned to try another one tonight.

title: Sports People; Rocket Is Hot
description: He may be the brightest prospect on the horizon, but the New England Patriots, who have the first pick in the 1991 National Football League draft, better think twice before making Raghib (the Rocket) Ismail their No. 1 choice.

title: An Unexpectedly Moving 'Menagerie'
description: EVERYONE expects to be moved by "The Glass Menagerie," but not so unexpectedly as in Emily Mann's exceptional production at the McCarter Theater here.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: Amy Hart to Wed Timothy M. Clyne
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Hart of Bedford Village, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Elizabeth Hart to Timothy Michael Clyne, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Clyne of Brooklyn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Homeless Group Proposes a Tax
description: The Partnership for the Homeless yesterday proposed a $300 million tax surcharge on large businesses in New York City to avoid social-service cuts and help provide housing and social services.

title: Airline and Tour Packager Liable in Nile Cruise Fire
description: TRAVEL law in New York State took a further step in the consumers' direction in November when a jury found an airline responsible for negligence in a 1983 fire that sank a Nile cruise boat used by the airline's packager. Two women who swam ashore holding a deck chair sued Trans World Airlines and the tour packager for personal injuries, charging negligence because the T.W.A. brochure said the airline had inspected the vessel. The airline's defense cited the brochure's small type, which, as is usual in tours combining more than one element, disclaimed any responsibility for actions of independent contractors.

title: Laura Schneeman Wed To Justin H. C. Lord
description: Laura Danielle Schneeman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Schneeman of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Justin Herent Caladine Lord, a son of Justice and Mrs. John H. Lord of Greenfield, Oldham, England. The Rev. Leonard Di Nola performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church in Buchanan, N.Y.

title:
Northeast Notebook: North Conway, N.H.;
Homeseeker Weekends
description: FACED with a slumping real estate market and too many homes for sale in this skiiing and hiking vacationland, lending institutions have taken to sponsoring "homeseeker weekends" to attract buyers.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portland, Ore.;
20-Year Plan for Railyard
description: A LOCAL development partnership has bought a little-used 48-acre railyard -- the largest undeveloped parcel in downtown Portland -- and plans over the next 20 years to turn it into a mixed-use neighborhood of housing, office buildings and shops.

title: Less-Than-Zero Defects
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday showing major nations in the Middle East labeled Iran's Government incorrectly. It is an Islamic republic controlled by Shiite Muslim clerics, not by Sunnis.

title: Teen-Ager Befriended By Police Chief Is Slain
description: A troubled teen-ager who found a fatherly friend four years ago in the man who was then Police Chief of this violence-plagued city has been shot to death.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CHILDREN'S TALES

title: Everything You Want to Know About Everything
description: THE CAMBRIDGE ENCYCLOPEDIAEdited by David Crystal.Illustrated. 1,478 pp. New York:Cambridge University Press. $49.50.THE RANDOM HOUSE ENCYCLOPEDIAEdited by James Mitchell and Jess Stein.Illustrated. 2,911 pp. New York:Random House. $129.95.

title: Virginia Cheston To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Cheston Jr. of Topsfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Cheston, to Kenneth Bryan Spencer Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer of Barrington, Ill. A May wedding is planned.

title: 'I Never Was an Ingenue'
description: 'I HAVE ALWAYS HAD A PROBLEM WITH MY weight," Kathy Bates says matter-of-factly. "I'm not a stunning woman. I never was an ingenue; I've always just been a character actor. When I was younger it was a real problem, because I was never pretty enough for the roles that other young women were being cast in. The roles I was lucky enough to get were real stretches for me: usually a character who was older, or a little weird, or whatever. And it was hard, not just for the lack of work but because you have to face up to how people are looking at you. And you think, 'Well, y'know, I 'm a real person.' " She gives a bubbling laugh of embarrassment.

title: Samba Takes a Back Seat to Spectacle
description: Every Saturday night, people from northeastern Brazil gather here at one of the world's most tuneful open-air markets. The Feria Nordestino (Northeastern Fair) sprawls over a plaza in Sao Cristovao, and it certainly beats any shopping mall. After buying goat cheese, sun-dried beef or corn-flour sweets, homesick Brazilians from states like Pernambuco and Paraiba can sit back with a beer at taverns made of scaffolding and plastic tarpaulins. There, all the way until Sunday afternoon, they can listen and dance to northeastern forro (bouncy songs for accordion, triangle and drum) or pagode (samba-flavored party music featuring percussion, miniature guitar or banjo).

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Opera's Uncanny Delights How is it that opera can move us so? Robert Donington argues that it works by evoking the most basic elements in our nature. This is from "Opera and Its Symbols: The Unity of Words, Music, and Staging" (Yale University).

title: Interstates
description: To the Editor: In discussing problems along Interstate 95 from New York to Florida ("All Roads Lead to Disney World, Slowly," Practical Traveler, Nov. 18) I'm surprised that Betsy Wade didn't mention I-81 as an excellent alternative route. Unlike I-95, I-81 has no major construction, no tolls and plenty of scenery as it follows Virginia's Shenandoah Valley.

title: Impure Thoughts About Dorothy Lamour
description: EVENINGS AT MONGINI'S And Other Stories. By Russell Lucas. 262 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: Replacing Fluorescent Lights
description: FLUORESCENT lights are more efficient than incandescent ones, but are also more complicated. Because of this, replacing the bulb, usually called a tube, when a light malfunctions is not always effective. In fact, even if the tube is more than a year old, the chances that it is solely at fault are slim.

title: Headliners; Fugitive Fiduciary
description: Shortly after New Year, Steven J. Romer, a Manhattan lawyer, sent letters to some of his clients informing them that he wasn't giving back the millions of dollars they had entrusted to him. "Your money is no longer available, I am sorry to say," he wrote. "I used the money to feed some hungry and poverty-stricken people." He went on to say that he had an inoperable brain tumor and no more than two months to live. All told, investigators for the Manhattan District Attorney's office say, Mr. Romer is accused of stealing as much as $25 million from as many as 40 clients before fleeing to Sierra Leone, where he is said to have an interest in some gold mines. David Halperin, a lawyer who knows Mr. Romer, said he had no reason to believe that his friend was ill. "I saw him at a Christmas party, and he seemed O.K. to me," Mr. Halperin said. "He was a fine lawyer and a model parent and a good guy in every respect. His family is completely bereft, as am I. In my wildest imagination I wouldn't have thought him capable of anything like this."

title: Sunday Outing; A Scenic Overlook on Great Americans
description: The busts of 10 American Presidents can be found in the Bronx. So can the likenesses of Nathaniel Hawthorne, Thomas Edison and Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.

title:
FOCUS;
Away From It All Close to Downtown Philadelphia
description: Daniel and Patricia Lieberman used to own a 4,000-square-foot home built in the stone shell of a factory that made cannonballs in rural Chester County outside Philadelphia. Their new home is half the size but equally unusual: a condominium town house near the end of a 67-year-old pier jutting 500 feet into the Delaware River.

title: Review/Opera; New Tenor in 'Zauberflote'
description: The cast of the Metropolitan Opera's lovely new production of "Die Zauberflote" is being kept pretty well together for the current run of performances. One exception is the role of Tamino. Peter Kazaras, the American tenor, has been singing Tamino on some evenings, and he did so again on Wednesday night.

title:
Gardening;
Consider the Honeybees When Making Plans for Planting
description: The seed catalogues are coming and their arrival signals the beginning of another year of pleasure in growing a garden. Although spring's arrival may be a few weeks away, the time has come to begin the happy task of planning.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 27, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran, stationed in Sioux country, adopts the ways of the Indians. 2 3 MYSTERY, by Peter Straub. (Signet, $5.95.) A bright young man and an elderly eccentric join hands to solve a murder that haunts them both. 3 37 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 4 5 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) Two Navajo tribal policemen pursue a mystery involving ceremonial masks. 5 23 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) An author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 6 10 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes of his behavior. 7 15 THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $5.95.) Espionage changes its ways as glasnost begins to rust the Iron Curtain. 8 * 6 SLEEPWALK, by John Saul. (Bantam, $5.95.) A madman with terrifying powers haunts the teen-agers of a quiet New Mexican desert town. 9 5 THE GIFT, by Julie Garwood. (Pocket, $5.50.) After a long absence the husband of a onetime child-bride returns to provide her with romance and mysteries to solve. 10 8 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Ancient documents and arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 11 1 PROBABLE CAUSE, by Ridley Pearson. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) A police detective strives to solve a string of murders staged to look like suicide. 12 1 THE CONQUEST, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $5.50.) Romance bonds two long-feuding feudal families in 15th-century England. 13 18 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 14 * 14 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former prosecutor defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 15 1 HARMFUL INTENT, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $5.50.) A physician struggles to clear his name in a "medical malpractice" death. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 62 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 2 NOT WITHOUT MY DAUGHTER, by Betty Mahmoody with William Hoffer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An American woman held captive in Iran. 3 24 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 4 379 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 5 20 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian remembers her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 6 9 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Cliff Stoll. (Pocket, $5.95.) Stalking a computer hacker. 7 33 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 8 * 7 EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.95.) The author recalls places he visited and books he read in his youth. 9 * 18 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's. 10 118 LOVE, MEDICINE, AND MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper Perennial, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 11 * 1 THE BROKEN CORD, by Michael Dorris. (Harper Perennial, $9.95.) A family's struggle with fetal alcohol syndrome. 12 * 13 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder. (Avon, $9.95.) A year in the life of a teacher. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 9 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 2 6 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1991. (World Almanac/Pharos, $6.95.) The latest edition of a standard reference work. 3 7 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. 4 117 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. 5 1 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $7.95.) The 1991 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Reveling in Quebec City's Winter
description: IT'S snowing, the sidewalks are icy and the temperature is around zero. Why on earth would anyone want to be in Quebec City at this time of year? For a start, precisely because it's midwinter. Even summer's best moments cannot match the magic of crunching through fresh snow after dark along the boardwalk in front of the Chateau Frontenac Hotel, the grande dame of Quebec City.

title: Norbert Bogdan, 87, An Investment Banker
description: Norbert A. Bogdan, an investment banking executive, died on Thursday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Tyringham, Mass.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Closter 240,000 36 New Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old colonial; pool, fenced property, full basement; taxes $5,276. Freehold 136,000 14 Helen Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, eat- in-kitchen, fireplace, h/w floors; taxes $2,147. Jackson 116,000 22 New Castle Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; patio, w/w carpeting, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $3,653. Manalapan 224,000 1 Winfield Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; 2-car garage, c/a, family room, patio, w/w carpeting; taxes $4,435. Ridgewood 400,000 245 Lott Road 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 36-year-old custom-built split level; h/w floors, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $8,588. Springfield 270,000 120 Laurel Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 43-year-old split level; c/a, 1-car garage, deck, den; taxes $4,540. OTHER AREAS Avon, Conn. 265,000 76 Paper Chase Trail 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, new kitchen, period details, 1.3 acres; taxes $3,646. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 285,000 466 Fisher Pond Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, deck; taxes $7,638. Great River 253,000 119 Widgeon Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old ranch; fireplace, great room, c/a, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,400.

title: Campus Life: Brigham Young; A Helping Hand To Hard-Pressed In Soviet Union
description: What started as a letter to the editor of Brigham Young University's student newspaper has turned into a small crusade by two professors to send money and food to hard-pressed Soviet citizens.

title: New Fabrics Give New Look to Parkas
description: Ski parkas with sleek, subdued classical lines are taking the fashion lead.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany; ANTI-WAR PROTEST IS STAGED IN BONN
description: Thousands of anti-war protesters from throughout Germany converged on Bonn today to show their opposition to war in the Persian Gulf.

title: This Show Plays Right In the Store
description: Think of it as a sort of Cable News Network for video stores. Later this year Video News Network, or VNN, is scheduled to begin broadcasting a daily three-hour variety show in stores around the country. The idea is to promote video generally and certain titles specifically. In this case, though, the program arrives by direct broadcast satellite.

title: Wall Street; Performance, Following the War-Fed Euphoria
description: The bounce in world stock markets on the first day of the war gave even the weakest of equities a lift. Auto stocks, down 30 percent last year, were up 6.7 percent, according to the Financial Times World Index. Oil and gold stocks were the worst performers, with oils up just 1.1 percent and gold down 4.35 percent.

title: Redmen Get Scare, But They Survive
description: St. John's ran up a couple of 11-point leads on Villanova in the second half today, then just barely managed to hold on for a 58-55 Big East victory before a crowd of 13,615 at the Spectrum. For Lou Carnesecca, coach of the Redmen, it was career victory No. 499. It was not exactly a pretty one, but that didn't faze the coach.

title: Companion Fares
description: To the Editor: Upon delivery of The New York Times on Nov. 19 I responded to Delta's newly advertised companion fare to Atlanta from Hartford-Springfield, and return, for Jan. 25 and 27, nine and a half weeks ahead. Only off-peak seats, midmorning going and late evening return, were available at the advertised rate. The ad nowhere mentioned that peak-time seats were not included.

title: Did Hollywood Sit on 'Fences'?
description: No one in Hollywood sets out to make a bad movie. It's like raising a child -- everyone involved wants to do the right thing. In the case of the long-delayed production of "Fences," August Wilson's Pulitzer Prize-winning 1987 play, both Eddie Murphy, the film's producer, and Paramount Pictures, the company financing the move from stage to screen, insist they want what's best for the film.

title: A Rest for Parents of the Disabled
description: IT was only three days, but for James and Kathleen Kiernan of Valhalla it was the perfect vacation. The Kiernans, who have a severely disabled child, recently spent a free weekend at the Marriott Hotel in Tarrytown, as part of the "Respitality" program organized by United Cerebral Palsy of Westchester, based in Purchase.

title: Treasures From the Jeweler to All the Kings
description: A gold cigarette case designed as an envelope addressed by Sir Winston Churchill to his son Randolph S. Churchill, in Kent, is a tour de force of design typical of many objects from Cartier's golden age. Commissioned as a present from Churchill for Randolph's 21st birthday, the case bears an enameled 1 1/2-cent stamp of George V, canceled on June 20, 1932.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: As far as spending is concerned, whoever came up with the phrase "we've gone from an era of swashbuckling to one of belt-buckling," had it down pat, although perhaps belt-tightening might have been more apt. The fact is that even the people who are not worried about money or affected by the economy are cutting down, watching what they spend and thinking several times before they do it. It's not only that untrammeled extravagance is now beyond bad taste; it's a general feeling that restraint is both in and desirable.

title: Laura Levine to Marry Kenneth Silver
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Levine of North Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Jill Levine to Kenneth Lawrence Silver, a son of Jane Silver of White Plains and the late Dr. Lawrence Silver. A July wedding is planned.

title: Perspectives: The Cooper Square Plan; Smoothing the Path to Redevelopment
description: NO love was lost between former Mayor Edward I. Koch and the Cooper Square Community Development Committee and Businessmen's Association. For that matter, the association has had its differences with mayors and housing commissioners for 31 years.

title: U.S. Plan on Child Care Is Reported to Be Stalled
description: For almost a year, Nicole McDaniel has worked nights and weekends as a registration clerk at St. Anthony Medical Center here. With the help of a state subsidy for child care, she can leave her daughter, Stacie, at Northside Child Development Center, one of a handful of such centers in the nation that are open seven days a week, 24 hours a day.

title: Stella Levy to Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Levy of Mount Vernon, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Stella Ancie Levy, and David Alan Ball, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Ball of Albany. Miss Levy, 22 years old, and her fiance, 24, are cum laude graduates of Brandeis University. She is an elementary-school teacher in Mount Vernon. The future bridegroom expects to receive a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania in May.

title: Man's Body Is Found In a Bay in Brooklyn
description: The body of a man was found in 15 feet of water at the edge of Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: A June Wedding For Ann Seaman
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Cann Seaman of Savannah, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Barnard Seaman, to Andrew Robert Rogerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Walker Rogerson of Old Lyme, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Soviet Envoy, in U.S., Voices Worry at Conduct of War
description: Soviet Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ended two and a half hours of talks today with the Foreign Minister voicing the first official Soviet doubts over the way the United States has conducted the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Postings: Park Ave. at 38th; Japanese Hotel Growing
description: After 18 years of operation, the Kitano Hotel -- the first hotel in New York owned by Japanese -- has embarked on a significant expansion that will nearly double the size of its building at Park Avenue and 38th Street.

title: Irene Sinrich to Marry Mark T. Sudac
description: Irene Leslie Sinrich, a vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Bank, and Mark Thomas Sudac, a vice president of IBJ Schroeder Bank, both in New York, plan to be married in March. The prospective bride is the daughter of Phyllis Sinrich of Stamford, Conn., and Norman Sinrich of New York. Mr. Sudac is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Sudac of Branford, Conn.

title: Heather Stanton, Banker, Is Wed
description: Heather Anne Stanton and Daniel Lynn Mosley were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York in a ceremony performed by the Rev. J. Seymour Flinn.

title: Bill Requires the Use Of Alternative Fuels
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has signed legislation intended to reduce air pollution by requiring the city to begin purchasing vehicles using fuels that burn more cleanly than gasoline and diesel fuel.

title: 2 Families in 24-Hour Race
description: That leading motor sports establishment, Andretti & Sons, will be doing business next weekend, driving a Porsche 962C in the SunBank 24-hour race at Daytona Beach, Fla. And, as might be expected, the junior member will have the tough jobs handed to him.

title: Facing Up, Finally, To Bach's Dark Vision
description: And now for something altogether unreviewable: 83 compact disks containing almost 200 church cantatas by Johann Sebastian Bach as recorded by Teldec over an 18-year period (13 years longer than it took to write them) by a who's who of early-music virtuosos under the joint direction of Gustav Leonhardt and Nikolaus Harnoncourt.

title: Sin Has Come a Long Way Since 1939
description: PERCHANCE TO DREAM Robert B. Parker's Sequel to Raymond Chandler's "The Big Sleep." By Robert B. Parker. 271 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: A la Carte: Economizing
description: LONG ISLAND restaurants and diners have the recession blues. People are dining out less, apparently as a result of the tight economy.

title: Headliners; Found Guilty
description: Sarah Smith, a 43-year-old social worker, does not dispute that she shot her husband, Owen, in the head with his .25-caliber pistol as he lay resting on a bed in their South Bronx apartment, or that she wrapped his body in two blankets, put it in the trunk of her car and dumped it in an abandoned schoolyard in Yonkers. But she says she acted in self defense. For three years, she testified in her trial in State Supreme Court in the Bronx, he abused and threatened her; one morning, she said, she woke up staring into the barrel of a gun. But she wasn't able to convince the jury that the killing was justified. Last week, on the third day of deliberations, she was convicted of second-degree murder. Her lawyer, Michael G. Dowd, who has successfully defended half a dozen battered women who killed their husbands or lovers, said he was astounded by the verdict. "I have never in 24 years been so shocked by a verdict," he said. One juror, interviewed as he was leaving the court, had a simple explanation for the trial's outcome: "We didn't believe her."

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; As Allies Use Its Bases, Ankara Faces an Implicit Threat From Iraq
description: Having allowed its territory to be used as a second front in the air war against neighboring Iraq, Turkey is now living under an implicit Iraqi threat of attack.

title: Roosevelt Island
description: To the Editor:

title: The Films Are Fine (Food's Good, Too)
description: Would that it were in every American home: the VCR with a built-in microwave oven. Such a breakthrough in video-cuisine technology would make it possible for couch potatoes to pig out on both food and videos without ever leaving the living room. Until science shows the way, we must make do with a bagful of foodie films.

title: Streetscapes: Chapel of the Sisters; Fighting to Save a Decaying 19th-Century Treasure
description: THE story is a familiar one of struggle: A small group forms to reclaim a forgotten, overgrown cemetery.

title: Sports People; Mayor on Giants' Side
description: He may or may not have inside information, but for the record, this is today's sole entry on the official public schedule for Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York: "6:00 P.M. Attends the victory of the New York Giants in the 1991 Super Bowl. Tampa Stadium -- Tampa, Florida (Skybox #7)". . . . Doug Williams, the former Washington Redskins quarterback and Super Bowl star, has been named athletic director and head football coach at Point Coupee Central High School in New Roads, La. . . . Mouse Davis, who was hired by Coach Wayne Fontes to supervise the Detroit Lions' run-and-shoot offense, said he was leaving the team after being told by Fontes that he planned to scrap the offense. . . . Johnny Most, who retired in December after more than 30 years as the Boston Celtics' play-by-play announcer, was hospitalized on Thursday complaining of shortness of breath and chest pains, symptoms his wife later attributed to complications related to chronic bronchitis and emphysema. . . . Ricky Sanders, the Redskin wide receiver accused of running over a parking lot attendant in Houston last May, gained a postponement in his scheduled trial, from tomorrow to Feb. 25, so the Oiler quarterback, Warren Moon, could be called as a defense witness.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our screened porch has a slate floor. There are some paint spots on it, and the floor is rather dusty. We would like to apply a sealer, but we want to remove the paint spots first. How would you suggest we go about it?

title: Choices for Beginning Another Season
description: NOW that catalogues are arriving and gardeners are making plans, newcomers may be looking for some help. If plants are selected with careful thought and set out with attention to their needs, they should provide splendid results.

title: A Singer Sways To Beat From Rio
description: ONE singer flew in from Paris, one from Bahia and two from Rio de Janeiro. But all Kenia had to do to show up for her star turn in a festival of Brazilian music in Manhattan was take the Long Island Expressway.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 27, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) On the eve of his retirement, a member of British intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy. 2 2 15 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age. 3 1 COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan. 4 5 9 DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and romantic life of an eighth-generation California woman who becomes a celebrity photographer. 5 3 12 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 6 4 20 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 7 6 9 JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician's use of genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park threatens to become a global emergency. 8 9 6 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets. 9 1 BATTLEGROUND, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $19.95.) The experiences of Marine corpsmen from Midway to Guadalcanal. 10 * 12 2 VITAL SIGNS, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $21.95.) A physician's quest for fertility brings her horrifying adventures in America, Australia and China. 11 7 23 MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 12 8 33 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death. 13 10 3 THE FOURTH K, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $22.) The tumultuous career of President Francis Xavier Kennedy, cousin of John and Robert Kennedy and inheritor of their charisma. 14 1 CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 2 3 16 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 3 1 11 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The memoirs of the itinerant television newscaster. 4 5 11 BO KNOWS BO, by Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The autobiography of the athlete who plays baseball for the Kansas City Royals and football for the Los Angeles Raiders. 5 * 4 2 THE NEW RUSSIANS, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A former Moscow correspondent surveys the profound changes in the Soviet Union during the past 15 years. 6 7 25 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The memoirs of the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House. 8 12 2 THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The nature of God and salvation as perceived by Christian, Jewish and Muslim children. 9 8 15 THE CAT AND THE CURMUDGEON, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) The continuing contentions of two curmudgeons. 10 10 11 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. 11 9 19 GET TO THE HEART, by Barbara Mandrell with George Vecsey. (Bantam, $19.95.) The autobiography of the country-music singer. 12 * 15 11 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $8.95.) An illustrated gift edition of the inspirational essay, with new commentary. 13 11 3 GOD, COUNTRY, NOTRE DAME, by Theodore M. Hesburgh with Jerry Reedy. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The autobiography of the theologian and former president of the University of Notre Dame. 14 * 1 PATRIMONY, by Philip Roth. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The novelist tells of his father's struggle with a fatal brain tumor. 15 13 14 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 8 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about managing your money. 2 2 24 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you and use it to deal with today's problems. 3 3 96 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Financial advice. 4 4 8 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. 5 5 58 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrated games.
