The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Jan. 13 misstated the toll-free telephone number for Bergen Line cruises. It is (800) 323-7436.

title: East Europeans Enliven Concerts
description: TWO prominent ensembles from Eastern Europe are appearing in the county this week: the Warsaw Wind Quintet, coming to the Emelin Theater for a Thursday evening recital, and the Prague Guitar Quartet, which is saving the day for the Chamber Series at the Hudson River Museum.

title: Subway Safaris on London's Tube
description: WHEN we met Adrian Starkey he was in work clothes, on hands and knees, at the edge of the woods, measuring and planning an area for a country fair to be held on an approaching Bank Holiday, one of several traditional long-weekend vacations for Britons.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Die Hard 2 1990. CBS/Fox. $94.98. 2 hours, 4 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Bruce Smith On . . .
description: The Super Bowl Crush: "It's rush here, rush there, rush, rush, rush. Everywhere you go somebody is slapping you on the back. You sit down to eat dinner and people say, 'Sorry to disturb you, but would you sign this?' You know about it, you prepare for it, but until it all happens, you have no idea how consuming it is." Lawrence Taylor: "When I said late this season that I was the best defensive player in the league, it was not a personal swipe at L.T. The New York newspapers turned it into that and it ticked me off. It was not fair. Here's the thing I feel good about: I really believe that L.T. understood exactly where I was coming from and what I meant. That's all that really matters." The Giants: "We expect a non-stop battle. They never stop fighting. They are capable of presenting a lot of problems for us but if we're on top of our game, we present more problems for them." The Buffalo fans: "You talk about people being happy for us! I've seen so many faces from Buffalo and they are everywhere. I don't believe half of them have tickets to the game, but they don't care and came anyway. They're as hungry as we are."

title: Dallas Chooses a Police Chief
description: A Los Angeles deputy police chief was chosen Friday to lead the Dallas force, succeeding Mack Vines, who was dismissed in September on charges that he had lied to officials investigating a shooting by a police officer. The new Chief, William Rathburn, 49 years old, was selected from more than 100 candidates. He was chief of security for the Los Angeles police force during the 1984 Olympic Games and has won community praise as commander of that city's Southern Bureau.

title: False Ideology
description: To the Editor: Someone finally got it right. Tonality does indeed depend upon a hierarchy of pitches, as Donal Henahan noted in passing [ "And So We Bid Farewell to Atonality," Jan. 6 ] .

title: Judge Spurns Rule on Sentencing; Rejects 17 1/2-Year Term for Drugs
description: A Federal judge refused Friday to impose the minimum 17 1/2-year prison term mandated by sentencing guidelines on a defendant convicted of selling one tablet of an illegal drug.

title: Camille Lamont To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Lamont of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Camille Haines Lamont to Nicholas Weir Burlingham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Burlingham Jr. of Cambridge, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: Cuts at Vanderbilt Planetarium Lead to Employees' Protests
description: THE Vanderbilt Museum in Centerport, long involved in political battles, is enmeshed in a new dispute, this time over the budget for the Vanderbilt Planetarium.

title: Malaysia
description: To the Editor: Simon Elegant's evocative description of Malaysia's Taman Negara park (Travel, Nov. 11) revived memories of our visit in 1988, but while he refers to the logging outside the park and the importance of preserving the park, he did not mention the devastating logging taking place in the Malaysian state of Sarawak on the island of Borneo.

title: Technology; In Search of Short-Order Chips
description: Amateur photographers once sent their film for developing to huge plants that took days or weeks to return the finished photos. Then film processing machines were built that were small and inexpensive enough to be used by small shops that could deliver the film in an hour.

title: IN SHORT/REFERENCE BOOKS
description: THE ILLUSTRATED ATLAS OF JEWISH CIVILIZATION 4,000 Years of Jewish History. Edited by Martin Gilbert. Text by Josephine Bacon. Macmillan, $35.

title: Style Makers; Alan Azzolino and Edwin Kobylarz, Antiques Recyclers
description: For Alan Azzolino, 44 years old, and Edwin (Koby) Kobylarz, 42, no antique is obsolete. They simply redefine its functions.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE WESTCHESTER PEOPLE'S ACTION COALITION;
Attack Is On Against the Military-Industrial-Media Complex
description: THE cadences of protests were familiar: an amplified voice, half-chanting, half-speaking, warning passers-by of the evils of American military activity. The sights, too, evoked another era: blue-jean clad teen-agers and earnest-looking adults, pacing back and forth on a street corner, wielding homemade picket signs and banners. The only thing different was the war in question: not Vietnam this time, but the Persian Gulf.

title: Corrections
description: Two artists' credits in The Times Book Review today are reversed in some copies. The illustration on page 3 is by Richard McGuire; the one on page 9 is by Janie Geiser.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Company Looks For A Cheap, Natural Way To Clean Up Pollution
description: SOMETIME this June, researchers from the General Electric Company plan to pound half a dozen six-foot-wide pipes into the bed of the upper Hudson River as part of an attempt to save the company as much as $280 million in environmental cleanup costs. When the results are in many months later, the company hopes to have the first evidence from the field that scientists can help nature reduce the toxicity of PCB's in sediment on the river bottom.

title: Camera
description: I can remember when shooting color-negative film meant waiting weeks for prints to arrive in the mail. The mini-lab revolution eliminated that irritation. Now, I often drop off my film in the morning and pick up the prints and negatives after lunch. One consequence of this: more color-negative film is being used than ever before.

title: Ms. Otis, Student, To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Otis 3d of Basking Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Otis, to George Charles Andrew Conrades, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Conrades of Greenwich, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Day Devoted to Anti-Drug Messages
description: STUDENTS throughout the county are invited to "Celebrate a Drug-Free Life" by participating in a special event at the County Center on Feb. 9 and by making banners on the same theme.

title: Travel Advisory; Gulf War Leads To a 30% Drop In World Travel
description: Fearful of terrorist attacks spawned by the Persian Gulf war, Americans are canceling vacation and business trips, not only in the Middle East but also in Europe, Latin America and the United States, according to travel agents and industry analysts. International travel has declined by at least 30 percent since war broke out Jan. 16, they said.

title: Jill Allyn Kreitman Plans to Marry
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Benjamin Z. Kreitman of Brooklyn have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Jill Allyn Kreitman and Dr. Corey Lance Goldstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Goldstein of Huguenot, S. I.

title: Ships of State
description: THIS PEOPLE'S NAVYThe Making of American Sea Power.By Kenneth J. Hagan.Illustrated. 434 pp. New York:The Free Press. $27.95.

title: Stephen P. Guardino Jr., Marine Contractor, 76
description: Stephen P. Guardino Jr., the former president of Guardino & Sons Marine Contractors, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giggling Their Way to Enlightenment
description: THE LAUGHING SUTRA By Mark Salzman. 263 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Vietnamese Cuisine, Virginia Settings
description: FOR Asian immigrants, Eden Center, a Vietnamese-operated shopping mall on Wilson Boulevard in Falls Church, Va., is a source of ingredients essential to their national cuisines; for non-Asians, the lure is the more than 20 Vietnamese restaurants in the area.

title: Suffering in the Cities Persists As U.S. Fights Other Battles
description: Nearly three decades after the Great Society, and after eight years of record economic growth, urban poverty remains an entrenched force in American life and an increasingly destructive one.

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's article on strange Scottish place names (Travel, Dec. 16) was most amusing, but he missed a bet in not reporting on Britain's northernmost island -- Unst, at the top of the Shetland Islands chain.

title: Soviet Doubts Before Talks
description: Before leaving for Washington today, Foreign Minister Bessmertnykh underlined the Kremlin's displeasure with the United States Congress for linking American economic aid with the harsh new military drive against the Baltic republics' attempt to regain independence.

title: He Doesn't Love New York, But Wants to Aid the Neediest
description: There are plenty of people who have donated to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund because they love New York. But Antony Chiang may well be the first to contribute because he hates it.

title: Outdoors; Amid Skyscrapers, a Bird Sanctuary
description: You have no doubt heard that bird watchers go to great lengths to spot a particularly rare specimen. But did you know they also go to great heights -- like 395 feet above the Manhattan skyline -- where a pair of peregrine falcons is nesting on a ledge at New York Hospital?

title: 4 Are Found Shot in Freezer Of Restaurant in Dallas Area
description: Four people were found shot to death today at a fast food restaurant in this Dallas suburb where a robbery had apparently occurred a short time before.

title:
DINING OUT;
Standard Fare in a Mess Hall Setting
description: IN spite of -- or perhaps because of -- its minimal steakhouse menu, its mess-hall ambience and its rigid format, Sammy's Ye Olde Cider Mill carries on as popular as ever. This Morris County institution, which has been around since Prohibition, must bring a twinge of nostalgia to boarding-school graduates with memories of meals in the dining hall.

title: Schools Help Students Face Fears of War
description: SHIRLEY CLAY'S fifth-grade class at West Broad Street School in Pawcatuck is well versed in the vocabulary of war. On a recent morning, a discussion of current events covered everything from the cost of Patriot missiles and who pays for them to the rudiments of the Geneva Conventions to a debate over censoring news reports of the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: TO survive inside a prison's walls, where time is hard and space uneasy, every man has a gimmick, something that can be bartered for power or privilege. William Pruden's gimmick has always been his art -- portraits, landscapes, heroic profiles, even personalized stationery, anything others need or want.

title: Sunday Brunch; From Exotic to Sociable On the Upper East Side
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some places to dine on the Upper East Side.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: WILLIAM OLSTEN;
Eager to Fill the Gaps in Offices
description: AN ornament William Olsten knocked off the Christmas tree as he swept out of his office recently at the Olsten Corporation headquarters in Westbury took one hop and shattered.

title: Travel Advisory; Tokyo-Narita Express Train
description: As of March 13, passengers traveling between the Narita International Airport and Tokyo Station downtown will reduce traveling time considerably when they take the new Narita Special Express train. The nonstop ride betweeen the airport terminal's lower level and central Tokyo will take 55 minutes and will eliminate the bus ride from the airport to the Narita railroad station, which took 25 minutes. The fare for the new express has yet to be announced.

title: On the Street; Serious Winter Headwear
description: Hoods, one of fashion's oldest and most practical designs, were seen all around town last week in the sweep of biting cold and wind. A variety of hoods were seen along Fifth Avenue, attached to coats, capes and parkas or worn separately. Some of the hooded coats ranged from the styles worn by monks to opulent ones trimmed in both real and fake fur. One of the more unusual designs was a drawstring hood that shrouded the head mysteriously. These echoes of the past were right at home on 20th-century Fifth Avenue and a cozy buffer against winter.

title: Financial Footnote to History
description: But what should baseball officials -- or the Players Association -- give Gary Gaetti when he already has an $11.4 million contract for the next four years and specifically a $2.7 million salary for the coming season, which is the reason he is being recognized here.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: The Promise And Perils Of M-Year
description: This is it: M-Day. The Mozart Bicentennial invasion has begun, fittingly enough on the 235th anniversary of Mozart's birth. Today's joint concert at Avery Fisher Hall by the New York Philharmonic and Juilliard orchestras sounds a tocsin whose reverberations will not cease at Lincoln Center until every work written by Mozart has passed through the ears of one or another group of listeners. From now until Dec. 6, the date of his death at age 35, concert halls and opera houses the world over will be occupied by legions of professional Mozarteans, those stout armies of musicians, scholars, recording executives and arts administrators who invariably rally behind anniversary causes. The Mozart industry has thrown down the glove, challenging musicians and listeners to search out every nook in which a Mozart note may have hidden unobserved for two centuries.

title: Tech Notes; An Extra Nudge for Toxic Waste
description: A process under development at the Batelle Memorial Institute in Columbus, Ohio, may offer a novel way to remove contaminated ground water from under the nation's dumps and landfills. The process, employed for several years to dry out coal but not yet tested in this application, uses electrical and acoustical energy to cause toxic liquids to migrate toward a drainpipe where they can be extracted by a pump. But over time, the migration stops as the residue left behind solidifies into "filtercake." "That is when the acoustical shock is applied," said Satya Chauchan, director of separation technology at Batelle. The ultrasonic shock disturbs the molecules of the filtercake and causes the migration of the contaminated material to recommence. As envisioned, a single cathode will be ringed with anodes placed around the dump site. The toxic liquids will migrate to the center as low-voltage electricity travels through the ground.

title: Across the U.S., The War Is Remote and Inescapable
description: BY its nature war is a journey down a dark, uncertain path, with the road ahead often becoming more twisted and unnerving the farther the journey progresses.

title: Poetry and Politics in 'Blood Knot'
description: BECAUSE the plays of Athol Fugard have become embedded in our culture and in our conscience, it is edifying to come upon "The Blood Knot," his breakthrough work.

title: DIVIDED LOYALTIES
description: With all the debate over whether or not Israel should exist as a sovereign state, it seems that Jordan is truly illegitimate. As Brinkley points out, it was King Hussein's grandfather who received Trans-Jordan from the British after being thrown out of Saudi Arabia. Historically, the Hashemites have no claim to the land Jordan now occupies.

title:
Commercial Property: Washington's Metro;
System Grows, but Projects Slow Along the Line
description: AS this city's commuter rail system approaches the 15th anniversary of the opening of its first five stations, commercial development has continued to follow the rail lines into suburban Virginia and Maryland.

title: IN SHORT/REFERENCE BOOKS
description: THE FEMINIST COMPANION TO LITERATURE IN ENGLISHWomen Writers From the Middle Ages to the Present.Edited by Virginia Blain,Patricia Clements and Isobel Grundy.Yale University, $49.95.

title: Dancing the Rumba With Pop
description: IN THE SPANISH BALLROOMBy Doris Rochlin.258 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Scriabin: 12 Etudes (Op. 8); Raff: Suite in D minor (Op. 91) Morton Estrin, piano. Newport NCD 60067; CD only.

title: Washington Banking Official Found Dead in a Hotel Room
description: A bank computer specialist from Washington was found dead in a hotel room in midtown Manhattan on Friday afternoon, the police said yesterday.

title: THE GUIDE
description: FUGARD PLAY

title: Decoding the Images of War for Children
description: WITH images of war interrupting regular television programming, and the Persian Gulf becoming a focus of discussion in recent weeks, what can parents do to help children understand disturbing world events?

title: Insidious Thought
description: To the Editor: As head of the Arts Council, Lord Palumbo looks like the fox in charge of the henhouse [ "Architectural Showdown in the House of Lords," Jan. 13 ] . He has been possessed to build a "masterpiece," whether London wants it or not. He is like the Boy Scout intent on doing a good deed who drags an old lady across the street when she doesn't want to go. Why doesn't he simply put this paragon of design on already vacant land?

title: A.C.L.U. CHOOSES A NEW PRESIDENT
description: The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday elected Nadine Strossen as the first female president of the 71-year-old civil rights organization.

title: Elizabeth Zaldastani Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Othar Zaldastani of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Reily Zaldastani to James Campbell Napier 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Napier Jr. of Atlanta. A summer wedding is planned.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. RICHARD H. FLYER;
Improving Child Emergency Services
description: SINCE 1984, Dr. Richard H. Flyer, a pediatrician, has campaigned to improve emergency medical services for critically ill and injured children in New Jersey. He says he worries that rescue personnel and hospital emergency rooms are not always prepared to deal with newborn children through 18-year-olds and that no statewide system exists to coordinate the immediate transport of children with life-threatening problems to the centers best equipped to treat them.

title: All Agree Orchestra Needs a Larger Endowment
description: BEYOND the charges and countercharges that surround the deadlock over contracts for the musicians of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra lies one issue on which both sides can agree: if the orchestra is to insure its long-term stability, it must establish a solid endowment.

title: Elizabeth Baton To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Scott Baton 2d of Ligonier, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Marks Baton, to Sean Francis Lydon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lydon of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Cheshire, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Sports and the Mind
description: Bill Parcells has hardly cornered the market on superstitious sports behavior with his trunks-up elephants pointing toward the door, his insistence that a certain pilot fly his Giants to championship games, his rigid breakfast routine before home games and his precise positioning during the pre-game singing of the national anthem.

title: Article 636591 -- No Title
description: The Henry Luce Foundation has given $10 million to Yale University to build and endow an international center in honor of the founder of Time magazine.

title: Levy Takes Scholarly Path to Tampa
description: In his choice of words (how many head coaches use "oxymoron" in a press conference?), style of dress and preparation, Marv Levy could be standing in front of an eager young collection of students at a prestigious college.

title: Pirates Extend Huskies' Slide
description: The pressure and trapping defenses so synonymous with the University of Connecticut's play last season -- when the Huskies won the Big East title -- are still being used. Many of the familiar names are also back, but two big ones are missing, Tate George and Nadav Henefeld. And so the Huskies have gone from being big winners to losers.

title: South Africa's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Potholes, Traffic Jams and Now a New Worry: Bigger Trucks
description: NEW JERSEY drivers who are already plagued by potholes, traffic jams and rising gas taxes may soon have another worry to add to the list: triple trailer trucks.

title: DESIGN: The Wedding; Wedding Bands
description: In the back room of a brownstone on the East Side of Manhattan, six young goldsmiths hover over miniature objects placed on metal work benches. Their craftsmanship is centuries old, yet their designs are unmistakably modern. Here in the workroom of Reinstein/ Ross, a seven-year-old company that is one of today's leading jewelry-design firms, traditional objects are given a new twist. And while their necklaces, earrings and bracelets are all popular, it's the age-old wedding band that has become the biggest seller.

title: A Phenomenologist Bares His Heart
description: GHOSTS IN THE MIRROR By Alain Robbe-Grillet. Translated by Jo Levy. 174 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld.

title: Minnesota's Teacher of the Year Is Laid Off in Budget Crisis
description: Cathy Nelson has been a teacher for 15 years, the last 13 of them teaching social studies at Fridley High School, in Fridley, Minn., near Minneapolis. She has found innovative ways to interest students in history, and has found time to earn a doctoral degree from the University of Minnesota.

title: Score Two for Education
description: BIG MAN ON CAMPUS John Thompson and the Georgetown Hoyas. By Leonard Shapiro. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: A John Macrae Book/Henry Holt & Company. $19.95. WINNING IS AN ATTITUDE A Season in the Life of John Chaney and the Temple Owls. By Steve Wartenberg. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $18.95.

title: Newark Arts Center: Other Opinions
description: Unfortunately, reporters are all too often mortgaged to the source of their information. A perfect example of this shortcoming was illustrated by the article on the arts center to be constructed in Newark.

title: A Human Face
description: This is the story of three kids who grew up and enlisted in the Army.

title: Margot Johnston To Marry in June
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Edward Johnston of Rye, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Margot Drake Johnston and Gregory Stephen Arent, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Arent of Darien, Conn.

title: Shaping U.S. Goals on Mental Retardation
description: IT may seem unusual that a Federal committee with only 21 appointed members should include two Westchester residents. Those who know the work of Linda Felner and Dr. Betty Osman, however, say both women are exceptionally well qualified to serve on the President's Committee on Mental Retardation.

title: Grace W. Sheffield To Marry in June
description: Thomas C. Sheffield of Chicago and Sandra S. Sheffield of Lake Forest, Ill, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Grace Wacker Sheffield, to Thomas Alan Patterson, a son of Dr. William R. Patterson of Grand Junction, Colo., and Joan T. Patterson of Denver. A June wedding is planned.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. MELANIE KILLEN;
How Children Figure Out Life's Rules
description: VERY young children, so conventional wisdom goes, are wild, unruly creatures who must be taught that harming others is wrong.

title: Talking: Inspections; Spotting Trouble for Sellers
description: AN increasing number of sellers in today's difficult market are finding it worthwhile to have their homes inspected to find problems that might put off a buyer. Such inspections often can turn up conditions, like leaky windows or damp in the basement, that the owner has lived with for years but that might kill a sale to a demanding buyer.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Hills 385,000 15 Candy Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 39- year-old ranch; den, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,500. Glen Head 300,000 92 Plymouth Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; new kitchen, finished basement, family room, fireplace; taxes $4,500. Great River 253,000 119 Widgeon Court, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old ranch; fireplace, great room, c/a, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,400. Hauppauge 136,000 46 Wayne Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old ranch; den, fireplace, partial basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. Islip 450,000 110 Elder Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 39-year-old waterfront colonial; fireplace, 2-car attached garage, 0.69 acre, 70 feet of bulkheading; taxes $7,900. Roslyn Heights 530,000 20 Spruce Drive 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 32-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, finished basement, maid's room; taxes $8,000. OTHER AREAS Avon, Conn. 265,000 76 Paper Chase Trail 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, new kitchen, period details, 1.3 acres; taxes $3,646. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 285,000 466 Fisher Pond Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, deck; taxes $7,638. Freehold, N.J. 136,000 14 Helen Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, eat- in-kitchen, fireplace, h/w floors; taxes $2,147.

title: Lucy Polese to Marry H. J. Rohner 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. James K. Polese of Beverly Farms, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lucy Adeline Polese to Henry John Rohner 3d, the son of Mrs. Robert D. Hedberg of Exton, Pa., and the late Mr. Rohner Jr. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Region; The Next Battle in Yonkers Will Be Over Power
description: EARLIER this month, in a windowless 35th-floor office of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development in Manhattan's Federal Plaza, signatures were affixed to a document that was the product of five years of civic and political strife and an estimated $12 million in lawyers' fees.

title: Where Peking Duck Is a Star Attraction
description: I GET letters. Most recently, they came from Smithtown and suggested a visit to the Sesame Tree, a Chinese restaurant on Main Street.

title: Kathleen Fitzgibbons To Wed John R. Turner
description: June wedding plans for Kathleen Ann Fitzgibbons and John Rollins Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar V. Turner of Darien, Conn., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John P. Fitzgibbons of Allentown, Pa.

title:
Hollywood Journal;
Memorial to Stars' Unmentionables
description: In a city so obsessed with fame that common people sometimes seek out the name of a celebrity's dog groomer, it should come as no surprise that a museum has been created to display the lingerie of the stars.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Volunteers; Feeling the Need to Help, Some Americans Volunteer to Work in Israel
description: Alexander Goldberg stood in the Manhattan office of Volunteers for Israel one day last week, trying to explain why, at the age of 74, he was signing up to work in Israel when Iraqi missiles are raining on the country and the United States Government has advised Americans against visiting the Middle East.

title: Sunday Menu; A Flavorful Pork Dish That's Low In Fat
description: All of the menus I offer for Sunday meals are low in fat, whether or not they are so labeled.

title: Jack Schaefer, Author of 'Shane' And Other Westerns, Dies at 83
description: Jack Schaefer, a newspaperman turned author of westerns whose best-known work was the novel "Shane," died Thursday at St. Vincent Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 83 years old.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Morphological Compromise in France's War of Words
description: THE French Government's efforts to simplify the rules of spelling have begun to resemble a sharp-tongued Moliere satire.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Montreal
description: Montreal in summer bares its Latin soul in cafe terraces, street fairs, and festivals of fireworks, jazz, theater and stand-up comedy. But when the snow piles up to the windows and hockey sticks fly, Montreal's jovial French-Canadian camaraderie and cosmopolitan flair combine to give this city its winter spirit. Yes, everyone complains about the length of the season and the ritual of brush, scrape, chisel, shovel and push to park and unpark cars. But who does not thrill at the sights of the city in winter -- snow falling through a neon pink sky from a cafe window on Rue St.-Denis, ice-skaters gliding by moonlight on the lagoon in Parc LaFontaine, toboggans zipping down Mount Royal.

title: Headliners; The Clustering of America, Part II
description: THE 1990 census figures for every city, county and crossroads in the United States -- more than 39,000 communities -- were released last week, giving the first fine-grained look at where Americans lived and moved in the decade that saw Wall Street boom and the farm country bust.

title: Correction
description: The Gazetteer accompanying an article on Jan. 13 about West Brighton misidentified the designer of Outerbridge Crossing and the Goethals Bridge. The architect was the firm of York & Sawyer of Manhattan, with Alexander Waddell as engineer.

title: When Artists Put Countries on the Map, It's Social Comment
description: GEOGRAPHY gets such short shrift in schools that money can be made betting even the well educated that they don't know where Mauritius is.

title: Seles Rallies Past Novotna To Win Australian Open
description: Monica Seles says her serve is weak, she doesn't know how to lob and she can't volley. Yet she is the winner of the 1991 Australian Open and only 38 computer points away from being ranked as the No. 1 women's player in the world.

title: Hearts Are Cute. So Are Children. Must They Go Together?
description: There are six designers of avant-garde children's clothing in New York City who are opposed to pastels and traditional prints.

title: Campus Life: Rochester Institute; Helping Industry Redesign Products To Cut Costs
description: As part of a cooperative project with corporations like the Ford Motor Company and J. I. Case, mechanical engineers at the Rochester Institute of Technology are helping to redesign products.

title: Postings: Chinatown Co-op; Going Private
description: For some of the limited-equity cooperatives built with public funds in the 50's and 60's, the expiration of city property tax abatements has led to wrenching internal struggles over whether to continue as nonprofit entities or "go private."

title: Devil Of a War; It May Not Be Vietnam, but Parallels Are Inescapable
description: FOR all of President Bush's passionate insistence to the contrary, the war in the Persian Gulf has more than a few similarities to the war in Vietnam, in the sort of problems that it poses if not in the probable outcome.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: North Conway, N.H.;
Homeseeker Weekends
description: FACED with a slumping real estate market and too many homes for sale in this skiiing and hiking vacationland, lending institutions have taken to sponsoring "homeseeker weekends" to attract buyers.

title: Suspect in 4 Slayings Pleads Guilty to One
description: A man pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the death of a New York man after a judge ruled that a jury could hear about his alleged connection to three slayings in Mississippi, where he could face the death penalty.

title: Prolific Author Weaves Spirituality Through Her Storytelling
description: MADELEINE L'ENGLE spent a recent cold morning in her studio at Crosswicks, her family homestead in Goshen, wondering if her editors had read her new book, worrying about whether they liked it and mulling over the revisions they might request. Those may seem like strange musings for an author who has published more than 40 books, including the Newbery Award winner "A Wrinkle in Time," a novel for young people that has had 50 hard-cover printings in 28 years.

title: Stenerud's Selected By the Hall of Fame
description: Jan Stenerud became the first pure place-kicker to make the Pro Football Hall of Fame, joining four others elected today.

title: Embrace the Stereotype; Kiss the Movie Goodbye
description: Who is the most ludicrous ethnic creation on screen right now? Is it the fanatical, small-minded Iranian or the foulmouthed, money-obsessed American or the warmhearted Italian who has to be blasted out of the family house in middle age?

title: Caroline Peet to Wed Andrew Kaplan
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Chester Peet Jr. of Shelter Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Cartier Peet to Andrew Mark Kaplan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Kaplan of Mamaroneck, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: A Little Cafe and Patisserie in Greenwich
description: SUBURBAN dwellers with a sweet tooth dream of having a little patisserie nearby where they can stop for midmorning or midafternoon coffee and a mouth-watering Danish pastry or petit-fours. Lucky Greenwich has more than one. Versailles, which is especially notable for the quality of its pastries, also doubles as a bakery and a cafe serving lunch and dinner.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our screened porch has a slate floor. There are some paint spots on it, and the floor is rather dusty. We would like to apply a sealer, but we want to remove the paint spots first. How would you suggest we go about it?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook; Patriots vs. Scuds: Iraqi Touchdown Is Averted
description: In the desert's evening chill the members of Bravo battery listened nervously to radio reports of Scud missile attacks against Israel and Riyadh and knew that Iraq's next target would be the sprawling air base they defend with Patriot missiles.

title: The G.O.P. Message: A State of Disunion
description: The public's focus on our war with Iraq is so intense that there is, understandably, little attention being paid to domestic issues. President Bush, in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, will address them -- how could he not? -- but in a relatively bland, almost nonpartisan way.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Democrats; Liberals in Search of Values Run Into Discord Over War
description: A group of liberal Democrats met here today to talk about reclaiming their party and restoring its "progressive values." But they found themselves struggling with and sometimes squabbling over the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: On Differences in Class and Culture
description: AS the county sees an influx of people from Asian, Hispanic and Caribbean cultures, social service professionals and educators are paying more attention to the ways in which subtle cultural and class differences can cause misunderstanding. Intercultural marriages and adoptions also play a role in the heightening interest in the subject.

title: East Harlem Mourns Girl, 13, Whose Killing Baffles Police
description: Among the people in East Harlem who knew Paola Illera, her rape and murder Thursday night cut deep into their hearts. The tall, well-spoken 13-year-old reflected their best hopes for their own sisters and daughters in a neighborhood where many young women lose their way among the pitfalls of drugs and early pregnancy.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE AGRICULTURE EXPERIMENT STATION;
'We Play a Very Important Role In the Quality of Life' in the State
description: IN the Steep Rock Reservation in Washington, thousands of hemlock trees are rapidly being destroyed by two types of insect pests. In time, the damage could radically alter the forest.

title: New Exhibition Sheds Light on the Ancient Montauk Indians
description: THAT the Montauk were an aboriginal people who inhabited eastern Long Island before the Europeans arrived is a fact that historians and archeologists do not question.

title: Heidi Brayer Is to Marry
description: Corey David Bell, a son of Paula Pines and George Bell, both of New York, and Heidi Elizabeth Brayer, a daughter of Susan Brayer and Charles Brayer, both of Philadelphia, plan to marry in August. Ms. Brayer and her fiance are 26 years old. A graduate of the University of Hartford, she is a veterinary technician in New York. Mr. Bell, a graduate of Syracuse University, is a certified public accountant with Blonder, Seymour & Shapss, an accounting firm in New York.

title: More Rebels in Colombia Lay Down Their Arms
description: Among the fishing boats and tourist ferries bobbing about this lively port today was a vessel of fully armed guerrillas. Far from being on a combat mission, the rebels were seeking the perfect spot to fling their guns into the turquoise waters of the Caribbean.

title: Science Provides a Business Introduction
description: WHEN the sixth graders in Ronni Black's science classes work on their project, the entire school knows it. The 11-year-olds at the Albert Leonard Middle School here are in the perfume business.

title: Self-Defeating on Nuclear Tests
description: Why does President Bush stubbornly resist all negotiations toward a ban on nuclear weapons tests? He has even backed away from Ronald Reagan's pledge to Congress to engage "immediately" in talks "on a step-by-step program . . . limiting and ultimately ending nuclear testing." Mr. Bush would better serve U.S. security interests by carrying out that pledge.

title: Boy, 16, Dies When Stolen Vehicle Crashes
description: A 16-year-old boy was killed and two companions were injured when the stolen Jeep-type vehicle they were in crashed into a car early yesterday morning in the New Lots section of Brooklyn, the police said. The driver of the car was also hurt.

title: Elizabeth Ennis to Wed
description: Elizabeth Marrs Ennis and Edward Mason Barron 2d plan to marry in April. Miss Ennis, 30 years old, is a daughter of Mrs. Paul Hoffmann of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Robert F. Ennis of Bay Head, N.J. Mr. Barron, 29, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Barron of South Dartmouth, Mass. The future bride, a graduate of the Rye Country Day School and Bucknell University, is a senior agent at Carlson Travel in White Plains. Mr. Barron is an analyst at the Citytrust Bank in Bridgeport, Conn. He graduated; from Fairfield University.

title: INSIDE
description: China Sentences Leaders Of Democracy Movement China's leading human rights advocate was sentenced to seven years in prison and its foremost student leader to four years for "counterrevolutionary" offenses. By Chinese standards, the sentences were relatively lenient. Page 3. Yugoslav Crisis Defused Yugoslavia's Communist-led army drew back from threats to use force to disarm police units of independence-minded Croatia. Page 3. News Summary, Page 2 Obituaries, Page 26 Weather, Page 27 Radio, Late TV, Page 44

title: Once Again, It's the Star-Spangled Super Bowl
description: No cameras will be allowed to be taken by fans into Tampa Stadium for the 25th Super Bowl today. No portable television sets, and no radios, either. But there will be plenty of flags. Some 72,000 hand-sized flags will be given to fans to wave. Mechanical devices could be used to store explosives, and the threat of terrorism in this time of war is real.

title: Bullet From First Floor Kills Man on Second
description: A man was killed on Friday night by a bullet that came through his floor from an assault rifle that was accidentally fired in a downstairs apartment, Suffolk County police said today.

title: How They Live in New York Now
description: SOMETHING BLUEBy Ann Hood.215 pp. New York:Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: Back to China Laden With New Ideas
description: Around a hairpin turn, after two days of driving on rough roads through the treeless loess hills of Shanxi Province in northeast China, suddenly, several thousand feet below, was the legendary Yellow River. It was enough to take one's breath away. Not only was the canyon through which it wound spectacular, but at this particular spot, called Hukou -- "teapot spout" in Chinese -- the entire river plunged over a precipice and roared into a gorge no wider than a narrow city street. Through the spray that rose like mist from the churning cataract, a rainbow arched over the river.

title: Mr. Unlikely? So Be It, Says Hostetler
description: Beneath the Official Super Bowl Merchandise Tent, just south of Tampa Stadium, and in smaller souvenir stands on corners and curbsides throughout this city, the image of Jeff Hostetler of the New York Giants, suddenly a Super Bowl quarterback after all these years, has been preserved forever on a T-shirt.

title: Ms. Carroll Weds John G. Bontempi
description: Moira Eileen Carroll, the daughter of Eileen Hayes Quinn of Somers, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to John Guy Bontempi, the son of Guy Bontempi and Nicki Bontempi of Spring Lake Heights, N.J. The Rev. Nicholas R. Reid performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; Some Iraqi Jets Flee to Iran; U.S. Says Reason Is Unclear
description: At least two dozen Iraqi aircraft, including fighter jets as well as military and civilian transport planes, have fled into Iran since the war in the Persian Gulf began, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Vienna's Celebration of Mozart
description: ONE evening in 1816 the 19-year-old Schubert attended a concert, and afterward wrote in his diary that the Zaubertone -- magic sounds -- of Mozart's music kept echoing in him, impressions "that no time, no circumstances extinguish." Vienna has chosen Schubert's coinage, Zaubertone, as the name of the grand exhibition that has opened the city's profuse observance of the Mozart bicentennial.

title: Sharmon Priaulx to Wed Shawn Rock
description: A July wedding is planned for Sharmon Veronica Priaulx and Shawn Brendan Rock, the son of Elizabeth U. Marlow of Silver Spring, Md., and John Manger Rock 3d of Austin, Tex., and Potomac, Md. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. John S. Meneely of Annapolis, Md., and Allan Priaulx of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Mutual Funds column on Jan. 13 about companies that levy a sales charge when reinvesting dividends included an outdated reference supplied by Morningstar Inc. The Rochester Group, listed as levying the charge, ceased doing so in May.

title: Alexandra Hillenmaier to Marry Kenneth Trapp
description: Alexandra Elisabeth Hillenmaier, the daughter of Bernice Hillenmaier of Holmdel, N.J., and the late Guenther Hillenmaier, is to be married in July to Kenneth W. Trapp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Trapp of Brooklin, Me.

title: Jitters Abound on Telecast
description: Got a minute? It will cost you $1.6 million.

title: U.S. Officials Conclude Air Power Is Not Enough to Defeat Hussein
description: American intelligence officials have concluded that air power alone will not be able to force Saddam Hussein's troops out of Kuwait and that ground attacks by American and allied forces will be needed.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our screened porch has a slate floor. There are some paint spots on it, and the floor is rather dusty. We would like to apply a sealer, but we want to remove the paint spots first. How would you suggest we go about it?

title: For the Homeless, Lessons in Self-Reliance
description: DON GOULETTE, executive director of the Open Hearth, a community for homeless men in Hartford, recalled a phone call he received seven years ago from a retired widow living on Social Security. Without introduction, she said, "I want to know, do you help the poor?" Of course, Mr. Goulette replied.

title: Fourteen Years in Castro's Prisons
description: LEAVE ME MY SPIRIT By Lawrence K. Lunt. 277 pp. Affiliated Writers of America, Box 2006, Tempe, Ariz. 85281. $19.95.

title: Lauren Bonfield To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bonfield of Iowa City have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Beth Bonfield, to Stephen Keyes, a son of Doris Keyes and the late Nelson Keyes of Louisville, Ky. An August wedding is planned.

title: Airline Seats
description: To the Editor: Recently I held a tourist-class return ticket from Belgrade to New York on J.A.T. Airlines. Due to an error my request for a deeper legroom bulkhead seat (I am 6 foot 3) resulted in my being assigned an aisle seat in the last rather than the first row. When I arrived at the seat I found an American woman in it. She refused to budge, saying she had requested an aisle seat and as one had not been assigned to her she was taking mine.

title: Big Bang Theory of Universe's Origin Hasn't Been Shaken
description: To the Editor:

title: Meredith Edelman, Lawyer, to Wed
description: The engagement of Meredith Ann Edelman and Evan Scott Rosen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosen of East Windsor, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel I. Edelman of Riverdale, the Bronx. A September wedding is planned.

title: Postings: Symposium; A Car-Free New York?
description: Put tolls on the East River Bridges to discourage drivers from coming into the city. No, build more parking garages so they have places to park. No, reduce the number of parking spaces and plant grass and trees in their place, and raise taxes on cab rides. No, leave medallion cabs alone but control private car services. No, put tolls on the East River bridges.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A TENURED PROFESSOR, by John Kenneth Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $7.95.) After a Harvard economist discovers how to quantify the irrational side of economic behavior, he and his wife reap a fortune, devoting their sudden millions to making the world a nicer place. Last year our reviewer, Barbara Ehrenreich, called the novel "a liberal wish-fulfillment fantasy, transmuting greed to good with rollicking zeal. Along the way, Mr. Galbraith has great fun at the expense of the powerful and their all-too-numerous admirers."

title: At 150, Manhattanville Celebrates a Willingness to Change
description: AS Manhattanville College begins a yearlong celebration of its 150th anniversary this week, it is proud of its Roman Catholic roots and of the multicultural, internationally oriented school it has become.

title:
Focus: Philadelphia;
Away From It All and Close to Downtown
description: DANIEL and Patricia Lieberman used to own a 4,000-square-foot home built in the stone shell of a factory that made cannonballs in rural Chester County outside Philadelphia. Their new home is half the size but equally unusual: a condominium town house near the end of a 67-year-old pier jutting 500 feet into the Delaware River.

title: Campus Life: Yeshiva; Soviet Emigres Help New Arrivals Adjust to U.S. Life
description: Some Soviet im migrants have trouble under standing why grocery prices in this country vary from store to store. Others find the American health-care system baffling, although they come from a country with a notable bureaucracy of its own. But all who visit Dr. Anna Krayn at Yeshiva University find talking about the problems of adjustment helpful.

title: Survey of 50 Cities Finds 36 Raised Taxes
description: A survey of 50 cities by the United States Conference of Mayors has found that 36 of them raised taxes in the last decade, and some mayors say this accelerated the flight of the middle class to the suburbs.

title: BETTING THE PLANET
description: It is not what a decade does to the cost of inanimate copper or tin that matters to the future of humankind but what happens to the nature and value of life. I thought your letters column would straighten the matter out, but not one letter alluded to the central environmental issue.

title: Fungus Is Harming Maple Trees in New York
description: A fungus disease new to the Northeast called giant tar spot is attacking Norway maple trees throughout New York State, plant pathologists say.

title: Hillary Simmers To Wed in May
description: Mrs. R. Thomas Sour of Rye, N.Y., has announced May wedding plans for her daughter, Hillary Trehare Simmers, and Philip Livingston Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr. of New York.

title: No Further Amnesty For State's Tax Evaders
description: AS state officials described their recent tax-amnesty program, it sounded like a game of hide and seek. Now, ready or not, here comes the taxman.

title: Flight Coupons
description: To the Editor: Our plane home was canceled in Frankfurt in May. Trans World Airlines had flown its Frankfurt (via London) to Baltimore flight directly from London -- and took the Baltimore passengers home eight hours late via St. Louis.

title: BETTING THE PLANET
description: The virulence and number of anti-environment letters (Dec. 23 and 30), in response to John Tierney's article "Betting the Planet" (Dec. 2), were surprising. But they worked on me! They convinced me that as long as my trash is hauled away (and piles up in someone's else's state), Love Canal happens somewhere else (with no cancer in my family) and radioactive waste doesn't leak until 500 or so years from now (long after I'm dead), then I guess I don't care either.

title: The Cajun Kingdom Of the Bayou
description: WHILE most of us spend our lives on terra firma, the Cajuns of southern Louisiana are an amphibious people, inhabiting a world of swamps and bayous, as comfortable on the water as they are on dry land.

title: Tough Economic Times for 'Military Town'
description: WHEN thundering jets climb into the evening and early morning skies here, residents in this Burlington County community rarely complain. Many who live and work here say the roar of straining engines brings with it a feeling of security, just like a ringing cash register.

title: Cracking the Whip
description: SEVERAL DAYS BEFORE the United States went to war with Iraq, Dick Cheney took a break from the final preparations for battle to discuss the crisis, the Pentagon and his improbable career. Toward the end of the conversation, he was asked about his visits to American troops in the desert.

title: Clark Kent and Other Supermen
description: In the Super Bowl talk show before the show itself, the hook had already been baited with controversy sure to create headlines. Several weeks ago, Bruce Smith, the Buffalo Bills' star defensive end, had described himself as pro football's best defensive player now, the successor to Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' linebacker. But when L. T. was reminded of Smith's boast in the approach to Super Bowl XXV early last week, he smiled.

title: Q and A
description: Tax on Sale .7 Question: I want to sell my two-family house and buy a one-family. I have not rented any part of my house for three years. I am over 55 years old and want to take the one-time $125,000 tax exclusion on the gain in the sale. Can I take the exclusion on the entire property (adjusting for depreciation taken when part of the house was rented), thus reducing the taxes? . . . Frank Dipre, Jackson Heights, Queens Answer: No. A spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service said that your one-time exclusion and postponement of tax on any gain would be applicable only to the portion of the house that served as your residence. The rental portion does not qualify for the tax benefits.

title: The Neatest of Tricks
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Update
Social Events
description: Art and Furnishings Auction

title: Corrections
description: An interview with the novelist John L'Heureux in The Times Book Review today misidentifies Mr. L'Heureux's wife. She is Joan Polston L'Heureux.

title:
MUSIC;
College's Jazz Program Expanding
description: THE nationally recognized jazz program at William Paterson College has been expanded with the creation of a two-year residency project for established jazz musicians.

title: Business Groups Urge New Farm Trade Talks
description: Business groups from throughout the world, at an unprecedented meeting here Thursday and Friday, pushed for a resumption of the trade talks that broke down last month in Brussels over the European Community's refusal to negotiate farm policies with the United States and other leading food-exporting nations.

title: Beirut: A War's Aftermath
description: A few days before the old year ended, the state-run Lebanese television station showed a film on Beirut before and after nearly 16 years of civil war. On the sound track was a song by one of the country's most famous singers, Majeda al Roumi: "This is what our hands have inflicted on you, O Beirut."

title: War Summary
description: FIGHTING A 40-MILE OIL SLICK The Saudis scrambled to contain the huge oil spill that is threatening their vital ports, refineries and desalting plants as it moves in from Kuwaiti waters. Heavy air raids on Iraqi targets continued in clear weather, and a U.S. spokesman said the campaign was veering toward "more of a battlefield preparation type." For the second night in a row, Israel and Saudi Arabia came under Scud missile attack. IRAQI PLANES FLY TO IRAN

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; U.S. Begins Saudi Evacuation After Scud Attack
description: The United States Embassy began a voluntary evacuation of American citizens from throughout Saudi Arabia today after the Scud missile attack Friday night that killed one person and wounded more than 30.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Ambitious Lovers: 'Lust' Elektra 960981; CD and cassette.

title: Two 2-Year Colleges Will Raise Tuition
description: Midyear tuition increases for students at Nassau and Corning Community Colleges were approved on Thursday by the trustees of the State University of New York.

title: Confrontation in Yugoslavia Headed Off
description: At an often stormy meeting of Yugoslavia's eight-member federal presidency that ended early this morning, the Communist-led national army drew back from its threats to use force to disarm paramilitary police units in the independence-minded republic of Croatia and to arrest high-ranking members of that republic's government.

title: Adrienne Lederman Wed
description: Adrienne Lederman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lederman of New York, was married last evening at the Tavern on the Green in New York to Randall Lang Cohen, a son of Gloria Shulman of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Dr. Richard Cohen of Los Angeles. Cantor Erno Grosz officiated. The bride, 25 years old, is a Syracuse University graduate. The bridegroom, 28, is the president of RCM Diversified, a clothing industry marketing consultant in Los Angeles and New York. He graduated from the University of Southern California.

title: Explosions by Base in Turkey
description: An explosion damaged a car outside the United States Consulate and another blast blew the door off a Turkish-American organization today in this southern city near an air base used to attack Iraq, the authorities said. No one was reported injured in the explosions, the first reported in Adana since the war against Iraq began. Adana is the main city near the strategic Incirlik base being used by American warplanes. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the explosions.

title: Everett Freeman, 79, Prolific Screenwriter
description: Everett Freeman, a screenwriter and producer whose films include "Marjorie Morningstar," "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty" and "You Can't Cheat an Honest Man," died Thursday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived in Westwood, Calif.

title: The Nation; California Expects Hispanic Voters To Transform Politics
description: WHEN voters in the 1st District of Los Angeles go back to the polls next month for a runoff in the county supervisor's race, they will choose between one of two Hispanic candidates. In so doing, they will begin what advocates expect to be a decade of Hispanic electoral empowerment in California that is being compared to the emergence of black political power in the South.

title:
The Executive Life;
Japan's Funky Export: Wild and Crazy Nights
description: Forget power lunches at the Downtown Association on Wall Street or evening bridge games at the Harvard Club. Japanese executives find it's easier to unwind while doing business outside the office by swilling whisky and singing schmaltzy songs at what are known as "karaoke bars." The karaoke club, which loosely translated means "empty orchestra" is a home away from home for many Japanese executives both in and outside of Japan.

title: Theresa Facos and Michael Casolo Are Engaged
description: Theresa Katina Facos and Michael A. P. Casolo plan to marry in June. Miss Facos is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Facos of Montpelier, Vt. Mr. Casolo is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Casolo of Norwalk, Conn. The prospective bride is an architect for International Business Machines in Stamford, Conn. She graduated from Yale University and has a master's degree in architecture from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Mr. Casolo is the director of design at J & S Development in New Haven and West Hartford, Conn. He is studying for a master's degree in urban planning at Columbia University.

title: A Question Of Influence
description: To the Editor: The fact that the International Center of Photography mounts, and Kodak sponsors, some exhibitions not to Andy Grundberg's taste [ "Same Old Stuff: Sex, Politics and Social Status," Dec. 30 ] is quite within his prerogative to criticize. However, his concern that Kodak may be influencing our choices is unwarranted. The truth is that Kodak exerts no pressure whatsoever on I.C.P. Indeed, at a time when institutions across the country are seeing their corporate support dwindle, our only regret is that there are so few corporations left who can be counted on for such generous support of the arts.

title: Environmental Chief Quits After Criticism
description: New Jersey's Environmental Commissioner, Judith A. Yaskin, who had been sharply criticized by environmental groups in recent months, has resigned, Gov. Jim Florio announced on Friday.

title: Editorial Notebook; Coercion and Contraception
description: Having babies is easy for Darlene Johnson. Trouble is, she's not fit to raise them. She's now in a California prison for beating two of her four children with a rope and an electrical cord. Her fifth child, when born in two months, will go, like the others, into foster care. There they'll stay until Ms. Johnson is out of prison and can satisfy Family Court that she'll be a good parent. The latter, of course, may never happen.

title: About Cars; New Technology Chips Away at Noise
description: There is such a thing as gee-whiz journalism, and I will admit to being a sometime practioner. But how can you not be excited about the likes of Acura's NSX supercar? Or antilock brakes, which prevent skids and save lives?

title: Style Makers; Temple St. Clair Carr, Jewelry Designer
description: Temple St. Clair Carr: The name suits the jewelry, which is elegant and sophisticated and suggests another time. It also suggests the South; Ms. Carr is a Virginia native who has spent much of her life in Europe.

title: How the West Was (Almost) Lost
description: ON A Montana battlefield, 114 years after the death of George Armstrong Custer, the atmosphere abounds in good intentions. On this summer day, after a long morning of warfare, Indian warriors and white soldiers paused for a hard-earned lunch. They do form separate lunch queues: half-clothed, long-haired Indians in one; blue-coated cavalrymen in the other. Good will, nonetheless, crosses the lines.

title: New-Home Deals Are Getting Sweeter
description: DOMINICK AND MARIE PANZERA wanted to retire near their daughter on the Jersey shore, and a developer's offer of a premium, very private lot in his new development at no extra cost clinched their decision to buy a new house in Bayville, N.J..

title: Friars Stun Syracuse, 92-82
description: Eric Murdock scored 23 points tonight to lead Providence over Syracuse, 92-82, in a Big East game.

title: Go, McEnroe; Patrick, That Is
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Pendragon,' the Arthurian Legend
description: CAMELOT was no congenial spot for happyily-ever-aftering, if you ask the playwright Laurie H. Hutzler. On the evidence of her play "Pendragon," don't.

title: SUPER BOWL XXV: Notebook; First 4-Team Super Bowl
description: Four teams made it to Super Bowl XXV in 300,000 programs printed for the game. That was done deliberately because there was one fewer week to prepare the 260-page program this year. The program is the biggest ever for a Super Bowl.

title:
DANCE;
Troupe to Open With 'Rodeo'
description: IN the annals of American dance, "Rodeo," choreographed 48 years ago by Agnes de Mille to a score by Aaron Copland, stands as a landmark work. As one of the first choreographers to create ballets on American themes, Miss De Mille created a signature dancescape by distilling the movement characteristic of working cowboys and integrating it with classical steps.

title: Managing; Executives, Take Your Risks
description: Anthony Luiso, the International Multifoods Corporation's chief executive, was due for a $100,000 raise last year. He not only turned it down, but also told the board to hold back $100,000 of his bonus. In their place, he took $200,000 in stock options, exercisable in 10 years at $32.625 each, the price on the day the deal was signed.

title: Germany
description: To the Editor: "In the Heartland of Old Germany" (Travel, Nov. 4), it is stated that in the Buchenwald concentration camp the East German regime emphasized the suffering of the Communists and that this bias is now being corrected. I saw this prejudice acutely when I toured the site with a Russian group and guide.

title: Barbara Kirby Is to Wed Ford Vernon Swick in June
description: Dr. Francis A. Kirby of Hyannis port, Mass., has announced June wedding plans for his daughter Barbara Kirby and Ford Vernon Swick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore P. Swick of Montclair, N.J.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse; Students' Letter Helps the Poor Win Federal Aid
description: One letter sent by students in a public policy course at Syracuse University has enabled 128 families to collect benefits that they never knew were available to them.

title: All About/Answering Machines; For Yuppies, Now Plain Folks, Too
description: Not too many years ago, back when telephone answering machines were rare, callers who reached a machine were either flustered or annoyed when they got a click, a hiss and a mechanical greeting instead of a live human voice. Some welcomed this tape-recorder-cum-Jeeves. The rest just sighed -- or hung up.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Ossining
description: WHEN most people think of a village, they imagine a small community with quaint streets and an unhurried pace. Ossining, in northern Westchester County on the banks of the Hudson River, is none of the above.

title: Campus Life:; Student-City Relations Strained over Taxes
description: Students from Washington and Lee University and city officials are holding meetings in an attempt to resolve their differences after students threatened to boycott businesses in downtown Lexington to protest a personal property tax the city intends to levy on students' cars.

title: Smith Speaks Up For Team of the 90's
description: It was Friday morning. All of the news conferences were over and nearly all of the preparation was complete for Bruce Smith and the Buffalo Bills, who play the Giants in Super Bowl XXV this evening in Tampa Stadium. Smith climbed back into bed in his hotel room, pulled the covers up close to his neck and used a few quiet moments to reflect.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Jan. 12 MANHATTAN Chelsea 550,000 475 West 22d Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,550-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; dining area, 2 fireplaces, private garden; maintenance $900, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Gramercy Park 445,000 60 Gramercy Park 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,700-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, herringbone floors, French doors; maintenance $1,190, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Cathy Fields Realty-Corcoran Group) SoHo 690,000 140 Grand Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 4,000-sq.-ft. loft co-op; high-ceilings, decorative columns, 2 exposures, elevator; maintenance $948, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Herbert H. title: White House Moves to End Feud at Information Agency
description: The White House has asked the director of the United States Information Agency, Bruce Gelb, to step down and accept the post of Ambassador to Belgium, Administration officials said today.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Private Owners Put Homes on the Block
description: AUCTIONS, which many developers and co-op sponsors are using to quickly dispose of unsold properties in a weak market, are now being offered to private homeowners on Long Island.

title: Markets Decide To Mark Time

In the Region: New Jersey;
The Waterfront Building Battle Heats Up
description: A NEW round of debate on permitting growth along the Jersey shore while protecting the environment was set off late last month when a court struck down emergency regulations put in place last summer to slow the pace of development along 127 miles of oceanfront.

title: The World; Israel, Enduring Missiles, Expects a Political Victory
description: WHEN American Patriot missiles intercepted one of the Iraqi Scuds hurtling toward Haifa late Friday night, it seemed oddly appropriate that much of the debris falling to earth shattered windows and dented cars in the city's Arab neighborhoods.

title: Headliners; Sudden Fame
description: Though he has written novels for some 40 years, Nicholas Mosley has been one of the lesser known lights on the London literary scene. Last week his reputation moved into the ascendent when the author, the 67-year-old son of Sir Oswald Mosley, who led the British Union of Fascists in the 1930's, won Britain's prestigious Whitbread Book of the Year award for his novel "Hopeful Monsters." In the book, a physics and biology student from England, living among Berlin's radical fringe in the 1920's and 1930's, falls in love with a German Jew. Einstein and Wittgenstein make cameo appearances in the novel, which explores genetics, the atomic bomb, linguistic philosophy and the rise of Fascism. "I am so used to being the dark horse that I was quite reconciled to ending my days as one," said the author, who has been described as liberal, soft-spoken and unlike his father in many other ways. The novelist and biographer A. N. Wilson called "Hopeful Monsters" "the finest work of fiction to be published in England since the war."

title: A Rite Arrives, Modified
description: Barring a major last-minute development in the Persian Gulf war or a major terrorist incident here, Super Bowl XXV will be played Sunday, with a few twists.

title: Eve Brown Engaged to John F. Waite
description: Melvin Brown of Syosset, L.I., and Sheila Brown-Blei of Mariner Harbor, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eve Jennifer Brown, to John Francis Waite, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Waite of Winchester, Mass. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Entrepreneurs Help Elderly Remain Independent
description: A FEW years ago, when Roberta Feinberg put a small advertisement aimed at the elderly in a local newspaper, she had no idea that she was starting a successful business. The ad read, "Woman with car available for shopping, errands and a little companionship."

title: The Protesters, Heard
description: Iraq is not Vietnam, and yesterday's antiwar demonstrators in Washington mostly shunned crude slogans like "No blood for oil!" Most of them would agree with Vice President Quayle about the need to support America's troops in the gulf. As the country braces for a longer war, there is no shouting down these protesters. Their arguments need to be answered.

title: Bridge
description: If the bidding of the diagramed deal appears extraordinary, it is. But, paradoxically, it is entirely ordinary and routine when placed in context.

title: Novo-Nordisk Rides the Enzyme Tide
description: Copenhagen's Assistens Cemetery is one of the burial sites established after the plague of 1711.

title: Laura Lee Eifert to Marry
description: April wedding plans for Laura Lee Eifert and Franklin Montross 4th, the son of Joan Oliver Montross of Bedford, N.Y., and Mr. Montross 3d of Boston, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Eifert of Tryon, N.C. Miss Eifert, 32 years old, is an account executive at Eifert, French & Ketchum, an insurance company headed by her father, in Pelham, N.Y. She is a graduate of Franklin Pierce College. Mr. Montross, 34, is a vice president at the General Reinsurance Corporation in Stamford, Conn. He is a graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., and Harvard University.

title: GORBACHEV GIVES K.G.B. NEW POWERS TO POLICE ECONOMY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today granted sweeping powers to the K.G.B. and the police to search private business premises and confiscate documents to combat "economic sabotage."

title: The Wedding; Unbridled Fantasies
description: It's a tradition left over from the grand days of couture. At the close of every collection, an ethereal bride wafted through the salons to waves of polite applause. Today, designers may still end their showings with a bridal outfit, but the atmosphere is totally different. The shows are set in tents or huge halls; spectators number well into the hundreds; cameras flash; the music roars. Some of these brides are like those of old -- dressed in dreamlike concoctions that express their creator's fashion fantasy. More often, these dresses are added for wit or as a punchy finale. Here are some recent, and memorable, runway brides.

title: Black Families Grapple With War
description: IN small communities and large last week, black Westchester families with relatives serving in the Persian Gulf sought to resolve their frustration over a war few people wanted with support for those who are serving.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Personal income and spending for December. TUESDAY: Durable goods for December. * Conference Board's index of consumer confidence for January. * Employment cost index for the fourth quarter. * State of the Union address. WEDNESDAY: Leading economic indicators for December. * Internal Revenue Service scheduled to auction off Willie Nelson's 44-acre ranch and 4,700-square-foot house in Evergreen, Colo. THURSDAY: New home sales for December. * United Steelworkers contract with USX expires at midnight. * Jobless claims for week ended Jan. 19. * Farm prices for January. FRIDAY: January unemployment. * Construction spending for December. * Governing board of International Energy Agency holds a private meeting in Paris.

title: Michael Donahue Plans to Be Wed To Reed von Gal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Vreeland von Gal of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Reed von Gal to Michael Phillip Donahue, a son of Margaret Mary Cooney of Albuquerque, N.M., and Phillip John Donahue of New York and Westport, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: The Nation; Between War And Slump, A Little Room For Congress
description: IN years past, Presidential State of the Union Messages often laid out legislative agendas as Congress convened. Nobody is sure whether that will happen when President Bush gives his speech to Congress and a national television audience on Tuesday. For, even without the war in the Persian Gulf and the Soviet troubles in the Baltics, two likely topics, Mr. Bush has shown little inclination to develop a substantial domestic program.

title: Where Some See Recession, Others See Opportunity
description: IN August, despite glum economic forecasts for Connecticut, Vivian Blaha decided to start a business. Without any advance advertising, she rented space in a shopping center in Guilford and hung up her handmade shingle: "Thimble Weeds: Tailoring and Alterations for Men and Women." Before long, she said, her rack was filled with garments awaiting new zippers, linings and hems. Lately, she has asked a local seamstress to take care of her overflow work.

title: Overwhelmed by Sex
description: AN HONORABLE PROFESSIONBy John L'Heureux.403 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Data Bank/January 27, 1991
Debra Gabelman To Marry in Fall
description: Debra Bonnie Gabelman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gabelman of East Meadow, L.I., and Gary Joseph Bachman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Bachman of Fair Lawn, N.J., plan to be married in October.

title: Susan Casazza to Wed N. E. Sienko Jr.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert R. Casazza of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Leslie Casazza, to Norman Edward Sienko Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman E. Sienko of Wethersfield, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Not Really Such Straightshooters, After All
description: Among the legends that lurk in the history of French Impressionism, none was more tenacious than the belief that Claude Monet was the archetypal upstanding Impressionist straightshooter. He, if anyone, was faithful -- so legend said -- to his immediate and fugitive impressions, and set them down unedited. As for the glazes, the sauces and the learned combinations that painters had traditionally cooked up in the studio, he turned his back upon them.

title: The Spirit Is Willing, But the Wood Is Weak
description: PINOCCHIO IN VENICEBy Robert Coover.330 pp. New York:Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: The World; For Some, a U.S. Victory Would Be the Third World's Loss
description: IF the war against Saddam Hussein has closed a gap between East and West, it has opened a chasm between North and South -- the developed nations and the third world.

title: Jenny Cox Is Wed To Howard Blum
description: Jane Davenport Cox, a book editor, and Howard Blum, a writer and journalist, were married yesterday at the Harvard Club in New York. Judge Robert G. M. Keating, the administrative judge of the New York City Criminal Court, officiated.

title: Caroline Cuevas Affianced
description: August wedding plans for Caroline Daniella Cuevas and Albert Paul Keck 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Keck of Indio, Calif., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Cuevas of New York. Miss Cuevas, 22 years old, is an elementary-school teacher in Redlands, Calif. She graduated from Stanford University and is a student at the Claremont (Calif.) Graduate School of Education. The prospective bridegroom, 23, is the production manager at the Hadley Date Gardens in Indio. He received a bachelor's degree and a master's in food research from Stanford.

title: EUROPEANS CONFER ON EMIGRE LIMITS
description: Once they get the freedom to travel, 1.5 million to 2 million Soviet citizens are likely to leave home looking for work in the West, a Soviet official told representatives from the Council of Europe this week at a conference on policies on migrants and refugees.

title: Teen-Age Limbo
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Pledge $13.5 Billion To Help Pay for War in Gulf
description: The Saudis will give $13.5 billion to help pay for the war with Iraq, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said tonight.

title:
FORUM;
U.S. Banks Need an Overseas Presence
description: Recently a California-based bank-holding company, the Security Pacific Corporation, joined Chase Manhattan, Chemical Bank, Manufacturers Hanover, and several other banking giants in slashing its foreign operations. This leaves Citibank as virtually the only American money center institution with a large, sustained overseas presence.

title: Suicide Prompts School to Reconsider Prevention Efforts
description: ABOUT six years ago, in response to a rash of teen-age suicides nationwide, officials at White Plains High School put together what they considered to be a suicide-prevention program that really worked. Its cornerstone was a plan to get help quickly to troubled students.

title: Far From the Madding Hearth
description: The Victorian explorer Sir Samuel Baker was pleased to discover that his wife possessed "a share of sang-froid admirably adapted for African travel. Mrs. Baker is not a screamer." Neither are many of the roughly 350 other estimable ladies in Jane Robinson's WAYWARD WOMEN: A Guide to Women Travellers (Oxford University, $29.95). And neither, unfortunately, are they as well known as their male counterparts. Ms. Robinson, a British bibliographer, set out to correct this situation by producing a reference guide to "all the first-hand travel accounts ever written by women" and published in the English language. But then, luckily for the reader, she committed what she charmingly calls "the bibliographer's cardinal sin" -- she started to read the books themselves. The result is a less comprehensive but far more engaging work, an annotated ramble through a surprisingly large chunk of history in the company of ancient pilgrims (the fourth-century abbess Etheria, who, lacking a Baedeker, merely used her Bible to map a route through the Holy Land), modern daredevils (the Hon. Mrs. Victor Bruce, the first woman known to be charged with speeding, who was still test-driving for the Ford Motor Company at the age of 78) and eternal eccentrics (Margaret Fountaine, a parson's daughter whose "three great passions" were "travel, butterflies, and Unsuitable Attachments"). Ms. Robinson not only introduces us to such tempting (and often out of print) titles as "On Sledge and Horseback to Outcast Siberian Lepers," "Unprotected Females in Norway" and "To Lake Tanganyika in a Bath Chair"; she also steers us wittily away from bores like Charlotte Cameron ("the patron saint of cruise liners") and Mrs. Theodore F. Hughes (a late 19th-century visitor to the Orient who "grew maudlin and weak on a diet of chicken and oysters"). Any dedicated reader of travel books is bound to have a few quibbles with her selections (Lola Montez and Florence Nightingale, but no Sybille Bedford?), although sheer gratitude for discoveries like "An English Girl's First Impressions of Burmah" by Beth Ellis ("one of the funniest travel books ever written") is likely to win out.

title: The Daily News Strike Tests The Will of Weakened Labor
description: Though small and in some ways parochial, the strike at The Daily News has become an important trial for an American labor movement that has been losing ground for decades.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Team of My Youth, Town of My Heart
description: The columnist George Will has said that professional football is "organized violence punctuated by committee meetings." I prefer to think of pro football as an example of entrepreneurial capitalism at its best.

title: Hers; The Virtues Of Virtue
