description: UNTIL THE DAY I was married, I'd never seen a naked man, nor had I spent a night away from my parents' home except for camp and college. I'd been out of college for two years, held a good job, but by night, if not by day, the world was my cloister.

title: War Casts Shadow On Show
description: What was to be the most gala Super Bowl ever presented has become the most understated.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; An Alumni Grant Leads to a Guide For the Disabled
description: The very qualities that make the 244-year-old Princeton University campus appealing to some students can be burdensome to those with physical disabilities. With a $65,000 grant from two anonymous alumni, the university has put together a Campus Accessibility Guide to reduce the exasperation of handicapped students and visitors.

title: Right-Wing Myths
description: Right-wing propagandists have discovered how to use the Persian Gulf war, which many of them oppose, to ride an old hobbyhorse back into the sunlight. Turn on the television, look at their columns, and learn two new meta-facts:

title: Coffee, Tea or Kitsch?
description: FROM Boston Harbor to California's Disneyland, our landscape is cluttered with hazardous kitsch lying in ambush for the unsuspecting traveler. But perhaps nowhere is the danger greater than in airport gift shops, which arguably represent the apogee of bad taste in this America. These commercial purgatories of idle airline passengers hawk the joys of pencils as thick as broom handles with a plastic Statue of Liberty on top, bags of sand from Florida, crushed ceramic beer cans, coffee mugs that have two legs wearing cowboy boots, and plaster frogs strumming guitars while sitting on a little toilet.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Dec. 2 about tours of Pacific battle sites referred incorrectly to a cruise scheduled for Feb. 21 to March 21, 1992. A letter from Kloster Cruise dated Jan. 11 said that the ship would not be the Royal Viking Star; the organizer, Valor Tours, has not yet named another.

title: On Language; Brits, Tommies, Poms, Limeys & Kippers
description: ONCE AGAIN, IN THE crunch, the Yanks find themselves side by side with the Brits .

title:
DINING OUT;
Discreet Charm of Japanese in Scarsdale
description: NO sprawling sign indicates this restaurant's presence, and the few discreet characters in Japanese and bit of bamboo and rice paper in the storefront window can easily go unnoticed. Nonetheless, Gyosai attracts a steady flow of diners who have discovered that this is the place to enjoy a superior and impressive variety of spectacularly fresh fish, beautifully cut for sushi, sashimi and the large number of snack-sized dishes this restaurant offers.

title: The Executioners' Idea of a Joke
description: GETTING USED TO DYING By Zhang Xianliang. Translated and edited by Martha Avery. 291 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $19.95.

title: Mutual Funds; Using Zeros as a Safe Harbor
description: Playing the financial markets these days is like hopping a ride on a rogue freight train: You may reach your destination or your investment may be completely derailed.

title: Theus Sparks Nets' Victory
description: Reggie Theus scored 15 of his 35 points in the third quarter and the Nets outscored Miami, 70-40, in the second half to defeat the Heat, 127-105, tonight.

title:
Your Own Account;
What to Do About Annuities
description: After a column about annuities appeared here Dec. 9, many readers wrote in expressing concern about the safety of the annuity contracts they bought from insurance companies and asking about how state guarantee funds protect them. Here are answers to some of their questions.

title: 'Love, Groucho'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf 12-17

title: The Executive Computer; Kodak Combines a Network Printer With a Copier
description: Making its first major thrust into the desktop computer printer market, the Eastman Kodak Company last week introduced a 16-page-a-minute laser-quality printer that also functions as a simple photocopying machine.

title: Reasonable Men Can Disagree
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read Mr. Henahan's clear, thoughtful expression of his views about atonal composition. Doubtless he speaks for a large majority of listeners who share his inability to find much satisfaction in this music.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: In Love With Numbers

title: ARE THINGS AS BAD AS THEY LOOK
description: Yertle the Turtle, Dr. Seuss assures us, came a cropper when his hastily rigged empire turned out to be just another shell game. Yertle was the ruler of a small turtle pond, who had the brilliant insight that his kingdom extended as far as he could see. His subjects were ordered to pile up in a higher and higher stack while Yertle, perched on top, exulted in his new glory. Alas, the underpinnings of his kingdom proved structurally unsound when a little turtle at the bottom of the pile had the bad manners to burp. The whole stack came crashing down and a thoroughly humbled Yertle ended up stuck deep in the turtle pond mud.

title: China Sentences 8 Leading Dissidents
description: A Chinese court today sentenced the nation's leading human rights advocate to seven years in prison and its foremost student leader to a four-year term for "counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement" during the Tiananmen democracy movement.

title: Sons, Lovers, Immigrant Souls
description: CRIME AGAINST NATUREBy Minnie Bruce Pratt.120 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.:Firebrand Books. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95.THE CITY IN WHICH I LOVE YOUBy Li-Young Lee.89 pp. Brockport, N.Y.:BOA Editions. Cloth, $18. Paper, $9.IN THE BUILDED PLACEBy Michael Heller.117 pp. Minneapolis:Coffee House Press. Paper, $8.95.

title: Mutual Funds; Predicting Recession's Winners
description: After a recession ends, what happens in the stock market? Standard & Poor's defines 65 industry groups, and Elaine Garzarelli, a market analyst with Lehman Brothers and manager of the $500 million Sector Analysis Portfolio, decided to look at how each performed after each of the eight recessions since 1949.

title: Where the First Amendment Can't Go
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE ON THE GULF
description: Trouble in Missile Defense Problems are becoming apparent with use of the Patriot missile to defend Israel against missile attack: Iraqi warheads can explode and cause serious damage even though the missiles carrying them are hit by the Patriots. Page 14. Hussein's Adviser: Himself President Saddam Hussein has surrounded himself with yes-men. In meetings, he states a position, then proceeds to ask questions, which he answers himself. Page 16. Moscow Lodges a Dissent With an American-Soviet summit meeting in doubt, the Soviet Foreign Minister, in Washington, expressed worry that the war was extending beyond the United Nations' mandate and presenting "a growing danger" to Iraqi civilians. Page 8. Protest, With a Difference Tens of thousands rallied against the war, with themes distinctly different from protests of the past. Flag-waving demonstrators spoke in support of American troops. Page 17.

title: Dust, Gas, Desert Storm
description: Desert storms, we are told, transpose dunes and alter the desert topography. But it is dust that they blow about, for the most part; lots of it. And dust, we are further told, is the stuff that people, let alone nations, tend to humble each other into. This Desert Storm is no exception.

title: Metro Matters; Deferred Fun: Jumping Hurdles Of Bureaucracy
description: The very notion that someone would be motivated to simulate reality in New York City -- as if anybody needed yet another dose of it -- and then expect to profit from the experience might evoke an archetypal New York response: Be real.

title: Lord Einstein Founder To Join Unit of Lintas
description: Kevin O'Neill, a founding partner of Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, is joining Lintas New York as executive vice president and group creative director. He replaces Mike Shalette, who was executive vice president and executive creative director and is moving to Lintas Marketing Communications.

title: Revoke Peace Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: Author's Worlds: Benign Reality and Violent Fantasy
description: A United States flag hangs from the front of her spacious Victorian house, which seems an image of the American dream. There are countless photographs of her husband and five children, chocolate cookies on the kitchen counter, a poodle called Andrew and peaceful vistas of snow-covered yards and other rambling frame homes. On this ordered back street of Andover, Mary McGarry Morris appears immersed in a life of utter and prosperous tranquillity.

title: A Nynex Account Is Put Under Review
description: The Nynex Corporation has put its $20 million corporate advertising account, now handled by Young & Rubicam, in review, according to a company spokesman.

title: Market Place; Wall St.'s Qualms About Kodak
description: THE news from the Eastman Kodak Company since Kay Whitmore became chief executive last summer has generally been good.

title: Islanders Manage to Let Lead Get Away
description: After the team had relinquished a two-goal lead in the third period and lost in overtime to the Washington Capitals, 5-4, this afternoon, Brent Sutter, the captain of the Islanders, and Al Arbour, the coach, agreed the team may be lacking confidence.

title: Hostetler Savors the Moment
description: Inside the dressing room of the Super Bowl champions, Jeff Hostetler of the Giants was listening to a chorus that a championship quarterback had not heard in a long time, if ever.

title: Loan By New York City to Help Hotel for Poor
description: At a cost of about $41,000 a room, New York City will finance the purchase and renovation of the Times Square Hotel, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday. Some of the 652 refurbished rooms in the hotel, at 255 West 43d Street at Eighth Avenue, will go to homeless people.

title: Pump-Priming Pail Is Dry As U.S. Budget Comes Up
description: In the textbook world, a primary tool to fight recession is an expanding Federal budget deficit. Extra Government stimulus, the theory goes, will make up for diminished spending in the private sector and thereby soften the economic downturn.

title: Bavaro Won't Retire Soon
description: The second one was sweeter, said Mark Bavaro, the Giants' tight end.

title: Lemieux Returns In His Grand Style
description: Mario Lemieux resumed his career Saturday night as if back problems hadn't interrupted it at all. And he was able to do it in front of his family in his native province.

title: Becker Earns Victory and the No. 1 Spot
description: Boris Becker was not interested in waiting for a computer to confirm that he is the No. 1 male tennis player in the world.

title: Voice Mail: Not Just Another Pretty Voice
description: Lorraine Routh Nelson wants the world to know that she is not some depersonalized, robotized drone lurking at the other end of a telephone. When she says, "To get your messages, press 2," she cares. Really.

title: Pinnacle West Reports Profits
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation has reported profits for the fourth quarter and for all of 1990, in contrast to losses in the comparable 1989 periods.

title: Winfield Aims to Reverse Suit
description: Lawyers for Dave Winfield are scheduled to appear in Texas state appellate court in Houston tomorrow in an effort to overturn a $1.6 million judgment against the California Angels' player in a matrimonial lawsuit. The hearing is the latest development in a bizarre collection of connected events.

title: Hoyas' Late Rally Surprises Pitt, 83-78
description: Georgetown is an entirely different team when the 7-foot-2-inch Dikembe Mutombo and the 6-10 Alonzo Mourning are on the floor together. And Pittsburgh is not the same when Brian Shorter is out of the game.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 27, 1990: MONDAY Armstrong World Inds Inc Philadelphia Elec Co Howell Corp Stone Container Corp Kentucky Utils Co Zurn Inds Inc Meredith Corp TUESDAY Alltel Corp McDonald & Co Invts Inc Becton Dickinson & Co Noble Affiliates Inc Black Hills Corp Warner-Lambert Co Borden Inc Weis Mkts Inc Cilcorp Inc WEDNESDAY Ashland Oil Inc McGraw-Hill Inc Beckman Instrs Inc New Jersey Res Corp Gencorp Inc United States Surgical Corp Lukens Inc THURSDAY Avemco Corp Parker Hannifin Corp Donnelley R R & Sons Co Quaker St Corp Interstate Pwr Co Sara Lee Corp Kaufman & Broad Corp Smiths Food & Drug Ctrs Oregon Stl Mls Inc FRIDAY Atlanta Gas Lt Co Temple Inland Inc Broad Inc Timken Co Lee Enterprises Inc United States Shoe Corp Omnicare Inc Washington Wtr Pwr Co State Mut Secs Tr SUNDAY Louisiana Pac Corp

title: Lakers Batter Celtics, 104-87
description: The Boston Celtics miss Larry Bird's scoring, passing, rebounding and, most of all, his leadership. That was never more evident than this afternoon when they took a 104-87, battering from the Los Angeles Lakers in the annual Boston Garden meeting of two franchises that between them have won 61 percent of the National Basketball Association titles.

title: The Killing Fields Aren't Level
description: Close to 30 percent of the Army's troops in Operation Desert Storm are black, though blacks are just 14 percent of the nation's population between the ages of 18 and 24. In a land war, black casualties will be similarly disproportionate. Is it fair? Is it inevitable? For answers, one must search the soul of American society.

title: Gas Masks And Face Masks
description: "ARMS up, sir," said the man in the yellow security jacket who was standing outside of Gate 1 at Tampa Stadium yesterday afternoon.

title: Ho Chi Minh City; Poking Around in the Attic of Vietnam's History
description: In the archeology of discarded foreign influence here, Soviet artifacts now sit atop the multilayered trash heap of history. But the fascination with America, if it ever disappeared, is re-emerging.

title: Japan Poised for Postwar Boom
description: With many countries struggling against slowdowns or recessions, economists are hanging on every development in the Persian Gulf for signs of how much economic damage the war is likely to cause. But few economies appear poised to benefit as much as Japan's in the event of a brief war, or have the staying power to endure a long war with as little strain, a range of experts say.

title: Outdoors: One Fly Fisher's Dream Comes True
description: SITTING here now, looking at the barren branches and the frost on the grass, it dawns on me that the seasons have made a full circle since I made a promise to myself. Last winter, I vowed that in the coming year I would catch a saltwater fish on a fly, a goal that had eluded me after almost three years of trying. It had been a long wait but it had not been passive waiting. It had become a quest costing thousands of dollars, covering four states and one foreign country.

title: Earthquake Rattles Cleveland
description: An earthquake centered in Lake Erie just north of Cleveland rattled windows here Friday night, but there were no reports of damage or injuries. The quake registered 3.2 on the Richter scale, said Frank Baldwin, a technician at the United States Geological Survey in Golden, Colo. A quake of 3.5 magnitude can cause slight damage.

title: Anderson Is Most Venerable and Most Valuable
description: Bart Oates stood at a podium, wearing a white T-shirt that somehow already read, "Giants 20, Bills 19."

title: African Sounds Spicing Up Brazil
description: An annunciatory salvo of drums, a percussive fanfare, echoes down the cobblestone hill of Ladeira do Pelourinho, and Olodum is on the march. Dancers, singers and some 30 drummers, dressed in African-inspired robes, with their drums striped in Afro-Jamaican red, green, gold and black, pound out a rhythm that is martial and unswerving below, volatile and syncopated above.

title: ABC's Coverage Stays in Perspective
description: Anxiety over the war in the Persian Gulf set the tone for ABC's Super Bowl coverage last night, subduing the telecast and putting the festivities in perspective for perhaps the first time in a quarter-century.

title: More on the Gulf
description: THE PATRIOT FACTORY There had been layoffs at the plant where Patriot missiles are made, but the weapon's success now means job security. Page A14.

title: Manhattan Bridge Had a Design Load Problem From the Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook; Whose Choice Is It, Anyway?
description: Darlene Johnson, an admitted menace to her children, was not the only dangerous person in Judge Howard Broadman's courtroom. The judge himself, a champion of "creative" sentencing, was a menace to justice.

title: Review/Music; Emerson's Russian Program
description: Carnegie Hall is not a hospitable home for chamber music these days, acoustically speaking, but the Emerson String Quartet and three associates made meaningful music there anyhow on Wednesday evening.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two dozen technicians worked in CHER's $4 million home overlooking Santa Monica Bay to put together a two-hour video collection of songs for American troops serving in the Persian Gulf.

title: Giants Bend But Don't Break
description: Ninety yards to go, 2 minutes 16 seconds to play, and Jim Kelly had the ball.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Congress; Explaining War Votes Back in Home Districts
description: Senator Sam Nunn scrapped a speech on the economy and spent three hours with the Chamber of Commerce in Gainesville, Ga., the other day, laying out details of tactics and strategy in the Persian Gulf war. He also explained his vote against authorizing the use of force.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Australian Wheat Board has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $600 million in debt securities. The board controls wheat produced in Australia. * Ford Credit Funding P.L.C., a unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $:40 million, or about $78.6 million, of 13 1/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1995 at 110.10 through J. P. Morgan. The issue is guaranteed by Ford Motor. The outstanding debt of the borrower is rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Manitoba, Canada, has filed for a shelf offering of $900 million in debt securities and warrants. RATINGS * Allied-Signal Inc.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to A-, from A, and its commercial paper to A-2, from A-1, by S.& P. The company is based in Morristown, N.J. * Harris Corp.'s senior unsecured debenture rating has been lowered to BBB, from BBB+, by S.& P. The company is based in Melbourne, Fla. * Olin Corp.'s debt rating is under review for possible downgading by Moody's. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., has interests in chemicals, metals, and military equipment.

title: Manhattan Bridge Had a Design Load Problem From the Start; And Scrap the Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: Scalpers Try to Find A Way
description: There are scalpers who work the hotels, scalpers who work the stadiums. But today they were working the highways.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday Personal Income...Dec. Tuesday Durable Goods...Dec. Wednesday eading Indicators...Dec. Thursday New-Home Sales...Dec. Friday Employment...Jan. Construction Spending...Dec.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Battle Report; Iraq's Warplanes Continue To Seek Safe Haven in Iran
description: Some of Iraq's best combat planes have been flown to Iran to escape destruction, the allied commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, said today.

title: 7 Shot to Death in New Mexico; After Search, Suspect Is in Custody
description: A policeman, a sheriff's deputy and five other people, including a 6-month-old baby, were shot to death near this rural village Saturday, and the police announced late tonight that a suspect was in custody.

title: AIDS and Privacy: A Bellevue Dilemma
description: Three years ago, at a time when Dr. Thomas Park and his wife were considering starting a family, a nurse at Bellevue Hospital dropped a knife in the operating room that nicked Dr. Park's thigh. The patient on the table was infected with the AIDS virus, and the doctor struggled with fears of death for more than a year before being tested for the disease himself.

title: Americans Should Buy a Bit More American; Their Surplus Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: 'We've Been There'
description: Us good ol' boys here in Texas have been following the economic tribulations of the Northeast with a sense of deja vu. We've been there, so we understand what you're going through.

title: Banks Are Looking a Lot Like S.& L.'s
description: Bankers proudly distinguish themselves from their counterparts in the savings and loan industry. Federal officials take offense at comparisons between the still-solvent Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the bankrupt Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. But these distinctions and protests are sounding increasingly hollow.

title: Helicopter Crash Kills Four in Pennsylvania
description: A hospital helicopter slammed into a northeastern Pennsylvania mountainside Saturday night, killing all four people on board, the authorities said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Fouled Sea; Relentless Tide of Oil Fouls Shores of Empty Saudi City
description: The cormorants, usually among nature's more elegant creatures, with their long necks and alert faces, looked like despondent hobos in their coats of thick, black sludge.

title: Parcells Likely To Remain
description: Bill Parcells tonight defused published reports that he might consider leaving the Giants for another National Football League club as general manager and coach, possibly the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Review/Ballet; A Martins And Others Take Roles In 'Jewels'
description: The New York State Theater was packed on Saturday night for George Balanchine's "Jewels," always the equivalent of a best seller at the New York City Ballet.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to today's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: Dispute Over Lease Threatens a Musical
description: The producers of the long-running black musical "Mama, I Want to Sing" say they will close the show on March 30, the eighth anniversary of its opening.

title: Embattled Anew, Winnie Mandela Faces Trial
description: In her 56 years, Nomzamo Winnifred Mandela has been no stranger to misfortune. She was born into grinding poverty. Less than five years after she married Nelson Mandela, he went to prison in 1962, and Mrs. Mandela was left to raise their two daughters alone in the face of unrelenting Government harassment.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO HOCKEY Bruins 3, Canadiens 1: Ray Bourque scored 12 minutes 50 seconds into the third period and Ken Hodge scored into an empty net with 11 seconds left yesterday as Boston won in Montreal. The Bruins had just held off a two-man advantage and the teams were playing at full strength when Bourque's low shot from the top of the right circle caught the far corner.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Oil Workers; Americans at Aramco Report Facing Job Loss if They Leave
description: Frightened by almost nighly attacks by Iraqi missiles, American employees of the Saudi national oil company are describing themselves as economic hostages, forced to choose between their jobs and their safety.

title: VIOLATIONS FOUND AT WEAPONS PLANT
description: A recent inspection of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant found many violations of safety rules, including allowing workers to enter contaminated areas without protective clothing.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Military Briefing; Excerpts From Remarks by General Schwarzkopf in Riyadh
description: Following are excerpts from a news briefing by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the American forces in the Persian Gulf, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, as transcribed by the Federal News Service: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Coke Softens Super Bowl Ads
description: The Coca-Cola Company toned down its commercials during the Super Bowl yesterday because of the war.

title: Bangladesh Graft Is Charged
description: The Government said today that the country's ousted President, H. M. Ershad, had been charged with receiving kickbacks in the purchase of three turboprop aircraft in 1990 from a British company. The Government said in a statement that Mr. Ershad and four senior aides received $8.46 million in the purchase of the advanced planes from British Aerospace for the Bangladesh Airlines fleet last October.

title: Review/Music; The Indianapolis and a Britten Song Cycle
description: Raymond Leppard's program for the Indianapolis Symphony concert last Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall was both ingenious and effective, although quite why the three pieces chosen fit together so neatly is hard to figure out. The best guess is that they were all earlyish works by Northern European composers, they all conformed to a late Romantic or neo-Classical sensibility, yet they offered enough variety to avoid sameness.

title: Washington Talk; 'Pauper' Cases Reshape High Court's Caseload
description: A dramatic surge in appeals filed by prisoners is reshaping the Supreme Court's caseload.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We are not in the business of destroying Kuwait while we are liberating Kuwait." -- Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the American forces in the Persian Gulf. [ A1:5. ]

title: Review/Film; Marital Reminiscences Of Good and Bad Days
description: In the Danish film "Memories of a Marriage" a group of friends and relatives convenes at the country cottage of Karl Age (Frits Helmuth) and his wife, Regitze (Ghita Norby), to share beer and herring and laughter. This reunion unleashes a flood of reminiscence from the principals, who recall all the stages of their many years together in a film that lasts only 90 minutes, but manages to feel as long as the couple's union.

title: INSIDE
description: Somali Rebels Claim Victory Rebels in Somalia said they had taken control of the capital and forced the President to flee his palace. French doctors largely confirmed the assertions. Page A3. Jobless and Desperate Many jobless workers, their unemployment benefits depleted, find themselves close to the financial and emotional edge. Page A14. Doctors and AIDS At Bellevue, doctors and nurses think their health is their own business, but are far from sure what they would do if they got AIDS. Page B1. Sears Catalogue at Risk Sears, Roebuck is considering drastic changes, including the sale or closing of its mail-order business. Page D1.

title: Updated Guidelines To Improve Fitness
description: REGULAR exercisers, from tennis players to aerobic dancers, typically spend an hour huffing and puffing through their allotted fitness routine. Many people think that anything less just isn't a workout and anything more cuts into the rest of their lives. But how many hours a week provides the optimum workout and what kind of exercise will benefit our overall level of fitness?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Travel; FEAR OF TERRORISM IS CURBING TRAVEL
description: Frightened by the threat of terrorism and preoccupied with the war against Iraq, Americans are canceling vacation plans and choosing to stay close to home.

title: Brief History of an Earlier Antiwar Group
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: Most Solid N.F.L. Mark

title: Review/Music; An All-American Program Highlights a Human Side
description: The San Francisco-based Francesco Trio was formed in 1965, and although it draws on the full trio repertory, its specialty is contemporary American music. The group has understandably made many friends among composers, and there were several in its audience on Wednesday evening, when it played an all-American program at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LYNNE MEADOW and ALAN AYCKBOURN have had one success together, the 1988 production of "Woman in Mind" with STOCKARD CHANNING. Now, on the eve of their second production, the artistic director of the Manattan Theater Club and one of Britain's most popular playwrights are looking toward further collaboration.

title: How Census Raised New York Count
description: How did 289,000 New Yorkers manage to pop out of Census Bureau computers in the final four months of the 1990 count?

title: Giants Took a Risk and Won
description: The way the Giants lined up their players on defense yesterday, with only two linemen, was a definite risk on the part of Bill Belichick, the defensive coordinator. But it was a risk that paid off, thanks to a missed Buffalo field goal at the end and the effectiveness of the Giants' offense, which kept the ball for 40 of the 60 playing minutes.

title: CBS Presses Hunt for Crew
description: CBS News stepped up its efforts yesterday to find the correspondent Bob Simon and his three-man crew, missing since last Monday in a front-line region of the Persian Gulf war. But no trace of the men was found, and a Cable News Network reporter in Baghdad quoted Iraqi officials as saying they had no word on the crew.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook; On the Road to Kuwait, 500,000 Mines
description: Iraq has laid half a million land mines in the desert, the Marine Corps said today.

title: New President At Muppet Unit
description: The oldest son of the creator of the Muppets, Jim Henson, has been named president of the television and film production company his father founded in 1958.

title: Remember The Kurds
description: Let's tug at a thread and see if it unravels a strategy.

title: Princeton Women Forge a New Era
description: Now that the last all-male eating club at Princeton University is being forced to open its doors to women, the question is: will women want to join?

title: Dallas Chooses a Police Chief
description: A Los Angeles deputy police chief was chosen Friday to lead the Dallas force, succeeding Mack Vines, who was dismissed in September on charges that he had lied to officials investigating a shooting by a police officer. The new Chief, William Rathburn, 49 years old, was selected from more than 100 candidates. He was chief of security for the Los Angeles police force during the 1984 Olympic Games and has won community praise as commander of that city's Southern Bureau.

title: 'We're No. 1' in Subdued Tone
description: It was the most thrilling ending to the most thrilling game. But even to die-hard Giants fans, people who get down on their knees in bars and pray for the kind of ending they got last night, this time it was only a game.

title: Andover Journal; At a Missile Maker, Pride and Relief
description: For many workers in this Boston suburb of 27,000 people, the success of the Patriot missile in the Persian Gulf war is more than just a matter of pride. It's a matter of job security.

title: Arab Site in Marseilles Is Hit by a Small Bomb
description: A small bomb exploded early today outside an information center for Arab immigrants in Marseilles, causing no casualties and little physical damage but adding to tensions among the port city's Muslims and Jews.

title: Review/Theater; Sondheim and Those Who Would Kill
description: No one in the American musical theater but Stephen Sondheim could have created the chorus line that greets -- or should one say affronts? -- the audience at the beginning and end of "Assassins," the new revue at Playwrights Horizons.

title: Hattie Kalish Marries Harold Lynton
description: Hattie Gruenstein Kalish, a social worker, and Harold Stephen Lynton, a lawyer, were married yesterday at Mr. Lynton's home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Judge Richard W. Wallach of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: MacLeod Trying To Stay Hopeful
description: The Knicks took some time off to watch the Super Bowl after arriving here today, but they were probably too distracted by the state of their own team to enjoy the play of the Giants and the Bills.

title: Tourism Shaken By 'CNN Effect'
description: Some travel specialists say a fascination with television news about the Persian Gulf war is keeping people at home.

title: Insurgents Claiming Victory in Somalia
description: Rebels in Somalia said on Saturday night that they had won control of the capital, Mogadishu, and had forced President Mohammed Siad Barre to flee his palace.

title: Review/Recital; Leontyne Price Travels From Arias to Gospel
description: Leontyne Price gave a remarkable recital at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening. But the most memorable moment of the performance came nearly an hour after the end of the printed program. Miss Price had already sung eight encores -- two spirituals, four arias by Puccini, one by Verdi and Gershwin's "Summertime" -- and the house lights had gone up before the last one.

title: Players in Their 80's Going Strong in 90's
description: RUNNING around a tennis court at the age of 80 may seem like a fantasy to most people, but to the players on the United States Tennis Association's octogenarian circuit, it's a glorious reality.

title: Some in Congress Harden on Trade
description: Many members of Congress are preparing for another confrontation with the Bush Administration over trade legislation.

title: Busy Week for Giants' Man in the Middle
description: At age 32, Bart Oates has been a professional football center for nine seasons: three with the Philadelphia/Baltimore Stars of the United States Football League and the last six with the Giants. Since June, he has graduated from Seton Hall Law School, passed the New Jersey Bar examination and been voted to the Pro Bowl. Yesterday, he played in his second Super Bowl. Here is his diary for the last week as told to Frank Litsky of The New York Times. Monday

title: Bronx Mourns First Death From Gulf War
description: At St. Anselm's Church in the South Bronx, hundreds gathered yesterday to mourn the war made real.

title: Slump Forcing Up Albany's Aid to Poor
description: In blaming New York's fiscal slide on the national recession, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been highlighting the corrosive effect of hard times on state revenues. But the recession is also applying great pressure to the spending side of the state budget by increasing the mandated costs of caring for the poor.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Children; How to Keep a Faraway War in the Right Perspective
description: It took only a few days after war erupted in the Persian Gulf for the action to spread to the snow-covered yard of the Duffy household in Montclair, N.J., where the two Duffy boys were at play.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The General; Man in the News; Tough but Politic Chief; H. Norman Schwarzkopf
description: In his two tours of duty in the Vietnam War, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf learned that a military leader must have more than enough force on the battlefield and more than enough political backing at home.

title: When Doctors Are Infected With AIDS
description: Should a surgeon or dentist infected with the virus that causes AIDS be allowed to operate on unsuspecting patients? That thorny question draws sharply conflicting answers from medical groups and health authorities. Some want to protect the careers of doctors and the smooth functioning of the health care system. Others want to safeguard patients and their right to make informed decisions.

title: Accounts
description: * Chiat/Day/Mojo Los Angeles has been awarded the Toshiba portable laptop computer business with a budget of about $15 million. The account was previously at Ayer.

title: Unexpected Tight Finish
description: Scott Norwood was asked the question last Wednesday: If Super Bowl XXV was to be decided by a last-second field goal, what did it mean that his team had entered having whipped the Raiders by 51-3 while the Giants were entering on a thrilling late field goal by Matt Bahr in their 15-13 victory over the 49ers?

title: Many Builders Say Inspectors Expect Bribes
description: The bribing of city inspectors to obtain approval to occupy new or completely renovated apartment buildings is widespread in New York, developers and contractors say.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; SAUDIS ABANDONING OLD SECRETIVENESS
description: Shedding its traditional reluctance to call attention to its accomplishments and weaknesses, Saudi Arabia has begun to discuss openly its conduct of the war against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Many Print Ads Revive 'A Bare and Open Look'
description: Wide open spaces are returning to American print advertising and publication design.

title: Soviets Said to Hedge on War With Future in Mind
description: Administration officials said today that they viewed the statements by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, cautioning the United States against destroying Iraq as the beginning of an effort by the Soviet Union to preserve its influence in the Arab world in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Huge Funeral Crowd Gathers Amid Unrest in South Africa
description: Thousands of mourners gathered in the black township of Sebokeng today to bury 39 supporters of the African National Congress who were killed in a recent massacre. The police reported seven more people slain in unrest nationwide, and leaders of the nominally independent Ciskei homeland said their military foiled a coup attempt.

title: Reader's Digest Looks Beyond Itself
description: For decades, this 127-acre tract of neo-Georgian buildings and sprawling oak trees was the place where hundreds of employees of the Reader's Digest Association began their careers and stayed for the rest of their working lives.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES M. LaROSSA has been named outstanding criminal lawyer of the year by the New York State Bar Association, which gave him the award at the group's annual meeting on Thursday in Manhattan. Mr. LaRossa has been the lawyer of choice for other lawyers, judges and politicians, including MARIO BIAGGI and MEADE ESPOSITO. He has also represented the late Paul Castellano, who law-enforcement officials said was the head of the Gambino crime family, a position authorities contend is now occupied by JOHN GOTTI.

title: Troops Are Edgy Watching the Game
description: With a pretzel in one hand and a beer in the other, Tech. Sgt. James Lee was ready for the kickoff, wishing his Bears were playing but adopting Buffalo instead.

title: Woman In The News; Dynamic Advocate; Nadine Strossen
description: The founding principles of the American Civil Liberties Union come to life in the family history of Nadine Strossen, its newly elected president.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S. BOMBS KUWAIT OIL STATIONS, SEEKING TO CUT FLOW INTO GULF; MORE IRAQI PLANES FLY TO IRAN
description: The United States bombed Iraqi-controlled oil installations along the Kuwaiti coastline in hopes of stemming a huge oil spill deliberately unleashed by Iraq nearly a week ago, the American military said today.

title: Shortage of Scores Has Bills Amazed
description: In the silver anniversary of the Super Bowl, there was no silver lining and no solace for the Buffalo Bills in their one-point loss. Their hurry-up, no-huddle offense had scored so many points so easily in the playoffs en route to Tampa Stadium tonight that it made this 20-19 loss to the Giants in Super Bowl XXV especially hard for the Bills to accept.

title: Manhattan Bridge Had a Design Load Problem From the Start; Slain Messenger
description: To the Editor:

title: End of Jobless Benefits Pushes Many Near Despair
description: Swollen and weary in her ninth month of pregnancy, 28-year-old Lisa Bramlette sat chatting at her kitchen table while her 5-year-old son, Tyler, romped around the house in a Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtle outfit.

title: Plight of Children Strikes Contributors to the Neediest Cases
description: Many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund say their gifts are an investment in an important and vulnerable resource, children.

title: U.S. Says Supremacists Targeted TV Stations
description: The Federal Government says three men accused of hoarding stolen military weapons were planning to use them against newspapers, television stations and businesses owned by Jews and blacks.

title: Talks on Cable Deal End
description: Landmark Communications Inc. says it has ended talks with the Mizlou Communications Company for the purchase of Mizlou's cable television sports network. Landmark decided to drop its plans for a sports news network partly because of changes in the sports television market, Wendy Stahl, Landmark's vice president for investments, said last week. Mizlou, based in Edison, N.J., had announced in December a preliminary agreement to sell its financially troubled Sports News Network and certain other assets to Landmark and the Telecable Corporation, which are both based in Norfolk.

title: F.T.C. Is Re-Emerging As Watchdog on Prices
description: The Federal Trade Commission, slowly emerging from the laissez-faire attitude of the Reagan Administration, is starting to use its antitrust muscles and renew its interest in cases that affect the public's pocketbook.

title: As Urban Blight Worsens, Victims Find Their Isolation Is Deepening
description: In the St. Thomas housing project, with its rows of boarded-up red brick buildings, the ghosts speak more eloquently than the living about the despair at the bottom of urban America.

title: Computer Programmers To Lose Overtime Pay
description: A change in Federal labor law will mean that thousands of computer programmers will no longer receive overtime pay. The change, pushed through by computer industry trade groups, could mean big savings for companies that pay programmers on an hourly basis, though it is unclear how many such programmers there are.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Oil Pipes; Manifolds: Pressure Points for Stemming the Spill
description: When the United States wanted to stop the flow of Kuwaiti oil into the Persian Gulf, it bombed two mazes of pipes and valves that regulate the flow of oil entering pipelines to nearby loading docks.

title: War Summary
description: STOPPING A FLOOD OF OIL

title: Giants Win
description: Last Sunday, the Giants got to Super Bowl XXV with a field goal on the final play of the game. Today, they won the Super Bowl when the Buffalo Bills missed a 47-yard field-goal attempt with four seconds left.

title: States Battle U.S. and Other States Over Waste
description: A dispute over the disposal of hazardous wastes in several Southeastern states is posing a challenge to the established principle that the Federal Government and not the states should control the transportation and disposal of dangerous industrial byproducts.

title: Books of The Times; What the U.S. Can Do to Pay for Its Past Mistakes
description: Within Our Means The Struggle for Economic Recovery After a Reckless Decade By Alfred L. Malabre Jr. Illustrated. 167 pages. Random House. $21.

title: Investors Challenging Banks on Bad Loans
description: Shareholders and the Securities and Exchange Commission are questioning whether some banks violated securities laws by concealing bad loans for months before they announced large losses.

title: Vietnam Shops Are Backed
description: The President of Vietnam has signed a law sanctioning and protecting private business in hopes of reviving one of the world's most backward economies.

title: War Reports May Provide A Springboard for Profits
description: EVEN with the costs of covering the Persian Gulf war piling up alarmingly for the network news divisions, there may be a light at the end of the tunnel. The light reads: "On the Air."

title: Clausewitz: Man of the Year?
description: Practicing soldiers do not usually bother themselves much with theories of war, and when they do the results are likely as not to be disastrous. You can't make war by the book, they say quite rightly, and there is no simple formula for victory.

title: Herman H. Kahn, 81, An Expert on Securities
description: Herman H. Kahn, a longtime partner in the Lehman Brothers investment banking firm, died on Friday at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and had homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Manhattan.

title: How to Read the Menu
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. Is Hoping To Lease Out Space At Its Headquarters
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is trying to lease out most of the space in its headquarters at 550 Madison Avenue and planning to shift its employees to less expensive office space elsewhere in New York City.

title: Giants Win Super Bowl With Nail-Biting Finish
description: How 'bout them Giants?

title: New Clerk for Supreme Court
description: Maj. Gen. William K. Suter, the Army's assistant judge advocate general, was chosen Friday as the new clerk of the Supreme Court. Mr. Suter, 53 years old, a career Army lawyer who is retiring from a job he has held since 1985, will take over his new duties on Feb. 1. He succeeds Joseph F. Spaniol Jr., who is retiring after five years as clerk. Mr. Suter will be paid an annual salary of $101,300 and will supervise a staff of 35.

title: Assessing the Drop in the G.N.P.
description: With the economy declining at a 2.1 percent annual rate in last year's fourth quarter, a much smaller drop than Wall Street had anticipated, questions have been raised among analysts about whether the current downturn is a full-blown recession or merely a three-month phenomenon.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Canada; Canadians Enter Gulf War, Sparking Debate
description: Canadian forces went to war last week against Iraq, and although their role has been modest, the commitment to offensive action has stirred considerable debate here.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Egypt; Hussein Could Stay in Power, Egyptian Says
description: Egypt said today that it was not in favor of the destruction of Iraq or the elimination of President Saddam Hussein as that country's leader, asserting that it was prepared to cooperate with him in the future as it had in the past.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; Kurds on Turkey's Border With Iraq Fear War Will Reach Them
description: The last people believed to have been gassed by Saddam Hussein's troops fill a tent city lying a few hundred yards from Hidir Ozmen's stone farmhouse.

title: Montana Senate Clears Judge Impeached in War Hysteria
description: The State Senate on Saturday exonerated a former judge who was removed from office in the anti-German hysteria of World War I.

title: A Focus on Introducing Blacks to Skiing
description: PLACING blacks on the United States Ski Team is the goal of the National Brotherhood of Skiers, a 12,000-member organization of skiers, most of whom are black, who belong to 63 ski clubs across the nation. But the group's mandate also extends to introducing growing numbers of blacks on a recreational level to a sport that has traditionally been the province of whites.

title: U.N.L.V. Leaves Varied Impressions
description: Funny how teammates can play in the same game against the same opponent and come away with completely different opinions about what happened. Take Everic Sullivan and LaBradford Smith.

title: Parcells Always Has a Plan
description: SHORTLY before noon, the Giants' locker room was empty except for one person. Already dressed in the blue-and-red sweater, red sports shirt and blue slacks that he would be wearing on the sideline more than six hours later, Bill Parcells was walking around, puffing occasionally on a cigarette, wondering if his game plan would work.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Tool Orders For Factories Rise 43.7%
description: The machine tool industry reported a surge in capital spending by American manufacturers in December.

title: Bridge
description: Cards that are equal on paper may be unequal at the table. If a declarer has touching high cards in his hand, he should lead the higher if he wishes to induce his opponent to cover, but low if he does not. This guideline can be significant at all levels of the game. The diagramed deal, from the Optiebeurs Tournament in the Netherlands last October illustrates the point.

title: Car Dealers See Hard Times
description: One in five auto dealerships may close within the next two years if car and truck sales do not pick up, the president of the nation's largest dealer group says.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A6-A12

title: Nine Lottery Tickets Split $90 Million Prize
description: The holders of nine lottery tickets bought in the New York metropolitan region will split the $90 million Super Lotto jackpot, the largest in New York history, lottery officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Jazz; Cool Intimacy By a Guitarist
description: John Pizzarelli, a 30-year-old guitarist and singer and son of the noted jazz guitarist Bucky Pizzarelli, belongs to a genteel pop-jazz tradition that extends from Django Reinhardt and the King Cole Trio to Micheal Franks and Kenny Rankin. Like his father, Mr. Pizzarelli plays a sevenstring guitar on which the extra is tuned to allow him to pluck the bass lines for his own solos.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING: Top Candidate Withdraws In Levine Huntley Search
description: LEVINE HUNTLEY SCHMIDT

title: Stephen P. Guardino Jr., Marine Contractor, 76
description: Stephen P. Guardino Jr., the former president of Guardino & Sons Marine Contractors, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: A Sense Of Proportion
description: U.S. and allied planes have flown 11,000 combat missions so far against Iraqi targets. But air bombardment will not be enough, intelligence officials say. The 500,000 troops massed in Saudi Arabia, most of them American, will have to go into action on the ground. The fighting may go on for months.

title: Big Change Is Expected For Sears
description: Sweeping changes at Sears, Roebuck & Company, including the possible sale or closing of the Sears catalogue, will be on the table next month when the company's board meets, retail executives and others watching the company say.

title: Spring Time On the Court
description: A new basketball shoe introduced this month by L.A. Gear, the Los Angeles footwear company, is designed to add spring to a player's steps.

title: In Tiananmen Trials, Attitude Counts
description: The three-hour trial of Wang Dan, the student leader sentenced Saturday to four years in prison, unfolded as smoothly as the script allowed it, and while the players assumed Mr. Wang's guilt, all eyes were on his performance.

title: A Great Defensive Struggle And a Special-Team Failure
description: Sam Wyche, who thought he would be coaching his Cincinnati Bengals in Super Bowl XXV in Tampa, Fla., turned to analysis during the game today between the Buffalo Bills and the Giants.

title: Americans Should Buy a Bit More American
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Policy Increases Abortions in Romania
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombian Kidnappings Are Gagging the Press
description: One recent evening, a remote-control bomb exploded on a street here, killing seven policemen. The next morning, this city's largest-selling newspaper, El Colombiano, carried this front-page lead headline: "Drug Trafficking Study Proposes Decriminalization and Elimination of Extradition."

title: Security Slows Crowd Entry
description: High above Tampa Stadium, in a grim counterpoint to children cavorting on the field in a pre-game extravaganza, antiterrorist police in camouflage and black uniforms patrolled the roof.

title: Publishers' Gamble: One Book, Two Types of Paperback
description: Toni Morrison's novel "Beloved" won the 1988 Pulitzer Prize for fiction, and after New American Library reprinted it as a trade paperback, it sold more than 600,000 copies. That is a stunning sale for a trade paperback -- a softcover book that looks like a hardcover and is sold almost entirely in bookstores.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; REFUGEES IN IRAQ TOLD TO GO BACK
description: Iraq has ordered thousands of war refugees stranded at the Jordanian border to return to Baghdad to collect exit visas, Jordanian officials said today. But the highway on which they are being forced to return has been coming under allied bombing raids, travelers say.

title: By Design; Hats and Hair
description: This winter, some of the prettiest heads in town are those muffled in cocoons of fur, shearling, wool or knit. How charming these all-enveloping hats look framing the face! And how practical, too. There's only one problem: What do you do with your hair when you take one off?

title: Former S.& L. Owner Freed
description: A Federal judge today freed the former owner of the Vernon Savings Association, Don R. Dixon, until he is sentenced on a fraud conviction.

title: Lexus Prices Rise
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. announced price increases of $1,000 for its Lexus LS 400 and $200 for the Lexus ES 250 luxury automobiles. The new base prices, effective Feb. 27, will be $39,000 for the LS 400 and $21,500 for the ES 250.

title: Rare Slice of Inner Earth
description: ALONG the rugged coast of northern Labrador, scientists have found the oldest known fragments of the earth's mantle, giving them a glimpse at how the planet evolved 4.5 billion years ago.

title: Many Are Calling; Some Will Be Chosen but Not All Will Fight
description: For recruiters finding themselves with both a popular war and a shrinking military, the Persian Gulf is providing a new sort of Catch-22.

title: Tucked Above a Rudder: 2 Men and Cocaine
description: Police scuba divers inspecting the hull of an oil tanker in New York Harbor made an unusual discovery Thursday, and it was not only 366 pounds of cocaine hidden under water in the rudder compartment, but the people who were guarding it: two shivering and louse-infested Colombians who had survived five stormy days in a 10-foot air pocket, virtual prisoners of the sea, authorities said.

title: Still, in All the Services, It's Hurry Up and Wait
description: Chief Master Sgt. Sharon McCall turned up the collar of her camouflage fatigue uniform to keep out the cold dawn wind sweeping in from the desert. She yawned, idly checked the bolt of the M-16 rifle cradled in her lap, and shifted her position on the steel cargo pallet where she had been waiting for more than 24 hours.

title: Business Scene; War Won't Open Too Many Jobs
description: FOR all its divisiveness, the Vietnam War broke down job barriers in ways the Persian Gulf war is never likely to match.

title: Ruling on Tapes Clears the Way for Noriega's Trial
description: A Federal judge refused today to dismiss the drug charges against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, saying that defense lawyers had failed to show that they were seriously harmed by the Government's taping of the general's telephone calls.

title: Council Subpoena Threat Fuels Feud With Dinkins
description: The New York City Council, known for decades as a place to win new names for streets but not much else, moved forcefully yesterday to assert its new role as a counterweight to mayoral power, threatening subpoenas against two city agencies by Friday and for the first time forcing a city official to testify under oath at a hearing.

title: Iraq Says Air Raids Have Killed 324 Civilians
description: The Baghdad Government said today that the American-led alliance had killed at least 324 civilians, wounded another 416 and damaged or destroyed religious, cultural and residential buildings during its aerial bombardment of Iraq.

title: USA Today Plans a Weekly Newspaper About Baseball
description: USA Today said yesterday that it planned to start a weekly tabloid newspaper on April 5 aimed at baseball fans with an insatiable hunger for statistics.

title: Colleagues Recall Mary Martin As Musicals' Cockeyed Optimist
description: With reminiscences and some of her favorite songs, friends of Mary Martin gathered at the Majestic Theater yesterday afternoon to celebrate her life.

title: Herbert G. Langford; Medical Professor, 68
description: Dr. Herbert Gaines Langford, a professor of medicine at the University of Mississippi who was an authority on high blood pressure, died Saturday at the university medical center, where he was hospitalized after suffering an aneurysm last Monday. He was 68 years old.

title: Dr. Preston Cloud, 78, A Geologist and Writer
description: Preston Cloud, a geologist who wrote extensively on the early history of the Earth and on the evolution of life, died Jan. 16 at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 78 years old.

title: 80 OF IRAQ'S PLANES NOW IN IRAN; HOSTS' INTENT CALLED A PUZZLE; U.S. SAYS FLOW OF OIL IS STEMMED
description: More than 80 Iraqi warplanes have been flown to Iran by their pilots in recent days, including more than 60 fighters and bombers, the United States reported today.

title: Cuomo to Seek A 10-Cent Rise In Gasoline Tax to Reduce Deficit
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will propose raising New York State's gasoline tax by 10 cents a gallon -- the first increase in nearly two decades -- as part of a plan to close the $6 billion deficit in New York State's next budget, Cuomo administration officials said today. The increase would more than double the current 8-cent tax.

title: Moody's May Lower Chrysler Debt to 'Junk Bond' Status
description: Another big credit-rating agency said today that it would review the Chrysler Corporation's creditworthiness and could lower the struggling auto maker's rating to "junk bond" status.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Zorro, the nom de plume of an American soldier on duty in Saudi Arabia, drew most of Sunday's "Doonesbury," the Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoon strip by GARRY TRUDEAU . The strip aroused such reaction that at least one paper, The Naples (Fla.) Daily News, didn't print it.

title: Critic's Notebook: CNN in Baghdad: Danger of Propaganda Vs. Virtue of Reporting
description: The Cable News Network, which began its coverage of the Persian Gulf war with exciting accounts of the first air raids on Baghdad and has attracted a large audience with carpet coverage, has run into flak from officials, competitors and viewers. Some people are taking aim at the general quality of CNN reporting, but the heaviest criticism has been directed at Peter Arnett's Iraqi-supervised dispatches from Baghdad. His latest exclusive was an interview yesterday with President Saddam Hussein in a bungalow in a suburb of Baghdad.

title: Wide-Ranging Bombings Tied to the War
description: Attacks apparently linked to the American-led military campaign against Iraq were reported yesterday in Lebanon, Turkey and the Philippines, and in Greece yesterday and today.

title: President on TV
description: President Bush's State of the Union Message to a joint session of Congress and a Democratic response will be televised live beginning at 9 P.M. today on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks and on the Cable News Network, C-Span, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network and Channel 13 in New York City. Channel 5 in New York will show a tape-delayed broadcast at 11:30 P.M. In addition, several radio stations in the city plan to broadcast the speech live.

title: Review/Music; Mozart Bicentennial Opens at Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center's 19-month project to perform every single blessed note that Mozart wrote got under way in amiably elephantine fashion on Sunday afternoon with a three-hour concert at Avery Fisher Hall. Sunday was Mozart's 235th birthday. One hopes he was pleased.

title: Careers; Marketing Holds Up In Recession
description: ADVERTISING spending is down and there have been many layoffs and forced retirements in the field, but demand for corporate marketing executives continues strong, according to Miles L. McKie, a managing director in the Chicago office of Russell Reynolds, the management recruiting firm.

title: Gail P. Kelly, 51, Dies; Professor of Education
description: Gail Paradise Kelly, a professor of comparative education at the State University of New York at Buffalo, died on Friday at Buffalo General Hospital. She was 51 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: Glenn Langan Dies; Film Actor Was 73
description: Glenn Langan, a leading man or second lead in dozens of Hollywood films, died on Saturday at Pleasant Valley Hospital in Camarillo, Calif. He was 73 years old and lived in Camarillo.

title: Professional Therapy
description: The Super Bowl has often been a blowout and a bore, a glittering stream of commercials for which advertisers part with millions, then get apoplectic when viewers turn away before the game is half over. Not this year.

title: Review/Cabaret; Sam Harris, a Kind of Debut
description: "When the neighborhood kids were playing with Lincoln Logs, I was singing 'Stormy Weather' and meaning it," said Sam Harris during last Tuesday's opening night show of his two-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza).

title: Sentencing in Fraud Case
description: A subcontractor on the Patriot missile, now used to defend Israel and Saudi Arabia against Iraqi Scud missiles, was given a two-year prison sentence today for overbilling the Government more than $540,000.

title: Hussein Hints Use of All His Weapons
description: President Saddam Hussein said in an interview reported from Baghdad yesterday that Iraq had maintained its balance in the war thus far by using only conventional weapons, but that his missiles could deliver chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. He suggested they would be used if necessary to preserve his nation.

title: A Year Later, Signs That Deng Guides China
description: After a year of playing with his grandchildren during a quiet retirement, Deng Xiaoping appears to have returned to the political scene in recent weeks to direct basic elements of national policy and to give a boost to the leaders he favors.

title: Bush Vows to Tackle Middle East Issues
description: As the United States grappled with signs of discord within the Persian Gulf coalition, President Bush promised today that when the war is over, Washington will take the lead in efforts "to bring peace to the rest of the Middle East."

title: Weather in the Gulf
description: A cold front will push showers into Syria, Israel and northwest Iraq. Increasing winds over northern Saudi Arabia will cause some blowing dust and sand. Clouds will spread east later today. Winds will become southeast at 7 to 15 knots over the Persian Gulf. Temperatures: Baghdad, high 64, low 38; Riyadh, high 75, low 47; Dhahran, high 72, low 57.

title: Weicker Sees $1 Billion Rise In State Taxes
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he was prepared to cut the preliminary state budget for the next fiscal year by 10 percent but that Connecticut's shortfall in tax revenues was so large that residents faced $1 billion or more in new or higher taxes.

title: Patterns
description: Couture in Crisis

title: Transplant Survival Up in Big New Study
description: Ninety-two percent of those who undergo the most common organ transplant, receiving a kidney from a cadaver, live at least one year after their operations, a new study shows.

title: Poll Says Most Blacks Prefer 'Black' to 'African-American'
description: Despite the increasing use of the term African-American, most black Americans still prefer to be called black, according to a survey.

title: Ex-Drexel Executive Heads Blair Brokerage
description: Richard A. Maio has taken a job heading a much smaller operation than he used to. But then his old company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., is no longer in business.

title: Our Towns; Seeking a Bridge To Span Oceans Of Mighty Paper
description: Here's the setting: Old U.S. 6 on the semi-rural south side of this even older central Connecticut town of 21,000.

title: Investors Hoping to Profit From Cleanup in Gulf
description: Some investors are hoping to make money on the stocks of companies that may play a role in cleaning up the huge Persian Gulf oil spill.

title: SAUDIS CRITICIZED ON MISSING CBS MEN
description: CBS News asserted today that restrictions imposed by the Saudi authorities were impeding an investigation of the disappearance of a news team near the Saudi-Kuwait border a week ago.

title: Robert F. Bonner, 55, Environment Engineer
description: Robert F. Bonner Jr., a professional engineer and an officer with Malcolm Pirnie, Inc., one of the nation's largest environmental engineering companies, died Sunday at his home in Hampton, Va. He was 55 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A10-A14

title: George Forsyth, 89, Historian Who Led Archeological Digs
description: Prof. George H. Forsyth Jr., an architectural historian who directed archeological expeditions in France, Turkey and Egypt, died Saturday at the University of Michigan Hospital in Ann Arbor. He was 89 years old and lived in Ann Arbor and Chatham, Mass.

title: U.S. Accuses 5 Oil Traders
description: Federal futures regulators today accused five individuals and two commodities futures firms of cheating customers through a series of fraudulent trades in oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Georgia-Pacific Sells French Assets
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation has completed the sale of its interest in its French operations to the International Paper Company of Purchase, N.Y., for $102 million. The sale had been announced previously.

title: Review/Concert; The Astonishing Winds, a New-Music Trio
description: Three wind soloists -- Robert Dick, a flutist; Esther Lamneck, a clarinetist, and Gary Louie, a saxophonist -- have banded together as the Astonishing Winds, an ensemble that is to specialize in new music. Last Tuesday evening, the trio made its debut at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University.

title: Daily News Meets With Mailers' Union
description: Negotiators for The Daily News and one of its striking unions met yesterday for the first time since management gave notice that it would close the newspaper unless a sale or a settlement could be arranged.

title: Common Virus Seen As Having Early Role In Arteries' Clogging
description: A COMMON viral infection may be the first step in a complex process in which human arteries become clogged as people age, a growing number of heart specialists say.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: 'Maybes' and 'Buts' Aren't Bothering the M.V.P.
description: Less than 12 hours after becoming the most valuable player of the Super Bowl, and within a week of facing the status of an unclaimed free agent, Ottis Anderson of the Giants was in an unforgettable sort of limbo this morning.

title: TENNIS: Notebook; Brother's Success Brings Out Best in McEnroe
description: John McEnroe was mostly joking when he told his younger brother Patrick how "sick and tired" he was of hearing about what a nice guy Patrick was.

title: Robert E. Yancey Sr.; Oil Executive, 69
description: Robert E. Yancey Sr., former president of Ashland Oil Inc., died Sunday at Our Lady of Bellefonte Hospital in Russell, Ky. He was 69 years old and lived in Ashland, Ky.

title: Fighting Subsides in Somalia's Capital
description: Fighting subsided in Mogadishu today after rebels took the war-ruined Somali capital and forced President Mohammed Siad Barre to flee.

title: Market Place; Collagen Goes Beyond the Cosmetic
description: The Collagen Corporation takes its name and has always made most of its money from a product that makes people look younger. Now the company is moving beyond products with cosmetic uses to ones that treat medical problems. And Wall Street, after neglecting the stock for years, is again enthusiastic about Collagen.

title: P.O.W.'s Facial Bruises Recall Ejection Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * The Province of Alberta is issuing $500 million (Canadian) of 10 5/8 percent Eurobonds due 1996, at a reoffered price of 99 5/8, through UBS Phillips & Drew Ltd. The bonds are rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Waste Management Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $600 million in unsecured debt securities to be issued from time to time. Ratings * The Town of North Hempstead, L.I., has had its general obligation bond rating lowered to A, from A-1, by Moody's. * Olympia & York Water Street Finance Corp.'s rating on secured notes due 1996 has been lowered to A, from AA, by S.& P. The company was set up by Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the Toronto-based real estate company, to finance a construction project in New York.

title: The Game, a Nail-Biter; the Ads, Well . . .
description: THE Super Bowl game Sunday night was the most exciting one in recent years, but as the premier advertising event of the year it fell far short of the mark, some agency and marketing executives said yesterday.

title: Rangers Enjoy Timeout In Canadian Rockies
description: Normand Rochefort doesn't often have a great deal in common with Wayne Gretzky, although he did today.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Notebook; Teams Ravaged By Key Injuries
description: How about this for an all-star team? Larry Bird of the Celtics and Charles Barkley of the 76ers, forwards; Akeem Olajuwon of the Rockets, center, and Isiah Thomas of the Pistons and Mark Price of the Cavaliers, guards?

title: Affordable-Housing Owners Get a Tax Cut in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that owners of subsidized low- and moderate-income housing were entitled to reduced property taxes.

title: Richmond Is Too Much for Knicks
description: The Knicks could not overcome Mitch Richmond's offense and their own costly turnovers tonight.

title: The Day After Is the Bills' Longest Day
description: The sun did rise this morning for the Buffalo Bills. Those Bills who had managed to sleep arose and found the same stinging result: Giants 20, Bills 19. This first day of accepting and living with a Super Bowl result that will undoubtedly become lore might have been the toughest day of all.

title: Eagles Hire Carson
description: The Philadelphia Eagles yesterday hired Bud Carson as defensive coordinator and Zeke Bratkowski and Richard Wood as assistant coaches. Bratkowski will guide the quarterbacks and Wood will coach the running backs. Carson also will coach the defensive backs.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: A CRAZED TYRANT? A psychological profile drawn by a former adviser to the United States Government suggests Saddam Hussein is ruthless but not crazy. Science Times, page C1. CNN UNDER FIRE Is Peter Arnett, the only American correspondent left in the Iraqi capital, sending out enemy propaganda, or is he doing the journalist's job under difficult conditions, or both? Critic's Notebook, page C11. DEAL ON RESERVES The 21-nation International Energy Agency willstick with its emergency plan to tap two million barrels of oil a day from Government reserves, even though supplies are plentiful. Business Day, page D6. INVESTOR INTEREST Some investors are hoping to make money on the stocks of companies that may play a role in cleaning up the huge Persian Gulf oil spill. Page D7. OUTLOOK ON JOBS The Persian Gulf war is not likely to match the Vietnam War in breaking down job barriers. Business Scene, page D2.

title: 3 Governors React To Budget Pressure
description: As the recession in the region worsens and a new fiscal year approaches, three states are contemplating stringent measures to balance their budgets.

title: Plunk Agrees to Deal
description: Eric Plunk, the only Yankee pitcher to record an earned run average under 3.00 over the course of the 1990 season, agreed to a one-year, $950,000 contract yesterday. Plunk, 27, who is eligible for arbitration, had submitted a salary request of $1,025,000 and the Yankees had countered with an offer of $875,000. Plunk (6-3, 2.72 e.r.a.) earned $514,500 last year.

title: Korea Effort to Aid Industry
description: The South Korean Government plans to provide $2.1 billion in grants and loans in the next five years to help finance industries' development of manufacturing technology, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.

title: Survey of College Freshmen Finds a Shift in Priorities
description: College freshmen continue to show a decreasing interest in pursuing business careers and making money and an increasing concern for the environment and better race relations, a nationwide survey has found.

title: Japan's Stern Warning on Trade Sanctions
description: A top Japanese Treasury official warned today that if the United States applied sanctions against his country because of slowness in opening financial markets, Tokyo would respond by curbing credit to the United States, creating a "very, very harmful" situation.

title: Haiti's Army Asserts Radicals Caused Strife
description: The army today accused radicals of stirring up street protests that led to violent clashes with soldiers and the deaths of at least 17 people.

title: Merrill Lynch Reports A Profit in 4th Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage, reported higher fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, but that compared with the fourth quarter of 1989, when the firm took a large restructuring charge.

title: After Long Chill, China Warms to Mongolians
description: Leaders of the Chinese and Mongolian Communist parties met today, advancing party and government relations between the two countries for the first time in three decades.

title: Review of California's Debt May Result in Downgrading
description: The ever-thinning ranks of triple-A-rated states may soon lose another if the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowers the rating of California's general obligation debt.

title: Review/Recital; Countertenor's High Drama
description: In another of the Metropolitan Museum's hourlong early-evening recitals on Friday, Derek Lee Ragin sang music ranging from Purcell and Handel to Samuel Barber and traditional spirituals. Mr. Ragin is a countertenor with a very good ear. He has also worked very hard on his technique.

title: Chess
description: When a radical strategy goes wrong, it invites scorn. That is natural because there is something grandiose about it, the promise of a great insight that undercuts the humdrum. When such an enterprise fails, it reminds us that it was, after all, a human product and subject to failures as well as triumphs. But we laugh anyway.

title: People
description: * Jeff Alphin and Don Austen have been promoted to vice president and copywriters at Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York. * Gary Palmer has been promoted to account executive at Taylor-Gordon-Aarons & Co., New York. * Jean Malley has been promoted to vice president and management supervisor at Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising, Southfield, Mich. * Syringa Combs has been appointed media buyer at Cramer-Krasselt, Phoenix. * Vonda M. LePage has joined Ayer Worldwide, New York, as corporate communications manager. * Jeri Cohen has been named vice president and director of communications at Ketchum Advertising/U.S.A., New York, a unit of Ketchum Communications Inc. * Mark A. Choate has been promoted to senior vice president and group creative director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis.

title: The Beat of War
description: A woman bleary-eyed from hours of watching the Cable News Network's coverage of the conflict in the Persian Gulf thinks maybe she's getting bleary-eared too. CNN is accompanying its garish "War in the Gulf" logo with some curious choices of music.

title: International Energy Agency Affirms Plan to Tap Stocks
description: The 21-nation International Energy Agency voted today to stick with its emergency plan of tapping two million barrels of oil a day from government reserves even though supplies remain plentiful.

title: 2 Networks Bar Ad by L.A. Gear Over Tagline
description: Though ABC television broadcast the first commercial for L.A. Gear Inc.'s newest sneaker, the Catapult, during the Super Bowl yesterday, CBS and NBC will not follow suit.

title: Experts Differ on Dissecting Leaders' Psyches From Afar
description: AS Government officials and military tacticians struggle to determine the aims and methods of Saddam Hussein, questions are being raised anew about the usefulness of psychological profiles.

title: Midwest to New York: Think Before Asking
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Cut in U.S. Deposits Hastened Fall of Freedom Bank in Harlem
description: While public funds were being used to shore up the Bank of New England, the Treasury Department sharply cut back similar deposits at the Freedom National Bank, thus hastening the collapse of the small minority-owned Manhattan institution.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. REPORT Iraq Says Air Raids Have Killed 324 Civilians; Iraq Says U.S. Caused Spill
description: Iraq denied responsibility for the huge oil slick in the Persian Gulf today and said allied bombing had created it, hurling back at the Americans their accusation of "environmental terrorism."

title: Frederic C. Decker; Publisher, 74
description: Frederic C. Decker, a publisher of business magazines, died on Sunday at his home in Elizabethtown, Pa. He was 74 years old.

title: The F.B.I. Is Calling
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, though brilliantly successful in recent years against domestic terrorism, still has something to learn about dealing sensitively with law-abiding American citizens. The value of information gathered in recent interviews with 200 prominent Americans of Arab descent has to be balanced against the heightened anxiety of the very leaders whose cooperation the bureau now seeks.

title: More Gains Among Oil Companies
description: The ranks of large oil companies posting sharply higher profits for the fourth quarter grew today, with ARCO, Phillips Petroleum, Unocal, Amerada Hess and Pennzoil each reporting substantial gains largely because of higher crude prices.

title: McDonald's Net Up 8.8% in the 4th Quarter
description: The McDonald's Corporation reported today that its net income rose 8.8 percent in the fourth quarter, to a record $186.2 million, and was up 10.4 percent for all of 1990, to $802.3 million, also a record. But analysts said that the earnings were inflated by unusual gains and other additions to profits that came from outside of its basic fast-food operations.

title: Spreading the Faith, and the Debate
description: Some people are calling it the "stealth" encyclical -- the long papal letter on missionary work that appeared last Tuesday with little advance notice and no English texts available in the United States.

title: Review/Fashion; In Paris, a Style Break From War
