description: From Gianni Versace 's heady curtain raiser Saturday night to Christian Dior's glamorous show this afternoon, the haute couture openings offered a diverting antidote to the gloom of war.

title: Louisiana Energy Tax-Exempt Offer
description: A $112.8 million issue of tax-exempt refunding revenue bonds being sold by the Louisiana Energy and Power Authority was priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.05 percent for a bond due 2013, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Bush to Offer Bank Proposal
description: In his State of the Union Message, President Bush is likely to propose easing barriers between banks and other financial concerns. The address will be broadcast at 9 o'clock tonight, Eastern standard time. Page A16.

title: Review/Piano; German Bill by Radu Lupu
description: Radu Lupu is not the most charismatically compelling of performers. He trudges onstage, sits down at the piano like a court stenographer at a tedious trial, and proceeds dispassionately to do his job. It's just that the execution of his particular job results in beautiful music.

title: Currents, Not Man, Will Decide the Spill's Effects
description: With oil from Kuwaiti spigots within 100 miles of reaching Saudi Arabia's main desalting plant, experts say that human efforts are no match for the tide of oil and that the plant's fate depends mostly on currents.

title: Corrections
description: A Reporter's Notebook article yesterday about a United States Army scout unit in Saudi Arabia misidentified the unit. It is Company D of the Second Battalion of the 325th Airborne Infantry Regiment, part of the 82d Airborne Division.

title: Devils Defeat Red Wings As MacLean Ends Slump
description: John MacLean, who had been mired in a goal-scoring slump, broke out tonight with his fifth career hat trick to lead the New Jersey Devils to a 6-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Comeback for Buccaneer Bomber
description: Britain has introduced the venerable Buccaneer bomber to the Persian Gulf conflict.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ambase Corp., New York, an insurance company, rescheduled its special shareholders meeting for Feb. 12 for a vote on the sale of its Home Insurance Co. unit to TVH Acquisition Corp. * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., the tool and outdoor products company, completed the sale of its Mallory Controls North American business to Emerson Electric Co., St. Louis, for about $90 million. * Cell Technology Inc., Boulder, Colo., said it would acquire Pioneer Pharmaceuticals Inc., a unit of Dow Chemical Co.'s Essex Chemical Corp. subsidiary, for cash equal to Pioneer's audited net book value of about $5.5 million. * First Charlotte Corp., Charlotte, N.C., a banking firm, and J. C. Bradford & Co., a securities firm, agreed to merge. * Hecla Mining Co., Couer D'Alene, Idaho, and Coca Mines, Denver, signed a provisional merger agreement. Hecla will issue more than 3.5 million common shares in exchange for the more than 12.6 million Coca common shares outstanding. * Home and City Savings Bank, Albany, said that Rose Associates I L.P., Albany, which owns 9.9 percent of the bank's outstanding common shares, had terminated its agreement to acquire the bank. * Raytheon Co., Lexington, Mass., the electronics, aviation and appliances company, said its United Engineers and Constructors subsidiary would provide the engineering services for a $130 million replacement co-generation power plant at Venezuela's Cardon oil refinery. * SL Industries, Laurel, N.J., a maker of electrical and mechanical equipment, sold all the business and assets of its SL Abrasives Inc. unit to Cincinnati Milacron Inc., Cincinnati, a maker of machine tools, metal works and other machinery. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CLINT EASTWOOD and DIANE KEATON were named Man and Woman of the Year by the Hasty Pudding theatricals at Harvard University for contributions to films. Ms. Keaton, whose portrayal of "Annie Hall" won an Oscar, will get her award on Feb. 12. Mr. Eastwood, star of the "Dirty Harry" movies, will receive his award Feb. 19.

title: L. A. Harper, 70, Dean Of Westchester College
description: Leonard A. Harper, vice president and dean of Westchester Community College, died on Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, apparently of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson.

title: Tougher Rubber
description: A University of Maryland researcher has invented a rubber-like compound he says is "virtually impervious to environmental damage" and costs only slightly more than the most commonly used synthetic rubber.

title: Giants Go Without Sleep But Nobody's Complaining
description: This was the day after the Giants' Super Bowl victory, and you could forgive the players if their eyes had difficulty focusing.

title: American to Share 'Saigon' Lead
description: An Asian-American actress will play a leading role on Broadway in "Miss Saigon" after all -- but only some of the time.

title: Pistons Move Ahead in Central Race
description: When Isiah Thomas was sidelined for the season with a wrist injury, the Detroit Pistons turned to a name from their past.

title: Bush Surrenders at Home
description: If anyone has reason to be grateful for the war in the Persian Gulf, it is the unfortunate White House speechwriter responsible for President Bush's State of the Union Address this evening. Without an international crisis, what would the President have to talk about?

title: U.S. Assails Sentences of Chinese Protesters
description: The State Department expressed disappointment today over prison sentences meted out to five advocates of democracy in China.

title: Steel Output Rises in Japan
description: Japan produced 2.2 percent more steel in 1990 than in the previous year but exported 15.7 percent less, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Software Deal For McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation's computer software subsidiary and Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer maker, said yesterday that Fujitsu would market McDonnell Douglas's most popular manufacturing design package on its work stations. In addition, the two companies agreed to cooperate in several software development projects.

title: New Principal Rules Sought
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman of New York has introduced legislation to revise disciplinary procedures against New York City school principals, saying that many incompetent or corrupt principals had been allowed to remain in their jobs.

title: Dale Long; Baseball Player, 64
description: Dale Long, who set a major league record with home runs in eight consecutive games while playing for the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1956, died Sunday. He was 64 years old.

title: Gasoline Prices Drop
description: Gasoline prices fell more than 3 cents a gallon in the last two weeks despite the start of war in the Middle East and a Persian Gulf oil spill that surpassed that of the Exxon Valdez. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service stations was $1.3035 a gallon on Friday, down 3.08 cents from Jan. 11, according to the nationwide Lundberg Survey released on Sunday. The biggest retail price decline over the two-week period was for regular unleaded gasoline at self-service stations. Its price fell 3.33 cents, to an average $1.1803 a gallon.

title: Domino's Pizza Weighs Switch
description: Domino's Pizza, has put its $50 million national account under review.

title: Lilian Bond, 83, Dies; Film Actress in 30's
description: Lilian Bond, an English actress who appeared in more than two dozen Hollywood films in the 1930's, died on Friday at Convalescent Hospital in Reseda, Calif., where she lived. She was 83 years old.

title: Lucky Towel Aided Giants
description: Early last week Bill Parcells, the coach of the Giants who is noted for his superstitions, said he had a "real good one going this week," and that he would reveal it after the Super Bowl.

title: Clemens Makes Appeal
description: Roger Clemens, his agent, Randy Hendricks, and union representatives met with the American League president, Dr. Bobby Brown, for nearly six hours yesterday to appeal a five-game suspension and $10,000 fine. The penalties, levied Dec. 21, resulted from the Red Sox pitcher's ejection from Game 4 of the 1990 League Championship Series against the Athletics on Oct. 10.

title: Connecticut Loses For 6th Time in Row
description: Connecticut's John Gwynn couldn't get a shot off in the closing seconds and No. 8-ranked Syracuse held the Huskies to one field goal in the final 9 minutes for a 68-66 Big East victory tonight. It was UConn's sixth loss in a row.

title: Teen-Agers Charged Slayings
description: Two teen-agers were charged with murder today in the shooting deaths of four people in a robbery of a Taco Bell last week. Mike Green, a 17-year-old employee at the restaurant, and Jessy Carlos San Miguel, 19, were charged with one count each of capital murder. They are being held without bail. Three additional murder charges were planned against each teen-ager on Tuesday, the police said.

title: Red Grange, Football Hero of 1920's, Dead at 87
description: Harold (Red) Grange, whose dramatic exploits as a football running back for the University of Illinois and the Chicago Bears more than 60 years ago made him an idol of his age and a legend to later generations, died yesterday at Lake Wales (Fla.) Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: Managing Your Money Even Better
description: MANY New Year's resolutions that sounded so reasonable four weeks ago now seem like a lot of work. This year, we resolved that we would finally take control of our finances, get organized, get a head start on taxes and make a budget.

title: Polish Emigres Lose Savings and Dreams
description: Maria Olejnik came to the United States three years ago with $50 in her pocket and the dream of saving enough to build a better life for her husband and the two small daughters she left behind in Poland.

title: Global Warming: Search for the Signs
description: AN ever-lengthening string of extraordinarily warm years has renewed fears of the greenhouse effect -- the trapping of the Sun's heat by gases that a rapidly industrializing world is pouring into the atmosphere. Responding to the alarm, delegates from around the globe will gather next week outside Washington to negotiate a treaty limiting the gases.

title: The Homeless Inspire Gifts for the Neediest
description: It was the end of December, and Marlene and David Lieberman had forgotten to make their annual donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Only after a chance encounter on a Saturday night did the couple remember to send a check.

title: Is That Lenin Speaking? No, Gorbachev
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Holiday in Argentina As Currency Plunges 12.5%
description: Argentine banks and foreign exchange houses were ordered closed and President Carlos Saul Menem's economic advisers offered to resign today after the austral plunged 12.5 percent against the dollar.

title: Low-Key Welcome for the Giants
description: The reception for the Giants, who were returning from the Super Bowl as champions today, was modest and tardy.

title: Chairman and Chief Quits at Fred Meyer
description: Frederick M. Stevens has resigned as chairman and chief executive of Fred Meyer Inc., the retail chain based in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Pricing Videos: A Rental-or-Sales Gamble
description: After weeks of speculation, Paramount Home Video is expected to announce on Thursday that "Ghost," one of the largest box-office hits of last year, will be released as a videocassette on March 21. Paramount sets no retail price on its videos, but using an industry formula based on the wholesale price that Paramount will probably charge distributors, "Ghost" should cost about $100.

title: CHRONICLE
description: So what do high-profile academics do when they get together? JACK GREENBERG , the dean of Columbia College and the former dean of the Columbia Law School, and JAMES VORENBERG , former dean of the Harvard Law School and the Roscoe Pound Professor of Law there, have written "Dean Cuisine, or the Liberated Man's Guide to Fine Cooking." It will be published next month by the Sheep Meadow Press and has already received a rave from JULIA CHILD , who reviewed it for The Harvard Law Review.

title: Wall St. Still Chasing Big Real Estate Profits
description: For Wall Street, the big profits from big real estate deals were not as easy to come by as they first seemed.

title: Onion-Roll Emergency as Fire Shuts a Landmark
description: Jack Brenner changed his lunch plans suddenly after a fire yesterday destroyed the kitchen of Ratner's Dairy Restaurant, considered one of the last vestiges of traditional Jewish cuisine in the city.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Miscellany
description: * Gavin Anderson & Co., New York, a financial and corporate communications unit of Omnicom Group Inc., has acquired Valin Pollen P.L.C., a British financial investor relations firm. The company, to be known as Gavin Anderson, will be headed by Howard Lee.

title: Nationwide Buys Sales Operation
description: The Landmark Land Company said the Nationwide Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, had acquired for $6 million most of the sales operations of Landmark Financial Services, a joint venture between Landmark and the Davenport Group of Oklahoma City. Landmark Financial markets and sells annuities, life insurance, mutual funds and other financial products.

title: 7 Captive U.S. Airmen Are Listed as P.O.W.'s
description: Seven United States airmen who had been listed as missing in action in the war in the Persian Gulf are now considered prisoners of war, the Pentagon said today.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) -- Agreed to terms with Todd Benzinger, first baseman; Billy Bates, infielder, and Keith Brown, Rodney Imes and Bill Risley, pitchers, on one-year contracts.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: The Making of a Pro - Second article of a series that will appear periodically about Dan McGwire as he prepares for the National Football League draft April 21-22.; Guessing Game Begins About McGwire
description: As far as Ed McCaffrey is concerned, Dan McGwire, the quarterback from San Diego State University, will make any coach in the National Football League happy.

title: Henry M. Stern; Clothier, 83
description: Henry M. Stern, a men's clothing manufacturer, died on Sunday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Teachers Union Pauses Over All-Black School
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro Bono
description: * The American Lyme Disease Foundation, Valhalla, N.Y., to McMoran Associates, New York.

title: Ideas to Help Poor Abound, But a Consensus Is Wanting
description: Wanted: An American anti-poverty policy. Strategy must offer reasonable prospect for ending cycles of dependency and despair that disfigure urban America. Long hours and serious commitment needed. Costs may be high. Costs of doing nothing may be higher.

title: Soft Soap Does The Trick
description: Here's good news for the military. It is called "Surviving Media" and is the latest book by Dr. Harold J. Liverworth, world's foremost authority.

title: Washington Goes to War, Besieging the TV Set
description: In a city where Administration officials do not feel well dressed unless they are clutching a folder marked "Secret," this has been a frustrating war.

title: Key Rates
Accounts
description: * Encyclopedia Britannica U.S.A., a unit of Encyclopedia Britannica Inc., Chicago, to Shain/Colavito/Pensabene Direct, New York, with a budget of $5 million. * Parade of Shoes, a division of J. Baker Inc., Hyde Park, Mass., to Rossin Greenberg Seronick, Boston, with a budget of $2.5 million. * Woman's Workout World, a chain of physical-fitness centers, Morton Grove, Ill., to Lou Beres & Associates, Chicago, with a budget of $1 million. * The Faultless Starch/Bon Ami Co., Kansas City, Mo., to GSD&M Advertising, Austin, Tex. Billings have not been determined. * Seventh Generation, makers of "environmentally responsible" products, to Beaumont-Bennett, New York, a unit of Grey Advertising, New York, for sales promotion. Billings have not been determined. * Foscavir, an anti-viral AIDS drug made by Astra Pharmaceutical, to William Douglass McAdams Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Four Editors In New Posts At The Times
description: Appointments to four editing positions at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the executive editor.

title: Fewer Oil and Gas Rigs
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 14 last week, to a total of 1,051, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The company, which has kept track of the rig count since 1940, said the latest count compares with 937 a year ago. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for petroleum and natural gas, not those producing oil and gas.

title: Octane Overkill
description: High-performance cars like Lamborghinis, Ferraris, BMW's and Jaguars require high-octane or "premium" gasoline to run their best. So do some less sporty models after years of wear and tear. All told, perhaps 20 percent of the cars on the American road truly need higher octane than regular gas provides. Yet about 30 percent of the gasoline sold in the U.S. last year was the more expensive premium -- suggesting that many consumers are throwing money away.

title: Charles W. Davis; Medal of Honor Winner, 73
description: Col. Charles W. Davis, retired, a holder of the Medal of Honor who spent more than 32 years on active Army duty, died Jan. 18 at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in San Francisco, where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Navy Nuclear Reactors Pose No Safety Threat; Low Level, Low Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan on Guard After Threats by Old Terror Group
description: Fearful that Japanese might be singled out in acts of terrorism, the police and security authorities here are stepping up their precautions against the Japanese Red Army, which has reportedly promised retaliation for Tokyo's support of the war against Iraq.

title: With a Little Help From a Missed Kick, Parcells's Philosophy Prevails
description: Bill Parcells was almost dapper in his gray suit today. But his words sounded like those of a football coach, and could have been spoken by his heroes of the 1950's, Woody Hayes and Bear Bryant.

title: Health Care A Growing Burden
description: With health-care costs pushing relentlessly upward, companies and employees are feeling the burden. Last year, in fact, fully 26 percent of the average company's net earnings went for medical costs, a survey released yesterday shows.

title: Books of The Times; Literate, Scandalous, One of a Kind
description: Colette A Life By Herbert Lottman Illustrated. 344 pages. Little, Brown. $24.95.

title: Missiles Provoke Debate in Tel Aviv: Is It a Patriotic Duty to Stay in City?
description: For dozens of Israelis jostling in line outside the El Al airline office today, gas-mask boxes bouncing at their sides, the under-the-breath curses were not reserved only for Saddam Hussein, who has rained terror and death on this city for the last 12 days.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 14 about the competition among galleries for artists misstated Chuck Close's status. Although there was speculation that he might join the Mary Boone Gallery, both Mr. Close and the Pace Gallery have said repeatedly that he never considered leaving Pace.

title: Opening Is Delayed For Brazilian Singer
description: Margareth Menezes, a Brazilian singer, will not open her engagement as scheduled tonight at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, Manhattan.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
The Gulf Could Be Another Korea
description: As the war in the Persian Gulf grows in intensity, Americans might find it useful to hear from a citizen of South Korea, where American soldiers fought against Communist aggression 40 years ago.

title: Jose de Jesus Martinez, Ex-Torrijos Aide, 61
description: Jose de Jesus Martinez, poet, playwright, philosopher and mathematician and a former aide to the late Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the Panamanian leader, died on Sunday at his home in Panama. He was 61 years old.

title: Qualify for Good Job
description: Times are hard and good jobs are not easy to get. But here's a simple test to find out if you qualify for a well-paying position as an opinion maker in the field of international affairs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 3 Charged in New Mexico Killings
description: Murder charges were filed today against a 29-year-old man suspected in the killings of as many as seven people, including two law-enforcement officers and the woman he lived with.

title: Cape Skirring Journal; Senegal Scenes: Idyllic Beaches, Bullets, Bombs
description: At first glance, Casamance is, as usual, thronged with tourists these days. It is the peak of the European vacation season, and on the surf-scrubbed beaches at the tip of the continent's bulge, scores of parents, children and young lovers picnic or saunter along the white sands.

title: Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in extremely listless trading yesterday, as bond prices inched higher and short-term notes moved a bit lower.

title: Reply Given By Neil Bush
description: President Bush's son Neil has accused Federal savings industry regulators of having a "Big Brother mentality" in their conflict-of-interest case against him.

title: Navratilova Wins A Comeback Match
description: Martina Navratilova, coming back from knee surgery, played her first competitive match in two months, beating Gabriela Sabatini, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday in an exhibition in Hong Kong.

title: Review/Ballet; Love and Death in Germany, by a Japanese Troupe
description: A ghost story about a woman betrayed by her lover: Japanese literature and drama are rich in such tales. Yet it was a Western variant, none other than the old Romantic ballet "Giselle," that the Matsuyama Ballet from Tokyo presented in a decisively strong production over the weekend.

title: War Summary
description: THE MYSTERY FLIGHT TO IRAN The unexplained flight of Iraqi warplanes to Iran continued on a large scale. Pentagon officials said more than 80 aircraft landed at various airfields. Iran vowed to impound them for the duration of the war, but the officials questioned Teheran's intentions. HUSSEIN GRANTS INTERVIEW In an interview with Peter Arnett of the Cable News Network, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said that "if Iraq uses oil for self-defense," it was justified. The journalist also quoted Mr. Hussein as saying that Iran was offering sanctuary to the Iraqi planes in a gesture of Muslim solidarity. STOPPING THE OIL SPILL U.S. and Saudi officials said the flow of crude from offshore Kuwaiti sources was virtually halted by the weekend's precision bombing. But they said the slick left by some 11 million barrels of spilled oil still threatened ecological disaster. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The Pentagon listed 21 American casualties as of yesterday, consisting of seven wounded and 14 missing or taken prisoner, a fate shared by 12 allied airmen. Aircraft: The loss of a Harrier jet of the Marine Corps brought the number of American aircraft shot down to 11 in 12 days of raids on Iraqi targets. Seven allied aircraft also were lost. IRAQI FORCES Troops: There was no current information on military casualties. Iraq informed the United Nations yesterday that at least 324 civilians died in air raids, 416 more were wounded and religious and cultural institutions were destroyed or damaged as well. Many of the casualties occurred Jan. 21, when bombs struck two towns south of Baghdad, Iraq said. Aircraft: In addition to the planes at Iranian airfields, the Pentagon counted 26 Iraqi aircraft shot out of the sky and 24 more confirmed to have been destroyed on the ground as of yesterday.

title: U.S. AND MOSCOW POSTPONE SUMMIT
description: The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that they were postponing the meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that had been scheduled for Feb. 11-13 in Moscow.

title: Bridge
description: Study the club layout on the diagramed deal, and consider whether it is right for East to play an honor when the four is led from the dummy.

title: Occidental Asset Sale
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its stake in the company that makes Arm & Hammer baking soda, seven weeks after the chairman of Occidental, Dr. Armand Hammer, died at the age of 92.

title: Trump Castle Lays Off 190
description: Nearly 200 employees were laid off today at the Trump Castle Casino Resort to save money. Donald J. Trump also announced that he had hired a new president for the Trump Plaza casino.

title: Q&A
description: Birds and Perches

title: Frederick S. Gilbert Jr., Citibank Executive, 51
description: Frederick S. Gilbert Jr., a banker and division executive of the Citibank Private Bank, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 51 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: What Really Threatens the Environment?
description: ARE Americans preoccupied with relatively modest environmental threats while neglecting big ones that could unleash catastrophe?

title: Tiny Link to the World
description: FOR a change, a new device is a snap to set up and get working.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday aboutthe Tiananmen Square trials in Beijing referred incompletely in some editions to the demonstration shown. It was in Hong Kong.

title: Guarding the Bomb: A Perfect Record, But Can It Last?
description: THE question of whether the world's 50,000 nuclear weapons are secure from falling into unfriendly hands is getting new scrutiny from Federal and private experts.

title: Florio Approves a Rise In Tolls on the Turnpike
description: Gov. Jim Florio today approved a toll increase on the New Jersey Turnpike of 70 percent for cars and 100 percent for trucks, on the same day that his Treasurer announced that some of the toll revenues will be used indirectly to balance the state budget.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "My elbow is killing me. My knee hurts. I still have a headache. It feels great." -- Jeff Hostetler, New York Giants' quarterback. [ B7:5. ]

title: Near Border, Saudis Abandon Town to the Troops
description: Only two weeks ago, the schools here were full and the streets were filled. But deliveries of milk, frozen food and newspapers stopped days ago, and today Hafr al Baten is nearly deserted.

title: New York City Is Going After the Engine Idlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Tomczak Available
description: Mike Tomczak, the Chicago Bears' quarterback, says he won't be on his team's 37-man protected list, leaving him free to negotiate with other teams. Tomczak said Sunday that he received a letter Friday from the Bears informing him he will become a Plan B free agent when the list is submitted Feb. 1.

title: Bush Speech to Urge Bank Law Changes
description: Although the Persian Gulf war will dominate his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Bush will also address domestic issues and will offer sweeping proposals to revamp the nation's banking laws, Administration officials said today.

title: Navy Nuclear Reactors Pose No Safety Threat; Not Like Civilian Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: Operating Gain of 13.2% For P.&G.
description: Helped largely by sales abroad, operating profit of the Procter & Gamble Company, the world's largest maker of detergent and personal-care products, rose 13.2 percent in the second quarter. Sales were up slightly more.

title: Nets Do A Major About-Face
description: The Nets may have been carried here on the wings of a winning spell, but they crash-landed tonight. They shot poorly, made mistake upon mistake and were left with a 101-83 loss to the Sacramento Kings at Arco Arena.

title: Aides Say U.S. Plans to Name Career Envoy to London Post
description: The White House is preparing to name Raymond G. H. Seitz, Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, to be the next United States Ambassador to Britain, Administration officials said today.

title: Dow Ends Day 4.95 Lower, But Smaller Stocks Are Up
description: In a sign that the market could be picking up steam, smaller stocks traded over the counter and on the American Stock Exchange continued to show gains yesterday.

title: Giants Not A Dynasty, Just Champs
description: For more than an hour Bill Parcells and Ottis Anderson were center stage yesterday with the Vince Lombardi trophy and the new Pete Rozelle trophy. But not once was the word "dynasty" mentioned in asking about the Giants' future. Not once were the Super Bowl XXV champions described as the "Team of the 90's."

title: Some Payments on Deposits
description: Depositors at nine closed banks and credit unions in Rhode Island will receive partial payments from their accounts this week, a month after the institutions were shut because their private deposit insurer failed.

title: U.S. Companies to Join Bid To Minimize Gulf Oil Spill
description: American companies specializing in oil-spill cleanups are preparing to join an international effort to help Saudi Arabia minimize the effects of the giant spill in the Persian Gulf. But some of the concerns say they are reluctant to send men and equipment to a war zone. .

title: Haiti's Press Holds Its Critical Tongue
description: After facing down guns and decrees in helping rid their country of a series of dictators, Haiti's independent press is struggling to redefine its role under the country's first democratically elected Government.

title: India's Poorest Find a Place in the Economy
description: When Indians talk of the poorest of the poor, the catch phrase they use is "scheduled castes and tribes" -- the people "scheduled" for special protection by the Constitution.

title: Commercial Jet Sales Spur Sharp Gain in Boeing's Net
description: Aided by continued strong sales of its commercial jets, the Boeing Company reported a fourfold increase in earnings and a sharp rise in sales for the fourth quarter.

title: Middle-Distance Star Starts Long Road Back
description: Usually, it is something unexpected or unsavory that forces an athlete out of competition, like an injury or drug suspension. In Tatyana Samolenko's case, her two-year absence from racing was entirely voluntary: She got married, then had a baby.

title: Polls Show Support for War, Even in Germany
description: Western European voters support the war to get Iraq out of Kuwait by varying majorities ranging from 54 to 70 percent in Britain, France and even Germany, according to public opinion polls in all three countries.

title: Navy Nuclear Reactors Pose No Safety Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: To Leave Israel, or Stay?

title: War's Shared Price -- and Costs
description: Allied pledges of $37 billion have poured in during the last few days to help defray the mounting costs of the Persian Gulf war. That welcome and substantial total won a warm salute yesterday from President Bush as evidence that, as he put it, "we're not going it alone."

title: When Nuclear Warheads Go Awry
description: A SOVIET long-range missile armed with a nuclear warhead was once fired by mistake during routine maintenance, according to Dr. Bruce G. Blair of the Brookings Institution. It landed near its launching point, perhaps because it lacked a navigational package telling it where to go.

title: New York Area Budgets
description: New York State, New Jersey, Connecticut and New York City face varying deadlines for proposing and enacting budgets for the next fiscal year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Art's-Way Manufacturing Co., Armstrong, Iowa, a maker of farm equipment, appointed Ronald W. Hottes president, succeeding Harold A. Westberg, who is retiring. * Amoco Oil Co., a subsidiary of Amoco Corp., named W. Douglas Ford executive vice president. * Bolt Beranek & Newman Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a communications and computer company, named Ralph A. Goldwasser senior vice president and treasurer. * Chase Manhattan Bank, a unit of Chase Manhattan Corp., appointed Dr. Richard C. Aspinwall chief economist. * Cisco Systems Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., named John T. Chambers senior vice president. * Claire's Stores Inc., Pembroke Pines, Fla., a jewelry and accessories retailer, appointed Bernard Newburg executive vice president of Decor Corp., its graphic arts subsidiary. * Medstat Systems Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., a health-care information company, named Deborah M. Gage and Michael J. Karaman vice presidents. * Parfums Nina Ricci U.S.A. Inc., New York, a unit of Sanofi, appointed Claudia Wood senior vice president of marketing in its fragrance and cosmetics unit. * Alan Patricof Associates Inc., a venture capital firm, named Robert M. Chefitz a general partner. * Rite Aid Corp., Shiremanstown, Pa., a retail chain, promoted Timothy J. Noonan and Alex Schamroth to vice presidents and Philip D. Markovitz to senior vice president of corporate real estate. * Utilicorp United Inc., Kansas City, Mo., an electricity and gas company, named Robert K. Green president of its Missouri Public Service division.

title: BOXING: Notebook; Hill-Hearns Title Bout Proving a Tough Task
description: With the World Boxing Association light heavyweight title match between the champion, Virgil Hill, and the challenger, Thomas Hearns, set for May 17 outdoors at Caesars Palace, the bout's promoter, the Great Western Forum in Los Angeles, is under the gun.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. REPORT Iraq Says U.S. Caused Spill
description: Iraq denied responsibility for the huge oil slick in the Persian Gulf today and said allied bombing had created it, hurling back at the Americans their accusation of "environmental terrorism."

title: New Delacorte Director
description: Brian DeFiore, the executive editor of Dell Publishing, has been named editorial director of Delacorte Press, Dell's hard-cover publishing imprint. He replaces Robert Miller, who left several months ago to become publisher of adult trade books for the Walt Disney Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a United States Marine unit in Saudi Arabia misidentified the unit. It is the First Battalion of the First Marine Regiment.

title: Harboring of Iraqi Planes by Iran Calls Its Neutrality Into Question
description: The flight of more than 80 Iraqi planes to Iran has raised urgent questions in the Bush Administration about Iran's intentions and avowed neutrality in the Persian Gulf war.

title: A.C.L.U. Shifts as Mission Grows More Complex
description: Even as the American Civil Liberties Union undergoes a change in leadership, an announcement today that it was deploying lawyers to deal with potential civil liberties abuses caused by the Persian Gulf war typified the approach of the nation's oldest civil liberties organization.

title: Apple Seeks Radio Slot For Use by Computers
description: Apple Computer Inc. asked the Federal Communications Commission today to set aside radio frequencies to allow personal computers to receive and transmit data without wires.

title: Food Notes
description: French Class

title: PRICES UP SHARPLY IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: In the month since price controls were lifted on most goods, prices in retail stores in Czechoslovakia have almost doubled, producing greater expressions of pain by consumers than the country's leaders had hoped would accompany the transition to a market economy.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Carolina Golden Products Co., which is 51 percent owned by the Golden Poultry Co., Atlanta, has completed the purchase of a poultry plant in Sumter, S.C., from the Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., for undisclosed terms. * CRI Inc., Rockville, Md., began a proxy contest to become managing general partner of four American Insured Mortgage partnerships now managed by an affiliate of the bankrupt Integrated Resources Inc., which has announced its intention to sell its interest as the managing general partner to Broad Inc. and Goldman, Sachs & Co. for up to $35 million. * Dyncorp, Reston, Va., a technical services firm, has bought the business and assets of Becton Services Corp., a unit of Bechtel Corp., San Francisco, an engineering concern. Terms were not disclosed. * ESCO Electronics Inc., St. Louis, a maker of military systems and products, said the Air Force had terminated the contract with ESCO's Electronics and Space unit to develop a tail defense radar system for B-52 bombers. * Foster's Brewing Group Ltd., Melbourne, Australia, said the Australian Government's Foreign Investment Review Board had approved the $175 million sale of some of its agribusinesses to Conagra Inc., Omaha, an agricultural products company. * Japan Fleet Services, Singapore, an aircraft lessor, has ordered four PW4000 propulsion systems worth $30 million from Pratt & Whitney, Hartford, a unit of United Technologies, to power two Airbus A300-600R wide-body airliners. * Norwest Corp., Minneapolis, a financial services company, has completed the acquisition of Wyoming National Bancorp, Casper, Wyo., for undisclosed terms. * Republic Automotive Parts Inc., Brentwood, Tenn., an automotive replacement parts company, will acquire the assets of Auto Parts Warehouse, Des Moines, for undisclosed

title: Ground Assault Now Carries Too High a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutors Study Awarding of Water Meter Pacts
description: Federal and New York City prosecutors are investigating a Kentucky company that has obtained contracts worth at least $40 million to install water meters in New York and other cities, law-enforcement officials said last night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Transcript of President's State of the Union Message to Nation
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's State of the Union Message last night at the Capitol, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Walter (Hoot) Evers, Baseball Player, 69
description: Walter A. (Hoot) Evers, a former outfielder with the Detroit Tigers and a long-time executive with the baseball club, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital in Houston after a short illness. He was 69 years old and had recently suffered a heart attack.

title: Cuts by the Travel Industry Adding to Publishers' Woes
description: WITH travel off sharply because of the war, many travel advertisers have substantially cut back spending, dealing a blow to some magazines and newspapers already reeling from an ad slump.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: EXPERTS ON HAND: American commanders are relying heavily on civilian employees sent by military contractors to provide technical expertise for the world's most advanced weapons. Business Day, page D2.

title: Shifts at Dillon, Read Stress Its 'Collegiality'
description: Dillon, Read & Company yesterday named Franklin W. Hobbs 4th as president, apparently putting him first in line to eventually succeed the chairman and chief executive, John K. Birkelund.

title: The Bolshoi Opera Is Set For the Met
description: The Bolshoi Opera is to present three grandly scaled 19th-century Russian operas at the Metropolitan Opera House in a two-week run starting on June 25. The series comprises the world premiere of a new production of Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin," and what are believed to be the first American staging of Rimsky-Korsakov's "Mlada" and the first New York staging of Tchaikovsky's "Maid of Orleans."

title: Florio Pledges No New Taxes In '92 Budget
description: Pledging a year of keeping his promises to New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio presented a $14.3 billion 1992 budget to the State Legislature today that he said would ease property taxes, shrink government, and assist education at a time of fiscal austerity.

title: For First Time, Tests With Gene Therapy Begin on Cancer Patients
description: Two cancer patients yesterday became the first people to receive gene therapy in an attempt to defeat otherwise incurable tumors.

title: Quebec Demands Greater Powers if It Is to Remain in Canada
description: Quebec challenged Canada today to agree to a new, broadly decentralized constitution within two years or face a referendum that would seek Quebec voters' approval for the French-speaking province's full independence.

title: Books of The Times; Troubled in the Role Of the Subjugator
description: The Smile of the Lamb By David Grossman Translated by Betsy Rosenberg. 325 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95

title: New York's City Hall Agrees: Closing Fire Companies Kills
description: To the Editor:

title: How Much to Tax? Two States Struggle
description: In New York, as the budget crisis deepens, officials are facing one of their least favorite questions: how much tax revenue should be squeezed from the state's citizens and companies?

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Public Opinion; A Slight Decline Is Found In U.S. Backing for War
description: Support by the American public for the war against Iraq continues to be strong, but there are further signs of reduced expectations, according to a new poll conducted by CBS News.

title: Carl Brown, 84, Dies; Former Ad Executive
description: Carl S. Brown, a former advertising executive, died on Saturday at the Courtland Gardens Health Center in Stamford, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived in Salisbury, Conn.

title: Cuomo Uses Image of F.D.R. and '32
description: Conjuring up the economic nightmares of the 1930's seems like perilous strategy for politicians facing hard times. But when the comparison invokes the image of Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was swept from Albany to Washington at the depth of the Great Depression, the strategy could have its benefits.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: Framers Would Approve of a Larger House
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: OLISA AGBAKOBA, president of the Civil Liberties Organization of Nigeria, received the first international Roger Baldwin Medal of Liberty Award in Manhattan Monday night. The award, named for the founder of the American Civil Liberties Union, is to be given in alternating years by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights to international human-rights advocates and by the A.C.L.U. in the United States.

title: I.R.S. Sells Singer's Ranch
description: Willie Nelson's 44-acre ranch and house were sold at auction by the Internal Revenue Service today for the minimum required bid of $203,840. The auction, at the Hays County Courthouse, was the third attempt by the I.R.S. to sell property that it seized in November from the 57-year-old singer and songwriter, who owes $16.7 million in back taxes and penalties. The identity of today's successful bidder was not disclosed.

title: Bird Practices With Celtics
description: Larry Bird, sidelined the last 11 games with back problems, returned to practice today, but it was unclear whether he would play Wednesday night for the Boston Celtics against Orlando.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALICE WATERS is creating a kitchen. TOM WOLFE is designing a writer's room. GEOFFREY BEENE, KENNY SCHARF, the artist, and DICK SYLBERT, the set designer, are all doing rooms of the Metropolitan Home Showhouse, admissions to which will benefit the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS. Mr. Sylbert, who designed the sets for "Dick Tracy," will dream up a bedroom for MADONNA. The show house will be open March 7-31 at 115 East 79th Street in Manhattan.

title:
REAL ESTATE;
Long Island Warehouse Gets Reprieve
description: A DECISION by the Nikon Corporation, the giant Japanese camera company, to sign a 10-year lease for 44,000 square feet of space in Melville, L.I., has changed the fate of an old warehouse. Instead of being demolished and replaced with an office building, as had been planned, the warehouse will be renovated and expanded by the owner-developer for a mix of uses.

title: Cuomo Proposes 10% Reduction In School Funds
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to close a $6 billion gap in the state's budget will include a cut of 10 percent -- or roughly $900 million -- in the state's aid to local school districts, officials familiar with the spending proposal said today.

title: The Military's New Myths
description: In the first euphoric hours of the Persian Gulf war, statements were made that the military reformers of the 1980's -- who argued for using technology to produce larger numbers of simpler weapons that could operate dependably and successfully in combat -- had clearly been proved wrong. In war, the first casualty may be the truth, but the first creation is myth.

title: Prosecutors Admit Using Stolen Documents
description: Federal prosecutors have admitted using documents stolen from a lawyer's office to prosecute the lawyer on money laundering charges, but they denied they were involved in the burglary.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Lebanon; P.L.O. Missiles Attack North of Israel
description: Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas based in southern Lebanon unleashed the biggest barrage of short-range surface-to-surface missiles toward Israel in eight years, but Israel said the rockets fell short of their targets.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel Israelis Say Their Patience With Scud Attacks Is Thin; Israeli-U.S. Talks
description: Two senior Israeli defense officials discussed the Patriot anti-missile system in high- level meetings at the Pentagon today and also pressed their request for timely intelligence information that would allow the Israeli military to attack fixed Scud missile sites in Iraq, administration officials said.

title: Conviction of Lebanese Man In '85 Hijacking Is Upheld
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel today upheld the conviction of a Lebanese man in the 1985 Beirut hijacking of a jetliner whose passengers included two Americans.

title: Holyfield-Foreman Showdown Is All Laughs, for Now
description: It's getting hard to find a straight man these days when George Foreman is around.

title: House Backs Aid for Agent Orange Victims
description: On a vote of 412 to 0, the House of Representatives sent to the Senate today a bill to insure that Vietnam veterans suffering from certain illnesses because of exposure to Agent Orange receive permanent disability benefits.

title: Series on U.S.S.R. Tops Broadcast Awards
description: "Inside Gorbachev's U.S.S.R.," a documentary series on public television, has won a Gold Baton, the highest award given in the Alfred I. Dupont-Columbia University Awards for broadcast journalism, the university has announced. The awards ceremony was at Columbia last night.

title: Intel to Spend Up to a Billion This Year
description: In a bold move to stay ahead of its competitors, the Intel Corporation plans to spend as much as $1 billion on new plants and equipment this year. If it does, that would make it the leader in capital spending among semiconductor companies, American or Japanese.

title: Edith Bry, Artist, 92; Noted for Her Glass In a 75-Year Career
description: Edith Bry, an artist who was best known for her work in fused glass, died on Jan. 19 at her apartment in Manhattan. She was 92 years old.

title: Accuracy of Transcript Argued in Murder Trial
description: The trial of Carolyn Warmus, a former teacher charged with murder, was delayed today when lawyers began arguing over the accuracy of a transcript of a police interview with her.

title: Chrysler to Idle Mini-Van Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation will close its mini-van plant here next month, temporarily laying off about 4,400 workers, according to a report published today in The Detroit Free Press.

title: Barton Wickstrum, 77; Headed General Time
description: Barton K. Wickstrum, retired president of the General Time Corporation, which made clocks and industrial-control devices, died on Friday at his home in Sun City West, Ariz. He was 77 years old and had formerly lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: Soviets to Sell Oil Leases
description: Plans for the first competitive sale of oil and gas leases in the Soviet Union were announced here today by Soviet representatives and officials of a Denver-based company. About 90,000 square kilometers of the Soviet Turkmen Republic will be available for sealed bids by non-Soviet oil and gas companies in a process put together by Geointertech, a venture of the Ministry of Geology of the Soviet Union and Wavetech Geophysical Inc. in Denver.

title: F.D.A. Rejects, for Now, a Change in How Long Blood Can Be Kept
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration has rejected a recommendation from one of its expert panels that could greatly reduce the amount of blood available through military and civilian blood banks.

title: Shuttle Launching Is Delayed Until March
description: The next launching of the space shuttle is being delayed nearly a week so workers can replace three thrusters used to steer the ship in orbit, the space agency said today.

title: Council Given Data It Sought, Deputy Mayor Says
description: The Dinkins administration said yesterday that it had turned over all the documents the City Council had threatened to subpoena as part of an investigation into bridge safety, but a Council spokeswoman said it was too early to tell if the administration had complied completely with the demands.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN G. RANGOS SR. will receive the National Patriots Award tonight from the Congressional Medal of Honor Society at a dinner in Washington. About 50 Medal of Honor winners plan to attend. Mr. Rangos, 61 years old, is president and chief executive officer of the Chambers Development Company, which is based in Pittsburgh and is primarily concerned with waste management.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the American Civil Liberties Union referred incorrectly in some copies to the year the organization decided to represent American Nazis seeking to march in Skokie, Ill. It was 1977, not 1976.

title: Treasuries Rise in Thin Trading
description: Credit market participants sifted through a variety of economic reports yesterday, and pushed prices of Treasury securities higher after concluding the data did not support the hypothesis that the current slump would end soon.

title: Overtime Pays Off Again For Knicks
description: Overtime has been good to the Knicks all season, and it was again tonight.

title: Repairing Machinery From Afar
description: A growing number of equipment suppliers are diagnosing a wide variety of their customers' problems from service centers hundreds or even thousands of miles away.

title: Murray Out of Danger
description: Troy Murray of the Chicago Blackhawks was declared "fine" yesterday after gagging when part of his dental plate lodged in his throat during a game on Monday at the Pacific Coliseum in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: India in an Uproar Over Refueling of U.S. Aircraft
description: A decision to allow United States military aircraft to refuel at Bombay's international airport en route from the Pacific to the Persian Gulf has set off a political outcry that could bring down the Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: Auto Slump Hits Honda And Production Is Cut
description: One of Japan's most successful auto makers is experiencing one of the most important rites of passage since it became a United States manufacturer: slumping sales and production cuts.

title: Medical Journal Picks a New Chief Editor
description: The New England Journal of Medicine, the world's oldest medical journal, has named Dr. Jerome P. Kassirer its new editor in chief.

title: Warsaw Journal; Catching Poland's Ear With West's Catchy Music
description: The newscasters at this city's newest radio station crowd around a rickety white table with two ancient microphone stands and a lamp secured by a woodworkers' clamp.

title: Durables Orders Up In Month
description: Buoyed in part by new military orders related to the Persian Gulf buildup, orders to factories for long-lasting goods climbed 4.4 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Albany Resists Dinkins's Anti-Crime Plan
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins lobbied for his troubled anti-crime plan in Albany for the first time today, but returned home unable to declare a legislative victory.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the world of film, PETER MEDAK, director of "The Krays," won the award for best film of the year Sunday at The Evening Standard British Film Awards in London. The film is about real-life twin brothers and their career in crime. IAIN GLEN won the award for best actor, and NATASHA RICHARDSON for best actress.

title: Canada Is Expected to Join U.S.-Mexico Trade Talks
description: After months of high-level talks, the United States, Mexico and Canada have reached agreement to include Canada in negotiations toward a continentwide North American free-trade zone, diplomats and trade officials said today.

title: Lawyers at Legal Aid Picket For Day to Show Frustration
description: Legal Aid Society lawyers struck the New York City courts for a single day yesterday in a display of frustration over the lawyers' roles as advocates for the poor.

title: Patriotic Theme Popular
description: With the onset of war, patriotic ads are quickly gaining popularity. Recently, the Boeing Company has run a patriotic ad and, during the Super Bowl, the Anheuser-Busch Companies broadcast a spot with a similar theme.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Resistance; Radio Voice Gives Heart To Kuwaitis
description: The skies over Kuwait are filled every night with menacing allied aircraft, and with the reassuring radio signals of the Voice of Kuwait.

title: Apple Bancorp Names Chief
description: Apple Bancorp Inc., the holding company for one of New York's largest savings and loan associations, announced the appointment yesterday of William J. Laraia as chairman and chief executive.

title: Iran Says It Will Make Missile
description: Iran will start producing a powerful long-range surface-to-surface missile next week and will soon launch its second submarine, the official Iranian press agency said today. It quoted a spokesman for the Ministry of Defense and Armed Forces Logistics, identified only as Hojatoleslam Alawi, as saying that Iran would start making the missiles on Sunday. He gave no information on what types of missile would be made, saying only that they would have "high destructive power."

title: Gas, Germs and Nukes
description: Two recent pronouncements, oceans apart, point to the next strategic crossroads for President Bush in the Persian Gulf -- how to respond to Iraq's expected use of chemical and other terror weapons.

title: Dealer Is Guilty In Gun Slaying Of Drug Battler
description: A man with a criminal record as a drug dealer was found guilty yesterday of the murder of a Brooklyn woman who had become a symbol of citizen courage in fighting drug traffic.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany; GERMANS TO GIVE $5.5 BILLION MORE
description: German leaders, under quiet but sustained criticism for not contributing enough to the anti-Iraq coalition, announced today that their Government would provide an additional $5.5 billion.

title: Wait for a Bed at Public Hospital Can Be Days
description: The average emergency room wait for a bed in the nation's public hospitals is now more than five and a half hours and in the worst cases 3 to 10 days, the National Association of Public Hospitals said today.

title: In New York State, That Question Again: How Much to Tax, and Who Should Pay?
description: As New York State's budget crisis slides from the painful to the excruciating, the state is being forced to confront anew one of its least favorite questions: how much tax revenue should be squeezed from its citizens and companies?

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Jan. 10 misstated a management change at Victoria's Secret Catalogue. Cynthia Fedus has been president since 1988; she was not just appointed. She announced that Laura Berkman had been promoted to vice president and creative director of the catalogue.

title: Dow Posts Gain of 8.16 In Uneventful Trading
description: Stock prices changed little yesterday in slow trading as blue-chip and over-the-counter issues advanced slightly and the broader market fell back a bit.

title: Sullivan Resigns Post With Patriots
description: In an emotional farewell, Patrick Sullivan, upset over his diminished duties with the New England Patriots, resigned last night as general manager of the team his father founded in 1960.

title: In Test, 'Star Wars' Picks Off a Warhead in Space
description: After seven years of research and $24 billion in spending, the Pentagon's "Star Wars" program to destroy enemy missiles has achieved its first interception of a mock warhead in space.

title: Market Place; Stock Funds Staged a Rally in '90
description: Mutual fund investors were cautious in early January, but flocked back to stock funds after war broke out, fund managers said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the appointment of an acting chief accountant to the Securities and Exchange Commission misstated the salary. It can range from $87,000 to $100,500 a year. The article also misidentified the chief accountant in the commission's corporation finance department. He is Robert Bayless.

title: Long-Distance Calls For Democratic Coffers
description: The Democratic National Committee will receive a commission from the cost of every long-distance telephone call made by those whom it can persuade to choose U S Sprint as their long-distance company.

title: Tetra Pak Bid For Alfa-Laval
description: Tetra Pak, a privately held packaging company, announced plans today for a $2.9 billion acquisition of Alfa-Laval A.B. The deal would create one of the largest food packaging and processing equipment companies in the world.

title: Wal-Mart to Open Puerto Rico Stores
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said it planned to build three Wal-Mart discount stores and one Sam's wholesale club in Puerto Rico, its first operations outside the continental United States. The nation's second-largest retailer said it would begin construction on the stores this spring. The company currently operates 1,537 Wal-Mart stores and 147 Sam's Clubs in 35 states.

title: Memorial for Princess
description: A memorial service for Princess Ileana of Romania , who was known as Mother Alexandra after becoming a nun, is to be held at 5:30 P.M. on Saturday at the Orthodox Cathedral of the Protection of the Holy Virgin, 59 East Second Street, at Second Avenue in Manhattan. Princess Ileana, daughter of King Ferdinand and Queen Marie of Romania, died in Youngstown, Ohio, on Jan. 21 at the age of 82.

title: All-Star Dream for King Come True
description: Bernard King was awakened yesterday morning at his home in Mitchville, Md., by a telephone call from Abe Pollin, the owner of the Washington Bullets, who told him he had been named to the All-Star team.

title: Christopher Jackman Dies at 74; Longtime Legislator in New Jersey
description: State Senator Christopher J. Jackman, a legislator in New Jersey for more than 20 years and a former Speaker of the Assembly, died on Monday at University Hospital in Newark. He was 74 years old and lived in West New York, N.J.

title: The Tastes Of a Century
description: Andre Tchelistcheff was a teen-ager when the Russian Revolution began, living on his family's estate east of Moscow and planning to become a physician. Today, approaching 90, he lives in a modest house here on the edge of California's wine country.

title: Commuted Death Sentences Fought in Ohio
description: The Ohio Attorney General said today that former Gov. Richard F. Celeste had improperly commuted the sentences of 11 prisoners, 7 of them convicted murderers on death row, shortly before he left office.

title: Nets' Trip Gloomier As the Lakers Coast
description: Two games in two nights have produced two losses for the Nets. And if they had hoped last week that they were embarking on an upward turn, they were wrong.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Israelis Say Their Patience With Scud Attacks Is Thin
description: After several days of growing frustration over the slow pace of allied efforts to eliminate Iraq's Scud missile launchers, Israeli officials warned today that Israel may not wait much longer before it attacks.

title: Anheuser-Busch's Record Beer Sales
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc., the world's largest brewery, reported it had sold an industry record 86.5 million barrels of beer in 1990 and had recorded the largest one-year increase by a brewer in more than a decade. Sales for the year rose 7.2 percent, from 80.7 million barrels in 1989. The performance by the company widened its market share to 43.7 percent of total industry sales in the United States.

title: Morris and Berenguer Opt for Free-Agent Status
description: Jack Morris, Juan Berenguer and Chili Davis chose freedom, but Dave LaPoint had little choice but to return to his team, the Yankees, as a midnight deadline for the five remaining new-look free agents to declare their intentions passed last night.

title: Students Come to Class Less Healthy So School Clinics Try to Offer More
description: The hammering had gone on for weeks, but few at Franklin K. Lane High School in Queens seemed to mind. In this castle of a school building that stands at the edge of a cemetery, there is a bubbling anticipation about what the room down the hall from the principal's office will become next month.

title: Giving Soviets a Lesson in Thinking
description: Slowly the room filled with dissent, but the first graders at the Watchung School were encouraged to keep on arguing. Claire Rosen said she believed she loved horses. Carlton Ayoung and Ali Altieri said they knew she loved horses because they had seen her bring in pictures of her pony, Pumpkin, nearly every day.

title: Drug Maker's Net Up 14.2%
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 14.2 percent on the strength of a record sales increase in the last three months of 1990.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: The President; President, in State of Union Talk, Dwells on War and the Economy
description: In a State of the Union Message to a nation burdened with war and recession, President Bush promised tonight that the "indomitable" American character would overcome Saddam Hussein abroad and economic troubles at home.

title: ABC Is Ratings Leader In Covering the War
description: In the first full week of the war in the Persian Gulf, all three network evening newscasts made ratings gains, but CBS trailed both ABC and NBC , with ABC continuing to be the leader. The three networks expanded their newscasts to a full hour for at least part of the week.

title: Review/Jazz; Banging the Drum Loudly
description: Marvin (Smitty) Smith's first set at the Knitting Factory last Wednesday night took off on the last tune, "Miss Ann." Until then, Mr. Smith, who can be a violent and tumultuous drummer, had been a whirlwind under glass, interacting with his soloists, keeping a swirling conversation going, but never enveloping them. The glass shattered during "Miss Ann"; the tune, fast and with a hyperactive melody, was loaded with structural details that allowed Mr. Smith the space to play loud and hard, as if he suddenly became liberated.

title: Borrowing By F.D.I.C. Suggested
description: Congress's chief economist proposed today that to head off insolvency, the Federal bank insurance program borrow from the Treasury and pay taxpayers back later.

title: Cash Draining, T.W.A. Asks U.S. to Act on Deal
description: Trans World Airlines, its coffers brimming with cash as it entered the winter, is now pleading hardship to the Federal Government.

title: Key Rates
'69 SLAYING OF GIRL BRINGS LIFE TERM
description: A man whose daughter suddenly recalled his slaying of her playmate more than two decades ago and then reported him to the police was sentenced today to the maximum punishment of life in prison. He will be eligible to apply for parole in seven years.

title: A. Zettlemoyer, 75, Chemistry Professor And Lehigh Official
description: Dr. Albert C. Zettlemoyer, a former president of the American Chemical Society and a former provost and vice president of Lehigh University, died on Sunday at Muhlenberg Hospital Center in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 75 years old and lived in Bethlehem.

title: Times to Seek Arbitration on New Plant
description: The publisher of The New York Times declared yesterday that negotiations had failed to resolve differences with a key union over operation of a new printing plant due to open at Edison, N.J., and that the paper would exercise its right to submit the dispute to binding arbitration.

title: A Club Med Vocation For a New Executive
description: Tod Seisser said he had little difficulty adjusting to his new position as senior vice president and associate creative director at Ammirati & Puris, the New York agency he joined this month.

title: Creating Computer Godzillas
description: Researchers at the computer maker Next Inc. have developed a potent program that harnesses the unused computing power in a network of computers. Affectionately named Godzilla or just Zilla, the program permits users to break up the thorniest scientific and other computing problems into small parts and then runs them in parallel on unoccupied machines.

title: Thomas Probably Out
description: Isiah Thomas, point guard of the Detroit Pistons, had bones in his right hand fused yesterday and the surgeon who performed the operation said it was unlikely Thomas would play again this season.

title: New Hampshire Journal; A Small-Town Drama Of Life, Love and Death
description: Pamela Smart's license plate reads "Halen," and her dog is named Halen. The name, friends say, reflects her passion for the heavy-metal rock band Van Halen, whose hit rock video "Hot for Teacher" featured a high school teacher who appeared to seduce her students.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A TESTIMONIAL I have lived in this city 25 years and all that time I have dropped things. I've dropped tissues, letters from women in Santa Fe, N.M., money, the keys to my house, books by Jacques Prevert. And all this time, you, the people of this city, have pointed to me, and said, "Hey!" "Sir!" "You! You dropped something!" and then I have picked it up. You have watched over me, all these years, and I've waited till now to thank you. -- MICHAEL GORELICK Dear Diary:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Aicorp Inc., Waltham, Mass., a software company, named Frank Chisholm president and chief operating officer. * Amwest Insurance Group Inc., Woodland Hills, Calif., named John E. Savage president of Amwest Surety Insurance Co., its primary unit. He replaces Gary R. Peterson, who retired last year. Arthur F. Melton was also named senior vice president. * Chase Manhattan Bank, a unit of Chase Manhattan Corp., appointed Timothy McGinnis and Thompson M. Swayne executive vice presidents. * Data-Design Laboratories Inc., Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., a computer hardware manufacturer, named Theodore D. Zucconi vice president of technology and quality. * Dynagen Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a manufacturer of diagnostic health-care products, named Jack L. Barlow chairman and executive vice president. * Lands' End Inc., Dodgeville, Wis., named Jane M. McAndrew and Jack Sidebotham vice presidents.

title: Buccaneers Interested In Giants' Belichick
description: Bill Belichick, the highly regarded architect of the Giants' Super Bowl defense, will be interviewed for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' head-coaching job. Both clubs indicated yesterday that the request to talk to Belichick, the defensive coordinator, was imminent.

title: Government Halts a Corn Reserve Program, Touching Off a Protest
description: With little public discussion, the Federal Government has halted a major part of a grain reserve program started in the 1970's to help stabilize prices and prevent food shortages.

title: Giants' Rally at City Hall Fizzles With a Fumble
description: Did the Giants leave New York City in the lurch once again? What did the Giants' president know, and when did he know it? Why were the losers the only ones celebrating the Super Bowl?

title: Eating Well
description: SINCE 1977 one branch or other of the Federal Government has been telling everyone in the country to eat less fat, cholesterol and salt. Everyone, that is, except the children who participate in the federally financed school-lunch program.

title: Berl Frymer, 78, Dies; Long a Zionist Leader
description: Berl Frymer, a leader in labor and Zionist groups in Europe, Israel and the United States for several decades, died on Jan. 19 at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Washburn in C.B.A.
description: Chris Washburn, a former National Basketball Association first-round pick serving a two-year suspension from the league for repeated drug use, signed with the Tulsa Fast Breakers of the Continental Basketball Association yesterday.

title: Men Playing The Old Recipe Game
description: RECIPE-SWAPPING is stereotypically a women's activity, done over clotheslines or telephone lines, at the hairdresser or at lovely little luncheons. It's a notion as outdated as the idea that men don't cook. Of course, men swap recipes as well, at the gym or at bars, over fax machines or card games, during half-times or seventh-inning stretches -- or even over clotheslines.

title: Filling Gap of School Chiefs
description: With big-city school systems begging for qualified leaders, the Harvard University Graduate School of Education has started the nation's first doctoral program for superintendents of urban school systems.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Transportation Displays Inc., a media network, has donated space on billboards and buses to promote "Reading Rainbow," a television program designed to promote children's literacy. The campaign was created on a pro bono basis by Bozell Advertising in Minneapolis.

title: The Key to Unity
description: A nation divided only a few weeks ago has become a nation largely united in support of the war in the Persian Gulf. Can that unity be maintained? History suggests that it won't be easy.

title: Spread of AIDS Is Worrying Uganda
description: When President Yoweri K. Museveni was shown a computerized slide presentation with mathematical models that projected how Uganda would look in the future if nothing was done to stem the AIDS epidemic, he immediately reversed a long-held position. The President urged Ugandans to use condoms.

title: Ethiopia Talks to Resume, Under U.S. Leadership
description: The United States will mediate the first formal peace talks between Ethiopia and Eritrean separatist guerrillas in more than a year in London next month in an effort to end 30 years of civil strife, Administration officials said today.

title: Consumers' Confidence Dips Again
description: Reflecting worry over rising unemployment and the Persian Gulf war, consumer confidence fell again in January, the Conference Board reported yesterday. Not since the early 1980's has the board's monthly survey turned up such pessimism.

title: Murdock Sets Record As Friars Edge Pirates
description: Eric Murdock scored 24 points and became the National Collegiate Athletic Association's career steal leader as Providence beat Seton Hall, 65-62, tonight.

title: Poland, Pioneer of Capitalism
description: Look: Something is rising from the smoking wreckage of Communism. Poland is creating capitalism, in ways that could provide a blueprint for all Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: The Ghost Galloped Into History
description: "All Grange can do is run," Fielding Yost, the football coach of Michigan, was quoted as saying.

title: Hilton Plans to Seek Atlantic City License
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that it planned to apply for a license to operate a hotel and casino in Atlantic City with an eye toward entering the market.

title: New York Is Featured In Sasson's Campaign
description: The Sasson Licensing Corporation has employed some of New York's most recognizable landmarks to sell its spring line of jeans, sleepwear, swimwear and shoes.

title: Dr. Alexander M. Schmidt, 61, Ex-Food and Drug Commissioner
description: Dr. Alexander M. Schmidt, a former Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, died Monday at his home in Oak Park, Ill. He was 61 years old.

title: One Woman, Her Lawyer And One Plea
description: For all the novelty in shooting a drugged, drunken man in the South Bronx, Sarah Smith might have filled another page in the annals of violence along Jackson Avenue, the rough strip of housing projects and tenements where she lived.

title: RJR Nabisco Increases Size Of Offer to Exchange Debt
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that because of the interest shown by many Wall Street investors it had increased the size of an exchange offer for its debt.

title: War Summary
description: THE RELENTLESS AIR WAR Amid some of the heaviest bombing yet, Iraq said a captured airman - name and nationality undisclosed - died in the wreckage of a Government building in Baghdad where he "had been evacuated." Closer to the Saudi border, allied warplanes caught an Iraqi convoy venturing into the open desert and destroyed 24 tanks, armored vehicles and trucks. THE PLIGHT OF THE CIVILIANS Refugees reached Jordan with tales of deprivation, fright and sheer despair griping the people of Kuwait and Iraq. They spoke of scarce water and food, severed communications, bombed bridges, roads and housing, and a black market in which one can make a living selling cigarettes one at a time. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Of the 28 airmen listed as missing before, 11 are now known to be held prisoner. These are 7 Americans, 2 Brittons, and 1 each from Italy and Kuwait. Another 7 Americans were among those still carried as missing. Aircraft: The United States command reported no losses yesterday. That left its cound of aircraft downed by the Iraqis at 18, including 11 American. Iraq claimed yesterday to have shot down 6 more "aerial targets." IRAQI FORCES Troops: No meaningful figures aircraft sequestered in Iran reached about 90. It is still not clear exactly why the planes' pilots sought refuge. The United States command in Riyadh said one more MIG-23 was shot down, raising to 52 its tally of aircraft destroyed, 27 of them in aerial combat and the rest on the ground.

title: Settlement Reached With Parents On Bible Stories at Florida School
description: The parents of a fifth-grade pupil and the Nassau County School Board have agreed to a $15,000 settlement of a lawsuit that was filed after the board refused to order a teacher to stop reading Bible stories in class.

title: Don't Bash the Messenger
description: War reporting is a perilous calling in which important or unwelcome information can be ungratefully received. The peril was underscored by the disappearance last week of the CBS correspondent Bob Simon and three members of his television crew near the Kuwaiti border. And the ungrateful reception was reflected in White House displeasure with reports from Baghdad by Peter Arnett of CNN, the only correspondent for a U.S. news organization still in that city.

title: Military Gives Big Role To Civilian Technicians
description: As they wage war on Iraq, the United States and its allies are relying heavily on civilian employees sent to the Persian Gulf by military contractors to provide technical expertise in maintaining the world's most advanced weapons, industry executives and military officials said.

title: About New York; The Massage Is the Message, The Soviet Way
description: When last we saw Kenny Schaffer, he was hustling a device to snag Russian television signals for curious Americans. From Soviet aerobics classes this improbable dynamo had learned at least one truth: "They're regular bozos like us."

title: Review/Film; Making Light of Franco With a Gentle Touch
description: Considering the grim nature of the dictatorship of Francisco Franco and its high cost to Spain in terms of life, limb and other essentials, Antonio Mercero's "Wait for Me in Heaven" is satire of almost stupefying gentleness.

title: Union Decides to Join Division I ECAC Hockey
description: Union College of Schenectady, N.Y., will join the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Division I hockey league next season as a replacement for Army. In a realignment of the league's 12 teams, the Dutchmen will be linked with nearby Rensselaer as a partner on the road and at home.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAN PROMISES IRAQI PLANES WON'T REJOIN THE FIGHTING; BUSH SAYS U.S. IS PREVAILING
description: On one of the heaviest days of the air war in the Persian Gulf, with allied pilots flying more than 2,600 missions, American officials said the number of Iraqi warplanes fleeing to Iran reached 90 today, up from 80-odd on Monday.

title: President Is Appointed At B. Dalton Bookseller
description: B. Dalton Bookseller, the chain of 800 bookstores, has a new president and chief operating officer. R. Richard Fontaine has been named to the posts and will take over on Feb. 11.

title: Stopping Drunken Drivers Before the Next Wreck
description: The Baltimore County Police Department has identified 41 people as the most dangerous drunken drivers in the area, and this weekend a group of officers will start watching their neighborhoods, their workplaces and the night spots they frequent to stop them from driving drunk.

title: William Little Sr., 81; Managed Trade Shows
description: William E. Little Sr., a manager of consumer goods trade shows, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and had homes in Manhattan and in Redding, Conn.

title: We'll Miss You, Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines died on Friday, Jan. 18, 1991. It was 62 years old. The immediate cause of death was a lack of cash. Eastern was eating up so much money -- more than $2 million a day -- that its demise had been predicted for months.

title: Rape and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Leading East German Figure Is Placed on Trial in Berlin
description: Harry Tisch, once mong the most powerful East Germans, went on trial today despite assertions by his lawyers that he was too ill to take the stand.

title: Hollywood May Lose Old Hangout of the Stars
description: The old Brown Derby restaurant is gone, and so is Schwab's Drug Store, Pickfair and the Pan Pacific Auditorium.
