And now the Formosa Cafe, once the hangout of Lauren Bacall, Humphrey Bogart, Douglas Fairbanks and Marilyn Monroe, is on the verge of being torn down for a five-story parking garage.

title: Ex-Navajo Leader and Son Convicted in Scheme to Defraud Tribe
description: The former chairman of the Navajo Nation, Peter MacDonald, was convicted today in tribal court on all charges that he plotted to influence the tribe to buy a ranch for an inflated price.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: S.& L. Figure Has Surgery
description: The former owner of the Vernon Savings Association, Don R. Dixon, who was convicted last month on fraud charges, was listed in fair condition today after open- heart surgery.

title: Unions at News Study Purchase by Employees
description: A legal adviser to the unions striking The Daily News, Theodore W. Kheel, said yesterday that the unions had authorized him to look into buying the newspaper through an employee stock ownership trust.

title: Ex-Banker's Plea Disputed
description: The ousted chairman of the Centrust Savings Bank, David L. Paul, is pleading poverty and claiming hardship on his legal bills, but Government lawyers have charged that he is lying.

title: Rare Islander Romp With 6 Goals in 2d
description: Pat LaFontaine's skills and Brent Sutter's determination helped inspire the Islanders to their largest goal-production of the season tonight, an 8-1 triumph over the Whalers at the Civic Center.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a cookbook by Jack Greenberg and James Vorenberg misidentified the publication in which Julia Child reviewed it. It was The Harvard Law Bulletin, not The Harvard Law Review. The report also misidentified a position held by Mr. Greenberg at Columbia Law School before he became dean of Columbia College. He was vice dean, not dean, of the law school.

title: Needs of Neediest Grow Amid Shrinking Aid
description: For more than a decade, Jackie Ebron has had the unenviable task of deciding which poor people will receive a check and which ones will not. Now she finds herself at the other end of the decision-making, not sure whether there will be money for her own salary.

title: INSIDE
description: A Bank Fund Proposal Congress's chief economist proposed that the troubled bank insurance fund borrow from the Treasury now and pay taxpayers back later. Page D1. Canada to Join Trade Talks Canada will be included in talks with the United States and Mexico to establish a North American free-trade zone, trade officials said. Page D1. Pentagon and Environment Giving priority to war efforts, the White House has waived a law requiring environmental assessments of military projects. Page A14. No Celebration for Giants There will be no victory celebration in New York for the Giants' Super Bowl victory. The team said it would not attend, citing the war. Page B4.

title: NCR Challenge To A.T.& T.
description: The NCR Corporation today challenged an A.T.& T. request for a special NCR shareholders meeting at which the phone company would try to remove NCR's directors and gain approval for its $6.1 billion takeover of the computer maker.

title: Muriel Stuart, 90, Dancer for Pavlova And Ballet Teacher
description: Muriel Stuart, an English-born ballerina who danced with Anna Pavlova and was a leading teacher at the School of American Ballet, died yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge
description: The degree of interest in a duplicate deal often depends on the number of different contracts reached. If every table reaches the same contract, the tendency is toward dullness; if there is a wide range of results, the post-mortems are likely to be lengthy.

title: Authority Delays Vote On Increases in Tolls
description: In a temporary reprieve for drivers, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey abruptly postponed a meeting yesterday at which a vote was planned on raising bridge and tunnel tolls.

title: Rise in Realty Taxes May Exceed What Dinkins Has Spelled Out
description: Real-estate taxes in New York City would rise considerably more than the Dinkins administration has clearly spelled out if the City Council approves the Mayor's proposed budget and tax package for the coming fiscal year, city officials have acknowledged.

title: Ellis Haizlip, Producer, 61, Dies; Mentor to Many Black Performers
description: Ellis B. Haizlip, a leading producer of black cultural events and mentor of black artists, died on Friday at George Washington University Medical Center in Washington. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Tax Rebate in New Hampshire Town Poses a Test for School-Choice Issue
description: A new program granting $1,000 tax breaks to families that send their children anywhere but the local public high school may turn this small town into a national testing ground for plans that offer parents a choice as to where their offspring will go to school.

title: 2 BLACK FACTIONS IN SOUTH AFRICA WILL END RIVALRY
description: South Africa's two largest black political movements agreed tonight to set aside their differences and put an end to a bitter rivalry that has cost thousands of lives.

title: Irate Americans Get Gas Masks
description: Bowing to pressure from angry Americans and their elected representatives back home, the United States Embassy said today that it would offer gas masks to American citizens in Saudi Arabia.

title: Italy's Bracing, Bitter Amari: Drinks to Top Off a Lusty Meal
description: An old Italian proverb states that people are not what they eat, as some philosophers proclaim, but how well they digest.

title: Johnson's Coach Quits
description: Loren Seagrave quit yesterday as Ben Johnson's coach, saying he was returning to Louisiana to be closer to his wife, the hurdler Kathy Freeman-Seagrave.

title: U.S. Gives El Salvador Aircraft
description: The United States today delivered three A-37 jet fighter-bombers and six attack helicopters to the Salvadoran Air Force, which has suffered heavy losses to guerrillas in recent months. The A-37s were inscribed with the names of the three United States servicemen killed when rebels shot down their helicopter in eastern El Salvador. Warrant Officer Daniel Scott, the pilot, died in the Jan. 2 crash, but leftist rebels have said their forces later killed Lieut. Col. David Pickett and Pvt. Ernest Dawson.

title: A Super Good Night For a Happy Parcells
description: There were not 200,000 Giant fans in Gallagher's Steak House last night. The few hundred who managed to squeeze into the restaurant on West 52d Street just sounded like that many when Bill Parcells took the microphone for his weekly radio program.

title: The Mayor Narrows the Document Gap
description: It's easy to understand why Mayor David Dinkins might feel picked on. Under previous Mayors the New York City Council was a rubber stamp, rarely known to ask embarrassing questions much less demand answers. But now that the city is operating under its new charter, the rules have changed dramatically. The Council this week asserted a more active oversight role and the Mayor has wisely, if grudgingly, begun to accommodate.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: The Capitol Scene; A Reassuring Ritual Counters the Tension of War
description: There was little doubt at the Capitol tonight that the state of the union was one of war. The security measures were extraordinary, the mood of the lawmakers subdued. President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had lines of weariness around their eyes.

title: Interfaith Coalition Acts To Aid Catholic Schools
description: A coalition of business leaders, both Christian and Jewish, took up the cause of Roman Catholic schools yesterday, announcing a $100 million fund campaign to keep schools open in poor areas of New York, from the South Bronx to Newburgh.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Weapons; A Search and Destroy Priority: Unconventional Iraqi Munitions
description: The United States-led coalition has destroyed Iraq's ability to produce nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, but Baghdad still has vast stocks of deadly nerve gas and germ agents, American military officials say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We all have something to give. So if you know how to read, find someone who can't. If you've got a hammer, find a nail. If you're not hungry, not lonely, not in trouble -- seek out someone who is." -- President Bush. [ A12:2. ]

title: 4 Agents Switch Allegiance To Rival
description: Four prominent talent agents whose clients include the actresses Julia Roberts, Anjelica Huston and Joanne Woodward are leaving the William Morris Agency to join International Creative Management.

title: The Pop Life
description: Gloria Estefan

title: Giants Are Deflecting the Big Question
description: Now that the Giants have won Super Bowl XXV with Jeff Hostetler at quarterback, the question is this: Will their quarterback next year be Hostetler or Phil Simms.

title: Weyerhaeuser Posts a Profit
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the wood products concern, today reported a profit for the fourth quarter but said its operating results were down in all but one of its business segments.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: War in the Gulf A8-11

title: Commodore Net Soars on Europe Sales
description: Continuing its rebound, Commodore International Ltd. today reported more than a threefold gain in earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31, primarily because of strong European sales of personal computers.

title: Study Says U.S. Coastal Pollution Is Easing
description: Chemical contamination has abated in vast stretches of America's coastal waters, but high levels of toxic pollution are still found in major cities and at some industrial sites, the Government said in a report today.

title: Egyptian Journalists Protest
description: About 100 Egyptian journalists staged a sit-in today to protest the allied bombing of Iraq and to demand that Egypt withdraw its 36,000 troops from the American-led coalition. The protest, by only a fraction of Egypt's 4,000 union journalists, reflected criticism of President Hosni Mubarak's anti-Iraq stance in the Persian Gulf war. Egypt has deployed the largest Arab force against Iraq.

title: Austrian Notes Tied to Stocks
description: The Republic of Austria yesterday priced a $100 million issue of notes tied to the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The underwriters are led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Bain Names Chief Executive And Begins a Reorganization
description: Bain & Company, the Boston-based consulting firm, said yesterday that W. Mitt Romney would become chief executive, replacing William W. Bain Jr., who would remain chairman.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; Baghdad Says Allied Air Raid Killed P.O.W.
description: An allied bombing raid on Baghdad last night killed a captured Western pilot detained apparently as a "human shield" at a Government building, the Baghdad radio said today.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: The Palestinians; WEST BANK LEADER ACCUSED OF SPYING
description: The Israeli authorities arrested one of the West Bank's most senior political leaders on Tuesday night and accused him of spying for Iraq.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: I AM often asked if it is appropriate to prepare fish in red wine. The answer is decidedly yes, and recipes dating back a century or more can be found to prove it. Carp Chambord, an elaborate dish, is made by braising the fish in the oven while basting it with red wine. One of the classic dishes of Burgundy, matelote, always calls for red wine in the sauce.

title: Ground Assault Now Carries Too High a Price; Grave Japanese Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlene Victor, 71, Arts Council Director
description: Charlene Victor, the executive director of BACA, the Brooklyn Arts Council, died on Monday at her home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. She was 71 years old.

title: Greek Troops To Aid Police
description: Responding to a series of terrorist attacks in Greece related to the Persian Gulf war, the Government said today that it would use troops to help police counter the threat of more violence against Western offices and installations.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: France; French Defense Chief Quits, Opposing Allied War Goals
description: Under attack at home for his dovish position on the Iraqi crisis, France's Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, resigned today, complaining that allied objectives in the Persian Gulf war risked going beyond those established by the United Nations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the collapse of a brokerage firm that served many Polish-Americans misidentified the law-enforcement agency investigating the case. It is the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, not in Brooklyn.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. King Leads Bullets Past Heat Bernard King scored 26 points and A. J. English scored 4 straight points in the final two minutes last night to lead the Washington Bullets to a 105-101 victory over the Miami Heat at Landover, Md. Harvey Grant had 24 points for the Bullets, who snapped a three-game losing streak. Grant Long and Glen Rice scored 20 points each for the Heat, which has lost eight consecutive road games and five in a row over all. English finished with 12 points. (AP) Cavaliers 125, Hornets 106: Chucky Brown scored 15 points during Cleveland's nearly perfect second quarter and the Cavaliers went on to beat the visiting Hornets. The Cavaliers made 17 of 18 field-goal attempts during the second period, outscoring the Hornets, 41-18, and taking a 60-41 halftime lead. (AP) Nuggets 126, Bucks 122: Michael Adams scored 41 points, including 4 on free throws in the final 6.4 seconds as Denver held off a late rally to win in Milwaukee. The victory was a season-high fourth straight for the Nuggets, who have won six of eight games after a 6-28 start. The Bucks have lost six straight after a 27-12 start and they were defeated for only the second time in 22 home games. (AP)

title: Review/Rock; ZZ Top, Stressing Total Control
description: ZZ Top, the headliners at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, were a lot bigger than the opening act, the Black Crowes, and in such an arena, size counts. Playing on a stage that was meant to be a surreal cartoon of a scrap yard -- the drums sat on the back of a flatbed truck, while stacks of crushed cars framed the set -- the group turned power-trio rock-and-roll into something immense and abstract.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: The Response; Mitchell Replies for Democrats to Bush's Message
description: Following is the transcript of remarks last night in Washington by George J. Mitchell of Maine, Senate majority leader, for the Democratic response to the State of the Union Message, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Yale Plans Cuts as Income Falls and Costs Rise
description: The president of Yale University has ordered all schools and departments to trim their budgets by between 5 percent and 10 percent next year and to consider long-range cuts in faculty and possibly entire departments to help the university offset declining revenues and steadily rising costs.

title: Kurri Unlikely to Return From Italy
description: Those recent stories about Jari Kurri's possible return to the National Hockey League may be nothing but wishful thinking on the part of the Los Angeles Kings, who might like to have him, and the Edmonton Oilers, who would like to trade his rights.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; War Transforms a Bypassed Desert Community Into a Boom Town
description: George Bush is a local hero here. America is Number One. And some Bedouins here have been calling their hunting falcons Patriot, a name that residents predict Bedouin children will soon bear.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook; Desert Fires Announce A Victory to the G.I.'s
description: The war against Iraq finally became visible today for hundreds of American soldiers camped out along the tense but still largely quiet border between Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.

title: USX Earnings Rise by 9.4% On Higher Profits at Oil Unit
description: The USX Corporation, the giant energy and steel company, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 9.4 percent, largely as a result of improved profitability at its Marathon Oil Company subsidiary.

title: MOSCOW ASSURES BUSH ON BALTICS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union ended three days of talks here today with Moscow promising to withdraw some troops from the troubled Baltic region and Washington renewing its offer to stop the war against Iraq if Baghdad pulls its army out of Kuwait.

title: Review/Fashion; Sea Changes For Couture
description: Three designers showed spring and summer couture collections today strong enough to change the way women think about clothes. Claude Montana at Lanvin is in the futurist spot occupied by Andre Courreges and Pierre Cardin 30 years ago when the space age was very new. His new space maidens are a gentler race, wearing soft silk clothes with small waistlines and spreading skirts. His collection was a perfect cameo expressing couture's latest new era. The barriers between coats, suits and dresses were broken down. For evening, a little glitter was added, but the shapes remained the same. It was the only collection shown in Paris so far that could be called avant-garde.

title: Soviet Opposition Weighs Disobedience
description: Stunned and wary, the Soviet opposition movement was considering today whether it could conduct a civil disobedience campaign to protest the Government's tough new military plan for policing the nation.

title: Travel Plus Writing Plus Reflection Equals V.S. Naipaul
description: In the art of V. S. Naipaul -- 20 books that include novels, histories, volumes of stories, essays and travel writing -- there has always been a sense of discovery. The author or a fictional surrogate visits or revisits a place and unveils the full richness of its people. As a writer, Vidiadhar Surajprasad Naipaul remains an insatiable traveler; his journeys are interior as well as geographic. .

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Refugees; War Refugees Flood Jordan, Telling of Raids and Extortion
description: Refugees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait streamed into Jordan today, telling of bridges and highways bombed in lands where food and hope are scarce and foreigners fear the perils of flight as much as they dread allied bombardment.

title: Only One U.S. Family in Four Is 'Traditional'
description: The decline of the traditional family two parents with children -- continued in America in the 1980's but at a slower pace than in the 1970's, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Weather in the Gulf
description: Mainly clear, mild weather will prevail across northern Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and southern Iraq. Cool winds from the Mediterranean will bring low clouds and a few gusty showers to western and northern Iraq. Snow showers will persist in the Kurdistan Mountains.

title: Environmental Rule Is Waived for Pentagon
description: Concerned that war efforts could otherwise be hampered, the White House has waived the legal requirement for assessments on the effect that Pentagon projects have on the environment.

title: A Fist and a Kiss in Old Damascus
description: To the Editor:

title: Net at Scripps Declines 32.3%
description: The E. W. Scripps Company, a diversified media concern, said on Monday that its fourth- quarter earnings dropped sharply because of reduced advertising revenues.

title: Bumbling Backward From the Summit
description: Diplomatic silence is no substitute for frank talk. Instead of going to Moscow and telling Mikhail Gorbachev how Americans feel about repression in the Baltics and regression on reform, President Bush has regrettably chosen to duck, and delay a summit meeting until the spring.

title: WAR IN THE GULF: Turkey; Turkish Fundamentalists Call for Withdrawal From Coalition
description: After the noon prayers, hundreds of worshipers streamed out of the Ulu Mosque the other day and filled the streets to denounce the United States and to protest Muslim Turkey's involvement in the war against neighboring Iraq.

title: 6 Charged in Trucking Thefts
description: Six men were charged today with breaking into truck terminals in New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania and stealing more than $600,000 worth of goods, the United States Attorney's office announced. The indictment alleges that between December 1988 and November 1989, the six stole fax machines, computer screens, ceiling fans, automobile tires, telephone machines and musical instruments from the terminals.

title: Book Notes
description: A Bellow in Progress

title: In Old New York, Savory Fare
description: ONCE, Manhattan was a British isle. Today, there is Myers of Keswick, a country store in the West Village where the shelves are stocked with dear little packets of Coleman's bread sauce mix, jars of Mrs. Beeton's strawberry conserves and Jacob's cream crackers, and the butcher case features Stilton, Cheddar and double Gloucester cheeses, as well as the savory pies and sausages that Peter Myers makes by hand.

title: Economic Scene; Even Stalin Did It Better
description: TO long-suffering Soviet citizens, last week's confiscation of 50- and 100-ruble notes may seem further proof that perestroika is just another word for nothing left to lose. But to many Western economists it is an example of good intentions gone awry, of Mikhail Gorbachev's disheartening brand of administrative incompetence tinged with nostalgia for a puritanical socialist past that never was.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a new stock trading system developed by Steve Wunsch, a former Kidder, Peabody trader, misstated the average daily volume on Instinet, an electronic stock trading system. Instinet says its average in the last six months has been about eight million shares -- most reported as trades through Nasdaq -- not 95,000.

title: U.S. Will Trim Sale of Reserve Oil by Half
description: The Energy Department, facing a very weak market for the high-sulfur crude it had planned to sell from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, said yesterday that it would cut the total sale by nearly 50 percent.

title: 6-Month High For Stocks; Dow Up 50.50
description: Stock prices advanced sharply yesterday, soaring to their highest level in six months, as investors rushed into the market in expectation of strong Administration efforts to put new bounce into the economy.

title: Best Seller Breaks Rule On Crossing The Atlantic
description: It is not your usual best seller.

title: Training Orchestra Is Given $14 Million
description: The New World Symphony, a Miami-based training orchestra, has been given a $14 million endowment grant by one of its founders. The donor is Ted Arison, the founder and chairman emeritus of Carnival Cruise Lines, who established the orchestra with Michael Tilson Thomas, its music director, in 1987. Mr. Arison is the chairman emeritus of its board.

title: When Is Gardening A Subversive Act?
description: I'M on my second personal computer now, a Macintosh Plus if it matters, but I've used it strictly as a very smart typewriter with some electronic clerical skills. It keeps track of correspondence, manuscripts and bills. I've gone without electronic frills, whistles and bells -- no games or other fancy toys.

title: No Evidence to Link Bombing Of Car to Daily News Strike
description: Detectives investigating a homemade pipe bomb that exploded on Monday night under a car belonging to a Daily News supervisor at his home said today that they had no evidence linking it to the newspaper's strike.

title: Ticking Over a New Tiffany's
description: SOME companies have famous logos. Tiffany & Company has its blue gift boxes -- and its Atlas clock.

title: Harazin Takes Another Step As the Successor to Cashen
description: Al Harazin, the business mind in what was once a Mets front-office troika, has always been the heir apparent to General Manager Frank Cashen. That long-planned succession was slowed briefly by the resignation of Joe McIlvaine -- Cashen's other protege -- this past summer, but yesterday the line of succession was brought back into focus by a reshuffling of titles and Cashen's reaffirmation that he would step aside by the 1993 season.

title: Disk Jockey Falsely Reports Nuclear Attack
description: A disk jockey here broadcast a mock emergency bulletin on Tuesday, saying that the United States was under nuclear attack, and the Federal Communications Commission said today that it was investigating to determine whether the announcement violated its rules.

title: Paul D. Catalano; Executive, 60
description: Paul D. Catalano, a specialist in computer data storage, died on Jan. 13 at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: Compaq's Profit Up 70%
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 70 percent mostly because of overseas growth and strong sales of new products.

title: Weather in the Gulf
description: Clouds and showers will be abundant across Lebanon, Syria and northwestern Iraq as strong Mediterranean disturbance moves across the region. Snow heavy at times in the Kurdistan mountains of Iraq. Sun will be mixed with high clouds in central Saudi Arabia. Temperatures: Baghdad, high 62, low 40; Riyadh, high 73; low 48; Dhahran, high 72, low 53.

title: Moving Snakes And Leaves
description: THE architect Charles Francis Annesley Voysey, who lived from 1857 to 1941, designed not just houses and a factory, but also textiles, furniture and wallpaper in the Arts and Crafts style. His textile and wallpaper designs are illustrated in 64 color plates in "The Decorative Designs of C. F. A. Voysey" by Stuart Durant (Rizzoli, 1991). The 84-page paperback is $25.

title: IRAN SAID TO PLAY BOTH SIDES IN GULF
description: By harboring scores of fleeing Iraqi warplanes, Iran is playing a balancing act calculated to optimize its political position once the gulf war is over, Administration officials and independent Middle East experts say.

title: Israelis of the Left and Right Assail Arab Leader's Arrest
description: Israeli officials of the left and the right expressed strong dissatisfaction today with the arrest of a prominent Palestinian political leader on Tuesday night on charges of spying for Iraq.

title: Review/Concert; The Toronto And a Leader Who's Going
description: Imagine campaigning for two years to become a lame-duck Congressman. The parallel is hardly precise, but consider the relationship of the German conductor Gunther Herbig and the Toronto Symphony.

title: Nike's 2 Stars Appear In a New Campaign
description: Spike Lee and Michael Jordan are back with Nike. This time, the two are starring in the company's $5 million "Stay in School" campaign.

title: New Competition At Top Set Up by ITT
description: The ITT Corporation realigned its management yesterday with new roles for two executives, in effect setting up a competition a rung below Rand V. Araskog, chairman and chief executive.

title: Nexgen Microsystems Names Chief Executive
description: Nexgen Microsystems said yesterday that Atiq Raza, its executive vice president, had been named president and chief executive. Based in San Jose, Calif., Nexgen is a privately held start-up company that is developing a microprocessor based on RISC, or reduced instruction set computing.

title: Duke Tops Georgia Tech On Hill's Late Baskets
description: Thomas Hill made a layup at the buzzer to give Duke a 77-75 victory over Georgia Tech in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: Cuomo and Senate Leader Present Cost-Cutting Plans
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed today a broad package of cost-cutting measures that would cushion local governments from the pain of impending budget cuts but would also lead to reduced services for the poor and disabled.

title: Report Faults F.D.I.C. in 2 Bank Bailouts
description: The Federal agency in charge of bailing out failed banks mishandled the two most costly collapses so far, a Congressional task force said in a report released today.

title: 6 Iraqi Boats Destroyed
description: United States and British helicopters and fighter-bombers today destroyed at least six Iraqi missile-carrying patrol boats in a 12-hour battle in the northern Persian Gulf, British officers said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bowater Communication Papers Inc., Darien, Conn., a subsidiary of Bowater Inc., named Sheldon B. Saidman president. * Cahners Publishing Co., Newton, Mass., a division of Reed Publishing U.S.A. Inc., appointed Frank J. Sibley executive vice president. * Carnival's Crystal Palace and Resort, a joint venture of Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. and Continental Companies, named George Brennan senior vice president of sales and marketing. * Cox Enterprises Inc., Atlanta, a media company, named Alexander V. Netchvolodoff vice president for government affairs. * Hoechst Celanese Corp., Somerville, N.J., a subsidiary of Hoechst A.G. of Germany, appointed James J. Conway president of its specialty chemicals group. He replaces Heinz K. Hofmeister, who will retire on March 1. * Litton Industries, Beverly Hills, Calif., named Spencer B. Latham president of its Clifton Precision division. * MCI Communications Corp., Arlington, Va., named Roy N. Gamse senior vice president of consumer service for its consumer markets unit. * New Line Cinema Corp., New York, an independent motion picture producer and distributor, promoted Greg Kaufman to vice president of business development. * Robinson Nugent Inc., New Albany, Ind., an electronics manufacturer, named Tom E. Merten vice president of marketing. * Teleware Inc., Parsippany, N.J., a software developer, named Christopher P. Lee president and chief executive. He replaces Terence Q. Kearney, who has been elected chairman.

title: Masking Decay: Try Lots of Taffeta
description: THEIR favorite tool is the staple gun. "But we also enjoy hot glue," Adam Kurtzman said.

title: Bridge
description: Defenders are usually advised to play smoothly, avoiding a break in tempo that will give useful information to the declarer. This is right in principle, but it has a drawback: a defender is liable to discover in the middle of the deal that he has missed a key move because he was playing smoothly.

title: Calendar: Tiffany, Art Walks And Quilts
description: Tiffany Inside Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street; (212) 534-1034.

title: People
description: * Nancy Smith has been named director of print and media relations and Ira Tumpowsky has been named director of local broadcast at Young & Rubicam Inc., New York. * Oglivy & Mather Advertising, New York, named 13 new vice presidents. They are: Ellen Azorin, Jill Bloess, Peter Cloutier, Patricia Enright, Diane Ford Seaton, Peter Haines, Laurie Klein, Roberta Levine, Richard Lobel, Anne Loring, Brendan O'Malley, Barbara Schiano and Serena Williams. * Kerri Fox has been appointed advertising promotion director at Woman's Day magazine. * Howard Rieger has been named creative director of Ayer Direct, a unit of Ayer Inc., New York. * Tove Nedergaard has been promoted to director of marketing at Benetton Cosmetics Corp., a subsidiary of Benetton S.P.A.

title: Yields End Week Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, after declining steadily for three weeks.

title: Excerpts From Report by Schwarzkopf on the Fighting in the Persian Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from a briefing today in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Gunmen Tied to War Kill a Turkish Aide
description: Gunmen killed the chief adviser to the Prime Minister's office today, and a statement found nearby took responsibility in the name of a leftist group involved in recent terrorism protesting Turkey's support for the war against Iraq, officials reported.

title: 2 Acquitted in Brawl With Jewish Students
description: Two youths accused of severely beating two Brooklyn College students in what prosecutors called an anti-Semitic attack were acquitted by a jury yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Review/Dance; On a Dream-Cartoon Journey, Asking: Who Am I?
description: Few artists exorcise their demons as creatively as Robert Desrosiers, a brilliantly outlandish Canadian choreographer whose image-rich "Incognito" had its United States premiere on Tuesday night.

title: C. E. Charlesworth; Former Flight Chief for NASA Was 59
description: Clifford E. Charlesworth, a physicist who was a flight director for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on several space missions, including the first moon landing, died Saturday at his home in Friendsworth, Tex. He was 59 years old.

title: Corrections
description: The Guidepost table on the Consumer's World page on Jan. 5, about appliance wattages, misstated two figures. According to the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers, a typical 0.9-cubic-foot microwave oven draws about 1,250 watts and a typical dishwasher, about 1,500 watts. The dishwasher's heater, which operates during some cycles, draws about 800 watts, which are included in the 1,500- watt total.

title: Labor Dept. Nominee Lists Her Goals
description: Former Representative Lynn Martin, President Bush's nominee to be Secretary of Labor, said today that she would press for tough enforcement of child-labor and worker-safety laws, try to curb discrimination in the workplace and seek better training both for new workers and for those who lose their jobs.

title: Gulf Concession That Wasn't: U.S. Moves to Quell a Furor
description: The Bush Administration scrambled today to contain political damage from a Soviet-American communique that embarrassed Mr. Bush with some of his allies and brought simmering conflicts between the White House and State Department into the open.

title: Marines Seize An Island
description: United States Marines have captured a second Kuwaiti island after blowing up Iraqi antiaircraft weapons and artillery.

title: Saying Life Is Not Enough, the Disabled Demand Rights and Choices
description: After 42 years as a quadriplegic, Irene Armistead can no longer afford the care she needs to live on her own. So she is trying to decide whether to die.

title: Miscellany
description: * Rowland Public Affairs and Sallingsbury Casey Ltd., both units of Saatchi & Saatchi, announced plans to merge under the name Rowland Public Affairs.

title: How a Kentucky Business Made It Big in New York
description: Using politically influential New Yorkers, a tiny Kentucky company that had trouble scraping together the money to qualify for its first city contracts has come to dominate a $290 million program to install water meters throughout the five boroughs.

title: Veiling Black Rage in Broad Humor on TV
description: Dealing with pain and rage through the exaggerations of broad humor is hardly a new phenomenon, but the technique does seem to be in fairly robust health among black writers these days. One polished and sophisticated example can be found tomorrow night at 9 in a "Great Performances" presentation of George C. Wolfe's play "The Colored Museum," which had its debut at Joseph Papp's Public Theater in 1986. Another, quite willing to be exuberantly gross, is Keenen Ivory Wayans's "In Living Color," the Fox Broadcasting series on Sundays at 8 P.M.

title: Layoff No Help as Rangers Are Beaten by Flames, 5-1
description: With four days off on their current tour of western Canada, the Rangers recently enjoyed a working retreat at nearby Banff, a famous ski restort.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WAR IN THE GULF A10-14

title: Walsh Stays at NBC
description: Tampa Bay's bid to lure Bill Walsh back to football fell short yesterday. Hugh Culverhouse, the owner of the Buccaneers, said the former coach of the San Francisco 49ers had decided to continue his broadcasting career with NBC.

title: A Cuban Adjusts Himself To System
description: The usual way to get yourself noticed as a track and field athlete in Cuba is to dabble in several events at once, show proficiency in one and work your way to world prominence. That is the way Javier Sotomayor did it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Canseco Seeks Divorce
description: The Oakland Athletics outfielder, Jose Canseco, has filed for divorce from his wife, Esther, after two years of marriage, his attorney said yesterday. In the divorce papers, Canseco said his marriage was "irrevocably broken."

title: Artists Give Bedrooms a Nautical Motif
description: FROM 1833 to 1976, Sailors' Snug Harbor on Staten Island was a retirement home for sailors. The "snuggies," as they were called, ate in a common dining room. In their small, spare bedrooms, lighted by one or two windows, they slept. Undoubtedly, they dreamed.

title: Economic Indicators Up by 0.1%
description: The Government's main economic forecasting index edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in December, the first increase in six months and a sign, many analysts said, that the economy may have begun to stabilize after falling into recession during the latter half of 1990.

title: INSIDE
description: A New Environmental Tool

title: Key Rates
Traffickers Suspend 'Total War' Against Colombia
description: Drug traffickers suspended their all-out war against the Government today, a day after the Government extended its lenient treatment of drug cartel leaders who surrender.

title: Hasan Dosti, 96, Dies; Ex-Official in Albania
description: Hasan Dosti, a former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Albania and the country's Minister of Justice in the early years of World War II, died on Tuesday at Hancock Park Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 96 years old.

title: Knicks Find Way to Win a Game
description: By winning Tuesday night, the Knicks made today's cross-country flight a lot easier to endure.

title: Review/Dance; So Happily Moving About
description: The physical beauty and happy all-out performing of Mark Dendy and his company made a good case for feel-good dance on Friday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church.

title: Accounts
description: * Safelite Auto Glass Stores, Columbus, Ohio, a chain of 630 auto glass replacement stores that is a division of Safelite Glass Corp., to Barkley & Evergreen Advertising. Billings were not disclosed. * Quaker Oats Co. to Burrell Advertising Inc., Chicago, for a campaign aimed at black consumers. Billings were not disclosed. * A. H. Robins, a unit of American Home Products, to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, for its Dimetapp cold medicine. Billings were estimated at $25 million. * Today's Man, Philadelphia, a retailer of men's fashions, to Waring & LaRosa Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: EX-NAVAJO LEADER IS CONVICTED AGAIN
description: The former chairman of the Navajo Nation, Peter MacDonald, was convicted Tuesday in tribal court on all charges that he plotted to influence the tribe to buy a ranch for an inflated price.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Now, there's no way that I'm suggesting that the Iraqi Army is close to capitulation and going to give up. I think their actions last night have proven that to all of us." -- Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. [ A1:3. ]

title: Review/Dance; Latin Americans and the World Beyond
description: "Dance Chance: Muevete," a program of choreography by six Latin Americans working in New York, opened on Sunday afternoon at the Dance Theater Workshop with an announcement by Merian Soto, the program's curator, that the matinee was dedicated to the cause of peace in the Middle East. Commitment and a sense of a world beyond the rehearsal studio animated much of the dance on the program, produced by the workshop and Pepatian, a New York-based organization that presents Latin arts.

title: 2 American Warships Denied Docking Rights by Sri Lanka
description: Two American warships apparently en route to the Persian Gulf were denied berthing rights in Sri Lanka and one docked in the Indian port of Bombay, shipping officials said today.

title: Will Society Defend Our Right to Live?
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesters Are Fighting the Last War
description: Peace movements, like generals, sometimes fight the last war. In honor of America's socialist leader of the 1930's, let us call this phenomenon the Norman Thomas syndrome.

title: Yugoslavia and Croatia: Arrest Order Reignites a Fire
description: The Yugoslav national Government today ordered the Defense Minister of the independence-minded republic of Croatia to be arrested and handed over to the custody of a federal military court in connection with allegations that he organized armed units planning to attack an national army base and carry out terrorist activities.

title: Kew, From the Royal Botanic Gardens
description: COLOR photographs of rare plants from Brunei and a recipe for a sweet parsnip tart, an English dessert, are among the contents of Kew, a new quarterly magazine published this month by the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew, England.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE war in the Persian Gulf has made parents more sensitive to their children's fears. Young children may worry that the fighting will soon be in their backyards and that bombs may fall on their homes. Older children may express their anxieties by becoming more aggressive in their play. Yet children do not need extraordinary events to upset them.

title: Haitian Victor's Backer Is Harsh Toward U.S.
description: Before winning the presidency last month in his country's first democratic election, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide often denounced Haiti's elite for "sitting at tables, eating steaks and pate and veal flown in from across the water" in a land where most people struggle to get by.

title: SUNY Ponders Varying Tuition
description: Top officials at the State University of New York are considering charging different tuition rates at undergraduate campuses, which could signify a break with the state's long-held philosophy that cost variations should play no role in students' decisions on which SUNY school to attend.

title: Business Improvement District Concept Can Work Citywide
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about arts events in Europe marking the bicentennial of Mozart's death misstated his birth anniversary. It was Sunday, not Saturday.

title: President of Guatemala Says Rebels Shot at His Helicopter
description: Rebel gunfire punctured a helicopter carrying President Jorge Serrano today, but the aircraft landed safely, the army said. No one was hurt.

title: Davey Waits By the Phone, And Waits
description: This may be more of a recession note than a baseball note. But two of the smartest managers in baseball are out of work as we turn toward spring training, and the phone isn't ringing.

title: CBS Campaign For Olympics
description: Though CBS is a year away from beginning its television coverage of the 1992 Winter Olympics, the network will begin its advertising campaign next month.

title: Review/Music; Contrasting The Head And Heart
description: Whether it intended to or not, the Kitchen put exponents of heart and head side by side on Saturday night. As part of the "Unusual Suspects" program, Loren Mazzacane played the guitar and Suzanne Langille sang. Then Henry Gwiazda presided from keyboard and guitar over an intricate network of programmed electronic sounds.

title: Will Society Defend Our Right to Live?; Proxy Offers Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Society Defend Our Right to Live?; Define 'Dead'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Passed to Aid Veterans Affected by Agent Orange
description: With a clear eye on the troops in the Persian Gulf, Congress moved today to put to rest one of the most emotional lingering issues of the last war, the effect of Agent Orange on Vietnam veterans.

title: Grocery Boycott Trial Ends in an Acquittal
description: The manager of a Korean grocery store in Brooklyn was acquitted of assaulting a black customer, a charge that ignited a boycott of the store and led to intense public soul searching into relations between blacks and Asian-Americans.

title: Air War Described as Slow but Effective
description: Although the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf today presented a picture of a devastatingly effective allied air war against Iraq, the kind of destruction he described is a slow process and the extent of its success in incapacitating Iraqi ground forces may not be known for weeks.

title: Mexico City Journal; Gasping, Mexicans Act to Clear the Capital's Air
description: With its peak smog season just a week away, Mexico City has begun to labor under a daily blanket of chilly, stagnant air and accumulating pollution that experts warn may rank among the most serious air contamination in the city's history.

title: Both U.S. and Soviets Give and Get In Their Statement on the Gulf Crisis
description: In many ways, the latest statement on the Persian Gulf, which was issued by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union without warning Tuesday night, is much more revealing about current American- Soviet relations than it is about the Middle East.

title: Alaska Wants $1.2 Billion to Drop Suit Over Spill
description: The new Governor of Alaska, Walter J. Hickel, has proposed dropping all state and Federal lawsuits against the Exxon Corporation over damage done by the nation's worst oil spill, in exchange for $1.2 billion to restore and enhance Prince William Sound.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Chicago Art Museum Names Design Finalists
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago has announced its selection of six architecture firms as finalists in the competition for the commission to design its new building and sculpture garden, which will occupy a two-acre site overlooking Lake Michigan just north of the Loop.

title: Phone Numbers for Relatives
description: The Pentagon has set up special 24-hour telephone lines to be used by relatives of military personnel seeking information about the status of family members stationed in the Persian Gulf. Army: (800) 626-1440 Air Force: (800) 253-9276 Marines: (800) 523-2694 Coast Guard: (800) 367-8724 Navy: (800) 255-3808* Navy: (800) 732-1206+ *Immediate family members. +Other relatives and friends.

title: Art That Moves the Child in Everyone
description: CHILDREN who visit the Lorence-Monk Gallery in SoHo have only one thing in mind: they want to ride the rocking horses.

title: For African Congress, Tough Path Lies Ahead
description: A year after it was legalized by President F. W. de Klerk, the African National Congress finds itself wavering between its past as a revolutionary liberation movement and its future as a more conventional political party.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in light trading, with short-term maturities basically unchanged and bond prices down slightly.

title: Hussein Is Controlling Plans For Ground War, Report Says
description: Hours after Iraqi troops sought to advance into Saudi Arabia, the Baghdad radio reported that President Saddam Hussein had taken personal charge of preparations for a ground offensive.

title: Excerpts From an Interview With the Fed's Chairman
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board:

title: Honor Student Found Stabbed to Death
description: A'ishah Coleman told her friends she believed she could become a civil engineer by the pure force of her ambition and intelligence, despite her poverty, the crime-ridden building she lived in, and the burden of her invalid mother.

title: Three Big Steel Companies Post Disappointing Results
description: Two of the nation's leading steel producers reported fourth-quarter losses yesterday, saying their earnings were hurt by special charges, sharply reduced steel prices and lower demand, and a third reported plummeting profits.

title: California Set to Impose Most Drastic Water Curbs
description: California stands on the verge of imposing the most drastic restrictions on water use in its history.

title: Ruth Dietz; Executive, 88
description: Ruth Dietz, who headed the Woolen Corporation of America in the 1950's, died on Monday at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Referendum on Puerto Rico's Future Could Be Delayed Until 1993
description: Senate Democrats and Republicans agreed today that a referendum on Puerto Rico's political future would probably be delayed until 1993 unless Congress enacted legislation by July 4 providing for such a referendum.

title: Review/Theater; Now Romeo And Juliet Love and Die On West 42d
description: When the Victory Theater on West 42d Street reopened as a legitimate theater for a brief time last year, the play was Mac Wellman's "Crowbar," and the audience sat on the stage as the action and the nostalgia unfolded all around them. For the Victory's new tenant, "Romeo and Juliet," theatergoers are in their traditional seats and the actors are on stage and rushing up the center aisle. The Victory, for too many years a low-grade movie house, is still in need of repairs, but watching "Romeo and Juliet," one can feel emanations of the building's former respectability and its possibilities as a home for classics.

title: The Domestic Front
description: There are many ways to watch America in action, but one of the most colorful is to stroll the public spaces of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, that squat, ever-busy gateway to the world on wheels. You can learn something about the State of the Union by the state of this place. And it has precious little to do with cuts in the capital gains tax.

title: War Summary
description: THE FIRST GROUND COMBAT Three Iraqi tank battalions attacked allied positions in Saudi Arabia near the Kuwaiti border late Tuesday night and early yesterday in the first sustained ground combat of the war. The Iraqis occupied the abandoned port town of Khafji, but were driven back by United States marines and Arab forces. Reports indicated that the Iraqis in Khafji had beaten back at least one counterattack. THE AIR WAR Round-the-clock bombing has forced the Iraqis to abandon central control of their air defense systems, given the allies "air supremacy" and vastly reduced the threat of Scud surface-to-surface missiles, the United States Command at Riyadh reported. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Twelve marines were killed in the ground combat and two were listed as wounded in action. Aircraft: After 30,000 sorties, 19 aircraft have been lost. Other: The Marines lost two light armored vehicles in the attack. IRAQI FORCES Troops: No figures are available for military casualties but the United States command reported 13 Iraqi prisoners captured in the ground fighting. Tanks: The United States command reported that the number of Iraqi tanks destroyed in the ground battle ranged from 24 confirmed to 41 possible and 13 other vehicles confirmed destroyed. In addition, air strikes targeting the positions of Republican Guards as of early yesterday morning had destroyed or damaged 52 tanks. Aircraft: United States command in Riyadh reported a total of of 29 aircraft destroyed since the start of the war and 38 of 44 airfields bombed, at least 9 of them being made non-operational. The number of planes that have been flown by Iraqi pilots to Iran was listed yesterday as 89. Other: Air attacks have destroyed more than 70 hardened aircraft shelters. Air attacks on Republican Guard positions have destroyed 178 trucks and destroyed or damaged 55 artillery pieces. Navy: Forty-six Iraqi naval vehicles have been sunk or disabled and 74 prisoners captured.

title: Albert Saley; Librarian, 63
description: Albert Saley, a librarian who was president of several library associations, died Jan. 13 at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Blairstown, N.J.

title: Ban on Campus Police Beards Is Overruled
description: A prohibition against the wearing of beards by the campus police at the University of Maryland discriminates against black police officers, the state's Human Relations Commission has ruled.

title: Bush Would Let the States Decide How to Spend $15 Billion in Aid
description: In his budget for the fiscal year 1992, President Bush will propose giving the states complete control over $15 billion a year in Federal aid now earmarked for specific activities like health care, education, housing, transportation and sewage treatment.

title: Congress Predicting $298 Billion Deficit, Reaching a Record
description: The Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the Federal budget deficit would reach $298 billion this year, $77 billion more than the highest deficit ever recorded by the Government.

title: Will Society Defend Our Right to Live?; Medical vs. Moral
description: To the Editor:

title: James R. Spicola, 60; Headed Grain Concern
description: James R. Spicola, president and chief operating officer of Cargill Inc., one of the nation's largest grain trading companies, died of cancer Tuesday at the University of Minnesota Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 60 years old and lived in Edina, Minn.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: LESS U.S. OIL FOR SALE The Energy Department said it would cut by nearly 50 percent the amount of high-sulfur crude oil it had planned to sell from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Business Day, page D2.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., which makes computer circuits and equipment, will phase out operations at a wafer fabrication plant by the end of the year. * British Aerospace P.L.C., London, said the planned merger of its guided weapons systems business with that of Thomson CSF S.A., the French military contractor, had been cleared by the British authorities. * BP Exploration, a unit of British Petroleum Co., and Statoil A.S., the Norwegian state-owned oil concern, have agreed to explore for oil and gas offshore in China, Vietnam, West Africa and the Soviet Union. * Furr's Inc., Lubbock, Tex., a grocery-store chain, said its managers would buy 70 of the company's 126 stores. Seven others would be sold, and 14 would be closed. * Hanson P.L.C., London, the British conglomerate, had protesters at its annual meeting. The protesters, Navajo Indians from Arizona, objected to mining by Hanson's Peabody Coal Co. unit in the Black Mesa region there. * SHL Systemhouse Inc., Ottawa, a computer systems company, has purchased the Computerland trademarks in Canada from Computerland Corp., Oakland, Calif. The price was $40.5 million (Canadian). * Tandem Computers Inc., Cupertino, Calif., which makes computer systems, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 1.5 million common shares on the open market. * Varity Corp., Toronto, a maker of farming and industrial machinery, has extended until April 30 its program for shareholders with fewer than 100 common shares as of Nov. 16 to sell them back to the company.

title: 12 Inducted Into Hall
description: Two Heisman Trophy winners were among a dozen players who were named to the College Hall of Fame by the National Football Foundation yesterday along with three coaches.

title: TV Images Damage Girls' Self-Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Forces Battle Palestinians For Second Day North of Border
description: Fighting with artillery and rockets broke out today between Israeli troops and Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon for the second successive day.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some editions on Saturday and some editions on Sunday about Everett Freeman, a screenwriter and producer, misidentified the film for which he received an Academy Award nomination in 1947. It was "It Happened on Fifth Avenue," not "It Happened One Night."

title: Union Carbide, ARCO Fined
description: The Justice Department said today that ARCO and the Union Carbide Corporation had each agreed to pay $1 million in fines to settle charges that they violated antitrust laws while orchestrating a transaction between two subsidiaries.

title: Sources for the Stars and Stripes
description: THE last time sales of American flags jumped dramatically was during the Bicentennial, in 1976. But these are flag-waving days. And business has been unusually brisk since war broke out in the Persian Gulf, said Ian Flamm, the owner of AAA American Flag, a Manhattan flag shop.

title: Review/Theater; Strindberg's War of Wills
description: If Chekhov, Ibsen and Strindberg are to be believed, one of the overriding facets of life at the end of the 19th century was a pervasive sense of discontent. In "Dance of Death," Strindberg's vicious portrait of marriage, which is being revived by the Pearl Theater Company, Edgar and Alice have escalated 25 years of dissatisfaction and ennui from daily sniping attacks into a mortal war of wills.

title: Review/Pop; Demonstrating American Influence on Haitian Roots
description: Friday night's double bill at S.O.B.'s, featuring two Haitian-American groups, System Band and Rara Machine, offered a primer on how time and environment affect culture. System Band, one of Haiti's oldest and most important groups, invoked an almost rural ease, using gracefulness to mask an intense swing. Rara Machine, one of the Haitian community's newest bands, has picked up New York's freneticism; most of its members have spent the major part of their lives here, and the music, with its jazz and rock influences and its speeded-up and nervous superactivity, sounds cosmopolitan.

title: Meanwhile, Back in the Union
description: The State of the Union, judging from Mr. Bush's address Tuesday, does not have much room for major cities that are staggered by epidemics of homelessness, AIDS and crack. Or for 40 million families lacking medical insurance; the fifth of all children who live in poverty, or the male high-school graduates earning less, after inflation, than at any time during the past 20 years. Intractable problems worthy of national attention are not part of Mr. Bush's union.

title: A Wide Gap Is Seen As USX Labor Talks Approach Deadline
description: The contract between the USX Corporation and 18,000 members of the United Steelworkers expires at midnight, and many steel industry specialists say a strike is more likely than they had believed earlier.

title: Poison Gas Attack: A Longstanding Fear That Continues to Nag the Troops
description: The renewed threat on Monday by Iraq's President Saddam Hussein to use chemical, biological and nuclear weapons against allied forces has sent a new chill through the front-line troops here.

title: New Course for 'Star Wars,' From Full to a Limited Defense
description: President Bush's decision to reduce the goals of the "Star Wars" program from an impenetrable shield to a limited defense against missile attacks is a milestone in the Government's slow rejection of Ronald Reagan's grandiose aims.

title: Officials Weigh 'Credit Crunch'
description: Senior banking regulators met today with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to work on proposals to ease what is widely seen as a "credit crunch."

title: The Quilts Wear Buildings
description: An intriguing display of modern quilts titled "Tactile Architecture 1991" went on display last weekend at Decatur House on Lafayette Square. All 52 quilts have an architectural theme.

title: 2 Competitors in Pact On Advanced TV Plan
description: Two competitors in the effort to develop a standard for transmitting high-definition television, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the General Instrument Corporation, said today that they would work together to develop an all-digital technology.

title: Ripples of Pain as U.S. Dips Deeper Into Military
description: Danette Gandy, a 24-year-old mother in Los Angeles, has not taken part in any military training since 1988 when she left active status in the Air Force Reserves.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Science Watch column of Science Times on Jan. 15 about archeological artifacts known as bone spatulas misidentified the journal that published a new theory about them. It was Biblical Archeologist, not Biblical Archeology Review.

title: Doctors May Not Do Enough To Treat Asthma, Study Says
description: Although doctors who treat asthma patients have long worried that the overuse of medication might be making their patients worse, a small new study suggests that the most common problem in controlling the disease may be that doctors are not aggressive enough in their treatments.

title: Once Blackballed, Romania Joins the Aid Club
description: Western industrialized nations agreed today to bring Romania into an economic aid program set up more than a year ago to help the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe.

title: Sears's Credit Ratings Downgraded by S.&P.
description: Standard & Poor's downgraded its credit ratings yesterday on the senior debt of Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, and also one of the country's largest financial services businesses.

title: Dr. John Bardeen, 82, Winner Of Nobel Prize for Transistor, Dies
description: John Bardeen, a co-inventor of the transistor that led to modern electronics and twice a winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics, died yesterday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 82 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A party to be given by Baroness PHILIPPINE de ROTHSCHILD in New York on Feb. 11 has been canceled because she is uncomfortable about traveling from her home in Paris during the Persian Gulf war, a spokesman said yesterday. The dinner party at Roxy, at $500 a ticket, was to have been followed by an auction to benefit the Keith Haring Foundation, which supports AIDS programs and education programs for poor youngsters. Money from the ticket sales was to pay for the dinner organized by the Baroness.

title: Pirates' Bonds Seeks A Multiyear Contract
description: Barry Bonds, the Pittsburgh Pirates left fielder, who won the National League's Most Valuable Player Award last season, said yesterday that he was seeking a multiyear contract worth about $25 million and vowed he would leave the Pirates via free agency after the 1992 season if he was faced with an arbitration hearing on Feb. 15.

title: Newark Clerics Battle Over Role of Women
description: Long-simmering differences between the ranking Roman Catholic and Episcopal Bishops in Newark erupted publicly yesterday over an Episcopal report that terms the Catholic attitude toward women "so insulting, so retrograde" that women should abandon Catholicism "for the sake of their own humanity."

title: John Gundelfinger; Landscape Artist, 53
description: John Gundelfinger, a landscape artist and teacher, died on Jan. 23 at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, was paid $11.25 million in 1990, according to a proxy statement mailed to shareholders this week. His salary was $750,000, and he received a $10.5 million bonus. In the 1989 fiscal year, he was paid $9.5 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Your Money column in Business Day on Saturday misstated the type of property that can be placed in grantor retained interest trusts. It includes principal residences, in addition to vacation homes.

title: Saatchi Expected to Offer New Plan for Shareholders
description: BOWING to pressure from shareholders, Saatchi & Saatchi, the troubled London-based advertising giant, is expected to announce early next week a new plan to change the terms of its equity ownership. If no plan is approved, there is a possibility that Saatchi could eventually be liquidated.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp. is offering $80 million in 7.68 percent consolidated systemwide bonds due 1995 at a price of 100 through Morgan Stanley & Co. Common Stock Potomac Electric Power Co. plans to offer 4.5 million common shares through Merrill Lynch & Co. Ratings * Trans World Airlines Inc.'s senior unsecured debt and special revenue bond rating has been lowered to CCC+, from B-, by S.&P. The company is based in Mount Kisco, N.Y. * Zenith Electronic Corp.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to B-, from B+, and subordinated debt to CCC, from B-, by S.&P. The company is based in Glenview, Ill.

title: Text of the Joint Statement by Baker and Bessmertnykh
description: Following is the text of the joint statement on the Persian Gulf issued on Tuesday night by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union:

title: Contributions To Neediest Hit $4 Million
description: With contributions still coming in, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday passed the $4 million mark, an amount that many charity officials had said would be difficult to raise amid concerns of recession, layoffs and a municipal fiscal crisis.

title: Metro Matters; Is Albany Battle Over School Aid Shifting to Court?
description: New York City officials are drafting a strategy more typically invoked by taxpayers than by governments: When friendly persuasion fails, sue.

title: Kremlin Says Its Extra Troops Have Left Lithuania
description: Kremlin officials said today that most troop reinforcements involved in the deadly attack on civilians in Lithuania earlier this month had been evacuated. But officials in the republic said there was no evidence yet of an easing in the Soviet crackdown that President Bush has said might be expected.

title: Don't Throw Away Victory
description: What our airmen are winning in the skies over Iraq our diplomats are losing behind closed doors in Washington.

title: GERMANS ARE TOLD OF GULF-WAR ROLE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl warned Germans today that they would not be able to avoid playing a role in the war against Iraq.

title: Review/Fashion; Saint Laurent, Reasonable Man
description: As has frequently happened during the almost 30 years he has dominated the haute couture shows here, Yves Saint Laurent pulled the diverging skeins of fashion together today and showed what clothes should look like. As other designers worried about the wisdom of presenting fashion shows at all, he proved that fashion can be comforting in troubled times. "It didn't stimulate you in the wrong way," Deeda Blair, one of the American clients, said after today's show. "It was just serene and beautiful."

title: Globex Debut Is Set
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade will begin their long-delayed Globex electronic trading system around the middle of this year, Merc officials said on Tuesday. Globex is envisioned as a worldwide computerized system for trading financial futures and options products of various international exchanges during the hours that their trading floors are closed. Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the third partner in the venture, is supplying the computer terminals and technology. The Merc first announced plans for Globex in September 1987 and hoped at that time to have it in operation by the spring of 1989.

title: Robber in Wheelchair Cleared
description: A 75-year-old wheelchair-bound man who robbed a bank of $70 two weeks ago because he did not have enough money to buy heart medicine will not be prosecuted if he stays out of trouble for the next year. Under an agreement between the United States Attorney's office and the lawyer representing the elderly man, William Henry Hart, the case will be put off and then dismissed if Mr. Hart does not break any state or Federal laws during that time. The agreement was approved Tuesday by Federal Magistrate Roger Curtis McKee.

title: Turmoil, Then Hope in Argentina
description: Following the appointment of a new Economy Minister, Argentina's stock market soared 30 percent today, in a stunning reversal of investor sentiment after three days of sharp plunges by the nation's currency.

title: Klingler Will Remain
description: David Klingler, who replaced the 1989 Heisman Trophy winner Andre Ware and broke many of his National Collegiate Athletic Association records last season, will return for his senior year at Houston, The Houston Post reported yesterday.

title: Continental Adds 32 Flights, 12 From Newark to Florida
description: Continental Airlines announced yesterday that it was adding 32 flights around the country, including 12 from Newark International Airport to Florida, to fill in some of the gaps left by the recent shutdown of Eastern Airlines.

title: Cypress Point Chooses to Surrender Its Status
description: The A. T. & T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am begins today with its unique blend of spectacular beauty, celebrity hackers and often brutal weather conditions. But for the first time in 45 years, it will not be played on what is widely considered the most idyllic course in the world.

title: Bank Warns About Rumors
description: A Rhode Island savings institution has taken out a newspaper advertisement threatening to prosecute those spreading rumors that it blames for a run on the institution.

title: IRAQ RAID ACROSS SAUDI BORDER LEADS U.S. INTO GROUND COMBAT; GENERAL RECOUNTS AIR SUCCESS
description: In the first sustained ground combat of the war in the Persian Gulf, Iraqi tank battalions launched attacks against allied positions near the Kuwaiti border late Tuesday night and this morning. The Iraqis were driven back along most of the front by United States marines and Arab infantry, but occupied the abandoned port town of Khafji.

title: New Jersey Officials Fault Property-Tax Figures
description: Local budget officials across New Jersey are challenging State Senate calculations that about half of the state's towns will be able to lower property-tax rates this year.

title: Excerpts From Saddam Hussein's Comments on the Gulf War
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in an interview Monday with Peter Arnett, Cable News Network correspondent in Baghdad. The interview was broadcast by CNN Tuesday night. The excerpts were provided to Reuters by News Transcripts Inc.

title: Marinovich Is Reported Likely to Enter the Draft
description: Mike McGee, the athletic director at the University of Southern California, said today that Todd Marinovich, the highly publicized quarterback who left the Trojans earlier this month after a disappointing sophomore season, would probably declare for the National Football League draft.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SLUGGISH or blocked sink and tub drains are usually easy to clear if you attend to them promptly, but the best strategy is prevention. Use strainers or baskets (the kind that also function as stoppers) in drain openings to trap debris, and clean them after each use of the sink or tub.

title: Vietnam Leaders Reported Deeply Divided
description: The aging Vietnamese leadership is deeply divided over the direction of future policies, Communist Party officials say, raising doubts that the 75-year-old General Secretary of the party will step down in May.

title: Memos Not Released by Dinkins Are Said to Call Bridges Unsafe
description: Documents that the New York City Council says the Dinkins administration has refused to release to an investigating committee include repeated warnings that the city's bridges are so badly deteriorated that budget cuts would jeopardize public safety.

title: Mistrust At Hearing On Art Regulation
description: In an atmosphere of heavily cordial mistrust, art dealers, auction house officials, city and state administrators and others squared off yesterday at a daylong public hearing in Manhattan on the regulation of the art market in New York City.

title: 'Patriots' Point the Way
description: The Strategic Defense Organization has spent $24 billion in research in the Utopian pursuit of a perfect defense. So far, it has produced nothing to defend anybody against anything. If our antimissile efforts had not been turned into a nearly dead-end program and had focused on workability, our troops in the gulf, and Israel, might have missile defenses far better than the Patriot.

title: Philip Morris Net Rose By 2% in Fourth Quarter
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, said yesterday that its earnings inched up only 2 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Getting a Roll-Top Desk Rolling Again
description: In America, roll-top desks were turned out by the vanload from the last quarter of the 19th century to the Depression. Not too long ago, these desks went begging, but with the revived popularity of oak, those in good condition have become collectors' pieces -- and expensive ones at that.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about helping children cope with the war in the Persian Gulf misidentified the president of the American Psychiatric Association. She is Dr. Elissa Benedek. The article also misstated the hometown of the family described in the opening paragraphs. James Duffy and his family live in Glen Ridge, N.J., not Montclair.

title: Louis Criscuolo; Designer, 46
description: Louis Criscuolo, a creative director and designer for several major cosmetics companies in New York, died yesterday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 46 years old.

title: Inside or Outside, Redmen Can't Match Hoyas
description: Lou Carnesecca came into tonight's game needing one victory to become the 30th coach to reach the 500 mark in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. But the St. John's coach knew there were two potentially insurmountable obstacles standing in his way: Dikembe Mutombo, the 7-foot-2-inch Georgetown center, and Alonzo Mourning, the 6-10 forward.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The DUKE and DUCHESS OF WESTMINSTER are celebrating the birth of a son, HUGH RICHARD LOUIS , born on Tuesday at St. Mary's Hospital in London. The Duke, reported to be Britain's richest man, and the Duchess have two daughters, Tamara and Edwina, but Hugh's birth insures the succession of the line. The Westminster holdings include land in 18 British counties, Australia, Canada and Hawaii.

title: In a Ghost Town, a Deadly Skirmish
description: What happened in Khafji, the scene of the first sustained land battle in the Persian Gulf war, was being debated today even as the deadly skirmishing continued.

title: Greenspan Warns of a Deep Recession if War Lasts
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, says the nation could face a long and deep recession if the war with Iraq lasts past the middle of April.

title: Marion Savage Rosette; Composer, 90
description: Marion Savage Rosette, a pianist, teacher and composer of children's songs, died at her home in Manhattan on Tuesday. She was 90 years old.

title: Net Declines 3% at Du Pont
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported today that its fourth-quarter net income fell 3 percent, as the company's petroleum business helped offset weak results in other segments.

title: A Fresh Eye on the Environment
description: The world's fastest computers, once used almost exclusively to build nuclear weapons and crack codes, are finding a variety of new uses as environmental tools.

title: A New Home and Style For Fairchild Publications
description: IN March, Fairchild Publications will move from its 12-story office at 7 East 12th Street to the former Ohrbach's department store at 7 West 34th Street, and in doing so, will change its style of publication.

title: From Misery and Jobs in Berlin to Hope and No Jobs
description: For Peter Heitmann, the trudge up Ruschestrasse is not a walk in a prosperous Germany.

title: Poll Backs Control of News
description: A new poll on news coverage of the war with Iraq shows strong public approval for both military censorship and efforts by the press to report what is happening.

title: Plea Bargain Is Accepted for Final Jogger-Case Defendant
description: Admitting that their case was falling apart, prosecutors agreed to a plea bargain with the final defendant in the Central Park jogger trial yesterday, ending the case that became synonymous with New Yorkers' fears of assaults by roving gangs of youths.

title: Palestinians Are Chafing At Hardships of Curfew
description: While the world watches Iraqi missile attacks on Israeli cities, millions of Palestinians a few miles away in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip are under a military curfew that began the day after the fighting started.

title: Children Staying Fit With Fonda
description: IN Jane Fonda's first two workout tapes for children, youngsters jump up and down, slither and rock and roll to percussive music not unlike the rhythms of rap.

title: Market Place; Investors Betting on Big Recovery
description: THE stock market seems to have concluded that this recession will be a short one, and that the economic recovery will not be a slow and cautious one.

title: Freeport-McMoran Convertible Notes
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc. yesterday priced $325 million in convertible subordinated notes due 2001 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Best Seller Breaks Rule on Crossing the Atlantic
description: It is not your usual best seller.

title: Gulf Oil Spill Should Come as No Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Doesn't Change Eriksen's Flair on Skis
description: After an athlete wins an Olympic medal, his age is forever on the record. Having won an Olympic gold medal in the giant slalom in 1952 at the age of 25, Stein Eriksen can't hide his 63 years, even though his distinctive style on skis is unchanged. In fact, the man has changed little, speaking with a lilting Swedish accent and moving with the agility and grace of a much younger athlete.

title: Jury Acquits Korean Cited By Boycotters
description: A jury yesterday acquitted the manager of a Korean grocery of the assault charge that ignited a long, racially tense black boycott in Brooklyn.

title: Black South Africa's Moment
description: Two proud black leaders, one a radical and the other a conservative, met in South Africa on Tuesday and called for an end to the murderous clashes between their followers. Nelson Mandela was at his generous best; his rival, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, grudgingly sought to score political points. Yet their meeting, the first in nearly three decades, may well turn out to be a defining moment in South African history.

title: Hangers and History
description: To The Home Section: "Hangers That Hold History, Not Clothes" [ Jan. 24 ] was hung up on a historical inaccuracy, I think.

title: Talking Deals; Harcourt Deal Raises Questions
description: IT took about six months for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich's investment bankers to find an acceptable buyer for the troubled, debt-ridden publishing company.
