Now the questions are whether the General Cinema Corporation, which is offering $1.4 billion for Harcourt, can get the deal done and at what price for Harcourt's bondholders.

title: Books of The Times; An Editor on a Dying Paper; a Traveling Banker
description: Rumor Has It By Charles Dickinson 232 pages. William Morrow & Company. $18.95. A Visit to Yazoo By Charles Neider 83 pages. Penguin Books. Paperback, $6.95.

title: State of the War
description: The State of the Union is to Washington what the lighted ball is to Times Square: the beginning of the new year. The political year that began on Capitol Hill Tuesday night is already stunningly different than 1990.

title: Eagerness in AIDS Fight Ruffles a Neighborhood
description: Three years ago, Jon C. Parker drove his van into the Mission Hill neighborhood here, opened his door and began swapping hypodermic needles with intravenous drug users.

title: Troopers in Connecticut's Small Towns May Fade Away
description: Master Sgt. Tom Kirchberger is a singular force in this small town in Connecticut's rural Northwest Corner. He is a one-man police department, detective division, parking violations bureau and highway patrol. He also serves as a de facto dogcatcher and as an occasional lassoer of loose livestock.

title: Deficit at U.S. Credit Union
description: The financial crisis that has plagued many of the nation's savings institutions has hit home. The credit union used by Government employees and former officials who regulate the nation's savings and loans has been insolvent since 1989, its president said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRED HAYMAN has been reappointed the fashion coordinator for the Academy Awards presentation on March 25. Mr. Hayman, the founder of the Giorgio boutique, which has been renamed Fred Hayman Beverly Hills, is a prominent Rodeo Drive retailer of designer fashions.

title: A Tour of Exotic Lands As Children Saw Them
description: From images of life in rural Africa, the Middle East, Southeast Asia or large cities in North America, 2- to 12-year-old artists are guiding both the young and the old viewer to places they will probably never see.

title: Tensions Rise Between Cairo And the Pro-Iraqi Sudanese
description: Egypt said today that its air force had conducted military exercises near its southern border with the Sudan in a move aimed at warning its neighbor, which is allied with Iraq, against any attempts to station Iraqi planes or missiles there.

title: America West Losses
description: America West Airlines Inc. lost $56.2 million in the fourth quarter of last year and $74.6 million for the year, as higher fuel costs from the Persian Gulf crisis took a heavy toll on the industry, the company said today. In the fourth quarter of 1989, America West earned $1.1 million, or 4 cents a share, on revenues of $278.3 million. For all of 1989, it reported earnings of $20 million, or $1 a share, on revenues of $993.4 million. Last year, America West had revenues of $1.31 billion. For the last three months, revenues totaled $346.1 million.

title: Another Oil Spill Imperils the Gulf
description: Even as salvage experts and environmentalists went to the Persian Gulf today to try to limit damage from the largest oil spill ever recorded, Western military officials reported that oil had begun cascading into the gulf from a new source, an Iraqi offshore oil terminal near Kuwait.

title: Fidelity Planning To Cut 226 Jobs
description: Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund operator, said it would lay off 226 workers because a slumping economy has weakened investor activity. The layoffs will reduce Fidelity's staff by 3.3 percent, to a total of 6,670. The cuts will affect 151 employees in Boston, where Fidelity is based; 30 in Dallas; 18 in New York City, 12 in Salt Lake City and smaller numbers at other locations.

title: Occidental Reports Loss Of $2 Billion
description: As part of its plan to reshape itself in the post-Armand Hammer era, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it took $2.05 billion in after-tax charges in the fourth quarter, causing a $2 billion loss. The loss masked a large increase in oil and gas income generated by higher oil prices.

title: Ending Long Fight, Ousted Gay Soldier Settles With Army
description: In a settlement that follows years of legal battles and national attention, the Army has agreed to give retroactive pay of about $135,000 and full retirement benefits to a soldier who was discharged in 1984 because he was a homosexual.

title: Tuning Out Everybody
description: To The Home Section:

title: Every Night's a Night at the Opera In One Man's 'Stage Set' for Life
description: THERE are some people for whom Shakespeare's "All the world's a stage" is a commentary on the pageant of life. Then there is Alexander Nixon, who takes the sentiment quite literally. A private opera house was what he had in mind for his New York City apartment.

title: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
description: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.

title: Clubs Must Make Plan B Decisions
description: By midnight tomorrow, each of the 28 National Football League teams must decide which 37 players it wants to keep, freeing the rest of the league's 600-odd players to make the best deals they can by April 1.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Jan. 22 listing the New York Stock Exchange's uncovered short sales for the four-week period ended on Jan. 15 carried incorrect figures provided by the Discount Corporation of New York. The short interest in the Discount Corporation's stock fell to 321,700 shares, not 1,700 shares, from the previous four-week total of 326,120 shares. As adjusted, the exchange's short interest totaled 785.3 million shares (down 8.2 percent), not 785 million (down 8.3 percent).
